analyzed: upatthambhana kiccassa iva idha adhippeta ttā tassa ca sattasu pi javanesu upaladdha ttā ati
translated: Because here only the function of supporting is intended, and that is found in all seven impulsions.

original: Yathā hi āhārarūpassa dvīsu kiccesu ojaṭṭhamakarūpajananakiccaṃ parittakaṃ appamattakaṃ
analyzed: yathā hi āhāra rūpassa dvīsu kiccesu ojaṭṭhamaka rūpa janana kiccam parittakam appamattakam
translated: For just as in the two functions of nutriment-as-form, the function of generating the nutriment-as-form consisting of the nutritive essence is small and slight,🔽while the function of consolidating the four-fold nutriment is great and excessive,🔽so too, in the case of the function of the impulsion in the first cognitive process, the function of generating the result is small and slight,

original: hoti. Catussanta tirūpupatthambhanakiccameva mahantaṃ adhimattaṃ. Tathāhi paṭṭhānepi
analyzed: hoti mahantam adhimattam tathā hi paṭṭhāne pi

original: tadupatthambhanakiccameva gahetvā kabaḷīkāro āhāro imassa kāyassa āhārapaccayena🔽paccayoti vibhaṅgavāro vibhatto. Evamevaṃ idhapi pathamajavanassa avunāva vipākajananakiccaṃ
analyzed: tad upatthambhana kiccam eva gahetvā kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ imassa kāyassa āhāra paccayena  paccayaḥ ti vibhaṅga vāro vibhattaḥ evam evam idha api pathama javanassa vipāka janana kiccam
translated: So too, here, the function of generating the result in the first impulsion is small and slight,🔽while the function of consolidating the impulsion is great and excessive. And that is found in the seven impulsion processes as well.🔽But since the function of generating the result is small and slight, it is said in the Commentaries, “It generates only the result without root-cause.”🔽And since the function of consolidating the impulsion is great and excessive, and that is found in the seven impulsion processes as well,🔽the exposition in the Vibhaṅga is made by taking that function, namely, “Kamma that is kamma-process condition for resultant consciousness is condition, as kamma condition, for that consciousness.”

original: parittakaṃ appamattakaṃ hoti. Ahetukavipākamattaṃ janetīti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttaṃ. Kammantarupatthambhanakiccameva
analyzed: parittakam appamattakam hoti ahetuka vipāka mattam janeti iti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttam kammantara upatthambhana kiccam eva
translated: So too, here, the function of generating the result in the first impulsion is small and slight,🔽while the function of consolidating the impulsion is great and excessive. And that is found in the seven impulsion processes as well.🔽But since the function of generating the result is small and slight, it is said in the Commentaries, “It generates only the result without root-cause.”

original: mahantaṃ adhimattaṃ. Tañca sattasupi javanesu upalabbhati yevāti. Yasmā pana ganthābhidheyye🔽ganthappakāre ganthappayojane ca ādito vivitesati sotu janānaṃ ganthassavane ussāho
analyzed: mahantam adhimattam tat ca satta supi javanesu upalabbhati yasmā pana gantha abhidheyye 🔽gantha ppakāre gantha ppayojane ca āditas sotu janānam gantha ssavane ussāhaḥ
translated: And since the function of consolidating the impulsion is great and excessive, and that is found in the seven impulsion processes as well,🔽the exposition in the Vibhaṅga is made by taking that function, namely, “Kamma that is kamma-process condition for resultant consciousness is condition,

original: jāyati. Tasmā tesaṃ ganthā bhidheyyādīnaṃ dassanaṃ ganthe ussāhajananatthaṃ. Ganthābhidhānadassanaṃ
analyzed: jāyati tasmā tesam gantha abhidheyya ādīnam dassanam ganthe ussāha janana attham gantha abhidhāna dassanam
translated: So the seeing of the knots’ untying, etc., is for the purpose of arousing zeal in them. The seeing of the description of the knots is

analyzed: vohāra sukha atthanti idam ettha piṇḍa attha dassanam

original: 4. Ayaṃ pana padattho. Sammāca bujjhi sāmañca bujjhīti sammā sambuddho. Ettha ca
analyzed: ayam pana padattho sammā ca bujjhi sāmañca bujjhi iti sammā sambuddhaḥ ettha ca
translated: But the meaning of the words is this. He is rightly and fully enlightened because he has rightly and fully known , thus he is rightly and fully enlightened . Herein,

analyzed: sammā saddaḥ a viparīta atthe nipātaḥ saḥ bujjhitabbesu ñeyya dhammesu bujjhana kriyāya asesa byāvi bhāvam
translated: the word rightly is a prefix, and it shows that the act of knowing in the knowable things to be known is unperverted, without remainder, and without exception.

original: dīpeti. Tathāhi padesañāṇe ṭhitā paccekabuddhādayo attano visaye eva aviparītaṃ bujjhanti.
analyzed: dīpeti tathā hi padesa ñāṇe ṭhitā paccekabuddha ādayaḥ attanaḥ visaye eva aviparītam bujjhanti
translated: For this is how it should be taken: the paccekabuddhas, etc., who stand in limited knowledge rightly know only in their own field,

original: Avisaye pana andhakāre paviṭṭhāviya hontīti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Visayo ca tesaṃ
analyzed: avisaye pana andhakāre paviṭṭhā viya honti iti aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam visayo ca tesam

analyzed: appamattakaḥ iva sabbaññu visayam upādāya yathā hattha puṭe ākāsaḥ appamattakaḥ iva ajaṭa ākāsam

analyzed: upādāya ati te hi phassa ādīsu dhammesu eka dhammam pi sabba ākārataḥ bujjhitum na sakkonti iti
translated: For they cannot know even one thing, such as contact, in all its aspects.

analyzed: sabbaññu buddhānam pana avisayaḥ nāma na atthi yattha te viparītam bujjheyyum te hi
translated: But there is nothing that is beyond the knowledge of the Buddhas, the all-seers, in regard to which they would be mistaken. For they know

original: anamatagge saṃsāre anantāsu ca lokadhātūsu tiyaddhagate addhamuttake ca dhamme hatthamaṇike🔽viya samasame katvā bujjhanti. Sabbe dhammā sabbākārena buddhassa bhagavato ñāṇamukhe
analyzed: anamatagge saṃsāre anantāsu ca lokadhātūsu tiyaddha gate addhamuttake ca dhamme hatthamaṇike  viya samasame katvā bujjhanti sabbe dhammā sabba ākārena buddhassa bhagavataḥ ñāṇa mukhe
translated: all dhammas in all their modes, in the beginningless and endless round of saṃsāra and in the infinite world systems, as clearly as a pearl in the palm of the hand.

original: āpāta māgacchantīti hi vuttaṃ. Tattha ñāṇamukheti sabbaññuṃmahābhavaṅgaṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: āpāta m āgacchanti iti hi vuttam tattha ñāṇa mukhā iti sabbaññum mahā bhavaṅgam sandhāya āha

analyzed: tattha hi te dhammā bodhimaṇḍe sabbam abhidhammam sammasanataḥ paṭṭhāya nicca kālam  upaṭṭhahanti iti sabbaññu buddhāḥ pana yattake dhamme vicāretum icchanti tattake dhamme

original: āvajjanāya visuṃ katvā āvajjitvā vicārentīti. Nanu dhammā mahantā bhavaṅgaṃ parittakanti

translated: But should it be objected that the dhammas are vast while the bhavaṅga is limited,

analyzed: na codetabbam etam arūpa dhammānam hi param ukkaṃsa pattānam esaḥ ānubhāvaḥ ti saṃsaddaḥ
translated: this objection is not valid. For this is the power of the dhammas, which are the highest of all immaterial things.🔽The word “and” in the text

analyzed: pana sāmanti etassa atthe upasaggo saḥ bhagavataḥ paṭivedha dhammesu
translated: But the prefix sam is added to the meaning of sāmaṃ. It shows that the Blessed One’s states of direct-knowledge were not taught by a teacher.

original: dīpeti. Na me ācariyo atthīti hi vuttaṃ. Nanu bhagavato tatīyacatutthāruppa samāpattiyo
analyzed: dīpeti na me ācariyaḥ atthi iti hi vuttam nanu bhagavato tatīya catuttha āruppa samāpattiyaḥ
translated: For it is said, “I have no teacher. ” But were not the Blessed One’s third and fourth immaterial jhānas taught by Āḷāra Kālāma and Uddaka Rāmaputta?

original: āḷārudakamūlikāti. Saccaṃ. Tā pana analaṅkaritvā laddhamattāva hutvā chaḍḍitattā
analyzed: āḷārudakamūlikā ati saccam tā pana an alaṅkaritvā laddha mattā ava hutvā
translated: They were. But he abandoned them as soon as he had attained them, without adorning them,

analyzed: pacchā bujjhana kriyāya pādaka mattā api na honti kutas paṭivedha dhammā ati tasmā tā bhagavato

original: buddhabhāve sācariyakataṃ na sādhentīti. Ayamettha pāḷi anugato attho. Yathāha –🔽Tattha katamo ca puggalo sammāsambuddho. Idhekacco puggalo pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu🔽sāmaṃ saccāni abhisambujjhi. Tattha ca sabbaññutaṃ pāpuṇāti. Balesu ca vasibhāvaṃ.
analyzed: buddha bhāve sācariyakatam na sādhenti iti ayam ettha anugataḥ atthaḥ yathā āha  tattha katamaḥ ca puggalaḥ sammāsambuddhaḥ idha ekaccaḥ puggalo pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu  sāmam saccāni abhisambujjhi tattha ca sabbaññu tam pāpuṇāti balesu ca vasi bhāvam
translated: For it is said:

original: Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo sammāsambuddhoti.
analyzed: ayam vuccati puggalo sammāsambuddho ti
translated: “Herein, what kind of person is a Perfect One? Here someone discovers for himself the truths that have not been discovered before, and he reaches the ending of suffering, and he teaches the truth that he has discovered and realized, and he does not fail to reach the stage of virtue that is praised by the wise. This kind of person is called a Perfect One” .

original: Tatthāti nimitte bhummaṃ. Balesūti dasabala ñāṇesu. Vasibhāvanti issarabhāvaṃ. Etthaca
analyzed: tattha ati nimitte bhummam balesu iti dasa bala ñāṇesu vasi bhāvam ti issara bhāvam ettha ca
translated: ‘Therein’ is locative in the sense of ‘ground’. ‘Powers’ is in the sense of the ten powers of knowledge. ‘Mastery’ is in the sense of sovereignty. Herein,

analyzed: pubbe la sāman ti etena saṃsaddassa attham dasseti tattha ati ādinā sammāsaddassa attham
translated: ‘formerly’ shows the meaning of ‘in the past’. ‘Therein’ and so on shows the meaning of ‘in the present’.

original: Sammāsambuddhapadaṃ]🔽5. Idāni thero attano vandanaṃ suṭṭhubalavaṃ karonto atulanti āha. Anekaguṇapadavisayā
analyzed: sammāsambuddha padam  idāni theraḥ attanaḥ vandanam suṭṭhu balavam karontaḥ atula āha aneka guṇa pada visayā
translated: The word ‘fully awakened’

original: hi vandanā suṭṭhutaraṃ balavatī hotīti. Nanu ekaguṇapadavisayāpi vandanā antarā yanīvāraṇesamatthā🔽siyāti kiṃ dutīyenāti. Na na samatthā. Viññujātikā pana satthuguṇatthomane mattakārino
analyzed: hi vandanā suṭṭhutaram balavatī hoti iti nanu eka guṇa pada visayā api vandanā  siyā iti kim dutīyena ati na na samatthāḥ viññu jātikāḥ pana satthu guṇa tthomane matta kārinaḥ
translated: Now the Elder, making his salutation very loud, said ‘incomparable’. For a salutation with many qualities and terms is very much louder and stronger. But is not a salutation with one quality and term, if it has no obstacle in the interval, enough?

original: nāma na honti. Thero ca tesaṃ aññataro. Tvaṃ pana aviññujātiko. Tasmā mattaṃ karonto
analyzed: nāma na honti thero ca tesam aññataro tvam pana a viññu jātiko tasmā mattam karonto
translated: Why a second? It is not that it is not enough. But those who are discerning do not become satisfied with paying homage to the Teacher’s special qualities. And the Elder is one of them. But you are not discerning. Therefore, being satisfied,

original: codesīti. Apica. Na kevalaṃ antarā yanīvāraṇameva vandanāya icchitabbaṃ hoti. Athakho
analyzed: codesi iti apica na kevalam antarā vandanāya icchitabbam hoti atha kho
translated: you are reproaching. Moreover, it is not only an obstacle in the interval that is wanted for a salutation to be effective. But rather,

original: paññāpāṭavādiatthopi icchitabboyeva. Sopi hi anāyāsena gantha niṭṭhānassa ganthapārisuddhiyā🔽ca paccayo hotīti. Anussatiṭṭhānesu hi cittabhāvanā cittasamādhānāvahā hoti. Citta
analyzed: paññāpāṭava ādi atthaḥ api icchitabbaḥ yeva saḥ api hi anāyāsena gantha niṭṭhānassa gantha pārisuddhiyā  ca paccayaḥ hoti iti anussati ṭṭhānesu hi citta bhāvanā citta samādhāna āvahā hoti citta
translated: The meaning of “swiftness of understanding” should be accepted too. For that also is a condition for the completion of the task without trouble and for the purification of the task.🔽For the development of consciousness in the meditation subject and the concentration of consciousness are conducive to the purification of the task.🔽And when there is concentration of consciousness, understanding becomes strong and powerful.

original: samādhāne ca sati paññātikkhāsūrā hutvā pahati. Samāhito bhikkhave yathābhūtaṃ pajānātīti
analyzed: samādhāne ca sati paññā tikkhāsūrā hutvā pahati samāhitaḥ bhikkhave yathābhūtam pajānāti iti
translated: For this is said: “Bhikkhus, one who is concentrated knows and sees correctly” .

original: hi vuttaṃ. Tasmā tadatthāyapi attano vandanā suṭṭhu balavatī kātabbāyevāti.
analyzed: hi vuttam tasmā tad atthāya api attanaḥ vandanā suṭṭhu balavatī kātabbāya eva ati
translated: So the paying of homage to oneself for that purpose should be done well and strongly too.

original: [5] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said as follows:🔽“Although the word ‘fully enlightened’ is used in the sense stated, still it is distinguished by the word ‘incomparable’ ” .

original: “Yathāvuttavacanattha yogepi sammāsambuddhasaddassa bhagavati samaññāvasena pavattattā atulanti iminā vise setī”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.🔽Mahantañhi satthuguṇapadānaṃ majjhe etaṃ sammāsambuddhapadaṃ, cando viya tārakānaṃ
analyzed: yathā vutta vacanattha yoge pi sammāsambuddha saddassa bhagavati samaññā vasena pavatta ttā atulanti iminā vise seti iti vuttam tat na sundaram  mahantam hi satthu guṇa padānam majjhe etam sammāsambuddha padam candaḥ viya tārakānam
translated: That is not good.🔽For this word “fully enlightened” is in the middle of a collection of the Teacher’s special qualities like the moon in the middle of the stars.

original: majjhe. Tasmā taṃ sabhāvaniruttiṃ jānantānaṃsantike bhāvatthasuññaṃ satthusamaññāmattaṃ
analyzed: majjhe tasmai tam sabhāva niruttim jānantānam santike bhāva attha suññam satthu samaññā mattam
translated: So it is only those who know the natural pronunciation of the words and who are devoid of the true meaning of the words that make the word “fully enlightened” a mere designation for the Master.

original: bhavituṃ nārahati. Aññesaṃ pana padasahassaṃ vuccamānaṃpi satthu samaññāmattameva
analyzed: bhavitum na arahati aññesam pana pada sahassam vuccamānam pi satthu samaññā mattam eva
translated: It is not possible to do so. But if a thousand other words were used, they would only be synonyms for the Teacher.

original: sampajjatīti. Tulayitabbo aññena saha pamitabboti tulo. Na tulo atulo, natthitulo

translated: It has no equal, therefore it is without equal. The Blessed One. For there is no one in the world equal to the Blessed One. As it is said:

analyzed: na me ācariyaḥ atthi sadisaḥ me na vijjati
translated: I have no teacher, and my like is not found;

translated: In the world with its gods, there is none my equal.

analyzed: yam buddha bhūtassa a tula ttam sampati jātassa api pana assa a tula tā
translated: But this is not a wonder, that one who has become a Buddha should be without equal. But even when he was in the womb, his greatness

analyzed: paññāyati tadā hi mahā purisaḥ sampatijātaḥ iva samāno puratthima disā abhimukho aṭṭhāsi

original: Tasmiṃ disā bhāge anantāni cakkavāḷāni ekaṅgaṇāni ahesuṃ. Tesu ṭhitā devabrahmāno
analyzed: tasmin disā bhāge anantāni cakkavāḷāni ekaṅgaṇāni ahesum tesu ṭhitāḥ devabrahmānaḥ
translated: In that direction, in the region of the world, an infinite number of world-spheres became one vast expanse. The gods and Brahmas who dwelt in those world-spheres

translated: worshipped the Great Man with the highest worship, saying: “There is no one here equal to you, how much less so superior!”

original: Evaṃ sesadisāsupi. translated: In the same way in the other directions. Then the Great Man, knowing his own pre-eminence in the whole world, proclaimed this undoubting speech:

original: [6] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī,

original: Samitatthe yyakārassa akārassa vā vasena etaṃ siddhanti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.

translated: it is said that this is established by the interchange of the letters m and y in the word samita. But that is not good.

original: Na hi tulasaddo dhātusiddho kammasādhano ca bhavituṃ na yutto. Tulayituṃ asakkuṇeyyoti

translated: For the word tulaya is not a root, nor is it suitable to be a verbal noun. It means “incapable of being weighed”.

original: atulo. Appame yyoti hi ṭīkāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Etena tulasaddo kammasādhanoti dipeti. Evañca
analyzed: atulaḥ appame yyaḥ iti hi ṭīkāyam vuttam etena tula saddo kamma sādhano ti dipeti evam ca
translated: ‘Incomparable’ is said in the commentary. This shows that the word ‘tula’ is a synonym for ‘kamma’.

original: sati kammasādhaneneva tadatthasiddhito kiṃ tato samitatthe yyakārassaakārassa vā🔽cintāyāti. Vatticchānugato saddappayogoti katvā etaṃ vuttanti ce. Na. Yathā sutaṃ
analyzed: sati kamma sādhanena iva tad attha siddhitaḥ kim tatas sami tatthe yyakārassa akārassa vā  cintāya ati vatti chā anugato sadda ppayogo ti katvā etam vuttan ti ce na yathā sutam
translated: And if that is so, since the meaning is established by the synonym itself, what is the point of considering the affix ‘-ya’ or ‘-ka’🔽as the meaning of ‘tula’? If it is asked: ‘Was it said because the use of a word is in accordance with the usage of the people?’, the answer is: No.

original: yuttaṃ vajjetvā assutassa parikappanāya payo janābhāvatoti. [Atula padaṃ]
analyzed: yuttam vajjetvā assutassa parikappanāya payaḥ jana abhāvato ti atula padaṃ

original: 6. Imehi pana dvīhi padehi satthu tisso sampadā vibhā vitā honti. Hetusampadā phalasampadā

original: [7] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana

original: [8] Yañca vibhāvaniyaṃ

original: 7. Punapi thero attano vandanaṃ balavataraṃ karonto sasaddhammagaṇuttamanti āha.
analyzed: puna api theraḥ attanaḥ vandanam balavataram karontaḥ sa saddhamma gaṇa uttaman ti āha
translated: Then the Elder, in order to make his salutation still more powerful, said, “The supreme group of the True Idea.”

original: Etena dhammasaṅghānaṃpi vandanā katā hoti. Dūratohaṃ namassissaṃ, sasaṅghaṃ lokanāyakanti

original: Tattha namassissanti namassiṃ.
analyzed: tattha namassissanti namassim
translated: Herein, “I pay homage” is “I pay homage to.”

original: na sakkā vattunti. Tathāhi abhivādiyāti vuttaṃ. Na abhivādiyāmīti. Esanayo aññatthapi.🔽Tattha saddhammena ca gaṇuttamena ca attanā nimmitena sakalalokassa saraṇabhūtena
analyzed: na sakkā vattunti tathā hi abhivādiya ati vuttam na abhivādiyāmi iti esa nayaḥ aññattha api  tattha saddhammena ca gaṇuttamena ca attanā nimmitena sakala lokassa saraṇa bhūtena
translated: This is not to be said, since it is said “I pay homage” and not “I do not pay homage.” This is the method in other places too.🔽Herein, the Blessed One is called “with the True Idea and the Community of Nobles” because he is associated with the True Idea and the Community of Nobles, which are the refuge for the whole world and are created by himself.

original: saha vattatīti sasaddhamma gaṇuttamo. Sammāsambuddho. Na hi paranimmitena saddhammena
analyzed: saha vattati iti sa saddhamma gaṇuttamaḥ sammāsambuddhaḥ na hi para nimmitena saddhammena
translated: For the Blessed One is the Supremely Enlightened One, and the Community of Nobles is the Community of Noble Ones.

original: gaṇuttamena ca sahitā sāvakā sasaddhammāti ca sagaṇuttamāti ca vuccanti. Na ca attanoeva
analyzed: gaṇuttamena ca sahitā sāvakā sa saddhammā ati ca sa gaṇuttamā ati ca vuccanti na ca attano eva
translated: The disciples are not called “with the True Idea” and “with the Community of Nobles” because they are associated with the True Idea and the Community of Nobles created by another.🔽And the Blessed One is not called “with the True Idea” and “with the Community of Nobles” because he is associated with the True Idea and the Community of Nobles created by himself.

original: saraṇabhūtena saddhammena sabrahmacārigaṇuttamena ca sahitā paccekabuddhā tathā thomanaṃ
analyzed: saraṇa bhūtena saddhammena sabrahmacāri gaṇuttamena ca sahitā paccekabuddhā tathā thomanam
translated: and the Paccekabuddhas are accompanied by the True Idea which is their refuge and by the community of their fellow-beings who are their equals, and so they are ‘ Worthy ’.

original: arahantīti, tasmā idaṃpi satthu asādhāraṇaguṇapadameva hotīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: arahanti iti tasmai idam pi satthu asādhāraṇa guṇa padam eva hoti iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: So this too should be regarded as a special quality of the Master.

original: Tattha dhāretīti dhammo. Ke dhāreti, attānaṃ dhārente. Dhammo have rakkhati dhammacārinti
analyzed: tattha dhāreti iti dhammaḥ ke dhāreti attānam dhārente dhammaḥ have rakkhati dhamma cārin ti
translated: Herein, it is the True Idea that bears , thus it is the True Idea . What bears? It bears itself. ‘ The True Idea protects the man who lives by it ’ is how it is said.

original: hi vuttaṃ. Kathañca dhāreti, catūsu apāyesu vaṭṭadukkhesuca apatamāne karonto. Kiñca🔽dhāraṇaṃnāma, yesaṃ vasena sattā apāyesuvā vaṭṭadukkhesuvā patanti, tesaṃ kilesānaṃ
analyzed: hi vuttam katham ca dhāreti catūsu apāyesu vaṭṭa dukkhesu ca a patamāne karontaḥ kiñca  dhāraṇam nāma yesam vasena sattāḥ apāyesu vā vaṭṭa dukkhesu vā patanti tesam kilesānam
translated: And how does it bear? By preventing falling into the four Unprofitable Courses and into the suffering of the round of rebirths. And what is it that bears?

original: ekadesenavā sabbasovā samucchindanaṃ. Imasmiṃ atthe cattāro ariyamaggā nibbānañca🔽nippariyāyato dhammonāma. Ariyamaggā hi kilese samucchindantā nibbānena saheva hutvā
analyzed: eka desena vā sabbasas vā samucchindanam imasmin atthe cattāro ariya maggāḥ nibbānañca  nippariyāyataḥ dhammaḥ nāma ariya maggāḥ hi kilese samucchindantāḥ nibbānena saha iva hutvā
translated: It is the cutting off of some or all of the defilements that cause creatures to fall into the unprofitable courses and into the suffering of the round of rebirths. In this sense the four Noble Paths and extinction are the True Idea in the ultimate sense.

original: samucchindanti. Na vināti, tasmā teyeva pañca ekantato dhammonāmāti. Pariyattidhammo
analyzed: samucchindanti na tasmā teya iva pañca ekantataḥ dhammo nāma ati pariyatti dhammo
translated: For the Noble Paths, in cutting off defilements, do so only as accompanied by extinction. They do not do so without it. So it is only these five that are the True Idea in the absolute sense. The True Idea as the True Idea in the sense of the text’s subject-matter is the True Idea in the sense of the text’s subject-matter.

original: pana dhāraṇupāyoyeva hoti. Cattāri sāmaññaphalānica dhāraṇaphalāniyeva honti, kilesānaṃ
analyzed: pana dhāraṇa upāyaḥ yā iva hoti cattāri sāmañña phalāni ca dhāraṇa phalāniyā iva honti kilesānaṃ
translated: but it is only a means of retaining. And the four Fruits of the Monk’s State are only fruits of retention of defilements.

original: paṭippassambhanavasena pavattattā dhāraṇānukūlappavattāni ca. Tasmā ete pañca pariyāyadhammāyevāti.
analyzed: paṭippassambhana vasena pavatta ttā dhāraṇa anukūla ppavattāni ca tasmai ete pañca pariyāya dhammāya eva ati
translated: but it is a means of retaining. And the four fruits of asceticism are fruits of retention, because they occur by way of the subsiding of defilements, and they occur in conformity with retention. Therefore, these five are only proximate dhammas.

original: Athavā, dhārīyatīti dhammo. Dhāraṇārahoti vuttaṃ hoti. Yo hi dhārentaṃ ekantena dukkhato
analyzed: athavā dhārīyati iti dhammaḥ dhāraṇā raho ti vuttam hoti yaḥ hi dhārentam ekantena dukkhato
translated: Or else, dhammo means that which is retained. It is said that it is worthy of retention. For that which delivers the retainer absolutely from suffering,

original: moceti. Aggasukheca patiṭṭhāpeti. Soyeva dhāraṇārahattā idha dhammonāmāti. Kopana
analyzed: moceti agga sukhe ca patiṭṭhāpeti saḥ yā iva dhāraṇā raha ttā idha dhammonāma ati kopana
translated: and establishes him in the highest bliss, is worthy of retention. That is the worthiness of retention here of the dhammas.

original: soti, yathā puttadhammāyeva. Tehi keci bhāvanā vasena keci sacchikiriyavasena keci
analyzed: saḥ ti yathā putta dhammāya iva tehi keci bhāvanā vasena keci sacchikiriya vasena keci
translated: Kopana so: just as the dhammas of a son are retained by him through development, through realization,

original: diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāravasena keci uggaha dhāraṇavasena dhārīyanti. Te ca evaṃ dhārīyamānā
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāra vasena keci uggaha dhāraṇa vasena dhārīyanti te ca evam dhārīyamānā
translated: through abiding in bliss here and now, and through learning and recitation. And they, being thus retained,

original: dhārentaṃ yathārahaṃ apāyadukkhato vaṭṭadukkhatoca mocenti, aggeca phalasukhevā nibbānasukhevā
analyzed: dhārentam yathāraham apāya dukkhataḥ vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ ca mocenti agge ca phala sukhā iva nibbāna sukhā iva
translated: deliver the retainer as is fitting from the suffering of the states of woe and from the suffering of the round, and establish him in the highest bliss of fruition and in the bliss of Nibbāna.

original: patiṭṭhāpentīti. Dhārentivā sappurisājanā apāyesu vaṭṭadukkhesuca attānaṃ apata mānaṃ🔽vahanti etenāti dhammo. Dharantivā ettha dhammadīpā dhammappaṭisaraṇā janā laddhappatiṭṭhā
analyzed: patiṭṭhāpenti iti dhārenti vā sappurisa ajanāḥ apāyesu vaṭṭa dukkhesu ca attānam apata mānam  vahanti etena ati dhammaḥ dharanti vā ettha dhamma dīpāḥ dhamma ppaṭisaraṇāḥ janāḥ laddha patiṭṭhā
translated: and they establish others in it. Or alternatively, good people, not falling into states of loss, or into the round of rebirths,🔽bear themselves by means of this, thus it is the Dhamma. Or alternatively, people who are islands unto themselves, who look to no external island,🔽who look to the Dhamma as their island,

original: hontīti dhammotipi yujjatiyeva. Kasmā panettha dhammo dasavidhova vutto. Nanu paṭipattidhammena🔽saha ekādasavidhova vattabboti. Saccaṃ. Sopana paṭipattidhammo maggassa pubbabhāgappaṭipadāeva🔽hotīti pubbacetanā viya dāne magge eva so saṅgahito. Tasmā dhammo dasavidhova sabbattha vuttoti daṭṭhabbo.🔽Apica, yadaggena pariyattidhammo idha dhammasmiṃ saṅgahito. Tadaggena pariyattidhārakopi
analyzed: honti iti dhammaḥ ti pi kasmā pana ittha dhammaḥ dasavidhaḥ iva vuttaḥ nanu paṭipatti dhammena  saha ekādasavidhaḥ va vattabbaḥ ti saccam so pana paṭipatti dhammo maggassa pubbabhāga paṭipadā eva  hoti iti pubba cetanā viya dāne magge eva so saṅgahitaḥ tasmā dhammo dasavidhaḥ iva sabbattha vuttaḥ ti daṭṭhabbaḥ  apica yad aggena pariyatti dhammo idha dhammasmim saṅgahito tad aggena pariyatti dhārakaḥ api
translated: and they establish others in it. Or else, good people, not falling into the states of loss and the suffering of the round, carry themselves by means of this, thus it is Dhamma. Or else, those who are the light of the Dhamma, the refuge of the Dhamma, come to have a footing by means of this, thus it is Dhamma. And that is quite appropriate too. But why is the Dhamma stated here as tenfold? Should it not be stated as elevenfold with the Dhamma of practice added to the ten? It is true that it should be, but the Dhamma of practice is only the practice that is the forerunner to the path. So like the first thought in giving, it is included in the path itself. That is why it should be regarded as stated as tenfold everywhere.

original: saṅgahito. Tadaggena tassa kalyāṇahetubhūto paṭipatti dhammopi dhamme vandaneyye🔽saṅgahitoti daṭṭhabbo. So hi puthujjanabhūtopi yehi dhammehi samannāgatattā sekhe
analyzed: saṅgahitaḥ tad aggena tassa kalyāṇa hetu bhūto paṭipatti dhammaḥ api dhamme vandaneyye  saṅgahito ti daṭṭhabbo saḥ hi puthujjana bhūtaḥ api yehi dhammehi samannāgata ttā sekhe
translated: and the virtue that is the cause of that good is included in the Dhamma that is to be worshipped.

original: sotāpatti phalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanne saṅgahito. Te pana dhammā sekkhe sotāpattimagge
analyzed: sotāpatti phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipanne saṅgahito te pana dhammā sekkhe sotāpatti magge
translated: The Dhamma should be regarded as included in the Dhamma that is to be worshipped. For even though he is a worldling, he is included in the category of those who are practising for the realization of the fruit of stream-entry because he possesses the Dhamma that is included in the category of the stream-enterer.🔽But it cannot be said that those dhammas are included in the stream-enterer’s path.

original: asaṅgahitāti nasakkā vattunti. Ettāvatā ye vadanti saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmīti, ettha
analyzed: a saṅgahitā ati na sakkā vattum ti ettāvatā ye vadanti saṅgham saraṇam gacchāmi iti ettha
translated: So far, those who say: “We go for refuge to the Saṅgha,”

original: puthujjana kalyāṇako saṅghe asaṅgahito. Na hi taṃsaraṇaṃ gacchantassa saraṇagamanaṃ🔽sampajjatīti. Tesaṃ taṃ paṭikkhittaṃ hoti. Evaṃ pana vattabbo, yo vo ānanda mayā
analyzed: puthujjana kalyāṇakaḥ saṅghe a saṅgahitaḥ na hi tat saraṇam gacchantassa saraṇa gamanam  sampajjati iti tesam tam paṭikkhittam hoti evam pana vattabbo yaḥ vaḥ ānanda mayā
translated: the good worldling is not included in the Saṅgha. For when one goes for refuge to him, the going for refuge🔽is not perfected. This is rejected by them. But this should be said: “The Dhamma and Discipline that have been taught and prescribed by me, Ānanda,

original: dhammoca vinayoca desito paññatto, so vo mamaccayena satthāti evaṃ satthuṭhāne thapetvā
analyzed: dhammo ca vinayo ca desito paññatto saḥ vaḥ mamaccayena satthā ti evam satthu ṭhāne thapetvā
translated: after I am gone, will be your Teacher” . Thus, having placed the Dhamma in the Teacher’s place,

original: bhagavatā saṃvaṇṇito pariyattidhammo dhammasaraṇe saṅgahitoti yutto, taṃ dhārentopana
analyzed: bhagavatā saṃvaṇṇitaḥ pariyatti dhammaḥ dhamma saraṇe saṅgahitaḥ iti yuttaḥ tam
translated: the Dhamma that is the doctrine taught by the Blessed One is rightly included in the Dhamma that is to be worshipped. And he who bears it in mind

original: kalyāṇappaṭipattiyaṃ ṭhitopi atthi. Aṭṭhitopi atthi. Yo aṭṭhito, so attanopi saraṇaṃ
analyzed: kalyāṇa ppaṭipattiyam ṭhitaḥ api atthi a ṭhitaḥ api atthi yaḥ a ṭhitaḥ saḥ attanaḥ pi saraṇam
translated: and there is one who, though not established, is a refuge. He who is not established is not even a refuge to himself,

original: nahoti. Kuto parassa. Satthārā ca anekesu suttasahassesu so garahito. Tasmā so saṅghasaraṇe
analyzed: na hoti kutas parassa satthārā ca anekesu sutta sahassesu saḥ garahitaḥ tasmā so saṅgha saraṇe
translated: how much less to another. And he is censured by the Teacher in many thousands of suttas. Therefore he is not included in the refuge in the Sangha,

original: asaṅgahito. Itarova saṅgahitoti yuttoti.
analyzed: a saṅgahitaḥ saṅgahitaḥ iti yuttaḥ iti
translated: but the other is included.

original: Santānaṃ dhammoti saddhammo. Samitakilesānaṃ tatoyeva pasatthānaṃ pūjitānaṃ sappurisānaṃ🔽paṇḍitānañca dhammoti attho. Yoca santānaṃ dhammo, sopi ekantena santoyeva hotīti
analyzed: santānam dhammo ti saddhammo samita kilesānam tatas yeva pasatthānam pūjitānam sappurisānam  paṇḍitānam ca dhammo ti attho yaḥ ca santānam dhammo saḥ api ekantena santaḥ yā iva hoti iti
translated: The Dhamma of the good: the good Dhamma. The Dhamma of those who have quelled defilements and are therefore praised and revered by the wise and the good,🔽is the meaning. And the Dhamma of the good is entirely good,

original: santo dhammotipi saddhammo. Pasattho pūjito dhammoti attho. Sacco vā. Ayañhi aññatitthiyadhammo
analyzed: santaḥ dhammo tipi sat dhammo pasattho pūjitaḥ dhammo ti attho saccaḥ vā ayam hi añña titthiya dhammo
translated: so it is also the good Dhamma. The meaning is: the Dhamma that is praised and revered. Or it is the truth. For this Dhamma, unlike the Dhamma of the sectarians,

original: viya dhārentaṃ navisaṃvādeti. So hi ayaṃ me hitoti dhārentassa ahitoyeva sampajjati.
analyzed: viya dhārentam so hi ayam me hitaḥ iti dhārentassa sampajjati
translated: does not deceive one who holds to it. For one who holds to the Dhamma of the sectarians, thinking: “This is good for me,” it turns out to be not good at all.🔽But this Dhamma, when held to, turns out to be good for one who holds to it.

original: Ayaṃ pana tathādhārentassa hitoyeva sampajjatīti. [Saddhammapadaṃ]. Gaṇuttamapade
analyzed: ayam pana tathā ādhārentassa hitoyā iva sampajjati iti saddhammapadam gaṇuttama pade
translated: The word “good” .

original: loke samāna diṭṭhisīlānaṃ sahadhammikānaṃ samūho gaṇoti vuccati. Idha pana uttamehi
analyzed: loke diṭṭhi sīlānam sahadhammikānam samūhaḥ gaṇaḥ ti vuccati idha pana uttamehi
translated: A group of people who are equal in view and virtue and who are in conformity with the Dhamma is called a “group.” But here the word “group” is used in the sense of the best group.

original: sīlādiguṇehi yutto bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho uttamoca so gaṇocāti atthena uttamagaṇonāma.
analyzed: sīla ādi guṇehi yuttaḥ bhagavato sāvaka saṅghaḥ uttamaḥ ca saḥ atthena uttama gaṇaḥ nāma
translated: The best group is the supreme group, namely, the community of the Blessed One’s disciples who are endowed with the highest virtue, etc.

original: Soyeva idha gaṇuttamoti vuccati yathā muniseṭṭho munivaroti.
analyzed: idha gaṇuttamo ti vuccati yathā muni seṭṭhaḥ muni varaḥ ti
translated: This is called the best group here, just as the best sage and the supreme sage are called the best sage.

original: [11] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhanga,

original: “Gaṇānaṃ gaṇesuvā devamanussādisamūhesu uttamo gaṇuttamo”ti ca vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: gaṇānam gaṇesu vā deva manussa ādi samūhesu uttamaḥ gaṇuttamaḥ ti ca vuttam tam na sundaram
translated: “The best group is the supreme group among the groups of gods, humans, etc., the various kinds of assemblies.” This is not good.

original: Etasmiñhi atthe sati uttamasaddo padhānabhūto hoti. Soca guṇamhiyeva pavattatīti
analyzed: etasmin hi atthe sati uttama saddo padhāna bhūtaḥ hoti saḥ ca guṇamhiyā iva pavattati iti
translated: For in this sense the word “best” is the principal term. And that occurs only in the sense of a quality.

original: tena idha ariyasaṅgho vuttoti nasijjhatīti. Etthaca gaṇoti saṅghoyeva vuccati. Soca🔽saṅgho duvidho sammutisaṅgho, dakkhiṇeyyasaṅghoti. Tattha samaggena saṅghena kataṃ
analyzed: tena idha ariya saṅghaḥ vutto ti ettha ca gaṇaḥ iti saṅghaḥ yā iva vuccati saḥ ca  saṅghaḥ duvidhaḥ sammuti saṅghaḥ dakkhiṇeyya saṅghaḥ ti tattha samaggena saṅghena katam
translated: Therefore it is not proper to say that the noble community is referred to here. And here the word “group” refers to the community.🔽The community is of two kinds: the conventional community and the community worthy of offerings.

original: upasampadākammaṃ sammutināma. Tāya sammutiyā upasampannabhūmiṃ patvā ṭhito bhikkhusaṅgho
analyzed: upasampadā kammam sammuti nāma tāya sammutiyāḥ upasampanna bhūmim patvā ṭhitaḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ
translated: Herein, the ordination procedure performed by a united community is called the “conventional community.” The community of bhikkhus who have reached the stage of being ordained by that conventional community🔽is called the “community worthy of offerings.”

original: sammutisaṅghonāma. So vinayakammesu pasiddho. Dakkhiṇeyyasaṅgho nāma aṭṭha ariyapuggalasamūho.🔽Sopana kiñcāpi sammutisaṅghepi antogadhoyeva hoti. Tathāpi saraṇagamana vandanā māna
analyzed: sammuti saṅghaḥ nāma so vinaya kammesu pasiddhaḥ dakkhiṇeyya saṅghaḥ nāma aṭṭha ariya puggala samūho  kiñca api sammuti saṅghe pi tathā api saraṇa gamana vandanā
translated: The Community of those who are agreed upon is well known in the disciplinary acts. The Community worthy of gifts is the group of the eight noble persons.

original: pūjāsakkārānussatiṭṭhānesu anuttara puññakkhetta vise sapariggahatthaṃ bhagavatā🔽tathā tathā saṃvaṇṇetvā so visuṃ vuttoti daṭṭhabbo. Puthujjanasaṅghohi puññakkhettaṃ🔽samānopi anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ nahoti. Kasmā. Sālikkhette tiṇānaṃ viya khettaduṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pūjā sakkāra anussati ṭṭhānesu anuttara puññakkhetta vise sa pariggaha ttham bhagavatā  tathā tathā saṃvaṇṇetvā saḥ visum vuttaḥ iti daṭṭhabbaḥ puthujjana saṅghaḥ hi puñña kkhettam  samānaḥ api anuttaram puññakkhettam kasmā sāli khette tiṇānam viya khetta duṭṭhānam
translated: Although it is included in the Community of those who are agreed upon, nevertheless it is mentioned separately by the Blessed One in order to show that it is the supreme field of merit for the giving of gifts.

original: sakkāyadiṭṭhi vicikicchānusayānaṃ sabbhāvāti. Puññakkhettabhāvo panassa purime saddhammapade
analyzed: sakkāya diṭṭhi vicikicchā anusayānam sabbhāvā ti puñña khetta bhāvaḥ panassa purime saddhamma pade
translated: The Community of ordinary men is not the supreme field of merit, although it is equal to it. Why is it not? Because it is not purified from the corruptions of the view of individual existence and from the underlying tendency to doubt, as a field of rice is not purified from the weeds.🔽But the Community of the eight noble persons is purified from these corruptions, as a field of rice is purified from the weeds.

original: vuttanayena veditabboti. [Sasaddhammagaṇuttamapadaṃ]
analyzed: vutta nayena veditabbaḥ iti sa saddhamma gaṇa uttama padam
translated: The supreme field of merit should be understood in the way already stated in the section on the True Idea.

original: 8. Abhivādiyāti visesato vanditvā. Ettha ca ayaṃ loke sīlādiguṇayutto seṭṭho vandaneyyoti
analyzed: visesataḥ vanditvā ettha ca ayam loke sīla ādi guṇa yuttaḥ seṭṭhaḥ vandaneyyaḥ ti

analyzed: sammā paṭipajjantā sabba lokiya sampattiyo ca sabba bodhi sambhāra dhamme ca ārādhenti
translated: Abiding in this conventional truth, those who practice rightly attain all mundane perfections and all the ideas that are requisites for enlightenment.

original: Micchāpaṭipajjantā apāyapūrakā honti. Evaṃ mahantañhi sammuti saccanti. Paramatthasaccaṃ
analyzed: micchā paṭipajjantāḥ apāya pūrakāḥ honti evam mahantam hi sammuti saccanti paramattha saccam
translated: Those who practice wrongly fill up the states of loss. So great is this conventional truth.

original: pana patvā taṃ saccameva nahoti. Tañhi sayaṃ avijjamānaṃyeva samānaṃ mahājane vijjamānantveva
analyzed: pana patvā tam saccam eva tam hi sayam a vijjamānam yā iva samānam mahājane
translated: But when it comes to the ultimate truth, that is not a truth at all. For that is not discerned as though it were present,

original: gaṇhāpeti. Sakkāyadiṭṭhi dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhi tividhamicchādiṭṭhīnaṃ vatthu hutvā bālajanānaṃ
analyzed: gaṇhāpeti sakkāya diṭṭhi dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi tividham icchā diṭṭhīnam vatthu hutvā bāla janānam
translated: It is the basis for the sixty-two views, for the three kinds of false view of individuality, and for the various kinds of wrong view.

original: vaṭṭadukkhato niyyātuṃ nadeti. Evaṃ viparītañhi sammutisaccaṃ. Evaṃ mahāsāvajjañcāti.🔽Paramatthasaccaṃpana duvidhaṃ sabhāvasaccaṃ ariyasaccanti. Tattha dhammasaṅgaṇiādīsu
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ niyyātum nadeti evam viparītam hi sammuti saccam evam mahā sāvajjam ca ati  duvidham sa bhāva saccam ariya saccan ti tattha dhamma saṅgaṇi ādīsu
translated: It prevents foolish people from escaping from the suffering of the round. This is how conventional truth is the opposite of the ultimate truth and how it is the more blameworthy.🔽The ultimate truth is twofold as the truth of individual essences and as the noble truth. Herein, the profitable, etc., states distinguished in the seven books beginning with the “Enumeration of States” are called the truth of individual essences.

original: sattasu pakaraṇesu vibhattā kusalādayo dhammā sabhāvasaccaṃnāma. Te hi sayaṃ sabhāvato
analyzed: sattasu pakaraṇesu vibhattā kusala ādayaḥ dhammā sabhāvasaccaṃnāma te hi sayam sabhāvataḥ
translated: For these are called the truth of individual essences because they exist in their individual essences.

original: vijjamānattā kusalānāma dhammā atthi sukhānāma vedanā atthīti gaṇhantena visaṃvādentīti.
analyzed: vijjamāna ttā kusala nāma dhammā atthi sukha nāma vedanā atthi iti gaṇhantena visaṃvādenti iti
translated: They deceive one who takes them thus: “There are profitable states,” “There are painful feelings.”

original: Taṃ pana ariyasaccaṃ patvā kiñci asaccaṃpi hotiyeva. Tathāhi anubhavanabhedamattaṃ
analyzed: tam pana ariya saccam kiñci asaccam pi tathā hi anubhavana bheda mattam
translated: But when it comes to the noble truth, there is nothing that is not true.🔽For feeling is called pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant only according to the difference in the experience of it;

original: upādāyeva vedanā sukhā dukkhā adukkhamasukhāti vuttā. Na sabbākārato sukhabhūtattā.
analyzed: upādāya iva vedanā sukhā dukkhā adukkham asukhā ti vuttā na sabba ākārataḥ sukha bhūta ttā
translated: it is not so in all aspects, since it is only pleasant in one aspect.

original: Sabbehi pana aniccatā saṅkhatatādīhi anekasatehi ākārehi sabbāpi vedanā dukkhāeva.
analyzed: sabbehi pana anicca tā saṅkhata tā ādīhi aneka satehi ākārehi sabbā api vedanā dukkhā eva
translated: But all feeling is painful in many hundreds of aspects, that is to say, as impermanent, as suffering through being subject to change, as having no core, as being due to be annihilated, as being under the control of kamma and the defilements, as being exposed to the suffering of birth, ageing, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief and despair, and so on.

original: Tathā anavajjasukhavipākaṭṭhena kusalabhāvopi akusalaṃ upādāyeva vutto. Sabbepi hi🔽tebhūmakā kusalasammatā dhammā sāsavatā saṃkilesikatā oghaniya yoganiya upādāniyatā
analyzed: tathā anavajja sukha vipāka ṭṭhena kusala bhāvaḥ api akusalam upādāya iva vuttaḥ sabbe api hi  tebhūmakā kusala sammatā dhammā sāsava tā saṃkilesika tā ogha niya yoga niya upādāniya tā
translated: Likewise, the profitable state of profitable consciousness is called “blameless” only in reference to the unprofitable.

original: saṅkhātehi vajjehi sāvajjāeva honti. Dukkhasaccabhūtānañca vipākānaṃ jananaṭṭhena
analyzed: saṅkhātehi vajjehi sāvajjāḥ eva honti dukkha saccabhūtānam ca vipākānam janana ṭṭhena
translated: For all states of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants in the three planes are “blameworthy” in being blameworthy by reason of the defilements, in being defiled, in being subject to the effluents, in being subject to cankers, in being subject to bondage, in being subject to the underlying tendency to lust, in being subject to the underlying tendency to aversion, in being subject to the underlying tendency to views, in being subject to the underlying tendency to craving, in being subject to the underlying tendency to conceit, in being subject to the underlying tendency to ignorance, in being subject to the underlying tendency to the shackle of views, in being subject to the underlying tendency to the shackle of ignorance, in being subject to the underlying tendency to insistence on rules and vows, in being subject to the underlying tendency to passion, in being subject to the underlying tendency to resistance, in being subject to the underlying tendency to conceit, in being subject to the underlying tendency to sensual desire, in being subject to the underlying tendency to ill will, in being subject to the underlying tendency to cruelty.🔽And they are “of painful result” in the sense that they generate resultant states that are the truth of suffering.

original: ekantena dukkhavipākāeva honti. Ajjhattattikañca sabbalokiyasammataṃ upādāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ekantena dukkha vipākāḥ eva honti ajjhatta ttikam ca sabba lokiya sammatam upādāya vuttam
translated: And the words “inward” and “outward” are said in reference to what is generally agreed upon in the world.

original: Sabbepi hi catubbhū makadhammā ekantena attāpināma natthi. Kuto ajjhattānāma. Bahiddhāeva
analyzed: sabbe api hi ekantena natthi kutas ajjhattā nāma bahiddhā eva
translated: For all states in the four planes are “inward” only in the sense of being one’s own , and they are “outward” only in the sense of being another’s .

original: honti. Saṅkhāre parato passāti hi vuttanti. Ayaṃ nayo sesattika dukadhammesupi yathārahaṃ🔽netabbo. Ariya saccaṃnāma sabbesaṃ tebhūmakadhammānaṃ ekanta dukkhabhāvo taṇhāya
analyzed: honti saṅkhāre paratas passa ati hi vuttanti ayam nayo sesa ttika duka dhammesu pi yathāraham  netabbaḥ sabbesam tebhūmaka dhammānam ekanta dukkha bhāvaḥ taṇhāya
translated: For it is said, “He sees determinations as other” . This method should be applied to the remaining dyads as appropriate.

original: ekanta dukkhasamudaya bhāvo nibbānasseva dukkhanirodha bhāvo aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggasseva
analyzed: ekanta dukkha samudaya bhāvaḥ nibbānassa iva dukkha nirodha bhāvaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa iva
translated: The noble truth is the fact that all states in the three planes are entirely suffering, that craving is the origin of suffering, that only Nibbāna is the cessation of suffering, and that only the eight-factored path is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.

original: dukkhanirodhamaggabhāvocāti. Idhameva hi parisuddhabuddhīnaṃ ariyānaṃ ñāṇe acalamānaṃ
analyzed: dukkha nirodha magga bhāvocāti idham eva hi parisuddha buddhīnam ariyānam ñāṇe acalamānam
translated: and the path leading to the cessation of suffering. For this is how the truth, complete with all its aspects, comes to be for the noble ones, whose understanding is purified and which does not waver in their knowledge.

original: sabbākāraparipuṇṇaṃ nippariyāyasaccaṃ hotīti. Tesu idha sammutisaccaṃ nivattento
analyzed: sabba ākāra paripuṇṇam nippariyāya saccam hoti iti tesu idha sammuti saccam nivattento
translated: Here, in order to exclude the conventional truth,

original: paramatthatoti ida māha. Tena vuttaṃ paramatthatoti paramatthasaccatoti. Tattha attho
analyzed: paramatthato ti idam mā āha tena vuttam paramatthato ti paramattha saccato ti tattha attho
translated: he says “ultimately.” Therefore it is said: “ultimately” means “in the ultimate truth.” Herein,

original: duvidho sabhāvasiddhoca parikappasiddhoca. Tattha yo vinā aññāpadesena kevalaṃ visuṃ🔽visuṃ attano lakkhaṇena vijjamāno hutvā siddho. So cittādiko attho sabhāvasiddhonāma.🔽Yopana attano lakkhaṇena vijjamānoyeva nahoti. Vijjamānassapana atthassa nānā pavattiākāre
analyzed: duvidhaḥ sa bhāva siddhaḥ ca parikappa siddhaḥ ca tattha yaḥ vinā añña apadesena kevalam visum  visum attanaḥ lakkhaṇena vijjamānaḥ hutvā siddhaḥ so citta ādikaḥ attho sabhāvasiddhaḥ nāma  lakkhaṇena vijjamānaḥ yeva na hoti vijjamānassa pana atthassa nānā pavatti ākāre
translated: the meaning is twofold: established by intrinsic nature and established by designation. Herein, that which is established by being found to exist, by its own characteristic, alone,🔽without depending on anything else, is the meaning established by intrinsic nature.

original: upādāya cittena parikappetvā saviggahaṃ katvā gahito cittamayo cittanimmito hutvā
analyzed: upādāya cittena parikappetvā sa viggaham katvā gahitaḥ citta mayaḥ citta nimmitaḥ hutvā
translated: That which is found to exist by its own characteristic, but is not so , and is apprehended by the mind, after being conceptually determined and designated by the mind, in terms of the various modes of existence of the meaning that is found to exist,

original: citteeva upalabbhamāno hoti. So sattapuggalādiko attho parikappasiddho nāma. Tesu
analyzed: upalabbhamānaḥ hoti so satta puggala ādikaḥ attho parikappa siddhaḥ nāma tesu
translated: and which is found to exist only in the mind, as if it were apprehended in the mind, is the meaning established by designation. Among these,

original: sabhāvasiddhoyeva paramatthonāma. So hi santi bhavanti buddhisaddā etthāti attho.
analyzed: sabhāvasiddhaḥ yā iva paramatthaḥ nāma saḥ hi santi bhavanti buddhi saddāḥ ettha ati attho
translated: It is the ultimate meaning in the sense of being established in its individual essence. For the meaning of paramattha is this: it is, it exists, the words buddhi and sad exist here.

original: Ekantavijjamānaṭṭhena itarato paramo ukkaṃsagato atthoti paramattho. Api ca, ye ayaṃ
analyzed: ekanta vijjamāna aṭṭhena itaratas paramaḥ ukkaṃsa gataḥ attho ti parama atthaḥ api ca ye ayam
translated: In the sense of being absolutely existent it is ultimate, supreme, the best, the meaning, the ultimate meaning.🔽Moreover, those who, having apprehended that “this is, this exists,”

original: atthi ayaṃ upalabbhatīti gahetvā tassa abhiññeyyassa abhiññatthāya, pariññeyyassa
analyzed: atthi ayam upalabbhati iti gahetvā tassa abhiññeyyassa abhiñña tthāya pariññeyyassa
translated: practice for the direct knowledge of what is to be directly known,🔽for the full understanding of what is to be fully understood,

original: pariññatthāya, pahātabbassa pahānatthāya, sacchikātabbassa sacchikaraṇatthāya, bhāvetabbassa🔽bhāvanatthāya paṭipajjanti. Tesaṃ tadatthasādhane avisaṃvādakaṭṭhena paramo uttamo🔽atthoti paramattho. Itaropana avijjamānattā tassa abhiññādiatthāya paṭipajjantānaṃ
analyzed: pariñña tthāya pahātabbassa pahāna tthāya sacchikātabbassa sacchikaraṇa tthāya bhāvetabbassa  bhāvana tthāya paṭipajjanti tesam tad attha sādhane avisaṃvādaka ṭṭhena paramaḥ uttamaḥ  attho ti avijjamāna ttā tassa abhiññā ādi atthāya paṭipajjantānam
translated: for the abandoning of what is to be abandoned, for the realization of what is to be realized,

original: tadatthasādhane visaṃvādakoyeva bhavissati. Napana tadatthaṃ sādhessa tīti paramatthoti vattuṃ nārahatīti.
analyzed: tad attha sādhane bhavissati na pana tad attham sādhessati iti paramatthaḥ ti vattum na ārahati iti
translated: and for the developing of what is to be developed, it is the ultimate, the supreme, the best, the meaning, the ultimate meaning, in the sense of being non-deceptive in accomplishing that meaning. But the other, not existing, would only be deceptive in accomplishing that meaning for those who practice for the direct knowledge, etc., of it. It is not fit to be called the ultimate meaning, since it does not accomplish that meaning.

original: [14] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhanga,

original: “Paramassavā uttamassa ñāṇassa attho gocaroti paramattho”tipi vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: paramassa vā uttamassa ñāṇassa attho gocaro ti paramattho tipi vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: “The meaning of the highest sense is the province of the highest knowledge, thus it is the ultimate” . That is not good.

original: Na hi paramasaddoñāṇe vattamāno dissati. Naca atthasaddo gocareti. Yañca anuṭīkāyaṃ
analyzed: na hi parama sadda ñāṇe vattamānaḥ dissati na ca attha saddaḥ gocara iti yat ca anuṭīkā ayam
translated: For the word “highest” is not seen to be used of knowledge, nor is the word “meaning” of a province. And what is said in the commentary:

original: saccameva saccikaṃ. So eva attho aviparītassa ñāṇassa visayabhāvaṭṭhenāti saccikaṭṭhoti
analyzed: saccam eva saccikam saḥ eva atthaḥ aviparītassa ñāṇassa visaya bhāva ṭṭhena ati saccikaṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: “The truth is the real, and that is the meaning of the real in the sense of being the province of unperverted knowledge” ,

original: vuttaṃ. Taṃpi aviparītena ñāṇena araṇīyato upagantabba to atthoti imamatthaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: vuttam aviparītena ñāṇena araṇīyataḥ attho ti imam attham dasseti
translated: that shows the meaning of the real as the object of unperverted knowledge, not as the meaning of the word “highest.”

original: Naparamasaddassa atthanti. [Paramatthapadaṃ]
analyzed: na parama saddassa atthan ti paramattha padam
translated: The word “real” is not a synonym for the word “highest.”

original: 13. Cittanti ettha cintetīti cittaṃ. Etthaca cintanakriyā nāma niccaṃ ārammaṇāpekkhā
analyzed: cittam ti ettha cintā iti iti cittam ettha ca cintana kriyā nāma niccam ārammaṇa apekkhā
translated: “Mind”: here the mind is what thinks . And the act of thinking is always dependent on a state of consciousness that has an object,

original: hoti. Na hi sā ārammaṇena vinā labbhatīti. Tasmā ārammaṇaggahaṇa ārammaṇupaladdhiyeva
analyzed: hoti na hi sā ārammaṇena vinā labbhati iti tasmai ārammaṇa ggahaṇe ārammaṇa upaladdhiyā iva
translated: for it is not found without an object. So the apprehension of an object, the perception of an object,

original: idha cintanāti daṭṭhabbāti. Evañhi sati bhavaṅgasamaya visaññisamayesu cittaṃ ārammaṇena
analyzed: idha cintanā ati daṭṭhabbā ti evam hi sati bhavaṅga samaya visaññi samayesu cittam ārammaṇena
translated: is what should be regarded as thinking here. For when that is so, then the mind in the course of the life-continuum and the mind in the state of unconsciousness are not excluded.

original: vināpi pavattatīti evaṃ vādīnaṃ vādo paṭikkhitto hoti. Santesupica nissaya samanantarādīsu
analyzed: vinā api pavattati iti evam vādīnam vādaḥ paṭikkhittaḥ hoti santesu pi ca nissaya samanantara ādīsu
translated: The view of those who say that it occurs without a condition is refuted.🔽And even though it has no name among the conditions such as support, proximity, etc.,

original: tassa paccayesu tehi nāmaṃ alabhitvā ārammaṇapaccayavasenevassa nāmaṃ siddhanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Cintenti sampayuttakā dhammā etenāti cittaṃ. Tañhi ārammaṇaggahaṇakicce pubbaṅgamabhūtanti
analyzed: tassa paccayesu tehi nāmam a labhitvā ārammaṇa paccaya vasena iva assa nāmam siddhanti daṭṭhabbaṃ  cintenti sampayuttakāḥ dhammāḥ etena ati cittam tat hi ārammaṇa ggahaṇa kicce pubbaṅgam abhūtanti
translated: it should be regarded as having its name established by way of object condition.🔽Mind is so called because associated states think by means of it. For it is the forerunner in the act of apprehending the object.

original: taṃ sampayuttadhammāpi ārammaṇaṃ gaṇhantā tassa vaseneva gaṇhantīti. Cintanamattaṃvā
analyzed: tam sampayutta dhammā api ārammaṇam gaṇhantā tassa vasena iva gaṇhanti iti cintana mattam vā
translated: And associated states apprehend the object only by its influence. Or mind is mere thinking.

original: cittaṃ. Sabbepi hi dhammā taṃtaṃ kriyāmattāva honti. Na tesu dabbaṃvā saṇṭhānaṃ vā🔽viggahovā upalabbhati. Paccayāyatta vuttino ca honti. Na te attano thāmenavā balenavā
analyzed: cittam sabbe api hi dhammā taṃ tam kriyā mattāḥ ava honti na tesu dabbam vā saṇṭhānam vā  viggahaḥ vā upalabbhati ca honti na te thāmena vā balena vā
translated: For all states are simply the respective acts of the states themselves. No shape or form or🔽configuration is found in them. And they exist in dependence on conditions. They cannot arise even by themselves, by their own power,

original: vasenavā sattiyāvā uppajjituṃpi sakkonti. Pageva cintetuṃvā phusetuṃvāti. Khaṇamattaṭṭhāyinoca
analyzed: vasena vā sattiyā vā uppajjitum pi sakkonti pagā iva cintetum vā phusetum vā ti khaṇa matta ṭṭhāyino ca
translated: by their own strength, by their own influence, by their own ability. How much less can they think or cognize? And they last only for a moment.

original: honti, na kadāci kassaci vase vattituṃ sakkontīti. Tasmā tesu idaṃ dabbaṃ, ayaṃ satti,
analyzed: honti na kadāci kassaci vase vattitum sakkonti iti tasmā tesu idam dabbam ayam satti
translated: and never at any time can be made to submit to anyone’s will. So it should be regarded as impossible to make a division of them in this way: ‘This is the axe, this the wedge,🔽this the act.’ And when it is put like this,

original: aya kriyāti evaṃ vibhāgo nalabbhatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evañca katvā sabbesu paramatthapadesu
analyzed: evam vibhāgaḥ na labbhati iti daṭṭhabbam evam ca katvā sabbesu paramattha padesu
translated: in all the terms that denote ultimate realities

original: ekaṃ bhāvasādhanameva padhānato labbhati. Tadañña sādhanānipana pariyāyatova labbhantīti🔽veditabbaṃ. Ettha ca dabbādivasena abhedassa cintanassa atthavisesañāpanatthaṃ vibhāga
analyzed: ekam bhāva sādhanam eva padhānataḥ labbhati pariyāyataḥ uva labbhanti iti  veditabbam ettha ca dabba ādi vasena abhedassa cintanassa attha visesa ñāpana attham vibhāga
translated: only one is found to be the means of accomplishing the state of being , while the others are found only as synonyms for the means.

original: kappanāvasena bhedakaraṇaṃ pariyāyakathāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yathā silā puttakassasarīranti,🔽tathā karaṇañca taṃ taṃ kriyāsaṅkhāta dhammavimuttassa paraparikappitassa kārakabhūtassa
analyzed: kappanā vasena bheda karaṇam pariyāya kathā ti daṭṭhabbam yathā silā puttakassa sarīran ti  tathā karaṇam ca tam tam kriyā saṅkhāta dhamma vimuttassa para parikappitassa kāraka bhūtassa
translated: And here the making of a distinction by way of the axe, etc., in order to show a difference in meaning of the thinking that is undifferentiated should be regarded as a discussion by way of supposition.

original: atta jīva satta puggalassa sabbaso abhāvadīpanatthaṃ. Sati hi attādimhi kiṃ abhedassa bhedakappanāyāti.
analyzed: atta jīva satta puggalassa sabbasas abhāva dīpana ttham sati hi atta ādimhi kim abhedassa bheda kappanāya ati
translated: And the making of that distinction is a way of showing that there is no such thing as a self, a living being, a creature, a human being, or a person, which is a doer of the action apart from the states called the action, etc., as supposed by others. For if there were such a self, etc., what would be the point of supposing a distinction in what is undifferentiated?

original: Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the analysis

original: Sasavisāṇaṃ viya abhūtassa bhūta kappanā vuttā viya dissati. Ayamassādhippāyo-dhammesu
analyzed: viya abhūtassa bhūta kappanā vuttā viya dissati ayam assa adhippāyaḥ dhammesu
translated: The ascription of the state of being to what is not is like the ascription of the state of having horns to a rabbit. This is the intention.

original: kattāvā kāre tāvā koci natthi. Lokepana attappadhāno kriyā nipphādako kattānāma siddho.
analyzed: kattāvā kāre tāvā koci natthi loke pana atta ppadhāno kriyā nipphādako kattā nāma siddhaḥ
translated: There is no doer or maker in the case of dhammas. In the world, however, the doer is established as the instigator of the action, the one who has the action done by himself.

original: Tasmā cintanakicce attappadhānatā dīpanatthaṃ taṃ kattubhāvaṃ citte āropetvā cintetīti cittanti vuttaṃ.🔽Cittassaca balena taṃsampayuttānaṃpi tasmiṃ kicce tadanukūlappavattidīpanatthaṃ punakaraṇabhāvaṃ
analyzed: tasmā cintana kicce atta ppadhāna tā dīpana attham tam kattu bhāvam citte āropetvā cinteti iti cittam ti vuttam  cittassa ca balena tad sampayuttānam pi tasmim kicce tad anukūla ppavatti dīpana ttham puna karaṇa bhāvam
translated: Therefore, in order to show that the function of thinking is done by oneself, the state of being a doer is ascribed to the mind, and it is said, “It thinks. ”

original: citte kattubhāvañca tesu āropetvā cintenti sampayuttakā dhammā etenāti cittanti vuttanti.
analyzed: citte kattu bhāvañca tesu āropetvā cintenti sampayuttakāḥ dhammāḥ etena ati cittan ti vuttan ti
translated: And in order to show that the associated dhammas also occur in conformity with that function by the power of the mind, the state of being a doer and the state of being an instrument are ascribed to the mind and the associated dhammas, respectively, and it is said, “The associated dhammas think by means of that. ”

original: Api cettha cittasaddo vicitratthavācako daṭṭhabbo. Vuttañhe taṃ saṃyuttake –
analyzed: api ca ittha citta saddaḥ vicitra attha vācakaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ vuttam he tam saṃyuttake
translated: Moreover, the word “citta” should be regarded as having a varied meaning. For it is said in the Saṃyutta Nikāya:

original: Diṭṭhaṃ vo bhikkhave caraṇaṃnāma cittanti. Evaṃ bhante. Tampi kho bhikkhave caraṇaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭham vaḥ bhikkhave caraṇam nāma cittam ti evam bhante tat api kho bhikkhave caraṇam
translated: “Bhikkhus, you have seen the so-called ‘mind-made body’ . ”—“Yes, venerable sir.”—“Bhikkhus, that mind-made body of his

original: cittaṃ citteneva cintitanti. Tenāpi kho bhikkhave caraṇena cittena cittaññeva cittataranti,
analyzed: cittam cittena iva cintitanti tena api kho bhikkhave caraṇena cittena cittaññā iva cittatarān ti
translated: by mind, by mind. By that practice, bhikkhus, mind is more high-minded than mind.

original: nā haṃ bhikkhave aññaṃ ekanikāyaṃpi samanupassāmi yaṃ evaṃ cittaṃ. Yathayidaṃ bhikkhave🔽tiracchānagatā pāṇā. Tepi kho bhikkhave tiracchānagatā pāṇā citteneva cittikatā.
analyzed: na ham bhikkhave aññam eka nikāyam pi samanupassāmi yam evam cittam yathā idam bhikkhave  tiracchāna gatā pāṇā te api kho bhikkhave tiracchāna gatā pāṇā cittena iva cittikatā
translated: Bhikkhus, I do not see even one other group in the world that is so high-minded as this one.🔽Even animals, bhikkhus, are high-minded by mind.

original: Tehipi kho bhikkhave tiracchāna gatehi pāṇehi cittaññeva cittataranti.🔽Tattha caraṇaṃnāma cittanti yatthavicitrāni dibbavimānādīni cittakammāni katvā idañcidañca🔽puññaṃ karontā idhacidhaca nibbattāti dassento vicaranti. Tassa paṭakoṭṭhakassetaṃ
analyzed: tehi pi kho bhikkhave tiracchāna gatehi pāṇehi cittaññā iva cittataranti  tattha caraṇam nāma cittam ti dibba vimāna ādīni citta kammāni katvā  puññam karontāḥ idha ca idha ca nibbattā ati dassentaḥ vicaranti tassa paṭakoṭṭhakassa etam
translated: By that practice, bhikkhus, animals are more high-minded than mind.🔽Herein, practice is called mind, where, having made various divine palaces, etc., with mind, they do meritorious deeds and are reborn here and there.

original: nāmaṃ. Cittenāti nissakke karaṇavacanaṃ. Yathayidanti yathā ime. Cittikatāti vicitrā
analyzed: nāmam cittena ati nissakke karaṇa vacanam yathā ime vicitrā
translated: This is the name for the first part. By mind: the instrumental case is used for the doing. As this: as these. High-minded: made various.

original: katā. Etthaca cittavicittakāya saññāvicittā. Saññāvicittatāya taṇhāvicittā. Taṇhāvicittatāya
analyzed: katā ettha ca citta vicittakāya saññā vicittā saññā vicitta tāya taṇhā vicittā taṇhā vicitta tāya
translated: Herein, the body is various by the various mind. By the various body, perception is various. By the various perception, craving is various. By the various craving,

original: kammāni vicittāni. Kammavicitta tāya yoniyo vicittā. Yonivicittatāya tesaṃ tiracchā
analyzed: kammāni vicittāni kamma vicitta tāya yoniyaḥ vicittāḥ yoni vicitta tāya tesam tiracchā
translated: and because of the variety of kamma, the kinds of rebirth are varied. And because of the variety of kinds of rebirth, the animals are varied.

original: nagatānaṃ vicittatā veditabbā. [Vacanattho]
analyzed: na gatānam vicitta tā veditabbā vacana attho
translated: And because of the variety of kamma, the kinds of generation are varied. And because of the variety of the kinds of generation, the variety of animals should be understood.🔽The meaning of the words.

original: Taṃ taṃ sabhāvo lakkhaṇaṃ, kiccasampattiyo raso;
analyzed: tam tam sabhāvaḥ lakkhaṇam kicca sampattiyaḥ raso
translated: The individual essence is the characteristic, the perfection of function is the state,

original: Gayhākāro phalaṃvāpi, paccupaṭṭhāna saññitaṃ.
analyzed: phalaṃ vā api paccupaṭṭhāna saññitam
translated: The mode of manifestation is the fruit, or else the proximate cause is the manifestation.

original: Āsannakāraṇaṃ yaṃ taṃ, padaṭṭhānanti taṃ mataṃ;
analyzed: āsanna kāraṇam yam tam padaṭṭhāna nti tam matam
translated: That which is the proximate cause is considered the proximate reason;

original: Dhammānaṃ vavatthānāya, alaṃ ete vibuddhino.🔽Ārammaṇavijānanalakkhaṇaṃ cittaṃ, pubbaṅgamarasaṃ, sandhānapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, nāmarūpapadaṭṭhānaṃ. [Cittaṃ]
analyzed: dhammānam vavatthānāya alam ete vibuddhinaḥ  ārammaṇa vijānana lakkhaṇam cittam pubbaṅgama rasam sandhāna paccupaṭṭhānam nāma rūpa padaṭṭhānam cittam
translated: For the delimitation of ideas these are enough for the discerning.🔽Mind has the characteristic of cognizing an object. Its function is to come to the front. It is manifested as receiving. Its proximate cause is mentality-materiality.

original: 14. Cetasikanti ettha cetasi bhavaṃ tadāyattavuttitāyāti cetasikaṃ. Phassādi dhammajātaṃ.
analyzed: cetasikanti ettha cetasi bhavam tad āyatta vutti tāya ati cetasikam phassa ādi dhamma jātam
translated: Mentality-derived: here what is derived in mind, dependent on mind, is mentality-derived. It is the idea class beginning with contact.

original: Etthaca tadāyattavuttitā nāma ekuppādatādīhi lakkhaṇehi cittena saha ekī bhūtassa
analyzed: ettha ca tad āyatta vutti tā nāma eka uppāda tā ādīhi lakkhaṇehi cittena saha ekī bhūtassa
translated: And here the dependence is the occurrence of the things beginning with contact as though it were a unity by means of the characteristics of single arising, etc., with the mind.

original: viya pavatti. Etena yā cittassa jāti. Sāeva phassādīnaṃ. Yā cittassa jarā, yaṃ cittassa
analyzed: etena yā cittassa jāti sā eva phassa ādīnam yā cittassa jarā yam cittassa
translated: By this, the birth of the things beginning with contact is the same as that of the mind, and their ageing and dissolution are the same as those of the mind.

original: maraṇaṃ, yaṃ cittassa ārammaṇaṃ, yaṃ cittassa vatthu, tadeva phassādīnanti evaṃ ekapuppha
analyzed: maraṇam yam cittassa ārammaṇam yam cittassa vatthu tat eva eka puppha
translated: Death is the object of consciousness, the basis of consciousness, and the same as contact, etc. Thus, in the case of a single flower,🔽

original: mañjariyaṃ ekavaṇṭupanibbandhāni pupphāni viya cittena saha ekajātiyādi upanibbandhā🔽phassādayo dhammā idha cetasikaṃnāmāti siddhā honti. Evañca sati cittaṃpi tehi phassādīhi
analyzed: mañjariyam eka vaṇṭu panibbandhāni pupphāni viya cittena saha eka jātiyā ādi upanibbandhā  phassa ādayaḥ dhammā idha siddhāḥ honti evañca sati cittam pi tehi phassa ādīhi
translated: Death is the same as the object of consciousness, the basis of consciousness, and so too are contact, etc. Thus, just as the flowers in a bunch of flowers are bound together by a single stalk, so too are the states of contact, etc., bound together by consciousness, which is their single birth, etc.

original: saha tatheva āyattaṃ pavattatīti taṃpi phassikaṃ vedanikantiādinā vattabbanti ce.
analyzed: saha tathā iva āyattam pavattati iti tam pi phassikam vedanikam ti ādinā vattabbanti ce
translated: Thus it is established that the states beginning with contact are called mental factors. And if that is so, then consciousness too must be called contactable, feelable, etc., since it occurs in dependence on those same states of contact, etc., in the same way.

original: Na. Cittasseva jeṭṭhakattā. Manopubbaṅgamā dhammā, manoseṭṭhā manomayāti hi vuttaṃ.🔽Etthaca manomayāti manasāeva pakatā nimmitā cittakriyā bhūtāti attho. Etena te phassādayo
analyzed: na cittassa iva jeṭṭhaka ttā manaḥ pubbaṅgamāḥ dhammāḥ manaḥ seṭṭhāḥ manaḥ mayāḥ ti hi vuttam  ettha ca manaḥ mayā ati manasā eva pakatā nimmitā citta kriyā bhūtā ati attho etena te phassa ādayaḥ
translated: No, because consciousness is the chief factor. For it is said: “Ideas have mind as their forerunner, mind is their chief, they are mind-made” (Dhp 1, 2).

original: dhammā cittena vinā nupalabbhantīti dasseti. Cittaṃpana tehi kehici vināpi pavattatiyeva.
analyzed: dhammā cittena vinā na upalabbhanti iti dasseti cittam pana tehi kehici vinā api
translated: And here the meaning of “mind-made” is this: they are created by mind, they are produced by mind, they are mental formations. This shows that the states beginning with contact are not found without consciousness. But consciousness occurs even without some of them.

original: Pañcaviññāṇa cittañhitehi kehici vitakkādīhi vinā uppajjatīti. Tasmā tesaññeva tadāyatta
analyzed: kehici vitakka ādīhi vinā uppajjati iti tasmā tesam na eva tad āyatta
translated: For the five-door consciousness arises without some of them, namely, with only the four beginning with contact.

original: vuttitā vattabbā na cittassāti.
analyzed: vutti tā vattabbā na cittassa ati
translated: and it is not the mind’s.

original: [15] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: Ekālambaṇatā mattena tesaṃ tadāyattavuttitaṃ cetasi kattañca vibhāveti. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.🔽Na hi ekālambaṇatāmattena cetasikaṃnāma jātanti. Ettha ca loke nānāvaṇṇadhātuyo udake
analyzed: eka ālambaṇa tā mattena tesam tad āyatta vutti tam cetasi tam na sundaram  na hi eka ālambaṇa tā mattena ettha ca loke nānā vaṇṇa dhātuyaḥ udake
translated: “They are distinguished by the fact that they have a single object, by the fact that they occur dependent on the mind, and by the fact that they are mental factors” . That is not good.🔽For it is not by having a single object that a state becomes a mental factor.

original: ghaṃsitvā vatthumhi nānā cittakammāni karonti, tattha vatthumhi pharaṇaṃ bandhanañca
analyzed: ghaṃsitvā vatthumhi nānā cittakammāni karonti tattha vatthumhi pharaṇam bandhanam ca
translated: And here, just as when various dyes are mixed in water and the mixture is poured over a cloth, the penetration and binding of the various dyeings to the cloth

original: udakasseva kiccaṃ, na vaṇṇadhātūnaṃ. Nānārūpa dassanaṃ vaṇṇadhātūnameva kiccaṃ, na
analyzed: udakassa iva kiccam na vaṇṇa dhātūnam dassanam vaṇṇa dhātūnam eva kiccam na
translated: is the water’s function, not the various dyes’, and the appearance of various colours is the various dyes’ function, not the water’s,

original: udakassa. Tattha vatthuviya ārammaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Udakaṃviya cittaṃ. Nānā vaṇṇadhātuyoviya
analyzed: udakassa tattha vatthu viya ārammaṇam daṭṭhabbam udakam viya cittam nānā vaṇṇa dhātuyo viya
translated: so here the object should be regarded as like the cloth, the mind as like the water, and the associated states as like the various dyes.

original: cetasikadhammāti. [Cetasikaṃ]
analyzed: cetasika dhammā ati cetasikam
translated: The mind is the common characteristic of all mental factors.

original: 15. Rūpanti ettha ruppatīti rūpaṃ. Sītuṇhādīhi virodhi paccayehi visama pavatti vasena vikāraṃ āpajjati, tehi vā vikāraṃ āpādīyatīti attho. Yathāha –
analyzed: rūpanti ettha ruppati iti rūpam sītuṇha ādīhi virodhi paccayehi visama pavatti vasena vikāram āpajjati tehi vā vikāram āpādīyati iti atthaḥ yathā āha
translated: The visible-data base: here what is called “visible data” is what is deformed . The meaning is that it undergoes change by occurrence in a way opposed to cold, heat, and so on, or it is caused to undergo change by them. As it is said:🔽“What is the visible-data base? It is what is deformed by cold, heat, etc., or it causes that to be known” .

original: Ruppatīti kho bhikkhave tasmā rūpanti vuccati. Kena ruppati. Sitenapi ruppati. Uṇhenapi
analyzed: ruppati iti kho bhikkhave tasmā rūpanti vuccati kena ruppati sitena api ruppati uṇhena api
translated: “It is disfigured , bhikkhus, thus it is called materiality . By what is it disfigured? It is disfigured by cold and heat,🔽by hunger and thirst,

original: ruppati. Jighacchāyapi ruppati. Vipāsāyapi ruppati. Ḍaṃsa makasa vātātapa sariṃ sapa
analyzed: ruppati ruppati vipāsāyapi ruppati ḍaṃsa makasa vātātapa sarim sapa
translated: by contact with gadflies, flies, wind, sun and serpents.

original: sapphassehipi ruppatīti. Ruppatītica ruppati, kuppati, ghaṭṭīyati, piḷī yati, bhijjatīti.
analyzed: sapphassehi pi ruppati iti ruppati iti ca ruppati kuppati ghaṭṭīyati piḷī yati bhijjati iti
translated: ‘It is disfigured’ means it is disfigured, it is disfigured and broken, it is disfigured and destroyed, it is disfigured and split up.

original: Mahāniddese vuttaṃ. Ayamettha piṇḍattho, ye dhammā ciraṭṭhitikāca honti sappaṭighasabhāvāca.🔽Tesaññeva ṭhitikkhaṇesu virodhipaccayehi samāgamonāma hoti. Napanaññesaṃ parittakkhaṇānaṃ🔽appaṭighasabhāvānanti. Tesañhi appaṭighasabhāvānaṃ sukhuma rūpānaṃpi bahiddhā sītādīhi
analyzed: mahāniddese vuttam ayam ettha piṇḍa atthaḥ ye dhammā cira ṭṭhitikāḥ ca honti sa paṭigha sabhāvāḥ ca  tesam eva ṭhiti kkhaṇesu virodhi paccayehi samāgamaḥ nāma hoti na pana aññesam paritta kkhaṇānam  appaṭigha sabhāvānam ti tesam hi appaṭigha sabhāvānam bahiddhā sītā ādīhi
translated: This is the meaning here. Those states that are long-lasting and have resistance🔽meet resistance in the moment of their duration through conditions that are incompatible with them, but not the others that are short-lived and have no resistance.🔽For those subtle material instances that have no resistance do not meet resistance from cold, etc., externally,

original: samāgamonāma natthi. Kuto parittakkhaṇānaṃ appaṭighasabhāvānañca arūpadhammānanti.
analyzed: samāgamaḥ nāma na atthi kutas paritta kkhaṇānam appaṭigha sabhāvānam ca arūpa dhammānam ti
translated: so how should immaterial states, which are short-lived and have no resistance, do so?

original: Yadievaṃ sukhumarūpānaṃ arūpatāpatti siyāti. Nasiyā. Oḷārikarūpehi samānagati kattā.
analyzed: yadi evam arūpa tā āpatti siyāti na siyā oḷārika rūpehi samāna gati kattā
translated: and so the subtle materiality would become immaterial? No, it would not. It is the cause of the same mode of occurrence as the gross materiality.

original: Tānihi oḷārikesu ruppamānesu ruppantiyevāti. Samāgamoca nāma idha thapetvā āpātagamanaṃ
analyzed: nāma idha āpāta gamanaṃ
translated: For when the gross material instances are being broken up, it is they that are being broken up.

original: ārammaṇakaraṇañca aññamaññaviruddhānaṃ ṭhitipattānaṃ oḷārikarūpānaṃ mahābhūtānamevavā
analyzed: ārammaṇa karaṇam ca aññamañña viruddhānam ṭhiti pattānam oḷārika rūpānam mahābhūtānam eva vā
translated: “Contact” is the mutual impact of the great primaries that have reached presence, which is opposed to the presence of the other great primaries.

original: aññamaññābhighaṭṭanaṃ vuccati, ruppati ghaṭṭīyati pīḷīyatīti hi vuttaṃ. Ruppanañcanāma
analyzed: aññamañña abhighaṭṭanam vuccati ruppati ghaṭṭīyati pīḷīyati iti hi vuttam ruppanam ca nāma
translated: It is called “contact” because it is said that “it contacts, it is impacted, it is pressed upon” .

original: parasenāyuddhena raṭṭhakhobhoviya kalāpantaragatadhātūnaṃ kuppanaṃ bhijjanaṃca vuccati.
analyzed: para senā yuddhena kalāpa antara gata dhātūnam kuppanam bhijjanam ca vuccati
translated: And “pressure” is the disturbance and breaking up of the elements that have reached presence, as in the case of the disturbance of a kingdom by a foreign army.

original: Kuppati bhijjatīti hi vuttaṃ. Etthaca kuppatīti khobhati cañcalati, bhijjatīti vikāraṃ🔽āpajjati. Yasmiṃ khaṇe virodhipaccayasamāgamaṃ labhanti. Tato paṭṭhāya sayaṃpi vikārapattā
analyzed: kuppati bhijjati iti hi vuttam ettha ca kuppati iti khobhati cañcalati bhijjati iti vikāram  āpajjati yasmin khaṇe virodhi paccaya samāgamam labhanti tatas paṭṭhāya vikāra pattā
translated: For it is said that “it is disturbed, it is broken up” . Herein, “disturbed” is what is agitated and shaken; “broken up” is what has reached alteration.

original: honti. Omattādhimattarūpasantatīnaṃ uppattiyā paccayabhāvaṃ pattā hontīti attho.
analyzed: honti omatta adhimatta rūpa santatīnam uppattiyā paccaya bhāvam pattāḥ honti iti attho
translated: From the moment they obtain the concurrence of opposing conditions, they are themselves a condition for the arising of a continuum of material instances that are more and more mature, and so they are said to “reach alteration” and “reach pressure.”

original: Apicettha ruppanaṃ duvidhaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ, hāyanañca. Tadubhayaṃpi kappavuṭṭhāne kappasaṇṭhāne
analyzed: apica ittha ruppanam duvidham vaḍḍhanam hāyanam ca tat ubhayam pi kappa vuṭṭhāne kappa saṇṭhāne
translated: Moreover, here, “to be broken up” is twofold: increase and decrease. Both of these are evident in the case of the world’s dissolution and re-evolution, in the case of the world’s arrangement in world-systems, and in the case of the changes of life-span, year, season, month, night and day, etc.

original: nānāāyukappa saṃvacchara utu māsa ratti divādīnaṃ parivattaneca pākaṭaṃ hotīti. Kasmā🔽pana rūpanti nāmaṃ ghaṭṭanavasena ruppanadhammānameva siddhanti. Tesameva saviggahattā.
analyzed: pākaṭam hoti iti kasmā  pana rūpanti nāmam ghaṭṭana vasena ruppana dhammānam eva siddhanti tesam eva sa viggaha ttā
translated: Why is it so?🔽Because it is only the states that are broken up by impact that are established as “form.”

original: Rūpadhammā hi samūhasaṇṭhānādi bhāvapattiyā saviggahā honti. Tasmā tesameva ruppanaṃ
analyzed: rūpa dhammāḥ hi samūha saṇṭhāna ādi bhāva pattiyā sa viggahāḥ honti tasmā tesam eva ruppanam
translated: For these states are broken up by impact.

original: paccakkhatopi lokassa pākaṭanti tesveva rūpanti nāmaṃ siddhanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Arūpadhammā🔽pana aviggahāti na tesaṃ vikāro paccakkhato lokassa pākaṭo hoti. Taṃ taṃ rūpavikāraṃ
analyzed: paccakkhataḥ pi lokassa pākaṭanti tesu eva rūpam iti nāmam siddham ti daṭṭhabbam arūpa dhammā  pana aviggahā ati na tesam vikāro paccakkhataḥ lokassa pākaṭaḥ hoti tam tam rūpa vikāram
translated: Therefore, since their breaking up is evident to the world even by direct-knowledge, it should be regarded as established that only they are called “form.”🔽But the formless states are not broken up by impact.

original: disvāvā sutvā vā pucchitvāyeva vā so lokena jānitabbo aññatra paracittavidūhi. Tasmā
analyzed: sutvā vā pucchitvāya iva vā so lokena jānitabbaḥ aññatra tasmā
translated: Therefore their change is not evident to the world by direct-knowledge. It can be known by the world only by seeing, hearing, or asking about the various changes in form, except by those who have penetrated the minds of others. Therefore

original: tesaṃ rūpatāpatti natthīti.
analyzed: tesam rūpa tā āpatti natthi iti
translated: they do not come under “form.”

original: [16] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: Tesaṃ rūpatāpattippasaṅgo sītādiggahaṇa sāmatthiyena nivattito. Yasmā pana vohāronāma
analyzed: tesam rūpa tā āpatti pasaṅgo sītā ādi gahaṇa sāmatthiyena nivattitaḥ yasmā pana vohāraḥ nāma
translated: The possibility of their being called “materiality” is ruled out by the fact that they are capable of being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽because the usage called “conventional usage” does not occur without a cause. And conventional usage does not occur without a visible cause. Therefore

original: lokopacārena vinā nasijjhati. Lokopacāroca pākaṭanimittavase neva pavatto. Tasmā
analyzed: loka upacārena vinā na sijjhati tasmā
translated: it should be regarded as established from the world’s usage that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is ruled out by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,

original: idha sītādiggahaṇena vināpi tappasaṅganivatti lokatova siddhāti daṭṭhabbā.🔽Yasmā ca brahmaloke brahmānaṃ kāyavikāra vacīvikārā ca iddhivikuppanāvasappavattā
analyzed: idha sītā ādi gahaṇena vinā api tad pasaṅga nivatti lokataḥ va siddhā iti daṭṭhabbā  yasmai ca brahma loke brahmānam ca iddhi vikuppanā vasa ppavattā
