translated: and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,

original: nānārūpavikārāca dissantiyeva. Teca ekena pariyāyena ruppanākārāeva nāma honti, tasmā
analyzed: nānā rūpa vikārāca te ca ekena pariyāyena ruppana ākārā eva nāma honti tasmā
translated: and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,

original: tesaṃ vasena tattha rūpānaṃ rūpatāsiddhi hotīti veditabbaṃ. Rūpayati vā attano sabhāvena🔽pakāsatīti rūpaṃ. Arūpadhammā hi na attano sabhāvena pākaṭā honti. Rūpasannissayeneva
analyzed: tesam vasena tattha rūpānam hoti iti veditabbam rūpayati vā attanaḥ sabhāvena  pakāsati iti rūpam arūpa dhammāḥ hi na attanaḥ sabhāvena pākaṭāḥ honti rūpa sannissayena iva
translated: and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,🔽and that the possibility of their being called “materiality” is established by their being apprehended as cold, etc.,

original: gahetabbā. Idaṃ pana attano sabhāveneva pākaṭaṃ pañcaviññāṇehipi gahetabbanti. Imasmiṃ
analyzed: gahetabbā idam pana attanaḥ sabhāvena iva pākaṭam pañca viññāṇehi pi gahetabbanti imasmin
translated: and that the possibility of their being called “materiality

original: atthe sati brahmaloke rūpānaṃpi uju katova rūpatāsiddhi hotīti.
analyzed: atthe sati brahmaloke uju uju hoti iti
translated: But when there is a world of Brahmā, the establishment of materiality is made in the same way by the straightness of material things.

original: [17] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana🔽Anuggāhakānaṃ sītādīnaṃ vasena taṃ sabhāvā nātivattana vasenaca tattha rūpatāsiddhi
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana  anuggāhakānam sītā ādīnam vasena tam vasena ca tattha
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga,🔽the establishment of materiality there is explained by the fact that the four primary elements do not exceed their individual characteristics through the influence of the four secondary ones, namely, heat, cold, etc.,

original: vibhāvitā. Yasmāpana sīte nāpi uṇhenāpītiādivacanaṃ nidassanamattaṃ hoti. Kamma cittāhārānaṃpi
analyzed: vibhāvitā sīte na api uṇhena api iti ādi vacanam nidassana mattam hoti
translated: because the statement “not through cold, not through heat” is merely an indication, since materiality occurs also through the influence of kamma, consciousness, and nutriment.

original: vasena ruppanassa sambhavato, tathāhi saññā viññāṇānipi rūpārammaṇarasārammaṇehi
analyzed: vasena ruppanassa sambhavato tathā hi saññā viññāṇāni pi rūpa ārammaṇa rasa ārammaṇehi
translated: For in the text, perception and consciousness are also indicated as having materiality and taste as their objects respectively,

original: eva pāḷiyaṃ niddiṭṭhāni. Na hi saññā rūpaṃeva sañjānāti. Na ca viññāṇaṃ rasa meva🔽vijānāti. Nidassanamattena desanā hotīti viññāyatīti. Tasmā sītādiggahaṇaṃ amuñcitvāva
analyzed: eva pāḷiyam niddiṭṭhāni na hi saññā rūpam eva sañjānāti na ca viññāṇam rasa meva  vijānāti nidassana mattena desanā hoti iti viññāyati iti tasmā sītā diggahaṇam a muñcitvā ava
translated: for perception does not perceive only materiality, and consciousness does not cognize only taste. It is known that the teaching is by way of indication.

original: tattha rūpatāsiddhivibhāvanena payojana natthīti. [Rūpaṃ]
analyzed: rūpa tā siddhi vibhāvanena natthi iti rūpam
translated: Therefore there is no purpose in explaining the establishment of materiality there without mentioning cold, etc.

original: 16. Nibbānanti ettha nibbāyanti sabbe vaṭṭadukkhasantāpā etasminti nibbānaṃ. Nibbāyantīti
analyzed: nibbānam ti ettha nibbāyanti sabbe vaṭṭa dukkha santāpāḥ etasmin ti nibbānam nibbāyanti iti
translated: Nibbāna: it is the “unbinding” because all the burning of the suffering of the round is extinguished in it. It is “unbinding” because it is unblended with the defilements.

original: ye kilesāvā khandhāvā abhāvitamaggassa āyatiṃ uppajjanārahapakkhe ṭhitā honti. Teyeva🔽bhāvitamaggassa anuppajjanārahapakkhaṃ pāpuṇantīti attho. Na hi khaṇattayaṃ patvā
analyzed: ye khandhāvā abhāvita maggassa āyatim uppajjana araha pakkhe ṭhitāḥ honti te yeva  bhāvita maggassa an uppajjana araha pakkham pāpuṇanti iti atthaḥ na hi khaṇa ttayam patvā
translated: and the defilements and aggregates that are in the position of being due to arise in the future for one whose path is undeveloped.🔽The meaning is that they reach the position of being not due to arise in the future for one whose path is developed. For it is not past states that have ceased after reaching the three instants that are called ‘quenched’;

original: niruddhā atītadhammā nibbāyanti nāma. Paccuppannesu āyatiṃ avassaṃ uppajjamānesuca🔽dhammesu vattabbameva natthīti. Vaṭṭadukkhasantāpāti kilesavaṭṭa kammavaṭṭa vipākavaṭṭa
analyzed: niruddhāḥ atīta dhammāḥ nibbāyanti nāma paccuppannesu āyatim avassam uppajjamānesu ca  dhammesu vattabbam eva natthi iti vaṭṭa dukkha santāpā ati kilesa vaṭṭa kamma vaṭṭa vipāka vaṭṭa
translated: and there is nothing to be said about present states and those in the future that are not due to arise.🔽‘The suffering of the misery of the round’ is the suffering of the misery of the round consisting of the round of defilements, the round of kamma, and the round of the kamma-result.

original: dukkhasantāpā. Na hi tividha vaṭṭadukkhasantāparahitānaṃ rukkhādīnaṃ anuppādanirodho
analyzed: dukkha santāpāḥ na hi rukkha ādīnam anuppāda nirodhaḥ
translated: For the non-arising and cessation of trees, etc., which are not related to the suffering of the misery of the round consisting of the three rounds, are not called ‘Nibbana.’🔽‘In this’ is locative case;

original: nibbānaṃnāma hotīti. Etasminti visaye bhummaṃ. Yathā ākāse sakuṇā pakkhantīti. Yehi
analyzed: nibbānaṃ nāma hoti iti etasmin ti visaye bhummam yathā ākāse sakuṇā pakkhanti iti yehi
translated: like ‘The birds fly in the sky.’

original: te nibbāyanti. Tesaṃ tabbinimuttaṃ aññaṃ nibbutiṭṭhānaṃnāma kiñci natthīti. Nibbāyanti
analyzed: te nibbāyanti tesam tad vinimuttam aññam nibbuti ṭṭhānaṃ nāma kiñci natthi iti nibbāyanti
translated: There is no other place of quenching called ‘Nibbana’ apart from them by which they are quenched.

original: vā ariyajanā etasminti nibbānaṃ. Nibbanti dhīrā yathayaṃ padīpoti hi vuttaṃ. Nibbāyantīti
analyzed: va ariya janāḥ etasmin ti nibbānam nibbanti dhīrāḥ yathā ayam padīpo ti hi vuttam nibbāyanti iti
translated: Or alternatively, the wise are quenched in this, thus it is Nibbana. For it is said, ‘The wise are quenched as this light’ .🔽‘Are quenched’ is the present participle of the verb nibbanti.

original: taṃ taṃ kilesānaṃvā khandhānaṃvā puna appaṭisandhikabhāvaṃ pāpuṇantīti attho. Ekasminti🔽visayeeva bhummaṃ, etasmiṃ adhi gatetipi yojenti. Ṭīkāsupana bhavābhavaṃ vinanato
analyzed: tam tam kilesānam vā khandhānam vā puna appaṭisandhika bhāvam pāpuṇanti iti attho ekasmin ti  visaye eva bhummam etasmin adhi bhava abhavam
translated: the meaning is that it does not again reach the state of rebirth-linking in any of the defilements or aggregates. In one:🔽the locative case is used in the sense of a locative of time. They explain it thus: “When this has been reached” .

original: saṃsibbana to vānaṃ vuccati taṇhā. Tato nikkhantanti nibbānanti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: saṃsibbana to vānam vuccati taṇhā tatas nikkhantan ti nibbānanti vuttam
translated: In the commentary it is said that craving is called “the forest of craving” because it is the cause of the repeated arising of becoming in the various kinds of becoming, and because it is the cause of the entanglement in the suffering of the round. It is said to be “the escape from that” because it is the escape from that craving.

original: [18] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī-ṭīkā it is said:

original: “Nibbābhivā etena rāgaggiādikoti nibbāna”ntipi vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: etena rāga aggi ādiko ti vuttam tam na sundaram
translated: “It is the quenching of the fire of lust, etc., thus it is Nibbāna.” That is not good.

original: Na hi maggeviya nibbāne katthaci karaṇasādhanaṃ diṭṭhaṃ, naca nibbānaṃ nibbūti kriyāsādhane rāgādikassa kattuno saha kāripaccayo hotīti. [Nibbānaṃ]
analyzed: na hi magga iva iya nibbāne katthaci karaṇa sādhanam diṭṭham na ca nibbānam nibbūti kriyā sādhane rāga ādikassa kattuno saha kāri paccayaḥ hoti iti nibbānam
translated: For nowhere is a locative case found in the case of Nibbāna as in the case of the path, and Nibbāna is not a condition by the conditionality of co-nascence for the doer of the act of quenching, which is the act of extinguishing lust, etc.

original: Dutīyagāthāya paramatthadīpanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutīya gāthāya paramattha dīpanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the second stanza is ended.

original: Cittasaṅgaha-paramatthadīpanī
translated: The Cittasaṅgaha-paramatthadīpanī

original: 17. Idāni uddesakkamena cittaṃ tāva niddisanto tattha cittantiādimāha. Tatthāti tesu catūsu abhidhammatthesu. Tāva pathamaṃ. Cattāro vidhā pakārā yassa taṃ catubbidhaṃ.🔽18. Kāmāvacaranti ettha kāmīyatīti kāmo. Kāmentivā ettha sattā avikkhambhitakāmarāgattā
analyzed: idāni uddesa kkamena cittam tāva niddisantaḥ tattha citta nti ādim āha tattha ati tesu catūsu abhidhamma atthesu tāva pathamam cattāro vidhāḥ pakārāḥ yassa tam catubbidham  kāmā avacaranti ettha kāmīyati iti kāmo ettha sattāḥ a vikkhambhita kāma rāga ttā
translated: Now, in the order of the headings, he first defines consciousness, saying, “Herein, consciousness” and so on. Herein, among the four kinds of things in the Abhidhamma, first, that which has four modes, four kinds, is fourfold.

original: kāmaratiyāeva ramanti. Na uparibhūmīsu viya jhānaratiyāti kāmo. Ekādasavidhā kāmabhūmi.
analyzed: ramanti na upari bhūmīsu jhāna ratiyā ati kāmaḥ ekādasavidhā kāma bhūmi
translated: In the clause “of the sense sphere,” it is sense desire that is called “sense” . Or alternatively, it is because of sense desire that beings are called “those who delight in sense desire” , since they delight in sense desire because their sense desire has not been suppressed by the practice of development. They do not delight in the happiness of jhāna as they do in sense desire. Sense desire is the eleven kinds of sense-object element .

original: Nanu cettha jhānalābhinopi santīti. Na na santi. Tepana kadāci devāti natthettha
analyzed: nanu ca ittha jhāna lābhinaḥ api santi iti na na santi kadācid
translated: But surely there are also those who obtain jhāna here? —There are, but they are not called “those who delight in sense desire” because they are not so continuously.

original: doso. Avīcinirayādayo kathaṃ kāmīyanti. Kathañca tattha sattā kāmaratiyā ramantīti.🔽Nimittassādavasenavā bhavanikantivasenavāti. Maraṇakāle hi upaṭṭhitā nirayaggijālā
analyzed: doso avīci niraya ādayo katham kāmīyanti katham ca tattha sattā kāma ratiyā ramanti iti  nimitta ssāda vasena vā bhava nikanti vasena vā ati maraṇa kāle hi upaṭṭhitā nirayaggi jālā
translated: There is no fault in that. But how can the hells, etc., be sense desire? And how can beings delight in sense desire there?

original: suvaṇṇavaṇṇāviya khāyanti. Eko kira micchādiṭṭhiko brāhmaṇo maraṇamañce nippanno
analyzed: suvaṇṇa vaṇṇau iya khāyanti ekaḥ kira micchādiṭṭhikaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ maraṇa mañce nippannaḥ
translated: Because of the relish for the sign and because of the relish for existence there. For at the time of death the hell-fire appears to those about to be reborn there as though it were a bed of golden lotuses. A certain brahmin, it seems, who held the wrong view that “One who does the deed does not experience its result” was reborn in hell after death.

original: hoti. Tassa ācariyabrāhmaṇā samīpe ṭhatvā brahmalokaṃ bho gacchāti vadanti. Tassapana
analyzed: hoti tassa ācariya brāhmaṇā samīpe brahma lokam bho gaccha ati vadanti
translated: The brahmin teachers stand near him and say, “Go to the brahma world, sir.”

original: avīciniraye aggijālā upaṭṭhahanti. Tadā so bho ācariyā suvaṇṇavaṇṇā paññāyantīti
analyzed: avīci niraye aggi jālāḥ upaṭṭhahanti tadā so bho ācariyā suvaṇṇa vaṇṇā paññāyanti iti
translated: Then the flames of the Avīci hell appear to him. Then he says, “Sir, the brahma world appears golden.”

original: āha. Esa bho brahmaloko. Tattha gacchāti vadanti. So kālaṅkatvā avīcimhi uppajji.
analyzed: āha esa bho brahma loko tattha gacchāti vadanti saḥ kālaṅkatvā avīcimhi uppajji
translated: “That is the brahma world, sir. Go there.” He dies and is reborn in Avīci.

original: Evaṃ nimittassādavasena te kāmīyanti. Tattha uppannānaṃpi bhavanikantināma hotīti.
analyzed: evam te kāmīyanti tattha uppannānam pi bhava nikanti nāma hoti iti
translated: So they long for sensual desires by the sign of the sensual desires. And the name “those subject to rebirth” is also given to those who are reborn there.

original: Apica, tattha uppannā avikkhambhitakāmarāgāeva honti, okāse sati kāmaratiyā ramissanti
analyzed: apica tattha uppannāḥ a vikkhambhita kāma rāgāḥ eva honti okāse sati kāma ratiyā ramissanti
translated: Besides, those reborn there are only those whose lust for sensual desires is unabandoned, and they will enjoy sensual pleasures if there is an opportunity,

original: yevāti. Tasmiṃ kāme avacaratīti kāmāvacaraṃ. Etthaca avacaratīti padassa uppajjatīti🔽attho na gahetabbo. So hi attho pāḷiyāca nasameti. Nānādosayuttoca hotīti. Yaṃ etasmiṃ
analyzed: tasmin kāme avacarati iti kāma avacaram ettha ca avacarati iti padassa uppajjati iti  atthaḥ na gahetabbo saḥ hi atthaḥ hoti iti yam etasmin
translated: so it is called the sense-sphere of sensual desires because sensual desires are experienced there. And here the meaning of the word “experiences” should not be taken as “is reborn,”🔽for that meaning is not found in the texts. And it is not right to say that it is associated with the various taints. For this is said in the texts:

original: antare etthāvacarā ettha pariyāpannāti hi pāḷiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Yadi cettha so attho adhippeto
analyzed: antare etthāvacarāḥ ettha pariyāpannāḥ iti hi pāḷiyam vuttam yadi ca ittha saḥ attho adhippeto
translated: “Those that are here are those that experience here, those that are included here” . If that meaning were intended here,

original: siyā. Evaṃ sabhi etthāvacarā etthuppannāti vuttaṃ siyā. Napana vuttaṃ. Naca pariyāpannasaddo
analyzed: siyā evam ettha avacarāḥ ettha uppannā iti vuttam siyā na pana vuttam na ca pariyāpanna saddo
translated: It may be said that they are found there and arisen there, but it is not said. And the word “included”

original: uppannasaddena saha samānatthoti sakkā vattuṃ. Na hi lokuttaracittāni tīsu bhavesu
analyzed: uppanna saddena saha samāna atthaḥ iti sakkā vattum na hi lokuttara cittāni tīsu bhavesu
translated: cannot be said to have the same meaning as the word “arisen,” for supramundane consciousness, though arisen in the three planes,

original: uppannā nipi tatra pariyāpannāniyeva hontīti. Evaṃ tāva pāḷiyā nasametīti.
analyzed: uppannā tatra honti iti evam tāva pāḷiyā na sameti iti
translated: is not included there. So it does not agree with the text in this way.

original: Yadica so attho gahito siyā. Evañca sati tasmiṃ kāme ye mahaggata lokuttaradhammā🔽uppajjanti. Tesaṃpi kāmā vacaratāpattidoso rūpāvacaratādi muttidosoca āpajjati. Yeca
analyzed: yadi ca saḥ atthaḥ gahito siyā evam ca sati tasmin kāme ye mahaggata lokuttara dhammā  uppajjanti tesam pi āpajjati ye ca
translated: And if that meaning were intended, then it would follow that the exalted and supramundane states that arise in the sense sphere

original: kāmāvacaradhammā rūpārūpabhūmīsu uppajjanti. Tesañca rūpārūpā vacaratā pattidoso🔽kāmāvacaratā muttidosoca āpajjatīti. Nanu yebhuyyavuttivasenapi kesañci nāmalābho
analyzed: kāmāvacara dhammā rūpa arūpa bhūmīsu uppajjanti tesam ca rūpa arūpa āvacara tā patti doso  kāma avacara tā āpajjati iti nanu yebhuyya vutti vasena api
translated: would have the sense sphere as their domain, and it would follow that they would not have the fine-material sphere, etc., as their domain. And it would follow that the states of the sense sphere that arise in the fine-material and immaterial spheres would have the fine-material and immaterial spheres as their domain, and it would follow that they would not have the sense sphere as their domain.

original: hoti. Yathā vanacarako saṅgāmāvacaroti. Tasmā idhapi tesaṃ dhammānaṃ attano attano
analyzed: hoti yathā vana carako saṅgāma avacaroti tasmai idha api tesam dhammānam attanaḥ attanaḥ
translated: But is it not the case that some things are called by the name of the majority, as in the case of the expression “the forest dwellers are those who take part in the battle”? So here too, since the majority of states in the fine-material sphere, etc., are associated with the fine-material sphere, etc., they are called by the name of the majority.

original: bhummīsu uppannabahulattā kāmāvacarādi nāmalābhe sati na koci dosoti.Na. Evañhi sati
analyzed: uppanna bahula ttā kāmāvacara ādi nāma lābhe sati na kaścid evam hi sati
translated: Since they arise mostly in the planes, there is no fault in their being called “sense-desire-world” and so on when they are given names.🔽No, because if that were so,

original: lokuttara dhammānaṃ kāmāvacaratādi muccanatthaṃ yebhuyyena uppannabhūmi visuṃ vattabbā
analyzed: dhammānam kāmāvacara tā ādi muccana attham yebhuyyena uppanna bhūmi visum vattabbā
translated: then the supramundane states would have to be called “sense-desire-world” and so on because they arise mostly in the sense-desire world.

original: siyā. Na ca sā nāmabhūmi atthi. Yattha te yebhuyyena uppajjantīti. Tehi uppajjantā
analyzed: siyā na ca sā nāmabhūmi atthi yattha te yebhuyyena uppajjanti iti tehi uppajjantā
translated: And there is no plane of existence called “sense desire” in which they arise mostly.

original: tīsu bhavesu eva uppajjanti. Tasmā tesaṃ kāma rūpārūpāvacaratāpattidoso dunnivāro🔽siyāti. Evaṃ nānādosayutto hotīti. Tasmāssa tathā atthaṃ aggahetvā etthāvacarā ettha
analyzed: tīsu bhavesu eva uppajjanti tasmā tesam kāma rūpa arūpāvacara tā āpatti doso dunnivāraḥ  siyā ati evam nānā dosa yuttaḥ hoti iti tasmā assa tathā attham aggahetvā etthāvacarāḥ ettha
translated: So they arise only in the three kinds of becoming. Therefore the fault of their being sense-desire-, fine-material-, and immaterial-world states is hard to avoid.🔽So it is associated with various faults.🔽Therefore, without taking the meaning in that way, the meaning should be taken in the way commended by the Blessed One in the text itself, namely, “They occur there, they are included there.”

original: pariyāpannāti bhagavatā saṃvaṇṇitena pāḷinayenevassa attho gahetabboti. Ayañhettha🔽attho. Kāme avacarati pariyāpannabhāvena tasmiṃ ajjhogāhetvā carati pavattatīti kāmāvacaranti.
analyzed: pariyāpannā iti bhagavatā saṃvaṇṇitena pāḷi nayena iva assa atthaḥ gahetabbo ti ayam ha ittha  attho kāme avacarati pariyāpanna bhāvena tasmin ajjhogāhetvā carati pavattati iti kāma avacaranti
translated: This is the meaning here:🔽it occurs in the sense desires, it goes there, it occurs there by being included there, by being immersed there, by being absorbed there, thus it is a sense-desire-world state .

original: Pariyāpannabhāvocanāma attano ādhārabhūtena tena kāmena saha samānajātigottanāmatā
analyzed: ādhāra bhūtena tena kāmena saha
translated: The word “sense desire” is a name for the kind of being and the kind of generation that are the same as those of the kind of being and the kind of generation that are the basis for it.

original: saṅkhātehi paritobhāgehi tasmiṃ kāme āpannabhāvo anuppaviṭṭha bhāvo. Antogadhabhāvoti
analyzed: saṅkhātehi paritobhāgehi tasmin kāme āpanna bhāvaḥ anuppaviṭṭha bhāvaḥ antogadha bhāvaḥ ti
translated: The meaning is that they are included in the sense desires, they have entered into them, they have come to be in them.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Soca tathā pariyāpannabhāvo pariggāhiniyā kāmataṇhāya katoti daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: vuttam hoti saḥ ca tathā pariyāpanna bhāvaḥ pariggāhiniyā kāma taṇhāya kato ti daṭṭhabbo
translated: And that inclusion should be regarded as effected by the craving for sense desires which grasps them.

original: Ettāvatā yedhammā rūpārūpasattasantānabhūtāpi mayhaṃ eteti kāma taṇhāya pariggahitā🔽kāme pariyāpannāva honti. Te kāmāvacarānāmāti siddhā honti. Rūpārūpā vacaresupi ayaṃ
analyzed: ettāvatā rūpa arūpa satta santāna bhūtā api mayham etā iti kāma taṇhāya pariggahitā  kāme honti te siddhāḥ honti ayaṃ
translated: So far, those states, though they are material and immaterial and are in the continuity of beings, are included by the craving for sense desires as “these are mine,”🔽and so they are included in sense desires. They are established as “in the sense-desire element.” The same method should be followed in the case of the material and immaterial elements.

original: nayo netabbo. Tesupana rūpataṇhā arūpataṇhāca pariggāhinī taṇhā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: nayaḥ netabbo tesu pana rūpa taṇhā arūpa taṇhā ca pariggāhinī taṇhā daṭṭhabbā
translated: But the craving for materiality and the craving for immateriality should be regarded as the craving that grasps.

original: Yepana dhammā tiṇṇaṃ taṇhānaṃ pariggahavimuttā honti. Te tīsu bhavesu uppannāpi tatra
analyzed: dhammā tiṇṇam taṇhānam pariggaha vimuttāḥ honti te tīsu bhavesu uppannā api tatra
translated: But those states that are free from the inclusion of the three kinds of craving, though they arise in the three kinds of becoming,

original: apariyāpannāeva hontīti lokuttarā nāma jātāti veditabbā. Etthaca paṭṭhāne āruppe
analyzed: a pariyāpannā eva honti iti lokuttarāḥ nāma jātā ati veditabbā ettha ca paṭṭhāne āruppe
translated: are not included there, and so they should be understood as “supramundane.” And here, in the exposition of the supramundane,

original: kāmacchandaṃ nīvaraṇaṃ paṭicca uddhaccanīvaraṇantiādinā arūpasattasantānepi kāmacchandasaṅkhātāya
analyzed: kāma chandam nīvaraṇam paṭicca arūpa satta santāne pi kāma chanda saṅkhātāya
translated: in the passage: “Depending on the fetter of lust for sense desires, the fetter of agitation is abandoned” , the lust for sense desires should be understood as the fetter of lust for sense desires in the material and immaterial becoming.

original: kāmataṇhāya uppatti vuttā. Tasmā rūpārūpa bhūmīsu uppannānaṃ kāmadhammānaṃ pariggāhinītaṇhā
analyzed: kāma taṇhāyaḥ uppatti vuttā tasmā rūpa arūpa bhūmīsu uppannānam kāma dhammānam pariggāhinī taṇhā
translated: The arising of craving for sensual desires is stated. Therefore, the craving that is the appropriator of sensual desires arisen in the form and formless planes should be seen as present in the continuum of existence of beings in the form and formless planes.

original: rūpārūpasattasantāna gatāpi daṭṭhabbā. Pāḷiyaṃ kāmacchandanīvaraṇanti idaṃ nīvaraṇajātikattā
analyzed: rūpa arūpa satta santāna gatā api daṭṭhabbā pāḷiyam kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam ti idam nīvaraṇa jātika ttā
translated: In the text, the hindrance of sensual desire is mentioned because it is a hindrance by nature.

original: vuttaṃ. Na hi jhānabhūmīsu ekantanīvaraṇakiccāni nīvaraṇāni sakkā laddhunti. Atra
analyzed: vuttam na hi jhāna bhūmīsu ekanta nīvaraṇa kiccāni nīvaraṇāni sakkā laddhunti atra
translated: For in the planes of jhāna, the hindrances cannot be taken as hindrances by function, since they do not function as hindrances. Here,

original: kāmabhedo vattabbo. Dvekāmā kile sakāmoca, vatthukāmocāti. Tattha thapetvā rūpārūparāge
analyzed: kāma bhedaḥ vattabbaḥ dve kāmā kile vatthu kāmo ca ati tattha rūpa a rūpa rāge
translated: the classification of sensual desire should be stated. There are two kinds of sensual desire: sensual desire as defilement and sensual desire as object.

original: añño sabbopi lobho imasmiṃ catubbhūmiparicchede kile sakāmonāma. Thapetvāca rūpārūpāvacaradhamme
analyzed: añño sabbaḥ api lobho imasmim catu bhūmi paricchede kile rūpa arūpāvacara dhamme
translated: Herein, all greed except for greed for form and formless states is called sensual desire as defilement in this chapter on the four planes. And all states arisen in the three planes, except for those of the form and formless planes, are called sensual desire as object.

original: aññe sabbepi tīsu bhūmīsu uppannā kāmāvacaradhammā vatthukāmonāmāti. Yaṃpana aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ
analyzed: aññe sabbe pi tīsu bhūmīsu uppannā kāmāvacara dhammā vatthukāmo nāma ati yam pana aṭṭhasāliniyam
translated: But in the Eight-Factored Discourse it is said: “All states belonging to the three planes are sensual desire as object.”

original: sabbepi tebhūmakā dhammā vatthukāmoti vuttaṃ. Taṃ mahāniddese niddiṭṭhena suttantikapariyāyena
analyzed: sabbe api tebhūmakāḥ dhammāḥ vatthu kāmo ti vuttam tam mahāniddese niddiṭṭhena suttantika pariyāyena
translated: This is said according to the method of the Suttanta exposition given in the Mahāniddesa.

original: vuttanti gahetabbaṃ. Na hi rūpārūpāvacaradhammā abhidhamme kāmanāmena vuttā atthīti. [Kāmāvacarapadaṃ]
analyzed: vuttam ti gahetabbam na hi rūpa arūpa avacara dhammāḥ abhidhamme kāma nāmena vuttāḥ atthi iti kāma avacara padam
translated: and what is stated there should be taken. For there is no such thing as the states of the fine-material and immaterial spheres being stated by the word “desire” in the Abhidhamma.

original: 19. Rūpāvacaraṃ arūpāvacaranti ettha rūpārūpasaddā tāsu bhūmīsu niruḷhāti daṭṭhabbā.🔽Apica dve bhūmiyo rūpabhūmi, arūpabhūmīti. Tattha ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ rūpaṃ yattha natthi,
analyzed: rūpāvacaram arūpāvacaranti ettha rūpa arūpa saddā tāsu bhūmīsu niruḍhā ati daṭṭhabbā  apica dve bhūmiyaḥ rūpa bhūmi arūpa bhūmi iti tattha ruppana lakkhaṇam rūpam yattha natthi
translated: The words “fine-material” and “immaterial” should be regarded as names for those two planes.🔽Moreover, there are two planes, namely, the fine-material plane and the immaterial plane. Herein, the fourfold plane where there is no materiality, which has the characteristic of distension,

original: sā catubbidhā bhummi arūpabhūmināma. Sesā sattavīsatividhā bhummi rūpabhūmināma.🔽Tatthaca heṭṭhā ekādasavidhā bhummi oḷārikena kāmena visesetvā kāma bhūmīti vuttā.
analyzed: sā catubbidhā bhummi arūpa bhūmi nāma sesā sattavīsatividhā bhummi rūpa bhūmi nāma  tattha ca heṭṭhā ekādasavidhā bhummi oḷārikena kāmena visesetvā kāma bhūmī iti vuttā
translated: is called the immaterial plane. The remaining twenty-sevenfold plane is called the fine-material plane.🔽And here the first elevenfold plane is called the sense-desire plane because it is distinguished by gross sense desire.

original: Upari soḷasavidhā bhummi rūpabhūmiicceva vuttāti daṭṭhabbā. Yatthapana taṇhāvā jhānānivā🔽rūpārūpasaddehi vuttāni. Tattha nissayassanāmaṃ nissite āropanavasena nissayopacāro
analyzed: upari soḷasavidhā bhummi rūpa bhūmi iccā iva vuttā ati daṭṭhabbā  rūpa arūpa saddehi vuttāni tattha nissayassa nāmam nissite āropana vasena nissaya upacāro
translated: The remaining sixteenfold plane should be regarded as called the fine-material plane. And the plane is so called because of the desire and the jhānas that are there,🔽which are stated by the words “fine-material” and “immaterial.” Herein, the designation of the “desire” should be understood as a figurative use based on superimposition, since the desire is superimposed upon what is desired.

original: veditabbo. Yatthaca kāmāvacarādisaddehi bhūmieva vuttā. Tattha nissitassa nāmaṃ nissaye
analyzed: veditabbaḥ yattha ca kāmāvacara ādi saddehi bhūmi eva vuttā tattha nissitassa nāmam nissaye
translated: And the designation of the “name” should be understood as a figurative use based on what is desired, since the name is desired by the desire.

original: āropanavasena nissito pacāroti. Yamettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ kāmāvacarapade vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: āropana vasena nissitaḥ pacāraḥ ti yam ettha vattabbam tam kāmāvacara pade vutta nayam eva ati
translated: and is called “cooked” in the sense of “cooked by being dependent on that.” What should be said here has already been said in the case of the plane of sensuality.

original: Ayamettha tebhūmaka paricchede pāḷianugatā paramatthadīpanā. Yathāha –🔽Katame dhammā kāmāvacarā. Heṭṭhato avīcinirayaṃ pariyantaṃ karitvā uparito paranimmitavasavattīdeve
analyzed: ayam ettha paricchede pāḷi anugatā param attha dīpanā yathā āha  katame dhammā kāmāvacarā heṭṭhatas avīcinirayam pariyantam karitvā uparitas
translated: This is the commentary on the meaning of the clause “The three-plane states.”🔽As to the words “What states are of the sense sphere?” etc., the following is the explanation.

original: anto karitvā yaṃ etasmiṃ antare etthāvacarā ettha pariyāpannā khandhadhātuāyatanā
analyzed: antar karitvā yam etasmin antare etthāvacarāḥ ettha pariyāpannāḥ khandha dhātu āyatanā
translated: What states are of the sense sphere? Having made the Avīci Hell the lower limit and the Paranimmitavasavatti Deities the upper limit, the aggregates, bases, and elements that occur and are included in this interval,

original: rūpā vedanā saññā saṅkhārā viññāṇaṃ. Imedhammā kāmāvacarā. Katame dhammā rūpāvacarā.
analyzed: rūpā vedanā saññā saṅkhārāḥ viññāṇaṃ ime dhammā kāmāvacarā katame dhammā rūpāvacarā
translated: the materiality, the feelings, the perceptions, the formations, and the consciousness—these states are of the sense sphere.

original: Heṭṭhato brahmalokaṃ pariyantaṃ karitvā uparito akaniṭṭhe deve anto karitvā yaṃ etasmiṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhatas brahma lokam pariyantam karitvā uparitas akaniṭṭhe deve antar karitvā yam etasmin
translated: What states are of the fine-material sphere? Having made the Brahmā-world the lower limit and the Akaniṭṭha Deities the upper limit, the states that occur and are included in this interval,

original: antare etthāvacarā ettha pariyāpannā samāpannassavā upapannassavā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārissavā
analyzed: antare etthāvacarā ettha pariyāpannā samāpanna ssavā upapanna ssavā diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāri ssavā
translated: the states of the fine-material sphere of the jhānas and the states of the fine-material sphere of the kinds of generation, and the states of the fine-material sphere of the abiding in bliss here and now—

original: cittacetasikā dhammā, ime dhammā rūpāvacarā. Katame dhammā arūpāvacarā. Heṭṭhato
analyzed: citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ ime dhammāḥ rūpāvacarā katame dhammāḥ arūpāvacarā heṭṭhatas
translated: the consciousness and the things associated with the consciousness—these states are of the fine-material sphere. What states are of the immaterial sphere? Having made the base consisting of boundless space the lower limit and the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception the upper limit, the states that occur and are included in this interval,

original: ākāsānañcāyatanupage deve pariyantaṃ karitvā uparito nevasaññā nāsaññā yatanupage
analyzed: ākāsānañca āyatana upage deve pariyantam karitvā uparitas na ivasaññāḥ na asaññāḥ yatana upage
translated: and the gods of the base of infinite space,🔽and above that, the gods of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,

original: deve anto karitvā yaṃ etasmiṃ antare. La. Ime dhammā arūpāvacarāti.
analyzed: deve karitvā yam etasmin antare le ime dhammāḥ
translated: and the gods of the base of infinite space as the limit above, and the gods of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception as the limit below, and what is in between these two, namely, the gods of the base of infinite consciousness and the gods of the base of nothingness, are the ideas called ‘ of the immaterial sphere ’ .

original: [19] Ṭīkāsu pana
analyzed: ṭīkāsu pana
translated: But in the commentaries

original: Yathāvuttaṃ suvisadaṃ pāḷinayaṃ aggahetvā aññathā vacanatthāca vinicchayāca ettha vuttā. Sabbe te sārato na paccetabbāti.
analyzed: yathāvuttam su visadam pāḷi nayam aggahetvā aññathā vacana atthāca vinicchayāca ettha vuttā sabbe te sārataḥ na paccetabbā ati
translated: the meaning of the words and the explanation are given in a different way from that in the text, which is quite clear, and all that is said there should not be accepted as authoritative.🔽But were they not also given in the Eight Section?

original: Nanu aṭṭhasāliniyameva teca aññeca atthā vuttāti. Saccaṃ. Bhūtaṃpana suvisadaṃ pāḷianugataṃ atthaṃ ñatvā kiṃvikkhepenāti.🔽20. Lokuttaranti ettha lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena loko vuccati yathāvutto tebhūmakadhammo.🔽Yathāha lujjati palujjatīti kho bhikkhave tasmā lokoti vuccatīti. Evaṃ sante lokuttaradhammānaṃpi
analyzed: nanu te ca aññe ca atthāḥ vuttā ati saccam bhūtam pana su visadam pāḷi anugatam attham ñatvā kiṃvikkhepena ati  lokuttaram ti ettha lujjana palujjana aṭṭhena lokaḥ vuccati yathā vuttaḥ tebhūmaka dhammo  yathā āha lujjati palujjati iti kho bhikkhave tasmā loko ti vuccati iti evam sante lokuttara dhammānam pi
translated: —Yes, but what is the point of confusing the issue by knowing the meaning that is quite clear and in accordance with the text?🔽In the case of the words supramundane , the world is what is called so in the sense of that which is broken up and that which breaks up , and it is the ideas of the three planes of existence stated thus .🔽For it is said, “Bhikkhus, it is broken up and it breaks up , thus it is called the world ” .

original: nibbānavajjānaṃ lokatāpatti siyā. Kasmā, tesaṃpi lujjanapalujjanadhammattāti. Nasiyā.
analyzed: nibbāna vajjānam loka tā āpatti siyā kasmā tesam pi lujjana palujjana dhamma ttā ati na siyā
translated: If that is so, then it follows that the supramundane ideas, which are free from the taint of the world, have the nature of the world.🔽—No, it does not.

original: Yattha hi nicco dhuvo sassatoti mahājanassa micchāgāho nivisati. Tattheva tassa nivāraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: yattha hi niccaḥ dhuvaḥ mahājanassa micchāgāhaḥ nivisati tattha iva tassa nivāraṇa attham
translated: For it is just where there is a great mass of people’s misapprehension of permanence, eternity, and eternalness that the definition of the world is restricted for the purpose of refuting that.

original: ayaṃ lokasamaññā niyamīyati. Tasmā sabbaso micchāgāhavimuttānaṃ tesaṃ lokatāpatti
analyzed: ayam loka samaññā niyamīyati tasmā sabbasas micchāgāha vimuttānam tesam loka tā āpatti
translated: So they say that those who are quite free from misapprehension do not come within the world’s scope.

original: natthīti vadanti. Yesaṃvā lujjanaṃpalujjanañca mahājanassa pākaṭaṃ. Tesaññeva lokatāsiddhīti
analyzed: natthi iti vadanti yesam vā lujjanam palujjanam ca mahājanassa pākaṭam tesam eva lokatā siddhi iti
translated: Or else, those who are well known to the great mass of people as liable to destruction and to be destroyed are the only ones that are established in the world’s scope.🔽So there is no coming within the world’s scope for those who are supramundane.

original: natthi lokuttarānaṃ lokattappasaṅgoti. Lokato uttaratīti lokuttaraṃ. Maggacittaṃ.
analyzed: natthi lokuttarānam lokatta pasaṅgo ti lokataḥ uttarati iti lokuttaram magga cittam
translated: The supramundane is the path consciousness.

original: Tato uttiṇṇanti lokuttaraṃ. Phalacittaṃ. Nibbānaṃpana idha nalabbhatīti. Uttaraṇañcettha
analyzed: tatas uttiṇṇanti lokuttaram phala cittam nibbānam pana idha na labbhati iti uttaraṇam ca ittha
translated: The fruition consciousness is “beyond the world” in the sense of “risen above it” . But Nibbāna does not come within the scope of the world’s definition here.

original: taṇhāttayaggāha vimuttiyā tīsu lokesu apariyāpannabhāvoyeva. Soca apariyāpannabhāvo
analyzed: vimuttiyā tīsu lokesu so ca apariyāpanna bhāvaḥ
translated: For the “rising above” here is only the state of being unincluded in the three worlds by the liberation consisting in the surmounting of the three kinds of craving.🔽And that state of being unincluded is apprehended as if it were a fourth state of existence that is the basis for those ideas.

original: kesaṃ dhammānaṃ adhiṭṭhāna bhūtoviya gayhatīti visuṃ ekā catutthī avatthābhūmināmāti.
analyzed: dhammānam gayhati iti ekā catutthī avatthā bhūmi nāmā ati
translated: So it is a fourth state that is distinguished.

original: Catubbhūmivibhāgassa paramatthadīpanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The demonstration of the ultimate truth in the analysis of the four states is ended.

original: 21. Evaṃ cittaṃ bhūmibhedena hīnapaṇītā nukkamato catudhā niddisitvā idāni tadeva
analyzed: evam cittam bhūmi bhedena hīna paṇītāḥ catudhā niddisitvā idāni tat eva
translated: Having thus shown the mind in four ways according to the inferior and superior division of the planes, now,

original: catubbidhaṃ cittaṃ yathāniddiṭṭhakkamena vibhajanto pathamaṃ kāmāvacaracittaṃ. Tatthaca🔽hīnaṃ asobhaṇacittaṃ. Tatthaca sabbahīnaṃ akusalacittaṃ tāva dassetuṃ somanassasaha
analyzed: catubbidham cittam yathā niddiṭṭha kkamena vibhajantaḥ pathamam kāmāvacara cittam tattha ca  hīnam asobhaṇa cittam tattha ca sabba hīnam akusala cittam tāva dassetum somanassa saha
translated: in order to analyse that same fourfold mind in the order in which it was shown, he first of all deals with the sense-desire-sphere mind. Herein,🔽the inferior is the ugly mind. And the most inferior of all in this sphere is the unprofitable mind. So in order to show that first of all he said “accompanied by joy” .

original: gatantiādimāha. Etthaca kāmāvacaracittassapi akusalāhetuka sahetukānukkamo hīna paṇītānukkamavasena vuttoti daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: gata nti ādim āha ettha ca kāmāvacara cittassa api akusala ahetuka sa hetuka anukkamaḥ hīna paṇīta anukkama vasena vuttaḥ iti daṭṭhabbo
translated: And here the unprofitable root-cause order of the sense-desire-sphere mind should be regarded as stated in the order of inferiority and superiority.

original: [20] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: Upari vuccamānānaṃ bahūnaṃ cittānaṃ sobhaṇasaññākaraṇasukhatthaṃ appake pāpāhetukeyeva pathamaṃ dassentoti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: upari vuccamānānam bahūnam cittānam sobhaṇa saññā karaṇa sukha attham appake pāpā hetuke iva pathamam dassento ti vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: “In order to make it easy to remember the many kinds of consciousness that will be dealt with later on, he shows the few kinds of bad unprofitable root-cause first” . That is badly put.

original: Tadattho hi yathāvuttahīnādikkameneva siddhoti.
analyzed: tad atthaḥ hi yathāvutta hīna ādi kkamena iva siddhaḥ ti
translated: For the meaning intended is established by the order of inferiority and so on as already stated.

original: [21] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there

original: Tesu tesuca bhavesu gahitappaṭisandhikassa sattassa ādito vīthicittavasena lobhasahagata cittuppādāna meva sambhavato teyeva pathamanti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi nayujjati.
analyzed: tesu tesu ca bhavesu gahita ppaṭisandhikassa sattassa āditas vīthi citta vasena lobha sahagata citta uppādānam eva sambhavato te yeva pathamanti vuttam tat pi na yujjati
translated: In the various kinds of becoming, the first to arise is the kind of consciousness associated with greed, which is the first to arise in the case of a being who has taken rebirth-linking in any kind of becoming, since it is the first to arise in the case of the consciousnesses of the cognitive series that occur at the beginning. But that is not correct.

original: Ādito vīthicittavasena manodvārā vajjanasseva sabbapathamaṃ uppajjanatoti. Akusalesu🔽pana lobhamūla cittaṃ bahukañca hoti. Dvīhi vaṭṭamūlehi yuttattā padhānaṃ pākaṭañca
analyzed: āditas vīthi citta vasena manaḥ dvārā vajjanassa iva sabba pathamam uppajjanato ti akusalesu  pana lobha mūla cittam bahukañca hoti dvīhi vaṭṭa mūlehi yutta ttā padhānam pākaṭam ca
translated: Because the adverting that occurs at the mind door is the first to arise of all.

original: hotīti tadeva pathamaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽22. Tattha sundaraṃ manoti sumano. Siniddhacittaṃ. Na hi anavajjaṭṭhena sundaratā🔽idha yuttāti. Sundaraṃ mano etassābhivā sumano. Siniddhacittasamaṅgī puggalo. Sumanassa
analyzed: hoti iti tat eva pathamam vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam  tattha sundaram manoti su mano na hi sundara tā  idha sundaram manaḥ sumanaḥ
translated: But in the case of unprofitable consciousness, that rooted in greed is the most usual, and it is the most obvious because it is associated with the two roots of the unprofitable and with the two unprofitable roots. So that should be regarded as the first.🔽Herein, the mind is beautiful in one who is glad , thus he is glad , has a clear mind . For it is not beauty in the sense of blamelessness that is intended here;🔽but rather beauty in the sense of loveliness. He who has a beautiful mind is a glad person , one possessing a clear mind.

original: bhāvo somanassa. Mānasikasukhavedanāyetaṃ nāmaṃ. Etthaca sumanassa bhāvoti tasmiṃ
analyzed: bhāvo so manassa mānasika sukha vedanāya itam nāmaṃ ettha ca su manassa bhāvo ti tasmin
translated: The state of being glad is gladness . This is a name for mental pleasant feeling. And here the state of being glad is the state of being glad in that .

original: citte puggalevā sumanābhidhānassavā ayaṃ so sumanoti sumanabuddhiyāvā pavattinimittanti
analyzed: citte ayam saḥ sumanaḥ iti pavatti nimittanti
translated: The meaning is that the expression “pleasant” occurs in the mind and in the person, and the idea “pleasant” occurs with that as its object.

original: attho. Bhāvoti hi abhidhānabuddhīnaṃ pavattinimittaṃ vuccati. Bhavanti pavattanti
analyzed: atthaḥ bhāvaḥ ti hi abhidhāna buddhīnam pavatti nimittam vuccati bhavanti pavattanti
translated: For the object of the occurrence of the idea and the expression is called the “state” .🔽The meaning is that the idea and the expression occur with that as their support.

translated: But some say that the expression “it looks on by way of neutrality” is not appropriate here, since what is unprofitable is not of the nature of neutrality.

original: hotīti vadanti. Upekkhāya sahagatanti samāso.
analyzed: hoti iti vadanti upekkhāya sahagatanti samāso
translated: The compound upekkhāsahagata is a copulative one.

original: 23. Etthaca kiñcāpi phassādayo vitakkādayo mohādayoca dhammā iminā sakalena aṭṭhavidhena
analyzed: ettha ca kiñca api phassa ādayaḥ vitakka ādayaḥ moha ādayaḥ ca dhammā iminā sakalena aṭṭhavidhena
translated: And here, although such things as contact, etc., and such things as applied thought, etc., and such things as delusion, etc., are associated with equanimity in the sense stated, nevertheless it is said in the texts that equanimity is a condition for such things as applied thought, etc., and for such things as delusion, etc., by acting as a support for them, etc., in the way already described.

original: cittena saha gatā sampayuttāca honti, na pana te vedanāviya sayaṃpi bhedavantā honti.
analyzed: cittena saha gatā sampayuttāḥ ca honti na pana te bhedavantāḥ honti
translated: and they are not, like the feelings, themselves divided.🔽And there is no such distinction as that there are some in this consciousness and some are not.

original: Naca diṭṭhisaṅkhārānaṃ viyatesaṃ imasmiṃ citte katthaci honti katthacinahontīti ayaṃ🔽vikappo atthi. Tasmāte imassacittassa bhedakarā nahontīti idha nagahitāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: na ca diṭṭhi saṅkhārānam imasmim citte katthaci honti katthaci na honti iti ayaṃ  vikappaḥ atthi tasmā te imassa cittassa bheda karā na honti iti idha daṭṭhabbā
translated: So they are not mentioned here as dividers of this consciousness.

original: Lobhopana aññehi imassa aṭṭhavidhassa bhedakaro hoti. Vedanādiṭṭhi saṅkhārāca imassa🔽aññamaññassa bhedakarā hontīti teeva idha gahitāti daṭṭhabbā. Nanu pīti māna thinamiddhānipi🔽bhedakarāni hontīti tānipi idha sapītikaṃ apītikanti mānasampayuttaṃ mānavippayuttanti
analyzed: aññehi imassa aṭṭhavidhassa bheda karaḥ hoti saṅkhārāḥ ca imassa  añña maññassa bheda karā honti iti te eva idha gahitā ati daṭṭhabbā nanu thina middhāni pi  bheda karāni honti iti tāni api idha sa pītikam apītikam ti māna sampayuttam māna vippayuttam ti
translated: But greed is a divider of this eightfold consciousness. And the feelings, etc.,🔽and the determinations are dividers of this consciousness one from the other. So only these three are mentioned here.🔽But are not happiness, conceit, and agitation and remorse also dividers? So should they not be mentioned here too, as associated with happiness, unassociated with happiness, associated with conceit, unassociated with conceit, associated with agitation and remorse, unassociated with agitation and remorse?

original: thinamiddhasampayuttaṃ thinamiddhavippayuttanti ca gahetabbā nīti. Na. Tesu hi somanasse
analyzed: thinamiddha sampayuttam thinamiddha vippayuttanti ca gahetabbāḥ ni iti na tesu hi somanasse
translated: They should not be mentioned. For in the case of happiness, etc.,

original: gahite pīti gahitāva hoti. Itarānica tīṇi aniyatayogīnica honti, yevāpana kānicāti nagahitānīti.
analyzed: gahite iti itarāni ca tīṇi aniyata yogīni ca honti kāni ca ati na gahitāni iti
translated: and when joy is included, so is happiness. The other three are included in the three given, namely, in the three given as “some” and in the three given as “some too.”

original: [27] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana🔽Phassādivitakkādimohādidhammā ito aññehipi citte hi yuttā hontīti nate aññehi imassa
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana  phassa ādi vitakka ādi moha ādi dhammā itas aññehi pi citte hi yuttāḥ honti iti nate aññehi imassa
translated: But in the analysis

original: visesaṃ karonti. Tasmā te idha na gahitāti iminā adhippāyena yaṃ vuttaṃ “kasmā panettha
analyzed: visesam karonti tasmā te idha na gahitā ti iminā adhippāyena yam vuttam kasmā pana ittha
translated: the states beginning with contact and ending with applied thought, and those beginning with ignorance and ending with agitation, are associated with other consciousnesses too, and so they do not distinguish this consciousness from others. That is why they are not included here. This is the intention.🔽But why is only the association with joy, etc., stated here

original: aññesupi phassādīsu sampayuttadhammesu vijjamānesu somanassasahagatādibhāvova vuttoti.🔽Somanassādīnameva asādhāraṇa bhāvatoti. Phassādayohi keci sabbacitta sādhāraṇā keci
analyzed: aññesu pi phassa ādīsu sampayutta dhammesu vijjamānesu somanassa sahagata ādi bhāvaḥ u vuttaḥ ti  somanassa ādīnam eva asādhāraṇa bhāvato ti phassa ādayo hi keci sabba citta sādhāraṇā keci
translated: when contact, etc., the associated states, are present?

original: kusalādi sādhāraṇā. Mohādayoca sabbā kusalasādhāraṇāti na tehi sakkā cittaṃ visesetu”nti. Taṃ vicāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: kusala ādi sādhāraṇā moha ādayaḥ ca sabbā kusala sādhāraṇā ati na tehi sakkā cittam visesetun ti tat vicāretabbam
translated: Because joy, etc., are not shared in common. For some of the states beginning with contact are shared in common by all consciousness, some are shared in common by all profitable, etc., consciousness, and some are shared in common by all profitable consciousness. So they cannot distinguish consciousness” . This should be examined.

original: Evañhi sati somanassupekkhā saṅkhārāpi aññesu dissantīti tepi aññehi imassa visesaṃ nakaronti. Tasmā tepi idha nagahetabbā siyunti.
analyzed: evañhi sati somanassupekkhā saṅkhārā api aññesu dissanti iti te pi aññehi imassa visesam na karonti tasmā te pi idha na gahetabbā siyunti
translated: For if that were so, then since the formations of joy and equanimity are found in the other two, they too would not distinguish it from the others. So they too should be included here.

original: 24. Etthaca somanassappaṭisandhikatā, agambhīrappakatitā, iṭṭhārammaṇasamāyogo, byasanamuttica🔽somanassassa kāraṇaṃ. Somanassappaṭisandhikohi sadā bhavaṅgasomanassena paribhāvita
analyzed: ettha ca so manassa paṭisandhika tā agambhīra pakati tā iṭṭha ārammaṇa samāyogaḥ byasana mutti ca  somanassassa kāraṇam somanassa paṭisandhikaḥ hi sadā bhavaṅga somanassena paribhāvita
translated: And here the cause of joy is the fact that it is rebirth-linking with joy, the fact that it is not of profound occurrence, the fact that it is associated with a desirable object, and the fact that it is free from affliction.🔽For the continuity of consciousness that is impregnated with the joy of the life-continuum that is rebirth-linking with joy is of profound occurrence.

original: santāno hotīti tassa cittaṃ uppajjamānaṃ yebhuyyena somanassasahagataṃ uppajjatīti.
analyzed: santānaḥ hoti iti tassa cittam uppajjamānam yebhuyyena somanassa sahagatam uppajjati iti
translated: So when consciousness arises in it, it generally arises accompanied by joy.

original: Agambhīrappakatikoca hīnajjhāsayo appakaṃpi mahantaṃ maññati. Hīnaṃpi paṇītaṃ maññati.
analyzed: appakam pi mahantam maññati hīnam pi paṇītam maññati
translated: And one of low mentality, whose nature is not of profound occurrence, regards even a little as much, and even the inferior as superior.

original: Tasmā tassapi cittaṃ uppajjamānaṃ yebhuyyena somanassasahagataṃ hotīti. Iṭṭhārammaṇasamāyogoti
analyzed: tasmā tassa api cittam uppajjamānam yebhuyyena somanassa sahagatam hoti iti iṭṭha ārammaṇa samāyogaḥ ti
translated: So when consciousness arises in him, it generally arises accompanied by joy. Associated with a desirable object:🔽associated with a desirable object, whether inferior or superior, that is wished for by oneself. Free from affliction:

original: attanā icchitena hīnenavā paṇītenavā ārammaṇena samāyogo. Byasanamuttīti ñātibyasanādito
analyzed: attanā icchitena hīnena vā paṇītena vā ārammaṇena samāyogaḥ byasana mutti iti ñāti byasana āditaḥ
translated: free from affliction by the loss of relatives, etc.,

original: mutti. Upekkhāpaṭisandhikatā, gambhīrappakatitā, majjhattārammaṇasamāyogo, byasanamuttica
analyzed: mutti upekkhā paṭisandhika tā gambhīra ppakati tā majjhatta ārammaṇa samāyogaḥ byasana mutti ca
translated: and release. The cause of equanimity is the condition of rebirth as equanimity, the state of being profound and subtle, the concurrence of a neutral object, and the escape from misfortune.

original: upekkhāya kāraṇaṃ. Etthaca gambhīrappakabhitānāma mahajjhāsayatā. Tādiso hi puggalo
analyzed: upekkhāya kāraṇam ettha ca mahajjhāsaya tā tādisaḥ hi puggalaḥ
translated: And here the state of being profound and subtle is the great desire to see. For such a person

original: mahantaṃpi appakaṃ maññati, paṇītaṃpi hīnaṃ maññatīti. Diṭṭhajjhāsayatā, diṭṭhivipannapuggalasevanā,
analyzed: mahantam pi appakam maññati paṇītam pi hīnam maññati iti diṭṭhajjhāsaya tā diṭṭhi vipanna puggala sevanā
translated: thinks even a great deal to be little, and thinks even the sublime to be low. The cause of view is the desire to see, the keeping company of persons who are victims of views,

original: saddhammavimukhatā, micchāvitakkabahulatā, ayoniso ummujjanañca diṭṭhiyā kāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: saddhamma vimukha tā micchā vitakka bahula tā ayonisaḥ ummujjanam ca diṭṭhiyā kāraṇam
translated: the turning away from the true Dhamma, the abundance of wrong thoughts, and the improper reflection.

original: Tattha diṭṭhajjhāsayatāti kāṇāriṭṭhassaviya sunakkhattassaviyaca purimabhave diṭṭhi🔽gatikabhāvena āgatattā imasmiṃ bhavepi sassatucchedāsaya bhāvo. Saddhammavimukhatāti🔽ciraṃpi kālaṃ saddhammena vinā āgatatā. Micchāvitakkabahulatāti attano avisayesu
analyzed: tattha purima bhave  gatika bhāvena āgata ttā imasmin bhave pi bhāvo saddhamma vimukha tā ti  ciram pi kālam saddhammena vinā āgata tā micchā vitakka bahula tā ati attanaḥ avisayesu
translated: Herein, the desire to see is the state of having come to the round of rebirths by the course of views in a previous existence, like the wanderer Kaṇḍarāyana and the wanderer Sunakkhatta.

original: sabbaññuvisayesu ṭhānesu attano pamāṇaṃ ajānitvā cintāpasutavasena micchāvitakkabahulabhāvo.
analyzed: sabbaññu visayesu ṭhānesu attanaḥ pamāṇam a jānitvā cintā pasuta vasena micchā vitakka bahula bhāvaḥ
translated: The turning away from the true Dhamma is the state of having come to this existence without the true Dhamma after a long time. The abundance of wrong thoughts is the state of being abundant in wrong thoughts by way of reflection and pondering without knowing one’s own measure in the field of omniscience, which is not one’s own province.

original: Ayoniso ummujjananti attanādiṭṭhakāraṇameva sārato saccato ummujjanaṃ. Tabbiparītena
analyzed: ayonisaḥ ummujjanan ti attanā ādiṭṭha kāraṇam eva sārataḥ saccataḥ ummujjanam tad biparītena
translated: “Arising by non-reflection” is the arising by taking as true and real only the reason of the view of self. The opposite of that

original: diṭṭhivippayuttakāraṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Asaṅkhārikakammajanitappaṭisandhi katā, kallakāya🔽cittatā, khanti bahulatā, purisakāresu diṭṭhānisaṃsatā, kammappasutatā, utubhojanādi
analyzed: diṭṭhi vippayutta kāraṇam veditabbam asaṅkhārika kamma janita ppaṭisandhi katā kallakāya  citta tā khanti bahula tā purisakāresu diṭṭha anisaṃsa tā kamma ppasuta tā utu bhojana ādi
translated: should be understood as the reason for the kinds of consciousness without root-cause. The rebirth-linking that is generated by root-cause-less kamma is done; the state of being a suitable body;

original: sappāya lābhoti idaṃ asaṅkhārikakāraṇaṃ. Tattha khantibahulatāti sītuṇhādīnaṃ khamanabahulatā.
analyzed: sappāya lābho ti idam asaṅkhārika kāraṇam tattha khanti bahula tā ati sītuṇha ādīnam khamana bahula tā
translated: the abundance of acquiescence; the seeing of advantages in manly activity; the being well-practiced in kamma; the gain of what is suitable as climate, food, etc. This is the reason without root-cause. Herein, the abundance of acquiescence is the abundance of acquiescence in cold, quiet, etc.

original: Purisakāresūti purisehi kattabbesu kammesu. Kammappasutabhāti kammesu ciṇṇavasitā.
analyzed: purisakāresu iti purisehi kattabbesu kammesu kammappasutabhā ati kammesu
translated: In manly activity: in the kinds of work that men do. Well-practiced in kamma: well-practiced in work.

original: Tabbiparī tena sasaṅkhārikakāraṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Imesaṃpana cittānaṃ uppatti vidhānaṃ🔽visuddhimagge gahetabbaṃ. Aṭṭhapīti pisaddena nesaṃ labbhamānakammapathabhedato kāla
analyzed: tad biparī tena sa saṅkhārika kāraṇam veditabbam imesam pana cittānam uppatti vidhānam  visuddhi magge gahetabbam aṭṭha pi iti pi saddena nesam labbhamāna kamma patha bhedato kāla
translated: The opposite of that should be understood as the reason with root-cause. And the method of arising of these kinds of consciousness

original: santānā rammaṇādi bhedatoca anekavidhattaṃ sampiṇḍetīti.
analyzed: santāna ārammaṇa ādi sampiṇḍeti iti
translated: should be taken from the Visuddhimagga . “Eight” : it combines into one the manifoldness of these kinds of consciousness that is due to the different kinds of action that can be found in them, and that is due to the difference in their time, continuity, object, etc.

original: Lobhamūlacittassa paramatthadipanā niṭṭhitā.🔽25. Dosamūlacitte duṭṭhumanobhi dummano. Virūpaṃ cittaṃ. Duṭṭhumano etassātivā dummano.
analyzed: lobha mūla cittassa paramattha dipanā niṭṭhitā  dosa mūla citte duṭṭhu manobhi dummanaḥ virūpam cittam duṭṭhu manaḥ etassa ativā dummanaḥ
translated: The exposition of the meaning of the consciousness rooted in greed is ended.🔽In the consciousness rooted in hate, the word “hateful” is duṭṭhu manobhi.🔽The word “hateful” is duṭṭhu manobhi. The person possessing hateful consciousness is “hateful” .

original: Virūpacittasamaṅgīpuggalo. Dummanassa bhāvo domanassaṃ. Mānasikadukkhavedanāyetaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ. Sā hi attanā sahagate cittevā taṃ samaṅgīpuggalevā dummanā bhidhānassavā🔽ayaṃ so dummanoti dummanabuddhiyāvā pavattinimittaṃ hotīti. Sesaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.
analyzed: virūpa citta samaṅgī puggalaḥ dummanassa bhāvaḥ domanassam mānasika dukkha vedanāya etam  adhivacanam sā hi attanā sahagate cittā iva tam samaṅgī puggalā iva dummanā  ayam saḥ dummano ti dummana buddhi yāvā pavatti nimittam hoti iti sesam heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva
translated: The state of being hateful is hate . This is a term for painful mental feeling.🔽For that is hateful to the person himself who possesses it and to others as well.🔽It is the reason for the occurrence of the idea “He is hateful” . The rest is as already stated.🔽The compound domanassa-sahagata is resolved into domanassañca taṃ sahagatañcāti domanassa-sahagataṃ .

original: Domanassena saha gatanti samāso. Paṭihaññatīti paṭigho. Doso. Sohi uppajjamāno sampayuttadhammepi🔽paṭihanati. Lūkhe santatte karoti. Attano vatthumpi paṭihanati. Hadayappadesaṃ dahati.
analyzed: domanassena saha gatanti samāsaḥ paṭihaññati iti paṭighaḥ doso saḥ hi uppajjamānaḥ sampayutta dhamme pi  paṭihanati lūkhe santatte karoti attanaḥ vatthum pi paṭihanati hadaya ppadesam dahati
translated: The word “repugnance” is paṭigha . It is hate .🔽For that, when it arises, repels associated states,🔽making them rough and unserviceable. It repels its own physical basis, burning the heart region.

original: Taṃ puggalaṃ dummukhaṃ karoti, attano ārammaṇaṃpi paṭihanati. Taṃ bādhaya māno gaṇhāti.
analyzed: tam puggalam dummukham karoti attanaḥ ārammaṇam pi paṭihanati tam bādhaya mānaḥ gaṇhāti
translated: It makes the person unsightly. It repels its own object, taking it as repulsive.

original: Tasmā paṭighoti vuccatīti.
analyzed: tasmā paṭighaḥ ti vuccati iti
translated: That is why it is called “repugnance” .

original: 26. Ettha siyā. Saṅkhāro tāva imassa cittassa bheda karoti tassa idha gahaṇaṃ yuttaṃ.🔽Vedanā paṭighāpana bhedakarā na hontīti te idha na gahetabbāti. Vuccate, domanassaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: ettha siyā saṅkhāro tāva imassa cittassa bheda karoti tassa idha gahaṇam yuttam  vedanā paṭighāpana bheda karā na honti iti te idha na gahetabbā ati vuccate domanassa ggahaṇam
translated: Here it may be asked: “But surely it is right to include formations here, since they are the breakup of this consciousness.🔽But feelings are not the breakup of resistance, so they should not be included here.”🔽It may be replied: “The inclusion of grief is for the purpose of excluding the possibility that this consciousness may be associated with some other feeling.

original: tāva imassa cittassa kadāci aññavedanāyogatā pasaṅganivattanatthanti. Yadāhi rājāno
analyzed: tāva imassa cittassa kadāci añña vedanā yoga tā yadā hi rājānaḥ
translated: For when kings, for instance,

original: hasamānāyeva coravadhaṃ pesenti. Yadāca janā attano verīnaṃ maraṇe tuṭṭhiṃ pavedenti.
analyzed: hasamānāya iva cora vadham pesenti yadā ca janāḥ maraṇe tuṭṭhim pavedenti
translated: are laughing, they may order the execution of a criminal, and when people are rejoicing over the death of their enemy,🔽they may be glad at his death.

original: Maraṇaṃ abhinandanti. Yadāca bālajanā hasamānāva migapakkhino mārenti. Tadā idaṃ
analyzed: maraṇam abhinandanti yadā ca bāla janāḥ miga pakkhinaḥ mārenti tadā idam
translated: And when foolish people are laughing, they may kill a deer or a bird.

original: nukho somanassena yuttanti attheva pasaṅgo. Upekkhāyogepana vattabbameva natthi.🔽Tappasaṅganivattanatthaṃ domanassaggahaṇanti. Paṭighaggahaṇaṃpi aññadhammasampayuttatā
analyzed: nu kho somanassena yuttanti attha iva pasaṅgaḥ upekkhā yogepana vattabbam eva natthi  tad pasaṅga nivattana attham domanassa ggahaṇam ti paṭigha ggahaṇam pi añña dhamma sampayutta tā
translated: So there is the possibility that this consciousness may be associated with joy. And there is no need to mention equanimity, since it is always present.🔽So the inclusion of grief is for the purpose of excluding the possibility of association with some other feeling.🔽And the inclusion of resistance is for the purpose of excluding the possibility of association with some other state.

original: pasaṅganivattanatthaṃ. Tathāhi ye natthikāhetukā kiriyamicchā diṭṭhikā pāṇavadhe
analyzed: pasaṅga nivattana attham tathā hi ye natthikā hetukā kiriyam icchā diṭṭhikā pāṇa vadhe
translated: For there are those who are materialists, nihilists, and doers of actions that are a cause of hell, who kill living things,

original: apuññaṃnāma natthīti gaṇhanti. Yeca manussapāṇa vadheeva apuññaṃ hoti, tiracchānagatapāṇavadhe
analyzed: apuññam nāma natthi iti gaṇhanti ye ca manussa pāṇa vadhe eva apuññam hoti tiracchāna gata pāṇa vadhe
translated: They take it that there is no such thing as demerit. And they take it that there is no demerit in killing creatures that are not human beings,🔽and that there is great merit in sacrificing creatures that are human beings,

original: apuññaṃ natthīti gaṇhanti. Yeca pāṇavadhaṃ katvā yaññaṃ yajantānaṃ mahantaṃ puññaṃ🔽hoti, dibbasaṃvattanikanti gaṇhanti. Te sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā vissaṭṭhā pāṇavadhaṃ sayaṃvā
analyzed: apuññam natthi iti gaṇhanti ye ca pāṇa vadham katvā yaññam yajantānam mahantam puññam  hoti dibbasaṃvattanikam ti gaṇhanti te sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā vissaṭṭhā pāṇa vadham sayaṃvā
translated: and that this leads to heavenly rebirth. They themselves kill creatures or they get others to do so.

original: karonti. Aññevā pesenti. Tadā idaṃ diṭṭhiyāpi sampayuttaṃ siyāti pasaṅgo hotiyeva.
analyzed: karonti aññā iva pesenti tadā idam diṭṭhiyā api sampayuttam siyā ti pasaṅgaḥ
translated: So there is a possibility that this view is associated with hate.

original: Yepana sammādiṭṭhikesu bālā abyattā, te kadāci tesaṃ micchādiṭṭhikānaṃ laddhiṃ gahetvā🔽pāṇaṃ vadhantā ādito vematikajātāva honti. Tadātesaṃ idaṃ vicikicchāyapi yuttaṃ siyāti🔽pasaṅgo hoti. Tappasaṅga nivattanatthaṃ paṭighaggahaṇanti. Itarathā purima cittassa
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhikesu bālāḥ a byattāḥ te kadāci tesam micchādiṭṭhikānam laddhim gahetvā  pāṇam vadhantāḥ āditas honti idam yuttam siyāti  pasaṅgaḥ hoti tad pasaṅga nivattana attham paṭigha ggahaṇan ti itarathā
translated: And when fools who are not discerning take the side of those who hold right view,🔽they sometimes adopt their opponents’ view that there is no such thing as demerit in killing creatures, and they themselves kill creatures or they get others to do so.🔽So there is a possibility that this view is associated with uncertainty.

original: lobhasahagatabhāvoviya imassa paṭighasampayuttabhāvo cūḷanigameneva siddhoti tesaṃ
analyzed: imassa paṭigha sampayutta bhāvaḥ cūḷa nigamena iva siddhaḥ ti tesam
translated: So the purpose of the words “and rejection” is to preclude this possibility. Otherwise, just as the first consciousness is associated with greed, so this would be associated with rejection, and that would be established by the Shorter Text.

original: gahaṇaṃ niratthakaṃ siyāti. Etthaca issāmacchariyakukkuccānaṃ thinamiddhassaca aggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: gahaṇam niratthakam siyāti ettha ca issā macchariya kukkuccānam thinamiddhassa ca a gahaṇam
translated: and then the apprehension of it would be pointless. And here the non-inclusion of envy, avarice, worry, and lethargy

original: purimacitte mānathinamiddhanayena veditabbaṃ. Ayamettha paramatthadīpanā.
analyzed: purima citte ayam ettha parama attha dīpanā
translated: should be understood according to the method of pride and lethargy in the preceding consciousness. This is the explanation of the actual meaning here.

original: [28] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana mahāṭīkāyañca
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī and in the Māhā-atthākā

original: “Asādhāraṇa dhammavasena cittassa upalakkhaṇatthaṃ domanassaggahaṇa”nti vuttaṃ. Tattha asādhāraṇadhammavasenāti idaṃ tāva nayujjati.
analyzed: asādhāraṇa dhamma vasena cittassa upalakkhaṇa attham domanassa ggahaṇan ti vuttam tattha asādhāraṇa dhamma vasena ati idam tāva na yujjati
translated: it is said, “The inclusion of grief is for the purpose of characterizing the consciousness by means of a state not common to other kinds of consciousness.” Herein, as to the words “by means of a state not common to other kinds of consciousness”: this is applicable thus.

original: [29] Satipi imassa somanassupekkhāsahagatabhāve anaññasādhāraṇeneva domanassena imassa🔽upalakkhaṇatthanti atthassa āpajjanato. Yathātaṃ satipi purimassa imassaca cittassa
analyzed: sati pi imassa somanassa upekkhā sahagata bhāve anañña sādhāraṇena iva domanassena imassa  upalakkhaṇa ttham ti atthassa āpajjanataḥ sati pi purimassa imassa ca cittassa
translated: [] Although this is accompanied by joy and equanimity, it is characterized by grief not common to any other kind of consciousness.

original: mohasahagatabhāve anaññasādhāraṇeneva lobhena paṭighenaca upalakkhaṇatthaṃ lobhasahagatapaṭigha
analyzed: moha sahagata bhāve anañña sādhāraṇena iva lobhena paṭighena ca upalakkhaṇa attham lobha sahagata paṭigha
translated: For the purpose of characterizing it: because the meaning is included. Just as, although this and the preceding consciousness are accompanied by delusion, the inclusion of that accompanied by greed and that associated with repulsion is for the purpose of characterizing it by means of greed and repulsion not common to any other kind of consciousness.

original: sampayuttaggahaṇanti. Upalakkhaṇatthanti ca na vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: sampayutta ggahaṇam ti upalakkhaṇa attham ti ca na vattabbam
translated: And it should not be said that it is for the purpose of characterizing it by means of grief not common to any other kind of consciousness.

original: Evañhi sati pākaṭena domanassena apākaṭānaṃ aññavedanā naṃpi idha laddhabhāvaṃ upalakkhetīti āpajjati. Yathā laddhātapatto rājakumāroti.🔽[30] Yañca vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: evam hi sati pākaṭena domanassena apākaṭānam añña vedanā idha laddha bhāvam upalakkheti iti āpajjati yathā laddha ātapattaḥ rāja kumāraḥ ti  yañca vibhāvaniyam
translated: For if it were so, then it would follow that the other feelings, which are not manifest, would have to be included here too, since they are included in grief. It would be like the case of a prince who has a servant.

original: “Paṭighasampayuttabhāvopana ubhinnaṃ ekanta sahacāritā dassanatthaṃ vutto”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: ubhinnam ekanta sahacāri tā dassana attham vuttaḥ ti vuttam tat pi na sundaram
translated: And the explanation given in the Vibhaṅga is not good: “It is said to be grief because of the state of being associated with resistance, in order to show the absolute co-occurrence of the two” .

original: Imassa cūḷanigameneva tadatthasiddhitoti.🔽27. Etthaca dosajjhāsayatā, agambhīrappakatitā, appassukatā, āghātavatthusamāyogovā,
analyzed: imassa cūḷa nigamena iva tad attha siddhitā ti  ettha ca dosa ajjhāsaya tā agambhīra ppakati tā appassuka tā āghāta vatthu samāyogaḥ vā
translated: For the meaning is established by the short summary itself.

original: aniṭṭhārammaṇasamāyo govā domanassassa paṭighassaca kāraṇaṃ. Tattha dosa bahula bhāvato
analyzed: aniṭṭha ārammaṇa samāyaḥ domanassassa paṭighassa ca kāraṇam tattha dosa bahula bhāvato
translated: Herein, the state of being disposed to hate, the state of being shallow and muddled, the state of being unintelligent, the presence of a cause for annoyance, and the presence of an undesirable object are the causes for grief and hate. Herein, the state of being disposed to hate should be understood as the presence of much hate,

original: āgatavasena dosajjhāsayatā daṭṭhabbā. Agambhīrappakatitā hīnajjhāsayatā. Appassutassaca
analyzed: āgata vasena dosa jjhāsaya tā daṭṭhabbā agambhīra ppakati tā hīna jjhāsaya tā appassutassa ca
translated: the state of being shallow and muddled as the presence of a low disposition, and the state of being unintelligent as the presence of a stupid disposition.

original: aniṭṭha loka dhammehiphuṭṭhassa taṃkutetthalabbhāti paccavekkhanā natthīti. Imesampi
analyzed: paccavekkhanā natthi iti imesam pi
translated: And the presence of a cause for annoyance is the presence of an object that is a cause for annoyance. The presence of an undesirable object is the presence of an object that is undesirable.

original: dvinnaṃ uppattividhānaṃ visuddhimagge gahetabbaṃ. Pisaddassa atthopi vuttanayoevāti.
analyzed: dvinnam uppatti vidhānam visuddhi magge gahetabbam pi saddassa atthaḥ api vutta nayaḥ eva ti
translated: The method of the two kinds of arising should be understood in the way stated in the Path of Purification. And the meaning of the words is also stated there.

original: Dosamūlacittassa paramatthadipanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dosa mūla cittassa paramattha dipanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The elucidation of the consciousness rooted in hate is ended.

original: 28. Mohamūlacitte vicikicchuddhaccānaṃ padattho upari āgamissati. Yasmāpana idaṃ
analyzed: moha mūla citte padatthaḥ upari āgamissati idam
translated: The meaning of the words doubt and delusion will come up later in the case of the consciousness rooted in delusion.

original: cittaṃ mūlantaravirahena laddhokāsena suṭṭhubalavantena mohenaceva saṃsappamānavikkhipamānehi🔽vicikicchuddhaccehi ca yuttaṃ hoti. Tasmā idha vedanāpi ārammaṇaṃ adhimattato anubhavituṃ🔽na sakkotīti upekkhāvedanāva yuttā hoti. Evaṃ santepi idaṃ cittaṃ somanassa domanassa
analyzed: cittam mūla antara virahena laddha ukāsena suṭṭhu balavantena mohena ca iva saṃsappamāna vikkhipamānehi  ca yuttam hoti tasmai idha vedanā api ārammaṇam adhimattataḥ anubhavitum  na sakkoti iti upekkhā vedanā ava yuttā hoti evam sante pi idam cittam somanassa domanassa
translated: But this consciousness is associated with delusion, which has obtained opportunity owing to the absence of any other root, and with doubt and distraction, which are distracted and unsteady🔽because of the delusion’s strength. That is why it is unable to experience the object as very evident,

original: sahagatānaṃpi anantare uppajjati. Tasmā tadubhayavedanāhipi idaṃ yuttaṃ siyāti pasaṅgo
analyzed: anantare uppajjati tasmā idam yuttam siyāti pasaṅgaḥ
translated: and it is associated only with equanimity. Still, it arises immediately after that associated with joy and with grief. Therefore the assumption arises that it is associated with both joy and grief.

original: hotīti tappasaṅganivattanatthaṃ idha upekkhāgahaṇaṃ kataṃ. Anaññacittasādhāraṇena
analyzed: hoti iti tad pasaṅga nivattana attham idha upekkhā gahaṇam katam anañña citta sādhāraṇena
translated: In order to forestall such an assumption, equanimity is mentioned here.

original: dhammena cittassa niyamanatthaṃ vicikicchāgahaṇaṃ. Uddhaccaṃ pana sabbākusalesu yuttaṃpi
analyzed: dhammena cittassa niyamana attham vicikicchā gahaṇam uddhaccam pana sabba akusalesu yuttam pi
translated: And the inclusion of uncertainty is for the purpose of restraining the mind by means of the True Idea. But agitation, though it is associated with all unprofitable thoughts,

original: idha laddhokāsaṃ hutvā suṭṭhu balavaṃ hotīti dassanatthaṃ idheva gahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: idha laddha ukāsam hutvā suṭṭhu balavam hoti iti dassana attham idha iva gahitan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: is nevertheless to be regarded as included here because it is shown that it has a place here and is strong.

original: Tenevahi dhammasaṅgaṇiyaṃ dhammuddesavāre uddhaccaṃ aññesu pāpacittesu sarūpato anuddharitvā
analyzed: tena iva hi dhammasaṅgaṇiyam dhamma uddesa vāre uddhaccam aññesu pāpa cittesu sarūpataḥ an uddharitvā
translated: That is why in the Schedule of Ideas in the Description of Ideas it is not extracted in its individual essence from the other evil thoughts,

original: yevāpanakabhāveneva vuttaṃ. Imasmiṃ antimacitteeva sarūpato uddhaṭanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: yevāpanaka bhāvena iva vuttam imasmin antima citte eva sarūpataḥ daṭṭhabbam
translated: but is mentioned only as a concomitant. And it should be regarded as extracted in its individual essence here in the last thought only.

original: Yasmāca idaṃcittadvayaṃ sattānaṃ pakatisabhāvabhūtanti payogena vā upāyena vā kenaci
analyzed: yasmāt ca payogena vā upāyena vā kenacid
translated: And because these two kinds of thought are the natural state of beings, they are not to be aroused by any means,

original: uppādetabbaṃ nāma natthi. Sabbakālampi bhavaṅgacittaṃviya anosakkamānaṃ asaṃsīdamānaṃ🔽akicchena akasirena pavattati. Tasmā ekantena asaṅkhārikameva hotīti katvā idha saṅkhārabhedo
analyzed: uppādetabbam nāma natthi sabbakālam pi bhavaṅga cittam viya anosakkamānam a saṃsīdamānam  akicchena a kasirena pavattati tasmai ekantena asaṅkhārikam eva hoti iti katvā idha saṅkhāra bhedaḥ
translated: by any method, or by any effort. They occur without difficulty, without effort, as does the life-continuum consciousness at all times without being interrupted or broken.🔽Therefore it should be regarded as not included here in the analysis of formations because it is exclusively unformed.

original: na gahitoti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tenevaca pāḷiyaṃpi purimacittesuviya idha sasaṅkhārenāti
analyzed: na gahito ti daṭṭhabbam idha sa saṅkhārena ati
translated: And that is why in the text here, as in the case of the preceding thoughts, it is said only “with formations” and not “with formations and with perception” .

original: dutīyacittavāro navuttoti. Ayamettha paramatthadīpanā.
analyzed: dutīya cittavāraḥ ayam ettha paramattha dīpanā
translated: and the second is said to be accompanied by equanimity. This is the explanation of the meaning of the words.

original: [31] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: Imāni dve cittāni atisammuḷhatāya aticañcalatāya ca sabbatthapi rajjanadussanarahitāni honti. Tasmā upekkhā sahagatāneva pavattantīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: imāni dve cittāni ati sammuḷha tāya ati cañcala tāya ca sabbattha api rajjana dussana rahitāni honti tasmai upekkhā sahagatāna eva pavattanti iti vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: “These two kinds of consciousness are devoid of greed and hate respectively because of extreme lack of confusion and extreme restlessness. That is why it is said that they occur accompanied by equanimity only. ” That is not good.

original: Rajjana sahitānaṃpi lobhamūla cittānaṃ upekkhā yogassa diṭṭhattāti.
analyzed: rajjana sahitānaṃ pi lobha mūla cittānaṃ upekkhā yogassa diṭṭha ttā ti
translated: For consciousness rooted in greed is also found accompanied by equanimity.

original: [32] Yañca tattha mahāṭīkāyañca
analyzed: yat ca tattha mahāṭīkāyat ca
translated: And what is said in the Mahā-aṭṭhakathā:

original: “Tatoyevaca sabhāvatikkhatāya ussāhetabbatāyaca abhāvato saṅkhārabhedopi nesaṃ natthī”ti
analyzed: tatas yeva ca abhāvato saṅkhāra bhedaḥ pi na esam natthi iti
translated: “And because of the absence of any natural end and of any need for exertion, they have no distinction of formation either”

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha sabhāvatikkhatāya abhāvatoti iminā imassa asaṅkhārikabhāvaṃ paṭikkhipati.
analyzed: vuttam tattha sabhāva tikkha tāya abhāvato ti iminā imassa asaṅkhārika bhāvam paṭikkhipati
translated: is not good. Herein, by “because of the absence of any natural end” he rejects the fact that it is unformed;

original: Ussāhetabbatāya abhāvatoti iminā sasaṅkhārikabhāvaṃ paṭikkhipati. Tadubhaye pana
analyzed: ussāhetabba tāya abhāvato ti iminā sasaṅkhārika bhāvam paṭikkhipati tad ubhaye pana
translated: by “because of the absence of any need for exertion” he rejects the fact that it is formed. But both together

original: idaṃ cittadvayaṃ sabbaso saṅkhāravimuttaṃ hotīti dasseti. Taṃ aṭṭhakathāyapi tāva na sameti.
analyzed: idam citta dvayam sabbaso saṅkhāra vimuttam hoti iti dasseti tam tāva na sameti
translated: show that this pair of consciousnesses is absolutely free from formations. That does not agree even with the commentary.

original: Paṭiccasamuppādavibhaṅgaaṭṭhakathāyañhi saṅkhārabhedena avijjāya duvidhabhāvova vutto.
analyzed: paṭicca samuppāda vibhaṅga aṭṭhakathā yat hi saṅkhāra bhedena avijjāya duvidha bhāvaḥ u vuttaḥ
translated: For in the commentary on the exposition of dependent origination it is only the twofold state of ignorance as classified according to formations that is mentioned.

original: Yadica idaṃdvayaṃ saṅkhāramuttaṃ siyā. Evaṃ sati idha mohopi saṅkhāramutto siyā.
analyzed: yadi ca idaṃdvayam saṅkhāra muttam siyā evam sati mohaḥ api saṅkhāra muttaḥ siyā
translated: And if this twofold state were outside the formations, then delusion too would be outside the formations here.

original: Soca avijjāyevāti tividhabhāvova avijjāya tattha vattabbo. Naca vuttoti. Evaṃ tāva
analyzed: saḥ ca avijjāya iva ati tividha bhāvaḥ u avijjāya tattha vattabbaḥ na ca vuttaḥ ti evam tāva
translated: And that is ignorance itself. So the threefold state of ignorance should be mentioned there, but it is not. So in the first place

original: aṭṭhakathāya nasameti.🔽[33] Yasmāca idha tikkhabhāvonāma vinā saṅkhārena kevalaṃ pakati paccaya gaṇa vaseneva🔽pavattanasamatthatā vuccati. Idañca cittaṃ tatheva pavattati. Tasmā idaṃ sabhāvatikkhaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāya na same ti  yasmā ca idha vinā saṅkhārena kevalam pakati paccaya gaṇa vasena iva  pavattana samattha tā vuccati idam ca cittam tathā iva pavattati tasmai idam sabhāva tikkham
translated: it does not agree with the commentary.

original: na hotīti na sakkā vattunti.
analyzed: na hoti iti na sakkā vattunti
translated: And since here the state of being keen is said to be the mere ability to occur by itself through the class-condition of the state of being a natural condition, and since this consciousness occurs in that way, it cannot be said that it is not keen by nature.

original: Laddhokāsena mohena suṭṭhu muyhantīti mohamūhānīti vattabbe niruttanayena momūhānīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: laddha okāsena mohena suṭṭhu muyhanti iti moha mūhāni iti vattabbe nirutta nayena momūhāni iti vuttam
translated: And although it should be said that they are deluded by delusion that has obtained an opportunity, they are said to be “deluded by delusion” in the way of expression of the text.

original: 29. Iccevantiādi mahānigamanaṃ. Tattha iccevanti iti evaṃ. Nipātasamudāyo hesa. Pacchimovā
analyzed: iti ceva iva anti ādi mahā nigamanam tattha iti evam nipāta samudāyaḥ ha isa pacchimaḥ vā
translated: So in this way, etc., is the great explanation. Herein, so in this way is a phrase-collection. The latter

original: evaṃ saddo purimassa itisaddassa atthavacano. Iccevantivā visuṃ eko nipāto. Sabbathāpi
analyzed: evam saddo purimassa iti saddassa attha vacanaḥ visum ekaḥ nipātaḥ sabbathā api
translated: In all ways,

original: iminā somanassasahagatantiādinā vuttappakāre nāti attho daṭṭhabbo. Idañca dvādasāti
analyzed: iminā somanassa sahagata nti ādinā vutta ppakāre na ati attho daṭṭhabbo idam ca dvādasa ati
translated: the meaning should be regarded as the kind stated thus “with joy” and so on. And this is the twelve

original: ettha visesanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Sabbathāpīti dhammasaṅgaṇīyaṃ vuttena pakārenāpi dvādaseva.
analyzed: ettha visesanam veditabbam sabbathā api iti dhammasaṅgaṇīyam vuttena pakārena api dvādasā iva
translated: in the case of the words “in twelve ways.” And this should be understood as the distinction. In all ways: in the twelve ways stated in the Dhamma- saṅgaṇī.

original: Vibhaṅge vibhattena pakārenāpi dvādaseva. Dhātukathādīsu vuttena pakārenāpi dvādaseva.
