translated: But they are not like the profitable of the higher realms and the supramundane, which are “with a definite root cause.”🔽And according to the method of the commentary, they would have to be admitted as “accompanied by applied thought” too.

original: pavattena upanissayañāṇena sambhūtattā kusalāni eva nāma honti. Evamidhapi tāni teneva
analyzed: pavattena upanissaya ñāṇena sambhūta ttā kusalāni eva nāma honti evam idha api tāni tena iva
translated: Or, just as they are called “profitable” in the sense of being “produced with skill” , so too they are called “profitable” here because they are produced with the skill of the associated knowledge that occurs in the various kinds of adverting in the course of a cognitive series.

original: vīmaṃsādhipatibhūtena sambhūtattā vīmaṃsādhipateyyānipi nāma hontīti na nasakkā vattunti
analyzed: vīmaṃsā adhipati bhūtena vīmaṃsā ādhipateyyāni pi nāma honti iti na na sakkā vattunti
translated: So they cannot be called.

original: iminā adhippāyena tāni visuṃ akatāni siyunti. Evaṃsantepi kāmakusalānināma adhipativimuttāni
analyzed: iminā adhippāyena tāni visum a katāni siyunti adhipati vimuttāni
translated: But even though they are so, there are still more profitable kinds of consciousness in the sense sphere that are not included in the predominance of the profitable with respect to the profitable.

original: eva bahutarāni honti. Tasmā nasakkā sabbāni kāmakusalāni vīmaṃsādhipatimūlikāni bhavitunti.
analyzed: eva bahutarāni honti tasmā na sakkā sabbāni kāma kusalāni vīmaṃsā adhipati mūlikāni bhavitun ti
translated: So it cannot be said that all kinds of profitable consciousness in the sense sphere have investigation as their predominance.🔽They are profitable kinds of consciousness in the sense sphere.

original: 43. Kāmāvacarānica tāni kusalāni cittānicāti viggaho. Tattha kenaṭṭhena kusalānīti.
analyzed: kāmāvacarāni ca tāni kusalāni cittāni ca ati viggahaḥ tattha kena ṭṭhena kusalāni iti
translated: Herein, why are they called profitable?

original: Ārogyaṭṭhena, sundaraṭṭhena, chekaṭṭhena, anavajjaṭṭena, sukhavipākaṭṭhenacāti. Rāgādayohi🔽dhammā cittasantānassa rujjanaṭṭhena rogānāma. Ahitaṭṭhena asundarā nāma. Anipuṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: ārogya ṭṭhena sundara ṭṭhena cheka ṭṭhena anavajja ṭṭena sukha vipāka ṭṭhena ca ati rāga ādayaḥ hi  dhammā citta santānassa rujjana ṭṭhena rogā nāma ahita ṭṭhena asundarāḥ nāma anipuṇa ṭṭhena
translated: In the sense of being healthy, in the sense of being beautiful, in the sense of being skilled, in the sense of being blameless, in the sense of having a happy outcome.🔽For defilements such as greed are called diseases because they afflict the continuity of consciousness. They are called ugly because they are harmful.🔽They are called unskilled because they are not subtle.

original: achekānāma. Gārayhaṭṭhena vajjānāma. Aniṭṭha vipākaṭṭhena dukkhavipākānāma honti.
analyzed: achekānāma gārayha ṭṭhena vajjānāma dukkha vipākānāma honti
translated: They are called blameworthy because they are reprehensible. They are called having an unhappy outcome because they have an unhappy result.

original: Imānipana tehi vuṭṭhitattā kusalānināma arogāni nāmāti attho. Tappaṭipakkhattāca
analyzed: imāni pana tehi vuṭṭhita ttā kusalāni nāma arogāni nāma ati attho tad paṭipakkha ttā ca
translated: But these are called profitable because they are free from those , and the meaning is that they are called healthy.🔽And because they are the opposites of the unprofitable.

original: sundarāni chekāni anavajjāni sukhavipākāni ca nāma hontīti. Kucchite pāpadhamme salayanti🔽cālenti kampenti viddhaṃsentīti kusalāni. Kucchitenavā ākārena sattasantāne senti
analyzed: sundarāni chekāni anavajjāni sukha vipākāni ca nāma honti iti kucchite pāpa dhamme  cālenti kampenti viddhaṃsenti iti kusalāni ākārena satta santāne senti
translated: They are “wholesome” because they “remove” , “shift,” “shake,” and “destroy” bad dhammas in the sense of “faults.”🔽Or they are “wholesome” because they “penetrate” , “follow” , and “pervade” the continuity of the being’s existence.🔽Or they are “wholesome” because they “cut off” , “sever” , and “destroy” greed, etc.

original: anusentīti kusā. Rāgādayo. Te lunanti chindantīti kusalāni. Kusaṃvā vuccati ñāṇaṃ
analyzed: anusenti iti kusāḥ rāga ādayaḥ te lunanti chindanti iti kusalāni vuccati ñāṇam
translated: The word “kusala” is also said to be derived from the root “kus” in the sense of “knowledge”🔽because it “destroys” , “weakens” , and “terminates” faults.

original: kucchitānaṃ sānaṭṭhena tanukaraṇaṭṭhena antakaraṇaṭṭhenavā. Kusena lātabbānīti kusalāni.🔽Kusāviya hatthappadesaṃ saṃkilesapakkhaṃ lunantītivā kusalāni. Apica, kucchite pāpadhamme
analyzed: kucchitānam sāna ṭhena tanu karaṇa ṭṭhena anta karaṇa ṭhena vā kusena lātabbāni iti kusalāni  hattha ppadesam saṃkilesa pakkham lunanti iti vā kusalāni apica kucchite pāpa dhamme
translated: Or they are “wholesome” because they should be “chosen” by means of the “kusala” .🔽Or they are “wholesome” because they “cut off” the defilements of the hand-span region, which is called “kusala” .🔽Or they are “wholesome” because they “go” and “afflict” bad dhammas in the sense of “faults.” The letter “ra” is replaced by “la.”

original: saranti hiṃsantīti kusalāni. Rakārassa lakāro. Kosallasambhūtaṭṭhenavā kusalānīti.
analyzed: saranti hiṃsanti iti kusalāni rakārassa lakāro kosalla sambhūta ṭṭhenavā kusalāni iti
translated: Or they are “wholesome” because they are “produced by skill” .🔽There is nothing to be said about the meaning of the words in the case of the “great fruitions.”

original: 44. Mahāvipākesu padatthato vattabbaṃ natthi. Vedanābhedo ārammaṇavasena vattabbo.
analyzed: mahā vipākesu padatthataḥ vattabbam na atthi vedanā bhedaḥ ārammaṇa vasena vattabbo
translated: The distinction of feeling should be stated according to the object.

original: Tānihi atiiṭṭhe iṭṭhamajjhatte ca ārammaṇe yathākkamaṃ somanassena upekkhāya ca yuttānīti.
analyzed: tāni hi ati iṭṭhe iṭṭha majjhatte ca ārammaṇe yathākkamam somanassena upekkhāya ca yuttāni iti
translated: For they are associated respectively with joy and equanimity in regard to desirable and desirable-neutral objects.

original: Sampayogabhedo kammavasena javanavasenaca vattabbo. Tānihi balavakammena janitāni

original: sampayuttaṃkusalacittaṃ pathamajjhānakusalacittaṃ. Tattha kenaṭṭhenapathamaṃ, kenaṭṭhenaca

original: jhānanti. Ādito paṭipajjitabbattā pathamaṃ. Kasiṇādikassa ārammaṇassa aniccādilakkhaṇassaca🔽upanijjhāyanato paccanīkadhammānañca jhāpanato dayhanato jhānaṃ. Imesu dvīsu atthesu

translated: It is the first because it is entered upon first of all. original: ekaggatāeva sāti sayayuttāti daṭṭhabbā. Sāhi ekattārammaṇasaṅkhāto eko aggokoṭikoṭṭhāsovā
analyzed: ekagga tā eva sā ati saya yuttā ti daṭṭhabbā sā hi ekatta ārammaṇa saṅkhāto ekaḥ aggo koṭi koṭṭhāsaḥ vā
translated: It is the “first” in the sense of being foremost, since it is the foremost of all states classed as mundane and supramundane.

original: assāti atthena ekaggasaṅkhātassa cittassa tathāpavattane ādhipaccaguṇayogena ekaggatāti

original: daḷhaṃ ārammaṇānubandhameva karoti. Ārammaṇānumajjanalakkhaṇo hi vicāro paññāpakatiko.🔽Vicikicchānīvaraṇassaca ujuppaṭipakkhoti. Pītica cittaṃ byāpādavasena ukkaṇṭhituṃ
analyzed: daḷham ārammaṇa anubandham eva karoti ārammaṇa anumajjana lakkhaṇaḥ hi vicāraḥ paññāpakatikaḥ  vicikicchā nīvaraṇassa ca uju paṭipakkho ti pīti ca cittam byāpāda vasena ukkaṇṭhitum
translated: He makes it keep hold of the object tenaciously. For applied thought has the characteristic of keeping the object submerged; it is the nature of understanding to do this.🔽And it is the opposite of the doubt hindrance.

original: adatvā ārammaṇe parituṭṭhameva karoti. Ārammaṇasaṃpi yāyanalakkhaṇā hi pīti. Byāpādanīvaraṇassaca🔽ujuppaṭipakkhāti. Tathā sukhañca naṃ uddhacca kukkuccavasena avūpasamituṃ adatvā

translated: And it makes the consciousness satisfied with the object without allowing it to be dissatisfied with it through ill will. For happiness has the characteristic of making the object acceptable; it is the nature of ill will to make it unacceptable.🔽And it is the opposite of the ill will hindrance.🔽And it makes the object more and more satisfying by not allowing it to be dissatisfied through agitation and worry. For bliss has the characteristic of satisfying; it is the nature of agitation and worry to make it dissatisfying.

original: ārammaṇe laddhasātaṃ upabrūhitaṃ karoti. Sākalakkhaṇañhi sukhaṃ, uddhaccakukkuccanīvaraṇassaca ujuppaṭipakkhanti.🔽Upekkhāca santasabhāvattā sukheeva saṅgahitāti. Evaṃ karontāca te dhammā tasmiṃ ārammaṇe

translated: And it is the opposite of the agitation and worry hindrance.🔽And equanimity is included as happiness because it is the state of peace.🔽And while doing this, these states are also the cause of the complete confidence of that consciousness in that object.

original: tassa cittassa suṭṭhu ekaggabhāvatthāyaca honti. Ekaggabhāvotica ekaggatāyeva. Sāca
analyzed: tassa cittassa suṭṭhu ekagga bhāva tthāya ca honti ekagga bhāva uti ca ekagga tāya iva sā ca

original: ekaggatā tehi dhammehi tathā anuggahitā suṭṭhu balavatī hutvā sayaṃ kāmacchandavasena
analyzed: ekagga tā tehi dhammehi tathā anuggahitā suṭṭhu balavatī hutvā sayam kāmacchanda vasena
translated: and unification of mind, being thus assisted by those states, becomes well steadied and strong itself.🔽

original: nānārammaṇesu cittavidhāvanaṃ nīvāretvā kasiṇanimittādike tasmiṃ ārammaṇe niccalaṃ
analyzed: nānā ārammaṇesu citta vidhāvanam nīvāretvā kasiṇa nimitta ādike tasmin ārammaṇe niccalam
translated: The unification of mind is assisted by those states in such a way that it becomes well-developed and strong. It prevents the mind’s running hither and thither by means of lust for sense desires, etc., and it keeps the mind anchored on the object of meditation, such as the sign of the kasiṇa, and so on, without wavering.

original: ṭhatvā taṃārammaṇaṃ upagantvā nijjhāyati oloketi. Tasmā te sabbepi dhammā upanijjhāyanaṭṭhenapi🔽jhānanti vuttāti. Tesuca tathā pavattamānesu tappaccanīkā nīvaraṇadhammā okāsaṃ alabhitvā
analyzed: ṭhatvā taṃ ārammaṇam upagantvā nijjhāyati oloketi tasmā te sabbe pi dhammā upanijjhāyana ṭṭhena api  jhānanti vuttā ti tesu ca tathā pavattamānesu tad paccanīkāḥ nīvaraṇa dhammāḥ okāsam a labhitvā
translated: Thus it is said that all these states are jhāna in the sense of “keeping in view” .🔽And while they are occurring in this way, the states of the hindrances, which are their opposites, are unable to intrude upon the mind even for a moment. They are as if annihilated. Thus it is said that they are jhāna in the sense of “annihilating opposites” .

original: manasmiṃpi pariyuṭṭhituṃ nasakkonti. Jhāpitānāma honti. Tasmā te paccanīkajjhāpanaṭṭhenapi🔽jhānanti vuttāti. Evaṃ santepi yasmā jhāna magga sambodhisaṅkhātesu tīsu ṭhānesu
analyzed: manasmiṃpi pariyuṭṭhitum na sakkonti jhāpitā nāma honti tasmā te paccanīka jhāpana ṭṭhena pi  jhānanti vuttā ati evam sante pi yasmā jhāna magga sambodhi saṅkhātesu tīsu ṭhānesu
translated: But even though this is so, the states of the jhāna factors are still more prominent in the sense of predominance by reason of their special qualities of quickness, keenness, and so on.🔽And the states of the hindrances are less prominent in the sense of weakness by reason of their special qualities of slowness, dullness, and so on.🔽So it is said that they are jhāna in the sense of “predominance” and “weakness” .

original: dhammasāmaggī padhānaṃ hoti. Aṅgānaṃ samaggabhāveeva appanāpattivasena upanijjhāya
analyzed: dhamma sāmaggī padhānam hoti aṅgānam samagga bhāve eva appanā āpatti vasena upanijjhāya
translated: But in the three instances of jhāna, path, and enlightenment, the states are in harmony with each other, and the predominance belongs to the states of the jhāna factors, which are successful in their function of keeping the states of the hindrances in abeyance.🔽For it is by the success of the function of keeping in view that the jhāna factors are successful in their function of keeping the states of the hindrances in abeyance.

original: nādi kiccasaṃsiddhito. Yasmāca ete dhammā vuttanayena visuṃvisuṃ attano kiccaṃ karontāpi
analyzed: na ādi kicca saṃsiddhitaḥ yasmā ca ete dhammā vutta nayena visum visum attano kiccam karontā api
translated: And although these states perform their several functions in the way already described, still the predominance belongs to the states of the jhāna factors, which are successful in their function of keeping the states of the hindrances in abeyance.

original: cittassa ārammaṇe niccalappavatti saṅkhātaṃ ekameva upanijjhānakiccaṃ sādhenti. Tasmā
analyzed: cittassa ārammaṇe niccala ppavatti saṅkhātam ekam eva upanijjhāna kiccam sādhenti tasmā
translated: They perform the single function of “absorption” in the sense of non-distraction of consciousness from the object.

original: rathaṅgānaṃ samudāyeeva rathavohāroviya tesaṃ samudāyeeva jhāna vohāro siddhoti veditabbo.
analyzed: rathaṅgānam samudāye eva tesam samudāye eva jhāna vohāro siddho ti veditabbo
translated: Therefore it should be understood that the expression “jhāna” is established as a collective for them, just as the expression “chariot” is a collective for the parts of a chariot.

original: Aparepana pañcannaṃpi tesaṃ ārammaṇābhiniropanādīni yathāsakaṃ kiccāniyeva visuṃ🔽visuṃ upanijjhānakiccānināma hontīti paṭṭhāne jhānapaccayaṃ patvā sabbepete visuṃ
analyzed: tesam ārammaṇa abhiniropana ādīni yathāsakam  visum honti iti paṭṭhāne jhāna paccayam patvā sabbe pete visum
translated: But others say that the functions of the five beginning with the arousing of the object are respectively the functions of absorption, etc.,

original: visuṃ jhānapaccayaṃ sādhentiyeva. Tasmā te visuṃ visuṃpi jhānāniyeva hontīti sakkā🔽vattuṃ. Yathāca pañcaṅgikaṃ sīlaṃ dasaṅgikaṃ sīlanti ettha pañcasamuditādīni tesaṃ🔽sīlānaṃ pañcaṅgikā dināmalābhasseva kāraṇāni honti. Na sīlabhāvassa. Na hi pāṇātipātā
analyzed: visum jhāna paccayam sādhentiyā iva tasmā te visum visum pi honti iti sakkā  vattum yathā ca pañcaṅgikam sīlam dasaṅgikam sīlanti ettha pañca samudita ādīni  sīlānam pañcaṅgikā ādi nāma lābhassa iva kāraṇāni honti na sīla bhāvassa na hi pāṇa atipātā
translated: and that therefore all of them together perform the function of absorption when they reach absorption as their fruit. Thus they can all be called “absorption.”🔽And just as the five training precepts are called the ten training precepts when the precept “one undertakes the training to refrain from dancing, singing, instrumental music, watching shows, wearing garlands, embellishing with scent, beautifying with unguents” is added to the five beginning with “one undertakes the training to refrain from killing living beings,” here too the five beginning with the arousing of the object are called “absorption” when the function of absorption is reached as their fruit.

original: veramaṇādikaṃ ekaṃpi samānaṃ sīlaṃnāma na hotīti. Evamevaṃ idhapi pañcasamuditādīni
analyzed: veramaṇa ādikam samānam pañca samudita ādīni
translated: And just as the five beginning with refraining from killing living beings are the cause of the obtaining of the five precepts, and the five are the cause of the obtaining of the ten, but the five are not the cause of the ten, and the ten are not the cause of the five, because there is no common character between them, so too here the five beginning with the arousing of the object are the cause of the obtaining of the five beginning with absorption, and the five are the cause of the obtaining of the ten, but the five are not the cause of the obtaining of the ten, and the ten are not the cause of the obtaining of the five, because there is no common character between them.

original: pañcaṅgikādi bhāvasseva pathamajjhānādi bhāvassevaca kāraṇāni. Napana jhānabhāvassāti
analyzed: pañcaṅgika ādi bhāvassa iva pathamajjhāna ādi bhāvassa iva ca kāraṇāni na pana jhāna bhāvassa ati
translated: and the five factors, etc., are the conditions for the first jhāna, etc., but not for the jhāna state.

original: nasakkā viññātuṃ. Itarathā jhānapaccaye jhānaṅgāni paccaniyāniyeva siyuntipi vadanti.
analyzed: na sakkā viññātum itarathā jhāna paccaye jhāna aṅgāni siyun tipi vadanti
translated: So it cannot be known. And in the other case the jhāna factors would be conditions only for the jhāna factor conditions, they say.

original: Ettāvatā satipi imassa cittassa phassādīhipi sahitabhāve tesaṃ tathāvidhakiccavisesābhāvā🔽idha aggahaṇantipi siddhaṃ nahotīti. Vicārapītisukhekaggatā saṅkhātena dutīyajjhānena
analyzed: ettāvatā sati pi imassa cittassa sahita bhāve tesam tathāvidha kicca visesa abhāvā  siddham siddham
translated: So far, then, although this consciousness is associated with contact, etc., as well, still, because of the absence of any such distinction in their functions,🔽it is established that they are not included here. The profitable consciousness associated with the second jhāna is that associated with applied thought, sustained thought, happiness, bliss, and concentration.

original: sampayuttaṃ kusalacittaṃ dutīyajjhāna kusalacittaṃ, evaṃ sesesupi.
analyzed: sampayuttam kusala cittam dutīya jhāna kusala cittam evam sesesu pi
translated: So too with the rest.

original: 49. Ettha siyā. Kenapana imesaṃ jhānānaṃ aṅgabhedo katoti. Puggalajjhāsayena katoti.🔽Yohi vitakkasahāyo hutvā pañcaṅgikaṃ pathamajjhānaṃ uppādetvā tattha vasībhāvaṃ katvā
analyzed: ettha siyā kena pana imesam jhānānam aṅga bhedo katoti puggala jhā sayena katoti  yaḥ hi vitakka sahāyaḥ hutvā pañcaṅgikam pathamajjhānam uppādetvā tattha vasībhāvam katvā
translated: Here it may be asked: But why is the division of the jhānas into five made in this way? It is made according to the inclinations of men.

original: punavitakke nibbindati. Tassa vitakkaṃ samatikkamitvā avitakkaṃ caturaṅgikaṃ jhānaṃ
analyzed: punavitakke nibbindati tassa vitakkam samatikkamitvā a vitakkam caturaṅgikam jhānam
translated: For one who, as a beginner, arouses the five-factored first jhāna with applied thought, sustained thought, happiness, bliss, and concentration, and who, having acquired mastery in it, becomes dissatisfied with it because of the co- presence of applied thought, etc., of him it is said that he “overcomes applied thought” and so on.

original: adhigantuṃ ajjhāsayo saṇṭhāti. Tadā so tameva pathamajjhānaṃ pādakabhāvatthāya daḷhaṃ🔽samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya tena ajjhāsayena saheva punabhāvanaṃ anuyuñjanto avitakkaṃ🔽caturaṅgikaṃ jhānaṃ adhigacchati. Tattha sā bhāvanāsayaṃ vitakkayuttāpi tena ajjhāsayena🔽paribhāvitattā vitakkavirāga bhāvanānāma hoti. Tassā bhāvanāya. Balena taṃ jhānaṃ🔽uppajja mānaṃ avitakkaṃ caturaṅgikaṃ uppajjati. Sesajjhānādhigamesupi esevanayoti.
analyzed: adhigantum tadā saḥ tam eva pathama jhānam pādaka bhāva tthāya daḷham  samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya tena ajjhāsayena saha iva punabhāvanam anuyuñjantaḥ a vitakkam  caturaṅgikam jhānam adhigacchati tattha sā bhāvanā sayam vitakka yuttā api tena ajjhāsayena  paribhāvita ttā vitakka virāga bhāvanā nāma hoti tassā bhāvanāya balena tam jhānam  uppajja mānam a vitakkam caturaṅgikam uppajjati sesa jjhāna adhigamesu pi
translated: and the intention to attain it is established. Then, after he has made that same first jhāna his support and has emerged from it, he again and again inclines his mind to that same intention, and he eventually reaches the second jhāna, which is without applied thought but still has sustained thought, and is accompanied by happiness and bliss, by making that same intention the proximate cause. Herein, although that intention is associated with applied thought, still it is called “the development of the second jhāna” because it is developed by the development of that intention, which is purified by the surmounting of the jhāna’s imperfections. And by the force of that development that jhāna arises in him without applied thought, and so on. The same method of explanation applies in the other cases of the attainment of the remaining jhānas.

original: Evaṃ puggalajjhāsayena tesaṃ jhānānaṃ aṅgabhedo katoti veditabbo. Etthaca uttaruttarajjhānā🔽dhigamane pādakabhāvatthāya purimapurimajjhānassa samāpajjanaṃ avassaṃ icchitabbaṃ.🔽Heṭṭhimaṃ heṭṭhimaṃ paguṇajjhānaṃ uparimassa uparimassa padaṭṭhānaṃ hotīti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: evam tesam jhānānam aṅga bhedaḥ kataḥ iti veditabbaḥ ettha ca uttaruttara jhānā 🔽dhi gamane pādaka bhāva tthāya purima purimajjhānassa samāpajjanam a vassam icchitabbam 🔽heṭṭhimam heṭṭhimam paguṇa jhānam uparimassa uparimassa padaṭṭhānam hoti iti aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: and the intention to attain it is established. Then, after he has made that same first jhāna very strong by repeatedly entering it and emerging from it, he inclines that same intention to the second jhāna, which is superior to the first jhāna. Then, as he inclines his mind to that, the hindrances are suppressed, and so on up to … there arises in him the consciousness belonging to the second jhāna. Herein, although that intention is associated with applied thought, still it is called “development of the second jhāna” because it is developed by the development of the second jhāna. And the second jhāna itself is called “development of the second jhāna” because it is the outcome of development. And the name “development of the second jhāna” is a conventional expression based on the second jhāna, which is what is denoted by the term . Translation: adhigamādhippāyo saṇṭhāti | atha naṃ tena adhippāyena saha bhāvanānuyogamanuyuttassa avitakkaṃ caturaṅgikaṃ jhānaṃ adhigataṃ hoti | tattha sā bhāvanādhippāyo vitakkasampayuttopi tena adhippāyena paribhāvitattā vitakkavirāgabhāvanānāmaṃ labhati | tassā bhāvanāya balena taṃ jhānaṃ uppajjamānaṃ avitakkaṃ caturaṅgikaṃ uppajjati | sesajjhānādhigamesupi eseva nayo | evaṃ puggalādhippāyavasena tesaṃ jhānānaṃ aṅgabhedo veditabbo | tattha ca uttaruttarajjhānādhigamanāya purimapurimajjhānānaṃ samāpajjanaṃ avassaṃ icchitabbaṃ | heṭṭhimaṃ heṭṭhimaṃ jhānaṃ uparimassa uparimassa padaṭṭhānaṃ hotīti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ

original: vuttaṃ. Ajjhāsayabalenapana uttarajjhānaṃ uppajjamānaṃ pādakajjhānasadisaṃ nahoti.
analyzed: vuttam ajjhā saya balena pana uttara jhānam uppajjamānam pādaka jjhāna sadisam nahoti
translated: And when the higher jhāna arises by the force of the habit of the kind already formed, it does not do so in the way in which the basic jhāna does.

original: Pādakajjhānatohi puggalajjhāsayova balavataro. Tenāha bhagavā ijjhati bhikkhave sīlavato
analyzed: pādaka jjhānataḥ hi puggala jjhāsayā uva balavataraḥ tena āha bhagavā ijjhati bhikkhave sīlavataḥ
translated: For the individual’s habit of the kind is stronger than the basic jhāna. That is why the Blessed One said: “Bhikkhus, it is possible that a faithful person, a clansman with serene confidence in the Buddha’s dispensation, might make an aspiration and, through the purity of his intention, be reborn in the Brahmā-world” .

original: cetopaṇidhi visuddhattāti. Ayañca attho upari lokuttaracittaṃ patvā āvi bhavissatīti.
analyzed: ayam ca atthaḥ upari lokuttara cittam patvā āvi bhavissati iti
translated: And this meaning will be made clear later in the passage beginning, “But when he has reached the supramundane state” .🔽Here it might be asked: Why is the classification by kinds of formations not stated here?🔽Because it is not stated in the text.

original: 50. Ettha siyā. Kasmā idha saṅkhārabhedo navuttoti. Pāḷiyameva avuttattā. Kasmāca🔽so pāḷiyaṃ avuttoti. Paṭipadā bhedavacaneneva siddhattāti. Tathāhi sabbesaṃpi lokiya🔽lokuttarajjhānānaṃ sukhappaṭipadabhāve siddhe asaṅkhārikabhāvo siddhoyeva hoti. Dukkhappaṭipadabhāveca
analyzed: ettha siyā kasmai idha saṅkhāra bhedaḥ pāḷiyam eva a vutta ttā kasmā ca  so pāḷiyam a vuttaḥ ti paṭipadā bheda vacanena iva siddha ttā ati tathā hi sabbesam pi lokiya  lokuttara jhānānam sukha ppaṭipada bhāve siddhe asaṅkhārika bhāvaḥ siddhaḥ yeva hoti dukkha ppaṭipada bhāve ca
translated: And why is it not stated in the text?🔽Because it is included in the statement of the classification by kinds of progress.🔽For when it is established that all mundane jhānas are of easy progress, then it is established that they are accompanied by equanimity as a kind of formation.🔽And when it is established that all supramundane jhānas are of difficult progress, then it is established that they are accompanied by painful feeling as a kind of formation.

original: siddhe tesaṃ sasaṅkhārikabhāvo siddhoyeva hotīti. Kathaṃ viññāyatīti ce. Aṭṭhakathādassanato.
analyzed: siddhe tesam sasaṅkhārika bhāvaḥ siddhaḥ yeva hoti iti katham viññāyati iti ce aṭṭhakathā dassanato
translated: How is that known? From the explanation in the commentaries.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ -
analyzed: vuttam ha etam aṭṭhasāliniyam
translated: For this is said in the Paṭisambhidā:

original: Yo ādito kilese vikkhambhento dukkhena sasaṅkhārena sappayogena kilamanto vikkhambheti.
analyzed: yaḥ āditas kilese vikkhambhentaḥ dukkhena sa saṅkhārena sa payogena kilamantaḥ vikkhambheti
translated: He who suppresses defilements by painful practice with applied thought and sustained thought is called one who proceeds with difficulty.

original: Tassa dukkhā paṭipadā hoti. Yo kilese vikkhambhento sukhena akilamanto vikkhambheti.
analyzed: tassa dukkhā paṭipadā hoti yaḥ kilese vikkhambhentaḥ sukhena a kilamantaḥ vikkhambheti
translated: He who suppresses defilements by pleasant practice without being wearied is called one who proceeds pleasantly.

original: Tassa sukhāpaṭipadā hotīti.🔽Tathā sammohavinodanī visuddhimaggesupīti. Etthaca pubbavākye dukkhena sasaṅkhārena
analyzed: tassa sukhā paṭipadā hoti iti  tathā sammoha vinodanī visuddhi maggesu pi iti ettha ca pubba vākye dukkhena sa saṅkhārena
translated: So his practice is pleasant.

original: sappayogenāti diṭṭhattā paravākyepi sukhe na asaṅkhārena appayogenāti diṭṭhameva
analyzed: sa payogena ati diṭṭha ttā para vākye pi sukhe na asaṅkhārena appayogena ati diṭṭham eva
translated: And in the same way in the Path of Purification, in the explanation of the removal of confusion, it is said: “Herein, because of the words ‘with difficulty, with applied thought and sustained thought’ in the first passage, it is evident that in the second passage also it is without applied thought and sustained thought that he proceeds pleasantly.

original: hoti. Tattha sasaṅkhārena sappayogenāti saṅkhārappayogasahitena kāmādīnavadassanādinā
analyzed: hoti tattha sa saṅkhārena sa payogena ati saṅkhāra ppayoga sahitena kāma ādīnava dassana ādinā
translated: Herein, ‘with applied thought and sustained thought’ means with the requisite of wisdom consisting in investigation of qualities, etc., which are the conditions for the arising of the jhāna.

original: paccayagaṇenāti attho. Etena sabbesaṃ dukkhappaṭipadajjhānānaṃ sasaṅkhārikabhāvo
analyzed: paccaya gaṇena āti atthaḥ etena sabbesam dukkha ppaṭipad ajjhānānam sasaṅkhārika bhāvo
translated: This shows that all the jhānas of difficult progress are accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought.

original: vutto hoti. Asaṅkhārena appayogenāti saṅkhārappayogarahitena teneva paccayagaṇena.
analyzed: vuttaḥ hoti asaṅkhārena appayogena ati saṅkhāra ppayoga rahitena tena iva paccaya gaṇena
translated: ‘Without applied thought and sustained thought’ means without that requisite of wisdom consisting in investigation of qualities, etc., which are the conditions for the arising of the jhāna.

original: Etena sabbesaṃ sukhappaṭipadajjhānānaṃ asaṅkhārikabhāvo vutto hotīti. Khippābhiññajjhānānaṃpihi
analyzed: etena sabbesam sukha ppaṭipada jhānānam asaṅkhārika bhāvaḥ vuttaḥ hoti iti
translated: This is said to show that all the jhānas of the happy-dwelling type are not accompanied by insistence.

original: dukkhappaṭipadabhāve sati sasaṅkhārikatāva viññāyati. Dandhabhiññajjhānānaṃpi sukhappaṭipadabhāve🔽sati asaṅkhārikatāva viññāyatīti. Yadievaṃ paṭipadārahitānaṃ magga siddhaupapattisiddhajjhānānaṃ
analyzed: dukkha ppaṭipad bhāve sati sasaṅkhārika tā va viññāyati dandha bhiñña jhānānam pi sukha ppaṭipad bhāve  sati asaṅkhārika tā ava viññāyati iti yadi evam paṭipada arahitānam magga siddha aupapatti siddha jhānānam
translated: And when the jhānas of quick direct-knowledge type are of the painful- to-the-happy-dwelling type, then they are accompanied by insistence.🔽And when they are of the happy-dwelling type, then they are not accompanied by insistence.

original: kathaṃ saṅkhārabhedo siddhoti. Tesaṃpi vaḷañjanakāle samāpattippaṭibandhakānaṃ paccayānaṃ
analyzed: katham saṅkhāra bhedaḥ siddho ti tesam pi vaḷañjana kāle samāpatti paṭibandhakānam paccayānam
translated: But how is it that insistence is distinguished in the case of those jhānas of the path and of those of success that are devoid of insistence?🔽For even in their case insistence is possible as painful or happy according to whether the conditions that obstruct the attainment are present or not present.

original: sannihitā sannihitavasena dukkhasukhappaṭipadabhāvasambhavo hotiyevāti. Tattha maggasiddhajjhānaṃnāma
analyzed: sannihitā sannihita vasena dukkha sukha ppaṭipada bhāva sambhavaḥ tattha
translated: Herein, jhāna of the path is that which is successful through the path.

original: suddhavipassanāyānikānaṃ maggappaṭilābhena saheva siddhajjhānaṃ. Taṃ duvidhaṃ heṭṭhimamaggasiddhaṃ,
analyzed: suddha vipassanā yānikānam magga ppaṭilābhena saha iva siddhajjhānam tam duvidham heṭṭhima magga siddham
translated: This is twofold as jhāna successful through the lower path and as jhāna successful through the Arahant path.

original: arahattamaggasiddhanti. Tattha mahāsamayasutte āgatānaṃ pañcasatānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ jhānaṃ
analyzed: arahatta magga siddhanti tattha mahāsamaya sutte āgatānam pañca satānam bhikkhūnam jhānam
translated: Herein, the jhāna of the five hundred bhikkhus mentioned in the Great Merit-Treasure Sutta is jhāna successful through the lower path.

original: heṭṭhima maggasiddhaṃ. Ānandattherassa jhānaṃ arahattamaggasiddhaṃ. Yaṃpi anāgāmīnaṃ
analyzed: magga siddham ānanda ttherassa jhānam arahatta magga siddham anāgāmīnam
translated: and that of the Elder Ānanda is accomplished by the path of Arahantship.

original: ajānantānaññeva satthena hanitvā sahasā marantānaṃ uppannaṃ. Taṃpi maggasiddhagatikaṃ.
analyzed: a jānantānam aññeva satthena hanitvā sahasā marantānam uppannam magga siddha gatikam
translated: And that which arises in those who are not yet non-returners but who are suddenly killed by a weapon, etc., is also accomplished by the path.

original: Yopana aṭṭhasamāpattiyo bhāvetvā aññatarasmiṃ rūpi brahmaloke nibbatti. Tassa tā
analyzed: yopana aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ bhāvetvā aññatarasmin rūpi brahma loke nibbatti tassa tā
translated: And that of one who, after developing the eight attainments, is reborn in some particular fine-material Brahmā-world,🔽is natural to that existence.

original: samāpatti yo tattha pākatikāeva honti. Idaṃ upapattisiddhanti. Ekasmiṃ bhavepi hi
analyzed: tattha ekasmin bhave pi hi
translated: For even in one becoming,

original: laddhajjhānāni vaḷañjanakāle sannihitapaccayavasena nānāpaṭipadāyuttāni hontīti.
analyzed: laddha jhānāni vaḷañjana kāle sannihita paccaya vasena nānā paṭipadā yuttāni honti iti
translated: the jhānas that have been obtained are associated with the various planes by the presence of the conditions for them at the time of reviewing them.

original: Jhānuppattippaṭipadā rahitattāvā asaṅkhārikajjhānesu tesaṃ saṅgaho yutto siyāti.🔽Apica, nettipāḷiyaṃ sabbesaṃ lokiya lokuttarasamādhīnaṃ saṅkhārabhedo sarūpatova
analyzed: jhāna uppatti paṭipadāḥ rahita ttāvā asaṅkhārika jhānesu tesam saṅgahaḥ yutto siyāti  apica sabbesam lokiya lokuttara samādhīnam saṅkhāra bhedo
translated: And it is proper to include them in the jhāna arisen without prompting because they are devoid of prompting due to the absence of prompting in the jhāna itself.

original: niddiṭṭho. Yathāha-dve samādhayo sasaṅkhāro samādhi asaṅkhāro samādhīti. Aṭṭhakathāyañca
analyzed: niddiṭṭhaḥ yathā āha dve samādhayaḥ sa saṅkhāro samādhi asaṅkhāro samādhi iti aṭṭhakathāyañca
translated: Besides, in the Nettippakarana the classification of all mundane and supramundane concentration according to prompting is given in its true nature thus: “There are two kinds of concentration: with prompting and without prompting” . And in the commentary to the Kindred Sayings:

original: sukhappaṭipadā pubbakānaṃ dvinnaṃ dandhābhiññakhippābhiññasamādhīnaṃ asaṅkhārabhāvo
analyzed: sukha ppaṭipadā pubbakānam dvinnam dandhābhiñña khippābhiñña samādhīnam a saṅkhāra bhāvaḥ
translated: The pleasant way is the signless state of the first two kinds of jhāna, namely, the sluggish insight and the swift insight kinds.🔽The painful way is the state with initial and sustained thought of the first two kinds of jhāna.

original: dukkhappaṭipadā pubbakānaṃ dvinnaṃ sasaṅkhārabhāvoca vuttoti. Ettāvatā sabbesaṃ mahaggatalokuttarajjhānacittānaṃ🔽asaṅkhārika sasaṅkhārikavasena visuṃ visuṃ duvidhabhāvo siddho hoti. Yasmāpana ayaṃ
analyzed: dukkha ppaṭipadā pubbakānam dvinnam vuttaḥ ti ettāvatā sabbesam mahaggata lokuttara jjhāna cittānam  sasaṅkhārika vasena visum visum duvidha bhāvaḥ siddhaḥ ayam
translated: So far, all the kinds of exalted and supramundane jhāna consciousness🔽are established as twofold, namely, with and without initial and sustained thought.🔽But this expression “with and without initial and sustained thought” is common to the unprofitable too.

original: saṅkhāravohāro akusalānaṃpi sādhāraṇo. Paṭipadāvohāropana visesena paṭipattidhammesveva
analyzed: saṅkhāra vohāraḥ sādhāraṇaḥ visesena paṭipatti dhammesu eva
translated: And the expression “way” is obvious only in the case of states of consciousness that are ways,

original: pākaṭo. Mahaggata lokuttaradhammāca ekantaṃ paṭipattidhammāeva. Tasmā tesaṃ bhedaṃ
analyzed: ekantam paṭipatti dhammāḥ eva tasmā tesam bhedam
translated: and the exalted and supramundane states are exclusively states of way. So the classification🔽of these should be understood as given in the Dhammasangani in terms of ways,

original: saṅkhāravasena avatvā paṭipadāvaseneva dhammasaṅgaṇi pāḷiyaṃpi vuttoti daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: saṅkhāra vasena avatvā paṭipadā vasena iva dhammasaṅgaṇi pāḷiyam pi vutto ti daṭṭhabbo
translated: without any mention of initial and sustained thought, and not in the Suttas.

original: Ayamettha paramatthadīpanā.
analyzed: ayam ettha parama attha dīpanā
translated: This is the explanation of the meaning of the words here.

original: 51. [47] Yaṃpana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yaṃpana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said as follows:🔽“Apart from the preliminary work called ‘readying’ ,

original: “Sabbassapi jhānassa parikammasaṅkhātapubbābhisaṅkhārena vinā kevalaṃ adhikāravasena
analyzed: sabbassa api jhānassa parikamma saṅkhāta pubba abhisaṅkhārena vinā kevalam adhikāra vasena
translated: all jhāna is ‘with initial and sustained thought’ in the sense of being the outcome of the initial and sustained thought of the preliminary work” .

original: anuppajjanato asaṅkhārikantipi. Adhikārenaca vinā kevalaṃ parikammābhisaṅkāravaseneva
analyzed: an uppajjanataḥ asaṅkhārikam ti pi adhikārena ca vinā kevalam parikamma abhisaṅkāra vasena iva
translated: and because it does not arise, it is not formed.🔽And without a specific object, it is only by the mere occurrence of the preliminary-work-consciousness and the registration-consciousness that

original: anuppajjanato sasaṅkhārikantipi nasakkā vattu”nti vuttaṃ. Tattha parikammasaṅkhāta.La.🔽Asaṅkhārikantipi nasakkā vattunti idaṃ tāva nayujjati.
analyzed: anuppajjanato sa saṅkhārikan ti pi na sakkā vattunti vuttam tattha  na sakkā vattum ti idam tāva
translated: and because it does not occur without a prior act of forming, it is not to be called “with a prior act of forming.” And because it does not occur without a condition, it is not to be called “without a prior act of forming.”

original: Na hi parikammasaṅkhāta pubbābhisaṅkhāro imasmiṃ saṅkhārabhede saṅkhāro evanāma hoti.
analyzed: na hi pubba abhisaṅkhāraḥ imasmin saṅkhāra bhede saṅkhāraḥ eva nāma hoti
translated: “Herein, the prior act of forming called the preliminary work is not called ‘forming’ in this category of forming.

original: Kasmā, jhānuppattiyā pakatipaccaya bhūtattā, tathāhi loke sāsaneca sabbaṃpi kusalākusala🔽kammaṃ attano anurūpena parikammasaṅkhāta pubbābhisaṅkhārena vinā uppannaṃnāma natthi.🔽Antamaso ālopabhikkhādānamattaṃpīti. Yañca cittaṃ yena attano anurūpena parikammasaṅkhātapubbā
analyzed: kasmā jhāna uppattiyā pakati paccaya bhūta ttā tathā hi loke sāsane ca  kammam attanaḥ anurūpena parikamma saṅkhāta pubba abhisaṅkhārena vinā uppannam nāma natthi  antamasaḥ yat ca cittam yena attanaḥ anurūpena parikamma saṅkhāta pubbā
translated: Why? Because it is a natural condition for the arising of jhāna. For in the world and in the Dispensation all profitable and unprofitable kamma is called “arisen” when it has occurred with the prior act of forming called the preliminary work appropriate to itself.🔽For there is no kamma that arises without the prior act of forming called the preliminary work appropriate to itself, even in the least, that is to say, even in the giving of a mere morsel of food.

original: bhisaṅkhārena vinā na uppajjati. So tassa cittassa pakatipaccayagaṇeevaanto gadho
analyzed: bhi saṅkhārena vinā na uppajjati saḥ tassa cittassa pakati paccaya gaṇe eva antaḥ gadho
translated: And the mind that does not arise without the prior act of forming called the preliminary work appropriate to itself is reckoned as the natural condition for that mind.🔽It is deep and hard to see.

original: hoti. Jhānānica lokiya lokuttara bhūtāni sabbāni attano anurūpena parikammasaṅkhāta
analyzed: hoti jhānāni ca lokiya lokuttara bhūtāni sabbāni attanaḥ anurūpena parikamma saṅkhāta
translated: And all mundane and supramundane jhānas are called “preliminary-work jhāna” in accordance with their own kind.🔽There is none that arises without the preliminary work of resolution.

original: pubbabhāgabhāvanā bhisaṅkhārena vinā uppannānināma natthīti so tesaṃ pakatipaccayagaṇesueva
analyzed: pubbabhāga bhāvanā bhisaṅkhārena vinā natthi iti so tesam pakati paccaya gaṇesu eva
translated: Therefore it is included only in the class of natural conditions.

original: antogadho hotīti. Itarathā sabbaṃpi kusalākusala kammaṃ asaṅkhārikaṃ nāmanatthīti āpajjatīti.
analyzed: antogadhaḥ hoti iti itarathā sabbaṃ api kusala akusala kammam asaṅkhārikam nāma natthi iti āpajjati iti
translated: Otherwise it would follow that no profitable or unprofitable kamma at all is without preliminary work of resolution.

original: [48] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there, namely,

original: Adhikārenaca vinā kevalaṃ.La. Sasaṅkhārikantipi nasakkā vattunti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na yujjatiyeva.
analyzed: adhikārena ca vinā sa saṅkhārikan ti pi na sakkā vattunti vuttam tat pi na yujjati yā iva
translated: that “without preliminary work of resolution it is impossible to call them ‘with preliminary work of resolution,’” is not right either.

original: Na hi lokiyajjhānānināma adhikārena vinā nuppajjantīti atthi. Kevalaṃpana pubbe samathakammesu
analyzed: na hi lokiya jjhānāni nāma adhikārena vinā nu ppajjanti iti atthi kevalam pana pubbe samatha kammesu
translated: For it is not the case that mundane jhānas do not arise without preliminary work of resolution.🔽But only the pleasant-to-pursue jhāna arises for one who has already done the preliminary work in the former kammas of serenity.

original: katādhikārassa sukhappaṭipadajjhānaṃ uppajjati. Akatādhikārassapana dukkhappaṭipadajjhānanti
analyzed: kata adhikārassa sukha ppaṭipad ajjhānam uppajjati akata adhikārassa pana dukkha ppaṭipad ajjhānan ti
translated: And the painful-to-pursue jhāna arises for one who has not done the preliminary work.

original: evameva aṭṭhakathāsu āgataṃ. Vuttañhi tattha yoca samathe akatādhikāro. Tassa dukkhā
analyzed: evam eva aṭṭhakathāsu āgatam vuttam hi tattha yaḥ ca samathe a kata adhikāro tassa dukkhā
translated: That is how it is stated in the commentaries. For this is said there: “One who has not done the preliminary work has painful progress and difficult practice;

original: paṭipadā hoti. Katādhikārassasukhāti. Apica, purimabhave siddhaṃ adhikāraṃ gahetvā🔽idha saṅkhārabhedavicāraṇāpi nayuttāeva. Kusalakriyajjhānesu hi sanni hitapaccayavaseneva
analyzed: paṭipadā hoti kata adhikāraḥ apica purima bhave siddham adhikāram gahetvā  saṅkhāra bheda vicāraṇā api kusala kriyā jhānesu hi sanni hita paccaya vasena iva
translated: and the way is painful. But when the practice is begun, it is pleasant.🔽Moreover, it is proper to consider the kinds of formations after taking over the practice begun in a previous existence.🔽For it is proper to consider them in the way stated only after taking over the practice begun in a previous existence.

original: tabbicāraṇā yuttāti.
analyzed: tad vicāraṇā yuttā iti
translated: For in profitable kamma and jhāna the consideration of them is proper only as a condition for the accumulation of requisites.

original: [49] Ettāvatā
analyzed: ettāvatā
translated: This is how the exposition should be understood here as to the way.

original: Athavātiādiko pacchima vikappopi paṭikkhitto eva hotīti.🔽52. Ettha jhānaṃ anuyuñjantassa nimittuppādato pubbaṃ paṭipadāya khettaṃ, pacchā
analyzed: athavā ati ādiko pacchima vikappaḥ api paṭikkhittaḥ eva hoti iti  ettha jhānam anuyuñjantassa nimitta uppādataḥ pubbam paṭipadāya khettam pacchā
translated: Or alternatively, the latter alternative beginning with “or” is also rejected.🔽Herein, the way is the province of the practice for one who is devoted to jhāna prior to the arising of the meditation subject.🔽Afterwards it is the province of the direct-knowledge.

original: abhiññāya khettaṃ. Tattha pubbe viruddhapaccayānaṃ sannihitena kilamantassa sato
analyzed: abhiññāya khettam tattha pubbe viruddha paccayānam sannihitena kilamantassa sataḥ
translated: Herein, when one who is devoted to the practice is exhausted by the proximity of opposing conditions,

original: paṭipajjantassa bhāvanā paṭipadā dukkhānāma hoti. Akilamantassa sukhā. Pacchāca dandhaṃ
analyzed: paṭipajjantassa bhāvanā paṭipadā dukkhā nāma hoti a kilamantassa sukhā pacchāca dandham
translated: his development of the way is called painful progress. When he is not exhausted, it is pleasant progress.

original: appanaṃ pattassa bhāvanābhiññā dandhābhiññānāma hoti. Khippaṃ pattassa khippābhiññānāma.
analyzed: appanam pattassa bhāvanā abhiññā dandha abhiññā nāma hoti khippam pattassa khippa abhiññā nāma
translated: And afterwards his development of direct-knowledge is called slow in direct-knowledge or quick in direct-knowledge according to whether his attainment of absorption is slow or quick.

original: Tattha pubbe dukkhā paṭipadā pacchā dandhaṃvā khippaṃvā uppannaṃ jhānaṃ dukkhappaṭipadaṃnāma
analyzed: tattha pubbe dukkhā paṭipadā pacchā dandham vā khippam vā uppannam jhānam dukkhappaṭipadaṃ nāma
translated: Herein, the jhāna that arises first in one whose progress is painful and afterwards in one whose progress is pleasant is called painful progress and pleasant progress respectively.

original: karoti. Sukhāpana sukhappaṭipadaṃnāma karotīti. Dutīyajjhānādīsupana purimajjhāne
analyzed: karoti karoti iti purima jhāne
translated: he makes it pleasant, he makes it easy to traverse. In the second jhāna, etc., the way is easy because of the absence of the disturbance of applied thought and the absence of the disturbance of sustained thought, and so on.

original: nikanti vikkhambhanassa dukkhasukhatāvasena paṭipadābhedo veditabbo. Yopana etarahi🔽gahaṭṭhovā pabbajitovā pubbabhave akatādhikāropi antarāyikadhammamutto kalyāṇapaṭipattiyaṃ
analyzed: nikanti vikkhambhanassa dukkha sukha tā vasena paṭipadā bhedaḥ veditabbaḥ yopane etarahi  gahaṭṭhaḥ vā pabbajitaḥ vā pubba bhave a kata adhikāraḥ api antarāyika dhamma mutto kalyāṇa paṭipattiyam
translated: The difference in the way should be understood as the difference in the difficulty of practice due to the difference in the degree of painfulness.

original: ṭhito chinnapalibodho pahitatto jhānaṃ bhāveti. Tassa jhānabhāvanā nasampajjatīti
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ chinna palibodhaḥ pahita ttaḥ jhānam bhāveti tassa jhāna bhāvanā na sampajjati iti
translated: Now, the person who is either a householder or one gone forth into homelessness and who in his previous lives has not made merit, who is not free from the obstructive states, who is not established in the right way, who has not severed the impediments, who is not intent, who develops jhāna —

original: natthīti niṭṭhamettha gantabbanti. [Kusalajjhānaṃ]
analyzed: na atthi iti niṭṭham ettha gantabbanti kusala jhānam
translated: his development of jhāna does not succeed, does not come to its conclusion.🔽This is the decision here.

original: 53. Vipākajjhāne kāmakusalaṃ appanaṃ apattaṃ mudubhūtaṃ dubbalaṃ hoti. Parittesu🔽nānākiccaṭṭhānesuca hīnesupi attabhāvesuca vipaccati. Tasmā taṃ attanā asadisaṃpi
analyzed: vipāka jjhāne kāma kusalam appanam apattam mudu bhūtam dubbalam hoti parittesu  nānā kicca ṭṭhānesu ca hīnesu pi atta bhāvesu ca vipaccati tasmā tam attanā asadisam pi
translated: As regards the jhāna of fruition attainment, the profitable of the sense sphere that has not reached absorption is weak and feeble, and it ripens in small, inferior kinds of rebirth among the minor deities.

original: vipākaṃ janeti. Mahaggatakusalaṃpana appanāpattaṃ tikkhaṃ balavaṃ hoti. Uḷāre brahmattabhāve
analyzed: vipākam janeti appanā pattam tikkham balavam hoti uḷāre brahmatta bhāve
translated: Therefore it produces a fruition that is not equal to itself. But the sublime profitable that has reached absorption is strong and powerful, and it ripens in a great, sublime kind of rebirth among the Brahmās.

original: bhavaṅgaṭṭhānesuyeva vipaccati. Tasmā taṃ sadāpi attanā sadisameva vipākaṃ janeti.
analyzed: vipaccati tasmā tam sadā api attanā sadisam eva vipākam janeti
translated: it ripens only in the plane of existence of the life-continuum. Therefore it always produces a result similar to itself.

original: Teneva vitakkavicārapīti sukhekaggatā sahitantiādinā vipākaṃpi sabbaso kusala sadisameva dasseti.
analyzed: tena iva vitakka vicāra pīti sukha ikagga tā sahita nti ādinā vipākam pi sabbaso kusala sadisam eva dasseti
translated: Hence it is shown that the result of the jhāna is similar to the profitable in every way, in the way beginning, “It has thinking and exploring, and so on” .

original: [50] Anantarabhaveyeva phaladānattā taṃ attanā sadisameva vipākaṃ janetītica vadanti, taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: phala dānattā tam sadisam eva vipākam janeti iti ca vadanti tam na sundaram
translated: They say that it produces a result similar to itself because it gives its fruit in the next existence. That is not good.

original: Evañhi sati kāmakusalaṃpi sattamajavanaṃ attanā sadisavipāka meva janeyyāti. Yasmāca
analyzed: evam hi sati sattama javanam sadisa vipākam mā eva janeyyāti yasmā ca
translated: For if it were so, then the seventh impulsion of the sense sphere would also produce a result similar to itself.

original: kusalameva niranusayasantāne pavattaṃ kriyajjhānaṃ nāma hoti. Tasmā kriyacittaṃpi
analyzed: kusalam eva niranusaya santāne pavattam kriyajjhānam nāma hoti tasmā
translated: And because it is only the profitable that is called “kamma-process jhāna” when it occurs in a continuity free from inherent tendency,

original: kusala sadisameva dasseti.🔽54. Pañcadhātiādisaṅgahagāthā. Tattha jhānabhedenāti pathamajjhānādīhi pañcahi jhānehi
analyzed: kusala sadisam eva dasseti  pañcadhā ati ādi saṅgaha gāthā tattha jhāna bhedena ati pathamajjhāna ādīhi pañcahi jhānehi
translated: therefore the result of the kamma-process is shown to be similar to the profitable.🔽The verse in the Schedule is “Fivefold, etc.” Herein, by jhāna-classification means that the fine-material-sphere consciousness is fivefold by classification of its association with the five jhānas beginning with the first.

original: sampayogabhedena. Rūpāvacaramānasaṃ jhānabhedena pañcadhā hoti. Pathamajjhānikaṃ,
analyzed: sampayoga bhedena rūpāvacara mānasam jhāna bhedena pañcadhā hoti pathamajjhānikam
translated: The first-jhāna impulsion,

original: dutīyajjhānikaṃ, tatīyajjhānikaṃ, catutthajjhānikaṃ, pañcamajjhānikanti evaṃ pañcavidhaṃ
analyzed: dutīya jhānikam tatīya jhānikam catuttha jhānikam pañcama jhānikam iti evam pañcavidham
translated: It is of five kinds as the jhāna of the first jhāna, and so on.

original: hotīti attho. Tameva puññapākakriyābhedena pañcadasadhā bhaveti yojanā.
analyzed: hoti iti tam eva puñña pāka kriyā bhedena pañcadasadhā bhava iti yojanā
translated: The meaning is that it is of five kinds as the jhāna of the first jhāna, and of the second, third, fourth, and fifth jhānas. The construction should be worked out as follows: “It is of five kinds as the jhāna of the first jhāna, and of the second, third, fourth, and fifth jhānas.”

original: [51] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said thus:🔽“‘Jhāna-born’: it is born of jhāna, produced by jhāna, arisen in one who has attained jhāna, manifested in one who has attained jhāna—🔽thus it is ‘jhāna-born’” .

original: Jhānabhedenāti jhānaṅgehi sampayogabhedenāti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: jhāna bhedena ati jhāna aṅgehi sampayoga bhedena ati vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: But that is not good.

original: Añño hi jhānabhedo. Añño jhānaṅgabhedo. Tattha pathamaṃ jhānaṃ dutīyaṃ jhānantiādijhānabhedo.🔽Pathamajjhāne pañca aṅgāni. Dutīyajjhāne cattārītiādi jhānaṅgabhedo. Tesu idha jhānabhedova
analyzed: aññaḥ hi jhāna bhedaḥ aññaḥ jhāna aṅga bhedo tattha pathamam jhānam dutīyam jhāna nti ādi jhāna bhedo  pathama jhāne pañca aṅgāni dutīya jjhāne cattāri itiādi tesu idha jhāna bhedaḥ
translated: For the classification of jhāna is one thing and the classification of the jhāna factors is another. Here the classification of jhāna is intended,🔽not the classification of the jhāna factors. For the consciousness is not of five kinds according to the classification of jhāna,

original: adhippeto. Na jhānaṅgabhedo. Cittañhi jhānabhede neva pañcavidhaṃ hoti. Najhānaṅgabhedena.
analyzed: adhippeto na jhāna aṅga bhedo cittam hi jhāna bhede na iva pañcavidham hoti na jhāna aṅga bhedena
translated: nor is it of five kinds according to the classification of the jhāna factors.

original: Jhānameva pana jhānaṅgabhedena pañcavidhanti.
analyzed: jhānam eva pana
translated: But the jhāna itself is of five kinds according to the classification of the jhāna factors.

original: [52] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there

original: “Pañcadhāti pañcaṅgikaṃ caturaṅgikaṃ tivaṅgikaṃ duvaṅgikaṃ puna duvaṅgikanti pañcavidhaṃ hotī”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: pañcadhā ati pañcaṅgikam caturaṅgikam tivaṅgikam duvaṅgikam puna duvaṅgikam ti pañcavidham hoti iti vuttam tat api na sundaram
translated: “It is fivefold as five- factored, four- factored, three- factored, two- factored, and again two- factored” . That is not good.

original: Jhānameva hi pañcaṅgikādi hoti. Na cittanti.
analyzed: jhānam eva hi pañcaṅgika ādi na cittam ti
translated: For only jhāna is five- factored, etc., not consciousness.

original: Rūpāvacara cittassa paramatthadhīpanā.🔽55. Idāni yathānuppattaṃ arūpacittaṃ niddisanto ākāsānañcā yatanakusalacittantiādi
analyzed: cittassa paramattha dhīpanā  idāni yathānuppattam arūpa cittam niddisantaḥ
translated: The demonstration of the ultimate sense of the consciousness of the fine-material sphere.🔽Now, as to the words “With the profitable consciousness of the base consisting of boundless space” and so on, he said this in order to point out the immaterial-sphere consciousness as it occurred.🔽Herein, space is “boundless” because it is not bounded by anything, and it is “space” because it is the absence of anything material.🔽For although it is itself unapprehendable in its individual essence,

analyzed: mā āha tattha bhusaḥ kāsati dibbati iti ākāsaḥ saḥ hi sayam sarūpataḥ an upalabbhamānaḥ api
translated: it is evident as though it were very bright by means of the light of the moon, the sun, the stars, torches, lamps, dawn, and lightning.🔽It is “boundless” because it is not bounded by anything, and it is “space” because it is the absence of anything material.🔽For although it is itself unapprehendable in its individual essence,🔽it is evident as though it were very bright by means of the light of the moon, the sun, the stars, torches, lamps, dawn, and lightning. It is “boundless” because it is not bounded by anything, and it is “space” because it is the absence of anything material.🔽For although it is itself unapprehendable in its individual essence,

analyzed: canda sūriya ubhāsa ādīnam vasena khāyati iti
translated: it is evident as though it were very bright by means of the light of the moon, the sun, the stars, torches, lamps, dawn, and lightning. It is “boundless” because it is not bounded by anything, and it is “space” because it is the absence of anything material.🔽For although it is itself unapprehendable in its individual essence,

analyzed: vasena na vilekhīyati iti akāsaḥ vadanti saḥ pana ajaṭa ākāsaḥ paricchinna ākāsaḥ
translated: it is evident as though it were very bright by means of the light of the moon, the sun, the stars, torches, lamps, dawn, and lightning. It is “boundless” because it is not bounded by anything, and it is “space” because it is the absence of anything material.🔽For although it is itself unapprehendable in its individual essence,

original: kasiṇugghāṭimākāso rūpakalāpaparicchedākāsoti catubbidho hoti. Tattha idha kasiṇugghāṭimākāso
analyzed: kasiṇukkhāṭima ākāsaḥ rūpa kalāpa pariccheda ākāsaḥ ti catubbidhaḥ hoti tattha idha kasiṇukkhāṭima ākāsaḥ
translated: it is evident as though it were very bright by means of the light of the moon, the sun, the stars, torches, lamps, dawn, and lightning. It is “bound

original: adhippeto. So hi anantena ajaṭākāsena saha ekībhūtoviya hoti. Yogināca anantabhāvena
analyzed: adhippetaḥ saḥ hi anantena ajaṭākāsena saha hoti ananta bhāvena
translated: It is the infinite space element that is intended. For that is as if unified with the infinite space element. And the meditator is pervaded by the infinite element.

original: pharīyati. Tasmā ananto ākāsoti ākāsānanto. Nāssa uppādantovā vayantovā paññāyatīti
analyzed: pharīyati tasmai anantaḥ ākāso ti ākāsa anantaḥ na assa uppādantaḥ vā vayantaḥ vā paññāyati iti
translated: That is why it is called “infinite space.” And it is called “infinite” because its arising or origin is not discerned or because its extent is not discerned.

original: anantotipi vuttaṃ. Soyeva ākāsānañcaṃ. Sakatthe yakārena saha siddhattā. Yathā pana
analyzed: anantaḥ tipi vuttam saka atthe yakārena saha siddha ttā yathā pana
translated: This is the base consisting of infinite space. It is called the base consisting of infinite space because it is the base of the consciousness and consciousness-concomitants associated with the attainment of jhāna that has reached that base and is occurring with that as its object.

original: devānaṃ adhiṭṭhānavatthu devāyatananti vuccati. Tathā idhapi tasmiṃ appanāpattassa🔽sasampayuttassa jhānassa adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena tadeva āyatanantipi vuccati. Iti ākāsānañcaṃ🔽āyatanamassāti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ. Cittacetasikarāsi.
analyzed: devānam adhiṭṭhāna vatthu devāyatananti vuccati tathā idha api tasmin appanā pattassa  sa sampayuttassa jhānassa adhiṭṭhāna aṭṭhena tat eva āyatanam ti pi vuccati iti  āyatanam assa ati ākāsānam ca āyatanam
translated: Just as the object of the divine eye is called the “base consisting of the fine-materiality of the devas” , so too this should be understood as the base consisting of infinite space.🔽The “base consisting of infinite space” is the “base consisting of infinite space” of one who has attained it or been reborn there, and it is the “state” of his consciousness and consciousness-concomitants.

original: Ākāsānañcā yatananti ākāsānañcā yatanaṃ samāpannassavā upapannassavā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārissavā citta ceta sikādhammāti hi vibhaṅge vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ākāsānañcā yatananti ākāsānañcā yatanam samāpannassavā upapannassavā diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārissavā hi vibhaṅge vuttam
translated: For this is said in the Vibhaṅga: “The base consisting of infinite space is the space element, and it is also the consciousness that has that as its object and is associated with it” .

original: Ākāsānañcāyatane pavattaṃ kusalacittanti ākāsānañcāyatanakusalacittaṃ. Viññāṇañcāyatananti
analyzed: ākāsānañcāyatane pavattam kusala cittanti ākāsānañcāyatana kusala cittam viññāṇañcāyatananti
translated: “Skillful consciousness occurring in the base of infinite space” is the skillful consciousness of the base of infinite space. “Base of infinite consciousness”:

original: ettha viññāṇaṃnāma ākāsānañcāyatanacittameva. Taṃpana sayaṃ uppādādi antavantaṃpi
analyzed: ettha viññāṇam nāma ākāsa anañca āyatana cittam eva tam pana sayam uppāda ādi antavantam pi
translated: Herein, “consciousness” is the consciousness of the base of infinite space. But that, although limited as to arising, etc.,

original: anantasaññite ākāse pavattanato anantanti vuccati. Koṭṭhāsatthovā antasaddo. Attano🔽uppādādīsu koṭṭhāsesu ekadese aṭṭhatvā sakalassa pharaṇavasena tadārammaṇāya bhāvanāya🔽pavattanato anantanti vuccati. Anantasaññitevā ākāse pavattanato anantanti evaṃ tadārammaṇāya
analyzed: ananta saññite ākāse pavattanataḥ ananta nti vuccati koṭṭhāsa tthaḥ vā anta saddaḥ attanaḥ  uppāda ādīsu koṭṭhāsesu eka dese sakalassa pharaṇa vasena tad ārammaṇāya bhāvanāya  pavattanataḥ anantanti vuccati ananta saññitā iva ākāse pavattanataḥ anantanti evam tad ārammaṇāya
translated: is called “infinite” because it occurs in the space conceived as infinite. Or the word “end” is a collective term for arising, etc.,

original: bhāvanāya pavattattā anantanti vuccati. Anantasaññitevā ākāse attano pharaṇākāra🔽vasenapi anantanti vattuṃ yujjatiyeva. Anantaṃ viññāṇanti viññāṇānantaṃ. Tameva viññāṇañcaṃ
analyzed: bhāvanāya pavattattā anantanti vuccati ananta saññitā iva ākāse attano  vasena api anantam iti vattum anantam viññāṇam ti viññāṇa anantam tam eva
translated: and it is called “infinite” because it occurs in the development of its object without stopping in any one of its own arisings, etc.,🔽like a bird flying through the sky. Or it is called “infinite” because it occurs in the space conceived as infinite by the perception of infinity.🔽But it is also proper to say that it is called “infinite” because of the mode of its occurrence in the conceiving of the infinity of its own object. “Infinite consciousness”: the infinity of consciousness. That same “consciousness base”

original: niruttinayena, viññāṇañcaṃ āyatanaṃ assāti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ. Viññāṇañcāyatana saṅkhāte
analyzed: nirutti nayena viññāṇañcam āyatanam assa ati viññāṇañcāyatanam viññāṇañcāyatana saṅkhāte
translated: is called “the base of infinite consciousness” in the method of derivation by means of a base. “Base of infinite consciousness” is said

analyzed: citta cetasika rāsimhi pavattam kusala citta nti samāsaḥ
translated: “Profitable consciousness occurring in the mind-element and the mind-consciousness element” is the analysis.

original: Viññāṇañcāyatananti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samāpannassavā upapannassavādiṭṭhadhammasukhavihārissavācittacetasikādhammātihi vibhaṅge vuttaṃ.
analyzed: viññāṇañca āyatananti viññāṇañca āyatanam samāpanna ssavāḥ upapanna ssavā a diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāri ssavā a citta cetasika a dhammā atihi vibhaṅge vuttam
translated: “The base consisting of boundless consciousness” is the attainment of the base consisting of boundless consciousness, and the states associated therewith, and the states associated with the consciousness that has arisen there, and the material states that occur together with that consciousness, and the jhāna factors, and the states that are conditionally arisen in one who has attained and is dwelling in the happiness of the present life in that attainment.

original: [53] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana mahāṭīkāyañca
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī and the Mahāṭīkā it is said:🔽“The second is to be discerned by consciousness, to be reached by consciousness, thus it is the base consisting of boundless consciousness.”

original: “Dutīyā ruppa viññāṇena añcitabbaṃ pāpuṇitabbanti viññāṇañca”ntipi vuttaṃ. Taṃ pāḷiyā na sameti.
analyzed: dutīyā ruppa viññāṇena añcitabbam pāpuṇitabbanti vuttam tam pāḷiyā na sameti

analyzed: anantam viññāṇan ti tat eva viññāṇam ñāṇena phuṭṭham manasikaroti anantam pharati  tena vuccati anantam viññāṇam ti iti hi vuttam etena ca tat viññāṇam ekantena ananta visesana yuttam
translated: “Infinite consciousness”: he gives attention to that same consciousness as “infinite” by delimiting it as “infinite” with knowledge.🔽Hence it is said, “It is said to be infinite consciousness because he gives attention to it as ‘infinite’” . original: hotīti viññāyatīti. Tameva ākāsantipi pāṭho. Ākiñcaññāyatananti ettha kiñci kiñcananti

analyzed: avasiṭṭham assa pathamā ruppa viññāṇassa ati akiñcanam akiñcanassa bhāvaḥ ākiñcaññam  pathama āruppa viññāṇa abhāvaḥ so hi natthi kiñci iti manasikāra vasena labhati iti
translated: What remains of it is the first immaterial-sphere consciousness. It is “nothing” . original: Ākiñcaññaṃ āyatanamassātiādi vuttanayameva. Nevasaññā nāsaññāyatananti ettha oḷārika🔽saññaṃ sandhāya nevatthi saññā assāti nevasaññaṃ. Sukhumasaññaṃ sandhāya naca natthi
analyzed: ākiñcaññam āyatanam assa atiādi vutta nayam eva nevasaññā na asaññāyatananti ettha oḷārika  saññam sandhāya na iva atthi saññā assa ati neva saññam sukhuma saññam sandhāya na ca natthi
translated: The base of the neither-perception-nor-non-perception … is the profitable consciousness that occurs in the neither-perception-nor-non-perception attainment.🔽Herein, perception is gross in the sense of being gross as an object of consciousness.🔽Because of the attention given to it as “there is no perception” it is “not perception” . Because of the remaining subtle perception it is “not non-perception” .

original: saññā assāti nāsaññaṃ, nevasaññañca taṃ nāsaññañcāti nevasaññā nāsaññaṃ majjhe dīghaṃ
analyzed: saññā assa ati nāsaññam nevasaññam ca tam nāsaññam ca ati nāsaññāḥ nāsaññam majjhe dīgham
translated: It is “neither perception nor non-perception” because of the absence of gross perception and the presence of subtle perception.

original: katvā, citta cetasikarāsieva. Tameva yogino sukhavisesānaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena āyatananti🔽nevasaññā nāsaññāyatanaṃ. Tasmiṃ pavattaṃ kusala cittanti samāso. Athavā. Saññāyeva
analyzed: tam eva yogino sukha visesānaṃ adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena āyatananti  nevasaññā na asaññāyatanam tasmim pavattam kusala cittam ti samāsaḥ athavā
translated: The “base” is the mere group of consciousness and its concomitants, which is so called because it is the foundation for the distinction of the kinds of pleasure.🔽Or alternatively, it is “neither perception” because of the absence of gross perception, the function of ordinary perception,

original: paṭusaññākiccassa abhāvato nevasaññāca hoti. Saṅkhārāvasesa sukhumabhāvena vijjamānattā
analyzed: paṭu saññā kiccassa abhāvataḥ hoti saṅkhāra avasesa sukhuma bhāvena vijjamāna ttā
translated: and it is “not non-perception” because of the presence of the remaining subtle perception.

original: asaññāca nahotīti katvā nevasaññānā saññānāma, sāyeva āyatanaṃ, tenaca sampayuttaṃ
analyzed: asaññā ca na hoti iti katvā āyatanam tena ca sampayuttam
translated: and it is not perception, thus it is neither-perception-nor-non-perception. That base is the same as the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: kusala cittanti samāso. Etthaca yasmā ādito paṭṭhāya oḷārike nīvaraṇadhamme vitakkādikeca
analyzed: ettha ca yasmai āditaḥ paṭṭhāya oḷārike nīvaraṇa dhamme vitakka ādike ca
translated: The compound is a copulative one. And here, since it is by abandoning the gross states of the hindrances, etc., beginning with applied thought,

original: pajahitvā sesadhammeca bhāvanā balena uparupari sukhumabhāvaṃ pāpetvā anukkamena
analyzed: pajahitvā sesa dhamme ca bhāvanā balena upari upari sukhuma bhāvam pāpetvā anukkamena
translated: and by bringing the remaining states to a subtle stage by means of the power of development that they eventually reach

original: paṭipajjantā sukhumaṭṭhena lokiyadhammesu muddhabhūtaṃ imaṃ samāpattiṃ pāpuṇanti.
analyzed: paṭipajjantā sukhuma ṭṭhena lokiya dhammesu muddha bhūtam imam samāpattim pāpuṇanti
translated: this attainment, which is the acme of subtlety among mundane states,

original: Tasmā idha cittaṃpi nevacittanācittameva hoti. Phassopi neva phassanāphassoeva hoti,
analyzed: tasmai idha cittam pi na iva cittanā cittam eva hoti phassaḥ pi na iva phassanā phassaḥ eva hoti
translated: therefore here the consciousness is not consciousness, but is non-consciousness, non-cognizance. The contact is not contact, but is non-contact, non-impingement.

original: tathā vedanādayopīti. Tasmā idhasaññāggahaṇaṃ desanāsīsamattanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Vipākesu
analyzed: tathā vedanā ādayaḥ api iti tasmai idha saññā ggahaṇam desanā sīsa mattan ti daṭṭhabbam vipākesu
translated: And so too with feeling, and so on. So the mention of perception should be regarded as a mere heading for the teaching.

original: viññāṇañcāyatananti ettha viññāṇanti pathamāruppakusala viññāṇameva. Tañca atītānantarabhave
analyzed: viññāṇañca āyatananti ettha viññāṇanti pathama āruppa kusala viññāṇam eva tat ca atīta anantara bhave
translated: In the case of the resultants, the base consisting of boundless consciousness: here the consciousness is the first fine-material profitable consciousness itself.🔽And that should be regarded as occurring in the next existence following the past existence. The meaning is that it has no more to do with nothingness.

original: pavattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Akiñcana bhāvoca tasseva natthi bhāvoti. Kriyacittesu pana viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: pavattam daṭṭhabbam akiñcana tassa iva natthi bhāvo ti kriya cittesu pana viññāṇam
translated: But in the case of the functional consciousnesses, the consciousness is

original: nāma kusalabhūtaṃ kriyabhūtañca duvidhaṃ pathamāruppaviññāṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Akiñcanabhāvoca
analyzed: nāma kusala bhūtam kriya bhūtam ca duvidham pathama āruppa viññāṇam veditabbam
translated: The first immaterial-sphere consciousness should be understood as twofold, namely, profitable and functional.

original: tasseva duvidhassa viññāṇassa abhāvo yevāti.
analyzed: tassa iva duvidhassa viññāṇassa abhāvaḥ
translated: The absence of any possession is the absence of that twofold consciousness.

original: 56. Saṅgahagāthāyaṃ ārammaṇappabhedenāti ālambi tabbānaṃ kasiṇugghāṭimākāsādīnaṃ
analyzed: saṅgahagāthāyam ārammaṇa ppabhedena ati ālambi tabbānam kasiṇugghāṭima ākāsa ādīnam
translated: In the verse of inclusion: “With the classification of object” means with the classification of the four objects to be contacted, namely, the sign of the kasiṇa, the sign of the limiting-sphere, space, and consciousness.

original: catunnaṃ ārammaṇānaṃ pabhedena. Duvidhaṃhi idha ārammaṇacatukkaṃ, atimikkatabba catukkaṃ,🔽ālambi tabba catukkañca. Tattha pathamāruppe rūpapañcamajjhānassa ārammaṇa bhūtaṃ.
analyzed: catunnam ārammaṇānam pabhedena duvidham hi idha ārammaṇa catukkam  tattha pathama āruppe rūpa pañcama jhānassa ārammaṇa bhūtam
translated: For there are two kinds of four objects here: the four objects to be transcended, and the four objects to be contacted. Herein, the sign of the kasiṇa is the object to be transcended in the first immaterial-sphere jhāna.

original: Kasiṇanimittaṃ atikkami tabbaṃnāma. Taṃ ugghāṭetvā laddhaṃ ākāsaṃ ālambitabbaṃ nāma.🔽Dutīyāruppe pathamāruppassa ārammaṇabhūtaṃ ākāsaṃ atikkamitabbaṃnāma. Pathamāruppaviññāṇaṃ
analyzed: kasiṇa nimittam atikkami tabbaṃ nāma tam ugghāṭetvā laddham ākāsam ālambitabbam nāma  dutīya āruppe pathama āruppassa ārammaṇa bhūtam ākāsam atikkamitabbaṃnāma pathama āruppa viññāṇam
translated: The space obtained by removing the kasiṇa is the object to be contacted.🔽In the second immaterial-sphere jhāna the space that was the object in the first is the object to be transcended. The first immaterial-sphere consciousness🔽is the object to be contacted. In the third immaterial-sphere jhāna that first immaterial-sphere consciousness is the object to be transcended. The second immaterial-sphere consciousness

original: ālambi tabbaṃnāma. Tatīyāruppe taṃpathamāruppaviññāṇaṃ atikkamitabbaṃnāma. Tassa
analyzed: ālambi tabbaṃ nāma tatīya āruppe taṃ pathama āruppa viññāṇam atikkamitabbaṃ nāma tassa
translated: is the object to be contacted. In the fourth immaterial-sphere jhāna that second immaterial-sphere consciousness is the object to be transcended. The third immaterial-sphere consciousness🔽is the object to be contacted. In the fourth immaterial-sphere jhāna that third immaterial-sphere consciousness is the object to be transcended. The fourth immaterial-sphere consciousness🔽is the object to be contacted. In the fourth immaterial-sphere jhāna that fourth immaterial-sphere consciousness is the object to be transcended. There is no object to be contacted beyond that. That is why it is called “having no object to be contacted.”

original: natthibhāvo ālambitabbaṃnāma. Catutthāruppe so natthi bhāvo atikkamitabbaṃ nāma.
analyzed: natthi bhāvaḥ ālambitabbam nāma catuttha āruppe saḥ natthi bhāvaḥ atikkamitabbam nāma
translated: Non-existence is what is to be discerned. The non-existence of the fourth immaterial state is what is to be surmounted.

original: Tatīyāruppaviññāṇaṃ ālambi tabbaṃ nāmāti. Tattha kiñcāpi imaṃ āruppamānasaṃ catunnaṃ🔽atikkami tabbānaṃpi bhedena catubbidhaṃ hoti, tathāpi ākāsānañcāya tanantiādinā idha
analyzed: tatīya āruppa viññāṇam ālambi tabbam nāma ati tattha kiñcā api imam āruppa mānasam catunnam  atikkami tabbānam pi bhedena catubbidham hoti tathā api idha
translated: The third immaterial consciousness is what is to be discerned.

original: ālambitabbānaññeva sarūpato gahitattā tesaṃ bhedena imassa bhedo pākaṭoti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: ālambitabbā anaññā iva sarūpataḥ gahita ttā tesam bhedena imassa bhedaḥ pākaṭaḥ ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: Herein, although this immaterial consciousness is fourfold according to the surmounting of the four, still it is to be regarded as evident as fourfold according to the objects discerned, since only the objects discerned are stated here in the way beginning, “The base consisting of boundless space” .

original: Āruppamānasaṃ ālambaṇappabhedena catudhā ṭhitaṃ. Tadeva puññapāka kriyabhedena dvādasadhā ṭhitanti yojanā.
analyzed: āruppa mānasam ālambaṇa ppabhedena catudhā ṭhitam tat eva puññapāka kriya bhedena dvādasadhā ṭhitan ti yojanā
translated: The immaterial consciousness is fourfold according to the division of the objects of discernment. It is twelvefold according to the division of merit, result, and function.

original: Arūpacittassa paramatthadīpanā.
translated: The exposition of the immaterial consciousness in the ultimate sense.

original: 57. Idāni yathānuppattaṃ lokuttara cittaṃ dassento sotāpattimaggacittantiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni yathānuppattam lokuttara cittam dassentaḥ sotāpatti magga cittam tiādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show the supramundane consciousness as it arises, he said, “The consciousness of the path of stream-entry,” and so on.

original: Tattha savati sandati anivattagamanavasena pavattatīti soto, gaṅgādīsu jalappavāho.
analyzed: tattha savati sandati anivatta gamana vasena pavattati iti sotaḥ gaṅgā ādīsu jala ppavāho
translated: Herein, a stream is a flow, a flux, a continuous occurrence without a break. It is a water-course such as the Ganges.

original: Sohi pabhavato paṭṭhāya yāvamahāsamuddā antarā anivatta māno savati sandati pavattatīti.
analyzed: so hi pabhavataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva mahā samuddā antarā anivatta māno savati sandati pavattati iti
translated: It flows, spreads, and occurs without turning back between the beginning and the great ocean.

original: Sotoviyāti soto. Aṭṭhaṅgiko ariyamaggo, yathāha-yokho āvuso ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo.

translated: The stream is the Noble Eightfold Path, as it is said: “And what, friends, is the Noble Eightfold Path?

original: Seyyathidaṃ, sammādiṭṭhi. La. Sammāsamādhi. Ayaṃ vuccatāvuso sototi. Ayaṃpihi yadā🔽uppajjati. Tato paṭṭhāya ānubhāvapharaṇavasena yāvaanupādisesanibbānadhātuyā antarā
analyzed: sā iyyathidam sammādiṭṭhi sammāsamādhi ayam vuccati avuso sotā iti yadā  uppajjati tatas paṭṭhāya ānubhāva pharaṇa vasena yāva anupādisesa nibbānadhātuyā antarā
translated: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration. This, friends, is called the stream.” And this, too,🔽when it arises, flows, spreads, and occurs without turning back between the beginning and the Nibbāna element that is without clinging left.

original: anivattamānoyeva hutvā savati sandati pavattatīti. Yathāha -🔽Seyyathāpi bhikkhave yākāci mahānadiyo. Seyyathidaṃ. Gaṅgā, yamunā, aciravatī, sarabhū,
analyzed: a nivattamānā iva hutvā savati sandati pavattati iti yathā āha  seyyathā api bhikkhave yākāci mahā nadiyo sā iyyathā idam gaṅgā yamunā aciravatī sarabhū
translated: As it is said:

original: bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento bahulikaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbāna pabbhāroti.
analyzed: bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventaḥ bahulikarontaḥ nibbāna ninnaḥ hoti nibbāna poṇaḥ nibbāna pabbhāro ti
translated: the bhikkhu who develops and makes much of the Noble Eightfold Path tends to Nibbāna, slopes to Nibbāna, flows to Nibbāna, and enters into Nibbāna.”

original: Etthaca tena tena maggena pahīnānaṃ kilesānaṃ puna anupagamana vasena saddhādīnaṃ indriyānaṃ anukkamena paripākagamanavasenaca anivattagamanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yathāha -🔽Seyyathāpi bhikkhave ghaṭo nikkujjo vamateva udakaṃ. Nopaccāvamati. Evamevakho bhikkhave
analyzed: ettha ca tena tena maggena pahīnānam kilesānam puna anupagamana vasena saddhā ādīnam indriyānam anukkamena paripāka gamana vasena ca anivatta gamanam daṭṭhabbam yathā āha  seyyathā api bhikkhave ghaṭaḥ nikkujjaḥ vamatā iva udakam na upaccāvamati evam eva kho bhikkhave
translated: Herein, the “non-return” should be regarded as the non-return of the defilements abandoned by each path, and as the gradual maturing of the faculties of faith, etc., in the sense of their non-return to the state of being immature. As it is said:

original: ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento bahulikaronto vamateva pāpake akusale dhamme.
analyzed: ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāventaḥ bahulikarontaḥ vamatā iva pāpake akusale dhamme
translated: “Bhikkhus, just as a pot turned upside down does not receive the water, so too, when the Ariyan eightfold path is being developed, evil unwholesome states that have already been abandoned are not liable to return” .

original: Nopaccāvamatīti. Yathācāha-sotāpatti maggaññāṇena ye kilesā pahīnā, te kilese napuneti
analyzed: na upacca avamati iti
translated: And as it is said: “The defilements that have been abandoned by the knowledge of the path of stream-entry do not lead him back” ,

analyzed: napat ca iti napat ca āgacchati itiādi  yathā ca puthujjanāḥ pahīne api kilese punar upagacchanti ti hetuka bhūtāḥ api punar dvi hetuka ahetuka bhāvam

analyzed: na upagacchanti puthujjana bhāvam vā heṭṭhimāriya bhāvam vā na gacchanti anukkamena  saddhā ādīnam indriyānam paripakka bhāvam eva upagacchanti iti sabbañca etat ariya maggassa iva
translated: regained by them. They do not revert to the state of an ordinary man or to the lower noble paths. They only go on to the

analyzed: ānubhāvena mūla ppabhava bhūte tasmin magge eva niruḷhanti daṭṭhabbam

analyzed: tassa sotassa āditas pajjanam pāpuṇanam sotāpatti sotāpattiyāḥ adhigamamānaḥ maggo  sotāpatti maggo athavā samāpanno ariyo ti pavuccati iti vutta ttā sabbe ariya santāna gatā
translated: The “entry into the stream” is the first penetration of the path. The path that is being penetrated is the

analyzed: lokiya lokuttara bhūtāḥ bodhi pakkhiya dhammāḥ upari sambodhi parā yana tā vasena an upādisesa nibbāna
translated: stream-entry path. Or alternatively, it is said that one who has reached the stream is called “entered into the noble fruitions, and the noble paths, and the states that are conascent with them, which are headed by the enlightenment factors, are directed to Nibbāna without trace left, in the manner of one who goes upstream to the source of a river.

analyzed: parāyana tā vasena ca anivatta gatiyā pavattamānāḥ yathā vuttena atthena sototi vuccanti  tam sotam āditas pajjanti pāpuṇanti etāya paṭipadāya ati sotāpatti sotāpatti ca sā
translated: And they are called “streams” in the above-mentioned sense because they flow on in an unbroken course.🔽The path is the stream’s entry because it is entered by those who arrive at the stream.

analyzed: sotāpatti maggaḥ pathama magga saṅkhātāya sotāpattiyāḥ sotāpatti

translated: The path is called the stream’s entry because it is entered by those who arrive at the stream.🔽The path is called the stream’s entry because it is entered by those who arrive at the stream.🔽The path is called the stream’s entry because it is entered by those who arrive at the stream.

original: Ariyamaggasotassa ādito pajjanaṃ etassāti sotāpatti. Puggaloti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.🔽Na hi puggale pavatto sotāpattisaddo katthaci diṭṭhoti.
analyzed: ariya magga sotassa āditas pajjanam etassa ati sotāpatti puggalo ti vuttam tat na sundaram  na hi puggale pavatto sotāpatti saddo katthaci diṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: The path is called the stream’s entry because it is entered by those who arrive at the stream.🔽The path is called the stream’s entry because it is entered by those who arrive at the stream.

original: [55] Etena tassa maggo sotāpattimaggoti idaṃpi paṭikkhittaṃ hoti.
analyzed: etena tassa maggo sotāpatti maggo ti idam pi paṭikkhittam hoti

original: Sotāpattimaggena sampayuttaṃ cittaṃ sotāpattimaggacittaṃ.
analyzed: sotāpatti maggena sampayuttam cittam sotāpatti magga cittam
translated: The path is called the stream’s entry because it is entered by those who arrive at the stream.

original: [56] Ṭīkāsu pana
analyzed: ṭīkāsu pana
translated: The path is called the stream’s

original: Sotāpattiyā laddhaṃ maggacittaṃ sotāpatti maggacittanti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: sotāpattiyā laddham magga cittam sotāpatti magga cittan ti vuttam tam na sundaram
translated: The path consciousness obtained at the time of the fruit of stream-entry is called “stream-entry path consciousness.” That is not good.

original: Na hi cittasaddasambandho sotāpattisaddo katthaci pāḷiyaṃ diṭṭhoti.
analyzed: na hi citta sadda sambandho sotāpatti saddo katthaci pāḷiyam diṭṭho ti
translated: For the word “stream-entry” is not found in the texts connected with the word “consciousness.”

original: 58. Paṭisandhivasena sakiṃ imaṃlokaṃ āgacchati sīlenāti sakadāgāmī. Dutīyaphalaṭṭho.
analyzed: paṭisandhi vasena sakim imaṃlokam āgacchati sīlena ati sakadāgāmī dutīya phala ṭṭho
translated: He comes back to this human world only once more by rebirth, thus he is a “once-returner” . This is the meaning of the second fruit.

original: So hi asamucchinnakāma rāgānusayattā kāmalokāgamana kilesasabbhāvena taṃ sabhāvānāti
analyzed: saḥ hi tam
translated: For he has not abandoned the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures, and he is similar to a once-returner in respect of the defilements that lead to the sensual-desire realm.

original: vattanato upari bhavagge ṭhitopi paṭisandhivasena puna imaṃ kāmadhātuṃ āgamanappakatikoeva
analyzed: vattanataḥ upari bhavagge ṭhitaḥ api paṭisandhi vasena puna imam kāmadhātum āgamana ppakatikaḥ eva
