translated: Although he stands in the higher realms by way of his course of life, he is still by nature one who will come back to this sensual-desire realm by rebirth.

original: hotīti. Vuttañhetaṃ catukkanipāte -
analyzed: hoti iti vuttam ha etam catukkanipāte
translated: This is said in the Catukkanipāta:

original: Idha sāriputta ekaccassa puggalassa orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni appahīnāni honti, so🔽diṭṭhevadhamme nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati. So aparihīno kālaṃ kurumāno
analyzed: idha sāriputta ekaccassa puggalassa orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni appahīnāni honti so  diṭṭheva dhamme nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati saḥ a parihīnaḥ kālam kurumānaḥ
translated: “Here, Sāriputta, some person has not abandoned the fetters that are on the side of destruction,🔽but he has entered upon the way to the realisation of the fruit of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. He, on the dissolution of the body, after death,

original: nesaññānāsaññā yatanupagānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati. So tato cuto āgāmī hoti
analyzed: nesañña anāsaññāḥ yatanupagānam devānam sahabyatam upapajjati saḥ tatas cutaḥ āgāmī hoti
translated: reappears in the company of the gods of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. He, on the dissolution of the body, after death,

original: āgantvā itthattaṃ. Idha pana sāriputta ekaccassa puggalassa orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni
analyzed: āgantvā itthattam idha pana sāriputta ekaccassa puggalassa orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni
translated: and he comes back to this human state. But here, Sāriputta, some person has destroyed the fetters of the lower world,

original: pahīnāni honti, so diṭṭheva.La. So tato cuto anāgāmī hoti anāgantvā itthattanti.
analyzed: pahīnāni honti so so tatas cutaḥ anāgāmī hoti an āgantvā itthattanti
translated: and he is a non-returner who does not come back to this human state.

original: Aṭṭhakathāyañca itthattanti imaṃ kāmāvacara pañcakkhandha bhāvanti vuttaṃ. Ayañca
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayañca itthattanti imam kāmāvacara pañcakkhandha bhāvanti vuttaṃ ayañca
translated: And in the Commentary it is said that “ this human state” is the five categories of form, etc., of the sense sphere.

original: attho kilesagativasena vutto. Na puggala gativasena. Na hi brahmabhūtā sotāpanna
analyzed: attho kilesa gati vasena vuttaḥ na gati vasena na hi brahma bhūtā sotāpanna
translated: And this meaning is stated in terms of the plane of defilement, not in terms of the plane of the person,

original: sakadā gāmino paṭipaṭisandhivasena heṭṭhimaṃpi brahmalokaṃ āgacchanti. Kuto kāma
analyzed: sakadā gāmino paṭipaṭisandhi vasena heṭṭhimam pi brahmalokam āgacchanti kutas
translated: for stream-enterers and once-returners who have become Brahmās do not come to the lower Brahmā-world by rebirth-linking,🔽so how could they come to the sense-sphere world?

original: lokaṃ. Kathaṃ viññāyatīti ce. Anusayayamake –
analyzed: lokam katham viññāyati iti ce anusaya yamake
translated: How is this known? In the “Treatise on Susceptibility to Depravity” :

original: Kāmadhātuyā cutassa rūpadhātuṃ arūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassa kassaci sattaanusayā anusenti,
analyzed: kāmadhātuyā cutassa rūpadhātum a rūpadhātum upapajjantassa kassaci satta anusayāḥ anusenti
translated: “One who has died in the sense-desire world and is being reborn in the fine-material or immaterial world has some of the ten depravities susceptible to arising,

original: kassaci pañcaanusayā anusenti, kassaci tayo anusayā anusentīti vatvā rūpa dhātuyā
analyzed: kassaci pañca anusayā anusenti kassaci tayo anusayā anusenti iti vatvā rūpa dhātuyā
translated: some has five, and some has three” . And in the fine-material world

original: arūpadhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātuṃ upapajjantassa satteva anusayā anusentīti.🔽Vuttattā viññāyati. Tattha purimavākye puthujjanassa vasena satta. Dvinnaṃ sotāpannasakadāgāmīnaṃ
analyzed: arūpadhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātum upapajjantassa sattā iva anusayāḥ anusenti iti  vutta ttā viññāyati tattha purima vākye puthujjanassa vasena satta dvinnam sotāpanna sakadāgāmīnam
translated: and when one who has died in the formless world is reappearing in the sense-desire world, only seven underlying tendencies underlie that reappearance.🔽It is evident that this is so because it is stated. Herein, in the first passage the seven are stated in the case of an ordinary man,🔽and in the case of the two kinds of stream-enterer and once-returner they are five,

original: vasena pañca. Anāgāmissa vasena kayoti vuttaṃ, pacchimavākyepana brahmabhūtānaṃ sotā
analyzed: vasena pañca anāgāmissa vasena kayā iti vuttam sotā
translated: and in the case of the non-returner they are four. But in the second passage only the seven are stated in the case of an ordinary man,

original: pannasakadāgāmianāgāmīnaṃ paṭisandhivasena kāmalokaṃ gamanassa natthitāya kevalaṃ
analyzed: panna sakadāgāmi anāgāmīnam paṭisandhi vasena kāma lokam gamanassa natthitāya kevalam
translated: because there is no reappearance in the sense-desire world in the case of the stream-enterer, once-returner, and non-returner who have become Brahmās by means of the divine abidings.

original: puthujjanasseva vasena sattevāti vuttaṃ. Dhammahadaya vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāyañca –
analyzed: puthujjanassa iva vasena sattā iva iti vuttam dhammahadaya vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāyañca
translated: And in the Dhammahadaya Vibhaṅga Commentary it is said:

original: “Rūpāvacare nibbattā sotāpannasakadāgāmino napuna idhā gacchanti, tattheva parinibbāyanti.🔽Etehi jhānaanāgāmino nāmā”ti ca. “Navasu brahmalokesu nibbattaariya sāvakānaṃ tatrupa
analyzed: rūpāvacare nibbattā sotāpanna sakadāgāminaḥ na puna idhā gacchanti tattha iva parinibbāyanti  etehi jhāna anāgāminaḥ nāma ati ca navasu brahmalokesu sāvakānam
translated: “Stream-enterers and once-returners who are reborn in the fine-material world do not come here again; they attain Nibbāna there.🔽These are called ‘non-returners by means of jhāna.’

original: pattipi hoti uparūpapattipi. Naheṭṭhu papatti. Puthujjanānaṃpana tatrupapattipi hoti
analyzed: hoti uparu upapatti pi naheṭṭhu papatti puthujjanānaṃ pana hoti
translated: ‘Noble disciples who are reborn in the nine Brahmā-world spheres attain to the state of those of that world and also to the state of those of a higher world. They do not attain to the state of those of a lower world.🔽But ordinary men attain to the state of those of that world and also to the state of those of a higher world.

original: uparūpapatti heṭṭhupapattipī”ti ca.
analyzed: uparūpapatti heṭṭhupapatti pīti ca
translated: and from a higher to a lower rebirth.”

original: Vuttaṃ. Tañcakho anāgamanaṃ maggasahāyena jhānānubhāveneva siddhaṃ. Namaggānubhāvenāti.
analyzed: vuttam tat ca kho anāgamanam magga sahāyena jhāna anubhāvena iva siddham na magga anubhāvena ati
translated: This is said. But that is accomplished by the jhāna’s potency, which is a companion of the path, and not by the path’s potency.

original: Etthaca imaṃ lokanti padassa imaṃ manussalokanti vā imaṃ kāmāvacaralokantivā dvidhāpi
analyzed: ettha ca imam lokanti padassa imam manussa lokanti vā imam kāmāvacara lokanti vā dvidhā api
translated: And here the meaning of the words “this world” is given in the commentaries in two ways as “this human world” and as “this sense-desire world.”

original: attho aṭṭhakathāsu vutto. Tattha purimasmiṃ atthe sati āgacchatīti etassa devalokato🔽āgacchatīti attho. Pacchimasmiṃ pana brahmalokatopi ca āgacchatīti. Pāḷiyaṃpana pacchimatthova🔽vuttoviya dissati. Vuttañhetaṃ puggalapaññattiyaṃ anāgantvā itthattaṃ anāgāmī tena
analyzed: attho aṭṭhakathāsu vutto tattha purimasmin atthe sati āgacchati iti etassa deva lokato  āgacchati iti ca āgacchati iti  vuttaḥ u iya dissati vuttam ha etam puggala paññattiyam an āgantvā itthattam anāgāmī tena
translated: Herein, in the first case, if it is taken as “this human world,” the meaning of the words “comes back no more” is that he does not come back from the deva world;🔽but in the second case, if it is taken as “this sense-desire world,” the meaning is that he does not come back from the fine-material world either. And the latter meaning appears to be intended in the text.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Āgantvā itthattaṃ sotāpannasakadā gāmino tena daṭṭhabbāti. Etthaca anāgantvā
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ āgantvā itthattam sotāpanna sakadā gāmino tena daṭṭhabbā ati ettha ca an āgantvā
translated: For this is said in the Paṭṭhāna: “The non-returner should be understood as one who, without having come back to this state of being, does not come back to the human state of being, and as one who, without having come back to this state of being, does not come back to the sense-desire world” .

original: itthattanti iminā imaṃ kāmāvacaralokaṃ na āgacchatīti anāgāmīti atthaṃ dasseti. Āgantvā
analyzed: itthattam ti iminā imam kāmāvacara lokam na āgacchati iti anāgāmī iti attham dasseti āgantvā
translated: And here the words “without having come back to this state of being” show the meaning of “non-returner” as “one who does not come back to this sense-desire world.”

original: itthattanti imināpana dvepi sotāpannasakadāgāmino sakiṃ puna imaṃ kāmāvacaralokaṃ🔽āgacchantīti sakadāgāminoti atthaṃ dasseti. Kasmā, nirantaravākyesu ṭhitānaṃ dvinnaṃitthatta
analyzed: dve pi sotāpanna sakadāgāminaḥ sakim punar imam kāmāvacara lokam  āgacchanti iti sakadāgāmino ti attham dasseti kasmai nirantara vākyesu ṭhitānam
translated: By the word “thus” he shows the meaning of “once-returner” in the sense that these two, the stream-enterer and the once-returner, come back to this world of sensual pleasures once.

original: saddānaṃ nānātthā sambhavato. Majjhimapaṇṇāseca kaṇṇakattha sutte -
analyzed: saddānam nānā atthā sambhavataḥ majjhima paṇṇāse ca kaṇṇakattha sutte
translated: Why? Because it is possible to discern a difference in meaning between the two words “thus” in the continuous sentence. In the Kaṇṇakatissa Sutta of the Majjhima Nikāya,

original: Yo so mahārāja brahmā sabyāpajjho, so brahmā āgantā itthattaṃ. Yoso brahmā abyāpajjho, so brahmā anāgantā itthattanti.
analyzed: yaḥ saḥ mahā rāja brahmā sa byāpajjhaḥ saḥ brahmā āgantā itthattam yaḥ saḥ brahmā a byāpajjhaḥ saḥ brahmā an āgantā itthattam ti
translated: “The brahmas who are subject to affliction, sire, come back to this state of being. The brahmas who are not subject to affliction do not come back to this state of being.”

original: Bhagavatā vuttaṃ. Tattha sabyāpajjhoti etena puthujjanena saha sotāpannasakadāgāmibhūtā🔽brahmāno gahitā honti. Tehi paṭighānusayassa appahīnattā cetasikadukkhasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: bhagavatā vuttam tattha etena puthujjanena saha sotāpanna sakadāgāmi bhūtā  brahmānaḥ gahitāḥ honti tehi paṭigha anusayassa a pahīna ttā cetasika dukkha saṅkhātam
translated: This is said by the Blessed One. Herein, “subject to affliction” refers to the brahmas who are stream-enterers and once-returners together with the worldlings.🔽Because they have not abandoned the underlying tendency to resistance, they have not abandoned the affliction called mental pain.

original: byāpajjhaṃpi apahīnamevāti sabyāpajjhānāma. Āgantā itthattanti imaṃ kāmalokaṃ paṭisandhivasena
analyzed: apahīnam eva ati āgantā itthattam ti imam kāma lokam paṭisandhi vasena
translated: They are called “subject to affliction.” “Come back to this state of being” means that they come back to this world of sensual pleasures by rebirth-linking.

original: puna āgamanasīlo āgamanappakatikoti attho. Tabbiparītena pacchimassa vākyassa attho🔽veditabbo. Tesupana dvīsu sakadāgāmīsu purimassa anaññasā dhāraṇeneva sabbapathamaṃ
analyzed: puna āgamana sīlaḥ āgamana ppakatiko ti attho tad biparītena pacchimassa vākyassa attho  veditabbo tesu pana dvīsu sakadāgāmīsu purimassa anaññasā dhāraṇena iva sabba pathamam
translated: The meaning is that he is one who has the nature of coming back. The meaning of the last clause should be understood in the opposite sense.

original: ariya magga sotādhi gamana guṇena sotāpanno tveva nāmaṃ siddhanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Puggalagativasena
analyzed: guṇena sotāpannaḥ tu eva nāmam siddhanti daṭṭhabbam puggala gati vasena
translated: But of these two once-returners, the former’s name is established first of all by the fact that he is one who has entered the stream of the path, by the quality of his going to the end of suffering, as one who is not liable to be led into another kind of becoming.

original: panettha brahmaloke ṭhitānaṃ sattakkhattuparamatādibhāvoviya sakadāgāmibhāvopi natthi.
analyzed: pana ittha brahma loke ṭhitānam satta kkhattu parama tā ādi bhāvaḥ viya sakadāgāmi bhāvaḥ api natthi
translated: But in this case, as regards the state of being a once-returner, there is no such thing as the state of being one who is limited to seven existences, and so on, as there is the state of being one who goes to the Brahmā-world.

original: Pathamadutīyaphalaṭṭhāpihi tattha anāgāmisaṅkhyameva gacchanti. Tasmā sakadāgāmīti
analyzed: tattha anāgāmi saṅkhyam eva gacchanti sakadāgāmī iti
translated: For those who have reached the first and second fruits are reckoned as non-returners there. Therefore the name “once-returner”

original: idaṃ kāmajātikā naṃeva dutīyaphalaṭṭhānaṃ siddhaṃ nāmanti katvā tesaṃ kāmaloke eva🔽heṭṭhuparupapatti vasena sakiṃ āgamanaṃ aṭṭhakathāsu vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evañca
analyzed: idam kāma jātikāḥ dutīya phala ṭṭhānam siddham katvā tesam kāma loke eva  vasena sakim āgamanam aṭṭhakathāsu vuttanti daṭṭhabbam evam ca
translated: is given to them, it seems, after the second fruit, which is called “having a single birth,” has been established.🔽And it should be understood that the once-returners’ single return to the sense-desire world is stated in the commentaries in terms of their rebirth in the lower and higher planes there.

original: katvā pāḷiyaṃpi pañcannaṃ idha niṭṭhā sattakkhattuparamassa kolaṃkolassa ekabījissa
analyzed: katvā pāḷiyam pi pañcannam idha niṭṭhā satta kkhattu paramassa kolaṃkolassa ekabījissa
translated: And in that case, the following passage in the texts is appropriate: “Five here complete their path, Seven at most, and one at most🔽With one more birth, and one who’s free From searching finds perfection” .

original: sakadāgāmissa yoca diṭṭheva dhamme arahāti vuttanti. Sopana chabbidho hoti. Idhapatvā🔽idhaparinibbāyī, tattha patvā tattha parinibbāyī, idhapatvā tattha parinibbāyī, tattha
analyzed: sakadāgāmissa yaḥ ca diṭṭhe iva dhamme arahā ati vuttanti saḥ upana chabbidhaḥ hoti  idha parinibbāyī tattha patvā tattha parinibbāyī idha patvā tattha parinibbāyī tattha
translated: The Non-Returner is of six kinds:

original: patvā idha parinibbāyī, idhapatvā tatthanibbattitvā idha parinibbāyī. Tatthapatvā🔽idhanibbattitvā tatthaparinibbāyīti. Tattha idha patvā idha parinibbāyīti idha manussabhave🔽sakadāgāmimaggaṃ patvā idhamanussa bhaveyeva arahattamaggaṃ labhitvā parinibbāyanadhammo.
analyzed: patvā idha parinibbāyī idha patvā tattha nibbattitvā idha parinibbāyī tattha patvā  idha nibbattitvā tattha parinibbāyīti tattha idha patvā idha parinibbāyīti idha manussa bhave  sakadāgāmi maggam patvā bhaveya iva arahatta maggam labhitvā parinibbāyana dhammo
translated: one who attains Nibbāna early in the life, one who attains Nibbāna late in life, one who attains Nibbāna by exerting, one who attains Nibbāna without exerting, one who attains Nibbāna by willpower, and one who is bound upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm.🔽Herein, one who attains Nibbāna early in life is one who attains Nibbāna after reaching the Non-Returner path in the human world and obtaining the Arahant path in the human world itself.🔽One who attains Nibbāna late in life is one who attains Nibbāna after reaching the Non-Returner path in the human world and obtaining the Arahant path in the deva world.

original: Tattha patvā tattha parinibbāyīti tasmiṃdevaloke sakadāgāmimaggaṃ patvā tasmiṃ devalokeyeva
analyzed: tattha patvā tattha parinibbāyi iti tasmin deva loke sakadāgāmi maggam patvā tasmin deva loke iya iva
translated: One who attains Nibbāna by exerting is one who attains Nibbāna after reaching the Non-Returner path in the human world and obtaining the Arahant path in the deva world by exerting.🔽One who attains Nibbāna without exerting is one who attains Nibbāna after reaching the Non-Returner path in the human world and obtaining the Arahant path in the deva world without exerting.🔽One who attains Nibbāna by willpower is one who attains Nibbāna after reaching the Non-Returner path in the human world and obtaining the Arahant path in the deva world by willpower.

original: arahattamaggaṃ labhitvā parinibbāyanadhammo. Nibbattitvāti paṭisandhiggahaṇavasena
analyzed: arahatta maggam labhitvā parinibbāyana dhammaḥ nibbattitvā iti paṭisandhi ggahaṇa vasena
translated: One who is bound upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm, is one who attains Nibbāna after reaching the Non-Returner path in the human world and obtaining the Arahant path in the Akaniṭṭha realm.

original: uppajjitvā. Yesaṃ pana imaṃ lokanti padassa imaṃ manussalokanti attho. Tesaṃ so pañcavidhoyeva
analyzed: uppajjitvā yesam pana imam lokan ti padassa imam manussa lokan ti attho tesam so pañcavidhaḥ yeva
translated: and he is reborn there.

original: vutto, na chaṭṭho puggalo.
analyzed: vuttaḥ na chaṭṭhaḥ puggalo
translated: But those who take the words of this world to mean the human world, for them the five kinds of once-returner are stated here, not the sixth kind.

original: Vibhāvaniyañca
analyzed: vibhāvaniyañ ca
translated: And it is said in the Vibhaṅga:

original: “Pañcasu sakadāgāmīsu pañcamakova idhādhippeto, so hi ito gantvā puna sakiṃ idha āgacchatī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pañcasu sakadāgāmīsu pañcamakaḥ u va idha adhippeto so hi itas gantvā puna sakim idha āgacchati iti vuttam
translated: “The fifth of the five kinds of once-returner is intended here. For he returns once from that world and comes here” .

original: Mahāparinibbāna suttaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana mahāvagga saṃyuttaṭṭhakathā yañca sopi chaṭṭho🔽puggalo sakiṃ āgamanaṭṭhena āgatoyeva. Yasmāca sabbaññubuddhāpi yāva uparimaggo nāgacchati.
analyzed: mahāparinibbāna sutta ṭṭhakathā ayam pana mahā vagga saṃyutta ṭṭhakathā yam ca saḥ api chaṭṭhaḥ  puggalaḥ sakim āgamana ṭṭhena āgataḥ yeva yasmā ca sabbaññu buddhāḥ api yāva upari maggaḥ na āgacchati
translated: But in the Mahāparinibbāna Sutta Commentary, in the commentary on the passage in the Mahāvagga, it is said that the sixth kind of once-returner is also a once-returner in the sense of returning once.🔽And since even Buddhas who are omniscient remain as far as the state of the eighth-lowest rebirth as long as the path to the highest fruit has not appeared,

original: Tāva pathamaphalaṭṭhabhūtā sattakkhattu paramatāyaṃviya dutīyaphalaṭṭhabhūtā sakiṃ
analyzed: tāva pathama phala aṭṭha bhūtā dutīya phala aṭṭha bhūtā
translated: they remain as far as the state of the once-returner as long as the path to the second fruit has not appeared.🔽So no one who has reached the second fruit is a once-returner in the strict sense of the word,

original: āgamanappakatiyaṃ saṇṭhitāyeva honti. Tasmā idha koci dutīyaphalaṭṭho sakiṃ āgamanaṭṭhena
analyzed: āgamana ppakatiyam saṇṭhitāya iva honti tasmai idha koci dutīya phala ṭṭho āgamana ṭṭhena
translated: that is to say, as a returner who returns once.

original: nippariyāyena sakadā gāmīnāma na nahotīti sabbopi so chabbidho puggalo idha nippariyāyena
analyzed: nippariyāyena sakadā gāmī nāma na nahoti iti sabbaḥ api saḥ chabbidhaḥ puggalaḥ idha nippariyāyena
translated: So all six kinds of once-returner are not once-returners in the strict sense of the word.

original: sakadāgāmiyevanāma hotīti daṭṭhabbo. Sakadā gāmissa maggo sakadāgāmimaggo. So hi🔽sayaṃ janakabhūto sakadāgāmīnaṃ janetabbaṃ janetīti idha janetabba janakasambandhena
analyzed: sakadāgāmi yevanāma hoti iti daṭṭhabbo sakadāgāmissa maggo sakadāgāmi maggo so hi  sayam janaka bhūtaḥ sakadāgāmīnam janetabbam janeti iti idha janetabba janaka sambandhena
translated: It should be regarded as the path of the once-returner.🔽For that is the path that generates the once-returner who is the generator of those to be generated. So here the relation of the qualified and the qualifier is established by the relation of the generator and the generated.

original: visesana visesitabbatā ñāyāgatā eva hoti. Yathā tissamātā phussamātāti.
analyzed: visesana visesitabba tā ñāyā āgatā eva hoti yathā tissamātā phussamātā ati
translated: Just as “mother of Tissa,” “mother of Phussa.”

original: [57] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhānga

original: Sāñāyāgatāeva nahoti. Payojanaṃ pana kiñci atthi. Payojanavasena aviruddhā hotīti
analyzed: payojanam pana kiñci atthi payojana vasena a viruddhā hoti iti
translated: it is not established by the relation of the generated and the generator. But there is some purpose in it. It is not contradicted by the purpose.

original: iminā adhippāyenayaṃ vuttaṃ “kiñcāpi maggasamaṅgino tathāgamanāsambhavato phalaṭṭhoyeva🔽sakadāgāmīnāma. Tassapana kāraṇabhūto purimuppanno maggo maggantarāvacchedanatthaṃ
analyzed: iminā adhippāyena ayam vuttam kiñca api magga samaṅgino tathā āgamana asambhavataḥ  sakadāgāmī nāma kāraṇa bhūtaḥ purima uppannaḥ maggaḥ magga antara avacchedana attham
translated: So it is said with this intention: “Although the state of being a once-returner is only the fruit for those who possess the path,

original: phalaṭṭhena visesetvā vuccati sakadāgāmimaggoti. Evaṃ anāgāmimaggo”ti. Taṃ na yujjati.
analyzed: phala ṭṭhena visesetvā vuccati sakadāgāmi maggo ti evam anāgāmi maggo ti tam na yujjati
translated: nevertheless the path that is the cause of that is stated as the path of the once-returner by distinguishing it as the fruit for the purpose of distinguishing it from the other path. So too the path of the non-returner.” That is incorrect.

original: Sakadāgāmimaggena sampayuttaṃ cittanti samāso.
analyzed: sakadāgāmi maggena sampayuttam cittan ti samāsaḥ
translated: The compound sakadāgāmimagga is a bahubbīhi compound, meaning “the mind associated with the path of the once-returner.”

original: 59. Orabbhāgiyasaṃyojanānaṃ sabbaso samucchinnattā paṭisandhivasena puna imaṃ kāmalokaṃ🔽na āgacchatīti anāgāmī. Ekantena brahmalokaparāyanoeva hotīti attho. Idañca kevalaṃ🔽imassa maggassa ānubhāvavaseneva vuttaṃ. Uparimagga vipassanāya pana āgatāya so tasmiṃ
analyzed: orabbhāgiya saṃyojanānam sabbaso samucchinna ttā paṭisandhi vasena puna imam kāmalokam  na āgacchati iti anāgāmī ekantena brahma loka parāyanaḥ eva hoti iti idam ca kevalam  imassa maggassa ānubhāva vasena iva vuttam upari magga vipassanāya pana āgatāya saḥ tasmin
translated: Because he has completely severed the fetters pertaining to the lower world, he does not come back to this world of sensual pleasure by way of rebirth. The meaning is that he goes only to the Brahma-world. And this is said only by way of the power of this path. But when the higher path of insight has arisen, he goes to the highest place, the highest world, the highest security from bondage, the highest refuge, the highest state.

original: ṭhāneyeva arahatta maggaparāyanopi hotiyeva. Anāgāmissa tatīyaphalaṭṭhassamaggo.
analyzed: ṭhāneyā iva arahatta magga parāyanaḥ api anāgāmissa tatīya phala ṭṭha samaggo
translated: Because he has completely severed the fetters that lead to the lower worlds, he does not come back to this world of sensual pleasures by way of rebirth. This is the meaning. And this is said only by way of the power of this path. But when the higher path of insight has arisen, he is also one who has reached the path to arahatship in that same place. The path of the non-returner is the third path.

original: Tena sampayuttaṃ cittanti viggaho.
analyzed: tena sampayuttam cittam ti viggahaḥ
translated: The mind associated with that is the third kind of consciousness.

original: 60. Mahapphalakāritāguṇayogena pūjāvisesaṃ arahatīti arahā. Khīṇāsavo catutthaphalaṭṭho.
analyzed: mahat phala kāri tā guṇa yogena pūjā visesam arahati iti arahā khīṇa āsavaḥ catuttha phala ṭṭho
translated: He is worthy of the highest offerings because he possesses the special qualities of great fruitfulness and helpfulness. This is the meaning of “worthy” . The fourth path is the state of one whose cankers are destroyed.

original: Arahato bhāvo arahattaṃ, catutthaphalaṃ. Tassa maggo. Tena sampayuttacittanti nibbacanaṃ.
analyzed: arahataḥ bhāvaḥ arahattam catuttha phalam tassa maggo tena sampayutta cittan ti nibbacanam
translated: The state of the arahat is arahatship, the fourth path. The path of the arahat is the fourth kind of consciousness.

original: Pisaddena pāḷiyaṃ vibhatte maggacittappabhede sampiṇḍeti. Tattha dhammasaṅgaṇiyaṃ
analyzed: pi saddena pāḷiyam vibhatte magga citta ppabhede sampiṇḍeti tattha dhammasaṅgaṇiyam
translated: Having analyzed the different kinds of consciousness belonging to the path in the text in a scattered way, the author now combines them.

original: tāva pathamamagge jhānanāmena vuttesu pañcasu vāresu pathame suddhikapaṭipadāvāredvinnaṃ🔽catukkapañcakanayānaṃ vasena navacittāni honti. Tathā suddhikasuññatāya suññatappaṭipadāya
analyzed: pathama magge jhāna nāmena vuttesu pañcasu vāresu pathame  vasena nava cittāni honti tathā suddhika suññatāya suññata paṭipadāya
translated: Similarly, in the case of the five divisions beginning with the pure void and the void path,

original: suddhikappaṇihite appaṇihitappaṭipadāyacāti pañcasu vāresu dasannaṃ nayānaṃ vasena
analyzed: suddhika paṇihite pañcasu vāresu dasannam vasena
translated: the pure signless and the signless path, and the pure desireless and the desireless path, there are fifty-four kinds of consciousness in all in the case of the ten methods.

original: pañcacattālīsacittāni honti. Tathā maggasatipaṭṭhānādīhi ekūnavīsatiyā nāmehi vuttesu
analyzed: pañcacattālīsa cittāni honti tathā magga sati paṭṭhāna ādīhi ekūnavīsatiyā nāmehi vuttesu
translated: Similarly, in the case of the hundred divisions mentioned under the twenty-one names beginning with the path and the foundations of mindfulness,

original: paccekaṃ pañcasu vāresūti vīsatiyā nāmehi vutte vārasate dvinnaṃ nayasatānaṃ vasena
analyzed: paccekam pañcasu vāresu iti vīsatiyā nāmehi vutte vāra sate dvinnam naya satānam vasena
translated: there are a hundred times nine, that is, nine hundred, in the case of the two hundred methods in the twenty names beginning with the five divisions in each of the twenty.

original: navacittasatāni honti. Puna catūhi adhipatīhi yojetvā vuttesu catūsu vārasatesu aṭṭhannaṃ
analyzed: nava citta satāni honti puna catūhi adhipatīhi yojetvā vuttesu catūsu vāra satesu
translated: Again, in the case of the four hundred divisions mentioned under the four dominants, there are three thousand six hundred in the case of the eight hundred methods in the four hundred divisions.🔽So in the first path there are four thousand five hundred in the case of the thousand methods.

original: nayasatānaṃ vasena tīṇi sahassāni chasatānica hontīti. Evaṃ pathamamagge naya sahassavasena🔽cattāricittasahassāni pañcacitta satānica honti. Tathā sesamaggesupīti evaṃ catūsu
analyzed: naya satānam vasena tīṇi sahassāni cha satāni ca honti iti evam pathama magge naya sahassa vasena 🔽cattāri citta sahassāni pañca citta satāni ca honti tathā sesa maggesu pi iti evam catūsu
translated: Similarly in the case of the other three paths.

original: maggesu catunnaṃ naya sahassānaṃ vasena aṭṭhārasa magga citta sahassāni honti. Saccasatipaṭṭhāna
analyzed: maggesu catunnam naya sahassānam vasena aṭṭhārasa magga citta sahassāni honti sacca satipaṭṭhāna
translated: There are eighteen thousand path-consciousness types by means of the four paths and the four hundred ways.

original: vibhaṅgesu pana vīsatinaya sahassānaṃ vasena navutimaggacittasahassāni. Maggavibhaṅge
analyzed: vibhaṅgesu pana vasena navuti magga citta sahassāni magga vibhaṅge
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga there are ninety thousand path-consciousness types by means of the twenty thousand ways.

original: aṭṭhavīsatiyā naya sahassānaṃ vasena satasahassaṃ chabbīsatisahassāni ca maggacittāni🔽hontīti. Aṭṭhakathāsupana nayabhedāeva vuttā. Nacitta bhedāti.
analyzed: aṭṭhavīsatiyā naya sahassānam vasena sata sahassam chabbīsati sahassāni ca magga cittāni  honti iti aṭṭhakathāsu pana naya bhedāḥ eva vuttā
translated: In the Magga-vibhaṅga there are a hundred and sixty-six thousand path-consciousness types by means of the twenty-eight thousand ways.

original: [58] Yaṃpana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yaṃpana vibhāvaniyam
translated: But in the commentaries only the different ways are mentioned, not the different consciousness types.

original: Pisaddena saccavibhaṅge āgataṃ saṭṭhisahassabhedaṃ nayaṃ saṅgaṇhātīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ imasmiṃ kusalanigame na vattabbaṃ.🔽Sohi saṭṭhisahassabhedo nayo vipākaṭṭhāneeva aṭṭhakathāyaṃ āgatoti.
analyzed: pi saddena sacca vibhaṅge āgatam saṭṭhi sahassa bhedam nayam saṅgaṇhāti iti vuttam tam imasmin kusala nigame na vattabbam  saḥ hi saṭṭhi sahassa bhedaḥ nayaḥ vipāka ṭṭhāne eva aṭṭhakathā ayam āgato ti
translated: And in the Vibhāvinī-ṭīkā it is said that the sixty thousand ways stated in the Sacca-vibhaṅga are included in the four hundred ways. But that should not be said in this treatise on what is skillful.

original: [59] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: For that sixty thousand ways are stated in the commentary only as the result of the twenty-eight thousand ways.

original: Paṭipadābhedaṃ anāmasitvā kevalaṃ suññato appaṇihi toti dvidhā vibhattoti vuttaṃ. Taṃ nayujjati.
analyzed: paṭipadā bhedam an āmasitvā kevalam dvidhā vibhatto ti vuttam tam na yujjati
translated: And it is said there that the four hundred ways are divided into two kinds, namely, “by means of emptiness and by means of non-adhesion,” without mentioning the division of the ways according to the paths. That is not correct.

original: Pāḷiyañhi paṭipadābhedo ādimhiyeva āgatoti. Naca ādimhi suññato appaṇihitoti dvidhā vibhatto nirantaravāro atthīti.
analyzed: pāḷiyam hi paṭipadā bhedaḥ ādimhi yeva āgato ti na ca ādimhi suññataḥ appaṇihito ti dvidhā vibhatto nirantara vāraḥ atthi iti
translated: For the classification of the path by way of jhāna is given at the very beginning of the text. And there is no section on the emptiness and desireless liberations that is divided into two parts, one after the other.

original: [60] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And the intention of the passage:

original: Suññato eko nayo, appaṇihito eko, paṭipadā visiṭṭhā suññatā cattāro, appaṇihitā cattāroti
analyzed: suññataḥ ekaḥ nayaḥ appaṇihitaḥ ekaḥ paṭipadā visiṭṭhā suññatā cattāro appaṇihitā cattāro ti
translated: “One way is emptiness, one way is desireless; the distinguished path is fourfold in emptiness, fourfold in desireless,”

original: katvā dasanayā hontīti adhippāyena evaṃ jhāna nāmena dasadhā vibhattoti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na yujjatiyeva.
analyzed: katvā dasanayā honti iti adhippāyena evam jhāna nāmena dasadhā vibhattoti vuttam tat pi na yujjati eva
translated: is to show that the ten ways are divided into ten by way of the name of the jhāna. But that is not correct.

original: Na hi suññatādayo idha nayānāma honti. Tesu pana eke kasmiṃ dve dve catukkapañcakanayāeva
analyzed: na hi suññata ādayaḥ idha nayā nāma honti tesu pana eke kasmim dve dve catukka pañcaka nayā eva
translated: For emptiness, etc., are not called ways here. But rather, two of them, namely emptiness and desireless, are each divided into four and five ways respectively.

original: idha nayānāmāti. Etena tathā maggasatipaṭṭhāniccādikaṃpi sabbaṃ paṭikkhittaṃ hotīti. [Maggacittaṃ]🔽61. Phalacitte phalanti vipākabhūto aṭṭhaṅgika maggo. Sampayuttadhammasamūhovā. Sotāpattiyā
analyzed: idha naya anāmā ti etena tathā magga sati paṭṭhā anicca ādikam pi sabbam paṭikkhittam hoti iti magga cittam  phala citte phalanti vipāka bhūto aṭṭhaṅgika maggo sampayutta dhamma samūho vā sa utāpattiyā
translated: So it is only these that are called ways here. And by this it is also rejected that the path, the establishment of mindfulness, etc., are the ten ways.

original: adhigataṃ phalaṃ. Tena sampayuttaṃ, tatthavā pariyāpannaṃ cittanti sotāpatti phala
analyzed: adhigatam phalam tena sampayuttam tatthavā pariyāpannam cittam
translated: The fruit is the eightfold path in the state of fruition, or the collection of associated states. The fruit of stream-entry is the attainment of the fruit of stream-entry. Associated with that, included in that, is the consciousness called the fruit of stream-entry.

original: cittaṃ. Esanayo dutīyatatīyesupi. Arahattañca taṃ phalañcāti arahattaphalaṃ. Tena
analyzed: cittam dutīya tatīye supi arahattam ca tam phalam ca ati arahatta phalam tena
translated: and mind. The search is the second and third. And that is Arahantship and that is fruition: thus Arahantship-fruit. By that

original: sampayuttaṃ, tasmiṃvā pariyāpannaṃ cittanti nirutti.🔽62. Saṅgahagāthāyaṃ catumaggappabhedenāti catukkhattuṃ pattabbattā catubbidhānaṃ
analyzed: sampayuttam tasmin vā pariyāpannam cittam ti nirutti  saṅgaha gāthāyam catu magga ppabhedena ati catu khattum pattabba ttā catu bidhānam
translated: and mind. The second and third are the same as the first. And it is the fruit of Arahantship, thus it is the fruit of Arahantship. It is associated with that, or it is included in that, thus it is mind.🔽In the verse of inclusion:🔽By the classification of the four paths: by the classification of the four kinds of eight-factored paths that can be reached in four ways.

original: aṭṭhaṅgikamaggānaṃ pabhedena. Kasmāpana te catukkhattuṃ pattabbāti. Vuccate. Sotāpattimagge
analyzed: aṭṭhaṅgika maggānam pabhedena kasmā apana te catukkhattum pattabbā iti vuccate sotāpatti magge
translated: But why can they be reached in four ways? It may be stated as follows.

original: tāva saddhādīni indriyāni mudūni honti, tasmā so diṭṭhivicikicchāeva samucchindituṃ🔽sakkoti. Aññepana kāmarāgabyāpādepi tanubhūtepi kātuṃ nasakkoti. Dutīyamagge tāni🔽thokaṃ paṭūni honti. Tasmā so kāmarāgabyāpāde tanubhūte kātuṃ sakkoti. Samucchindituṃ
analyzed: saddhā ādīni indriyāni mudūni honti tasmā saḥ diṭṭhi vicikicchā eva samucchinditum  sakkoti kāma rāga byāpāde api tanu bhūte api kātum na sakkoti dutīya magge tāni  thokam paṭūni honti tasmā saḥ kāma rāga byāpāde tanu bhūte kātum sakkoti samucchinditum
translated: In the first place, in the path of stream-entry the faculties of faith, etc., are weak, and so he can only cut off wrong view and uncertainty,🔽but he cannot make lust and ill will that are already subdued still more attenuated. In the second path the faculties are slightly stronger, and so he can make lust and ill will that are already subdued still more attenuated,🔽but he cannot cut them off. In the third path the faculties are stronger still, and so he can cut off lust and ill will that are already subdued,

original: pana nasakkohiyeva. Tatīyamagge tāni paṭutarāni honti. Tasmā so kāmarāgabyāpāde samucchindituṃ
analyzed: pana tatīya magge tāni paṭutarāni honti tasmā saḥ kāma rāga byāpāde samucchinditum
translated: but he cannot make them extremely attenuated. In the fourth path the faculties are still stronger, and so he can make lust and ill will extremely attenuated,🔽but he cannot cut them off.

original: sakkoti. Rūpārūpa rāgamānuddhaccāvijjāyopana samucchindituṃ nasakkotiyeva. Catuttha🔽maggepana tāni indriyāni paṭutamāni honti. Tasmā so tāca aññeca sabbepi pāpadhamme
analyzed: samucchinditum samucchinditum  tāni indriyāni paṭutamāni honti tasmā so aññe ca sabbe pi pāpa dhamme
translated: and he is able to cut off the subtler forms of greed for the fine-material and immaterial, and the delusion, conceit, and restlessness associated with them.🔽In the fourth path these faculties are still more powerful, and so he is able to cut off all the remaining imperfections.

original: samucchindituṃ sakkoti. Evaṃ catukkhattuṃ pavattamānāeva pariniṭṭhitakiccattā te
analyzed: samucchinditum sakkoti evam catu khattum pavattamānā eva pariniṭṭhita kicca ttā te
translated: So the paths are to be reached in four stages because they have four functions to perform.

original: maggā catukkhattuṃ pattabbā hontīti. Kusalaṃ cittaṃ catumaggappabhedena catudhā mataṃ.
analyzed: maggāḥ catu khattum pattabbāḥ honti iti kusalam cittam catu magga ppabhedena catudhā matam
translated: The profitable consciousness is considered as fourfold by way of the four paths.

original: Pākaṃpi tassa catubbidhassa kusalassa phalattā tathā catudhāmataṃ. Iti anuttaraṃ
analyzed: tassa catubbidhassa kusalassa phalattā tathā iti anuttaram
translated: And its fruition is also considered as fourfold because it is the fruit of that fourfold profitable .🔽So the unsurpassed consciousness is considered as eightfold.

original: cittaṃ aṭṭhadhā matanti yojanā. Natthi attano uttaraṃ adhikaṃ etassāti anuttaraṃ.
analyzed: cittam aṭṭhadhā matanti yojanā na atthi attanaḥ uttaram adhikam etassa ati anuttaram
translated: It has no higher, that is, no greater, than itself.🔽Why is the functional consciousness not included here? Because there is no unsurpassed function.

original: 63. Kasmā panettha kriyacittaṃnāmana gahitanti, kriyānuttarassa abhāvāti, kasmā panassa
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha gahitanti kriyā anuttarassa abhāvā ati kasmā pana assa
translated: But why is there none?🔽Because the path consciousness is a single moment.

original: abhāvoti. Maggacittassa ekacittakkhaṇikattāti. Yadi hi taṃ lokiyakusalaṃviya nānākkhaṇesu
analyzed: abhāvaḥ ti magga cittassa eka citta khaṇika ttā ti yadi hi tam nānā kkhaṇesu
translated: For if it were a number of moments like the mundane profitable, then it would not be the path of arahatship.

original: pavatteyya. Tadā niranusayasantānepi pavattitvā kriyā nuttaraṃnāma siyāti. Kasmāpana
analyzed: tadā niranusaya santāne pi kriyā siyāti
translated: and it would be called “superlative action” even though it had occurred in a continuity devoid of underlying tendencies.🔽But why does it occur only for a single conscious moment?

original: taṃ ekacittakkhaṇikameva hotīti. Maggassa mahānubhāvattāti. Kathañca mahānubhāvoti.
analyzed: tat eka citta khaṇikam eva hoti iti maggassa mahā anubhāva ttā ati kathañca mahā anubhāvaḥ ti
translated: Because the path is of great potency. And how is it of great potency?

original: Vuccate. Ariyamaggohi nāma sakiṃ pavattamānoyeva attanā pahātabbe kilese puna anuppādadhammataṃ🔽āpādetvā pajahati. Ayamassa eko ānubhāvo. Vipākañca kusalakriyajavanaṃviya javanakicca
analyzed: vuccate ariya maggaḥ hi nāma sakim pavattamānaḥ yā iva attanā pahātabbe kilese puna anuppāda dhamma tat  āpādetvā pajahati ayam assa ekaḥ ānubhāvaḥ vipākam ca
translated: It is said: for when the noble path occurs it causes the defilements to be abandoned by it to become non- liable to arise again.

original: yuttaṃ yadā kadāci samāpajjanakkhamañca katvā attano anantarato paṭṭhāya janeti.
analyzed: yuttam yadā kadāci samāpajjana khamam ca katvā attanaḥ anantarataḥ paṭṭhāya janeti
translated: This is its first potency. And it generates the profitable javanas that are its fruition, as if they were its own function, and it makes them capable of being attained by the attainment of cessation.

original: Ayamassa dutīyo ānubhāvo. Tasmā tassa kilesappahānatthāyapi puna uppādetabbakiccaṃnāma
analyzed: ayam assa dutīyaḥ ānubhāvaḥ tasmā tassa kilesa ppahāna tthāya api punar
translated: This is its second potency. So there is no function that needs to be performed again for the purpose of abandoning defilements,

original: natthi. Tathā samāpatti atthāyapīti. Sacepi hi koci ahaṃ phalaṃ samāpajjituṃ na icchāmi.
analyzed: natthi tathā samāpatti atthāya api iti sace pi hi koci aham phalam samāpajjitum na icchāmi
translated: nor for the purpose of attaining the attainment of cessation. For even if someone were to make preliminary work and think, “I do not want to attain the fruition;

original: Pubbe laddhaṃ maggameva samāpajjissāmīti parikammaṃ kareyya. Tadā pubbe sakiṃ uppajjitvā
analyzed: pubbe laddham maggam eva samāpajjissāmi iti parikammam kareyya tadā pubbe sakim uppajjitvā
translated: I shall attain the path that I have already attained,” then the path that had already occurred once would occur again.

original: niruddhamaggacetanānubhāvena phalacittameva pavatteyya. Na maggacittaṃ. Kasmā, appaṭibāhi
analyzed: niruddha magga cetanā anubhāvena phala cittam eva pavatteyya na magga cittam kasmai
translated: and the fruit consciousness would occur by the force of the path consciousness that has ceased. Not the path consciousness. Why?

original: yānubhāvattā maggassa. Ayañhi maggānubhāvonāma kenaci chandena vā vasenavā ajjhāsayenavā🔽parikammenavā paṭibāhituṃ asakkuṇeyyoyeva hotīti.
analyzed: yā anubhāva ttā maggassa ayam hi magga anubhāvaḥ nāma kenaci chandena vā vasena vā ajjhāsayena vā  parikammena vā paṭibāhitum hoti iti
translated: Because the path is not capable of being obstructed. For this so-called force of the path is incapable of being obstructed by any desire, or by any influence, or by any wish, or by any effort.

original: 64. Dvādasākusalānevantiādi sabbesaṃ catubbhūmaka cittānaṃ jātivasena saṅgaho. Evaṃ🔽iminā vuttappakārena akusa lāni dvādasevahonti. Kusalāni ekavīsatieva. Vipākānichattiṃ
analyzed: sabbesam cittānam jāti vasena saṅgahaḥ evam  iminā vutta ppakārena akusalāni kusalāni
translated: . The twelve unprofitable kinds, etc. is the inclusion of all the four-plane consciousnesses by way of their kinds. Thus🔽they are of the kind called unprofitable only. The profitable are of the kind called profitable only. The resultant are of the kind called resultant only. The functional are of the kind called functional only.

original: seva. Kriyacittāni vīsatievāti ṭīkāyaṃ yojīyati. Kecipana kusalānaṃ vipākānañca uparivaḍḍhamānattāevasaddaṃ🔽ādiantapadesveva yojesuṃ. Catupaññāsadhātiādi bhūmivasena saṅgaho. Kāmepariyā pannāni
analyzed: kriya cittāni ṭīkā ayam kusalānam vipākānam ca  ādi anta padesu eva bhūmi vasena saṅgahaḥ pannāni
translated: . The commentary explains the inclusion by way of plane thus: “The profitable are of twenty-one kinds. The resultant are of thirty-six kinds. The functional are of twenty kinds.” But some have explained the inclusion by way of plane thus: “The profitable and the resultant are of twenty-one kinds. The functional are of twenty kinds.”

original: cittāni catupaññāsadhā īraye katheyya. Rūpe pannarasa. Arūpe dvādasa. Tathā anuttare
analyzed: cittāni catupaññāsadhā īraye katheyya rūpe pannarasa arūpe dvādasa tathā anuttare
translated: . The inclusion by way of plane is stated thus: “He would describe the consciousnesses that occur in the sense sphere as being of fifty-four kinds, in the fine-material sphere as being of fifteen kinds, in the immaterial sphere as being of twelve kinds, and in the supramundane sphere as being of four kinds.”

original: pariyāpannāni cittāni aṭṭhadhā īrayeti yojanā. Etthaca anuttareti lokuttara bhūmiyaṃ.
analyzed: pariyāpannāni cittāni aṭṭhadhā īraya iti yojanā etthaca anuttarā iti lokuttara bhūmi iyaṃ
translated: The interpretation is: “The eight kinds of consciousness that are included in the supramundane plane of the path are called ‘the supramundane plane of the path.’ ”

original: Sā pana duvidhā saṅkhatabhūmi, asaṅkhatabhūmīti. Saṅkhatāpi catubbidhā. Yathāha –
analyzed: sā pana duvidhā saṅkhata bhūmi asaṅkhata bhūmi iti saṅkhatā api catubbidhā yathā āha
translated: And this is twofold as the formed plane and the unformed plane. The formed plane is also fourfold, according as it is said:

original: Yasmiṃ samaye lokuttaraṃ jhānaṃ bhāveti pathamāya bhūmiyā pattiyā.La. Dutīyāya.La. Tatīyāya.La. Catutthāya bhūmiyā pattiyāti.
analyzed: yasmin samaye lokuttaram jhānam bhāveti pathamāya bhūmiyā dutīyāyala tatīyāyala catutthāya bhūmiyā
translated: “At whatever time he develops the supramundane jhāna … for the attainment of the first … second … third … fourth plane” .

original: Tattha bhūmīti sāmaññaphalaṃ adhippetanti vuttaṃ. Pathamamaggaphalayu gaḷaṃvā pathamabhūmi.La.
analyzed: tattha bhūmi iti sāmañña phalam adhippetanti vuttam
translated: Herein, the “plane” is intended as the fruition of the path. The pair of first path and fruition is the first plane.

original: Catuttha maggaphala yugaḷaṃ catutthabhūmīti evaṃpi yujjatiyeva. Atthatopana rāgattayapariggahavimuttiyā
analyzed: catuttha magga phala catuttha bhūmī iti rāga ttaya pariggaha vimuttiyā
translated: The pair of fourth path and fruition is the fourth plane. This is also appropriate. But in the true sense the term “plane” is a term for a particular state consisting in the formed, which is endowed with a particular kind of relinquishment of the three kinds of lust,

original: tebhūmakadhammesu apariyāpannatā saṅkhātena avatthā visesena yutto dhammaviseso.
analyzed: tebhūmaka dhammesu apariyāpanna tā saṅkhātena avatthā visesena yuttaḥ dhamma viseso
translated: and with a particular kind of distinction of states that is not included among the states of the three planes.

original: Soca kilesappahāna visesena catubbidho jātoti.
analyzed: catubbidhaḥ jātaḥ ti
translated: And that is fourfold according as it is distinguished by the particular kinds of abandoning of defilements.

original: [61] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: Itarabhūmiyoviya lokuttarabhūmināma visuṃ natthi. Nava vidhadhammasamūhoeva tesaṃ🔽bhūmipariyāyoti katvā yaṃ vuttaṃ. “Katthaci apariyāpannāni navavidhalokuttara dhammasamūhekadesabhūtāni
analyzed: lokuttara bhūmiyo viya lokuttara bhūmi nāma visum natthi nava vidha dhamma samūhaḥ eva tesam  bhūmi pariyāyaḥ iti katvā yam vuttam katthaci a pariyāpannāni navavidha lokuttara dhamma samūha eka desa bhūtāni
translated: The supramundane states have no separate plane of their own, like the other planes. They are simply a group of nine kinds of states.🔽So it is said: “In some places the supramundane states are called ‘the unsurpassed states of consciousness’ as a group consisting of the nine kinds of states that are not included in the planes” .

original: rukkhe sākhā tyādīsu viya anuttare cittānīti vuttānī”ti. Taṃ nayujjati.
analyzed: rukkhe sākhā tyādīsu viya anuttare cittāni iti vuttāni iti tam
translated: That is not correct.

original: Duvidhāhi bhūmi avatthābhūmi, okāsabhūmīti. Tattha avatthā bhūmieva nippariyāyabhūmi.
analyzed: duvidhā hi bhūmi avatthā bhūmi okāsa bhūmi iti tattha avatthā bhūmi eva nippariyāya bhūmi
translated: The planes are of two kinds, that is to say, the plane of being and the plane of location. Herein, the plane of being is only the plane of being in the ultimate sense ;

original: Na itarā. Sā hi okāsabhūmināma dhammānaṃ taṃ taṃ avatthāvisesavaseneva siddhāti.
analyzed: na itarā sā hi okāsa bhūmi nāma dhammānam tam tam avatthā avisesa vasena iva siddhā ati
translated: not the other. For that is established only by the difference in the particular plane of being of the states called the plane of location.

original: Taṃ taṃ avatthā visesotica heṭṭhā vuttanayena kāmāvacaratādi avatthā viseso daṭṭhabbo.🔽Apica ekattiṃsabhūmiyopi kusalākusaladhammānaṃ hīnapaṇītaoḷārikasukhumatā saṅkhātehi
analyzed: tam tam avatthā visesaḥ ti ca heṭṭhā vutta nayena kāmāvacara tā ādi avatthā visesaḥ daṭṭhabbo  apica ekattiṃsa bhūmiyaḥ pi kusala akusala dhammānam hīna paṇīta oḷārika sukhuma tā saṅkhātehi
translated: And the difference in the particular plane of being should be understood according to the method stated above as “the sensuous, etc., plane of being” .

original: avatthāvisesehieva sijjhantīti.
analyzed: avatthā avisesehi eva sijjhanti iti
translated: Besides, the twenty-one planes are established only by the difference in the particular planes of being called the inferior, superior, gross, and subtle planes of being of profitable and unprofitable states.

original: 65. Evaṃ catubbhūmaka cittāni saṅkhepato niddisitvā idāni puna vitthārato niddisanto
analyzed: evam catubbhūmaka cittāni saṅkhepataḥ niddisitvā idāni puna vitthārataḥ
translated: Having thus briefly indicated the kinds of consciousness belonging to the four planes, he now undertakes to indicate them again in detail,

original: itthantiādigāthamāha. Tatrāyaṃ yojanā. Athavāpana itthaṃ yathāvuttappakārena ekunanavutippabhedaṃ
analyzed: itthat iti ādi gātham āha tatra ayam yojanā athavā āpane ittham yathāvutta ppakārena eku na navu tippa bhedam
translated: beginning with the verse that begins “Thus.” Here is the construction:🔽Or else, the wise, the learned, divide the mind, which is of eighty-nine kinds in the way just stated,

original: mānasaṃ cittaṃ ekavīsasataṃ katvā vicakkhaṇā paṇḍitā vibhajantīti.
analyzed: mānasam cittam ekavīsa satam katvā vicakkhaṇāḥ paṇḍitāḥ vibhajanti iti
translated: into one hundred and twenty-one kinds.

original: [62] Ṭīkāsu pana
analyzed: ṭīkāsu pana
translated: But in the commentaries

original: Gāthāya pubbaddhaṃ purimagāthānaṃ nigamanaṃ katvā aparaddhameva ārabbhantaraṃ katvā yojenti. Taṃ kathamekūna navutividhaṃ cittaṃ ekavīsasataṃ hotīti iminā nasametīti.🔽Idāni taṃ ekavīsasatavibhāgaṃ dassento kathaṃ.La. Hotīti pucchitvā vitakkavicārapīti
analyzed: gāthāya pubbaddham purima gāthānam nigamanam katvā aparaddham eva ārabbhantaram katvā yojenti tam katham ekūna navutividham cittam ekavīsa satam hoti iti iminā nasam eti iti  idāni tam ekavīsa sata vibhāgam dassento katham la hoti iti pucchitvā
translated: the latter half of the verse is construed with the latter half of the preceding verse, and the former half with the former half. That is how they construe it.

original: sukhekaggatā sahitantiādimāha. Tattha pathamajjhāna sotāpattimaggacittanti ettha
analyzed: sukha ikagga tā sahita nti ādim āha tattha pathama jhāna sotāpatti magga cittan ti ettha
translated: Now, in order to show that division into one hundred and twenty-one, he asks, “How?” and then answers, “With applied thought and sustained thought, and happiness and bliss, and unification of mind, it is the first jhāna” , and so on. Herein,🔽in the passage “The first jhāna, the stream-entry path consciousness” ,

original: pañcaṅgikena pathamajjhānena yutto sotāpattimaggo pathamajjhānasotāpattimaggo. Tena
analyzed: pañcaṅgikena pathamajjhānena yutto sotāpatti maggo pathama jhāna sotāpatti maggo tena
translated: the stream-entry path is associated with the first jhāna consisting of five factors, thus it is the “first jhāna, the stream-entry path.” By that

original: sampayuttaṃ cittanti samāso.
analyzed: sampayuttam cittam ti samāsaḥ
translated: and the mind associated with it: this is the compound.

original: [63] Ṭīkāsu pana
analyzed: ṭīkāsu pana
translated: But in the commentaries

original: “Pathamajjhānañca taṃ sotāpattimaggacittañcā”ti yojenti. Taṃ na yuttaṃ.
analyzed: pathama jhānam ca tam sotāpatti magga cittam ca ati yojenti tam na yuttam
translated: they construe it as “the first jhāna and the stream-entry path mind.” That is incorrect.

original: Na hi jhānaṃ cittaṃ hoti. Naca cittaṃ jhānaṃ. Aññañhi jhānaṃ, aññaṃ cittanti.
analyzed: na hi jhānam cittam hoti na ca cittam jhānam aññan hi jhānam aññam cittanti
translated: For the jhāna is not the mind, nor is the mind the jhāna. The jhāna is one thing, the mind is another.

original: [64] Yañca vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yañca vibhāvaniyam
translated: And what is said in the Vibhaṅga

original: “Jhānaṅgavasena pathamajjhāna sadisattā pathamajjhānañcā”ti vuttaṃ. Tampi na yuttaṃ.
analyzed: jhāna aṅga vasena pathamajjhāna sadisa ttā pathamajjhānam ca iti vuttam tat pi na yuttam
translated: is also incorrect when it is stated thus: “It is the first jhāna because it is similar to the first jhāna in being possessed of the jhāna factors” .

original: Na hi pañcaṅgikaṃ lokuttarajjhānaṃ pathamajjhānasadisaṭṭhena pathamajjhānasaññaṃ
analyzed: na hi pañcaṅgikam lokuttara jhānam pathamajjhāna sadisaṭṭhena pathamajjhāna saññam
translated: For it cannot be said that the supramundane jhāna possessed of five factors obtains the name of the first jhāna by similarity to the first jhāna possessed of five factors.

original: labhatīti sakkā vattuṃ. Tañhi sayameva attano pañcaṅgikabhāvena nippariyāyato pathamajjhānaṃnāma
analyzed: labhati iti sakkā vattum tat hi sayam eva attanaḥ pañcaṅgika bhāvena nippariyāyato pathamajjhānaṃ nāma
translated: For that is called the first jhāna in the true sense of the term by possession of its own five factors.

original: hotīti. Idañhi jhānaṃnāma lokiyaṃvā hotu lokuttaraṃvā. Yaṃ pañcaṅgikaṃ hoti. Taṃ
analyzed: hoti iti idam hi jhānam nāma lokiyam vā hotu lokuttaram vā yam pañcaṅgikam hoti tam
translated: For this jhāna, whether it be mundane or supramundane, when it is possessed of five factors,

original: sayameva pathamajjhānanti siddhaṃ. Yaṃ caturaṅgikaṃ. Tiyaṅgikaṃ. Duvaṅgikaṃ. Puna
analyzed: sayam eva siddham yam catur aṅgikam tiyaṅgikam duvaṅgikam punar
translated: it is established as the first jhāna by itself. But when it is possessed of four factors, three factors, two factors,

original: duvaṅgikaṃ. Taṃ sayameva pañcamajjhānanti siddhanti. Lokuttarevā dutīyādibhāvassa
analyzed: duvaṅgikam tam sayam eva pañcama jhānanti dutīya ādi bhāvassa
translated: and the fifth jhāna is the same as the first, only with the addition of equanimity as a fifth factor.

original: uppattikkamavasena asiddhattā evaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: uppatti kkama vasena asiddha ttā evam vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: But this is not so, because the second and higher jhāna are not established by the method of arising.

original: [65] Yañca tattha🔽Sadisabhāveneva lokuttare tesaṃ pañcaṅgikādīnaṃ jhāna vohārasiddhatādīpanatthaṃ.🔽“Pādakajjhāna sammasitajjhāna puggalajjhāsayesu hi aññataravasena taṃ taṃ jhānasadisattā
analyzed: yañca tattha  sadisa bhāvena iva lokuttare tesam pañcaṅgika ādīnam vohāra siddha tā dīpana ttham  hi aññatara vasena tam tam jhāna sadisa ttā
translated: And what is said there🔽is in order to show that the supramundane jhāna is called the first, second, etc., according to the mundane jhāna with which it is respectively associated.

original: vitakkādiaṅgapātubhāvena cattāropi maggā pathamajjhānādi vohāraṃ labhantā paccekaṃ
analyzed: vitakka ādi aṅga pātubhāvena cattāro api maggā pathama jhāna ādi vohāram labhantā paccekam
translated: For it is said: “The four paths are called the first jhāna, etc., according to which of the five jhānas they resemble in respect of the jhāna factors manifested, whether they be jhānas of access or of absorption or jhānas of a person of such and such a kind.

original: pañcadhā vibhajantī”ti vuttaṃ. Tampi nayujjatiyeva.
analyzed: pañcadhā vibhajanti iti vuttam tat pi
translated: And they are each divided into five classes according to the difference in the jhāna factors.”🔽But that is not correct.

original: Na hi maggā pathamajjhānādi vohāraṃ labhanti. Añño hi maggo, aññaṃ jhānanti. Apica,
analyzed: na hi maggā pathamajjhāna ādi vohāram labhanti aññaḥ hi maggaḥ aññam jhānanti apica
translated: For the paths are not called the first jhāna, etc., because the jhāna is one thing and the path another.🔽Besides,

original: yadi upanijjhāyanaṭṭhena paccanīkajjhāpanaṭṭhenaca jhānaṃnāma siyā. Tadā lokuttarajjhānānieva
analyzed: yadi upanijjhāyana ṭṭhena paccanīka jhāpana ṭṭhena ca jhānam nāma siyā tadā lokuttara jhānāni eva
translated: if jhāna were called so because of looking on and because of looking down, then only the supramundane jhānas would be jhāna.

original: sātisayato jhānānināma siyuṃ. Na itarāni. Tāni hi kasiṇādinimittamattaṃ upecca nijjhāyanti.🔽Paccanīkadhammeca vikkhambhanamattena jhāpenti. Lokuttarāniyevapana atigambhīraṃ
analyzed: siyum na itarāni tāni hi kasiṇa ādi nimitta mattam upecca nijjhāyanti  paccanīka dhamme ca vikkhambhana mattena jhāpenti ati gambhīram
translated: They are called “absorptions” in the sense of “they absorb” in the way already stated. The others are not. For they absorb by merely taking the sign of the kasiṇa, and so on, as their object.

original: abhiduddasaṃ nibbānaṃ upecca nijjhāyanti. Paccanīkadhammeca samūle sānusaye sabbaso
analyzed: abhiduddasam nibbānam upecca nijjhāyanti paccanīka dhamme ca sa mūle sa anusaye sabbaso
translated: And they absorb by merely suppressing the opposing states. But only the supramundane absorptions absorb by taking Nibbāna, which is extremely profound, as their object. And they absorb by completely eradicating the opposing states together with their underlying tendencies.

original: samucchindanavasena jhāpentīti. Etthaca appanājhānānaṃ pañcaṅgikabhāvonāma pakatiyā🔽eva siddho hotīti na pathamajjhānikesu maggaphalesu pādakajjhā nādinā paccayavisesena
analyzed: samucchindana vasena jhāpenti iti ettha ca appanā jhānānam pañcaṅgika bhāvaḥ nāma pakatiyā  eva siddhaḥ hoti iti na pathama jhānikesu magga phalesu pādaka jjhā na ādinā paccaya visesena
translated: And here the five-factoredness of the jhāna of absorption is established by nature in the case of the first jhāna,

original: kiccaṃ atthi. Caturaṅgikādi bhāvo pana tena paccayavisesena vinā na sijjhati. Asatihi
analyzed: kiccam atthi caturaṅgika ādi bhāvaḥ pana tena paccaya visesena vinā na sijjhati asatihi
translated: so there is no need for a special condition in the case of the path and fruition jhānas in the first jhāna. But the four-factoredness, etc., do not come about without a special condition.

original: tasmiṃ sabbaṃpi jhānaṃ pañcaṅgikameva bhavissatīti. Tattha yathā lokiyajjhānesu ādikammikakāle
analyzed: tasmin sabbam api jhānam pañcaṅgikam eva bhavissati iti tattha yathā lokiya jhānesu ādikammika kāle
translated: If that were not so, all jhāna would be five-factored.

original: tassa tassa dutīyādikassa jhānassa upacārabhūtā bhāvanā sayaṃ vitakkādiyuttā samānāpi
analyzed: tassa tassa dutīya ādikassa jhānassa upacāra bhūtā bhāvanā sayam vitakka ādi yuttā samānā api
translated: Herein, in the case of the mundane jhānas, the development that is access in the case of each jhāna, beginning with the second, is itself associated with applied thought, etc.,🔽at the time of its being the beginner’s development.

original: vitakkādīsu ādīnavadassanaññāṇenaceva idāni avitakkaṃ jhānaṃ uppādessāmi, idāni avicāraṃ🔽jhānaṃ uppādessāmīti evamādinā pavattena ajjhāsaya visesenaca yuttattā kāci vitakkavirāgabhāvanānāma🔽hoti. Kāci vicāra virāgabhāvanā nāma. Kāci pītivirāgabhāvanā nāma. Kāci sukhavirāgabhāvanānāma.
analyzed: vitakka ādīsu ādīnava dassana ññāṇena ca iva idāni avitakkam jhānam uppādessāmi idāni avicāram  jhānam uppādessāmi iti evamādinā pavattena visesena ca yutta ttā kāci vitakka virāga bhāvanā nāma  kāci vicāra virāga bhāvanā nāma kāci pīti virāga bhāvanā nāma kāci sukha virāga bhāvanā nāma
translated: And because of the knowledge of seeing the danger in applied thoughts, etc., and because of the special intention that occurs thus, “Now I shall arouse a jhāna without applied thought,” “Now I shall arouse a jhāna without sustained thought,” etc.,

original: Kācī rūpavirāgabhāvanānāma. Asaññigāmīnaṃ pana saññāvirāgabhāvanānāma hoti. Sā attano
analyzed: kācī rūpa virāga bhāvanā nāma asaññi gāmīnam pana saññā virāga bhāvanā nāma hoti sā attano
translated: some of the kinds of development of the jhāna are called “development of the jhāna with applied thought and sustained thought abandoned,” some “with happiness and bliss abandoned,” some “with in-breath and out-breath abandoned,” some “with the sign of materiality abandoned,” some “with the sign of the base consisting of boundless space abandoned,” some “with the sign of the base consisting of boundless consciousness abandoned,” some “with the sign of the base consisting of nothingness abandoned,” some “with the sign of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception abandoned,” some “with the sign of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception abandoned,” some “with perception and feeling abandoned.”

original: attano jhānaṃ avitakkaṃvā avicāraṃvā appītikaṃvā upekkhāsaha gataṃvā kātuṃ sakkoti.🔽Jhānesu vasībhūtakālepana ādīnavadassanaññāṇena vinā kevalaṃ ajjhāsayamattena yaṃyaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ jhānam a vitakkam vā a vicāram vā appītikam vā upekkhā saha gatam vā kātum sakkoti  jhānesu ādīnava dassana ññāṇena vinā kevalam ajjhāsaya mattena yaṃ yaṃ
translated: But when he has reached mastery in the jhānas, then, without any knowledge of seeing the danger in them, he can make any jhāna without applied thought, without sustained thought, without happiness, and with bliss only in the fourth, accompanied by equanimity, as he wishes.

original: jhānaṃ icchati. Taṃ taṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjatiyeva. Evamevaṃ idhapi tassa tassa maggassa
analyzed: jhānam icchati tam tam jhānam samāpajjati eva evam evam idha api tassa tassa maggassa
translated: And just as, when he has reached mastery in the jhānas, he can enter upon any jhāna he wishes without any knowledge of seeing the danger in them, so too, when he has reached mastery in the paths, he can enter upon any path he wishes without any knowledge of seeing the danger in them.🔽And just as, when he has reached mastery in the jhānas, he can enter upon any jhāna he wishes without any knowledge of seeing the danger in them, so too, when he has reached mastery in the paths, he can enter upon any path he wishes without any knowledge of seeing the danger in them.

original: upacārabhūtā vuṭṭhānagāmini vipassanāsaṅkhātā bhāvanā sayaṃ vitakkādiyuttā samānāpi
analyzed: upacāra bhūtā vuṭṭhāna gāmini vipassanā saṅkhātā bhāvanā sayam vitakka ādi yuttā samānā api
translated: And the development called insight leading to emergence, which is the proximate cause, is itself associated with applied thought, etc.,

original: nānāsattiyuttā hoti. Kāci vitakkavirāgabhāvanānāma. Kāci vitakkavicāravirāgabhāvanā
analyzed: nānā āsatti yuttā hoti kāci vitakka virāga bhāvanā nāma kāci vitakka vicāra virāga bhāvanā
translated: but it is associated with different characteristics. Some is called development of the fading away of applied thought. Some is called development of the fading away of applied thought and sustained thought.

original: nāma. Kāci vitakkavicārapīti virāgabhāvanānāma. Kāci vitakkavi cārapītisukhavirāgabhāvanānāma.
analyzed: nāma kāci vitakka vicāra pīti virāga bhāvanā nāma kāci vitakka vi cāra pīti sukha virāga bhāvanā nāma
translated: Some is called development of the fading away of the happiness and bliss born of applied thought and sustained thought. Some is called development of the fading away of the happiness and bliss born of equanimity.

original: Tattha yā vitakkaṃ virājetuṃ atikkāmetuṃ sakkoti. Sā vitakkavirāgabhāvanānāma. Esa nayo sesāsupīti.
analyzed: tattha yā vitakkam virājetum atikkāmetum sakkoti sā vitakka virāga bhāvanā nāmaḥ esa nayaḥ sesāsu pi iti
translated: Herein, that which is able to fade away and surmount applied thought is called development of the fading away of applied thought. So too with the rest.

original: 66. Kassapana balena sā vipassanā nānāsatti yuttā hotīti. Vuccate, pādakajjhānabalenāti
analyzed: balena sā vipassanā nānāsatti yuttā hoti iti vuccate pādakajjhāna balena ati
translated: By what power is this insight associated with different characteristics? It is said that it is by the power of the basic jhāna.

original: eko theravādo. Sammasitajjhāna balenāti eko. Puggalajjhāsaya balenāti eko. Tattha
analyzed: ekaḥ thera vādaḥ balena ati ekaḥ balena ati ekaḥ tattha
translated: This is one view. It is by the power of the absorbed jhāna, say another. It is by the power of the jhāna according to the individual’s wish, say another.

original: yaṃ yaṃ jhānaṃ tassā vipassanāya pādakatthāya āsanne samāpajjīyati. Taṃtaṃ pādakajjhānaṃnāma.
analyzed: yam yam jhānam tassāḥ vipassanāya pādaka tthāya āsanne samāpajjīyati taṃ tam pādakajjhānaṃnāma
translated: Herein, that jhāna is called “basic” which is adjacent to that insight and is entered upon for the purpose of its support.

original: Taṃce pathamajjhānaṃ hoti. Vipassanā pākatikāeva. Sace dutīyajjhānaṃ hoti. Vipassanā🔽vitakkavirāgasattiyuttā hoti. Magge avitakkaṃ jhānaṃ niyāmetuṃ sakkoti. Esanayo sesesupi🔽pādakajjhānesūti ayaṃ pādakavādo. Pādakajjhāne sati taṃsadisameva magge jhānaṃ hoti.🔽Asatipana magge pathamajjhānameva hoti. Sammasi tajjhānaṃvā puggalajjhāsayovā magge
analyzed: tat ce pathama jhānam hoti vipassanā pākatikā eva sace dutīya jhānam hoti vipassanā  vitakka virāga satti yuttā hoti magge avitakkam jhānam niyāmetum sakkoti sesesu pi  pādaka jhānesu iti ayam pādaka vādaḥ pādaka jjhāne sati tad sadisam eva magge jhānam hoti  asati pana magge pathama jhānam eva hoti magge
translated: And if it is the first jhāna, the insight is only ordinary. If it is the second jhāna, the insight is associated with the support of the fading away of happiness. He is then able to determine the jhāna in the path as without thinking. This is the method in the case of the remaining jhānas.🔽This is the theory of the basic jhāna. When there is a basic jhāna, the jhāna in the path is of the same kind. But when there is not, the jhāna in the path is only the first.🔽The person who is devoted to jhāna determines the jhāna in the path as the jhāna he is devoted to.🔽

original: jhānaṅgaṃ niyametuṃ nasakkotīti adhippāyoti. Pādakajjhāne sati taṃvā aññaṃvā yaṃyaṃ🔽jhānaṃ sammasīyati. Taṃce pathamajjhānaṃ hoti. Vipassanā pākati kāeva. Sace dutīyajjhānaṃ🔽hoti. Vipassanā vitakkavirāgasatti yuttā hoti. Magge avitakkaṃ jhānaṃ niyāmetuṃ sakkoti.🔽Esanayo sesesupi sammasitajjhānesūti ayaṃ sammasitavādo. Vipassanāya ārammaṇabhāvena
analyzed: jhāna aṅgam niyametum na sakkoti iti adhippāyaḥ ti pādakajjhāne sati taṃ vā aññaṃ vā yaṃ yaṃ 🔽jhānam sammasīyati tat ce pathama jjhānam hoti vipassanā sace dutīya jjhānam 🔽hoti vipassanā vitakka virāga satti yuttā hoti magge avitakkam jhānam niyāmetum sakkoti 🔽sesesu pi sammasita jhānesu ti ayam sammasita vādaḥ vipassanāya ārammaṇa bhāvena
translated: But if it is the first jhāna, then insight is ordinary. If it is the second jhāna, then insight is associated with the virtue of the surmounting of applied thought. He can then determine the jhāna in the path as without applied thought. The same method applies in the case of the remaining jhānas as bases. This is the theory of the bases. When there is a jhāna as a basis, the jhāna in the path is of the same kind. But when there is not, the first jhāna is in the path. The intention is this: the person who is familiar with that jhāna or with jhāna in general is unable to determine the jhāna factors in the path. When there is a jhāna as a basis, then whichever jhāna he comprehends, if it is the first jhāna, then insight is ordinary. If it is the second jhāna, then insight is associated with the virtue of the surmounting of applied thought. He can then determine the jhāna in the path as without applied thought. The same method applies in the case of the remaining jhānas comprehended. This is the theory of comprehension. When there is no jhāna as a basis, then whichever jhāna he comprehends as object for insight, if it is the first jhāna, then insight is ordinary. If it is the second jhāna, then insight is associated with the virtue of the surmounting of applied thought. He can then determine the jhāna in the path as without applied thought. The same method applies in the case of the remaining jhānas comprehended. This is the theory of comprehension.

original: saha caritattā sammasitajjhānameva pādakajjhānato ajjhāsayatoca balavataranti adhippāyoti.
analyzed: saha carita ttā sammasita jhānam eva pādaka jhānataḥ ajjhāsayato ca balavataranti adhippāyo ti
translated: because it is the companion of insight, the jhāna that is the basis for insight is stronger than the jhāna that is the preliminary work, both as to its proximity and as to its strength. This is the intention.

original: Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:🔽“There is no jhāna that is the basis for insight” in the passage of the Vibhaṅga dealing with the “sign of stilling” .

original: Vipassanāpādakaṃ kiñcijhānaṃ natthīti imasmiṃ vāde vuttaṃ. Taṃ aṭṭhakathāya na sameti.
analyzed: vipassanā pādakam kiñci jhānam na atthi iti imasmin vāde vuttam tat aṭṭhakathāya na sameti
translated: But that does not agree with the commentary.

original: Pādakajjhāne sati taṃvā aññaṃvā magge yaṃyaṃjhānaṃ icchati. Taṃtaṃ jhānaṃ ijjhati.
analyzed: pādakajjhāne sati taṃ vā aññaṃ vā magge yaṃ yaṃ jhānam icchati taṃ tam jhānam ijjhati
translated: When there is jhāna as preliminary work, then whichever jhāna he wants for the path, that jhāna succeeds.

original: Vipassanāpi icchānurūpaṃ vitakkavirāgādibhāvaṃ pattā hotīti puggalajjhāsayavādo.
analyzed: vipassanā api icchā anurūpam vitakka virāga ādi bhāvam pattā hoti iti puggala jjhā saya vādo
translated: And insight reaches the state of the fading away of thinking, etc., in accordance with the wish. This is the theory of the “individual’s temperament.”

original: Yathā lokiyajjhānesu āsanne vuṭṭhitajjhānaṃ uparijjhānupacāra bhāvanāya upatthambhakamattaṃ
analyzed: yathā lokiya jhānesu āsanne vuṭṭhita jhānam upari jhāna upacāra bhāvanāya upatthambhaka mattam
translated: Just as in the case of mundane jhānas, when one who has emerged from a jhāna enters the next higher one, the jhāna that is the basis for the next higher jhāna is only a condition for the support of it,

original: hoti. Na pana uparijjhāne jhānaṃ attasadisaṃ kātuṃ sakkoti. Ajjhāsayoeva uparijjhāne
analyzed: hoti na pana upari jhāne jhānam atta sadisam kātum sakkoti upari jhāne
translated: but it is not able to make the next higher jhāna like itself; it is only the individual’s temperament that directs the jhāna factors in the next higher jhāna;

original: jhānaṅgaṃ niyāmeti. Evamevaṃ idhapi pādakajjhānaṃ vipassanāya tikkha visadabhāvatthāya
analyzed: evam evam idha api pādakajjhānam vipassanāya
translated: so too here the jhāna that is the preliminary work is only a condition for the support of insight,

original: balavupanissa yo hoti. Ajjhāsayoeva vipassanaṃ vitakkavirāgādibhāvaṃ pāpetvā magge🔽jhānaṅgaṃ niyāmetīti adhippāyoti. Yo panettha vuṭṭhānagāminivipassanāeva magge jhānaṅgaṃ🔽niyāmetīti mahāṭṭhakathā vādo. Tatthapi puggalajjhāsayavisesabalena vitakkavirāgādisatti
analyzed: balavā upanissa yaḥ hoti vipassanam vitakka virāga ādi bhāvam pāpetvā magge  jhāna aṅgam niyāmeti iti adhippāyaḥ ti yaḥ pana ittha vuṭṭhāna gāmini vipassanā eva magge jhāna aṅgam  niyāma iti iti mahā aṭṭhakathā vādaḥ tattha api puggala jhā saya visesa balena vitakka virāga ādi satti
translated: and the strength of his underlying tendency. The intention is that insight itself, which has the name of “leading to emergence,” brings about the state of being free from applied thought, etc., and then determines the jhāna factors in the path.

original: visesayuttā vuṭṭhānagāmini vipassanāevāti attho veditabbo. Kāmañcettha aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ🔽imesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ theravādānaṃ aññamaññaṃ avirodho vuttoviya dissati. Imepana vādā aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: visesa yuttā vuṭṭhāna gāmini vipassanā eva ati atthaḥ veditabbo kāmam ca ittha aṭṭhasāliniyam  imesam tiṇṇam thera vādānam aññamaññam avirodho vuttaḥ viya dissati ime pana vādāḥ aññamaññam
translated: But the view of the Great Commentary is that it is only insight that has the name of “leading to emergence” that determines the jhāna factors in the path. And here too the meaning should be understood in the way already stated, namely, that it is insight that has the name of “leading to emergence” and is associated with the distinction of being free from applied thought, etc., by the power of the distinction of the underlying tendency to jhāna in the individual.

original: saṃsanditvā pavattā nahonti. Paccekaṃ sabbaṃ lokuttarajjhānaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ katvā pavattā.
analyzed: saṃsanditvā pavattāḥ na honti paccekam sabbam lokuttara jhānam paripuṇṇam katvā pavattā
translated: But in the Eightfold Questions it seems that the non-conflicting nature of these three elder bhikkhus’ views is shown. And these views, which occur separately, each making the whole of the supramundane jhāna complete,🔽are not in conflict with one another. So it is not possible to avoid their conflict.

original: Tasmā nasakkā tesaṃ aññamaññaṃ virodho pariharitunti. Etthaca jhānalābhīnaṃ vipassanākamme
analyzed: tasmā na sakkā tesam aññamaññam virodho pariharitun ti ettha ca jhāna lābhīnam vipassanā kamme
translated: And here, as regards the function of insight in those who have obtained jhāna,

original: pādakajjhānasamā pajjanaṃnāma bhagavatāeva suṭṭhuvihitaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ cūḷasuññatasutte –
analyzed: pādakajjhāna samā pajjanam nāma bhagavatā eva suṭṭhu vihitam vuttam ha etam cūḷasuññata sutte
translated: The kind of attention called “arisen together with the basic jhāna” is well described by the Blessed One in the Cūḷa-Suññata Sutta:

original: Idhānanda bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi pathamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja🔽viharati. Dutīyaṃ jhānaṃ. Tatīyaṃ jhānaṃ. Catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.🔽So ajjhattaṃ suññataṃ manasikaroti. Tassaceajjhattaṃsuññatāya cittaṃ napakkhandati.🔽Napasīdati. Tena bhikkhunā tasmiṃyeva purimasmiṃ samādhinimitte ajjhattameva cittaṃ
analyzed: idha ānanda bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi pathamam jhānam upasampajja  viharati dutīyam jhānam tatīyam jhānam catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati  saḥ ajjhattam suññatam manasikaroti tassa ce ajjhattaṃsuññatāya cittam na pakkhandati  na apasīdati tena bhikkhunā tasmin yeva purimasmim samādhi nimitte ajjhattam eva cittam
translated: “Here, Ānanda, a bhikkhu, quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unwholesome things, enters upon and abides in the first jhāna … the second jhāna … the third jhāna … the fourth jhāna, which has purity of mindfulness due to equanimity and is without pleasure and pain.

original: santhape tabbaṃ, sannisādetabbaṃ, ekodi kātabbaṃ, samādahātabbantiādi.
analyzed: santhape tabbam sannisādetabbam ekodi kātabbam samādahātabba ntiādi
translated: He directs his mind to the knowledge of the recollection of his former habitations, and he recollects his manifold past habitations, that is to say, one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, many eons of world-contraction, many eons of world-expansion, many eons of world-contraction and expansion: ‘There I was so named, of such a race, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my sensitivity and pleasure and pain, such my life-term; and passing away from there, I was reborn elsewhere; and there too I was so named, of such a race, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my sensitivity and pleasure and pain, such my life-term; and passing away from there, I was reborn here.’ Thus with its aspects and particulars he recollects his manifold past habitations.

original: Tattha suññataṃ manasikarotīti vipassanākammaṃ vuttaṃ. Tasmiṃyeva purimasmiṃ samādhinimitteti pādakajjhānasamādhi nimitte. Navanipāteca –
analyzed: tattha suññatam manasikaroti iti vipassanā kammam vuttam tasmin yeva purimasmin samādhi nimitte iti pādaka jjhāna samādhi nimitte
translated: He directs his mind to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings, and with the purified divine eye, he sees beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, happy and unhappy in their destiny; he understands how beings pass on according to their actions thus: ‘These worthy beings who were ill-conducted in body, speech, and mind, revilers of noble ones, wrong in their views, giving effect to wrong view in their actions, on the dissolution of the body, after death, have reappeared in a state of deprivation, in a bad destination, in perdition, even in hell; but these worthy beings who were well-conducted in body, speech, and mind, not revilers of noble ones, right in their views, giving effect to right view in their actions, on the dissolution of the body, after death, have reappeared in a good destination, even in the heavenly world’—thus with the purified

original: Pathamaṃ pāhaṃ bhikkhavejhānaṃ nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi.La. Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ pāhaṃ bhikkhave jhānaṃ nissāya āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pathamam pā aham bhikkhave jhānam nissāya āsavānaṃ khayam vadāmi ila nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam pā aham bhikkhave jhānam nissāya āsavānaṃ khayam vadāmi iti vuttaṃ
translated: “First, I say, bhikkhus, by depending on a jhāna, the destruction of the taints is to be expected. And again, I say, by depending on the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, the destruction of the taints is to be expected” .

original: 67. Imesupana tīsuvādesu puggalajjhāsayavādo balavataroviya khāyati. Lokiyajjhānesupi
analyzed: imesu pana lokiya jhānesu pi
translated: Of these three statements, the statement of the individual’s temperament seems the strongest.

original: hi pādakajjhānaṃnāma icchitabbameva. Tañca uparijjhānassa upacārabhāvanāya tikkhavisada🔽bhāvatthāyaeva hoti. Ajjhāsayoevapana upacāra bhāvanāya vitakkavirāgādibhāvaṃ sādheti.🔽Upacārabhāvanāeva uparijjhāne jhānaṅgaṃ niyāmeti. Evamevaṃ idhapi pādakajjhānabalena🔽tikkhavisada bhāvapattā vuṭṭhānagāmini vipassanāeva ajjhāsayavisesabalena vitakkavirāgādisattivisesayuttā
analyzed: hi pādakajjhānam nāma icchitabbam eva tat ca upari jhānassa upacāra bhāvanāya  bhāva tthāya eva upacāra bhāvanāya vitakka virāga ādi bhāvam sādha iti  upacāra bhāvanā eva evam evam idh api pādaka jhāna balena  bhāva pattā vuṭṭhāna gāmini vipassanā eva ajjhāsaya visesa balena vitakka virāga ādi satti visesa yuttā
translated: For even in the case of mundane jhānas, the basic jhāna must be admitted. And that is only for the purpose of making the access development of the higher jhāna more acute and clear.🔽But it is temperament that makes the access development possess the special qualities of the absence of applied thought, and so on.🔽And it is the access development that brings about the jhāna factors in the higher jhāna. So too here, it is insight that, with the aid of the basic jhāna’s power, reaches the state of being able to emerge by attaining the basic jhāna, and it is insight that possesses the special qualities of the absence of applied thought, and so on, by the special strength of temperament.

original: hutvā magge nānājhānāni sādheti. Asati pana ajjhāsayavisese taṃtaṃ pādakajjhānānurūpaṃ
analyzed: hutvā magge nānā jhānāni sādheti asati pana ajjhā saya visese taṃtam pādaka jhāna anurūpam
translated: And it is insight that brings about the various jhānas in the path. But if there is no special quality in the temperament, then the path arises in conformity with the basic jhāna that is the support for the insight that reaches the state of being able to emerge by attaining the basic jhāna.

original: ajjhāsayasāmaññaṃsaṇṭhāti. Tasmā ajjhāsayavisese asati pādakajjhānameva pamāṇaṃ hoti.🔽Satipana tasmiṃ soeva pamāṇanti yuttaṃ. Icchi ticchita lokiyajjhāna samāpajjana sadisañhi
analyzed: tasmai ajjhāsaya visese asati pādaka jjhānam eva pamāṇam hoti  tasmin yuttam
translated: and the similarity of intention is the same. Therefore, if there is no difference in intention, the basic jhāna is the measure.

original: sabbajjhānesu ciṇṇavasībhūtānaṃ maggesu icchitajjhāna nibbattananti. Yo panettha
analyzed: sabba jjhānesu maggesu
translated: But if there is one, then that is the measure. For it is proper to say this, since those who have attained mastery in all the jhānas produce the jhāna whenever they choose, as if summoning it, just as they produce a consciousness that is the same in all respects as that of the jhāna by attaining the supramundane jhāna.

original: pādakajjhānādivasena pavatto viseso. So sabbopi vipassanā visesatthāya eva hoti.
analyzed: pādaka jjhāna ādi vasena pavattaḥ viseso so sabbaḥ api vipassanā visesa tthāya eva hoti
