translated: But whatever difference there is here in the basic jhāna, etc., all that is only for the purpose of distinguishing insight.

original: Vipassanā visesoeva magge jhānaṅgaṃ niyāmetīti katvā aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ visuddhi maggeca🔽vipassanāva pamāṇaṃ katvāvuttā. So sabbopi viseso pādakajjhānena vinā nasijjhatīti
analyzed: vipassanā magge jhāna aṅgam niyāmeti iti katvā  vipassanā ava pamāṇam katvā vuttā so sabbaḥ api visesaḥ pādakajjhānena vinā
translated: It is insight that determines the jhāna factors in the path, and so it is insight that is stated as the measure in the Ashtasahasrikā Prajñāpāramitā and in the Visuddhimagga.

original: katvā maggavibhaṅgamaggasaṃyuttaṭṭha kathāsu pādakajjhānaṃ eva pamāṇaṃ katvā vuttanti
analyzed: katvā kathāsu pādaka jhānam eva pamāṇam katvā vuttanti
translated: But since all that difference does not occur without the basic jhāna, it is stated in the Paṭisambhidā, the Magga-Vibhaṅga, the Saṃyutta Commentary, and the Peṭaka Commentary that the basic jhāna is the measure.

original: veditabbaṃ. Yasmā pana pāḷiyaṃ –
analyzed: veditabbam yasmā pana pāḷiyam
translated: But in the text of the Abhidhamma it is said:🔽“What is the jhāna of the first jhāna? The profitable consciousness belonging to the jhāna of the first jhāna, associated with knowledge, with joy and happiness born of seclusion, and accompanied by factors of the first jhāna.

original: Idha gahapati bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi. La. Pathamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: idha gahapati bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi la pathamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: Here, householder, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhana…

original: So iti paṭisañcikkhati. Idaṃpi kho pathamajjhānaṃ abhisaṅkhataṃ abhisañcehayitaṃ
analyzed: saḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati idam api kho pathamajjhānam abhisaṅkhatam abhisañcehayitam
translated: He considers thus: ‘This first jhana is conditioned and volitionally produced.

original: yaṃkhopana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṃ abhisañcetayitaṃ. Tadaniccaṃ. Taṃ nirodhadhammanti
analyzed: kiñci abhisaṅkhatam abhisañcetayitam tat aniccam tam nirodha dhammanti
translated: Whatever is conditioned and volitionally produced is subject to destruction, subject to cessation.’🔽Abiding in that, he attains the destruction of the taints.🔽He considers thus: ‘This second jhana…

original: pajānāti so tattha ṭhito āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti. La. Dutīyaṃ jhānaṃ, tatīyaṃ jhānaṃ,
analyzed: pajānāti saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti dutīyam jhānam tatīyam jhānam
translated: this third jhana…🔽this fourth jhana…🔽this deliverance of the mind by loving-kindness…🔽this deliverance of the mind by compassion…

original: catutthaṃ jhānaṃ, mettā cetovimuttiṃ. Karuṇā, muditā, upekkhāceto vimuttiṃ, ākāsānañcā
analyzed: catuttham jhānam mettā cetaḥ vimuttim karuṇā muditā upekkhā cetaḥ vimuttim
translated: this deliverance of the mind by gladness…🔽this deliverance of the mind by equanimity…🔽this attainment of the base of infinite space…

original: yatanaṃ.La. Ākiñcaññā yatanaṃ upasampajja viharati. So iti paṭisañcikkhati. Ayaṃpikho
analyzed: yatanaṃle ākiñcaññā yatanam upasampajja viharati saḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati ayaṃpikho
translated: this attainment of the base of infinite consciousness…🔽this attainment of the base of nothingness is conditioned and volitionally produced.

original: ākiñcaññā yatanasamāpatti abhisaṅkhatā abhisañcetayitā. Yaṃ khopana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṃ.La. Khayaṃ pāpuṇātīti.
analyzed: ākiñcaññā yatana samāpatti abhisaṅkhatā abhisañcetayitā yam khopana kiñci khayam pāpuṇāti iti
translated: Whatever is conditioned and volitionally produced is subject to destruction, subject to cessation.’

original: Evaṃekādasanipāte –
analyzed: evam ekādasa nipāte
translated: Thus in the eleven groups of the first section,

original: Idhānanda bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ🔽vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ pathamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. So yadeva tattha hoti🔽rūpagataṃ vedanāgataṃ saññāgataṃ saṅkhāragataṃ viññāṇagataṃ, te dhamme aniccato dukkhato
analyzed: idha ānanda bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram  viveka jam pīti sukham pathamam jhānam upasampajja viharati saḥ yat eva tattha hoti  rūpa gatam vedanā gatam saññā gatam saṅkhāra gatam viññāṇa gatam te dhamme aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ
translated: Here, Ananda, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.🔽Whatever exists therein of material form, feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness, he sees those states as impermanent, as suffering,

original: anattato samanupassati. So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpuṇāti. No ce āsavānaṃ🔽khayaṃ pāpuṇāti. Teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ
analyzed: anattataḥ samanupassati saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti no ce āsavānam  khayam pāpuṇāti tena iva dhamma rāgena tāya dhamma nandiyā pañcannam orambhāgiyānaṃ
translated: Here, Ananda, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion. Whatever exists therein of the material form category, of the feeling category, of the perception category, of the formations category, of the consciousness category - he sees those states as impermanent, as suffering, as a disease, a tumour, a barb, a calamity, an affliction, as alien, as disintegrating, as void, as not self. Standing upon that, he reaches the destruction of the taints.

original: saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā upapātiko hoti. Tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokāti.🔽Ādinā mālukyaputtasutta anupadasuttādīsuca anekesu suttantesu aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu
analyzed: saṃyojanānam parikkhayā upapātikaḥ hoti tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo tasmā lokā ati  ādinā anekesu suttantesu aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu
translated: If he does not reach the destruction of the taints, then because of that desire for the Dhamma, that delight in the Dhamma, with the destruction of the five lower fetters he becomes one due to reappear spontaneously in the Pure Abodes and there attain final Nibbana without ever returning from that world.🔽In the Malunkyaputta Sutta, the Anupada Sutta, and in many other suttas, the contemplation of the states of the eight attainments is given only in the form of the review of the states of the attainment that has just been emerged from.

original: ekekāya samāpattiyā vuṭṭhāya vuṭṭhitasamāpattidhammasammasanameva āgataṃ. Napana
analyzed: ekekāya samāpattiyā vuṭṭhāya vuṭṭhita samāpatti dhamma sammasanam eva āgatam na pana
translated: The contemplation of the states of the attainment that is being entered upon is not given.

original: aññajjhāna sammasanaṃ. Tasmā satipi yogīnaṃ icchāvasena pādakajjhānato aññajjhānasammasane
analyzed: sammasanam icchā vasena pādakajjhānato añña jhāna sammasane
translated: Therefore, although the surmounting of jhāna is by means of another jhāna according to the meditator’s wish,🔽it can be understood that only the basic jhāna is the measure.

original: pādakajjhānameva pamāṇanti sakkā viññātunti. Ettāvatā sammasitavādo sabbadubbaloti
analyzed: pādakajjhānam eva pamāṇanti sakkā viññātunti ettāvatā sammasita vādaḥ sabba dubbalaḥ ti
translated: So far the view that there is surmounting of jhāna is established as the weakest of all.

original: siddho hotīti. Yepana aṭṭhasamāpattilābhinopi jhānaṃ pādakaṃ akatvāva maggaṃ uppādenti.🔽Pathamajjhānamevavā pādakaṃ katvā ajjhāsayavisesaṃ akatvā maggaṃ uppādenti. Pathamajjhānamattalābhinovā
analyzed: siddhaḥ hoti iti aṭṭha samāpatti lābhinaḥ api jhānam pādakam a katvā ava maggam uppādenti  pathamajjhānam eva vā pādakam katvā ajjhāsaya visesam a katvā maggam uppādenti pathamajjhāna matta lābhinaḥ vā
translated: Even those who have attained the eight attainments arouse the path without making a jhāna the basis.🔽They arouse the path without making any distinction in the inclination, having made only the first jhāna the basis. Or those who have attained only the first jhāna

original: hutvā tameva pādakaṃ katvā maggaṃ uppādenti. Yeca sukkhavipassakā hutvā maggaṃ uppādenti.
analyzed: hutvā tam eva pādakam katvā maggam uppādenti ye ca sukkha vipassakāḥ hutvā maggam uppādenti
translated: make that the basis and arouse the path. And those who are bare- insight workers and arouse the path

original: Tesaṃ pathamajjhānikova maggo hotīti veditabbo. Apica ye pakatiyāva aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu
analyzed: tesam pathamajjhānikaḥ va maggaḥ hoti iti veditabbaḥ api ca ye pakatiyā va aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu
translated: should be understood as having the first jhāna as the path. Furthermore, those who have already become masters of the eight attainments

original: ciṇṇavasībhūtā honti. Te vināpi āsannapādakena yaṃyaṃjhānaṃ icchanti. Taṃtaṃ jhānaṃ
analyzed: ciṇṇavasībhūtāḥ honti te vinā api āsanna pādakena yaṃ yam jhānam icchanti taṃ tam jhānam
translated: without even a proximate basis, whichever jhāna they want,

original: tesaṃ maggesu nasamijjhatīti navattabbaṃ.
analyzed: tesam maggesu na samijjhati iti
translated: that jhāna succeeds for them in the paths.

original: 66. [66] Yaṃpana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yaṃpana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Sacepana puggalassa tathāvidho ajjhāsayo natthi. Heṭṭhimaheṭṭhimajjhānato vuṭṭhāya
analyzed: sace pana puggalassa tathāvidhaḥ ajjhāsayaḥ natthi heṭṭhima heṭṭhima jhānataḥ vuṭṭhāya
translated: “But if a person has no such underlying tendency,🔽then the path that is produced after emerging from the lower and lower jhānas,

original: uparuparijjhānadhamme sammasitvā uppāditamaggo pādakajjhānaṃ anapekkhitvā sammasitajjhānasadiso
analyzed: upari upari jhāna dhamme sammasitvā uppādita maggaḥ pādaka jjhānam an apekkhitvā sammasita jjhāna sadisaḥ
translated: without regard for the jhāna as a basis for direct-knowledge, is like the jhāna of direct-knowledge.

original: hotīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ vicāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: hoti iti vuttam tat vicāretabbam
translated: This should be investigated.

original: Na hi ārammaṇamattabhūtaṃ sammasitajjhānaṃ uparimaṃpi samānaṃ āsanne vuṭṭhitajjhānato
analyzed: na hi ārammaṇa matta bhūtam sammasita jhānam uparimaṃ pi samānam āsanne vuṭṭhita jhānato
translated: For the jhāna of direct-knowledge, which is merely the object of the direct-knowledge, is not a condition for the higher jhāna that is like it,🔽and it is not proper that it should be a more proximate condition for the jhāna arisen next to it.

original: balavataraṃ bhavituṃ arahati. Āsanne vuṭṭhitasseva cittasantānaṃ visesetuṃ samatthabhāvato.
analyzed: balavataram bhavitum arahati āsanne vuṭṭhitassa iva citta santānam visesetum samattha bhāvato
translated: And because it is only able to distinguish the mind’s continuity from that of the jhāna arisen next to it,

original: Tato yevahi so sammasitavādo sabbaaṭṭhakathāsu kecivādapakkhe eva thapitoti. Nanu🔽puggalajjhāsayavādopi tathāthapitoevāti. Saccaṃ, sopana lokiyajjhānānaṃ uppattividhānena
analyzed: tatas yeva hi so sammasita vādaḥ sabba aṭṭhakathāsu keci vāda pakkhe eva thapitaḥ iti nanu  saccam lokiya jhānānam uppatti vidhānena
translated: the theory of direct-knowledge is established in all the commentaries only in the opinion of some.🔽But is not the theory of underlying tendency also established in the same way?

original: saha saṃsandikattā yuttataroeva hotīti.
analyzed: saha saṃsandi kattā yuttataraḥ eva hoti iti
translated: It is true, but it is more reasonable because it is connected with the method of arising of the mundane jhānas.

original: [67] Etena yaṃ tattha vuttaṃ.
analyzed: etena yam tattha vuttam
translated: So it should be understood that what is said there

original: “Uparuparijjhānato pana vuṭṭhāya heṭṭhima heṭṭhimajjhāna dhamme sammasitvā uppāditamaggo🔽sammasitajjhānaṃ anapekkhitvā pāda kajjhānasadiso hoti. Heṭṭhimaheṭṭhimajjhānatohi
analyzed: upara upari jhānataḥ pana vuṭṭhāya heṭṭhima heṭṭhima jhāna dhamme sammasitvā uppādita maggaḥ  sammasita jhānam an apekkhitvā hoti heṭṭhima heṭṭhima jhānataḥ hi
translated: But when he emerges from the higher jhāna and comprehends the states of the lower jhāna, the path that he has generated🔽does not look to the comprehended jhāna for support, like a man with sound feet who does not need to look to his feet. For🔽

original: uparu parijjhānaṃ balavatara”nti. Taṃpi paṭikkhittaṃ hoti.
analyzed: uparu parijjhānam balavataranti tat pi paṭikkhittam hoti
translated: But when he emerges from the higher jhāna and comprehends the states of the lower jhāna, the path that he generates is like the basic jhāna and does not look to the comprehended jhāna for support. For the higher jhāna is stronger than the lower jhāna. ”🔽That is also rejected.

original: Na hi pādakajjhānaṃ uparima bhūtattāyeva balavataraṃ hoti. Pādakabhūtattāyeva pana balavataraṃ hotīti.
analyzed: na hi pādaka jjhānam bhū tattāya iva balavataram hoti pādaka bhū tattāya iva pana balavataram hoti iti
translated: For the basic jhāna is not stronger just because it is higher; it is stronger because it is basic.

original: [68] Yañca tattha🔽Magge vedanāniyamopana pādakajjhānādīnaṃ vasena nasiddho. Aññathā vipassanā yāyakāyacivedanāya🔽yuttā hutvā tehi niyamitāya ekekāya maggavedanāya saddhiṃ ghaṭi yeyyāti iminā adhippāyena
analyzed: yañca tattha  magge aññathā vipassanā  yuttāḥ hutvā tehi niyamitāya ekekāya magga vedanāya saddhim iminā adhippāyena
translated: And the statement🔽“The path is generated by the law of the presence of the feeling in the basic jhāna, etc., and it is generated by the law of the presence of the feeling in the path in all instances where the insight leading to emergence has the feeling of the basic jhāna as its object” is not correct.

original: “vedanāniyamopana sabbatthapi vuṭṭhānagāmini vipassanāniyamena hotī”ti vuttaṃ. Tampi na yujjati.
analyzed: sabbattha api vuṭṭhāna gāmini vipassanā niyamena hoti iti vuttam tat pi na yujjati
translated: For if it were, then insight that has the feeling of the basic jhāna as its object would be insight leading to emergence, and it would be necessary to include it in the section on insight leading to emergence.

original: Pādakajjhānādīnaṃ vaseneva vipassanāya saha vedanāniyamassa siddhattā. Tathāhi taṃtaṃ🔽pādakajjhānato vuṭṭhāya vipassantassa vipassanā ādito kadāci somanassasahagatāvā🔽hoti. Kadāci upekkhāsahagatāvā. Maggavuṭṭhānakālepana yadipādakajjhānaṃ somanassajjhānaṃ
analyzed: pādaka jjhāna ādīnam vasena iva vipassanāya saha vedanā niyamassa siddha ttā tathā hi taṃ taṃ  pādakajjhānataḥ vuṭṭhāya vipassantassa vipassanā āditas kadāci somanassa sahagatā vā  hoti kadāci
translated: For the regularity of feeling is established by insight together with the basic jhāna, etc.,🔽For when he emerges from the basic jhāna and contemplates, his insight is sometimes accompanied by joy and sometimes by equanimity.

original: hoti. Vipassanā ekantena somassasaha gatāva hutvā maggena saddhiṃ ghaṭiyatīti. Vuttañhetaṃ
analyzed: hoti vipassanā ekantena somassa saha gatā ava hutvā maggena saddhim vuttam ha etam
translated: And at the time of the path’s emergence, if the basic jhāna is a jhāna of joy, then his insight becomes accompanied by joy and it is only then that it is in conformity with the path.

original: saḷāyatana vibhaṅgasutte –🔽Tatra bhikkhave yā cha nekkhammassitā upekkhā. Tā nissāya tā āgamma yāni cha nekkhammassitāni
analyzed: saḷāyatana vibhaṅga sutte  tatra bhikkhave yā cha nekkhammassitāḥ upekkhā tā nissāya tāḥ āgamma yāni cha nekkhammassitāni
translated: This is said in the Saḷāyatana Saṃyutta:

original: somanassāni. Tāni pajahatha. Tāni samatikkamatha. Evametesaṃ pahānaṃ hoti. Evametesaṃ samatikkamo hotīti.
analyzed: somanassāni tāni pajahatha tāni samatikkamatha evam etesam pahānam hoti evam etesam samatikkamaḥ hoti iti
translated: “Bhikkhus, depending upon and relying upon those six kinds of equanimity based on renunciation, abandon those six kinds of joy based on renunciation, surmount them; thus their abandoning is effected and their surmounting comes about” .

original: Aṭṭhakathāyañca aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu pathamādinica tīṇijhānāni suddhasaṅkhāreca pādake
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāyañca aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu pathama ādini ca tīṇi jhānāni suddha saṅkhāre ca pādake
translated: And in the Commentary to the Aṭṭhasālinī it is said that the first three jhānas and the formations of the fourth are the basic jhāna in the case of the first eight attainments.

original: katvā vipassanaṃ āraddhānaṃ catunnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pubbabhāga vipassanā somanassasahagatā
analyzed: katvā vipassanam āraddhānam catunnam bhikkhūnam pubbabhāga vipassanā somanassa sahagatā
translated: When he has done so, then the insight of the four bhikkhus begins with joy accompanied by happiness.

original: vā hoti. Upekkhāsaha gatāvāvuṭṭhānagāminīpana somanassasahagatāva hoti. Catutthajjhānādīni
analyzed: vā hoti upekkhā saha somanassa sahagatā ava hoti catuttha jhāna ādīni
translated: Or it begins with equanimity accompanied by happiness. But that which ends in emergence is accompanied by equanimity.

original: pādakānikatvā vipassanaṃ āraddhānaṃ pañcannaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pubbabhāgavipassanā purima
analyzed: pādakāni katvā vipassanam āraddhānam pañcannam bhikkhūnam pubbabhāga vipassanā purima
translated: When he has made the fourth jhāna, etc., the basis for insight, then the insight of the five bhikkhus begins as in the first case.

original: sadisāva. Vuṭṭhānagāminīpana upekkhāsahagatāva hoti. Idaṃ sandhāyayā chanekkhammassitā.La.
analyzed: upekkhā sahagatā ava hoti idam
translated: But that which ends in emergence is accompanied by equanimity. This is the meaning here.🔽The words “and he abandoned” are said with reference to the abandoning of the defilements at the end of the path.

original: Pajahathāti vuttaṃ. Ajjhāsayavisesena saha maggavuṭṭhānepi esevanayo. Balavavipassanākāle
analyzed: pajahatha iti vuttam ajjhāsaya visesena saha magga vuṭṭhāne pi balava vipassanā kāle
translated: The same method applies to the emergence of the path in one of the kinds of direct-knowledge.🔽For at the time of the powerful insight called “the radiance of insight” the bhikkhu’s insight is very clear and brilliant.

original: hi vipassanāratināma suṭṭhu paṇītatarā hoti. Sakalasarīraṃ pharamānā ajjhottharamānā
analyzed: hi vipassanā rati nāma suṭṭhu paṇītatarā hoti sakala sarīram pharamānā ajjhottharamānā
translated: It occurs pervading the whole body and suffusing it.

original: pavattati. Yathāha –🔽Suññāgāre paviṭṭhassa, santacittassa bhikkhuno;
analyzed: pavattati yathā āha  suññāgāre paviṭṭhassa santa cittassa bhikkhuno
translated: As it is said:🔽When a bhikkhu enters an empty place🔽And his mind is peaceful,🔽He has a superhuman bliss

original: Amānusī rati hoti, sammadhammaṃ vipassatoti.
analyzed: amānusī rati hoti samma dhammam vipassato ti
translated: When he sees the Dhamma rightly.

original: Tasmā tadā pādakajjhānavisesenavā ajjhāsayavisesena vā vinā vipassanā upekkhāsahagatā
analyzed: tasmā tadā vipassanā upekkhā sahagatā
translated: So insight is accompanied by equanimity without the distinction of the basic jhāna or the distinction of the inclination.

original: na hoti. Ekantena somanassasahagatāva hotīti. Etthapana sabbajjhānesu vasībhūtassa
analyzed: na hoti ekantena somanassa sahagatā ava hoti iti ettha pana sabba jjhānesu vasībhūtassa
translated: Therefore, at that time, insight is not accompanied by equanimity without a distinction of jhāna as basis or a distinction of inclination. It is definitely accompanied by joy only.🔽But when mastery has been achieved in all jhānas,🔽then, having made any one jhāna the basis, whether that one or another,

original: yaṃkiñci ekaṃ jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā taṃ pā aññaṃvā maggeyaṃyaṃ jhānaṃ icchati. Maggavuṭṭhānakāle
analyzed: yaṃ kiñci ekam jhānam pādakam katvā tam aññam vā maggeyaṃyam jhānam icchati magga vuṭṭhāna kāle
translated: at the time of emerging from the path,

original: ajjhāsayabalena taṃtaṃjhānānurūpaṃ vipassanāyaca maggeca vedanā pariṇāmo veditabbo.
analyzed: ajjhāsaya balena tat tat jhāna anurūpam vipassanāya ca magge ca vedanā pariṇāmaḥ veditabbo
translated: the change in feeling in insight and in the path should be understood to be in conformity with that jhāna by the power of the inclination.

original: Napana vedanāniyāmonāma visuṃ vattabboti.🔽67. Saṅgahagāthāyaṃ anuttaraṃ aṭṭhavidhaṃ cittaṃ jhānaṅgayogabhedena ekekaṃ pañcadhā
analyzed: na pana vedanā niyāmaḥ nāma visum vattabbo ti  anuttaram aṭṭhavidham cittam jhā aṅga yoga bhedena ekekam pañcadhā
translated: But the change in feeling is not to be told separately under the name of “change of consciousness.”🔽In the summary verse, the eight kinds of unsurpassed consciousness are said to be of forty kinds by taking each one as fivefold

original: katvā cattālīsavidhanti ca vuccatīti yojanā. Idāni sabbāni mahaggatā nuttaracittāni
analyzed: katvā cattālīsavidhanti ca vuccati iti yojanā idāni sabbāni mahaggatā anuttara cittāni
translated: by the division of the jhāna factors. Now, in order to show all the kinds of exalted unsurpassed consciousness

original: pañcavidhe jhāna koṭṭhāse saṅgahetvā dassetuṃ yathāca rūpāvacarantiādimāha. Yathā
analyzed: pañcavidhe jhāna koṭṭhāse saṅgahetvā dassetum yathā ca rūpa avacaranti ādim āha yathā
translated: by including them in the five sections of jhāna, he said, “And as to the profitable of the fine-material sphere,”🔽and so on.

original: rūpāvacaraṃ cittaṃ pathamādijjhānabhede gayhati. Jhāna bhedasiddhe pathamajjhānikacittādike🔽pañcavidhe cittabhede saṅgayhati, tathā anuttarañca cittaṃ pathamādijjhānabhede saṅgayhati.🔽Āruppañcacittaṃ upakkhekaggatā saṅkhātena pañcamajjhānena yuttattā pañcame jhāne
analyzed: rūpāvacaram cittam pathama ādi jhāna bhede gayhati jhāna bheda siddhe pathama jhānika citta ādike  pañcavidhe citta bhede saṅgayhati tathā anuttaram ca cittam pathama ādi jhāna bhede saṅgayhati  āruppañcacittam saṅkhātena pañcamajjhānena yutta ttā pañcame jhāne
translated: The fine-material-sphere consciousness is included in the first jhāna, etc., according to the analysis of the jhānas. When the jhānas are established according to the analysis of the first jhāna, etc.,🔽it is included in the fivefold analysis of consciousness. Likewise, the supramundane consciousness is included in the first jhāna, etc., according to the analysis of the jhānas.

original: pañcamajjhānikacittabhede saṅgayhati. Tasmā ekekaṃ patamādikaṃ pathamajjhānikacittādikaṃ🔽jhānaṃ jhānacittaṃ ekādasa vidhaṃ hoti. Antetu antimabhūte pañcamajjhānikacittabhedepana🔽jhānaṃ cittaṃ tevīsatividhaṃ bhaveti yojanā. Etthaca jhānasaddena taṃsampayuttaṃ
analyzed: pañcama jhānika citta bhede tasmai ekekam patama ādikam pathama jhānika citta ādikam  jhānam jhāna cittam ekādasa vidham ante tu antima bhūte  jhānam cittam tevīsatividham bhava iti yojanā ettha ca jhāna saddena tad sampayuttam
translated: The five immaterial consciousnesses are included in the fifth jhāna, because they are associated with the fifth jhāna called the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception. Thus the jhāna, which is the first jhāna, etc., the consciousness of the first jhāna, etc.,

original: cittameva vuccati. Na hi jhānaṃ ekādasavidhaṃvā tevīsatividhaṃvā hotīti.
analyzed: cittam eva vuccati na hi jhānam ekādasavidham vā tevīsatividham vā hoti iti
translated: is of eleven kinds. But the jhāna, which is the fifth jhāna, the consciousness of the fifth jhāna, is of twenty-three kinds, according to the analysis of the fifth jhāna, which is the last. This is the construction. And here the word “jhāna” denotes only the consciousness associated with it. For the jhāna is not of eleven kinds or twenty-three kinds.

original: [69] Yaṃpana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yaṃpana vibhāvaniyam
translated: But in the analysis it is said:

original: “Rūpāvacaracittaṃ pathamajjhānantiādinā vuccatītica āruppañcāpi pañcamajjhānavohāraṃ labhatī”ti ca vuttaṃ. Taṃ na yujjati.
analyzed: rūpāvacara cittam pathama jhānam ti ādinā vuccati iti ca āruppam ca api pañcama jhāna vohāram labhati iti ca vuttam tam na yujjati
translated: “The formless states are called the first jhāna, etc., and they get the designation ‘fifth jhāna’ too” .🔽But that is not correct.

original: Na hi cittaṃ pathamajjhānaṃ hoti. Naca pañcamajjhānavohāraṃ labhatīti.
analyzed: na hi cittam pathama jhānam hoti na ca pañcama jhāna vohāram labhati iti
translated: For the mind is not the first jhāna, nor does it get the designation ‘fifth jhāna.’

original: [70] Yāca imissāgāthāyaṃ aparāpi yojanā vuttā. Sāpi na yuttāeva.
analyzed: aparā api yojanā vuttā sā api na yuttā eva
translated: And the other interpretation of the verse is not correct either.🔽And the word “first” should be construed with each of the words “perceptions” and “jhānas.”

original: Tathā saddassa pathamādijjhānabhedeti padassa purato paṭhitattāti. Evaṃ yathā vibhajitabbe
analyzed: tathā saddassa pathama ādi jhāna bheda iti padassa puratas paṭhita ttā ati evam yathā vibhajitabbe
translated: So when one part is analysed in this way,

original: ekadese vibhatte sabbaṃ ekūnanavutividhaṃ cittaṃ ekavīsasataṃ katvā vibhattaṃnāma
analyzed: eka dese vibhatte sabbam ekūna navutividham cittam ekavīsa satam katvā vibhattaṃnāma
translated: all the eighty-nine kinds of consciousness are analysed by making them into two hundred and one kinds.

original: hoti. Tathā vibhajitvā idāni taṃsaṅgahaṃ dassento antimagāthamāha. Puññaṃ sattatiṃsavidhaṃ
analyzed: hoti tathā vibhajitvā idāni tad saṅgaham dassentaḥ antima gātham āha puññam sattatiṃsavidham
translated: Now, in order to show the inclusion of them, he stated the last verse:

original: hoti. Tathā pākaṃ dvipaññāsavidhaṃ hoti. Iti ekūnanavutividhāni cittāni ekavīsasataṃ
analyzed: hoti tathā pākam dvipaññāsavidham hoti iti ekūna navutividhāni cittāni ekavīsa satam
translated: The profitable is of thirty-one kinds,🔽And so is the functional;🔽The wise declare that all the eighty-nine

original: katvā budhā paṇḍitā āhu kathesuṃ. Kathentivā vibhajanti vicakkhaṇāti vuttaṃ hotīti.
analyzed: katvā budhā paṇḍitā āhu kathesum kathentivā vibhajanti vicakkhaṇā iti vuttam hoti iti
translated: Are thus included in the three.

original: Iti paramatthadīpaniyānāma abhidhammatthasaṅgahassa
analyzed: iti
translated: So in the Abhidhamma-attha-saṅgaha, called “The Illumination of the Ultimate Meaning”,

original: Catutthavaṇṇanāya cittasaṅgahassa
analyzed: catuttha vaṇṇanāya citta saṅgahassa
translated: the fourth chapter, called “The Collection of Consciousness”,

original: Paramatthadīpanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: is finished.

original: Cetasikasaṅgaha paramatthadīpanī
translated: The Collection of Mental Factors, The Illumination of the Ultimate Meaning

original: 68. Evaṃ cittaṅgahaṃ dassetvā idāni anupattaṃ cetasika saṅgahaṃ dassento catūhi sampayogalakkhaṇehi
analyzed: evam cittaṅgaham dassetvā idāni anupattam saṅgaham dassento catūhi sampayoga lakkhaṇehi
translated: Having thus shown the collection of consciousness, now, in order to show the collection of mental factors that is appropriate, he begins the first stanza in order to show the four characteristics of association,🔽the meaning of the term, and the individual nature. Therein, the seeing of the four characteristics of association is:

original: saha vacanatthañca sarūpatthañca tāva dassetuṃ ādi gāthamāha. Tattha ekuppādanirodhācaekālambaṇavatthukāti🔽catussampayogalakkhaṇadassanaṃ. Ceto yuttāti vacanatthadassanaṃ. Cetasiyuttā cetasāvā
analyzed: saha vacana ttham ca sarūpa attham ca tāva dassetuṃ ādi gātham āha tattha eka uppāda nirodhāt ca eka ālambaṇa vatthukā ti  catur sampayoga lakkhaṇa dassanam cetaḥ yuttā ati vacana attha dassanam cetasiyuttā cetasāvā
translated: “Having the same arising and cessation, the same object, and the same basis.”🔽The seeing of the meaning of the term is: “Associated with the mind.”🔽The seeing of the individual nature is: “They are associated with the mind, they are associated with the mind, they are mental factors.”

original: yuttā cetasikāti dassanato. Dvipaññāsadhammāti sarūpadassanaṃ. Cetasikāti pana siddhapada
analyzed: yuttā cetasikā ati dassanataḥ dvipaññāsa dhammā ati sarūpa dassanam cetasikā ati pana siddha pada
translated: The seeing of the established term is: “Mental factors.”

original: dassanaṃ. Tattha dhammānaṃ anāgatabhāvasaṅkhātā pubbantato uddhaṃ pajjanaṃ gamanaṃ
analyzed: dassanam tattha dhammānam anāgata bhāva saṅkhātā pubbantataḥ uddham pajjanam gamanam
translated: Therein, the going, the arising, of dhammas from the past, which is called the future state,

original: sarūpato pātubhavanaṃ uppādo. Jātīti vuttaṃ hoti. Sabbepihi saṅkhata dhammā anāgatabhāvapubbā🔽eva honti. Tato paccayasāmaggiṃ labhitvā paccuppannabhāvaṃ gacchanti. Tato nirujjhitvā🔽atītabhāvaṃ gacchantīti. Nirujjhanaṃ nirodho. Sarūpavināso bhaṅgo aniccatā maraṇanti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Yā cittassa jāti, sāyeva phassādīnaṃ. Yā cittassa jarā, yaṃ cittassa🔽maraṇaṃ, yaṃ cittassa ārammaṇaṃ vatthu. Tadeva phassādīnantiādinā heṭṭhā vuttanayena🔽eko uppādo etesanti ekuppādā. Eko nirodho etesanti ekanirodhā. Ekuppādāca te ekanirodhācāti
analyzed: sarūpataḥ pātubhavanam uppādaḥ jātī iti vuttam hoti sabbe pi hi dhammāḥ anāgata bhāva pubbā  eva honti tatas paccaya sāmaggim labhitvā paccuppanna bhāvam gacchanti tatas nirujjhitvā  atīta bhāvam gacchanti iti nirujjhanam nirodho sarūpa vināsaḥ bhaṅgaḥ anicca tā  vuttam hoti yā cittassa jāti sāyā iva phassa ādīnam yā cittassa jarā yam cittassa  maraṇam yam cittassa ārammaṇam vatthu tat eva phassa ādīnam ti ādinā heṭṭhā vutta nayena  ekaḥ uppādaḥ etesanti eka uppādāḥ ekaḥ nirodhaḥ etesanti eka nirodhāḥ eka uppādāḥ ca te eka nirodhāḥ ca ati
translated: Arising is the manifestation of the individual essences. Birth is what is meant. And all formed things are in the future state before they come to be. Then, when they obtain the concurrence of conditions, they come to be in the present state. Then, having ceased, they go to the past state.🔽Cessation is the ceasing of that. The dissolution of the individual essences, impermanence, death, is what is meant.🔽And the arising of consciousness is the arising of contact, etc.,🔽and the ageing of consciousness is the ageing of contact, etc.,🔽and the death of consciousness is the death of contact, etc.,🔽and the object of consciousness is the object of contact, etc.,🔽in the way already stated .🔽They have one arising, thus they are of one arising. They have one cessation, thus they are of one cessation. They are of one arising and of one cessation,

original: ekuppādanirodhā. Uttarapade ekasaddassa lopo. Evaṃ paratthapi. Ekaṃ ālambaṇaṃ etesanti
analyzed: eka uppāda nirodhāḥ uttara pade eka saddassa lopaḥ evam parattha api ekam ālambaṇam etesan ti
translated: Arising is the manifestation of the individual essences. Birth is what is meant. And all formed things are in the future state before they come to be. Then they reach the present state by obtaining the concurrence of conditions. Then they reach the past state by ceasing. Cessation is the ceasing. Destruction of the individual essences is what is meant by dissolution, impermanence, and death. And the arising of consciousness is the arising of contact, and so on. The ageing of consciousness is the ageing of contact, and so on. The death of consciousness is the death of contact, and so on. The object of consciousness is the object of contact, and so on. Thus, in the way already stated, there is one arising of these, thus they are of one arising. There is one cessation of these, thus they are of one cessation. And they are of one arising and of one cessation because of the omission of the word “one” in the second instance. So too with the rest. They have one object, thus they are of one object.

original: ekālambaṇā. Ekaṃ vatthu etesanti ekavatthukā. Ekālambaṇāca te ekavatthukācāti ekālambaṇavatthukā.
analyzed: eka ālambaṇāḥ ekam vatthu etesanti eka vatthukāḥ eka ālambaṇāḥ ca te eka vatthukāḥ ca ati eka ālambaṇa vatthukā
translated: They have one object. They have one basis. They have one object and one basis.

original: Ālambaṇaṃ panettha ekacittassapi bahudeva hoti. Ekattaṃpana upanetvā ekaṃ ālambaṇanti🔽vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: ālambaṇam pana ittha eka cittassa api hoti ekattam pana upanetvā ekam ālambaṇanti  vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: But here the object is many even for a single consciousness. But it should be regarded as “one object” by way of the unity of the object.

original: [71] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī

original: “Ekato uppādoca nirodhoca yesaṃ, te ekuppādanirodhā”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: ekatas uppādaḥ ca nirodhaḥ ca yesam te eka uppāda nirodhā ti vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: it is said, “Those that have one arising and one cessation are of one arising and one cessation.” That is not good.

original: Na hi ekakkhaṇe ekato uppādamattena ekuppādatā idha adhippetā. Athakho vuttanayeneva adhippetā. Vuttañhetaṃ mūlaṭīkāyaṃ –
analyzed: na hi eka kkhaṇe ekatas uppāda mattena ekuppāda tā idha adhippetā atha kho vutta nayena iva adhippetā vuttam ha etam mūlaṭīkāyam
translated: For here “of one arising” is not intended by way of mere arising together in one moment, but rather by way of the method stated. For this is said in the Mula-Tika:

original: Ekakalāpapariyāpannānaṃ rūpānaṃsahevauppādādippavattito
analyzed: eka kalāpa pariyāpannānam
translated: “Because the material instances included in one moment arise, etc., together,

original: Ekassakalāpassauppādādayo ekekāva hontīti.
analyzed: ekassa kalāpa sauppāda ādayaḥ ekekāḥ ava honti iti
translated: the arising, etc., of one moment are only one each.”

original: Tatrāyaṃ yojanā. Ekuppādanirodhāca ekālambaṇavatthukā ca hutvā yedhammā cetoyuttā.
analyzed: tatra ayam yojanā eka uppāda nirodhāt ca eka ālambaṇa vatthukā ca hutvā cetaḥ yuttā
translated: Here is the application: Those states that are associated with consciousness are of one arising and one cessation and have one object and one basis.

original: Te dvipaññāsadhammā cetasikā matāti. Bhāvapadhānaṃpivā ettha yuttaṃ. Visesaneca nissakkavacanaṃ.
analyzed: te dvipaññāsa dhammā cetasikā matā ati ettha yuttam visesane ca nissakka vacanam
translated: These fifty-two ideas are called mental factors. But it is the mental formation that is appropriate here, and the specification is a locution of non-separation.

original: Ekuppādanirodhabhāvena ekālambaṇa vatthuka bhāvenaca yedhammā cetoyuttā. Te dvipaññāsadhammā🔽cetasikānāma matā ñātāti. Etthaca ye cetoyuttā. Te cetasikāti vutte cittassa sahajātapaccayuppannarūpānipi
analyzed: eka uppāda nirodha bhāvena eka ālambaṇa vatthuka bhāvena ca ye dhammā cetaḥ yuttā te dvipaññāsa dhammā  cetasikā nāma matā ñātā ati ettha ca ye cetaḥ yuttā te cetasikā ati vutte cittassa sahajāta paccaya uppanna rūpāni pi
translated: Those ideas that are associated with cognizance by having a single arising and a single cessation, and by having a single object and a single physical basis, are called🔽the fifty-two mental factors.🔽And here, if those that are associated with cognizance were called mental factors, then the conascent and postnascent materiality that is bound up with cognizance would be called mental factors too,

original: tadāyattavuttitāya ekantena cittasambandhīni hutvā cetoyuttāni cetasikāni nāma siyuṃ.
analyzed: tad āyatta vutti tāyai ekantena citta sambandhīni hutvā cetaḥ yuttāni cetasikāni nāma siyum
translated: since it is bound up with cognizance by being dependent on cognizance for its occurrence.

original: Tasmā tesaṃ nivattanatthaṃ ekuppādanirodhāca, ekā lambaṇavatthukāti vuttaṃ. Tānihi
analyzed: tasmā tesam nivattana attham eka uppāda nirodhāt ca ekā lambaṇa vatthukā ti vuttam tāni hi
translated: So in order to exclude that, it is said that they have a single arising and a single cessation, and a single object and a single physical basis. For those

original: cittena khaṇato sahuppannānipi bhinnasantānattā yā cittassa jāti, sāeva tesanti imaṃ
analyzed: cittena khaṇataḥ bhinna santāna ttā yā cittassa jāti sā eva tesanti imam
translated: ideas, though they arise together with cognizance at the same moment, do not share the same characteristics as the cognizance’s birth,

original: lakkhaṇaṃpi nānubhonti. Aññaṃhi rūpasantānaṃ. Aññaṃ arūpasantānanti. Phassādīnaṃpana
analyzed: lakkhaṇam pi na anubhonti aññam hi rūpa santānam aññam arūpa santānam ti phassa ādīnam pana
translated: because they have a different continuity. For the materiality continuity is one, and the immaterial continuity is another. And though contact, etc.,🔽are bound up with cognizance, they are not called mental factors, because they are not associated with cognizance by having a single arising and a single cessation, and a single object and a single physical basis.

original: uppādamattameva cittena saha ekaṃ nahoti. Athakho nirodhopi ālambaṇaṃpi vatthupi
analyzed: uppāda mattam eva cittena saha ekam nahoti athakho nirodhaḥ api ālambaṇam vatthu pi
translated: and the mere arising of consciousness does not occur together with the object. Then cessation, too, is the object, and the basis,

original: sabbaṃ ekamevāti ñāpanatthaṃ eka nirodhādiggahaṇaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Na hi evaṃ🔽avutte sakkā tathā jānitunti. Yasmāpana yathā bahujanasantako eko goṇo tissassa goṇo
analyzed: sabbam ekam eva ati ñāpana ttham eka nirodha ādi ggahaṇam vuttanti daṭṭhabbam na hi evam  a vutte sakkā tathā jānitun ti yasmā apana yathā bahu jana santakaḥ ekaḥ goṇaḥ tissassa goṇaḥ
translated: and the mere arising is not one with the consciousness. Then, in order to show that the cessation, the object, and the physical basis are all one, the words “one cessation” and so on are stated. For if they were not stated in this way, it would not be possible to know that they are one.

original: dattassa goṇoti evaṃ visuṃ visuṃpi vattabboyeva hoti. Evamevaṃ uppādo nirodhoca ekasmiṃ
analyzed: dattassa goṇo ti evam visum vattabbo yeva hoti evam evam uppādaḥ nirodhaḥ ca ekasmin
translated: But just as a single ox belonging to many people is called “the ox of Devadatta,” “the ox of Yajñadatta,” and so on, and must be spoken of separately in this way, so too, although the arising and the cessation are the same in a single aggregate of material form or immateriality, the arising of contact, the arising of feeling, the arising of the earth element, the arising of the water element, and so on must be spoken of separately in this way. Therefore in the suttas it is said:

original: rūpārūpakalāpe ekovasamānopi phassassa uppādo vedanāya uppādo pathavidhātuyā uppādo🔽āpodhātuyā uppādoti evamādinā nayena visuṃ visuṃpi vattabboyeva. Tasmā suttantesu –
analyzed: rūpa arūpa kalāpe phassassa uppādaḥ vedanāya uppādaḥ pathavi dhātuyā uppādaḥ  āpodhātuyāḥ uppādaḥ ti evamādinā nayena visum visum pi vattabbaḥ yeva tasmā suttantesu
translated: “The arising of feeling is discerned, the fall of it is discerned, and its change while standing is discerned. The arising of perception …

original: Vedanāya uppādo paññāyati. Vayo paññāyati. Ṭhikāya aññatthaṃ paññāyati. Saññāya.
analyzed: vedanāya uppādo paññāyati vayo paññāyati ṭhikāya aññattham paññāyati saññāya
translated: The arising of volitional formations … The arising of consciousness is discerned, the fall of it is discerned, and its change while standing is discerned.”

original: Saṅkhārānaṃ. Viññāṇassa. La. Paññāyatīti vuttaṃ. Tathā yo bhikkhave pathavidhātuyā
analyzed: saṅkhārānam viññāṇassa paññāyati iti vuttam tathā yaḥ bhikkhave pathavi dhātuyā
translated: And so too: “Bhikkhus, that which in the world is called earth is the four great elements and the material form derived from the great elements.

original: uppādo ṭhitiabhinibbatti pātubhāvo. Dukkhasseso uppādo rogānaṃ ṭhiti jarā maraṇassa
analyzed: uppādaḥ ṭhiti abhinibbatti pātubhāvaḥ dukkhassa esaḥ uppādaḥ rogānaṃ ṭhiti jarā maraṇassa
translated: This is the arising of suffering, the presence of the disease, the manifestation of ageing-and-death.

original: pātubhāvo. Yo bhikkhave āpodhātuyā. Yo bhikkhave tejo dhātuyā. Yo bhikkhave vāyodhātuyā.
analyzed: pātubhāvaḥ yaḥ bhikkhave āpaḥ dhātuyā yaḥ bhikkhave tejaḥ dhātuyā yaḥ bhikkhave vāyaḥ dhātuyā
translated: “Bhikkhus, whatever has the earth element in it, whatever has the water element in it, whatever has the fire element in it, whatever has the air element in it,🔽whatever has the eye faculty in it, whatever has the ear faculty in it, … whatever has the mind faculty in it,

original: Yo bhikkhave cakkhussa.La. Manassa uppādo.La. Jarāmaraṇassa pātubhāvoti.
analyzed: yaḥ bhikkhave jarā maraṇassa pātubhāvaḥ
translated: its arising is the arising of ageing-and-death. Its presence is the presence of ageing-and-death. Its manifestation is the manifestation of ageing-and-death.”

original: Vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Itarathā jīvitindriyādīnapi ekasmiṃ kalāpe bahubhāvo vattabbo
analyzed: vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam itarathā jīvitindriya ādīn api ekasmin kalāpe bahu bhāvaḥ vattabbaḥ
translated: “Should be seen” is said. Otherwise, the presence of many in one group would have to be stated even of the life faculty, etc.

original: siyā. Yo arūpīnaṃ dhammānaṃ āyu ṭhiti avaṭṭhitīti hi vuttaṃ. Tathā vikārarūpānaṃ.
analyzed: siyā yaḥ arūpīnam dhammānam āyu ṭhiti avaṭṭhiti iti hi vuttam tathā vikāra rūpānam
translated: For it is said: “What is the life of immaterial dhammas, their presence, their non-disappearance?” Likewise of the changing material dhammas.

original: Sabbesaṃpivā cakkhādīnaṃ upādārūpānaṃ. Catunnaṃ cahābhūtānaṃ upādāyarūpantica catunnaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu ādīnam upādā rūpānam catunnam cahābhūtānam catunnam
translated: Or of all the eye, etc., derived materiality, and of the four primary elements.

original: mahābhūtānaṃ upādāya pasādotica vuttanti. Kāyalahutā cittalahutādayopana atthavisesadīpanatthaṃ
analyzed: upādāya vuttam
translated: The derived materiality consisting of the four primary elements is said. The clarity consisting of the four primary elements is said. The lightness of body, the lightness of mind, etc., are stated

analyzed: dvidhā bhinditvā vuttā sā ca bhavissati iti ayam ettha paramattha dīpanā

original: [72] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī,

original: Imamatthaṃ asallakkhetvā yaṃ vuttaṃ “yadi ekuppādamatteneva cetoyuttāti adhippetā.

translated: Without considering this matter, it is said: “If what is intended is that they are associated with the mind only in the sense of having a single arising,

analyzed: tadā cittena saha uppajjamānānam rūpa dhammānam pi cetaḥ yutta tā āpajjeyya ati eka nirodha ggahaṇaṃ

original: Evampi cittānuparivattino viññattidvayassa pasaṅgo nasakkā nīvāretuṃ. Tathā ekato
analyzed: evam pi citta anuparivattinaḥ viññatti dvayassa pasaṅgaḥ na sakkā nīvāretum tathā ekatas
translated: Even so, it is not possible to prevent the two kinds of intimation from being included, which in turn are subject to the mind. Thus,

analyzed: uppādaḥ vā nirodhaḥ vā etesanti eka uppāda nirodhā ti parikappentassa puretaram uppajjitvā
translated: having arisen together, they are called ‘having a single arising’ and ‘having a single cessation’ by the assumption that they have a single arising or a single cessation.

original: cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe nirujjhamānānampi rūpadhammānanti ekālambaṇaggahaṇaṃ. Ye evaṃ
analyzed: cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe nirujjhamānānam pi rūpa dhammānam ti eka ālambaṇa ggahaṇam ye evam
translated: And at the moment of the dissolution of the mind that arose previously, the material phenomena that are ceasing are also called ‘having a single object.’ Those that

original: tividhalakkhaṇā. Te niyāmato ekavatthukā yevāti dassanatthaṃ. Ekavatthukaggahaṇanti.
