analyzed: alam atipapañcena ati sabbam tam niratthakam eva
translated: There is no need for so much verbosity.” All this is pointless.

original: 69. Kathañca dvipaññāsa hontīti pucchitvā pathamaṃ dvipaññāsa sarūpaṃ tīhi rāsīhi
analyzed: kathañca dvipaññāsa honti iti pucchitvā pathamam dvipaññāsa sarūpam tīhi rāsīhi
translated: How are they fifty-two? Having asked this, the first fifty-two are materiality. They are divided into three groups:

original: vibhajitvā dassento kathantiādimāha. Tattha phusatīti phasso. Phusanti sampayuttakā🔽dhammā etenāti phasso. Phusanamattamevavā etanti phasso. Phusanañcettha ārammaṇassa🔽iṭṭhāniṭṭharasaṃ āhacca upahacca gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yato tadanubhavanti vedanā pātubhavati.
analyzed: vibhajitvā dassentaḥ katham ti ādim āha tattha phusati iti phassaḥ phusanti sampayuttakā  dhammāḥ etena ati phassaḥ phusanam attam eva vā etat ti phassaḥ phusanam ca ittha ārammaṇassa  iṭṭha aniṭṭha rasam āhacca upahacca gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam yatas tat anubhavanti vedanā pātubhavati
translated: He said “Contact” in order to show that it is divided up. Herein, it touches , thus it is contact . Or alternatively, the things associated with it touch , thus it is contact . Or alternatively, it is merely the touching , thus it is contact . Herein, the touching should be regarded as the apprehension of the object by impinging upon it with the respective aspect of what is agreeable or disagreeable, since it is only when that has occurred that the experiencing of it, which is feeling, becomes manifest.🔽🔽

original: Phassapaccayā vedanāti hi vuttaṃ. Svāyaṃ phusanalakkhaṇo. Nanucāyaṃ arūpadhammo.
analyzed: phassa paccayā vedanā ti hi vuttam svāyam phusana lakkhaṇaḥ nanu ca ayam arūpa dhammo
translated: He shows this by the question and answer beginning with “Contact is what? ” Herein, it touches , thus it is contact . Or alternatively, the associated states are touched by it, thus it is contact . Or alternatively, it is just mere touching, thus it is contact . Herein, touching is to be regarded as the impinging apprehension of an object’s desirable or undesirable aspect, since it is said, “With contact as condition, feeling” , and it has the characteristic of touching. But this is an immaterial state.

original: Naca arūpadhammā appaṭighasabhāvā kiñci phusantīti. Saccaṃ, ayaṃpana phusanā kārenaca
analyzed: na ca arūpa dhammā appaṭigha sabhāvā kiñci phusanti iti saccam ayam pana phusanā kārena ca
translated: And immaterial states do not touch anything, since they have no impact.

original: pavattati. Yañca phusantehi sādhetabbaṃ. Tañca kiccaṃ sādheti. Tasmā ayaṃ phassotica
analyzed: pavattati yat ca phusantehi sādhetabbam tat ca kiccam sādheti tasmai ayam phassaḥ iti ca
translated: That is so, but this contact occurs as the cause of touching, and it accomplishes the function of touching,

original: phusanalakkhaṇotica vutto. Kiṃpana sādhetīti. Ārammaṇarasānurūpaṃ cittassa vikārapatti.
analyzed: phusana lakkhaṇaḥ ti ca vuttaḥ sādheti iti ārammaṇa rasa anurūpam cittassa vikāra patti
translated: so it is said to have the characteristic of touching. But what does it touch? It touches the object’s aspect that is in accordance with the feeling,

original: Vedanāvisesuppattiṃvā. Ayañca attho ambilakhādādike disvā aparassa kheḷuppādādīsu pākaṭoti.
analyzed: vedanā visesuppattim vā ayam ca atthaḥ ambila khāda ādike disvā aparassa kheḷuppāda ādīsu pākaṭaḥ ti
translated: or it touches the occurrence of a particular kind of feeling. And this meaning is evident in such cases as the following: when one sees someone eating sour mangoes, another gets saliva, and so on.

original: [73] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī,

original: “Kheḷuppādādiviya daṭṭhabbo”ti vuttaṃ. Evañcasati idaṃ upamā mattaṃ siyā. Atipākaṭāyapana phassappavattiyā dassana midanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: kheḷuppāda ādi viya daṭṭhabbaḥ ti vuttam evam ca sati idam upamā mattam siyā phassa pavattiyā dassana midam ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: “It should be regarded as like the arising of sweat,” it is said. And if that is so, the simile would be too obvious. But it should be regarded as the seeing of the occurrence of contact, which is very obvious.

original: 70. Vedayatīti vedanā. Ārammaṇarasaṃ anubhavati. Aviditaṃvā ārammaṇarasaṃ sampayuttānaṃ🔽taṃsamaṅgipuggalānaṃ vā viditaṃpākaṭaṃ karotīti attho. Vindantiva etāya sattā sātaṃvā
analyzed: vedayati iti vedanā ārammaṇa rasam anubhavati aviditam vā ārammaṇa rasam sampayuttānam  tad samaṅgi puggalānam vā viditam pākaṭam karoti iti atthaḥ sattā
translated: It feels, thus it is feeling . It experiences the taste of the object. Or the meaning can be regarded as follows: it makes known to the associated states

original: asātaṃvā labhantīti vedanā. Vedayitamattamevavā etanti vedanā. Pāḷiyaṃpana –
analyzed: asātam vā labhanti iti vedanā vedayitam attam eva vai etat iti vedanā
translated: or to the person who possesses the associated states the taste of the object that is not yet known, or it makes it evident if it is already known. Or it is called feeling because beings obtain pleasure or pain by means of it. Or feeling is merely that which is felt . And in the texts it is said:

original: Vedayati vedayatīti kho bhikkhave tasmā vedanāti vuccati. Kiñca vedayati, sukhaṃpi vedayati. Dukkhaṃpi vedayati. Adukkhamasukhaṃpi vedayatīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vedayati vedayati iti kho bhikkhave tasmā vedanā ati vuccati kiñca vedayati sukham pi vedayati dukkham pi vedayati adukkham asukham pi vedayati iti vuttam
translated: “Bhikkhus, it feels, thus it is called feeling . And what does it feel? It feels pleasure, it feels pain, it feels neither-pain-nor-pleasure” .

original: Nanu sabbepi cittacetasikā dhammā ārammaṇarasānubhavanappa katikāevāti tepi vedanānāma
analyzed: nanu sabbe pi citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ ārammaṇa rasa anubhavana ppa katikā eva ati te pi vedanā nāma
translated: But do not all states of consciousness and its concomitants experience the taste of the object? And so are they not all called feeling?

original: siyunti. Nasiyuṃ. Tehi kiccantarabyāvaṭā honti. Ārammaṇarasaṃ ujuṃ anubhavituṃ nasakkonti.
analyzed: siyunti na siyum tehi kicca antara byāvaṭāḥ honti ārammaṇa rasam ujum anubhavitum na sakkonti
translated: “They do not know” means they are not aware. They are occupied with their own functions and cannot experience the taste of the object in its entirety.

original: Attano attano kiccaṃ karontāva ekadesamattena anubhavanti. Vedanāyevapana anaññakiccatāya
analyzed: attano attano kiccam eka desam attena anubhavanti anañña kicca tāya
translated: They experience it only in part, each according to its own function. Feeling alone is capable of experiencing,

original: anubhavanakicce ādhipaccayogatāyaca issarabhāvena anubhavatīti sāeva vedanānāma bhavituṃ
analyzed: anubhavana kicce issara bhāvena anubhavati iti sā eva vedanā nāma bhavitum
translated: because it is the dominant condition for the function of experiencing. Therefore it alone is the one that experiences.

original: arahatīti. Evañcakatvā rājaggabhojana rasānubhavane tesaṃ sūdasadisatā vedanāyaevaca🔽rājasadisatā vuttāti.
analyzed: arahati iti evam ca katvā vedanāya eva ca  rāja sadisa tā vuttā ati
translated: If it were not so, they would be like cooks in the experience of the taste of the king’s meal, and feeling alone would be like the king.

original: 71. Sañjānātīti saññā. Puna jānanatthaṃ saññāṇaṃ karotīti attho. Ayañhi pubbe gahitasaññānena
analyzed: sañjānāti iti saññā puna jānana attham saññāṇam karoti iti atthaḥ ayam hi pubbe gahita saññānena
translated: “ Perceives” means conceives. The meaning is that it makes the conceiving of perceiving again. For at the time of conceiving through the perception of what was apprehended before,

original: sañjānanakālepi puna jānanatthaṃ saññāṇaṃ karotiyevāti. Sāhi evaṃ punappunaṃ saññāṇaṃ
analyzed: sañjānana kāle pi puna jānana attham saññāṇam karoti yeva ati sā hi evam punappunam saññāṇam
translated: it makes the conceiving of perceiving again for the purpose of perceiving again. Thus it arises again and again by making the conceiving of perceiving,

original: katvā uppajjamānā thirasaññābhāvaṃ patvā yāvatāyukaṃpi bhavantaraṃ patvāpi sattānaṃ
analyzed: katvā uppajjamānā thira saññā bhāvam patvā bhavantaram patvā api sattānam
translated: and it reaches the state of gross perception. It reaches the state of an existence that lasts for the whole life-span, or even for an existence that lasts for an eon.

original: appamuṭṭhabhāvaṃ sādheti. Micchā bhinivesasaññābhāvaṃ patvāca ime satte sabbaññu
analyzed: appamuṭṭha bhāvam sādheti micchā abhinivesa saññā bhāvam ime satte sabbaññu
translated: and it establishes the state of being unforgotten. And when it has reached the state of being a wrong perception of misapprehension, it makes these beings incapable of being awakened even by omniscient Buddhas.

original: buddhehipi bodhetuṃ asakkuṇeyye karotīti. Tathāhi sā puna sañjānanatthaṃ nimittakaraṇe
analyzed: buddhehi pi bodhetum karoti iti tathā hi sā puna sañjānana attham nimitta karaṇe
translated: And that is why it is like a saw for the purpose of making the sign arise again for the purpose of remembering.

original: dārutacchakasadisātica. Yathāgahita nimittavasena abhinivesakaraṇe hatthidassaka
analyzed: yathā gahita nimitta vasena abhinivesa karaṇe hatthi dassaka
translated: It is like a blind man’s guide for the purpose of misapprehending the sign as apprehended.🔽It is like a young deer in the grass for the purpose of apprehending the objective field that has appeared.

original: andhasadisātica. Upaṭṭhitavisayaggahaṇe tiṇapurisakesu migapotakasadisātica vuttāti. Pāḷiyaṃpana –
analyzed: andha sadisā ati ca upaṭṭhita visaya ggahaṇe tiṇa purisakesu miga potaka sadisā ati ca vuttā ati pāḷiyam pana
translated: And in the texts it is said:

original: Sañjānāti sañjānātītikho bhikkhave tasmā saññāti vuccati. Kiñca sañjānāti. Nīlaṃpi sañjānāti. Pītakaṃpi sañjānātītiādi vuttanti.
analyzed: sañjānāti sañjānāti iti kho bhikkhave tasmā saññā iti vuccati kiñca sañjānāti nīlam pi sañjānāti pītakam pi sañjānāti itiādi vuttanti
translated: “He perceives, bhikkhus, he perceives: that is why ‘perception’ is said. And what does he perceive? He perceives blue, he perceives yellow” , and so on.

original: 72. Cetayatīti cetanā. Sampayuttadhamme tasmiṃ tasmiṃ ārammaṇevā kiccevā abhisandahati
analyzed: cetayati iti cetanā sampayutta dhamme tasmin tasmin ārammaṇā iva abhisandahati
translated: It directs , thus it is direction . It is the directing of associated states on to that or the other object,

original: punappunaṃ ghaṭeti, tattha pabandhavasena nirantaraṃ pavattamāne karotīti attho.
analyzed: punappunam ghaṭa iti tattha pabandha vasena nirantaram pavattamāne karoti iti attho
translated: or it is the repeated combining of them there, or it is the making of them occur uninterruptedly there by binding them to it.

original: Pakappeti vā te. Saṃvidahati ārammaṇapaṭilābhāyavā kammasiddhiyā abhisaṅkharoti.
analyzed: pakappeti vā te saṃvidahati ārammaṇa paṭilābhāya vā kamma siddhiyai abhisaṅkharoti
translated: Or he makes them ready. He resolves them for the obtaining of the object and for the success of the kamma he is about to do.

original: Āyūhativā te. Ārammaṇe sampiṇḍeti ekato samo sarante karotīti attho. Tathāhi sā āyūhanarasāhica
analyzed: āyūhati vā te ārammaṇe sampiṇḍeti ekatas samaḥ sarante karoti iti tathā hi sā
translated: Or he assembles them. The meaning is that he combines them into one and makes them go together to the object.

original: saṃvidhānapaccupaṭṭhānātica vuttā. Tāyahi tasmiṃ nirantaraṃ ussukkana byāpāravasena
analyzed: saṃvidhāna paccupaṭṭhānā ati ca vuttā tāyahi tasmin nirantaram byāpāra vasena
translated: For that is why it is said that it has the characteristic of assembling.

original: pavattamānāya taṃ sampayuttāpi attano attano kiccaṃ kurumānā tasmiṃ tatheva pavattantīti.
analyzed: pavattamānāya tam sampayuttā api attano attano kiccam kurumānā tasmin tathā iva pavattanti iti
translated: For by it, occurring in the way already stated by the application of urgency to that object without break, the associated states also occur in that way while performing their several functions.

original: Teneva sā sakicca parakicca sādhaka jeṭṭhasissa mahāvaḍḍhaki ādisadisāti vuttāti.🔽[74] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana🔽Ceteti saṅkhatābhisaṅkharaṇe byāpāramāpajjatīti vatvā tadatthasādhanatthaṃ yaṃ vuttaṃ🔽“vibhaṅge suttantabhājaniye saṅkhā rakkhandhaṃ vibhajantena saṅkhatamatisaṅkharontīti🔽saṅkhārāti vatvā”ti. Taṃ na yujjati.
analyzed: tena iva sā ādi sadisā ati vuttā ati 🔽vibhāvaniyam pana 🔽cetā iti saṅkhata abhisaṅkharaṇe byāpāram āpajjati iti vatvā tad attha sādhana ttham yam vuttam 🔽vibhaṅge suttanta bhājaniye saṅkhāḥ rakkhandham vibhajantena saṅkhatam atisaṅkharonti iti 🔽saṅkhāra ati tam na yujjati
translated: That is why it is said to be like a chief builder who is skilled in his work and who assembles and arranges the timber, etc., that he has ready.

original: Na hi vibhaṅge suttantabhājaniye saṅkhatama bhisaṅkharontīti saṅkhārāti vuttaṃ atthi. Khandhasaṃyuttake panetaṃ vuttanti.🔽73. Ekattārammaṇasaṅkhāto aggo koṭṭhāso koṭi vā etassāti ekaggaṃ. Cittaṃ, tassa bhāvo
analyzed: na hi vibhaṅge suttanta bhājaniye saṅkhatam abhisaṅkharonti iti saṅkhārā ati vuttam atthi khandha saṃyuttake pana etam vuttan ti  ekatta ārammaṇa saṅkhātaḥ aggaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ koṭi vā etassa ati ekaggam cittam tassa bhāvaḥ
translated: For in the Vibhaṅga, in the section dealing with the suttas, it is not said that they are formations that form what is formed; it is said that they are formations that form what is formed in the Khandha Samyutta.🔽It has a single peak, that is, a single foremost or principal state, in the sense of an object, thus it is “single-peaked” . The state of that is🔽singleness. For the object is of various kinds, even if it is only one. Therefore,

original: ekaggatā. Ārammaṇañhi nāma ekaṃpi nānāsabhāvaṃ hoti. Tasmā tassa ekassapi nānāsabhāvesu
analyzed: ekagga tā ārammaṇam hi nāma ekam pi nānā sabhāvam hoti tasmā tassa ekassa api nānā sabhāvesu
translated: without straying from that single object to various kinds of objects,

original: vikkhepaṃ apatvā ekasmiṃ sabhāve khaṇamattaṃpi pavattassa cittassa yoniccalākāro
analyzed: vikkhepam a patvā ekasmin sabhāve khaṇa mattam pi pavattassa cittassa yo niccala ākāro
translated: the state of the mind that occurs for just a moment on a single kind of object is a state of non-wavering.

original: atthi ayaṃ tasmiṃ ekaggābhidhānassa ekaggabuddhiyāca pavattihetubhāvena gayhatīti.
analyzed: atthi ayam tasmin ekagga abhidhānassa ekagga buddhiyāḥ ca pavatti hetu bhāvena gayhati iti
translated: This is what is meant by singleness, and it is that which is the cause of the singleness concept and the singleness idea.

original: Te neva hi sā nivāte dīpaccīnaṃ ṭhitiviya cetaso ṭhitīti daṭṭhabbāti vuttā.
analyzed: te na iva hi sā nivāte dīpaccīnam ṭhiti viya cetasaḥ ṭhiti iti daṭṭhabbā ati vuttā
translated: For it is said that it is like the steadiness of a lamp’s flame in a windless place.

original: [75] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Ekaṃ ārammaṇaṃ aggaṃ imassāti ekagga”nti vuttaṃ. Tatthapi aggasaddo koṭṭhāsevā koṭiyaṃvā pavattoti yutto. Kecipana ārammaṇe pavattoti vadanti. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: ekam ārammaṇam aggam imassa ati ekagganti vuttam tattha api agga saddo koṭṭhāse iva koṭiyam vā pavattoti yuttaḥ ārammaṇe pavattoti vadanti tam na sundaram
translated: “It is ‘one-pointed’ because it is the best of its object” . Here too the word “best” is appropriate as a term for a peak or for a head. But some say that it is used as a term for the object. That is not good.

original: Na hi aggasaddo ārammaṇapariyāyo katthaci diṭṭhoti.🔽74. Jīvanti sampayuttādhammā etenāti jīvitaṃ. Indoti issaro. Idha pana issarabhāvo
analyzed: na hi agga saddaḥ ārammaṇa pariyāyaḥ katthaci diṭṭhaḥ ti  jīvanti sampayutta adhammā etena ati jīvitam indo ti issaraḥ idha pana issara bhāvaḥ
translated: For the word “best” is not seen to be used as a term for an object anywhere.

original: vuccati. Indaṃ issarabhāvaṃ kāretīti indriyaṃ. Jīvitañca taṃ indriyañcāti jīvitindriyaṃ.
analyzed: vuccati indam issara bhāvam kāreti iti indriyam jīvitam ca tam indriyam ca ati jīvitindriyam
translated: It is “life” because it is the cause of the life of conascent states. It is “lord” because it is a master. Here, however, lordship is meant. It “makes” , that is, causes, “lord” , that is, master, to be “Inda” , that is, sovereign. It is the “life faculty” .

original: Tañhi mayā vinā tumhākaṃ jīvitaṃ natthi. Tasmā tumhākaṃ jīvanakicce maṃ issaraṃ karothāti🔽vadantamiva sahajātadhamme abhibhavitvā pavattatīti. Tathā hi taṃ pavattasantatādhipateyyanti
analyzed: tat hi mayā vinā tumhākam jīvitam na atthi tasmā tumhākam jīvana kicce mam issaram karotha ati  vadantam iva sahajāta dhamme abhibhavitvā pavattati iti tathā hi tam
translated: For it occurs as if saying, “Without me there is no life for you, so make me your sovereign in the matter of your living.”🔽For it is said that it occurs dominating the continuity of states that are conascent with it,

original: ca padumuppa lānupālakamudakaṃ viyātica vuttaṃ. Tattha yāva khandhaparinibbānā anuppabandhavasena
analyzed: ca viyā ti ca vuttam tattha yāva khandha parinibbānā an uppabandha vasena
translated: like the water that is the sovereign of the lotus and its stalk. Herein, it is the sovereign of the conascent states until the cessation of the aggregates .

original: pavattamānā cittasantati pavattasantatināma. Adhipatibhāvo ādhipateyyaṃ. Pavattasantatiyaṃ🔽ādhipateyyaṃ assāti samāso. Punappunaṃ niruddhaṃpi hi cittasantānaṃ tassa balena
analyzed: pavattamānā citta santati pavatta santati nāma adhipati bhāvaḥ ādhipateyyam pavatta santatiyam  ādhipateyyam assa ati samāsaḥ punappunam niruddham api hi citta santānam tassa balena
translated: The process of consciousness occurring is called the process of occurrence. The state of predominance is predominance. The predominance in the process of occurrence is the predominance of the process of occurrence. The compound is resolved thus: “In the process of occurrence, it is the predominance.”

original: punappunaṃ jīvantaṃ hutvā yāva khandhaparinibbānā punappunaṃ pavattatiyeva.
analyzed: punappunam jīvantam hutvā yāva khandha parinibbānā punappunam pavattatiyā iva
translated: For although the process of consciousness has ceased again and again, it occurs again and again, as if living, through the power of this, until the attainment of the cessation of the aggregates.

original: Na hi jīvitarahitesu anindriyabaddhadhammesu tādiso pavattasantati visesonāma atthīti.
analyzed: na hi jīvita rahitesu anindriya baddha dhammesu tādiso pavatta santati viseso nāma atthi iti
translated: For there is no such thing as a process of occurrence in things devoid of life and not bound up with faculties.

original: 75. Manasmiṃ ārammaṇaṃ asuññaṃ manaṃvā ārammaṇe niccaninnaṃ karotīti manasikāro.🔽So pana tividho vīthipaṭipādako javanapaṭipādakoārammaṇapaṭipādakoti. Tattha pañcadvārāvajjanaṃ
analyzed: manasmim ārammaṇam asuññam manaṃ vā ārammaṇe nicca ninnam karoti iti manasikāro  so pana tividhaḥ vīthi paṭipādakaḥ javana paṭipādakaḥ ārammaṇa paṭipādakaḥ ti tattha pañca dvāra āvajjanam
translated: The meaning of “mentality” is that it makes the mind not void of an object, or it makes the mind constantly inclined to the object.

original: vīthi paṭipādako nāma. Tañhi pañcadvārika cittasantatiṃ ārammaṇe paṭipādeti yojetīti.
analyzed: paṭipādakaḥ nāma tat hi pañca dvārika citta santatim ārammaṇe paṭipādeti yojeti iti
translated: It is of three kinds as the forerunner of the cognitive series, as the forerunner of impulsion, and as the forerunner of the object. Herein, the adverting of the five doors is called the forerunner of the cognitive series. For that leads on the process of consciousness of the five doors to the object, it yokes it to the object.

original: Manodvārāvajjanaṃ javanapaṭipādako nāma. Taṃpi javana santatiṃ ārammaṇe paṭipādeti
analyzed: javana paṭipādakaḥ nāma santatim ārammaṇe paṭipādeti
translated: The adverting of the mind door is called the forerunner of impulsion. That leads on the process of impulsion to the object,

original: yojetīti. Idameva dvayaṃ tattha tattha yoniso manasikārotica ayoniso manasikāro tica
analyzed: yoja iti iti idam eva dvayam tattha tattha yonisaḥ manasikāro utica a yonisaḥ manasikāro tica
translated: “It yokes” . This very dyad is called “wise attention” and “unwise attention” there and there.

original: vuttaṃ. Tañhi pakatiyā samudāciṇṇaninnaniyāmitādīhi paccaye hi upatthambhitaṃ hutvā🔽cittasantānaṃ yoniso ayonisovā ārammaṇe ninnaṃ karotīti. Paṭisandhicittato pana paṭṭhāya
analyzed: vuttam tat hi pakatiyā samudāciṇṇa ninna niyāmita ādīhi paccaye hi upatthambhitam hutvā  citta santānam yonisas ayonisas vā ārammaṇe ninnam karoti iti paṭisandhi cittato pana paṭṭhāya
translated: For that, being assisted by conditions such as natural disposition, previous habit, and the influence of others,🔽makes the stream of consciousness inclined to the object wisely or unwisely.

original: pavattamānā cittasantati ārammaṇaṃ muñcitvā nirujjhitvāpi puna uppajjamānā yassa
analyzed: pavattamānā citta santati ārammaṇam muñcitvā nirujjhitvā api punar uppajjamānā yassa
translated: But the stream of consciousness that has arisen since the rebirth-linking consciousness,

original: dhammassa vasena tasmiṃyeva ārammaṇe uppajjati asati kāraṇavisese. So ārammaṇapaṭipādakonāma.
analyzed: dhammassa vasena tasmin yeva ārammaṇe uppajjati asati kāraṇa visese so ārammaṇa paṭipādakaḥ nāma
translated: having ceased by giving up the object, arises again in dependence on that same object, unless there is a special reason for its not doing so.🔽This is called “the condition by object.”

original: Ayamidhā dhippeto. Ayañhi ārammaṇaṃ citte cittaṃvā ārammaṇe paṭipādeti yojetīti.
analyzed: ayam idha dhippetaḥ ayam hi ārammaṇam citte cittam vā ārammaṇe paṭipādeti yojeti iti
translated: This is what is intended here. For this “makes the object enter into the consciousness” or “it yokes the object to the consciousness.”

original: Tathā hi ayaṃ sāraṇa lakkhaṇoti ca sampayuttānaṃ ārammaṇena saṃpayojanarasotica ārammaṇapaṭipādakaṭṭhena
analyzed: tathā hi ayam ca sampayuttānam ārammaṇena saṃpayojana rasaḥ ti ca ārammaṇa paṭipādaka ṭṭhena
translated: For this is the characteristic of “making the object enter into the consciousness” . Its function is to connect the associated states with the object. Its manifestation is “making the object enter into the consciousness.”

original: sampayuttānaṃ sārathīviya daṭṭhabbotica vutto. Tattha sāraṇalakkhaṇoti sārathīviya
analyzed: sampayuttānam sārathī viya daṭṭhabbaḥ iti ca vuttaḥ tattha sāraṇa lakkhaṇo ti sārathī viya
translated: It should be regarded as the charioteer of the associated states.

original: assānaṃ sampayuttadhammānaṃ ujuṃ ārammaṇābhimukhaṃ pavattayanalakkhaṇoti attho. Samaṃ
analyzed: assānam sampayutta dhammānam ujum ārammaṇa abhimukham pavatta yana lakkhaṇaḥ ti attho samam
translated: Herein, the characteristic of directing is the characteristic of steering the associated states straight to the object, as a charioteer does the horses.

original: dhārentiti sādhāraṇā. Sabbesaṃ cittānaṃ sādhāraṇā sabbacittasādhāraṇā.
analyzed: dhārenti iti sādhāraṇā sabbesam cittānam sādhāraṇā sabba citta sādhāraṇā
translated: It is common to all consciousnesses: it is shared by all consciousnesses, thus it is common to all consciousnesses.

original: 76. Vitakketīti vitakko. Tathā tathā saṅkappetvā ārammaṇaṃ ārohatīti attho. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: vitakketi iti vitakkaḥ tathā tathā saṅkappetvā ārammaṇam ārohati iti atthaḥ tasmin
translated: It thinks thus and thus: the meaning is that it mounts the object by directing it thus and thus.🔽But when it mounts the object in this way, the associated states also mount it.

original: pana taṃ kathā ārohante sampayuttadhammāpi taṃ ārohanti. Tadā soyeva te ārammaṇaṃ🔽abhiniropentonāma hotīti katvā ārammaṇā bhiniropanalakkhaṇo vitakkoti vutto. Rājavallabhaṃ🔽nissāya janapadagāsino rājagehārohanañcettha nidassanaṃ. Avitakkaṃpi hi cittaṃ savitakkadhammasantāne
analyzed: pana tam kathā ārohante sampayutta dhammā api tam ārohanti tadā saḥ yā iva te ārammaṇam  abhiniropento nāma hoti iti katvā ārammaṇa abhiniropana lakkhaṇo vitakko ti vuttaḥ rājavallabham  nissāya janapada gāsinaḥ rāja geha ārohanam ca ittha nidassanam a vitakkam api hi cittam sa vitakka dhamma santāne
translated: Then it is said that it is the directing on to the object by him who mounts it.🔽The mounting of the royal household on to the palace by the people of the country, depending on the king’s favourite, may be cited here as an illustration.

original: vitakkena saha pavattaparicaya balena ārohanato vitakkena atinirovitamevanāma hotīti.
analyzed: vitakkena saha pavatta paricaya balena ārohanataḥ vitakkena hoti iti
translated: For although the consciousness is without thinking, still it is called “with thinking” because it mounts the object by the power of the habit energy of the associated states’ occurrence together with thinking in the continuity of states with thinking.

original: Apica, avitakkaṃpi pañcaviññāṇaṃ vatthārammaṇa saṅghaṭṭanavasena ārohati. Dutīyajjhānādīnica
analyzed: apica avitakkam pi pañca viññāṇam vattha ārammaṇa saṅghaṭṭana vasena ārohati dutīya jhāna ādīni ca
translated: The second jhāna consciousness, etc., ascend by way of the development of access.

original: upacārabhāvanāvasena ārohanti. Majjhimaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana kiṃvā etāya yuttiyāti vatvā
analyzed: upacāra bhāvanā vasena ārohanti majjhima ṭṭhakathā ayam pana kiṃvā etāya yuttiyā iti vatvā
translated: But in the Majjhima commentary it is said: “What is the use of this interpretation?

original: imamatthaṃ dasseti. Cittaṃpi hi ārammaṇaṃ āruhatiyeva. Tassa pana niccaṃ sahāyo manasikāro.
analyzed: imam attham dasseti cittam pi hi ārammaṇam āruhatiyā iva tassa pana niccam sahāyaḥ manasikāro
translated: For consciousness also ascends the object. But its constant companion is attention.

original: Tasmiñhi asati taṃ niyāmakarahi tā nāvāviya yaṃvātaṃvā ārammaṇaṃ gahetvā pavatteyyāti.
analyzed: tasmin hi asati tam yam vā a tam vā ārammaṇam gahetvā pavatteyya ati
translated: For if that is absent, it will not be able to ascend the object, like a ship without a helmsman, and it will take whatever object comes within its range.

original: Iti pañcaviññāṇaṃ manasikārasahāyaṃ hutvā attano ārammaṇavijānanasattivaseneva ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: iti pañca viññāṇam manasikāra sahāyam hutvā attanaḥ ārammaṇa vijānana satti vasena iva ārammaṇam
translated: So the five consciousnesses, with attention as their companion, ascend the object by the mere fact that they experience their respective objects.

original: ārohati. Akusalaṃ patvā pana cittaṃpi lobhādayopi ārammaṇāruhane thāmavatā eva honti.
analyzed: ārohati akusalam lobha ādayaḥ pi ārammaṇa āruhane thāmavatāḥ eva honti
translated: But when they fall on to the unprofitable, then consciousness, greed, etc., are strong in ascending the object.🔽For it is said: “The mind delights in evil” .

original: Pāpasmiṃ ramate manoti hi vuttaṃ. Dutīyajjhāna cittādīnica manasikāra vīriyassatīnaṃpi
analyzed: pāpasmim ramate manaḥ ti hi vuttam dutīya jjhāna citta ādīni ca manasikāra vīriya ssatīnam pi
translated: The second-jhāna consciousness, etc., are strong in ascending the object by the strength of attention, energy, and mindfulness.

original: vasena ārohanti. Vitakko pana tathā tathā saṅkappetvā attasahite dhamme ārammaṇāruhane
analyzed: vasena ārohanti vitakkaḥ pana tathā tathā saṅkappetvā atta sahite dhamme ārammaṇa āruhane
translated: and they ascend by way of it. But applied thought, after directing the associated states towards the object in such and such a way,

original: suṭṭhutaraṃ balavante karoti. Iti tasmiṃ kicce aññesaṃ sābhisayabyāpāratāyaeva ayaṃ
analyzed: suṭṭhutaram balavante karoti iti tasmim kicce aññesam sa abhisaya byāpāra tāya eva ayam
translated: and it is by means of this that they mount the object. But applied thought makes the associated states more powerful by directing them to the object in such and such a way. So it is because of its pre-eminence in this function that it is said to be

original: vitakkoti vuttoti. Evaṃ pana vattabbaṃ. Nanu aññepi arūpadhammā sārammaṇasabhāvā🔽ārammaṇaṃ ārohanti. Atha ca pana kasmā ayameva vitakkoti vuttoti. Aññesaṃ pana āruhanaṃ
analyzed: vitakkaḥ ti vuttaḥ ti evam pana vattabbam nanu aññe pi arūpa dhammā sārammaṇa sabhāvā  ārammaṇam ārohanti atha ca pana kasmai ayam eva vitakko ti vutto ti aññesam pana āruhanam
translated: pre-eminent in mounting the object. But this is how it should be said: “But do not other immaterial states that have an object mount the object too?

original: kiccantarayogavaseneva siddhaṃ. Imassa pana ito aññaṃ kiccaṃ nāma natthi. Tasmā ayameva tathā vuttoti.🔽77. Vicaratīti vicāro. Vicāretivā sampayuttakedhamme, te vā dhammā vicaranti etenāti🔽vicāro. Vicaraṇañcettha vitakkā ruḷhe tasmiṃyeva ārammaṇe sabhāvākārapātubhāvatthaṃ
analyzed: kicca antara yoga vasena iva siddham imassa pana itas aññam kiccam nāma natthi tasmai ayam eva tathā vuttaḥ ti  vicarati iti vicāraḥ te vā dhammāḥ vicaranti etena ati  vicāraḥ vicaraṇam ca ittha vitakkā ruḷhe tasmin yeva ārammaṇe sabhāva ākāra pātubhāvattham
translated: If so, why is only this called applied thought?”—The mounting of the others is established by their being associated with what is called applied thought. But this has no other function than this. That is why it is said to be pre-eminent in mounting the object.

original: punappunaṃ anumajjanavasena pavattanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Etthaca vitakko oḷāriko pubbaṅgamo
analyzed: punappunam anumajjana vasena pavattanam daṭṭhabbam ettha ca vitakkaḥ oḷārikaḥ pubbaṅgamaḥ
translated: It “examines” , thus it is “sustained thought” . Or alternatively, the associated states are examined by it, or they examine with it, thus it is “sustained thought” . And here the function of examining should be regarded as occurring by way of repeated adverting to the object already apprehended by applied thought, for the purpose of making it evident in its specific and general characteristics. And here applied thought is gross, being the forerunner of the rest;

original: ārammaṇe cittassa pathamābhinipātabhūtoca hotīti ghaṇḍābhighāto viya daṭṭhabbo. Vicāro
analyzed: ārammaṇe cittassa pathama abhinipāta bhūto ca hoti iti ghaṇḍa abhighātaḥ viya daṭṭhabbaḥ vicāro
translated: It is like the striking of a gong, in that it is the first impact of the mind on the object.

original: sukhumo anucaro tasmiṃyeva ārammaṇe cittassa anubandhanabhūto ca hotīti ghaṇḍānuravoviya daṭṭhabboti.
analyzed: sukhumaḥ anucaro tasmiṃ yeva ārammaṇe cittassa anubandhana bhūto ca hoti iti daṭṭhabbo ti
translated: It is like the reverberation of the gong, in that it is the subsequent following of the mind along with the object.

original: 78. Adhimuccanaṃ adhimokkho. Ārammaṇe evaṃ nukho no nukhoti evaṃ pavattaṃ saṃsappanaṃ
analyzed: adhimuccanam adhimokkhaḥ ārammaṇe evam nukho no nukho ti evam pavattam saṃsappanam
translated: Adhimokkha is the act of deciding. It is the act of deciding in the form of the occurrence of the mind in the mode of resolving in this way, “It is thus, not otherwise,” after overcoming and cutting off the vacillation that occurs thus, “Perhaps it is so, perhaps it is not.”

original: adhibhavitvā vicchinditvā pakkhako muccanavasena cittassa pavattīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: adhibhavitvā vicchinditvā pakkhako muccana vasena cittassa pavatti iti vuttam hoti
translated: What is meant is that it occurs in the mode of resolving in the mind.

original: Evañca katvā so ārammaṇe sanniṭṭhānalakkhaṇoti ca ārammaṇe niccalabhāvena indakhīlasadisotica vutto.
analyzed: evam ca katvā saḥ ārammaṇe sanniṭṭhāna lakkhaṇo ti ca ārammaṇe niccala bhāvena inda khīla sadisaḥ ti ca vutto
translated: And in this way it is said to have the characteristic of deciding on the object, and to be like an earth-spike in being unshaken by the object.

original: 79. Vīrassa kammasūrassa bhāvo kammavā vīriyaṃ. Taṃsamaṅgī puggalo hi kammasūro hoti.
analyzed: vīrassa kammasūrassa bhāvaḥ kamma vā vīriyam tad samaṅgī puggalaḥ hi kammasūraḥ hoti
translated: Vīriya is the state of being a hero, the state of being a worker. For the person who possesses it is a worker.

original: Mahantaṃpi kammaṃ appakato gaṇhāti. Dukkaraṃpi sukarato, bhāriyaṃpi abhāriyato gaṇhāti.
analyzed: mahantam pi kammam appakataḥ gaṇhāti dukkaram pi sukarataḥ bhāriyam pi a bhāriyataḥ gaṇhāti
translated: He takes on a great task as if it were small. He takes on what is difficult as if it were easy, what is onerous as if it were not onerous.

original: Attakilamathaṃ nagaṇeti. Kammasiddhiyā niccaṃ paggahita kāya cittova hoti. Tasmā
analyzed: atta kilamatham kamma siddhiyā niccam hoti tasmā
translated: He does not neglect bodily effort. He is always intent on bodily and mental effort for the sake of accomplishing his work. Therefore

original: taṃ tassa puggalassa tathāpavattiyā hetubhāvoceva tathāpavattassa ca tassa puggalassa🔽kāya cittakriyābhūtaṃ hotīti. Vidhināvā nayena upāyena vīriyavato kiṃ nāmakammaṃ
analyzed: tam tassa puggalassa tathāpavattiyā tathāpavattassa ca tassa puggalassa  kāya citta kriyā bhūtam hoti iti vidhinā vā nayena upāyena vīriyavato kim nāmakammaṃ
translated: it is the cause for the occurrence of that kind of person in that way. And it is the bodily and mental activity of that person who occurs in that way

original: na sijjhatītiādikena pubbābhisaṅkhārena īrayitabbaṃ pavattayitabbanti vīriyaṃ. Visesenavā🔽sakaparahitahetu īranti kampanti taṃ samaṅgino etenāti vīriyaṃ. Etthaca vīriyu patthambhitā
analyzed: na sijjhati iti ādikena pubba abhisaṅkhārena īrayitabbam pavattayitabbam ti vīriyam visesena vā  īranti kampanti tam samaṅginaḥ etena ati vīriyam ettha ca
translated: that is called energy. What work of a person who has energy is not accomplished by means of the method, the way, the practice? Therefore it should be aroused, it should be set going, by means of the prior condition of thinking, “What work of a person who has energy is not accomplished?”🔽And it is by means of that that those who possess it are made to shake, are made to tremble, in the sense of being made to shake and tremble for the sake of one’s own and others’ welfare.

original: sampayuttadhammā sadā anikkhittadhurā paggahitasīsāviya hutvā attano attano kiccasampattiyā🔽niccaṃ ussāhajātāva honti, tesuca tathāhontesu taṃsamaṅgino puggalāpi attanovā paresaṃvā
analyzed: sampayutta dhammā sadā a nikkhitta dhurā hutvā attanaḥ attanaḥ kicca sampattiyā  niccam ussāha jātāḥ ava honti tesu ca tathā hontesu tad samaṅgino puggalā api attanaḥ vā paresam vā
translated: And here, the associated states are stiffened by energy, and they are always undeluded, like a head that is held up, and they are always intent, being intent on the success of their own functions.

original: hitahetu niccaṃ byāvaṭakāyacittā honti. Tasmā īranti kampantīti vuccantīti. Tathā
analyzed: hita hetu niccam byāvaṭa kāya cittāḥ honti tasmai īranti kampanti iti vuccanti iti tathā
translated: And when they are so, the persons who possess them are always intent on their own and others’ welfare, with their bodies and minds on the qui vive. Therefore they are said to shake and tremble.🔽And so it is said:

original: hi taṃ upatthambhanalakkhaṇanti ca paggahalakkhaṇanti ca ussāhalakkhaṇanti ca gehassa
analyzed: hi tam upatthambhana lakkhaṇanti ca paggaha lakkhaṇanti ca ussāha lakkhaṇanti ca gehassa
translated: for it is said to have the characteristic of supporting, the characteristic of exertion, the characteristic of stimulation, the characteristic of being like a pillar for a house,

original: thūṇūpatthambhana sadisanti ca sammā āraddhaṃ sabbasampattīnaṃ mūlanti ca vuttanti.
analyzed: ca sammā āraddham sabba sampattīnam mūlanti ca vuttanti
translated: and the characteristic of being the root of all attainments when rightly undertaken.

original: 80. Vinayati kāyacittaṃ tappeti, tuṭṭhaṃ suhitaṃ janeti, supupphitapadumaṃviyavā🔽vaḍḍhetīti pīti, vinantivā etāya taṃ samaṅgino puṇṇacandoviya virocamāna kāyacittā
analyzed: vinayati kāya cittam tappeti tuṭṭham su hitam janeti  tam samaṅginaḥ kāya cittā
translated: It restrains body and mind, it warms them, it makes them well and happy, it makes them expand like a fully opened lotus.

original: hontīti pīti. Sā pañcavidhā khuddikā pīti, khaṇikāpīti, okkantikā pīti, ubbegā pīti, pharaṇāpītīti.🔽81. Chandanaṃ chando. Icchā patthanā abhisandhīti vuttaṃ hoti. Sopana duvidho taṇhāchando,🔽kattukamyatā chandoti. Idha kattukamyatā chando adhippeto. Etthaca kattuṃ kāmeti
analyzed: honti iti pi iti sā pañcavidhā khuddikā pīti khaṇikā api iti okkantikā pīti ubbegā pīti pharaṇā api iti iti  chandanam chando icchā patthanā abhisandhi iti vuttam hoti duvidho taṇhāchando  kattu kamya tā chandaḥ iti idha kattu kamya tā chandaḥ adhippetaḥ ettha ca kattum kāmā iti
translated: It is called “joy” because it makes the body and mind of one possessing it shine like the full moon. It is fivefold as minor, momentary, leaping, uplifting, and pervading joy.

original: icchatīti kattukāmo. Chandasamaṅgipuggalo. Tassa bhāvo kattukamyaṃ. Tadeva kattukamyatā,
analyzed: icchati iti kattu kāmo chanda samaṅgi puggalo tassa bhāvaḥ kattu kamyam tat eva kattu kamya tā
translated: It is will, desire, aspiration, longing. It is twofold as craving-will and desire-to- act-will. Herein, desire-to-act-will is intended. And here one who has the desire to do is a “desire-to-act-er” . His state is “desire to act” . That itself is “desire-to-act-will” .

original: yathā devoyeva devatāti. Etthaca kattusaddo sabbesaṃ dhātusaddānaṃ atthe saṅgahetvā🔽pavatto. Tasmā kattukamyatāti etena kathetukamyatā cintetukamyatā daṭṭhukamyatā sotukamyatāti
analyzed: yathā devaḥ yā iva devatā iti ettha ca kattu saddo sabbesam dhātu saddānam atthe saṅgahetvā  pavattaḥ tasmā kattu kamya tā ati etena kathetu kamya tā cintetu kamya tā daṭṭhu kamya tā sotu kamya tā ati
translated: Here the word “doing” occurs as a collective term for all the words for states.🔽Therefore it should be understood that “willing to do” includes all such verbal nouns as “willing to tell,” “willing to think,” “willing to see,” “willing to hear,”

original: evamādīni sabba kriyāpadāni saṅgahitāni hontīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. So pana ārammaṇaṃ icchantopi
analyzed: evamādīni sabba kriyāpadāni saṅgahitāni honti iti daṭṭhabbam saḥ pana ārammaṇam icchantaḥ api
translated: and so on. And although he wills an object,

original: taṇhā viya assādana rajjana laggana vasena naicchati. Yena yena pana atthiko hoti.🔽Taṃ taṃ atthaṃ ārādhetu kāmatāvaseneva icchati. Yathā rañño issāsā dhanenavā yasenavā
analyzed: taṇhā viya assādana rajjana laggana vasena na ecchati yena yena pana atthikaḥ hoti  tam tam attham ārādhetu kāmatā vasena iva icchati yathā rañño issāsā dhanena vā yasena vā

original: atthikā rājaverīnaṃ vijjhanavasena chaḍḍitabbayuttakepi sare bahū icchantiyeva. Evamevaṃ

translated: just as when a king’s archers are in need of arrows, they will even want many arrows that are to be discarded as no longer usable, since they are blunt from striking the enemy king’s chariots, horses, and so on.

original: ayaṃpi parassa vissajjitabbayutta kānipi dānavatthūni aladdhānipi laddhuṃ icchati.
analyzed: ayam pi parassa kāni api dāna vatthūni aladdhāni api laddhum icchati
translated: So too, this man wants to get even those things that are fit to be given away by others, which he has not yet obtained.🔽And when he has obtained them, he wants to keep them.

original: Laddhānipi rakkhituṃ icchatīti. Ayañca attho vibhāvaniyaṃpi vuttoyeva.
analyzed: laddhāni api rakkhitum icchati iti ayam ca atthaḥ vuttaḥ yā iva
translated: And this meaning is stated in the Vibhaṅga too.

original: Vuttañhi tattha
analyzed: vuttam hi tattha
translated: For this is said there:

original: Dānavatthuvissajjanavasena pavattakālepi cesa vissajji tabbena tena atthikoyeva. Khipitabbausūnaṃ gahaṇe atthiko issāsoviyāti.🔽Tattha yadaggena dānaṃ dassāmīti dānavatthupariyesanādivasena pavattā pubbabhāgacetanā🔽dānavatthuvissajjana saṅkāte dāne saṅgahitā hoti. Tadaggena tassā pubbabhāgacetanāya
analyzed: dāna vatthu vissajjana vasena pavatta kāle api ca isa vissajji tabbena tena atthikaḥ yā iva khipitabba osūnam gahaṇe atthikaḥ  tattha yad aggena dānam dassāmi iti dāna vatthu pariyesana ādi vasena pavattā pubbabhāga cetanā  dāna vatthu vissajjana saṅkāte dāne saṅgahitā hoti tad aggena tassā pubba bhāga cetanāya
translated: And when the time comes for the giving of the gift, he is only concerned with giving it to one who needs it. He is only concerned with getting the needles and thread when he needs them for sewing.🔽Herein, the volition occurring as the seeking out of the gift-object, etc., with the thought “I shall give a gift” is included in the giving of the gift when the gift-object is being given.🔽The time when that volition occurs is what should be understood as the time when the gift-object is being given.

original: pavattikālo idha dānavatthu vissajjanavasena pavatta kāloti veditabbo. Vissajjitabbenāti🔽vissajjitabba yuttakena. Tena atthikoyeva parassa vissajjanatthāyāti adhippāyo. Khipitabbausūnaṃ
analyzed: pavatti kālaḥ idha dāna vatthu vissajjana vasena kālaḥ iti veditabbaḥ vissajjitabbena ati  vissajjitabba yuttakena tena atthikaḥ yeva parassa vissajjana tthāya ati adhippāyaḥ khipitabba osūnam
translated: “To be given”: to be given to one who needs it. The intention is that he is only concerned with giving it to another who needs it.

original: gahaṇeti tesaṃ akatānaṃ karaṇavasena aladdhānaṃ pariyesanavasena gahaṇe. Ettha pana
analyzed: gahaṇa iti tesam akatānam karaṇa vasena aladdhānam pariyesana vasena gahaṇe ettha pana

original: keci issāso usūnikhipitvāpi labhamāno tehi usūhi atthikoyevāti eva matthaṃ vadanti.

translated: Herein, some say that the meaning should be regarded thus: he is only concerned with the needles and thread when he needs them for sewing, even if he has to get them by borrowing.

original: So nayujjati. Evañhi sati khipitausūnanti vuttaṃ siyā. Yathā kathitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatenāti.

original: Tathā vissajjitabbe nāti etthapīti. Keci issāso usūhi anatthiko khipanto nahoti.

translated: Some say that the envious man does not throw the poison because he has no use for it.

original: Atthikoyeva samāno aññaṃ ānisaṃsaṃ icchanto khipatīti evaṃ atthaṃ vadanti. Sopi nayujjati.
analyzed: atthikaḥ yā iva samānaḥ aññam ānisaṃsam icchantaḥ khipati iti evam attham vadanti saḥ api na yujjati
translated: But one who has use for it throws it because he wants some other advantage. That is the meaning. But that is not tenable.

original: Evañhi sati usūhi atthikoyeva tāni khipanto issāsoviyātivuttaṃ siyāti. Atthato pana

translated: But in fact both of these are to be rejected.🔽And because the mind associated with zeal takes the object as if it were eager for it by reason of the zeal, as if it were oozing out. That is why it is said that it is like the stretching out of the hand to take the object.

translated: For if it were of equal strength with craving,

How mixed?

original: 82. Sobhaṇā sobhaṇesu cittesu pakirantīti pakiṇṇā. Keeva pakiṇṇakā. Aññehi aññesaṃvā🔽samānā aññasamānā. Yadā sobhaṇacittesu yuttā, tadā tehi asobhaṇato aññehi samānā.

translated: They are the same as others or different from others.🔽When they are associated with beautiful thoughts, then they are the same as those.

original: 83. Idāni akusalarāsiṃ dassento mohotiādimāha. Tattha muyhatīti moho. Muyhanti sattā🔽etenātivā moho. Etthaca appaṭipattīti kalyāṇapakkhe aññāṇameva🔽vuccati. Micchāpaṭipattīti pāpapakkhe micchāñāṇameva vuccatīti, tathā hi pāpapakkhaṃ
analyzed: idāni akusala rāsim dassentaḥ mohaḥ ti ādim āha tattha muyhati iti mohaḥ muyhanti sattā  etena ati vā mohaḥ caturaṅgatamassa viya cakkhussa sabbaso kalyāṇa pakkham  paṭicchādetvā cittassa andha bhāva karaṇanti vuttam hoti pāpa pakkham pana patvā so  ñāṇa gatiko hoti iti daṭṭhabbo tathā ha esa pāḷiyam micchāñāṇam ti vutto aṭṭhakathāsu ca  micchā ñāṇam ti pāpa kriyāsu upāya cintā vasena pavatto mohaḥ ti vuttam avijjāya ca appaṭipatti  micchā paṭipatti vasena duvidha bhāvaḥ vuttaḥ ettha ca appaṭipatti iti kalyāṇa pakkhe aññāṇam eva  vuccati micchā paṭipatti iti pāpa pakkhe micchā ñāṇam eva vuccati iti tathā hi pāpa pakkham
translated: Now, showing the unprofitable aggregates, he said “Delusion” . Herein, he deludes , thus it is delusion . Or alternatively, beings are deluded by this , thus it is delusion . Or alternatively, delusion is mere delusion , just as eye is mere eye , and so on. It is said to be the blinding of cognizance by concealing the whole of the profitable side. But when it has reached the unprofitable side it should be regarded as having the mode of knowledge , since it is called “wrong knowledge” in the texts and in the commentaries it is said to be delusion occurring by the mode of thinking of a means for evil-doing . And ignorance is said to have a twofold state as non-performance and wrong performance. Herein, non-performance is simply non-knowing of the profitable side, and wrong performance is simply wrong knowledge of the unprofitable side. For it is said in the texts, “What is ignorance? It is non-knowing of suffering, non-knowing of the origin of suffering, non-knowing of the cessation of suffering, and non-knowing of the way leading to the cessation of suffering” , and in the commentaries it is said to be delusion occurring by the mode of thinking of a means for evil-doing. And it is said in the texts, “What is wrong knowledge? It is knowledge of sensual desires, knowledge of ill will, knowledge of cruelty, knowledge of whatever other unprofitable ideas there are” .

original: patvā pañcadhammā ñāṇagatikā honti moho, lobho, diṭṭhi, vitakko, vicāroti. Cittena
analyzed: patvā pañca dhammā ñāṇa gatikāḥ honti mohaḥ lobhaḥ diṭṭhi vitakko vicāro ti cittena
translated: Now, showing the unprofitable aggregates, he said “Delusion” . Herein, he deludes , thus it is delusion . Or alternatively, beings are deluded by this , thus it is delusion . Or alternatively, delusion is mere delusion , just as eye is mere eye , and so on. It is said to be the blinding of cognizance by concealing the whole of the profitable side. But when it has reached the unprofitable side it should be regarded as having the mode of knowledge , for in the texts it is called “wrong knowledge” . And in the commentaries it is said that “wrong knowledge” is delusion occurring as the thinking of a means in the case of evil-doing . And ignorance is said to have a twofold state as non-performance and wrong performance . Herein, non-performance is simply non-knowing of the profitable side, and wrong performance is simply wrong knowledge of the unprofitable side. For thus, when it has reached the unprofitable side, the five ideas have the mode of knowledge , namely, delusion, greed, false view, applied thought, and sustained thought. With cognizance

original: pana saddhiṃ chabbidhā honti. Tehi pakatiyā viññujātikesu sutapariyattisampannesuca🔽uppannā pāpakriyāsu taṃ taṃ upāyadassanavasena tesaṃ tattha chekabhāvaṃ paṭibalabhāvañca sādhentīti.
