original: yasa issariyādīhi ceva sīla suta lābhasakkārā dīhica guṇehi upatthambhito atirekataraṃ
analyzed: yasas issariya ādīhi ca iva sīla suta lābha sakkāra ādīhi ca guṇehi atirekataram
translated: and by fame, lordship, etc., and by virtue, learning, gain, and honour, and by the qualities of longevity, etc.,🔽

original: vaddhitvā attānaṃ janamajjhe ketuṃviya accuggataṃ maññati. Tasmā so unnatilakkhaṇotica
analyzed: vaddhitvā attānam jana majjhe ketum viya accuggatam maññati tasmā saḥ unnati lakkhaṇā iti ca
translated: He thinks that he has raised himself above the crowd, like a banner, by means of his fame, his lordship, etc., and by means of his virtues of virtue, learning, gain, honour, and long standing. Therefore it is called conceit in the sense of overweening .

original: ummādoviyātica vutto.🔽90. Dussatīti doso. Sopana caṇḍikkaṭṭhena pahatā sivisoviya visappanaṭṭhena asanipātoviya
analyzed: vutto  dussati iti doso caṇḍikka ṭṭhena pahatā visappana ṭṭhena
translated: It is called vanity in the sense of being like a flag.

original: attano nissaya dahanaṭṭhena dāvaggiviya dussanaṭṭhena laddhokāso sapattoviya sabbaso🔽ahitarāsi bhāvaṭṭhena visa saṃsaṭṭha pūtimuttaṃ viya daṭṭhabbo.🔽91. Issatīti issā. Parasampattiṃ ussūyatīti attho. Sāhi paresaṃ pakatiyā laddhasampattiṃ🔽disvā vā sutvāvā nasahati. Tassā sampattiyā vipattiṃ icchati ākaṅkhati. Asuko idaṃnāma
analyzed: attanaḥ dahana ṭṭhena dussana ṭṭhena laddha ukāsaḥ sabbaso  bhāvaṭṭhena saṃsaṭṭha pūti muttam viya daṭṭhabbo  issati iti issā para sampattim ussūyati iti attho sā hi paresam pakatiyā laddha sampattim  disvā vā sutvā vā na sahati tassā sampattiyāḥ vipattim icchati ākaṅkhati asukaḥ idaṃnāma
translated: It is called hate in the sense of being hostile . It should be regarded as a poison mixed with food in the sense of being a mass of what is unprofitable, like a forest conflagration in the sense of burning up one’s own support, like an enemy in the sense of destroying all that is good, like a viper in the sense of the nature of striking.

original: labhissatīti sutvāpi nasahati. Tassa alābhaṃ icchati ākaṅkhati. Tasmā sā parasampattīnaṃ
analyzed: labhissati iti sutvā api na sahati tassa alābham icchati ākaṅkhati tasmā sā para sampattīnam
translated: It is called envy in the sense of swelling up at another’s success. The meaning is that it is swelling up at another’s success. When one sees or hears of another’s natural success, one cannot bear it. One wants it, one longs for it, to fail. When one hears that “So-and-so has got such and such,” one cannot bear it. One wants it, one longs for it, not to be got. Therefore it is called envy in the sense of swelling up at another’s success.

original: ussūyanalakkhaṇāti vuttā.🔽92. Mama eva idaṃ guṇajātaṃvā vatthuvā hotu. Mā aññassāti evaṃ attano sampattihetu🔽avipphārikatāvasena carati pavattatīti maccharaṃ, tathā pavattaṃ cittaṃ. Maccharassa🔽bhāvo macchariyaṃ. Idaṃca issā viya duvidhaṃ attanā laddhasampatti labhitabbasampatti
analyzed: ussūyana lakkhaṇā ti vuttā  mama eva idam hotu mā aññassa ati evam attanaḥ sampatti hetu  a vipphārika tā vasena carati pavattati iti maccharam tathā pavattam cittam maccharassa  bhāvaḥ macchariyam idam ca issā viya duvidham attanā laddha sampatti labhitabba sampatti
translated: It is called the characteristic of envy.

original: vasena. Tattha pakatiyā laddhasampattiyaṃ tāva taṃ parehi sā dhāraṇaṃvā yena kenacivā🔽kāraṇena attasantakabhāvato muccitvā paresaṃ santakabhāvaṃ gamissamānaṃ disvā vā🔽sutvāvā cintetvā dukkhī dummano hoti, labhitabbasampattiyaṃpi asukasmiṃ dese vākālevā
analyzed: vasena tattha pakatiyā tāva tam parehi sā dhāraṇam vā yena  kāraṇena atta santaka bhāvataḥ muccitvā paresam santaka bhāvam gamissamānam disvā vā  sutvā vā cintetvā dukkhī dummanaḥ hoti labhitabba sampattiyam pi asukasmin dese
translated: “Let this kind of excellence or this property be mine alone, not another’s.” Thus it goes, occurs, by way of non-diffusion. It is selfishness, the mind that occurs thus. The state of selfishness is selfishness. And this is twofold, like envy, by way of excellence already obtained by oneself and excellence to be obtained. Herein, firstly, as to excellence already obtained, he is pained and depressed on seeing or hearing that another is keeping what is his own or on thinking thus.🔽Or else, on seeing or hearing or thinking that what is his own is being taken away by another through some means or other and is being made another’s property, he is pained and depressed.

original: idaṃnāma bhavissatīti sutvāvā cintetvāvā taṃ attanāva laddhuṃ icchati. Aññesaṃ lābhaṃ
analyzed: idaṃnāma bhavissati iti sutvā vā cintetvā vā tam attanā ava laddhum icchati aññesam lābham
translated: As to excellence to be obtained, on hearing or thinking that “In such a place at such a time such a thing will come to be,” he wishes to obtain it for himself alone.

original: naicchati. Aññe labhissantīti sutvāvā cintetvāvā dukkhī dummano hotīti. Tathā hetaṃ
analyzed: na ecchati aññe labhissanti iti sutvā vā cintetvā vā dukkhī dummanaḥ hoti iti tathā ha itaṃ
translated: He is discontented and depressed on hearing or thinking that others are getting it.

original: laddhānaṃvā labhitabbānaṃvā attano sampattīnaṃ nigguhanalakkhaṇanti vuttaṃ. Etthaca🔽labhitabbasampattiyaṃ yassa lābhaṃ naicchati. Solabhatītivā labhissatītivā sutvāvā
analyzed: laddhānam vā labhitabbānam vā attanaḥ sampattīnam nigguhana lakkhaṇa nti vuttam ettha ca  labhitabba sampattiyam yassa lābham na ecchati saḥ labhati iti vā labhissati iti vā sutvā vā
translated: Because it is so, it is said that it has as its characteristic the concealing of one’s own good fortune, whether obtained or to be obtained.🔽And here, when it is good fortune to be obtained, he who does not want another to get it is discontented and depressed on hearing or thinking that the other is getting it or will get it.

original: cintetvāvā cittavighāto issānāma. Yaṃ yaṃ attanā laddhuṃ icchati. Taṃ taṃ attanā
analyzed: citta vighātaḥ issā nāma yam yam attanā laddhum icchati tam tam attanā
translated: And when it is good fortune that he himself has obtained, he is discontented and depressed on thinking that he himself is not getting something else that he wants to get.

original: alabbhamānakaṃ cintetvā cittavighāto macchariyaṃnāma. Na hi ete dve ekato uppajjantīti.🔽93. Kukkuccanti ettha kiriyā kataṃ. Kucchitaṃ katanti kukataṃ. Kucchitakiriyāti attho.🔽Paṇḍitehi ekantena ninditabbo cittappavattivisesoti vuttaṃ hoti. Atthato pana akataṃ
analyzed: alabbhamānakam cintetvā citta vighātaḥ macchariyaṃnāma na hi ete dve ekatas uppajjanti iti  kukkuccanti ettha kiriyā katam kucchitam katanti kukatam kucchita kiriyā ati attho  paṇḍitehi ekantena ninditabbaḥ citta pavatti visesaḥ ti vuttam hoti atthataḥ pana akatam
translated: These two, however, do not arise together.🔽As to worry , here what is done badly is kukataṃ ; the meaning is, what is done with regret.🔽It is a state of consciousness that occurs with regret as its proximate cause, and it is a particular occurrence of consciousness that is entirely blameworthy and deprecated by the wise. But in meaning it is the state of consciousness itself that is associated with regret.

original: vata me kalyāṇaṃ kataṃ pāpanti evaṃ anusocanavasena pavatto kukkucca sampayuttacittuppādoyeva,
analyzed: vata me kalyāṇam katam pāpanti evam anusocana vasena pavattaḥ
translated: For it is said that “worry is the state of consciousness that occurs by way of regretting what has been done and what has not been done thus, ‘Good has been done by me; evil has been done by me’” .

original: so hi tathā pavattamānopi pubbe akataṃvā kalyāṇaṃ puna kataṃ kātuṃ na sakkoti. Pubbe🔽kataṃ vā pāpaṃ puna akataṃ kātuṃ nasakkoti. Athakho kusaladhammesu cittapariyādānāyaeva🔽saṃvattati. Tasmā kucchitakiriyā mattattā kukatanti vuccatīti. Vuttañhetaṃ aṭṭha🔽kathāyaṃ katākatassa sāvajjānavajjassa abhimukhagamanaṃ paṭisāronāma. Yasmā paneso
analyzed: saḥ hi tathā pavattamānaḥ api pubbe akatam vā kalyāṇam puna katam kātum na sakkoti pubbe  katam vā pāpam puna a katam kātum na sakkoti atha kho kusala dhammesu citta pariyādānāya eva  saṃvattati tasmā kucchita kiriyā matta ttā kukatanti vuccati iti vuttam ha etam aṭṭha  kathā ayam kata akatassa sāvajja anavajjassa abhimukha gamanam paṭisāraḥ nāma yasmai pana iso
translated: for although it occurs thus, it cannot make what was not done previously good again, nor can it make what was done bad again. But rather it leads to the exhaustion of consciousness in profitable states. That is why it is called done, since it is merely the doing of what is bad. This is said in the Eight Questions: “The going forth to what has been done and what has not been done, to what is reprehensible and what is not, is called ‘restraint.’ But since it is the opposite of the unprofitable, it is called profitable.

original: kataṃvā pāpaṃ akataṃ nakaroti. Akataṃvā kalyāṇaṃ kataṃ nakaroti. Tasmā virūpo kucchito🔽vā paṭisāroti vippaṭisāroti. Etthaca vippaṭisāroti kukkucca meva. Kukkucceca kucchite🔽sati taṃ sampayuttacittuppādopi kucchitoyeva. Yenaca kāraṇena kukkuccaṃ kucchitaṃnāma🔽hoti. Teneva kāraṇena so cittuppādopi kucchitonāma hotīti katvā so cittuppādova kukatapade
analyzed: katam vā pāpam a katam na karoti a katam vā kalyāṇam katam na karoti tasmai virūpaḥ kucchitaḥ 🔽vā paṭisāroti vippaṭisāroti ettha ca vippaṭisāroti kukkucca mā iva kukkucce ca kucchite 🔽sati tam sampayutta cittuppādaḥ api yena ca kāraṇena kukkuccam kucchitam nāma 🔽hoti tena iva kāraṇena so cittuppādaḥ api kucchitaḥ nāma hoti iti katvā saḥ cittuppādaḥ uva kukata pade
translated: for although it occurs thus, it cannot make what was not done previously good or make what was done bad again. But rather it leads to the exhaustion of consciousness in profitable states. That is why it is called done badly because of the mere doing of what is bad. For this is said in the Eight Questions: “The going forth to meet what is blameworthy and what is not blameworthy, whether done or undone, is called remorse.” But since it does not make what is done bad or what is not done good, it is opposed to what is not done badly, or it is opposed to what is done badly. Herein, opposed to what is not done badly is remorse, and when there is remorse, the consciousness associated with it is also remorse. And because of the reason for which remorse is called done badly, that kind of consciousness is also called done badly. That is why the kind of consciousness called done badly is included in the head- ing of remorse.

original: gahetuṃ yuttoti veditabbo. Sudinnakaṇḍaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana ayamattho ujukatova vutto.
analyzed: gahetum yuttaḥ ti veditabbaḥ sudinnakaṇḍa ṭṭhakathāyam pana ayam atthaḥ uju kato va vutto
translated: It should be understood that it is fit to be seized upon. But in the commentary on the Sudinna chapter the meaning is stated straightforwardly.

original: Yathāha-viññūhi akattabbatāya kucchitakiriyābhāvato kukkuccanti.
analyzed: yathā ha viññūhi a kattabba tāya kucchita kiriyā abhāvataḥ kukkuccanti
translated: For it is said there: “Because it is not done by the wise, because it is the absence of doing what is proper, it is called ‘remorse’ (kuk-kucca).

original: [76] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: ” But in the Vibhāvinī-ṭīkā,

original: Imamatthaṃ asallakkhetvā yaṃ vuttaṃ “kucchitaṃ katanti kukataṃ. Katākata duccaritasucarita”nti.🔽Taṃ na yujjatiyeva. Etena yañca tattha vuttaṃ “akataṃpi hi kukatanti voharanti. Yaṃ
analyzed: imam attham a sat lakkhetvā yat vuttam kucchitam katanti kukatam kata akata duccarita su caritanti  tam na yujjati iva etena yat ca tattha vuttam a katam api hi kukatanti voharanti yam
translated: without considering this meaning, it is said: “Kuk means ‘done badly,’ kuc means ‘done badly.’ Kukata means ‘done badly.’ Kata-akata means ‘bad conduct and good conduct.’ ”

original: mayā akathaṃ. Taṃ kukatantica. Idha pana katā kataṃ ārabbha uppanno vippaṭisāracittuppādo
analyzed: mayā akatham tam kukatam ti ca idha pana katā katam ārabbha uppannaḥ vippaṭisāra cittuppādo
translated: This is not right. And by this it is also refuted what is said there: “For they say ‘not done is done badly,’ meaning ‘what I have not done, that is done badly.’ But here the arising of the thought of regret in regard to what is done is called ‘done badly.’ ”

original: kukata”ntica. Taṃpi sabbaṃ paṭikkhittameva hotīti.🔽Kukatassa yathāvuttacittuppādassa tathāpavatti hetubhāvo kukkuccaṃ. Apica, dhātupāṭhesu
analyzed: kukatam ti ca tat pi sabbam paṭikkhittam eva hoti iti  yathā vutta cittuppādassa hetu bhāvaḥ kukkuccam apica dhātu pāṭhesu
translated: So all this is refuted.🔽Kukkucca is the state of being a cause for the occurrence of the thought of regret in the way just described. Moreover, in the Dhatupatha,🔽the word kuc is given the meanings of “contraction” and “mental scratching.”

original: kucasaddaṃ saṅkocana mano vilekhanatthesu paṭhantiyeva. Tasmā kucchitena ākārena
analyzed: kuca saddam manaḥ vilekhana atthesu tasmā kucchitena ākārena
translated: Therefore, because of the meaning of kuc,

original: kocati saṅkocati na pāpajigucchanākārenāti kukkuco. Kucchitenavā ākārena kocati vilikhati🔽nakilesasallīkhanā kārenāti kukkuco. Tathā pavattadhammasamūho. Sohi kucchitena akataṃ
analyzed: kocati saṅkocati na pāpa jigucchana ākārena ati ākārena kocati vilikhati  kārena ati kukkucaḥ tathā pavatta dhamma samūhaḥ saḥ hi kucchitena a katam
translated: It is a “worry” because it scratches, in the way already stated. It is not a “scratching out of defilements.”🔽The state of being a worry is a state of being that occurs in this way. For it is said:

original: vata me kalyāṇaṃ kataṃ pāpanti evaṃ pavattena anutthunanākārena saṅkocati. Kusaladhammasamādāne
analyzed: vata me kalyāṇam katam pāpanti evam pavattena an utthunana ākārena saṅkocati kusala dhamma samādāne
translated: “I have not done what is good, I have done what is bad,”🔽and so it occurs by arousing in this way. It “worries” in the sense of not allowing the mind to be inclined to the undertaking of profitable actions.

original: cittaṃ namituṃpi nadeti. Manaṃvā vilekhati. Saddhādīnaṃ sāradhammānaṃ tanukaraṇena
analyzed: cittam namitum pi nadeti vilekhati saddhā ādīnam sāra dhammānam tanu karaṇena
translated: Or it “scratches the mind” by making the mind thin through making the principal states of faith, etc., thin.

original: cittaṃ kusaladhammasamādāne pariyādinnathāmabalaṃ karoti. Tasmā kukkucoti vuccati.
analyzed: cittam kusala dhamma samādāne karoti tasmā kukkuco ti vuccati
translated: It makes the mind’s strength exhausted in undertaking profitable actions. That is why it is called “worry.”🔽But the state of being a worry is called “worry” because it occurs in this way owing to the state of being that is a worry.

original: Yena pana dhammena yuttattā so tathā pavatto hoti. So kukkuccaṃnāma kukkucassa bhāvoti
analyzed: yena pana dhammena yutta ttā so tathā pavattaḥ hoti saḥ kukkuccaṃ nāma kukkucassa bhāvo ti
translated: And that is the “worriedness” of the worry,🔽which is a term for the fact that it is the state of being a worry.

original: katvā. Taṃ pana yasmā pubbe akatañca kalyāṇaṃ katañca pāpaṃ ārabbha pacchā anutāpanavasena
analyzed: katvā tam pana yasmai pubbe a katam ca kalyāṇam katam ca pāpam ārabbha pacchā anutāpana vasena
translated: But that is said because it is the subsequent regret that occurs in this way, having as its object what was done previously that was good or bad.

original: anusocanavasenaca pavattati. Tasmātaṃ pacchānutāpalakkhaṇaṃ katākatānuyocana rasanti
analyzed: anusocana vasena ca pavattati pacchā anutāpa lakkhaṇam rasanti
translated: and it occurs by way of sorrow. That is why it is said to have the characteristic of subsequent repentance, and its function is to regret what is done and what is not done.

original: ca vuttaṃ. Etthaca pacchānutāpalakkhaṇanti pubbe kalyāṇañca akatvā pāpañca katvā
analyzed: ca vuttam ettha ca pacchā anutāpa lakkhaṇam ti pubbe kalyāṇañca a katvā pāpañca katvā
translated: And here the meaning is this: because of not having done what is good and because of having done what is evil in the past,

original: āgatattā pacchime kāle anutāpalakkhaṇanti attho. Tena kukkuccassa ekantena atītārammaṇatā
analyzed: āgata ttā pacchime kāle anutāpa lakkhaṇanti attho tena kukkuccassa ekantena atīta ārammaṇa tā
translated: there is the characteristic of subsequent repentance. By that it is established that remorse has only the past as its object,

original: siddhā hoti. Paccuppannānāgatārammaṇatāca paṭisiddhāti. Katākatā nusocanarasanti
analyzed: siddhā hoti paccuppanna anāgata ārammaṇa tā ca paṭisiddhā ati kata akatā
translated: and it is prohibited that it has the present and future as its object. And its function is to regret what is done and what is not done.

original: ettha katañca pāpaṃ akatañca kalyāṇanti yo jetabbaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ mahāniddese –
analyzed: ettha katam ca pāpam akatam ca kalyāṇanti yo jetabbam vuttam ha etam mahāniddese
translated: Herein, what is done is evil and what is not done is good. This is said in the Mahāniddesa:

original: Dvīhākārehi kukkuccaṃ uppajjati katattā ca akatattā ca. Kathañca dvīhā.La. Akatattāca.🔽Akataṃ me kāyasu caritaṃ. Kataṃ kāyaduccaritanti uppajjati kukkuccaṃ. Akataṃ me vacīsucaritaṃ.La.
analyzed: dvīhākārehi kukkuccam uppajjati kata ttā ca a kata ttā ca kathaṃca a kata ttā ca  akatam me kāyasu caritam katam kāya duccaritan ti uppajjati kukkuccam akatam me
translated: “Remorse arises in two ways: because of what is done and because of what is not done. And how in two ways? Because of what is not done and because of what is done.

original: Kataṃ manoduccaritanti uppajjati kukkuccaṃ. Akatāme pāṇātipātā veramaṇī. Kato pāṇāti
analyzed: katam manoduccaritanti uppajjati kukkuccam a katā ame pāṇātipātā veramaṇī kataḥ
translated: Because of what is not done: ‘I have not done what is good bodily, I have done what is evil bodily,’ remorse arises. ‘I have not done what is good verbally, I have done what is evil verbally,’ remorse arises. ‘I have not done what is good mentally, I have done what is evil mentally,’ remorse arises. ‘I have not done the abstention from killing breathing things, I have killed breathing things,’ remorse arises.

original: pātoti uppajjati kukkuccaṃ.La. Akatā me sammādiṭṭhi. Katā micchāmiṭṭhīti uppajjati kukkuccanti.🔽Etena pana akatasucaritā rammaṇatāya kataduccaritā rammaṇatāyaca vasena kukkuccassa
analyzed: uppajjati kukkuccanti a katā me sammādiṭṭhi katā micchāmiṭṭhī iti uppajjati kukkuccanti  etena pana a kata su caritāḥ rammaṇa tāya kata duccaritāḥ rammaṇa tāya ca vasena kukkuccassa
translated: and “I have not made right view arise, I have made wrong view arise” .🔽But by this it is established that remorse has a twofold state,🔽as the pleasantness of good conduct that has not been done and the unpleasantness of misconduct that has been done.

original: dvidhābhāvoyeva siddho hoti. Dvīhākārehīti hi vuttaṃ. Soca kho pubbe pāpaṃ katvā
analyzed: dvidhā bhāvaḥ yā iva siddhaḥ hoti dvīhākārehi iti hi vuttam saḥ ca kho pubbe pāpam katvā
translated: And that is only for those who have done evil previously,

original: pacchā apāyabhayatajjitānañceva apāyesu patitvā pubbe attanā katakammaṃ anussarantānañca
analyzed: pacchā apāya bhaya tajjitānam ca iva apāyesu patitvā pubbe attanā kata kammam anussarantānam ca
translated: who are terrified by the fear of the states of loss, and who, after falling into the states of loss, remember the deeds they did previously.

original: hoti. Naaññesaṃ, akataṃ me kāyasucaritaṃ. Kataṃ kāyaduccaritanti hi vuttaṃ. Yathā🔽pana māno duvidho hoti yāthāvamāno ayāthāvamānoti. Tathā kukkuccaṃpi, yāthāvakukkuccaṃ,
analyzed: hoti na aññesam akatam me kāya su caritam katam kāya duccaritam ti hi vuttam yathā  pana mānaḥ duvidhaḥ tathā
translated: It is not for others, for it is said: “I have not done what is good by body, I have done what is bad by body” .🔽But just as conceit is twofold, namely, conceit in its primary sense and conceit in a derived sense ,

original: ayāthāva kukkuccanti duvidhaṃ hoti. Tattha ayāthāva kukkuccaṃpi uppajjamānaṃ dvīhākāreho
analyzed: ayāthāva kukkuccanti duvidham hoti tattha ayāthāva kukkuccam pi uppajjamānam
translated: so too remorse is twofold, namely, remorse in its primary sense and remorse in a derived sense. Herein, remorse in its primary sense also arises in a twofold way,

original: uppajjati akataṃ vata me kalyāṇaṃ kataṃ pāpanti. Katamaṃ pana tanti. Yañca pubbe
analyzed: uppajjati akatam vata me kalyāṇam katam pāpanti katamam pana tat ti yat ca pubbe
translated: as “I have not done what is good” and as “I have done what is bad.” But what is that?

original: kalyāṇakammepi pāpasaññī pāpadiṭṭhi akatvā pāpakammepi kalyāṇasaññī kalyāṇadiṭṭhi🔽katvā pacchā anusocanavasena uppajjati. Yañca pubbe kalyāṇe kalyāṇasaññī katvā pacchā
analyzed: kalyāṇa kamme pi pāpa saññī pāpa diṭṭhi a katvā pāpa kamme pi kalyāṇa saññī kalyāṇa diṭṭhi  katvā pacchā anusocana vasena uppajjati yat ca pubbe kalyāṇe kalyāṇa saññī katvā pacchā
translated: And when he has done a good action, he has a bad perception of it and a bad view of it, and when he has not done a bad action, he has a good perception of it and a good view of it,

original: pāpasaññino pāpeca pāsaññī akatvā pacchā kalyāṇasaññino uppajjati. Idaṃ ayāthāvakukkuccaṃnāma.
analyzed: pāpa saññino a katvā pacchā kalyāṇa saññino uppajjati idam ayāthāvakukkuccaṃ nāma
translated: and it arises in him later in the form of remorse. And when he has done a good action, he has a good perception of it, but later he has a bad perception of it. And when he has not done a bad action, he has a good perception of it, but later he has a bad perception of it. This is called remorse about what is not wrong.

original: Anavajje sāvajjasaññī, kappiye akappiyasaññī, anāpattiyaṃ āpattisaññītiādināpi yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: anavajje sāvajja saññī kappiye akappiya saññī anāpattiyam āpatti saññī iti ādinā api yojetabbam
translated: It can also be construed thus: “When there is no offence, he perceives that there is an offence” and “When there is what is allowable, he perceives that it is not allowable” and “When there is no offence, he perceives that there is an offence” and so on.

original: Idañca sabbaṃ uppajjamānaṃ dvīhā kāreheva uppajjati. Tasmā dvīsueva saṅgahitanti
analyzed: idam ca sabbam uppajjamānam dvīhā kārehā iva uppajjati tasmā dvīsu eva saṅgahitan ti
translated: And all this remorse arises only in two ways. Therefore it should be regarded as included in the two.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yaṃ pana mahāniddeseyeva hatthakukkuccakaṃpi kukkuccaṃ. Pādakukkuccakaṃpi🔽kukkuccaṃ. Hatthapādakukkuccakaṃpi kukkuccanti niddiṭṭhaṃ. Taṃ asaṃyata kukkuccaṃnāma.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam yam pana mahā niddeseya iva hattha kukkucca kaṃpi kukkuccam pāda kukkucca kaṃpi  kukkuccam hattha pāda kukkuccakaṃpi kukkuccanti niddiṭṭham tam asaṃyata kukkuccaṃnāma
translated: But in the Great Analysis the following is given as remorse: “Remorse about the hand, remorse about the foot, remorse about the hand and foot” .🔽This is called unbridled remorse.

original: Yaṃ pana taṃ bhikkhu kukkuccāyantā napaṭiggaṇhiṃsūti vinaye āgataṃ. Yañca kathaṃ
analyzed: yam pana tam bhikkhu kukkuccāyantāḥ na paṭiggaṇhiṃsu iti vinaye āgatam yat ca katham
translated: And that given in the Vinaya as “The bhikkhus did not accept out of remorse” , and that given in the Suttas as “The bhikkhus did not ask questions out of remorse” ,

original: kukkuccappakatatāya āpajjati kappiye akappiyasaññitā akappiye kappiyasaññitāti āgataṃ.
analyzed: kukkucca appakata tāya āpajjati kappiye akappiya saññi tā akappiye kappiya saññi tā ati āgatam
translated: “Through being scrupulous” is stated because of the perception of what is not allowable as allowable and of what is allowable as not allowable.

original: Taṃ vinayakukkuccaṃnāma. Taṃpana vinayasaṃsayoeva. Soca kho attano avisaye kappati
analyzed: tam vinayakukkuccam nāma tam pana vinaya saṃsayaḥ eva so ca kho attanaḥ avisaye kappati
translated: This is called scruples about the Monastic Law. But it is just doubt about the Monastic Law. And that is allowable in one’s own case,

original: nukho nonukhoti saṃsappanākārena pavatto kusala kriya cittuppādo. Sopana yesaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: nukho nonukho ti saṃsappana ākārena pavatto kusala kriya cittuppādo sopana yesam uppajjati
translated: but not in the case of others. The arising of a wholesome volitional activity that occurs in the form of a wavering, thinking, “Is it? Isn’t it?”

original: Tesu ye sikkhākāmā, te taṃkammaṃ nakaronti. Te sandhāya kukkuccāyantā napaṭiggaṇhiṃsūti
analyzed: tesu ye sikkhā kāmā te tat kammam na karonti te sandhāya kukkuccāyantāḥ na paṭiggaṇhiṃsu iti
translated: Those who are desirous of training do not do that action. It is in reference to them that it is said that they did not consent out of scruples.

original: vuttaṃ. Ye pana karontiyeva. Te kappiyavatthusmiṃpi āpattiṃ āpajjanti. Te sandhāya
analyzed: vuttam ye pana karontiyā iva te kappiya vatthusmiṃ pi āpattim āpajjanti te sandhāya
translated: But those who do that action commit an offense even in regard to allowable things. It is in reference to them that it is said that

original: kukkuccappakatatāya āpattiṃ āpajjatīti vuttaṃ.🔽94. Thiyaticittaṃ mandamandaṃ katvā ajjhottharatīti thinaṃ. Thiyiyanā thiyitattanti hi pāḷiyaṃ niddiṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: kukkucca ppakata tāya āpattim āpajjati iti vuttam  manda mandam katvā ajjhottharati iti thinam thiyiyanā hi pāḷiyam niddiṭṭham
translated: they commit an offense through being scrupulous.🔽“Dullness” is the state of being dull and slow, which is stated in the text as “dullness, mental numbness, mental darknesss”.

original: 95. Medhati cetasike dhamme akammaññabhūte katvā vihiṃ satīti middhaṃ. Tathā hi ārammaṇe
analyzed: cetasike dhamme akammañña bhūte katvā sati iti middham tathā hi ārammaṇe
translated: “Drowsiness” is the state of being drowsy, which is stated in the text as “drowsiness, sleep, nodding while dozing, dozing off, dozing, dozing off, being drowsy, being drowsy and sleepy”.

original: vipphāravasena taṃ taṃ iriyā pathaṃ sandhāretvā pavattamānesu sampayuttadhammesu🔽muggarena pothetvā viya te ārammaṇato oliyāpetvā iriyāpathaṃpi sandhāretuṃ asamatthe
analyzed: vipphāra vasena tam tam iriyā patham sandhāretvā pavattamānesu sampayutta dhammesu  muggarena pothetvā viya te ārammaṇato oliyāpetvā iriyāpathaṃpi sandhāretuṃ asamatthe
translated: When the associated states occur in the way already described, holding the various postures by the influence of the state of composure,🔽then, as if being shaken by a shaker, the mind is unable to hold the posture by directing it to the object,

original: katvā thinaṃ cittaṃ abhibhavati. Middhaṃ cetasiketi.🔽96. Vicikicchāti ettha. Cikicchanaṃ cikicchā. Ñāṇappaṭikā roti attho. Tikicchituṃ🔽dukkaratāya vigatā cikicchā etāyāti vicikicchā. Sabhāvaṃ vicinantā kicchanti kilamanti
analyzed: katvā thinam cittam abhibhavati middham cetasikā iti  vicikicchāti ettha cikicchanam cikicchā ñāṇa paṭikā roti attho tikicchitum  dukkara tāya vigatā cikicchā etā ayā ati vicikicchā sa bhāvam vicinantā kicchanti kilamanti
translated: and torpor overwhelms it. “Drowsiness is a state of mental sluggishness” .

original: etāyātivā vicikicchā. Vicikicchativā dveḷhakabhāvena pavattatīti vicikicchā. Sā nīvaraṇabhūtā,
analyzed: vicikicchā vicikicchati vā dveḷhaka bhāvena pavattati iti vicikicchā sā nīvaraṇa bhūtā
translated: Doubt . Herein, the seeking is the seeking out ; the meaning is, the opposing of knowledge. It is devoid of the seeking out that is difficult to cure , thus it is doubt . Or alternatively, they seek , they tire, by means of this, thus it is doubt . Doubt occurs with a twofold aspect, thus it is doubt . It is twofold as a hindrance

original: paṭirūpakāti duvidhā. Tattha buddhādīsu aṭṭhasu vatthūsu vimativasena pavattamānā
analyzed: paṭirūpakā ati duvidhā tattha buddha ādīsu aṭṭhasu vatthūsu vimati vasena pavattamānā
translated: and as a semblance of the true one. Herein, that which occurs by way of misinterpreting the eight things beginning with the Buddha is a hindrance.

original: nīvaraṇabhūtā. Tato aññāpana asabbaññūnaṃ tesu tesu ārammaṇesu kathaṃ nukho evaṃ
analyzed: nīvaraṇa bhūtā tatas asabbaññūnam tesu tesu ārammaṇesu katham nu kho evam
translated: That which occurs in other instances, such as, “How is it that the omniscient Buddhas, who are difficult to cure,

original: nukho idaṃnukhoti vematikabhāvena pavattā sabbā vicikicchā paṭirūpakānāma. Sā pana
analyzed: nukho idam nukhoti vematika bhāvena pavattā sabbā vicikicchā paṭirūpakā nāma sā pana
translated: All doubt that occurs through uncertainty as to whether or not this is so is doubt about what is not a fact.

original: kusalāpi hoti, akusalāpi khīṇā savānaṃ uppanna kriyābyākatāpīti. Idha pana ekantākusalabhūtā🔽nīvaraṇavicikicchāva adhippekāti.
analyzed: kusalā api hoti akusalā api khīṇā savānam uppanna kriyā abyākatā api iti idha pana ekanta akusala bhūtā  nīvaraṇa vicikicchāva adhippekā ati
translated: This is the kind of doubt that occurs in the form of uncertainty about what is correct. But it is also wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate in the case of those whose cankers are exhausted. Here, however, only the unwholesome kind of doubt that is a hindrance is intended.

original: Akusalarāsimhi paramatthadīpanā.🔽97. Saddahatīti saddhā. Yathā acchaṃ pasannaṃ nisinnaṃ udakaṃ canda sūriyādīni rūpanimittāni🔽suṭṭhu attani dahati. Evaṃ ayaṃ buddhaguṇā dīni suṭṭhu attani dahati dhāreti thapetivāti🔽attho. Saddahantivā etāyāti saddhā. Saddahanamattamevavā etanti saddhā. Sāpi buddhā🔽dīsu saddheyyavatthūsu akālussiyabhāvena pavattamānāeva idha adhippetā. Tato aññāpana
analyzed: sat dahati iti saddhā yathā accham pasannam nisinnam udakam canda sūriya ādīni rūpa nimittāni  suṭṭhu attani dahati evam ayam buddha guṇā dīni suṭṭhu attani dahati dhāreti  attho saddahanti vai etāya ati saddhā saddahana mattam eva vai etat ti saddhā sā api buddhā  dīsu saddheyya vatthūsu akālussiya bhāvena pavattamānā eva idha adhippetā tatas
translated: The explanation of the ultimate sense in the mass of the unwholesome.

original: titthiyesuvā titthiyadhammesu vā evarūpesu asaddheyyavatthūsu saddahanavasena pavattā
analyzed: titthiyesu vā titthiya dhammesu vā evarūpesu asaddheyya vatthūsu saddahana vasena pavattā
translated: It “holds” , thus it is faith . Just as clear, pure, still water “holds” , i.e. reflects, the signs of the moon, sun, etc., so this “holds” , i.e. reflects, the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., in oneself. The meaning is that it “keeps them in being” . Or alternatively, it is “faith” because of the “holding on” by means of it. It is “faith” because of the mere “holding on” by means of it. And that is intended here only as it occurs with the nature of non-distrust in the objects of faith, namely, the special qualities of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. But that which occurs with the nature of trust in objects that are not worthy of trust, such as sectarians and their doctrines,🔽is not faith.

original: okappanā saddhā paṭirūpakānāma hoti. Sā pana atthato micchādhimokkho yevāti. Yathā
analyzed: okappanā saddhā paṭirūpakā nāma hoti sā pana atthataḥ micchādhimokkhaḥ yā iva ati yathā
translated: Faith is a semblance of resolve. But in meaning it is a mere wrong resolve.

original: pana manussā hatthe asati ratanāni disvā pi-gahetuṃ na sakkonti. Vitte asati tesaṃ
analyzed: pana manussāḥ hatthe asati ratanāni disvā pigahetum na sakkonti vitte asati tesam
translated: But just as when people have no hands they are unable to pick up gems even though they see them,🔽and when they have no wealth they are unable to enjoy the use of all kinds of property,

original: sabbabhogā na sampajjanti. Bīje asati sassādīni nasampajjanti. Evaṃ saddhāya asati
analyzed: sabba bhogāḥ na sampajjanti bīje asati sassa ādīni na sampajjanti evam saddhāya asati
translated: and when there is no seed they are unable to grow crops, etc.,

original: puññakriyāvatthūni nasampajjanti. Tasmā esā hatthavittabīja sadisāti vuttā.🔽98. Saratīti sati. Attanā katāni kattabbāni ca kalyāṇakammāvā buddhaguṇādīnivā appamajjanavasena🔽upagacchatīti attho. Sāpi sammāsati micchāsati duvidhā hoti. Tattha sammāsati idha
analyzed: puñña kriyā vatthūni tasmai esā hattha vitta bīja sadisā iti vuttā  sarati iti sati attanā katāni kattabbāni ca appamajjana vasena  upagacchati iti attho sā api sammāsati micchāsati duvidhā hoti tattha sammāsati idha
translated: so too, when there is no faith, the bases for making merit are not successful. That is why it is said to be like a hand, wealth, and seed.

original: adhippetā. Itarā pana satiyeva na hoti. Katassa kattabbassaca pāpakammassa appamajjanavasena
analyzed: adhippetā itarā pana satiyā iva na hoti katassa kattabbassa ca pāpa kammassa appamajjana vasena
translated: Remembers is sati . Its meaning is that it approaches by not overlooking what has been done and what ought to be done, such as good deeds, and the special qualities of the Buddha, etc. That is twofold as right mindfulness and wrong mindfulness. Herein, right mindfulness is intended. The other is not even mindfulness. It is a mere unprofitable consciousness that is a semblance of mindfulness that occurs by not overlooking a bad deed that has been done and ought not to be done.

original: pavatto satipaṭirūpako akusalacittuppādoyeva. Yasmā panesā cittaṃ sabbehi akusaladhammehica
analyzed: pavattaḥ sati paṭirūpako akusala cittuppādaḥ yā iva yasmā pana esā cittam sabbehi akusala dhammehi ca
translated: But because this keeps the mind from all unprofitable states

original: rakkhituṃ kusaladhammehica yojetuṃ sakkoti. Tasmā sā rañño sabbakammika mahāamacco
analyzed: rakkhitum kusala dhammehi ca yojetum sakkoti tasmā sā raññaḥ mahā amacco
translated: He is able to protect and to apply himself to profitable things. Therefore it should be regarded as the king’s chief minister who is the doer of all his work.

original: viya daṭṭhabbāti. Satiṃkhvāhaṃ bhikkhave sabbatthikaṃ vadāmīti hi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: viya daṭṭhabbā ati satim khvā aham bhikkhave sabbatthikam vadāmi iti hi vuttam
translated: “Bhikkhus, I say that mindfulness is to be practised in all things” .

original: 99. Hiriyatīti hiri. Kāyaduccaritādīhi lajjati jigucchati ukkaṇṭhatīti attho.
analyzed: hiriyati iti hiri kāya duccarita ādīhi lajjati jigucchati ukkaṇṭhati iti attho
translated: It is ashamed : it is ashamed of bodily misconduct, etc., is the meaning.🔽It is afraid : it is afraid of them, is the meaning. Herein, there are those who pretend to have a conscience and shame,

original: 100. Tehiyeva ottappatīti ottappaṃ. Ubbijjatīti attho. Etthapi hiriottappappaṭirūpakānāma atthi, vuttañhi –
analyzed: tehiyā iva ottappati iti ottappam ubbijjati iti attho ettha api hiri uttappa paṭirūpakā nāma atthi vuttam hi
translated: and it is said:🔽They are not ashamed who should be ashamed,

original: Lajjitabbe nalajjanti, alajjiyesu lajjareti ca;
analyzed: lajjitabbe na lajjanti ca
translated: And they are shameless who should be ashamed;🔽They are not afraid who should be afraid,

original: Bhāyitabbe nabhāyanti, abhaye bhayadassinoti ca.
analyzed: bhāyitabbe nabhāyanti abhaye bhaya dassino ti ca
translated: And they see fear where there is no fear.

original: Yasmā pana sappurisā hiriyā attani ottappenaca paresu ārakkhadevatādīsu gāravaṃ uppādetvā pāpato vajjetvā suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharanti. Tasmā ime dve lokapāladhammāti vuttā.
analyzed: yasmai pana sappurisāḥ hiriyā attani ottappena ca paresu ārakkha devatā ādīsu gāravam uppādetvā pāpataḥ vajjetvā suddham attānam pariharanti tasmai ime dve lokapāla dhammā ti vuttā
translated: But since good people, by means of conscience and shame, arouse respect for themselves as for a deity that guards them, and so avoid evil and maintain themselves in purity, these two are called the world’s guardians .

translated: Or the middlemostness of cognizance and cognizance-concomitants in this or that profitable action is here and there middlemostness.🔽For it is said to be like a charioteer who looks on at well-trained horses that are evenly progressing, since it looks on at associated states that are evenly progressing by means of equanimity.

original: ajjhupekkhanasārathīviya daṭṭhabbāti vuttā. Ayamevaca brahmavihāresu upekkhāti vuttā.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā ati vuttā ayam eva ca brahmavihāresu upekkhā iti vuttā
translated: This is what is called equanimity in the divine abidings.

original: 104. Kāyappassaddhādīsu kāyoti vedanādikkhandhattaya saṅkhāto cetasikasamūho vuccati.
analyzed: kāya ppassaddha ādīsu kāyo ti cetasika samūhaḥ vuccati
translated: As regards bodily tranquillity, etc., the “body” is a collection of states consisting of the three aggregates, etc., that is associated with the body.

original: Cittanti sobhaṇacittaṃ. Kāyassa passaddhi kāyappassaddhi. Cittassa passaddhi cittappassaddhītiādinā
analyzed: cittanti sobhaṇa cittam kāyassa passaddhi kāya ppassaddhi cittassa passaddhi citta ppassaddhi iti ādinā
translated: “Mind” is a beautiful mind. “Calmness of the body” is the calmness of the body. “Calmness of the mind” is the calmness of the mind.

original: samāso. Passambhanaṃ passaddhi. Santasītalabhāvoti attho. Yesaṃ idaṃ dvayaṃ dubbalaṃ
analyzed: samāsaḥ passambhanam passaddhi santasī tala bhāvaḥ ti atthaḥ yesam idam dvayam dubbalam
translated: The compound is made in this way. “Calmness” is the state of being calmed. The meaning is: the state of being cool and peaceful. Those in whom this pair is weak

original: hoti. Te puññakammesu cittasukhaṃ napindanti. Bahiddhāeva nesaṃ cittaṃ pakkhandati.
analyzed: hoti te puñña kammesu citta sukham na pindanti bahiddhā eva nesam cittam pakkhandati
translated: do not find pleasure in meritorious deeds. Their mind goes out to the external world.

original: Santatte pāsāṇapiṭṭhe thapitamacchoviya hoti. Yesaṃ pana balavaṃ hoti. Teyeva tattha
analyzed: santatte pāsāṇa piṭṭhe hoti yesam pana balavam hoti teyā iva tattha
translated: They are like a fish placed on hot sand. But those in whom it is strong

original: taṃ vindanti. Tesaṃ cittaṃ sītale udake pakkhitta maccho viya hoti.
analyzed: tam vindanti tesam cittam sītale udake pakkhitta macchaḥ viya hoti
translated: find it there. Their mind is like a fish placed in cool water.

original: 105. Lahubhāvo lahutā. Agarutā adandhatāti attho. Yesaṃ idaṃ dubbalaṃ. Tesaṃ cittaṃ🔽puññakammesu napasāreti saṅkocati. Tattapāsāṇe pakkhittapadumapupphaṃ viya hoti.
analyzed: lahu bhāvaḥ lahu tā agaru tā adandha tā ati atthaḥ yesam idam dubbalam tesam cittam  puñña kammesu na pasāreti saṅkocati tatta pāsāṇe pakkhitta paduma puppham viya hoti
translated: . “Lightness” is the state of being light. The meaning is: the state of being unencumbered and unfettered. Those in whom this is weak🔽do not find pleasure in meritorious deeds. Their mind contracts. It is like a lotus flower placed on hot sand.

original: Yesaṃ pana balavaṃ. Tesaṃ cittaṃ tattha pasāreti. Sītale udake pakkhitta padumapupphaṃ viya hoti.
analyzed: yesam pana balavam tesam cittam tattha pasāreti sītale udake pakkhitta paduma puppham viya hoti
translated: But those in whom it is strong find pleasure in meritorious deeds. Their mind is like a lotus flower placed in cool water.🔽. “Wieldiness” is the state of being wieldy.

original: 106. Mudubhāvo mudutā. Yesaṃ idaṃ dubbalaṃ. Tesaṃ cittaṃ puññakammesu thaddhaṃ hoti.
analyzed: mudu bhāvaḥ mudu tā yesam idam dubbalam tesam cittam puñña kammesu thaddham hoti
translated: 106. Malleability is the quality of being malleable. Those in whom it is weak have a mind that is stiff in regard to profitable actions.

original: Verīnaṃ majjhe gatamahāyodhoviya hoti. Yesaṃ pana balavaṃ. Tesaṃ cittaṃ tattha mudu
analyzed: verīnam majjhe hoti yesam pana balavam tesam cittam tattha mudu
translated: They are like a great warrior who has gone into the midst of enemies. But those in whom it is strong have a mind that is malleable in regard to that.

original: hoti. Viyaññātīnaṃ majjhe gatamahāyodho viya hoti.
analyzed: hoti viyaññātīnam majjhe gata mahā yodhaḥ viya hoti
translated: They are like a great warrior who has gone into the midst of kinsmen.

original: 107. Kammani sādhu kammaññaṃ. Tadeva kammaññatā. Yesaṃ idaṃ dubbalaṃ. Tesaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: kammani sādhu kammaññam tat eva kammañña tā yesam idam dubbalam tesam cittam
translated: 107. Wieldiness is the quality of being wieldy. Those in whom it is weak have a mind

original: puññakammesu yathicchitaṃ thapetuṃ nalabbhati, vikkirati. Paṭivāte khittathusamuṭṭhiviya
analyzed: puñña kammesu yathicchitam thapetum na labbhati vikkirati paṭivāte
translated: that cannot be set as they would wish in profitable actions, it breaks up. It is like a handful of chaff thrown against the wind.

original: hoti. Yesaṃ pana balavaṃ. Tesaṃyeva taṃ tattha yathicchitaṃ thapetuṃ labbhati navikkirati.
analyzed: hoti yesam pana balavam tesam yeva tam tattha yathicchitam thapetum labbhati na vikkirati
translated: But those in whom it is strong have a mind that can be set as they would wish in that and does not break up.

original: Paṭivāte khittasuvaṇṇakkhandhoviya hoti.
analyzed: paṭivāte khitta suvaṇṇa khandhaḥ viya hoti
translated: It is like a handful of gold coins thrown against the wind.

original: 108. Paguṇassa bhāvo pāguññaṃ. Tadeva pāguññatā. Yesaṃ idaṃ dubbalaṃ. Tesaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: paguṇassa bhāvaḥ pāguññam tat eva pāguñña tā yesam idam dubbalam tesam cittam
translated: 108. Proficiency is the quality of being proficient. Those in whom it is weak have a mind

original: puññakammesu vikampati vihaññati. Gambhīre udake khittavānaroviya hoti. Yesaṃ pana
analyzed: puñña kammesu vikampati vihaññati gambhīre udake khittavānaraḥ viya hoti yesam pana
translated: that wavers and is upset in regard to profitable actions. They are like a monkey in deep water. But those in whom it is strong have a mind that does not waver and is not upset in regard to that. They are like a man in deep water.

original: balavaṃ, te saṃ taṃ tattha navikampati navihaññati. Gambhīre udake khitta kumbhilo viya hoti.
analyzed: balavan te sam tam tattha na vikampati na vihaññati gambhīre udake khitta kumbhilaḥ viya hoti
translated: and when it is strong, then he is not shaken or disturbed by them, but is like a crocodile in deep water.

original: 109. Ujueva ujukaṃ, ujukassa bhāvo ujukatā. Yesaṃ idaṃ dubbalaṃ. Tesaṃ cittaṃ puññakammesu
analyzed: uju eva ujukam ujukassa bhāvaḥ ujuka tā yesam idam dubbalam tesam cittam puñña kammesu
translated: Straightness is the state of being straight of one whose crookedness is weak. The mind of those whose crookedness is weak

original: visamagahikaṃ hoti. Kadāci līnaṃ. Kadāci uddhaṭaṃ. Kadāci onataṃ. Kadāci unnataṃ.
analyzed: visamagahikam hoti kadācid līnam kadācid uddhaṭam kadācid onatam kadācid unnatam
translated: is uneven in its dealings with meritorious deeds. Sometimes it is slack, sometimes excited, sometimes stooping, sometimes over- excited.

original: Surāmadamattassa maggagamanaṃ viya hoti. Yesaṃ pana balavaṃ, tesaṃ taṃ vuttavipariya yena veditabbanti.🔽110. Etthaca siddhesupi cittappassaddhādikesu vuttesu visuṃ kāyappassaddhādīnaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: surā mada mattassa magga gamanam viya hoti yesam pana balavam tesam tam vutta vipariya yena veditabbanti  ettha ca siddhesu pi citta ppassaddha ādikesu vuttesu visum kāya ppassaddha ādīnam vacanam
translated: It is like the going of one drunk with arrack. But that of those whose crookedness is strong should be understood in the opposite way to that just stated.🔽And here the words “calmness of the body” and so on should be understood as stated separately from the “calmness of consciousness” and so on already mentioned,

original: tesaṃ vasena rūpakāyassapi passaddhādi dīpanatthanti veditabbaṃ. Tattha taṃ taṃ suttantaṃ🔽sutvā gelaññavuṭṭhā nādīsu rūpakāyassa passaddhabhāvo pākaṭo iddhimantānaṃ iddhiyā
analyzed: tesam vasena rūpa kāyassa api passaddha ādi dīpana tthan ti veditabbam tattha tam tam suttantam 🔽sutvā gelañña vuṭṭhā na ādīsu rūpakāyassa passaddha bhāvo pākaṭaḥ iddhimantānam iddhiyā
translated: because they illustrate the calmness of the material body by means of the calmness of consciousness and so on.🔽Herein, the calmness of the material body is evident in those who have attained perfection, in those who have recovered from illness, and so on.🔽And the calmness of the material body of those possessing supernormal power is evident through their supernormal power.

original: ākāsagamanādīsu lahu bhāvo. Kāyaṃ khuddakaṃ vā mahantaṃ vā katvā nimminanesu mudubhāvo.
analyzed: ākāsa gamana ādīsu lahu bhāvaḥ kāyam khuddakam vā mahantam vā katvā nimminanesu mudu bhāvaḥ
translated: lightness in the case of going through the air, etc.; malleability in the case of creating a small or large body.

original: Antopathaviyaṃvā antopabbate suvā asajjamānaṃ katvā gamanādīsu kammaññabhāvo. Nāgavaṇṇaṃvā🔽garuḷavaṇṇaṃvā katvā nimminanādīsu paguṇabhāvo tesveva sabbesu yathānimmitavasena
analyzed: antopathaviyam vā antopabbate suvā a sajjamānam katvā gamana ādīsu kammañña bhāvaḥ nāga vaṇṇam vā  garuḷa vaṇṇam vā katvā nimminana ādīsu paguṇa bhāvaḥ tesu eva sabbesu yathā nimmita vasena
translated: Lightness is in the case of going through space, etc.; malleability is in the case of creating a small or large body; wieldiness is in the case of going, etc., without touching the ground or the surface of the water; plasticity is in the case of creating the appearance of a nāga, of a garuḍa, etc.;

original: cirappavattibhāvesu ujukabhāvo pākaṭo hotīti veditabbo. Samaṃ dhārentīti sādhāraṇā,
analyzed: cira pavatti bhāvesu ujuka bhāvaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti iti veditabbaḥ samam dhārenti iti sādhāraṇā
translated: straightforwardness is evident in all these in the case of their lasting as created for a long time.

original: sabbehi sobhaṇacittehi, tesaṃvā sādhāraṇā sobhaṇa sādhāraṇā.🔽111. Sammāvācāti ettha tividhā sammāvācā kathā, cetanā, virativasena, tattha atthadhammappaṭisaṃyuttā
analyzed: sabbehi sobhaṇa cittehi tesaṃvā sādhāraṇā sobhaṇa sādhāraṇā  sammāvācā iti ettha tividhā sammāvācā kathā cetanā virati vasena tattha attha dhamma paṭisaṃyuttā
translated: They maintain evenly: they are shared in common by all beautiful consciousnesses, or they are shared in common by the beautiful itself and the rest.

original: subhāsitā vācā kathā sammāvācānāma. Taṃsamuṭṭhāpikā kusalakriyacetanā cetanāsammāvācānāma.
analyzed: su bhāsitā vācā kathā sammāvācā nāma tad samuṭṭhāpikā kusala kriya cetanā cetanā sammāvācā nāma
translated: Right speech: here there are three kinds of right speech as speech, as volition, and as abstinence. Of these, the speech consisting of good verbal conduct that is connected with profitable meaning and profitable things is called right speech as speech. The profitable volitional activity that originates it is called right speech as volition.

original: Yā pana musāvādā veramaṇādīni sikkhāpadāni samādiyantassavā adhiṭṭhahantassavā sampattaṃ
analyzed: yā pana musāvādā veramaṇa ādīni sikkhāpadāni samādiyantassa vā adhiṭṭhahantassa vā sampattam
translated: But that called right speech as abstinence is the volition of one who undertakes and observes the training precepts beginning with the abstinence from false speech.

original: vatthuṃ avītikkamantassavā pāpaviramaṇākārena cittassa pavatti. Ayaṃ virati sammāvācānāma.
analyzed: vatthum a vītikkamantassa vā pāpa viramaṇa ākārena cittassa pavatti ayam virati sammā vācā nāma
translated: The state of consciousness occurring as the avoidance of what is evil is the right speech.🔽This is what is intended here.

original: Sā idha adhippetā. Sammā vadanti etā yāti sammāvācā. Etāyāti cettha karaṇatthe hetuatthe
analyzed: sā idha adhippetā sammā vadanti etā yāti sammāvācā etāyā ati ca ittha karaṇa atthe hetu atthe
translated: The words “right speech” are derived as follows. They speak rightly with this, thus it is right speech.🔽Herein, the instrumental case should be understood as the reason for the state of being a cause.

original: vā karaṇavacanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tattha vācāya sikkhāpadāni samādiyantassa samādānavacanāni
analyzed: vā karaṇa vacanam daṭṭhabbam tattha vācāya sikkhāpadāni samādiyantassa samādāna vacanāni
translated: Herein, in the case of one who undertakes the training precepts by means of speech, the instrumental case and the state of being a cause are appropriate in the sense of the words of undertaking.

original: sandhāya karaṇattho hetuattho ca yujjati. Tato yathāsamādinnānivā yathādhiṭṭhitānivā🔽sikkhāpadāni suṭṭhurakkhāmāti yāni anavajjānieva vacanāni vadantā vicaranti. Tāni
analyzed: sandhāya karaṇa atthaḥ hetu attho ca yujjati tatas yathā samādinnān iva yathā adhiṭṭhitān iva  sikkhāpadāni yāni anavajjāni eva vacanāni vadantāḥ vicaranti tāni
translated: Then, in the case of one who abides by the training precepts as undertaken and as assumed, the state of being a cause is appropriate in the sense of the reason for the state of being a cause.

original: sandhāya karaṇatthānukūlo hetu atthoyeva yujjatīti. Athavā, tathā vadantuvā māvā.
analyzed: sandhāya karaṇa ttha anukūlaḥ hetu yujjati iti athavā tathā
translated: Herein, in the case of one who speaks only blameless speech, the state of being a cause is appropriate in the sense of the reason for the state of being a cause.🔽Or alternatively, whether or not they speak thus,

original: Ayaṃpana vadamānesu sati tesaṃ sammā vattuṃeva deti. Namicchā vattunti katvā sammā
analyzed: ayam pana vadamānesu sati tesam sammā vattum eva deti na micchā vattunti katvā sammā
translated: this gives them the opportunity to speak rightly when they speak.🔽It is called right speech because it is the opposite of wrong speech.

original: vācātveva vuccati. Apica, ayaṃ vacīduccaritānaṃ pajahanavasena pavattamānā vacīdvārasuddhiyā
analyzed: vācā tu eva vuccati apica ayam pajahana vasena pavattamānā vacī dvāra suddhiyā
translated: Moreover, this occurs as the abandoning of verbal misconduct, and it is the purification of the speech door.

original: eva hotīti sammāvācāti vuccatīti.🔽112. Sammākammantopi tividho kriyā, cetanā, virati vasena. Tattha yaṃkiñci anavajjaṃ
analyzed: eva hoti iti sammāvācā iti vuccati iti  tividhaḥ kriyā cetanā virati vasena tattha yaṃ kiñci anavajjam
translated: It is thus rightly spoken of as right speech.

original: kammaṃ karontassa kāyikakriyā kriyākammantonāma. Taṃsamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā cetanākammanto🔽nāma. Yā pana pāṇātipātā veramaṇādīni sikkhāpadāni samādi yantassavā adhiṭṭhahantassavā
analyzed: kammam karontassa kāyika kriyā kriyā kammantaḥ nāma tad samuṭṭhāpikā cetanā cetanā kammantaḥ  nāma yā pana pāṇa atipātā veramaṇa ādīni sikkhāpadāni samādi yantassa vā adhiṭṭhahantassa vā
translated: Right action is threefold as action, volition, and abstinence. Herein, the bodily action of one who is doing any kind of blameless action is called “right action as action.” The volition that originates that is called “right action as volition.”

original: sampattaṃ vatthuṃ avītikkamantassavā pāpaviramaṇākārena cittassa pavatti. Ayaṃ virati
analyzed: sampattam vatthum a vītikkamantassa vā pāpa viramaṇa ākārena cittassa pavatti ayam virati
translated: But the occurrence of consciousness in the aspect of abstinence from killing breathing things, etc., in one who has undertaken the training precepts beginning with “Do not kill breathing things,” who is resolving, and who is not transgressing a rule that ought to be obeyed, is called “right action as abstinence.”

original: sammākammanto nāma. Sammā karonti etenāti sammākammaṃ, tadeva sammā kammanto suttanto🔽vanantoviya. Sesamettha vuttanayameva.🔽113. Sammāājīvopi vīriya, virativasena duvidho. Tattha pakatiyā anavajjāni kasikammādīnivā
analyzed: sammākammantaḥ nāma sammā karonti etena ati sammākammam tat eva sammā kammantaḥ suttanto  vananto viya sesam ettha vutta nayam eva  sammāājīvaḥ pi vīriya virati vasena duvidhaḥ tattha pakatiyā anavajjāni
translated: It is right action because it is action rightly done . It is right action in the way already stated . The rest is as already stated.

original: bhikkhācariyādīnivā katvā jīvitaṃ kappentānaṃ uṭṭhānabalasaṅkhāto vāyāmo vīriyasammāājīvonāma.
analyzed: bhikkhā cariyā ādīni vā katvā jīvitam kappentānam uṭṭhāna bala saṅkhāto vāyāmaḥ vīriya sammāājīvaḥ nāma
translated: Right livelihood is twofold as energy and abstinence. Herein, the energy called “the footing of relinquishment” in one who makes a living by blameless kinds of work such as agriculture, trade, service, etc., or by the kinds of livelihood such as the bhikkhu’s proper conduct, etc., is called “right livelihood as energy.”

original: Yā pana ājīvasuddhiṃ apekkhitvā attano ājīvasīlavipattikāraṇāni kāyavacīduccaritāni
analyzed: yā pana ājīva suddhim apekkhitvā attanaḥ ājīva sīla vipatti kāraṇāni kāya vacī duccaritāni
translated: But those who, in order to preserve their livelihood, commit bodily and verbal misconduct as the cause of their own failure in livelihood,

original: pajahantānaṃ pāpaviramaṇākārena cittassa pavatti. Ayaṃ virati ājīvonāma. Ayamidhādhippeto.
analyzed: pajahantānam pāpa viramaṇa ākārena cittassa pavatti ayam virati ājīvaḥ nāma ayam idha adhippeto
translated: But that which occurs in the mind of those who abandon bodily and verbal misconduct as the cause of their own failure in livelihood by looking to the purification of livelihood is the kind of virtue called “refraining” in the sense of refraining from evil. This is what is intended here.

original: Sammā ājīvanti jīvitaṃ pavattenti etenāti sammāājīvo. Sesamettha vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: sammā ājīvanti jīvitam pavattenti etena ati sammāājīvaḥ sesam ettha vutta nayam eva ati
translated: He lives rightly : he lives by means of this, thus he lives rightly . The rest is as already stated.

original: 114. Ekekāpi cettha sampatta virati, samādāna virati, samucchedavirativasena tividhā.
analyzed: ekekā api ca itthā tividhā
translated: And here each one of the kinds of virtue is threefold as virtue consisting in limited purification, virtue consisting in unlimited purification, and virtue consisting in purification not shared by ordinary men.

original: Tattha yā sikkhāpadāni asamā diyitvāvā samādinnānipivā tāni anapekkhitvā kevalaṃ
analyzed: tattha yā sikkhāpadāni asamā diyitvā vā tāni an apekkhitvā kevalam
translated: Herein, virtue that occurs in those who, without taking up the training precepts or having taken them, without taking any account of them,

original: hiri ottappabaleneva sampattaṃ vatthuṃ avītikkamantānaṃ uppannā virati. Ayaṃ sampattaviratināma.
analyzed: hiri ottappa balena iva sampattam vatthum a vītikkamantānam uppannā virati ayam sampattavirati nāma
translated: simply avoid an object that should not be done by the strength of conscience and shame is called “virtue consisting in limited purification.”

original: Sā paccuppannārammaṇāyeva. Pañcasikkhā padā paccuppannārammaṇāti hi vuttaṃ. Yā pana
analyzed: sā paccuppanna ārammaṇāya iva pañca sikkhā padā paccuppanna ārammaṇā ti hi vuttam yā pana
translated: That is only an object of the present, for it is said, “The five training precepts are an object of the present” .

original: sikkhāpadāni samādi yantassavā adhiṭṭhahantassavā yathāsamādinnānivā yathādhiṭṭhitāni
analyzed: sikkhāpadāni samādi yantassa vā adhiṭṭhahantassa vā yathā samādinnāni vā yathā adhiṭṭhitāni
translated: But that which occurs in those who take up the training precepts and undertake them and who, whether they have taken them thus or not,

original: vā suṭṭhurakkhāmīti sampatta vatthuṃ apītikkamantassavā uppannā. Ayaṃ samādānaviratināma.
analyzed: vā suṭṭhu rakkhāmi iti vatthum uppannā ayam samādānavirati nāma
translated: and “I will guard it well” is abstention by undertaking.

original: Sā pana paccuppannārammaṇāvā hoti anāgatārammaṇāvā. Tathā hi pañcasikkhāpadā paccuppannārammaṇāti🔽idaṃ sampattavirativasena vuttanti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Maggakkhaṇe pana sabbaduccaritānaṃ
analyzed: sā pana hoti anāgata ārammaṇā vā tathā hi pañca sikkhāpadā paccuppanna ārammaṇā ti  idam sampatta virati vasena vuttanti aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam magga kkhaṇe pana sabba duccaritānam
translated: But that is only with a present object or a future object. For the five precepts are said to have a present object.🔽This is said in the commentary to be abstention by arrival.🔽But at the moment of the path it is called “abstention by cutting off” because it cuts off the conditions for all misconduct.

original: paccayasamucchedavasena uppannā samucchedaviratināma. Sā pana nibbānārammaṇāeva.
analyzed: paccaya samuccheda vasena uppannā samucchedavirati nāma sā pana nibbāna ārammaṇā eva
translated: And that has only Nibbāna as its object.🔽And the “abstention of fruition” is included here too.

original: Phalaviratipi ettheva saṅgahitāti. Tattha lokiyaviratiyo jīvitindriyādīni vītikkamitabbavatthūni
analyzed: phala virati pi ettha iva saṅgahitā ati tattha lokiya viratiyaḥ jīvitindriya ādīni vītikkamitabba vatthūni
translated: Herein, the mundane kinds of abstention abandon the things to be abandoned, namely, killing living things, etc.,🔽making the life faculty, etc., and the things to be abstained from, namely, killing living things, etc., their object.

original: ārammaṇaṃ katvā pāṇātipātādīni viramitabbavatthūni pajahanti. Lokuttaraviratiyo pana
analyzed: ārammaṇam katvā pāṇa atipāta ādīni viramitabba vatthūni pajahanti lokuttara viratiyo pana
translated: But the supramundane kinds of abstention abandon the things to be abstained from, namely, killing living things, etc.,

original: nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā tāniyeva viramitabbavatthūni pajahantīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā tāniyā iva viramitabba vatthūni pajahanti iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: making Nibbāna their object. This is how they should be regarded.

original: 115. Paradukkhe sati kāruṇikānaṃ hadayakhedaṃ karotīti karuṇā. Kirativā paradukkhaṃ🔽vikkhipati, kiṇātivā paradukkhaṃ hiṃsatīti karuṇā. Kirīyati dukkhitesu pasārīyatītivā
analyzed: para dukkhe sati kāruṇikānam hadaya khedam karoti iti karuṇā kirati vā para dukkham  vikkhipati kiṇāti vā para dukkham hiṃsati iti karuṇā kirīyati dukkhitesu pasārīyati iti vā
translated: Compassion is the state of mind of those who are compassionate, which causes pain when there is suffering in others. It is compassion because it scatters the suffering of others, or because it hurts the suffering of others. It is compassion because it is scattered among those who are suffering, or because it is extended to them.

original: karuṇā. Apica kali uṇāti chedo. Kalīti dukkhaṃ vuccati, yathā-kali sambhave bhaveti.🔽Kalītivā pāpapi parājayopi vuccati. Pāpe kali parājayeti hi vuttaṃ. Sabbañcetaṃ kāruṇikā🔽naṃ kāruññahetubhūtameva hoti. Iti kaliṃ dukkhaṃvā pāpaṃvā sabbasampattito parājayaṃvā
analyzed: karuṇā apica kali chedo kali iti dukkham vuccati yathā kali sambhave bhava iti  vuccati pāpe kali parājaya iti hi vuttam sabbam ca etam kāruṇikā  kāruñña hetu bhūtam eva hoti iti kalim dukkham vā pāpam vā sabba sampattitaḥ parājayam vā
translated: Compassion is the heart’s distress of the compassionate at the suffering of others. It is compassion because it scatters the suffering of others, or because it hurts the suffering of others, or because it is scattered over the suffering of others. Or alternatively, it is compassion because it is scattered over the afflicted. Moreover, kali is a cutting off; suffering is what is called kali, as in the passage, “Suffering is born with birth” .

original: sattehi avanti rakkhanti, sattevā tato vidhakalito avanti rakkhanti kāruṇikā janā etāyāti karuṇā.🔽116. Parasampattiṃ disvā modanti etāyāti muditā. Natthi pamāṇaṃ etesanti appamāṇā,
analyzed: sattehi avanti rakkhanti sattā iva tatas avanti rakkhanti kāruṇikāḥ janāḥ etāya ati karuṇā  para sampattim disvā modanti etāya ati muditā natthi pamāṇam etesan ti appamāṇā
translated: Or kali is also said to be a defeat by evil; for it is said, “Kali is a defeat by evil” . But all that is a cause of compassion for the compassionate. So the compassionate people protect by this, or they are protected by this from all suffering, evil, and defeat in every respect, in regard to creatures. Thus it is compassion .

original: sattā. Appamāṇesu bhavāti appamaññā. Etāhi ettakesuyeva sattesu pavattetabbā. Na
analyzed: sattāḥ appamāṇesu bhavāti appamaññāḥ etāhi ettakesu yeva sattesu pavattetabbāḥ na
translated: It is gladness because they are glad by it on seeing the success of others. It is the measureless because there is no measure of these, that is, of the beings. It is the measurelessness because it is in the measureless. It should be practiced in regard to just this many beings, that is, to all beings.

original: ito aññesūti evaṃ paricchedappamāṇassa abhāvā ekasmiṃ satte pavattāpi appamaññāevanāma hontīti.
analyzed: itas aññesu iti evam pariccheda ppamāṇassa abhāvā ekasmin satte pavattā api honti iti
translated: because there is no limitation of extent in the way that there is in the case of the others.

original: [77] Ṭīkāsu pana
analyzed: ṭīkāsu pana
translated: But in the commentaries it is said:

original: Appamāṇasattā rammaṇattā appamāṇā. Tāeva appamaññāti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: appamāṇa sattā rammaṇa ttā appamāṇā tā eva appamaññā iti vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: “They are immeasurable because of the immeasurable number of beings to be loved, and they are called ‘immeasurable’ because they are immeasurable in extent.” That is not good.

original: 117. Paññindriyanti heṭṭhā vutto amohoeva. So hi pajānanaṭṭhena paññā, adhipatiyaṭṭhena indriyañcāti katvā paññindriyanti vuccatīti.
analyzed: paññindriyam ti heṭṭhā vuttaḥ amoho eva so hi pajānana ṭṭhena paññā adhipatiya ṭṭhena indriyañca ati katvā paññindriyanti vuccati iti
translated: The understanding faculty is simply non-delusion as already described . It is called “understanding” in the sense of act of understanding, and it is called “faculty” in the sense of predominance.

original: Sobhaṇarāsimhi paramatthadīpanā.🔽118. Ettāvatātiādi tiṇṇaṃ rāsīnaṃ saṅgaho. Evaṃ dvipaññāsa sarūpaṃ dassetvā idāni
analyzed: ettāvatā atiādi tiṇṇam rāsīnam saṅgahaḥ evam dvipaññāsa sarūpam dassetvā idāni
translated: The exposition of the ultimate sense in the “Treasure of Understanding” is finished.

original: cetoyuttappakāraṃ dassento tesantiādimāha. Ito cetasikānaṃ sarūpadassanato paraṃ🔽tesaṃ cittāviyuttānaṃ cittena aviyuttānaṃ cetasikānaṃ cittuppādesu paccekaṃ sampayogo
analyzed: cetaḥ yutta pakāram dassentaḥ tesam ti ādim āha itas cetasikānam sarūpa dassanataḥ param  tesam citta aviyuttānam cittena aviyuttānam cetasikānam cittuppādesu paccekam sampayogaḥ
translated: “So far” : this includes the three “treasures.” Having thus shown the fifty-two mental factors in their individual natures, he now said “Of these” in order to show the way in which they are associated with consciousness. After the individual natures of the mental factors have been shown,🔽the association of the mental factors that are inseparable from consciousness with the kinds of consciousness is stated.🔽The construction of the expression should be understood in this way: “The association of those mental factors that are inseparable from consciousness with the kinds of consciousness is stated in the way appropriate to each.” The meaning is: “In the kinds of consciousness.”

original: tathāyogaṃ vuccateti yojanā. Cittuppādesūti cittesu icceva attho. Uppajjanti cetasikā
analyzed: tathāyogam vuccata iti yojanā cittuppādesu iti cittesu icca eva atthaḥ uppajjanti cetasikā
translated: The mental factors arise

original: etesūti uppādā. Cittānieva uppādā cittuppādāti katvā. Dvipañcaviññāṇānaṃ sabbadubbalattā
analyzed: etesu ti uppādā cittāni eva uppādā cittuppādā ti katvā dvi pañca viññāṇānam sabba dubbala ttā
translated: Because the two sets of five consciousnesses are the weakest of all,

original: tesu cha pakiṇṇakā nuppajjanti. Bhāvanābalena pahīnattā vitakko dutīyajjhānikādīsu,
analyzed: tesu cha pakiṇṇakāḥ nuppajjanti bhāvanā balena pahīna ttā vitakkaḥ dutīya jjhānika ādīsu
translated: the six secondary characteristics do not arise in them. Thinking is absent in the second jhāna and so on because it has been abandoned by the force of development.

original: vicāro tatīyajjhānikādīsu, pīti catutthajjhānikādīsu nuppajjati. Sanniṭṭhānasabhāvattā🔽adhimokkho asanniṭṭhānasabhāve vicikicchā citte nuppajjati. Vīriyaṃ balanāyakattā🔽dubbalesu pañcadvārāvajjanā dīsu soḷasacittesu nuppajjati. Pīti sampiyāyanasabhāvattā
analyzed: vicāraḥ tatīya jjhānika ādīsu pi iti catuttha jjhānika ādīsu nu uppajjati sanniṭṭhāna sabhāva ttā  adhimokkhaḥ a sanniṭṭhāna sabhāve vicikicchā citte nu uppajjati vīriyam bala nāyaka ttā  dubbalesu soḷasa cittesu nu pajjati pīti
translated: Rumination is absent in the third jhāna and so on. Happiness is absent in the fourth jhāna and so on.🔽Resolution is absent in doubt, which is non-resolution. Energy is absent in the sixteen kinds of consciousness beginning with the five-door adverting, because it is the leader of strength.🔽Sympathetic joy is absent in the kinds of consciousness accompanied by grief and equanimity, because it has the nature of delighting.

original: domanassupekkhā sahagatesu nuppajjati. Chando icchāsabhāvattā icchārahitesu ahetukesu🔽momūhacittesuca nuppajjatīti āha pakiṇṇakesupana vitakko.La. Momūhavajjitacittesūti.
analyzed: domanassupekkhā sahagatesu nuppajjati chandaḥ icchā sabhāvattā icchā rahitesu ahetukesu  momūha cittesu ca nuppajjati iti āha
translated: Desire is absent in the root-causeless consciousnesses and in the deluded consciousness, because it has the nature of wanting.🔽‘In the secondary characteristics, however, thinking is present’ is said. ‘Except in the deluded consciousness.’

original: Te pana cittuppādā pakiṇṇakavivajjitā sapakiṇṇakāti sambandho.
analyzed: te pana cittuppādā pakiṇṇaka vivajjitā sa pakiṇṇakā ati sambandho
translated: And the connection is this: these kinds of consciousness, excluding the secondary characteristics, are accompanied by secondary characteristics.

original: 119. Akusalesūti akusalacetasikesu. Sabbākusala sādhāraṇānāma. Tasmā sabbesupi dvādasākusalacittesu labbhantīti yojanā.
analyzed: akusalesu iti akusala cetasikesu sabba akusala sādhāraṇa nāma tasmā sabbesu pi dvādasa akusala cittesu labbhanti iti yojanā
translated: “In unprofitable” means in those associated with unprofitable consciousness. They are the general terms for all unprofitable . Therefore the construction is: they are found in all twelve unprofitable consciousnesses.

original: [78] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga:

original: Pacchimaṃ purimassa samatthanavacananti adhippetaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: pacchimam purimassa samatthana vacanan ti adhippetam tam na sundaram
translated: “The last is said to be the opposite of the former” is intended. That is not good.

original: Idañhi ṭhānaṃ cittesu labbhamānatādassanapadhānanti. Yasmā pana sabbāni akusalacittāni
analyzed: idam hi ṭhānam cittesu labbhamāna tā dassana padhānan ti yasmā pana sabbāni akusala cittāni
translated: For this is the main point: showing where these are found among the kinds of consciousness.🔽But since no unprofitable consciousness arises without these four,

original: imehi catūhi vinā nuppajjanti. Na hi tāni pāpesu ādīnavaṃ passitvā ṭhitānaṃ uppajjanti.
analyzed: imehi catūhi vinā nu uppajjanti na hi tāni pāpesu ādīnavam passitvā ṭhitānam uppajjanti
translated: they do not arise in those who see danger in evil and abide here .

original: Naca tehi lajjāyavā bhayenavā ukkaṇṭhitānaṃ. Nāpi kusalesu dhammesu samāhitānanti.
analyzed: na ca tehi ukkaṇṭhitānam na api kusalesu dhammesu samāhitānam ti
translated: Nor do they arise in those who are ashamed of evil, afraid of it, and disgusted with it, nor in those who are concentrated on profitable things.

original: Tasmā te sabbesu tesu labbhantīti. Yasmāca diṭṭhimānā khandhesu assādaṃ amuñcitvāva
analyzed: tasmā te sabbesu tesu labbhanti iti yasmā ca diṭṭhimānā khandhesu assādam a muñcitvā ava
translated: So they are found in all those . And since the conceit “I am” and false view do not arise🔽without the relishing of gratification in the aggregates,

original: tesu tathā tathā āmasitvā pavattanti. Tasmā te lobhamūlacittesveva uppajjanti. Tattha
analyzed: tesu tathā tathā āmasitvā pavattanti tasmā te lobha mūla cittesu eva uppajjanti tattha
translated: they occur only in the kinds of consciousness rooted in greed. Herein:

original: uppajjantesu pana tesu diṭṭhi khandhesu attaggāhaṃ daḷhaṃ gahetvā taṃ attaṃ niccatādīhi
analyzed: uppajjantesu pana tesu diṭṭhi khandhesu atta ggāham daḷham gahetvā tam attam nicca tā ādīhi
translated: But when these views arise, the self-habit grasps them as the self, and it occurs conceiving the self as permanent, etc.,

original: micchāsabhāvehieva parāmasantī pavattati. Māno pana khandhe ahanti daḷhaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: micchā sabhāvehi eva parāmasantī pavattati māno pana khandhe daḷham gahetvā
translated: by the wrong way of conceiving. But conceit, having grasped the aggregates as the self,

original: taṃ gahitākāraṃ seyya tādīhieva āmasanto pavattati. Tasmā te āmasanākārato asadisavuttinoeva🔽hontīti āha. Diṭṭhicatūsu.La. Vippayuttesūti. Ye pana diṭṭhigatikā diṭṭhiyā yathāgahitaṃ🔽attānameva ahanti gaṇhanti. Tesaṃpi diṭṭhimānā āmasanākāraṃ patvā asadisavuttikāeva
analyzed: tam gahita ākāram āmasantaḥ pavattati tasmā te āmasana ākārataḥ asadisa vuttinaḥ eva  honti iti āha ye pana diṭṭhi gatikāḥ diṭṭhiyā yathāgahitam  attānam eva ahanti gaṇhanti tesam pi diṭṭhimānāḥ āmasana ākāram patvā asadisa vuttikāḥ eva
translated: occurs conceiving the self as superior, etc., to the self as it is grasped. Therefore they are unlike in the way they conceive.🔽In the four views, in the unassociated,

original: honti. Na hi mānassa viya diṭṭhiyā atta saṃpaggahaṇe byāpāro atthi. Na ca diṭṭhiyā🔽viya mānassa dhammānaṃ ayāthāvapakkhaparikappaneti. Teneva hi ahaṃgāho māno anāgāmīnaṃpi
analyzed: honti na hi mānassa viya diṭṭhiyā atta saṃpaggahaṇe byāpāraḥ atthi na ca diṭṭhiyā  viya mānassa dhammānam a yāthāva pakkha parikappanā iti tena iva hi ahaṃgāhaḥ mānaḥ anāgāmīnam pi
translated: But those who are theorists grasp the self as it is grasped by the view. For them too conceit and view are unlike in the way they conceive, having reached the way of conceiving. For the view does not have the function of grasping the self as does conceit. And conceit does not have the function of misconstruing dhammas as does the view.

original: pavattati. Attaggāhabhūtā pana diṭṭhi puthujjanāna mevāti.
analyzed: pavattati attaggāha bhūtā pana diṭṭhi puthujjanāna meva ati
translated: That is why the self-habit of conceit occurs even in non-returners, but the view that is the self-habit occurs only in ordinary men.

original: [79] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Mānopi ahaṃmānavasena pavattanato diṭṭhisadisova pavattatīti diṭṭhiyā saha ekacittuppāde napavattatī”ti vatvā kesara sīho pamāya taṃ atthaṃ sādheti. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: mānaḥ api ahaṃmāna vasena pavattanataḥ diṭṭhi sadisaḥ iva pavattati iti diṭṭhiyā saha eka cittuppāde na pavattati iti vatvā kesara sīho pamāya tam attham sādha iti tam na sundaram
translated: “Conceit occurs like a view, since it occurs by way of the conceit ‘I am,’ and so it does not occur in a single consciousness along with a view.” The lion cub’s argument is not good.

original: Sadisappavatti hi nāma sahapavattiyā eva kāraṇanti. Macchariyaṃ pana attasampattīsu
analyzed: sadisa ppavatti hi nāma saha pavattiyāḥ eva kāraṇan ti macchariyam pana atta sampattīsu
translated: For the occurrence of what is similar is a cause for the occurrence of what is similar. But stinginess arises from greed for one’s own possessions.

original: lagganalobhasamuṭṭhitaṃpi tāsaṃ parehi sādhāraṇabhāvaṃ asahanākārena pavattattā ekantena
analyzed: tāsam parehi sādhāraṇa bhāvam asahanā ākārena pavatta ttā ekantena
translated: Since it occurs in the form of an inability to bear the thought of sharing one’s possessions with others, it is entirely associated with repugnance.🔽Thus it is said that repugnance is associated with four feelings.

original: paṭighasampa yuttameva hotīti vuttaṃ doso.La. Cittesūti. Akammañña lakkhaṇaṃ thinamiddhaṃ
analyzed: yuttam eva hoti iti vuttam cittesu iti akammañña lakkhaṇam thinamiddham
translated: Sloth-and-torpor has the characteristic of unserviceability.🔽It does not occur in the five consciousnesses, which are unprompted.

original: kammaññasabhāvesu asaṅkhārikesu nasambhavatīti vuttaṃ thinamiddhaṃ pañcasu sasaṅkhārika
analyzed: kammañña sabhāvesu asaṅkhārikesu na sambhavati iti vuttam thinamiddham pañcasu sa saṅkhārika
translated: Thus it is said that sloth-and-torpor occurs in the five prompted consciousnesses.

original: cittesūti. Cattāro sabbā kusalasādhāraṇā. Tayo lobha diṭṭhimānā. Cattāro dosādayo.
analyzed: cittesu iti cattāro kusala sādhāraṇā tayo cattāro dosa ādayo
translated: Four are common to all profitable consciousness. Three are associated with greed, with false view, and with conceit. Four are associated with repugnance, etc.

original: Dvayaṃ thinamiddhaṃ. Vicikicchā cittecāti casaddo avadhāraṇe. Vicikicchācitteevāti
analyzed: dvayam thinam iddham vicikicchā citte ca ati ca saddaḥ avadhāraṇe vicikicchā citte eva ati
translated: Two are associated with uncertainty. The word “or” in the text is in the sense of “only.” Thus uncertainty occurs only in the consciousness associated with uncertainty.

original: attho. Catuddasa akusala cetasikā.
analyzed: catuddasa akusala cetasikā
translated: and meaning. There are fourteen unprofitable thoughts.

original: 120. Sobhaṇesūti sobhaṇacetasikesu. Lokuttare aṭṭhaṅgikamagge tīsu khandhesu paññākkhandhe
analyzed: sobhaṇesu iti sobhaṇa cetasikesu lokuttare aṭṭhaṅgika magge tīsu khandhesu paññā kkhandhe
translated: In the beautiful: in beautiful thoughts. In the three categories in the supramundane eight-factored path, the understanding category

original: sammāsaṅkappo nāma sammādiṭṭhipacchimakova hoti. Tasmā pādakajjhānādivasena tasmiṃ
analyzed: sammāsaṅkappo nāma sammādiṭṭhi pacchimako va hoti
translated: is right thought. Right thought is the last of the right views, and so🔽even though it is not present in the path when it is made to occur as a basic jhana, etc.,

original: asatipi paññākkhandho naparihāyati. Sīlasamādhikkhandhadhammesu pana eko ekassa kiccaṃ
analyzed: asati pi paññā kkhandho na parihāyati sīla samādhi kkhandha dhammesu pana ekaḥ ekassa kiccam
translated: the understanding category is not lacking. But in the case of the virtue category, the concentration category, and the ideas category, each one

original: nasādheti. Tasmā lokuttara maggo sattaṅgikato heṭṭhā napavattatīti āha viratiyo pana
analyzed: tasmā lokuttara maggo sattaṅgikataḥ heṭṭhā na pavattati iti āha viratiyo pana
translated: does not fulfil the function of the other. That is why the supramundane path does not occur with fewer than eight factors. So it was said that the abstinences🔽are all three.

original: tissopi.La. Labbhantīti. Niyatāva ekatova sabbathāpi labbhantīti yojanā. Tattha niyatāvāti
analyzed: tisso pila labbhanti iti ekato va sabbathā api labbhanti iti yojanā tattha niyatā ava ati
translated: The construction is: they are obtainable only as a unit, only as a set, in every way. Herein, only as a unit means

original: na lokiyesuviya kadācieva labbhanti. Athakho sabbadāpi niyatā hutvāva labbhanti.
analyzed: na lokiyesu viya kadāci eva labbhanti athakho sabbadā api niyatāḥ hutvā ava labbhanti
translated: they are not obtainable sometimes as in the case of the mundane kinds. But rather they are obtainable only as a unit, as a set, all the time.

original: Kasmā, lokuttaradhammānaṃ niccaṃ sīlesu paripūrakāritāvasena pavattattā. Na hi te
analyzed: kasmā lokuttara dhammānam niccam sīlesu paripūra kāri tā vasena pavatta ttā na hi te
translated: Why? Because the supramundane ideas occur by making the virtue category always complete. For they

original: lokiyā viya kadāci dānavasena kadāci sutapariyattivasena kadāci kasiṇabhāvanādivasena
analyzed: lokiyāḥ kadāci dāna vasena kadāci suta pariyatti vasena kadāci kasiṇa bhāvanā ādi vasena
translated: They occur sometimes by way of giving, sometimes by way of learning and studying, and sometimes by way of the development of the kasiṇas, etc., like mundane jhāna.🔽They are called “unrelated” because they are not found in the way that mundane jhāna is found in the four foundations of mindfulness, etc., and because they are not found in the way that mundane jhāna is found in the four immaterial states.

original: pavattantīti. Ekato vāti nalokiyesu viya visuṃ visuṃ labbhanti. Athakho tissopi ekato
analyzed: pavattanti iti ekatas vā ati nalokiyesu viya visum visum labbhanti athakho tissaḥ api ekatas
translated: They are called “related” because they are found in the way that mundane jhāna is found in the four jhānas and the four immaterial states.🔽They are called “unrelated” because they are not found in the way that mundane jhāna is found in the four paths and the four fruits.🔽They are called “related” because they are found in the way that mundane jhāna is found in the four paths and the four fruits.

original: hutvāva labbhanti. Kasmā, abhinnārammaṇattā. Na hi te lokiyā viya vītikkamitabbavatthusaṅkhātāni
analyzed: hutvā ava labbhanti kasmai abhinna ārammaṇa ttā na hi te lokiyāḥ viya vītikkamitabba vatthu saṅkhātāni
translated: They are called “unrelated” because they are not found in the way that mundane jhāna is found in the four immaterial states.🔽They are called “related” because they are found in the way that mundane jhāna is found in the four immaterial states.🔽They are called “unrelated” because they are not found in the way that mundane jhāna is found in the four jhānas.

original: jīvitindriyādīni nānārammaṇāni ārabbha pavattanti. Ekaṃpana nibbānameva ārabbhapavattantīti.
analyzed: jīvitindriya ādīni nānā ārammaṇāni ārabbha pavattanti ekam pana nibbānam eva ārabbha pavattanti iti
translated: They are called “related” because they are found in the way that mundane jhāna is found in the four jhānas.

original: Sabbathāpīti na lokiyesu viya ekade sappahānavasena labbhanti. Athakho tissopi anavasesa
analyzed: sabbathā api iti na lokiyesu viya eka de sa pahāna vasena labbhanti atha kho tisso pi

analyzed: sakkoti na itarāni musā vādaṃpi sa mūlam sa anusayam pajahitum na sakkoti tathā pisuṇa vācā  virati pisuṇa vācam eva pajahitum sakkoti na itarāni sa mūlam sa anusayam
translated: and the other three do not. He cannot abandon lying together with its root and with its underlying tendency. So too with malicious speech.

analyzed: sabbāni vacī duccaritāni sa mūlāni sa anusayāni pajahati sakim uppannaḥ sammākammanto  sabbāni kāya duccaritāni sa mūlāni sa anusayāni pajahati sakim uppannaḥ sammāājīvaḥ sabbāni
translated: abandons all verbal misconduct together with its root and with its underlying tendency. Right action, which arises together with the path,

analyzed: ājīva hetukāni kāyavacī duccaritāni sa mūlāni sa anusayāni pajahati iti tissaḥ lokuttaresu eva

analyzed: musāvāda pahāna vasena api labbhati na kevalam ca tad pahāna vasena iva atha kho pisuṇa vācā apahāna vasena api
