original: bhāgiyāni kāmarāgānusayādīni uparimaggavajjhāni kilesajātāni arūpasekkhānaṃpi santiyeva.
analyzed: bhāgiyāni kāma rāga anusaya ādīni upari magga vajjhāni kilesa jātāni arūpa sekkhānam pi
translated: and so on. Herein, the unprofitable courses of action together with their roots and with their underlying tendencies are all found in the fine-material and immaterial meditative development, too, but only in the fine-material and immaterial worlds.

original: Kāmarūpasekkhānaṃ pana vattabbameva natthi. Tasmā tesaṃ pajahanavasena uparimagga
analyzed: kāmarūpa sekkhānam pana vattabbam eva na atthi tasmā tesam pajahana vasena upari magga
translated: But there is no need to mention them in the case of the fine-material and immaterial worlds.🔽So their abandoning should be understood as the abandoning of the unprofitable courses of action by means of the higher paths and fruits.

original: phalaviratīnaṃ duccaritappahānaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kāmāvacarakusalesveva, napana kāmāvacaravipākakriyacittesu,
analyzed: phala viratīnam duccarita ppahānam daṭṭhabbam kāmāvacara kusalesu eva na pana kāmāvacara vipāka kriya cittesu
translated: The intention is that they are only in the fine-material-sphere profitable consciousnesses, not in the fine-material-sphere resultant and functional consciousnesses,🔽nor in the immaterial-sphere consciousnesses.

original: nāpimahaggatacittesūti adhippāyo. Kāmāvacarakusalesupi kāmabhūmiyaṃ uppannesueva,🔽narūpārūpabhūmiyaṃ uppannesu. Na hi brahmānaṃ viramitabbavatthu saṅkhātāni kāyavacīduccaritānināma
analyzed: na api mahaggata cittesu iti adhippāyaḥ kāmāvacara kusalesu pi kāma bhūmiyam uppannesu eva  uppannesu na hi brahmānam viramitabba vatthu saṅkhātāni
translated: And they are only in the fine-material-sphere profitable consciousnesses that arise in the fine-material sphere,🔽not in those that arise in the immaterial sphere. For the unprofitable courses of action consisting in bodily and verbal action have no existence in the Brahmā-world as objects of abstinence.

original: atthi. Naca lokiyaviratiyo viramitabba vatthurahitesu puggalesu pavattantīti. Upari
analyzed: atthi na ca lokiya viratiyaḥ vatthu rahitesu puggalesu pavattanti iti upari
translated: And the mundane kinds of abstinence do not occur in relation to beings who are not objects of abstinence.

original: chakāmāvacaradeve supi napavattantīti vadanti. Taṃ kathāvatthumhi vicāritameva. Yadi
analyzed: cha kāma avacara deve supi vadanti tam kathā vatthumhi vicāritam eva yadi
translated: and they do not occur among the six kinds of sense-sphere deities. This has been discussed in the section dealing with the story of the discussion of the matter .

original: evaṃ manussalokepi tīsu heṭṭhimaphalaṭṭhesu tāsaṃ appavatti āpajjati. Na hi tesaṃpi
analyzed: evam manussa loke pi tīsu heṭṭhima phala ṭṭhesu tāsam appavatti āpajjati na hi tesam pi
translated: If that is so, then it follows that they do not occur among human beings either, since the three fruits are not found among them. For they have no such things as abstention from killing breathing things, etc., as grounds for non-transgression.

original: pāṇātipātādīni viramitabbavatthūnināma atthīti. Saccaṃ, idha pana sattavidhaāpattikkhandhāpi
analyzed: pāṇa atipāta ādīni atthi iti saccam idha pana sattavidha āpatti kkhandhā api
translated: —True, but here the seven kinds of grounds for the classes of offence are the grounds for non-transgression,

original: viramitabbavatthuṭṭhāne ṭhitā. Tathā tividhakuhanavatthūnica. Tānica kānici tesaṃ
analyzed: viramitabba vatthu ṭṭhāne ṭhitā tathā tividha kuhana vatthūni ca tāni ca kānici tesam
translated: and so are the three kinds of grounds for deception. And some of these are common to the grounds for the fruits of those who have entered upon the way.

original: phalaṭṭhānaṃpi sādhāraṇānieva. Manussānañca yāni kānici tassa tassa samādinnassa🔽sikkhāpadassa vatthūnipi viramitabbavatthūnieva. Yānipi kāmasekkhānaṃ kāyavācā vipphandanakarāni
analyzed: phala ṭṭhānam pi sādhāraṇāni eva manussānam ca yāni kānici tassa tassa samādinnassa  sikkhāpadassa vatthūni pi viramitabba vatthūni eva yāni pi kāma sekkhānam kāya vācā vipphandana karāni
translated: And some of the grounds for the training precepts that are undertaken by human beings are also grounds for non-transgression.🔽And there are some defilements that are the grounds for the kinds of bodily and verbal action that are the source of human beings’ lust, etc., and are the grounds for the kinds of abstention that are the kinds of virtue consisting in limited purification.

original: kilesajātāni samucchedaviratīnaṃ vatthubhūtāni santi. Tāni tesaṃ tadaṅga viratīnaṃpi
analyzed: kilesa jātāni samuccheda viratīnam vatthu bhūtāni santi tāni tesam tad aṅga viratīnam pi
translated: These are also grounds for the kinds of abstention that are the kinds of virtue consisting in purification by knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path.

original: vatthūnievāti. Kadāci sandissantīti samādānasampattaviratīnaṃ aññataravasena pavattakāleeva
analyzed: vatthūni eva ati kadāci sandissanti iti samādāna sampatta viratīnam aññatara vasena pavatta kāle eva
translated: So they are sometimes found. The meaning is that they occur as one or other of the kinds of abstention consisting in virtue that is acquired by undertaking.

original: sandissanti. Evaṃ sandissa mānāpi bhinnārammaṇattā naekato hutvā sandissantīti vuttaṃ
analyzed: sandissanti evam sandissa mānā api bhinna ārammaṇa ttā na ekatas hutvā sandissanti iti vuttam
translated: They appear thus. But though they appear thus, they do not appear as one because of the difference in their object.

original: visuṃ visunti. Visuṃvisuṃ sandissamānāpi ekekaduccaritappahānavaseneva sandissanti.
analyzed: visum visunti visuṃvisum sandissamānā api ekeka duccarita pahāna vasena iva sandissanti
translated: They appear separately, separately. And though they appear separately, they appear only as the abandoning of each kind of misconduct.

original: Na lokuttaresu viya sabbathāpīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: na lokuttaresu viya sabbathā api iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: They should be regarded as not appearing in all ways like the supramundane jhānas.

original: 121. Appanāpattānaṃ appamaññānaṃ somanassasahagatabhāvova vibhaṅge vuttoti vuttaṃ
analyzed: appanā pattānam appamaññānam somanassa sahagata bhāvaḥ va vibhaṅge vuttaḥ ti vuttam
translated: The fact that the measureless states consisting in absorption are associated with joy is stated in the Vibhaṅga.🔽Therefore it is said, “in the higher consciousness except for the fifth jhāna.”

original: pañcamajjhānavajjitamahaggatacittesūti. Etāhi parasattānaṃ hetu adhimattabyāpārā
analyzed: pañcama jhāna vajjita mahaggata cittesu iti etāhi para sattānam adhimatta byāpārā
translated: They are the cause of other beings’ suffering because of their excessive activity.

original: honti, tasmā atisantāya nibyāpārāya pañcamajjhānupekkhāya saha napavattantīti. Appanāpubbabhāgabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: honti tasmai ati santāya nibyāpārāya pañcama jhāna upekkhāya saha na pavattanti iti appanā pubbabhāga bhūtānam
translated: That is why they do not occur together with the fifth jhāna, which is extreme neutrality and has no such activity.🔽But in the commentaries the association of these states with the feeling of equanimity, which is a forerunner to absorption, is allowed.

original: pana tāsaṃ upekkhāvedanāyapi sampayogo aṭṭhakathāyaṃ anuññātoyevāti vuttaṃ kāmāvacara.La.
analyzed: pana tāsam sampayogaḥ aṭṭhakathāyam anuññātaḥ yeva iti vuttam
translated: That is why it is said, “in the consciousness of the sense sphere.”

original: Cittesucāti. Kadācīti kāruññappakatikassa anissukinoca paresaṃ vipattisampattidassanakāle.
analyzed: cittesu ca ati kadāci iti kāruñña ppakatikassa anissukino ca paresam vipatti sampatti dassana kāle
translated: Sometimes means when one who is naturally compassionate and disinterested sees the misfortune or good fortune of others.

original: Nānāhutvā jāyantīti tesaṃ vipattidassanakāle anukampanavasena karuṇā eva jāyati,
analyzed: nānā hutvā jāyanti iti tesam vipatti dassana kāle anukampana vasena karuṇā eva jāyati
translated: When the time comes to see their failure, compassion arises in him, out of compassion,

original: namuditā. Sampattidassanakāle pana modanavasena muditāva jāyati, nakaruṇāti evaṃ🔽visuṃ visuṃ hutvā jāyantīti attho. Yasmā panetā dosasamuṭṭhitānaṃ vihiṃsā aratīnaṃ
analyzed: na muditā sampatti dassana kāle pana modana vasena muditā ava jāyati na karuṇāti evam  visum visum hutvā jāyanti iti atthaḥ yasmā pana itā dosa samuṭṭhitānam vihiṃsā aratīnam
translated: not gladness. But when the time comes to see their success, gladness arises in him, not compassion. So they arise🔽separately.🔽But since they are stated in the texts as the escape from the ill will and grief that arise from hate,

original: nissaraṇabhūtāti suttantesu vuttā. Domanassapaṭipakkhañcaso manassameva hoti. Tasmā🔽tāsaṃ appanāpubbabhāgabhūtānaṃpi niccaṃ somanassayogameva keci icchantīti vuttaṃ
analyzed: nissaraṇa bhūtā ti suttantesu vuttā manassam eva hoti tasmā  tāsam appanā pubbabhāga bhūtānam pi niccam somanassa yogam eva keci icchanti iti vuttam
translated: and since they are the opposite of grief, they are simply states of mind.🔽Therefore some people claim that they are always associated with joy,🔽and so it was said: “Some say they are found in those associated with equanimity.”

original: upekkhāsahagatesu.La. Keci vadantīti. So pana tesaṃ vādo aṭṭhakathāyapi saha viruddho.
analyzed: keci vadanti iti saḥ pana tesam vādaḥ saha viruddho
translated: But that view is contrary to the commentaries as well.

original: Tasmā taṃ bahū viññuno na sampaṭicchantīti katvā sovādo therena kecivādonāma kato.
analyzed: tasmā tam bahū viññunaḥ na sampaṭicchanti iti katvā sovādaḥ therena kato
translated: So the Elder Moggaliputta Tissa said “Some say” in order to show that that view is not accepted by many wise men.

original: Yasmāca sabbesaṃpi lokiya lokuttarajjhānānaṃ pubbabhāga bhāvanā nāma appanāsannakāleeva
analyzed: yasmāca sabbesam pi lokiya lokuttara jhānānam pubbabhāga bhāvanā nāma
translated: And since the development of the preliminary stage of all mundane and supramundane jhānas is only the development of the neighbour of absorption,

original: somanassajjhānānaṃ pubbabhāgā somanassasahagatā honti. Upekkhājhānānaṃ pubbabhāgā
analyzed: somanassa jjhānānam pubbabhāgā somanassa sahagatāḥ honti upekkhā jhānānam pubbabhāgāḥ
translated: The preliminary-work concentration is associated with joy. The jhāna that is the preliminary-work concentration is associated with equanimity.

original: upekkhāsahagatā honti. Anāsannakāle pana sabbesaṃpi tesaṃ pubbabhāgā kadāci somanassasahagatā,
analyzed: upekkhā sahagatāḥ honti anāsanna kāle pana sabbesam pi tesam pubbabhāgā kadāci somanassa sahagatā
translated: The first jhāna of joy is accompanied by joy. The first jhāna of equanimity is accompanied by equanimity. But at the time of non-excess of any one of them, the first jhāna of all of them is sometimes accompanied by joy,

original: kadāci upekkhāsahagatāhonti. Tasmā so vādo kecivādova kātuṃ yuttoti. Etthaca sabbānipi
analyzed: kadāci upekkhā sahagatā honti tasmā so vādo kātum yuttaḥ ti ettha ca sabbāni pi
translated: sometimes by equanimity. So that statement is suitable only for some.

original: samathavipassanābhāvanācittānināma ādimhi yebhuyyena upekkhāsahagatānieva bhaveyyuṃ,🔽yadiyi tāni āditoyeva paṭṭhāya somanassasahajātāni siyuṃ. Tadā ime sattā so manassajātesu
analyzed: ādimhi yebhuyyena upekkhā sahagatāni eva bhaveyyuṃ  tāni āditoyā iva paṭṭhāya somanassa sahajātāni siyum tadā ime sattā
translated: And here all the consciousnesses of the development of serenity and insight are accompanied by equanimity for the most part at the beginning.

original: kammesu anabhiratānāma natthīti aññaṃ kammaṃ chaḍḍetvā bhāvanākammameva anuyuñjeyyunti.
analyzed: kammesu anabhiratā nāma natthi iti aññam kammam chaḍḍetvā bhāvanā kammam eva anuyuñjeyyunti
translated: If they were accompanied by joy from the beginning, then there would be no beings disliking the kinds of kamma consisting in the development of serenity and insight. They would therefore be devoted to the kamma consisting in development alone, abandoning other kinds of kamma.

original: Pacchā pana attano bhāvanāya pubbāpariyavisesadassanakāleeva somanassa sahajātāni
analyzed: pacchā pana attanaḥ bhāvanāya pubba apariya visesa dassana kāle eva somanassa sahajātāni
translated: But afterwards, at the time of seeing the difference between earlier and later in one’s own development, they are accompanied by joy.

original: bhavanti. Paṭikūlā rammaṇesu pana asubhabhāvanācittesu dukkhitasattārammaṇesuca karuṇābhāvanācittesu
analyzed: bhavanti paṭikūlāḥ rammaṇesu pana asubha bhāvanā cittesu dukkhita satta ārammaṇesu ca karuṇā bhāvanā cittesu
translated: But there is no need to say that they are in the consciousnesses of the meditation that is foulness in the lovely, and in the meditation that is compassion in the consciousnesses of beings who are miserable.

original: vattabbameva natthi. Apica imā karuṇāmuditānāma pakatikālepi uppajjantiyeva. Tāsu🔽pana muditā tāva iṭṭhasampattivisayāti sāyebhuyyena somanassa sahajātāti yuttametaṃ.🔽Karuṇā pana aniṭṭhavipattivisayāti sā yebhuyyena upekkhāsahajātā eva siyā. Naca etā
analyzed: vattabbam eva natthi apica imā karuṇā muditā nāma pakati kāle pi uppajjantiyā iva tāsu  pana muditā tāva iṭṭha sampatti visayā ati sāyebhuyyena somanassa sahajātā ati yuttam etam  karuṇā pana aniṭṭha vipatti visayā ti sā yebhuyyena upekkhā sahajātā eva siyā na ca etā
translated: Moreover, these two, compassion and gladness, arise even in the ordinary man’s normal state.🔽But as for gladness, it is the province of the success of what is wished for, and so it is proper that it should be normally conascent with joy.🔽But as for compassion, it is the province of the misfortune of what is not wished for, and so it can be normally conascent with equanimity.

original: parasattahetu adhimatta byāpārāti katvā upekkhāvedanāya saha viruddhāevāti sakkā
analyzed: katvā upekkhā vedanāya saha viruddhā eva ati sakkā
translated: And it cannot be said that it is incompatible with the feeling of equanimity because it has no great concern for other beings as its cause.

original: vattuṃ. Sā hi appanaṃ apattā vedanupekkhānāma ārammaṇarasānubhavaneeva nibyāpārāhoti.🔽Na aññakiccesu. Tathā hi sattā upekkhāsahagata cittehi adinnaṃpi ādiyanti, dānaṃpi
analyzed: vattum sā hi appanam apattā vedanupekkhā nāma ārammaṇa rasa anubhavane eva  na añña kiccesu tathā hi sattā upekkhā sahagata cittehi adinnam pi ādiyanti dānam pi
translated: For it is only when it has reached absorption that it is concerned with the experience of the taste of the object of equanimity of feeling. It has no concern with other tasks.🔽For beings take what is not given, give gifts, and perform other great meritorious and unmeritorious actions by means of consciousnesses accompanied by equanimity.

original: denti, aññānipi mahantāni puññāpuññakammāni karontiyevāti. Tasmā appanā pattānaññeva
analyzed: denti aññāni pi mahantāni puññāpuñña kammāni karontiyā iva ati tasmai appanā pattānaññā iva
translated: So it is only when it has reached absorption that it is

original: tāsaṃ vedanupekkhāya saha viruddhabhāvo vattuṃ yuttoti.
analyzed: tāsam vedanupekkhāya saha viruddha bhāvaḥ vattum yuttaḥ iti
translated: and it is right to say that the equanimity of feeling is opposed to them.

original: [80] Ettāvatā yaṃ vuttaṃ vibhāvaniyaṃ🔽“Karuṇāmuditā bhāvanākāle appanāvīthito pubbe paricayavasena upekkhāsahagatacittehipi

translated: So it is said that the abstinences and the measureless states are incompatible with each other as regards function and object, and that is why two of them cannot be found in a single consciousness.🔽But the abstinences and the measureless states can be yoked together here in the way stated.

translated: The abstinences are the abandoning of the several kinds of misconduct.

translated: with reference to the mundane training precepts.🔽The divine abidings are not found in these kinds of consciousness because the measureless states have a limited-sphere object and because the great-sphere profitable has an entirely

analyzed: paritta ārammaṇa ttā tāsam tesu sambhavaḥ natthi iti vuttam appamaññā virati vajjitā ti  nanu kāma kusalam satta paññatta ādi ārammaṇam pi hoti iti tad vipākena api tena sadisā rammaṇena  bhavitabbanti na vikappa rahita ttā paññattiyaḥ hi a vijjamāna ttā mahaggata anuttara dhammāḥ ca  saṇha sukhuma dhamma ttā tathā tathā vikappetvā vā paṭivijjhitvā vā gaṇhantānam kusala ādīnam
translated: limited-sphere object. original: vigahetuṃ nasakkonti, kuto paṭivijjhitvā gahetuṃ. Tasmā tāni paññattiyovā mahaggatānuttaradhammevā🔽ālambituṃ na sakkontīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Mahaggatavipākāni pana vikapparahitānipi appanāpattakammavise
analyzed: vigahetum na sakkonti kutas paṭivijjhitvā gahetum tasmā tāni paññattiyaḥ vā mahaggata anuttara dhamme vā  ālambitum na sakkonti iti daṭṭhabbam mahaggata vipākāni pana vikappa rahitāni api appanā āpatta kamma visese

translated: But in the Vibhaṅga,

Moreover, craving for sensual desires

original: kāmadhammeeva ārammaṇaṃ karoti. Na paññattidhammeti natthi. Naca itthipurisādi hattha🔽pādādi paññattīsu assādavasena pavattā taṇhā kāmataṇhā nāma nahotīti atthi. Subheti
analyzed: kāma dhamme eva ārammaṇam karoti na paññatti dhamme ti natthi na ca itthi purisa ādi hattha  pāda ādi paññattīsu assāda vasena pavattā taṇhā kāmataṇhā nāma atthi subhā iti

analyzed: jhāna dhammā ti vitakka ādayaḥ majjhime mahaggate appamaññā ca jhāna dhammā ca parittesu
translated: “In the jhana states” : applied thought, etc. “In the middling and the exalted” : the measureless and the jhana states. “In the limited” :

analyzed: kāma sobhaṇesu virati ati attho

original: 126. Sattarasadhammā lobhadiṭṭhīhi saddhiṃ ekūnavīsati hutvā saṅgahaṃ gacchantīti

The eighteen states consisting of the sixteen states just mentioned, plus envy and avarice, are included in the unprofitable consciousnesses by way of the three roots, greed, etc., thus: in the five consciousnesses accompanied by greed there are eighteen states; in the two kinds of hate consciousness there are seventeen states, leaving out happiness; in the two kinds of consciousness accompanied by delusion there are sixteen states, leaving out both happiness and grief.🔽Envy and avarice are classed separately from the unprofitable roots by way of function and object.

translated: But in the Vibhanga,

analyzed: vuttam tattha ca saddena vedanā saṅgahaḥ ca vedanā sahagata cittuppāda saṅgahaḥ ca ati imasmin  atthe ekasesa niddeso hoti iti dasseti tam na sundaram  idha hi vedanā bhedaḥ imassa saṅgahassa nissaya dhamma pariggaha ttham eva vuttaḥ na vedanānam ca

translated: But feeling is threefold by way of its characteristic of experiencing. For whatever anyone experiences, he experiences it as pleasant, or unpleasant, or neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant. translated: But feeling is threefold by characteristic of mere experience. For whatever anyone experiences, he experiences it as pleasant or painful or neither-painful-nor-pleasant. And two kinds are mentioned as pleasant and painful, according as it is said: “Two kinds of feeling have been stated by the Lord: pleasant feeling and painful feeling” . original: Indriyabhedavasena pañca. Phassabhedavasena cha. Upavicārabheda vasena aṭṭhārasa.🔽Cha gehassitāni cha nekkhammassitānīti evaṃ paccekaṃ dvādasannaṃ somanassa domanassaupekkhānaṃ
analyzed: indriya bheda vasena pañca phassa bheda vasena cha upavicāra bheda vasena aṭṭhārasa  cha gehassitāni cha nekkhammassitāni iti evam paccekam dvādasannam somanassa domanassa aupekkhānam
translated: According to the division of faculties, there are five. According to the division of contacts, there are six. According to the division of the six kinds of investigating, there are eighteen.

original: vasena chattiṃsa. Tāyeva kālattayavasena aṭṭhasataṃ vedanā vuttāti. Yañca katthaci
analyzed: vasena chattiṃsa tāya iva kāla ttaya vasena aṭṭhasatam vedanā vuttā ati yat ca katthaci
translated: According to the division of the twelve kinds of joy, grief, and equanimity, which are respectively associated with the six kinds of sense-desire and the six kinds of renunciation, there are thirty-six. According to the division of the three times, there are one hundred and eight kinds of feeling.🔽And in some sutta, where it is said: “Whatever is felt is included in suffering,”

original: sutte yaṃkiñci vedayitaṃ sabbaṃ taṃ dukkhasminti vuttaṃ. Taṃ saṅkhāradukkhatāvasena
analyzed: sutte yaṃ kiñci vedayitam sabbam tam dukkhasmin ti vuttam tam saṅkhāra dukkha tā vasena
translated: it is said according to the suffering of formations.

original: vuttanti. Heṭṭhā pana cittaniddese cittāni indriyabhedavasena niddiṭṭhānīti katvā
analyzed: vuttam ti heṭṭhā pana citta niddese cittāni indriya bheda vasena niddiṭṭhāni iti katvā
translated: But in the description of consciousness below, the kinds of consciousness are described according to the division of faculties.

original: idhapi indriyabhedavaseneva cittāni saṅgahetuṃ puna sukhaṃ.La. Pañcadhā hotīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idh api indriya bheda vasena iva cittāni saṅga hetum puna pañcadhā hoti iti vuttam
translated: Therefore, in order to include the kinds of consciousness according to the division of faculties, it is said here: “Pleasure is fivefold.”

original: Ettha ca yesu dhammesu ādhi paccavasena sukhadukkhāni indriyāni nāma honti. Tesaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca yesu dhammesu ādhi paccavasena sukha dukkhāni indriyāni nāma honti tesaṃ
translated: And here, in those states in which pleasure and pain are faculties by way of predominance,

original: kāyika mānasikavasena duvidhattā tānipi sukhindriyaṃ somanassindriyaṃ dukkhindriyaṃ
analyzed: kāyika mānasika vasena tāni api sukha indriyam somanassa indriyam dukkha indriyam
translated: those are twofold as bodily and mental. Therefore, those are also included in the pleasure faculty, the joy faculty, the pain faculty,🔽and the equanimity faculty.

original: domanassindriyanti dvidhā vuttāni. Upekkhāya pana ādhipaccaṭṭhānabhūtā dhammā mānasikāeva
analyzed: domanassindriya nti dvidhā vuttāni upekkhāya pana ādhi paccaṭṭhāna bhūtāḥ dhammāḥ mānasikāḥ eva
translated: The words “the sorrow faculty” are said in two ways. But the states that are the basis for the pre-eminent position of equanimity are only mental.

original: hontītisā upekkhindriyanti ekadhāva vuttāti. Apica, tepi pariyāyena duvidhā honti.
analyzed: honti iti sā upekkhindriyanti ekadhā ava vuttā ati apica te pi pariyāyena duvidhā honti
translated: So they are said in one way as “the equanimity faculty.” Moreover, they are twofold by implication.

original: Cakkhādipasādakāya nissitānaṃpi sabbhāvato. Vedanāpana ekarasattā ekadhāva vuttāti.
analyzed: cakkha ādi pasādakāya nissitānam api sabbhāvataḥ vedanāpane ekarasa ttā ekadhā ava vuttā ti
translated: For although they are dependent on the eye, etc., as sensitive materiality, still they are said in one way because of their single nature as feeling.

original: Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Kāyika mānasika sātabhedato sukhadukkhāni dvidhā vuttānī”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Tattha sabhāvato iṭṭhāniṭṭhaphoṭṭhabbā nubhavanalakkhaṇāni sukha dukkhāni. Sabhāvatovā🔽parikappanatovā iṭṭhāniṭṭhamajjhattānubhavana lakkhaṇāni itarānīti. Sesānīti yathāvutta
analyzed: kāyika mānasika sāta bhedato sukha dukkhāni dvidhā vuttāni iti vuttam  tattha sabhāvataḥ iṭṭha aniṭṭha phoṭṭhabba anubhavana lakkhaṇāni sukha dukkhāni sabhāvataḥ vā  parikappanataḥ vā iṭṭha aniṭṭha majjhatta anubhavana lakkhaṇāni itarāni iti sesāni iti yathā vutta
translated: “The pleasant and painful are said in two ways, by division into bodily and mental.”🔽Herein, the pleasant and painful are characterized by the experiencing of desirable and undesirable tangible data respectively. Or they are characterized by the experiencing of desirable, undesirable, and desirable-undisirable tangible data respectively, according to their individual natures.

original: sukhadukkhato manassa domanassayuttehi sesāni bāttiṃsa kāmāvacaracittāni tevīsati
analyzed: sukha dukkhataḥ manassa domanassa yuttehi sesāni bāttiṃsa kāmāvacara cittāni tevīsati
translated: The remaining are characterized by the experiencing of desirable, undesirable, and desirable-undisirable mental data respectively, according to their individual natures or according to supposition.🔽The remaining are the thirty-two kinds of sense-sphere consciousness associated with grief and the twenty-five kinds of consciousness in the fifth jhāna.

original: pañcamajjhānikacittānicāti sabbāni pañcapaññāsacittāni. Ekatthāti ekasmiṃ citte.
analyzed: pañcamajjhānika cittāni ca ati sabbāni pañca paññāsa cittāni ekattha ati ekasmim citte
translated: All these fifty-five kinds of consciousness are said in one way as “the equanimity faculty” because they are of one kind in a single consciousness.

original: Itarā hi upekkhāvedanā.
analyzed: itarā hi upekkhā vedanā
translated: The other is the feeling of equanimity.

original: 131. Hetūnaṃ bhedena taṃsampayuttānaṃ cittacetasikāna saṅgaho hetusaṅgaho.
analyzed: hetūnam bhedena tad sampayuttānam saṅgahaḥ hetu saṅgahaḥ
translated: The classification of the states associated with the roots is the root-cause classification.

original: [85] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Lobhādihetūnaṃ vibhāgavasena taṃsampayuttadhammavasenaca saṅgaho hetusaṅgaho”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: lobha ādi hetūnam vibhāga vasena tad sampayutta dhamma vasena ca saṅgahaḥ hetu saṅgahaḥ ti vuttam tam na sundaram
translated: “The classification of the states associated with the roots by way of the division of the roots beginning with greed is the root-cause classification” . That is not good.

original: Kāraṇaṃ vuttameva. Hetūnāma chabbidhā bhavantīti sambandho. Tattha hetukiccaṃnāma
analyzed: kāraṇam vuttam eva hetu nāma chabbidhāḥ bhavanti iti sambandhaḥ tattha
translated: The reason is stated thus: “The roots have six modes” . Herein, the function of a root is

original: ārammaṇe sampayuttadhammānaṃ suppatiṭṭhitabhāva sādhanaṃ. Yathā hi rukkhassa mūlāni
analyzed: ārammaṇe sampayutta dhammānam suppatiṭṭhita bhāva sādhanam yathā hi rukkhassa mūlāni
translated: the establishment of the associated states in the object. For just as the roots of a tree

original: sayaṃ anto pathaviyaṃ vaddhitvā pathaviraseca āporaseca gahetvā rukkhaṃ yāva aggā
analyzed: sayam antar pathaviyam vaddhitvā pathavi rase ca āpo rase ca gahetvā rukkham yāva aggā
translated: having grown down into the earth and having drawn up the sap of the earth and water,

original: abhiharanti. Vātevā mahoghevā āgate rukkhaṃ suṭṭhu ākaḍḍhitvā tiṭṭhanti, evaṃ rukkho🔽vuddho viruḷho vipulo ciraṭṭhitikoca hoti. Evamevaṃ imepi dhammā sayaṃ ārammaṇesu
analyzed: abhiharanti vātā iva mahoghā iva āgate rukkham suṭṭhu ākaḍḍhitvā tiṭṭhanti evam rukkho 🔽vuddhaḥ viruḷhaḥ vipulaḥ cira ṭṭhitikaḥ ca hoti evam evam ime pi dhammā sayam ārammaṇesu
translated: carry it to the top of the tree, and when a strong wind or a violent storm arises, they hold the tree firmly and do not allow it to shake, so too these states, having🔽grown down into the object, and having drawn up the sap of the object, carry it to the top of the mind, and when a strong wind or a violent storm of an object arises, they hold the mind firmly and do not allow it to shake. Thus the mind grows, develops, and becomes great and long-lasting.

original: thirapattā hutvā sampayuttadhamme tattha vuddhe viruḷhe vipule ciraṭṭhitikeca sādhentīti.
analyzed: thira pattāḥ hutvā sampayutta dhamme tattha vuddhe viruḷhe vipule cira ṭṭhitike ca sādhenti iti
translated: and they cause the associated states to grow, to increase, to expand, and to last long.

original: Ahetukacittānipana jalatale amūlakasevā lāni viya ārammaṇe suṭṭhu patiṭṭhitāni na
analyzed: ahetuka cittāni pana jala tale amūlaka sevā ārammaṇe suṭṭhu patiṭṭhitāni na
translated: The root-cause-free consciousnesses are not well established in their object, like trees without roots in the water.

original: hontīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Apare pana dhammānaṃ kusalādibhāvasādhanaṃ hetukiccanti vadanti.
analyzed: honti iti daṭṭhabbam apare pana dhammānam kusala ādi bhāva sādhanam hetu kiccanti vadanti
translated: Others say that the function of root-cause is to establish the profitable, etc., nature of states.

original: Evaṃsante yesaṃ sahajātahetu natthi. Tesaṃ akusalabhāvo abyākatabhāvoca nasampajjeyya.
analyzed: evaṃsante yesam sahajāta hetu natthi tesam akusala bhāvaḥ na sampajjeyya
translated: If that were so, then those states that have no conascent root-cause would not be established as unprofitable or indeterminate.

original: Yānica laddhahetupaccayāni rūpāni. Tesañca kusalādibhāvo āpajjeyyāti vatvā taṃvādaṃ
analyzed: yāni ca laddha hetu paccayāni rūpāni tesam ca kusala ādi bhāvaḥ āpajjeyya iti vatvā tam vādam
translated: And the material states that have obtained root-cause conditions would be established as profitable, etc.

original: paṭipakkhipanti. Yathā pana loke andhakāronāma kenaci paccaya visesena sādhetabbo🔽na hoti. Yattha āloko natthi. Tattha so attano dhammatāya siddho hoti. Evamevaṃ dhammesu
analyzed: paṭipakkhipanti yathā pana loke andhakāraḥ nāma kenaci paccaya visesena sādhetabbo  na hoti yattha ālokaḥ na atthi tattha so attanaḥ dhamma tāya siddhaḥ hoti evam evam dhammesu
translated: But this is rejected by them, who say that just as darkness is not to be established by any special condition in the world,

original: muyhanakriyābhūto mohandhakāropi attano dhammatāya eva akusalo bhavituṃ arahati.
analyzed: muyhana kriyā bhūtaḥ moha ndhakāraḥ api attanaḥ dhamma tāya eva akusalaḥ bhavitum arahati
translated: but where there is no light it is established by its own individual essence, so too, the darkness of delusion, which is the state of being deluded about states, is rightly unprofitable by its own individual essence.

original: Tathā hi icchānāma atthi. Sāmuyhanakriyāya yuttā lagganabhāvaṃ patvā lobho akusalo
analyzed: tathā hi icchā nāma atthi sāmuyhana kriyāya yuttā laggana bhāvam patvā lobhaḥ akusalaḥ
translated: For there is a desire, and it is associated with the act of grasping, and it reaches the state of being a tie, and it is greed that is unwholesome.

original: nāma hoti. Saddhāya yuttā pana dhammacchandabhāvaṃ patvā kusalacchandonāma hoti.🔽Tathā akkhantināma atthi. Sāpi muyhana kriyāya yuttā paṭighabhāvaṃ patvā doso akusalonāma🔽hoti. Saddhāya yuttā pana uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ nādhivāsetītiādinā nayena pāpadhamma🔽pāpārammaṇa virodhabhāvaṃ patvā alobho kusalonāma hoti. Muyhanakriyā pana asukena
analyzed: nāma hoti saddhāya yuttā pana dhamma chanda bhāvam patvā kusala chandaḥ nāma hoti  tathā akkhanti nāma atthi sā api kriyāya yuttā paṭigha bhāvam patvā dosaḥ akusalaḥ nāma  hoti saddhāya yuttā pana uppannam kāma vitakkam na adhivāseti iti ādinā nayena pāpa dhamma  virodha bhāvam alobho kusalaḥ nāma hoti muyhana kriyā pana asukena
translated: For there is will-desire. When associated with the act of conceiving, it becomes greed and is called unprofitable. But when associated with faith, it becomes will-desire for the True Idea and is called profitable will-desire.

original: yuttā akusalonāma. Asukena yuttā kusalonāmāti natthi. Ambilatthāya aññena saṃyogakiccarahito🔽jātiambilaraso viya ekantaakusalajātikāeva hotīti. Yoca dhammo kusalo akusaloca na
analyzed: yuttā akusalo nāma asukena yuttā kusalo nāma ati natthi ambila tthāya aññena saṃyoga kicca rahito  jāti ambila rasaḥ viya ekanta akusala jātikā eva hoti iti yaḥ ca dhammo kusalo akusalo ca na
translated: Likewise there is intolerance. When associated with the act of conceiving, it becomes hate and is called unprofitable. But when associated with faith, it becomes non-greed in the way stated thus ‘He does not consent to arisen evil unprofitable thoughts’ , and is called profitable will-desire. But the act of conceiving is not called unprofitable when associated with this or that and profitable when associated with that or that. It is always unprofitable, like the juice of the mango-shoot, which is always sour, though it is not sour when associated with this or that and sweet when associated with that or that, because it lacks the function of combining with it.

original: hoti. So abyākatoti ettakameva dhammānaṃ abyākatabhāvasiddhiyā kāraṇaṃ. Tasmā ahetukacittānaṃ
analyzed: hoti so abyākato ti ettakam eva dhammānam abyākata bhāva siddhiyā kāraṇam tasmai ahetuka cittānam
translated: And the only reason for establishing that a state is indeterminate is that it is neither profitable nor unprofitable. So it is only in the case of the root-causeless consciousnesses that the act of conceiving is indeterminate. But in the case of the other consciousnesses it is unprofitable.

original: rūpanibbānānañca abyākatabhāvopi attano dhamma tāyaeva siddho. Tattha moho sesamūlānaṃpi
analyzed: rūpa nibbānānam ca abyākata bhāvaḥ api attanaḥ dhamma tāya eva siddhaḥ tattha moho sesa mūlānam pi
translated: And the state of being indeterminate of materiality and Nibbāna is established by their mere nature as dhammas. Herein, delusion is the root of the other roots too,

original: mūlaṃ hoti. Rajjanadussanānipi hi muyhananisandānieva honti. Alobhādīnañca kusalabhāvo
analyzed: mūlam hoti rajjana dussanāni pi hi muyhana nisandāni eva honti alobha ādīnam ca kusala bhāvaḥ
translated: for greed and hate are the outcome of delusion. And the state of being profitable of non-greed, etc.,

original: avijjānusayena saheva siddhoti. Tāni pana lobhādīni lobhasahagatādīnaṃ visesamūlāni🔽honti. Rajjanādi nisandāni hi diṭṭhimānādīni. Arajjanādinisandāni ca saddhādīnīti.
analyzed: saha iva siddhaḥ ti tāni pana lobha ādīni lobha sahagata ādīnam visesa mūlāni  honti rajjana ādi nisandāni hi diṭṭhi māna ādīni a rajjana ādi nisandāni ca saddhā ādīni iti
translated: is established only with the underlying tendency to ignorance. But these, greed, etc., are the specific roots of those associated with greed, and so on.🔽For the outcome of greed is the outcome of delusion, and so on, and the outcome of non-greed is the outcome of non-delusion, and so on. And the outcome of greed, etc., is the outcome of false view, and so on, and the outcome of non-greed, etc., is the outcome of right view, and so on.

original: Yasmā pana hetuyonāma sampayuttesu padhānadhammā honti. Tasmā sahetukavipākakriyānaṃ
analyzed: yasmā pana sampayuttesu padhāna dhammāḥ honti tasmā sa hetuka vipāka kriyānaṃ
translated: But since the roots are the principal states among the associated states,

original: abyākatabhāvo pana hetu mukhenapi vattuṃ yutto.
analyzed: abyākata bhāvaḥ pana hetu mukhena api vattum yuttaḥ
translated: the state of being indeterminate of the root- causeless resultant and functional is rightly described in terms of root.

original: [86] Ettāvatā yaṃ vuttaṃ vibhāvaniyaṃ🔽“Apare pana kusalādīnaṃ kusalādibhāvasādhanaṃ hetu bhāvo”ti vadanti. Evaṃ sati hetūnaṃ
analyzed: ettāvatā yam vuttam  apare pana kusala ādīnam kusala ādi bhāva sādhanam hetu vadanti evam sati
translated: So far it has been shown how the profitable, etc., are established as profitable, etc., by means of the roots, etc., as stated in the Vibhaṅga,🔽“But others say that the establishment of the profitable, etc., as profitable, etc., is by means of the presence of a root. ” If that were so, then another root would have to be sought for the establishment of the roots themselves as profitable, etc.,

original: attano kusalā dibhāvasādhano añño hetu maggitabbo siyā. Atha sesasampayuttahetupaṭibaddho
analyzed: attanaḥ kusala ādi bhāva sādhanaḥ aññaḥ hetu maggitabbaḥ siyā atha sesa sampayutta hetu paṭibaddho
translated: since they are associated with the other associated roots.

original: tesaṃ kusalādibhāvo, evampi momūha cittasampayuttassa hetuno akusala bhāvo appaṭibaddho
analyzed: tesam kusala ādi bhāvo evam pi citta sampayuttassa hetuno akusala bhāvo appaṭibaddho
translated: And so too the profitable, etc., state of the other causes would not be bound up with the associated states.

original: siyā. Atha tassa sabhāvato akusalabhāvopi siyā. Evaṃsati sesahetūnampi sabhāvato🔽kusalādibhāvoti tesaṃ viya sampayutta dhammānampi so hetupaṭibaddho nasiyā, yadica
analyzed: siyā atha tassa sabhāvataḥ akusala bhāvaḥ api siyā evam sati sesa hetūnam pi sabhāvataḥ  kusala ādi bhāvaḥ ti tesam viya dhammānam pi so hetu paṭibaddhaḥ yadi ca
translated: And then their unprofitable state by individual essence might be so too.🔽And so the profitable, etc., state of the other causes would not be bound up with the associated states as it is with the causes.

original: hetupaṭibaddho kusalādibhāvo. Tadā ahetukānaṃ abyākatabhāvo nasiyāti alamatinippīḷanenāti
analyzed: hetu paṭibaddhaḥ kusala ādi bhāvaḥ tadā ahetukānam abyākata bhāvaḥ alam ati nippīḍanena ati
translated: And if the profitable, etc., state is bound up with the causes, then the state of being indeterminate would not be bound up with the causes.

original: taṃ paṭikkhittaṃ hoti.🔽Yathāca laddhajjhānapaccayesu rūpārūpadhammesu jhānaṅgāni arūpadhammesueva upanijjhānaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: tat paṭikkhittam hoti  yathā ca laddha jhāna paccayesu rūpa arūpa dhammesu jhāna aṅgāni arūpa dhammesu eva upanijjhāna ṭṭham
translated: So it is a mere torment.

original: pharanti, na rūpadhammesu. Te pana jhānadhamma samuṭṭhi tattāeva jhānapaccayuppannesu
analyzed: pharanti na rūpa dhammesu te pana jhāna dhamma jhāna paccaya uppannesu
translated: And just as the jhāna factors in the material and immaterial states that have obtained the jhāna condition penetrate only the immaterial states in the sense of being the proximate cause for their occurrence, not the material states,🔽but they are called “arisen with jhāna as their condition” because they originate from the jhāna states,

original: vuttā. Evameva hetuyopi arūpa dhammesueva kusalādibhāvaṃ pharanti. Na rūpadhammesu.
analyzed: vuttāḥ evam eva arūpa dhammesu eva kusala ādi bhāvam pharanti na rūpa dhammesu
translated: so too the causes penetrate only the unprofitable, etc., state of the immaterial states, not of the material states.

original: Te pana hetu samuṭṭhitattāeva hetupaccayuppannesu vuttāti na tesaṃ rūpadhammānaṃ
analyzed: te pana hetu samuṭṭhita ttā eva hetu paccaya uppannesu vuttā ati na tesam rūpa dhammānam
translated: But since they are originated by causes, they are included among the causally-originated material dhammas mentioned above.

original: kusalādibhāvāpatti codetabbāti.
analyzed: kusala ādi bhāva āpatti codetabbā iti
translated: But since they are originated by causes, they are included among the causally-originated kinds of materiality mentioned in the Vibhaṅga, and so they are not to be taken as a reason for claiming that materiality can be profitable, etc.

original: [87] Yañca vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yañca vibhāvaniyam
translated: And the statement in the Vibhaṅga:🔽“But the profitable, etc., state of the profitable, etc., is due to proper, etc., attention” ,

original: “Kusalādibhāvo pana kusalākusalānaṃ yoniso ayoniso manasikārapaṭibaddho”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi vicāre tabbaṃ.
analyzed: kusala ādi bhāvaḥ pana kusala akusalānam yonisas ayonisas manasikāra paṭibaddhaḥ ti vuttam tat pi vicāre tabbam
translated: should be examined.🔽For when sunlight comes, the day is the occasion for the geese, etc.,

original: Tathā hi sūriyāloke āgate divā balānaṃ haṃsādīnaṃ okāso hoti. Rattandhakāle āgate
analyzed: tathā hi sūriyāloke āgate divā haṃsa ādīnam okāsaḥ āgate
translated: and when darkness comes, the night is the occasion for the owls, etc.,

original: rattibalānaṃ ulūkādīnaṃ okāso hoti. Naca te ālokandhakārā tesaṃ vaṇṇādivisesaṃ sāmenti.
analyzed: ratti balānam ulūka ādīnam okāsaḥ hoti na ca te āloka ndhakārā tesam vaṇṇa ādi visesam
translated: but the light and the darkness do not cause them to have the different colours, etc., they have.

original: Taṃ pana tesaṃ yoniyoeva sādhenti. Tattha āloko viya yonisomanasikāro daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: tam pana tesam yoniyo eva sādhenti tattha ālokaḥ viya yoniso manasikāro daṭṭhabbo
translated: But their own wombs cause them to have the different colours, etc., they have. Herein, proper attention should be regarded as like the light,🔽improper attention as like the darkness,🔽the beings as like the geese, etc., and the owls, etc.,

original: Andhakāro viya itaro. Te sattā viya kusalākusalā. Vaṇṇādiviseso viya kusalādibhāvo.
analyzed: andhakāraḥ viya itaraḥ te sattāḥ viya kusala akusalāḥ vaṇṇa ādi visesaḥ viya kusala ādi bhāvo
translated: and the profitable, etc., state as like the different colours, etc.,🔽The wombs should be regarded as like the causes.

original: Yoniyo viya hetuyo daṭṭhabbāti. Abyākatānaṃ panāti sabbaṃ yo dhammo kusalo akusaloca
analyzed: yoniyaḥ viya hetuyaḥ daṭṭhabbā ati abyākatānam pana ati sabbam yaḥ dhammo kusalaḥ akusalaḥ ca
translated: But the unprofitable and the indeterminate, etc.,

original: na hoti. So abyākatoti vuttapakkhe patatiyevāti. Tatthāti hetusaṅgahe. Sahetukānaṃ
analyzed: na hoti so abyākato ti vutta pakkhe patatiyā iva ati tattha ati hetu saṅgahe sa hetukānam
translated: Herein, ‘in the case of those with root-cause’ is a summing up.

original: pariggahasukhatthaṃ idha vajjetabbānipi ahetukāni pathamaṃ uddhaṭāni. Tenāha sesāni
analyzed: pariggaha sukha attham idha vajjetabbāni api ahetukāni pathamam uddhaṭāni tena āha sesāni
translated: The root-causeless states are mentioned first here for the purpose of showing the pleasure of delimitation of those with root-cause. Hence he said, ‘The rest are with root-cause, not root-causeless’ .

original: pana. La. Sahetukā nevāti. Tesaṃvā ahetukanāmaṃpi hetūnaṃ vaseneva visuṃ siddhanti
analyzed: pana sa hetukāḥ hetūnam vasena iva visum
translated: Or alternatively, their name ‘root-causeless’ is established separately only by reason of the root-causes.

original: tesaṃpi idha saṅgahaṇaṃ aviruddhaṃ hoti. Tenāha ahetu kāṭṭhārasekātiādi. Sabhāva🔽bhedena chabbidhāpi hetuyo kusalā kusalā byākatajātibhedena navadhā hontīti vuttaṃ lobho dosocātiādi.
analyzed: tesam idha saṅgahaṇam aviruddham hoti tena āha ahetu sabhāva  bhedena chabbidhā api kusalā kusalāḥ byākata jāti bhedena navadhā honti iti vuttam lobho
translated: So their inclusion here is not inconsistent. Hence he said, ‘The root-causeless states, etc.’🔽The root-causes, which are of six kinds according to the distinction of individual essence, become ninefold according to the distinction of the kinds of profitable, unprofitable, and indeterminate. Hence he said, ‘Greed, hate, delusion, etc.’ .

original: 132. Cuddasannaṃ kiccānaṃ bhedena taṃkiccavantānaṃ cittacetasikānaṃ saṅgaho kiccasaṅgaho.
analyzed: kiccānam bhedena tad kiccavantānam citta cetasikānam saṅgahaḥ kicca saṅgahaḥ
translated: The inclusion of those states that possess the functions is the function inclusion.

original: [88] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Paṭisandhādīnaṃ kiccānaṃ vibhāgavasena taṃkiccavantānañca paricchedavasena saṅgaho kiccasaṅgaho”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: paṭisandhā ādīnam kiccānam vibhāga vasena tad kiccavantānam ca pariccheda vasena saṅgahaḥ kicca saṅgahaḥ iti vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: ‘The inclusion by way of the distinction of the functions of rebirth-linking, etc., and by way of the delimitation of those that possess the functions is the function inclusion’ . That is not good.

original: Yena ekakammena eko upapattibhavonibbattati. Tasmiṃ sarasenavā laddhavibādhanenavā🔽parikkhīṇe so bhavo nirujjhati. Ekassa kammassa okāso hoti. Tasmā tato nibbatta bhavato🔽cutassa antarā khaṇamattaṃpi aṭṭhatvā laddhokāsena ekena kammena puna bhavantarādi🔽paṭisandhāna vasena abhinibbatti paṭisandhikiccaṃ. Tathā nibbattassa upapattibhavasantānassa
analyzed: yena eka kammena ekaḥ upapatti bhavaḥ nibbattati tasmin sa rasena vā laddha vibādhanena vā  parikkhīṇe saḥ bhavaḥ nirujjhati ekassa kammassa okāsaḥ hoti tasmā tatas nibbatta bhavato  cutassa antarā laddha ukāsena ekena kammena puna  paṭisandhāna vasena abhinibbatti paṭisandhi kiccam tathā nibbattassa upapatti bhava santānassa
translated: The rebirth-process that is generated by a single kamma-formation, whether it be a single wholesome or unwholesome kamma-formation or a combination of such, is called a single becoming.🔽When the single becoming, whether it be a single wholesome or unwholesome kamma-formation or a combination of such, is exhausted, it ceases. There is an opportunity for a single kamma to function. Therefore, immediately after the cessation of the becoming that has been generated by that kamma, there is an opportunity for a single kamma to function.🔽The function of rebirth-linking is the generation of a new becoming, etc., by a single kamma, without the lapse of a single moment, through the process of rebirth-linking.🔽The function of generation is the generation of the continuum of the rebirth-process.

original: yāva taṃ kammaṃ nakhiyyati. Tāva aviccheda pavattipaccayaṅgabhāvena pavatti bhavaṅgakiccaṃ.🔽Tassa hi tathā pavattiyā sati āyupabandhāca usmā pabandhāca pavattantiyevāti ete
analyzed: yāva tam kammam tāva bhavaṅga kiccam  tassa hi tathā pavattiyā sati āyu pabandhāca usmā pabandhāca pavattanti iva ati ete
translated: and by which one rebirth-process is generated by a single kamma. When that single kamma’s influence is exhausted, that process ceases. There is an opportunity for a single kamma. Therefore, immediately after the cessation of the rebirth-process generated by that kamma, there is a single kamma’s opportunity for the generation of another rebirth-process, etc., by rebirth-linking, which is the function of rebirth-linking. Likewise, the occurrence of the continuity of the rebirth-process that has been generated, without interruption, as a condition for the kamma’s opportunity, is the function of the life-continuum.

original: tayo dhammā imaṃ kāyaṃ abhijjamānaṃ rakkhantīti. Yathāha –
analyzed: tayo dhammāḥ imam kāyam abhijjamānam rakkhanti iti yathā āha
translated: For when there is such occurrence, the life faculty and heat occur uninterruptedly. These three things protect this body as it is being carried along. As it is said:🔽“When life, heat, and consciousness

original: Āyu usmāca viññāṇaṃ, yadā kāyaṃ jahanti maṃ;
analyzed: āyuḥ viññāṇam yadā kāyam jahanti mam
translated: Leave the body and depart,🔽Then cast aside like a useless log

original: Apaviddho tadā seti, niratthaṃva kaliṅgaranti.
analyzed: apaviddhaḥ tadā sa iti
translated: The body lies abandoned on the earth.

original: Āvajjanaṃ cittasantānassa āvaṭṭanaṃ, taṃvā āvajjeti āvaṭṭeti, āvaṭṭativā taṃ ettha
analyzed: āvajjanam citta santānassa āvaṭṭanam tam vai āvajjeti āvaṭṭeti āvaṭṭati vā tam ettha
translated: “Adverting” is the turning of the mind-continuum; it is what adverts, or it is what is turned, or it is what turns, or it is by means of that that there is adverting.

original: etenātivā āvajjanaṃ. Bhavaṅga vīthito okkamitvā ārammaṇantarābhimukhaṃ pavattatīti
analyzed: etena ativā āvajjanam bhavaṅga vīthitaḥ okkamitvā ārammaṇa antara abhimukham pavattati iti
translated: The meaning is that it occurs facing the object after emerging from the life-continuum.

original: attho. Āvajjetivā ārammaṇantare ābhogaṃ karotīti āvajjanaṃ. Dassanādīni pākaṭāni.
analyzed: āvajjetivā ārammaṇa antare ābhogam karoti iti āvajjanam dassana ādīni pākaṭāni
translated: Or alternatively, it is adverting because it makes the mind impinge upon another object. Seeing, etc., are obvious.

original: Voṭṭhabbananti visuṃ avacchinditvā thapanaṃ idaṃ nīlantivā pītakantivā subhantivāasubhantivā
analyzed: voṭṭhabbananti visum avacchinditvā thapanam idam nīlanti vā pītakanti vā subhanti vā a subhanti vā
translated: “Determining” is the fixing by distinguishing, as “This is blue,” “This is yellow,” “This is a man,” “This is a woman,” “This is past,” “This is future,” “This is present,” “This is seen,” “This is heard,” “This is sensed,” “This is cognized,” “This is to be done by me,” “This is to be done by another,” “This is to be done thus by me,” “This is to be done thus by another,” “This is possible,” “This is impossible,” “This is profitable,” “This is unprofitable,” “This is indeterminate,” “This is formed,” “This is unformed,” “This is mundane,” “This is supramundane,” “This is included in the seen, etc.,” “This is not included in the seen, etc.”;🔽it is the fixing without confusion. “Defining” is what is meant.

original: asaṅkaratothapanaṃ niyamananti vuttaṃ hoti. Javanantivā javotivā vegotivā atthato
analyzed: asaṅkarataḥ thapanam niyamananti vuttam hoti atthato
translated: “Impulsion” is what impels, or it is what is impelled, or it is the state of impulsion.

original: ekaṃ. Asaninipāto viya vegasahitassa ekekassa pittassa pavatti javanakiccaṃ.
analyzed: ekam asani nipātaḥ viya vega sahitassa ekekassa pittassa pavatti javana kiccaṃ
translated: The meaning is the same as that of the word “speed.” The function of impulsion is the occurrence of each individual unit of bile, phlegm, etc., together with speed, like the occurrence of a single lightning flash.

original: [89] Yaṃpana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yaṃpana vibhāvaniyam
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī-Țīkā it is said:

original: “Ārammaṇe taṃtaṃkiccasādhanavasena anekakkhattuṃ ekakkhattuṃvā javamānassa viya pavatti javanakicca”nti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: ārammaṇe tad tad kicca sādhana vasena aneka kkhattum eka khattum vā javamānassa viya pavatti javana kiccan ti vuttam tam na sundaram
translated: “The function of impulsion is the occurrence of the mind that is impelling, as it were, in the accomplishment of its several functions on the object, either many times or once only.” That is not good.

original: Na hi javamānassa cittassa ekavāramattena nivattināma atthi. Maggātiññājavanānipi
analyzed: na hi javamānassa cittassa eka vāra mattena nivatti nāma atthi magga atiññā javanāni pi
translated: For there is no turning back of a thought that is running its course in a single moment.🔽The impulsions of the path to the knowledge of the first jhāna’s danger

original: hi ekāvajjanaparikammacittato paṭṭhāya ekavegena pavattajavamānacittasantānapatitāni
analyzed: hi eka āvajjana parikamma cittataḥ paṭṭhāya eka vegena pavatta javamāna citta santāna patitāni
translated: For there is no turning back of a thought that is running. The impulsions of the path are included in the continuity of thought that is running with speed, beginning with the consciousness that is the proximate cause of the adverting.

original: eva honti. Na pana tāni visuṃ siddhena javena javantīti.
analyzed: eva honti na pana tāni visum siddhena javena javanti iti
translated: But they do not run with a speed that is separately accomplished.

original: [90] Tattha ca🔽Javamānassa viya pavattīti etena visuṃ visuṃ uppajjitvā niruddhā naṃ khaṇikadhammānaṃ🔽sīghagamanasaṅkhāto javonāma visuṃ natthi. Bahukkhattuṃ pavattivasena pana sīghagacchantapurisa
analyzed: tattha ca  javamānassa viya pavatti iti etena visum visum uppajjitvā niruddhā naṃ khaṇika dhammānam  sīgha gamana saṅkhātaḥ javaḥ nāma visum natthi bahu kkhattum pavatti vasena pana
translated: And here,🔽by the words “as if it were running” it is shown that the momentary states of consciousness that arise and cease separately do not have a separate speed called “running,” which is a swift going. But it is said that they are called “impulsions” because they are like a man running swiftly by going many times.

original: sadisattā eva javananti vuccatīti dassitaṃ hoti. Taṃpi na sundaraṃ.🔽Asaninipāto viya vegasahitassa ekekassa cittassa pavattijavanakiccanti hi heṭṭhā
analyzed: sadisa ttā eva javananti vuccati iti dassitam hoti tat pi na sundaram  asani nipātaḥ viya vega sahitassa ekekassa cittassa pavatti javana kiccanti hi heṭṭhā
translated: That is not good.🔽For it was said above that the function of the impulsion is the occurrence of each consciousness with speed, as though it were a blow with a cudgel.

original: vuttaṃ. Bhavaṅgacittañhi dīghaṃ addhānaṃ pūretvā pavattaṃpi nadisote vuyhamānaṃ sukkhapaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: vuttam bhavaṅga cittam hi dīgham addhānam pūretvā nadi sote vuyhamānam sukkha paṇṇam
translated: For the life-continuum consciousness occurs for a long time, but it is like a dry leaf blown along a path by the wind.

original: viya vegarahitaṃ hoti. Javanacittaṃ pana ekamekaṃpi samānaṃ indena vissaṭṭha vajiraṃ
analyzed: viya vega rahitam hoti javana cittam pana ekam ekam pi samānam indena vissaṭṭha vajiram
translated: and it is like a blow without force. But the impulsion consciousness should be regarded as occurring with force, like a diamond-tipped drill, though each is the same in kind.🔽The meaning is: that which has that as its object.

original: viya vegasahitameva pavattatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Taṃ ārammaṇaṃ etassāti tadārammaṇaṃ.🔽Yaṃ javanena gahitaṃ, tadevassa ārammaṇanti vuttaṃ hoti. Yaṃ javanena gahitārammaṇaṃ,
analyzed: viya vega sahitam eva pavattati iti daṭṭhabbam tam ārammaṇam etassa ati tad ārammaṇam  yam javanena gahitam tat eva assa ārammaṇanti vuttam hoti yam javanena gahita ārammaṇam
translated: What is meant is: it has as its object that which is apprehended by the impulsion.🔽For it is said: “It is called ‘having that as its object’ because it has as its object that which is apprehended by the impulsion.”

original: tasseva gahitattā tadārammaṇaṃ nāmāti hi vuttaṃ. Tassavā javanassa ārammaṇaṃ assa
analyzed: tassa iva gahita ttā tad ārammaṇam nāma ati hi vuttam tassa vā javanassa ārammaṇam assa
translated: The meaning here is: that which is the object of that impulsion is its object,

original: ārammaṇanti tadārammaṇaṃ. Idha pana tadārammaṇabhāvo adhippeto. Nibbattamānabhavato
analyzed: ārammaṇanti tad ārammaṇam idha pana tad ārammaṇa bhāvaḥ adhippetaḥ nibbattamāna bhavataḥ
translated: thus it has that as its object. But here the state of having that as its object is intended.🔽The word “occurs” is a synonym for “is born.” “Cessation” is the giving up, the letting go, of the occurrence of the life-continuum that has reached its end.

original: vacanaṃ muccanaṃ parigaḷanaṃ cuti. Idāni tāni kiccāni aniyamato na pavattanti. Ṭhānaniyameneva🔽pavattantīti dassetuṃ ṭhānabhedo vutto. Tiṭṭhati pavattati taṃtaṃ kiccavantaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: vacanam muccanam parigaḷanam idāni tāni kiccāni aniyamataḥ na pavattanti ṭhāna niyamena iva  pavattanti iti dassetum ṭhāna bhedaḥ vuttaḥ tiṭṭhati pavattati taṃ tam kiccavantam cittam
translated: Now, in order to show that these functions do not occur without regularity but occur in a regular order, the order of the states is stated.🔽The state is the place, the location, where the consciousness that is endowed with the several functions stands, occurs.

original: etthāti ṭhānaṃ. Okāso. Taṃtaṃ antarākāloti vuttaṃ hoti. Kālopi hi kālavantānaṃ pavattivisayattā
analyzed: ettha ati ṭhānam okāso taṃ taṃ antarākālo ti vuttam hoti kālaḥ api hi kālavantānam pavatti visaya ttā
translated: The meaning is: it is the particular time. For time is the domain of occurrence of what is endowed with time.

original: ṭhānanti vuccati. Paṭisandhiyā ṭhānaṃ paṭisandhiṭṭhānaṃ. Paṭisandhakālo paṭisandhikkhaṇoti
analyzed: ṭhānanti vuccati paṭisandhiyā ṭhānam paṭisandhi ṭhānam paṭisandha kālaḥ paṭisandhi khaṇoti
translated: is called a ‘place.’ The place of rebirth-linking is the place of rebirth-linking. The time of rebirth-linking is the moment of rebirth-linking.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Evaṃ sesesupi.
analyzed: vuttam hoti evam sesesu pi
translated: So too with the rest.

original: [91] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana🔽“Paṭisandhiyā ṭhānaṃ paṭisandhiṭṭhānanti vatvā kāmaṃ paṭisandhivini muttaṃ ṭhānaṃnāma
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana  paṭisandhiyā ṭhānam paṭisandhiṭṭhānanti vatvā kāmam paṭisandhi vini muttam ṭhānaṃ nāma
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: natthi. Sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ pana silā puttakassa sarīrantiādīsu viya abhedepi bhedaparikappanāti
analyzed: natthi sukha ggahaṇa attham pana silā puttakassa sarīram ti ādīsu viya abhede pi bheda parikappanā ti
translated: “The place of rebirth-linking is the place of rebirth-linking. Of course, there is no place apart from rebirth-linking. But in order to make it easy to understand, it is as if there were a place, just as in such passages as ‘The body of the stone-pillar boy’ , where there is no difference but a difference is assumed” .

original: daṭṭhabba”nti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam ti vuttam tat na gahetabbam
translated: That should not be accepted.

original: Kālo hi nāma sabhāvato avijjamānopi cittassa visuṃ ārammaṇabhūto eko paññattidhammo.
analyzed: kālaḥ hi nāma sabhāvataḥ avijjamānaḥ api cittassa visum ārammaṇa bhūtaḥ ekaḥ paññatti dhammo
translated: For although time does not exist as a real entity, it is a single concept- entity that is the object of consciousness.

original: Tathā hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ imesaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ mahāvipākacittānaṃ vipaccanaṭṭhānaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tathā hi aṭṭhakathāyam imesam aṭṭhannam mahā vipāka cittānam vipaccana ṭṭhānam veditabbam
translated: For in the commentary to the passage, “The place where these eight kinds of consciousness ripening as resultant have their field of action should be understood” ,🔽it is said:

original: Etāni hi catūsu ṭhānesu vipaccanti. Paṭisandhiyaṃ bhavaṅge cutiyaṃ tadārammaṇeti
analyzed: etāni hi catūsu ṭhānesu vipaccanti paṭisandhiyam bhavaṅge cutiyam tad ārammaṇā iti
translated: “These eight kinds of consciousness ripen in four places, that is to say, in rebirth-linking, in the life-continuum, in death, and in adverting” .

original: vatvā taṃ vitthārentena paṭisandhiggahaṇakāle paṭisandhihutvā vipaccanti. Asaṅkhyeyyaṃpi
analyzed: vatvā tam vitthārentena paṭisandhi ggahaṇa kāle paṭisandhi hutvā vipaccanti asaṅkhyeyyam pi
translated: and so on, and then by one who explains it in detail, it is said that the life-continuum is the life-continuum, and the death consciousness is the death consciousness, and the rebirth-linking is the rebirth-linking.

original: āyu kālaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ hutvā maraṇa kāle cuti hutvāti kālova vuttoti. Itarathā kiccāni
analyzed: āyu kālam bhavaṅgam hutvā maraṇa kāle cuti hutvā ati kālaḥ uva vuttaḥ iti itarathā kiccāni
translated: The “time” is mentioned because the life-continuum is so called because it is a continuity of life, and the death consciousness is so called because it dies, and the rebirth-linking is so called because it links up with the rebirth.

original: viya ṭhānānipi cuddasavidhānieva vattabbāni siyunti. Ṭhānānaṃ vitthārabhedo pana
analyzed: ṭhānāni pi cuddasavidhāni eva vattabbāni siyunti ṭhānānam vitthāra bhedaḥ pana
translated: Otherwise, the “stations” would have to be mentioned in fourteen ways like the “functions.”

original: upari dvīsu pavattisaṅgahesu cittapavattividhānānusārena veditabboti. Yasmā omakaṃ
analyzed: upari dvīsu pavatti saṅgahesu citta pavatti vidhāna anusārena veditabbaḥ uti yasmai omakam
translated: But the analysis of the “stations” in detail should be understood according to the method of the “arising of consciousness” in the two “Compendiums” above .

original: dvihetukakusalaṃ sayaṃ so manassayuttaṃpi samānaṃ atidubbalattā somanassa paṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: dvi hetuka kusalam sayam so manassa yuttam pi samānam ati dubbala ttā somanassa paṭisandhim
translated: because, although the single-root wholesome consciousness is itself associated with joy, it is unable to give rebirth-linking with joy because it is too weak.

original: dātuṃ nasakkoti. Tasmā somanassasantīraṇaṃ paṭisandhiṭṭhānaṃ nagacchatīti vuttaṃ🔽dveupekkhāsahagatasantīraṇānicevāti. Tathā hi paṭṭhāne pītisahagatattike paṭiccavāre
analyzed: dātum na sakkoti tasmā somanassa santīraṇam paṭisandhi ṭṭhānam na gacchati iti vuttam  dve upekkhā sahagata santīraṇāni ca iva ati tathā hi paṭṭhāne pīti sahagata ttike paṭicca vāre
translated: Therefore it is said that the station of joy does not occur in rebirth-linking.🔽It is only the two stations accompanied by equanimity that occur in rebirth-linking.🔽For in the “Section on Conditions” in the Paṭṭhāna the three kinds of consciousness accompanied by happiness are excluded by the station of rebirth-linking.

original: hetupaccanike taṃ paṭi sandhiṭṭhānena uddhaṭanti. Manodvārāvajjanaṃ parittārammaṇevā
analyzed: hetu paccanike tam paṭi sandhiṭṭhānena uddhaṭanti manaḥ dvāra āvajjanam paritta ārammaṇā iva
translated: The adverting at the mind door has only a limited object.

original: avibhūtā rammaṇevā dvattikkhattuṃ pavattamānaṃpi vipāka santānato laddhapaccayabhāvena
analyzed: avibhūtā dvatti khattum pavattamānam pi vipāka santānataḥ laddha paccaya bhāvena
translated: Though it occurs thirty-two times without interruption, it is still weak in the absence of the conditions obtained through the continuity of the result.

original: dubbalattā javanavegarahitameva hotīti vuttaṃ āvajjana dvaya vajjitānīti.
analyzed: dubbala ttā javana vega rahitam eva hoti iti vuttam āvajjana dvaya vajjitāni iti
translated: Therefore it is said that it is devoid of the impulsion of impulsion.

original: [92] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī-Țīkā,

original: “Ārammaṇarasānubhavanā bhāvato”ti kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃ a kāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: ārammaṇa rasa anubhavanā bhāvato ti kāraṇam vuttam tam a kāraṇam
translated: the reason is given as “because it experiences the taste of the object.” But that is not a reason.

original: Na hi ārammaṇa rasānubhavanaṃ javanakicca siddhiyā javananāma lābhassaca kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: na hi ārammaṇa rasa anubhavanam javana kicca siddhiyā javana nāma lābhassa ca kāraṇam
translated: For the experience of the taste of the object is not a reason for the accomplishment of the function of impulsion and for the acquisition of the name “impulsion.”🔽But it is the fruit of the accomplishment of the function of impulsion.

original: hoti. Taṃ pana javanakiccasiddhiyā phalame vahotīti. Yasmā pana phalacittaṃ āsevanabhāvarahitaṃpi
analyzed: hoti tam pana javana kicca siddhiyā yasmā pana phala cittam
translated: But because the resultant consciousness lacks the quality of being cultivated,

original: magga cetanāya mahānubhāvattā parikammabhāvanābalena ca pavattattā ārammaṇe vegasahitameva
analyzed: cetanāya mahā anubhāva ttā parikamma bhāvanā balena ca pavatta ttā ārammaṇe vega sahitam eva
translated: it falls upon the object with impulsion when it occurs through the power of the strong volition of the path and through the power of the development of the preliminary work.

original: patatīti tassajavanesu gahaṇaṃkataṃ.
analyzed: patati iti gahaṇaṃkatam
translated: Therefore it is included among the impulsions.

original: [93] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī-Țīkā,

original: Maggābhiññājavanānaṃ ekavārameva pavattattā javanakiccaṃ na sampajjatīti adhippāyena
analyzed: magga abhiññā javanānam eka vāram eva pavatta ttā javana kiccam na sampajjati iti adhippāyena
translated: the intention is that the function of impulsion is not accomplished because the impulsions of the path and of direct-knowledge occur only once.

original: “ekacittakkhaṇikaṃpi lokuttara maggāditaṃ taṃsabhāvavantatāya javanakiccaṃ nāmā”ti
analyzed: eka citta khaṇikam pi lokuttara magga āditam javana kiccam nāma ati
translated: “The javana process is the state of being of the supramundane path, etc., even for a single moment of consciousness.”

original: vatvā sabbaññutaññāṇopamāya tamatthaṃ vibhāveti. Taṃ na yujjatiyeva.
analyzed: vatvā sabbaññu taññāṇa upamāya tam attham vibhāveti tam na
translated: Having said this, he elucidates the meaning by means of the simile of omniscient knowledge. But that is not correct.

original: Idāni samānakiccagaṇanāni cittāni saṅgahetvā dassetuṃ tesu panātiādimāha. Paṭisandhādayo nāma cittuppādāti sambandho.
analyzed: idāni samāna kicca gaṇanāni cittāni saṅgahetvā dassetum tesu pana ati ādim āha paṭisandhā ādayaḥ nāma citta uppādā ti sambandho
translated: Now, in order to show the kinds of consciousness that have the same function by collecting them together, he says, “Among these,” and so on. The construction is: the consciousnesses called rebirth-linking, and so on.

original: [94] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the analysis

original: Nāmakiccabhedenātipi yojeti. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: nāma kicca bhedena atipi tam na sundaram
translated: he says: “Or it is said: by the division of the function of the name.” That is not good.

original: Nāmabhedassa visuṃ vattabbābhāvatoti. Ekakiccaṭṭhāna dvikiccaṭṭhāna tikiccaṭṭhāna
analyzed: nāma bhedassa visum vattabba abhāvato ti eka kicca ṭṭhāna dvi kicca ṭṭhāna ti kicca ṭṭhāna
translated: Because there is no need to mention the different names separately. The kinds of consciousness that have one function, two functions, three functions,

original: catukiccaṭṭhāna pañcakiccaṭṭhānāni cittāni yathākkamaṃ aṭṭhasaṭṭhica tathā dveca
analyzed: catu kicca ṭṭhāna pañca kicca ṭṭhānāni cittāni yathākkamam tathā
translated: four functions, and five functions are respectively shown in the following two,

original: navaca aṭṭhaca dveca niddiseti yojanā.
analyzed: niddisa iti yojanā
translated: nine, eight, and two sections.

original: 133. Cakkhādīnaṃ dvārānaṃ bhedena cittacetasikānaṃ saṅgaho dvārasaṅgaho.
analyzed: cakkhu ādīnam dvārānam bhedena citta cetasikānam saṅgahaḥ dvāra saṅgahaḥ
translated: The collection of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants according to the division of the doors of the eye, etc., is the collection according to the doors.

original: [95] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the analysis

original: “Dvārānañca dvārapavattacittānañca paricchedavasena saṅgaho dvārasaṅgaho”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: dvāra anañca dvāra pavatta cittānañca pariccheda vasena saṅgahaḥ dvāra saṅgahaḥ iti vuttam tam na sundaram
translated: “The ‘door-approach’ is the approach by way of the delimitation of the doors and of the consciousnesses occurring with the doors,” it is said. That is not good.🔽Two kinds of people go out and come in by it, thus it is a door .

original: Dve janā aranti gacchanti etenāti dvāraṃ. Nagarassa anto janā bahijanāca yena chiddamaggena
analyzed: dve janāḥ gacchanti etena ati dvāram nagarassa antar janāḥ bahi janāḥ ca yena chidda maggena
translated: People inside the city and people outside the city go out and come in by the hole in the fence,🔽and that is what it is called.

original: nikkhamanti pavisantica, tassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Dve janā aranti gacchanti etthāti dvārantipī
analyzed: nikkhamanti pavisanti ca tassa itam nāmam dve janāḥ aranti gacchanti ettha ati dvārantipī
translated: And they also say that two kinds of people go out and come in by it, thus it is a door .

original: vadanti. Apica, duvidhaṃ dvāraṃ ākāsadvāraṃ maṇḍadvāranti. Tattha ākāsadvāraṃnāma
analyzed: vadanti apica duvidham dvāram ākāsadvāram maṇḍadvāranti tattha ākāsadvāram nāma
translated: Moreover, a door is of two kinds, that is to say, the sky door and the panel door . Herein, the sky door is

original: yathāvutto chiddamaggo. Maṇḍadvāraṃnāma ādāsa paṭṭamayo ālokamaggo. Taṃ pana puññavantānaṃ
analyzed: yathā vutto chidda maggo maṇḍadvāraṃ nāma ādāsa paṭṭa mayaḥ āloka maggo tam pana puññavantānam
translated: the hole in the fence already mentioned. The panel door is a light-making hole consisting of a piece of glass. That is fitted into the houses of the fortunate,

original: gehesu yojīyati. Yathā ca tesu, tathā sattānaṃ sarīresupi dveeva honti. Navadvāro
analyzed: gehesu yathā ca tesu tathā sattānam sarīresu pi dve eva honti nava dvārā
translated: and just as it is in them, so it is in the bodies of living beings, which have two of them. The nine orifices

original: mahāvaṇoti hi chiddadvāraṃ vuttaṃ. Navanavutilomakūpasahassā nipi chiddadvārānieva.
analyzed: mahāvaṇo ti hi chiddadvāram vuttam nava navuti lomakūpa sahassā chiddadvārāni eva
translated: are called the hole door. And the nine hundred and ninety-two families of pores are also hole doors.

original: Idha pana ādāsapaṭṭasadisaṃ maṇḍadvāraṃ adhippetaṃ. Taṃpi hi ārammaṇikadhammānaṃ
analyzed: idha pana ādāsa paṭṭa sadisam maṇḍa dvāram adhippetam tat pi hi ārammaṇika dhammānam
translated: But here the panel door that is like a piece of glass is intended. For that is the approach by way of the delimitation of the object- presenting states.

original: ārammaṇadhammānañca niggamana pavisana mukhapathabhāvato dvārasadisattā dvāranti
analyzed: ārammaṇa dhammānam ca niggamana pavisana mukha patha bhāvataḥ dvāra sadisa ttā dvāranti
translated: And because of the occurrence of the objective states by way of the door of the eye, etc., the eye, etc., are called doors because they are like doors.

original: vuccatīti. Taṃ pana rūpamaṇḍa dvāraṃ arūpamaṇḍadvāranti duvidhaṃ. Rūpamaṇḍadvāraṃpi
analyzed: vuccati iti tam pana dvāram duvidham
translated: That material form is twofold as the door of the fine-material sphere and the door of the immaterial sphere. The door of the fine-material sphere

original: kammavisesamahābhūta visesasiddhena maṇḍabhāvavisesena pañcavidhanti dassetuṃ cakkhudvārantiādimāha.
analyzed: kamma visesa mahābhūta visesa siddhena maṇḍa bhāva visesena pañcavidhanti dassetum cakkhu dvāra nti ādim āha
translated: is fivefold by way of the distinction of the spheres of the great primaries, which are accomplished by the distinction of kamma. In order to show this, the text says “eye-door,” etc.

original: Tattha cakkhumevacakkhudvāranti yasmiṃ cakkhumhi canda maṇḍalādīni rūpa nimittāni
analyzed: tattha yasmin cakkhumhi canda maṇḍala ādīni rūpa nimittāni
translated: Herein, the eye itself is the eye-door. In the eye which is the door, the signs of visible forms such as the moon’s orb, etc.,

original: paññāyanti. Āvajjanādīnica yamhi paññātāni tāni nimittāni gaṇhanti. Tasmā tadeva
analyzed: paññāyanti āvajjana ādīni ca yamhi paññātāni tāni nimittāni gaṇhanti tasmā tat eva
translated: are discerned. The adverting, etc., which are discerned, apprehend those signs. Therefore,

original: cakkhu tesaṃ dvinnaṃ visayavisa yibhāvupagamanassa mukhapathabhūtattā cakkhudvāraṃnāmāti
analyzed: cakkhu tesam dvinnam visaya visa yi bhāva upagamanassa mukha patha bhūta ttā cakkhudvāraṃnāma ati
translated: that eye itself is called the eye-door because it is the path of the approach of the two, the object and the subject.

original: attho. Athavā, yena cakkhumaṇḍena bahiddhā candamaṇḍalādīni rūpāni anto āvajjanādīnaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ athavā yena cakkhu maṇḍena bahiddhā canda maṇḍala ādīni rūpāni antaḥ āvajjana ādīnam
translated: This is the meaning. Or alternatively, by means of which eye-orb the visible forms such as the moon’s orb, etc., outside

original: visayabhāvaṃ upagacchanti. Yenaca anto āvajjanādīni bahiddhā tesaṃ rūpānaṃ visayibhāvaṃ
analyzed: visaya bhāvam upagacchanti yena ca antar āvajjana ādīni bahiddhā tesam rūpānam visayi bhāvam
translated: become the object of the adverting, etc., inside, and by means of which the adverting, etc., inside become the subject of those visible forms outside,

original: upagacchanti. Tameva yathāvutta kāraṇena cakkhudvāraṃ nāmāti attho. Evaṃ sesesupi.🔽[96] Ṭīkāsu pana
analyzed: upagacchanti tam eva yathā vutta kāraṇena cakkhudvāram nāma ati attho evam sesesu pi  ṭīkāsu pana
translated: They approach it. The meaning is that it is the door of the eye because of the aforesaid reason. So too with the rest.

original: “Āvajjanādīnaṃ arūpadhammānaṃ pavattimukhabhāvato dvārasadisattā dvārānī”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: āvajjana ādīnam arūpa dhammānam pavatti mukha bhāvataḥ dvāra sadisa ttā dvārāni iti vuttam tam na sundaram
translated: But in the commentaries it is said: “They are called doors because they are like doors in being the openings for the occurrence of the immaterial states beginning with adverting.” That is not good.

original: Rūpādīnaṃ ārammaṇānaṃpi pavattimukhabhūtattā. Vakkhati hi chabbidhā visayapavattiyoti.
analyzed: rūpa ādīnam ārammaṇānaṃ pi pavatti mukha bhūta ttā vakkhati hi chabbidhāḥ visaya pavattiyaḥ ti
translated: Because objects consisting of visible data, etc., are also openings for the occurrence of the states beginning with adverting. For it is said: “The occurrence of the six objects is sixfold.”

original: Etthaca visayānaṃ rūpādīnaṃ ārammaṇānaṃ dvāresu āpātā gamana saṅkhātā pavattiyo visayapavattiyoti🔽vuccantīti. Tattha cakkhumeva cakkhudvāranti etena cakkhussa dvāraṃ cakkhudvāranti
analyzed: ettha ca visayānam rūpa ādīnam ārammaṇānam dvāresu āpātāḥ gamana saṅkhātā pavattiyaḥ visaya pavattiyaḥ ti  vuccanti iti tattha cakkhum eva cakkhu dvāram ti etena cakkhussa dvāram cakkhu dvāram ti
translated: And here the occurrence of the objects consisting of visible data, etc., which are the objects of the states beginning with adverting, is called “the occurrence of the objects” in the doors.

original: atthaṃ nivatteti. Tathā sotādayo sota dvārādīnīti etena sota meva sotadvāraṃ.La.
analyzed: attham nivatta iti tathā sota ādayaḥ sota dvāra ādīni iti etena sota mā eva
translated: So it is said. Herein, the eye itself is the eye-door. By this he rejects the meaning “The door of the eye is the eye-door.” So too, the ear, etc., are the ear-door, and so on.

original: Manoeva manodvāraṃ. Na manānaṃ dvāraṃ manodvāranti imamatthaṃ atidissati. Tassa pana
analyzed: manaḥ eva manaḥ dvāram na manānam dvāram manaḥ dvāram ti imam attham atidissati tassa pana
translated: The mind itself is the mind-door. By this he shows that the meaning “The door of the mind is the mind-door” is not to be construed as “The door of the act of minding is the mind-door.” But

original: manassa bahuvidhattā idha adhippetaṃ manaṃ dassento manodvāraṃ pana bhavaṅganti pavuccatīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: manassa bahuvidhattā idha adhippetam manam dassentaḥ manaḥ dvāram pana bhavaṅganti pavuccati iti vuttam
translated: The mind intended here is the mind of the cognitive series, which is of many kinds. But the mind door is called the life-continuum because it is the door of the mind.

original: [97] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: In the Vibhāvinī-ṭīkā, however, it is said:

original: “Āvajjanādīnaṃ manānaṃ dvāranti manodvāra”ntipi vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: āvajjana ādīnam manānam dvāran ti manaḥ dvāran ti pi vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: “The mind door is the door of the mind’s various kinds of adverting, etc.” This is not good.

original: Kāraṇaṃ vuttameva. Tattha sabbaṃ ekūnanavutividhaṃpi cittaṃ manodvāra mevanāma hoti.
analyzed: kāraṇam vuttam eva tattha sabbam ekūna navutividham api cittam manaḥ dvāra hoti
translated: The reason has already been given. Herein, all the eighty-nine kinds of consciousness are called the mind door.

original: Idha pana upapattidvārameva adhippetanti katvā bhavaṅganti pavuccatīti vuttaṃ. Paṭisandhito🔽paṭṭhāya yāvatāyukaṃ nadisotamiva pavattamānaṃ ekūnavīsatividhaṃ bhavaṅgacittameva
analyzed: idha pana upapatti dvāram eva adhippetanti katvā bhavaṅganti pavuccati iti vuttam paṭisandhito  paṭṭhāya yāvatāyukam nadi sotam iva pavattamānam ekūnavīsatividham bhavaṅga cittam eva
translated: But because the rebirth-linking door is intended here, it is called the life-continuum.

original: idha manodvāranti vuccati, kathīyatīti attho.
analyzed: idha manodvāranti vuccati kathīyati iti attho
translated: The twenty-one kinds of life-continuum consciousness, which occur as long as life lasts, like the current of a river, are called the mind door here; the meaning is, they are spoken of as the mind door.

original: [98] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: In the Vibhāvinī-ṭīkā, however, it is said:

original: Yathā gāmassa dvāraṃnāma gāmānantarameva hoti. Evaṃ āvajjanādīnaṃ manānaṃ pavattimukhaṭṭhena
analyzed: yathā gāmassa dvāraṃ nāma gāma anantaram eva hoti evam āvajjana ādīnam manānam pavatti mukha ṭṭhena
translated: “Just as the door of a village is the place next to the village, so too, the mind door is the place next to the mind’s various kinds of adverting, etc., in the sense of being the door of their occurrence.”

original: dvāraṃnāma āvajjanānantaraṃ bhavaṅgameva siyā. Na tato purimāni bhavaṅgānīti adhippāyena
analyzed: dvāram nāma āvajjana anantaram bhavaṅgam eva siyā na tatas purimāni bhavaṅgāni iti adhippāyena
translated: The meaning intended is that the term ‘door’ applies only to the life-continuum that occurs next to adverting, not to the prior life-continua.

original: yaṃ vuttaṃ “bhavaṅganti āvajjānānantaraṃ bhavaṅga”nti. Taṃ na gahetabbaṃ.🔽Evañhi sati yesu cakkhupasādādīsu rūpādīni āpātaṃ nāgacchanti. Tānipi āvajjanādīnaṃ
analyzed: yam vuttam bhavaṅganti āvajjāna anantaram bhavaṅganti tat na gahetabbam  evam hi sati yesu cakkhu pasāda ādīsu rūpa ādīni āpātam na āgacchanti tāni api āvajjana ādīnam
translated: So the statement ‘The life-continuum is the door next to adverting’ should not be accepted.

original: vīthicittānaṃ pavattimukhāni eva na hontīti katvā dvārānināma nasiyuṃ. Na ca tathā🔽sakkā vattuṃ. Pāḷiyameva tesaṃ dvārarūpabhāvassa vuttattā. Idhaca vakkhati pasādaviññattisaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: vīthi cittānam pavatti mukhāni eva na honti iti katvā nasiyum na ca tathā  sakkā vattum pāḷiyam eva tesam dvāra rūpa bhāvassa vuttattā idha ca vakkhati pasāda viññatti saṅkhātam
translated: For if it were, then the eye, etc., in the presence of which visible data, etc., come into focus would not be doors for the occurrence of the cognitive series beginning with adverting. And it would not be tenable to say that they are doors.🔽But that cannot be said, because it is stated in the texts that they are doors. For it is said here:

original: sattavidhaṃpi dvārarūpaṃnāmāti.
analyzed: sattavidham pi
translated: ‘The seven kinds of visible-data base, etc., are called “door” ’.

original: [99] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And the statement:🔽‘Adverting is called the life-continuum,

original: Sāvajjanaṃ bhavaṅgantu, manodvāranti vuccatīti –
analyzed: sāvajjanam manodvāranti vuccati iti
translated: And the mind-door is said to be next to that’

original: Sādhakavacanaṃ āhaṭaṃ; Taṃpi idha nayujjatiyeva.
analyzed: sādhaka vacanam
translated: is a statement that is correct, and it is applicable here too.🔽For that adverting is indicated as belonging to the mind door.

original: Tañhi āvajjanaṃpi manodvārapakkhikaṃ katvā dīpetīti. Yattha pana cakkhuñca paṭicca
analyzed: tat hi āvajjanam pi manaḥ dvāra pakkhikam katvā dīpeti iti yattha pana cakkhuñca paṭicca
translated: But where the eye and visible data, etc., are present,

original: rūpeca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Sotañca. La. Manañca paṭicca dhammeca uppajjati🔽manoviññāṇanti vuttaṃ. Tattheva taṃ yuttaṃ. Tattha hi cakkhuviññāṇuppattiyā catūsu
analyzed: rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇam sotañca la manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati  manaḥ viññāṇanti vuttam tattha iva tam yuttam tattha hi cakkhu viññāṇa uppattiyā catūsu
translated: And eye-consciousness arises with visible data as its object. And ear-consciousness arises with sounds as its object. And nose-consciousness arises with odours as its object. And tongue-consciousness arises with flavours as its object. And body-consciousness arises with tangible data as its object. And mind-consciousness arises with mental data as its object.

original: paccayesu cakkhurūpāni eva sarūpato vuttānīti itare āvajjanañca sampayuttakkhandhā🔽cāti dve paccayā casaddena gahitā, evaṃ sotaviññāṇādīsupi. Manoviññāṇe pana manañcāti
analyzed: paccayesu cakkhu rūpāni eva sarūpataḥ vuttāni iti itare āvajjanam ca sampayutta kkhandhāḥ  ca ati dve paccayā ca saddena gahitā evam sota viññāṇa ādīsu pi manaḥ viññāṇe pana manaṃ ca ati
