analyzed: tad ārammaṇa vārassa ārammaṇa bhūtāḥ abhivibhūtānāma javana vārassa vibhūtānāma voṭṭhabbana vārassa
translated: Herein, the registration kind is the scope for the registration consciousness, the impulsion kind for the impulsion consciousness, the adverting kind for the adverting consciousness,

original: avibhūtānāma. Moghavārassa ārammaṇabhūtā atiavibhūtānāmāti yojetabbā.🔽Etthaca ārammaṇassavā cittassavā atibalavatāya abhivibhūtatā veditabbā. Dubbalepi
analyzed: avibhūtā nāma moghavārassa ārammaṇa bhūtā ati avibhūtā nāma ati yojetabbā  ettha ca ārammaṇa ssavā citta ssavā ati balava tāya abhivibhūta tā veditabbā dubbale pi
translated: and the receiving kind for the receiving consciousness.

original: hi citte pathavipabbatādivasena atibalavantaṃ ārammaṇaṃ ativibhūtaṃnāma hoti. Atibalavante
analyzed: hi citte pathavi pabbata ādi vasena ati balavantam ārammaṇam hoti ati balavante
translated: And here the object’s being very powerful and the consciousness’s being very weak should be understood as the reason for the registration consciousness’s being very clear, and the impulsion consciousness’s being clear, and the adverting consciousness’s being not clear, and the receiving consciousness’s being very much not clear.🔽For when the object is very powerful, as when the earth quakes, etc., then even in a weak consciousness the object is called very clear.🔽And when the consciousness is very powerful, as when the object is a mere trifle, then even in a weak object the object is called very clear.

original: ca citte atisukhumaṃpi nibbānaṃ ativibhūtaṃnāma hotīti. Evaṃ sesesupīti. Vārabhedo🔽panettha anubandhako, visuṃ siddhoti duvidho. Tattha anubandhako cakkhudvārānubandhakādivasena
analyzed: ca citte nibbānam hoti iti evam sesesu pi iti vāra bhedaḥ  pana ittha anubandhakaḥ visum siddho ti duvidho tattha anubandhako cakkhu dvāra anubandhaka ādi vasena
translated: The mode of permutation

original: pañcavidho. Ekekasmiñcettha atītagahaṇaṃ, samudāya gahaṇaṃ, vatthugahaṇaṃ, nāmagahaṇanti
analyzed: pañcavidhaḥ eka ekasmin ca itthā atīta gahaṇam samudāya gahaṇam vatthu gahaṇam nāma gahaṇanti
translated: is of two kinds here as continuous and discrete. Herein, the continuous is of five kinds as following on the eye door, and so on. And in each case there are four permutations, that is to say, taking the past, taking the aggregate, taking the physical basis, and taking the name.

original: cattāro cattāro vārā. Tesuca tadārammaṇavārādayo yathārahaṃ yojetabbā. Visuṃ siddho🔽pana diṭṭha vāro, diṭṭhasambandhavāro, sutavāro, sutasambandhavāro, viññātavāro,🔽viññātasambandhavāroti chabbidho hoti. Etthaca saddhā ruci ākāra parivitakkādi vasena
analyzed: cattāro cattāro vārā tesu ca tad ārammaṇa vāra ādayaḥ yathāraham yojetabbāḥ visum siddhaḥ  pana diṭṭha vāro diṭṭha sambandha vāro sutavāro suta sambandha vāro viññātavāro  viññāta sambandha vāro ti chabbidhaḥ hoti ettha ca saddhā ruci ākāra parivitakka ādi vasena
translated: And the permutation of the corresponding mental phenomena should be construed in each case as appropriate.🔽The discrete is of six kinds as the mode of perception, the mode of perception-relation, the mode of hearing, the mode of hearing-relation, the mode of knowing, and the mode of knowing-relation.

original: pavattavārā viññātavāro, viññāta sambandhavāroti vuttāti daṭṭhabbā. Aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ
analyzed: pavatta vārā viññātavāro viññāta sambandhavāro ti vuttā ati daṭṭhabbā aṭṭhasāliniyam
translated: And the mode of knowing and the mode of knowing-relation should be regarded as the modes of occurrence of the permutations of the faculties of faith, of inclination, of reflection on the aspect , and so on.

original: pana saddhāruciyādiva senagahitaṃ ārammaṇaṃ tathāpi hoti. Aññathāpi hoti. Tasmā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: pana saddhā ruciyāt iva sena gahitam ārammaṇam tathā api hoti aññathā api hoti tasmai aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: But in the Eight-Factored Discourse the object is said to be “as apprehended by the army of faith, inclination, and so on, and it is also otherwise. Therefore in the commentary

original: na gahitanti vuttaṃ. Tathāvā hotu aññathāvā. Vīthicittapavattiyā sati gahetabbameva.
analyzed: na gahitanti vuttam tathāvā hotu aññathāvā vīthi citta pavattiyā sati gahetabbam eva
translated: and it is not so said. Let it be so or not so. When the course of consciousness occurs, it must be apprehended.

original: Tattha ekekasmiṃvāre tadārammaṇavārādivasena cattāro cattāro vārā. Tesuca kāma mahaggatā
analyzed: tattha eka ekasmin vāre tad ārammaṇa vāra ādi vasena cattāro cattāro vārā tesu ca kāma mahaggatā
translated: Herein, in each section there are four sections, namely, the object-resultant section, etc., and in those sections the object- dhammas are classed according to the three kinds of consciousness, namely, sense-desire-sphere, fine-material-sphere, and supramundane,

original: nuttara paññatti vasena paccuppannātītānāgatakāla vimuttavasenaca ārammaṇadhammā
analyzed: nuttara paññatti vasena paccuppanna atīta anāgata kāla vimutta vasena ca ārammaṇa dhammā
translated: and according to the three times, namely, present, past, and future, and according to the three kinds of liberation, namely, with- taints, taintless, and unexcelled.

original: yathārahaṃ yojetabbāti. Etarahi pana atītabhavaṅgavasena tadārammaṇavasena ca vārabhedaṃ🔽kappenti. Tattha atītabhavaṅgavasena vārabhedakappanaṃ niratthakaṃ. Na hi manodvāre
analyzed: yathāraham etarahi pana atīta bhavaṅga vasena tad ārammaṇa vasena ca vāra bhedam  kappenti tattha atīta bhavaṅga vasena vāra bheda kappanam niratthakam na hi manaḥ dvāre
translated: So they should be construed as appropriate. But at present they are classed according to the past life-continuum and according to the object-resultant.

original: pañcadvāre viya ārammaṇānaṃ khaṇavasena balava dubbalatā sambhavo atthi. Tadā avijjamānānaṃpi🔽atītānāgatānaṃ kālavimuttānañca tattha āpātāgamanatoti. Ettha siyā, ekāvajjanavīthiyā
analyzed: pañca dvāre viya ārammaṇānam khaṇa vasena atthi tadā avijjamānānam pi  atīta anāgatānam kāla vimuttānam ca tattha āpāta āgamanato ti ettha siyā eka āvajjana vīthiyā
translated: Herein, the classing according to the past life-continuum is pointless, for in the mind door there is no such thing as a difference in the strength or weakness of objects according to the moment, as there is in the case of the five senses.🔽And because past and future dhammas and those liberated from time are not actually present, they come into focus in the mind door all at once.

original: ārammaṇaṃnāma dhammatoca kālatoca abhinna meva icchanti aṭṭhakathācariyā. Imeca sattā
analyzed: ārammaṇam nāma dhammatoca kālatoca abhinnam eva icchanti aṭṭhakathā cariyāḥ ime ca sattā
translated: Here it may be objected: “The teachers of the commentaries hold that the object of a single cognitive series is undifferentiated as to kind and time. But these seven kinds of consciousness

original: taṃ taṃ ākāraṃ sallakkhetvā aññamaññassa cittaṃ jānantiyeva. Paracittaviduniyo pana
analyzed: tam tam ākāram sallakkhetvā añña maññassa cittam jānantiyā iva para citta viduniyā pana
translated: and by observing this or that sign they know each other’s cognizance. But deities who are experts in other beings’ thoughts

original: devatā ākārasallakkhaṇena vināpi jānanti. Tattha paccuppannaṃ parassa cittaṃ jānanakāle
analyzed: devatāḥ ākāra sallakkhaṇena vinā api jānanti tattha paccuppannam parassa cittam jānana kāle
translated: know without observing a sign. Herein, when they know another’s cognizance that is present,

original: āvajjanaṃ bhāvayaṃ parassa cittaṃ attanā sahuppannaṃ. Taṃ vā āvajjati. Udāhu parato
analyzed: āvajjanam bhāvayam parassa cittam attanā sahuppannam tam vai āvajjati udāhu paratas
translated: they either develop adverting and know another’s cognizance that is present with their own, or they advert to that or

original: taṃ taṃ javanena sahuppannaṃvā. Javanānica yaṃ āvajjanena sahuppannaṃ taṃ vā jānanti,
analyzed: tam tam javanena sahuppannam vā javanāni ca yam āvajjanena sahuppannam tam vā jānanti
translated: they know that which is present with impulsion, or they know that which is present with impulsion that is present with adverting,

original: paccekaṃ attanā sahuppannaṃvāti. Kiñcettha, yadi tāva āvajjanena sahuppannaṃ āvajjati
analyzed: paccekam attanā kiñca ittha yadi tāva āvajjanena sahuppannam āvajjati
translated: or they know each separately that is present with their own. What is the point here? If firstly they advert to that which is present with adverting and know it,

original: jānantica. Evaṃ sati dhammato abhinnaṃ hoti. Kālato bhinnaṃ. Tañhi cittaṃ āvajjanassa
analyzed: jānanti ca evam sati dhammataḥ abhinnam hoti kālataḥ bhinnam tat hi cittam āvajjanassa
translated: then it is undifferentiated as to state but differentiated as to time, since that cognizance is present with the adverting,

original: paccuppannaṃ hoti. Javanānaṃ pana atītanti. Atha paccekaṃ attanā sahuppannaṃ āvajjati
analyzed: paccuppannam hoti javanānam pana atha paccekam attanā sahuppannam āvajjati
translated: but with the impulsions it is past. But if they advert to each separately that is present with their own and know it,

original: jānantica. Evañca sati kālato abhinnaṃ hoti. Dhammato bhinnameva. Athapi yaṃ paccekaṃ
analyzed: jānanti ca evam ca sati kālataḥ abhinnam hoti dhammataḥ bhinnam eva atha api yam paccekam
translated: then it is undifferentiated as to time but differentiated as to state. And again, that which is present with adverting

original: sahuppannaṃ jānanti. Tadeva āvajjati. Evaṃpi bhinnameva hotīti. Ettha aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: sahuppannam jānanti tat eva āvajjati bhinnam eva hoti iti ettha aṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: and they know what is present with it. It is that same consciousness that adverts. So it is still the same. Herein, in the commentary it is said:

original: tāva yaṃ āvajjanena sahuppannaṃ. Tadeva āvajjati jānanticāti dhammato abhinnaṃ vatvā
analyzed: tāva yam āvajjanena sahuppannam tat eva āvajjati jānanti ca ati dhammataḥ abhinnam vatvā
translated: “What is present with the adverting is that same consciousness that adverts and knows.” So it is not different as regards state.

original: taṃ cittaṃ niruddhaṃpi addhāvasena santativasenaca gahitaṃ javanānaṃpi paccuppannameva🔽hotīti vinicchitaṃ. Ācariyānandamatena pana parassa taṃ taṃ ākāraṃ sallakkhetvā taṃ
analyzed: tam cittam niruddham api addhā vasena santati vasena ca gahitam paccuppannam eva  hoti iti vinicchitam ācariya ānanda matena pana parassa tam tam ākāram sallakkhetvā tam
translated: But it is decided that the consciousness that has ceased is still present as a continuity and as a series, and it is still present as the impulsions.

original: taṃ adhippāyajānanakāle āvajjanajavanāni paccekaṃ attanā sahuppannaṃ cittaṃ āvajjati
analyzed: tam adhippāya jānana kāle āvajjana javanāni paccekam attanā sahuppannam cittam āvajjati
translated: But according to the teacher Ānandamat, when one is discerning another’s state thus and thus and knowing his intention thus and thus, the adverting and the impulsion advert to and know the consciousness that is present with themselves respectively.

original: jānanti ca. Na cettha dhammato kālatoca bhinnaṃnāma hoti. Sabbesaṃpi hi ārammaṇaṃ🔽cittameva hoti paccuppannañcāti. Naca javanāni nirāvajjanānināma honti. Āvajjanenapi
analyzed: jānanti ca na ca ittha dhammataḥ kālataḥ ca bhinnam nāma hoti sabbesam pi hi ārammaṇam  cittam eva hoti paccuppannam ca ati na ca javanāni honti āvajjanena pi
translated: And here there is no difference as regards state or time, for the object of all is consciousness only, and that is present.🔽And the impulsions are not without adverting, for it is consciousness itself that is adverted to by the adverting,

original: hi cittanteva āvajjitaṃ hoti. Javanānica cittanteva jānantīti. Yadi pana āvajjane
analyzed: hi cittantā iva āvajjitam hoti javanāni ca cittantā iva jānanti iti yadi pana āvajjane
translated: and it is consciousness itself that knows by the impulsions. But if it were said that the adverting and the impulsion are different,

original: na cittanti āvajjite javanāni rūpanti jānanti. Rūpantivā āvajjite cittanti jānanti,🔽nīlantivā āvajjite pītanti jānanti. Evaṃ sati javanāni dhammato nirāvajjanāni nāma
analyzed: na cittanti āvajjite javanāni rūpanti jānanti āvajjite cittanti jānanti  āvajjite pītanti jānanti evam sati javanāni dhammataḥ nirāvajjanāni nāma
translated: But when he adverts to mind, the impulsions do not know materiality. And when he adverts to materiality, they do not know mind.🔽And when he adverts to blue, they do not know yellow. So the impulsions are called “without adverting” as to object.

original: honti. Tathā atītanti āvajjite paccuppannanti. Evañca sati tāni kālato nirāvajjanānināma🔽hontīti. Yasmā ca atīto dhammo paccuppannassa dhammassa anantarapaccayena paccayoti
analyzed: honti tathā āvajjite paccuppannanti evam ca sati tāni kālataḥ  honti iti yasmā ca atītaḥ dhammo paccuppannassa dhammassa anantara paccayena paccayo ti
translated: And likewise they are called “without adverting” as to time when he adverts to the past and they are present.🔽And since in the Dependent Origination the past state is stated as a condition for a present state by means of the condition being that of immediate-proximity,

original: paṭṭhāne vutto. Tasmā idha khaṇavaseneva paccuppannaṃ vattuṃ yuttaṃ. Na addhāsantati
analyzed: paṭṭhāne vuttaḥ tasmai idha khaṇa vasena iva paccuppannam vattum yuttam na addhā santati
translated: it is proper to speak here of the present only in the sense of moment, not in the sense of period of existence or continuity.

original: vasenāti. Itarathā sabba vīthicittavāresupi ārammaṇānaṃ atītādibhāvo addhāsantativaseneva
analyzed: vasena āti itarathā ārammaṇānam atīta ādi bhāvaḥ addhā santati vasena iva
translated: Otherwise, in all the cases of consciousness in a cognitive series, the past, etc., state of the object would have to be stated only in the sense of period of existence or continuity.🔽In the verse there are only three: only three are mentioned by function.

original: vattabbo siyāti. Gāthāyaṃ tīṇevāti kiccavasena tīṇi eva. Cittuppādā daseritāti cittuppattikkhaṇavasena
analyzed: vattabbaḥ siyā iti gāthāyam tīṇi eva ati kicca vasena tīṇi eva cittuppādāḥ dasa īritā ti cittuppatti kkhaṇa vasena
translated: The consciousnesses are ten:

original: dasa īritāni kathitāni. Vitthā renāti cittasarūpavitthārena. Etthāti manodvāre. Ekacattālīsāti
analyzed: dasa īritāni kathitāni vitthā rena ati citta sarūpa vitthārena ettha iti manaḥ dvāre ekacattālīsā ati
translated: Ten are mentioned, ten are spoken of. With the extension of consciousness and form: with the extension of consciousness and form. Here: in the mind door. Forty-one:

original: pañcaviññāṇamanodhātūhi vajjitānaṃ kāmāvacaracittānaṃ vasena ekacattālīsaṃ. Etthāti
analyzed: pañca viññāṇa manaḥ dhātūhi vajjitānam kāmāvacara cittānam vasena ekacattālīsam ettha ati
translated: forty-one by way of the sense-sphere consciousnesses excluding the five consciousnesses and the mind element. Here:

original: parittajavanavāre. [Parittavāro]🔽138. Vibhūtāvibhūtabhedo natthi ekaṃ vibhūtameva labbhatīti adhippāyo. Na hi avibhūte🔽ārammaṇe appanānāma sambhavatīti. Tathā tadārammaṇuppādoca natthi. Na hi atisantataraṃ
analyzed: paritta javana vāre  vibhūta avibhūta bhedaḥ na atthi ekam vibhūtam eva labbhati iti adhippāyaḥ na hi avibhūte  ārammaṇe appanā nāma sambhavati iti tathā tad ārammaṇa uppādo ca natthi na hi atisantataram
translated: in the limited occurrence. [Limited occurrence]🔽The intention is that there is no distinction of extension and non-extension, only extension is possible. For when the object is not extended🔽there is no possibility of absorption. And so there is no arising of that object. For the absorption consciousness

original: appanājavanaṃ tadārammaṇaṃ anubandhatīti. Tattha hi chabbīsati mahaggata lokuttara
analyzed: appanā javanam tad ārammaṇam anubandhati iti tattha hi chabbīsati mahaggata lokuttara
translated: does not follow the object in a more continuous series. Here, in the twenty-six kinds of exalted and supramundane javanas,

original: javanesu yaṃkiñci javanaṃ appanāvīthimotaratīti sambandho. Ñāṇarahitaṃ dvihetukajavanaṃ
analyzed: javanesu yaṃ kiñci javanam appanā vīthim otarati iti sambandhaḥ ñāṇa rahitam dvi hetuka javanam
translated: any javana enters the path of absorption. The sense-sphere javana associated with knowledge, which is eightfold,

original: athirasabhāvattā appanāya anantarūpanissayo nahotīti vuttaṃ ñāṇasampayutta kāmāvacarajavanānamaṭṭhannanti.
analyzed: athi rasa bhāva ttā appanāya ananta rūpa nissayaḥ nahoti iti vuttam ñāṇa sampayutta kāmāvacara javanānam aṭṭhannam ti
translated: is not a proximate condition for absorption because it is not firm by nature. Thus it is said.

original: Parikammopacārānulomagotratunāmenāti ettha indriyasamatādīhi paritobhāgehi appanā
analyzed: ettha indriya samatā ādīhi paritobhāgehi appanā
translated: The “preliminary-work, access, conformity, and lineage” are so called because absorption is made, is prepared, by means of the preliminary work, etc., respectively.

original: karīyati sajjīyati etenāti parikammaṃ. Appanaṃ upecca caratīti upacāro. Samīpacāroti🔽attho. Samīpacaraṇañcettha āsannekāle appanāvahasamatthabhāvena daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yassa🔽pavattiyā aciraṃ kālaṃ appanā sambhavo hotīti. Anulomanti appanāpavattiyā paccanīkadhammavidhamanena
analyzed: karīyati sajjīyati etena ati parikammam appanam upecca carati iti upacāro samīpacāro ti  atthaḥ samīpa caraṇam ca ittha āsanne kāle appanā vaha samattha bhāvena daṭṭhabbam yassa  pavattiyāḥ aciram kālam appanā sambhavaḥ hoti iti anulomanti appanā pavattiyā paccanīka dhamma vidhamanena
translated: Absorption is made by means of the preliminary work. It is prepared by means of access. It is conformity because it occurs in conformity with absorption.🔽The meaning is that it occurs in proximity to absorption. And here the conformity should be regarded as the ability to produce absorption in the next moment.🔽For it is said that absorption is possible soon after its occurrence.

original: appanāya anukūlaṃ appanāhitaṃ appanā vahanticceva attho, yassa pavattiyā appanā vibandhako🔽paccanī konāma natthīti. Gamīyati bujjhīyati attho etenātivo. Abhidhānaṃ buddhica.
analyzed: appanāya anukūlam appanā āhitam appanā vahanti icca iva atthaḥ yassa pavattiyā appanā vibandhakaḥ  paccanī ko nāma natthi iti gamīyati bujjhīyati atthaḥ abhidhānam buddhi ca
translated: It is called “conformity” because it is favourable to absorption by the removal of states that are adverse to the occurrence of absorption. The meaning is that it is directed towards absorption, that it is conducive to absorption.

original: Taṃ duvidhaṃpi gavaṃ tāyati rakkhatīti gottaṃ. Paritta jātisaṅkhāto anvayo. Gottaṃ
analyzed: tam duvidham pi gavam tāyati rakkhati iti gottam paritta jāti saṅkhātaḥ anvayaḥ gottam
translated: It is called “lineage” because it is the protection, the preservation, of the twofold knowledge.

original: abhibhuyyati chijjati etthāti gotrabhu. Ettha ca cattāripi javanāni parikammajavanānīti
analyzed: abhibhuyyati chijjati ettha ati gotrabhu ettha ca cattāri pi javanāni parikamma javanāni iti
translated: The meaning is that it is the preservation of the lineage. And here the four impulsions are called “impulsions of preliminary-work.”

original: vā upacārajavanānitivā anulomajavanānītivā vuccantiyeva. Gotrabhūti pana pacchimasseva🔽nāmaṃ. Idha pana catunnaṃpi nāmānaṃ saṅgahaṇatthaṃ parikammo pacārānuloma gotrabhunāmenāti
analyzed: vā anuloma javanāni iti vā pana  nāmam idha pana catunnam pi nāmānam saṅgahaṇa attham
translated: or access, or quickening, or conformity, or change-of-lineage.🔽But the last of these is the name for the last only.🔽But here the preliminary work is called access, conformity, and change-of-lineage, in order to include all four names.

original: evaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evañca katvā kasmā pathamameva parikammaṃnāma. Nanu itarānipi🔽appanaṃ parisaṅkharontiyevāti evamādikā codanā anokāsā hotīti. Catukkhattuṃ tikkhattumevavāti🔽catukkhattumevavā tikkhattumevavā. Tattha pathamena eva saddena pañcamaṃ gotrabhusambhavo🔽paṭikkhitto hoti. Tadā hi javanaṃ patitaṃnāma hoti. Pavedhati kampati. Kāmagottaṃ
analyzed: evam vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam evam ca katvā kasmā pathamam eva nanu itarāni pi  appanam eva ati evamādikā codanā anokāsā hoti iti catu khattum ti khattum eva vā ati  catukkhattum eva vā tikkhattum eva vā tattha pathamena eva saddena pañcamam  paṭikkhittaḥ hoti tadā hi javanam patitaṃnāma hoti pavedhati kampati kāma gottam
translated: or access, or speed, or conformity, or impulsion, are so called. But the name “pre-nascence condition” is only that of the last of these. But here it is said thus in order to include all four names. And when it is so taken, the question, “Why is the first called pre-nascence? Are not the others also pre-nascent to the fruition? ” and so on, does not arise. Four times or three times:

original: abhikkamitvā uparibhūmantarappattiyā paccayo bhavituṃ na sakkotīti. Dutīyena dutīyaṃ
analyzed: abhikkamitvā upari bhūma antara ppattiyā paccayaḥ bhavitum na sakkoti iti dutīyena dutīyam
translated: only four times or only three times. Herein, the possibility of the fifth, namely, pre-nascence of the path in the fruition of stream-entry, is rejected by the first repetition. For then the impulsion has fallen, it is said. It is shaken. It is unable to be a condition for the attainment of a higher stage by passing beyond the plane of sensual desires. By the second the possibility of the second, namely, pre-nascence of the path in the fruition of once-return, is rejected.

original: gotrabhu sambhavo paṭikkhitto hoti. Tadā hi aladdhāsevanaṃ anulomaṃ attano anantare
analyzed: gotrabhu sambhavaḥ paṭikkhittaḥ hoti tadā hi a laddha āsevanam anulomam attanaḥ anantare
translated: the origination of the clan is prohibited. For then the conformity is not the cultivation of what has not been obtained, but of what has been obtained.

original: cittaṃ gotrabhubhāvaṃ pāpetuṃ na sakkotīti. Eteneva pañcamato paraṃ catutthatoca
analyzed: cittam gotrabhu bhāvam pāpetum na sakkoti iti etena iva pañcamatas param
translated: The state of being the root of the generation of the next consciousness is prohibited. For then it is not able to bring about the state of being the root of the generation of the next consciousness in the next consciousness, which is in conformity with it, because it has not yet obtained repetition.

original: oraṃ appanāya asambhavo sādhito hotīti. Vāsaddena pana mandapaññassa catukkhattumeva.
analyzed: oram appanāya asambhavaḥ sādhitaḥ hoti iti vā saddena pana manda paññassa catu khattum eva
translated: And by this it is also established that absorption is impossible after the fifth and before the fourth.🔽But by the amount of time it is five times for one of slow understanding, not four times for one of quick understanding.

original: Na tikkhattuṃ. Tikkhapaññassa tikkhattumeva. Na catukkhattunti dassitaṃ hoti. Aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ🔽pana mandamajjhima mahāpaññavasena tidhā bhinditvā pañcakkhattuṃpi parikammajavanānaṃ🔽uppatti anuññātā viya dissati. Itaraṭṭhakathāsu pana suṭṭhu vicāretvā paṭisiddhattā
analyzed: na tikkhattum tikkhapaññassa tikkhattum eva na catukkhattum ti dassitam hoti aṭṭhasāliniyam  pana manda majjhima mahā pañña vasena tidhā bhinditvā pañca khattuṃpi  uppatti anuññātā viya dissati itara ṭṭhakathāsu pana suṭṭhu vicāretvā paṭisiddha ttā
translated: It is shown that it is three times for one of quick understanding, not five times.🔽But in the Eight-Factored Discourse it seems as if the occurrence of the preliminary-work and the access is allowed up to five times, for it is divided into three kinds according to slow, medium, and quick understanding.

original: sā na gahetabbāvāti.
analyzed: sā na gahetabbā avāti
translated: But since it is refuted in the other commentaries after being thoroughly examined, it should not be accepted.

original: Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yam pana
translated: But what is said in the Vibhāvinī-Țīkā:

original: “Chaṭṭhaṃ sattamaṃ bhavaṅgassa āsannabhāvena papātāsannapuriso viya appanāvasena patiṭṭhātuṃ na sakkotī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: chaṭṭham sattamam bhavaṅgassa āsanna bhāvena papāta āsanna purisaḥ viya appanā vasena patiṭṭhātum na sakkoti iti vuttam
translated: “The sixth and the seventh do not succeed in steadying themselves by absorption, as if they were men standing too near a precipice, because they are too near the life-continuum” ,

original: Tattha bhavaṅgassa āsannabhāvenāti bhavaṅgabhāvassa āsanna bhāvenāti attho. Pañcamajavanato
analyzed: tattha bhavaṅgassa āsanna bhāvena ati bhavaṅga bhāvassa āsanna bhāvena ati attho pañcama javanato
translated: Herein, by the proximity of the life-continuum: the meaning is, by the proximity of the state of the life-continuum.

original: hi paṭṭhāya javanasantānaṃ anupubbena parikkhīṇajavaṃ hoti. Bhavaṅgabhāvatthāya pariṇamatīti.
analyzed: hi paṭṭhāya javana santānam anupubbena parikkhīṇa javam hoti bhavaṅga bhāva tthāya pariṇamati iti
translated: For from the fifth impulsions onwards the continuity of impulsions is gradually exhausted and it turns to the state of the life-continuum.

original: Evañca katvā papātāsannapurisopamāpi upapannā hotīti. Niruddhānantaramevāti niruddhe
analyzed: evam ca katvā papāta āsannapurisa upamā api upapannā hoti iti niruddha anantaram eva ati niruddhe
translated: And when it is put like this, the simile of the man on the precipice is appropriate.🔽Immediately next to the ceased: the compound is resolved into “immediately next to the ceased”;

original: anantaramevāti padacchedo. Kassa anantaranti, aññassa asutattā niruddhassāti atthato🔽laddhamevāti. Yasmā pana appanānāma uppajjamānā catutthatovā pañcamatovā paṭṭhāya
analyzed: anantaram eva ati padacchedaḥ kassa anantaram ti aññassa a suta ttā niruddhassa ati atthataḥ  laddham eva ati yasmā pana appanā nāma uppajjamānā catutthataḥ vā pañcamataḥ vā paṭṭhāya
translated: and since there is no other, the meaning is “next to the ceased.”🔽But since the fourth or the fifth arises when the others arise,🔽it arises from the fourth or the fifth.

original: uppajjati. Na chaṭṭhatovā sattamatovā. Sāhi vasībhūtāpi catuttha pañcamesu uppattiṃ
analyzed: uppajjati na chaṭṭhataḥ vā sattamataḥ vā sā hi vasībhūtā api catuttha pañcamesu uppattim
translated: And since it has been mastered, it does not arise at all if it fails to get an opportunity to arise in the fourth or the fifth.

original: alabhamānā sabbaso nuppajjatiyeva. Labhamānā pana divasaṃpi nirantaraṃ pavattatiyeva.
analyzed: a labhamānā sabbasas nuppajjatiyā iva labhamānā pana divasam pi nirantaram pavattatiyā iva
translated: But if it does get an opportunity, it occurs uninterruptedly even for a whole day.

original: Tasmā catutthaṃvā pañcamaṃvāti idaṃ ādimattaniyamanatthaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Teneva
analyzed: tasmā catuttham vā pañcamam vā iti idam ādimatta niyamana attham vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam tena iva
translated: So it should be regarded as said in order to show the beginning of the uninterrupted occurrence in the fourth or the fifth.

original: hi appanāvīthimotaratīti ca tatoparaṃ appanāvasāne bhavaṅgapātova hotīti ca vakkhatīti.
analyzed: hi appanā vīthim otarati iti ca tatas uparam appanā avasāne bhavaṅga pāto va hoti iti ca vakkhati iti

original: Yadi pana pañcamato paṭṭhāya javanaṃ patitaṃ nāma hoti. Evaṃ sati kasmā tato paṭṭhāya🔽patanakhette appanājavanaṃ pavattatīti. Vuccate, hatthe thapitaleḍḍussa patanakhettaṃnāma

translated: “the impulsion of absorption occurs in the field of fall after that”?🔽The field of fall of a stone thrown from the hand is the place where it comes to rest.

original: hatthato muttamatte hoti. Evaṃ santepi hatthabalena khipitaṃ leḍḍu dūraṃpi gacchatiyeva.🔽Ettha ca leḍḍussa javonāma hatthajavamūlako hoti. Hatthajavoca sarīrabalamūlako.
analyzed: hatthataḥ mutta matte hoti evam sante pi hattha balena khipitam dūram pi  ettha ca leḍḍussa javaḥ nāma hattha java mūlakaḥ hoti sarīra bala mūlakaḥ
translated: Even though that is so, a stone thrown by the force of the hand goes a long way.🔽And here the impulsion of the stone is rooted in the impulsion of the hand, and the impulsion of the hand is rooted in the strength of the body.

original: Tattha leḍḍu viya appanājavanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Leḍḍussa patanakhettaṃ viya catutthato🔽pacchākālo. Hatthajavoviya gotrabhujavo. Sarīrabalaṃ viya purimānaṃ parikammajavanānaṃ
analyzed: tattha leḍḍu viya appanā javanam daṭṭhabbam leḍḍussa patana khettam viya catutthato  pacchā kālaḥ hattha javaḥ viya gotrabhu javaḥ sarīra balam viya purimānam
translated: Herein, the impulsion of absorption should be regarded as the stone; the time after the fourth impulsion should be regarded as the field of fall of the stone; the impulsion of the first stage of change of state should be regarded as the impulsion of the hand; the strength of the earlier preparatory impulsion should be regarded as the strength of the body.

translated: The power of the first is like the power of a strong man, and the power of the second is like the power of a weak man.

original: Yathā ca bāladārakena khittaṃ leḍḍu hatthato muttamattepi patati. Evaṃ ādikammikavīthiyaṃ🔽appanājavanaṃ ekavāraṃ javitvā patati. Yathāvuddhipattena khittaṃ leḍḍu patanakhettepi🔽apatitvā dūraṃpi dūrataraṃpi gacchati. Tathā samāpattivīthiyaṃ appanājavanaṃ ciraṃpi
analyzed: yathā ca bāla dārakena khittam leḍḍu hatthataḥ mutta matte pi patati evam ādikammika vīthiyam  eka vāram patati yathā vuddhi pattena khittam leḍḍu patana khette pi  a patitvā dūram pi dūrataram pi gacchati tathā samāpatti vīthiyam appanā javanam ciram pi
translated: And just as a stone thrown by a child falls as soon as it leaves the hand, so the impulsion of absorption in the first cognitive series falls as soon as it has impulsion.

original: cirataraṃpi pavattatīti. Mūlaṭīkāyaṃ pana appanājavanaṃ patanakhette pavattaṃpi bhūmantarapattiyāvā
analyzed: cirataram pi pavattati iti mūlaṭīkāyam pana appanā javanam patana khette pavattam pi
translated: But just as a stone thrown by a man who has attained proficiency in the art of throwing falls not on the spot where it is released but after having gone a long way or a very long way, so the impulsion of absorption in the second cognitive series continues for a long time or a very long time in the cognitive series.🔽But in the Root Commentary it is said: “The impulsion of absorption falls not even on the spot where it occurs in the cognitive series, but only on the attainment of a different plane or on the acquisition of a different object.”

original: ārammaṇantaraladdhiyāvā patitaṃnāma nahotīti vuttaṃ. Ettha siyā, kasmā pañcamato
analyzed: ārammaṇa antara laddhi yāvā patitaṃnāma na hoti iti vuttam ettha siyā kasmā pañcamato
translated: Here it may be asked: Why is it said that the impulsion falls from the fifth?

original: paṭṭhāya javanaṃ patitanti vuttaṃ. Nanu apati tattā eva suṭṭhu balavabhāvato sattamajavanacetanā
analyzed: paṭṭhāya javanam patitanti vuttam nanu a pati tad tā eva suṭṭhu balava bhāvato sattama javana cetanā
translated: Surely, since the seventh impulsion of consciousness is the strongest, it is the one that should not fall.

original: sīghaṃ anantare bhave vipākadāyinīca ānantariyakammañca hoti. Majjhe pañcacetanā🔽tathā balavabhāvābhāvato cirena tatīyabhavādīsu vipākadāyinīca honti, anantariyabhāvañca
analyzed: sīgham anantare bhave vipāka dāyinī ca ānantariya kammañca hoti majjhe pañca cetanā  tathā balava bhāva abhāvataḥ cirena tatīya bhava ādīsu vipāka dāyinī ca honti
translated: and it is also a kamma that is next to ripening. The five cetanās in the middle

original: na gacchantīti. Nakho panetaṃ evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yadi hi sīghaṃ vipākadānatāya balavatīnāma🔽siyā. Evaṃsati paṭhamacetanā sabbabalavatīnāma siyā. Sā hi imasmiṃyeva bhave vipākaṃ🔽detīti. Idaṃ panettha sanniṭṭhānaṃ. Eka vassajīvīnaṃ tiṇarukkhānaṃ pariṇāmoviya pathamacetanāya

translated: are not next to ripening because they are not strong in the way that the first and last are. But this is how it should be seen: If it were because of the quickness of ripening that they are strong,

original: pariṇāmo daṭṭhabbo. Dvivassajīvīnaṃ viya sattamacetanāya. Mahāsālānaṃ viya majjhimacetanānanti.
analyzed: pariṇāmaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ dvi vassa jīvīnam viya sattama cetanāya mahā sālānam viya
translated: then the first cetanā would be the strongest of all, for it gives its result in this very existence. This is the decision here. The ripening of the first cetanā should be seen to be like the ripening of the grasses and trees that live for one year; that of the seventh like that of those that live for two years; and that of the middle cetanās like that of the great sala trees.

original: Tattha ekavassajīvino tiṇarukkhānāma asārā honti. Asārattāca dubbalā anaddhaniyā
analyzed: tattha eka vassa jīvinaḥ tiṇa rukkhā nāma asārāḥ honti asārattāḥ ca dubbalāḥ an addha niyā
translated: Herein, those that live for one year are sapless; and because they are sapless they are weak, not capable of growth,

original: aciraṭṭhikā. Tasmā tesaṃ sīghatarapariṇāmo hoti. Te hi sīghataraṃ ruhanti. Vuddhiṃ🔽viruḷhiṃ āpajjanti. Sīghataraṃ pupphanti phalanti patanti antaradhāyanti. Ekaṃ nidāghasamayaṃ🔽atikkamituṃ nasakkonti. Dutīyaṃ vassaṃ na pāpuṇanti. Etthaca nidāghasamayo viya maraṇakālo🔽veditabbo. Dvivassajīvino pana thokaṃ sārabhūtā honti. Sārabhūtattāca thokaṃ balavantā🔽addhaniyā. Tato yevacatesaṃ cirapariṇāmo hoti. Te hi pathamaṃ vassaṃ ruhanti vuddhiṃ🔽viruḷhiṃ āpajjanti. Pupphituṃvā phalituṃvā nasakkonti. Dutīyavasseeva pupphanti phalanti
analyzed: tasmā tesam sīghatara pariṇāmaḥ hoti te hi sīghataram ruhanti vuddhim  viruḷhim āpajjanti sīghataram pupphanti phalanti patanti antaradhāyanti ekam nidāgha samayam  atikkamitum na sakkonti dutīyam vassam na pāpuṇanti ettha ca nidāgha samayaḥ viya maraṇa kālaḥ  veditabbaḥ dvi vassa jīvinaḥ pana thokam sāra bhūtāḥ honti sāra bhūta ttā ca thokam balavantā  cira pariṇāmaḥ hoti te hi pathamam vassam ruhanti vuddhim  viruḷhim āpajjanti pupphitum vā phalitum vā na sakkonti dutīya vasse eva pupphanti phalanti
translated: therefore their ripening is quicker. For they grow quickly, and they reach growth and increase. They flower and fruit and fall and disappear quickly. They cannot get through one hot season. They do not reach a second year. And here the hot season should be understood as the time of death. But those that live for two days are a little more substantial. And because they are more substantial, they are a little stronger, and they are not so easily destroyed. Therefore their ripening is slower. For they grow in the first year, and they reach growth and increase. But they cannot flower or fruit. They flower and fruit in the second year.

original: patanti antaradhāyanti. Dutīyaṃ pana nidāgha samayaṃ atikkamituṃ na sakkonti. Tatīyaṃ🔽vassaṃ na pāpuṇanti. Mahāsālā pana sabbasārabhūtā honti. Balavantā cirataraṭṭhāyino.
analyzed: patanti antaradhāyanti dutīyam pana nidāgha samayam atikkamitum na sakkonti tatīyam 🔽vassam na pāpuṇanti mahā sālāḥ pana sabba sāra bhūtāḥ honti balavantā ciratara ṭṭhāyino
translated: therefore their change is quicker. For they grow quickly, and they reach growth and increase. They flower and fruit and fall and disappear quickly. They cannot get through one hot season. They do not reach a second year. And here the hot season should be understood as the time of death. But those living two days are a little more mature. But they cannot get through a second hot season. They do not reach a third year. But the long-lived ones are quite mature. They are strong and they last longer.

analyzed: tasmāt te saṇikam eva pariṇāmam gacchanti te hi dve vassāni
translated: So they last only a short time. They are no bigger than a rat’s testicles for one or two years.

translated: They do not grow or increase. They cannot flower or fruit. They last a very long time,

analyzed: atikkamitum na sakkoti imasmin bhave eva a vipaccitvā vā a vipaccitvā vā khiyyati sattama  javana cetanā pana laddha āsevana tāya thokam sāra bhūtā hoti visum ekam bhavam nibbattetum  sakkoti sāra bhūta ttā saṇikam eva pariṇāmam gacchati imasmin bhave
translated: lasting for five or six hundred years before they fall. So too, the first impulsion-consciousness is weak and unsubstantial because it has not obtained repetition. It can produce a single existence by itself. And because it is more substantial, it lasts only a short time. It cannot ripen in this existence. It ripens after the next existence has been reached.

analyzed: na sakkoti bhavantaram patvā ava vipaccati patita javanesu pana
translated: But the last impulsion-consciousness among the impulsion-consciousnesses that have reached impulsion is

analyzed: dubbala ttā dutīyam maraṇa kālam atikkamitum na sakkoti dutīya bhave eva
