original: āpajjanti. Sīghataraṃ jiṇṇā honti maranti. Dīghāyukajātikānaṃ pana gabbhavāsādīni
analyzed: āpajjanti sīghataram jiṇṇāḥ honti maranti dīgha āyuka jātikānam pana gabbha vāsa ādīni
translated: live in the womb a short time and are quickly born, and their limbs are quickly developed, and their faculties are quickly matured, and on the very day of their birth they get up and walk about, and they take an interest in their several objects quickly, and they quickly become old and die. But those that are long-lived by nature live a long time in the womb and are slowly born, and their limbs are slowly developed, and their faculties are slowly matured, and they get up and walk about after many days, and they take an interest in their several objects slowly, and they become old and die slowly.

original: sabbāni saṇika meva sijjhantīti. Etthaca mahaggata kusalāni sattama javanaṭṭhāne🔽ṭhitānīti veditabbāni. Parikammajavanāni hi ciraṭṭhitikaṭṭhena supakka sālidhaññasadisāni.
analyzed: sabbāni saṇika meva sijjhanti iti ettha ca mahaggata kusalāni sattama javanaṭṭhāne  ṭhitāni iti veditabbāni parikamma javanāni hi ciraṭṭhitika ṭṭhena su pakka sāli dhañña sadisāni
translated: And here the profitable of the fine-material sphere should be understood as being established in the seventh impulsion.🔽For the impulsions of the preliminary-work stage are like well-cooked rice of a kind that takes a long time to digest.🔽And the impulsions of absorption are like the same kind of rice when it is well cooked and eaten as a main meal, which is digested more quickly.

original: Appanājavanāni aciraṭṭhitikaṭṭhena supakka sālibhattasadisānīti tānipi acirataraṭṭhitikānieva
analyzed: appanā javanāni acira ṭṭhitika ṭṭhena supakka sālibhatta sadisāni iti tāni pi aciratara ṭṭhitikāni eva
translated: But they are still digested more slowly than the other kind.

original: honti. Dutīye bhave vipaccitvāvā avipaccitvāvā khiyyanti. Imasmiṃ bhavepi appakena
analyzed: honti dutīye bhave a vipaccitvā vā khiyyanti imasmin bhave pi appakena
translated: And they are exhausted either in the second existence or without being exhausted.

original: kāmacchandādinā paccanīkadhammena paṭibāhitāni sabbaso avipākabhāvaṃ āpajjanti. Tasmātāni
analyzed: kāmacchanda ādinā paccanīka dhammena paṭibāhitāni sabbasas avipāka bhāvam āpajjanti tasmā tāni
translated: And in this existence they are hindered by the opposing states of lust for sense desires, etc., and so they come to have no ripening at all.

original: tena pariyāyena dubbalāni nāma hontīti.
analyzed: tena pariyāyena dubbalāni nāma honti iti
translated: So they are called “weak” in that sense.

original: Yasmā ca ānantariyakammānaṃ phaladānaniyatatānāma kālaniyamena vinā na sambhavati.
analyzed: ca ānantariya kammānam kāla niyamena vinā na sambhavati
translated: And because the giving of ripening by kamma that is certain to give ripening is not possible without a determination of time,

original: Kālaniyamocanāma ekantena sattamajavanasseva hoti. Na majjhimajavanānaṃ. Tesañhi
analyzed: ekantena sattama javanassa iva hoti na majjhima javanānam tesam hi
translated: and because the determination of time is only in the seventh impulsion and not in the middle impulsions,

original: asukasmiṃ bhaveeva vipaccantīti evaṃ niyamo natthīti. Tasmā duvidhassa niyamassa
analyzed: asukasmim bhave eva vipaccanti iti evam niyamaḥ natthi iti tasmā duvidhassa niyamassa
translated: There is no such restriction. Therefore, since both kinds of restriction are established,

original: siddhattā eva sattamajavanacetanāya anantariyakammatā siddhā hoti. Na balavataratāyāti
analyzed: siddha ttā eva sattama javana cetanāya anantariya kamma tā siddhā hoti na balavatara tāya ati
translated: the seventh impulsion-consciousness is established as the proximate cause. It is not the strongest.🔽This is the conclusion to be drawn here.

original: niṭṭhametthagantabbanti. Mūlaṭīkāyaṃ pana nanuca sattamajavanacetanāya balavatāya
analyzed: niṭṭham ettha gantabbanti mūla ṭīkā ayam pana nanu ca sattama javana cetanāya balavatāya
translated: But in the commentary on the sub-commentary, after raising the question, “But since the seventh impulsion-consciousness is the strongest,

original: upapajjavedanīyabhāvo hoti ānantariyatāpīti codanaṃ samuṭṭhāpetvā tatthāyaṃ adhippāyo
analyzed: upapajja vedanīya bhāvaḥ hoti ānantariya tā api iti codanam samuṭṭhāpetvā tattha ayam adhippāyaḥ
translated: would not the kamma be of the kind that ripens in the next existence?” the following opinion is stated:🔽“The intention here is this:

original: siyā. Paṭisandhiyā anantarapaccayabhāvino vipākasantānassa anantarapaccayabhāvena
analyzed: siyā paṭisandhiyā anantara paccaya bhāvinaḥ vipāka santānassa anantara paccaya bhāvena
translated: The continuity of the result that is the next-after condition for rebirth-linking is the next-after condition for the last impulsion-consciousness.

original: antimajavanacetanāya susaṅkhatattāsā sattamajaganacetanā upapajjavedanīyā ānantariyakāca
analyzed: antima javana cetanāya sattama jagana cetanā upapajja vedanīyā ānantariyakā ca
translated: So the seventh impulsion-consciousness is both of the kind that ripens in the next existence and the proximate cause, because it is well-defined.🔽It is not the strongest, like the impulsion-consciousness of one who has just fallen from the imperturbable state” .

original: hoti. Na apatitajavanacetanā viya balavatāyāti uttaraṃ vadati. Taṃ yuttaṃ viya na
analyzed: na a patita javana cetanā viya balavatā āyāti uttaram vadati tam yuttam viya na
translated: That answer does not seem appropriate. For if that were so,

original: dissati. Evañhi sati pathamajavanacetanā kassa anantarapaccayabhāvena susaṅkhatattā
analyzed: dissati evam hi sati pathama javana cetanā kassa anantara paccaya bhāvena su saṅkhata ttā
translated: then the first impulsion-consciousness would be well-defined because it is the next-after condition for what?

original: diṭṭhadhammavedanīyānāma jātāti vattabbā hotīti. Mahāṭīkāyaṃ pana dubbalāpi antimajavana🔽cetanā sanniṭṭhānakiccavisesayuttatāya phalavipaccane sattivise sayuttā hotīti upapajjavedanīyā
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyā nāma jātā ati vattabbā hoti iti mahā ṭīkā ayam pana dubbalā api  cetanā sanniṭṭhāna kicca visesa yutta tāya phala vipaccane satti vise sayuttā hoti iti upapajja vedanīyā
translated: and it should be said that they are born to be experienced in the present existence. But in the Great Commentary it is said that even the weak last impulsion🔽has the special function of bringing the rebirth-linking to fulfilment, and so it is as though it were endowed with the special function of ripening the result.🔽🔽

original: ānantariyakāca sā hotīti vuttaṃ. Yathārahanti taṃ taṃ puggalānurūpaṃ. Yathābhinīhāra🔽vasenāti tassa tassa parikammabhāvanā cittassa kasiṇanimittā dīsuvā aniccalakkhaṇādīsuvā🔽abhinīharaṇānurūpaṃ. Appanāvīthinti appanāpabandhaṃ. Idañca anekavāre pavattānaṃ
analyzed: ānantariyakā ca sā hoti iti vuttam yathā arahanti tam tam puggala anurūpam yathā abhinīhāra  vasena ati tassa tassa parikamma bhāvanā cittassa kasiṇa nimittā anicca lakkhaṇa ādīsu vā  abhinīharaṇa anurūpam appanā vīthinti appanā apabandham idam ca aneka vāre pavattānam
translated: and it should be said that they are of the kind that is to be felt in the present existence. But in the Great Commentary it is said that even though the last impulsion is weak, it is nevertheless strong in the ripening of the fruit because it is associated with the special function of determining, and it is of the kind to be felt on rebirth and it is also of the kind to be felt in the next existence.🔽As befits each: in accordance with each person.🔽According to the direction given: according to the direction given to the development of the preliminary-work consciousness, whether to the kasiṇa sign or to impermanence, etc., as its object.

original: appanājavanānaṃ saṅgahaṇatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Tenevāha tatoparaṃ appanāvasāne bhavaṅgapātova
analyzed: appanā javanānam saṅgahaṇa attham vuttam tena iva āha tatas uparam appanā avasāne bhavaṅga pāto va
translated: In the course of the absorption: this is said in order to include the absorption impulsion that occurs many times. That is why he said, “After that, at the end of the absorption, it is reborn in the life-continuum” .🔽Herein, after that: either after the fourth or after the fifth.

original: hotīti. Tattha tatoti catutthatovā pañcamato vā. Imasmiṃ atthe sati pañcamevā chaṭṭhevā
analyzed: hoti iti tattha tatoti catutthataḥ vā pañcamataḥ vā imasmin atthe sati pañcamena iva chaṭṭhena iva
translated: In this sense, only the fifth or the sixth is intended.

original: ekantena bhavaṅgapāto hotīti āpajjati. Tasmā puna appanāvasāneti vuttaṃ. Bhavaṅgapātovahoti.
analyzed: ekantena bhavaṅga pātaḥ hoti iti āpajjati tasmā puna appanā avasāne iti vuttam
translated: and so he falls into the life-continuum. That is why it was said above, “at the end of absorption,” and “falling into the life-continuum.”

original: Natthi tadārammaṇuppādoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: na atthi tad ārammaṇa uppādaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no arising of the object of that .

original: Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Katthaci appanāvāre sattajavana paripūraṇatthaṃ appanāvasānepi kāmāvacarajavanappavattiṃ vadantānaṃ nikāyantarikānaṃ vādo idha evasaddena nivattito”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: katthaci appanā vāre satta javana paripūraṇa attham appanā avasāne pi kāmāvacara javana ppavattim vadantānam nikāya āntarikānam vādaḥ idha eva saddena nivattitaḥ ti vuttam
translated: “The view of the Nikāyanteriyas who say that there is occurrence of sense-sphere impulsions at the end of absorption in order to fulfil the seven impulsion moments in some instances of absorption is refuted here by the word ‘only’” .

original: Tatthāti tasmiṃ appanājavanavāre. Nirantarapavattānaṃ javanānaṃ bhinnavedanatānāma natthīti vuttaṃ somanassasahagata javanā nantarantiādi.
analyzed: tattha ati tasmin appanā javana vāre nirantara pavattānam javanānam bhinna vedanatā nāma natthi iti vuttam somanassa sahagata javana anantara ntiādi
translated: Herein, in the passage beginning, “There is no … of impulsion accompanied by joy,” what is said is that there is no occurrence of impulsion accompanied by different kinds of feeling in the impulsion moments that occur uninterruptedly in the course of the impulsion-moments of absorption.

original: [132] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Bhinnavedanānaṃ aññamaññaṃ āsevanapaccayabhāvassa anuddhaṭattā”tikāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: bhinna vedanānam aññam aññam āsevana paccaya bhāvassa anuddhaṭa ttā ati kāraṇam vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: “Because there is no establishing of a condition by way of repetition between those of different kinds of feeling” . That is not good.

original: Na hi idha āsevanapaccayabhāvo pamāṇaṃ. Kasmā, āsevana paccanikānaṃ phalajavanānaṃpi
analyzed: na hi idha āsevana paccaya bhāvaḥ pamāṇam kasmai āsevana paccanikānam
translated: For here the state of being a condition by way of repetition is not the criterion. Why not? Because the resultant impulsion that is a condition by way of repetition for the impulsion of the kind of rebirth-linking, etc.,

original: parikammajavanehi aññamaññañca abhinnavedanatāya icchitabbattāti. Pāṭikaṅkhitabbāti avassaṃ icchitabbā.
analyzed: parikamma javanehi aññam aññam ca abhinna vedanatāya icchitabba ttā ati pāṭikaṅkhitabbā ati avassam icchitabbā
translated: and because it is necessary to assume that the two kinds of impulsions, namely, those of the path and those of the fruition, are of the same feeling as each other.

original: [133] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Pasaṃsitabbā”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.🔽Na hi tādiso saṃvaṇṇanāpadeso dissatīti. Arahatta phale maggavīthiyaṃ maggakusalānantaraṃ
analyzed: pasaṃsitabbā iti vuttam tat na sundaram  na hi tādisaḥ saṃvaṇṇanā apadeso dissati iti arahatta phale magga vīthiyam magga kusala anantaram
translated: “It is to be commended” . That is not good.🔽For no such expression as “to be commended” is found.🔽And although it occurs in the path’s functional consciousness that arises next to the path’s profitable consciousness in the path of Arahantship,

original: pavattamānepi ayaṃ pubbāpara niyamo parikammajavanehi eva saha appanājavanānaṃ hotīti🔽katvā kriyajavanānantaraṃ arahattaphalañcāti vuttaṃ. Sukhapuññamhā paraṃ dvattiṃsa🔽appanājavanāni sambhavanti. Upekkhakā puññamhā paraṃ dvādasa, sukhitakriyato paraṃ🔽aṭṭha. Upekkhakā kriyato paraṃ cha appanājavanāni sambhavantīti yojanā. Tattha dvattiṃsāti
analyzed: pavattamāne pi ayam pubba apara niyamaḥ parikamma javanehi eva saha appanā javanānam hoti iti  katvā kriya javana anantaram arahatta phalam ca ati vuttam param dvattiṃsa  appanā javanāni sambhavanti upekkhakāḥ puññamhā param dvādasa sukhita kriyataḥ param  aṭṭha upekkhakā param cha appanā javanāni sambhavanti iti yojanā tattha dvattiṃsā ti
translated: this order of the path’s fruition consciousnesses is nevertheless stated thus: “Next to the path’s functional consciousness, the fruition of Arahantship” because it is only with the path’s impulsion that the path’s fruition consciousnesses have this order.🔽Thirty-two path’s fruition consciousnesses occur next to the path’s functional consciousness. Twelve occur next to the path’s profitable consciousness. Eight occur next to the path’s functional consciousness. Six occur next to the path’s functional consciousness.

original: arahattaphalasabbapañcamajjhānavajjitānaṃ catunnaṃ rūpakusalānaṃ soḷasannaṃ maggakusalānaṃ
analyzed: arahatta phala sabba pañcama jhāna vajjitānam catunnam rūpa kusalānam soḷasannam magga kusalānam
translated: Herein, thirty-two means that thirty-two occur next to the four kinds of fine-material profitable consciousnesses and the sixteen kinds of path consciousnesses excluding the fifth path in the fine-material sphere and the fifth path in the immaterial sphere.

original: dvādasannaṃ heṭṭhimaphalānañca vasena dvattiṃsa. Dvādasāti pañcamajjhānikānaṃ rūpārūpamaggakusalānaṃ🔽heṭṭhimaphalānañca vasena dvādasa. Aṭṭhāti pañcamajjhānavajjitānaṃ catunnaṃ rūpakriyānaṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhima phalānam ca vasena dvattiṃsa dvādasa ati pañcamajjhānikānam rūpa arūpa magga kusalānam  heṭṭhima phalānam ca vasena dvādasa pañcama jhāna vajjitānam catunnam rūpa kriyānam
translated: and by means of the twelve lower fruitions, there are thirty-two. Twelve: by means of the twelve kinds of profitable consciousness of the fine-material and immaterial paths in the fifth jhāna,🔽and by means of the twelve lower fruitions. Eight: by means of the four fine-material and four immaterial kinds of resultant-making consciousness in the four jhānas excluding the fifth,

original: catunnaṃ arahattaphalānañca vasena aṭṭha. Chāti pañcamajjhānikānaṃ pañcannaṃ rūpārūpakriyānaṃ🔽arahattaphalassaca vasena cha. Puthujjanānaṃ sekkhānañca kāmapuññatihetuto paraṃ
analyzed: catunnam arahatta phalānam ca vasena aṭṭha pañcamajjhānikānam pañcannam rūpa arūpa kriyānam  arahatta phalassa ca vasena cha puthujjanānam sekkhānam ca kāma puññati hetutaḥ param
translated: and by means of the four fruitions of Arahantship. Six: by means of the five fine-material and immaterial kinds of resultant-making consciousness in the five jhānas,🔽and by means of the fruition of Arahantship. For ordinary men and for those in training, the profitable root of the sense sphere is the cause of the other four profitable roots.

original: catucattālīsa appanā sambhavanti. Vītarāgānaṃ arahantānaṃ tihetukāmakriyato paraṃ
analyzed: catucattālīsa sambhavanti vīta rāgānam arahantānam param
translated: So there are forty-four kinds of absorption. For those who are free from greed, the profitable root of the sense sphere is the cause of the other three profitable roots.

original: cuddasa appanā sambhavantīti yojanā.🔽139. Sabbathāpīti atimahantādinā sabbapakārenapi. Etthāti etesu yathāvuttesu pañcadvāra
analyzed: cuddasa appanā sambhavanti iti yojanā  sabbathā api iti atimahanta ādinā sabba pakārena api ettha ati etesu yathā vuttesu pañca dvāra
translated: So there are twelve kinds of absorption. The construction is as follows.🔽In every way: in all ways, that is, in the way beginning with “very great” . Here: in these five doors of the eye, etc.,

original: manodvāresu. Sabbatthāpi pana aniṭṭhe tivā pāṭho. Teneva ṭīkāsu sabbatthāpīti pañcadvāra
analyzed: manas dvāresu sabbattha api pana aniṭṭhe ti vā pāṭho tena iva ṭīkāsu sabbattha api iti pañca dvāra
translated: and in the mind door stated as above. But the reading “in every place” is not good. Therefore in the commentaries the reading “in every way” is preferred.

original: manodvārepīti vuttaṃ. Icchitabbanti iṭṭhaṃ. Kena icchitabbanti. Lokiyamahājanena.
analyzed: manaḥ dvāre pi iti vuttam icchitabbanti iṭṭham kena icchitabbanti lokiya mahājanena
translated: ‘Desired’ is what is wished for. By whom is it wished for? By the worldling.

original: Tattha ca atiukkaṭṭhe atiduggateca jane agahetvā majjhimakena mahājanena. Evañhi🔽sati iṭṭhāniṭṭhānaṃ suṭṭhuvavatthānaṃ hotīti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Yasmiṃ ārammaṇekusala
analyzed: tattha ca ati ukkaṭṭhe ati duggate ca jane a gahetvā majjhimakena mahājanena evam hi  sati iṭṭha aniṭṭhānam suṭṭhu vavatthānam hoti iti aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam yasmin
translated: And here, leaving out the very low and the very high people, it is by the middle sort of people that it is wished for.🔽For in that case the distinction of what is desired and what is undesired is well defined, so it is said in the Commentary.🔽And in the case of the object in which a profitable resultant consciousness arises, that is called ‘desired.’

original: vipākaṃ uppajjati, tadeva iṭṭhaṃnāma. Yasmiṃ pana akusalavipākaṃ uppajjati, tadeva
analyzed: vipākam uppajjati tat eva iṭṭhaṃnāma yasmin pana akusala vipākam uppajjati tat eva
translated: But in the case of the object in which a unprofitable resultant consciousness arises, that is called ‘undesired.’

original: aniṭṭhaṃnāma. Na hi sakkā iṭṭhaṃvā aniṭṭhaṃvā ārammaṇaṃ vipākacittaṃ vañcetuntica.
analyzed: aniṭṭham nāma na hi sakkā iṭṭham vā aniṭṭham vā ārammaṇam vipāka cittam vañcetun ti ca
translated: For it is not possible to deceive a resultant consciousness by means of a desired or undesired object.

original: Apica dvāravasenāpi iṭṭhāniṭṭhatā veditabbāti ca vuttaṃ. Tasmā indriyānindriyabaddhasantānagate🔽eke kasmiṃ rūpakalāpe vaṇṇādīsu rūpesu kiñci iṭṭhaṃ hoti. Kiñci aniṭṭhaṃ. Kadāci
analyzed: apica dvāra vasena api iṭṭha aniṭṭha tā veditabbā iti ca vuttam tasmai indriya anindriya baddha santāna gate  eke kasmim rūpa kalāpe vaṇṇa ādīsu rūpesu kiñci iṭṭham hoti kiñci aniṭṭham kadāci
translated: Besides, it is said that the distinction of what is desired and what is undesired should be understood also according to the door .🔽So in the case of a visible-data object, in some continuity bound up with a sense faculty, some visible data such as colour are desired, some are not desired.🔽Sometimes they are desired, sometimes not.

original: iṭṭhaṃ hoti. Kadāci aniṭṭhaṃ, tattha kiñci iṭṭhaṃ hoti kiñci aniṭṭhanti yathā kiṃsmiṃci
analyzed: iṭṭham hoti kadāci an iṭṭham tattha kiñci iṭṭham hoti kiñci an iṭṭhanti yathā kiṃsmiṃci
translated: Herein, some are desired, some are not desired, just as in the case of some kinds of food.

original: ekasmiṃ pupphe vaṇṇo iṭṭho. Gandho aniṭṭho, raso aniṭṭho, phoṭṭhabbo aniṭṭho, kharasamphasso.
analyzed: ekasmin pupphe vaṇṇaḥ iṭṭhaḥ gandhaḥ aniṭṭhaḥ rasaḥ aniṭṭhaḥ phoṭṭhabbaḥ aniṭṭhaḥ khara samphassaḥ
translated: In one flower the colour is desirable, but the smell, the taste, the tangible object, and the temperature are undesirable.🔽In another flower all these properties are desirable.

original: Kiṃsmiṃci vaṇṇopi iṭṭho, gandhopi iṭṭho, rasādayo aniṭṭhāyeva. Tathā buddhassa sarīragatepi🔽ekasmiṃ kalāpe vaṇṇo iṭṭho hoti. Gandho aniṭṭho. Matakaṇhasunakhassa uddhumātasarīrepi
analyzed: kiṃsmiṃci vaṇṇaḥ api iṭṭhaḥ gandhaḥ api iṭṭhaḥ rasa ādayaḥ an iṭṭhāya iva tathā buddhassa sarīra gate pi  ekasmin kalāpe vaṇṇo iṭṭhaḥ hoti gandhaḥ an iṭṭhaḥ mata kaṇha sunakhassa uddhumāta sarīre pi
translated: So too, in the case of the colour, etc., of the Master’s bodily remains.🔽In one relic the colour is desirable, but the smell is undesirable.🔽In another relic the colour is desirable, but the smell is undesirable.🔽That colour, if it had been in the cloth worn by the Master,

original: vaṇṇo iṭṭho hoti. Gandho aniṭṭho. So hi vaṇṇo yadi nivatthapārutassa vatthassa bhaveyya.
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ iṭṭhaḥ hoti gandhaḥ an iṭṭhaḥ saḥ hi vaṇṇaḥ yadi nivattha pārutassa vatthassa bhaveyya
translated: would have made the cloth valuable.

original: Taṃ vatthaṃ mahagghaṃ hotīti. Kadāci iṭṭhaṃ kadāci aniṭṭhanti aggināma hemante iṭṭho🔽sukhavipākassa paccayo. Gimhe aniṭṭho dukkhavipākassa paccayo. Sītudakaṃ gimhe iṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: tam vattham mahaggham hoti iti kadāci iṭṭham kadāci an iṭṭhanti aggi nāma hemante iṭṭhaḥ  sukha vipākassa paccayaḥ gimhe aniṭṭhaḥ dukkha vipākassa paccayaḥ sītudakam gimhe iṭṭham
translated: Sometimes it is desirable, sometimes undesirable: in winter it is desirable,🔽being a condition for a pleasant ripening; in summer it is undesirable, being a condition for a painful ripening. Cold water is desirable in summer,

original: Hemante aniṭṭhaṃ. Tathā sukha samphassaṃ vatthaṃ pakatikāye iṭṭhaṃ hoti. Vaṇaṃ patvā
analyzed: hemante aniṭṭham tathā sukha samphassam vattham pakati kāye iṭṭham hoti vaṇam patvā
translated: but undesirable in winter. So too, a tangible object that is desirable in the normal body🔽is undesirable in a wound.

original: aniṭṭhaṃ. Tenavā saṇikaṃ phusantassa iṭṭhaṃ, gāḷhaṃ phusantassa aniṭṭhanti. Naiṭṭhanti
analyzed: an iṭṭham tenavā saṇikam phusantassa iṭṭham gāḷham phusantassa an iṭṭhanti na eṭṭhanti
translated: and unpleasurable. And so it is because of that that what is touched lightly is pleasurable and what is touched hard is unpleasurable.

original: aniṭṭhaṃ. Tasmiṃ aniṭṭhe. Iṭṭheti iṭṭhamajjhatte, kusalavipākāni pañcaviññāṇa sampaṭicchana🔽santīraṇa tadārammaṇānīti sambandho. Santīraṇa tadārammaṇāni cettha upekkhāsahagatānieva
analyzed: aniṭṭham tasmin aniṭṭhe iṭṭha iti iṭṭha majjhatte kusala vipākāni  santīraṇa tad ārammaṇāni iti sambandho santīraṇa tad ārammaṇāni ca ittha upekkhā sahagatāni eva
translated: Unpleasurable: unpleasurable. In that: in that unpleasurable. Pleasurable: in the middle of the pleasurable. The five kinds of resultant consciousness that are profitable are the kinds of receiving, investigating, and adverting that have that as object.🔽The connection is this. And here the investigating and the adverting should be understood as being only accompanied by equanimity.

original: veditabbāni. Tenevāha atiiṭṭhepanātiādi. Tattha abhiiṭṭheti suvaṇṇa rajata maṇivaṇṇādike
analyzed: veditabbāni tena iva āha tattha abhiiṭṭhā iti suvaṇṇa rajata maṇi vaṇṇa ādike
translated: That is why he said ‘in the very pleasurable, etc.’ Herein, in the very pleasurable is in the six objects that are very much desired by the world’s great folk, such as the colours of gold, silver, gems, etc.,

original: haritālavaṇṇādike koseyya vatthavaṇṇādi ke devaccharāvaṇṇādikeca ativiya lokiyamahājanena🔽icchitabbe chaḷārammaṇe. Yasmā cettha aniṭṭhārammaṇa samāyogo akusalakammasseva vipaccanokāso
analyzed: haritāla vaṇṇa ādike lokiya mahājanena  icchitabbe chaṭṭha ārammaṇe samāyogo akusala kammassa iva
translated: the colours of betel leaves, etc., the colours of silk clothes, etc., and the colours of celestial nymphs, etc.🔽And since here the concurrence of an unpleasurable object is the opportunity for the ripening of unprofitable action,🔽and the concurrence of a pleasurable object is the opportunity for the ripening of profitable action, therefore in the unpleasurable the resultants are only unprofitable,

original: hoti. Iṭṭhārammaṇasamāyogoca kusalakammasseva, tasmā aniṭṭhe akusalavipākāneva. Iṭṭhe
analyzed: hoti iṭṭha ārammaṇa samāyogo ca kusala kammassa iva tasmai aniṭṭhe akusala vipākāna eva iṭṭhe
translated: and in the pleasurable they are only profitable.

original: kusalavipākānevāti ayaṃ niyamo siddho. Vedanāniyamo pana ādāse mukhanimittassa viya
analyzed: kusala vipākān eva ati ayam niyamaḥ siddhaḥ vedanā niyamaḥ pana mukha nimittassa viya
translated: This is the established rule. But the rule about feeling is seen in the case of the reflections of the face in a mirror, etc.,

original: attano ussāha balena vinā kevalaṃ kammabalena nibbattānaṃ vipākānaṃ paridubbalattā
analyzed: attanaḥ ussāha balena vinā kevalam kamma balena nibbattānam vipākānam paridubbala ttā
translated: where the reflections are produced by the power of the kamma of the face, etc., and so on,

original: tathā tathā kappetvā pakappetvā gahaṇā bhāvato yathārammaṇameva siddho hotīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: tathā tathā kappetvā pakappetvā gahaṇāḥ bhāvataḥ yathārammaṇam eva siddhaḥ hoti iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: and so it should be regarded as established as to object according to the object.

original: Na kevalañca vipākānaṃ eva. Athakho vipallāsarahite khiṇāsavasantāne pavattānaṃ kāmakriyajavanānaṃ🔽viyathārammaṇameva vedanāyogo hotīti adhippāyena vuttaṃ tatthāpi somanassasahagata
analyzed: na kevalam ca vipākānam eva vipallāsa rahite khiṇa āsava santāne kāmakriya java nānam  viyatha ārammaṇam eva vedanā yogaḥ hoti iti adhippāyena vuttam tattha api somanassa sahagata
translated: And not only in the case of the resultants, but also in the case of the functional consciousnesses that occur in the worldling’s mental process,🔽the combination of feeling with the object is according to the object. This is the intention in the words, “And so too in the case of the functional consciousnesses” .

original: kriyajavanāvasāne tiādi. Tatthāpīti tesu vipākesupi. Somanassasahagata kriya javanā
analyzed: kriya javana avasāne tiādi tattha api iti tesu vipākesu pi
translated: Herein, in the case of the resultants, too, at the end of the functional consciousnesses accompanied by joy,

original: vasāneti buddhavaṇṇādike atiiṭṭhārammaṇe pavattānaṃ somanassa sahagata kriyajavanānaṃ
analyzed: vasānā iti buddha vaṇṇa ādike ati iṭṭha ārammaṇe pavattānam
translated: at the end of the functional consciousnesses accompanied by joy that occur with a very much liked object such as a beautiful colour-form, etc.,

original: avasāne. Upekkhāsahagata kriya javanā vasāneti aniṭṭhe iṭṭhamajjhatteca pavattānaṃ
analyzed: avasāne upekkhā sahagata kriya javanā vasānā iti aniṭṭhe iṭṭha majjhatte ca pavattānam
translated: at the end of the functional consciousnesses accompanied by equanimity that occur with a neutral object,

original: upekkhāsahagatakriyajavanānaṃ avasāne. Ayañca kriyajavanāvasāne tadārammaṇaniyamo
analyzed: upekkhā sahagata kriya javanānam avasāne ayam ca kriya javana avasāne tad ārammaṇa niyamaḥ
translated: And this rule about the object of the functional consciousness at the end of the impulsions

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃpi vuttoyeva. Vuttañhi tattha kāmāvacara tihetuka somanassa sahagatakriyadvayaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam pi vuttaḥ yā iva vuttam hi tattha
translated: is stated in the commentary too. For this is said there: “The two kinds of functional consciousness accompanied by joy in the sense sphere with three roots

original: tadārammaṇavasena pañcannaṃ somanassasahagata vipākānaṃ anantarapaccayotiādi. Idañca🔽pakatinīhārena pavattānaṃ kriyajavanānaṃ vasena vuttaṃ. Tathā rūpena pana cittātisaṅkhārena
analyzed: tad ārammaṇa vasena pañcannam somanassa sahagata vipākānam anantara paccaya utiādi idam ca  pakati nīhārena pavattānam kriya javanānam vasena vuttam tathā rūpena pana citta ati saṅkhārena
translated: are a condition, as object condition, for five resultants accompanied by joy.”🔽This is said of the functional impulsions that occur by way of the normal process.🔽But when the functional impulsions occur by way of the process called “with visible form as object,”

original: pavattānaṃ kriyajavanānaṃ iṭṭhepi upekkhāvedanāyogo aniṭṭhepi somanassa vedanāyogo hotiyeva. Yathāha –
analyzed: pavattānam kriya javanānam iṭṭhe pi upekkhā vedanā yogaḥ aniṭṭhe pi somanassa vedanā yogaḥ yathā āha
translated: the feeling of equanimity is associated with the desirable object, and the feeling of joy is associated with the undesirable object. As it is said:

original: Kathañcānanda ariyo hoti bhāvitindriyo. Idhānanda bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā
analyzed: kathañca ānanda ariyaḥ hoti bhāvita indriyaḥ idha ānanda bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpam disvā
translated: “And how, Ānanda, is one a noble one with developed faculties? Here, Ānanda, when a bhikkhu has seen a visible object with the eye,

original: uppajjati manāpaṃ uppajjati amanāpaṃ. Uppajjati manāpāmanāpaṃ. So sace ākaṅkhati
analyzed: uppajjati manāpam uppajjati amanāpam uppajjati manāpa amanāpam saḥ sace ākaṅkhati
translated: there arises in him what is agreeable, there arises what is disagreeable, there arises what is both agreeable and disagreeable. If he so wishes,

original: paṭikūle appaṭikūlasaññī vihareyyanti. Appaṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati. Sace ākaṅkhati
analyzed: paṭikūle appaṭikūla saññī vihareyyanti appaṭikūla saññī tattha viharati sace ākaṅkhati
translated: ‘In the unrepulsive, perceiving the unrepulsive, he would dwell …’ He dwells perceiving the unrepulsive there. If he wishes:

original: appaṭikūle paṭikūla saññī vihareyyanti. Paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharatīti.
analyzed: a paṭikūle paṭikūla saññī vihareyyanti paṭikūla saññī tattha viharati iti
translated: ‘In the unrepulsive, perceiving the repulsive, he would dwell …’ He dwells perceiving the repulsive there.

original: Sabbaṃ uparipaṇṇāsake indriyabhāvanāsuttaṃ āharitabbaṃ. Tattha uppajjati manāpaṃ
analyzed: sabbam upari paṇṇāsake indriya bhāvanā suttam āharitabbam tattha uppajjati manāpam
translated: The whole of the Indriya-bhāvanā Sutta of the second section should be quoted here. Herein, the words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.🔽The words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.

original: uppajjati amanāpaṃ. Uppajjati manāpāmanāpanti etena khīṇāsavānaṃ kāmakriyajavanānaṃ🔽pakatinīhārena iṭṭhe so manassayogo aniṭṭhe upekkhā yogo dassito hoti. Sosace ākaṅkhati
analyzed: uppajjati amanāpam uppajjati manāpa amanāpanti etena khīṇa āsavānam kāmakriya javanānam  pakatinīhārena iṭṭhe so manassayogaḥ aniṭṭhe upekkhā yogo dassito hoti sosace ākaṅkhati
translated: The words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.🔽The words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.

original: paṭikūle appaṭikūlasaññī vihareyyanti. Appaṭikūlasaññī tattha viharatītiādinā pana🔽tesaṃ tathārūpe cittābhisaṅkhāre sati iṭṭhepi upekkhāyogo aniṭṭhepisomanassa yogo
analyzed: paṭikūle appaṭikūla saññī vihareyyanti appaṭikūla saññī tattha viharati iti ādinā pana  tesam tathārūpe citta abhisaṅkhāre sati iṭṭhe pi upekkhā yogaḥ aniṭṭhe pi somanassa yogo
translated: The words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.

original: vutto hotīti. Yaṃ pana khīṇāsavānaṃ satatavihārasutte idha bhikkhunā rūpaṃ disvā
analyzed: vutto hoti iti yam pana khīṇāsavānam satatavihāra sutte idha bhikkhunā rūpam disvā
translated: The words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.🔽The words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.🔽The words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.🔽The words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.🔽The words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.🔽The words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.🔽The words ‘what is agreeable and what is disagreeable arise’ refer to the occurrence of the kinds of javanas that are profitable and unprofitable in one whose cankers are destroyed.

original: neva sumano hoti. Na dummano. Upekkhako viharati sato sampajānotiādinā chasudvāresu🔽somanassa paṭikkhipanaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃpi tesaṃ tathā rūpacittābhisaṅkhārabāhullavasena🔽vuttanti gahetabbaṃ. Yasmā vā khīṇālavāpi buddharūpadassanādīsu padhānasāruppaṭṭhānadassanādīsu
analyzed: na iva sumanaḥ hoti na dummanaḥ upekkhakaḥ viharati sataḥ sampajānoti ādinā chasu dvāresu  somanassa paṭikkhipanam vuttam tam pi tesam tathā rūpa citta abhisaṅkhāra bāhulla vasena  vuttam ti gahetabbam yasmā vā khīṇālavā api buddha rūpa dassana ādīsu padhāna sāruppa ṭṭhāna dassana ādīsu
translated: In the six doors beginning with the eye door🔽the abandoning of gladness is stated. That should be taken as said because of the abundance of the kinds of materiality and consciousness and of the formations that occur in them in such-and-such a way.

original: ca somanassitā hontiyeva. Tasmā kevalaṃ rāgādivatthu bhūtāni rūpārammaṇādīni iṭṭhāniṭṭhāni
analyzed: ca somanassitāḥ tasmā kevalam rāga ādi vatthu bhūtāni rūpa ārammaṇa ādīni iṭṭha aniṭṭhāni
translated: Or alternatively, it may be rightly said that this is said with reference to the desirable and undesirable material objects, etc., as the basis for greed, etc., because even one whose cankers are destroyed is glad when he sees the Enlightened One’s material body, etc., and when he sees the occurrence of the chief requisites, etc.

original: sandhāya idaṃ vuttantipi yuttaṃ. Ettha ca. Kathaṃ paṭikūle appaṭikūlasaññī viharati.
analyzed: sandhāya idam vuttam tipi yuttam ettha ca katham paṭikūle appaṭikūla saññī viharati
translated: And here: How does he dwell perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive?

original: Aniṭṭhasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ mettāyavā pharati. Dhātutovā upasaṃharati. Evaṃ paṭikūle appaṭikūlasaññī
analyzed: aniṭṭhasmim vatthusmim dhātutaḥ vā upasaṃharati evam paṭikūle a paṭikūla saññī
translated: He extends loving-kindness towards a desirable object, or he resolves the elements. That is how he dwells perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive.

original: viharati. Kathaṃ appaṭikūle paṭikūlasaññī viharati iṭṭhasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ asubhāyavā
analyzed: viharati katham appaṭikūle paṭikūla saññī viharati iṭṭhasmim vatthusmim asubhāyavā
translated: How does he dwell perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive? He extends the perception of foulness towards a desirable object,🔽or he resolves it in terms of impermanence. That is how he dwells perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive.

original: pharati. Aniccato vā upasaṃharati. Evaṃ appaṭikūle paṭikūlasaññī viharatītiādinā
analyzed: pharati aniccataḥ vā upasaṃharati evam appaṭikūle paṭikūla saññī viharati itiādinā
translated: And so on.

original: paṭisambhidāmagganayena idha tathārūpo cittābhisaṅkhāro nāma veditabbo. Apare pana
analyzed: paṭisambhidā magga nayena idha tathārūpaḥ citta abhisaṅkhāro nāma veditabbaḥ apare pana
translated: Herein, the kind of mental formation should be understood as such by way of the path of the analytical knowledges.

original: vadanti-khīṇāsavā yadā devaccharā vaṇṇādikaṃ atiiṭṭhārammaṇaṃ āpātamā gacchati. Tadā🔽tattha asubhāyavāpharanti. Aniccatovā upasaṃharanti tattha aniṭṭhabhūtaṃ asubha lakkhaṇaṃvā
analyzed: vadanti khīṇa āsavāḥ yadā devaccharā vaṇṇa ādikam ati iṭṭha ārammaṇam gacchati tadā  tattha aniccataḥ vā upasaṃharanti tattha aniṭṭha bhūtam asubha lakkhaṇaṃvā
translated: Others say that when the objects of the sense-desire-freed deities, such as their beauty, etc., come into the focus of the sense-door,

original: aniccalakkhaṇaṃvā upekkhā kriya javanānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ hoti. Na atiiṭṭhārammaṇabhūtaṃ
analyzed: anicca lakkhaṇam vā upekkhā kriyā javanānam ārammaṇam hoti na ati iṭṭha ārammaṇa bhūtam
translated: then the sense-desire-freed meditator extends the aspect of foulness to them, or he brings them under the concept of impermanence. Then the sign of foulness or the sign of impermanence becomes the object of the functional javanas of equanimity.

original: devaccharāvaṇṇādikaṃ.
analyzed: deva charāvaṇṇa ādikam
translated: It is not the object of the sense-desire-freed deities’ beauty, etc., which are the desirable objects.

original: Tathā yadā kudhibhakuṭṭhasarīrādikaṃ atianiṭṭhārammaṇaṃ āpātamāgacchati. Tadā tattha
analyzed: tathā yadā kudhibha kuṭṭha sarīra ādikam ati aniṭṭha ārammaṇam āpātam āgacchati tadā
translated: Similarly, when the objects of the sense-desire-freed deities, such as their beauty, etc., come into the focus of the sense-door,

original: mettāyavā pharanti. Dhātutovā upasaṃharanti. Tattha iṭṭhabhūtaṃ averatāvādilakkhaṇameva
analyzed: pharanti dhātutaḥ vā upasaṃharanti tattha iṭṭha bhūtam avera tā vādi lakkhaṇam eva
translated: then the sense-desire-freed meditator extends the aspect of foulness to them, or he brings them under the concept of impermanence. Then the sign of foulness or the sign of impermanence becomes the object of the functional javanas of equanimity.

original: somanassakriyajavanānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ hoti. Na atianiṭṭhabhūtaṃ kudhita kuṭṭhasarīrādikaṃ.
analyzed: ārammaṇam hoti na ati aniṭṭha bhūtam kudhita kuṭṭha sarīra ādikam
translated: It is not the object of the sense-desire-freed deities’ beauty, etc., which are the desirable objects.

original: Tasmā tāni javanāni kāmavipākāniviya sabbadāpi ārammaṇānurūpameva vedanāyuttāni hontīti.
analyzed: tasmā tāni javanāni sabbadā api ārammaṇa anurūpam eva vedanā yuttāni honti iti
translated: Therefore they are always associated with feeling in conformity with their object, as in the case of the resultant kinds of javanas in the sense sphere.

original: Taṃ nayujjati. Na hi tāni lakkhaṇāni devaccharāvaṇṇādīhi vinā visuṃ labbhanti. Tehi🔽pana saheva labbhanti. Tasmā yathā ānisaṃsadassanena bhāvanāya pubbāpariyavisesadassanenaca
analyzed: tam na yujjati na hi tāni lakkhaṇāni deva charāvaṇṇa ādīhi vinā visum labbhanti tehi  pana saha iva labbhanti tasmā yathā ānisaṃsa dassanena bhāvanāya pubba apariya visesa dassanena ca
translated: That is not so. For those characteristics are not found separately without the divine ear and so on.

original: uddhumātakādīsu ati aniṭṭhesupi somanassuppatti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttā. Yathāca mahā🔽moggalānattherassa buddhasubuddhatādassanena attasampattidassanenaca aniṭṭhabhūtepi🔽aṭṭhikaṅkalikapetarūpe somanassuppatti pāḷiyaṃ vuttā. Yathā ca mahākassapattherassa
analyzed: uddhumātaka ādīsu ati aniṭṭhesu pi somanassa uppatti aṭṭhakathā ayam vuttā yathā ca mahā  moggalāna ttherassa buddha subuddha tā dassanena atta sampatti dassanena ca aniṭṭha bhūte pi  aṭṭhi kaṅkalika peta rūpe somanassa uppatti pāḷiyam vuttā yathā ca mahākassapa therassa
translated: But they are found with them. Therefore, just as it is said in the commentary that joy arises in the case of the bloated and the rest, which are extremely unpleasant, through seeing the benefit and through seeing the difference between the earlier and later stages in the development of the meditation subject,🔽and just as it is said in the texts that joy arises in the case of the skeleton and the ghost, which are unpleasant, through seeing the perfection of the Buddha and through seeing one’s own perfection, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Moggallāna,

original: tathārūpena cittābhi saṅkhārena kuṭṭhino hatthato laddhe aniṭṭhabhūte pūtikummāsepi
analyzed: tathārūpena citta abhi saṅkhārena kuṭṭhinaḥ hatthataḥ laddhe aniṭṭha bhūte pūti kummāse pi
translated: and just as it is said in the commentary that joy arises in the case of the foul-smelling rotten fruits, which are unpleasant, through the Elder Mahā Kassapa’s mental direction of attention in the way beginning, “They are not fruits,” when he received them from a leper,

original: somanassuppatti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttā. Evamevaṃ idhapi asubhapharaṇādiko cittābhisaṅkhāro
analyzed: somanassa uppatti aṭṭhakathā ayam vuttā evam evam idha api asubha pharaṇa ādikaḥ citta abhisaṅkhāro
translated: so too here joy arises in the case of the sign of foulness, which is unpleasant, through the mental direction of attention.

original: atiiṭṭhe upekkhājavanānaṃ atianiṭṭheca somanassajavanānaṃ uppattiyā paccayo hotīti
analyzed: ati iṭṭhe upekkhā javanānam ati aniṭṭhe ca somanassa javanānam uppattiyāḥ paccayaḥ hoti iti
translated: It should be regarded as a condition for the arising of equanimity impulsions in regard to what is very much liked, and for the arising of joy impulsions in regard to what is very much disliked.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ayañhi ārammaṇānaṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhabhāvonāma lokiyamahājanānaṃ icchāvasena
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam ayam hi ārammaṇānam iṭṭha aniṭṭha bhāvaḥ nāma lokiya mahājanānam icchā vasena
translated: For this is the liking of the great multitude of worldly people that determines what is liked and disliked among objects,

original: siddho hoti agambhīro vipallāsadhammānaṃ kilesānañca vatthubhūto. Yathāha-tattha
analyzed: siddhaḥ hoti agambhīraḥ vipallāsa dhammānam kilesānam ca vatthu bhūtaḥ
translated: and it is shallow and a basis for the defilements of perversion. As it is said:

original: katamaṃ rūpaṃ hīnaṃ. Yaṃ rūpaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ uññātaṃ avaññātantiādi. Ettha
analyzed: katamam rūpam hīnam yam rūpam tesam tesam sattānam uññātam avaññātam tiādi ettha
translated: “Herein, what is inferior visible form? It is that visible form which is despised and scorned by such and such beings” .

original: hi tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānanti etena ārammaṇadhammānaṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhabhāvo nāma lokiyamahājana
analyzed: hi tesam tesam sattānam ti etena ārammaṇa dhammānam iṭṭha aniṭṭha bhāvaḥ nāma lokiya mahājana
translated: Herein, by the words “of such and such beings” he shows that the liking and disliking of objects is established by the agreement of the great multitude of worldly people.

original: sammutiyā siddhoti dasseti. Tasmā yañca appahīnavipallāsānaṃ lokiyamahājanānaṃ devaccharāvaṇṇā🔽dīsu ati iṭṭhesu atiiṭṭhākārato gahaṇaṃ. Yañca buddhavaṇṇā dīsu atiiṭṭhesu aniṭṭhākārato
analyzed: sammutiyā siddhaḥ ti dasseti tasmai yat ca appahīna vipallāsānam lokiya mahājanānam  dīsu ati iṭṭhesu ati iṭṭhākārataḥ gahaṇam yat ca buddhavaṇṇāḥ dīsu ati iṭṭhesu an iṭṭhākārato
translated: Therefore, the apprehension of the very much liked as very much liked in the case of the divine maidens’ beauty, etc., which is very much liked by worldly people whose perversions have not been abandoned,🔽and the apprehension of the very much liked as unliked in the case of the beauty of the Enlightened One, etc., which is very much liked by wise men who are disciples of the Enlightened One,

original: gahaṇaṃ. Tadubhayaṃpi tesaṃ vipallāsavaseneva hoti. Yaṃpana paññavantānaṃ buddhasāvakānaṃ
analyzed: gahaṇam tat ubhayam pi tesam vipallāsa vasena iva hoti yam pana paññavantānam buddha sāvakānam
translated: are both due to perversion.

original: devaccharāvaṇṇādīsu aniṭṭhākārato gahaṇaṃ. Yañca buddhavaṇṇādīsu atiiṭṭhākārato gahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: devaccharā vaṇṇa ādīsu an iṭṭhākārataḥ gahaṇam yat ca buddhavaṇṇa ādīsu ati iṭṭhākārataḥ gahaṇam
translated: And the apprehending of the beauty of the Enlightened One, etc., as attractive.

original: Tadubhayaṃpi paññābaleneva hotīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tat ubhayam pi paññā balena iva hoti iti veditabbam
translated: It should be understood that both these kinds of apprehending are due to the power of understanding.

original: [134] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yam pana
translated: But in the Description of the Aggregates it is said:

original: “Kusalākusalānaṃ pana appahīnavipallāsesu santānesu pavattiyā atiiṭṭhepi iṭṭhamajjhattaaniṭṭhākārato aniṭṭhepi iṭṭhaiṭṭhamajjhattākārato gahaṇaṃ hotīti” vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kusala akusalānam pana appahīna vipallāsesu santānesu pavattiyāḥ ati iṭṭhe pi iṭṭha majjhatta aniṭṭha ākārataḥ aniṭṭhe pi iṭṭha eṭṭha majjhatta ākārataḥ gahaṇam hoti iti vuttam
translated: “But when the continuity is not yet abandoned as to the unprofitable and the unprofitable has not yet been abandoned, then the occurrence of the profitable and the unprofitable is due to apprehending what is attractive as attractive and what is unattractive as unattractive. ”

original: Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And there it is said:

original: “Khīṇāsavānaṃ cittavipallāsābhāvena kriyajavanānipi yathārammaṇameva pavattantī”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ vicāretabbameva.
analyzed: khīṇāsavānam citta vipallāsa abhāvena kriya javanāni pi yathārammaṇam eva pavattanti iti vuttam tat vicāretabbam eva
translated: “But in the case of those whose cankers are destroyed, the functional javanas occur in the same way as the object, since there is no perversion of consciousness.”🔽This should be investigated.

original: Ye hi te dhamma cakkhurahitā honti. Teyeva vipallāsa vasena cittavasānugā ārammaṇavasānugāca
analyzed: ye hi te dhamma cakkhu rahitāḥ honti te yeva vipallāsa vasena citta vasa anugāḥ ārammaṇa vasa anugāḥ ca
translated: For it is only those who are devoid of the eye of understanding who follow the perversions of consciousness and follow the perversions of the object.

original: hontīti kusalā kusalāniyeva yebhuyyena yathārammaṇaṃ pavattanti. Na pana kriya javanāni.
analyzed: honti iti yebhuyyena yathārammaṇam pavattanti na pana
translated: So it is only the profitable and unprofitable javanas that occur in the way the object occurs, not the functional javanas.

original: Na hi khīṇāsavā lokiyamahājanasammatesu iṭṭhāniṭṭhesu cittavasānugā ārammaṇavasānugāca hontīti. Yathāha –
analyzed: na hi khīṇa āsavāḥ lokiya mahājana sammatesu iṭṭha aniṭṭhesu citta vasa anugāḥ ārammaṇa vasa anugāḥ ca honti iti yathā āha
translated: For those whose cankers are destroyed do not follow the inclination of the mind and the inclination of the object in regard to what is approved and disapproved by the world. As it is said:

original: Rūpā saddā gandhā rasā, phoṭṭhabbāca manoramā;
analyzed: rūpā saddā gandhā rasā phoṭṭhabbā ca manoramā
translated: Forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches, too, Are lovely, and so are unlovely things;

original: Iṭṭhadhammā aniṭṭhāca, na pavedhanti paṇḍitāti.
analyzed: iṭṭha dhammāḥ aniṭṭhāḥ ca na pavedhanti paṇḍitā ti
translated: The wise are not perturbed by these, By lovely things or by unlovely.

original: Tasmā somanassa kriya javanānantaraṃpi tadārammaṇāni somanassupekkhā vedanāyuttāni🔽eva siyuṃ. Tathā upekkhākriyajavanānantaraṃpīti. Mūlaṭīkāyaṃ panettha paṭṭhāne-kusalākusale
analyzed: tasmā tad ārammaṇāni somanassa upekkhā vedanā yuttāni  eva siyum tathā mūla ṭīkā ayam pana ittha paṭṭhāne kusala akusale
translated: So the functional consciousnesses that occur next to the joy-producing impulsions and have that same object are accompanied by joy and equanimity.🔽And so are those that occur next to the equanimity-producing impulsions.

original: niruddhe vipāko tadārammaṇatāuppajjatīti kusalakusalānantaraṃ eva tadārammaṇaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: niruddhe vipākaḥ tad ārammaṇa tā uppajjati iti kusala kusala anantaram eva tad ārammaṇam vuttam
translated: But in the commentary to the Paṭṭhāna it is said that “when a profitable or unprofitable consciousness has ceased, its result, the functional consciousness, arises with that same object” .

original: Na abyākatānantaraṃ naca katthaci kriyānantaraṃ tadārammaṇassa vuttaṭṭhānaṃ dissati.
analyzed: na abyākata anantaram na ca katthaci kriyā anantaram tad ārammaṇassa vutta ṭṭhānam dissati
translated: And nowhere is it said that the functional consciousness arises with that same object after a resultant consciousness, nor after a functional consciousness.🔽And there is no reason why such a statement should not have been made if it were so.

original: Vijjamāneca tasmiṃ avacane kāraṇaṃnatthi. Bhavaṅgañcanāmetaṃ nadisotoviya paṭisotagāmināvaṃ
analyzed: vijjamāne ca tasmin avacane kāraṇam natthi paṭisota gāmi nāvam
translated: And this functional consciousness is like the stream of a river flowing on uninterrupted.

original: savipphārikaṃ evajavanaṃ anubandhatīti yuttaṃ. Na pana chaḷaṅgupekkhāvato khīṇāsavassa
analyzed: sa vipphārikam eva javanam anubandhati iti yuttam na pana chaḷaṅgu pekkhāvataḥ khīṇāsavassa
translated: and it is proper to say that it is the impulsion that is accompanied by the jhāna that is followed by the registration. But in the case of one who has reached the sixth stage of purification, namely, purification by knowledge and vision (of the way things are), and who is a candi- date for the state of an Arahant, the registration is not followed by impulsion.

original: santavuttikriyajavanaṃ. Tasmā kriyajavanānantaraṃ tadārammaṇavidhānaṃ upaparikkhitabbanti
analyzed: santa vutti kriya javanam tasmā kriya javana anantaram tad ārammaṇa vidhānam upaparikkhitabbanti
translated: So it is said that the registration should be investigated as to whether or not it is followed by impulsion.

original: vuttaṃ. Paṭṭhāne pana kusalattike pañhā vāre ārammaṇapaccayavibhaṅge tīsu abyākatapadāvasānavāresu
analyzed: vuttam paṭṭhāne pana kusala ttike pañhā vāre ārammaṇa paccaya vibhaṅge tīsu abyākata pada avasāna vāresu
translated: But in the Paṭṭhāna, in the section on the profitable triad, in the section on the condition being a decisive-support condition, in the three sections on the indeterminate, and in the two sections on the candi- date and the worldling,

original: sekkhaputhujjanānaṃ tadārammaṇameva padhānaṃ hoti. Na kusalā kusalajavanaṃ. Tasmā
analyzed: sekkha puthujjanānam tad ārammaṇam eva padhānam hoti na kusalā kusala javanam tasmā
translated: registration is the decisive-support only for the candi- date and the worldling, not for the profitable impulsion. Therefore

original: dvīsupi vāresu sekkhāvā puthujjanāvā kusalaṃ aniccato vipassanti kusalaṃ assādentītiādikaṃ🔽vatvā punaca kusale niruddhe akusale niruddhe vipāko tadārammaṇatā uppajjatīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dvīsu pi vāresu sekkhāvā puthujjanāvā kusalam aniccataḥ vipassanti kusalam assādenti iti ādikam  vatvā puna ca kusale niruddhe akusale niruddhe vipākaḥ tad ārammaṇa tā uppajjati iti vuttam
translated: in the two sections on the candi- date and the worldling, after it has been said that the candi- date and the worldling contemplate the profitable as impermanent, etc., and enjoy the profitable,🔽it is then said that when the profitable ceases, when the unprofitable ceases, the result is the registration of that.

original: Arahato pana javanaṃpi tadārammaṇaṃpi padhāna meva hoti. Tasmā arahā kusalaṃ aniccato
analyzed: arahataḥ pana javanam pi tad ārammaṇam pi padhāna meva hoti tasmai arahā kusalam aniccato
translated: But in the case of an Arahant, the impulsion and the registration are both decisive-support only. Therefore, after it has been said that the Arahant contemplates the profitable as impermanent, etc.,🔽and enjoys the profitable,

original: dukkhato anattato vipassati icceva vuttaṃ. Napana vuttaṃ kriyābyākate niruddhe vipāko
analyzed: dukkhataḥ anattataḥ vipassati icca eva vuttam na pana vuttam kriyā byākate niruddhe vipākaḥ
translated: But when a kriyā-javana has ceased, its result🔽arises with that as its object.

original: tadārammaṇatā uppajjatīti. Yadi cetaṃ vucceyya tadārammaṇameva padhānaṃ kataṃnāma
analyzed: tad ārammaṇa tā uppajjati iti yadi ca itam vucceyya tad ārammaṇam eva padhānam kataṃnāma
translated: And if this were said, then the act of predominance would be done by the object itself.🔽But even though this is not said, still the seeing of it is included by the words “he sees that” .

original: siyā. Avuttepica tasmiṃ vipassatīti iminā tadārammaṇaṃpi gahitameva hotīti. Tasmā🔽yaṃ vuttaṃ paṭṭhāne kusalā.La. Uppajjatīti kusalākusalānantarameva tadārammaṇaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: siyā a vutte pi ca tasmin vipassati iti iminā tad ārammaṇam pi gahitam eva hoti iti tasmā  yat vuttam paṭṭhāne kusala ālaḥ uppajjati iti kusala akusala anantaram eva tad ārammaṇam vuttam
translated: So it is said

original: Na abyākatānantarantica. Vijjamāneca tasmiṃ avacane kāraṇaṃ natthīti ca vuttaṃ. Taṃ🔽na yujjatiyeva. Anantarapaccayavibhaṅgesu pana kusalaṃ vuṭṭhānassa akusalaṃ vuṭṭhānassa🔽kriyaṃ vuṭṭhānassātica vipākadhammadhammā khandhā vuṭṭhānassa nevavipāka nāvipākadhammadhammā
analyzed: na vijjamāne ca tasmin avacane kāraṇam natthi iti ca vuttam tam  na yujjatiyā iva anantara paccaya vibhaṅgesu pana kusalam vuṭṭhānassa akusalam vuṭṭhānassa  kriyam vuṭṭhānassa ati ca vipāka dhamma dhammā khandhāḥ vuṭṭhānassa na iva vipāka na avipāka dhamma dhammā
translated: in the Paṭṭhāna that “The profitable arises with the profitable as its condition” and “The unprofitable arises with the unprofitable as its condition” and “The indeterminate arises with the indeterminate as its condition” and “The profitable arises with the unprofitable as its condition” and “The unprofitable arises with the profitable as its condition” and “The indeterminate arises with the profitable as its condition” and “The indeterminate arises with the unprofitable as its condition” and “The profitable and the unprofitable arise with the indeterminate as their condition” and “The profitable and the indeterminate arise with the unprofitable as their condition” and “The unprofitable and the indeterminate arise with the profitable as their condition” and “The profitable and the unprofitable arise with the indeterminate as their condition” and “The profitable and the unprofitable and the indeterminate arise with the unprofitable as their condition” and “The profitable and the unprofitable and the indeterminate arise with the profitable as their condition” and “The profitable and the unprofitable and the indeterminate arise with the indeterminate as their condition” .

original: khandhā vuṭṭhānassātica evamādinā kriyajavanānantaraṃ bhavaṅgena saha tadārammaṇassapi
analyzed: khandhāḥ evamādinā kriya javana anantaram bhavaṅgena saha tad ārammaṇassa api
translated: And it is said that “The profitable arises with the profitable as its condition” and “The unprofitable arises with the unprofitable as its condition” and “The indeterminate arises with the indeterminate as its condition” and “The profitable arises with the unprofitable as its condition” and “The unprofitable arises with the profitable as its condition” and “The indeterminate arises with the profitable as its condition” and “The indeterminate arises with the unprofitable as its condition” and “The profitable and the unprofitable arise with the indeterminate as their condition” and “The profitable and the indeterminate arise with the unprofitable as their condition” and “The unprofitable and the indeterminate arise with the profitable as their condition” and “The profitable and the unprofitable arise with the indeterminate as their condition” and “The profitable and the unprofitable and the indeterminate arise with the unprofitable as their condition” and “The profitable and the unprofitable and the indeterminate arise with the profitable as their condition” and “The profitable and the unprofitable and the indeterminate arise with the indeterminate as their condition” .

original: vuṭṭhānanāmena vuttaṭṭhānaṃ dissatiyeva. Tasmā yañca vuttaṃ na katthaci kriyānantaraṃ
analyzed: vuṭṭhāna nāmena vutta ṭṭhānam tasmai yat ca vuttam na katthaci kriyā anantaram
translated: The place where the object of the next consciousness is stated by the name of the consciousness that arises is seen.

original: tadārammaṇassa vuttaṭṭhānaṃ dissatīti. Taṃpi na yujjatiyeva. Naca chaḷaṅgupekkhāva🔽to khīṇāsavassa santavuttipi kriyajavanaṃ savipphārikaṃ na hoti. Kusalajavanassa
analyzed: tad ārammaṇassa vutta ṭṭhānam dissati iti tat pi na yujjatiyā iva na ca chaḷaṅgu pekkhā va  khīṇa āsavassa kriya javanam sa vipphārikam na hoti kusala javanassa
translated: Therefore what was said, namely, “And the place where the object of the next consciousness is stated is not seen after any of the kinds of registration,” is not correct.🔽And the six kinds of equanimity are not registration.

original: viya tassapi oḷārikakāyavacī payogasamuṭṭhā panatoti.
analyzed: viya oḷārika kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhā panatoti
translated: So the bodily and verbal activities of one whose cankers are destroyed are not registration, though they are functional consciousness with reaction.

original: [135] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana🔽Ṭīkāvādassa uttaraṃ vadantena yaṃ vuttaṃ “yadi abyākatā nantaraṃpi tadārammaṇaṃ vucceyya.
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana  ṭīkā vādassa uttaram vadantena yam vuttam yadi abyākatā anantaram pi tad ārammaṇam
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī-ṭīkā,

original: Parittārammaṇe voṭṭhabbanā nantaraṃpi tassa pavattiṃ maññeyyunti kriyajavanānantaraṃ
analyzed: paritta ārammaṇe voṭṭhabbana anantaram pi tassa pavattim maññeyyuḥ ti kriya javana anantaram
translated: in the answer to the question in the ṭīkā, it is said: “If registration were mentioned after the indeterminate, they would think that it occurred after the adverting whose object is limited.🔽So the object of registration is not mentioned after functional consciousness.”

original: tadā rammaṇaṃ na vutta”nti. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: tadā rammaṇam na vuttan ti tam na sundaram
translated: That is not good.

original: Na hi paṭṭhāne imasmiṃ vutte idaṃnāma maññeyyunti avuttaṃnāma atthi. Na ca arahā
analyzed: na hi paṭṭhāne imasmin vutte idaṃnāma maññeyyunti avuttaṃnāma atthi na ca arahā
translated: For when this is stated in the Paṭṭhāna, there is nothing not mentioned that they would have to think of.

original: kusalaṃ aniccato dukkhato anattato vipassatītiādinā vipassanācāravasena vuttaṭṭhāne
analyzed: kusalam aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ anattataḥ vipassati itiādinā vipassanā ācāra vasena vutta ṭṭhāne
translated: When it is said in the way beginning, “He contemplates as impermanent, as painful, as not self, what is profitable” ,

original: pañcadvārika parittārammaṇa vārapasaṅgo atthīti. Domanassa.La. Upekkhā sahagatāneva
analyzed: pañca dvārika paritta ārammaṇa vāra pasaṅgo atthi iti domanassala upekkhā sahagatāna eva
translated: there is the inclusion of the limited object of the five doors.

original: bhavanti. Na somanassasahagatāni. Kasmā, somanassa domanassānaṃ aññamaññaviruddhattā.🔽Teneva hi paṭṭhāne tesaṃ itarītarānantarapaccayatā navuttāti. Etthaca kriyajavana
analyzed: bhavanti na somanassa sahagatāni kasmā somanassa domanassānam aññamañña viruddha ttā  tena iva hi paṭṭhāne tesam itarītara anantara paccaya tā ettha ca
translated: They are only associated with equanimity, not with joy. Why? Because joy and grief are mutually incompatible.🔽And that is why in the Paṭṭhāna their conditionality as prenascence, postnascence, and repetition condition is stated in the affirmative, while their conditionality as proximity condition is stated in the negative.

original: domanassajavanāna meva anantaraṃ tadārammaṇa niyamaṃ dassentena therena itaresaṃ
analyzed: anantaram tad ārammaṇa niyamam dassentena therena itaresam
translated: And here the Elder Thera, by showing the restriction to the object of the grief-notion and the grief-root impulsions only,

original: kusalākusalajavanānaṃ anantaraṃ pana tādiso niyamo natthīti dassito hoti. Tasmā aṭṭhannaṃ
analyzed: kusala akusala javanānam anantaram pana tādisaḥ niyamaḥ natthi iti dassitaḥ hoti tasmai aṭṭhannam
translated: has shown that there is no such restriction in the case of the other profitable and unprofitable impulsions.🔽So all the life-continuum consciousnesses that are the object of the grief-notion and the grief-root impulsions occur as the registration of the object of those impulsions, and they occur as the life-continuum after eighteen kinds of impulsion, that is to say,

original: kāmakusalānaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ lobhamūlānaṃ dvinnaṃ mohamūlānanti aṭṭhārasannaṃ javanānaṃ
analyzed: kāma kusalānam aṭṭhannam lobha mūlānam dvinnam moha mūlānanti aṭṭhārasannam javanānam
translated: after the eight kinds of sense-desire-sphere unprofitable, the eight rooted in greed, and the two rooted in delusion.

original: anantaraṃ ārammaṇānurūpaṃ sabbāni tadārammaṇāni bhavaṅgāni ca pavattanti. Yebhuyyena
analyzed: anantaram ārammaṇa anurūpam sabbāni tad ārammaṇāni bhavaṅgāni ca pavattanti yebhuyyena
translated: For the most part,

original: pana akusalajavanānantaraṃ tadārammaṇaṃ ahetukameva. Dvihetukajavanānantaraṃ dvihetukameva.🔽Tihetukajavanānantaraṃ tihetukamevāti ayaṃ yebhuyyaniyamo. Yassa pana dvihetukānivā
analyzed: pana akusala javana anantaram tad ārammaṇam ahetukam eva dvi hetuka javana anantaram dvi hetukam eva  ti hetuka javana anantaram ti hetukam eva ati ayam yebhuyya niyamaḥ yassa pana
translated: But after unprofitable impulsions, it is only the non-root-causeless kind that occurs. After impulsions with two roots, it is only the two-rooted kind that occurs.

original: tihetukānivā kusalajavanāni bahulaṃ samudācaranti. Tassa kadāci akusalajavanesu javitesu🔽akusalānantaraṃpi dvihetukānivā tihetukānivātadārammaṇāni pavattanti. Yassa akusalajavanāni🔽bahulaṃ samudācaranti. Tassa kadāci dvihetukesuvā tihetukesuvā kusalajavanesu javitesu
analyzed: ti hetukāni iva kusala javanāni bahulam samudācaranti tassa kadāci akusala javanesu javitesu  akusala anantaram pi dvi hetukāni vā ti hetukāni vā tad ārammaṇāni pavattanti yassa akusala javanāni  bahulam samudācaranti tassa kadāci dvi hetukesu vā ti hetukesu vā kusala javanesu javitesu
translated: After impulsions with three roots, it is only the three-rooted kind that occurs. This is the general rule. But in the case of one in whom profitable impulsions with two roots or with three roots are frequently repeated, then sometimes, after unprofitable impulsions have been impulsed, the two-rooted or three-rooted kinds occur after the unprofitable ones.

original: kusalānantaraṃpi ahetukatadārammaṇāni pavattanti. Vuttañhetaṃ paṭṭhāne-ahetuke khandhe🔽aniccato.La. Domanassaṃ uppajjati. Kusalākusale niruddhe sahetuko vipāko tadā rammaṇatā
