original: pana parittārammaṇānevāti natesaṃ avasāne tadārammaṇuppatti pasaṅgo atthi. Abhiññājavanānica
analyzed: pana paritta ārammaṇāni eva ati na tesam avasāne tad ārammaṇa uppatti pasaṅgaḥ atthi abhiññā javanāni ca
translated: So there is no possibility of their being followed by the arising of the object of the fine-material-sphere and supramundane javanas.🔽And some of the javanas of the path have a limited object.

original: kānici parittārammaṇānipi santatarāni hontīti tesaṃpi avasāne taduppatti natthiyevāti.
analyzed: kānici paritta ārammaṇāni pi santatarāni honti iti tesam pi avasāne tad uppatti
translated: So there is no arising of the object of the path javanas at the end of them either.

original: [137] Etena
analyzed: etena
translated: By this

original: Ajanakattā janaka samānattābhāvatotiādipi paṭikkhittaṃ hoti.
analyzed: ajanaka ttā janaka samāna ttā abhāvato ti ādi pi paṭikkhittam hoti
translated: it is also refuted that the object of the fine-material-sphere and supramundane javanas cannot be the object of the javanas of the sense sphere because they are not its source, because they are not the same as its source, and so on.

original: Kāmāvacarasattānaṃeva tadārammaṇaṃ icchanti. Na rūpārūpasattānaṃ. Na hi tesu uppannānaṃ🔽parittārammaṇānaṃpi kāmāvacarajavanānaṃ avasāne tadārammaṇuppatti atthi. Tadārammaṇūpa
analyzed: kāmāvacara sattānam eva tad ārammaṇam icchanti na rūpa arūpa sattānam na hi tesu uppannānam  paritta ārammaṇānaṃ pi kāmāvacara javanānaṃ avasāne tad ārammaṇa uppatti atthi tad ārammaṇa upa
translated: They want it to be the object of only the beings in the sense-desire world, not of those in the fine-material and immaterial worlds. For when the sense-desire-world impulsions, which are limited objects, arise in the latter,🔽the appearance of the object of the registration does not occur at the end of them.🔽

original: nissayassa kāma bhavaṅgassa abhāvato mahaggata bhavaṅgassa ca santa tarassa tadārammaṇa🔽kiccā bhāvatoti. Cakkhuviññāṇa sota viññāṇāni pana rūpasattānaṃ cakkhusotaindriya
analyzed: nissayassa kāma bhavaṅgassa abhāvataḥ mahaggata bhavaṅgassa ca santa tarassa tad ārammaṇa  kiccā bhāvato ti cakkhu viññāṇa sota viññāṇāni pana rūpa sattānam cakkhu sota aindriya
translated: They want it to have only the beings of the sense sphere as its object, not those of the fine-material and immaterial spheres. For when the sense-desire-sphere javanas that have a limited object arise in those two spheres, there is no occurrence of the registration that has them as its object. Because there is no sense-desire-sphere life-continuum that is the support for the registration, and because the fine-material-sphere life-continuum is peaceful and sublime and so cannot have that function.

original: pavattiānubhāvato sampaṭicchanasantīraṇānica dvāravīthibhede cittaniyamasiddhito🔽rūpasattesu pavattanti yevāti. Kāmāvacaradhammesveva ārammaṇabhūtesu tadārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: pavatti ānubhāvataḥ dvāra vīthi bhede citta niyama siddhitaḥ  rūpa sattesu pavattanti yā iva ati kāmāvacara dhammesu eva ārammaṇa bhūtesu tad ārammaṇam
translated: But eye-consciousness and ear-consciousness occur in beings of the fine-material sphere because of the influence of the operation of the eye and ear faculties there. And the receiving and investigating consciousnesses occur in beings of the fine-material sphere because of the establishment of the rule that consciousness occurs in a door.

original: icchanti, na mahaggatānuttarapaññattidhammesu. Ekantaparittārammaṇattā tadārammaṇānaṃ.
analyzed: icchanti na mahaggata anuttara paññatti dhammesu ekanta paritta ārammaṇa ttā tad ārammaṇānam
translated: They want the registration to have only the states of the sense sphere as its object, not the states of the fine-material and immaterial spheres and the supramundane. Because the registrations have only a limited object.

original: Tesaṃ pana ekantaparittā rammaṇabhāve kāraṇaṃ heṭṭhā vuttamevāti.
analyzed: tesam pana ekanta parittāḥ ārammaṇa bhāve kāraṇam heṭṭhā vuttam eva ati
translated: The reason for their having only a limited object has already been given above.

original: [138] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhānga it is said:

original: “Aparicitattā”ti kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃ akāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: a paricita ttā iti kāraṇam vuttam tam akāraṇam
translated: The reason given is that it is not familiar. But that is no reason.

original: Cittañhi nāma vikappabalevā appanāpattabhāvanākammavisese vā sati nibbāne viya aparicitepi ārammaṇe pavattatiyevāti.
analyzed: cittam hi nāma vikappa balā iva appanā āpatta bhāvanā kamma visese vā sati nibbāne viya a paricite api ārammaṇe pavattatiyā iva āti
translated: For mind occurs even with regard to an unfamiliar object if there is the special development of the act of adverting or the power of the change-of-lineage.

original: [139] Yañca vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yañca vibhāvaniyam
translated: And the reason given in the Vibhāvinī-Țīkā, namely,

original: “Kāmataṇhāyattakammajanitattāpī”ti kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃpi heṭṭhā paṭikkhittameva.
analyzed: kāma taṇhā āyatta kamma janita ttā api iti kāraṇam vuttam tat pi heṭṭhā paṭikkhittam eva
translated: that it is produced by kamma accompanied by craving for sensual pleasures, is also rejected below.

original: Teneva hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ kiṃvā etāya yutticintāyāti vatvā sabbāni vibhāvaniyaṃ vutta
analyzed: tena iva hi aṭṭhakathā ayam kiṃvā etāya yutti cintāya ati vatvā sabbāni
translated: For that is why, after saying, “What is the use of this kind of reasoning? ” all the reasons given in the Vibhāvinī-Țīkā

original: kāraṇāni paṭikkhittānīti.🔽Kāme javana sattālambaṇānaṃ niyamesatīti kāmabhūmipariyāpannānaṃ javanānaṃ sattānaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇāni paṭikkhittāni iti  niyamesati iti kāmabhūmi pariyāpannānam javanānam sattānam
translated: are rejected.🔽It determines the occurrence of the six kinds of consciousness in the sense sphere, and the occurrence of the object in the three ways,

original: ārammaṇānañca vasena tividhe niyame sati. Vibhūte timahanteca tadārammaṇamīritanti
analyzed: vasena tividhe niyame sati vibhūte tat ārammaṇam īritan ti
translated: and it is the object of the great, and it is called the object of what is past.

original: etena tadārammaṇaṃnāma pavattamānaṃ vibhūtārammaṇevā atimahantārammaṇe vā pavattatīti
analyzed: etena tat ārammaṇam nāma pavattamānam ati mahanta ārammaṇe vā pavattati iti
translated: By this he shows that the object of what is past is only an object of what is past, or it is an object of what is great, when it occurs in one who is in the fine-material sphere.

original: ayameva niyamo dassito. Na pana yattha tadā rammaṇaṃ pavattati. Etadeva vibhūtañca🔽atimahantañca nāmāti niyamo. Tasmā uḷārakammanibbattānaṃ suvisadavatthukānaṃ rūpabrahmānaṃ
analyzed: ayam eva niyamaḥ dassitaḥ na pana yattha tad ā rammaṇam pavattati etat eva vibhūtam ca  ati mahantam ca nāma ati niyamaḥ tasmai uḷāra kamma nibbattānam su visada vatthukānam rūpa brahmānam
translated: but this is the only rule shown. It is not that the object is only what occurs then. This is the only rule:🔽it is the object that is called ‘great’ and ‘very great.’🔽Therefore the courses of the material-sphere Brahmās, who are born of exalted kamma and have a very pure physical support,

original: uppannāvīthiyo yebhuyyena vibhūtārammaṇāeva atimahantā rammaṇāevaca hontīti veditabbā.🔽Keci pana imamatthaṃ asallakkhetvā rūpārūpabhūmīsu vibhūtārammaṇavīthiyo atimahantārammaṇavīthiyoca
analyzed: uppannā vīthiyaḥ yebhuyyena vibhūta ārammaṇāḥ eva ati mahantāḥ rammaṇāḥ eva ca honti iti veditabbā  keci pana imam attham a sat lakkhetvā rūpa arūpa bhūmīsu vibhūta ārammaṇa vīthiyaḥ atimahanta ārammaṇa vīthiyaḥ ca
translated: should be understood to be for the most part very great and very great objects.

original: nalabbhantīti vadanti. [Tadārammaṇaniyamo].🔽140. Javanesucāti casaddo pana saddattho. Chakkhattu mevavā javanti. Pakatikālepi🔽ārammaṇassa dubbalabhāve satīti adhippāyo. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃpi hi pakatikāle ārammaṇadubba
analyzed: na labbhanti iti vadanti tad ārammaṇa niyamo  javanesu ca iti ca saddo pana sadda attho chakkhattu mā iva vā javanti pakati kāle pi  ārammaṇassa dubbala bhāve sati iti adhippāyaḥ aṭṭhakathāyam pi hi pakati kāle ārammaṇa dubbala
translated: But some, without discerning the meaning, say that in the fine-material and immaterial spheres there are no courses of consciousness with a very great object and with a very great object as object.🔽The word “and” in the words “in the fine-material and immaterial, and” has the meaning of “but.” They run only six times. The intention is that even at the normal time🔽the object is weak. For in the commentary too it is said that the occurrence six times of the fine-material-sphere impulsions is due to the weakness of the object at the normal time.

original: laṭṭhāneeva kāmāvacarajavanānaṃ chakkhattuṃ pavatti vuttāti. Keci pana chakkhattunti
analyzed: kāmāvacara javanānam cha khattum pavatti vuttā ati keci pana cha khattum ti
translated: But some say that “six times” is said

original: idaṃ mucchākālavasena vuttanti maññanti. Mandavattiyanti maraṇāsannakāle bahucittakkhaṇātītakassa🔽vatthussa dubbalattā itarakālesuca mudutarabhāvena kenaci upadduta bhāvena ajjhotthaṭabhāvenaca
analyzed: idam mucchā kāla vasena vuttanti maññanti manda vattiyanti maraṇa āsanna kāle bahu citta kkhaṇa atītakassa  vatthussa dubbala ttā itara kālesu ca mudutara bhāvena kenacid upadduta bhāvena ajjhotthaṭa bhāvena ca
translated: This is said, they believe, in terms of the time of fainting. “In the case of the slow-witted” means that the object is past in many consciousness-moments at the time of the approach of death.

original: vatthussa dubbalattā tannissitānaṃ javanānaṃ mandībhūtavegatā vasena pavattikāle.
analyzed: vatthussa dubbala ttā tad nissitānam javanānam mandībhūta vega tā vasena pavatti kāle
translated: Because of the weakness of the object, and because of the slowness of the process at other times, and because of the weakness of the object, the impulsion consciousnesses that are dependent on it occur with a slow speed.

original: Maraṇakālādīsūti maraṇāsannakāle mucchākāle visaññibhūta kāle atitaruṇakāleca, tattha
analyzed: maraṇa kāla ādīsu iti maraṇa āsanna kāle mucchā kāle visaññi bhūta kāle ati taruṇa kāle ca tattha
translated: “At the time of death, etc.” means at the time of the approach of death, at the time of fainting, at the time of unconsciousness, and at the time of extreme youth. Herein,

original: mucchākālonāma asayha rūpehi dukkhadhammehi atibhūtānaṃ adhimattato karajakāyassa🔽vihaññappattikālo. Visaññi bhūtakālonāma pītivegenavā niddābhibhūtatāyavā yakkhagahaṇenavā
analyzed: rūpehi dukkha dhammehi ati bhūtānaṃ adhimattataḥ karaja kāyassa  vihañña ppatti kālo bhūtakālo nāma pīti vegena vā niddā abhibhūta tāya vā yakkha gahaṇena vā
translated: the time of fainting is the time when those who are overcome by painful things that are hard to bear are afflicted in their mortal frames.🔽The time of unconsciousness is the time when the natural consciousness is absent either through the force of rapture, or through being overcome by sleep, or through being possessed by a spirit, or through intoxication by liquor, etc.

original: surāmadādi vasenavā pakatisaññāya vigatakālo. Atitaruṇakālonāma gabbhagatassavā sampatijātassavā
analyzed: surā mada ādi vasena vā pakati saññāya vigata kālo ati taruṇa kālo nāma gabbha gatassa vā sampati jātassa vā
translated: The time of extreme youth is the time of the embryo, or the time of the newly born.

original: dārakassa ajjhatta vatthūnaṃ atimudukālo. Tādisesu hi kālesu antarantarā chadvārikavīthiyo🔽pavattamānāpi yebhuyyena paripuṇṇajavanavārā na pavattanti. Dvattivoṭṭhabbanikāvā
analyzed: dārakassa ajjhatta vatthūnam ati mudu kālaḥ tādisesu hi kālesu antarantarā chadvārika vīthiyaḥ  pavattamānā api yebhuyyena paripuṇṇa javana vārāḥ na pavattanti
translated: is the time of the child’s internal basis being too young. For at such times, though the six-door cognitive series occurs now and again,🔽the majority of the impulsions in the complete javanas do not occur.🔽

original: catupañcajavanikāevavā pavattantīti. Etthaca dvattivoṭṭhabbanikavārā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ🔽vuttā. Catupañca javanikavārā mūlaṭīkāyaṃ vuttā. Pañcavāramevāti idaṃ pana maraṇā
analyzed: pavattanti iti ettha ca aṭṭhakathā ayam  vuttā catu pañca javanika vārāḥ mūla ṭīkā āyam vuttā pañca vāram eva ati idam pana maraṇā
translated: The time when the child’s internal factors are too weak is the time when the child is in the womb. For at such times the six-door cognitive series, though occurring from time to time, does not occur for the most part with a full complement of impulsions. Only the two-impulsion and the four- or five-impulsion cognitive series occur. And here the two-impulsion cognitive series is given in the commentary,🔽and the four- or five-impulsion cognitive series is given in the subcommentary.🔽But the words “up to five times” are said with reference to the time of dying.

original: sannakālavasena vuttaṃ. Namucchākālādivasena. Tañca khopākatikasattānaṃ vaseneva.🔽Ye pana jhānasamanantaraṃvā paccavekkhaṇa samanantaraṃvā abhiññāsamanantaraṃvā cavantivā🔽parinibbāyantivā. Tesaṃ jhānādīniyeva pañcavārato adhikānivā ūnānivā maraṇā sannajavanānināma
analyzed: sanna kāla vasena vuttam namucchā kāla ādi vasena tat ca khopākatika sattānam vasena iva  ye pana jhāna samanantaram vā paccavekkhaṇa samanantaram vā abhiññā samanantaram vā cavanti vā  parinibbāyantivā tesam jhāna ādīniyā iva pañca vārataḥ adhikāni vā ūnāni vā
translated: And that is said with reference to the beings of the human species.🔽But those who die immediately after jhāna, or immediately after reviewing, or immediately after direct-knowledge, or who attain Nibbāna,🔽should be regarded as having jhāna, etc., as their five-fold or more than five-fold impulsions at the time of death, according as the jhāna, etc., are more or less than five.

original: hontīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ayañca attho upari maraṇuppattiyaṃ āvibhavissatīti. Bhagavato
analyzed: honti iti daṭṭhabbam ayam ca attho upari maraṇa uppattiyam āvibhavissati iti bhagavato
translated: And this matter will be made clear in the section on death and rebirth.

original: pana yamakapāṭihāriya kālādīsūti ettha aññesaṃpi mahāmoggalānattherādīnaṃ evarūpo
analyzed: pana kāla ādīsu iti ettha aññesam pi mahāmoggalānatthera ādīnam evarūpaḥ
translated: But in the Yamaka-pāṭihāriya, etc., there were other great disciples such as the Elder Mahā-Moggallāna,🔽

original: lahuppavattikālo ādisaddena saṅgahitoti daṭṭhabbo. Vuttañhi visuddhimagge ayaṃ pana
analyzed: lahu ppavatti kālaḥ ādi saddena saṅgahitaḥ ti daṭṭhabbaḥ vuttam hi visuddhimagge ayam pana
translated: But in the case of the Twin Miracle, etc., the time of occurrence is quick, etc.,’ here the time of occurrence of such a miracle for other great disciples such as the Elder Moggallāna is included by the word ‘etc.’. For this is said in the Path of Purification:

original: matthakapattā vasī bhagavato yamakapāṭihāriye labbhati. Aññesaṃvā evarūpe kāleti.🔽Sakalena pana vākyena thapetvā yamakapāṭihāriyasadisaṃ lahuka pavattikālaṃ aññasmiṃ
analyzed: matthaka pattā vasī bhagavataḥ yamaka pāṭihāriye labbhati aññesam vā evarūpe kāle ti  sakalena pana vākyena yamaka pāṭihāriya sadisam pavatti kālam aññasmin
translated: ‘But this is allowable for the Master, who has reached the summit, in the Twin Miracle. Or for others at such a time.’

original: kāle bhagavatopi chavā sattavā paccavekkhaṇacittāni pavattanti. Aññesaṃ pana vattabbameva🔽natthīti dasseti. Cattāri pañcavā paccavekkhaṇacittāni bhavantīti etthapi bhagavatopi
analyzed: kāle bhagavataḥ api chavā sattavā paccavekkhaṇa cittāni pavattanti aññesam pana vattabbam eva  natthi iti dasseti cattāri pañca vā paccavekkhaṇa cittāni bhavanti iti ettha api bhagavataḥ pi
translated: And by the whole sentence it is shown that except for the time of occurrence, which is quick in the case of the Twin Miracle, in other cases the Master’s consciousnesses occur seven or six times,🔽but in the case of others there is no need to mention it.

original: lahukappavattiyaṃ pañca paccavekkhaṇacittāni bhavanti. Lahukatarapavattiyaṃ cattārīti
analyzed: lahuka ppavattiyam pañca paccavekkhaṇa cittāni bhavanti lahukatara pavattiyam cattāri iti
translated: In the passage ‘There are four or five contemplations of foulness’ the Master’s consciousnesses occur five times when the occurrence is quick and four times when it is quicker,

original: atthopi yujjatiyeva.
analyzed: a tthaḥ pi yuj jatiyā iva
translated: and the meaning is appropriate in this way too.

original: Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī it is said:

original: Bhagavato cattāri aññesaṃ pañcapīti yuttaṃ viya dissatīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bhagavato cattāri aññesam pañca pīti yuttam viya dissati iti vuttam
translated: ‘It seems right to say that the Master’s are four and those of others five.’

original: Tattha yamakapāṭihāriyaṃ karonto bhagavā aggikkhandhaudaka dhārādīnaṃ dvinnaṃ dvinnaṃ🔽pāṭihāriyānaṃ pavattanatthaṃ pathamaṃ tejokasiṇe pādakajjhānaṃ samāpajji. Tato dve
analyzed: tattha yamaka pāṭihāriyam karontaḥ bhagavā dhārā ādīnam dvinnam dvinnam  pāṭihāriyānam pavattana attham pathamam tejaḥ kasiṇe pādakajjhānam samāpajji tatas dve
translated: Herein, when performing the Twin Marvel, the Blessed One first attained jhāna in the fire kasiṇa in order to bring about the occurrence of the two pairs of marvels beginning with the fire-ball and the water miracle.

original: jhānaṅgāni paccavekkhi. Tato uparimakāyato aggikkhandho pavattatūti adhiṭṭhāsi. Tato🔽tasmiṃyeva kasiṇe abhiññaṃ samāpajji. Abhiññāvasena uparimakāyato aggikkhandho pavattati.🔽Tato āpokasiṇe pādakajjhānaṃ samāpajji. Tato dve jhānaṅgāni paccavekkhi. Tato heṭṭhimakāyato🔽udakadhārā pavattantūti adhiṭṭhāsi. Tato tasmiṃyeva kasiṇe abhiññaṃ samāpajji. Abhiññāvasena
analyzed: jhāna aṅgāni paccavekkhi tatas uparima kāyataḥ aggi kkhandho pavattatu iti adhiṭṭhāsi tatas  tasmin yeva kasiṇe abhiññam samāpajji abhiññā vasena uparima kāyataḥ aggi kkhandho pavattati  tatas āpokasiṇe pādakajjhānam samāpajji tatas dve jhāna aṅgāni paccavekkhi tatas heṭṭhima kāyato  udaka dhārāḥ pavattantu iti adhiṭṭhāsi tatas tasmin yeva kasiṇe abhiññam samāpajji abhiññā vasena
translated: Herein, when performing the Twin Marvel, the Blessed One first attained jhāna in the fire kasiṇa in order to bring about the occurrence of the two pairs of marvels beginning with the fire-ball and the water-stream. Then he reviewed the two jhāna factors. Then he resolved: “Let there be a fire-ball coming out from the upper part of my body.” Then he attained the supernormal power in that same kasiṇa. By means of the supernormal power the fire-ball came out from the upper part of his body.

original: heṭṭhima kāyato udakadhārā pavattanti. Sesayamakesupi eseva nayo. Etthaca lahukappavattiyā
analyzed: udaka dhārā pavattanti sesa yamakesu pi esa iva nayaḥ ettha ca lahuka ppavattiyā
translated: Then he attained jhāna in the water kasiṇa. Then he reviewed the two jhāna factors. Then he resolved: “Let there be a water-stream coming out from the lower part of my body.” Then he attained the supernormal power in that same kasiṇa. By means of the supernormal power the water-stream came out from the lower part of his body. The same method applies in the case of the rest of the marvels. And here the order of the marvels is given according to the order in which they are easy to do.

original: icchitattā dve dve paccavekkhaṇavārā catupañcajavanikāeva bhavanti. Dvinnañca javanavārānaṃ
analyzed: dve dve paccavekkhaṇa vārā bhavanti
translated: Since they are wished for, the two sets of two contemplations are only four and five impulsions. And between the two sets of impulsions

original: antarā dve eva bhavaṅgāni bhavanti. Tānica dve pāṭihāriyāni passantānaṃ ekappahāreneva🔽pavattāni viya paññāyantīti. Etarahi pana keci ādikammikajjhānapaccavekkhaṇesupi
analyzed: antarā dve eva bhavaṅgāni bhavanti tāni ca dve pāṭihāriyāni passantānam eka pahārena iva  pavattāni viya paññāyanti iti etarahi pana keci ādi kammika jhāna paccavekkhaṇesu pi
translated: there are only two life-continua. And those two are known as occurring in a single moment to those who see the two miracles.🔽But some at present say that there are four or five impulsions in the case of the beginner’s and the jhāya’s contemplations.

original: cattāri pañcavājavanāni vadanti. Ādikammikassāti yogakammasiddhiyā ādimhi niyuttassa.
analyzed: cattāri pañca vājavanāni vadanti ādikammikassa ati yoga kamma siddhiyāḥ ādimhi niyuttassa
translated: The beginner: one who is occupied with the beginning of the success of the exercise.🔽The first occurrence of absorption is the first occurrence of the absorption. In that first occurrence of the absorption:

original: Pathamaṃ uppannā appanā pathamakappanā. Tassaṃ pathamakappanāyaṃ. Ādikammikaappanāvīthiyanti
analyzed: pathamam uppannā appanā pathama kappanā tassam pathama kappanā ayam ādikammika appanā vīthiyanti
translated: the meaning is, in the course of the first occurrence of the absorption.

original: attho. Tadā hi sabbānipi mahaggatajavanāni puna āsevanābhāvato paridubbalāni hontīti🔽ekavārameva javantīti. Abhiññājavanāni pana iddhivikubbanādi. Kiccasiddhiyāeva payuttānīti
analyzed: attho tadā hi sabbāni api mahaggata javanāni puna āsevana abhāvataḥ paridubbalāni honti iti  eka vāram eva javanti iti abhiññā javanāni pana iddhi vikubbana ādi kicca siddhiyā eva payuttāni iti
translated: For then all the exalted impulsions are very weak because they have not been practiced again.🔽So they only impel once. But the kinds of direct-knowledge impulsions are only occupied with the success of the exercise consisting of the miracles of supernormal power, etc.

original: kiccasiddhito paraṃ kattabbābhāvato ādikammikakālepi vasībhūtakālepi ekavārameva
analyzed: kicca siddhitaḥ param kattabba abhāvataḥ ādikammika kāle api vasībhūta kāle api eka vāram eva
translated: So they only impel once, whether at the time of the beginner’s practice or at the time of mastery, because there is nothing more to be done after the success of the exercise.

original: javantīti vuttaṃ abhiññājavanānica sabbadāpīti. Yathāca abhiññājavanādi evaṃ maggajavanānipi🔽taṃ taṃ kilesappahānakiccasiddhito paraṃ kattabbā bhāvato ekavārameva javantīti vuttaṃ
analyzed: javanti iti vuttam abhiññā javanāni ca sabbadā api iti yathā ca abhiññā javana ādi evam magga javanāni pi  tam tam kilesa ppahāna kicca siddhitaḥ param kattabbāḥ bhāvataḥ eka vāram eva javanti iti vuttam
translated: And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.

original: cattāro pana.La. Eka cittakkhaṇikāvāti. Athavā, maggacetanāya anantarikaphalattā🔽sakiṃ uppanneyeva magge phalassavāro āvatoti natthi maggacittassa punuppattiyā okāsoti
analyzed: cattāro athavā magga cetanāya anantarika phala ttā  sakim uppanne yeva magge phala savāro āvato ti natthi magga cittassa punuppattiyā okāso ti
translated: And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.🔽And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.

original: vuttaṃ cattāro pana.La. Ekacittakkhaṇikāvāti. Javanuppattiyā pakatiyā sattakkhuparamattā🔽mandassa pañcamaṃ uppannamaggato paraṃ dve phalacittāni uppajjanti. Tikkhassa catutthaṃ
analyzed: vuttam cattāro javan uppattiyā pakatiyā satta kkhu parama ttā  mandassa pañcamam uppanna maggataḥ param dve phala cittāni uppajjanti tikkhassa catuttham
translated: And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.🔽And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.🔽And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.🔽And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.🔽And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.🔽And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.🔽And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.🔽And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.🔽And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.🔽And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.

original: uppannamaggato paraṃ tīṇīti vuttaṃ tato paraṃ.La. Uppajjantīti. Nirodhasamāpattikāle🔽pana pubbabhāgeyeva tādi sassa payogābhisaṅkhārassa katattā dvinnaṃ vārānaṃ upari
analyzed: uppanna maggataḥ param tīṇi iti vuttam tatas uppajjanti iti nirodha samāpatti kāle 🔽pana sassa payoga abhisaṅkhārassa kata ttā dvinnam vārānam upari
translated: And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges’ because they are the direct knowledge of the three kinds of object” are said.🔽And the words “but they are called ‘direct-knowledges

original: cittappavatti natthīti vuttaṃ nirodha.La. Javatīti. Etthaca dvikkhattunti idaṃ ukkaṭṭha
analyzed: citta pavatti natthi iti vuttam ettha ca dvi khattum ti idam ukkaṭṭha
translated: “There is no occurrence of consciousness” is said because of cessation.🔽“Twice” is said here in terms of the maximum number.

original: niddesavasena vuttaṃ. Ekaṃvā dvevā cittavāre atikkamitvā acittako hotīti hi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: niddesa vasena vuttam ekam vā dve vā citta vāre atikkamitvā acittakaḥ hoti iti hi vuttam
translated: For it is said that “after one or two consciousness-moments he becomes without consciousness.”

original: Catutthāruppajavananti anāgāmino kusalabhūtaṃ arahato kriyabhūtaṃ nevasaññānāsaññā
analyzed: anāgāmino kusala bhūtam arahato kriya bhūtam nevasaññānāsaññā
translated: “The fourth immaterial-sphere impulsions” are the profitable impulsions of the non-returner and the functional impulsions of the Arahant in the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: yatana javanaṃ. Vuṭṭhānakāleca nirodhassa nisandamattattā ekavārameva vajanaṃ pavattatīti
analyzed: vuṭṭhāna kāle ca nirodhassa nisanda matta ttā eka vāram eva vajanam pavattati iti
translated: And since the outlet of cessation is only a threshold, the impulsion occurs only once at the time of the outlet.🔽That is why it is said, “At the time of the outlet … .”

original: vuttaṃ vuṭṭhānakālecātiādi. Tattha anāgāmi phalaṃvā arahattaphalaṃvāti anāgāmiphalevā
analyzed: vuttam vuṭṭhāna kāle ca atiādi tattha anāgāmi phalam vā arahatta phalam vā ti anāgāmi phalā iva
translated: Herein, “the fruition attainment of non-return or Arahantship” is the fruition attainment of the non-returner or the fruition attainment of the Arahant.🔽The word “itself” is a demonstrative pronoun referring to the characteristic of the state of being a fruition attainment.

original: arahattaphalevā. Bhāvena bhāvalakkhaṇe hetaṃ paccattavacanaṃ. Tenāha niruddheti.
analyzed: arahatta phala iva bhāvena bhāva lakkhaṇe hetam paccatta vacanam tena āha niruddha iti
translated: That is why it is said, “Cessation … has ceased.”

original: Sabbatthāpi samāpattivīthiyanti jhānasamāpatti phalasamāpattivasena sakalāyapi samāpattivīthiyaṃ.
analyzed: sabbattha api samāpatti vīthiyan ti jhāna samāpatti phala samāpatti vasena sakalāya api samāpatti vīthiyam
translated: “In the whole course of the attainment” is in the whole course of the attainment consisting of the jhāna attainment and the fruition attainment.🔽“There is no interval” means that there is no interval in the course of the attainment as there is in the course of the life-continuum.

original: Bhavaṅgasotoviya vīthiniya mo natthīti idaṃ ciṇṇavasībhūtakālaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vīthiniya mo natthi iti idam sandhāya vuttam
translated: This is said with reference to the time when mastery has been obtained.

original: Akatā dhikārassa pana jhānasamāpattiyaṃ ādito paṭṭhāya dve tīṇi cattārītiādinā jhānajavanāni
analyzed: a kata a dhikārassa pana jhāna samāpattiyam āditaḥ paṭṭhāya dve tīṇi cattāri iti ādinā jhāna javanāni
translated: But in the case of one who has not made the resolution, the impulsions of jhāna, which are two, three, four, and so on, occur in succession from the beginning,

original: anukkamena vaddhamānāni pavattanti. Katā dhikārānaṃ pana mahāpurisajātikānaṃ paṭiladdhakālato🔽paṭṭhāya ciṇṇavasībhāvāneva honti. Tathā phalajavanānica sabbesaṃpi phalaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: anukkamena vaddha mānāni pavattanti katā adhikārānam pana mahāpurisa jātikānam paṭiladdha kālataḥ  paṭṭhāya honti tathā phala javanāni ca sabbesam pi phala ṭṭhānanti
translated: increasing in number. But in the case of one who has made the resolution, and of those of great mental power, they are all of them mastered from the time of their acquisition,🔽and they are all of them present in one who has reached fruition.🔽The word “also” in the words “many kinds of fruition consciousness also” includes the rest of the kinds that occur in the first stage, etc.,

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Bahūnipīti pisaddo sampiṇḍanattho. Tena ādikammikakālādīsu ekavārādivasenapi🔽avasesānaṃ pavattiṃ sampiṇḍetīti. [Jānaniyamo].🔽141. Evaṃ pubbāparaniyāmavasena vīthicittānaṃ pavattiṃ dassetvā idāni puggalabhedavasena
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam bahūni pi iti pi saddaḥ sampiṇḍana atthaḥ tena ādi kammika kāla ādīsu eka vāra ādi vasena api  avasesānam pavattim sampiṇḍeti iti  evam pubba apara niyāma vasena vīthi cittānam pavattim dassetvā idāni puggala bheda vasena
translated: by single or multiple occurrence.

original: bhūmibhedavasenaca tesaṃ pavattiṃ dassento duhetukānantiādimāha. Paṭisandhiviññāṇasahagatā
analyzed: bhūmi bheda vasena ca tesam pavattim dassentaḥ du hetukānaṃ ti ādim āha paṭisandhi viññāṇa sahagatā
translated: Having thus shown the occurrence of the kinds of consciousness in the cognitive series according to the order of priority and posteriority, he now said “With two causes” in order to show their occurrence according to the division of persons and according to the division of planes.🔽Those that have two causes are those that have two causes together with rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: dve hetuyo etesanti duhetukā. Catūhi ñāṇavippa yuttamahāvipākehi gahitapaṭisandhikā.
analyzed: dve dve hetuyo catūhi ñāṇa vippa yutta mahā vipākehi gahita paṭisandhikā
translated: Those that have four causes are those that have four causes together with the four great resultants devoid of knowledge.

original: Dvīhi pana ahetuka vipākehi gahita paṭisandhikā ahetukā natthi paṭisandhihetu etesanti
analyzed: dvīhi pana ahetuka vipākehi gahita paṭisandhikā ahetukā natthi paṭisandhi hetu etesanti
translated: But there is no rebirth-linking of the kind called “without root-cause” that is included among the two kinds called “with root-cause” and “without root-cause” that is a result.

original: katvā. Tesaṃ dvinnaṃpi vipākāvaraṇasabbhāvato mahagga tajjhānānipi tāva nuppajjanti.
analyzed: katvā tesam dvinnam pi vipāka āvaraṇa sabbhāvataḥ mahagga tad jhānāni pi tāva nuppajjanti
translated: So it is said that “the two great paths of jhāna do not arise in them because of the similarity of the obscuration that is a result.”

original: Kuto lokuttarāni. Kriyajavanāni pana khīṇāsavānameva āvenika bhūtānīti vuttaṃ kriyajavanāni🔽cevaappanājavanānica na labbhantīti. Tattha vipākā varaṇaṃ nāma ahetuka paṭisandhikatā
analyzed: kutas lokuttarāni kriya javanāni pana khīṇa āsavānam eva bhūtāni iti vuttam kriya javanāni  na labbhanti iti tattha vipāka āvaraṇam nāma ahetuka paṭisandhika tā
translated: How much less can the supramundane! But the functional impulsions of those whose cankers are destroyed are of a kind not shared by ordinary men.🔽So it is said that “the functional impulsions and the impulsion of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception are not found in them.”🔽Herein, the obscuration that is a result is the kind of rebirth-linking called “without root-cause” and the kind called “with two root-causes.”

original: dvihetuka paṭisandhikatāca. Tathā ñāṇasampayuttavipākānica sugatiyanti sugati bhave
analyzed: dvi hetuka paṭisandhika tā ca tathā ñāṇa sampayutta vipākāni ca
translated: And so too the great results associated with knowledge that are included among those in a happy destiny.

original: pariyāpannānaṃ tesaṃ dvinnaṃ tathā ñāṇampayuttamahāvipākānica na labbhantīti attho.🔽Etthaca sugatiyanti etena duggatipariyāpanne ahetuka puggale nivatteti. Na hi tesaṃ
analyzed: pariyāpannānam tesam dvinnam tathā ñāṇam payutta mahā vipākāni ca na labbhanti iti attho  ettha ca sugatiyan ti etena duggati pariyāpanne ahetuka puggale nivatteti na hi tesam
translated: The meaning is that the great results associated with knowledge that are included among those in a happy destiny are not found in them.🔽And here the words “in a happy destiny” exclude the kind of person included among those in a unhappy destiny, for the results dissociated from knowledge that are permitted in this passage for the rest are not found in him.

original: imasmiṃ vākye itaresaṃ anuññātāni ñāṇavippayuttavipākānipi labbhantīti. Tenāha duggati
analyzed: imasmim vākye itaresam anuññātāni ñāṇa vippayutta vipākāni pi labbhanti iti tena āha duggati
translated: That is why he said “in a happy destiny” and “in a bad destiny.”

original: yaṃ panātiādi. Tattha duggatiyaṃ pariyāpannānaṃ ahetukānaṃ ñāṇasampayuttavipākānica🔽ñāṇavippayuttāni mahāvipākānica na labbhantīti paripuṇṇa yojanā daṭṭhabbā. Ettha🔽siyā. Kasmā panettha sugatipariyāpannānaṃ ahetukānaṃ cattāri ñāṇasampayuttavipākāni🔽duggatipariyāpannānañca aṭṭhapi sahetuka mahāvipākāni na labbhantīti vuttaṃ. Nanu
analyzed: yam pana atiādi tattha duggatiyam pariyāpannānam ahetukānam ñāṇa sampayutta vipākāni ca  ñāṇa vippayuttāni mahā vipākāni ca na labbhanti iti paripuṇṇa yojanā daṭṭhabbā ettha  siyā kasmā pana ittha sugati pariyāpannānam ahetukānam cattāri ñāṇa sampayutta vipākāni  duggati pariyāpannānam ca aṭṭha pi sa hetuka mahā vipākāni na labbhanti iti vuttam nanu
translated: As to the rest, etc. Herein, the four kinds of resultants associated with knowledge belonging to those without root-cause in the unhappy destinies are not found, and the eight kinds of great resultants associated with knowledge belonging to those with root-cause in the happy destinies are not found. The complete interpretation should be understood as follows.

original: paṭṭhāne sahetukaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ ahetukassa bhavaṅgassa anantarapaccayena paccayoti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: paṭṭhāne sa hetukam bhavaṅgam ahetukassa bhavaṅgassa anantara paccayena paccayaḥ ti vuttam
translated: Here it may be asked: But why is it said that the four kinds of resultants associated with knowledge belonging to those without root-cause in the happy destinies and the eight kinds of great resultants associated with knowledge belonging to those with root-cause in the unhappy destinies are not found? For is it not said in the Paṭṭhāna that “The life-continuum with root-cause is a condition, as proximity condition, for the life-continuum without root-cause”?

original: Ettha hi ekasmiṃ bhave ekassa sattassa kadāci sahetukaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ kadāci ahetukaṃ🔽bhavaṅganti evaṃ mūlabhavaṅge pavattibhedo natthīti katvā sahetukaṃ bhavaṅganti idaṃ
analyzed: ettha hi ekasmin bhave ekassa sattassa kadāci sa hetukam bhavaṅgam kadāci ahetukam  bhavaṅganti evam mūla bhavaṅge pavatti bhedaḥ na atthi iti katvā sa hetukam bhavaṅganti idam
translated: Here, in one becoming, in one being, sometimes the life-continuum is with root-cause, sometimes it is without root-cause.

original: tadārammaṇasaṅkhātaṃ āgantukabhavaṅgaṃ sandhāya vuttanti viññāyati. Sahetukantica
analyzed: tad ārammaṇa saṅkhātam āgantuka bhavaṅgam sandhāya vuttan ti viññāyati sa hetukam ti ca
translated: So there is no difference in the occurrence of the basic life-continuum. Consequently it is understood that this statement is made with reference to the adventitious life-continuum called “registration” . And the “with root-cause” is said

original: sāmaññavacanattā dvihetukaṃ tihetukañca tadārammaṇaṃ viññātabbaṃ hoti. Ahetukassa
analyzed: sāmañña vacana ttā dvi hetukam ti hetukañca tad ārammaṇam viññātabbam hoti ahetukassa
translated: and because of the general statement, it should be understood that the two kinds of consciousness with two root-causes and with three root-causes have that as object.

original: bhavaṅgassāti idha pana tassa tadārammaṇassa anantaraṃ uppannaṃ mūlabhavaṅgameva
analyzed: bhavaṅgassa ati idha pana tassa tad ārammaṇassa anantaram uppannam mūla bhavaṅgam eva
translated: As to the root-cause-less life-continuum: but here what is intended is only the root-cause-less life-continuum that arises next to that object.

original: adhippetaṃ. Idhapi sāmaññavacanattā dvīsu a- ahetukabhavaṅgesu yaṃkiñci gahetabbamevāti.
analyzed: adhippetam idha api sāmaññavacana ttā dvīsu a ahetuka bhavaṅgesu yaṃ kiñci gahetabbam eva ati
translated: And here too because of the general statement, any one of the two kinds of root-cause-less life-continuum should be taken.

original: Tasmā dvinnaṃ ahetukānaṃpi aṭṭhasahetuka tadārammaṇānipi labbhamānānieva siyuṃ. Duhetukānaṃ
analyzed: tasmā ahetukānam pi labbhamānāni eva siyum du hetukānam
translated: So it is only the two kinds of root-cause-less life-continuum that have the eight kinds of consciousness with root-causes as object. But there is no need to mention the two kinds of consciousness with two root-causes.

original: pana vattabbameva natthīti. Vuccate, ahetu kesu tāva duggatipariyāpannānaṃ sahetukatadārammaṇasambhavo🔽sabbaaṭṭhakathāsu paṭikkhitto. Tasmā ahetukassa bhavaṅgassāti idaṃ kusalavipākabhūtaṃ
analyzed: pana vattabbam eva natthi iti vuccate ahetu kesu tāva duggati pariyāpannānam sa hetuka tad ārammaṇa sambhavaḥ  sabba aṭṭhakathāsu paṭikkhittaḥ tasmai ahetukassa bhavaṅgassa ati idam kusala vipāka bhūtam
translated: It may be objected: “But in the first place the possibility of the two kinds of consciousness with root-causes having as object the two kinds of root-cause-less life-continuum is denied in all the commentaries.🔽So it is proper to say ‘as to the root-cause-less life-continuum’ referring to the root-cause-less life-continuum that is a result of profitable action.

original: ahetukabhavaṅgaṃ sandhāya vuttanti yuttaṃ. Ayañhi paṭṭhāne dhammatā. Yadidaṃ yathālābhagahaṇanti.
analyzed: ahetuka bhavaṅgam sandhāya vuttanti yuttam ayan hi paṭṭhāne dhamma tā yat idam yathā lābha gahaṇan ti
translated: For this is the rule in the Paṭṭhāna, namely, that ‘Any one of the two kinds of root-cause-less life-continuum should be taken’ according to what is appropriate.”

original: Itarathā sabbaaṭṭhakathāvirodho siyāti. Yathāca kusalānaṃ yogasādhanīyattā pavattiyaṃpi🔽yogakammavasena ñāṇayogo hoti. Na tathā vipākānaṃ. Tesaṃ pana ayogasādhanī yattā
analyzed: itarathā sabba aṭṭhakathā virodhaḥ siyāti yathā ca kusalānam yoga sādhanīya ttā  yoga kamma vasena ñāṇa yogaḥ hoti na tathā vipākānam tesam pana ayoga sādhanī yattā
translated: And just as the profitable is accompanied by knowledge in the way of the function of the kamma-result, so too the functional is accompanied by knowledge in the way of the function of the kamma-result.

original: pavattiyaṃ bhavaṅgañāṇasaṅkhātena upanissayaññāṇena vinā ñāṇayogo na sambhavati.
analyzed: pavattiyam bhavaṅga ñāṇa saṅkhātena upanissaya ñāṇena vinā ñāṇa yogaḥ na sambhavati
translated: But the resultant is not accompanied by knowledge in the way of the function of the kamma-result. But it is not possible for the resultant to be accompanied by knowledge in the way of the function of the kamma-result.

original: Tasmā sahetukaṃ bhavaṅganti idhapi ñāṇavippayuttabhūtaṃ sahetukatadārammaṇameva gahetuṃ
analyzed: tasmā sa hetukam idha api ñāṇa vippayutta bhūtam sa hetuka tad ārammaṇam eva gahetum
translated: So it is proper to take the “with cause” here as the “with cause” that is the object of the “with cause” that is not accompanied by knowledge,

original: yuttanti katvā dvihetukānaṃ ahetukānañca ñāṇasampayuttatadārammaṇa paṭikkhepo therena🔽katoti. Ācariyabuddhadattattherena pana yena vipākacittena paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhanti.
analyzed: yuttanti katvā dvi hetukānam ahetukānam ca ñāṇa sampayutta tad ārammaṇa paṭikkhepaḥ therena  ācariya buddhadatta ttherena pana yena vipāka cittena paṭisandhim gaṇhanti
translated: and the Elder’s rejection of the “with two roots” and the “without root” that are accompanied by knowledge should be understood as made on that basis.

original: Tena sadisaṃ vā tato hīnaṃ vā tadārammaṇaṃ tesaṃ sambhavati. Na paṇītanti katvā dvinnaṃpi
analyzed: tena sadisam vā tatas hīnam vā tad ārammaṇam tesam sambhavati na katvā
translated: But the teacher, the Elder Buddhadāsa, said that the object of the “with two roots” and the “without root” is not necessarily inferior to the consciousness by which rebirth-linking is taken,

original: ahetukānaṃ aṭṭhamahāvipākāni paṭikkhipitvā sattatiṃsacittapaṭi lābho vutto. So pana
analyzed: ahetukānam aṭṭha mahā vipākāni paṭikkhipitvā sattatiṃsa citta paṭi lābhaḥ vutto saḥ pana
translated: and that it is possible for it to be equal or superior. So he rejected the eight great resultants of the two “without root” kinds and mentioned the obtaining of thirty-seven kinds of consciousness.

original: yathā vuttapaṭṭhānapāḷiyā virujjhati. Apare pana yathā ahetukānaṃ sugatipariyāpannānaṃ
analyzed: yathā vutta paṭṭhāna pāḷiyā virujjhati apare pana yathā ahetukānam sugati pariyāpannānam
translated: But others say that just as the object of the profitable consciousness of the sense sphere is the object of the profitable of the fine-material sphere,

analyzed: tad ārammaṇam evam dvi hetukānam pi ti hetuka tad ārammaṇam sambhavati iti
translated: so the object of the profitable of the fine-material sphere is the object of the profitable of the immaterial sphere.🔽And that seems reasonable, since in the commentary the two are mentioned without distinction as

original: vadanti. Taṃ yuttaṃviya dissati. Aṭṭhakathāyañhi katthaci tesaṃ dvinnaṃpi avisesena
analyzed: vadanti tam yuttam viya dissati aṭṭhakathāyan hi katthaci tesam dvinnam pi avisesena
translated: having the eight great reapings.

original: aṭṭhamahāvipākapavatti vuttāti. Paṭisandhiviññāṇa sahagatā tayo hetū etesanti tihetukā.
analyzed: vuttā ati paṭisandhi viññāṇa sahagatā tayaḥ hetū etesanti ti hetukā
translated: They are called “having three roots” because they are associated with the three roots that are present in rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: Te pana kāmarūpārūpavasena tividhā honti. Puthujjano aṭṭhaariyācāti navavidhā. Tesu
analyzed: te pana kāmarūpa arūpa vasena tividhāḥ honti puthujjanaḥ navavidhā tesu
translated: They are of three kinds as being of the sense sphere, the fine-material sphere, and the immaterial sphere. original: khīṇāsavānaṃ kusalākusala javanānica nalabbhanti. Sabbaso anusayapahānena sabbesaṃ
analyzed: khīṇāsavānam na labbhanti sabbasas anusaya pahānena sabbesam
translated: because all their profitable and unprofitable consciousness has ceased altogether with the complete abandoning of the inherent tendencies.

original: kusalākusalānaṃ saha niruddhattā anusaya paṭibaddho hi tesaṃ tabbhāvoti. Tathāsaddo
analyzed: kusala akusalānam saha paṭibaddhaḥ hi tesam tad bhāvaḥ ti tathā saddaḥ
translated: For their state is bound up with inherent tendencies. The word “too”

original: pakkhantarattho. Apariniṭṭhitasikkhākiccatāya sikkhanasīlayuttā sattaariyā sekkhānāma.
analyzed: pakkha antara tthaḥ a pariniṭṭhita sikkhā kicca tāya sikkhana sīla yuttā satta ariyā sekkhā nāma
translated: means “also.” The seven noble persons are called “learners” because they are occupied with training since their duty of learning is not finished.

original: Idha pana tayo heṭṭhimaphalaṭṭhā adhippetā. Tesañhi ādito sotāpattimaggeneva diṭṭhivicikicchānaṃ

translated: But here the three who stand on the lower paths are intended. For in them the wrong view and doubt that have been abandoned by the path of stream-entry

original: pahīnattā taṃ sahagatāni pañcajavanāni nalabbhantīti. Anāgāmipuggalānaṃ pana paṭighajavanānica🔽na labbhanti. Anāgāmimaggena pahīnattā. Maggassa pana ekacittakkhaṇikattā. Catunnaṃ🔽maggaṭṭhānaṃ paccekaṃ yathāsakaṃ maggajavanānieva labbhanti. Uparimānañca phalānaṃ
analyzed: pahīna ttā tam sahagatāni pañca javanāni na labbhanti iti anāgāmi puggalānam pana paṭigha javanāni ca  na labbhanti anāgāmi maggena pahīna ttā maggassa pana eka citta khaṇika ttā catunnam  magga ṭṭhānam paccekam yathāsakam magga javanāni eva labbhanti uparimānam ca
translated: But here the three persons who stand in the three lower paths are intended. For them, since views and doubt are abandoned by the path of stream-entry first of all, the five impulsions accompanied by them are impossible. But the impulsions of resistance are impossible for non-returners,

original: heṭṭhimehi puggalehi anamigatattā heṭṭhimānañca uparimesu puggalantaresu anuppajjanato
analyzed: heṭṭhimehi puggalehi an ami gata ttā heṭṭhimānam ca uparimesu puggala antaresu an uppajjanato

original: catunnaṃ phalaṭṭhānaṃpi paccekaṃ yathāsakaṃ phalajavanānieva labbhantīti vuttaṃ lokuttara.La.
analyzed: catunnam phala ṭṭhānam pi paccekam yathāsakam phala javanāni eva labbhanti iti vuttam lokuttara lakkhaṇa
translated: the four kinds of fruit-impulsion are possible only for those standing in the four fruits. This is what is said in the commentarial exegesis of the words “Supramundane … arise” .

original: Samuppajjantīti. Etthaca uparimagge āgate heṭṭhimamaggānubhāvassa sabbaso paṭipassaddhivasena
analyzed: samuppajjanti iti ettha ca upari magge āgate heṭṭhima magga anubhāvassa sabbaso paṭipassaddhi vasena
translated: Herein, since the influence of the lower paths is completely stilled by the arrival of the higher paths,

original: uparimānaṃ puggalantaratāsiddhi veditabbāti. Idāni tesaṃ tesaṃ puggalānaṃ pārisesato
analyzed: uparimānam puggala antara tā siddhi veditabbā ati idāni tesam tesam puggalānam pārisesato
translated: and the establishment of the other persons above them should be understood.🔽Now, in order to show the kinds of consciousness that occur in the various kinds of persons, he gives a verse.

original: labbhamānavīthicittāni dassetuṃ gāthamāha. Pariniṭṭhi tasikkhākiccattā natthi sikkhitabbakiccaṃ🔽etesanti asekkhā. Khīṇāsavā. Tesaṃ tevīsatikāmavipāka vīsatikriya arahattaphala vasena
analyzed: labbhamāna vīthi cittāni dassetum gātham āha pariniṭṭhi ta sikkhā kicca ttā natthi sikkhitabba kiccam  asekkhā khīṇa āsavā tesam tevīsati kāma vipāka vīsati kriyā arahatta phala vasena
translated: They have no training to do because they have finished the task of training.🔽They are “without training” . original: catucattālīsa vīthicittāni sambhavā yathāsambhavaṃ uddise. Avasesānaṃ catunnaṃ
analyzed: catucattālīsa vīthi cittāni sambhavā yathāsambhavam uddise sattannam sekkhānam diṭṭhi vicikicchā javana vajjitānam  sattannam akusalānam ekavīsatiyā kusalānam tevīsatiyā kāma vipākānam tiṇṇam heṭṭhima phalānam  āvajjana dvayassa ca vasena cha paññāsa vīthi cittāni sambhavā uddise avasesānam catunnam
translated: For the seven kinds of trainee, excluding the impulsions of views and doubt,🔽there are fifty-six kinds of consciousness that occur, namely, seven kinds of unprofitable consciousness, twenty-one kinds of profitable consciousness, twenty-two kinds of resultant consciousness of the kinds of sense-desire existence, and two kinds of adverting.

original: puthujjanānaṃ kāmavipāka lokiyakusalākulāvajjana dvayavasena catupaññāsa vīthicittāni
analyzed: puthujjanānam dvaya vasena catupaññāsa vīthi cittāni
translated: For the remaining four kinds of ordinary men, there are fifty-four kinds of consciousness that occur, namely, twenty-two kinds of resultant consciousness of the kinds of sense-desire existence and thirty-two kinds of functional consciousness, excluding the two kinds of adverting.

original: sambhavā uddiseti yojanā. Puggala bhedena vīthicittānaṃ bhedo puggalabhedo.
analyzed: sambhavā uddisa iti yojanā puggala bhedena vīthi cittānam bhedo puggala bhedo
translated: The construction is: “The possibility of occurrence is stated.” The difference in the individual is the difference in the individual’s consciousnesses in the cognitive series.

original: 142. Sabbānipi vīthicittāni upalabbhanti puggalānaṃ dvārānañca ettheva paripuṇṇasambhavato.
analyzed: sabbāni api vīthi cittāni upalabbhanti puggalānam dvārānam ca ettha iva paripuṇṇa sambhavato
translated: All the consciousnesses in the cognitive series are found in the individual, since the possibility of occurrence is complete in him.

original: Yathārahanti taṃ taṃ bhūmipuggalānaṃ uppattiarahānurūpaṃ. Rūpāvacarabhūmiyaṃ vajjitabbesu
analyzed: yathā arahanti tam tam bhūmi puggalānam uppatti arahā anurūpam rūpāvacara bhūmiyam vajjitabbesu
translated: “According to the case” means according to the occurrence of the individual in the various planes. In the fine-material sphere,

analyzed: cittesu channam cittānam upari vākye  vajjitāni iti vuttam arūpāvacara bhūmiyam rūpāvacara hasana heṭṭhima āruppa vajjitāni  paṭigha javana tad ārammaṇa vajjitāni ca vīthi cittāni labbhanti iti yojanā ettha api vajjitabbesu
translated: among the sixteen consciousnesses in the cognitive series, six consciousnesses are excluded,🔽since they are mentioned above. In the immaterial sphere, the consciousnesses in the cognitive series are found, excluding the fine-material-sphere adverting and the fine-material- and immaterial-sphere impulsion and registration.🔽The construction is: “The consciousnesses in the cognitive series are found, excluding the fine-material-sphere adverting and the fine-material- and immaterial-sphere impulsion and registration.” Here too, among the thirty-eight consciousnesses in the cognitive series, the sixteen consciousnesses are to be excluded, since they are mentioned above.

original: aṭṭhatiṃsa vīthicittesu soḷasannaṃ cittānaṃ uparivuccamānatā daṭṭhabbā. Sabbatthāpīti
analyzed: aṭṭhatiṃsa vīthi cittesu soḷasannam cittānam upari vuccamāna tā daṭṭhabbā sabbattha api iti
translated: “Everywhere” means

original: sabbāsupi rūpārūpabhūmīsu. Taṃtaṃ pasādarahitānaṃ taṃtaṃdvārika vīthicittāni na labbhantevāti
analyzed: sabbāsu pi rūpa arūpa bhūmīsu taṃtaṃ pasāda rahitānam taṃtaṃdvārika vīthi cittāni na labbhanteva ati

original: rūpāvacarabhūmiyaṃ tāva ghānādittayaṃ natthīti ghānajivhākāyapasāda rahitānaṃ rūpībrahmānaṃ🔽ghāna jivhākāyadvārikāni cha vīthicittāni nalabbhanteva. Yāni sandhāya channaṃ cittānaṃ
analyzed: rūpāvacara bhūmiyam tāva natthi iti ghāna jivhā kāya pasāda rahitānam rūpī brahmānam  jivhā kāya dvārikāni cha vīthi cittāni yāni sandhāya
translated: So they have no door-to-door consciousnesses of nose, tongue, and body.🔽It is with reference to these that it is said above, “In the passage above, ‘six kinds of consciousness’ is said” .

original: uparivākye vuccamānattāti heṭṭhā vuttaṃ. Arūpabhūmiyaṃ pana pañcapi pasādā natthīti
analyzed: upari vākye vuccamānattā ati heṭṭhā vuttam arūpa bhūmiyam pana pañca api pasādāḥ natthi iti
translated: But in the immaterial sphere there is no sensitivity at all,

original: pañcadvārikāni dvipañcaviññāṇa manodhā tuttika santīraṇattayavasena soḷasavīthicittāni🔽nalabbhanteva. Yāni sandhāya soḷasannaṃ cittānaṃ upari vuccamānatāti vuttaṃ. Kāmabhūmiyaṃ
analyzed: pañca dvārikāni soḷasa vīthi cittāni  yāni sandhāya cittānam upari vuccamāna tā ti vuttam kāmabhūmiyam
translated: so they have no door-to-door consciousnesses. They have no street-to-street consciousnesses either. For there are sixteen kinds of street-to-street consciousnesses, namely, the five kinds of sense consciousness, the six kinds of consciousness of the fine-material sphere, and the five kinds of consciousness of the immaterial sphere.🔽It is with reference to these that it is said above, “In the passage above, ‘sixteen kinds of consciousness’ is said” .🔽But in the sense sphere the absence of the respective kinds of sensitivity should be understood as due to the presence of congenital blindness, etc.,

original: pana taṃtaṃ pasādarahitatā jaccandhādīnaṃ vasena yo jetabbā. Kāme asīti vīthicittāni
analyzed: pana taṃ tam pasāda rahita tā jat candha ādīnam vasena yaḥ jetabbā kāme asi iti vīthi cittāni
translated: so there are eighty kinds of door-to-door consciousnesses in the sense sphere.

original: yathārahaṃ labbhare labbhanti. Rūpe catusaṭṭhi tathā yathārahaṃ labbhare. Arūpe dve🔽cattālīsa yathārahaṃ labbhareti yojanā. Etthaca brahmalokevā upari chakāmāvacara🔽devalokesuvā aniṭṭhārammaṇāni nāma natthi. Tasmā rūpāvacarabhūmiyaṃ catunnaṃ akusalavipākānaṃ
analyzed: yathāraham labbhare labbhanti rūpe tathā yathāraham labbhare arūpe dve  yathāraham yojanā upari  deva lokesu vā aniṭṭha ārammaṇāni nāma natthi tasmā rūpāvacara bhūmiyam catunnam akusala vipākānam
translated: and so on. In the fine-material sphere there are sixty-four, and so on. In the immaterial sphere there are forty, and so on. This is how the calculation should be done.🔽And here in the fine-material sphere and in the six sense-sphere heavens there are no undesirable objects,

original: labbhamānatāvacanaṃ tattha ṭhatvāvā idha āgantvāvā idha anaṭṭhehi rūpasaddehi samāgacchantānaṃ
analyzed: labbhamāna tā vacanam tattha anaṭṭhehi rūpa saddehi samāgacchantānam
translated: so the statement that four unprofitable resultants are found in the fine-material sphere should be understood as referring to those who, having been reborn there, come to the sense sphere and meet with undesirable visible data, sounds, odours, and so on,

original: vasena daṭṭhabbaṃ. Keci pana idha āgatānaṃyeva brahmānaṃ aniṭṭhārammaṇasamāyogo hotīti
analyzed: vasena daṭṭhabbam keci pana idha āgatānam yeva brahmānam aniṭṭha ārammaṇa samāyogaḥ hoti iti
translated: either while still there or after coming here. But some say that the undesirable objects that are met with are only those met with by the Brahmās who have come here,

original: thāni cattāri rūpabhūmiyaṃ laddhānināma na honti. Tasmā tattha saṭṭhiyeva vīthicittānīti🔽vadanti. Taṃ na yujjati. Idha āgatānaṃyeva uppannānipi brahmattabhāve uppannattā
analyzed: cattāri rūpabhūmiyam na honti tasmā tattha saṭṭhiyā iva vīthi cittāni iti  vadanti tam na yujjati idha āgatānam yā iva uppannāni iva brahmatta bhāve uppanna ttā
translated: and that therefore the four positions are not found in the fine-material sphere. So they say that there are only sixty processes there.🔽But that is not right. For even though they arise only in those who have come here, still they should be called “arisen in the Brahmā-world” because they arise in the individual essence of a Brahmā.

original: brahmaloke uppannāni icceva vattabbattā. Naca tattha ṭhitāpi idha aniṭṭhāni nagaṇhanti.
analyzed: brahma loke uppannāni icca iva vattabbattā na ca tattha ṭhitā api idha aniṭṭhāni na gaṇhanti
translated: And those who are established there do not apprehend undesirable objects here.

original: Dūrepi ārammaṇaṃ gahetuṃ samatthattā brahmānanti.
analyzed: dūre pi ārammaṇam gahetum samatthattā brahmā ananti
translated: Because they are able to take objects even at a distance, they are called Brahmās.

original: [140] Yañca vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yañca vibhāvaniyam
translated: And what is to be analyzed here

original: Tassa vādassa paṭikkhipanatthaṃ vuttaṃ “idha pana tattha ṭhatvāpi imaṃ lokaṃ passantānaṃ
analyzed: tassa vādassa paṭikkhipana attham vuttam idha pana tattha ṭhatvā api imam lokam passantānam
translated: is the statement, “But when they stand there and look down on this world,🔽it cannot be said that there is no undesirable object for them.”

original: aniṭṭhārammaṇassa asambhavo na sakkā vattu”nti. Tena tattha ṭhatvā imaṃ lokaṃ passantānaṃ
analyzed: aniṭṭha ārammaṇassa asambhavaḥ na sakkā vattunti tena tattha ṭhatvā imam lokaṃ passantānam
translated: So it is allowed that the four kinds of consciousness that arise in them when they stand there and look down on this world

analyzed: uppannāni tāni cattāri cittāni tattha honti idha āgatānam uppannāni
translated: are called “arisen there” and that the four kinds that arise in them when they come here are called “arisen here.”

analyzed: idha honti iti anuññātam hoti tat ca na yuttam
translated: But that is not correct.

original: Taṃ taṃ bhūmipariyāpanne sattasantāne uppannānieva taṃtaṃbhūmiyaṃ uppannānīti siddhattā.
analyzed: tam tam bhūmi pariyāpanne satta santāne uppannāni eva taṃ taṃbhūmiyam uppannāni iti siddha ttā
translated: For it is established that they are arisen in such and such a plane only when they arise in the continuum of being belonging to that plane.

original: Iccevantiādi mahānigamanaṃ. Yathāsambhavanti taṃ taṃ bhūmipuggaladvārārammaṇesu sambhavānurūpaṃ.
analyzed: mahā nigamanam yathā sambhavanti tam tam bhūmi puggala dvāra ārammaṇesu sambhava anurūpam
translated: “Thus” and so on is the Great Contemplation. “According to the way” is according to the way in which they occur in the various planes, persons, doors, objects, etc.

original: Bhavaṅgena antaritā bhavaṅgantaritā. Yāvatāyukanti tasmiṃ tasmiṃ bhave bhavanikanti
analyzed: bhavaṅgena antaritāḥ bhavaṅga antaritāḥ tasmin tasmin bhave
translated: “Intercepted by the life-continuum” means interrupted by the life-continuum. “For as long as life lasts” means for as long as the life-habit of that being lasts in that becoming.

analyzed: vīthitaḥ paṭṭhāya yattakam kālam jīvita santānam pavattati tattakam kālanti attho
translated: and the time during which the life-continuum occurs from the end of the cognitive series. The meaning is: that much time.

original: Abbhocchinnā pavattati asati nirodha samāpattiyanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: pavattati asati nirodha samāpattiyanti adhippāyo
translated: The intention is: it occurs when the attainment of cessation is absent.🔽In the Abhidhamma-attha-saṅgaha,

original: Iti paramatthadīpaniyānāma abhidhammatthasaṅgahassa
analyzed: iti
translated: which is a commentary on the ultimate meaning,🔽the explanation of the fourth chapter,

original: Catutthavaṇṇanāya vīthi saṅgahassa
analyzed: catuttha vaṇṇanāya vīthi saṅgahassa
translated: the “Collection of the Cognitive Series,”🔽is finished.

original: Paramatthadīpanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The ultimate-meaning commentary🔽on the “Collection of the Cognitive Series”🔽is finished.🔽The ultimate-meaning commentary

original: Vīthimutta saṅgaha paramatthadīpanī
translated: on the “Collection of the Non-Cognitive Series”

analyzed: evam pavatti kāle pavatti saṅgaham dassetvā idāni paṭisandhiyam pavatti saṅgaham  dassetum ādi gātha m āha evam vutta nayena pavattiyam pavatti saṅgahaḥ nāma vīthi citta vasena
translated: Having shown the collection of the occurrence in the time of occurrence in this way, now, in order to show the collection of the occurrence in rebirth-linking,🔽he says the introductory verse. Now, the collection of the occurrence in the linking is called the non-cognitive series.

original: udīritokathito. Idāni sandhiyaṃ pavattisaṅgaho nāma vīthimutta cittānaṃ vasena vuccatīti
analyzed: idāni sandhiyam pavattisaṅgahaḥ nāma cittānam vasena vuccati iti
translated: The explanation is: the collection of the occurrence in the rebirth-linking is called the non-cognitive series.

analyzed: yojanā ettha ca paṭisandhiyam citta cetasikānam pavattiyā kathitāya tato param bhavaṅga kāle ca
translated: Herein, since the occurrence of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants in the rebirth-linking has been spoken of, then, in the life-continuum,

analyzed: cuti kāle ca tesam pavatti kathitāya iva hoti iti katvā sandhiyam iccā iva vuttam
translated: And since the occurrence of these at the time of death has already been stated, only the link is mentioned.

analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī,

analyzed: paratas maraṇa uppattiyam pathamam cutim dassetvā pacchā anantare paṭisandhiyā  idha sandhi ggahaṇena gahetabbā ati adhippāyena yam vuttam tad āsanna tāya

translated: The departed is the departed one. The departed one’s realm is the departed one’s realm. analyzed: sattānam tikkhatarasūra vicitra cittāḥ honti paripuṇṇānam kusala akusala kamma pathānam
translated: are more sluggish than those of men. But the minds of men are quick,

analyzed: ānantariya kammānam ca ettha iva sambhavato ti tesu pi pana jambudīpa vāsinaḥ eva atisayena  ussita manāḥ honti itare pana tehi samāna vaṇṇa āditāya manussāḥ icca iva vuccanti imasmin

original: cakkavāḷe pana vattabbameva natthi, yathāha-tīhi bhikkhave ṭhāne hi jambudīpakā manussā

translated: as it is said: “Bhikkhus, in three respects the men of Jambudīpa surpass the people of Uttarakuru and the Tāvatiṃsa devas.🔽In what three respects? They are superior in heroism, in mindfulness, and in the life of purity. ”

analyzed: akkhara cintakā pana vadanti mahāsammata rājā

analyzed: vuccati ime ca janā tena thapitesu mariyāda dhammesu ṭhitā tassa putta ṭṭhāniyāḥ honti

original: Viruḷhako kumbhaṇḍānaṃ. Virūpakkho nāgānaṃ. Kuvero yakkhānaṃ. Tattha paṭisandhivasena

analyzed: pana oḷārikam rūpam māpetvā attānam dassenti tadā eva passanti esanayaḥ upari bhūmīsu pi  yam pana brahmanimantana sutta ṭṭhakathāyam vuttam brahmānam pakati rūpam kassaci āpātam  na gacchati iti tam brahma puras hitāḥ dīnam uparimānam brahmānam pakati rūpam kassaci
translated: when the Great Brahmās make their bodies manifest in gross physical form, then they are seen. The same applies to the higher planes.🔽But what is said in the Commentary on the Brahmajāla Sutta, namely, that ‘the natural form of the Brahmās does not come within the range of vision of any of the lower Brahmās,’🔽is said because the natural form of the higher Brahmās, the Brahmā Priests, etc., does not come within the range of vision of any of the lower Brahmās,

original: brahmapārisajjādinovā devassavā manussassavāāpātaṃ nagacchatīti katvā vuttaṃ. Heṭṭhimānaṃ
analyzed: brahma pārisajja ādino vā deva ssavā manussa ssavā āpātam na gacchati iti katvā vuttam heṭṭhimānam
translated: the Brahmā Assembly, etc., or of any of the gods or men.

original: pana pakatirūpaṃ uparimassa āpātaṃ āgacchissatiyeva. Teneva hi janavasabhasuttaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: pana uparimassa āpātam āgacchissati yeva tena iva hi jana vasabha sutta ṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: but the materiality of the lower will come into the range of the higher. That is why it is said in the commentary to the Janavasabha Sutta:

original: heṭṭhimaheṭṭhimāhi devā uparimadevānaṃ oḷārikaṃ katvā māpitameva attabhāvaṃ passituṃ🔽sakkontīti vuttaṃ. Tatthadutīyatale parittābhāti brahmapārisajjāeva. Appamāṇābhāti
analyzed: devāḥ uparima devānam oḷārikam katvā māpitam eva atta bhāvam passituṃ  sakkonti iti vuttam tattha dutīya tale parittā ābhāti brahma pārisajjā eva appamāṇā ābhāti
translated: “The gods of the lower plane can see the material bodies of the gods of the higher plane as gross,

original: brahmapurohitā eva. Ābhassarāti mahābrahmānoeva. Tasmiṃ tale adhipati brahmānoevāti
analyzed: brahma purohitāḥ eva mahābrahmānaḥ eva tasmin tale adhipati brahmānaḥ eva ati
translated: and they can see them as made.” Herein, on the second plane the Parittābhā are only the Brahmapārisajja gods. The Appamāṇābhā are only the Brahmapurohita gods. The Ābhassarā are only the Mahābrahmās. The Adhipateyyakā are only the Mahābrahmās.

original: attho. Heṭṭhimatalato pana visesa karaṇatthaṃ ābhāvasena nāmagahaṇaṃ hotīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: atthaḥ heṭṭhima talataḥ pana visesa karaṇa attham ābhā vasena nāma gahaṇam hoti iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: The meaning is that they are only the Brahmās. But the naming by way of light should be regarded as being for the purpose of distinguishing them from the gods of the lower plane.

original: Tattha parittā ābhā etesanti parittābhā. Appamāṇā ābhā etesanti appamāṇābhā. Ābhāsaranti🔽niccharanti etesūti ābhassarāti. Tatīyatale parittasubhāti brahmapārisajjāeva. Appamāṇasutāti
analyzed: tattha parittāḥ ābhāḥ etesanti paritta ābhāḥ appamāṇāḥ ābhāḥ etesanti appamāṇa ābhāḥ  niccharanti etesu iti tatīya tale parittasubhāti brahma pārisajjā eva appamāṇa sutāti
translated: Herein, they have little light, thus they are Parittābhā. They have immeasurable light, thus they are Appamāṇābhā. They shine forth, thus they are Ābhassarā.

original: brahmapurohitāeva. Sutakiṇṇāti mahābrahmanoeva. Tasmiṃ tale adhipatibrahmāno evāti
analyzed: brahma purohitāḥ eva mahābrahmanaḥ eva tasmin tale adhipati brahmānaḥ eva ati
translated: On the third plane the Parittasubhā are only the Brahmapārisajja gods. The Appamāṇasubhā are only the Brahmapurohita gods. The Vehapphalā are only the Mahābrahmās. The Adhipateyyakā are only the Mahābrahmās.

original: attho. Tattha subhāti ekagghanā acalasaṇṭhitā ābhāeva vuccanti. Parittā subhā etesanti
analyzed: tattha subhā ti ekagghanā acala saṇṭhitā ābhā eva vuccanti parittā subhā etesan ti
translated: Herein, the lights that are of one single radiance and are firmly established are called “subhas” .

original: parittasubhā. Appamāṇā subhā etesanti appamāṇasubhā. Sutehi ākiṇṇāti subhākiṇṇā.
analyzed: paritta subhā appamāṇā subhā etesanti appamāṇa subhā sutehi ākiṇṇā ati subha ākiṇṇā
translated: Those who have little subhas are Parittasubhas. Those who have immeasurable subhas are Appamāṇasubhas. Those who are filled with subhas are Subhakiṇhas.

original: Subhakiṇhātipi paṭhanti. Tesaṃ ākārassa rasso antimaṇakārassa ca hakāro daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: paṭhanti tesam ākārassa rassaḥ antima ṇakārassa ca hakāro daṭṭhabbo
translated: Some read Subhakiṇṇas. The shape of that should be seen as the shape of the word “subha” and the letter “ha” .

original: Imesu pana dvīsu talesu pakatikāyappabhā adhimattā honti. Tasmā tāsaṃ vasena parittābhātiādikaṃ
analyzed: imesu pana dvīsu talesu pakati kāya ppabhāḥ adhimattāḥ honti tasmā tāsam vasena paritta ābhāti ādikam
translated: In these two planes the natural radiance of the body is intense, and that is why the name Parittābhā, etc.,

original: nāmaṃ siddhaṃ. Na brahmapāri sajjātiādikaṃ. Evañca katvā verañjasutte pathamatalavāsino
analyzed: nāmam siddham na brahma pāri sat jāti ādikam evañca katvā verañja sutte pathama tala vāsinaḥ
translated: is established according to that, not according to the Brahmapārisajya, and so on. And when it is put like this, the first-plane dwellers are called “Brahmakāyika gods” in the Verañjā Sutta ,

original: brahmakāyikā devāti āgatā. Dutīyatalavāsino ābhādevāti. Tatīyatalavāsino subhādevāti🔽catutthatale vipulaṃ phalaṃ etesanti vehapphalā. Athavā iñjanajātikehi somanassajjhānehi
analyzed: brahmakāyikāḥ devāti āgatāḥ dutīya tala vāsinaḥ ābhādevāti tatīya tala vāsinaḥ subhādevāti  catuttha tale vipulam phalam etesanti vehapphalāḥ athavā iñjana jātikehi somanassa jhānehi
translated: the second-plane dwellers “Ābhassara gods,” and the third-plane dwellers “Subhakiṇha gods” .🔽In the fourth plane the fruit is abundant, thus they are Vehapphala . Or alternatively, the three lower planes are generated by the jhāna of joy that is of the kind called “trembling” ,

original: nibbattānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ heṭṭhimatalānaṃ tejosaṃ vaṭṭādikena antarāyena bhūmitalena saha
analyzed: nibbattānam tiṇṇam heṭṭhima talānam tejosam vaṭṭa ādikena antarāyena bhūmi talena saha
translated: and their radiance is obstructed by the earth’s surface and so on.

original: āyukappanivattivasena iñjitaṃ puññaphalaṃ atthi. Tesu hi yaṃ subhākiṇṇānaṃ devānaṃ
analyzed: āyu kappa nivatti vasena iñjitam puñña phalam atthi tesu hi yam subhākiṇṇānam devānam
translated: The merit that has been accumulated by the gods of the Subhakiṇha realm is exhausted by the time the world has expanded to its maximum extent.

original: catusaṭṭhikappānīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ tasmiṃ tale ādikappikānaṃ vasena vuttaṃ. Pacchimikānaṃ
analyzed: catur aṭṭhi kappāni iti vuttam tam tasmin tale ādikappikānam vasena vuttam pacchimikānam
translated: The life span of the gods of the Subhakiṇha realm is said to be sixty-four eons.🔽But the merit of the gods of the Vehapphala realm is not exhausted in this way.

original: pana tesaṭṭhikappa dvāsaṭṭhikappa ekasaṭṭhi kappādi vasena iñjitaṃ paṭilīnaṃ puññaphalaṃ🔽hotīti. Āneñjajātikena upekkhājhānena nibbattānaṃ pana kenaci antarāyena tādisaṃ🔽iñjitaṃ puññaphalaṃ nāma natthi. Tasmā jhāna sāmatthiyānurūpaṃ visesena īhitaṃ abhivaḍḍhitaṃ
analyzed: pana tesaṭṭhikappa dvāsaṭṭhikappa ekasaṭṭhi kappa ādi vasena iñjitam paṭilīnam puñña phalam  hoti iti āneñja jātikena upekkhā jhānena nibbattānam pana kenaci antarāyena tādisam  iñjitam puñña phalam nāma natthi tasmā jhāna sāmatthiyā anurūpam visesena īhitam abhivaḍḍhitam
translated: The merit of the gods of the Vehapphala realm is not exhausted in this way.

original: puññaphalaṃ ettha atthīti vehapphalā.🔽Natthi saññāmukhena gahitā cattāro arūpakkhandhā etesanti asaññā. Asaññāca te sattācāti
analyzed: puñña phalam ettha atthi iti vehapphalā  natthi saññā mukhena gahitā cattāro arūpa kkhandhā etesan ti asaññāḥ asaññā ca te sattā ca ati
translated: Therefore, the gods of the Vehapphala realm are called Vehapphala because their merit is increased and expanded in a special way in accordance with the power of their jhāna.🔽The gods of the Asaññasatta realm are called asaññasatta because they do not possess the four immaterial aggregates that are grasped by perception.

original: asaññasattā. Cittace tasikānaṃ pana natthitāya tesaṃ asattapasaṅgatā sambhavatīti
analyzed: asaññasattā citta cetasikānam pana na thitāya tesam asatta pasaṅga tā sambhavati iti
translated: The gods of the Asaññasatta realm are called asaññasatta because they are beings without perception.🔽The gods of the Asaññasatta realm are called asaññasatta because they are beings without perception.

original: sattagahaṇaṃ katanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ete dvepi ekatalavāsino eva honti. Etthapi nibbattakajjhānassa
analyzed: satta gahaṇam katanti daṭṭhabbam ete dve pi eka tala vāsinaḥ eva honti ettha api nibbattaka jhānassa
translated: The seven are to be regarded as the same in this respect. And both these kinds of gods are of the same plane. But there is this difference in them that the gods of the first kind are of inferior, medium, and superior grade according to the jhāna they have produced in their last existence, and so the gods of the Brahmā-order are of the same kind as the jhāna.

original: hīnamajjhimapaṇītatā visesassa atthitāya tadanurūpaṃ brahmānaṃpi pārisajja purohita🔽mahābrahmatta viseso sambhavatiyeva. Āyuvemattatāya pana aññamañña adassanādīnañca
analyzed: hīna majjhima paṇīta tā visesassa atthitāya tad anurūpam pārisajja purohita  mahābrahmatta viseso sambhavatiyā iva āyu vemattatāya pana aññamañña adassana ādīnam ca
translated: The gods of the second kind are of the same kind as the path. And there is this difference in them too that the gods of the first kind are of the same kind as the jhāna of the first jhāna, etc., and the gods of the second kind are of the same kind as the path of stream-entry, and so on.🔽And there is this difference in the gods of the first kind too that the gods of the first Brahmā-world are of the same kind as the first jhāna of the fine-material sphere, and so on.🔽And there is this difference in the gods of the second kind too that the gods of the Stream-Enterers’ Brahmā-world are of the same kind as the first path, and so on.

original: natthitāya pārisajjādivasena bhūmivibhāgo natthīti veditabbo. Evaṃ avihādīsupi. Oḷārikānaṃ
analyzed: pārisajja ādi vasena bhūmi vibhāgaḥ natthi iti veditabbaḥ evam oḷārikānam
translated: And there is this difference in the gods of the first kind too that the gods of the first Brahmā-world are of the same kind as the first jhāna of the fine-material sphere, and so on.🔽And there is this difference in the gods of the second kind too that the gods of the Stream-Enterers’ Brahmā-world are of the same kind as the first path, and so on.

original: kāmarāgapaṭighānusayānaṃ natthitāya suddhānaṃ anāgāmiarahantānameva āvāsāti suddhāvāsā.
analyzed: kāma rāga paṭigha anusayānam suddhānam anāgāmi arahantānam eva suddhāvāsā
translated: And there is this difference in the gods of the first kind too that the gods of the first Brahmā-world are of the same kind as the first jhāna of the fine-material sphere, and so on.

original: Tattha pathamabhūmivāsino appakena kālena attano ṭhānaṃ navijahantīti avihā. Athavā,🔽oḷārikānaṃ pañcannaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ pahīnattā natthi cittassa vihaññanaṃ samathavipassa
analyzed: tattha pathama bhūmi vāsinaḥ appakena kālena attanaḥ ṭhānam athavā 🔽oḷārikānam pañcannam saṃyojanānam pahīna ttā natthi cittassa vihaññanam samatha vipassa
translated: And there is this difference in the gods of the second kind too that the gods of the Stream-Enterers’ Brahmā-world are of the same kind as the first path, and so on.🔽And there is this difference in the gods of the first kind too that the gods of the first Brahmā-world are of the same kind as the first jhāna of the fine-material sphere, and so on.🔽And there is this difference in the gods of the second kind too that the gods of the Stream-Enterers’ Brahmā-world are of the same kind as the first

original: nādhammesu avipphārikatāpatti etesanti avihā. Dutīyabhūmi vāsino na kenaci cittapariḷāhena
analyzed: na adhammesu avipphārika tā āpatti etesanti avihāḥ dutīya bhūmi vāsinaḥ na kenacid citta pariḷāhena
translated: thus they are not heated .

original: tappantīti atappā. Tatīya talavāsino parisuddhehi pasādacakkhu dibbacakkhu dhammacakkhu🔽paññā cakkhūhi sampannattā suṭṭhu passantīti sudassā. Catutthabhūmivāsino pana tato
analyzed: tappanti iti atappā tatīya tala vāsino parisuddhehi pasāda cakkhu dibba cakkhu dhamma cakkhu  paññā cakkhūhi sampanna ttā suṭṭhu passanti iti sudassā catuttha bhūmi vāsinaḥ pana tatas
translated: Those who live in the third plane are endowed with the eye of purified confidence, the divine eye, the eye of Dhamma,🔽and the eye of wisdom, thus they see very well, thus they are the Very-Well-Seeing Ones .🔽But those who live in the fourth plane are endowed with the state of seeing very well in the sense of being superior to that,

original: atisayena suṭṭhu dassanabhāvena samannāgatāti sudassino. Atisayatthe hi ayaṃ īkāroti.
analyzed: atisayena suṭṭhu dassana bhāvena samannāgatā ati sudassinaḥ atisaya tthe hi ayam īkāraḥ ti
translated: thus they are the Very-Well-Seeing Ones . For this is the meaning of the suffix -in ;

original: Pañcamabhūmi vāsino upari aññassa bhūmantaragatassa rūpibrahmuno natthitāya natthi
analyzed: pañcama bhūmi vāsinaḥ upari aññassa bhūma antara gatassa rūpi brahmunaḥ natthitāya natthi
translated: Those who live in the fifth plane have no superior to them in the sense that there is no other visible-world Brahmā above them in a higher plane,

original: rūpīnaṃ sattānaṃ majjhe kenaci guṇena kaniṭṭhabhāvo etesanti akaniṭṭhā.🔽Ākāsānañcāyatanabhūmīti ettha yattakaṃ ākāsapadesaṃ pharitvā ākāsānañcāyatana saññitā
analyzed: rūpīnam sattānam majjhe kenacid guṇena kaniṭṭha bhāvaḥ etesanti akaniṭṭhā  ākāsa anañcāyatana bhūmi iti ettha yattakam ākāsa padesam pharitvā ākāsa anañcāyatana saññitā
translated: thus they are the unsurpassed .🔽As to the base consisting of boundless space, as much space as is pervaded by the four aggregates called the base consisting of boundless space,

original: catukkhandhā pavattanti. So khandhasahito ākāsapadeso ākāsānañcāyayanabhūmi. Evaṃ
analyzed: catu khandhā pavattanti saḥ khandha sahitaḥ ākāsa padesaḥ ākāsa anañcāyayana bhūmi evam
translated: and the space itself together with the aggregates, is the base consisting of boundless space.

original: sesāsu. Puthujjanā sotāpannā sakadāgāminocāpi puggalā suddhāvāsesu sabbathā sabbapakārenapi
analyzed: sesāsu puthujjanā sotāpannā puggalā suddhāvāsesu sabbathā sabba pakārena api
translated: In the rest, ordinary men, stream-enterers, and once-returners, do not exist in any way at all in the Pure Abodes.

original: nalabbhantīti yojanā. Etthaca sakadāgāmīnaṃ paṭikkhepena anāgāmi maggaṭṭhassapi tattha🔽paṭikkhepo siddho hotīti uparimānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ ariyānameva tattha paṭilābho imāya gāthāya
analyzed: na labbhanti iti yojanā ettha ca sakadāgāmīnam paṭikkhepena anāgāmi tattha  paṭikkhepaḥ siddhaḥ hoti iti uparimānam tiṇṇam ariyānam eva tattha paṭilābhaḥ imāya gāthāya
translated: In the rest, however, the interpretation is that ordinary men, stream-enterers, and once-returners do not obtain any of the kinds of rebirth in the Pure Abodes. And here the denial of once-returners implies the denial of non-returners, who are on the non-return path,

original: vuttoti veditabbo. Sesaṭṭhānesūti pañcasuddhāvāsato asaññāpāyatoca avasesesu ekavīsatiyā
analyzed: vuttaḥ ti veditabbaḥ sesa ṭṭhānesu ti avasesesu ekavīsatiyā
translated: so it should be understood that only the three higher kinds of noble persons obtain rebirth there, according to this verse. In the remaining places, that is, in the twenty-one places other than the five Pure Abodes and the non-percipient realm,

original: ṭhānesu, anariyāti puthujjanā. [Bhūmicatukkaṃ]🔽144. Okkantikkhaṇeti paṭisandhikkhaṇe. Paṭisandhihi bhavantare okkamanaṃ anupavisananthi🔽atthena okkantīti vuccati. Tato paraṃ bhavaṅgaṃ hutvāti yojanā. Keci pana bhavaṅgapariyosāneti
analyzed: ṭhānesu puthujjanāḥ bhūmi catukkam  okkanti khaṇe iti paṭisandhi khaṇe paṭisandhihi bhavantare okkamanam  atthena okkantī iti vuccati tato param bhavaṅgam hutvā iti yojanā keci pana bhavaṅga pariyosānā iti
translated: ordinary men, that is, non-noble persons, can obtain all the kinds of rebirth.

original: paṭhanti. Taṃ na yujjati. Jātiyā andho jaccandho. Ādisaddena jāti badhira jaccaghānaka
analyzed: paṭhanti tam na yujjati jātiyāḥ andhaḥ ādi saddena jāti badhira
translated: At the moment of descent, that is, at the moment of rebirth-linking. Rebirth-linking is called “descent” because it is the entry into the next existence. The interpretation is that after that it is the life-continuum. But some read “at the end of the life-continuum” . That is not correct. One blind from birth is a “congenitally blind” . The word “etc.” includes one deaf from birth, one with a congenital hare-lip,🔽and so on.

original: jātimūga jacceḷa jaccummattaka paṇḍaka ubhato byañjanaka napuṃsaka mammādayo saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: jātimūga jacceḍa jaccummattaka paṇḍaka ubhatas saṅgaṇhāti
translated: and the blind from birth, the deaf, the dumb, the mad, the distracted, the paṇḍakas, the hermaphrodites, the eunuchs, and so on.

original: Tattha yassa cakkhuṃ uppādetuṃ asamatthena kammena paṭisandhi laddhā. So jaccandho🔽nāma. Esanayo sesesupi. Tattha pasādasota rahito jātibadhiro nāma. Pasāda ghānarahito🔽jacca ghānako nāma. Pasādajivhārahito nāma natthi. Vacanarahito jātimūgonāma. Disāvidisāmattaṃpi
analyzed: tattha yassa cakkhum uppādetum asamatthena kammena paṭisandhi laddhā saḥ jaccandho  nāma esanayo sesesu pi tattha rahitaḥ jātibadhiraḥ nāma pasāda ghāna rahito  jat ca ghānakaḥ nāma pasāda jivhā rahitaḥ nāma natthi vacana rahitaḥ jāti mūgaḥ nāma
translated: Herein, one who has taken rebirth-linking by means of a kamma incapable of producing eye is called “blind from birth.”🔽The same method of explanation applies in the case of the others. Herein, one who is devoid of the eye-sensitivity is called “deaf from birth.” One who is devoid of the nose-sensitivity is called “blind from birth.”🔽One who is devoid of the tongue-sensitivity is called “dumb from birth.” One who is incapable of making known any direction,
