original: saññāpetuṃ asakkuṇeyyo jātieḷo nāma. Sabbakālaṃpi vipallaṭṭhacitto jaccummattakonāma.
analyzed: saññāpetum asakkuṇeyyaḥ jātieḷaḥ nāma sabbakālam pi vipallaṭṭha cittaḥ jaccummattako nāma
translated: whether it is up or down, is called “the distracted from birth.” One whose cognizance is perverted all the time is called “the mad from birth.”

original: Kāmahetu āsittakādibhāvena vippakārapatto paṇḍakonāma. Dvīhi byañjanehi samannāgato
analyzed: kāma hetu āsittaka ādi bhāvena vippakāra patto paṇḍako nāma dvīhi byañjanehi samannāgataḥ
translated: One who has become perverted in appearance owing to his having sat on the ground of sensuality, etc., is called “the paṇḍaka from birth.” One who possesses two sex

original: ubhato byañjanakonāma. Bhāvadvaya rahito napuṃsakonāma. Pakativacanepi ekamekaṃ akkharaṃ
analyzed: ubhatas byañjanakaḥ nāma bhāva dvaya rahitaḥ napuṃsakaḥ nāma pakativacane pi ekam ekam akkharaṃ
translated: organs is called “the hermaphrodite from birth.” One who is devoid of the two sexes is called “the eunuch from birth.” One who utters each syllable

original: mahussāhena uppādento vibacchavacano mammonāma. Etthaca cakkhuṃ uppādetuṃ samatthena
analyzed: mahussāhena uppādentaḥ vibaccha vacanaḥ ettha ca cakkhum uppādetum samatthena
translated: with great difficulty is called “the stammerer from birth.” Herein, one who is capable of producing eye is called “not blind from birth.”

original: kammena laddhapaṭisandhikassa pavattikāle taṃvā aññaṃvā kammaṃ cakkhuṃ uppādeti.🔽Asamatthenakammena laddhapaṭisandhi kassa pana vatthuvipannassa pavattikāle aññaṃpi
analyzed: kammena laddha paṭisandhikassa pavatti kāle tam vā aññam vā kammam cakkhum uppādeti  asamatthena kammena laddha paṭisandhi kassa pana vatthu vipannassa pavatti kāle aññaṃpi
translated: At the time of the rebirth-linking consciousness obtained by kamma, that kamma itself generates the eye.

original: kammaṃ cakkhuṃ uppādetīti natthi. Tasmā gabbhaseyyakānaṃpi jaccandhabhāvo paṭisandhikkhaṇeyeva
analyzed: kammam cakkhum uppādeti iti natthi tasmā gabbhaseyyakānam pi jat candha bhāvo paṭisandhi kkhaṇe yeva
translated: But there is no rebirth-linking consciousness obtained by kamma that is incapable of generating the eye, and there is no rebirth-linking consciousness obtained by kamma that generates the eye at the time of the occurrence of the rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: siddhoti veditabbo. Esanayo sesesu jāti badhirādīsu. Āyatanānaṃ paṭilābho jātīti🔽vuttattā cakkhussa uppajjanārahakālo cakkhussa jātikālonāma. Tadā anuppanna cakkhuko
analyzed: siddhaḥ ti veditabbaḥ esanayo sesesu jāti badhira ādīsu āyatanānam paṭilābhaḥ jāti iti  vutta ttā cakkhussa uppajjana araha kālo cakkhussa jāti kālo nāma tadā anuppanna cakkhuko
translated: Therefore it should be understood that the state of being born blind is established in the case of those who sleep in the womb by the mere occurrence of the rebirth-linking consciousness.🔽The same method of explanation applies in the case of the other kinds of congenital blindness.

original: jaccandhonāmāti evaṃ attano attano uppajjanāraha kālavasena tassa tassa āyatanassa
analyzed: evam attanaḥ attanaḥ kāla vasena tassa tassa āyatanassa
translated: Since the obtaining of the bases is called “birth,” the time when the eye is due to arise is called the “birth moment of the eye.” At that time, one who is without eye is called “one born blind.”

original: jātikālo veditabbo. Evañhisati jātimūgādayopi upapanno hontītica vadanti. Vibhāvani
analyzed: jāti kālaḥ veditabbaḥ evam hi sati jāti mūga ādayaḥ api upapannaḥ honti iti ca vadanti vibhāvani
translated: Thus the birth moment of each of the bases should be understood according to the time when it is due to arise.

original: yaṃpi ayamattho vibhāvitoti.🔽[142] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: ayam attho vibhāvito ti 🔽yam pana
translated: For if it were otherwise, it would be said that the congenitally blind and the congenitally deaf are reborn.

original: “Apare pana jaccandhoti pasutiyaṃyeva andho. Mātu kucchiyaṃ andho hutvā nikkhantoti
analyzed: apare pana jaccandhoti pasutiyaṃ yeva andhaḥ mātu kucchiyam andhaḥ hutvā nikkhantoti
translated: “But others say that the word ‘born blind’ in the text refers to one who is blind from birth, that is, who comes out of his mother’s womb blind.

original: attho. Tena duhetukatihetukānaṃ mātukucchiyaṃ cakkhussa avipajjanaṃ siddhanti vadantīti”
analyzed: attho tena du hetuka ti hetukānam mātukucchiyam cakkhussa a vipajjanam siddhanti vadanti iti
translated: They say that this establishes that the eye is not destroyed in the womb of one of the two kinds due to two causes and due to three causes.

original: vuttaṃ. Taṃ na yuttaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam tam na yuttam
translated: ” This is not correct.

original: Loke mātukucchiyaṃyeva andho hutvā nikkhantassapi ekaccassa taṃ taṃ sippavijjāṭhānesu🔽paññāveyyattiyabhāvassa diṭṭhattā. Thapetvā hi mahābodhisatte aññeca pacchimabhavike🔽satte avasesānaṃ dvihetuka tihetukānaṃpi mātukucchimhi parūpakkamenavā mātuyā visamapayogenavā
analyzed: loke mātukucchiyaṃ yā iva andhaḥ hutvā nikkhantassa api ekaccassa tam tam sippa vijjā ṭhānesu  paññā veyyattiya bhāvassa diṭṭha ttā thapetvā hi mahā bodhisatte aññe ca pacchimabhavike  satte avasesānam mātukucchimhi paru pakkamena vā mātuyā visama payogena vā
translated: For it is seen that some who are born blind in the world, that is, who come out of their mother’s womb blind, have a measure of understanding in some craft or science or other.

original: nānābādhenavā uppannānaṃpi cakkhusotānaṃ vipattināma natthīti na sakkā niyametunti.
analyzed: uppannānam pi cakkhu sotānam vipatti nāma natthi iti na sakkā niyametunti
translated: For, except for the Great Being in his last existence and for the being in his last existence who is to be reborn as a Buddha, there is no other being in the womb who is of the two kinds due to two causes and due to three causes, and the eye of the rest is not destroyed in the womb, whether through the mother’s eating unsuitable food or through her doing unsuitable work or through some disease. So it cannot be asserted that there is no destruction of the eye.

original: Bhummassitānañca vinipātikāsurānanti ettha bhūmiyaṃ jātāti bhummā. Bhūmisambandhesu
analyzed: ettha bhūmiyam jātā ati bhummā bhūmi sambandhesu
translated: As to the words “and the ghosts of the kind called Bhummadevaputta” , the ghosts called Bhummadevaputta are those born on the ground. They are called “ground-born” because they are born in places connected with the ground.

original: rukkhaṭṭhaka pabbataṭṭhaka vimānesu nibbattā āḷavaka sātāgira hemavatādayo mahiddhikā
analyzed: rukkha aṭṭhaka pabbata aṭṭhaka vimānesu nibbattāḥ āḷavaka sātāgira hemavata ādayaḥ mahiddhikā
translated: The great-powerful earth-gods are the earth-gods who have been reborn in the tree-gods, rock-gods, and palace-gods, such as Alavi, Sata, Giri, Hemavata, etc.

original: bhummādevā. Ye loke baliharaṇa vasena pūjanīyaṭṭhena yakkhātipi vuccanti. Ye pana
analyzed: ye loke bali haraṇa vasena pūjanīya ṭṭhena vuccanti ye pana
translated: They are called “yakkhas” in the sense of being worthy of worship by means of offerings made in the world. But those who,

original: bhummadevajātikāpi samānā attano puññanibbattassa kassaci bhogasukhassa abhāvā kicchajīvi
analyzed: bhumma deva jātikā api samānā attanaḥ puñña nibbattassa kassaci bhoga sukhassa abhāvā kiccha jīvi
translated: though of the earth-god type, wander about in the world because of the absence of the enjoyment of the pleasure of wealth produced by their own merit,

original: kappattā vicaranti. Te tesaṃ mahiddhikānaṃ bhummadevānaṃ paraṃpara pārisajjesu pariyāpannattā
analyzed: kappattāḥ vicaranti te tesam mahiddhikānam bhummadevānam paraṃpara pārisajjesu pariyāpanna ttā
translated: are called “earth-gods” because they are included in the retinue of the great-powerful earth-gods by way of succession.

original: bhumme deve sitā nissitāti atthena bhummassitānāma honti. Bhummissitātipi pāṭho.🔽Puññanibbattassa nivāsaṭṭhānassa abhāvā rukkhagumbaleṇaguhāsusānā dīsu vivittesu
analyzed: bhumme deve sitā nissitā ati atthena bhummassitā nāma honti bhummissitā atipi pāṭhaḥ  puñña nibbattassa nivāsa ṭṭhānassa abhāvā vivittesu
translated: The reading is also “bhummissitā.”

original: bhūmipadesesu nissāya vasantīti attho. Teyeva virūpā hutvā bhavantare nipatantīti
analyzed: bhūmi padesesu nissāya vasanti iti attho teyeva virūpāḥ hutvā bhavantare nipatanti iti
translated: The meaning is that they live in dependence on trees, bushes, caves, hollows, and charnel grounds, in lonely places, because of the absence of a place of residence produced by merit. They are called “vinipātikas” because they fall into the next existence in the form of a monster.

original: vinipātikā. Vinipātikāca te heṭṭhāvuttaṭṭhena asurācāti vinipātikā surā. Te pana
analyzed: vinipātikā vinipātikā ca te heṭṭhāvutta ṭṭhena asurā ca ati vinipātikā surā te pana
translated: And they are called “asuras” because they are gods who have fallen from the status of gods.

original: gāmasamīpevā antogāmevā vivittaṭṭhānesu vasitvā gāmavāsīhi chaḍḍitāni bhattasitthapūvakhajjamacchamaṃsādīni
analyzed: gāma samīpe vā antogāme vā vivitta ṭṭhānesu vasitvā gāma vāsīhi chaḍḍitāni bhatta sittha pūva khajja maccha maṃsa ādīni
translated: and they live in the vicinity of villages, in villages, in lonely places, and they seek out and eat the food, rice, cakes, fish, meat, etc., that are thrown away by village-dwellers,

original: pariyesitvāvā tāni alabhitvā dārakevā gilānevā pīḷetvāvā sakkontā pana aññepi manusse
analyzed: pariyesitvā vā tāni a labhitvā dārakā iva gilānā iva pīḍetvā vā sakkontā pana aññe pi manusse
translated: and when they cannot find them they torment their own children, and when they are able they torment other men too,

original: tāsetvā pīḷetvāvā jīvitaṃ kappentīti. Tesaṃ vinipātikāsurānaṃ. Ekaccānanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tāsetvā pīḍetvā vā jīvitam kappenti iti tesam vinipātika asurānam ekaccānam nti adhippāyaḥ
translated: and they make a living. The meaning is that some of them are of such a kind.🔽For it cannot be said of all of them that they are ghosts without a reason for their state.

original: Na hi sabbe vinipātikā surānāma ahetu kāevāti sakkā vattuṃ. Dvihetukatihetukānaṃpi
analyzed: na hi sabbe vinipātikā surā nāma ahetukā eva ati sakkā vattum dvi hetuka ti hetukānaṃ pi
translated: For some have two reasons and some have three.

original: sabbhāvato. Evañca katvā tesaṃ ekaccānaṃ piyaṅkaramātā uttaramātā dhammaguttā phussamittādīnaṃ
analyzed: sabbhāvataḥ evam ca katvā tesam ekaccānam piyaṅkara mātā uttara mātā dhamma guttā phussa mitta ādīnam
translated: And in that case the mother of Piyaṅkara, the mother of Uttara, Dhammaguttā, Phussamittā, etc.,

original: dhammābhisamayopi aṭṭhakathāsu vuttoti. Ekacce yakkhajātikāpi rakkhasajātikāpi vemānikapetāpi
analyzed: dhamma abhisamayaḥ api aṭṭhakathāsu vuttaḥ ti ekacce yakkha jātikā api rakkhasa jātikā api vemānika petā api
translated: and their penetration of the Dhamma, are included here. And some are of such a kind that they are included among the ghosts, yakkhas, rakkhasas, and vetālas,

original: paradattupajīvi petāpi ettha saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: para datta upajīvi petā api ettha saṅgahitā ati daṭṭhabbā
translated: and among the ghosts who live on what is given by others.

original: Tesūti yathāvuttapaṭisandhi yuttesu puggalesu. Yasmā āyuparicchedonāma ekabhūmipariyāpannānaṃ
analyzed: tesu iti yathā vutta paṭisandhi yuttesu puggalesu yasmai eka bhūmi pariyāpannānam
translated: Among those beings: among those persons who have such a kind of rebirth-linking as has been described. Because the life span of those who are included in the plane of the four primary elements

original: sabbasattānaṃ asesasā dhāraṇaniyamaparimāṇavasena pavatto. Apāyānaṃ manussānaṃ bhumma
analyzed: sabba sattānam asesasā dhāraṇa niyama parimāṇa vasena pavatto apāyānam manussānam bhumma
translated: and it is not so for all beings.🔽There is no such limitation of life-span for the unfortunate planes, for human beings, and for the gods.🔽For all the hells in the world do not have the same life-span.

original: devānañca tādiso niyamaparimāṇonāma natthi. Na hi sakalacakka vāḷapariyāpannā ekabhūmakā🔽sabbanirayā ekaāyuparicchedā honti. Tiracchānādīsupi esevanayo. Tasmā vuttaṃ catunnaṃ
analyzed: devānam ca tādisaḥ niyama parimāṇaḥ nāma natthi na hi sakala cakka vāḷa pariyāpannāḥ eka bhūmakā  sabba nirayā eka āyu paricchedāḥ honti tiracchāna ādīsu pi tasmā vuttam catunnam
translated: Nor do the animals, etc., have the same life-span.🔽Therefore it is said, “There is no limitation of life-span for the four unfortunate planes.”

original: apāyānantiādi. Catunnaṃ apāyānaṃ āpāyikapuggalānaṃ āyuppamāṇa gaṇanāya niyamo natthi,🔽tattha yebhuyyena kammapamāṇattā. Tattha nirayesu abbudādīnaṃ dasannaṃ nirayānaṃ
analyzed: apāyānaṃ tiādi catunnam apāyānam āpāyika puggalānam āyu ppamāṇa gaṇanāya niyamaḥ natthi  tattha yebhuyyena tattha nirayesu abbuda ādīnam dasannam nirayānam
translated: There is no limitation of life-span for the unfortunate planes, for the beings in the unfortunate planes, by calculation.🔽For the most part, it is determined by the kamma.🔽In the hells, the life-span of the ten hells beginning with the Abbuda is stated by the Blessed One.

original: bhagavatā vutto āyuparicchedopi tattha tattha nibbattakena kammenevasiddhoti veditabbo.
analyzed: bhagavatā vuttaḥ āyu paricchedaḥ api tattha tattha nibbattakena kammena iva siddhaḥ ti veditabbaḥ
translated: It should be understood that the life-span of the beings born there is determined by the kamma itself.🔽“For human beings” is said with reference to those in Jambudīpa.

original: Manussānanti idaṃ jambudīpagāsīnaṃ vasena vuttanti vadanti. Te saññeva hi āyukappassa
analyzed: manussānam ti idam jambu dīpa gāsīnam vasena vuttanti vadanti te saññā iva hi āyu kappassa
translated: For they alone have an increase and decrease of life-span.🔽Not so the inhabitants of the other continents.

original: ārohaṇaṃ orohaṇañca atthi. Na itaradīpavāsīnaṃ. Tesu hi uttarakuruvāsīnaṃ niyamato
analyzed: ārohaṇam orohaṇam ca atthi na itara dīpa vāsīnam tesu hi uttarakuru vāsīnam niyamataḥ
translated: For the inhabitants of Uttarakuru have a life-span limited to a thousand years.

original: vassa sahassaṃ hoti. Itaresaṃ dvinnaṃ pañcavassa satānītica vadanti. Evaṃ sante tesu🔽dīpesu ādikappikānaṃpi soeva paricchedoti āpajjati. Jambudīpavāsīnaṃ pana samavisamācāranisandabhūtā
analyzed: vassa sahassam hoti itaresam dvinnam pañca vassa satāni iti ca vadanti evam sante tesu  dīpesu ādikappikānam pi saḥ eva paricchedaḥ ti āpajjati jambudīpa vāsīnam pana sama visama ācāra nisanda bhūtā
translated: and for the other two continents, five hundred years. If this is so, then the same limitation of life would apply to the first-born inhabitants of those continents.🔽But the prosperity and adversity of the moon, sun, stars, etc., which are the cause of the good and bad conduct of the inhabitants of Jambudīpa,

original: candasūriyanakkhattādīnaṃ visamasamagatimūlikāutuāhārānaṃ sampatti vipattiyo tesaṃpi🔽sādhāraṇāeva honti. Tasmā tesupi āyuparicchedānaṃ ārohaṇaṃ orohaṇañca natthīti navattabbaṃ.🔽Nisandamattattā jambudīpagatiyā ekagatikā nahontīti pana vattabbaṃ. Tathā hi pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: canda sūriya nakkhatta ādīnam sampatti vipattiyaḥ tesaṃpi  sādhāraṇāḥ eva honti tasmā tesu pi āyu paricchedānam ārohaṇam orohaṇañca natthi iti  nisanda matta ttā jambudīpa gatiyāḥ eka gatikāḥ na honti iti pana vattabbam tathā hi pāḷiyam
translated: and the prosperity and adversity of the seasons, which are the cause of the food supply, are common to all three continents.🔽Therefore the limitation of life in those continents is not subject to increase or decrease.🔽But it should be said that they are not subject to the same movement as the inhabitants of Jambudīpa, because they are not in the same plane. For in the texts it is said:

original: uttarakurukā manussā amamā apariggahā. Niyatāyukā avasesāyunāti vuttaṃ. Tattha avasesāyunāti
analyzed: uttarakurukāḥ manussāḥ amamāḥ apariggahāḥ niyata āyukāḥ avasesa āyunā ati vuttam tattha avasesa āyunā ati
translated: “The people of Uttarakuru are unowned, unclaimed, without possessions, living without wives, living in forests, in the open air, in any old shelter, with heads uncut, with hair untrimmed, with nails and body unkempt, with no choice or effort over their appearance. Their life is fixed, their life span is a hundred years” .🔽Here “fixed” means

original: asaṅkhyeyyato orohitvā niccalaṃ ṭhitena vassasahassenāti atthoti.
analyzed: asaṅkhyeyyataḥ orohitvā niccalam ṭhitena vassa sahassena ati attho ti
translated: that their life span is a thousand years, which is not subject to increase or decrease, but is fixed at a thousand years.

original: Vinipātikāsurānanti idaṃ nidassanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sabbesaṃpi mahesakkhānaṃ appesakkhānañca
analyzed: vinipātika asura ānanti idam nidassana mattam daṭṭhabbam sabbesam pi mahesakkhānam appesakkhānam ca
translated: This is only a demonstration.🔽

original: bhummadevānaṃ vemānikapetādīnañca idha adhippetattā. Tesañhi sabbesaṃpi kammameva
analyzed: bhummadevānam vemānika peta ādīnam ca idha adhippeta ttā tesam hi sabbesam pi kammam eva
translated: This is only a demonstration. For all the great and the lesser earth gods, and the Vehapphala deities, etc., are intended here. For all of them, too, kamma is the measure.

original: pamāṇanti. Cātumahārājikānaṃpanadevānanti idaṃ uparime cātumahārājike sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idam uparime cātumahārājike sandhāya vuttam
translated: The deities of the Four Kings’ Heaven: this is said with reference to the deities of the Four Kings’ Heaven above.

original: Dibbānīti tasmiṃ devaloke siddhāni. Pañca vassasatānīti idañca yebhuyyavasena vuttanti🔽gahetabbaṃ. Yasmā pana kassapabuddhassa sāvakabhūtā sotāpannadeva puttā ākāsaṭṭhaka
analyzed: dibbāni iti tasmin deva loke siddhāni pañca vassa satāni iti idam ca yebhuyya vasena vuttan ti  gahetabbam yasmā pana kassapa buddhassa sāvaka bhūtā sotāpanna deva puttā
translated: Divine: established in that divine world. Five hundred years: this should be taken as said by and large.

original: vimānesu nibbattā yāva nimirājakālāpi tiṭṭhantīti jātakaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttā. Tasmā🔽kesañci ākāsaṭṭhakadevānaṃpi kammapamāṇatā siddhā hotīti veditabbaṃ. Na cettha punappunaṃ
analyzed: vimānesu nibbattāḥ yāva nimi rāja kālā api tiṭṭhanti iti jātaka ṭṭhakathā ayam vuttā tasmā  kesañci kamma pamāṇa tā siddhā hoti iti veditabbam na ca ittha punappunam
translated: For it is said in the Jataka Commentary that the sons of the devas who were stream-enterers in the time of the Buddha Kassapa were reborn in celestial palaces in the sky and remained there until the time of King Nimi.

original: nibbatti cintetabbā. Na hi sotā pannānaṃ sattakkhattuto paraṃ kāmabhave paṭisandhināma
analyzed: nibbatti cintetabbā na hi sotā pannānam satta kkhattutaḥ param kāma bhave paṭisandhi nāma
translated: Therefore it should be understood that the measure of kamma for some of the deities of the celestial palaces in the sky is established. But here no further rebirth should be assumed. For stream-enterers do not take rebirth in the sense-sphere becoming more than seven times.

original: atthi. Na ca tasmiṃ devaloke sahassakkhattuṃ nibbattamānāpi tattakaṃ kālaṃ saṃpāpuṇituṃ
analyzed: atthi na ca tasmin deva loke sahassa kkhattum nibbattamānā api tattakam kālam saṃpāpuṇitum
translated: There is. And even though they are reborn there a thousand times, they are not able to reach the end of that life-span.

original: sakkontīti. Manussagaṇanāyāti manussānaṃ vassagaṇanāya. Manussaloke hi paññāsavassāni
analyzed: sakkonti iti manussa gaṇanāya ati manussānam vassa gaṇanāya manussa loke hi paññāsa vassāni
translated: By human reckoning: by human years. For in the human world fifty years

original: cātumahārājike eko dibbarattidivo hoti. Tiṃsarattidivā eko dibbamāso. Dvādasamāsā
analyzed: cātumahārājike ekaḥ dibba rattidivaḥ hoti tiṃsa rattidivāḥ ekaḥ dibba māsaḥ dvādasa māsā
translated: correspond to one night and day in the sense-sphere heavenly world of the Four Great Kings. Thirty such days make up one month. Twelve months make up

original: ekaṃ dibbavassaṃ. Tena dibbavassena tesaṃ pañcavassasatāni manussagaṇanāya navutivassasatasahassaṃ🔽hotīti. Tatoti cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇato. Catuguṇanti āyupamāṇassa diguṇavuddhiyāceva
analyzed: ekam dibba vassam tena dibba vassena tesam pañca vassa satāni manussa gaṇanāya navuti vassa sata sahassam  hoti iti tatas ti cātumahārājikānam devānam āyu ppamāṇato catuguṇam ti āyu pamāṇassa diguṇa vuddhiyā ca iva
translated: one year. By that heavenly year the life-span of the gods of the Four Great Kings is five hundred years, which by human reckoning is ninety million years.

original: dibbassa rattidivassa diguṇavuddhiyāca vasena catūhi bhāgehi guṇitaṃ vaḍḍhitanti
analyzed: dibbassa ratti divassa vasena catūhi bhāgehi guṇitam vaḍḍhitam ti
translated: Beyond that: beyond the life-span of the gods of the Four Great Kings. Four times: the meaning is that it is increased, made four times, by the increase of the life-span by a factor of two and by the increase of the heavenly night and day by a factor of two.

original: attho. Esanayo sesesupi. Tattha āyupamāṇassa diguṇavuddhināma heṭṭhimānaṃ devānaṃ
analyzed: sesesu pi tattha āyu pamāṇassa diguṇa vuddhi nāma heṭṭhimānam devānam
translated: This method applies to the rest . Therein, the increase of the life-span by a factor of two is as follows:

original: āyupamāṇato uparimānaṃ devānaṃ āyupamāṇassa diguṇavuddhi. Etena tāvatiṃsānaṃ dibbaṃ
analyzed: āyu pamāṇataḥ uparimānam devānam āyu pamāṇassa etena tāvatiṃsānam dibbam
translated: The life-span of the gods above increases by doubling. Thus the life-span of the Thirty-Three gods is

original: ekaṃ vassasahassaṃ. Yāmānaṃ dvevassasahassāni. Tusitānaṃ cattāri, nimmānaratīnaṃ
analyzed: ekam vassa sahassam yāmānam dve vassa sahassāni tusitānam cattāri nimmāna ratīnam
translated: one thousand divine years. That of the Yāma gods is two thousand divine years. That of the Tusita gods is four thousand, that of the Nimmāṇarati gods

original: aṭṭha. Vasavattīnaṃ dibbāni soḷasavassa sahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ hotīti siddhaṃ hoti.🔽Dibbassa rattidivassa diguṇavuddhināma heṭṭhimānaṃ devānaṃ rattidivato uparimānaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭha vasavattīnam dibbāni soḷasa vassa sahassāni āyu ppamāṇam hoti iti siddham hoti  dibbassa rattidivassa diguṇavuddhi nāma heṭṭhimānam devānam rattidivataḥ uparimānam
translated: is eight thousand, and that of the Paranimmitavasavatti gods is sixteen thousand divine years.🔽The divine day and night of the gods below increases by doubling. Thus one hundred human years

original: rattidivassa diguṇavuddhi. Etena manussaloke ekaṃ vassasataṃ tāvatiṃse eko dibbarattidivo.
analyzed: etena manussa loke ekam vassa satam tāvatiṃse ekaḥ dibba ratti divaḥ
translated: are one divine day and night for the Thirty-Three gods.

original: Dvevassasatāni yāme. Cattāri tusite. Aṭṭha nimmānaratiyaṃ. Sahassaṃ cha cavassasatāni
analyzed: dve vassa satāni yāme cattāri tusite aṭṭha nimmāna ratiyam sahassam cha ca vassa satāni
translated: Two hundred years are one day and night for the Yāma gods. Four hundred years are one day and night for the Tusita gods. Eight hundred years are one day and night for the Nimmāṇarati gods. One thousand six hundred years are one day and night for the Paranimmitavasavatti gods.

original: vasavattiyaṃ eko dibbarattidivoti siddhaṃ hoti. Rattidivānañca diguṇavuddhiyā siddhāya
analyzed: ekaḥ siddham siddhāya
translated: When the divine day and night has been established by doubling,

original: māsasaṃvaccharānaṃpi diguṇavuddhi siddhāva hotīti. Evañcasati yathāvuttāni tāvatiṃsādīnaṃ
analyzed: yathā vuttāni tāvatiṃsa ādīnam
translated: the months and years are also established by doubling. Thus the life-span of the Thirty-Three gods, etc.,🔽is

original: dibbavassasahassādinipi attano attano rattidivamāsasaṃvaccharetieva veditabbānīti
analyzed: dibba vassa sahassa ādi nipi attanaḥ attanaḥ ratti diva māsa saṃvacchara iti eva veditabbāni iti
translated: and so on up to a thousand divine years. They should be understood as the day and night, month, and year of those deities.

original: siddhaṃ hoti. Tathāca sati uparimānaṃ āyuparimāṇāni heṭṭhimānaṃ āyuparimāṇato catuguṇānīti
analyzed: siddham hoti tathā ca sati uparimānam āyu parimāṇāni heṭṭhimānam āyu parimāṇato catuguṇāni iti
translated: Thus it is established. And when that is so, then the measure of the life span of the higher deities is established as four times that of the lower ones.

original: siddhaṃ hoti. Tena vuttaṃ. Tato catuguṇaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ. Tato catuguṇaṃ yāmānantiādi.
analyzed: siddham hoti tena vuttam tatas catuguṇam tāvatiṃsānam tatas catuguṇam yāmānam tiādi
translated: Hence it is said: “Four times that is the life span of the Tāvatiṃsa devas. Four times that is the life span of the Yāma devas,” and so on.

original: Dibbagaṇanāya ca tathā siddhāya sati manussagaṇanāyapi catuguṇabhāvo siddhoyeva hoti.
analyzed: dibba gaṇanāya ca tathā siddhāya sati catuguṇa bhāvaḥ siddhaḥ yeva hoti
translated: And when it is established thus by divine reckoning, then it is established by human reckoning too.

original: Tasmā manussagaṇanāyapi heṭṭhimānaṃ navutivassasatasahassādīni catūhi uparūpariguṇitāni
analyzed: tasmā heṭṭhimānam navuti vassa sata sahassa ādīni catūhi
translated: Therefore, by multiplying the lower life spans of ninety thousand years, etc., by four,🔽the higher life spans of three million six hundred thousand years, etc., are established.

original: uparimānaṃ tikoṭisaṭṭhivassasata sahassādini bhavantīti katvā tāni sabbānipi ādiantadassana🔽vasena niddisanto navasatanti gāthamāha. Vassānaṃ navasataṃ koṭiyo ca ekavīsa koṭiyo
analyzed: uparimānam bhavanti iti katvā tāni sabbāni api ādi anta dassana  vasena niddisantaḥ nava satam ti gātham āha vassānam nava satam koṭiyo ca ekavīsa koṭiyo
translated: And so, showing the beginning and end of all these life spans, he said:🔽“Ninety-one times a hundred thousand million years,

original: ca tathāsaṭṭhivassa satasahassāni ca vasavattīsu devesu āyuppamāṇaṃ hotīti yojanā.
analyzed: ca sata sahassāni ca vasavattīsu devesu āyu ppamāṇam hoti iti yojanā
translated: and also twenty-two thousand million years, and also three hundred and sixty thousand million years, is the life span of the Vasavatti devas.”

original: Yasmā avitakkavicāramattaṃ jhānaṃ oḷārikassa vitakkassa samatikkamā pathamajjhānato🔽suṭṭhubalavaṃ hoti. Tatoyeva tatīyajjhānatopi nātidubbalañca hoti. Tasmā taṃ tatīyajjhānena
analyzed: yasmai a vitakka vicāra mattam jhānam oḷārikassa vitakkassa samatikkamā pathama jhānataḥ  suṭṭhu balavam hoti tatoyā iva tatīya jhānataḥ pi na ati dubbalam ca hoti tasmā tam tatīya jhānena
translated: Since the jhāna with applied thought and sustained thought is more quiet than the first jhāna by surmounting the grossness in the form of applied thought,

original: ekato hutvā samatale bhūmantare vipākaṃ detīti vuttaṃ dutīyajjhānavipākaṃ tatiyajjhānavipākañca
analyzed: ekatas hutvā sama tale bhūma antare vipākam deti iti vuttam dutīya jhāna vipākam tatiya jhāna vipākam ca
translated: and it is not too quiet for that reason, being less quiet than the third jhāna, therefore it is said that it gives its ripening in the third jhāna together with the second jhāna,

original: dutīyajjhānabhūmiyanti. Tenevaca bhūmīnaṃ ṭhitikkamopi catutthajjhāna vaseneva siddho.
analyzed: dutīya jjhāna bhūmiyanti tena iva ca bhūmīnam ṭhiti kkamaḥ api catuttha jjhāna vasena iva siddhaḥ
translated: in the plane of the second jhāna. And that is why the order of the planes is established according to the fourth jhāna.

original: Therena pana heṭṭhā pañcakanayavaseneva jhānāni vuttāni. Tasmā idhapi teneva nayena
analyzed: therena pana heṭṭhā pañcaka naya vasena iva jhānāni vuttāni tasmai idha api tena iva nayena
translated: But the elder has stated the jhānas according to the method of the pentad. So here too,

original: vipākāni gahetvā catutthajjhānavipākaṃ tatīyajjhānabhūmiyantiādi vuttaṃ. Tesūti tāhi
analyzed: vipākāni gahetvā catuttha jjhāna vipākam tatīya jjhāna bhūmiyan tiādi vuttam tesu iti tāhi
translated: having taken the kinds of resultant jhāna according to that method, he said, “The plane of the third jhāna is the ripening of the fourth jhāna,” and so on.🔽As to these: in the cases of the six kinds of rebirth-linking stated thus,

original: chahi paṭisandhīti gahitapaṭisandhikesu. Kappassāti idaṃ asaṅkhyeyyakappaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: chahi paṭisandhi iti gahita paṭisandhikesu kappassa ati idam asaṅkhyeyya kappam sandhāya
translated: the “aeon” is said with reference to an asaṅkhyeya great aeon.

original: vuttaṃ. Catubbidhā hi kappāmahākappo asaṅkhyeyyakappo antarakappo āyukappoti, tattha
analyzed: vuttam catubbidhā hi kappāmahākappaḥ asaṅkhyeyyakappaḥ antarakappaḥ āyukappaḥ ti tattha
translated: For there are four kinds of aeons, that is, a great aeon, an asaṅkhyeya aeon, an intermediate aeon, and a life-span aeon.

original: āyukapponāma tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ taṃtaṃ āyuparicchedo vuccati. Antarakapponāma ekassavivaṭṭaṭṭhāyiasaṅkhyeyyassa
analyzed: āyu kappo nāma tesam tesam sattānam taṃ taṃ āyu paricchedaḥ vuccati antara kappo nāma
translated: The life-span is the measure of the life of the various beings. The minor aeon is the aeon of increase and decrease within one station of the world-cycle.

original: abbhantare manussānaṃ āyukappassa hāyanavaḍḍhanavasena dissamānantarā catusaṭṭhipabhedā
analyzed: abbhantare manussānam āyu kappassa hāyana vaḍḍhana vasena dissamāna antarā catur aṭṭhi pabhedā
translated: The life-span of beings is called the life-span period. The intermediate period is the forty-four kinds of minor periods that are seen in the course of the decrease and increase of the life-span of human beings during the interval between a single pair of twin-miraculous discoveries.

original: cūḷakappā vuccanti. Pīsatibhedāti keci. Asītibhedāti apare. Cuddasappa bhedāti vedavidu.
analyzed: cūḷakappāḥ vuccanti pīsati bhedā ati keci asīti bhedā ati apare bhedā ati
translated: Some say that it is divided into eighty, others that it is divided into fourteen.

original: Ye loke manvantarakappāti vuccanti. Ekamekena manunāmakena mahāsammatarājena upalakkhitā
analyzed: ye loke manvantara kappā ti vuccanti ekam ekena manu nāmakena mahāsammata rājena upalakkhitā
translated: What are called the world-cycles are the periods marked by a single Great Universal Monarch called Manu.

original: antarakappāti vuttaṃ hoti. Keci pana ekasmiṃ vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyimhi mahāsammatarā jānaṃ
analyzed: antara kappā ti vuttam hoti keci pana ekasmin vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyimhi
translated: But some say that in the course of a single pair of twin-miraculous discoveries there is only one Great Universal Monarch.

original: ekameva icchanti. Catusaṭṭhiantarakappā pana eko asaṅkhye kapponāma. So catubbidho
analyzed: ekam eva icchanti ekaḥ asaṅkhye kappo nāma so catubbidhaḥ
translated: However, forty-four intermediate periods make up a single incalculable, which is of four kinds as follows:

original: saṃvaṭṭo saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyī vivaṭṭo vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyīti. Tattha vinassamāno kappo saṃvaṭṭo.
analyzed: saṃvaṭṭaḥ saṃvaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī vivaṭṭaḥ vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī iti tattha vinassamānaḥ kappaḥ saṃvaṭṭaḥ
translated: contraction, expansion, contraction and expansion, and stability. The period during which the world is destroyed is called “contraction.”

original: Yathā vinaṭṭhaṃ tiṭṭhamāno kappo saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyī. Vaḍḍhamāno kappo vivaṭṭo. Yathā
analyzed: yathā vinaṭṭham tiṭṭhamānaḥ kappo saṃvaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī vaḍḍhamānaḥ kappo vivaṭṭaḥ yathā
translated: Just as a world-system that is being destroyed is one that is standing, so too, a world-system that is being expanded is one that is expanding.🔽

original: vivaṭṭaṃ tiṭṭhamāno kappo vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyīti veditabbo. Te pana cattāro asaṅkhyeyyakappā🔽eko mahākapponāma. Etthaca yo janāyāmavitthāre setasāsaparāsimhi vassasata vassasataccayena
analyzed: vivaṭṭam tiṭṭhamānaḥ kappaḥ vivaṭṭa ṭhāyī iti veditabbo te pana cattāro asaṅkhyeyya kappā  ekaḥ mahākappaḥ nāma ettha ca yaḥ jana āyāma vitthāre vassa sata vassa sata cayena
translated: As the aeon that is being destroyed is called the aeon of dissolution. As the aeon that is expanding is called the aeon of evolution. As the aeon that is expanding and has reached the world of the first jhāna Brahmās is called the aeon of evolution and abiding. But those four incalculable aeons

original: ekekabījaharaṇena parikkhīṇepi eko mahākappo parikkhayaṃ nagacchati. Evaṃ digho mahākappoti veditabbo.🔽Tattha yadā kappo tejena saṃvaṭṭati. Ābhassarato heṭṭhā agginā dayhati. Yadā āpena🔽saṃvaṭṭati. Subhākiṇṇato heṭṭhā udakena vilīyati. Yadā vāyunā saṃvaṭṭati. Vehapphalato
analyzed: ekeka bīja haraṇena parikkhīṇe api ekaḥ mahā kappo parikkhayam na gacchati evam dighaḥ mahā kappo ti veditabbo  tattha yadā kappaḥ tejena saṃvaṭṭati heṭṭhā agginā dayhati yadā āpena  saṃvaṭṭati subhā kiṇṇataḥ heṭṭhā udakena vilīyati yadā vāyunā saṃvaṭṭati vehapphalataḥ
translated: are one great aeon. And here, when the great aeon is exhausted, the aeon of the world’s dissolution has not yet come to an end. So long as the great aeon lasts, the world does not dissolve. This is how long the great aeon should be understood.

original: heṭṭhā vātena viddhaṃsatīti evaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttattā ayaṃ loko nirantaraṃ sattasu
analyzed: heṭṭhā vātena viddhaṃsati iti evam aṭṭhakathā ayam vutta ttā ayam lokaḥ nirantaram sattasu
translated: When the aeon dissolves by fire, it burns from the world of the Gods of Radiance downwards. When it dissolves by water, it dissolves from the Subhakiṇha Brahmā-world downwards. When it dissolves by wind, it is dispersed from the Vehapphala Brahmā-world downwards. This is how it is stated in the commentary. So this world is without interruption🔽for seven

original: vāresu agginā vinassati. Aṭṭhame vāre udakena vinassati. Puna sattasu agginā. Aṭṭhame🔽udakenāti evaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ aṭṭhakānaṃ vasena catusaṭṭhivāresu antime udakavāre udakaṃ
analyzed: vāresu agginā vinassati aṭṭhame vāre udakena vinassati puna sattasu agginā aṭṭhame  udakena ati evam aṭṭhannam aṭṭhakānam vasena catur aṭṭhi vāresu antime udaka vāre udakam
translated: and in the eighth it is destroyed by fire. In the eighth it is destroyed by water. Again, in seven it is destroyed by fire. In the eighth

original: pahāya vātavāro hotīti ayamattho siddho hoti. Kathaṃ. Yaṃ vuttaṃ ābhassarānaṃ aṭṭhakappānīti.
analyzed: pahāya vātavāraḥ hoti iti ayam attho siddhaḥ hoti katham yat vuttam ābhassarānam aṭṭhakappāni iti
translated: it is destroyed by water. Thus, by the method of eights, in the sixty-four periods, in the last one, which is that of water, the water disappears and the wind period comes. This is the meaning that is established. How? It is said:🔽“The Brahmas of the Aviha plane live for eight eons.”

original: Etena aṭṭhame vāre āposaṃvaṭṭo hoti. Antarā sattasu sattasu vāresu tejosaṃvaṭṭā hontīti🔽siddhaṃ. Yañca vuttaṃ subhākiṇṇānaṃ catusaṭṭhikappānīti. Etena catusaṭṭhime catusaṭṭhime
analyzed: etena aṭṭhame vāre āposaṃvaṭṭaḥ hoti antarā sattasu sattasu vāresu tejosaṃvaṭṭāḥ honti iti  siddham yat ca vuttam subha ākiṇṇānam catusaṭṭhi kappāni iti etena catus aṭṭhime catusaṭṭhime
translated: By this it is established that in the eighth period there is the dissolution of water, and in the intervening seven periods there are the dissolutions of fire.

original: vāre vātasaṃvaṭṭohoti. Antarā tesaṭṭhiyā vāresu tejosaṃvaṭṭā āposaṃvaṭṭāca hontīti
analyzed: vāre antarā tesaṭṭhiyāḥ vāresu tejaḥ saṃvaṭṭāḥ āposaṃvaṭṭāḥ ca honti iti
translated: And it is said: “The Brahmas of the Sudassa plane live for sixty-four eons.” By this it is established that in the sixty-fourth period there is the dissolution of wind, and in the intervening sixty-three periods there are the dissolutions of fire and water.

original: siddhaṃ hotīti. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: siddham hoti iti tena āhu porāṇā
translated: Therefore the ancients said:🔽“The world is destroyed by fire below the Brahmas of Radiance,

original: Agginā bhassarā heṭṭhā, āpena subhākiṇṇato;
analyzed: agginā bhassarā heṭṭhā āpena subhā kiṇṇataḥ
translated: by water below the Subhakiṇha Brahmas,

original: Vehapphalato vātena, evaṃ loko vinassati.
analyzed: vehapphalataḥ vātena evam lokaḥ vinassati
translated: and by wind below the Vehapphala Brahmas.”

original: Sattasattagginā vārā, aṭṭhame aṭṭhame dakā;
analyzed: satta sattagginā vārāḥ aṭṭhame aṭṭhame dakā
translated: In seven periods there is fire, in the eighth water,

original: Catusaṭṭhi yadā puṇṇā, eko vāyuvāro siyāti.
analyzed: catusaṭṭhi yadā puṇṇāḥ ekaḥ vāyuvāraḥ siyāti
translated: When the sixty-four are full, One wind-period is what it is called.

original: Evañca vinaṭṭhe loke ekasmiṃ kappepi pathamajjhānabhūmi avinaṭṭhānāma natthi. Tasmā
analyzed: evam ca vinaṭṭhe loke ekasmin kappe pi pathamajjhāna bhūmi avinaṭṭhā nāma natthi tasmā
translated: And when the world is thus destroyed, there is no plane of the first jhāna that is not destroyed in a world-cycle.

original: brahmapārisajjānaṃdevānaṃ kappassatatīyo bhāgo āyuppamāṇaṃ, brahmapurohitānaṃupaḍḍhakappo,
analyzed: brahmapārisajjānam devānam kappassa tatīyaḥ bhāgaḥ āyu ppamāṇam brahmapurohitānam upaḍḍha kappaḥ
translated: So the life-span of the Brahmapārisajja gods is three-quarters of a world-cycle, of the Brahmapurohita gods a half-cycle,

original: mahā brahmānaṃekokappoti ettha asaṅkhyeyya kappova sambhavati. Namahākappo. Tena
analyzed: ettha asaṅkhyeyya kappo uva sambhavati tena
translated: and of the Mahā-Brahmā gods one whole cycle. Herein, a “cycle” is not a “countless” of world-cycles.

original: vuttaṃ kappassāti idaṃ asaṅkhyeyyakappaṃ sandhāya vuttanti. Āyukappaṃ sandhāya vuttantipi
analyzed: vuttam kappassa ati idam asaṅkhyeyya kappam sandhāya vuttan ti āyu kappam sandhāya vuttan tipi
translated: So it is said that “a world-cycle” is said with reference to a “countless” of world-cycles. But it is also appropriate to say that it is said with reference to a life-span of a world-cycle.

original: yujjatiyeva. Tejosaṃvaṭṭakappesu hi pathamajjhānatalaṃ vivaṭṭamānaṃ sabbapathamaṃ🔽vivaṭṭati. Saṃvaṭṭamānaṃ sabbapacchā saṃvaṭṭati. Tasmā vivaṭṭassa pacchimaḍḍhena
analyzed: yujjatiyā iva tejaḥ saṃvaṭṭa kappesu hi pathama jhāna talam vivaṭṭamānam sabba pathamam  vivaṭṭati saṃvaṭṭamānam sabbapacchā saṃvaṭṭati tasmai vivaṭṭassa pacchimaḍḍhena
translated: For in the case of the conflagration world-cycles, the plane of the first jhāna is the first to be destroyed and the last to be re-formed.

original: saṃvaṭṭassaca pubbaḍḍhena saha ekaṃ vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyikappaṃ gahetvā dve asaṅkhyeyyāni
analyzed: saṃvaṭṭassa ca pubbaḍḍhena saha ekam vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyi kappam gahetvā dve asaṅkhyeyyāni
translated: So taking the last half of the re-formation and the first half of the destruction together as one “world-cycle of re-formation” and doing the same with the other three,

original: tasmiṃ tale eko āyukappoti sakkā vattunti. Dutīya talato paṭṭhāya pana mahākappova
analyzed: tasmin tale ekaḥ āyu kappo ti sakkā vattunti dutīya talataḥ paṭṭhāya pana
translated: But from the second aeon onwards the aeons are to be taken as great aeons.

original: gahetabbo. Appakaṃ ūnakaṃvā adhikaṃvā gaṇanūpagaṃ na hotīti katvā upaḍḍhehi saha
analyzed: gahetabbaḥ appakam ūnakam vā adhikam vā gaṇana upagam na hoti iti katvā upaḍḍhehi saha
translated: Because a small number, whether less or more, does not come to an aeon,🔽it is said that the Brahmā’s life-span is eight aeons, referring to seven aeons together with a half.

original: sattakappāni sandhāya ābhassarānaṃ aṭṭhakappānīti vuttaṃ. Evaṃ catusaṭṭhikappānīti
analyzed: satta kappāni sandhāya ābhassarānam aṭṭha kappāni iti vuttam evam catur aṭṭhi kappāni iti
translated: So too in the case of the forty-six aeons.

original: etthapīti. Ākāsānañcāyatanabhavaṃ upagacchantīti ākāsānañcāyatanupagā, tesaṃ. Ekova
analyzed: ettha api iti ākāsa anañcāyatana bhavam upagacchanti iti ākāsa anañcāyatana upagā tesam ekaḥ uva
translated: They go to the becoming of the base consisting of boundless space, thus they are bound for the base consisting of boundless space.🔽The object, the objective field, of that is one only, thus it is the “one-object” .

original: visayo ārammaṇaṃ yassa taṃ ekavisayaṃ. Ekajātiyanti ekasmiṃ bhave. [Paṭisandhicatukkaṃ.]
analyzed: visayaḥ ārammaṇam yassa tam eka visayam eka jātiyanti ekasmin bhave paṭisandhi catukkam
translated: In one kind of becoming, thus in one kind of rebirth-linking.

original: 145. Janetīti janakaṃ upatthambhetīti upatthambhakaṃ. Upapīḷetīti upapīḷakaṃ. Upaghātetīti🔽upaghātakaṃ. Tattha janakaṃ nāma paṭisandhipavattīsu vipākakkhandha kaṭattārūpānaṃ
analyzed: janeti iti janakam upatthambheti iti upatthambhakam upapīḍeti iti upapīḍakam upaghāteti iti  upaghātakam tattha janakam nāma paṭisandhi pavattīsu vipāka kkhandha kaṭattā rūpānam
translated: It generates, thus it is a generator. It supports, thus it is a supporter. It oppresses, thus it is an oppressor. It destroys, thus it is a destroyer.🔽Herein, profitable and unprofitable volition that generates the aggregates subject to ripening and the kinds of materiality due to kamma performed is a generator of rebirth-linking and occurrence.

original: nibbattikā kusalākusalacetanā. Tattha paṭisandhinibbattikā kammapathapattāva daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: nibbattikā kusala akusala cetanā tattha paṭisandhi nibbattikā kammapatha pattā ava daṭṭhabbā
translated: Herein, only that which generates rebirth-linking should be regarded as a course of kamma.

original: Pavattinibbattikā pana kammapathaṃ pattāpi apattāpi antamaso pañcadvārikajavanacetanāpi🔽supinante kusalākusalacetanāpīti. Upatthambhakaṃnāma vipaccituṃ aladdhokāsāvā vipakkavipākā
analyzed: pavatti nibbattikā pana kammapatham pattā api a pattā api antamaso pañca dvārika javana cetanā api  kusala akusala cetanā api iti upatthambhakam nāma vipaccitum a laddha ukāsāvā vipakka vipākā
translated: But the instigation is the volition of the five doors and the triple- door consciousnesses that has reached the state of a path of action and that which has not, and also the profitable and unprofitable volition in dreams.

original: vā sabbāpi kusalākusalacetanā. Sā hi janakabhūtāpi samānā attanovipākavārato purevā
analyzed: vā sabbā api kusala akusala cetanā sā hi janaka bhūtā api samānā attanaḥ vipāka vārataḥ purā iva
translated: The support is all profitable and unprofitable volition that has not yet obtained an opportunity to ripen or whose ripening has already ripened.

original: pacchāvā sabhāṅgaṃ kammanta raṃvākammanibbattakkhandhasantānaṃvāupatthambhamānā pavattati.
analyzed: pacchā vā sabhā aṅgam kammantaram vā a kamma nibbatta kkhandha santānam vā upatthambhamānā pavattati
translated: For that, though it is the generator, occurs supporting the continuity of aggregates produced by the kamma that is its own result, whether before or after it, as a whole, as it were, as a unit, as a single thing.

original: Yathā ganthārabbhe ratanattayapaṇāmacetanāti. Yaṃ pana visuddhimagge upatthambhakaṃ
analyzed: yathā gantha ārabbhe yam pana visuddhi magge upatthambhakam
translated: Like the volition of paying homage to the Three Jewels, which is the condition for the continuity of aggregates beginning with the binding together of the limbs.

original: pana vipākaṃ janetuṃ nasakkotīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ aladdhavipākavāraṃ sandhāya vuttanti
analyzed: pana vipākam janetum na sakkoti iti vuttam tat aladdha vipāka vāram sandhāya vuttan ti
translated: But what is said in the Path of Purification, “The support is that which is unable to generate ripening,” should be taken as said with reference to that which has not yet obtained an opportunity to ripen;

original: gahetabbaṃ. Na hi paccayasāmaggiyaṃ sati kiñcikammaṃ pavattivipākamattassapi ajanakaṃnāma
analyzed: gahetabbam na hi paccaya sāmaggiyam sati kiñci kammam ajanakam nāma
translated: for there is no kamma that, when the concurrence of conditions is present, is unable to generate even the mere occurrence and ripening.

original: atthīti. Tattha kammantarassa upatthambhanaṃnāma aladdhokāsassa aññassa janakakammassa
analyzed: atthi iti tattha kammantarassa upatthambhanaṃ nāma a laddha ukāsassa aññassa janaka kammassa
translated: Herein, the “support” of other kamma is that of kamma that has not obtained an opportunity, which is a generator of kamma.

original: okāsakaraṇaṃ. Taṃ pana maraṇāsannakāle pākaṭaṃ. Tadā hi kusale javite aññaṃ paṭisandhijanakaṃ
analyzed: okāsakaraṇam tam pana maraṇa āsanna kāle pākaṭam tadā hi kusale javite aññam paṭisandhi janakam
translated: and the opportunity is the occasion. But that is evident only at the time of death. For then, if the profitable is quick in effective action, it finds the opportunity to produce rebirth-linking instead of the unprofitable, and vice versa. This is what is said in the following lines:

original: kusalakammaṃ okāsaṃ labhati. Akusale javite aññaṃ akusalakammanti. Vuttañhetaṃ iti vuttake –
analyzed: kusala kammam okāsam labhati akusale javite aññam akusala kamman ti vuttam ha etam iti vuttake
translated: “If a man should die, good people,

original: Imasmiṃ cāyaṃ samaye, kālaṅkariyātha puggalo;
analyzed: imasmin ca ayam samaye puggalaḥ
translated: At this time, he would be reborn in heaven,

original: Saggamhi upapajjeyya, cittañhissa pasāditaṃ.
analyzed: saggamhi upapajjeyya cittam hissa pasāditam
translated: Since his mind is purified.🔽If a man should die, good people,

original: Imasmiṃ cāyaṃ samaye, kālaṅkariyātha puggalo;
analyzed: imasmin ca ayam samaye puggalaḥ
translated: At this time, he would be reborn in hell,

original: Niraye upapajjeyya, cittañhissa padūsitanti.🔽Pavattikālepi etaṃ bahulaṃ labbhatiyeva. Kammanibbattakhandhasantānassa upatthambhanaṃnāma🔽aññena laddhokāsena kusalakammenavā akusalakammenavā nibbattassa khandhasantānassa
analyzed: niraye upapajjeyya cittam hissa padūsitanti  pavatti kāle pi etam bahulam labbhatiyā iva kamma nibbatta khandha santānassa upatthambhanaṃ nāma  aññena laddha okāsena kusala kammena vā akusala kammena vā nibbattassa khandha santānassa
translated: Since his mind is corrupted.”

original: jīvitantarāye apanetvā jīvitaparikkhāre samudānetvā ciratara pavattikaraṇaṃ. Yathāha –
analyzed: jīvita antarāye apanetvā jīvita parikkhāre samudānetvā ciratara pavatti karaṇam yathā āha
translated: And this is also frequent at the time of rebirth-linking. The “support” is the prolonging of the continuity of aggregates produced by profitable or unprofitable kamma that has found the opportunity, by warding off obstacles to life and by providing requisites for life, and so causing it to continue for a long time. As it is said:🔽“He who is of polite behaviour,

original: Abhivādanasīlissa, niccaṃ vuddhāpacāyino;
analyzed: abhivādana sīlissa niccam vuddha apacāyinaḥ
translated: Who is ever respectful to elders,

original: Cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti, āyu vaṇṇo sukhaṃ balanti.🔽Ettha pana kusalaṃpi akusalakammanibbattassa khandhasantānassa akusalaṃpi kusalakammanibbattassa🔽upatthambhakaṃnāma natthīti navattabbaṃ. Akusala kamma nibbattassapi hi mahiddhikānaṃ
analyzed: cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti āyu vaṇṇo sukham  ettha pana kusalam pi akusala kamma nibbattassa khandha santānassa akusalam pi kusala kamma nibbattassa  upatthambhakaṃ nāma natthi iti akusala kamma nibbattassa api hi mahiddhikānam
translated: The four things increase: life, beauty, happiness, strength.🔽Herein, however, there is no such thing as a profitable or unprofitable state that is a support for a continuity of aggregates produced by profitable or unprofitable kamma.

original: nāgasupaṇṇādīnaṃ khandhasantānassa pavattikāle pubbakataṃ kusalaṃ vuttanayena upabrūhanaṃ🔽karotiyeva. Tathākusalakammanibbattassapi kesañci vinipātikāsurādīnaṃ khandhasantānassa
analyzed: nāga supaṇṇa ādīnam khandha santānassa pavatti kāle pubba katam kusalam vutta nayena upabrūhanam  karotiyā iva tathā akusala kamma nibbattassa api kesañci vinipātika asura ādīnam khandha santānassa
translated: For even when the continuity of aggregates of nāgas, supaṇṇas, etc., of great power produced by unprofitable kamma is occurring, the profitable kamma done previously causes the support to be strengthened in the way already described.

original: pavattikāle pubbakataṃ akusalaṃ ciratarappavattiṃ karotiyevāti. Upapīḷakaupaghātakānipi
analyzed: pavatti kāle pubba katam akusalam ciratara ppavattim upapīḍaka aupaghātakāni pi
translated: And even when the continuity of aggregates of some beings in states of loss, etc., produced by profitable kamma is occurring, the unprofitable kamma done previously causes the support to last longer.

original: vuttappakārā kusalākusala cetanāyoeva. Tāpi hi janakabhūtāpi samānā attano vipākavārato
analyzed: vutta ppakārā tā api hi janaka bhūtā api samānāḥ attanaḥ vipāka vārato
translated: And the states that are a source of affliction and a source of harm are profitable and unprofitable volition itself.

original: purevā pacchā vā vipākavāra gahaṇa kālepi vā kammantaraṃvā kammanibbatta khandhasantānaṃvā
analyzed: purā vā pacchā vā vipāka vāra gahaṇa kāle pi vā kamma antaram vā kamma nibbatta khandha santānam vā
translated: And although that is the producer, it causes the occurrence of the continuity of aggregates produced by kamma either before or after the time of the occurrence of the kamma itself or at that same time.

original: dubbalataraṃ katvāvā vibādhayamānā sabbasovā upacchindamānā pavattantīti. Tattha🔽upapīḷake tāva kammantarassa vibādhanaṃnāma aññassa janakakammassa dubbalabhāvakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: dubbalataram vibādhayamānā sabbaso vā upacchindamānā pavattanti iti tattha  upapīḍake tāva kamma antarassa vibādhanaṃ nāma aññassa janaka kammassa dubbala bhāva karaṇaṃ
translated: and it is called “obstructing” because it obstructs the other productive kamma by weakening it.

original: Kammañhi nāma āyūhanakāle balavantaṃpi pacchā katena ujupaṭipakkhena kammantarena🔽vibādhiyamānaṃ puna vihatasāmatthiyaṃ hoti. Uparibhūmi nibbattakaṃpi samānaṃ heṭṭhābhūmiyaṃ
analyzed: kamman hi nāma āyūhana kāle balavantam pi pacchā katena uju paṭipakkhena kammantarena  vibādhiyamānam puna vihata sāmatthiyam hoti upari bhūmi samānam heṭṭhābhūmiyam
translated: For kamma, though powerful, is weakened by the kamma that is produced later and is in opposition to it.🔽It causes it to be reborn in a lower plane, though it is due to be reborn in a higher one;

original: nibbatteti. Mahesakkhesu mahiddhikesu nibbattakaṃpi samānaṃ appesakkhesu nibbatteti.
analyzed: nibbattā iti mahesakkhesu mahiddhikesu nibbattakam api samānam appesakkhesu nibbattā iti
translated: in the next rebirth it causes it to be reborn in a lower family, though it is due to be reborn in a higher one;🔽in a poor family, though it is due to be reborn in a rich one;

original: Tathā uccakulesu nibbattakaṃpi nīcakulesu. Dīghāyukesu nibbattakaṃpi appāyukesu.🔽Mahābhogesu nibbattakaṃpi appabhogesu. Purisatta bhāvanibbattakaṃpi samānaṃ itthattabhāvaṃvā
analyzed: tathā ucca kulesu nibbattakam pi nīca kulesu dīgha āyukesu nibbattakam pi appa āyukesu 🔽mahā bhogesu nibbattakam pi appabhogesu bhāva nibbattakam pi samānam itthatta bhāvam vā
translated: in the female sex, though it is due to be reborn in the male sex;

original: napuṃsakabhāvaṃ vā nibbatteti. Vaṇṇasampattinibbattakaṃpi dubbaṇṇabhāvaṃ. Indriyasampattinibbattakaṃpi🔽andhaṃvā badhiraṃvā yaṃkiñci indriyavekallaṃ. Aṅgapaccaṅga sampattijanakaṃpi hatthapādādi
analyzed: napuṃsaka bhāvam vā nibbatteti vaṇṇa sampatti nibbattakam pi dubbaṇṇa bhāvam indriya sampatti nibbattakam pi  andham vā badhiram vā yat kiñci indriya vekallam aṅga paccaṅga sampatti janakam pi hattha pāda ādi
translated: or it produces the state of a eunuch. That which produces the possession of beauty produces ugliness. That which produces the possession of the faculties produces🔽blindness, deafness, and so on, and any deficiency of faculties. That which produces the possession of the major and minor parts produces deficiency of

original: aṅgavekallaṃ janeti. Tathā āyūhanakāle mahānirayesu nibbattakaṃpi akusalaṃ pacchākatena
analyzed: aṅga vekallam janeti tathā āyūhana kāle mahānirayesu akusalam pacchākatena
translated: hands, feet, and so on. Similarly, unprofitable action that produces rebirth in the great hells at the time of the accumulation of kamma produces rebirth in the minor hells or the animal realm or the ghost realm, and so on,

original: balavakusalena vibādhiyamānaṃ ussadesuvā petesuvā nibbatteti. Ajātasattu rājā cettha🔽nidassanaṃ. Ussadesu nibbattakaṃpi petesuvā tiracchā nesuvāti ādisabbaṃ vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: balava kusalena vibādhiyamānam ussadesuvā petesuvā nibbattā iti ajātasattu rājā ca ittha  nidassanam ussadesu tiracchā nesu vā tiracchā
translated: when it is obstructed by strong profitable action or unprofitable action that has arisen later. King Ajātasattu is an example here.🔽And that which produces rebirth in the minor hells produces rebirth in the animal realm or the ghost realm, and so on.

original: Upatthambhakaṃpi tabbipariyāyena veditabbameva. Tathā hi kammaṃ nāma katakāledubbalaṃpisamānaṃ
analyzed: upatthambhakaṃpi tad vipariyāyena veditabbam eva tathā hi kammam nāma kata kāle dubbalaṃpi samānam
translated: That which consolidates should be understood in the opposite sense. For although kamma is weak at the time of its doing,

original: pacchāsabhāgenabalavatākusalenavā akusalenavā upatthambhīyamānaṃ suṭṭhu balavaṃ hotīti.
analyzed: pacchā sabhāgena balavatā akusalena vā akusalena vā upatthambhīyamānam suṭṭhu balavam hoti iti
translated: it becomes strong when consolidated by strong profitable or unprofitable action that arises later.

original: Kammanibbatta khandhasantānassa vibādhanaṃnāma aññena kammena nibbattassa sattassa
analyzed: kamma nibbatta khandha santānassa vibādhanaṃ nāma aññena kammena nibbattassa sattassa
translated: “Hindering the continuity of aggregates produced by kamma” means that when a being is produced by another kamma,

original: gahitapaṭisandhito paṭṭhāya yadākadāci sarīre nānāantarāye uppādetvāvā ṭhānantarakhettavatthu
analyzed: gahita paṭisandhito paṭṭhāya yadā kadāci sarīre nānā antarāye uppādetvā vā
translated: from the moment he has taken rebirth-linking, at some time or other, by producing various obstacles in his body, or by destroying his dwelling place, field,

original: gomahiṃsa dhana dhaññabhoga sampattīnaṃ puttadārañāti mittānañca vipattiṃ katvāvā
analyzed: go mahiṃsa dhana dhañña bhoga sampattīnam putta dāra ñāti mittānam ca vipattim katvā vā
translated: cattle, buffaloes, wealth, grain, and enjoyments, or by causing misfortune to his children, wife, and friends,

original: dukkhuppatti karaṇaṃ. Duvidhañhi kammaphalaṃnāma vipākaphalaṃ nisandaphalanti. Tattha
analyzed: dukkha uppatti karaṇam duvidham hi kamma phalam nāma vipāka phalam nisanda phalanti tattha
translated: he causes the arising of suffering. For the fruit of kamma is twofold, namely, the fruit of resultants and the fruit of natural outcome.

original: vipākaphalaṃnāma kammakārakasseva hoti. Na aññassa. Nisanda phalaṃ pana aññesaṃpi
analyzed: vipāka phalam nāma kamma kārakassa iva hoti na aññassa nisanda phalam pana aññesam pi
translated: Herein, the fruit of resultants belongs only to the doer of the kamma, not to others. But the fruit of natural outcome is common to others also.

original: sādhāraṇameva. Dhammapade ānandaseṭṭhivatthu ettha vattabbaṃ. Cakkhādīsu pana kammajasantathisīsesu
analyzed: sādhāraṇam eva dhamma pade ānanda seṭṭhi vatthu ettha vattabbam cakkha ādīsu pana kamma ja santathi sīsesu
translated: The story of the merchant Anan-da in the Dhammapada Commentary should be told here. But in the case of the eye, etc., which are a continuity produced by kamma,

original: yena kammena yaṃkiñci ekaṃvā dvevā tīṇivā sabbaso bhijjanti. Cakkhupālatthe rādīnaṃ
analyzed: yena kammena yaṃ kiñci ekaṃvā dve vā tīṇi vā sabbasas bhijjanti cakkhupāla tthe ra ādīnam
translated: when one or two or three are completely destroyed by a certain kamma,🔽that kamma is included in the heading of “hindering,” like the “eye-spokes” in the story of the chariot.

original: viya. Taṃ kammaṃ upaghātake saṅgahitanti yuttaṃ. Upaghā takanti pana upacchedakantica
analyzed: viya tat kammam upaghātake saṅgahitanti yuttam upaghā takanti pana upacchedakanti ca
translated: But “hindering” is also called “obstructing.”

original: atthato ekaṃ. Tathā hi majjhimaṭṭha kathāyaṃ pathamaṃ upacchedakanāmena vatvā upaghātakantipi
analyzed: atthataḥ ekam tathā hi kathā ayam pathamam upacchedaka nāmena vatvā
translated: and in meaning it is one. For in the Majjhima Commentary, after first mentioning it under the name of “cutting off”, it is said that “it is also called ‘suppressing’ ” .

original: etasseva nāmanti vuttaṃ. Aṅguttaraṭṭhakathāyaṃ pathamaṃ upaghātakanāmena vatvā upacchedakantipi
analyzed: etassa iva nāman ti vuttam aṅguttara ṭṭhakathā ayam pathamam upaghātaka nāmena vatvā
translated: And in the Anguttara Commentary, after first mentioning it under the name of “suppressing”, it is said that “it is also called ‘cutting off’ ” .

original: tassevetaṃ nāmanti vuttaṃ. Visuddhi maggepi maraṇassatiniddese tadeva kammupacchedakakammanti
analyzed: tassa iva itam nāman ti vuttam visuddhi magge pi maraṇa ssati niddese tat eva kamma upacchedaka kamman ti
translated: And in the Path of Purification, in the description of mindfulness of death, it is called “the action of cutting off the kamma that is to be retributed next” .

original: vuttaṃ. Idhaca parato upacchedakakammunāti vakkhati.
analyzed: vuttam idha ca paratas upacchedaka kammunā ti vakkhati
translated: But here it is called “the action of cutting off the next kamma” .

original: Imassapi kammantarupacchedanaṃ maraṇāsannakāle pākaṭaṃ. Tadāhi pathamaṃ pāpakammabalena🔽duggatinimitte upaṭṭhahante puna kalyāṇa kammaṃ taṃ paṭibāhitvā sugatinimittaṃ dassetvā
analyzed: imassa api kamma antar upacchedanam maraṇa āsanna kāle pākaṭam tadā hi pathamam pāpa kamma balena  duggati nimitte upaṭṭhahante puna kalyāṇa kammam tam paṭibāhitvā sugati nimittam dassetvā
translated: And the cutting off of the next kamma is evident at the time of the approach of death. For then, when the signs of an unhappy destiny appear owing to the power of evil kamma,🔽a good kamma again prevents that and shows the signs of a happy destiny,🔽and it causes rebirth in a happy destiny in the worlds of the gods. And when the signs of a happy destiny appear owing to the power of good kamma,

original: sagge nibbatteti. Kalyāṇakammabalena sugatinimitte upaṭṭhahante puna pāpakammaṃ taṃ
analyzed: sagge nibbattā iti kalyāṇa kamma balena sugati nimitte upaṭṭhahante puna pāpa kammam tam
translated: an evil kamma again prevents that and shows the signs of an unhappy destiny,

original: paṭibāhitvā duggatinimittaṃ dassetvā apāye nibbatteti. Duṭṭha gāmaṇirañño soṇattherapituca
analyzed: paṭibāhitvā duggati nimittam dassetvā apāye nibbattā iti duṭṭha
translated: and it causes rebirth in an unhappy destiny in the states of deprivation. The father of the Elder Soṇa, who was the king of the wicked men of Duṭṭhagama,

original: vatthūni kathetabbāni. Aṅguttaraṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana kusalākusalakammakkhaya karassa
analyzed: vatthūni kathetabbāni aṅguttara ṭṭhakathāyam pana kusala akusala kamma kkhaya karassa
translated: and the bases for them should be told. But in the Commentary on the Book of Fives it is said that the profitable and unprofitable kamma that is exhausted

original: maggakammassapi kammantarupacchedakahā vuttā. Aṅgulimālattherādīnaṃ viyāti. Imasmiṃ🔽bhave laddhāni mahaggatakammāni yena akusalena parihāyanti. Tassapi kammantarupacchedake
analyzed: magga kammassa api kammantara upaccheda kahā vuttā aṅguli māla tthera ādīnam viyāti imasmin  bhave laddhāni mahaggata kammāni yena akusalena parihāyanti tassa api kamma antar upacchedake
translated: is also a kamma that cuts off the continuity of kamma. As in the case of the Elder Aṅgulimāla, etc.

original: saṅgaho yutto. Devadattassa viyāti. Kammanibbattakhandhasantānupacchedanaṃ pana tasmiṃ🔽tasmiṃ bhave āyu kammesu vijjamānesu laddhokāsassa kassaci aparādhakammassa balena
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ yuttaḥ devadattassa viyāti kamma nibbatta khandha santāna upacchedanam pana tasmin  tasmin bhave āyu kammesu vijjamānesu laddha ukāsassa kassaci aparādha kammassa balena
translated: The profitable kamma acquired in this existence is lost through unprofitableness. That too is included in the kamma that cuts off the continuity of kamma. As in the case of Devadatta.

original: kalalakālato paṭṭhāya antarāva kenacirogenavā bhayenavā upakkamenavā marantānaṃ vasena veditabbaṃ.🔽Etthaca kammantarassavā kammanibbattakhandhasantānassavā upatthambhanā dīni sandhāya
analyzed: kalala kālataḥ paṭṭhāya kenacid rogena vā bhayena vā upakkamena vā marantānam vasena veditabbam  ettha ca kamma antara ssavā kamma nibbatta khandha santāna ssavā upatthambhanā dīni sandhāya
translated: But the cutting off of the continuity of the aggregates that produce the kamma is to be understood as occurring in this or that existence through the power of some kamma that is blameworthy and finds an opportunity to do so, among the kammas and lives that exist, by way of dying in the interval from the time of the kalala stage onwards through some disease or through fear or through an attack.

original: imesaṃ catunnaṃpi kammānaṃ kusalākusalabhāvo visuddhimagge aṅguttaraṭṭhakathāyañca
analyzed: imesam catunnam api kammānam kusala akusala bhāvaḥ visuddhi magge aṅguttaraṭṭhakathāyañca
translated: And here the profitable and unprofitable characters of these four kinds of kamma should be understood according to the fourfold method of cutting off the continuity of kamma, of cutting off the continuity of the aggregates that produce the kamma, of support, etc.,🔽as stated in the Path of Purification and in the Commentary on the Book of Fives.

original: vutto. Majjhimaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana saṃvaṇṇetabbasuttānurūpaṃ kammanibbattakhandhasantānasseva
analyzed: vuttaḥ majjhima ṭṭhakathāyam pana saṃvaṇṇetabba sutta anurūpam kamma nibbatta khandha santānassa iva
translated: But in the Majjhima commentary, in the introduction to the Majjhima Nikāya, the aggregates that are the basis for the kamma that should be commended are given as follows:

original: upatthambhanādīni sandhāya upatthambhakassa kusalabhāvo upapīḷakaupaghātakānaṃ akusalabhāvo
analyzed: upatthambhana ādīni sandhāya upatthambhakassa kusala bhāvaḥ upapīḍaka aupaghātakānaṃ akusala bhāvaḥ
translated: But in the Majjhima commentary, the profitable and unprofitable characters of the supporter and the oppressor are stated respectively in terms of the maintenance and so on and the oppression and so on of the continuity of aggregates that is the doer of the action, in accordance with the sutta to be commented on.🔽But that is stated as if it were not acceptable in the Majjhima commentary and the Anguttara commentary.

original: vutto. So pana majjhimaṭīkāyaṃ aṅguttaraṭīkāyañca aruccamāno viya vutto. Mahāṭīkāyaṃ🔽pana so keci vādopi kato. Tatthapana saṃvaṇṇetabbasuttānurūpaṃ vuttattā visuṃ pāḷinayoti
analyzed: vutto so pana majjhima ṭīkāyam aṅguttara ṭīkāyam ca a ruccamānaḥ viya vuttaḥ mahā ṭīkāyam  pana saḥ keci vādaḥ api kataḥ tattha pana saṃvaṇṇetabba sutta anurūpam vutta ttā visum
translated: But in the Mahā commentary it is also stated as the opinion of some.🔽But it should be regarded as a separate method of reading because it is stated in accordance with the sutta to be commented on.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Na ca kecivādo kattabbo. Suttasmiṃhi appāyukasaṃvattanikāesā māṇavapaṭipadā,🔽yadidaṃ pāṇātipātī hotītiādinā upaghātakaṃ pāṇātipātavaseneva vuttaṃ. Upapīḷakañca
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ na ca kecivādaḥ kattabbaḥ suttasmin hi māṇava paṭipadā  yat idam pāṇa atipātī hoti iti ādinā upaghātakam pāṇa atipāta vasena iva vuttam upapīḍakam ca
translated: And it should not be stated as the opinion of some, because in the sutta the course that leads to having a short life is stated as the oppressing of breathing things by killing breathing things, and so on.

original: batvābādhasaṃvattanikā esā māṇava paṭipadā, yadidaṃ sattānaṃ viheṭhakajātiko hotītiādinā
analyzed: batvā ābādha saṃvattanikā esā māṇava paṭipadā yat idam sattānam viheṭhaka jātikaḥ hoti itiādinā
translated: And the course that leads to having much illness is stated as the course that is of a kind to inflict suffering on beings by killing breathing things, and so on.

original: vihiṃsādīnaṃ vasena vuttaṃ. Upatthambhakañca dīghāyukasaṃvattanikā esā māṇava paṭipadā.
analyzed: vihiṃsā ādīnam vasena vuttam upatthambhakam ca dīgha āyuka saṃvattanikā esā māṇava paṭipadā
translated: and so on. “The way of life that leads to a long life-span” is the way of life that causes the support of life to be prolonged.🔽“The abstention from killing living beings” and so on are stated

original: Yadidaṃ pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hotītiādinā pāṇātipātaviratiādīnaṃ
analyzed: yat idam pāṇa atipātam pahāya pāṇa atipātā paṭivirataḥ hoti iti ādinā
translated: by way of the abstention from killing living beings and so on.

original: vasena vuttaṃ. Sabbañcetaṃ manussattaṃ āgatasseva sattassa vasenāti evaṃ visuṃ pāḷinayo
analyzed: vasena vuttam sabbañca itam manussattam āgatassa iva sattassa vasena ati evam visum pāḷinayo
translated: And all this is stated by way of a living being who has come to the human state. This is how the method of explanation in the text should be understood.

original: veditabboti. Mahāṭīkāyaṃ pana aṅguttaraṭīkāyañca kammantarupatthambhanādīni anicchantehi🔽janakādibhāvonāma vipākaṃ paṭiicchitabbo. Nakammanti vipākasseva upaghātakatā yuttā
analyzed: veditabbo ti mahā ṭīkā ayam pana aṅguttara ṭīkāyam ca kammantara upatthambhana ādīni an icchantehi  janaka ādi bhāvaḥ nāma vipākam paṭiicchitabbaḥ na kammanti vipākassa iva upaghātaka tā yuttā
translated: But in the Mahā-ṭīkā and the Aṅguttara-atthakathā, those who do not accept the support of life, etc.,🔽must accept the result called the state of being a human being, etc. The statement “not by way of action”

original: viya dissatīti vuttaṃ.🔽Kiccavasenāti jananaṃ upatthambhanaṃ upapīḷanaṃ upacchindananti catunnaṃ kiccānaṃ
analyzed: viya dissati iti vuttam  kicca vasena ati jananam upatthambhanam upapīḷanam upacchindananti catunnam kiccānam
translated: seems to imply that the destruction of the result is not appropriate.🔽“By way of function” means by way of the four functions of giving birth, supporting, oppressing, and destroying.

original: vasena. Tattha ekā pāṇātipātacetanā cattāri kiccāni sādheti. Sā hi yāva vipaccituṃ
analyzed: vasena tattha ekā pāṇātipāta cetanā cattāri kiccāni sādheti sā hi yāva vipaccitum
translated: Herein, a single volition of killing living beings accomplishes four functions. For that volition gives birth to the result, supports it, oppresses it, and destroys it.

original: okāsaṃ nalabhati. Tāva upatthambhanādīsu tīsu kiccesu yaṃkiñci laddhapaccayaṃ kiccaṃ
analyzed: okāsam na labhati tāva upatthambhana ādīsu tīsu kiccesu yaṃ kiñci laddha paccayam kiccam
translated: and so it does not find an opportunity. It performs one of the three functions, namely, consolidation, etc., for which it has obtained conditions.

original: karoti. Yadā vipaccituṃ okāsaṃ labhati. Tadā ekāya cetanāya ekāeva paṭisandhi hotīti
analyzed: karoti yadā vipaccitum okāsam labhati tadā ekāya cetanāya ekā eva paṭisandhi hoti iti
translated: When it finds an opportunity to ripen, then it generates only one rebirth-linking.

original: evaṃ sāketapañhe vuttanayena ekaṃ apāyabhavaṃ janeti. Tato paraṃ pana paṭisandhijananakiccaṃ
analyzed: evam sāketa pañhe vutta nayena ekam apāya bhavam janeti tatas param pana paṭisandhi janana kiccam
translated: So it generates one single lower-world becoming in the way described in the “Questions on the Suttas” . But after that it has no more opportunity to generate a rebirth-linking.

original: natthi. Pavatti vipākajananena saha itarāni tīṇi kiccāni bhavasatasahassepi kappasatasahassepi
analyzed: natthi pavatti vipāka jananena saha itarāni tīṇi kiccāni bhava sata sahasse pi kappa sata sahasse pi
translated: The process of becoming accomplishes the other three functions, namely, generating, establishing, and guiding, together with the generation of the result, even in a hundred thousand becoming-existences, even in a hundred thousand aeons.

original: sādhetiyeva. Dhammadinnāyanāma uggasena rañño deviyā vatthu ettha vattabbaṃ. Sā pana
analyzed: sādhetiyā iva uggasena raññaḥ deviyā vatthu ettha vattabbam sā pana
translated: The story of the nun named Dhammadinnā, the queen of King Uggasena, should be told here.

original: yadā attano vipākavārato pure ariyabhūtassavā puthujjanabhūtassapi kalyāṇa cittasamaṅginovā
analyzed: vipāka vārataḥ pure ariya bhūtassa vā puthujjana bhūtassa api
translated: But when she cut off her own nose, she did so when she was a worldling and had a good mind, not when she was a noble disciple.

original: upacchedanaṃ karoti. Tadā upacchinditvā kammanta rasseva okāsaṃ karoti. Sayaṃ vipākaṃ
analyzed: upacchedanam karoti tadā upacchinditvā okāsam karoti sayam vipākam
translated: When she cut it off, she gave the opportunity only for the action to produce a result. She herself did not experience the result.

original: najaneti. Yadā pana pāpacittasamaṅgino khandhasantānaṃ upacchindati. Tadāeva upacchinditvā🔽attano vipākaṃ janeti. Sakiṃ laddhapaṭisandhivārato pana paṭṭhāya anekesu attabhāva
analyzed: yadā pana pāpa citta samaṅginaḥ khandha santānam upacchindati tadā eva upacchinditvā  attanaḥ vipākam janeti sakim laddha paṭisandhi vārato pana paṭṭhāya anekesu atta bhāva
translated: and it generates its own result. But when it cuts off the continuity of aggregates of those who are possessed of evil thoughts, then it cuts off and

original: satasahassesupi upacchedanādīniyeva karoti. Ettha mahāmoggalāna tthera vatthu sāmāvati
analyzed: karoti ettha mahāmoggalāna tthera vatthu
translated: generates its own result. But from the time of receiving rebirth-linking once, it causes cutting off, etc., in many hundreds of thousands of existences. Herein, the story of the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, the story of Sāmāvatī,

original: vatthu vaggumudātīriyabhikkhu vatthu dussimāra kalāburājavatthūni kathetabbāni. Yasmā🔽pana idaṃ upacchedakakammaṃ nāma tiracchānagatānaṃ bahulaṃ labbhati. Tasmā suṭṭhu🔽balavaṃ akusalakammaṃ dubbalassa akusalakammassavā akusalakammanibbattakhandhasantānassavā🔽upacchedakaṃnāma na hotīti na vattabbaṃ. Teneva hi majjhimaṭṭhakathāyaṃ bahukasmiñhi
analyzed: vatthu vaggumudātīriya bhikkhu vatthu dussimāra kalāburāja vatthūni kathetabbāni yasmā  pana idam upacchedaka kammam nāma tiracchāna gatānam bahulam labbhati tasmā suṭṭhu  balavam akusala kammam dubbalassa akusala kamma ssavā akusala kamma nibbatta khandha santānassa vā  upacchedakam nāma na hoti iti na vattabbam tena iva hi majjhima ṭṭhakathā ayam bahukasmin hi
translated: the story of the monk Vaggamūḷha, and the story of the ogre Dussi Māra and King Kalābu should be told. But since this cutting off of kamma is found mostly in the case of animals, therefore

original: akusalakamme āyūhite balavakammaṃ dubbala kammassa vipākaṃ paṭibāhitvā attano vipākassa
analyzed: akusala kamme āyūhite balava kammam kammassa vipākam paṭibāhitvā attanaḥ vipākassa
translated: it should not be said that a very strong unprofitable kamma is a cutter of a weak unprofitable kamma and of the continuity of aggregates that produces the weak unprofitable kamma. For in the Majjhima Commentary it is said, “When many unprofitable kammas have been stored up, a strong kamma prevents the result of a weak kamma and makes its own result arise instead.

original: okāsaṃ karotīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: okāsam karoti iti vuttam
translated: and so it is said that it makes room.

original: Apica pavattiyaṃpi kammantarajanitaṃ bhavaṅgasantānaṃ anupacchinditvā pañcasu cakkhu🔽sota ghāna jivhā bhāva dasaka saṅkhātesu santati sīsesu aññatarassa santatisīsassa
analyzed: apica pavattiyam pi kamma antara janitam bhavaṅga santānam an upacchinditvā pañcasu cakkhu  sota ghāna jivhā bhāva dasaka saṅkhātesu santati sīsesu aññatarassa santatisīsassa
translated: Besides, in the course of an existence, the severing of the continuity of the life-continuum generated by a kamma other than that which generates the rebirth-linking is also a function of this consciousness.🔽For this is said in the Paṭṭhāna: “When rebirth-linking consciousness has eye-sensitivity as its object, it may be the cause thereof by acting as root-cause, by acting as decisive-support, by acting as prenascence, by acting as postnascence, by acting as presence, by acting as non-disappearance.🔽But when it has the continuity of the five consciousnesses as its object, it may be the cause thereof by acting as root-cause, by acting as decisive-support, by acting as prenascence, by acting as postnascence, by acting as presence, by acting as non-disappearance, by acting as nutriment, by acting as faculty, by acting as jhāna, by acting as path, by acting as association, by acting as dissociation, by acting as presence, by acting as non-disappearance” .

original: sabbaso upacchindanaṃpi imasseva kiccanti yuttaṃ. Yaṃ pana mahāṭīkāyaṃ aṅguttaraṭīkāyañca
analyzed: sabbasas upacchindanam pi imassa iva kiccanti yuttam yam pana mahā ṭīkāyam aṅguttara ṭīkāyam ca
translated: But what is said in the Mahā-aṭṭhakathā and the Aṅguttara-aṭṭhakathā,

original: upapīḷikaṃ aññassa vipākaṃ chindati. Na sayaṃ attano vipākaṃ janetīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ🔽aṭṭhakathāyaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ pīḷeti, addhānaṃ pavattituṃ na detīti idaṃ disvā vuttaṃ
analyzed: upapīḷikam aññassa vipākam chindati na sayam attanaḥ vipākam janeti iti vuttam tam  aṭṭhakathā ayam sukha dukkham pīḷeti addhānam pavattitum na deti iti idam disvā vuttam
translated: namely, that “it severs the other’s ripening, not its own ripening,”🔽is said after seeing that it “afflicts pleasure and pain, and does not allow the life-continuum to go on occurring” .

original: siyā. Addhānaṃ pavattituṃ nadetīti ettha pana sukhasantānaṃvā dukkhasantānaṃvā cirakālaṃ🔽pavattituṃ nadeti iccevattho. Na pana upaghātakaṃ viya bhavaṅgasantānena saha aññassa
analyzed: siyā addhānam pavattitum nadeti iti ettha pana sukha santānam vā dukkha santānam vā cira kālam  pavattitum nadeti icca iva atthaḥ na pana upaghātakam viya bhavaṅga santānena saha aññassa
translated: But the meaning of the words “does not allow the life-continuum to go on occurring” should be understood in this way: it does not allow a continuity of pleasure or a continuity of pain to go on occurring for a long time,

original: kammassa vipākaṃ chindatīti.
analyzed: kammassa vipākam chindati iti
translated: but it does not sever the ripening of another kamma along with the life-continuum as does a kamma that is a life-span-cutter .

original: [143] Yaṃpana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yaṃpana vibhāvaniyam
translated: But what is said in the Vibhāvinī-atthakathā,

original: “Janakaṃ kammantarassa vipākaṃ anupacchinditvāva vipākaṃ janeti. Upaghātakaṃ upacchedanapubbakanti idaṃ tāva aṭṭhakathāsu sanniṭṭhānanti vuttaṃ”. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.🔽Idha pubbakatena upacchedanakakammena maritvā sagge nibbattānaṃ vatthūnaṃ aṭṭhakathāsuyeva āgatattāti.
analyzed: janakam kammantarassa vipākam an upacchinditvā ava vipākam janeti upaghātakam upacchedana pubbakanti idam tāva aṭṭhakathāsu sanniṭṭhānam ti vuttam tat na sundaram  idha pubba katena upacchedanaka kammena maritvā sagge nibbattānam vatthūnam aṭṭhakathāsu yā iva āgata ttā ti
translated: “The productive kind produces its result without interrupting the continuity of the kamma that produces the life span. The destructive kind does so after interrupting it. This is the conclusion in the commentaries.”

original: [144] Yañca tattha🔽Apare pana ācariyā vadantītiādinā upaghātakassa sayaṃ vipākanibbattakattā bhāvavacanaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: yañca tattha  apare pana ācariyāḥ vadanti iti ādinā upaghātakassa sayam vipāka nibbattaka ttā bhāva vacanam vuttam tat pi na sundaram
translated: But that is not good.🔽For the stories of those reborn in the brahma world after dying through the destructive kamma mentioned above are found in the commentaries themselves.

original: Teneva kammena apāye nibbattānaṃ dussimāra kalāburājā dīnaṃ tassa kammassa upacchedakakammabhāvena aṭṭhakathāsu āgatattāti. [Janakacatukkaṃ]
analyzed: tena iva kammena apāye nibbattānam dussimāra kalābu rājā dīnam tassa kammassa upacchedaka kamma bhāvena aṭṭhakathāsu āgata ttā ti janaka catukkam
translated: And the statement that the destructive kind is called “kamma that produces a result in the next existence” because it produces its own result is not good either.🔽For the stories of those reborn in the lower worlds through that kamma are found in the commentaries as kamma that interrupts that kamma.

original: 146. Garukanti aññena kammena paṭibāhituṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ kusalapakkhe mahaggatakammaṃ
analyzed: garukam ti aññena kammena paṭibāhitum a sakkuṇeyyam kusala pakkhe mahaggata kammaṃ
translated: Heavy means profitable kamma of the fine-material and immaterial spheres that cannot be prevented from producing its result by any other kamma.

original: akusalapakkhe niyatamicchādiṭṭhiyā saha pañcānantariyakammaṃ. Ettha siyā. Mahaggatakammanti
analyzed: akusala pakkhe niyatam icchādiṭṭhiyā saha pañca ānantariya kammaṃ ettha siyā mahaggata kamman ti
translated: In the unprofitable section, the five kinds of immediate-resultant kamma are so called together with the fixed wrong view.

original: kasmā vuttaṃ. Tañhi pamādavasenavā nīvaraṇadhammapavattiyāvā parihāyiyamānaṃ nikantibalenavā
analyzed: kasmā vuttam tat hi pamāda vasena vā nīvaraṇa dhamma pavattiyā vā parihāyiyamānam nikanti balena vā
translated: Here it may be asked: Why is it said that “greatness” is a condition for the kamma to be effective?🔽For that kamma, when it is being weakened by the presence of the hindrances and the unprofitable states, does not yield its result because of the strength of the attachment to the kamma.

original: paṭibāhiyamānaṃ vipākaṃ na detīti. Tathā ekassa bahūsu ānantariyakammesu katesu ekasmiṃ🔽vipaccante sesāni na vipaccantīti. Vuccate, mahaggatakammaṃ tāvathapetvā pamādadhammanīvaraṇadhammanikantidhamme🔽attano balavatarañca mahaggatakammantaraṃ aññena puññakammena appaṭibāhaniyaṭṭhena
analyzed: paṭibāhiyamānam vipākam na deti iti tathā ekassa bahūsu ānantariya kammesu katesu ekasmin  vipaccante sesāni na vipaccanti iti vuccate mahaggata kammam pamāda dhamma nīvaraṇa dhamma nikanti dhamme  attanaḥ balavataram ca mahaggata kammantaram aññena puñña kammena appaṭibāhaniyaṭṭhena
translated: And when one has done many kinds of immediate-resultant kamma, it is not the case that when one of them has yielded its result the others do likewise.🔽It may be replied: “The great kamma is great in the sense of being weighty in that it is not outshone by other profitable kamma, although it may be weakened by the presence of the hindrances, unprofitable states, and attachment.

original: garukaṃ nāma hoti. Ānantariyakammāni pana thapetvā attano balavataraṃ ānantariyakammaṃ
analyzed: garukam nāma hoti ānantariya kammāni pana thapetvā attanaḥ balavataram ānantariya kammaṃ
translated: And the immediate-resultant kamma is great in the sense of being weighty in that it is not outshone by any other kamma except one of its own kind that is stronger.

original: aññena kenaci dhammena appaṭibāhaniyaṭṭhenāti evaṃ yathārahaṃ tesaṃ garukatā veditabbāti.
analyzed: aññena kenacid dhammena appaṭibāhaniya ṭṭhena ati evam yathāraham tesam garuka tā veditabbā ati
translated: So the greatness of these should be understood according to the circumstances.”
