original: Āsannanti maraṇakāle anussaritaṃ tadā katañca. Tattha tadākatanti antima javanavīthito🔽pubbabhāge āsanne kataṃ yaṃkiñci kusalākusalakammaṃ. Micchādiṭṭhikammaṃ pana vipassanādivasena🔽pavattaṃ sammādiṭṭhikammañca antimajavanavīsiyaṃpi katanti gahetabbaṃ. Yathāha-maraṇakāle🔽vāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi sammādiṭṭhi samattā samādinnāti. Etena tato micchādiṭṭhikammato
analyzed: maraṇa kāle anussaritam tadā katam ca tattha  pubba bhāge āsanne katam yaṃ kiñci kusala akusala kammam micchādiṭṭhi kammam pana vipassanā ādi vasena  pavattam sammādiṭṭhi kammam ca katam ti gahetabbam yathā aha maraṇa kāle  vā assa hoti micchādiṭṭhi sammādiṭṭhi samattā samādinnā ati etena tatas micchādiṭṭhi kammato
translated: ‘Near’ means that done at the time of death and that remembered at the time of death. Herein, ‘that done at the time of death’ is any profitable or unprofitable action done in the period preceding the last thought-unit. But action done by one of wrong view and so on, and action done by one of right view and so on, should be understood as done in the last thought-unit. For it is said: ‘Or his wrong view … or his right view comes to fulfilment and culmination in the last thought-unit’ . And so too with the action done by one of wrong view and so on.🔽🔽

original: aññaṃ antimajavanavīthiyaṃ pavattaṃ kammaṃ paṭisandhiṃ janetuṃ na sakkotīti siddhaṃ
analyzed: aññam antima javana vīthiyam pavattam kammam paṭisandhim janetum na sakkoti iti siddham
translated: ‘Near’ means done at the time of death and remembered at the time of death. Herein, ‘done at the time of death’ is any profitable or unprofitable action done in the period preceding the last thought-unit of the cognitive series. But action done by one of wrong view and so on, and action done by one of right view and so on, should be understood as done in the last thought-unit of the cognitive series. For it is said: ‘Or his wrong view, right view, etc., may be at the time of death’ . By this it is established that action done in the last thought-unit of the cognitive series other than that done by one of wrong view, etc., is incapable of generating rebirth-linking.

original: hotīti. Āciṇṇanti dīgharattaṃ abhiṇhaso kataṃ. Sakiṃ karitvāpivā pacchā punappunaṃ
analyzed: hoti iti dīgharattam katam sakim karitvā api vā pacchā punappunam
translated: ‘Habitual’ means done frequently over a long period. Or alternatively, it may be done only once, but if it is a cause for gladness and for remorse afterwards,

original: somanassajanakaṃ santāpajanakañca. Kaṭattākammanti kāriyitthāti kammanti evaṃ katakāraṇāeva
analyzed: somanassa janakam santāpa janakam ca kaṭattā kammanti kāriyittha ati kammanti evam kata kāraṇā eva
translated: ‘Action as accumulation’ is action that is done. The word ‘kamman’ is derived as follows: ‘kā’ means ‘to do’ , ‘kam’ is the same as ‘kamma’ , and ‘na’ is a mere affix.

original: kammanti vattabbaṃ kammaṃ. Garukādibhāvena vattabbaṃ kammaṃ na hotīti attho. Tattha
analyzed: kammanti vattabbam kammam garuka ādi bhāvena vattabbam kammam na hoti iti atthaḥ tattha
translated: It should be called kamma that should be called kamma by reason of its being heavy, etc., is not kamma.

original: purimāni tīṇi imasmiṃ bhave katāni upapajjavedanīyakammānieva. Kaṭattākammaṃ pana🔽atītabhavesu katehi aparapariyāyavedanīyehi saha imasmiṃ bhave kataṃ garukā sannāciṇṇabhāvarahitaṃ
analyzed: purimāni tīṇi imasmin bhave katāni upapajja vedanīya kammāni eva kaṭattā kammam pana  atīta bhavesu katehi apara pariyāya vedanīyehi saha imasmin bhave katam garukā sanna āciṇṇa bhāva rahitam
translated: Herein, the first three kinds of kamma are only kamma to be experienced in the next rebirth in this becoming. But kamma of accumulation

original: kammapathapattaṃ yaṃkiñci upapajjavedanīyakammaṃ. Mahāṭīkāyaṃ pana kaṭattākammaṃ
analyzed: kamma patha pattam yaṃkiñci upapajja vedanīya kammam mahāṭīkāyam pana kaṭattā kammam
translated: is any kamma whatever, heavy or otherwise, that is not classed as “to be experienced here and now,” etc., and is done in this becoming along with that to be experienced in some subsequent becoming done in past existences. But in the Great Commentary kamma of accumulation

original: purima jātīsu kataṃeva gahitaṃ. Taṃ aṭṭhakathāya na sameti. Etehi pana tīhi muttaṃ🔽punappunaṃ laddhāsevanaṃ kaṭattāvā pana kammaṃnāma hotīti hi vuttaṃ. Na ca atītabhavesu
analyzed: purima jātīsu katam eva gahitam tam aṭṭhakathāya na sameti etehi pana tīhi muttam  punappunam laddha āsevanam kaṭattāvā pana kammaṃ nāma hoti iti hi vuttam na ca atīta bhavesu
translated: is taken as only that done in previous births. That does not agree with the commentary. What is excepted by the three kinds of kamma🔽is called kamma of conscious choice. For it is said that “Kamma of conscious choice is that which is done again and again after repeated reflection.”

original: katāni mātughātakādīnipi aparapariyāya kammāni etehi tīhi muttānītivā amuttānītivā
analyzed: katāni mātughātaka ādīni pi apara pariyāya kammāni etehi tīhi muttāni itivā a muttāni itivā
translated: And it is not possible to distinguish the parricide, etc., done in past existences as kamma to be experienced in some subsequent becoming, excepted or excepted and not excepted, or as kamma done again and again after repeated reflection or not done again and again after repeated reflection.

original: punappunaṃ laddhāsevanānītivā aladdhāsevanānītivā sakkā visesetuṃ. Tadā hi tāni garuka
analyzed: punappunam laddha āsevanāni iti vā a laddha āsevanāni iti vā sakkā visesetum tadā hi tāni garuka
translated: For at that time they were heavy

original: kammasantāne pavattānipi honti. Āsannavaciṇṇakammasantāne pavattānipīti.
analyzed: kamma santāne pavattāni api honti āsanna vaciṇṇa kamma santāne pavattāni api iti
translated: and they occur in the kamma-process too.

original: Aṅguttaraṭṭhakathāyañca etehi pana tīhi muttaṃ aññāṇavasenakataṃ kaṭattāvā pana kammaṃnāmāti
analyzed: aṅguttara ṭṭhakathāyañca etehi pana tīhi muttam aññāṇa vasena katam kaṭattā vā pana kammaṃnāmā ti
translated: And in the Commentary to the Book of Elevens it is said: “But kamma is called ‘kamma that is done’ because it is done by the act of volition that is accompanied by unknowing.

original: vuttaṃ. Na tāni aññāṇavasena kabhānīti sakkā visesetuṃ. Tāni hi purimabhavesu aññāṇa🔽vasena katānipi honti. Ñāṇavasena katānipīti. Tāni pana visesanāni imasmiṃ bhave
analyzed: vuttam na tāni aññāṇa vasena kabhāni iti sakkā visesetum tāni hi purima bhavesu aññāṇa  vasena katāni api honti ñāṇa vasena katāni api iti tāni pana visesanāni imasmin bhave
translated: ” But it cannot be specified that it is done by unknowing, for it is done by unknowing in previous becoming too, and it is done by knowing.

original: katānaṃ garukādīhi tīhi muttānaṃ sattamajavana kammānaṃ vasena vuttānīti tehi saha🔽purimajātīsu katāni aparapariyāya kammāni kaṭattā kammaṃnāmāti veditabbāni. Evañca
analyzed: katānam garuka ādīhi tīhi muttānam kammānam vasena vuttāni iti tehi saha  purima jātīsu katāni apara pariyāya kammāni kaṭattā kammaṃnāmā ati veditabbāni evam ca
translated: But these specifications are stated in terms of the seventh impulsion of kamma that is done in this becoming and is freed from the three, namely, the weighty, the near, and the kamma already done.🔽So it should be understood that kamma that is done in this becoming and kamma done in previous existences, which are kamma to be experienced in accordance with the nearness of the object, are called “kamma that is done” in the sense of being done by the act of volition.

original: katvā yattha taṃpubbakataṃ kammanti āgataṃ. Tatthapi imasmiṃ bhavevā atītabhavesuvā
analyzed: katvā yattha taṃpubba katam kammanti āgatam tattha api imasmin
translated: And when it is put like this, then in the passage, “Kamma that was done in the past” , the meaning should be understood as kamma done in this becoming or in a past becoming in the past period.

original: pubbakāle katanti attho veditabboti. Imesu pana catūsu kammesu vijjamānesu garukameva
analyzed: pubba kāle katanti attho veditabbo ti imesu pana catūsu kammesu vijjamānesu garukam eva
translated: And of these four kinds of kamma, the weighty is the most effective in producing result.

original: anantare bhave paṭisandhiṃ deti. Garuke asati āsannaṃ. Āsanne asati āciṇṇaṃ. Āciṇṇe
analyzed: anantare bhave paṭisandhim deti garuke asati āsannam āsanne asati āciṇṇam āciṇṇe
translated: and when there is no weighty kamma, then kamma done in proximity. When there is no kamma done in proximity, then kamma done frequently. When there is no kamma done frequently, then kamma done long ago.

original: asati kaṭattākammaṃ. Tenāha pākadānapariyāyenāti. Pākadānavārenāti attho. Ettha siyā.
analyzed: asati kaṭattā kammam tena āha pāka dāna pariyāyena āti pāka dāna vārena ati atthaḥ ettha siyā
translated: Therefore it is said that the order of the sequence of the ripening of kamma is the order of the sequence of the giving of the ripening of kamma.🔽Here it may be asked:

original: Kasmā idha āsannaṃ āciṇṇato pathamaṃ vuttaṃ. Nanu pāḷiyaṃ āsannato āciṇṇameva pathamaṃ
analyzed: kasmai idha āsannam āciṇṇataḥ pathamam vuttam nanu pāḷiyam āsannataḥ āciṇṇam eva pathamam
translated: Why is kamma done in proximity stated first here, when in the text kamma done frequently is stated first?

original: vuttaṃ. Yathāha-yaṃ garukaṃ yaṃ bahulaṃ. Yadāsannaṃ. Kaṭattāvā pana kammanti. Aṭṭhakathāsuca
analyzed: vuttam yathā hayam garukam yam bahulam yat āsannam aṭṭhakathāsu ca
translated: For it is said: “What is weighty, what is frequently done, what is done near—but kamma is of accumulated performance” . And in the commentaries

original: teneva kamena pākadānavāro vihitoti. Vuccate, sabhāvato balavadubbalakkamena pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: tena iva kamena pāka dāna vāraḥ vihitaḥ iti vuccate sabhāvataḥ balavat ubbala kkamena pāḷiyam
translated: it is said: “The order of the sequence of the giving of the ripening of kamma is determined by that kamma” .

original: āciṇṇaṃ pathamaṃ vuttaṃ. So pana kamo kadāci pākadānapariyāyopi sambhavatīti katvā🔽aṭṭhakathāsu teneva kamena pākadānavāro vihito. Āsannaṃpi hisamānaṃ cittaṃ tosetuṃvā
analyzed: āciṇṇam pathamam vuttam saḥ pana kamaḥ kadāci pāka dāna pariyāyaḥ api sambhavati iti katvā  aṭṭhakathāsu tena iva kamena pāka dāna vāraḥ vihitaḥ āsannam pi cittam tosetum vā
translated: We reply: In the text kamma done frequently is stated first because it is the strongest in its individual essence. But that kamma may sometimes be the order of the sequence of the giving of the ripening of kamma.🔽Therefore in the commentaries the order of the sequence of the giving of the ripening of kamma is determined by that kamma. For even though kamma done in proximity is similar, it is not able to prevent kamma done frequently that is strong, when it is unable to establish or torment the mind.

original: santāpetuṃvā asakkontaṃ hutvā dubbalaṃ balavato āciṇṇassa nivattakaṃ na hotīti. Yasmā
analyzed: santāpetum vā a sakkontam hutvā dubbalam balavataḥ āciṇṇassa nivattakam na hoti iti yasmā
translated: Because

original: pana mahākammavibhaṅgasutte pubbevāssataṃ kataṃ hoti kalyāṇakammaṃ sukhavedanīyaṃ.
analyzed: pana mahākammavibhaṅga sutte pubbevāssatam katam hoti kalyāṇa kammam sukha vedanīyam
translated: but in the Mahā-Kammavibhaṅga Sutta the good deed done previously is said to be of pleasant feeling.

original: Pacchāvāssataṃ kataṃ hoti kalyāṇakammaṃ sukhavedanīyaṃ. Maraṇakālevāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi🔽samattā samādinnāti evaṃ āciṇṇaduccaritassapi ekaccassa āsannena kalyāṇa kammena🔽saggagamanaṃ vuttaṃ. Tathā pubbevāssataṃ kataṃ hoti pāpakammaṃ dukkhavedaniyaṃ.La.
analyzed: pacchāvāssatam katam hoti kalyāṇa kammam sukha vedanīyam maraṇa kāleva assa hoti sammādiṭṭhi  samattā samādinnā ati evam āciṇṇaduccaritassa api ekaccassa āsannena kalyāṇa kammena  sagga gamanam vuttam tathā pubbevāssatam katam hoti pāpa kammam
translated: But in the Mahā-Kammavibhaṅga Sutta it is said that one who has done good kamma that is to be experienced as happiness both before and after, and who at the time of death has right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration,🔽goes to heaven as a result of the good kamma that is near to him, though he has previously done bad kamma.🔽And in the same way it is said that one who has done bad kamma that is to be experienced as pain both before and after, and who at the time of death has wrong view, wrong intention, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong concentration,

original: Micchādiṭṭhi samattā samādinnāti evaṃ āciṇṇa sucaritassapi ekaccassa āsannena pāpakammena
analyzed: micchādiṭṭhi samattā samādinnā ati evam āciṇṇa su caritassa api ekaccassa āsannena pāpa kammena
translated: goes to an unhappy destination as a result of the bad kamma that is near to him, though he has previously done good kamma.

original: apāyagamanaṃ vuttaṃ. Yasmāca ubhinnaṃpi balavabhāve sati āsannameva pariyattaṃ bhavituṃ
analyzed: apāya gamanam vuttam balava bhāve sati āsannam eva pariyattam bhavitum
translated: And since it is proper that what is near should be effective when both are of equal strength,🔽therefore it should be understood that the Elder has mentioned what is near first here.

original: arahati. Tasmā idha therena āsannameva pathamaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Etthaca pubbevāssakataṃ
analyzed: arahati tasmai idha therena āsannam eva pathamam vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam ettha ca pubbevāssakatam
translated: And here

original: hotīti idaṃ āsannānussaritakammavasena vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Tambadāṭhikanāmassa coraghātakassa
analyzed: hoti iti idam āsanna anussarita kamma vasena vuttan ti veditabbam tamba dāṭhika nāmassa cora ghātakassa
translated: This should be understood as said by way of the kamma of remembering what is near. Tambadāṭhī, a robber-murderer,

original: mahāvātakālanāmassaca upāsakassa vatthu ettha kathetabbanti.
analyzed: upāsakassa vatthu ettha kathetabbanti
translated: This should be understood as said by way of the kamma that is remembered as near. The story of the robber-murderer Tambadāṭhī and the story of the lay devotee Mahāvātakalāpa should be told here.

original: [145] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī

original: Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ āgataṃ jaraggavopamaṃ dassetvā āsannameva pathamaṃ vipākaṃ detīti ekaṃsena vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāyam āgatam jaraggava upamam dassetvā āsannam eva pathamam vipākam deti iti ekaṃsena vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: in the Commentary, the simile of the old ox is given as it occurs in the Peṭaka, and then it is stated categorically that “it gives first the result that is nearest.” But that is not good.

original: Na hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ evaṃ ekaṃsena vuttaṃ. Naca uṭṭhātuṃpi asakkonto so jaraggavo pajadvārassa āsanne ṭhitopi pathamataraṃ nikkhamissatīti. [Garukacatukkaṃ]
analyzed: na hi aṭṭhakathāyam evam ekaṃsena vuttam na ca uṭṭhātum pi a sakkonto so jaraggavaḥ paja dvārassa āsanne ṭhitaḥ api pathamataram nikkhamissati iti garuka catukkaṃ
translated: For it is not stated categorically in the Commentary in this way, nor can the old ox, unable even to rise up, get out first, though standing near the door of the pen.

original: 147. Diṭṭhadhammo vuccati paccakkhabhūto paccuppanno attabhāvo. Veditabbaṃ anu bhavitabbanti vedanīyaṃ. Phalaṃ. Diṭṭhadhamme vedanīyaṃ phalaṃ etassāti diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ.
analyzed: diṭṭhadhammo vuccati paccakkha bhūtaḥ paccuppannaḥ atta bhāvo veditabbam anu bhavitabbanti vedanīyam phalam diṭṭhadhamme vedanīyam phalam etassa ati diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam
translated: The present state is called the visible state. It is the present individual form that is evident. What is to be felt is what is to come into being after that. The fruit. It has the visible state as the fruit to be felt, thus it is of visible fruit.

original: [146] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī

original: “Diṭṭhadhamme veditabbaṃ vipākānubhavana vasenāti diṭṭhadhammavedanīya”nti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamme veditabbam vipāka anubhavana vasena ati diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyan ti vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: “It is to be experienced in the seen order, in the sense of the experiencing of the result, thus it is kamma to be experienced here and now” . That is not good.

original: Diṭṭheva dhamme vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedetīti hi pāḷiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Ettha hi vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedetīti
analyzed: diṭṭhe iva dhamme vipākam paṭisaṃvedeti iti hi pāḷiyam vuttam ettha hi vipākam paṭisaṃvedeti iti
translated: For it is said in the text, “He experiences the result in the seen order” . Here🔽the words “he experiences the result”

original: etena idha vedanīyasaddo kammasādhano vipākātidheyyoca hotīti dasseti. Evañca sati
analyzed: etena idha vedanīya saddo kamma sādhanaḥ hoti iti dasseti evam ca sati
translated: show that the word vedanīya is a kamma-qualifier and that it refers to the result. And that being so,

original: idha aññapadatthasamāso eva labbhati. Na uttarapadatthasamāsoti. Diṭṭhadhammaṃ upecca
analyzed: idha añña padattha samāsaḥ eva labbhati na uttara padattha samāsaḥ ti diṭṭhadhammam upecca
translated: here only a compound with the first member governed by a preposition is possible, not a compound with the second member governed by a preposition. That kamma is to be experienced after being reborn,

original: tassa anantare pajjitvā pāpuṇitvā veditabbaṃ phalaṃ etassāti upapajjavedanīyaṃ. Teneva
analyzed: tassa anantare pajjitvā pāpuṇitvā veditabbam phalam etassa ati upapajja vedanīyam tena iva
translated: since the fruit of it is to be experienced after having gone to the next existence and having been reborn there, is called kamma to be experienced after being reborn. Therefore

original: hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ upapajja saddassa atthaṃ vadantena upapajjitvāti vuttaṃ. Suttapadesu
analyzed: hi aṭṭhakathāyam upapajja saddassa attham vadantena upapajjitvā iti vuttam sutta padesu
translated: in the commentary the meaning of the word upapajja is given as upapajjitvā . But in the texts🔽the reading is upapajjeva . Therefore it should be understood that it is kamma to be experienced

original: pana upapajjevāti pāṭho diṭṭho. Tasmā diṭṭhadhammassa samīpe anantare pajjitabbo
analyzed: pana upapajja iva iti pāṭhaḥ diṭṭhaḥ tasmā diṭṭha dhammassa samīpe anantare pajjitabbo
translated: in the next existence, since it is to be experienced after having been reborn immediately next to the seen existence.

original: gantabboti upapajjo. Dutīyo attabhāvo upapajjeveditabbaṃ phalaṃ etassāti upapajjavedanīyanti
analyzed: gantabbaḥ iti upapajjaḥ dutīyaḥ atta bhāvaḥ upapajjeveditabbam phalam etassa ati upapajja vedanīyanti
translated: It should be gone to: it should be reborn. It has a fruit to be experienced after rebirth: it is to be experienced after rebirth.

original: evamattho pāṭhassa vasena veditabbo. Upapajjātivā anantare bhave pavatto eko nipāto. Yathā paccāti.🔽[147] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: evamatthaḥ pāṭhassa vasena veditabbo anantare bhave pavattaḥ ekaḥ nipātaḥ yathā  vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: This is the meaning of the words as they are. The rebirth mode is one mode occurring in the next becoming. As it is said:🔽“In the Vibhaṅga it is said: ‘It is to be experienced after rebirth, after reappearance, in the next world,’ thus it is kamma to be experienced after rebirth’ (Vibh 260).

original: “Diṭṭhadhammato anantaraṃ upapajjitvā veditabbanti upavajjavedanīya”nti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: diṭṭhadhammataḥ anantaram upapajjitvā veditabbanti upavajja vedanīyanti vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: That is not good.

original: Upapajjavā vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedetīti hi pāḷiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Pariyāyati punappunaṃ āgacchatīti🔽pariyāyo. Aparoca so pariyā yocāti aparapariyāyo. Diṭṭhadhammā nāgatā nantara bhavehi🔽añño atta bhāva parivatto. Te neva hi mahāṭīkāyaṃ aṅgutta raṭīkāyañca aparapariyāyeti
analyzed: upapajjavā vipākam paṭisaṃvedeti iti hi pāḷiyam vuttam pariyāyati punappunam āgacchati iti  so apara ca so apara pariyāyaḥ diṭṭha dhammā na āgatāḥ bhavehi  aññaḥ atta bhāva parivatto te na iva hi mahāṭīkāyam aṅgutta ra ṭīkāyam ca apara pariyāya iti
translated: For it is said in the text: ‘He experiences the result in the rebirth-linking and in the life-continuum’ (Vbh. 100). It is a mode in the sense of a way.🔽It is a mode in the sense of a way in which it comes again and again.🔽It is not a mode in the sense of another: it is not another mode. It is not another selfhood in the sense of a different selfhood in the next becoming after this one.

original: diṭṭhadhammānantarānāgatato aññasmiṃ attabhāvapariyāye attabhāvaparivatteti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma anantara anāgatataḥ aññasmin attabhāva pariyāye attabhāva parivattā iti vuttam
translated: For in the Great Commentary and the Anutīkā it is said: ‘It is not a mode in the sense of another. It is a mode in the sense of a different selfhood in the next becoming after this one’ .

original: Suttapadesu pana aparevā pariyāyetica aparāparevā pariyāyetica dvidhā pāṭho diṭṭho.
analyzed: sutta padesu pana aparā iva pariyāya iti ca apara aparā iva pariyāya iti ca dvidhā pāṭhaḥ diṭṭho
translated: But in the Suttas the reading is found in two ways, namely, as “in another way” and as “in another and another way”.🔽Herein, in the last-mentioned reading the word “another” is omitted in the middle.

original: Tattha pacchimasmiṃ pāṭhesati idha majjhe ekassa aparasaddassa lopo daṭṭhabbo. Saṅgahapoṭṭhakesu
analyzed: tattha pacchimasmin idha majjhe ekassa apara saddassa lopaḥ daṭṭhabbo saṅgaha poṭṭhakesu
translated: But in the Sangīti- and Poṭṭhapāda-peyyālas🔽the word “another and another” is found with a long ā in the middle.

original: pana majjhe dīgho yākāranaṭṭhoca aparāpariyasaddo dissati. So bahūsu aṭṭhakathāsu
analyzed: pana majjhe dīghaḥ aparāpariya saddo dissati saḥ bahūsu aṭṭhakathāsu
translated: That is not in the many commentaries,

original: natthi. Pāḷiyāca na sameti.
analyzed: natthi pāḷiyāca na sameti
translated: and it does not agree with the text.

original: [148] Yañca vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yañca vibhāvaniyam
translated: And what is said in the Vibhaṅga

original: “Apare apare diṭṭhadhammato aññasmiṃ yatthakatthaci attabhāve veditabbaṃ kammaṃ aparāpariya vedanīya”nti vuttaṃ. Tattha diṭṭhadhammatoti idaṃ tāva nayujjati.
analyzed: apare apare diṭṭhadhammataḥ aññasmin yattha katthaci attabhāve veditabbam kammam vedanīyanti vuttam tattha diṭṭhadhammato ti idam tāva na yujjati
translated: is not correct either, namely, “Kamma to be experienced in some other existence than the present one, in some other than the present body, is kamma to be experienced in another existence” . Herein, as regards the words “in the present existence”:

original: Na hi majjhe upapajjabhavaṃ vajjetvā pathamo diṭṭhadhammova idha tatīye pade adhikatoti yutto.
analyzed: na hi majjhe upapajja bhavam vajjetvā pathamaḥ diṭṭhadhammaḥ u idha tatīye pade yutto
translated: for it is not correct to take the first, that is, the present existence, as intended here in the third place, omitting the existence that is next after the present one.

original: [149] Atthato pana byañjanatoca sabbaṃ pāḷiyā na sameti.
analyzed: atthataḥ pana byañjana to ca sabbam pāḷiyā na sameti
translated: But as to meaning and as to phrasing, all this does not agree with the text.

original: Aparevā pariyāye vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedetīti hi pāḷiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Aparāparevā pariyāyetivā.
analyzed: apare iva pariyāye vipākam paṭisaṃvedeti iti hi pāḷiyam vuttam apara apare iva pariyāya iti vā
translated: and “he experiences the result in another way” is said in the text.

original: Ahosināmakaṃ kammaṃ ahosikammaṃ. Ahosikammaṃ. Bhavissatikammaṃ. Atthikammaṃ. Natassa
analyzed: ahosi nāmakam kammam ahosi kammam ahosi kammam bhavissati kammam atthi kammam natassa
translated: “Past action” is action called “past.” “Future action” is action called “future.” “Present action” is action called “present.” “Non-existent action” is action called “non-existent.”🔽“The result of that is not” is the text stated thus.

original: vipākoti evaṃ vuttapāṭhavasena ācariyehi tathāgahitanāma dheyyaṃ sabbaso aladdhavipākavāraṃ
analyzed: vipākaḥ ti evam vutta pāṭha vasena ācariyehi tathāgahita nāma dheyyam sabbasas aladdha vipāka vāram
translated: The teachers have given the name “entirely non-resultant” to the section of text stated thus.

original: kammanti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha sattasu kusalākusalajavanesu pathamajavanacetanā diṭṭhadhammave🔽danīyaṃnāma. Sā hi aladdhāsevanatāya sabbadubbalattā aciraṭṭhi tikāca hoti appataravipākācāti.🔽Paccayaṃ laddhā diṭṭhadhammeeva ahetukamattaṃ phalaṃ datvā vigacchati. Na ekaṃpi
analyzed: kammanti vuttam hoti tattha sattasu kusala akusala javanesu pathama javana cetanā diṭṭhadhamma ve  sā hi a laddha āsevana tāya sabba dubbala ttā hoti appatara vipākā ca ati  paccayam laddhā diṭṭhadhamme eva ahetuka mattam phalam da tvā vigacchati na ekaṃ pi
translated: “Action” is what is stated. Herein, the volition of the first impulsion in the seven impulsion-moments of profitable and unprofitable impulsions is called “to be experienced here and now.”🔽For that is weak in the extreme because it has not obtained repetition, and it lasts only a short time and has a small result.

original: maraṇakālaṃ atikkamma santānaṃ anubandhituṃ sakkoti. Paccayaṃ pana alabhamānā ahosikaṃnāma
analyzed: maraṇa kālam atikkamma santānam anubandhitum sakkoti paccayam pana a labhamānā ahosikaṃnāma
translated: Having obtained conditions, it gives its fruit, which is merely the mere state of being without root-cause here and now, and then it ceases. It cannot continue on in the life-continuum beyond the time of death. But when it does not obtain conditions, it is called “to be experienced in the visible here and now” .

original: hoti. Paccayotica attano phaluppattiyā okāsadāyako nānā iriyāpathesu iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇasamā
analyzed: hoti paccayaḥ ti ca attanaḥ phala uppattiyā okāsa dāyakaḥ nānā iriyāpathesu iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇa samā
translated: And any condition whatever that gives opportunity for the arising of its fruit is a condition for it, such as the various postures, the agreeable and disagreeable objects, etc., that are in conformity with it.

original: gamādiko yokoci paccayopi yujjatiyeva. Ṭīkāsu pana paṭipakkhehi anabhibhūtatāyātiādinā
analyzed: gama ādikaḥ paccayaḥ api yujjati yā iva ṭīkāsu pana paṭipakkhehi anabhibhūta tāya āti ādinā
translated: But in the commentaries it is stated in the way beginning, “Because it is not overcome by opposition” .

original: mahantaṃ katvā paccayo vutto. So kākavaliyādīnaṃ viya pākaṭataraphaladānaṃ sandhāya🔽vuttoti veditabbo. Na hi kammapathajavanasantāne pavattamānā itarāpivā pathamajavanacetanā
analyzed: mahantam katvā paccayaḥ vuttaḥ saḥ kākavaliya ādīnam viya pākaṭatara phala dānam sandhāya  vuttaḥ iti veditabbaḥ na hi kamma patha javana santāne pavattamānā itarā api vā pathama javana cetanā
translated: That should be understood as said with reference to the giving of a more obvious fruit, like the crow’s valli creeper .

original: iṭṭhāniṭṭhasamāyogavasenapi laddha paccayā kāci attano balānurūpaṃ phalaṃ na detīti
analyzed: iṭṭha aniṭṭha samāyoga vasena api kāci attanaḥ bala anurūpam phalam na deti iti
translated: For there is no first impulsions in a continuity in which a path of action is occurring, or elsewhere, that do not give their fruit according to their strength, even though they have obtained conditions by conformity with the agreeable and disagreeable.

original: atthi. Nacatāya diyyamānaṃ sabbaṃpi phalaṃ mahājanassavā kammakārakasseva vāpākaṭameva
analyzed: atthi nacatāya diyyamānam sabbam pi phalam mahājanassa vā kamma kārakassa iva vā apākaṭam eva
translated: And it is not the case that all the fruit given by them is obvious to everyone or even to the doer of the action.🔽But it can be said that the fruit of the one that is given is obvious to the great multitude.

original: siyāti sakkā vattunti. Yaṃ pana ñāṇavibhaṅgaṭṭha kathāyaṃ ekaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ
analyzed: siyā iti sakkā vattunti yam pana ekam diṭṭha dhamma vedanīyaṃ
translated: But in the Niddesa Commentary it is said: “One kind gives its ripening to be experienced in this very life. The rest do not give ripening” .

original: vipākaṃ deti. Sesāni avipākānīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ aladdhapaccayāni sesāni sandhāya vuttanti
analyzed: vipākam deti sesāni avipākāni iti vuttam tat aladdha paccayāni sesāni sandhāya vuttan ti
translated: That is said with reference to the rest that have not obtained conditions.

original: gahetabbaṃ. Na hi eko diṭṭhadhammo ekasseva diṭṭhadhammavedanī yassa okāsoti sakkā
analyzed: gahetabbam na hi ekaḥ diṭṭhadhammo ekassa iva diṭṭhadhamma vedanī yassa okāsaḥ ti sakkā
translated: for it is not possible to know that the kamma that is to be experienced here and now is the opportunity for one who is to experience it here and now.

original: viññātunti. Atthasādhikā pana sanniṭṭhāpakabhūtā satthamajavanacetanā upapajja vedanīyaṃnāma.
analyzed: viññātunti attha sādhikā pana sanniṭṭhāpaka bhūtā satthama javana cetanā upapajja vedanīyam nāma
translated: But the volition that is the climax and the culmination of the process of kamma-formation is called “to be experienced on rebirth.”

original: Sā hi laddhāsevanatāya thokaṃ sārabhūtā hotīti pathamacetanā viya sīghataraṃ vipaccituṃ
analyzed: sā hi laddha āsevana tāya thokam sāra bhūtā hoti iti pathama cetanā sīghataram
translated: For that, by being obtained and repeatedly practiced, becomes somewhat strong, and so it is unable to ripen quickly like the first volition.

original: nasakkoti. Balavatīca hotīti ekaṃ bhavaṃ janetuṃ sakkoti. Patita java nesu pana antimajavanatāya🔽majjhimacetanāyo viya ciraṭṭhitikā na hotīti paccayaṃ laddhā anantare eva bhave paṭisandhiṃvā🔽pavatti phalamevavā datvā vigacchati. Aladdhā pana ahosikammameva hoti. Na dutīyaṃ
analyzed: na sakkoti balavatī ca hoti iti ekam bhavam janetum sakkoti patita java nesu pana antima javana tāya  majjhima cetanāyaḥ viya cira ṭṭhitikā na hoti iti paccayam laddhā anantare eva bhave paṭisandhiṃ vā  vigacchati aladdhā pana ahosikammam eva hoti na dutīyam
translated: But because it is strong it is able to generate a single becoming. But because of the slowness of its speed, which is the opposite of that of the first,🔽it is not long-lasting like the middle volition. So when it obtains a condition it gives its fruit either as rebirth-linking or as the course of an individual existence and then ceases. But when it does not obtain a condition it becomes merely accumulated kamma. It is unable to go beyond the time of death.

original: maraṇakālaṃ atikkamituṃ sakkoti. Yaṃpana ñāṇavibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāyaṃ ekaṃ upapajjavedanīyaṃ
analyzed: maraṇa kālam atikkamitum sakkoti yaṃ pana ñāṇa vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathā ayam ekam upapajja vedanīyam
translated: But in the Commentary on the Niddesa it is said that kamma to be experienced on rebirth is of two kinds, that is, according to the distinction of being effective or not effective.

original: paṭisandhiṃ ākaḍḍhati. Sesāni avipākānīti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi paṭisandhivipākaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: paṭisandhim ākaḍḍhati sesāni avipākāni iti vuttam tat pi paṭisandhi vipākam sandhāya
translated: But that should be taken as said with reference to the rebirth-linking result.

original: vuttanti gahetabbaṃ. Sesānipi hi yāva dutīyacuti nāgacchati. Tāva laddhapaccayāni🔽pavatti vipākaṃ dentiyeva. Idha missaka kammāni katvā anantarabhave missakakammaphalaṃ
analyzed: vuttam ti gahetabbam sesāni pi hi yāva dutīya cuti na āgacchati tāva laddha paccayāni  pavatti vipākam idha missaka kammāni katvā anantara bhave missaka kamma phalam
translated: For the rest, too, so long as the second death does not come, they give result when they occur, having obtained conditions.

original: anubhontāni vemānika petavatthūni aññānica taṃtaṃkammaṃ katvā anantarabhave eva sugati🔽yaṃ kabbipākabhūtaṃ vipattiṃ anubhavantāni duggatiyaṃvā tabbipākabhūtaṃ sampattiṃ
analyzed: aññāni ca tat tat kammam katvā anantara bhave eva sugati  yam kad bipāka bhūtam vipattim anubhavantāni duggatiyam vā tad vipāka bhūtam sampattim
translated: Herein, the stories of the ghosts of various kinds of deeds in the Vimānavatthu, which tell of those who, after doing various kinds of deeds, experienced the fruit of various kinds of deeds in the next rebirth,🔽and the many hundreds of stories of those who, after doing various kinds of deeds, experienced in the next rebirth the good fortune that was the fruit of good deeds,

original: anubhavantāni anekāni vatthusatāni ettha kathe tabbānīti.
analyzed: anubhavantāni anekāni vatthu satāni ettha kathe tabbāni iti
translated: or the misfortune that was the fruit of bad deeds, should be told.

original: [150] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yam pana
translated: But what is said in the Vibhaṅga:🔽“It gives its result as rebirth-linking and then gives its result as kamma-result of occurrence. But it does not give its result as kamma-result of occurrence without giving its result as rebirth-linking” ,

original: “Sāca paṭisandhiṃ datvāva pavattivipākaṃ deti. Paṭisandhiyā pana adinnāya pavattivipākaṃ detīti natthī”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na yujjati.
analyzed: sā ca paṭisandhim da tvā ava pavatti vipākam deti paṭisandhiyā pana adinnāya pavatti vipākam deti iti natthi iti vuttam tam na yujjati
translated: is not correct.

original: Yathāvuttavatthūhi saddhiṃ virujjhanato.
analyzed: yathā vutta vatthūhi saddhim virujjhanataḥ
translated: Because it contradicts the stories given.

original: [151] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there:

original: “Cuti anantarañhi upapajjavedanīyassa okāso”ti kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃpi akāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: cuti anantaram hi upapajja vedanīyassa okāso ti kāraṇam vuttam tat pi akāraṇam
translated: But that is no reason,

original: Putianantarato paṭṭhāya yāvajīvaṃpi okāsasambhavato.
analyzed: puti anantarataḥ paṭṭhāya okāsa sambhavato
translated: because there is room for it to be effective from the time of death onwards even for a hundred years.

original: [152] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there, namely,

original: “Paṭisandhiyā pana dinnāya jātisatepi pavattivipākaṃ detīti vuttaṃ”. Taṃpi na gahetabbaṃ.🔽Kammasaṅkarāpattito. Aṅguttaraṭṭhakathāyañca diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ upapajjavedanīyaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhiyā pana dinnāya jāti sate pi pavatti vipākam deti iti vuttam tat api na gahetabbam  kamma saṅkara āpattitaḥ aṅguttara ṭṭhakathāyañca diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam upapajja vedanīyam
translated: that “when rebirth-linking has been given, it gives its ripening in the course of the next existence even if a hundred times repeated,” should not be accepted.🔽Because it would then follow that the kammas were mixed up. And in the Commentary to the Anguttara Nikāya it is said, “There is no mixing of the kind called ‘to be felt here and now’ with that called ‘to be felt in the next existence,’

original: aparapariyāya vedanīyanti tesaṃ saṅkamanaṃ natthi. Yathāṭhāneyeva patiṭṭhantīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: apara pariyāya vedanīyanti tesam saṅkamanam natthi yathā ṭhāneya iva patiṭṭhanti iti vuttam
translated: or of either of these two with that called ‘to be felt in some future existence,’ but each kind is established in its own place” .🔽And it cannot be said that this is said only with reference to rebirth-linking.

original: Na cettha paṭisandhivasena evaṃ vuttanti sakkā vattuṃ. Tadatthasādhakassa aṭṭhakathāpadesassavā
analyzed: na ca ittha paṭisandhi vasena evam vuttan ti sakkā vattum tad attha sādhakassa aṭṭhakathā padesassa vā
translated: Because there is no statement of the commentary that would support that, nor any other statement, nor any sound logical ground.

original: vatthussavā yuttiyāvā abhāvatoti. Majjhe pana pañcajavana cetanā aparapariyāya vedanīyaṃnāma.
analyzed: vatthussavāḥ abhāvato ti majjhe pana
translated: But the five impulsions in the middle are called “to be felt in some future existence.”

original: Etā hi suṭṭhu balavantī sārabhūtāca hontīti na sīghaṃ vipaccituṃ sakkonti. Ciraṭṭhitikā
analyzed: etāḥ hi suṭṭhu balavanti sāra bhūtāḥ ca honti iti na sīgham vipaccitum sakkonti cira ṭṭhitikā
translated: For these are very strong and powerful and so they are unable to give their fruit quickly. They last a long time.

original: pana honti. Tasmā tatīyabhavato paṭṭhāya yadā okāsaṃ labhanti. Tadā pañcavāre paṭisandhiṃ🔽datvā saṃsārapavattiyā sati kappasatasahassepi pavattivipākaṃ dentīti. Imāniyeva
analyzed: pana honti tasmā tatīya bhavato paṭṭhāya yadā okāsam labhanti tadā pañca vāre paṭisandhim  da tvā saṃsāra pavattiyā sati kappa sata sahasse pi pavatti vipākam denti iti imāniyā eva
translated: But they do occur. Therefore, from the second becoming onwards, when they get the opportunity, they give rebirth-linking in five turns,

original: pana tīṇi kammāni attano attano khette sabbaso vipākavāraṃ alabhamānāni ahosikammaṃnāma.
analyzed: pana tīṇi kammāni attanaḥ attanaḥ khette sabbasas vipāka vāram alabhamānāni
translated: and they give their ripening in the course of existence even for a hundred thousand eons. But these three kinds of kamma that do not get a turn to ripen at all in their own field are called “kamma that has been done in vain.”

original: Khettañca nesaṃ pathamassa diṭṭha dhammacutiyā paricchinnaṃ. Dutīyassa anāgatānantarabhavacutiyā.
analyzed: khettam ca nesam pathamassa diṭṭha dhamma cutiyā paricchinnam dutīyassa anāgata anantara bhava cutiyā
translated: And their field is limited to the death in the present existence in the case of the first, to the death in the next existence in the future in the case of the second,

original: Tatīyassa parinibbānacutiyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. [Diṭṭhadhammacatukkaṃ]🔽148. Pākaṭṭhānavasenāti apāyādikassa vipaccanaṭṭhānassa vasena tathā cattāri kammānināma
analyzed: tatīyassa parinibbāna cutiyā ti daṭṭhabbam diṭṭhadhamma catukkam  pāka ṭṭhāna vasena ati apāya ādikassa vipaccanaṭṭhānassa vasena tathā cattāri
translated: and to the death in parinibbāna in the case of the third.🔽By the “place of ripening”: by the place where the ripening of the bad destinations, etc., occurs. So it should be construed.

original: hontīti yojanā. Tatthāti tesu akusalādīsu catūsu kammesu. Kammadvāravasenāti kammasiddhiyā
analyzed: honti iti yojanā tattha ati tesu akusala ādīsu catūsu kammesu kamma dvāra vasena ati kamma siddhiyā
translated: Therein: among the four kinds of kamma beginning with the unprofitable.🔽By the “door of kamma”: by the door of kamma consisting in the body, etc., which is a factor in the accomplishment of kamma.

original: aṅgabhūtānaṃ kāyādi kammadvārānaṃ vasena. Pāṇaṃ atipātenti etenāti pāṇātipāto. Atipātanañcettha
analyzed: aṅga bhūtānam kāya ādi kamma dvārānam vasena pāṇam atipātenti etena ati pāṇātipātaḥ atipātanam ca ittha
translated: Killing breathing things is “killing breathing things” . Herein,

original: sarasato patituṃ adatvā antarāeva payogabalena pātanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Adinnaṃ ādiyanti
analyzed: sarasataḥ patitum a datvā antarā eva payoga balena pātanam daṭṭhabbam adinnam ādiyanti
translated: Without waiting for it to fall from the mouth, it should be regarded as fallen by the power of the effort in the act of taking. Taking what is not given:

original: etenāti adinnādānaṃ. Agamanī yavatthusaṅkhātesu vatthukāmesu micchā caranti etenāti🔽kāmesumicchācāro. Tattha parapāṇe pāṇasaññino tassa jīvitindriyasantānupacchedakassa
analyzed: etena ati adinnādānam agamanī ya vatthu saṅkhātesu vatthu kāmesu micchā caranti etena ati  tattha para pāṇe pāṇa saññinaḥ tassa jīvitindriya santāna upacchedakassa
translated: by this they take what is not given. Sexual misconduct:

original: kāyavacīpayogassa samuṭṭhāpikā vadhakacetanā pāṇātipātonāma. Sayameva attano jīvitindriyaṃ
analyzed: kāya vacī payogassa samuṭṭhāpikā vadhaka cetanā pāṇātipātaḥ nāma sayam eva attanaḥ jīvitindriyaṃ
translated: by this they engage in sexual intercourse with objects of sexual misconduct, that is, with objects that are the bases for the offence of sexual misconduct. Herein, killing a living being: the volition to kill, which is the instigation to the bodily or verbal act that cuts off the continuity of the life faculty of a living being, is called “killing a living being” when one who has the perception of a living being as such kills another living being.

original: pātentassa pāṇātipātonāma natthi. Parapariggahite parapariggahitasaññino tato viyogakāraṇassa🔽kāya vacīpayogassa samuṭṭhāpikā acchindakacetanā adinnādānaṃnāma. Agamanīyavatthūsu
analyzed: pātentassa pāṇātipātaḥ nāma natthi para pariggahite para pariggahita saññinaḥ tatas viyoga kāraṇassa  kāya vacī payogassa samuṭṭhāpikā acchindaka cetanā adinnādānaṃ nāma agamanīya vatthūsu
translated: There is no killing of a living being when one kills one’s own life. Taking what is not given:🔽the volition to steal, which is the instigation to the bodily or verbal act that causes separation of what is held as one’s own by another who has the perception of it as such, is called “taking what is not given.” Sexual misconduct:

original: maggenamaggapaṭipādakassa kāyapayogassa samuṭṭhāpikā assādacetanā kāmesumicchācāronāma.
analyzed: maggena magga paṭipādakassa kāya payogassa samuṭṭhāpikā assāda cetanā kāmesu micchā ācāraḥ nāma
translated: the volition to enjoy, which is the instigation to the bodily act that goes by a path not used by householders, is called “sexual misconduct.”

original: Keci panaetthapi agamanīya vatthusaññinoti padaṃ icchanti. Taṃ aṭṭhakathāya na sameti.
analyzed: keci pana ettha api agamanīya vatthu saññino ti padam icchanti tam aṭṭhakathāya na sameti
translated: But some want to read the words “with the perception of objects of sexual misconduct” here also. That does not agree with the commentary.

original: Agamayanīvatthu tasmiṃ sevanacittanti hi tattha vuttaṃ. Etena agamanīyavatthumhi
analyzed: agamayanī vatthu tasmin sevana cittan ti hi tattha vuttam etena agamanīya vatthumhi
translated: For it is said there: “The state of mind of one who has intercourse with a person with whom one should not have intercourse.”

original: sati gamanīya saññāyavā agamanīya saññāyavā sevantassa kammapatho hoti yevāti siddhaṃ
analyzed: sati gamanīya saññāyavā agamanīya saññāyavā sevantassa kamma pathaḥ hoti siddham
translated: By this it is established that if there is the perception of one who should not be approached in regard to a person with whom one should not have intercourse, and the state of mind of one who has intercourse with her, there is a course of kamma.

original: hoti. Itarathā agamanīyavatthu tathā saññitā tasmiṃ sevanacittanti vuttaṃ siyāti.🔽Apare pana sayaṃ payogaṃ katvā attani parena karīyamānaṃ maggena maggapaṭipādanaṃ
analyzed: hoti itarathā agamanīya vatthu tathā saññi tā tasmim sevana cittan ti vuttam siyā ti  apare pana sayam payogam katvā attani parena karīyamānam maggena magga paṭipādanam
translated: Otherwise it would have to be said that the person with whom one should not have intercourse is so regarded, and the state of mind of one who has intercourse with her is the state of mind of one who has intercourse with a person with whom one should not have intercourse.

original: assādentassa sevanacitte satipi natthi kammappathabhedo. Payogassa abhāvāti vadanti.
analyzed: assādentassa sevana citte sati pi natthi kammappatha bhedaḥ payogassa abhāvā ti vadanti
translated: But others say that if one enjoys the act of intercourse performed by another on oneself, even though there is the state of mind of one who has intercourse, there is no difference in the course of kamma because there is no performance of the act by oneself.

original: Sevanacitte pana sati payogo appamāṇanti eke. Evañca sati tiyaṅgikova micchācāro,
analyzed: sevana citte pana sati payogaḥ appamāṇanti eke evañca sati tiyaṅgikaḥ uva micchācāro
translated: But others say that if there is the state of mind of one who has intercourse, the performance of the act is immeasurable. And if that is so, then it follows that sexual misconduct has only three factors,

original: na caturaṅgikoti āpajjati. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana sevana payogena saha caturaṅgikova
analyzed: na caturaṅgikaḥ iti āpajjati aṭṭhakathā ayam pana sevana payogena saha caturaṅgikaḥ uva
translated: not four. But in the commentary it is said to have four factors, namely, the performance of the act together with the state of mind of one who has intercourse.

original: vuttoti aññe. Sevanapayogo pana yebhuyyena labbhamānattāyeva vutto. Na pana ekantaaṅgabhāvato.
analyzed: vutto ti aññe sevana payogaḥ pana yebhuyyena labbhamāna ttāya iva vuttaḥ na pana ekanta aṅga bhāvato
translated: But the performance of the act is mentioned because it is usually present, not because it is an invariable factor.

original: Itarathā itthīnaṃ yebhuyyena payogakiccaṃ natthīti tāsaṃ micchācāro dullabho siyāti
analyzed: itarathā itthīnam yebhuyyena payoga kiccam natthi iti tāsam micchācāraḥ dullabhaḥ siyāti
translated: Otherwise, since women generally have no function in the use of it, their sexual misconduct would be rare.

original: ca vadanti. Bhikkhunidūsanaṃpi ettheva saṅgayhati. Sā hi rakkhitāsu saṅgahitāti.🔽Ṭīkāsu pana sā dhammarakkhitāpi na hoti. Kuto mātādirakkhitā. Dhammoti hi idha pāsaṇḍiyadhammova
analyzed: ca vadanti bhikkhu nidūsanam pi ettha iva saṅgayhati sā hi rakkhitāsu saṅgahitā ati  ṭīkāsu pana sā dhamma rakkhitā api na hoti kutas mātā ādi rakkhitā dhammā ti hi idha pāsaṇḍiya dhammā uva
translated: And they say that the defiling of a bhikkhunī is included here too, since she is protected and guarded.🔽But in the commentaries it is said that she is not even protected by the Dhamma, let alone by mother, father, etc.,

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttoti vadanti. Sāsanadhammopi nana yutto. Sabrahmacāri niyopi upajjhāyinī🔽ādikā tassā mātādiṭṭhāniyāeva honti. Tathā hi sikkhāpadavibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāyaṃ micchācāropi
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam vutto ti vadanti sāsana dhammo api yutto sabrahmacārī upajjhāyinī  ādikā honti tathā hi sikkhāpada vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathā ayam micchācāropi
translated: for the Dhamma here is the doctrine of the sectarians, which is not the Dhamma of the Dispensation, they say.🔽The spiritual companions, the preceptor, etc., are like her mother, etc.,

original: dussīlāya.La. Sāmaṇeriyā, puthujjanabhikkhuniyā, sotāpannāya, sakadāgāminiyā, tato
analyzed: sāmaṇeriyā puthujjana bhikkhuniyā sotāpannāya sakadāgāminiyā tato
translated: for the commentary on the training precepts says that the transgression of a woman of immoral habit, a probationer, a lay devotee, a worldling bhikkhunī, a stream-enterer, a once-returner,

original: anāgāminiyā vītikkamo mahāsāvajjo. Khīṇāsavāya pana ekantamahāsāvajjovāti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: anāgāminiyā vītikkamaḥ mahā sāvajjo khīṇāsavāya pana ekanta mahā sāvajjaḥ uvā ti vuttam
translated: and a non-returner is a serious offense, but the transgression of one whose cankers are destroyed is a very serious offense.

original: Kasmāpanettha surāpānaṃ nagahi taṃ. Taṃpihi apāyasaṃvattani kabhāvena vuttaṃ. Yathāha-surāmerayapānaṃ
analyzed: kasmā apanettha surā pānam tam taṃpihi ka bhāvena vuttam
translated: Why is drinking of wine mentioned here? It is mentioned because it is a cause of heedlessness. It is said to lead to the states of loss.

original: bhikkhave āsevitaṃ bhāvitaṃ bahulīkataṃ nirayasaṃvattanikaṃ tiracchānayonisaṃvattanikaṃ🔽pettivisayasaṃvattanikaṃ. Yoca sabbalahuko surāmeraya pānassa vipāko. So manussabhūtassa
analyzed: bhikkhave āsevitam bhāvitam bahulīkatam niraya saṃvattanikam tiracchāna yoni saṃvattanikam  petti visaya saṃvattanikam yaḥ ca sabba lahukaḥ pānassa vipākaḥ saḥ manussa bhūtassa
translated: Why is drinking liquor mentioned here? It is mentioned because it is a cause for the other three. As it is said: “The drinking of liquor and strong drink, monks, when practiced, developed, and cultivated, tends to hell, to rebirth as an animal, or to the realm of hungry ghosts.🔽And the least desirable result, for a human being, of the drinking of liquor and strong drink is insanity.”

original: ummattakasaṃvattaniko hotīti. Aṭṭhakathāsupi koṭṭhāsato pañcapi pāṇātipātā dayo kammapathāevāti🔽vuttanti. Vuccate, mūlaṭīkāyaṃ tāva tassa sabhāgattena micchācāre upakārakattena
analyzed: ummattaka saṃvattanikaḥ hoti iti aṭṭhakathāsu pi koṭṭhāsato pañca api pāṇātipātāḥ dayo kamma pathāḥ eva ati  vuttam iti vuccate mūla ṭīkāyam tāva tassa sabhāga ttena micchācāre upakāraka ttena
translated: And in the commentaries it is said: “The five beginning with killing living beings are courses of kamma in the sense of being principal.”🔽It may be objected: “But in the Mula-Tikā it is said: ‘It is not included among the ten courses of kamma because it is similar to and assists the course of kamma called misconduct.’🔽” There it is said that drinking liquor is not included among the ten courses of kamma because it is similar to and assists the course of kamma called misconduct.

original: dasasupi kammapathesu anupavesoti vuttaṃ. Tattha sabhāgattaṃ gahetvā vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: dasasu pi kamma pathesu anupaveso ti vuttam tattha sabhā gattam gahetvā vibhāvaniyam
translated: Taking this similarity, the Vibhānā-Ṭīkā says:

original: surāpānaṃpi ettheva saṅgayhatīti vadanti rasasaṅkhātesu kāmesu micchācārabhāvatoti
analyzed: etthā iva saṅgayhati iti vadanti rasa saṅkhātesu kāmesu micchā ācāra bhāvataḥ ti
translated: “Drinking liquor is included here too, because it is a form of misconduct in the sense of being a sensual pleasure consisting of taste.”

original: vuttaṃ. Upakārakattaṃ gahetvā paṭisambhidāmaggaṭīkāyaṃ kusalākusalāpica paṭisandhijanakāyeva
analyzed: vuttam upakāraka ttam gahetvā paṭisambhidā magga ṭīkāyam kusala akusalā api ca paṭisandhi jana kāya iva
translated: The commentary on the Path of Discrimination, taking the meaning of “helpful,” says:🔽“The profitable and unprofitable are called ‘courses of kamma’ only when they generate rebirth-linking.

original: kammapathāti vuttā. Vuttāvasesā paṭisandhijanane anekanti kattā kamma pathāti na
analyzed: kamma pathā ati vuttā vuttā avasesā paṭisandhi janane anekanti kattā kamma pathā ati na
translated: The rest of what is said are not ‘courses of k kamma’ because they do not generate rebirth-linking, though they are many in number.”

original: vuttāti imassa vākyassa saṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttāvase sāti surāpānādayo tabbiramaṇādayoca.
analyzed: vuttā ti imassa vākyassa saṃvaṇṇanā ayam sā ati surā pāna ādayaḥ tad viramaṇa ādayaḥ ca
translated: In the commentary on the words of this passage, “The rest of what is said” refers to the drinking of wines and spirits, etc., and the abstaining from them, etc.

original: Surāpānañhi madassa paccayo. Mado apuññapathassa. Tabbiratipi nimmadatāya. Sāca puññapathassāti🔽kammapathūpanissayāni tāni tadāsannakammavasena sandhijanakānipi hontīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: surā pānam hi madassa paccayaḥ madaḥ a puñña pathassa nimmada tāya sā ca puñña pathassa ati  kamma pathu upanissayāni tāni tad āsanna kamma vasena sandhi janakāni pi honti iti vuttam
translated: For the drinking of wines and spirits is a condition for intoxication, and intoxication is a course of demerit, and the abstaining from intoxication is a course of merit.🔽So it is said that these are “courses of kamma” and that they are “conditions for rebirth-linking” and that they “generate rebirth-linking” because they are kamma proximate to the courses of kamma.

original: Tattha tadāsannakammavasenāti tassa surāpānassavā surāpānaviratiyāvā āsanne pavattānaṃ
analyzed: tattha tad āsanna kamma vasena āti tassa āsanne pavattānam
translated: Herein, the meaning of the words “because they are kamma proximate to the courses of kamma” is this:🔽they are proximate to the drinking of wines and spirits, and they are proximate to the abstaining from the drinking of wines and spirits,🔽and they are kamma that occurs in association with them.

original: tammūlakānaṃ apuññakammānaṃvā puññakammānaṃvā vasenāti attho. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti-yo
analyzed: tad mūlakānam apuñña kammānam vā puñña kammānam vā vasena ati attho idam vuttam hotiyo
translated: The meaning is that they are kamma that has them as its root.

original: suraṃ pivitvā surāmadahetu pāṇā pātādīsu yaṃkiñci kammaṃ karoti, tassa surāpānaṃ
analyzed: suram pivitvā surām adahetu pāṇā pāta ādīsu yaṃ kiñci kammam karoti tassa surā pānam
translated: This is what is said: he who, after drinking wines and spirits, does any kind of kamma such as killing living things, etc., for the sake of the intoxication of wines and spirits,

original: tassati kammassa balavūpanissayo hoti pubbacetanāṭhāniyañca. Tadeva visuṃ paṭisandhiṃ🔽janeti, na itaranti. Yathā hi pubbāparacetanā yopi kammapathapattassa kammassa parivārabhūtāeva🔽paṭisandhiṃ janenti, na itarā. Evamidaṃpīti. Na hi kammapathasuttesu sarūpato āgatānieva
analyzed: tassati kammassa balavūpanissayaḥ hoti pubba cetanā ṭhāniyam ca tat eva visum paṭisandhim  janeti na itaranti yathā hi pubba apara cetanā yaḥ api kamma patha pattassa kammassa parivāra bhūtā eva  paṭisandhim janenti na itarāḥ evam idam pi iti na hi kamma patha suttesu sarūpataḥ āgatāni eva
translated: and the strength of the kamma, and the prior volition, and the state of being the cause, are the conditions for rebirth-linking.🔽It is only that which generates rebirth-linking, not the other.🔽Just as the prior and subsequent volitions that are the companions of the kamma that has reached the plane of the paths only generate rebirth-linking, not the other volitions, so too this kamma.

original: paṭisandhiṃ janenti. Na itarānīti sakkā niyametuṃ. Yāni pana ekantena paṭisandhijananasāmatthiya
analyzed: paṭisandhim janenti na itarāni iti sakkā niyametum yāni pana ekantena paṭisandhi janana sāmatthiya
translated: For it cannot be definitely asserted that only those that are stated in the Suttas on the courses of kamma generate rebirth-linking, not the others.

original: yuttāni, tāneva tattha sarūpato vuttāni. Yānipana paṭisandhijanane anekantikāni honti.
analyzed: yuttāni tāni eva tattha sarūpataḥ vuttāni yāni pana paṭisandhi janane anekantikāni honti
translated: But only those that are suitable to generate rebirth-linking are stated there in the Suttas.🔽And it can be understood that only those that are not definite in generating rebirth-linking are not stated there in the Suttas.

original: Tāni tatthasarūpato na vuttānīti sakkā viññātuṃ. Tathā hi paṭisambhidā maggaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: tāni tad tha sarūpataḥ na vuttāni iti sakkā viññātum tathā hi paṭisambhidā magga ṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: For in the Paṭisambhidā, in the commentary to the “Path of So-and-So” ,

original: kusalākusalāpica paṭisandhijanakāyeva kammapathāti vuttā. Vuttāvasesā paṭisandhijanane
analyzed: kusala akusalā api ca paṭisandhi jana kāyā iva kamma pathā ati vuttā vuttā avasesā paṭisandhi janane
translated: it is said that only the profitable and unprofitable are courses of kamma that generate rebirth-linking.🔽The rest of what is said there is not stated in the Suttas on the courses of kamma.

original: anekanti kattā kammapathāti na vuttāti vuttaṃ. Tasmā idaṃpi paṭisandhijanane anekantikattā
analyzed: kamma pathā ati na vuttā iti vuttam tasmai idam pi paṭisandhi janane anekantika ttā
translated: So it is not stated there in its own individual essence.🔽What was said above about it as generating rebirth-linking by means of the kamma that is present at the time of rebirth-linking,

original: tattha sarūpato na vuttantica. Yaṃ tadā sannakammavasena paṭisandhijanakanti pubbe🔽vuttaṃ. Taṃ tattha sarūpato vuttesu tadā sannakammesu anupaviṭṭhantica sakkā vattunti.
analyzed: tattha sarūpataḥ na vutta nti ca yam tadā sanna kamma vasena paṭisandhi janakanti pubbe  vuttam tam tattha sarūpataḥ vuttesu tadā sanna kammesu anupaviṭṭhanti ca sakkā vattun ti
translated: that can be said of it as not included among those stated there in their own individual essences.

original: Tassa pana duvidhaṃ kiccaṃ paṭisandhijananaṃ kammajananañcāti. Tattha paṭijananato
analyzed: tassa pana duvidham kiccam paṭisandhi jananam kamma jananam ca ati tattha paṭijananato
translated: But it has a twofold function, namely, generating rebirth-linking and generating kamma. Herein,🔽since it is the generating of kamma that is its great function and has great scope,

original: kammajananamevassa mahantaṃ mahāvipphārañca hotīti katvā sakkena devānamindena kumbhajātake –
analyzed: kamma jananam eva assa mahantam mahā vipphārañca hoti iti katvā sakkena devānamindena kumbhajātake
translated: Sakka, lord of the devas, said in the Kumbha Jātaka,

original: Yaṃ ve vivitvā duccaritaṃ caranti,
analyzed: yam ve vivitvā duccaritam caranti
translated: “The evil-doers who do their deeds in secret,

original: Kāyena vācāya cetasāca;
analyzed: kāyena vācāya cetasā ca
translated: With body, speech, and mind,

original: Nirayaṃ vajanti duccaritaṃ caritvā,
analyzed: nirayam vajanti duccaritam caritvā
translated: Go to hell when their deeds are done;

original: Tassā puṇṇaṃ kumbhamimaṃ kiṇāthāti.
analyzed: tassā puṇṇam kumbham imam kiṇātha ati
translated: Buy this full jar from me.”🔽So it is said that it sends him to an unhappy destiny by means of the kamma that is present at the time of rebirth-linking.

original: Evaṃ tadāsannakammavaseneva tassa apāyagāmitā vuttā. Tadubhayaṃ panassa kiccaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: evam tad āsanna kamma vasena iva tassa apāya gāmi tā vuttā tat ubhayam panassa kiccam gahetvā
translated: But taking both functions of it,

original: surāmerayapānaṃ bhikkhave āsevitaṃ.La. Saṃvattanikanti aṅguttare vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: surā meraya pānam bhikkhave āsevitam saṃvattanikanti aṅguttare vuttanti veditabbam
translated: The meaning of “conducive” should be understood as stated in the Aṅguttara-nikāya.

original: Ayañhisuttapadesu dhammatā. Yadidaṃ saṃvattanikanti vuttaṭṭhāne yathālābhayojanāti.
analyzed: dhamma tā yat idam saṃvattanikan ti vutta ṭṭhāne yathā lābha yojanā ti
translated: For this is the nature of the passages in the suttas: where the word “conducive” occurs, the meaning is “as far as possible.”

original: Tathāhi mūlaṭīkāyaṃpunabbhavaṃdetipunabbhavāya saṃvattetīti pāṭhe kammasahajātā punabbhavaṃdeti.
analyzed: tathā hi mūla ṭīkā ayam punar bhavaṃdeti punarbhavāya saṃvatteti iti pāṭhe kamma sahajātā punar bhavaṃdeti
translated: For in the Mula-Tika it is said with reference to the reading “punabbhavaṃ deti punabbhavāya saṃvattati”: “The rebirth-linking consciousness gives rebirth-linking and is conducive to rebirth-linking.”

original: Kammasahāyabhūtā akammasahajā tāpunabbhavaṃ saṃvattetīti vuttaṃ. Keci pana imamatthaṃ
analyzed: kamma sahāya bhūtā a kamma sahajā tā punabbhavam saṃvatteti iti vuttam keci pana imam attham
translated: And with reference to the reading “punabbhavaṃ deti na punabbhavāya saṃvattati”: “The kamma that is conascent with consciousness does not give rebirth-linking.🔽But the kamma that is not conascent with consciousness but is a companion to the kamma that is conascent does give rebirth-linking and is conducive to rebirth-linking.”

original: anupadhāretvā imāya pāḷiyā tassa visuṃ ekantakammapathabhāvaṃ maññanti. Yaṃ pana🔽koṭṭhāsato pañcapi kammapathāevāti aṭṭhakathāvākyaṃ. Tattha evasaddena tesaṃ cetanādhammattā
analyzed: an upadhāretvā imāya pāḷiyā tassa visum ekanta kammapatha bhāvam maññanti yam pana  koṭṭhāsato kamma pathāḥ evā ti aṭṭhakathā vākyam tattha eva saddena tesam cetanā dhamma ttā
translated: But some, without considering this meaning, think that this passage shows that each of the five kinds of kamma is a complete course by itself.🔽But the statement in the commentary that “all five are courses of kamma by way of their component parts”🔽sets aside the view that they are courses of kamma by way of their component parts such as jhāna, etc.

original: jhānādikoṭṭhāsikattaṃ nivatteti. Cetanā hi kammapathaṃ pattāpi apattāpi koṭṭhāsato
analyzed: jhāna ādi koṭṭhāsika ttam nivatteti cetanā hi kamma patham pattā api a pattā api koṭṭhāsato
translated: For though volition is a course of kamma, it is not a course of kamma by way of its component parts.

original: kamma pathakoṭṭhāsikāeva hotīti. Teneva mūlaṭīkāyaṃ kammapathā evāti kammapathakoṭṭhāsikāevāti
analyzed: kamma patha koṭṭhāsikā eva hoti iti tena iva mūla ṭīkā ayam kamma pathā eva ati kamma patha koṭṭhāsikā eva ati
translated: That is why in the commentary on the root text it is said, “The courses of kamma are only a section of the courses of kamma” .

original: vuttaṃ. Anuṭīkāyañca kamma pathakoṭṭhāsikāeva. Na jhānādikoṭṭhāsikāti vuttaṃ. Kecipana
analyzed: vuttam anuṭīkāyam ca kamma patha koṭṭhāsikā eva na jhāna ādi koṭṭhāsikā ti vuttam keci pana
translated: And in the subcommentary it is said, “It is only a section of the courses of kamma, not a section of the jhānas, etc.”

original: imamatthaṃ asallakkhetvā iminā vākyena tassa visuṃ kammapathabhāvaṃ vadanti.
analyzed: imam attham a sat lakkhetvā iminā vākyena tassa visum kamma patha bhāvam vadanti
translated: But some, not discerning the meaning, say that this passage states that it is a course of kamma in its own right.

original: Khuddakapāṭhaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana sabbenasabbaṃ tassa kammapathabhāvo paṭikkhittoyeva,🔽tattha hi purimānaṃ catunnaṃ kāyakammādibhāvañca kammapathabhāvañca visuṃ vatvā surāpānaṃpatvā
analyzed: khuddaka pāṭha ṭṭhakathā ayam pana sabbena sabbam tassa kammapatha bhāvo paṭikkhittaḥ yeva  tattha hi purimānam catunnam kāya kamma ādi bhāvañca kamma patha bhāvañca visum vatvā surā pānam patvā
translated: But in the Khuddakapāṭha commentary the whole of it is rejected as a course of kamma,

original: kāyakammamevāti vuttaṃ. Etena vacīkammabhāvañca kammapathabhāvañca paṭikkhipatīti.
analyzed: kāya kammam eva ati vuttam etena vacī kamma bhāvañca kammapatha bhāvañca paṭikkhipati iti
translated: for after stating separately the fact that the first four are bodily action, etc., and courses of kamma, and the fact that the drinking of intoxicants is verbal action, it is said, “By this he rejects the fact that it is verbal action and a course of kamma.”

original: Dhātusaṃyuttaṭṭhakathā yañca paṭikkhitto. Yathāha-tatīyaṃpañcakammavasena bujjhanakānaṃ
analyzed: dhātusaṃyutta ṭṭhakathā yat ca paṭikkhittaḥ yathāha tatīyam pañca kamma vasena bujjhanakānam
translated: And it is rejected in the commentary on the Dhātusamyutta, which says: “The third is stated according to the inclination of those who are enlightened by means of the fivefold kamma.

original: ajjhāsayavasena vuttaṃ. Catutthaṃ sattakammapathavasena pañcamaṃ dasa kammapathavasenāti.
analyzed: ajjhāsaya vasena vuttam catuttham satta kammapatha vasena pañcamam dasa kammapatha vasena ati
translated: The fourth is stated according to the sevenfold kamma. The fifth is stated according to the tenfold kamma.”

original: Tattha hi tatīye surāpānamissakattā pañcakammavasena icceva vuttaṃ. Na pañcakammapathavasenāti.
analyzed: tattha hi tatīye surā pāna missaka ttā pañca kamma vasena icca eva vuttam na pañca kammapatha vasena ati
translated: For in the case of the third, drinking liquor is included in the five precepts, and so it is mentioned only as the five precepts, not as the five training precepts.

original: Etāsupica paṭisandhijanane anekanti kattāeva paṭikkhittoti na nasakkā vattuṃ evañhi
analyzed: etāsu pi ca paṭisandhi janane anekanti kattā eva paṭikkhittaḥ iti na na sakkā vattum evam hi
translated: And since the doer is prohibited in the case of all these, it cannot be said that they are not precepts.🔽For in that case all the commentaries on the texts would be contradicted.

original: sati sabbā pāḷiṭṭhakathāṭīkāyo saṃsanditā hontīti. Kāyakammanti ettha kāyo tividho
analyzed: sati sabbā saṃsanditā honti iti kāya kamman ti ettha kāyaḥ tividhaḥ
translated: As regards the words bodily action, body is of three kinds:

original: sasambhārakāyo pasādakāyo copanakāyoti. Idha kāyaviññattisaṅkhāto copanakāyo adhippetoti
analyzed: sa sambhāra kāyo pasāda kāyo copana kāyo ti idha kāya viññatti saṅkhāto copana kāyo adhippeto ti
translated: the body with its components, the body as the sense base of tactile consciousness, and the body as the physical frame. Here the body as the physical frame is intended.🔽This is why it is said, “in the sense of bodily intimation.”

original: vuttaṃ kāyaviññattisaṅkhāteti. Copanakāyo hi kadāci kāyaṅgena attanoadhippāyaṃ parassa🔽viññā panatthāyapi karīyatīti kāyaviññattīti vuccatīti. So yevaca kammānaṃ pavattimukhattā
analyzed: vuttam kāya viññatti saṅkhātā iti copana kāyaḥ hi kadāci kāyaṅgena attano adhippāyam parassa  viññā pana tthāya api karīyati iti kāyaviññattī iti vuccati iti saḥ yā iva ca kammānam pavatti mukha ttā
translated: For the body as the physical frame sometimes causes its own purpose to be intimated to another, and so it is called bodily intimation.🔽And that is a door for the occurrence of kamma,🔽and so it is called the bodily door.

original: dvāranti kāyadvāraṃ. Tasmiñhi tena tena upakkama kiccena pavattamāneeva jīvitindriyupacchedādikiccasiddhito
analyzed: dvāranti kāya dvāram tasmin hi tena tena upakkama kiccena pavattamāne eva jīvitindriya upaccheda ādi kicca siddhitaḥ
translated: For it is only when it occurs with the function of the particular effort that it accomplishes the function of severing the life faculty, etc.

original: taṃjana kassa cetanādhammassa āyūhana kiccanibbattica kāyakammanāma lābhoca hotīti.
analyzed: cetanā dhammassa hoti iti
translated: The function of the volition of the action of the eye is the production of the accumulation of kamma. It is also the acquisition of the name “ bodily action.”

original: Tasmiṃ kāyadvāre. Etthaca yasmāsabbānipi kammāni pubbaṅgamabhūtena sampayuttamanena
analyzed: tasmim kāya dvāre ettha ca kammāni pubbaṅgama bhūtena sampayuttam anena
translated: In that bodily door. And here, since all actions do not occur without the associated volition that precedes them,

original: vinā nasijjhanti. Manopubbaṅgamā dhammā. Manoseṭṭhā manomayāti hi vuttaṃ. Dhammāti🔽cettha sucaritaduccaritadhammā vuccanti. Tasmā manodvāraṃ sabbakammasādhāraṇattā
analyzed: vinā manaḥ pubbaṅgamāḥ dhammā manaḥ seṭṭhāḥ manaḥ mayā iti hi vuttam dhamma ati  ca ittha su carita duccarita dhammāḥ vuccanti tasmā manodvāram sabba kamma sādhāraṇa ttā
translated: it is said: “Ideas are preceded by mind, led by mind, and made by mind” . Herein, the term “ideas” refers to good and bad ideas. Therefore,

original: kammāni visesetuṃ nasakkoti. Asādhāraṇabhūtā pana kāyavacīyo eva sakonti. Yasmāca
analyzed: kammāni visesetum na sakkoti asādhāraṇa bhūtā pana eva sakonti yasmā ca
translated: since the mind door is common to all actions, it cannot distinguish the actions. But the bodily and verbal actions, which are uncommon, can.

original: purimāni sattavidhāni kammāni kevalaṃ manomattena nasijjhanti. Taṃsamuṭṭhitehi pana🔽kāya vacīpayogehi eva sijjhanti. Tasmā teeva tesaṃ kammānaṃ pavattimukhasaṅkhyaṃ
analyzed: purimāni sattavidhāni kammāni kevalam manaḥ mattena nasijjhanti taṃsa muṭṭhitehi pana  kāya vacī payogehi eva sijjhanti tasmā te eva tesam kammānam pavatti mukha saṅkhyam
translated: And since the first seven kinds of action do not occur merely through the mind alone, but they occur only through the bodily and verbal processes originated by the mind,

original: gacchantīti vuttaṃ kāyadvāreti. Parato vacīdvāreti ca.
analyzed: gacchanti iti vuttam kāya dvāra iti paratas vacī dvāra iti ca
translated: therefore it is said: “The bodily door is the entrance to the occurrence of those three kinds of action.” The verbal door is the entrance to the occurrence of the last three kinds of action.

original: Yasmā pana kāyadvāre vuttito kāyakammaṃ nāma. Vacīdvāre vuttito vacīkammaṃnāmāti🔽ettakamatte vutte pāṇātipātādīni tīṇi kāyakammaṃnāma. Musāvādādīni cattāri vacīkammaṃnāmāti🔽evaṃ dvārena kammānaṃ nāmavavatthānaṃ asiddhaṃ siyā. Kathaṃ. Yadā hi purimāni dve
analyzed: yasmā pana kāya dvāre vuttitaḥ kāya kammam nāma vacī dvāre vuttitaḥ vacī kammaṃ nāma ati  ettaka matte vutte pāṇātipāta ādīni tīṇi kāya kammaṃnāma musāvāda ādīni cattāri vacī kammaṃnāma ati  evam dvārena kammānam nāma vavatthānam asiddham siyā katham yadā hi purimāni dve
translated: But since bodily action occurs in the body door, it is called bodily action. And since verbal action occurs in the speech door, it is called verbal action.🔽If only this much were stated, the naming of the actions according to the doors would be unsuccessful. For then the three beginning with killing living beings would be called bodily action, and the four beginning with false speech would be called verbal action.

original: āṇattivasena appakena vacīdvāre bhijjhanti. Tadā tāni kāyakammanti nāmaṃ jaheyyuṃ.
analyzed: āṇatti vasena appakena vacī dvāre bhijjhanti tadā tāni kāyakammanti nāmam jaheyyuṃ
translated: How so? When the first two are broken by a small amount of verbal action by way of intimation, then they would lose the name “bodily action”

original: Vacīkammanti saṅkhyaṃ gaccheyyuṃ kasmā vacīdvāre vuttito vacīkammaṃnāmāti vuttattā.🔽Dvevā nesaṃ nāmāni bhaveyyuṃ. Ubhayadvāresupi sandissanato. Yadāpana majjhimāni cattāri
analyzed: saṅkhyam gaccheyyum kasmāt vacī dvāre vuttitaḥ vacī kammaṃ nāmā ati vutta ttā  dveva nesam nāmāni bhaveyyuṃ ubhaya dvāresu pi sandissanataḥ majjhimāni cattāri
translated: and would be reckoned as “verbal action.” Why? Because it is said: “Since verbal action occurs in the speech door, it is called verbal action.”🔽So they would have two names, because they are found in both doors.

original: hatthamuṭṭhādivasena appakena kāyadvāre sijjhanti. Tadā tānipi vacīkammanti nāmaṃ
analyzed: hattha muṭṭha ādi vasena appakena kāya dvāre sijjhanti tadā tāni pi vacīkammanti nāmaṃ
translated: But when the middle four are accomplished by a small amount of bodily action by way of the hand-span, etc., then they too would lose the name “verbal action”

original: jaheyyuṃ. Kāyakammanti saṅkhyaṃ gaccheyyuṃ. Kasmā kāyadvāre vuttito kāyakammaṃnāmāti
analyzed: jaheyyum saṅkhyam gaccheyyum kasmā kāya dvāre vuttitaḥ kāya kammaṃ nāmā ti
translated: and would be reckoned as “bodily action.” Why? Because it is said: “Since bodily action occurs in the body door, it is called bodily action.”

original: vuttattā. Dvevā nesaṃ nāmāni bhaveyyuṃ. Ubhayadvāresupi sandissanato. Evañcasati
analyzed: vutta ttā dve vā nāmāni bhaveyyuṃ ubhaya dvāresu pi sandissanataḥ
translated: And because they are found in both doors, in this way

original: pāṇātipāto.La. Micchācāroceti kāyakammaṃnāmāti idaṃ vavatthānameva niratthakaṃ siyā.
analyzed: idam vavatthānam eva niratthakam siyā
translated: the definition “Killing-breathing-things is bodily action” and “Misconduct is bodily action” would be pointless.🔽Similarly, the definition “Lying is verbal action” and “Malicious speech is verbal action” would be pointless.

original: Tathā parato musāvādo.La. Ppalāpoceti vacīkammaṃnāmāti. Bāhullavuttitoti vuttepana
analyzed: tathā paratas bāhulla vuttitaḥ ti
translated: Because of the abundance of usage.

original: ekamekena bāhullasaddena chabbidhāni tāni vajjāni vajjetvā vuttappakāraṃ dvārena
analyzed: ekam ekena bāhulla saddena chabbidhāni tāni vajjāni vajjetvā vutta ppakāram dvārena
translated: Thus, having found fault with those six kinds of action by means of the word “abundance” in each case,

original: kammavavatthānaṃ siddhaṃ bhavati. Yathā vanacarako saṅgāmāvacaroti.
analyzed: kamma vavatthānam siddham bhavati yathā vana carako saṅgāma avacaroti
translated: the definition of action by means of the door is established in the way stated. Just as a forest ranger and a battle ranger.

original: Manokammāni pana dvārantaresu carantānipi caraṇamattāni eva honti. Na dvārantarāni
analyzed: manaḥ kammāni pana dvāra antaresu carantāni pi caraṇa mattāni eva honti na dvāra antarāni
translated: But the mental actions, though they range in the intervals between the doors, are only ranging; they are not

original: tesaṃ kammasiddhiyā aṅgaṃ honti. Tasmā tāni visuṃ katānīti veditabbaṃ. Yasmā pana
analyzed: tesam kamma siddhiyāḥ aṅgam honti tasmā tāni visum katāni iti veditabbam yasmā pana
translated: a condition for the success of action in the intervals between the doors. So they should be understood to be classed separately.

original: kāyadvārassa kāyoti nāmaṃ anekesu suttasahassesu sayameva siddhaṃ pākaṭañca. Tathā
analyzed: kāyadvārassa kāyo ti nāmam anekesu sutta sahassesu sayam eva siddham pākaṭam ca tathā
translated: But because the name “body door” is established and obvious in many thousands of suttas by itself,🔽and because the name “speech door” is established and obvious in many thousands of suttas by itself,🔽and because the name “mind door” is established and obvious in many thousands of suttas by itself,

original: vacīdvārassa vācāti nāmaṃ. Kusalākusala javanacittasaṅkhākassa manodvārassaca manoti🔽nāmaṃ. Tasmā sabbattha kāyadvāraṃ vacīdvāraṃ manodvāranti vutte kammena dvārassa
analyzed: vacī dvārassa vācā ati nāmam kusala akusala javana citta saṅkhākassa manaḥ dvārassa ca  nāmam tasmā sabbattha kāya dvāram vacī dvāram manaḥ dvāram iti vutte kammena dvārassa
translated: The speech door is called speech. The mind door is called mind.🔽Therefore, in all these cases, when it is said, “the body door, the speech door, the mind door,” there is no function of defining the door by way of the action.

original: vavatthāna kiccaṃnāma natthi. Yattha pana kāyakammadvāraṃ vacīkammadvāraṃ manokammadvāranti
analyzed: vavatthāna kiccaṃnāma natthi yattha pana kāya kamma dvāram vacī kamma dvāram manaḥ kamma dvāranti
translated: But where it is said, “the body-action door, the speech-action door, the mind-action door,”

original: āgataṃ. Tattheva dvārakathādīsu kammena dvāravavatthānaṃpi visuṃ vattabbaṃ hotīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: āgatam tattha iva dvāra kathā ādīsu kammena dvāra vavatthānam pi visum vattabbam hoti iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: there, in the discussion of the doors, etc., the defining of the door by way of the action should be understood separately.

original: [153] Etena yaṃ vuttaṃ vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: etena yam vuttam
translated: By this, what is said in the Vibhanga is refuted:

original: “Kāyakammassaca pavattimukhabhūtaṃ kāyadvāranti vuccatīti”. Taṃ paṭikkhittaṃ hoti.
analyzed: kāya kammassa ca pavatti mukha bhūtam kāyadvāranti vuccati iti tat paṭikkhittam hoti
translated: “The body door is called the body, which is the door of the occurrence of body-action.”

original: [154] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there:

original: “Tathā musāvādādiṃ kāyavikārena karontassa vacīkammaṃ kāyadvārepi pavattatīti kammena dvāravavatthānaṃpi nasiyāti” vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na yujjati.
analyzed: tathā musāvāda ādim kāya vikārena karontassa vacī kammam kāya dvāre pi pavattati iti kammena dvāra vavatthānam pi na siyā ti vuttam tat pi na yujjati
translated: “Likewise, when one who is telling a lie, etc., does it by bodily gesture, the speech-action occurs in the body door. Therefore, the defining of the door by way of the action is not necessary,” is not correct.

original: Na hi kāyavikārena karīyamānaṃ vacīkammaṃ kāyadvāre pavattamānaṃpi tassa dvārassa nāmaṃ bhindituṃvā attano nāmaṃ dātuṃvā sakkoti. Sabhāva siddhattā tassa nāmassāti.🔽[155] Eteneva yañca tattha🔽Vuttaṃ “tathā kāyakammameva yebhuyyena kāyadvāre pavattati. Na itarāni. Tasmā kāyakammassa
analyzed: na hi kāya vikārena karīyamānam vacī kammam kāya dvāre pavattamānam pi tassa dvārassa nāmam bhinditum vā attanaḥ nāmam dātum vā sakkoti tassa nāmassa ati  etena iva yat ca tattha  vuttam tathā kāya kammam eva yebhuyyena kāya dvāre pavattati na itarāni tasmā kāya kammassa
translated: For when verbal kamma is done by bodily intimation, though it occurs in the door of the body, it cannot take the name of that door or give its own name to it, because the name of that door is established by nature.

original: yebhuyyena ettheva pavattanato kāyakammadvārabhāvo siddho. Brāhmaṇagāmādīnaṃ brāhmaṇagāmādi🔽bhāvoviyāti”. Taṃpi paṭikkhittaṃ hoti.
analyzed: yebhuyyena ettha iva pavattanato kāya kamma dvāra bhāvaḥ siddhaḥ brāhmaṇa gāma ādīnam brāhmaṇa gāma ādi  tat pi paṭikkhittam hoti
translated: By this same reasoning it should be understood that the words of the Vibhaṅga, “Likewise, bodily kamma occurs mostly in the door of the body, not the others. Therefore, since bodily kamma occurs here mostly, the state of being a door of bodily kamma is established. It is like the state of being a brahmin village, etc., of a village inhabited by brahmins, and so on” , are rejected.

original: Na hi kāyakammadvāranti nāmaṃ idha vuttaṃ atthīti. [Kāyakammaṃ]🔽149. Musāti abhūtatthe nipāto. Musā vadanti etenāti musāvādo. Visati paresaṃ aññamaññasammodabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: na hi kāya kamma dvāran ti nāmaṃ idha vuttam atthi iti kāya kammaṃ  musā iti abhūta atthe nipātaḥ musā vadanti etena ati musāvādaḥ paresam aññamañña sammoda bhāva saṅkhātam
translated: For the name “door of bodily kamma” is not mentioned here.

original: sāmaggirasaṃ saṃcuṇṇeti paribhindati mithu bhedaṃ karoti etāyāti pisuṇā. Attano piyabhāvaṃ
analyzed: sāmaggirasam saṃcuṇṇā iti paribhindati mithu bhedam karoti pisuṇā attanaḥ piya bhāvam
translated: “Musā” is a particle in the sense of “untruth.” It is a lie because of lying with it. It is slander because of splitting by it, because of breaking up, because of causing dissension, the concord consisting in mutual endearment of others. It is a malicious tale because of causing others to be split by it. It is a tale of one’s own excellence because of causing others to be split by it. It is a tale of one’s own excellence because of causing others to be split by it. It is a tale of one’s own excellence because of causing others to be split by it. It is a tale of one’s own excellence because of causing others to be split by it. It is a tale of one’s own excellence because of causing others to be split by it.
