It is a tale of one’s own excellence because of causing others to be split by it. It is a tale

original: paresañca mittasuññabhāvaṃ karoti etāyātivā pisuṇā. Niruttinayena. Vadanti etāyāti
analyzed: paresam ca mitta suñña bhāvam karoti pisuṇāḥ nirutti nayena vadanti etāya ati
translated: and it makes others devoid of friends. Or else, it is ‘malicious’ because it is done by way of maliciousness.🔽It is ‘speech’ because they speak by means of it.

original: vācā. Pisuṇāca sā vācācāti pisuṇavācā. Yena suyyati, tassa hadayaṃ pharamānā usati
analyzed: vācā sā pisuṇa vācā yena tassa hadayam pharamānā usati
translated: And it is ‘malicious speech’ because it is both malicious and speech.🔽It is ‘harsh’ because it goes and burns the heart of him by whom it is heard.

original: dahatīti pharusā. Pharusāca sā vācācāti pharusavācā. Sādhujanehi adhigantabbaṃ saṃsukhaṃ
analyzed: dahati iti pharusā pharusā ca sā pharusa vācā sādhu janehi adhigantabbam saṃsukham
translated: And it is ‘harsh speech’ because it is both harsh and speech.

original: hitañca phalati visarati vināseti hitasukhamaggaṃ bhindatīti samphaṃ. Taṃvā phalati🔽bhijjati etenāti samphaṃ. Atthadhammāpagatassa paṭibhāṇacittassa bhāratayuddhasītāharaṇā
analyzed: hitam ca phalati visarati hita sukha maggam bhindati iti tam vā phalati  bhijjati etena ati attha dhamma apagatassa paṭibhāṇa cittassa bhārata yuddha sītā haraṇā
translated: It is ‘gossip’ because it is the outcome of, it flows out from, it destroys the path to welfare and pleasure.🔽It is ‘gossip’ because it is that by means of which one is ‘gossiped about’ .

original: dikassa vācā vatthumattassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Yattha diṭṭhadhammahitabuddhiyāvā samparāyika
analyzed: dikassa vācā vatthumattassa etam nāmam diṭṭhadhamma hita buddhi yāvā
translated: This is a name for the speech of one who has gone outside the True Idea and the good Dhamma, of one who is a chatterer, of one who is a talker of the battle of the Bharatas, of the carrying off of Sita.

original: hitabuddhiyāvā upāyadīpakaṃ kiñci atthadhammavinayapadaṃ natthi. Samphaṃ palapantipakārena
analyzed: hita buddhi yāvā upāya dīpakam kiñci attha dhamma vinaya padam natthi
translated: It is ‘gossip’ because there is no word of the True Idea, the good Dhamma, the Discipline, that illuminates the means in any case, either for welfare here and now or for welfare in the life to come.🔽It is ‘gossip’ because they talk by way of the opposite of that.

original: kathayanti etenāti sapphappalāpo. Tattha parassavisaṃ vādanapurekkhārena visaṃ vādaka
analyzed: kathayanti etena ati sappha ppalāpaḥ tattha parassa visam vādana purekkhārena visam
translated: It is ‘misusing speech’ because it is that by means of which one misuses speech.

original: kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā akusalacetanā musāvādo. So parassa atthabhañjanakova kammapathabhedo.
analyzed: kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā akusala cetanā musāvādaḥ so parassa attha bhañjanakaḥ uva kamma patha bhedo
translated: False speech is unwholesome volition originating in bodily and verbal effort. It is a breach of the path of action in the way already stated.

original: Itaro kammameva. Ettha ca kamma pathoti paṭisandhijanakānaṃ kammānaṃ uṭṭhānamukhamaggo
analyzed: itaro kammam eva ettha ca kamma patho ti paṭisandhi janakānam kammānam uṭṭhāna mukha maggo
translated: The other is just action. And here the path of action is said to be the door of the origin of the kamma that generates rebirth-linking.

original: vuccati. Yathā hi rajānaṃ uṭṭhānapadeso rajapathoti vuccati. Tathā loke sandissamānesu
analyzed: vuccati yathā hi rajānam uṭṭhāna padeso raja pathaḥ ti vuccati tathā loke sandissamānesu
translated: For just as the place where a king arises is called “the royal path,” so too, of the bodily, verbal, and mental intimation of beings that is seen in the world,🔽the kinds of intimation by which kamma that generates rebirth-linking arises

original: sattānaṃ kāyavacīcittābhisaṅkharaṇakiccesuyehi kiccehi paṭisandhijanakāni kammāni🔽uṭṭhahanti. Yesuvā kiccesu tāni uṭṭhahanti pavattanti. Tāni kāyavacīcittā bhisaṅkharaṇakiccāni
analyzed: sattānam kāya vacī citta abhisaṅkharaṇa kiccesuyehi kiccehi paṭisandhi janakāni kammāni  uṭṭhahanti yesu vā kiccesu tāni uṭṭhahanti pavattanti tāni kāya vacī citta abhisaṅkharaṇa kiccāni
translated: and by which it occurs, that is, the bodily, verbal, and mental intimation,

original: paṭisandhijanakānaṃ kammānaṃ uṭṭhānamukhamaggattā kammapathoti vuccanti. Katamāni
analyzed: paṭisandhi janakānam kammānam uṭṭhāna mukha magga ttā kamma patho ti vuccanti katamāni
translated: is called the path of action because it is the door of origin of kamma that generates rebirth-linking. But what are they?

original: pana tānīti. Aṅgasampannāni akusalesu pāṇaghāta kiccādīni kusalesu tabbiramaṇakiccādīni
analyzed: pana tāni iti aṅga sampannāni akusalesu pāṇa ghāta kicca ādīni kusalesu tad viramaṇa kicca ādīni
translated: They are the kinds of action such as killing living beings, etc., in the case of unwholesome , and such as abstaining from killing living beings, etc., in the case of wholesome .

original: dasavidhāni kiccānīti. Kammāniyeva sugatiduggatīnaṃ taduppajjanakasukhadukkhānañca
analyzed: dasavidhāni kiccāni iti sugati duggatīnam tad uppajjanaka sukha dukkhānam ca
translated: “Ten kinds of business” : only the legal procedures, for the good and bad destinations and the happiness and suffering that arise from them are🔽

original: pathabhūtattā kammapathonāmātipi vadanti.
analyzed: vadanti
translated: “Ten kinds of actions”: these are called “courses of kamma” because they are the path to good and bad destinations and to the happiness and suffering that arise there.

original: Parassa bhedapurekkhārena bhedakakāyagacīpayogasamuṭṭhā pikā saṃkiliṭṭhacetanā pisuṇāvācā.🔽Sāpi pare bhinneyeva kammapathabhedo. Abhinne kammameva. Parassa mammacchedakakāya🔽vacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā duṭṭhacetanā pharusavācā. Etthaca maranti sattā, maraṇamattaṃvā🔽dukkhaṃ nigacchanti etasmiṃ ghaṭṭiyamāneti mammaṃ. Duṭṭhavaṇo. Mammaṃ chindati bhindati
analyzed: parassa bheda purekkhārena bhedaka kāya gacī payoga samuṭṭhā saṃkiliṭṭha cetanā pisuṇā vācā  sā api pare bhinneya iva kamma patha bhedaḥ abhinne kammam eva parassa  vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā duṭṭha cetanā pharusa vācā ettha ca maranti sattāḥ maraṇam attam vā  dukkham nigacchanti etasmin ghaṭṭiyamānā iti mammam duṭṭhavaṇaḥ mammam chindati bhindati
translated: “Malicious speech” is a corrupt volition originating in the body, speech, and thought of one bent on dividing others.

original: ghaṭṭetīti mammacchedako. Vaṇaghaṭṭanapayogo. Idha pana mammaṃviyāti mammaṃ. Jātiādīsu🔽dasasu akkosavatthūsu yaṃkiñci. Mammacchedakoti jātiādīsu ghaṭṭana vasena pavatto
analyzed: ghaṭṭeti iti mamma chedakaḥ vaṇa ghaṭṭana payogaḥ idha pana mammam viyāti mammam jāti ādīsu 🔽dasasu akkosa vatthūsu yaṃkiñci jāti ādīsu ghaṭṭana vasena pavattaḥ
translated: This too is a course of kamma only when it has succeeded in dividing others; when it fails, it is merely kamma. “Harsh speech” is a corrupt volition originating in the body and speech of one bent on wounding another’s feelings. Here “wounding” means that beings die or experience suffering. “Harsh” means a wounding utterance. “Wounding” is the act of wounding by speech. But here “wounding” is a mere figure of speech. “Harsh speech” is any one of the ten grounds for accusation such as “You are of such and such a caste,” etc. “Wounding” is the act of wounding by speech.🔽“Gossip” is a volition originating in the body, speech, and thought of one bent on prattling.

original: pharusa kāyavacī payogo. Aya mattho sīlakkhandha ṭīkā vasena veditabbo. Athavā. Mamāyatīti
analyzed: pharusa kāyavacī payogaḥ aya mattho sīlakkhandha ṭīkā vasena veditabbaḥ athavā mamāyati iti
translated: and the bodily and verbal acts of speaking harshly. This is the meaning to be understood by the method of the commentary on the virtue chapter.

original: mamo. Mitto. Mamassa bhāvo mammaṃ. Mettācittaṃ. Mammaṃ chindatīti mammacchedako.
analyzed: mamaḥ mittaḥ mamassa bhāvaḥ mammam mettā cittam mammam chindati iti mamma chedakaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, mamāyati = mammo. Mitto = friend. The state of mammo is mammaṃ. Mettācittaṃ = a loving mind. Mammaṃ chindatīti = mammacchedako.

original: Ayaṃpi akkositabbassa sammukhāeva kammapathabhedoti keci. Parammukhāpīti apare. Yathā🔽pana paraṃ akkositvā khamāpentassa khamāpanakammaṃ parassa dūre ṭhitassapi matassapi
analyzed: ayam pi akkositabbassa sammukhā eva kamma patha bhedo ti keci parammukhā api iti apare yathā  pana param akkositvā khamāpentassa khamāpana kammam parassa dūre ṭhitassa api matassa api
translated: Some say that this is a breach of the training rule only when the person who is to be abused is present. Others say it is also when he is absent.

original: sampajjati. Evaṃ akkosanakammaṃpīti dīghamajjhimaṭīkākārā icchanti. Akkosādhippāyena🔽caṇḍā mahiṃsī taṃ anubandhatūtivā corā taṃ khaṇḍā khaṇḍikaṃ karontūtivā muddhā te🔽phalatu sattadhātivā evamādinā nayena paraṃ abhisapantassapi kammapathabhedo hotiyevātica vadanti.
analyzed: sampajjati evam akkosana kammaṃpi iti dīgha majjhima ṭīkākārāḥ icchanti akkosa adhippāyena  caṇḍā mahiṃsī tam corā tam khaṇḍā khaṇḍikam karontu utivā muddhā te  phalatu evamādinā nayena param abhisapantassa api kamma patha bhedaḥ vadanti
translated: But the commentators on the Digha and Majjhima Nikāyas maintain that just as the act of asking forgiveness succeeds when one asks another’s forgiveness even though he is far away or dead, so too the act of abusing succeeds.

original: Anatthaviññāpana kāyavacīpayoga samuṭṭhāpikā pāpacetanā samphappalāpo. Sopi bhāratayuddha
analyzed: samuṭṭhāpikā pāpa cetanā samphappalāpaḥ saḥ api bhārata yuddha
translated: And they say that there is also a breach of the training rule when one curses another by such expressions as “May a fierce tigress follow you” or “May thieves cut you to pieces” or “May your head split into seven” when one is motivated by the wish to abuse.

original: sītāharaṇādikesu paṭibhāṇacittesu vācāvatthumattesueva kammapathabhedo. Socakho pare
analyzed: sītā haraṇa ādikesu paṭibhāṇa cittesu kamma patha bhedo pare
translated: Or in the case of the speech of the mind-reading, such as the speech of the demon who carried off Sīhā, there is a division of the course of kamma by the mere words. He who is angry

original: taṃ anatthaṃ saccato gaṇhanteyeva. Agaṇhante pana kammameva. Tathā rājakathādīsu
analyzed: tam anattham saccataḥ gaṇhanteyeva a gaṇhante pana kammam eva tathā rāja kathā ādīsu
translated: takes that harm as true, but if he does not take it as true, then there is only kamma. So too in the case of🔽the thirty-two kinds of animal talk such as talk about kings.

original: dvattiṃsa tiracchāna kathāpabhedesupi kammameva. Tañca kho tadassādavasena kathentasseva.
analyzed: kammam eva tat ca kho tad assāda vasena kathentassa iva
translated: But that is only kamma in the case of one who talks about it for the sake of the pleasure of it.

original: Atthadhammavinayanissitaṃ katvā kathentassa pana sabbaṃpi satthakameva hotīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: attha dhamma vinaya nissitam katvā kathentassa pana sabbam pi satthakam eva hoti iti veditabbam
translated: But it should be understood that all talk about the True Idea, the True Idea and Discipline, and the True Idea and the True Object is the True Object.

original: Vacīkammanti ettha vacīti vācāyeva. Sā catubbidhā saddavācā virativācā cetanāvācā🔽copanavācāti. Idha pana saddasahitā vacīviññattisaṅkhātā copana vācā adhippetāti
analyzed: vacīkammanti ettha vacī iti vācāya iva sā catubbidhā sadda vācā virati vācā cetanā vācā  copana vācā ti idha pana sadda sahitā vacī viññatti saṅkhātā vācā adhippetā ati
translated: Speech as a Course of Kamma: here speech is just the voice. It is fourfold as sound-speech, abstinence-speech, volition-speech,🔽and prompting-speech. But here prompting-speech, which is called ‘intimation by the voice’, is intended.

original: vuttaṃ vacīviññattisaṅkhāteti. Copanavācā hi kadāci vācaṅgena attano adhippāyaṃ parassa
analyzed: vuttam vacī viññatti saṅkhātā iti copana vācā hi kadāci vācaṅgena attanaḥ adhippāyam parassa
translated: That is why it is said ‘called “intimation by the voice” ’. For prompting-speech sometimes causes one’s own intention to be understood by another through the voice,

original: viññāpanatthāyapi karīyatīti vacīviññattīti vuccatīti. Sāyevaca kammānaṃ pavatti
analyzed: viññāpana tthāya api karīyati iti vacīviññattī iti vuccati iti sāyeva ca kammānam pavatti
translated: and so it is called ‘intimation by the voice’. That is the occurrence of kamma as a course of kamma.

original: mukhattā dvāranti vacīdvāraṃ. Tāya hi taṃtaṃvacīpayogakiccena pavattamānāya eva visaṃvādanādikiccasiddhito
analyzed: vacī dvāram tāya hi taṃ taṃ vacī payoga kiccena pavattamānāya eva visaṃvādana ādi kicca siddhito
translated: Because the act of deceiving, etc., is accomplished by the mere occurrence of the act of the respective bodily or verbal action,

original: taṃsamuṭṭhāpakassa cetanādhammassa āyūhanakriyānibbattica vacīkammanāmalābhoca hotīti.
analyzed: tad samuṭṭhāpakassa cetanā dhammassa āyūhana kriyā nibbatti ca vacī kamma nāma lābhaḥ ca hoti iti
translated: the bodily or verbal action that is the volition that gives rise to it is also called the “act of accumulation” and the “act of non-restraint.”

original: Tasmiṃ vacīdvāre. Yamettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ kāyakamme vuttamevāti. [Vacīkammaṃ]
analyzed: tasmin vacī dvāre yam ettha vattabbam tam kāya kamme vuttam eva ati vacī kammam
translated: In regard to that bodily or verbal action, what is to be said has already been said in the case of bodily action.

original: 150. Abhijjhāyanti assādamatte aṭṭhatvā parabhaṇḍassa attano pariṇāmanavasena atirekataraṃ🔽jhāyanti nijjhāyanti etāyāti abhijjhā. Byāpādenti parasatte vināsaṃ āpanne katvā
analyzed: abhijjhāyanti assāda matte a ṭhatvā parabhaṇḍassa attano pariṇāmana vasena atirekataram  jhāyanti nijjhāyanti abhijjhāḥ byāpādenti para satte vināsam āpanne katvā
translated: Covetousness: not being satisfied with one’s own possessions, one covets the goods of others, thinking, “How nice it would be if they were mine!”🔽Ill will: thinking, “May these beings be destroyed, perish, be annihilated, or not exist!”

original: cintenti etenāti byāpādo. Micchādiṭṭhīti ettha micchāti viparītatthe nipāto. Atthidinnantiādinayapavattaṃ
analyzed: cintenti etena ati byāpādaḥ micchādiṭṭhī iti ettha micchā ati viparīta atthe nipātaḥ
translated: Wrong view: micchā is a negative prefix; diṭṭhi is a view that occurs in the way beginning, “There is nothing given,”

original: sabbaṃ sappurisa maggaṃ sappurisapaññattaṃ bhinditvā natthi dinnantiādinayena tabbiparī
analyzed: sabbam sappurisa maggam sappurisa paññattam bhinditvā natthi dinna nti ādi nayena tad biparī
translated: contradicting all the right views of good people and the right views proclaimed by the Noble Ones. It occurs in the way beginning, “There is nothing given.”

original: tato passanti etāyāti micchādiṭṭhi. Tattha parasantakaṃ disvā kevalaṃ assādanābhinandanarajjanamattesu
analyzed: tatas passanti etāya ati micchādiṭṭhi tattha para santakam disvā kevalam assādana abhinandana rajjana mattesu
translated: Then they see it as ‘mine’ : this is wrong view. Herein, when someone sees what belongs to another and does not just enjoy it with enjoyment consisting in lust, etc.,

original: aṭṭhatvā ahovata idaṃ mamassāti evaṃ attano katvā cittena pariṇāmentasseva abhijjhākammapathabhedo🔽hoti. Parasantakabhāveyeva thapetvā lābhāvatime. Ye īdisaṃ paribhuñjanti. Ahovatāhaṃpi
analyzed: a ṭhatvā ahovata idam mama assa ati evam katvā cittena pariṇāmentassa iva abhijjhā kamma patha bhedaḥ  ye īdisam paribhuñjanti
translated: but instead thinks, “Oh, that this might be mine!” and appropriates it mentally, then there is the course of kamma consisting in covetousness.🔽But when he thinks, “How fortunate that those who enjoy such things as this get them by way of inheritance or by begging or by theft!” and he enjoys it, then there is the course of kamma consisting in mere approval.

original: tāvakālikaṃ paribhuñjeyyaṃ. Yācitvāvā kiṇitvāvā attano kareyyaṃ. Aññaṃvā īdisaṃ labheyyanti🔽evaṃ assādentassa kammameva. Vuttañhetaṃ aṭṭhakathāsu parabhaṇḍavatthuke hi lobhe
analyzed: tāvakālikam paribhuñjeyyam yācitvā vā kiṇitvā vā attano kareyyam aññam vā īdisam labheyyanti  evam assādentassa kammam eva vuttam ha etam aṭṭhakathāsu parabhaṇḍa vatthuke hi lobhe
translated: When he thinks, “Oh, that I might enjoy such things as this for a time! I would make it mine by way of inheritance or by begging or by theft, or I would get something else like it,” and he enjoys it, then there is the course of kamma consisting in mere approval.

original: uppannepi na tāva kammapathabhedo hoti. Yāva na ahovata idaṃ mamassāti attano pariṇāmetīti.
analyzed: uppanne pi na tāva kamma patha bhedaḥ hoti yāva na ahovataḥ idam mamassa ati attano pariṇāmeti iti
translated: For this is said in the commentaries: “When greed arises in regard to what belongs to another, there is no course of kamma consisting in covetousness as long as one does not appropriate it mentally by thinking, ‘Oh, that this might be mine!’”

original: Antamaso ḍaṃsamakasādikepi ārabbha ime nassantu vinassantu. Ahovatime nasseyyuṃ vinasseyyuṃ.
analyzed: antamasaḥ ḍaṃsama kasādike pi ārabbha ime nassantu vinassantu ahovatime nasseyyum vinasseyyum
translated: When he thinks, “May these beings be destroyed and exterminated in every way! Oh, that they might be destroyed and exterminated! May they perish and be no more! May they disappear and not be seen!”

original: Avaḍḍhitāvā bhaveyyuṃ ciraṃvā natiṭṭheyyuṃ. Kadāvā nassanti vinassantīti evaṃ para🔽sattassa khandhajīvavināsaṃ cintentasseva byāpādo. Itaro kammameva. Vuttañhetaṃ parasattavatthuke
analyzed: bhaveyyum ciram vā natiṭṭheyyum kadāvā nassanti vinassanti iti evam para  sattassa khandha jīva vināsam cintentassa iva byāpādaḥ itaro kammam eva vuttam ha etam para satta vatthuke
translated: Or they would not be born at all, or they would not die at all. When would they be lost, when would they perish? ’ So he thinks only of the destruction of the other being’s aggregates and life, and this is ill will. The other is action. For this is said:

original: hi kodhe uppannepi na tāva kammapathabhedo hoti. Yāva na ahovatāyaṃ ucchijjeyya vināseyyāti
analyzed: hi kodhe uppanne pi na tāva kamma patha bhedaḥ hoti yāva na ucchijjeyya vināseyya ati
translated: ‘When anger arises in him about a living being, there is no breach of the path of action until he thinks “I will kill him, I will destroy him” about his destruction. ’

original: tassa vināsaṃ cintetīti. Kammassavā kammavipākassavā sabbaso paṭibāhikā natthikāhe
analyzed: tassa vināsam cinteti iti kamma ssavā kamma vipāka ssavā sabbaso paṭibāhikā
translated: So he is called one who has the view of action and the view of the result of action, and he is called one who denies, one who is opposed to, one who rejects, one who does not accept, one who does not believe in.

original: tukākriyavasena tividhā niyata micchādiṭṭhieva kammapathabhedo. Dasavatthukamicchādiṭṭhi🔽pana natthikadiṭṭhipabhedāeva. Sabbaññudesanaṃ paṭibāhitvā pavattā ariṭṭhakaṇṭakādīnaṃ
analyzed: tukā kriya vasena tividhā kamma patha bhedaḥ dasa vatthuka micchādiṭṭhi  pana natthika diṭṭhi pabhedā eva sabbaññu desanam paṭibāhitvā pavattā ariṭṭha kaṇṭaka ādīnam
translated: The view that is definitely wrong is threefold according to whether it denies action, the result of action, or both. The wrong view that has ten bases is only the view that denies.🔽But the view of individuality that has twenty bases and the sixty-two views are only action.

original: diṭṭhiyopi kammapathāevāti vadanti. Vīsativatthukā sakkāyadiṭṭhivā dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhigatānivākammamevāti.
analyzed: diṭṭhiyaḥ pi kamma pathā evā ti vadanti vīsati vatthukā sakkāyadiṭṭhi vā dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi gatāni iva akammam evā ti
translated: They say that the views of Ariṭṭha, Kaḷāramaṭṭaka, and so on, are paths of action because they occur denying the teaching of the Omniscient One.

original: Niyatāti cettha yathā tīṇi lakkhaṇāni yattakaṃ passitvā saddhādhimokkhena sanniṭṭhānaṃ🔽gacchantassa cittuppādo attano anantaraṃ phaladānaniyamena niyato hoti. Tattakaṃ
analyzed: niyatā ati ca ittha yathā tīṇi lakkhaṇāni yattakam passitvā saddhā adhimokkhena sanniṭṭhānam  gacchantassa cittuppādaḥ attanaḥ anantaram phala dāna niyamena niyataḥ hoti tattakam
translated: As to ‘definite’: just as, when one who has gone forth into the Divine Life sees as much as the three characteristics and comes to a decision by faith-consent,

original: passanto kusalesu dhammesu niyāmaṃ okkamatīti vutto. Tathādiṭṭhiṭṭhā nāni kāraṇa
analyzed: passantaḥ kusalesu dhammesu niyāmam okkamati iti vuttaḥ
translated: then the consciousness that arises is definite in the sense of being certain to give its fruit next to itself; and when he sees that much he is said to have ‘entered upon the certainty in profitable ideas’ .

original: paṭirūpakāni yattakaṃ passitvā micchādhimokkhena sanniṭṭhānaṃ gacchantassa cittuppādocutianantarephaladānaniyamena🔽niyato hoti. Tattakaṃ passitvā sanniṭṭhānaṃ gacchanto akusalesu dhammesu niyāmaṃ🔽okkamati, atekicchonāma hoti. Tathā pana apassitvā kevalaṃ micchādhimokkhamattena
analyzed: paṭirūpakāni yattakam passitvā micchādhimokkhena sanniṭṭhānam gacchantassa cittuppāda ucuti anantare phala dāna niyamena  niyataḥ hoti tattakam passitvā sanniṭṭhānam gacchantaḥ akusalesu dhammesu niyāmam  okkamati atekiccho nāma hoti tathā pana a passitvā kevalam micchā adhimokkha mattena
translated: So too, when one who has gone forth into the Divine Life sees as much as the reasons that are counterfeits of the standpoints of views and comes to a decision by wrong consent,🔽then the consciousness that arises is definite in the sense of being certain to give its fruit next to the cessation of the life-continuum ;🔽and when he sees that much and comes to a decision, he is said to have ‘entered upon the certainty in unprofitable ideas’ .

original: evameva bhavissatīti sanniṭṭhānaṃ gantvā sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ samayaṃ paggaṇhitvā ṭhito
analyzed: evam eva bhavissati iti sanniṭṭhānam gantvā sakam ācariyakam samayam paggaṇhitvā ṭhitaḥ
translated: But when he does not see that much but comes to a decision by mere wrong consent, thinking ‘ It must be like this ‘, and he stands by his own teacher’s doctrine,

original: atekicchonāma nahoti. Kasmā, phaladāna niyamābhāvāti. Ayañca attho micchattattikena
analyzed: atekicchonāma kasmā ayam ca atthaḥ micchattattikena
translated: he is not said to be incurable. Why? Because there is no certainty of his giving fruit. And this meaning is stated in the Micchattavagga:

original: dīpetabbo. Tattha hi phaladāna niyamavaseneva ubhinnaṃpi sammattamicchattadhammānaṃ
analyzed: dīpetabbo tattha hi phala dāna niyama vasena iva ubhinnam pi sammatta micchatta dhammānam
translated: For in the Paṭṭhāna the obtaining of the name “determinate” is said of both the profitable and the unprofitable by way of the limitation of giving fruit.

original: niyatasaññāpaṭilābho aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttoti. Suttantasaṃvaṇṇanāsu pana gahaṇaniyamavasenāpi🔽tassā niyatabhāvo vuttoti.
analyzed: niyata saññā paṭilābho aṭṭhakathā ayam vutto ti suttanta saṃvaṇṇanāsu pana gahaṇa niyama vasena api  tassā niyata bhāvo vutto ti
translated: But in the commentaries on the suttas the fact that it is determinate is said by way of the limitation of taking effect.

original: Aññatrāpiviññattiyāti viññattidvayena vināpi. Viññattidvayaṃ asamuṭṭhāpetvāpīti attho.🔽Apisaddena pana viññattidvayena sahāpīti dasseti. Imāni hi tīṇi kammāni yadā kāyaṅgavā
analyzed: aññatra api viññattiyā ti viññatti dvayena vinā api viññatti dvayam a samuṭṭhāpetvā api iti attho  api saddena pana viññatti dvayena saha api iti dasseti imāni hi tīṇi kammāni yadā
translated: “And also otherwise than by intimation”: without the two kinds of intimation. The meaning is: without arousing the two kinds of intimation.

original: caṅgāni acopetvā manasmiṃeva sijjhanti. Tadāviññattiyā vināva pavattanti. Yadā pana
analyzed: caṅgāni a ca upetvā manasmin eva sijjhanti tadā viññattiyā vinā ava pavattanti yadā pana
translated: But by the word “also” he shows that it occurs with the two kinds of intimation too. For these three kinds of kamma occur without intimation when they succeed in the mind only without involving the bodily or verbal formation.

original: tāni copetvā kāyavacīdvāresu sijjhanti, tadā viññattiyā saheva pavattantīti. Etena
analyzed: tāni ca upetvā kāya vacī dvāresu sijjhanti tadā viññattiyā saha iva pavattanti iti etena
translated: But when they succeed in the doors of body and speech involving those formations, then they occur with intimation.🔽By this he shows that they occur in the three doors.

original: imesaṃ tīsupi dvāresu pavattiṃ dīpeti. Evaṃsantepi imāni manodvāreeva bahulaṃ pavattanti.
analyzed: imesam tīsu pi dvāresu pavattim dīpeti evam sante pi imāni manaḥ dvāre eva bahulam pavattanti
translated: But even so, they occur mostly in the mind door.

original: Kāyavacīdvāresu pana appakameva pavattantīti vuttaṃ manasmiṃyevabāhullavuttitoti.
analyzed: kāya vacī dvāresu pana appakam eva pavattanti iti vuttam
translated: But in the door of the body and in the door of speech they occur only a little. That is why it is said, “In the mind they occur abundantly.”

original: Tattha manasmiṃ yevāti kusalā kusalajavanacittasaṅkhāte manodvāreeva. Etena purimesupi🔽kāyadvāre vacīdvāreti padesu evasaddasambhavo dīpito hoti. Evañhi sati tatthapi dvārena🔽kammavavatthānaṃ suṭṭhutaraṃ upapannaṃ hotīti. Itarathā upalakkhaṇādivasena atthantarapasaṅgopi
analyzed: tattha manasmim kusalā kusala javana citta saṅkhāte manaḥ dvāre eva etena purimesu pi  kāya dvāre vacī dvāra iti padesu eva sadda sambhavaḥ dīpitaḥ hoti evam hi sati tattha api dvārena  kamma vavatthānam suṭṭhutaram upapannam hoti iti itarathā upalakkhaṇa ādi vasena attha antara pasaṅgaḥ api
translated: Herein, in the mind itself means in the mind door itself, which is called the mind door of profitable and unprofitable impulsions. By this it is shown that the word itself in the passages about the door of the body and the door of speech is to be construed thus:🔽in the body itself, in the speech itself. For in that case the definition of the kinds of kamma by means of the doors is more exact. Otherwise, there would be the possibility of taking the meaning of the words in some other way, as by way of a distinguishing mark, and so on.

original: siyāti. Apica, idha evasaddena ayaṃpi visesattho dīpito hoti. Pāṇavadhādīsu hi vadhāmi🔽naṃ avaharāmi na ntiādinā saṃvidhānākārena pavattā cetayitakriyāeva padhānaṃ hoti.
analyzed: siyā iti api ca idha eva saddena ayam pi visesa atthaḥ dīpitaḥ hoti pāṇa vadha ādīsu hi vadhāmi  avaharāmi na nti ādinā saṃvidhāna ākārena pavattā cetayita kriyā eva padhānam
translated: Besides, by the word itself here the following distinction in meaning is shown. For in the case of killing breathing things, etc., the volition that occurs in the mode of determining “I shall kill” or “I shall steal,” etc., is the principal factor.

original: Sāca kāyavacīpayogehi vinā nasijjhati. Tasmā tesu kāya vacī payogā kammasiddhiyā🔽ekaṃ aṅgaṃ honti. Taṃ sahajātāca abhijjhādayo cetanāpakkhikāeva hutvā abbohārikattaṃ
analyzed: sā ca kāya vacī payogehi vinā tasmā tesu kāya vacī payogā kamma siddhiyā 🔽ekam aṅgam honti tam sahajātāḥ ca abhijjhā ādayo cetanā pakkhikāḥ eva hutvā abbohārika ttam
translated: And that cannot be accomplished without the bodily and verbal effort. Therefore, in the case of those, the bodily and verbal effort are a single factor for the accomplishment of the kamma. And the greed, etc., associated with that volition become the non-renunciation of the kamma.

original: gacchanti. Parabhaṇḍā bhijjhāyanādīsu pana abhijjhādīnaṃ attapadhānānaṃ kāyavacīdvāresu🔽pavattānaṃpi kāya vacīpayogākammasiddhiyā aṅgameva nahonti. Tathā cintāpavatti matteneva
analyzed: gacchanti parabhaṇḍāḥ bhijjhāyana ādīsu pana abhijjha ādīnam atta padhānānam kāya vacī dvāresu  aṅgam eva na honti tathā cintā pavatti mattena iva
translated: But in the case of coveting another’s goods, etc., the greed, etc., that are the roots of the unprofitable are only factors in the sense of being causes for the success of the bodily and verbal efforts that occur in the bodily and verbal doors.🔽And likewise in the case of the occurrence of thinking, they are only factors in the sense of being causes for the success of the kamma there.

original: tattha kammasiddhito. Iti imesu kammesu kāya vacīdvārānaṃ sabbenasabbaṃ aṅgabhāvapaṭikkhipanatthaṃ🔽manasmiṃ yevāti eva gahaṇaṃ idheva katanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tesu pana dvāresu pavattimatta
analyzed: tattha kamma siddhitaḥ iti imesu kammesu kāya vacī dvārānam sabbena sabbam aṅga bhāva paṭikkhipana attham  eva gahaṇam idha iva katam ti daṭṭhabbam tesu pana dvāresu
translated: So the words “in the mind itself” should be regarded as stated here in order to exclude the bodily and verbal doors altogether from all these kinds of kamma.

original: sabbhāvaṃ sandhāya bāhullasaddopi idha gahitoti.
analyzed: sabbhāvam sandhāya bāhulla saddaḥ api idha gahitaḥ iti
translated: And the word “abundantly” is included here in the sense of occurrence in the doors.

original: [156] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yam pana
translated: But what is said in the Vibhaṅga, namely,

original: “Viññattisamuṭṭhāpaka cittasampayuttācettha abhijjhādayo cetanāpakkhikāva hontīti” vuttaṃ. Taṃ idha na yujjati.
analyzed: viññatti samuṭṭhāpaka citta sampayuttāḥ ca ittha abhijjhā ādayo cetanā pakkhikāḥ va honti iti vuttam tat idha na yujjati
translated: “Herein, the greed, etc., that are conascent with the consciousness that originates the intimation are only on the side of volition” , is not applicable here.

original: Na hi viññattisamuṭṭhāpakacittasampayuttāpi kevalaṃ manokamma kiccavisesena pavattamānā abhijjhādayo cetanāpakkhikā honti. Cetanāeva pana abhijjhādipakkhikā hotīti. [Manokammaṃ]
analyzed: na hi viññatti samuṭṭhāpaka citta sampayuttā api kevalam manaḥ kamma kicca visesena pavattamānāḥ abhijjhā ādayaḥ cetanā pakkhikāḥ honti cetanā eva pana abhijjhā ādi pakkhikā hoti iti manaḥ kammam
translated: For covetousness, ill will, and wrong view, though they occur in association with the consciousnesses that originate intimation, are not on the side of volition merely by virtue of the function of mental action. It is only volition that is on the side of covetousness, etc.;🔽but mental action is on the side of all ten courses of action.

original: 151. Ettha ca dasannaṃpi imesaṃ kammapathānaṃ pubbāparacetanāyo paṭisandhiākaḍḍhane
analyzed: ettha ca dasannam api imesam kammapathānam pubba apara cetanāyo paṭisandhi ākaḍḍhane
translated: And here the earlier and later volitions of these ten courses of action, which are included in rebirth-linking,

original: anekantikapakkhaṃ gatāti paṭisambhidā maggaṭīkāyaṃ vuttā. Tasmā tāpi imaṃ sattaṃ🔽māressāmi imaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ adinnaṃ ādiyissāmītiādinā nayena ādito paṭṭhāya pavattā balavapaccaye
analyzed: aneka antika pakkham gatā ti paṭisambhidā magga ṭīkāyam vuttā tasmā imam sattam  māressāmi imam bhaṇḍam adinnam ādiyissāmi itiādinā nayena āditaḥ paṭṭhāya pavattā balava paccaye
translated: are said in the Paṭisambhidā and the Maggaṭṭhakattha to be “on the side of many” .

original: laddhā paṭisandhiṃ ākaḍḍhanti. Aladdhā nākaḍḍhantīti yuttā. Yāni pana kusalākusalāni
analyzed: laddhā paṭisandhim ākaḍḍhanti aladdhā na ākaḍḍhanti iti yuttāḥ yāni pana kusala akusalāni
translated: Therefore it is proper to say that they include rebirth-linking when they get a powerful condition, and they do not include rebirth-linking when they do not get a powerful condition.

original: kammapathabhedaṃ appattāni honti. Tāni kāyadvāre dissamānāni kāyakammānināma honti.
analyzed: kamma patha bhedam appattāni honti tāni kāya dvāre dissamānāni honti
translated: But those that are neither profitable nor unprofitable and do not reach the grade of a course of action are called bodily action when they occur in the body door,

original: Vacīdvāre dissamānāni vacīkammānināma. Suddhe manodvāre dissamānāni manokammānināmāti
analyzed: vacī dvāre dissamānāni vacī kammānināma suddhe manaḥ dvāre dissamānāni manaḥ kammānināma ati
translated: and they are called verbal action when they occur in the speech door, and they are called mental action when they occur in the mind door only.

original: veditabbānīti. Dosamūlenāti dosasaṅkhātamūlena dosamūlakacittenāti dvidhā attho.
analyzed: veditabbāni iti dosa mūlena ati dosa saṅkhāta mūlena dosa mūlaka cittena ati dvidhā atthaḥ
translated: should be known. ‘With a root in hate’: with a root called ‘hate’. ‘With a mind rooted in hate’: the meaning is twofold.

original: Tattha purimo byāpādavajjehi dvīhi yujjati, pacchimo tīhipi. Lobhamūlenāti ettha🔽esanayo. Tatthāpiti purimo abhijjhāvajjehi dvīhi yujjati. Pacchimo tīhīti. Dvīhi
analyzed: tattha purimaḥ byāpāda vajjehi dvīhi yujjati pacchimaḥ lobha mūlena ati ettha  tattha ap iti purimaḥ abhijjhā vajjehi dvīhi pacchimaḥ tīhi iti dvīhi
translated: Herein, the first is applicable to the two beginning with ‘ill will’, while the second is applicable to all three. ‘With a root in greed’:🔽‘With a root in greed’ is the second. ‘With a root in greed’:

original: mūlehīti kadāci dosamūlena kadāci lobhamūlenāti evaṃ dvīhi mūlehi sambhavanti. Moho
analyzed: mūlehi iti kadācid dosa mūlena kadācid lobha mūlena ati evam dvīhi mūlehi sambhavanti mohaḥ
translated: ‘With two roots’: sometimes with a root in hate and sometimes with a root in greed. But delusion,

original: pana sabbasādhāraṇattā visesakaro na hotīti idha na gahito.
analyzed: pana sabba sādhāraṇa ttā visesa karaḥ na hoti iti idha na gahito
translated: being common to all, does not distinguish them, so it is not included here.

original: [157] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yam pana
translated: But in the Vibhanga,

original: “Nidhipāṭhakapamāṇato duṭṭhaniggahatthaṃ parasantakaṃ harantānaṃ rājūnaṃ brāhmaṇānañca
analyzed: nidhi pāṭhaka pamāṇataḥ duṭṭha niggahattham para santakam harantānam rājūnam brāhmaṇānam ca
translated: ‘From the time of the treasure-discoverers’ is said. ‘When kings and brahmans take what is not given for the purpose of suppressing the wicked,

original: sabbamidaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ rājūhi dinnaṃ. Tesaṃ pana sabbadubbalabhāvena aññe bhuñjanti.
analyzed: sabbam idam brāhmaṇānam rājūhi dinnam tesam pana sabba dubbala bhāvena aññe bhuñjanti
translated: all this is given to the brahmans by the kings. But others enjoy it because of the extreme poverty of the brahmans.🔽The brahmans enjoy only what is their own’—saying this, they take what is not given,

original: Attasantakameva brāhmaṇā paribhuñjantīti evamādīni vatvā sakasaññāya eva yaṃkiñci
analyzed: atta santakam eva brāhmaṇāḥ paribhuñjanti iti evamādīni vatvā saka saññāyaḥ eva yaṃkiñcid
translated: thinking it is their own.

original: harantānaṃ kammaphalasambandhāpavādīnañca mohamūlenā”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ idha na yujjati.
analyzed: harantānam kamma phala sambandha apavādīnam ca moha mūlena ati vuttam tam idha na yujjati
translated: and of those who take it away and deny the connection of action and result, it arises through delusion as its root.” But that is not appropriate here.

original: Sahajātamūlañhi idha adhippetaṃ asādhāraṇabhūtañca. Tesañca tathāharantānaṃ haraṇaṃ
analyzed: sahajāta mūlam hi idha adhippetam asādhāraṇa bhūtam ca tesam ca haraṇam
translated: For what is intended here is the root that is conascent and is the uncommon support, and the taking away of those who take it away in that way

original: haraṇakāle kadācidosamūlena kadāci lobhamūlenāti evaṃ dvīhi mūlehi eva sambhavatīti.🔽Yo pana moho mahāsammatādīnaṃdhammikarājūnaṃ kāle pavattaṃ porāṇaka nidhisatthaṃ
analyzed: haraṇa kāle kadācid dosa mūlena kadācid lobha mūlena ati evam dvīhi mūlehi eva sambhavati iti  yaḥ pana mohaḥ mahāsammata ādīnam dhammika rājūnam kāle pavattam porāṇaka nidhi sattham
translated: occurs by means of two roots, namely, at the time of taking away sometimes through the root of demerit that is non-cognizance, and sometimes through the root of demerit that is greed.🔽But the delusion that arises in righteous kings such as Mahāsammata and so on in the case of ancient treasure troves that are found

original: thapetvā pacchā adhammikānaṃrājūnaṃ kāle pavattesu yebhuyyena adhammikesu dhammasattha
analyzed: thapetvā pacchā adhammikānam rājūnam kāle pavattesu yebhuyyena adhammikesu dhammasattha
translated: in the earth and that are not the property of anyone, and in the case of the treasure troves that are found in the earth in the time of unrighteous kings and that are mostly unrighteous, and in the case of the treasure troves that are called “treasure troves of the righteous king” and “treasure troves of the unrighteous king,”

original: rājasattha saṅkhātesu nidhipāṭhesu dhammikasaññīnaṃ rājūnaṃ uppanno. Yoca rājūnaṃ🔽abhisekakāle dinnaññevasamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃtiṇakaṭṭhodakanti vacanaṃ upādāya sabbamidaṃ
analyzed: rāja sattha saṅkhātesu nidhi pāṭhesu dhammika saññīnam rājūnam uppannaḥ yaḥ ca rājūnam  abhiseka kāle vacanam upādāya sabbam idam
translated: in the case of those that arise in righteous kings who are deluded as to the fact that they are treasure troves, and in the case of those that arise in brahmans who are deluded as to the fact that they are treasure troves,

original: brāhmaṇānaṃ rājūhi dinnanti evaṃ saññīnaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ uppanno. Yoca natthi sukata
analyzed: brāhmaṇānam rājūhi dinnanti evam saññīnam brāhmaṇānam uppannaḥ yaḥ ca natthi
translated: and in the case of those that arise in brahmans who are deluded as to the fact that “All this treasure trove belongs to brahmans because of the statement made by kings at the time of their coronation that ‘Hereafter let all the brahmans take grass, wood, and water from me,’ and because of the fact that all this treasure trove was given to brahmans by kings,”🔽and in the case of those that arise in brahmans who are deluded as to the fact that “There is no such thing as good or bad action, or result of good or bad action, or world beyond this, or any world beyond that, or mother, or father, or Ascetic or Brahman who leads the holy life and is rightly self-awakened. When a person is broken up, at death, he is annihilated, perishes, and does not exist after death, and of those who take it away and deny the connection of action and result, it arises through delusion as its root.”

original: dukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipākoti evaṃ diṭṭhikānaṃ kammaphalasambandhā pavādīnaṃ
analyzed: dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti evam diṭṭhikānam kamma phala sambandhā pavādīnam
translated: “The result of bad actions” : thus the wrong view of those who deny the connection between action and its result

original: uppanno. Sosabbopi upanissayamoho nāma hoti. So idha nādhippeto. Itarathā lobho nidānaṃ
analyzed: uppannaḥ upanissaya mohaḥ nāma hoti saḥ idha na adhippetaḥ itarathā lobhaḥ nidānam
translated: arises. And all of them have the underlying tendency to delusion, which is called the “underlying tendency to delusion.” But that is not intended here. Otherwise, it would follow that greed, hatred, and delusion are the roots of all unwholesome kamma.

original: kammānaṃ samudayāya. Doso nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya. Moho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāyāti
analyzed: kammānam samudayāya dosaḥ nidānam kammānam samudayāya mohaḥ nidānam kammānam samudayāya ati
translated: For it is said: “Greed is the source for the origin of kamma, hatred is the source for the origin of kamma, delusion is the source for the origin of kamma.”🔽Thus all the unwholesome roots of kamma would have to be mentioned here. But this is not done.🔽If it were done, then it would follow that the unwholesome roots of kamma are the source for the origin of kamma and its result.🔽But the unwholesome roots of kamma are the source for the origin of kamma only.🔽Thus it is said: “Greed, hatred, and delusion are the roots of kamma.”🔽 Translation: “duṭṭhullānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko”ti evaṃ kammapaccayā pavattassa diṭṭhigatassa uppannā |

original: vacanato sabbepi akusalakamma pathāti mūlakāeva idha vattabbā siyunti. Evaṃpanettha
analyzed: vacanato sabbe pi akusala kamma pathā ti mūlakāḥ eva idha vattabbā siyun ti evam pana ittha
translated: so pana idha na adhippeto | itarathā hi lobho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāyātiādivacanato sabbampi akusalaṃ kammapathā eva vattabbā siyuṃ |

original: vattabbaṃ siyā, kammesuca kammaphalesuca sañjātakaṅkhānaṃ janānaṃ kaṅkhā pariyuṭṭhāna
analyzed: vattabbam siyā kammesu ca kamma phalesu ca sañjāta kaṅkhānam janānam kaṅkhā pariyuṭṭhāna
translated: evaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ siyā – kammesu ca kammapaccayesu ca sañjātakānkhānaṃ janānaṃ kaṅkhāpariyuṭṭhānacittena

original: cittenasahevatadanurūpāniadinnādānādīni cattārikammāni karontānaṃ tāni kammāni suddhena
analyzed: cittena saha iva tad anurūpāni adinnādāna ādīni cattāri kammāni karontānam tāni kammāni suddhena
translated: anurūpāni adinnādānādīni cattāri kammāni karontānaṃ tāni kammāni suddhena mohamūlena jāyantīti |

original: mohamūlena jāyantīti. Evañhi sati parato vicikicchā cetanāya paṭisandhijanakesu gahaṇaṃpi
analyzed: moha mūlena jāyanti iti evam hi sati paratas vicikicchā cetanāya paṭisandhi janakesu gahaṇam pi
translated: evañhi sati parato vicikicchācetanāya paṭisandhijanakesupi gahaṇaṃ upapannaṃ hotīti |

original: upapannaṃ hotīti. [Akusalakammaṃ].
analyzed: upapannam hoti iti akusala kammaṃ
translated: akusalakammaṃ |

original: 152. Kāmāvacarakusalaṃpi kāyadvāre pavattaṃ kāya kammanti ettha dve pariyāyā veditabbā.
analyzed: kāmāvacara kusalam pi kāya dvāre pavattam kāya kammanti ettha dve pariyāyā veditabbā
translated: 152. Also profitable kamma of the sense sphere that occurs in the body door is bodily action. Herein, two methods of explanation should be understood.

original: Kathaṃ, vakkhamānesu hi puññakriyavatthūsu yaṃkiñci puññakriyavatthuṃ kāyaṅgaṃ copetvā🔽pavattitaṃ kāyakammaṃ nāma. Vācaṅgaṃ copetvā pavattitaṃ vacīkammaṃ nāma. Kāyaṅga
analyzed: katham vakkhamānesu hi puñña kriya vatthūsu yaṃkiñci puñña kriya vatthum kāyaṅgam ca upetvā  pavattitam kāya kammam nāma vācaṅgam ca upetvā pavattitam vacī kammam nāma kāyaṅga
translated: For when the bases for making merit are being spoken of, any base for making merit that occurs in association with a bodily formation is called bodily action,🔽any that occurs in association with a verbal formation is called verbal action,

original: vācaṅgāni acopetvā manodvāreeva pavattitaṃ manokammaṃ nāmāti ayameko pariyāyo. Ayaṃ🔽pana mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āviceva raho ca. Mettaṃ
analyzed: vācaṅgāni manaḥ dvāre eva pavattitam manokammam nāma ati ayam ekaḥ pariyāyaḥ ayam  pana mettam kāya kammam paccupaṭṭhitam hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvicā iva raho ca mettam
translated: and any that occurs in association with a mental formation only, without associating with a bodily or a verbal formation, is called mental action. This is the first method.🔽But the second method is this. “He maintains bodily acts of loving-kindness towards his fellows in the life of purity both openly and by word of mouth,

original: vacīkammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āviceva rahoca. Mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ🔽hoti sabrahmacārīsu āviceva rahocātica. Sabbaṃ kāyakammaṃ ñāṇapubbaṅgamaṃ ñāṇānuparivattaṃ.
analyzed: vacī kammam paccupaṭṭhitam hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvicā iva raho ca mettam manaḥ kammam paccupaṭṭhitam  hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvicā iva raho ca atica sabbam kāya kammam ñāṇa pubbaṅgamam ñāṇa anuparivattam
translated: and he maintains mental acts of loving-kindness towards them both openly and by word of mouth.🔽All his bodily actions are preceded by knowledge and controlled by knowledge,

original: Sabbaṃ vacīkammaṃ ñāṇapubbaṅgamaṃ ñāṇānuparivattaṃ. Sabbaṃ manokammaṃ ñāṇapubbaṅgamaṃ
analyzed: sabbam vacī kammam ñāṇa pubbaṅgamam ñāṇa anuparivattam sabbam manaḥ kammam ñāṇa pubbaṅgamam
translated: all his verbal actions are preceded by knowledge and controlled by knowledge, all his mental actions are preceded by knowledge and controlled by knowledge.

original: ñāṇānuparivattanti ca.🔽Padakkhiṇaṃ kāyakammaṃ, vācākammaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ;
analyzed: ñāṇā anuparivattanti ca  padakkhiṇam kāya kammam vācā kammam padakkhiṇam
translated: and the knowledge that follows it.🔽Right bodily action, right speech,🔽Right mental action, and the rightness in what is excellent.

original: Padakkhiṇaṃ manokammaṃ, paṇīhite padakkhiṇe tica.
analyzed: padakkhiṇam manokammam paṇīhite padakkhiṇe ti ca
translated: This is the meaning in the passages of the texts.

original: Evamādīsu suttapadesu āgato. Apica, aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ sakalāya navakammadvārakathāya
analyzed: evamādīsu sutta padesu āgataḥ api ca aṭṭhasāliniyam sakalāya nava kamma dvāra kathāya
translated: Moreover, in the Eight-Factored Discourse the whole of the explanation of the ninefold action should be illustrated by this meaning.

original: ayamattho dīpetabbo. Tattha hi dānamayaṃpi kāyavacī manokammavasena tidhā vibhattaṃ.🔽Tathā sīlamayaṃ bhāvanāmayañcāti. Yasmiṃ pana dussilye pavattamāne kāyo aparisuddho
analyzed: ayam atthaḥ dīpetabbo tattha hi kāya vacī manaḥ kamma vasena tidhā vibhattam  tathā sīla mayam bhāvanā mayam ca ati yasmin pana dussilye pavattamāne kāyaḥ a parisuddhaḥ
translated: For there, giving is divided into three kinds as bodily action, verbal action, and mental action.🔽So too are virtue and development.🔽But when evil conduct is occurring, the body is impure,🔽and bodily restraint is broken.

original: hoti. Kāyasaṃvaro bhijjati. Yaṃ pana kusalaṃ pavattamānaṃ tadaṅgapahānādivasena taṃ
analyzed: hoti kāya saṃvaraḥ bhijjati yam pana kusalam pavattamānam tad aṅga pahāna ādi vasena tam
translated: But when profitable action is occurring, it is by abandoning that evil conduct by means of abandoning its conditions, etc.,

original: dussilyaṃ pajahitvā kāyadvāraṃ sodhayamānaṃ kāyasaṃvaraṃ pūrayamānaṃ pavattati. Taṃ
analyzed: dussilyam pajahitvā kāya dvāram sodhayamānam kāya saṃvaram pūrayamānam pavattati tam
translated: and by purifying the bodily door that it occurs fulfilling bodily restraint.

original: kāyacopana rahitaṃpi kāyaṅga saṃvaraṇa kiccattā kiccasīsena kāyadvāre pavattaṃ kāyakammaṃnāma.
analyzed: kāya dvāre pavattam
translated: That is called bodily action occurring in the bodily door by way of the predominance of the function, since it has the function of restraining the bodily formation, though it is free from bodily prompting.

original: Kāyasucaritantipi vuccati. Etthaca taṃ dussilyaṃ pajahitvāti yasmiṃ citte uppajjamāne
analyzed: vuccati ettha ca tam dussilyam pajahitvā ati yasmin citte uppajjamāne
translated: It is also called bodily good conduct. Herein, having abandoned that misconduct: in the mind that arises thus,

original: pāṇaghātādikaṃ kāyadussilyaṃ uppajjeyya. Tassa cittassa uppajjituṃ appadānavasena🔽taṃ kāyadussilyaṃ pajahitvā. Kāyadvāraṃ sodha yamānanti yasmiṃ dussilye uppajjamāne
analyzed: pāṇa ghāta ādikam kāya dussilyam uppajjeyya tassa cittassa uppajjitum appadāna vasena  tam kāya dussilyam pajahitvā kāya dvāram sodha yasmin dussilye uppajjamāne
translated: It is also called bodily good conduct. Herein, having abandoned that misconduct: having prevented the arising of that bodily misconduct consisting in killing living things, and so on,🔽in whatever consciousness arises.

original: kāyaṅgaṃ asuddhaṃ hoti. Tassa uppajjituṃ appadānavasena kāyadvāraṃ sodhayamānaṃ.
analyzed: kāya aṅgam asuddham hoti tassa uppajjitum appadāna vasena kāya dvāram sodhayamānam
translated: Purifying the bodily door: making the bodily door pure by preventing the arising of that misconduct.

original: Kāyasaṃvaraṃ pūrayamānanti sayaṃ kāyaṅgasaṃvaraṇakiccasampādanena kāyasaṃvaraṃ pūrentanti
analyzed: kāya saṃvaram pūrayamānanti sayam kāyaṅga saṃvaraṇa kicca sampādanena kāya saṃvaram
translated: Fulfilling bodily restraint: the meaning is, fulfilling bodily restraint by accomplishing the function of restraining the bodily door.

original: attho. Vacīkammepi eseva nayo. Avayesaṃ pana sabbaṃpi kalyāṇakammaṃ tīsu dvāresu
analyzed: atthaḥ vacī kamme pi esa iva nayaḥ avayesam pana sabbam pi kalyāṇa kammam tīsu dvāresu
translated: The same method applies in the case of verbal action. But all good conduct, which occurs in the three doors,

original: pavattaṃpi manodvāraṃeva sodhayamānaṃ manosaṃvaraṃeva pūrayamānaṃ pavattatīti manodvāre
analyzed: manaḥ dvāram eva sodhayamānam manaḥ saṃvaram eva pūrayamānam pavattati iti manaḥ dvāre
translated: occurs making pure the mind door alone, fulfilling mental restraint alone. Therefore mental action that occurs in the mind door

original: pavattaṃ manokammaṃnāma. Manosucaritantipi vuccati. Ayameko pariyāyo. Ayaṃ pana anekasatesu
analyzed: pavattam manokammaṃ nāma manosucaritanti pi vuccati ayam ekaḥ pariyāyaḥ ayam pana aneka satesu
translated: is called mental good conduct. This is one method. But in the case of the many hundreds of kinds of good conduct,

original: kammapathasuttesu āgato. Apica, aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ sakalāya dvārakathāka ayamattho dīpetabboti.
analyzed: kammapatha suttesu āgataḥ apica aṭṭhasāliniyam sakalāya ayam attho dīpetabbo ti
translated: and in the Kammapathasutta . Besides, this meaning can be demonstrated in the whole of the Dvārakaṇṭaka Sutta in the Aṭṭhasālinī .

original: Imesu pana dvīsu pariyāyesu sattusāsane kalyāṇadhammapūraṇaṃnāma yāvadeva pāpadhammapahānatthāya
analyzed: imesu pana dvīsu pariyāyesu sattu sāsane kalyāṇa dhamma pūraṇam nāma yāvat eva pāpa dhamma pahāna atthāya
translated: And in these two ways, the filling up of the good Dhamma in the Dispensation of the Enemy’s Son is only for the purpose of abandoning the bad Dhamma;🔽and therefore the latter is to be understood as the principal .

original: eva hotīti pacchimoyeva padhānanti veditabboti. Diyyati etenāti dānaṃ. Vatthupariccāgacetanā.
analyzed: eva hoti iti pacchimo yā iva padhānanti veditabbo ti diyyati etena ati dānam vatthu pariccāga cetanā
translated: Dāna means that by which is given ; the volition of giving up the object.

original: Sīlayatīti sīlaṃ. Kāya vacīkammāni sāvajjāni nīvāretvā anavajjāni susamāhitāni katvā
analyzed: sīlayati iti sīlam kāya vacī kammāni sāvajjāni nīvāretvā anavajjāni su samāhitāni katvā
translated: Sīla means that by which one is restrained ; having restrained the body and speech from what is blameworthy, having well-collected what is blameless,

original: sammādahati thapeti, uparime kusaladhammeca upadhāreti. Tesaṃ patiṭṭhā hutvā dhāretīti
analyzed: sammā ādahati thapeti uparime kusala dhamme ca upadhāreti tesam patiṭṭhā hutvā dhāreti iti
translated: one burns up , one places , and one burns up the higher profitable ideas. The meaning is that one bears them up having become their support.

original: attho. Bhāventi etāyāti bhāvanā. Adhikusaladhamme anuppannevā uppādenti uppannevā
analyzed: atthaḥ bhāventi etāya ati bhāvanā adhi kusala dhamme anuppannā iva uppādenti uppannā iva
translated: Bhāvanā means that by which one is developed ; the meaning is that one causes the non-arisen profitable ideas to arise and the arisen ones to increase.

original: vaḍḍhentīti attho. Apacāyanti etenāti apacāyanaṃ. Pūjenti kāyavācāhi attānaṃ nīcavuttiṃ dassentīti attho.
analyzed: vaḍḍhenti iti atthaḥ apacāyanti etena ati apacāyanam pūjenti kāya vācāhi attānam nīca vuttim dassenti iti atthaḥ
translated: Apacāyana means that by which one is served ; the meaning is that one serves oneself by body and speech, showing oneself to be of low estate.
