analyzed: ṭhiti kara ādayaḥ taṃ taṃ satta nikāyam ajjhottharamānāḥ āyum paricchindantā pavattanti iti
translated: The life-span of beings in the various orders of beings is determined by the life- determining kamma that they have respectively accumulated.

original: asaṅkhyeyyāyuka saṃvattanikaṃ cakkavattisampatti saṃvattanikañca kammaṃ dasavassike
analyzed: asaṅkhyeyya āyuka saṃvattanikam cakkavatti sampatti saṃvattanikam ca kammam dasa vassike
translated: The kamma that leads to the attainment of the status of a world-ruling monarch and the kamma that lead to the status of a Buddha, a Paccekabuddha, and a disciple of the Buddha, respectively, ripen in the course of a hundred thousand years.

original: kāle vipaccamānaṃ tadanurūpaṃeva bhogañca issariyañca datvā dasavasena khiyyati.🔽Taṃ taṃ sattanikāya pariyāpannā sattā santānabhūtā rūpadhammā sabbaññu buddhānaṃ
analyzed: kāle vipaccamānam tad anurūpam eva bhogam ca issariyam ca da tvā dasa vasena khiyyati  tam tam satta nikāya pariyāpannā sattā santāna bhūtā rūpa dhammā sabbaññu buddhānam
translated: The kamma that ripens in the course of a hundred thousand years gives rise to wealth and sovereignty in proportion to the life-span of a hundred thousand years.🔽The material phenomena that constitute the life-continuum of beings in the various orders of beings, which are included in the various orders of beings, are transformed in such a way that they are in conformity with the life-span of a hundred thousand years.

original: khandhasantāna bhūtāpi taggatikā tadanūvattikā eva hutvā pariṇamanti aññatra iddhimaya
analyzed: khandha santāna bhūtā api tad gatikā tad anūvattikā eva hutvā pariṇamanti aññatra iddhi maya
translated: The material phenomena that constitute the life-continuum of the omniscient Buddhas are transformed in such a way that they are in conformity with the life-span of a hundred thousand years.

original: vijjāmaya rasāyanavidhi jīvita saṅkhāra vidūhīti. Vuttañhetaṃ mahāpadānasuttaṭṭhakathāyaṃ –
analyzed: vijjā āmaya rasāyana vidhi jīvita saṅkhāra vidūhi iti vuttam ha etam mahāpadāna sutta ṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: This is stated in the commentary to the Mahapadana Sutta:

original: Sabbepi sabbaññubuddhā asaṅkhyeyyāyukā. Kasmā te asaṅkhyeyyaṃ na aṭṭhaṃsūti. Utubhojanavipattiyā. Utubhojanavasena hi āyu hāyatipi vaḍḍhatipīti.
analyzed: sabbe api sabbaññu buddhāḥ asaṅkhyeyya āyukā kasmā te asaṅkhyeyyam na uti utu bhojana vipattiyā utu bhojana vasena hi āyu hāyati pi vaḍḍhati pi iti
translated: “All omniscient Buddhas have a life-span of a hundred thousand years. Why do they not live longer? Because of the failure of climate and food. For the life-span increases and decreases according to the climate and food.”

original: Tasmā padhānanissayabhūtesu dvisamuṭṭhānika rūpadhammesu taṃ taṃ āyukappavasena pariṇamantesu
analyzed: tasmā padhāna nissaya bhūtesu dvi samuṭṭhānika rūpa dhammesu tam tam āyu kappa vasena pariṇamantesu
translated: So when the material phenomena that are the basis for the kamma that is the condition for life span are generated in two ways and then change according to the measure of life span,

original: jiyyamānesu yāvamahantaṃpi kammaṃ attano vipākādhiṭṭhānassa abhāvā khiyyatiyeva.🔽Socassa khayo na sarasena hoti. Athakho āyusaṅkhāravipattiyā eva hotīti idha āyukkhayo🔽visuṃ gahitoti. Esanayo upacchedakamaraṇepi netabbo. Tattha upacchedakamaraṇanti
analyzed: jiyyamānesu yāvamahantam pi kammam attanaḥ vipāka adhiṭṭhānassa abhāvā  socassa khayaḥ na sa rasena hoti athakho āyu saṅkhāra vipattiyai eva hoti iti idha āyu khayaḥ  visum gahito ti esa nayo upacchedaka maraṇe pi netabbo tattha upacchedaka maraṇam ti
translated: and when they are being destroyed, then even a great deal of kamma is exhausted because there is no more occurrence of its result.🔽The exhaustion of sorrow does not come about through the exhaustion of the life span. It comes about through the exhaustion of the formations of life span.🔽So the exhaustion of life span is mentioned separately here. The same method of explanation applies to the exhaustion of search.

original: akālamaraṇaṃ vuccati. Tañhipavattamānaṃ upacchedakakammunāvā pavattati. Aññehivā
analyzed: akāla maraṇam vuccati tat hi pavattamānam upacchedaka kammunā vā pavattati aññehi vā
translated: Herein, untimely death is called “death by cutting off.”🔽For that occurs either through the action of cutting off or through other causes as well.

original: aneka sahassehi kāraṇehi. Tāni pana pāḷiyaṃ mūlabhedato saṃkhipitvā aṭṭhadhā vuttāni.
analyzed: aneka sahassehi kāraṇehi tāni pana pāḷiyam mūla bhedato saṃkhipitvā aṭṭhadhā vuttāni
translated: But in the texts it is mentioned in eight ways by way of the principal causes.

original: Katamāni pana tānīti. Atthi vātasamuṭṭhānā ābādhā. Atthi vittasamuṭṭhānā. Atthi semha
analyzed: katamāni pana tāni iti atthi vāta samuṭṭhānā ābādhā atthi vitta samuṭṭhānā atthi semha
translated: What are the eight? There are sicknesses originating from wind, from bile, from phlegm,

original: samuṭṭhānā. Atthi sannipātikā. Atthi utusamuṭṭhānā. Atthi visamaparihārajā. Atthi
analyzed: samuṭṭhānā atthi sannipātikā atthi utu samuṭṭhānā atthi visama parihāra jā atthi
translated: from a combination of these three, from change of climate, from over-indulgence in food, from violent assault, and from a supernormal being’s will.

original: opakkamikā. Atthi kammavipākajā ābādhāti. Tattha kammavipākajā keci upapīḷakakammajākeci
analyzed: opakkamikā atthi kamma vipāka jā ābādhā ti tattha kamma vipāka jā keci upapīḍaka kamma jā keci
translated: and some are due to kamma-result. Herein, some are due to kamma-result, some are due to what is born of kamma, some are due to what is eaten, some are due to climate, and some are due to misconduct.🔽

original: upacchedakakammajā. Yasmā pana vāto kuppamāno sītuṇhādīhi dasahi kāraṇehi kuppati.
analyzed: upacchedaka kamma jā yasmā pana vātaḥ kuppamāno sītuṇha ādīhi dasahi kāraṇehi kuppati
translated: and due to a combination of these. There is sickness due to kamma-result. Herein, some sicknesses are due to kamma-result, some are due to disturbance, and some are due to a combination of these. But when the wind is disturbed, it is disturbed for ten reasons, such as cold, heat, etc.

original: Tesuca ekameva kamma vipākajaṃ hoti. Sesāni pana akammavipākajānīti milinda pañhe
analyzed: tesu ca ekam eva kamma vipāka jam hoti sesāni pana a kamma vipāka jāni iti milinda pañhe
translated: And of these ten, only one is due to kamma-result, while the rest are not due to kamma-result. This is said in the Milindapañha.

original: vuttaṃ. Yasmāca kammavipākajāpi ābādhā uppajjamānā vāta kuppanādīhi vinā na uppajjanti.
analyzed: vuttam yasmā ca kamma vipāka jāḥ api ābādhāḥ uppajjamānāḥ vāta kuppana ādīhi vinā na uppajjanti
translated: And because sicknesses due to kamma-result also arise without the disturbance of the wind, etc.,

original: Tasmā keci vātasamuṭṭhānādayopi kammavipākajā hontiyevāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: tasmā keci vāta samuṭṭhāna ādayaḥ api kamma vipāka jāḥ daṭṭhabbā
translated: it must be understood that some sicknesses due to the disturbance of the wind, etc., are also due to kamma-result.

original: Tattha sannipātikāti vātādīnaṃ dvinnaṃ tiṇṇaṃvā sannipatitānaṃ vasena pavattā. Ye🔽pana loke sattānaṃ payogamuttā sayaṃ jātā nānābhayupaddavā. Te utusamuṭṭhānesu saṅgahitāti
analyzed: tattha sannipātikā ati vāta ādīnam dvinnam tiṇṇam vā sannipatitānam vasena pavattāḥ ye  pana loke sattānam payoga muttā sayam jātā nānā bhaya upaddavā te utu samuṭṭhānesu saṅgahitā ati
translated: Herein, “due to a combination” is that which occurs by the combination of two or three of the wind, etc.🔽But those various kinds of dangers and calamities that arise in the world by the power of beings’ kamma, without being produced by the effort of any person, should be understood as included among those “due to temperature.”

original: daṭṭhabbā. Visamaparihārajāti anisammakārīnaṃ anekavidhe visame vipattimukhe attānaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā visama parihāra jāti anekavidhe visame vipatti mukhe attānam
translated: And those that arise through the negligence of people who do not act with circumspection should be understood as included among those “due to external agency.”

original: payojantānaṃ tato tatovā tattha tattha vā patana pakkhalanādivasena pavattā. Opakkamikāti
analyzed: tatas tatas vā tattha tattha vā patana pakkhalana ādi vasena pavattā opakkamikā ti
translated: and it occurs by the falling, stumbling, etc., of those who are engaged in it here and there.

original: attanāvā parehi rājacoraverīhivā amanussavāḷayakkhadevatāhivā vāḷamigādīhivā katānaṃ🔽payogānaṃ vasena pavattā. Kuppitā hi devatā sakalaṃ rajjaṃvā raṭṭhaṃvā dīpakaṃvā
analyzed: atta nāvā parehi rāja cora verīhi vā amanussa vāḷa yakkha devatāhi vā vāḷa miga ādīhi vā katānam  payogānam vasena pavattā kuppitā hi devatā sakalam rajjam vā raṭṭham vā dīpakam vā
translated: It occurs by the agency of others, of kings, thieves, enemies, non-human beings, wild beasts, etc.,

original: ekappahārena asesaṃ katvā vināsenti daṇḍakaraṭṭha majjharaṭṭha kaliṅgaraṭṭha mātaṅgaraṭṭhesu
analyzed: eka pahārena asesam katvā vināsenti daṇḍaka raṭṭha majjha raṭṭha kaliṅga raṭṭha mātaṅga raṭṭhesu
translated: For angry deities destroy an entire kingdom, a country, an island, all at once, leaving nothing at all, as in the case of Daṇḍaka, Mātaliṅga, and Kaliṅgara kingdoms.

original: viya. Anekasahassevā vāḷayakkhe vissajjanti vesāliyaṃ viya. Rakkhasevā vissajjanti
analyzed: viya aneka sahassa ivāḥ vāḷa yakkhe vissajjanti vesāliyam viya rakkhasevāḥ vissajjanti
translated: Or they send out many thousands of wild beasts and demons, as in the case of Vesāli.

original: suvaṇṇabhūmiyaṃviya. Vuttañhetaṃ aṅguttare yakkhā vāḷe amanusse ossajjanti. Tena🔽bahumanussā kālaṃ karontīti. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃpi yakkhāti yakkhādhipatino. Vāḷe amanusse
analyzed: aṅguttare yakkhāḥ vāḷe amanusse ossajjanti tena  bahu manussā kālam karonti iti yakkhā ati yakkha adhipatino vāḷe amanusse
translated: Or they send out demons, as in the case of the Suvaṇṇabhūmi country. For this is said in the Aṅguttara Nikāya: “Deities send out wild demons and non-human beings.

original: ossajjantīti caṇḍe yakkhe manussapathe vissajjanti. Te laddhokāsā mahājanaṃ jīvitakkhayaṃ
analyzed: ossajjanti iti caṇḍe yakkhe manussa pathe vissajjanti te laddha okāsāḥ mahājanam jīvita kkhayam
translated: Because of that many human beings die” . And in the commentary to that it is said: “Yakkhas” are lords of the yakkhas. “Wild demons and non-human beings” are fierce yakkhas. “They send out” means they let loose on the human path. They, having got their opportunity, destroy the lives of many people.

original: pāpentīti vuttaṃ. Tattha vissajjantīti visamācāra bahule manusse disvā bhinnasaddhā
analyzed: pāpenti iti vuttam tattha vissajjanti iti bahule manusse disvā bhinna saddhā
translated: is what is said. Herein, “she sends forth” means that when she sees people who are full of misconduct, she does not take up the protection of people as she did before.

original: yakkhasenāpatino manussānaṃ atthāya pubbeviya ārakkhaṃna gaṇhantīti attho. Janapadanagaranigamagāmesuceva
analyzed: yakkha senāpatino manussānam atthāya pubbeviya ārakkhaṃ na gaṇhanti iti atthaḥ janapada nagara nigama gāmesu ca iva
translated: The meaning is that she does not have faith in them. In the country, town, village, and home,

original: tasmiṃ tasmiṃ puggaleca vattabbameva natthi. Aṅguttare vuttā satthadubbhikkharoga🔽kappāpi idha vattabbāti. Kammavipākajāti upapīḷakopaghātakānaṃ kammānaṃ vipaccanavasena
analyzed: tasmin tasmin vattabbam eva natthi aṅguttare vuttā  kappā api idha vattabbā ti kamma vipāka jāti upapīḍaka upaghātakānam kammānam vipaccana vasena
translated: and in the case of each person, there is nothing to be said. The famine, disease, and war spoken of in the Aṅguttara Nikāya should also be mentioned here.

original: pavattā ābādhāti attho. Evaṃ akālamaraṇaṃ upacchedakammunāvā aññehivā anekasahassehi
analyzed: evam akāla maraṇam aññehi vā aneka sahassehi
translated: The meaning is that the affliction that occurs by the ripening of the kamma of birth, oppression, and destruction, is the ripening of kamma. Thus untimely death occurs by the kamma of cutting off, or by many thousands of other causes.

original: kāraṇehi hotīti. Yehi keci loke dissanti. Pāṇaharā jīvitavināsakā nānārogāvā nānābādhāvā
analyzed: kāraṇehi hoti iti yehi keci loke dissanti pāṇa harāḥ jīvita vināsakāḥ nānā rogāvā nānā bādhāvā
translated: Whatever in the world are seen to be killers of living beings, destroyers of life, various diseases, various afflictions,

original: nānābhayā nivā nānā daṇḍāvā nānā upaddavu pasaggāvā. Sabbe te sakakamma samuṭṭhitāeva
analyzed: nānā bhayā nīvā nānā daṇḍāvā nānā upaddavu pasaggāvā sabbe te saka kamma samuṭṭhitā eva
translated: various fears, various punishments, various calamities, various misfortunes, all of them arise from their own kamma.

original: attano sādhāraṇāti natthi. Parakammasamuṭṭhitāpi attano sādhāraṇāeva. Sakakammasamuṭṭhitāpi
analyzed: attano sādhāraṇā ti natthi para kamma samuṭṭhitā api attano sādhāraṇā eva saka kamma samuṭṭhitā api
translated: There is none that is common to oneself.🔽Those that arise from the kamma of another are common to oneself.🔽Those that arise from one’s own kamma are common to others.

original: paresaṃ sādhāraṇāeva. Kammena vinā yato kutoci samuṭṭhitāpi attano vā paresaṃvā sādhāraṇāeva.
analyzed: paresam kammena vinā yatas kutoci samuṭṭhitā api attanaḥ vā paresam vā
translated: Those that arise from anywhere without kamma are common to oneself and to others.

original: Sabbasādhāraṇakammasamuṭṭhitesu vattabbameva natthi. Yathāha-visuddhimagge.
analyzed: sabba sādhāraṇa kamma samuṭṭhitesu vattabbam eva na atthi yathā ha visuddhi magge
translated: There is nothing to be said about those that arise from the kamma common to all. As it is said in the Visuddhimagga:

original: Yathā catumahāpathe thapite lakkhamhi sabbadisāhi āgatā sarasattitomarapāsāṇādayo nipatanti. Evaṃ kāyepi sabbupaddavā nipatantīti.
analyzed: yathā catu mahāpathe thapite lakkhamhi sabba disāhi āgatā sara satti tomara pāsāṇa ādayaḥ nipatanti evam kāye pi sabba upaddavāḥ nipatanti iti
translated: “Just as arrows shot from bows, spears, stones, etc., from all directions fall on a man standing in the middle of a crossroads, so all calamities fall on a man.”

original: Yesuca rajjaraṭṭhādīsu te uppajjanti. Tattha yejanā upāya kusalāvā na honti. Naca🔽paṭikārakusalā. Nāpi parihāra kusalā. Kammañca yesaṃ dubbalaṃ hoti. Uppanno anattho
analyzed: yesu ca rajja raṭṭha ādīsu te uppajjanti tattha na honti na ca  paṭikāra kusalāḥ na api parihāra kusalāḥ kamman ca yesam dubbalam hoti uppannaḥ anattho
translated: And in those countries, such as Rājagaha, where they do not know how to prevent the calamities,🔽they are not skilled in counteracting them,🔽and their kamma is weak, then the calamity that has arisen, whether strong or weak,

original: bala vā. Tejanā vināpi upacchedakakammunā tato na muccanti. Maraṇaṃ vā maraṇamattaṃvā
analyzed: vā tejanā vinā api upacchedaka kammunā tatas na muccanti maraṇam vā maraṇa mattam vā
translated: cannot be averted without the kamma that would cut it off. They die or suffer death’s anguish.

original: dukkhaṃ pāpuṇantiyeva. Kalyāṇabhūtaṃpi hi kammaṃ attano balavataraṃ yatokutoci samuṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: dukkham pāpuṇantiyā iva kalyāṇa bhūtam pi hi kammaṃ attanaḥ balavataram yatas kutoci samuṭṭhitam
translated: and they come to suffering. For even good kamma, wherever it arises,🔽

original: rogaṃvā ābādhaṃ vā bhayaṃvā daṇḍaṃvā upaddavupasaggaṃvā paṭibāhituṃ nasakkoti. Rogādayoeva
analyzed: rogam vā ābādham vā bhayam vā daṇḍam vā upaddava upasaggam vā paṭibāhitum na sakkoti roga ādayaḥ eva
translated: and they come to suffering. For even good kamma cannot prevent the occurrence of a disease, an affliction, a danger, a punishment, a calamity, or an obsession, whatever it may be, that has arisen owing to kamma more powerful than itself. Disease, etc.,

original: taṃkhepentā pavattanti. Yathā hi udakaṃ attano balavataraṃ aggiṃ paṭibāhituṃ na sakkoti.
analyzed: pavattanti yathā hi udakam attanaḥ balavataram aggim paṭibāhitum na sakkoti
translated: overcome it and go on to their own end. Just as water cannot prevent the occurrence of a fire more powerful than itself.

original: Aggieva taṃ khepento pavattatīti evaṃ sampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Imesañca sattānaṃ
analyzed: aggi eva tam khepentaḥ pavattati iti evam sampadam idam daṭṭhabbam imesam ca sattānam
translated: The fire overcomes it and goes on to its own end. This is how it should be regarded. And the natural weakness of kamma should not be illustrated by the Suttas and the Commentaries with the examples of disease, etc.,

original: pakatiyāpi kammassa dubbalabhāvo mahāniddese jarā suttaniddesena visuddhi maggeca🔽maraṇassati niddese āyu dubbalatoti padassa niddese na dīpetabbo. Yathāha –
analyzed: pakatiyā api kammassa dubbala bhāvaḥ mahāniddese jarā sutta niddesena visuddhi magge ca  maraṇassa ati niddese āyu dubbala toti padassa niddese na dīpetabbaḥ yathā āha
translated: in the Mahānidāna Sutta, the Jarā Sutta, the Niddesa, and the Maraṇassati Sutta in the Visuddhimagga,🔽as follows: “The word ‘weakness’ in the phrase ‘because of the weakness of life’ should be illustrated by the following.

original: Āyunāmetaṃ abalaṃ dubbalaṃ. Tathā hi sattānaṃ jīvitaṃ assāsapassāsupanibandhañceva iriyāpathupanibandhañca sītuṇhu panibandhañca mahābhūtupanibandhañca āhārupanibandhañcātiādi.
analyzed: āyu nāmetam abalam dubbalam tathā hi sattānam jīvitam assāsa passāsa upanibandhañca iva iriyāpatha upanibandhañca sītuṇhu panibandhañca mahābhūta upanibandhañca āhāra upanibandhañca ati ādi
translated: For life is weak because of its dependence on the in-breaths and out-breaths, on the postures, on cold and heat, on the primary elements, on nutriment, and so on.”

original: Tathā kāyabahusādhāraṇato animittatoti imesaṃ padānaṃ niddesenapi pākaṭoyeva. Kammanibbattassa
analyzed: tathā kāya bahu sādhāraṇataḥ animittato ti imesam padānam niddesena api kamma nibbattassa
translated: Likewise, the words “in a place frequented by many” and “signless” are also clear from the explanation.

original: hi āyuno tiṇagge ussāvabindusseva paridubbalabhāve pāḷiyaṃ aṭṭhakathā yañca vutte
analyzed: hi āyunaḥ tiṇagge paridubbala bhāve pāḷiyam aṭṭhakathā yat ca vutte
translated: For when the life span of one produced by kamma is as feeble as a dewdrop on the tip of a blade of grass, it is established as feeble in the texts and in the commentaries.

original: kammasāpi tatheva paridubbalatā siddhā hotīti. Evañcetaṃ sampaṭicchitabbaṃ. Itarathā
analyzed: kammasā api tathā iva paridubbala tā siddhā hoti iti evañca itam sampaṭicchitabbam itarathā
translated: This is how it should be accepted. Otherwise

original: sabbaṃ pubbekatahetudiṭṭhināma siyā. Yathāha –
analyzed: sabbam pubbekata hetu diṭṭhi nāma siyā yathā āha
translated: it would all be the view called “causation by what was done in the past.” For it is said:

original: Idhekacco samaṇovā brāhmaṇovā evaṃvādī hoti evaṃ diṭṭhī. Yaṃ kiñcāyaṃpurisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃvā dukkhaṃvā adukkhamasukhaṃvā. Sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetūti.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā evaṃvādī hoti evam diṭṭhī yam kiñca ayam purisa puggalaḥ paṭisaṃvedeti sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā sabbam tam pubbekata hetu ti
translated: “Herein, some recluse or brahmin is a speculator about the past, and he asserts various speculative theories about the past, saying: ‘The world is eternal’ … ‘The world is not eternal’ … ‘The world is finite’ … ‘The world is infinite’ … ‘The soul and the body are the same’ … ‘The soul is one thing and the body another’ … ‘The Tathāgata exists after death’ … ‘The Tathāgata does not exist after death’ … ‘The Tathāgata both exists and does not exist after death’ … ‘The Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist after death.’

original: Ayañca attho milindapañhe tīsu ṭhānesu vitthārato āgato. Yathāvuttehi pana anekasahassehi
analyzed: ayam ca atthaḥ milinda pañhe tīsu ṭhānesu vitthārataḥ āgataḥ yathā vuttehi pana aneka sahassehi
translated: And this matter is given in detail in three places in the Milindapañha.

original: kāraṇehi pavattamaraṇaṃpi akālamaraṇatāsāmaññena idha upacchedakamaraṇe saṅgahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: kāraṇehi pavatta maraṇam api akāla maraṇa tā sāmaññena idha upacchedaka maraṇe saṅgahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: But the dying that occurs by means of the many thousands of causes mentioned should be regarded as included here under “dying by violence” since it is similar to “dying prematurely.”

original: Vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam
translated: In the Vibhāvinī

original: “Idaṃ pana nerayikānaṃ uttarakuruvāsinaṃ kesañci devānañca nahotīti” vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idam pana nerayikānam uttarakuru vāsinam kesañci devānam ca vuttam
translated: “But it is not so for the denizens of hell, for the inhabitants of Uttarakuru, and for some gods.”

original: Yathā pana mahāṭīkāyaṃ kesañci petānaṃ ito ñātake hi dinnaṃ puññapatti anumoditvā
analyzed: yathā pana mahā ṭīkāyam kesañci petānam itas ñātake hi dinnam puññapatti anumoditvā
translated: But just as in the Mahā-ṭīkā it is said that for some ghosts, when their relatives give gifts here and dedicate the merit with the wish that they be reborn in a happy state,

original: taṅkhaṇeyeva cavitvā sugatiyaṃ nibbattānaṃ kusalabhūtaṃ upacchedakaṃ vuttaṃ. Tathā🔽kesañci nerayi kānaṃpi yamarañño samanuyuñjanakālādīsu attanā katapuññaṃ anussaritvā
analyzed: tad khaṇeya iva cavitvā sugatiyam nibbattānam kusala bhūtam upacchedakam vuttam tathā  samanuyuñjana kāla ādīsu attanā kata puññam anussaritvā
translated: they die at that very moment and are reborn in a happy state, and that the wholesome is cut off for them,🔽so too it should not be said that the cutting off of the wholesome is not death for some denizens of hell who, when they are questioned by Yama, recollect the good they have done and

original: taṅkhaṇeyeva cavitvā sugatiyaṃ nibbattānaṃ upacche dakamaraṇaṃnāma na na sakkā vattuṃ.🔽Kesañci tāvatiṃsādīnaṃ devānañca taṃ upacchedakamaraṇaṃ hotiyeva. Tathā hi subrahmadeva🔽putta saṃyuttaṭṭhakathāyaṃ atha rukkhaṃ abhiruḷhā upacchedakakammādi vasenaekappahāreneva
analyzed: cavitvā sugatiyam nibbattānam upacche dakamaraṇam nāma na na sakkā vattum  upacchedaka maraṇam tathā hi subrahmadeva  atha rukkham abhiruḷhā upacchedaka kamma ādi vasena eka ppahārena iva
translated: die at that very moment and are reborn in a happy state.

original: kālaṅkatvā avīcimhi nibbattāti vuttaṃ. Tattha rukkhanti tāvatiṃse pāricchattakarukkhaṃ.
analyzed: kālaṅkatvā avīcimhi nibbattā iti vuttam tattha rukkhanti tāvatiṃse pāricchattaka rukkham
translated: And it is death by cutting off the wholesome for some gods such as the Tāvatiṃsas. For in the Subrahma-devaputta Saṃyutta commentary it is said: “Then, when they climb the tree, they die by cutting off the wholesome and are reborn in Avīci hell.” Herein, the tree is the pāricchattaka tree in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.

original: Abhiruḷhāti āruḷhā pañca satadevaccharāyo. Manopadosika khiṭṭāpadosika devānaṃ maraṇaṃ
analyzed: āruḍhā pañca
translated: “Mounted” means mounted by the five hundred celestial maidens. “Death of the devas” is death of the devas who are subject to the stain of mind and the stain of action.

original: mahābodhisattānaṃ dighāyuke devalokevā brahmalokevā nibbattānaṃ adhimutti kālaṅkiriyā
analyzed: mahā bodhisattānam dighāyuke deva loke iva brahma loke iva nibbattānam adhimutti kālaṅkiriyā
translated: “Death of the great Bodhisattas” is the death of the great Bodhisattas who are reborn in the long-lived devas’ world or in the Brahma-world and die by the exhaustion of their life-span.

original: channattheragodhikattherādīnaṃviya sayameva satthaṃ āharitvā parinibbāyantānaṃ maraṇañca
analyzed: channatthera godhikatthera ādīnam viya sayam eva sattham āharitvā parinibbāyantānam maraṇam ca
translated: “Death of those who die by their own hand” is the death of such as the Elder Channa and the Elder Godhika, who take their own lives and attain final Nibbāna.

original: ettheva saṅgayhatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tathācāti tehi pakārehica. Marantānaṃ channaṃ dvārānaṃ
analyzed: ettha iva saṅgayhati iti daṭṭhabbam tathā ca ati tehi pakārehi ca marantānam channam
translated: It should be regarded as included here. “In the same way” means in the same way as the above-mentioned ways of dying. “In one of the six doors of death”

original: aññatarasmiṃ paccupaṭṭhātīti sambandho. Maraṇakāleti maraṇāsannakāle. Yathārahanti
analyzed: aññatarasmim paccupaṭṭhāti iti sambandhaḥ maraṇa kāle iti maraṇa āsanna kāle yathārahanti
translated: means that the connection is with one of the six doors of death. “At the time of death” means at the time of dying. “In the appropriate way”🔽means in the way appropriate for those who are going to a good or a bad destination. As to those who are without cankers, they are not reborn anywhere.

original: sugatiduggatigāmīnaṃ arahānurūpaṃ. Yepana khīṇāsavā katthaci nuppajjanti. Tesu sukkhavipassakānaṃ
analyzed: sugati duggati gāmīnam araha anurūpam ye pana khīṇa āsavā katthaci na uppajjanti tesu sukkha vipassakānam
translated: In the case of those who are dry-insight meditators,

original: pakatiyā yatho paṭṭhitaṃ nāmarūpa meva antima javanānaṃ ārammaṇaṃhoti. Samāpattilābhīnaṃ
analyzed: pakatiyā yathā upaṭṭhitam samāpatti lābhīnam
translated: the last impulsions have as their object the mentality-materiality that has arisen in the normal way. In the case of those who have attained jhāna,

original: pana jhānasamanantare parinibbāyantānaṃ kasiṇanimittādikaṃ. Paccavekkhanasamanantare
analyzed: pana jhāna samanantare parinibbāyantānam kasiṇa nimitta ādikam paccavekkhana samanantare
translated: but in the case of those who attain Nibbāna in the interval between jhānas, it is the kasiṇa sign, and so on. In the case of those who attain Nibbāna in the interval of reviewing,

original: parinibbāyantānaṃ jhānaṅgāni abhiññāsamanantare parinibbāyantānaṃ attano karajarūpaṃ.
analyzed: parinibbāyantānam jhāna aṅgāni abhiññā samanantare parinibbāyantānam attano kara ja rūpam
translated: it is the jhāna factors. In the case of those who attain Nibbāna in the interval of direct-knowledge, it is the materiality originated by kamma.🔽But in the case of those who attain Nibbāna in the interval of the life-continuum, it is the path factors, and so on,

original: Jīvita samasīsīnaṃ pana aggamaggassa paccavekkhanasamanantare parinibbāyantānaṃ maggaṅgādini🔽antimajavanānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ hotīti. Parinibbānacuticittassa pana sabbesaṃpi ādito attano🔽attano paṭisandhiyāyathāgahitaṃ kammādīsu aññatarameva ārammaṇaṃ hotīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: pana aggamaggassa paccavekkhana samanantare parinibbāyantānam maggaṅga ādini  antima javanānam ārammaṇam hoti iti parinibbāna cuti cittassa pana sabbesam pi āditas attano  attanaḥ paṭisandhiyā ayathā gahitam kamma ādīsu aññataram eva ārammaṇam hoti iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: of the last impulsion of the life-continuum. But in the case of those who attain Nibbāna in the interval of reviewing the path, it is the path factors, and so on,🔽of the reviewing. In the case of those who attain Nibbāna in the interval of fruition, it is the path factors, and so on,🔽of the fruition. In the case of those who attain Nibbāna in the interval of adverting, it is the object of the adverting. In the case of those who attain Nibbāna in the interval of registration, it is the object of the registration.🔽But in the case of all those who attain Nibbāna in the interval of death, the object of the death consciousness is the rebirth-linking that occurred at the beginning, which was acquired in whichever of the ways stated in the Description of the Dependent Origination , namely, “due to kamma,” and so on.

original: Yepana anejosanti mārabbhayaṃ kālamakarīmunīti imaṃ suttapadaṃ disvā nibbānameva
analyzed: kālam akari muni iti imam sutta padam disvā nibbānam eva
translated: So it should be understood that the object of the death consciousness is any one of kamma, and so on, according to the way in which it was acquired.

original: bhagavato parinibbānacutiyā ārammaṇanti vadanti. Te tena sayameva abhidhamme ārammaṇattikesu
analyzed: bhagavato parinibbāna cutiyā ārammaṇanti vadanti te tena sayam eva abhidhamme ārammaṇattikesu
translated: But those who say that the object of the Blessed One’s death consciousness was Nibbāna, on the evidence of the passage, “Nibbāna is the end of the stress of the search for existence, the end of the stress of the search for non-existence” ,🔽show that they are not skilled in the Abhidhamma, which treats of objects ,

original: attano akovidataṃ dassenti. Yathāha –
analyzed: attanaḥ a kovida tam dassenti yathā āha
translated: as follows:

original: Katame dhammā parittārammaṇā, sabbo kāmāvacaravipāko kriyamanodhātu kriyāhetuka manoviññāṇa dhātu somanassasahagatā. Ime dhammā parittārammaṇāti.
analyzed: katame dhammā paritta ārammaṇā sabbaḥ kāmāvacara vipāko kriya manaḥ dhātu kriyā hetuka manas viññāṇa dhātu somanassa sahagatā ime dhammā paritta ārammaṇā ti
translated: What are the ideas with limited objective fields? All the ideas of the result type in the sense-desire world, and the functional mind element and the functional mind-consciousness element accompanied by joy that have a cause. These are the ideas with limited objective fields.

original: Yasmā pana parinibbānaṃnāma santi atthāyeva hoti. Ajjhāsayo cassa ekantena santininnoyeva🔽hoti. Tasmā anejosanti mārabbhāti suttapadaṃ vuttaṃ. Tathā hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ santimārabbhāti
analyzed: yasmā pana parinibbānaṃ nāma santi atthāya iva hoti ajjhāsayo ca saḥ ekantena  hoti tasmai anejosantim mā ārabbha iti sutta padam vuttam tathā hi aṭṭhakathā ayam santim ārabbha ati
translated: But since the extinction called “extinction” is a mere non-existence, and since its purport is entirely immersed in peace,🔽it is said in the text that it is “unagitated” in the sense of “in relation to Mara.” For in the Commentary the words “in relation to extinction” are said to mean “in relation to extinction, having extinction as the object.”

original: anupādisesaṃ nibbānaṃ ārabbha paṭicca sandhāyāti vuttaṃ. Na pana vuttaṃ ārabbha ālambitvā🔽ārammaṇaṃ katvāti. Theragāthaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana santimārabbhāti santiṃ anupādisesaṃ
analyzed: anupādisesam nibbānam ārabbha paṭicca sandhāya ati vuttam na pana vuttam ārabbha ālambitvā  ārammaṇam katvā iti thera gātha ṭṭhakathāyam pana santim ārabbha ati santim anupādisesam
translated: But it is not said that it is “in relation to” in the sense of “having as the object.”

original: nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvāti vuttaṃ. Taṃ mahāparinibbānapāḷiyā tadaṭṭhakathāyaca nasameti.
analyzed: nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā iti vuttam tam mahāparinibbāna pāḷiyā tad aṭṭhakathāya ca
translated: But in the Commentary on the Elders’ Verses it is said that “in relation to extinction” means “having extinction, which is non-remnant, as the object.”🔽But that does not agree with the text of the Great Passing, nor with its Commentary.

original: Tāsu hi bhagavato parinibbānaṃ jhānaṅga paccavekkhanasamanantaranti vuttaṃ. Etthaca
analyzed: tāsu hi bhagavataḥ parinibbānam jhāna aṅga paccavekkhana samanantaran ti vuttam ettha ca
translated: For in the latter it is said that the Blessed One’s extinction was “immediately next to the reviewing of the jhana factors” .

original: purimāni dve samanantarāni parinibbānasuttaṭṭhakathāsu vuttāni. Abhiññāsamanantaraṃ🔽udānaṭṭhakathādisu āgataṃ. Yathāha-vuṭṭhahitvā parinibbāyīti iddhicittato vuṭṭhahitvā
analyzed: purimāni dve samanantarāni parinibbāna sutta ṭṭhakathāsu vuttāni abhiññā samanantaram  udāna aṭṭhakathā ādisu āgatam yathā āha vuṭṭhahitvā parinibbāyi iti iddhicittataḥ vuṭṭhahitvā
translated: The first two kinds of immediately preceding conditions are those stated in the Parinibbana Sutta commentary.🔽The immediately preceding condition of direct-knowledge is that stated in the Udana commentary, etc.,🔽according to which the Buddha attained final Nibbana after emerging from the attainment of supernormal power.

original: bhavaṅgacittena parinibbāyīti. Aggamaggassa paccavekkhanasamanantaraṃ puggalapaññattiṭṭhakathādīsu
analyzed: bhavaṅga cittena parinibbāyi iti aggamaggassa paccavekkhana samanantaram puggala paññatti ṭṭhakathā ādīsu
translated: The immediately preceding condition of reviewing is that stated in the Puggalapannatti commentary, etc.,

original: āgataṃ. Yathāha-ekūnavīsati me paccavekkhanaññāṇe patiṭṭhāya bhavaṅgaṃ otaritvā parinibbāyatīti.
analyzed: āgatam yathā āha ekūnavīsati me paccavekkhana ññāṇe patiṭṭhāya bhavaṅgam otaritvā parinibbāyati iti
translated: according to which the Buddha attained final Nibbana after emerging from the life-continuum and reviewing the nineteen kinds of knowledge.

original: Saṃyuttaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana arahattamaggānantaraṃ phalaṃ. Phalānantaraṃ bhavaṅgato🔽vuṭṭhāya paccavekkhanaṃ. Taṃ pana paripuṇṇaṃvā hoti aparipuṇṇaṃvā. Tikhiṇena asinā
analyzed: saṃyutta ṭṭhakathā ayam pana arahatta magga anantaram phalam phala anantaram bhavaṅgataḥ  vuṭṭhāya paccavekkhanam tam pana paripuṇṇam vā hoti a paripuṇṇam vā tikhiṇena asinā
translated: But in the Saṃyutta commentary it is said that the immediately preceding condition is the fruition attainment that follows immediately upon the path attainment of Arahantship, and that after emerging from the life-continuum he reviews the path and fruition.

original: sīse chijjamānepi ekaṃvā dvevā paccavekkhanāni uppajjantiyevāti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sīse chijjamāne api ekam vā dve vā paccavekkhanāni uppajjantiyā iva ati vuttam
translated: But this review is either complete or incomplete. If it is complete, it is said that even when the head is being cut off with a sharp sword, two or three reviewing consciousnesses occur.

original: [164] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāna it is said that the immediately preceding condition is the life-continuum.

original: Evaṃ vavatthānaṃ akatvā yaṃ vuttaṃ. “Katthaci pana anuppajjamānassa khīṇāsavassa
analyzed: evam vavatthānam a katvā yam vuttam katthaci pana anuppajjamānassa khīṇāsavassa
translated: Without making such a distinction, it was said: “But in some places it is said that the cankers are destroyed in one who is not generating it.

original: yathopaṭṭhitaṃ nāmarūpadhammādikameva cutipariyosānānaṃ gocarabhāvaṃ gacchati. Na
analyzed: yathā upaṭṭhitam nāma rūpa dhamma ādikam eva cuti pariyosānānam gocara bhāvam gacchati na
translated: Without making such a distinction, it is said: “But in some it is the states of mentality-materiality, etc., as they are found, that become the object of the death consciousness of an arahat in whom no rebirth-producing kamma has matured.

original: kamma kammani mittādayoti.” Taṃ na sundaraṃ.🔽Na hi tassa cuticittaṃ kammakammanimittādayo ārammaṇaṃ nakaroti. Naca cutiyā gahitāni
analyzed: tam na sundaram  na hi tassa cuti cittam kamma kamma nimitta ādayaḥ ārammaṇam na karoti na ca cutiyā gahitāni
translated: Not kamma, sign of kamma, friend, etc.” That is not good.

original: kammādīnināma sabbasattānaṃpi bhavantarassa atthāya bhavantīti. Abhimukhībhūtanti
analyzed: sabba sattānam pi atthāya bhavanti iti
translated: For the death consciousness of an arahat does not make kamma, sign of kamma, etc., its object. Nor do kamma, etc., which are included in death, exist for the purpose of rebirth for all beings.

original: kammantarassa okāsaṃ adatvā attano okāsaṃ katvā paccupaṭṭhitaṃ. Kammaṃvā paccupaṭṭhātīti🔽sambandho. Upaladdhapubbanti tassa kammassa ārammaṇa bhūtāni deyyadhamma vatthādīni
analyzed: kammantarassa okāsam a datvā attanaḥ okāsam katvā paccupaṭṭhitam kammaṃ vā paccupaṭṭhāti iti  sambandhaḥ upaladdhapubbanti tassa kammassa ārammaṇa bhūtāni deyyadhamma vattha ādīni
translated: “Appears as though it were present” : it occurs by making a place for itself without giving place to another kamma. The construction is: “Kamma appears.”🔽“Previously experienced” : this is said with reference to the things given as gifts, such as cloth, etc., which have been the object of that kamma, and with reference to the living beings, etc., that have been the recipients of the gifts.

original: parapāṇādīnica sandhāya vuttaṃ. Upakaraṇabhūtanti kammasiddhiyā upakaraṇabhūtāni
analyzed: para pāṇa ādīni ca sandhāya vuttam upakaraṇa bhūtanti kamma siddhiyā upakaraṇa bhūtāni
translated: “As a means” : as a means for the accomplishment of kamma.

original: parivārabhūtānica paṭiggāhakādīni āvudhabhaṇḍādinica sandhāya vuttaṃ. Yasmāca lakkhaṇa
analyzed: parivāra bhūtāni ca paṭiggāhaka ādīni āvudha bhaṇḍa ādini ca sandhāya vuttam yasmā ca lakkhaṇa
translated: and the recipients, etc., and the weapons, etc., are included by the word “surroundings.”🔽And because the bones, etc., which are the heaps of slaughtered cattle, etc., in the “Characteristic” Thread, etc., are the signs of the kamma that is the cause of their being reborn there,

original: saṃyutte gavādīni vadhitvā rāsikatāni aṭṭhipuñjādīni kammanimittāni hutvā upaṭṭhahantīti
analyzed: saṃyutte go ādīni vadhitvā rāsikatāni aṭṭhi puñja ādīni kamma nimittāni hutvā upaṭṭhahanti iti
translated: it is said in the commentary, “The bones, etc., are the signs of the kamma that is the cause of their being reborn there.”

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Tasmā kammasambandhāni yāni kānici vatthūni vā ārammaṇānivā
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam vuttam tasmā kamma sambandhāni yāni kānici vatthūni vā ārammaṇāni vā
translated: So whatever things or objects are connected with kamma should be regarded as included here under “requisites.”

original: idha upakaraṇe saṅgahi tānīti daṭṭhabbāni. Upalabhitabbanti duggatinimittaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: idha upakaraṇe tāni iti daṭṭhabbāni upalabhitabbanti duggati nimittam sandhāya
translated: “To be experienced” is said with reference to the sign of an unhappy destiny.🔽“To be used” is said with reference to the sign of a happy destiny.

original: vuttaṃ. Upabhogabhūtanti sugatinimittaṃ. Ubhayaṃpi vā yaṃ kāyapaṭibaddhaṃ hutvā labhitabbaṃ
analyzed: vuttam upabhoga bhūtam ti sugati nimittam ubhayam pi vā yam kāya paṭibaddham hutvā labhitabbam
translated: Or alternatively, what is to be experienced is what is to be obtained as something connected with one’s own person;

original: hoti. Taṃ upalabhitabbaṃnāma. Apaṭibaddhaṃ hutvā kevalaṃ sukhadukkhānubhavanatthāya
analyzed: hoti tam upalabhitabbaṃnāma apaṭibaddham hutvā kevalam sukha dukkha anubhavana tthāya
translated: what is to be used is what is to be obtained as not connected with one’s own person, only for the purpose of experiencing pleasure and pain.

original: labhitabbaṃ upabhoga bhūtaṃnāma. Etthaca aggijāla lohakumbhi nirayapāla nirayasunakhādīni
analyzed: labhitabbam upabhoga bhūtaṃnāma ettha ca aggijāla lohakumbhi nirayapāla nirayasunakha ādīni
translated: Herein, the fire-pit, the copper cauldron, the hell warders, the hell dogs, etc.,

original: nirayanimittaṃ. Taṃ pana kesañci janānaṃ attano vasanaṭṭhāneviya upaṭṭhāti. Kesañci
analyzed: niraya nimittam tam pana kesañci janānam attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhāne iviya upaṭṭhāti kesañci
translated: are the sign of a hell. But that appears to some people even in their own dwelling.

original: tato tato āgantvā attānaṃ saṃparivārentaṃ viya upaṭṭhāti. Yathāha-tassa gilānaseyyāya
analyzed: tatas tatas āgantvā attānam saṃparivārentam viya upaṭṭhāti yathā āhatassa gilāna seyyāya
translated: and it appears to him as though it were surrounding him from all sides. As it is said: “When he has arisen from his sickbed,

original: nippannassa nirayo upaṭṭhāti. Soṇagiripādato mahantā mahantā sunakhā āgantvā khāditukāmāviya🔽saṃparivāresunti. Tathā deva nimittepi. Yathāha-nandavana cittalatāvana missakavana
analyzed: nippannassa nirayaḥ upaṭṭhāti soṇagiri pādataḥ mahantā mahantā su nakhā āgantvā khāditu kāmau iya  tathā deva nimitte pi yathā āha nanda vana cittalatā vana missaka vana
translated: hell appears to him as though great dogs were coming from the foot of Mount Sineru and surrounding him, as if they wanted to eat him.” So too with the divine signs. As it is said: “The Nandana Grove, the Missaka Grove, the Chaddanta Lake,

original: phārusakavana vimānāniceva devanāṭakānica parivāretvā ṭhitāniviya ahesunti. Kesañci🔽pana sayaṃ tattha tattha patvā diṭṭhaṃviya upaṭṭhāti. Kambalayānasadiso mātukucchivaṇṇo
analyzed: phārusaka vana vimānānica iva devanāṭakānica parivāretvā ṭhitāniviya ahesunti kesañci  pana sayam tattha tattha patvā diṭṭhaṃviyaḥ upaṭṭhāti kambala yāna sadisaḥ mātukucchi vaṇṇo
translated: the Phārusaka Wood, the divine mansions, the celestial dancing girls all appear to him as though they were standing surrounding him.”

original: Vīthicittā vasānevāti kāmabhavato cavitvā kāmabhaveyeva uppajjamānānaṃ javana pariyosānānaṃvā
analyzed: vīthi cittā vasānā iva ati kāma bhavataḥ cavitvā uppajjamānānam
translated: ‘At the end of the process-of-consciousness’: at the end of the process-consciousness of those who die in the sense-desire becoming and are reborn in the sense-desire becoming, whether it be the end of the impulsions or the end of the registration.

original: tadārammaṇa pariyosānānaṃvā vīthicittānaṃ avasāne. Itaresaṃ pana javanapariyosānānaṃeva🔽vīthicittānaṃ avasāneti attho. Ayamattho aṭṭhakathāyaṃpi vuttoyeva. Yathāha-taṃ ārabbha
analyzed: tad ārammaṇa pariyosānānam vā vīthi cittānam avasāne itaresam pana javana pariyosānānam eva  vīthi cittānam avasāne ti atthaḥ ayam atthaḥ aṭṭhakathā ayam pi vuttaḥ yā iva yathāhatam ārabbha
translated: But the meaning is the end of the process-consciousness of those who die in the sense-desire becoming and are reborn in the fine-material becoming, the end of the impulsions only.

original: uppannāya tadārammaṇapariyosānāya suddhāyavā javanavīthiyā anantaraṃ cuticittaṃ uppajjatīti.
analyzed: uppannāya tad ārammaṇa pariyosānāya suddha āyavā javana vīthiyāḥ anantaram cuti cittam uppajjati iti
translated: This is the meaning stated in the commentary too, where it is said: ‘Immediately next to the pure impulsions that have arisen making that as object, the death consciousness arises in one who dies in the sense-desire becoming and is reborn in the sense-desire becoming, and immediately next to the pure registrations that have arisen making that as object, the death consciousness arises in one who dies in the sense-desire becoming and is reborn in the fine-material becoming’ .

original: [167] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī-Tikā it is said:🔽‘Herein, the registrations of those who die in the sense-desire becoming and are reborn there have that as object, and the impulsions of the rest have that as object’ . This is stated in the Dhammānusāriṇī.

original: “Tattha kāmabhavato cavitvā tattheva uppajjamānānaṃ tadārammaṇapariyosānāni sesānaṃ javanapariyosānānīti dhammānusāraṇiyaṃ vutta”nti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: tattha kāma bhavataḥ cavitvā tattha eva uppajjamānānam tad ārammaṇa pariyosānāni sesānam javana pariyosānāni iti dhammānusāraṇiyam vuttanti vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: That is not good.

original: Aṭṭhakathāyañhi paripuṇṇaṃ katvā vutte kiṃaparipuṇṇāya dhammā nusāraṇiyāti. Bhavaṅgakkhayevāti
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāyam hi paripuṇṇam katvā vutte kiṃaparipuṇṇāya dhammā nusāraṇiyā ti bhavaṅga khayā iva āti
translated: For when it is stated in the commentary in full, what is the point of a Dhammānusāriṇī that is not full?🔽‘In the life-continuum’:

original: bhavaṅgāvasānevā iccevattho. Yadi duvidhapīthicittato paraṃ pañcavokāre vatthurūpaṃ
analyzed: bhavaṅga avasānevā param pañca vokāre vatthu rūpam
translated: The meaning is: at the end of the life-continuum. If, after the two kinds of death consciousness, there is materiality of the five-constituent kind in the fourfold existence,

original: catuvokāre cittasantānaṃ dvicittakkhaṇāyusesaṃ hoti. Tadā ekassa bhavaṅgassa avasāneti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Etthaca somanassa paṭisandhikassa domanassacittena cavantassa āgantukabhavaṅga
analyzed: catu vokāre citta santānam dvi cittakkhaṇa āyusesam hoti tadā ekassa bhavaṅgassa avasāne ti  vuttam hoti ettha ca somanassa paṭisandhikassa domanassa cittena cavantassa āgantuka bhavaṅga
translated: and a mind-cum-materiality continuum in the three-constituent kind, and if there is a remainder of two consciousnesses and a life-span,🔽then it is said that there is an end of the life-continuum.

original: sambhavo. Taṃ sambhaveca sati aññabhavaṅgasambhavopi avāri toti suvuttametaṃ bhavaṅgakkhayevāti.
analyzed: sambhavaḥ tam sambhave ca sati añña bhavaṅga sambhavaḥ api su vuttam etam bhavaṅga kkhayā iva ati
translated: And here there is the possibility of a life-continuum of the opposite kind to that of the rebirth-linking consciousness, that is to say, of grief in the case of one whose rebirth-linking is joy. And when that is possible, then the possibility of another life-continuum is not excluded. So it is rightly said that “the end of the life-continuum is the death consciousness” .

original: Tasmiṃniruddhāvasāneti tasmiṃ niruddhe tassa niruddhassa avasāne. Ye pana loke cuti🔽paṭisandhīnaṃ antare eko antarābhavonāma atthi. Yattha uppanno satto dibbacakkhuko
analyzed: tasmin niruddha avasāne iti tasmin niruddhe tassa niruddhassa avasāne ye pana loke  paṭisandhīnam antare ekaḥ antarābhavaḥ nāma atthi yattha uppannaḥ sattaḥ dibba cakkhuko
translated: When that has ceased: when that has ceased, at the end of the ceased state of that.🔽But there are those who say that there is something called an intermediate existence between death and rebirth-linking,

original: viya iddhimā viya ca khaṇena icchitaṃ ṭhānaṃ gantuṃ samattho. Ito cutā keci tattha
analyzed: ca khaṇena icchitam ṭhānam gantum samatthaḥ itas keci tattha
translated: in which a being who has arisen there is able to go to the place he is to go to in an instant as if possessing the divine eye or supernormal power.

original: uppajjitvā mātāpitu samāgamādīni āgamentā sattāhaṃvā atireka sattāhaṃvā tiṭṭhantīti
analyzed: uppajjitvā mātā pitu samāgama ādīni āgamentā satta aham vā atireka satta aham vā tiṭṭhanti iti
translated: And they say that some beings who have died here and are reborn there, after coming to the meeting of parents, etc., remain for seven days or more than seven days.

original: laddhiṃ gaṇhanti. Tesaṃ taṃnisedhetuṃ tassānantaramevāti vuttaṃ. Savatthukaṃ pañcavokāre
analyzed: laddhim gaṇhanti tesam tat nisedhetum tassa anantaram eva ati vuttam sa vatthukam pañcavokāre
translated: and they take it as a rule. In order to prohibit that, the following is stated. With a basis, in the five doors.

original: avatthukamevavā catuvokāre. Yathārahanti kusalabhūtassavā akusalabhūtassa vā saṅkhārassa🔽arahānurūpaṃ. Avijjātaṇhānusayā kusalabhūtassa appahīnaṭṭhena akusalabhūtassa pana🔽sahajātabhāvenāpi parivārabhūtā mūlabhūtāca hontīti attho. Pariyuṭṭhānāvatthaṃ apatvā
analyzed: avatthukam eva vā catuvokāre yathā rahanti kusala bhūtassa vā akusala bhūtassa vā saṅkhārassa  arahā anurūpam kusala bhūtassa appahīna ṭṭhena akusala bhūtassa pana  sahajāta bhāvena api parivāra bhūtāḥ mūla bhūtāḥ ca honti iti
translated: Without a basis, only in the four doors. As is proper means in accordance with the proper of a formation of the profitable or of the unprofitable.🔽The underlying tendency to ignorance and the underlying tendency to craving are the root cause and the surrounding cause of a formation of the profitable in the sense of their not being abandoned, and of a formation of the unprofitable in the sense of their being conascent.

original: kusalābyākatacittasantānenapi aviruddhabhāvena anurūpaṃ. Anubandhamānovā seti, anuanuvānirantaraṃ🔽setīti anusayo. Anusayabhūtāya avijjāya parikkhittoti avijjānusayaparikkhitto. Taṇhānusayo
analyzed: aviruddha bhāvena anurūpam sa iti  seti iti anusayaḥ anusaya bhūtāya avijjāya parikkhitto ti avijjā anusaya parikkhitto taṇhā anusayo
translated: This is the meaning. original: mūlaṃ etassāti taṇhānusaya mūlako. Avijjānusaya mūlakena taṇhānusaya parikkhittenāti

original: gahaṇenāti. Teneva aṭṭhakathāyaṃpi taṇhā avijjānaṃ appahīnattāti evaṃ appahīnasaddena
analyzed: gahaṇena āti tena iva aṭṭhakathāyam pi taṇhā avijjānam appahīna ttā ti evam appahīna saddena
translated: That is why in the Commentary too it is said, ‘Because craving and ignorance have not been abandoned’ .

original: ekantānusayāeva gahitāti. Saṅkhārenāti paṭisandhijanakakammasaṅkhātena cetanāsaṅkhārena.
analyzed: ekanta anusayā eva gahitā ati saṅkhārena ati paṭisandhi janaka kamma saṅkhātena cetanā saṅkhārena
translated: By the word ‘formations’ is meant the formation of volition by the formation of kamma that generates rebirth-linking.

original: Taṃ sahajātaphassādidhammasamūhenapivā. Sopi hi upanissayabhāve na paṭisandhiṃ janetiyevāti.
analyzed: tam sahajāta phassa ādi dhamma samūhena pi vā saḥ api hi upanissaya bhāve na paṭisandhim
translated: Or it is also the aggregate of states consisting of the contact associated with that, and so on. For that too generates rebirth-linking by being a decisive-support condition.

original: Athavā, saṅkhārenāti maraṇasanna javanaviññāṇa sahajātena cetanāsaṅkhārena. Taṃ sahajāta
analyzed: athavā saṅkhārena ati sahajātena cetanā saṅkhārena tam sahajāta
translated: Or alternatively, by the word ‘formations’ is meant the formation of volition associated with the death consciousness and the death impulsions.

original: phassādidhammasamūhenapivā. Tadubhayaṃpi hi kammādivisaye khipanaka saṅkhārabhāvena🔽paṭisandhiṃ janetīti. Tathā hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ taṇhā avijjānaṃ appahīnattā avijjāya🔽paṭicchāditādīnave tasmiṃ visaye taṇhā nāmeti. Sahajātasaṅkhārā khipantīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: phassa ādi dhamma samūhena pi vā tat ubhayam pi hi kamma ādi visaye saṅkhāra bhāvena  paṭisandhim janeti iti tathā hi aṭṭhakathā ayam taṇhā avijjānam appahīna ttā avijjāya  paṭicchādita ādīnave tasmin visaye taṇhā nāma iti sahajāta saṅkhārāḥ khipanti iti vuttam
translated: Or it is also the aggregate of states consisting of the contact associated with that, and so on. For both these are formations in the sense of driving in the field of kamma, and so🔽they generate rebirth-linking. That is why in the Commentary it is said, ‘Because craving and ignorance have not been abandoned, craving seeks out the object that is concealed by ignorance, and the associated formations drive it forward’ .

original: Mūlaṭīkāyañca sahajātasaṅkhārāti cutiāsannajavanaviññāṇasahajātā cetanā. Sabbepivā
analyzed: mūla ṭīkāyan ca sahajāta saṅkhārā ti cuti āsanna javana viññāṇa sahajātā cetanā
translated: And in the Root Commentary it is said, ‘Associated formations: volition associated with the death consciousness and the death impulsions. Or all the states associated with the death consciousness are formations in the sense of forming, and they are also formations in the sense of driving forward in the field of kamma. They are called “associated formations” because they are formations associated with the death consciousness’ .

original: phassādayoti vuttaṃ. Sakalena pana vacanena aggamaggena appahīnā avijjākammādivisayevā🔽bhavantarevā ādīnavaṃ paṭicchādeti, tathā rūpāyeva taṇhā tadubhayasmiṃ cittasantānaṃ🔽nāmeti. Yathāvuttasaṅkhārā taṃ tattha khipanti. Tasmiṃ abhinava viññāṇapātubhāvaṃ
analyzed: phassa ādayaḥ ti vuttam sakalena pana vacanena aggamaggena appahīnā  bhavantar eva ādīnavam paṭicchādeti tathā taṇhā tad ubhayasmin citta santānam  nāma iti yathā vutta saṅkhārā tam tattha khipanti tasmin abhinava viññāṇa pātubhāvam
translated: and so on. But by the whole statement it is ignorance, action, etc., that are not yet abandoned, which🔽conceal the danger in becoming itself, and so too craving for form, etc., which directs the continuity of consciousness🔽to that, and the formations described above, which throw it into that. The manifestation of the new consciousness🔽

original: sādhentīti dassetīti.
analyzed: sādhenti iti
translated: and so on. But by the whole statement he shows that it is ignorance, kamma, and so on, that are not yet abandoned by the noble path that conceal the danger in becoming, and that it is craving for form, etc., that leads the continuity of consciousness on to that becoming, and that the formations described above throw it into that becoming, and that the manifestation of the new consciousness in that becoming is established by that.

original: Sampayuttehi pariggayhamānanti phassādīhi sampayuttadhammehi parivāretvā gayhamānaṃ.
analyzed: sampayuttehi pariggayhamānanti phassa ādīhi sampayutta dhammehi parivāretvā gayhamānam
translated: “Is seized upon by what is associated with it”: is surrounded and seized upon by the states associated with it, that is, by contact, etc.🔽“By what is conascent with it”: by the states of mentality-materiality.

original: Sahajātānanti nāmarūpadhammānaṃ. Adhiṭṭhāna bhāvenāti nissayabhāvena. Pubbaṅgamabhūtanti
analyzed: sahajātānam ti nāma rūpa dhammānam adhiṭṭhāna bhāvena ati nissaya bhāvena pubbaṅgama bhūtam ti
translated: “By what is based upon it”: by what has it as its support.🔽“By what is prior to it”: by what is antecedent to it.

original: padhānabhūtaṃ. Pada dvayena vijānanadhātuyā ativiya mahānubhāvabhāvaṃ dasseti. Yathā
analyzed: padhāna bhūtam dvayena vijānana dhātuyā mahā anubhāva bhāvam dasseti yathā
translated: By these two phrases he shows that the consciousness element is of very great potency,

original: hi loke ekasmiṃ mahānubhāve purisavisese jāyamāne parivārabhūtā sahajātajanāca tassa
analyzed: hi loke ekasmin mahā anubhāve purisa visese jāyamāne parivāra bhūtā sahajāta janāḥ ca tassa
translated: just as in the world when a man of great potency is born, the people who are his retinue and his relations are of great potency too.

original: upabhoga paribhogabhūtā pāsādakapparukkhādayova tena saha jāyanti. Evaṃ sampadamidaṃ
analyzed: upabhoga paribhoga bhūtā pāsāda kappa rukkha ādayaḥ uva tena saha jāyanti evam sampadam idam
translated: and the palaces, mansions, trees, etc., which are the objects of his enjoyment, are born together with him. This is how it should be understood.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Bhavantarapaṭisandhānavasenāti ekasmiṃbhave niruddhe tena saha nirantaraṃ🔽katvā bhavantarassa paṭisandahana vasena. Uppajjamānameva patiṭṭhāti na purimabhave🔽uppajjitvā anirujjhitvā ṭhitibhāvena gantvā bhavantare patiṭṭhātīti adhippāyo. Na
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam bhava antara paṭisandhāna vasena ati ekasmin bhave niruddhe tena saha nirantaram  katvā bhavantarassa paṭisandahana vasena uppajjamānam eva patiṭṭhāti na purima bhave  uppajjitvā a nirujjhitvā ṭhiti bhāvena gantvā bhava antare patiṭṭhāti iti adhippāyaḥ na

translated: For this is said in the Commentaries: “In the five doors the object that has arrived at the door is present.

original: kammanimittaṃ āsannakatakammārammaṇa santatiyaṃ uppannaṃ taṃsadisañca daṭṭhabbanti.🔽Tattha yesu deyyadhammavatthūsu cetiyādīsuvā yehi satthādīhivā pubbe kammaṃ siddhaṃ.
analyzed: kamma nimittam āsanna kata kamma ārammaṇa santatiyam uppannam tad sadisam ca daṭṭhabbanti  tattha yesu deyya dhamma vatthūsu cetiya ādīsu vā yehi sattha ādīhi vā pubbe kammam siddham
translated: The sign of the kamma is what arises in the continuity of the kamma that has just been done and is similar to that.🔽Herein, the sign of the kamma is the sign of the object of the kamma, that is, of the thing given, such as a shrine, and so on, or the sign of the instrument of the kamma, such as a sword, and so on.

original: Tesaṃ paccakkhe dharamānataṃ sandhāya santatiyaṃ uppannanti vuttaṃ. Tehi sadi savatthūnaṃ🔽dharamānataṃ sandhāya taṃsadisañcāti vuttaṃ. Sadisavatthūnipi hi kammassa laddhokāsakāraṇāni
analyzed: tesam paccakkhe dharamānatam sandhāya santatiyam uppannanti vuttam tehi sadi sa vatthūnam  dharamāna tam sandhāya tat sadisam ca iti vuttam sadisa vatthūni pi hi kammassa laddha ukāsa kāraṇāni
translated: The words “arises in the continuity” are said with reference to the fact that the thing given, such as a shrine, and so on, or the instrument of the kamma, such as a sword, and so on, is still present.🔽The words “and is similar to that” are said with reference to the fact that the object of the kamma, such as a shrine, and so on, or the instrument of the kamma, such as a sword, and so on, is still present.

original: hontiyeva. Yathā taṃ ito parittakena pāpakammena niraye ussadasāmante nibbattānaṃ🔽pubbe puññakaraṇakāle laddhanimittasadisaṃ nirayaggijālānaṃ saddaṃ sutvāvā vaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: yathā tam itas parittakena pāpa kammena niraye ussada sāmante nibbattānam  pubbe puñña karaṇa kāle laddha nimitta sadisam nirayaggi jālānam saddam sutvāvā vaṇṇam
translated: For the objects of the kamma, such as a shrine, and so on, or the instruments of the kamma, such as a sword, and so on, are the cause of the opportunity for the kamma to be effective.

original: disvāvā puññaṃ saritvā cavitvā sagge nibbattānaṃ aggijālāni viyāti.
analyzed: disvāvā puññam saritvā cavitvā sagge nibbattānam aggi jālāni viyāti
translated: Just as, when people are reborn in the adjacent hells because of some bad kamma done by them here, they hear the sound of the flames of the hells or see their colour, and then, remembering the good kamma they did in the past, they die and are reborn in a heavenly world, the flames of the hells are similar to the sign they had when they were doing the good kamma.

original: [172] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī-Țīkā,

original: Mūlaṭīkāpāṭhaṃ avicāretvā taṃsadisañcātiettha naṭṭhacakāraṃ pāṭhaṃ disvā “manodvārika
analyzed: mūla ṭīkā pāṭham a vicāretvā pāṭham disvā manodvārika
translated: without examining the reading of the Mula-Țīkā, the reading “and is similar to that” is given without the negative particle na, and it is said that the words “and is similar to that” refer to the mental object of the kamma.

original: javanānaṃ ārammaṇabhūtena saha samānattā tadekasantatipatitaṃ cutiāsannajavanagahi
analyzed: ārammaṇa bhūtena saha tad eka santati patitam
translated: because of the similarity with the object of the impulsions, it is said that it is “impulsion near to death in the same continuity.”

original: taṃpi paccuppannaṃ vaṇṇādikaṃ kammanimitta bhāvena vutta”nti vuttaṃ. Taṃ anupapannameva.🔽Apica, aṭṭhakathāyaṃ aparassa maraṇasamaye ñātakā ayaṃ tāta tavatthāya buddhapūjā🔽karīyati. Cittaṃ pasādehīti vatvā pupphadāmadhajapaṭākādivasena rūpārammaṇaṃvā dhammasavanatūriyapūjādi🔽vasena saddārammaṇaṃvā dhūmavāsagandhādivasena gandhārammaṇaṃvā idaṃ tāva sāyassu,🔽tavatthāya dātabbaṃ deyyadhammanti vatvā madhuphāṇi tādivasena rasārammaṇaṃvā idaṃ
analyzed: tat pi paccuppannam vaṇṇa ādikam kamma nimitta bhāvena vuttan ti vuttam tam anupapannam eva  apica aṭṭhakathā ayam aparassa maraṇa samaye ñātakāḥ ayam tāta tavatthāya buddha pūjā  cittam pasādehi iti vatvā puppha dāma dhaja paṭāka ādi vasena rūpa ārammaṇam vā dhamma savana tūriya pūjā ādi  vasena sadda ārammaṇam vā dhūma vāsa gandha ādi vasena gandha ārammaṇam vā idam tāva sāyassu  tavatthāya dātabbam deyya dhammanti vatvā tad ādi vasena rasa ārammaṇam vā idam
translated: and because of the similarity of the state of being the object of impulsion processes, the visible-data object of the dying consciousness is said to be present, though it is included in the same continuity as the impulsion processes that are near to death and that have already occurred.🔽But this is not correct.

original: tāva phusassu, tavatthāya dātabbaṃ deyyadhammanti vatvā cīnapaṭa somārapaṭādivasena
analyzed: tāva phusassu tavatthāya dātabbam deyya dhamman ti vatvā cīnapaṭa somārapaṭa ādi vasena
translated: Moreover, in the commentary it is said that at the time of the death of the second person, relatives say to him, “Dear, this is being done for your sake. Rouse your mind to faith,” and they present to him an object consisting of visible data by means of flowers, garlands, flags, banners, etc., or an object consisting of sounds by means of the preaching of the Dhamma, the playing of musical instruments, etc., or an object consisting of odours by means of incense, scents, etc., saying, “Now be happy, dear, this is an offering to be given for your sake,” or an object consisting of flavours by means of honey, sugar, etc., saying, “Now taste this, dear, this is an offering to be given for your sake,” or an object consisting of tangible data by means of Chinese silk, Somāra cloth, etc., saying, “Now touch this, dear, this is an offering to be given for your sake.”

original: phoṭṭhabbā rammaṇaṃvā pañcadvāre upasaṃharantīti vuttaṃ. Tattha rūpasaddagandhārammaṇāni
analyzed: phoṭṭhabbāḥ rammaṇam vā pañca dvāre upasaṃharanti iti vuttam tattha rūpa sadda gandha ārammaṇāni
translated: Herein, the objects consisting of visible data, sounds, and odours

original: sandhāya ṭīkāyaṃ santatiyaṃ uppannanti vuttaṃ. Rasaphoṭṭhabbā rammaṇāni sandhāya
analyzed: sandhāya ṭīkāyam santatiyam uppannanti vuttam rasa phoṭṭhabbāḥ rammaṇāni sandhāya
translated: and in the commentary on the meaning of the word “series” it is said: “arisen in a series.”🔽and it is said: “like those” because they are agreeable in taste and touch.

original: taṃsadisañcāti vuttaṃ. Tāni hi pathamaṃ sāyita phusitāni aññāni honti. Pacchā dinnāni
analyzed: tad sadisam ca iti vuttam tāni hi pathamam sāyita phusitāni aññāni honti pacchā dinnāni
translated: For those first drunk and touched are one thing, and those given later are another.

original: aññānīti etthaca evaṃ upasaṃhaṭāni rūpārammaṇādīni pathamaṃ pañcadvārena gahetvā🔽acavitvā pacchā puna atthi dāni evarūpānīti suddhena manodvārena gahetvā cavantānaṃ
analyzed: aññāni iti ettha ca evam upasaṃhaṭāni rūpa ārammaṇa ādīni pathamam pañca dvārena gahetvā  a cavitvā pacchā puna atthi dāni evarūpāni iti suddhena manodvārena gahetvā cavantānam
translated: And here the visible-data object, etc., collected in this way are first apprehended by the five doors,

original: tāni manodvāragahitāni paccuppannabhūtāni kammanimittāni hontīti veditabbānīti. Pathamatatīyāruppa🔽paṭisandhīnaṃ paññatti bhūtaṃ dutīyacatutthāruppapaṭisandhīnaṃ mahaggatabhūtanti
analyzed: tāni manaḥ dvāra gahitāni paccuppanna bhūtāni kamma nimittāni honti iti veditabbāni iti pathama tatīya āruppa  paṭisandhīnam paññatti bhūtam dutīya catuttha āruppa paṭisandhīnam mahaggata bhūtam ti
translated: and after that, without being reflected upon, they are again apprehended by the pure mind door, thinking, “Now there are such and such,” and they should be understood as the kamma-resultant material phenomena that are apprehended by the mind door and are present at that moment.

original: vuttaṃ yathārahanti. Āruppesu uparibhūminibbattānaṃ arūpīnaṃ heṭṭhimajjhānāni paṭipassambhanti.
analyzed: vuttam yathārahanti āruppesu upari bhūmi nibbattānam arūpīnam heṭṭhimajjhānāni paṭipassambhanti
translated: The first and third kinds of rebirth-linking are described as “having as their physical basis the kinds of existence in the fine-material sphere,” and the second and fourth kinds of rebirth-linking are described as “having as their physical basis the kinds of existence in the immaterial sphere.”🔽The words “as appropriate” are said because the jhānas of the lower plane are abandoned in the case of immaterial beings born in the higher planes.

original: Na ca te tāni puna āyūhantīti vuttaṃ heṭṭhimāruppa vajjitāti. Pamādapakkhe patitvā
analyzed: na ca te tāni punar āyūhanti iti vuttam heṭṭhima āruppa vajjitā ati pamāda pakkhe patitvā
translated: and they do not again revive them. That is why it is said “except for the lower immaterial states.”

original: vissaṭṭhajjhānānaṃ tatoyevaca appahīnehi orambhāviya saṃyojanehi heṭṭhabhāgaṃ ākaḍḍhita
analyzed: vissaṭṭha jjhānānam saṃyojanehi heṭṭha bhāgam
translated: And those who have broken up their jhāna and are reborn in the lower part of the fine-material world by means of the lower fetters that have not been given up are called “those who go thus” .

original: mānasānaṃ kāmabhave uppajjamānānaṃ tesaṃ thapetvā tihetu kukkaṭṭhabhūtaṃ upacārajjhānacetanaṃ🔽aññaṃ dubbalakammaṃ okāsaṃ nalabhatīti vuttaṃ tathā kāmatihetukāti. Tathā hi aṅguttaraṭṭha
analyzed: mānasānam kāma bhave uppajjamānānam tesam thapetvā ti hetu kukkaṭṭha bhūtam upacāra jhāna cetanam  aññam dubbala kammam okāsam na labhati iti vuttam tathā kāmati hetukā iti tathā hi aṅguttaraṭṭhakathā
translated: And those who are reborn in the sense-desire world are called “those who go thus” because they have no other kamma that is strong enough to provide a rebirth-linking except the volition of access jhāna, which is like a cock’s claw .🔽For this is said in the Aṅguttara Commentary: “There is no kamma stronger than access jhāna for one who has not given up the lower fetters” .🔽And in the Paṭisambhidā Commentary: “There is no kamma stronger than that for him” .

original: kathāyaṃ-na hi tassa upacārajjhānato balavataraṃnāma kammaṃ atthīti vuttaṃ. Ṭīkāyañca🔽na hi tassa.La. Atthīti iminā tato cavantānaṃ upacārajjhānameva paṭisandhijanakaṃ
analyzed: hi tassa upacāra jhānataḥ balavataram nāma kammaṃ atthi iti vuttam ṭīkāyan ca  na hi atthi iti iminā tatas cavantānam upacāra jhānam eva paṭisandhi janakam
translated: This shows that the kamma that causes rebirth-linking in those who pass away from the access is only the access jhāna itself.🔽But they have no rebirth-linking in the fine-material sphere at all.

original: kammanti dīpetīti vuttanti. Rūpāvacarapaṭisandhi pana tesaṃ natthiyeva. Evañca katvā🔽yamakearūpadhātuyā cutassa arūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassātivā arūpa dhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātuṃ
analyzed: dīpeti iti vuttanti rūpāvacara paṭisandhi pana tesam natthiyeva evam ca katvā 🔽yamake arūpa dhātuyā cutassa arūpa dhātum upapajjantassa ativā arūpa dhātuyā cutassa kāmadhātum
translated: And when this is so, then it is proper to say that “One who has died in the fine-material or immaterial world and is being reborn in the fine-material or immaterial world” is “one who goes thus” .

original: upapajjantassātivā vuttaṃ. Na pana vuttaṃ arūpadhātuyā cutassa rūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassāti.
analyzed: upapajjantassa ativā vuttam na pana vuttam arūpadhātuyā cutassa rūpadhātum upapajjantassa ati
translated: Or it is said that he reappears in the fine-material sphere. But it is not said that he reappears in the fine-material sphere after dying in the immaterial sphere.🔽But when they die in the fine-material sphere, no other weak kamma finds an opportunity to make them reappear here.

original: Rūpa lokato cavantānaṃ pana aññaṃ dubbalakammaṃ okāsaṃ nalabhatīti navattabbaṃ. Evaṃsantepi
analyzed: rūpa lokato cavantānam pana aññam dubbala kammam okāsam na labhati iti na vattabbam evam sante pi
translated: Even though it is so,

original: suṭṭhu vikkhambhitanīvaraṇānaṃ tesaṃ appanā pattajjhānavisesena suparibhāvitacittasantānattā
analyzed: suṭṭhu vikkhambhita nīvaraṇānam tesam appanā patta jhāna visesena su paribhāvita citta santāna ttā
translated: their continuity of consciousness is well developed by the jhāna that has reached absorption and has well suppressed the hindrances.

original: jaccandhādivipatti janakaṃ dvihetukomakakammaṃpi okāsaṃ na labhati. Kuto apāyagāmikammanti
analyzed: jat candha ādi vipatti janakam okāsam na labhati kutas apāya gāmi kammanti
translated: So no kamma that would make them reappear in the lower realms finds an opportunity, much less kamma that would make them go to the unhappy destinations.

original: vuttaṃ ahetuka rahitā siyunti.
analyzed: vuttam siyunti
translated: So it is said that they are without kamma that is without root cause.

original: [173] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī-ṭīkā,

original: “Upacārajjhānā nubhāveneva duhetuka tihetuka paṭisandhiyo siyu”nti vuttaṃ. Taṃ vicāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: upacāra jhāna anubhāvena iva du hetuka ti hetuka paṭisandhiyaḥ siyun ti vuttam tat vicāretabbam
translated: it is said that they have rebirth-linking with two or three roots according to the predominance of access jhāna. That should be investigated.

original: Yadi hi taṃ paṭisandhidānaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ siyā. Duhetukapaṭi sandhi na yujjati.
analyzed: yadi hi tam paṭisandhi dānam sandhāya vuttam siyā du hetuka paṭi sandhi na yujjati
translated: For if it is said with reference to the giving of rebirth-linking, rebirth-linking with two roots is not logical.

original: Na hi suṭṭhu vikkhambhitanīvaraṇānaṃ appanāvīthiyaṃ pavattaṃ upacārajjhānaṃ tihetukomakaṃnāma
analyzed: na hi suṭṭhu vikkhambhita nīvaraṇānam appanā vīthiyam pavattam upacāra jjhānam ti hetu komakam nāma
translated: For access jhāna, which has well suppressed the hindrances, does not have two roots.

original: sambhavatīti. Atha kammantarassa upatthambhanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ siyā. Sayaṃ balavatarassapi
analyzed: sambhavati iti atha kammantarassa upatthambhanam sandhāya vuttam siyā sayam balavatarassa api
translated: Or it may be said that it is stated with reference to the support of the other kamma.

original: sato paṭisandhiṃ adatvā dubbalassa kammantarassa upatthambhane kāraṇaṃ natthīti.
analyzed: sataḥ paṭisandhim a datvā dubbalassa kammantarassa upatthambhane kāraṇam natthi iti
translated: But there is no reason for the support of the other kamma, which is weaker, without giving rebirth-linking to one who is stronger himself.

original: Yasmā pana rūpabrahmānaṃ upacārajjhānato aññānipi kāyavacīmanokammakusalāni uppajjantiyeva
analyzed: yasmai pana rūpa brahmānam upacāra jjhānato aññāni pi kāya vacī manaḥ kamma kusalāni uppajjantiyā iva
translated: But because the wholesome kamma of body, speech, and mind arises in the fine-material Brahmās other than those who are in access concentration,

original: tāniyevaca kānici tihetukomakānipi kānici dvihetukukkaṭṭhānipi bhavanti. Oḷārikānaṃ🔽pana nīvaraṇānaṃ suṭṭhu vikkhambhitattā savipattikapaṭi sandhijanakāni dvihetukomakāni🔽tesaṃ nuppajjanti. Aparapariyāya bhūtānica tādisāni tesaṃ okāsaṃ nalabbhanti. Nānārammaṇesuca
analyzed: kānici ti hetu komakāni pi kānici dvi hetu kukkaṭṭhāni pi bhavanti oḷārikānam  pana nīvaraṇānam suṭṭhu vikkhambhita ttā sa vipattika paṭi sandhi janakāni dvi hetu komakāni  tesam nuppajjanti apara pariyāya bhūtāni ca tādisāni tesam okāsam na labbhanti nānā ārammaṇesu ca
translated: and because some of them have two roots and some have three roots, and some🔽are strong and some weak, and because the gross hindrances are well suppressed in them, they do not arise with the two roots and the three roots that produce rebirth-linking with conflict.🔽And the kinds of kamma that are similar to them do not get an opportunity in the next becoming.🔽And in them desire and lust occur only in regard to the various objects,

original: nesaṃ chandovā nikantivā pavattatiyeva. Yena nānākammānipi vipaccituṃ okāsaṃ labhanti.
analyzed: na isam chando vā nikanti vā yena nānā kammāni api vipaccitum okāsam labhanti
translated: by means of which the various kinds of kamma get an opportunity to come to fruition.

original: Yenaca te cakkhu sotadvārehipi tato cavanti. Tasmā ettha upacārajjhānena kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: yena ca te cakkhu tato cavanti tasmai ettha upacāra jhānena kāraṇam
translated: And by means of which they pass away from the eye and ear doors. Therefore the access concentration is not the cause here.

original: avatvā vuttanayeneva taṃkāraṇaṃ vattuṃ yuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kāmatihetumhā cutiyā🔽paraṃ sabbā vīsati paṭisandhiyo siyuṃ. Itarā duhetukāhetukacutito paraṃ kāmesveva🔽bhavesu dasapaṭisandhiyo siyunti yojanā. Evaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe visayappavattiyā saha
analyzed: a vatvā vutta nayena iva tat kāraṇam vattum yuttam ti daṭṭhabbam kāmati hetumhā cutiyā  param sabbāḥ vīsati paṭisandhiyaḥ siyuṃ itarāḥ du hetuka ahetuka cutitaḥ param kāmesu eva  bhavesu dasa paṭisandhiyaḥ siyun ti yojanā evam paṭisandhi khaṇe visaya pavattiyā saha
translated: and it should be understood that it is proper to state the reason in the way already stated.🔽All the twenty kinds of rebirth-linking would be after death as a result of a cause.🔽The other ten kinds of rebirth-linking would be in the sensual-desire becoming after death as a result of a cause and as a result of no cause.

original: vīthimuttacittānaṃ pavattākāraṃ dassetvā idāni pavattikāle paraṃparabhavesuca dassetuṃ
analyzed: vīthi mutta cittānam pavatta ākāram dassetvā idāni pavatti kāle paraṃpara bhavesu ca dassetum
translated: So the method should be applied. Having thus shown the way in which the kinds of consciousness that are outside the cognitive series occur at the moment of rebirth-linking together with the occurrence of the objective fields, he now said, “If … then” in order to show the occurrence in the cognitive series and in the other kinds of becoming.

original: iccevantiādimāha. Paṭisandhinirodhānantaratoti paṭisandhiyā nirodhassa bhaṅgassa🔽anantarakālato. Tamevacittanti tassadise tabbohāro daṭṭhabbo. Yathā tāniyeva osadhānīti.
analyzed: iccā iva iti ādim āha paṭisandhi nirodha anantarato ti paṭisandhiyā nirodhassa bhaṅgassa  anantara kālataḥ tam eva cittam ti tad sadise tad ohāraḥ daṭṭhabbo yathā tāniyā iva osadhāni iti
translated: After the cessation of the rebirth-linking: after the cessation, the dissolution, of the rebirth-linking.🔽That same kind of consciousness: the same kind of consciousness should be regarded as the rebirth-linking. As the same herbs,

original: Yāva cuticittuppādāti ettha cutiggahaṇena tadāsanna vīthicittānampi gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: yāva cuti citta uppādā ti ettha cuti ggahaṇena tad āsanna vīthi cittānam pi gahaṇam daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: As long as the death consciousness has not arisen: here the death consciousness should be understood as including the kinds of consciousness in the cognitive series that are proximate to it.

original: Asati vīthicittuppādeti antarantarā vīthicittānaṃ uppattiyā asati. Bhavassaaṅgabhāvenāti
analyzed: asati vīthi citta uppāde iti antar antarā vīthi cittānam uppattiyāḥ asati
translated: If there is no occurrence of the kinds of consciousness in the cognitive series: if there is no occurrence of the kinds of consciousness in the cognitive series in between. As a factor of becoming: as a factor of the kind of becoming in which the rebirth-linking occurs.

original: upapattibhavassa aviccheda kāraṇabhāvena. Tasmiṃti avattamāne pacchājātapaccayarahitānaṃ
analyzed: upapatti bhavassa aviccheda kāraṇa bhāvena tasmin ti avattamāne pacchājāta paccaya rahitānam
translated: Because it is the cause of the non-interruption of rebirth-linking. In the absence of that,

original: rūpadhammānaṃ vassodaka rahitānaṃ taruṇasassānaṃ viya milāta bhāvapattiyā upapattibhavo🔽occhijjatīti. Cuticittaṃ hutvā nirujjhati tameva cittanti sambandho. Yathākkamaṃ
analyzed: rūpa dhammānam vassa udaka rahitānam taruṇa sassānam viya milāta bhāva pattiyā upapatti bhavaḥ  occhijjati iti cuti cittam hutvā nirujjhati tam eva cittam iti sambandhaḥ yathākkamam
translated: rebirth-linking is cut off, like the crops in the absence of rain.🔽The meaning is that it is cut off, it ceases, as the death consciousness.🔽They revolve and occur in order,

original: eva parivattantā pavattantīti yāva parinibbānacutiyā yathākkamaṃ parivattantā pavattantieva.
analyzed: eva parivattantā pavattanti iti yāva parinibbāna cutiyā yathākkamam parivattantā pavattanti eva
translated: The meaning is that they revolve and occur in order until death-consciousness at the end of the life-span.

original: Na pana parasamaye viya kadāci katthaci nivattiṃ pāpuṇantīti attho.
analyzed: na pana para samaye viya kadāci katthaci nivattim pāpuṇanti iti atthaḥ
translated: But they do not come to a stop at any time or place, as they do at the time of the dissolution of the world.

original: [174] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhānga it is said,
