analyzed: vuttā nanu sā mudu bhūtā api hoti iti saccam mudu bhūtā api pana sā sesa bhūtattayam upādāya
translated: Is it not also found soft? It is true that it is found soft, but it is reckoned as hard because of the other three great primaries.

original: kakkhaḷā tveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati. Aññamaññaṃ upādāyeva pana ayaṃmudu ayaṃ kakkhaḷāti
analyzed: kakkhaḷā tu eva saṅkhyam gacchati aññam aññam upādāya iva pana ayam mudu ayam kakkhaḷā ati
translated: And it is only in relation to each other that these are soft or hard.

original: bhavati. Teneva mudukakkhaḷānaṃ dīgharassānaṃ viya anavaṭṭhānatā hoti. Mudubhūtāpi
analyzed: bhavati tena iva mudu kakkhaḷānam dīgha rassānam viya anavaṭṭhāna tā hoti mudu bhūtā api
translated: and so they are not turned back, as are soft and hard, long and short.

original: hi tato mudutaraṃ patvā kakkhaḷānāma jātā. Kakkhaḷāpi kakkhaḷataraṃ patvā mudubhūtānāma🔽jātāti. Ābandhanalakkhaṇo āpoti vutto. Soca pakatiudake adhimattoti pakatiudakaṃ
analyzed: hi tatas mudutaram patvā kakkhaḷā nāma jātā kakkhaḷā api kakkhaḷataram patvā mudubhūtā nāma  jātā ati ābandhana lakkhaṇo āpo ti vutto so ca pakati udake adhimatto ti pakati udakam
translated: and so it is not fixed as to softness and hardness, as to length and shortness. For although it is soft, it becomes softer still and so it is born as long; and although it is hard, it becomes harder still and so it is born as short.🔽The characteristic of binding is stated as that of water. But if it is excessive in ordinary water, then the ordinary water will be bound and become solid.

original: baddhaṃ ghanībhūtameva siyāti ce. Na. Ābandhitabbāya pathaviyā tattha paridubbalattāti,
analyzed: baddham ghanībhūtam eva siyā ati ce na ābandhitabbāya pathaviyā tattha paridubbala ttā ati
translated: —No; because the earth to be bound is weak there.

original: yattha pana pathavī balavatī hoti tattheva so baddhataraṃ ābandhatīti. Uṇhatta lakkhaṇo
analyzed: yattha pana pathavī balavatī hoti tattha iva so baddhataram ābandhati iti uṇhatta lakkhaṇo
translated: But where the earth is strong, there the binding is stronger.🔽The characteristic of heat is stated as that of fire.

original: tejoti vutto. Evañcasati sītabhāvo tejoyeva na siyāti ce. Na. Usati dahati paripāceti
analyzed: tejaḥ ti vuttaḥ na siyāti ce na usati dahati paripāca iti
translated: But if that is so, then the state of cold will not be fire.🔽—No; for it is called “heat” because it burns, cooks, ripens, and brings to consummation;

original: pariṇa tabhāvaṃ gametīti uṇhonāma. Sītabhāvoca dahati paripāceti tabbhāvaṃ gametiyevāti.
analyzed: pariṇa ta bhāvam gama iti iti dahati paripāca iti tad bhāvam
translated: and the state of cold burns, cooks, ripens, and brings to consummation too.

original: Vuttañca mūlaṭīkāyaṃ tejoeva hi sītaṃ. Himapātasamayādīsu sītassa paripācakatādassana
analyzed: vuttam ca mūla ṭīkāyam hi sītam hima pāta samaya ādīsu sītassa
translated: And it is said in the commentary: “For fire is cold too. For the ripening of cold is seen in the cold season, etc.,

original: toti. Vitthambhana lakkhaṇo vāyoti vutto. So pana ghana thaddhesu silāthambhādīsu
analyzed: toti vitthambhana lakkhaṇo vāyo ti vutto so pana ghana thaddhesu silā thambha ādīsu
translated: Or it is said to be “that which causes distension.” But that is not found in such things as a stone pillar, which are solid and compact.

original: nalabbhatīti ce. Na. Tattha hi pathavī attanā sahajātavāyuvitthambhanaṃ labhitvā
analyzed: na labbhati iti ce na tattha hi pathavī sahajāta vāyu vitthambhanam labhitvā
translated: If it be said: “No, for there the earth, having obtained the distension of the co-arisen air,🔽is steadied and becomes more firmly established and so it supports,”

original: thāmappattā thiratarappattāca hutvā vahatīti. Cakkhatīti cakkhu. Samavisamaṃ ācikkhati
analyzed: thāma ppattā thiratara ppattā ca hutvā vahati iti cakkhati iti cakkhu sama visamam ācikkhati
translated: it is the eye because it sees what is equal and unequal.

original: samavisamajānanassa tammūlakattā. Rūpaṃvā assādeti āpātaṃ āgatāgatassa rūpassa anirākaraṇato.
analyzed: sama visama jānanassa tad mūlakattā rūpam vā assādeti āpātam āgata āgatassa rūpassa a nirākaraṇato
translated: It is the root of the knowledge of what is equal and unequal. Or it is the eye because it delights in visible form, since it does not reject visible forms as they come into the visual field.

original: Taṃvā vibhāvetīti attho. Suṇātīti sotaṃ. Suṇanti suyyantivā ete nāti sotaṃ. Ghāyatīti
analyzed: tam vā vibhāveti iti attho suṇāti iti sotam suṇanti ete na ati sotam ghāyati iti
translated: The meaning is that it distinguishes them. It is the ear because it hears. It is the ear because these sounds are heard by it, or because it hears them. It is the nose because it smells.

original: ghānaṃ. Ghāyanti ghāyiyantivā etenāti ghānaṃ. Jīvitanimittaṃ raso jīvitanti vuccati.🔽Tasmiṃ ninnatāya taṃ avhāyatīti jivhā. Athavā. Jīvitaṃ vahati etāyavā taṃ vahanti
analyzed: ghānam ghāyanti etena ati ghānam jīvita nimittam rasaḥ jīvitanti vuccati  tasmin ninna tāya tam avhāyati iti jivhā athavā jīvitam vahati tam vahanti
translated: It is the nose because smells are smelt by it, or because it smells them. Taste is called “life” because it is the cause of life.🔽It is the tongue because it is bent on that. Or alternatively, it is the tongue because it conveys life, or because it conveys the two,

original: pavattenti jīvitavuttisampādanattāti jivhā. Jītivā jayo parājayovā vuccati. Tadubhayaṃ
analyzed: pavattenti jīvita vutti sampādana ttā ati jivhā jītivā vuccati tat ubhayam
translated: victory and defeat. Victory is called “life” and defeat is called “life” too.

original: vahati vahantivā etāyāti jivhā. Sasambhārajivhā. Yathāha –
analyzed: vahati vahantivā etā āyāti jivhā sa sambhāra jivhā yathā āha
translated: It conveys , it causes to be conveyed , thus it is the tongue . The tongue with its concomitant . As it is said:🔽When a man is born, a knife

original: Purisassa hi jātassa, kudārī jāyate mukhe;
analyzed: purisassa hi jātassa kudārī jāyate mukhe
translated: Is born in his mouth, with which

original: Yāya chindati attānaṃ, naro dubbhāsitaṃ bhaṇanti.🔽Idha pana taṃ sahacaritattā jivhāti pasādarūpamo vuccati. Kucchitānaṃ kesādīnaṃ pāpadhammānañca
analyzed: yāya chindati attānam naraḥ dubbhāsitam bhaṇanti  idha pana tam sahacarita ttā jivhāti pasāda rūpamaḥ vuccati kucchitānam kesa ādīnam pāpa dhammānam ca
translated: He cuts himself, speaking evil words.🔽Here, however, it is the sensitive matter called “tongue” that is intended, which is classed as derived materiality.🔽The body is the source of the foulness beginning with head hairs, etc.,

original: āyo uppattiṭṭhānanti kāyo. Sasambhārakāyo. Idha pana taṃ sahacarito pasāda kāyoeva🔽adhippeto. Pasīdantīti pasādā. Pasīdanti vā ettha candamaṇḍalādīni ārammaṇanimittāni
analyzed: āyo uppatti ṭṭhāna nti kāyo sa sambhāra kāyo idha pana tam sahacaritaḥ pasāda kāyo eva  pasīdanti iti pasādā pasīdanti vā ettha canda maṇḍala ādīni ārammaṇa nimittāni
translated: and of evil states. The body with its concomitant . Here, however, the sensitive matter called “body” is intended, which is classed as derived materiality.🔽The sensitive matter is sensitive matter because it is sensitive . Or alternatively, the sensitive matter is sensitive matter because the moon’s orb, etc., as object signs, are sensitive there, are melted there, as it were, and appear in their own form.

original: tattha saṃsīdamānāni viya sarūpato sandissantīti pasādā, suparisuddhaādāsamaṇḍasadisā🔽kammajamaṇḍā. Ime pana pañca daṭṭhukāmatādi nidāna kammasamuṭṭhāna bhūtapasāda lakkhaṇā
analyzed: tattha saṃsīdamānāni viya sarūpataḥ sandissanti iti pasādā su parisuddha ādāsa maṇḍa sadisā  kamma ja maṇḍāḥ ime pana pañca daṭṭhu kāma tā ādi nidāna kamma samuṭṭhāna bhūta pasāda lakkhaṇā
translated: The sensitive matter is a circle of sensitive matter that is classed as kamma-born and is like a very pure polished shell.🔽These five kinds of sensitive matter beginning with the eye should be regarded as having the characteristic of sensitive matter consisting of primary elements that is originated by kamma and is the basis for the apprehension of visible data, etc., or as having the characteristic of sensitive matter consisting of primary elements that is the basis for the apprehension of visible data, etc.

original: rūpādi abhighātāraha bhūtapasādalakkhaṇā vā cakkhupasādādayo daṭṭhabbā. Tattha cakkhu
analyzed: rūpa ādi bhūta pasāda lakkhaṇā vā cakkhu pasāda ādayaḥ daṭṭhabbā tattha cakkhu
translated: Herein, the eye

original: tāva setamaṇḍala parikkhittassa kaṇhamaṇḍalassa majjhe ūkāsirapamāṇe atimukhe ṭhitānaṃ🔽sarīrasaṇṭhānuppatti padesabhūte diṭṭhamaṇḍale telamiva sattapicupaṭalāni sattaakkhipaṭalāni🔽byāpetvā tiṭṭhati. Sotaṃ sotabilabbhantare aṅguliveṭhanākāraṃ upacitatanutambalomaṃ
analyzed: tāva seta maṇḍala parikkhittassa kaṇha maṇḍalassa majjhe atimukhe ṭhitānam  sarīra saṇṭhāna uppatti padesa bhūte diṭṭha maṇḍale telam iva satta picu paṭalāni satta akkhi paṭalāni  byāpetvā tiṭṭhati sotam sota bila bbhantare aṅguliveṭhana ākāram upacita tanu tamba lomam
translated: In the middle of the dark circle enclosed by the white circle, in the eye’s aperture, which is the size of a louse’s resting-place,🔽it is to be found spread out like oil over the circle that is seen, which is the location for the appearance of the shape of the body. The ear is the shape of a finger-guard for the fourth finger. It is to be found spread out over the location inside the ear-holes.

original: padesaṃ byāpetvā tiṭṭhati. Ghānaṃ nāsikabbhantare ajapadasaṇṭhānaṃ padesaṃ byāpetvā🔽tiṭṭhati. Jivhā sasambhāra jivhāmajjhe uppala dalagga saṇṭhānaṃ padesaṃ byāpetvā🔽tiṭṭhati. Kāyo pana mahanti yā kappāsa paṭalavaṭṭiyaṃ āsittatelaṃviya thapetvā pācaka
analyzed: padesam byāpetvā tiṭṭhati ghānam nāsikā abbhantare aja pada saṇṭhānam padesam byāpetvā  tiṭṭhati jivhā sa sambhāra jivhā majjhe uppala dalagga saṇṭhānam padesam byāpetvā  tiṭṭhati kāyo pana mahanti yā thapetvā
translated: The nose is the shape of a bird’s nest. It is to be found spread out over the location inside the nostrils.🔽The tongue is the shape of a rice-holding tray’s lid. It is to be found spread out over the location in the middle of the mouth.

original: tejassa patiṭṭhānaṭṭhānaṃ kesagga lomagga nakhagga sukkhacammānica avasesaṃ sakalasarīraṃ
analyzed: tejassa patiṭṭhāna ṭhānam avasesam sakala sarīram
translated: The body is the shape of the body’s outline. It is to be found spread out over the whole body except for the locations of the head hairs, body hairs, teeth, nails, and the hard dry skin of the buttocks.

original: byāpetvā tiṭṭhatīti. Te pana pañca yathārahaṃ pañcadvārikacittānaṃ vatthudvārabhāvaṃ
analyzed: byāpetvā tiṭṭhati iti te pana pañca yathāraham pañcadvārika cittānam vatthu dvāra bhāvam
translated: And these five are the door for the five consciousnesses that occur as appropriate.

original: sādhenti. Tesuca ekekassa catasso catasso dhātuyo sandhāraṇaābandhana paripācana
analyzed: sādhenti tesu ca ekekassa catassaḥ catassaḥ dhātuyaḥ sandhāraṇa ābandhana paripācana
translated: They help by supporting, binding together, maturing, and

original: samudīraṇa kiccehi upakāraṃ karonti. Yathākhatti yakumārassa catasso dhātiyo dhāraṇa🔽nahāpana maṇḍana bījana kiccehīti. Utucittāhārāca naṃ upatthambhenti. Yathā taṃ khattiyakumāraṃ🔽pitu jeṭṭhabhātu jeṭṭhabhaginiyoviya. Āyuca naṃ suṭṭhu anupāleti. Yathā taṃ khattiyakumāraṃ
analyzed: samudīraṇa kiccehi upakāram karonti yathākhatti ya kumārassa catassaḥ dhātiyaḥ dhāraṇa  nahāpana maṇḍana bījana kiccehi iti utu citta āhārāḥ ca naṃ upatthambhenti yathā tam khattiya kumāram  jeṭṭha bhātu jeṭṭha bhaginiyo viyaḥ nam suṭṭhu anupāleti yathā tam khattiya kumāram
translated: distending the four primary elements in each of them. They are like the four nurses of a noble youth who help him by supporting, bathing,🔽anointing, and bringing up. The temperature, consciousness, and nutriment maintain them. They are like the father and the elder brother and the elder sister of the noble youth🔽who maintain him. Life preserves them well. They are like the chief of the guild, the king, or the most eminent man in the city who preserves the noble youth

original: disāpāmokkho rājasammato mahābhisakkoviya. Vaṇṇādayoca naṃ parivārenti. Yathā taṃ
analyzed: disāpāmokkhaḥ rāja sammataḥ vaṇṇa ādayaḥ ca nam parivārenti yathā tam
translated: well. And the colour, etc., surround them. They are like the sons of the ministers who are the noble youth’s companions.

original: khattiyakumāraṃ sahajātā amaccaputtā viyāti. Yasmā pana sattānaṃ cittaṃ nāma vicittaṃ🔽hoti. Cittavicittatāya saññāvicittā. Saññāvicittatāya taṇhāvicittā. Taṇhāvicitta
analyzed: khattiya kumāram sahajātāḥ amacca puttāḥ viyāti yasmā pana sattānam cittam nāma vicittam  hoti citta vicitta tāya saññā vicittā saññā vicitta tāya taṇhā vicittā taṇhā vicitta
translated: But because beings’ consciousness is various,

original: tāya kammāni vicittāni. Kammavicittatāya kammasamuṭṭhānāni bhūtāni vicittāni. Bhūtavicittatāya
analyzed: tāya kammāni vicittāni kamma vicitta tāya kamma samuṭṭhānāni bhūtāni vicittāni bhūta vicitta tāya
translated: their perceptions are various because of the variety of consciousness. Because of the variety of perceptions, their craving is various. Because of the variety of craving, their volitions are various. Because of the variety of volitions, the primary elements produced by kamma are various. Because of the variety of the primary elements, the derived materiality derived from them is various.

original: ime pasādā vicittā. Aññamaññaṃ asadisā honti. Tehi pasādamaṇḍabhūtāpi samānā keci
analyzed: ime pasādāḥ vicittāḥ aññam aññam asadisāḥ honti tehi pasāda maṇḍa bhūtā api samānā keci
translated: These kinds of confidence are various, not the same as each other. Although they are all kinds of confidence, some are capable of being affected by visible data, not by sounds, etc.,

original: rūpasseva abhighātārahā honti, na saddādīnaṃ. Keci saddādīnaṃ eva, na rūpassāti.
analyzed: rūpassa iva abhighāta arahāḥ honti na sadda ādīnam keci sadda ādīnam eva na rūpassa ati
translated: while others are capable of being affected by sounds, etc., not by visible data.

original: Tasmā tesaṃ aññamaññañca aññarūpehica lakkhaṇato asaṃmissatā veditabbāti.
analyzed: tasmā tesam aññam aññam ca añña rūpehi ca lakkhaṇato a saṃmissa tā veditabbā ati
translated: So their individual essences should be understood as unmixed, both as between themselves and as between each other and the kinds of materiality.

original: Rūpayatīti rūpaṃ. Vaṇṇavisesaṃ āpajjitvā hadayaṅgatabhāvaṃ pakāseti. Pakatiyāpi vā🔽yaṃkiñcidabbaṃ samavisamaṃvā pakāse tīti attho. Sappati sotaviññeyyabhāvaṃ gacchatīti🔽saddo. Saddayatīti saddo. Taṃ taṃ atthaṃvā attano vatthuṃvā ācikkhatīti attho. Sadativā🔽taṃ taṃ disaṃvā desaṃvā khaṇena vissarati vippharatīti saddo. Gandhayatīti gandho.
analyzed: rūpayati iti rūpam vaṇṇa visesam āpajjitvā hadayaṅgata bhāvam pakāseti vā  yat kiñcid abbam sama visamam vā pakāse ti iti attho sappati sota viññeyya bhāvam gacchati iti  saddo saddayati iti saddo tam tam attham vā attanaḥ vatthum vā ācikkhati iti attho sadati vā  tam tam disam vā desam vā khaṇena vissarati vippharati iti saddaḥ gandhayati iti gandhaḥ
translated: It distorts , thus it is materiality . It makes manifest the state of being in the heart by assuming a special colour. Or the meaning is that it makes manifest any object, whether equal or unequal to it.🔽It is sounded , thus it is sound . It is sounded in the ear, thus it is sound. It sounds , thus it is sound . The meaning is that it announces this or that meaning or its own physical basis. Or alternatively,🔽it sounds in this or that direction or place, thus it is sound . It smells , thus it is odour .

original: Attano vatthuṃsūcetīti attho. Gacchatīti go. Vāto. Tena dhārīyatīti gandho. Rasīyati
analyzed: attanaḥ vatthuṃsūceti iti atthaḥ gacchati iti goḥ vāto tena dhārīyati iti gandhaḥ rasīyati
translated: The meaning is that it indicates its own physical basis. It goes , thus it is a goer . Wind. It is borne by that, thus it is odour . It is savoured , thus it is flavour .

original: assādīyatīti raso. Rasantivā taṃ assādentīti raso. Phusīyatīti phoṭṭhabbaṃ. Phusanañcettha
analyzed: assādīyati iti rasaḥ tam assādenti iti rasaḥ phusīyati iti phoṭṭhabbam phusanam ca ittha
translated: It is savoured, thus it is flavour . Or alternatively, it is savoured by that, thus it is flavour . It is touched, thus it is tangible datum . Herein,

original: pasādena saha ghaṭṭanaṃ kalāpantarabhūtehi saddhiṃ paṭihananañca veditabbaṃ. Tadubhayaṃpi🔽āpo dhātuyā natthīti vuttaṃ āpodhātuvivajjitanti. Kasmā pana taṃ tassā natthi. Nanu
analyzed: pasādena saha ghaṭṭanam kalāpa antara bhūtehi saddhim paṭihananañca veditabbam tat ubhayam pi  āpaḥ dhātuyā natthi iti vuttam āpaḥ dhātu vivajjitan ti kasmā pana tam tassā natthi nanu
translated: touching is to be understood as the impact of the elements of fluidity and heat, and contact as the impact of the elements of cohesion and impact with what is inside the body and with what is outside it. Both these kinds of impact🔽are absent in the water element, which is why it is said, “Excluding the water element.” But why is it absent in that? Is it not felt when cold or hot water is drunk?

original: sītatāvā dravatāvā phusitvā gayhatīti. Vuccate, sītatā hi tejoyeva, na āpo. Yadi🔽hi sā āpoyeva siyā. Pakkumite santatte loharasepissa sītatā labbhamānā siyā. So hi
analyzed: sīta tāvā drava tāvā phusitvā gayhati iti vuccate sīta tā hi na āpaḥ yadi  hi sā siyā pakku mite santatte loha rase pi sīta tā labbhamānā siyā saḥ hi
translated: It is heat that is felt as cold or hot, not water. For if it were water that were felt, then it would be felt in molten copper, which is full of water.🔽That liquid is full of water. But that is not so. Therefore it is heat, not water.

original: raso āpādhiko hotīti. Evaṃ pana nalabbhati. Tasmā sā tejoyeva, na āpoti. Apica, sītuṇhānaṃ🔽ekasmiṃ kalāpe saha appavattanato orapārānaṃ viya tesaṃ anavaṭṭhānatoca viññāyati.
analyzed: rasaḥ hoti iti evam pana na labbhati tasmā sā tejoyā iva na āpo ti apica  ekasmin kalāpe saha appavattanato viya tesam anavaṭṭhānato ca viññāyati
translated: Besides, it can be inferred from the fact that cold and heat do not occur together in the same lump that they do not occur together in the water element.

original: Na hi sītakalāpe uṇhaṃ, uṇhakalāpevā sītaṃ saha pavattati. Yasmiṃca vatthumhi pubbe
analyzed: na hi sīta kalāpe uṇham uṇha kalāpe vā sītam saha pavattati yasmin ca vatthumhi pubbe
translated: For cold and heat do not occur together in the same lump, just as the near and the far sides of the same thing do not.🔽And it can be inferred from the fact that cold and heat are not found in the same physical basis that they do not occur together in the water element.

original: sītasaññā saṇṭhāti. Pacchā tato sītatare āgate tasmiṃyeva puna uṇhasaññā saṇṭhāti.
analyzed: sīta saññā saṇṭhāti pacchā tatas sītatare āgate tasmin yeva puna uṇha saññā saṇṭhāti
translated: and the perception of heat subsides. Later, when heat is applied again, the perception of heat subsides.🔽The same method applies to the perception of cold and the perception of heat.

original: Pubbe uṇhasaññāyaṃpi eseva nayo. Tathā uṇhe mande sītasaññā saṇṭhāti. Sīte mande uṇhasaññāti.
analyzed: pubbe uṇha saññāyam pi esa iva nayo tathā uṇhe mande sīta saññā saṇṭhāti sīte mande uṇha saññā ati
translated: And when the heat is slight, the perception of cold is strong, and when the cold is slight, the perception of heat is strong.

original: Atha pana dravabhāvabhūto āpo phusitvā gayhati. Ayo piṇḍādīsu ābandhanabhūtopi phusitvāva
analyzed: atha pana drava bhāva bhūtaḥ āpaḥ phusitvā gayhati piṇḍa ādīsu ābandhana bhūtaḥ api
translated: But when water in the liquid state is touched, it is felt. And iron, etc., in the state of a lump is felt when touched.

original: gayheyya. Evañca sati yathā tesu itarāni tīṇi bhūtāni vinā itarītarena visuṃ visuṃ🔽kāyika sukhadukkhānaṃ ārammaṇabhūtāni honti. Tathā sopi vinā itarehi visuṃ kāyikasukhadukkhānaṃ
analyzed: evam ca sati yathā tesu itarāni tīṇi bhūtāni vinā itarītarena visum visum  kāyika sukha dukkhānaṃ ārammaṇa bhūtāni honti tathā saḥ api vinā itarehi visum kāyika sukha dukkhānaṃ
translated: If that were so, then just as the other three elements are the objects of tactile consciousness separately and not together,🔽so this element too would be the object of tactile consciousness separately and not together. But that is not so.

original: ārammaṇabhūtoeva siyā. Na pana hoti. Yañhi tāni ayopiṇḍādīni phusantānaṃ kāyikaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇa bhūtaḥ eva siyā na pana hoti yat hi tāni ayaḥ piṇḍa ādīni phusantānam kāyikam
translated: For when those things such as iron lumps, etc., are touched, the bodily pleasure or pain that arises does so by virtue of the softness or hardness,

original: sukhaṃvā dukkhaṃvā uppajjati, taṃ saṇhathaddhatā vasenavā uppajjati. Sītuṇhatāvasenavā
analyzed: sukham vā dukkham vā uppajjati tam saṇhathaddha tā vasena vā uppajjati sītuṇha tā vasena vā
translated: by virtue of the coolness or heat, by virtue of the sluggishness or quickness of the internal cohesion.

original: abbhantarathambhanassa mandagāḷhatāvasenavā. No aññathāti. Tasmā purimabhāge tīṇi
analyzed: abbhantara thambhanassa no aññathā ati tasmā purima bhāge tīṇi
translated: It does not arise in any other way. Therefore, in the first part of the sutta, the Blessed One said that the four primary elements are the object of tactile consciousness.

original: bhūtāni phusitvāvā vaṇṇaṃ disvāvā pacchā bhāge suddhena mano viññāṇasantānena dīgharassādisaṇṭhānaṃvā🔽rattiyaṃ alātacakkaṃ vā taṃtaṃchiddavivaraṃvā jānantā viya pathamaṃ dravatāsahitāni
analyzed: bhūtāni phusitvā vā vaṇṇam disvā vā pacchā bhāge suddhena manaḥ viññāṇa santānena dīgha rassa ādi saṇṭhānam vā  rattiyam alāta cakkam vā pathamam drava tā sahitāni
translated: Having touched the primary elements or having seen the colour, afterwards they know the shape as long, short, etc., by means of a pure mental consciousness.

original: vilīnāni mudūni tīṇi bhūtāni pathaviṃ eva vā phusitvā pacchā suddhena mano viññāṇasantānena
analyzed: vilīnāni mudūni tīṇi bhūtāni pathavim eva vā phusitvā pacchā suddhena manaḥ viññāṇa santānena
translated: Just as, in the dark of the night, they know a whirling firebrand as a wheel or a net of bells as a continuous sound, so too, having first touched the three primary elements together with the fluidity, or the earth element alone, afterwards they know the fluidity, the moistness, by means of a pure mental consciousness.🔽Though that is so, still they think, “We know by touching,” because they are not discerning.

original: visuṃ dravabhāvaṃ addatintabhāvaṃ jānanti. Evaṃ santepi taṃ phusitvā jānantā icceva🔽maññanti avisesavidunoti. Gunnaṃ abhiṇhaṃ caraṇaṭṭhānaṃ gocaro. Gocarasadisattā idha
analyzed: visum drava bhāvam jānanti evam sante api tam phusitvā jānantāḥ iccā iva  maññanti gunnam abhiṇham caraṇa ṭhānam gocaraḥ gocara sadisa ttā idha
translated: The place where the qualities occur frequently is their “domain” . Here the “domain” is similar to a domain in the sense of a place of occurrence.

original: gocaro. Gotivā idha cakkhādīni indriyāni vuccanti. Tāni viññāṇādhiṭṭhitāni hutvā
analyzed: gocaraḥ gotivā idha cakkha ādīni indriyāni vuccanti tāni viññāṇa dhiṭṭhitāni hutvā
translated: The faculties beginning with the eye are called “species” . They occur in the primary elements that are clung to as the eye, etc.,

original: etesu caranti. Etānivātesu caranti pavattanti ghaṭṭentīti gocarā. Teyeva idha ekattaṃ
analyzed: etesu caranti caranti pavattanti ghaṭṭenti iti gocarā teyā iva idha ekattam
translated: or they occur in them, that is, they occur and function in the primary elements by striking them.

original: upanetvā gocararūpanti vuttaṃ. Imānipana pañca yathākkamaṃ cakkhādīsu paṭihanana
analyzed: upanetvā gocara rūpan ti vuttam imāni pana pañca yathākkamam cakkha ādīsu
translated: They are therefore called “objects of the faculties” . The five beginning with the eye are called “objects of the faculties” because they are the objects of the faculties.

original: lakkhaṇāni rūpādīnīti veditabbāni.
analyzed: lakkhaṇāni rūpa ādīni iti veditabbāni
translated: The characteristics of visible data, etc., should be understood as the respective individual essences of visible data, etc.

original: Itthī vuccati avisadākārasaṇṭhitaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ. Yassa pana dhammassa ānubhāvena
analyzed: itthī vuccati a visada ākāra saṇṭhitam khandha pañcakam yassa pana dhammassa ānubhāvena
translated: The “woman” is the five aggregates of clinging in a form that is not virile.🔽But the “woman state” is the state of being of that, which is so formed and occurs, by the influence of which

original: taṃ tathā saṇṭhāti pavattati. So itthi yā bhāvoti itthattaṃ. Puriso vuccati visadākārasaṇṭhitaṃ🔽khandhapañcakaṃ. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva. Tattha itthiliṅga itthinimitta itthi kutta
analyzed: tam tathā pavattati saḥ bhāvo ti itthattam puriso vuccati visada ākāra saṇṭhitam  khandha pañcakam sesam vutta nayam eva tattha itthi liṅgaḥ itthi nimittaḥ itthi kutta
translated: it is so formed and occurs. The “man” is the five aggregates of clinging in a form that is virile.🔽The rest is as already stated. Herein, the “woman’s sex” is the characteristic of being a cause for the woman’s sign, the woman’s idea, the woman’s action,

original: itthākappānaṃ hetubhāva lakkhaṇaṃ itthattaṃ. Purisaliṅga purisanimitta purisakutta
analyzed: itthā kappānam hetu bhāva lakkhaṇam itthattam purisa liṅga purisa nimitta purisa kutta
translated: and the woman’s disposition. The “man’s sex” is the characteristic of being a cause for the man’s sign, the man’s idea, the man’s action,

original: purisākappānaṃ hetubhāva lakkhaṇaṃ purisattaṃ. Tattha liṅganti padhānaṅgabhūtaṃ mahāsaṇṭhānaṃ.🔽Nimittanti paccaṅgabhūtaṃ khuddakasaṇṭhānaṃ. Kuttanti kīḷālilādi kriyāviseso. Ākappoti
analyzed: hetu bhāva lakkhaṇam purisattam tattha liṅganti mahā saṇṭhānam  nimittam ti paccaṅga bhūtam khuddaka saṇṭhānam kuttam ti kīḷālila ādi kriyā visesaḥ ākappo ti
translated: and the man’s disposition. Herein, the “sign” is the large formation that is the principal part.🔽The “idea” is the small formation that is the subordinate part. The “action” is the particular kind of activity such as play and sport. The “disposition” is the modification of appearance such as going, etc.

original: gamanādiko ākāravikāro. Sabbepete khandhapañcakassa pavattivisesāeva. Ye saddasatthesu
analyzed: gamana ādikaḥ ākāra vikāraḥ ye sadda satthesu
translated: All these are simply particular occurrences of the five aggregates.

original: liṅganti vuccanti. Yesañca vasena ayaṃ itthīeva, na puriso. Ayaṃ purisoeva, na itthīti
analyzed: liṅganti vuccanti vasena ayam itthī eva na purisaḥ ayam purisaḥ eva na itthī iti
translated: and the sex is called the sign. And by reason of which this is a woman and not a man, this is a man and not a woman,

original: sañjānanti. Yasmā panettha saṇṭhānādīnaṃ avisadādibhāvoeva atthato itthipurisatā
analyzed: sañjānanti yasmā pana ittha saṇṭhāna ādīnam atthataḥ itthi purisa tā
translated: they perceive. But since the state of being a woman or a man is in fact the condition of the shape, etc., being not-mixed, etc.,

original: hoti. Tadubhayamuttabhāvoca napuṃsakatā. Soca akkharapada saṅkhātesu vacanesu ca🔽vacanatthesuca yathārahaṃ sandissatiyeva. Tasmā indriyarahitesupi padesuca rukkhādīsu
analyzed: napuṃsaka tā akkhara pada saṅkhātesu vacanesu ca  vacana atthesu ca yathāraham tasmai indriya rahitesu pi padesu ca rukkha ādīsu
translated: and the state of being a neuter is the condition of both of them being mixed, and that is found in words consisting of letters and words,🔽and in word-meanings, as appropriate, therefore the establishment of the states of being a woman, a man, and a neuter is to be understood by implication in the case of the parts of a tree, etc.,

original: padatthesuca pariyāyena itthipumanapuṃsakatāsiddhi veditabbāti.
analyzed: pada atthesu ca pariyāyena itthi puma napuṃsaka tā siddhi veditabbā ati
translated: which are devoid of faculties and in the case of word-meanings.

original: [178] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yam pana
translated: But in the Vibhānā it is said:

original: “Itthīnaṃ aṅgajātaṃ itthiliṅga”nti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: itthīnam aṅga jātam vuttam tam na sundaram
translated: “The genitals of women are the sign of a woman.” That is not good.

original: Na hi katthaci pāḷiyaṃ aṭṭhakathāsuca nimittasaddoviya liṅgasaddo aṅgajāte pākaṭo diṭṭhoti.
analyzed: na hi katthaci pāḷiyam aṭṭhakathāsu ca liṅga saddo aṅga jāte pākaṭaḥ diṭṭho ti
translated: For nowhere in the texts or in the commentaries is the word “sign” found used in the obvious way for the genitals.

original: [179] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there:🔽“The shape of a woman, the voice of a woman, the bodily condition of a woman, the disposition of a woman, the adornments of a woman, the craft of a woman, the gait of a woman, the bearing of a woman, the laughter of a woman, the weeping of a woman, the affection of a woman, the jealousy of a woman—these are the woman’s parts” ,

original: “Itthisaṇṭhānaṃ itthākappo”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: itthi saṇṭhānam itthākappo ti vuttam tat pi na sundaram
translated: that is not good either.

original: Na hi liṅgasaddo viya ākappasaddo saṇṭhāne pākaṭo diṭṭhoti. Sesaṃpana tattha vuttaṃ
analyzed: na hi liṅga saddaḥ viya ākappa saddaḥ saṇṭhāne pākaṭaḥ diṭṭhaḥ ti sesam pana tattha vuttam
translated: For the word ‘sign’ is not seen to be evident in shape as the word ‘sex’ is. The rest is as stated there.🔽Whatever is not found in the Commentaries is appropriate in that way.

original: yaṃkiñci aṭṭhakathāya asamentaṃpi tena pariyāyena yujjatiyeva. Bhavanti pavattanti
analyzed: yaṃ kiñci aṭṭhakathāya tena pariyāyena bhavanti pavattanti
translated: They are, they occur,

original: taṃsahite khandhasantāne esā itthī, eso purisoti evaṃ pavattā sadda buddhiyo etenāti
analyzed: tad sahite khandha santāne esā itthī esaḥ puriso ti evam pavattā etena ati
translated: in the continuity of aggregates associated with that. The words and the ideas that occur in this way, ‘This is a woman’, ‘This is a man’, are called ‘sex’ .

original: bhāvo bhavantivā pātubhavanti taṃsahite khandhasantāne liṅgādīni etasmiṃ satīti bhāvo.
analyzed: bhāvaḥ bhavanti vā pātubhavanti tad sahite khandha santāne liṅga ādīni etasmin sati iti
translated: Or alternatively, the sex is the occurrence, the manifestation, of the signs, etc., in the continuity of aggregates associated with that. The presence of that is the sex.🔽That itself is the form of presence.

original: So eva rūpanti bhāvarūpaṃ. Hadanti sattā taṃtaṃatthaṃvā anatthaṃvā pūrenti etenāti
analyzed: bhāva rūpam sattā taṃ taṃ attham vā anattham vā pūrenti etena ati
translated: They fulfil, they bring about, this or that benefit or harm, by means of this,

original: hadayaṃ. Hadantivā sattā ito nānāvikakke osajanti muñcantīti hadayaṃ. Harantivā pariharanti
analyzed: hadayam hadantivā sattāḥ itas nānā vikakke osajanti muñcanti iti hadayam harantivā pariharanti
translated: so it is the heart . Or they are attached to, they are released from, various things here, so it is the heart . They take it, they carry it,

original: taṃ sattā jīvitaṃviya dayanti rakkhanticāti hadayaṃ. Vasanti nivasanti cittaceta
analyzed: tam sattāḥ jīvitaṃviya dayanti rakkhanti ca ati hadayam vasanti nivasanti
translated: so it is the heart . Or they give it, they protect it, as they do life, so it is the heart .🔽The mind and consciousness,

original: sikādhammā etthāti vatthu. Hadayañca taṃ vatthucāti hadayavatthu. Dhātudvayanissayalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: sikā dhammāḥ ettha ati vatthu hadayam ca tam vatthu ca ati hadaya vatthu dhātu dvaya nissaya lakkhaṇam
translated: the states of consciousness, dwell, they live, here, thus it is a physical basis . And it is a heart and a physical basis, thus it is a heart physical basis. Its characteristic is that of being the support for the two elements.

original: vatthurūpaṃ. Taṃ pana hadayakosabbhantare aḍḍhapasatamattaṃ lohitaṃ byāpetvā tiṭṭhatīti
analyzed: vatthu rūpam tam pana hadaya kosabbhantare aḍḍha pasata mattam lohitam byāpetvā tiṭṭhati iti
translated: and that is material form. But it should be understood that it is to be found in the heart-basis, having spread out over the hundred and eight sections of blood.

original: veditabbaṃ. Dhammasaṅgaṇiyaṃ pana desanābhedarakkhanatthaṃ avatvā paṭṭhāneeva taṃ🔽vuttaṃ. Yathāha-vatthu kusalānaṃ khandhānaṃ nissayapaccayena paccayo. Vatthu akusalānaṃ
analyzed: veditabbam dhammasaṅgaṇiyam pana desanā bheda rakkhana attham avatvā paṭṭhāne eva tam  vuttam yathā āha vatthu kusalānam khandhānam nissaya paccayena paccayaḥ vatthu akusalānam
translated: But in the Dhammasanganī it is given as a heading, not as a classification,

original: khandhānaṃ nissayapaccayena paccayotiādi. Etthaca chahi vatthūhi aññaṃ vatthunāma
analyzed: khandhānam nissaya paccayena paccayaḥ ti ādi ettha ca chahi vatthūhi aññam vatthu nāma
translated: as in the Vibhaṅga, as shown in the following passages: “The materiality aggregate is a condition, as presence condition, for the profitable aggregates” (Vibh 89), “The materiality aggregate is a condition, as presence condition, for the unprofitable aggregates” (Vibh 89), and so on.🔽And here there is no other presence condition than the six beginning with the eye.

original: natthi. Tesuca purimāni pañca kusalādīnaṃ nissayāeva na honti. Tasmā tesaṃ nissayabhāvena
analyzed: natthi tesu ca purimāni pañca kusala ādīnam nissayāḥ eva na honti tasmā tesam nissaya bhāvena
translated: And of these, the first five are not presence conditions for the profitable, etc.,

original: tattha vuttaṃ vatthunāma visuṃ ekaṃ vatthurūpamevāti siddhanti.
analyzed: tattha vuttam vatthu nāma visum ekam vatthu rūpam eva ati siddham ti
translated: So it is established that the presence condition mentioned there is only the materiality called “presence” as a separate item.

original: [180] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana🔽Yaṃ rūpaṃ nissāyāti pāṭhassa uddhaṭattā rūpasāmaññapasaṅgo hotīti taṃ visodhetuṃ
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana  yam rūpam nissāya ati pāṭhassa uddhaṭa ttā rūpa sāmañña pasaṅgaḥ hoti iti tam visodhetum
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga🔽the reading is “The materiality that is a condition for the profitable … the unprofitable … the indeterminate” , and so it is necessary to remove the general sense of “materiality” and

original: yuttināma vuttā. Paṭṭhāne pana bahūsu anaññasādhāraṇesu ṭhānesu vatthunāmena visesetvā
analyzed: yutti nāma vuttā paṭṭhāne pana bahūsu anañña sādhāraṇesu ṭhānesu vatthu nāmena visesetvā
translated: to show the particular sense. In the Paṭṭhāna it is distinguished by the word “presence” in many places where it is not shared by anything else,

original: vuttattā sopasaṅgo natthiyevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Jīvanti sahajātadhammā yenāti jīvitaṃ. Tesaṃ jīvane ādhipaccayogena tesu indaṃ issaraṃ🔽attānaṃ karotīti indriyaṃ. Jīvitañca taṃ indriyañcāti jīvitindriyaṃ. Sahajātā nupālana
analyzed: vutta ttā sa upasaṅgaḥ na atthiya iva āti daṭṭhabbam  jīvanti sahajāta dhammāḥ yena ati jīvitam tesam jīvane ādhi paccayogena tesu indam issaram  attānam karoti iti indriyam jīvitam ca tam indriyam ca ati jīvitindriyam
translated: and so it should be regarded as having no connection with the words.

original: lakkhaṇaṃ jīvitindriyaṃ. Yathā hi bījanibbattāni uppalādīni bījevinaṭṭhepi udakānupālitāni
analyzed: lakkhaṇam jīvitindriyam yathā hi bīja nibbattāni uppala ādīni udaka anupālitāni
translated: “It causes to live, it is the sovereign, the lord, of those conascent states,” thus it is the life faculty. It is the life faculty and it is an indriya, thus it is the life faculty indriya. The life faculty indriya is the conascent states’ preservation characteristic. For just as the water that preserves the lotus and so on that is born with it causes them to live even when the seed is destroyed,

original: ciraṃpi kālaṃ jīvanti. Evamevaṃ niruddha kammanibbattāni kammajarūpāni kamme asantepi🔽jīvitānupālitāni santativasena vassasataṃpi vassasahassaṃpi kappaṃpi soḷasakappasahassānipi🔽jīvantiyeva, tathā hi jīvitarahitāni itararūpāni jīvantānināma nahonti. Tāni hi yena
analyzed: ciram pi kālam jīvanti evam evam niruddha kamma nibbattāni kamma ja rūpāni kamme asante pi  jīvita anupālitāni santati vasena vassa satam pi vassa sahassam kappam soḷasa kappa sahassāni pi  tathā hi jīvita rahitāni itara rūpāni tāni hi yena
translated: so too, the conascent states born with the kamma that preserves the kamma-born materiality cause it to live even when the kamma is exhausted.

original: ekena cittenavā utunāvā āhārenavā jāyanti. Tasmiṃ niruddhe nirujjhanti, paraṃ muhuttamattaṃpi
analyzed: ekena cittenavā utunā vā āhārenavā jāyanti tasmin niruddhe nirujjhanti param
translated: They live in continuity for a hundred years, a thousand years, an eon, sixteen eons, and so on. For the other kinds of materiality that are not so preserved do not live; they are called “non-living.” For they are born with a single consciousness, or with a single temperature, or with a single nutriment, and when that ceases they cease too, and they do not continue for even a moment beyond that.

original: santānaṃ ghaṭetuṃ nasakkonti. Tesu hi cittajarūpānaṃ santatipaccuppannaṃ ekavīthi🔽ekajavanavāra ekasamāpattivārena paricchinnaṃ hoti. Utujāhārajānañca sabhāgeka utuāhāra
analyzed: santānam ghaṭetum na sakkonti tesu hi citta ja rūpānam santati paccuppannam eka vīthi  eka javana vāre eka samāpatti vārena paricchinnam sa bhāga ekaḥ utuāhāra
translated: They cannot do so. For the continuity of the mind and its states is limited to a single cognitive series, a single impulsion, a single attainment. And the continuity of the material phenomena originated by temperature and nutriment is limited to a single temperature and a single nutriment.

original: vasena paricchinnaṃ hoti. Kammajarūpānaṃ pana visuṃ santatipaccuppannaṃnāma natthi.
analyzed: vasena paricchinnam hoti kamma ja rūpānam pana visum santati paccuppannam nāma natthi
translated: They cannot be strung together in a series. For the life-continuum of material instances is delimited by a single cognitive process, a single impulsion, a single attainment. And the material instances born of temperature and nutriment are delimited by a single temperature and a single nutriment. But the material instances born of kamma have no separate life-continuum.

original: Tesaṃ ekabhavaparicchinnaṃ addhāpaccuppannameva hotīti. Yadi evaṃ arūpadhammānaṃ
analyzed: tesam eka bhava paricchinnam addhā paccuppannam eva hoti iti yadi evam arūpa dhammānam
translated: They are delimited only by a single existence. But how is it with the immaterial states?

original: kathanti. Tehi jīvitayogena jīvantāeva honti. Evaṃsantepi tesaṃ santatipaccuppannaṃ🔽dissatīti. Vuccate, arūpadhammesu vipākāni tāva kammajarūpasadisāni. Tānipi hi asati🔽vīthicittuppāde yāvajīvaṃpi ekasantativasena pavattissantiyeva. Itarāni pana yassa
analyzed: kathanti tehi jīvita yogena jīvantā eva honti evaṃsante pi tesam santati paccuppannam  dissati iti vuccate arūpa dhammesu vipākāni tāva kamma ja rūpa sadisāni tāni api hi asati  vīthi cittuppāde yāvajīvam pi eka santati vasena itarāni pana yassa
translated: They are only “living” by the life faculty. But even so, their life-continuum is seen.

original: ārammaṇassa āpātāgatattā uppajjanti. Tasmiṃ niruddhe tadabhāvepi tadārammaṇā bahū
analyzed: ārammaṇassa āpāta āgata ttāḥ uppajjanti tasmin niruddhe tad abhāve pi tad ārammaṇāḥ bahū
translated: We reply: As to the resultant immaterial states, they are like the material instances born of kamma. For they too occur only in a single series as long as life lasts, even when there is no arising of a cognitive process. But the others arise when their object comes into focus. When that has ceased, they continue to occur even in the absence of that object,

original: cittasantatiyo jīvitassaaddhānapharaṇānubhāvena pavattantiyeva. Apica, yāvakhandhaparinibbānā
analyzed: citta santatiyaḥ jīvita ssa addhāna pharaṇa anubhāvena apica yāva khandha parinibbānā
translated: and the continuity of consciousness goes on by the power of the life faculty’s extending the duration .🔽🔽Moreover,

original: anantarapaccayupanibandhena abbocchinnaṃ pavattamānāya cittasantatiyāvasenapi ayamattho

original: katvā veditabbanti. Etthaca upādinnakapathavīhi saha ghaṭṭanaṃ cittajapathavīnaṃ🔽kiccaṃ. Yaṃ pana tāsaṃ yathāvā tathāvā aghaṭṭetvā yathā icchitakkharaṃ sampajjati.🔽Tathā ghaṭṭanapakāravidhānaṃ. Idaṃ kāyaviññattiyā kiccaṃ. Ghaṭṭanena saheva uppannasaddānaṃ
analyzed: katvā veditabbanti ettha ca upādinnaka pathavīhi saha ghaṭṭanam citta ja pathavīnam  kiccam yam pana tāsam yathāvā tathāvā a ghaṭṭetvā yathā icchita kharam sampajjati  tathā ghaṭṭana pakāra vidhānam idam kāya viññattiyā kiccam ghaṭṭanena saha iva uppanna saddānam
translated: and it should be understood thus. And here the function of the mind-made earth-element and the earth-element derived from the primary elements is to make contact with the appropriated earth-element.🔽But the function of the bodily intimation is to arrange the order of the impact in such a way that the desired sound is produced, whether it is the one or the other.

original: taṃtaṃvaṇṇatta pattiyā vidahanameva vacīviññattiyā kiccaṃ. Kumbhathunatalaṃ viyaca
analyzed: pattiyā vidahanam eva vacī viññattiyā kiccam kumbhathuna talam
translated: The function of the verbal intimation is just the arrangement of the order of the impact together with the sound that arises, in such a way that the desired sound is produced. The appropriated earth-element is like the surface of a clay pot.

original: upādinnakapathavī. Paharaṇahattho viya cittajapathavī. Hatthapari vattana vikāro
analyzed: upādinnaka pathavī paharaṇa hatthaḥ viya citta ja pathavī hattha pari vikāro
translated: The mind-made earth-element is like the hand that strikes it. The bodily intimation is like the alteration in the hand that moves it.

original: viya kāyaviññatti. Saddavikāro viya vacīviññatti. Kumbhathunassa nānāsaddapabhedoviya🔽nānāvaṇṇabhedoti. Etthaca yadetaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ idaṃ vakkhāmi etaṃ vakkhāmīti uppajjamānaṃ
analyzed: viya kāya viññatti sadda vikāraḥ viya vacī viññatti kumbhathunassa nānā sadda pabhedaḥ viya  nānā vaṇṇa bhedaḥ ti ettha ca yat etam aṭṭhakathāyam idam vakkhāmi etam vakkhāmi iti uppajjamānam
translated: The verbal intimation is like the alteration in the sound. The various distinctions of sound in the clay pot are like the various distinctions of colour.

original: cittaṃ aṭṭharūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti. Tesaṃ abbhantare citta samuṭṭhānā pathavīdhātu upādinnakaṃ
analyzed: cittam aṭṭharūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti tesam abbhantare citta samuṭṭhānā pathavī dhātu upādinnakam
translated: And here, the mind that arises thinking “I shall speak thus” or “I shall speak thus” generates the eight kinds of matter. Among them, the earth-element that arises with the mind, which is appropriated,

original: ghaṭṭayamānāva uppajjati. Tena dhātughaṭṭanena saheva saddo uppajjatītica purimacittasamuṭṭhā🔽nāya upatthambhanakiccaṃpi natthītica vuttaṃ. Taṃpi anekasatesu javanavāresu pavattamānesu
analyzed: uppajjati tena dhātu ghaṭṭanena saha iva saddaḥ uppajjati iti ca purima citta samuṭṭhā  upatthambhana kiccaṃpi natthi iti ca vuttam tat pi aneka satesu javana vāresu pavattamānesu
translated: and it arises as if striking. The sound arises together with the striking of the elements.🔽Therefore it is said that there is no function of consolidating in the consciousness that arises first.

original: yasmiṃvāre paribyattaṃ akkharaṃ pavattati, taṃ sandhāya vuttanti gahetabbaṃ. Teneva
analyzed: yasmin vāre paribyattam akkharam pavattati tam sandhāya vuttam ti gahetabbam tena iva
translated: But that should be understood to refer to the syllable that occurs in the series of impulsions that occurs in the course of many hundreds of impulsion moments.

original: hi mūla ṭīkāyaṃ upatthambhanakiccaṃ natthi laddhāsevanena citteneva ghaṭṭanassa balavabhāvatoti
analyzed: upatthambhana kiccam natthi laddha āsevanena cittena iva ghaṭṭanassa balava bhāvato ti
translated: For it is said in the commentary on the root text: “There is no function of consolidating because the striking is powerful by reason of the consciousness that has obtained repetition.”

original: vuttaṃ. Etthaca laddhāsevanenāti etena pubbabhāge nānājavanavīthīhi laddhāsevanabhāvaṃ🔽dasseti. Pathama javanacittassapi laddhāsevanatāya adhippetattā. Naca ekajavana vāramattena
analyzed: vuttam ettha ca laddha āsevanena ati etena pubba bhāge nānā javana vīthīhi laddha āsevana bhāvam  dasseti pathama javana cittassa api laddha āsevana tāya adhippeta ttā na ca eka javana vāra mattena
translated: And here by “that has obtained repetition” he shows that it has obtained repetition in the course of the many series of impulsions in the prior stage.🔽For the first impulsion consciousness is intended, because it has obtained repetition.🔽And it cannot be known that a single syllable is completed in a single impulsion moment.

original: paribyattaṃ ekakkharaṃ sampajjatīti sakkā viññātuṃ. Kasmā, tassa ekadviaccharakkhaṇamattena
analyzed: paribyattam eka kkharam sampajjati iti sakkā viññātum kasmā tassa eka dvi accha rakkhaṇa mattena
translated: Why not? Because a single syllable is not completed in a single or two or three impulsion moments.

original: kālena vattabbattā ekaccharakkhaṇeca anekasatasahassānaṃ javanavīthīnaṃ pavattisambhavato. Vuttañca –
analyzed: kālena vattabbattā ekaccha rakkhaṇe ca aneka sata sahassānam javana vīthīnam pavatti sambhavataḥ vuttam ca
translated: because it is possible for a hundred thousand thought-moments to occur in the time taken up by a single thought-conascence. And it is said:

original: Ekamattā tayo rassā, dvimattā dīghamuccare;
analyzed: eka mattā tayoḥ rassāḥ dvi mattāḥ dīgham uccare
translated: “One unit is three short, two units are said to be long,

original: Timatto tu gīto ñeyyo, byañjanā aḍḍhamattikāti.
analyzed: timattaḥ tu gītaḥ ñeyyaḥ byañjanā aḍḍhamattikā ati
translated: Three units are known as a gīti, and a byañjana is half a unit.”

original: Milindapañheca sādhike vīhivāhasate vīhibījāni ekaccharakkhaṇe uppannassa cittassa🔽kalaṃpi naupenti. Kalabhāgaṃpi naupentīti dīpitaṃ. Ekakkharaṃ uccārentassaca tattakaṃpi
analyzed: sādhike vīhi vāha sate vīhi bījāni ekaccha rakkhaṇe uppannassa cittassa  kalam pi na upenti kalabhāgam pi na upenti iti dīpitam ekakkharam uccārentassa ca
translated: And in the Milindapañha it is shown that the seeds of a hundred extra wagonloads of grain do not equal a fraction of a thought that has arisen in a single moment.

original: kālaṃ uccāraṇacittabyāpāro sandissatiyeva. Naca paramatthato ekameva saddaṃ uccāremītivā🔽suṇomītivā sakkā niyametvā uccāretuṃ sotuñca. Tathā niyamentassapi saddānaṃ pubbāparato
analyzed: kālam uccāraṇa citta byāpāraḥ sandissatiyā iva na ca paramatthataḥ ekam eva saddam uccāremi iti vā  suṇomi iti vā sakkā niyametvā uccāretum sotum ca tathā niyamentassa api saddānam pubba aparato
translated: And when one is uttering a single syllable, the duration of the consciousnesses that occur in uttering it is evident. And it is not possible to utter or hear a sound, saying: “I am uttering or hearing a single sound.”

original: anekasatasahassasseva uccāraṇa savana sambhavato. Ekamevāti abhimāno pana samūhaghana
analyzed: aneka sata sahassassa iva uccāraṇa savana sambhavato ekam eva ati abhimānaḥ pana samūha ghana
translated: For even when one utters or hears in this way, it is only a hundred thousand sounds that occur successively in the past and future. But the conceit “one” arises in regard to them.

original: santatighanehi paṭicchannattāeva hotīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sesamettha kāyaviññattiyaṃ vuttana
analyzed: santati ghanehi paṭicchanna ttā eva hoti iti daṭṭhabbam sesam ettha kāya viññattiyam
translated: It should be regarded as hidden by the compact mass of the other parts. The rest here should be understood as in the case of bodily intimation.

original: yena yathāsambhavaṃ veditabbanti. Etthaca viññattisaddo kāyena viññāpeti vācāya viññāpetītiādisu
analyzed: yena yathāsambhavam veditabbam ti ettha ca viññatti saddo kāyena viññāpeti vācāya viññāpeti itiādisu
translated: And here the word viññatti is in the sense of making known in such passages as “He makes known by the body, he makes known by speech”

original: bodhanattho. Sudinna kaṇḍe tikkhattuṃ viññāpetītiādīsu pavattanattho. Idha pana duvidhopi🔽yujjati. Evañhi sati paraṃ bodhetukāmatārahi tesu sabbesu kāyaṅgavācaṅgacopanesupi🔽pavattakaviññattiyā labbhamānatā veditabbā hotīti. Mūlaṭīkāyaṃ pana paraṃ bodhetukāmatāya
analyzed: bodhana atthaḥ sudinna kaṇḍe tikkhattum viññāpeti iti ādīsu pavattana atthaḥ idha pana duvidhaḥ api  yujjati evam hi sati param bodhetu kāma tā rahi tesu sabbesu kāyaṅga vācaṅga copanesu pi  pavattaka viññattiyāḥ labbhamāna tā veditabbā hoti iti mūla ṭīkā ayam pana param bodhetu kāma tāya
translated: and in the sense of occurrence in such passages as “He makes known three times” in the Sudinna chapter . But in this context both senses🔽are appropriate. For in that case it is the occurrence of the intimation that is meant, and it is the intimation that is made known to another.

original: vināpi abhikkamanādipavattanena so citta sahabhūvikāro adhippāyaṃ viññāpeti. Sayañca
analyzed: vinā api abhikkamana ādi pavattanena so citta sahabhūvikāraḥ adhippāyam viññāpeti sayam ca
translated: And in the Root Commentary it is said that the mode of activity that is conascent with the consciousness makes known the intention without the occurrence of going forward, etc.,🔽and that it is intimation in both ways because it is also made known by oneself.

original: viññāyatīti dvidhāpi viññattiyevāti vuttaṃ, tattha dvīsu bodhanaviññattīsu purimā
analyzed: viññāyati iti dvidhā api viññattiyā iva ati vuttam tattha dvīsu bodhana viññattīsu purimā
translated: Herein, of the two kinds of intimation, the first,

original: kāyaviññatti aṅgapaccaṅgassa calamānavaṇṇaṃ cakkhuviññāṇavīthiyā calamānaṅgapaccaṅgaṃ
analyzed: kāya viññatti aṅga paccaṅgassa calamāna vaṇṇam cakkhu viññāṇa vīthiyā calamāna aṅga paccaṅgam
translated: bodily intimation, is the movement of the limbs and the trunk, which is the cause of the arising of the eye-consciousness in another.

original: kāyaviññāṇavīthiyā gahetvā pacchā suddhena manodvārikajavanenaeva viññāyati pacchimāca🔽vacīviññatti uccāriyamānaṃ saddaṃ sotaviññāṇavīthiyā gahetvā pacchā suddhena manodvārikajavanenaeva🔽viññāyati, na pañcadvārikajavanena. Sā hi attānaṃ jānanteeva parasatte attanā samaṅgino
analyzed: kāya viññāṇa vīthiyā gahetvā pacchā suddhena manodvārika javanena eva viññāyati pacchimā ca  vacī viññatti uccāriyamānam saddam sota viññāṇa vīthiyā gahetvā pacchā suddhena manodvārika javanena eva  viññāyati na pañcadvārika javanena sā hi attānam jānantā eva para satte attanā samaṅginaḥ
translated: and then it is cognized by a pure mind-door impulsion only.🔽When a vocal intimation is uttered, the sound is cognized by the ear-consciousness, and then it is cognized by a pure mind-door impulsion only, not by a five-door impulsion. For that intimation intimates the state of mind of the person who has the same intimation himself, not of another person who has not.

original: puggalassa cittaṃ viññāpeti, na ajānante. Ñāpaka hetu hi nāma attānaṃ jānanteeva🔽ñāpetabbaṃ ñāpeti, no ajānante. Evañca katvā kāyaṅga copanaṃ disvāvā parāmasitvāvā
analyzed: puggalassa cittam viññāpeti na a jānante ñāpaka hetu hi nāma attānam jānante eva  ñāpetabbam ñāpeti no a jānante evañca katvā kāyaṅga copanam disvā vā parāmasitvā vā
translated: It intimates only when it is cognized by the intimer himself, not when it is not cognized by him. For that which is called an intimation intimates only when it is cognized by the intimer himself, not when it is not cognized by him.🔽Thus, when a person sees or touches the bodily expression, or hears the sound of the vocal expression, he cognizes the intention of another who has the same intimation himself.

original: saddaṃ sutvāvā parassa taṃtaṃadhippāyaṃ jānantānaṃ tiracchāna gatānaṃpi pathadhaṃ🔽viññattijānanaṃ siddhaṃ bhavati. Taṃjānanena vinā adhippāyajānanassa asambhavato.
analyzed: saddam sutvā vā parassa taṃ taṃ adhippāyam jānantānam tiracchāna gatānam pi  viññatti jānanam siddham bhavati tad jānanena vinā adhippāya jānanassa asambhavato
translated: The cognizing of the intimation is established even in animals.🔽For without cognizing the intimation, the intention cannot be cognized.

original: Viññattiṃ jānantānaṃca purimasiddhasaṅketa sambandha jānanena vinā adhippāyajānanaṃ
analyzed: viññattim jānantānam ca purima siddha saṅketa sambandha jānanena vinā adhippāya jānanam
translated: And the cognizing of the intention of those who cognize the intimation is established only when there is the prior cognizing of the connection of the sign and the intimation.

original: na sambhavatīti majjhe visuṃ pubbasaṅketa sambandhagahanaṃpi icchanti, dvīsu pana🔽pavattakaviññattīsu paraṃ abhikkamantaṃ cakkhuviññāṇavīthiyā disvā abhikkamanaviññattiñca
analyzed: na sambhavati iti majjhe visum pubba saṅketa sambandha gahanam pi icchanti dvīsu pana  pavattaka viññattīsu param abhikkamantam cakkhu viññāṇa vīthiyā disvā abhikkamana viññattiñca
translated: and it does not occur in the middle. They want the connection with the previous sign to be dense. But in the two kinds of intimation that occur, having seen one who is approaching in the visual-consciousness cycle, and the intimation of approaching,

original: abhikkamanacittañca manoviññāṇavīthiyā jānanti. Esanayo paṭikkamanādīsu. Tathā parassa🔽kathaṃ sotaviññāṇavīthiyā sutvā kathanaviññattiñca kathanacittañca manoviññāṇavīthiyā🔽jānanti. Paraṃ rattacittena kāyaṅgaṃ cālentaṃ disvā calanaviññattiñca rāgacittañca
analyzed: abhikkamana cittam ca manaḥ viññāṇa vīthiyā jānanti esanayo paṭikkamana ādīsu tathā parassa  katham sota viññāṇa vīthiyā sutvā kathana viññattim ca kathana cittam ca manaḥ viññāṇa vīthiyā  jānanti param ratta cittena kāyaṅgam cālentam disvā calana viññattim ca rāga cittam ca
translated: They want to know the connection between the two by means of a previous sign. But when the other is coming towards him, they know the intimation of coming and the mind of coming by means of the eye-door adverting and seeing the other’s eye-consciousness process. And so with the other processes of looking, listening, etc.,

original: jānanti. Rattassa kathaṃ sutvā kathana viññattiñca rāgacittañca jānanti. Esanayo
analyzed: jānanti rattassa katham sutvā kathana viññattiñca rāga cittañca jānanti esanayo
translated: Similarly, when they hear the other speaking, they know the intimation of speaking and the mind of speaking by means of the ear-door adverting and hearing the other’s ear-consciousness process. When they see the other moving a limb with lust in his mind, they know the intimation of moving and the lustful mind by means of the eye-door adverting and seeing the other’s eye-consciousness process. And when they hear the other speaking with lust, they know the intimation of speaking and the lustful mind by means of the ear-door adverting and hearing the other’s ear-consciousness process. And so with the other defilements.🔽They know all bodily and verbal activities in this way.

original: sabbāsu kāyikavācasikakriyāsūti. Lahuno bhāvo lahutā. Muduno bhāvo mudutā. Kammani
analyzed: sabbāsu kāyika vācasika kriyāsu iti lahunaḥ bhāvaḥ lahu tā mudunaḥ bhāvaḥ mudu tā kammani
translated: Lightness is the quality of being light. Malleability is the quality of being malleable.

original: sādhu kammaññaṃ. Kammayogyanti attho. Kammaññassa bhāvo kammaññatā.
analyzed: sādhu kammaññam kamma yogyanti atthaḥ kammaññassa bhāvaḥ kammañña tā
translated: Wieldiness is the quality of being wieldy. The meaning is, fit to be wielded. Workableness is the quality of being worklike.

original: Adandhatālakkhaṇā rūpassa lahutā. Athaddhatā lakkhaṇā rūpassa mudutā. Sarīrakriyānukūlakammaññabhāvalakkhaṇā
analyzed: adandha tā lakkhaṇā rūpassa lahu tā athaddha tā lakkhaṇā rūpassa mudu tā sarīra kriyā anukūla kammañña bhāva lakkhaṇā
translated: Lightness of matter is the characteristic of non-stiffness. Malleability of matter is the characteristic of non-stiffness. Wieldiness of matter is the characteristic of suitability for action.

original: rūpassa kammaññatā. Aññamaññaṃ avijahantiyopi etā viruddhapaccayasappāya paccayānaṃ🔽vasena asaṃmissato veditabbā. Tathā hi attano kāyaviruddhaṃ utuṃvā āhāraṃvā cittakriyaṃvā
analyzed: rūpassa kammañña tā aññamaññam a vijahantiyaḥ api etāḥ viruddha paccaya sappāya paccayānam  vasena a saṃmissataḥ veditabbā tathā hi attanaḥ kāya viruddham utum vā āhāram vā citta kriyam vā
translated: These are to be understood as unmixed, though not mutually exclusive, by reason of the conditions that are opposed to the conditions that are opposed to them.

original: sevantānaṃ sarīragatā dhātuyo kadāci sakalasarīraṃvā sarīrekadesaṃvā khobhetvā visesato
analyzed: sevantānam sarīra gatāḥ kadācid sakala sarīram vā sarīra eka desam vā khobhetvā visesataḥ
translated: For when people use a season, food, or bodily reaction that is opposed to their bodies, then the elements in their bodies sometimes agitate the whole body or a part of the body and, in particular,

original: pūtimukha sappasaṅkhātaāpo pariyuṭṭhānaṃ katvā kāyaṃ asayhabhāraṃ viya garuṃ bhāriyaṃ🔽karonti. Iriyā pathaparivattane kāyabhāriyanimittaṃ dukkhaṃ uppādenti. Tadārūpassa
analyzed: pūti mukha pariyuṭṭhānam katvā kāyam a sayha bhāram viya garum bhāriyam  karonti iriyā patha parivattane kāya bhāriya nimittam dukkham uppādenti tadārūpassa
translated: they cause the body to be heavy and unwieldy like a heavy load that is hard to move about, by making it full of the water called “pus” that is found in the mouth.🔽They cause pain to arise as a sign of the body’s unwieldiness when the postures are changed. Then the lightness of matter does not occur.

original: lahutā napavattati. Puna attano sarīrasappāyaṃ utuṃvā āhāraṃvā cittakiriyaṃvā sevantānaṃ
analyzed: lahu tā na pavattati puna attano sarīra sappāyam utum vā āhāram vā citta kiriyam vā sevantānam
translated: But when people use a season, food, or bodily reaction that is suitable to their bodies,

original: so dhātukkhobho vūpasammati. Kāyo sallahuko hoti. Iriyāpathaparivattane kāya bhāriyanimittaṃ
analyzed: saḥ dhātu khobhaḥ vūpasammati kāyaḥ sat lahukaḥ hoti iriyāpatha parivattane kāya bhāriya nimittam
translated: and the disturbance of the elements subsides. The body becomes light. There is no bodily pain due to the change of posture.

original: dukkhaṃnāma natthi. Tadā sā pavattati. Esanayo sesāsupi. Visesanato panettha mudubhāyaṃ
analyzed: dukkhaṃ nāma natthi tadā sā pavattati sesāsu pi visesanato pana ittha
translated: That is how it occurs. The same method applies in the case of the rest. But here, in the case of malleability,

original: kaṭṭhamukhasappasaṅkhāta pathavīpariyuṭṭhānaṃ katvā sukkhakaṭṭhaṃviya kāyaṃ thaddhaṃ🔽kakkhaḷaṃkaronti. Iriyāpathaparivattane aṅgamaṅgānaṃchijjanabhijjanākārapattaṃ thaddhaṃ
analyzed: kaṭṭha mukha sappa saṅkhāta pathavī pariyuṭṭhānam katvā sukkha kaṭṭham viya kāyam thaddham  kakkhaḷaṃkaronti iriyāpatha parivattane thaddham
translated: the earth element, which is like a saw, makes the body stiff and rigid like dry wood.

original: kakkhaḷanimittaṃ dukkhaṃ uppādentīti vattabbaṃ. Kammaññatāyaṃ satthamukhasappasaṅkhāta
analyzed: kakkhaḷa nimittam dukkham uppādenti iti vattabbam kammañña tā ayam sattha mukha sappa saṅkhāta
translated: It should be said that it produces pain due to stiffness and rigidity in the form of the breaking and splitting of the limbs when the postures are changed. In the case of wieldiness,

original: vāyo pariyuṭṭhānaṃ vāyovisamaṃ katvā dāmarikacorapariyuṭṭhitaṃ paccantaraṭṭhaṃ viya
analyzed: vāyo pariyuṭṭhānam vāyo visamam katvā dāmarika cora pariyuṭṭhitam paccantaraṭṭham viya
translated: the air element, which is like a butcher’s steel, makes the body unworkable by making the air element uneven, like a country that is surrounded by enemies and is in a state of civil war.

original: kāyaṃ vivaṭṭamānaṃ karonti, sabbairiyāpathesu sukhaṃnāma natthīti vattabbaṃ. Tejodhātu
analyzed: kāyam vivaṭṭamānam karonti sa bairiyāpathesu sukham nāma natthi iti vattabbam tejaḥ dhātu
translated: It should be said that there is no comfort in any posture.

original: pana tāsaṃ sabbāsaṃpi mūlabhūtā hotīti veditabbā.
analyzed: pana tāsam sabbāsam pi mūla bhūtā hoti iti veditabbā
translated: But the fire element should be understood as the basis for all these.

original: Imā pana arogino kallabhāvoviya suparimadditacammassa mudubhāvoviya sudandhasuvaṇṇassa🔽kammakkhamabhāvoviya rūpakāyassa iriyāpathaparivattane sallahukatādivasena sandissamānā
analyzed: imā pana arogino su parimaddita cammassa mudu bhāvo viya su dandha suvaṇṇassa  rūpa kāyassa iriyāpatha parivattane sallahuka tā ādi vasena sandissamānā
translated: And these are called “derived materiality” because they are seen to be like the state of health of one who is not sick, like the pliability of well-kneaded leather, like the workability of well-smelted gold, and like the lightness of a man’s body when it is in good condition and can be turned this way and that without difficulty.🔽The meaning is that it is generated in the form of a mass.

original: visesākārā hontīti katvā vikārarūpaṃ nāma. Cayanaṃ cayo. Piṇḍavasena abhinibbattīti🔽attho. Ādito uparitoca cayo upacayo. Pathamābhinibbatti uparuparivaḍḍhicāti attho.
analyzed: visesa ākārāḥ honti iti katvā vikāra rūpam nāma cayanam cayaḥ piṇḍa vasena abhinibbatti iti  atthaḥ āditas uparitas ca cayaḥ upacayaḥ pathama abhinibbatti upari upari vaḍḍhi ca ati atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is the first generation and the subsequent increase.

original: Ayañhi upasaddo upaññattantiādīsu viya pathamattho upasittantiādīsu viyaca upari🔽atthoti. Vuttañca mūlaṭīkāyaṃ upasaddo pathamattho upariatthoca hotīti. Tenevahi
analyzed: ayam hi upasaddaḥ upaññattanti ādīsu viya pathama atthaḥ upasittanti ādīsu upari  atthaḥ iti vuttam ca mūla ṭīkāyam upasaddo pathama atthaḥ upari atthaḥ ca hoti iti tena iva hi
translated: For this prefix u- has the meaning of “first” as in upajjhāya , and it has the meaning of “above” as in upasampadā .🔽And it is said in the Mula-Tika: “The prefix u- has the meaning of ‘first’ and the meaning of ‘above.’”

original: pāḷiyaṃ yo āyatanānaṃ ācayo, so rūpassa upacayo. Yorūpassa upacayo, sā rūpassa santatīti
analyzed: pāḷiyam yaḥ āyatanānaṃ ācayo saḥ rūpassa upacayaḥ yaḥ rūpassa upacayo sā rūpassa santati iti
translated: That is why it is said in the text: “The accumulation of the bases is the growth of materiality; the growth of materiality is the continuity of materiality” .

original: vuttaṃ. Tananaṃ vitthāraṇaṃ tati. Sambandhā tati punappunaṃvā tati santati. Yathā
analyzed: vuttam tananam vitthāraṇam tati sambandhā tati punappunaṃvā tati santati yathā
translated: The meaning of the prefix u- is “spreading out” as in uddhacca . The meaning of the prefix u- is “connection” as in upaṭṭhāna . The meaning of the prefix u- is “repeatedly” as in upajjhāya . The meaning of the prefix u- is “continuity” as in upaṭṭhāna .

original: pavattānaṃ āyatanānaṃ addhānapūraṇavasena pavattīti attho. Tattha gabbhaseyyakānaṃ
analyzed: pavattānam āyatanānam addhāna pūraṇa vasena pavatti iti attho tattha gabbhaseyyakānam
translated: The meaning is that it occurs by filling up the duration of the bases. Herein, the arising of material instances in beings who are lying in the womb

original: sattānaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe rūpānaṃ uppādo pathamānibbattiatthena upacayonāma. Tato
analyzed: sattānam paṭisandhi khaṇe rūpānam uppādaḥ pathamā nibbatti atthena upacayaḥ nāma tatas
translated: is called “accumulation” in the sense of first appearance. After that,

original: paraṃ yāva sabbapathamaṃ uppannānaṃ cakkhu sota ghānajivhānaṃ uppādo, etthantare
analyzed: param yāva sabba pathamam uppannānam cakkhu sota ghāna jivhānaṃ uppādo etthantare
translated: the arising of the eye, ear, nose, and tongue faculties, which are the first to arise, is called “accumulation” in the sense of increase. After that,

original: rūpānaṃ uppādo upari vaḍḍhiatthena upacayonāma. Tato paraṃ yāvajīvaṃ catusantatirūpānaṃ
analyzed: rūpānaṃ uppādo upari vaḍḍhi atthena upacayo nāma tato param yāvajīvam catu santati rūpānaṃ
translated: the arising of the fourfold continuity of material instances is called “continuity” for as long as life lasts. For this is said in the commentary:

original: uppādo santatināma. Vuttañhetaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ nadītīre nikhātakūpasmiṃ udakuggamanakāloviya
analyzed: uppādo santati nāma vuttam ha etam aṭṭhakathāyam nadī tīre nikhāta kūpasmim
translated: “Just as the filling up of a well dug on the bank of a river is called ‘filling up,’🔽so the arising of material instances is called ‘accumulation’ in the sense of production. Just as the time when it is completely full is called ‘filled up,’🔽so the arising of material instances is called ‘accumulation’ in the sense of increase. Just as the time when it overflows is called ‘overflowing,’

original: ācayo nibbatti. Paripuṇṇakāloviya upacayo vaḍḍhi. Ajjhottharitvā gamanakālo viya santati pavattīti.
analyzed: ācayaḥ nibbatti paripuṇṇa kālo viya upacayaḥ vaḍḍhi ajjhottharitvā gamana kālo viya santati pavatti iti
translated: so the arising of material instances is called ‘continuity’ in the sense of occurrence.”

original: Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī

original: Paṭisandhito paṭṭhāya yāvacakkhādi dasakānaṃ uppatti. Etthantare rūpuppādo upacayonāma. Tato paraṃ santati nāmāti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi tena pariyāyena yujjatiyeva.🔽Saṃsedajopavātikānaṃ pana paṭisandhikkhaṇe rūpānaṃ uppādo pathamā bhinibbatti atthena
analyzed: paṭisandhitaḥ paṭṭhāya yāvacakkhādi dasakānam uppatti ettha antare rūpa uppādo upacayaḥ nāma tatas param santati nāma ati vuttam tat pi tena pariyāyena yujjati yeva  saṃseda ja upavātikānam pana paṭisandhi khaṇe rūpānam uppādaḥ pathamā abhinibbatti atthena
translated: From the moment of rebirth-linking until the arising of the eye, etc., the arising of material instances is called growth. What comes after that is called continuity. That too is appropriate in this way.

original: paripuṇṇa vaḍḍhi atthenaca upacayo nāma, tato paraṃ rūpānaṃ uppādo santatināma. Apica,🔽tisamuṭṭhānika rūpānaṃpi visuṃ visuṃ santatipaccuppannaṃnāma atthi. Tassaca ekekassa
analyzed: upacayaḥ nāma tato param uppādo santati nāma apica  ti samuṭṭhānika rūpānaṃ pi visum visum santati paccuppannaṃ nāma atthi tassa ca ekekassa
translated: But in the case of the material instances of the egg-born and womb-born, the arising of material instances at the moment of rebirth-linking is called growth in the sense of first production and in the sense of increase to completion. What comes after that is called continuity. Moreover,🔽there is what is called present continuity for each of the material instances originated by the three roots. And for each of these there are three states,

original: nibbatti vaḍḍhi pavatti vasena tisso tissoavatthā honti. Tattha ekekasantatiyaṃ ādimhi🔽santatisīsarūpānaṃ sabbapathamaṃ uppādo nibbattināma. Tato vaḍḍhanarūpānaṃ uppādo
analyzed: nibbatti vaḍḍhi pavatti vasena tissaḥ tisso avatthā honti tattha ekeka santatiyam ādimhi  santati sīsa rūpānam sabba pathamam uppādaḥ nibbatti nāma tatas vaḍḍhana rūpānam uppādaḥ
translated: that is to say, arising, growth, and occurrence. Herein, in a single continuity,

original: vaḍḍhīnāma. Vaḍḍhane samatte avaḍḍhitvā pabandhaṭṭhitivasena vattanavasenauppādopavattināma.
analyzed: vaḍḍhī nāma vaḍḍhane samatte a vaḍḍhitvā pabandha ṭṭhiti vasena vattana vasena auppādopavatti nāma
translated: the first arising of the material instances of the head hairs, etc., is called arising. The arising of the material instances that grow is called growth. When the growth is complete, the occurrence by way of the twenty kinds of persistence without growth is called occurrence.

original: Tattha ca nibbattivaḍḍhiyo upacayonāma. Pavattisantati nāma. Saṅkhepato pana loke
analyzed: tattha ca nibbatti vaḍḍhiyaḥ upacayaḥ nāma pavatti santati nāma saṅkhepato pana loke
translated: But in brief, in the world🔽in all the occurrences of materiality bound up with faculties and not bound up with faculties,

original: sabbāsu indriyānindriyabaddharūpapavattīsu sandissamāne jāyana vaḍḍhana pavattanasaṅkhāte
analyzed: sabbāsu indriya anindriya baddha rūpa pavattīsu sandissamāne jāyana vaḍḍhana pavattana saṅkhāte
translated: having seen the state consisting in generation, growth, and occurrence, called “generation,” “growth,” and “occurrence,”🔽respectively, the “accumulation” and the “series” should be understood. Here is the method:

original: avatthābhede disvā upacayasanta tiyo veditabbā. Tatrāyaṃ nayo-rukkhatiṇādīnivā sākhā
analyzed: avatthā bhede disvā tiyaḥ veditabbā tatra ayam sākhā
translated: just as, in the case of a tree, branches,🔽leaves, flowers, and fruits, etc., are generated first,

original: pattapupphaphalādīnivā ādimhi jāyanti. Jāyitvā vaḍḍhanti. Vaḍḍhane samatte avaḍḍhitvā🔽pabandhavasena pavattitvā bhijjantīti. Jīraṇaṃ jarā, jīranti jiṇṇabhāvaṃ gacchanti🔽etāyāti jarā. Sāyeva jaratā. Uppādajarābhaṅgehi niccalati nakampatīti nicco asaṅkhata
analyzed: ādimhi jāyanti jāyitvā vaḍḍhanti vaḍḍhane samatte a vaḍḍhitvā  bhijjanti iti jīraṇam jarāḥ jīranti jiṇṇa bhāvam gacchanti  etā āyāti jarā sā āyā iva jaratā uppāda jarā bhaṅgehi niccalati na kampati iti niccaḥ
translated: and having been generated, they grow, and when the growth is complete, they do not grow any more but occur by way of a continuity without breaking up, and then they break up;🔽so too, in the case of materiality, the generation is the generation of material instances, the growth is their growth, the occurrence is their occurrence by way of a continuity after the growth is complete.🔽The breaking up of the generated and grown materiality is called “ageing,” “decay,” “breaking up,” “disappearance,” “impermanence.”🔽They age, they become decayed, they go to destruction by this, thus it is ageing, decay, breaking up, disappearance, impermanence.

original: dhammo. Na nicco anicco, saṅkhatadhammo. Aniccassa bhāvo aniccatā, bhaṅgo.🔽[183] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: dhammaḥ na niccaḥ aniccaḥ saṅkhata dhammaḥ aniccassa bhāvaḥ anicca tā bhaṅgo  vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: That itself is ageing, decay, breaking up, disappearance, impermanence.

original: “Niccadhuvabhāvena na iccaṃ anugantabbanti anicca”nti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: nicca dhuva bhāvena na iccam anugantabbanti aniccanti vuttam tam na sundaram
translated: It does not move, it does not tremble, it does not shake, it does not waver, it does not oscillate, it does not vacillate, it does not quake, it does not reel, it does not tremble violently, it does not tremble slightly, it does not quake violently, it does not quake slightly, it does not shake violently, it does not shake slightly, it does not move, it does not tremble, it does not shake, it does not waver, it does not oscillate, it does not vacillate, it does not quake, it does not reel, it does not tremble violently, it does not tremble slightly, it does not quake violently, it does not quake slightly, it does not shake violently, it does not shake slightly, it does not move, it does not tremble, it does not shake, it does not waver, it does not oscillate, it does not vacillate, it does not quake, it does not reel, it does not tremble violently, it does not tremble slightly, it does not quake violently, it does not quake slightly,

original: Niccasaddo hi sāsane lokeca pākaṭo. So eva idha nakārayutto aniccoti vuttoti. Lakkhīyanti
analyzed: nicca saddo hi sāsane loke ca pākaṭaḥ saḥ eva idha nakāra yuttaḥ aniccaḥ ti vuttaḥ ti
translated: For the word “permanent” is well known in the world and in the Dispensation. It is that very word, with the negative na attached to it, that is referred to here as “impermanent.”🔽“Characteristic” :

original: sallakkhīyanti vinicchīyanti dhammā ime saṅkhatāti etenāti lakkhaṇaṃ. Saṅkhata bhāvajānananimitanti
analyzed: sallakkhīyanti vinicchīyanti dhammā ime saṅkhatā ati etena ati lakkhaṇam saṅkhata bhāva jānana nimitanti
translated: the dhammas are characterized, i.e., discerned, determined, by this, thus it is a characteristic . The meaning is: the cause for the knowledge of the formed .

original: attho. Yathāha- aṅguttare tīṇi māni bhikkhave saṅkhatassa saṅkhatalakkhaṇāni. Katamāni
analyzed: atthaḥ yathā āha aṅguttare tīṇi māni bhikkhave saṅkhatassa saṅkhata lakkhaṇāni katamāni
translated: As it is said: “Bhikkhus, there are three characteristics of the formed that are to be known.

original: tīṇi, uppādo paññāyati, vayo paññāyati, ṭhitassa aññathattaṃ paññāyatīti. Nanu pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: tīṇi uppādo paññāyati vayo paññāyati ṭhitassa aññathattam paññāyati iti nanu pāḷiyam
translated: What are the three? Arising is discerned, passing away is discerned, change while remaining the same is discerned” .🔽But in the text it is called “birth” . Therefore it is said here: “Birth is the same as the characteristic of origination.”

original: jātināma āgatā. Tasmā sāpi idha vattabbāti vuttaṃ jātirūpamevātiādi. Etthāti rūpasamuddese.🔽Jananaṃ pātubhavanaṃ jāti. Jāyantivā etāyāti jāti, upacaya santati nāmenapavuccati
analyzed: jāti nāma āgatā tasmā sā api idha vattabbā ati vuttam jāti rūpam eva ātiādi ettha ati rūpa samuddese  jananam pātubhavanam jāti jāyantivā
translated: Here means in the exposition of materiality .🔽Birth is the manifestation, the coming to birth, of the aggregates. Or it is the cause of their coming to birth, thus it is birth . It is also called “accumulation” and “continuity” .

original: tassājātiyātathā avatthābhedayogatoti adhippāyo. Sā hi ādito paṭisandhirūpāni pātubhavantāni
analyzed: avatthā bheda yogato ti adhippāyaḥ sā hi āditas paṭisandhi rūpāni pātubhavantāni
translated: The intention is that it is not suitable to be called “non-birth” because of the non-division of the state. For it is birth that causes the aggregates to manifest at the beginning as rebirth-linking .

original: karoti. Puna aparipuṇṇānica āyatanāni pūreti. Pūritāni ca dīghaṃpi addhānaṃ abbocchinnaṃ
analyzed: karoti puna a paripuṇṇāni ca āyatanāni pūreti pūritāni ca
translated: and he makes it last for a long time without interruption.

original: katvā pavatteti pabandhayatīti. Ekā dasavidhaṃpīti mahābhūtādibhāvena ekattaṃ upanayanavasena
analyzed: katvā pavattā iti pabandhayati iti ekā mahābhūta ādi bhāvena upanayana vasena
translated: It is one, and it is of ten kinds, too, in the sense of being one by being reduced to the primary elements and so on.

original: ekā dasapabhedaṃpi. Kathaṃ sarūpavasena aṭṭhavīsatividhaṃ hotīti pucchitvā bhūtappasāda
analyzed: katham sarūpa vasena aṭṭhavīsatividham hoti iti pucchitvā bhūtappasāda
translated: How is it of twenty-eight kinds by its individual essence? Having asked this, the answer is given by the eleven kinds beginning with the primary elements and the sensitive material according to their individual essences.

original: visayātiādinā ekādasavidhasseva sarūpato dassanaṃ antogadhabhedānaṃ pubbe vuttabhāvena
analyzed: visaya ati ādinā ekādasavidhassa iva sarūpataḥ dassanam antogadha bhedānam pubbe vutta bhāvena
translated: The various kinds included in these should be regarded as already made clear by the explanation given above.

original: supākaṭattāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tenāha-aṭṭhārasavidhanti.🔽Cattāri bhūtāni pañcapasādā agahitagahaṇena cattāro visayā gocarā. Duvidho bhāvo.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam tena āha aṭṭhārasavidham ti  cattāri bhūtāni pañca pasādāḥ agahita gahaṇena cattāro visayāḥ gocarāḥ duvidhaḥ bhāvo
translated: That is why he said “of eighteen kinds.”

original: Ekaṃ hadayaṃ. Iti idaṃ soḷasavidhaṃ rūpaṃ jīvitāhārarūpehi saha aṭṭhārasavidhaṃ hoti
analyzed: ekam hadayam iti idam soḷasavidham rūpam jīvita āhāra rūpehi saha aṭṭhārasavidham hoti
translated: The four primary elements, the five kinds of sensitivity, the four objects, which are the objective fields, the two kinds of states, the one heart-basis, and the two kinds of materiality called life and sex are the eighteen kinds of materiality.

original: tathā eko paricchedo. Duvidhā viññatti. Agahitagahaṇena tividho vikāro. Catubbidhaṃ
analyzed: tathā ekaḥ paricchedaḥ duvidhā a gahita gahaṇena tividhaḥ vikāro catubbidham
translated: So too, there is one kind of delimitation, two kinds of intimation, three kinds of change, which are the kinds not already included by the previous terms, and four kinds of nutriment.

original: lakkhaṇanti dasa anipphannācāti rūpaṃ sarūpato aṭṭhavīsatividhaṃ bhaveti yojanā.
analyzed: dasa rūpam sarūpataḥ aṭṭhavīsatividham bhava iti yojanā
translated: The characteristic is the ten unoriginated. The interpretation is this: materiality is of twenty-two kinds as to individual essence.

original: Etthaca pacchimāni dasarūpāni sabhāvato anupalabbhamānattā paccayehi nipphāditāni🔽rūpāni na hontīti anipphannāni nāma. Api cettha abhidhamme visuṃ uddiṭṭhāni niddiṭṭhānica
analyzed: ettha ca pacchimāni dasa rūpāni sabhāvataḥ anupalabbhamāna ttā paccayehi nipphāditāni  rūpāni na honti iti anipphannāni nāma api ca ittha abhidhamme visum uddiṭṭhāni niddiṭṭhāni ca
translated: And here the last ten kinds of materiality are called unoriginated because they are not originated by conditions as materiality that exists in individual essence.

original: etāni sabhāvato anupalabbhamānānīti vā paramatthato avijjamānānītivā nasakkā vattuṃ.🔽Vohārasiddha mattabhāvaṃ atikkamma tādisena suddhadhammagatiyā siddhena paramattha🔽lakkhaṇena upaladdhattā. Itarathā nibbattilakkhaṇarahitaṃ asaṅkhata nibbānaṃpi sabhāvato
analyzed: etāni sabhāvataḥ anupalabbhamānāni iti vā paramatthataḥ avijjamānāni iti vā na sakkā vattum  vohāra siddha matta bhāvam atikkamma tādisena suddha dhamma gatiyā siddhena paramattha  lakkhaṇena itarathā nibbatti lakkhaṇa rahitam asaṅkhata nibbānam api sabhāvato
translated: But although they are so called in the Abhidhamma, they cannot be said to be non-existent in individual essence or non-existent in the ultimate sense.

original: anupalabbhamānaṃ paramatthato avijjamānañca nāma siyāti. Tasmā nibbatti lakkhaṇarahitattāeva
analyzed: anupalabbhamānam paramatthataḥ avijjamānam ca nāma siyāti tasmā nibbatti lakkhaṇa rahita ttā eva
translated: For they are apprehended by means of the ultimate characteristic that is established by a mode of progress confined to pure states, which transcends the mere state of being established by usage. Otherwise, the unformed element, Nibbāna, would be non-existent in individual essence and non-existent in the ultimate sense, since it lacks the characteristic of being originated.

original: etāni anipphannānināma. Na sabhāvato anupalabbhamānattāti yuttaṃ siyāti. [Rūpasamuddeso]
analyzed: etāni na sabhāvataḥ anupalabbhamāna ttā ati yuttam siyā iti rūpa samuddesaḥ
translated: So it is proper to say that they are called unoriginated because they lack the characteristic of being originated, not because they are non-existent in individual essence.🔽The exposition of materiality is ended.

original: 157. Rūpavibhāgesabbañca pana etaṃ yathāsamuddiṭṭhaṃ aṭṭhavīsati vidhaṃ rūpaṃ ahetukaṭṭhena🔽ekavidhameva. Na sahetukā hetuka vasena duvidhaṃ. Tathāsappaccayaṭṭhena ekavidhameva.🔽Na sappaccayāpaccaya vasena duvidhanti evaṃ pavattaṃ ekavidhanayaṃ tāva dassetuṃ
