analyzed: pana etam yathā samuddiṭṭham aṭṭhavīsati vidham rūpam ahetuka ṭṭhena  ekavidham eva na sa hetuka ahetuka vasena duvidham tathā sa paccaya ṭṭhena ekavidham eva  na sa paccaya apaccaya vasena duvidhanti evam pavattam ekavidha nayam tāva dassetuṃ
translated: And all this materiality, of the twenty-eight kinds as stated, is of one kind only as without root-cause,🔽not of two kinds as with and without root-cause. Likewise it is of one kind only as having conditions,🔽not of two kinds as having and not having conditions. So far the method of one kind is shown by the words “And all this” ,

original: sabbañcātiādimāraddhaṃ.
analyzed: sabbañca ati ādim āraddham
translated: which are stated in order to introduce the method of one kind.

original: [184] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga,

original: Ekavidhanayopi rūpavibhāgoevāti katvā “yathā uddiṭṭha rūpānaṃ ekavidhādinayaṃ dassanatthaṃ sabbañca panetantiādi vutta”nti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sameti.
analyzed: ekavidha nayaḥ api rūpa vibhāgaḥ eva iti katvā yathā ekavidha ādi nayam dassana ttham sabbam ca pana itantiādi vuttanti vuttam tam na sameti
translated: after the words “The exposition of materiality is of one kind” , it is said: “The words ‘And all this’ are stated in order to show the method of one kind, etc., of the material instances as stated” . That is incorrect.

original: Vakkhati hi –
analyzed: vakkhati hi
translated: For it is said:

original: Ajjhattikādibhedena, vibhajanti yathārahanti.
analyzed: ajjhattika ādi bhedena vibhajanti yathārahanti
translated: “They are classed according to what is appropriate As internal and so on” .

original: Etena ajjhattikādibhedo eva rūpavibhāgonāmāti viññāyati.
analyzed: etena ajjhattika ādi bhedaḥ eva rūpa vibhāgaḥ nāma ati viññāyati
translated: And by this it is evident that the exposition of materiality is only the classification according to what is appropriate as internal and so on.

original: Tattha sabbaṃpi rūpaṃ hetusampayogā bhāvato ahetuka meva, na kiñci sahetukaṃ. Kiñci
analyzed: tattha sabbam api rūpam hetu sampayogāḥ bhāvataḥ ahetukam eva na kiñci sa hetukam kiñci
translated: Herein, all materiality, as to its being associated with root-cause, is in reality without root-cause, not with root-cause. Some is

original: ahetukanti evaṃ vibhāgo atthīti adhippāyo. Sappaccayaṃ sāsavaṃ saṅkhataṃ lokiyanti
analyzed: ahetukam ti evam vibhāgaḥ atthi iti adhippāyaḥ sa paccayam sa āsavam saṅkhatam lokiyanti
translated: The intention is that there is this distinction. The reading is “With conditions, with taints, formed, mundane.” But it is proper to read “With conditions, formed, mundane, with taints.”🔽For it is seen in the text in that way.

original: pāṭho. Sappaccayaṃ saṅkhataṃ lokiyaṃ sāsavanti pana yutto. Pāḷiyaṃpi tathā diṭṭhattā
analyzed: sappaccayam saṅkhatam lokiyam pana yuttaḥ tathā diṭṭhattā
translated: Because of the occurrence of a pair of terms in common. The other terms, though not mentioned in the text, are proper

original: sabhāgayugaḷasambhavatocāti. Itarāni pana pāḷikamena asamentānipi sabhāga yugaḷattā
analyzed: itarāni pana
translated: because of the occurrence of a pair of terms in common.

original: bhāgato yuttānieva. Tattha attano janakena paccayena saheva vattatīti sapaccayaṃ.
analyzed: bhāgataḥ yuttāni eva tattha attanaḥ janakena paccayena saha iva vattati iti sa paccayam
translated: Herein, it occurs together with the conditions that generate it, thus it is with conditions .

original: Paccayehi saṅgamma karīyatīti saṅkhataṃ. Pañcupādā nakkhandhasaṅkhāte lokeeva pariyāpannanti
analyzed: paccayehi saṅgamma karīyati iti saṅkhatam pañca upādāḥ nakkhandha saṅkhāte loke eva pariyāpannanti
translated: It is formed by being formed together with conditions, thus it is formed . It is included only in the world consisting of the five aggregates called “formed,” thus it is mundane .

original: lokiyaṃ. Attānaṃ ārabbha pavattehi āsavehi saheva vattatīti sāsavaṃ. Akaniṭṭha brahmasantāna
analyzed: lokiyam attānam ārabbha pavattehi āsavehi saha iva vattati iti sa āsavam akaniṭṭha brahmasantāna
translated: It occurs together with the taints that occur having it as their object, thus it is with taints . The materiality that occurs in the continuity of the Brahmā of the Highest should be understood as the fine-material sphere,

original: bhūtaṃpi rūpaṃ kāmataṇhā visayabhāvena kāmeeva pariyāpannattā kāmāvacaraṃ. Natthi
analyzed: rūpam kāma taṇhā visaya bhāvena kāme eva pariyāpanna ttā kāmāvacaram natthi
translated: because it is included in the fine-material sphere as an object of sense desire, since it is the object of sense desire of the sense-desire-sphere deities.🔽There is no object called “seized by oneself,” thus it is without object .

original: attanā gahitaṃ kiñci ārammaṇaṃnāma assāti anārammaṇaṃ. Yo dhammo aññena payogena
analyzed: attanā gahitam kiñci assa ati anārammaṇam yaḥ dhammaḥ aññena payogena
translated: There is no other state of existence that is reached by a different method, thus it is not a state to be reached by another method.

original: pahīnopi samudayapahāne asati apahīnova hoti. Puna avassaṃ uppajjamānattā. Appahīnopi
analyzed: pahīnaḥ api samudaya pahāne asati apahīnaḥ uva hoti puna avassam uppajjamāna ttā a pahīnaḥ api
translated: And what has been abandoned is abandoned only so long as the origin is not present again. And what has not been abandoned is abandoned

original: tasmiṃ sati pahīnova hoti. Puna anuppajjamānattā. Tādiso dhammo pahānavāyāmassa aṭṭhānattā🔽appahātabbonāma. Rūpaṃpi edisameva hotīti vuttaṃ appahātabba mevāti. Aṭṭhānattā pahāna
analyzed: tasmin sati pahīnaḥ iva hoti puna anuppajjamāna ttā tādisaḥ dhammaḥ pahāna vāyāmassa aṭṭhāna ttā  rūpaṃ pi edisam eva hoti iti vuttam a pahātabba meva ati aṭṭhāna ttā pahāna
translated: only so long as the origin is not present again. Such a state is not to be abandoned because of the non-existence of the effort to abandon it.

original: vāyāmaṃ na arahatīti attho. Athavā, vinā samudayapahānena pahātuṃ asakkuṇeyyoti attho.🔽Yadi evaṃ rūpaṃ bhikkhave na tumhākaṃ. Taṃ pajahatha. Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ dīgharattaṃ
analyzed: vāyāmam na arahati iti attho athavā vinā samudaya pahānena pahātum asakkuṇeyyaḥ ti attho  yadi evam rūpam bhikkhave na tumhākam tam pajahatha tam vaḥ pahīnam dīgharattam
translated: And so it was said of materiality that it is not to be abandoned. It is not to be abandoned because it is not possible to abandon it by the effort to abandon it. Or else the meaning is that it cannot be abandoned without abandoning its origin.

original: atthāya hitāya sukhāya bhavissatīti idaṃ kathanti. Taṃpi tabbisayassa rāgassa pahānaṃ
analyzed: atthāya hitāya sukhāya bhavissati iti idam kathanti tad pi tad visayassa rāgassa pahānaṃ
translated: If that is so, then why is this said: “Materiality, bhikkhus, is not yours. Abandon it. When it is abandoned by you, it will lead to your welfare and happiness for a long time” ?

original: sandhāya vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yathāha –
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam iti daṭṭhabbam yathā āha
translated: That should be regarded as said with reference to the abandoning of the lust for that. For it is said:

original: Rūpe kho rādha yo chando, yo rāgo, yānandī, yā taṇhā, taṃ pajahatha. Evaṃ taṃrūpaṃ pahīnaṃ bhavissati ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṃkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammanti.🔽Ayaṃ nayo aññesupi kusalādīsu appahātabbesu veditabboti. Evasaddo cettha purimapadesupi
analyzed: rūpe kho rādha yaḥ chandaḥ yaḥ rāgaḥ yā ānandī yā taṇhā tam pajahatha evam taṃrūpam pahīnam bhavissati ucchinna mūlam tālā vatthukatam anabhāvaṃkatam āyatim an uppāda dhammanti  ayam nayaḥ aññesu pi kusala ādīsu appahātabbesu veditabbaḥ iti eva saddo ca ittha purima padesu pi
translated: “In regard to materiality, Rādha, abandon desire… “

original: yojetabbo. Itisaddo ādiattho, pakāratthovā. Tena pāḷiyaṃ āgataṃ na hetu hetuvippayuttantiādiṃ
analyzed: yojetabbaḥ iti saddaḥ ādi attho pakāra atthaḥ vā tena pāḷiyam āgatam na hetu hetu vippayutta nti ādim
translated: This method should be understood in the case of the other wholesome, etc., dhammas that are not to be abandoned. The word eva should be construed with each of the preceding terms. The word iti has the meaning of “beginning with” or the meaning of “indicating.”🔽Thus it includes what is stated in the text beginning with “not a root, not dissociated from a root,” etc.

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Tassa tassa puggalassa attabhāvapariyāpanno dhammasamūho ajjhattaṃnāma.
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti tassa tassa puggalassa atta bhāva pariyāpannaḥ dhamma samūhaḥ ajjhattam nāma
translated: The collection of dhammas included in the individual essence of a person is called “internal.”

original: Tasmiṃpica yattha taṇhāya atirekataraṃ daḷhapariggaho hoti. So cakkhādiko cittena
analyzed: tasmin pi ca yattha taṇhāya atirekataram daḷha pariggaho hoti so cakkha ādiko cittena
translated: And in regard to that, that which is the object of the most intense and firm grasping of craving is the internal sixfold base beginning with the eye, which is accompanied by mind.

original: saha chabbidho dhammo ajjhattiko nāma. Ajjhatte vidito pākaṭoti katvā. Tathā hi so
analyzed: saha chabbidhaḥ dhammaḥ ajjhattikaḥ nāma ajjhatte viditaḥ pākaṭaḥ iti katvā tathā hi so
translated: It is called “internal” because it is known and evident to oneself. For this reason it is also called “internal-external.”

original: ajjhattajjhattantipi vutto. Itarāni pana rūpādini phassādīnica tadupādāya taṇhāpariggahassa
analyzed: vuttaḥ itarāni pana rūpa ādini phassa ādīni ca tat upādāya taṇhā pariggahassa
translated: The other dhammas, such as material form, contact, etc., are called “external” because they are the objects of craving that grasps the internal.

original: mandattā bāhirāni nāma. Yathā hi loke maṇivā suvaṇṇaṃvā rajataṃvā bahigehe nidahitvā🔽thapitaṃ hoti. Pacchivā suppaṃvā ghaṭovā sarāvovā anto gehe thapito. Tattha pacchimāni
analyzed: bāhirāni nāma yathā hi loke maṇi vā suvaṇṇam vā rajatam vā bahi gehe nidahitvā  thapitam hoti pacchivā suppam vā ghaṭaḥ vā sarāvaḥ vā antar gehe thapitaḥ tattha pacchimāni
translated: and the external are so called because of their weakness. For just as in the world a jewel or gold or silver is kept🔽in an outer room,🔽and a pot or a water-jug or a water-pot is kept in an inner room,

original: chaḍḍetvāpi purimāni rakkhanti. Tasmā tāneva taṇhāpariggahadaḷhatāya antoparibhogātveva
analyzed: chaḍḍetvā api purimāni rakkhanti tasmā tān eva taṇhā pariggaha daḷha tāya
translated: there the latter are discarded and the former are kept. Therefore they are called “internal” because they are kept for one’s own use and are firmly held by craving,

original: vuccanti. Pacchimāni pana bāhira paribhogātveva. Evaṃ sampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Idhapi
analyzed: vuccanti pacchimāni pana evam sampadam idam daṭṭhabbam idha api
translated: and the latter are called “external” because they are kept for others’ use. This is how the matter should be regarded here.

original: hi yadi sakkuṇeyya. Rūpādīni phassādinica sabbāni chaḍḍetvāpi cakkhādikaṃ chabbidhameva🔽avassaṃ rakkhissantīti. Iti taṇhā pariggahassa daḷhamandatā vaseneva tesaṃ dvinnaṃ
analyzed: hi yadi rūpa ādīni phassa ādini ca sabbāni chaḍḍetvā api cakkha ādikam chabbidham eva  avassam rakkhissanti iti iti taṇhā pariggahassa daḷha manda tā vasena iva tesam dvinnam
translated: For if one could discard the visible-data base, etc., and keep only the eye base, etc.,🔽one would do so. So the internal and external should be understood as stated according to the strength or weakness of the holding by craving,

original: ajjhattika bāhiratā vuttā. Na pavattidesavasenāti niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ.
analyzed: ajjhattika bāhira tā vuttā na pavatti desa vasena ati niṭṭham ettha gantabbam
translated: not according to the direction in which they occur. This is the decision here.

original: [185] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Ajjhattikarūpaṃ atthabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ attānaṃ adhikicca uddissa pavattattā. Kāmaṃ
analyzed: ajjhattika rūpam attha bhāva saṅkhātam attānam adhikicca uddissa pavatta ttā kāmam
translated: “The internal materiality is called ‘one’s own’ because it occurs having appropriated what is called the ‘self.’

original: aññepi ajjhattasambhūtā atthi. Ruḷhīvasena pana cakkhādikameva ajjhattikanti” vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: aññe pi ajjhatta sambhūtāḥ atthi ruḷhī vasena pana cakkha ādikam eva ajjhattikanti vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: and there are other things that are internal to it. But it is only the eye, etc., that are called ‘internal’ in the sense of being ‘grown on one’s own person.’ ” This is not good.

original: [186] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there, namely,

original: “Attasaṅkhātaṃpā cittaṃ adhikicca tassa dvārabhāvena pavattatīthi ajjhattaṃ. Tadeva ajjhattikanti” vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: cittam adhikicca tassa dvāra bhāvena pavattati ajjhattam tat eva ajjhattikanti vuttam na sundaram
translated: “The mind called ‘self’ is the principal factor, and the eye, etc., occur as its doors and as its objects,” is not good.

original: Tasmiṃ atthe hi sati cittassa ajjhattatā na sampajjati. Ajjhattadhamma ajjhattikammonañca aviseso āpajjatīti.
analyzed: tasmin atthe hi sati cittassa ajjhatta tā na sampajjati ajjhatta dhamma ajjhatti kammonam ca avisesaḥ āpajjati iti
translated: For if that were the meaning, the mind would not be internal, and there would be no difference between an internal state and an internal object.

original: Yaṃ pana tattha
analyzed: yam pana tattha
translated: But what is said there, namely,

original: Athavā yadi mayaṃ na homa, tvaṃ kaṭṭhakaliṅgarūpamo bhavissatīti vadantā viya attabhāvassa sātisayaṃ upakārakattā cakkhādineva visesato ajjhattikānīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ yuttataraṃ.
analyzed: athavā yadi mayam na tvam bhavissati iti vadantāḥ viya atta bhāvassa sa atisayam upakāraka ttā cakkha ādinā iva visesataḥ ajjhattikāni iti vuttam tam yuttataram
translated: Or alternatively, just as when it is said, “If you are not, you will be like a post of acacia wood,” the eye, etc., are called “internal” in the sense of being especially helpful to the self. That is more reasonable.🔽For it is because of their special helpfulness that beings cling to them as themselves.

original: Tathā upakārātisayattāeva hi tesu sattānaṃ pariggaha daḷhatā hotīti. Sattavidhaṃpi
analyzed: tathā hi tesu sattānam daḷha tā hoti iti sattavidham pi
translated: The internal is sevenfold,

original: dvārarūpaṃnāma. Yathākkamaṃ vīthi cittānaṃ pāṇātipātādikammānañca pavattimukhattā.
analyzed: yathākkamam cittānam pāṇātipāta ādi kammānam ca pavatti mukha ttā
translated: It is the door-shaped materiality. Because it is the door of occurrence for the consciousnesses of the cognitive series and for the kamma-process consisting in killing-breathing-things, etc., respectively.

original: Tattha pana pañca vidhaṃ pasādarūpaṃ upapattidvāraṃnāma. Viññattidvayaṃ kammadvāraṃnāmāti
analyzed: tattha pana pañca vidham pasāda rūpam upapatti dvāram nāma viññatti dvayam kamma dvāram nāma ati
translated: Herein, the five-sensed-door-natured materiality is the door of rebirth. The two kinds of intimation are the door of kamma.

original: oḷārikarūpaṃ pakatiyā thūlasabhāvattā ghaṭṭanasaṅkhātassaca attano kiccassa oḷārikattā.
analyzed: oḷārika rūpam pakatiyā thūla sabhāvattā ghaṭṭana saṅkhātassa ca attano kiccassa oḷārika ttā
translated: The gross materiality is so called because it is by nature gross, and because its function, which is called “impaction,” is gross.

original: Santikerūpaṃ dūre pavattassapi sīghataraṃ ñāṇena gahaṇayogyattā. Sappaṭigharūpañcāti
analyzed: dūre pavattassa api sīghataram ñāṇena gahaṇa yogya tā sa paṭigha rūpam ca ati
translated: The subtle materiality is so called because it is fit to be apprehended by knowledge that occurs more rapidly, even though it is far away. And the impinged-upon materiality is so called

original: ettha paṭihananaṃ paṭigho. So duvidho visayavisayīnaṃ paṭighaṭṭanaṃ mahā bhūtānaṃ🔽aññamaññapaṭighaṭṭananti. Tattha yena paṭighaṭṭanena pasāda dvārānaṃ bhavaṅgassaca🔽vikārappatti hoti. Idaṃ visayavisayīnaṃ paṭighaṭṭanaṃnāma. Yena ruppanalakkhaṇānaṃ
analyzed: ettha paṭihananam paṭighaḥ saḥ duvidhaḥ visaya visayīnam paṭighaṭṭanam mahā  añña mañña paṭighaṭṭananti tattha yena paṭighaṭṭanena bhavaṅgassa ca  vikāra ppatti hoti idam visaya visayīnam paṭighaṭṭanam nāma yena ruppana lakkhaṇānam
translated: because of impinging. The impinging is twofold as impinging of object and of objective field, and as impinging of the great primaries upon each other.🔽Herein, the impinging by which there is modification of the door-sensibles and of the life-continuum is called impinging of object and of objective field. That by which there is modification of the material phenomena characterized by deformation,

original: rūpadhammānaṃ ruppana kuppana ghaṭṭana pīḷana bhijjanādayo pavattanti. Idaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ
analyzed: rūpa dhammānam ruppana kuppana ghaṭṭana pīḍana bhijjana ādayaḥ pavattanti idam mahābhūtānam
translated: such as the arising of the deformation called “breaking,” etc., is called impinging of the great primaries upon each other.

original: aññamaññapaṭighaṭṭanaṃ nāma. Paṭighena saha vattatīti sappaṭighaṃ.
analyzed: aññamañña paṭighaṭṭanam nāma paṭighena saha vattati iti sa paṭigham
translated: It is the mutual impact. It is impinging with impact, thus it is with impact.

original: [187] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said as follows:

original: “Yo sayaṃ nissayavasenaca sampattānaṃ asampattānañca paṭimukhabhāvo aññamaññapatanaṃ.
analyzed: yaḥ sayam nissaya vasena ca sampattānam a sampattānam ca paṭimukha bhāvaḥ aññamañña patanam
translated: “The mutual impact of those that have reached and those that have not reached impingement by way of support is impact.

original: So paṭigho viyāti paṭigho. Yathāhi paṭighāte sati dubbalassa calanaṃ hoti. Evaṃ aññamaññapaṭimukhabhāve🔽sati arūpasabhāvattā dubbalassa bhavaṅgassa calanaṃ hotīti” evaṃ mahābhūtaghaṭṭanaṃ
analyzed: so paṭighaḥ viyā ati paṭighaḥ yathā hi paṭighāte sati dubbalassa calanam hoti evam aññamañña paṭimukha bhāve  sati arūpa sabhāva tā dubbalassa bhavaṅgassa calanam hoti iti evam mahābhūta ghaṭṭanam
translated: It is like impact, thus it is impact. For just as, when there is impact, there is movement of the weak one, so too, when there is mutual impingement,

original: upamāmattaṃ katvā visayavisayighaṭṭanameva gahitaṃ. Taṃ anupapannaṃ.
analyzed: upamā mattam katvā visaya visayi ghaṭṭanam eva gahitam anupapannam
translated: there is movement of the weak life-continuum, which is not material” . So it is the impact of the great primaries that is meant by “impact,” taking it as similar to impact. But that is not correct.

original: Evañhi sati yāni loke ajjhattabahiddhāsantānesu ghaṭṭanāni dissanti. Yesaṃ vasena🔽rūpadhammesu aññamaññaṃ laggana bandhana thambhana dhāraṇa calanādīnivā vaḍḍhana
analyzed: evam hi sati yāni loke ajjhatta bahiddhā santānesu ghaṭṭanāni dissanti yesam vasena  rūpa dhammesu aññamaññam laggana bandhana thambhana dhāraṇa calana ādīni iva vaḍḍhana
translated: For if that were so, then the impacts that are seen in the world in the case of internal and external series would not be included here.🔽And it is by means of them that the increase and decrease, the binding, the fixing, the supporting, the moving, etc., of material things, and the growth, the decay, the cutting, the breaking, the melting, the scattering, etc., of material things,

original: hāyana chedana bhedana vilīna vikiraṇādīnivā pavattanti. Tāni idha asaṅgahitāni siyuṃ.
analyzed: hāyana chedana bhedana vilīna vikiraṇa ādīni vā pavattanti tāni idha asaṅgahitāni siyum
translated: take place.

original: Naca tāni anuggaha upaghāta vasena pavattibhūta sannipāta saṅkhātaṃ ghaṭṭanaṃvinā
analyzed: naca tāni anuggaha upaghāta vasena pavatti bhūta sannipāta saṅkhātam ghaṭṭanam vinā
translated: And they do not occur without the impact called the concurrence that is the basis for their occurrence as assistance and obstruction.

original: aññapakārānieva sakkā bhavitunti. Itaraṃ soḷasavidhaṃ vuttapaṭipakkhavasena sukhumarūpaṃ
analyzed: sakkā bhavitun ti itaram soḷasavidham vutta paṭipakkha vasena sukhuma rūpam
translated: And they cannot be otherwise than the impingement called ‘concourse’ which is the cause of their occurrence by way of benefit and harm.🔽The other sixteen kinds are subtle matter, distant matter, and unimpeded matter, respectively.

original: dūrerūpaṃ apaṭigharūpañca. Upādinnarūpaṃ nāma katthaci yaṃkiñci sarīraṭṭhakarūpaṃ
analyzed: dūrerūpam apaṭigha rūpam ca upādinna rūpam nāma katthaci yaṃkiñci sarīraṭṭhaka rūpam
translated: ‘Matter derived’ is any matter whatever that is a constituent of the body in some place.

original: vuccati. Katthaci kammasamuṭṭhāna meva tadubhayaṃpi taṇhādiṭṭhīhi tusaṃ ādinnaparāmaṭṭhattā
analyzed: vuccati katthaci kamma samuṭṭhāna meva tat ubhayam pi taṇhā diṭṭhīhi ādinna parāmaṭṭha ttā
translated: In some places it is said to be the two, that is, both the kamma-originated and the nutriment-originated, because it is derived and clung to by craving and views.

original: upādinnaṃ nāma nippariyāyato pana kammasamuṭṭhānameva upādinnaṃnāma. Kasmā tasseva
analyzed: upādinnam nāma nippariyāyato pana kamma samuṭṭhānam eva upādinnam nāma kasmā tassa iva
translated: But in the true sense of the word it is only the kamma-originated that is called ‘derived’ because it is derived by kamma.

original: sattasantāne niccakālaṃ pavattivasena sātisayaṃ bhusaṃ ādinnagahitaparāmaṭṭhatāsambhavatoti🔽vuttaṃ kammajaṃupādinnarūpanti. Etaṃ mamātiādinā taṇhādiṭṭhīhi bhusaṃ ādiyatīti upādinnaṃ.
analyzed: satta santāne nicca kālam pavatti vasena sa atisayam bhusam ādinna gahita parāmaṭṭha tā sambhavato ti  vuttam kamma jam upādinna rūpan ti etam mama ati ādinā taṇhā diṭṭhīhi bhusam ādiyati iti upādinnam
translated: Why? Because it is possible for it to be derived, taken, and clung to in abundance by the fact of its occurrence all the time in a being’s continuity.🔽So it is said that ‘Derived matter is kamma-born.’🔽It is ‘derived’ because it is derived, taken, and clung to in abundance by craving and views with the words ‘This is mine, this I am, this is my self’ .

original: Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana taṇhādiṭṭhīhi upetena kammunā attano phalabhāvena ādinnaṃ gahitanti
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam pana taṇhā diṭṭhīhi upetena kammunā attanaḥ phala bhāvena ādinnam gahitanti
translated: But in the commentary it is said that it is ‘derived’ because it is taken and clung to as its own fruit by kamma accompanied by craving and views.

original: imamatthaṃ dasseti. Saha nidassanena sanidassanaṃ. Nidassananti cakkhuviññāṇena daṭṭhabbabhāvo
analyzed: imam attham dasseti saha nidassanena sa nidassanam nidassananti cakkhu viññāṇena daṭṭhabba bhāvaḥ
translated: He shows the meaning of this. It is visible because it is together with the visible. The visible is said to be the state of being seen by eye-consciousness.

original: vuccati. So pana dhammato anaññattepi aññe viya katvā upacarīyati. Evañhi sati atthavisesabodho
analyzed: vuccati saḥ pana dhammataḥ anaññatte pi aññe viya katvā upacarīyati evam hi sati attha visesa bodhaḥ
translated: But although it is not different from the state of being seen, it is treated as though it were different. For in that case there is understanding of a particular meaning.🔽Or the visible is said to be the function of eye-consciousness. It is called visible because it occurs together with that.

original: hotīti. Nidassanantivā cakkhuviññāṇakiccaṃ vuccati. Tena saha vattatīti sanidassanantipi
analyzed: hoti iti cakkhu viññāṇa kiccam vuccati tena saha vattati iti
translated: It is also appropriate to say that it is visible because it is the visible that is the object of the eye-door process.

original: yujjatiyeva. Cakkhādidvayaṃ asampattavasena gocaraggāhikaṃ. Ghānādittayaṃ sampattavasena🔽gocaraggāhikanti pañcavidhaṃpi gocaraggāhikarūpanti yojanā. Tattha pasāde allīyitvā
analyzed: cakkha ādi dvayam a sampatta vasena gocaraggāhikam ghāna ādi ttayam sampatta vasena  gocaraggāhikanti pañcavidham pi gocaraggāhika rūpanti yojanā tattha pasāde
translated: The two, eye and ear, are called “the visible that is the object of the apprehending of the objective field” because they apprehend the objective field without coming into contact with it. The three, nose, tongue, and body, are called “the visible that is the object of the apprehending of the objective field” because they apprehend the objective field by coming into contact with it.

original: laggitvā uppannaṃ ārammaṇaṃ sampattaṃnāma. Kesaggamattaṃpi muñcitvā uppannaṃ asampattaṃnāma.
analyzed: laggitvā uppannam ārammaṇam sampattam nāma kesagga mattam pi muñcitvā uppannam a sampattam nāma
translated: The meaning is that the five kinds of visible should be construed as “the visible that is the object of the apprehending of the objective field.” Herein, the object that arises after penetrating into the clearness of the eye is called “come into contact with.” The object that arises after letting go of the eye even by the mere fraction of the time it takes a bird to pass a paddy field is called “not come into contact with.”🔽But why is it that the two, eye and ear, apprehend only what has not come into contact,

original: Kasmā panettha cakkhādidvayaṃ asampattameva gaṇhāti. Ghānādittayaṃ sampattamevāti,
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha cakkha ādi dvayam a sampattam eva gaṇhāti ghāna ādi ttayam sampattam eva ati
translated: and the three, nose, etc., apprehend only what has come into contact?

original: paccayavisesato. Āloko hi rūpagahaṇe cakkhussa paccayo. Ākāsoca saddagahaṇe sotassāti
analyzed: paccaya visesato ālokaḥ hi rūpa gahaṇe cakkhussa paccayaḥ sadda gahaṇe sotassa ati
translated: As to difference in condition: light is a condition for the eye in apprehending visible data. Space is a condition for the ear in apprehending sounds.

original: cakkhurūpesuca aññamaññaṃ laggitvā uppajjamānesu ālokaparivārassa okāso natthi. Tathā
analyzed: cakkhu rūpesu ca aññam aññam laggitvā uppajjamānesu āloka parivārassa okāso na atthi tathā
translated: But when the eye and visible data arise by sticking together, there is no room for light as a surrounding medium.🔽And so too with the ear and sounds and with the space surrounding the ear.

original: sotasaddesuca ākāsaparivārassāti. Vāyuāpapathaviyo pana ghānādittayassa gandhādigahaṇe🔽paccayā honti. Tattha vāyunāma gandhākaḍḍhanako nāsavātoyeva, soca sampattasseva🔽paccayo. Āponāma jivhātemanako āpo, sopi sampattasseva paccayo. Na hi raso sukkhajivhāya
analyzed: ākāsa parivārassa ati vāyu āpa pathaviyo pana gandha ādi gahaṇe  paccayāḥ honti tattha vāyu nāma gandhākaḍḍhanakaḥ soca sampattassa iva  paccayaḥ āpaḥ nāma jivhā temanakaḥ āpaḥ saḥ api sampattassa iva paccayaḥ na hi raso sukkha jivhāya
translated: But air and earth are conditions for the nose, etc., in apprehending odour, etc.,🔽The air is the air in the nostrils that carries off the odour. That is a condition only for what has reached the nose.🔽Water is the water in the tongue that spreads out the taste. That is a condition only for what has reached the tongue. For the taste does not spread on a dry tongue.

original: pharatīti. Pathavīca ghaṭṭanatthāya paccayo. Na hi dubbalapathavīsannissayo ālokovā🔽rajovākāye patamānopi pasāde ghaṭṭetīti. Iti paccayavisesato tesaṃ sampattāsampattavasena
analyzed: pharati iti ghaṭṭana tthāya paccayaḥ na hi dubbala pathavī sannissayaḥ ālokaḥ vā  rajaḥ vākāye patamānaḥ api pasāde ghaṭṭeti iti iti paccaya visesato tesam sampatta a sampatta vasena
translated: Earth is a condition for impact. For even though light, air, and dust particles fall on the sensitive skin, they do not impact on it if it is not supported by weak earth.🔽So there is a difference in their apprehension as to whether or not there is contact.

original: gahaṇa viseso hotīti. Tattha cakkhussa tāva asampattagahaṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ. Tañhi samīpe
analyzed: gahaṇa viseso hoti iti tattha cakkhussa tāva asampatta gahaṇam pākaṭam tat hi samīpe
translated: Herein, the eye’s non-contact apprehension is obvious. For that is

original: akkhivaṇṇaṃvā bhamukamūlaṃvā napassati. Dūre pana mahantaṃ candamaṇḍalādikaṃvā phalikāditirohitaṃvā
analyzed: akkhi vaṇṇam vā bhamuka mūlam vā na passati dūre pana mahantam canda maṇḍala ādikam vā phalika ādi tirohitam vā
translated: and he does not see the moon’s disk, etc., as big as a winnowing basket. But he sees the colour of the moon’s disk, etc., as far away as it may be, and he sees the direction and the place.

original: vaṇṇaṃ passati. Disādesavavatthānañcassa paññāyatīti. Sotassa pana kathanti, tattha🔽hi dūre saddo cirena suyyamāno dissati pacchimadisābhāge uppannopi saddo antarā mahante
analyzed: vaṇṇam passati disā desa vavatthānam ca ssa paññāyati iti sotassa pana kathanti tattha  hi dūre saddo cirena suyyamānaḥ dissati pacchima disā bhāge uppannaḥ api saddaḥ antarā mahante
translated: As to the ear, it is said that the sound is heard as if it were near when it is far away.🔽For a sound arisen in the western direction is heard without distinction in the southern or northern direction when there is an obstruction by a great mountain, and so on,

original: cetiyādike antarite sati dakkhiṇapassatovā suyyati. Uttarapassatovā. Asuyyamānovā
analyzed: cetiya ādike antarite sati dakkhiṇa passatā vā suyyati uttara passatā vā a suyyamānaḥ vā
translated: and it is not heard when there is no such obstruction.

original: hotīti. Vuccate, uppanno saddasaṅghāṭo āsanne ṭhitānaṃ ādito paṭṭhāya yāva avasānā
analyzed: hoti iti vuccate uppannaḥ sadda saṅghāṭaḥ āsanne ṭhitānam āditas paṭṭhāya yāva avasānā
translated: It may be said that the sound’s continuity becomes evident in sequence from the beginning to the end to those who are near,

original: kamena pākaṭībhūto hoti. Paṭighaṭṭanānighaṃsoca balavā hoti. Ahaṃ suṇomīti pavattā
analyzed: kamena pākaṭībhūtaḥ hoti balavā hoti aham suṇomi iti pavattā
translated: and the impact of the sound’s impingement is strong. The processes of adverting, etc., occur rapidly and uninterruptedly, as it were, and the process of determining is “I hear.”

original: sallakkhaṇavīthiyo sīghataraṃ nirantaraṃ viya pavattanti. Dūre ṭhitānaṃ pana paṭighaṭṭanānighaṃso
analyzed: sat lakkhaṇa vīthiyaḥ sīghataram nirantaram viya pavattanti dūre ṭhitānam pana
translated: But to those who are far away the impact of the sound’s impingement is weak,

original: mandataro hoti. Ādito apākaṭo. Majjhevā avasānevā piṇḍavasena pākaṭībhūto. Sallakkhaṇavīthiyo
analyzed: mandataraḥ hoti āditaḥ apākaṭaḥ majjhe vā avasāne vā piṇḍa vasena pākaṭībhūto sat lakkhaṇa vīthiyaḥ
translated: and so it is slower. At first it is not clear, but in the middle and at the end it becomes clear as a mass.🔽The succession of the moments of adverting, etc.,

original: cirena parena pavattanti. Tasmā tesaṃ lahuṃ suto. Cirena sutoti atimāno hotīti. Apica,
analyzed: cirena parena pavattanti tasmā tesam lahum sutaḥ cirena sutaḥ ti atimānaḥ hoti iti apica
translated: occurs later, and so it is heard slowly. And it is heard slowly because it is heard after a long time.🔽Moreover,

original: saddonāma nissayadhātuparaṃparāya pavattitvā dūraṃpi desaṃ gacchatiyeva. Evaṃ gacchantoca🔽gatagataṭṭhāneeva ṭhatvā savanūpacāre ṭhitānaṃ sotasahassaṃpi ghaṭṭeti. Mahante pana
analyzed: nissaya dhātu paraṃparāya dūram pi desam evam  gata gata ṭṭhāne eva ṭhatvā savana upacāre ṭhitānam sota sahassam pi ghaṭṭeti mahante pana
translated: sound travels by a succession of physical basis, and it goes to a place far away. And while it is doing so,🔽it strikes the thousand ear-drums of those who are standing in the place reached by it. But when there is an obstruction,

original: cetiyādike antarite sati yato ākāso ujuṃ vivaṭo hoti. Tato dakkhiṇapassatovā uttarapassatovā
analyzed: cetiya ādike antarite sati yatas ākāsaḥ ujum vivaṭaḥ hoti tatas dakkhiṇa passataḥ vā uttara passataḥ vā
translated: such as a great shrine, then it strikes the ear-drum from the direction of the south or the north,

original: gatagataṭhānatovasotaṃ ghaṭṭeti. Mandataro pana saddoasuyya mānopi hoti. Evaṃ gacchantoca
analyzed: gata gata ṭhānataḥ vasotam ghaṭṭeti mandataraḥ pana hoti evam gacchanto ca
translated: from the place reached by it. But a slow sound is also less arrogant. And while it is doing so,

original: yāva sotapasāde allīyitvā nuppajjati. Tāva asampattoyeva hoti. Yo pana allī yitvā
analyzed: yāva sotapasāde allīyitvā na uppajjati tāva hoti yaḥ pana
translated: it does not arise until it has entered the ear-sensitivity. So long as it has not done so,🔽it is not yet reached.

original: uppajjati. So sampattonāma hoti. Na so suyyatīti. Yadi pana sotaṃ sampattavisayaṃ🔽siyā. Yathā anto kucchigato gandho bahi naghāyiyati. Tathā anto kucchigato saddopi
analyzed: uppajjati saḥ sampattaḥ nāma hoti na saḥ suyyati iti yadi pana sotam sampatta visayam  siyā yathā antar kucchi gataḥ gandhaḥ bahi tathā antar kucchi gataḥ saddo pi
translated: It is called “reached” when it has reached the object. It does not hear.🔽If the ear were to be the apprehender of the object that has reached it,🔽then just as the smell inside the stomach does not manifest outside, so too the sound inside the stomach

original: bahi nasuyeyya. Gandhassa viya disādesavavatthānaṃ vissana siyāti.
analyzed: bahi gandhassa viya disā desa vavatthānam siyāti
translated: would not be heard outside. And there would be no distinction of direction and place in the object, as there is with smell.

original: [188] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī-Țīkā,

original: “Gantvā visayadesaṃ taṃ, pharitvā gaṇhatīti ce. Adhiṭṭhāna vidhā nepi, tassa so gocaro siyā.” Tipi vicāritaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: gantvā visaya desam tam pharitvā gaṇhati iti ce adhiṭṭhāna vidhā tassa so gocaro siyā vicāritam na sundaram
translated: “If you say that it goes to the place of the object and apprehends it by pervading it, then that would be its domain even without the resolution.” This is discussed in the Tipiṭaka Commentary. That is not good.🔽For there is no going out to the place of the object on the part of the two, the eye and the ear.

original: Na hi cakkhādidvayassa bahiddhā visayadesagamanasaṅgo atthīti. Gocaraṃ gaṇhātīti gocaraggāhikaṃ. Pasāda maṇḍabhūtattā āpātamāgataṃ ārammaṇanimittaṃ sampaṭicchatīti attho.
analyzed: na hi cakkha ādi dvayassa bahiddhā visaya desa gamana saṅgaḥ atthi iti gocaram gaṇhāti iti gocaraggāhikam pasāda maṇḍa bhūta ttā āpātam āgatam ārammaṇa nimittam sampaṭicchati iti attho
translated: “It apprehends the domain” : it is the apprehender of the domain. The meaning is that it adverts to the sign of the object that has come into focus because it is the sphere of the clear essence .

original: Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī-Țīkā,

original: Viññāṇādhiṭṭhitaṃ hutvā taṃtaṃ gocaragahaṇa sabhāvattāti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: viññāṇa adhiṭṭhitam hutvā taṃ taṃ gocara gahaṇa sabhāvattā iti vuttam
translated: it is said that it is the apprehender of the object of that particular kind because it is resolved upon by consciousness.

original: Vaṇṇoti rūpārammaṇassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Ojāti āhāra rūpa māha. Vinibhujjatīti vinibbhogo.
analyzed: rūpa ārammaṇassa etam nāmam āha vinibhujjati iti vinibbhogaḥ
translated: Colour is the name for the object of the eye-consciousness. Vitality is the nutriment called physical food. Disintegration is the breakup of the materiality that has come to be.

original: Ṭhānato desato uppattikāraṇato visuṃvisuṃ vavatthapīyatīti attho. Navinibbho goti🔽avinibbhogo. So eva rūpanti avinibbhogarūpaṃ. Ācariyānandattherenapanettha gandharasaojā
analyzed: ṭhānataḥ desataḥ uppatti kāraṇataḥ visum visum vavatthapīyati iti atthaḥ na vinibbhaḥ go ti  a vinibbhogo so eva a vinibbhoga rūpam
translated: The meaning is that it is defined as to place, as to direction, and as to cause of arising. Non-disintegration is

original: katthaci vinībhuttā dissantīti pañcavidhameva avinibbhogarūpaṃ icchitaṃ. Taṃ parato🔽āgamissatīti. [Rūpavibhāgo].
analyzed: katthaci vinībhuttāḥ dissanti iti pañcavidham eva a vinibbhoga rūpam icchitam tam paratas  āgamissati iti rūpa vibhāgaḥ
translated: non-breakup. That same materiality is non-disintegrating materiality. The teacher Ānandatissa has said that smell, taste, and vitality are sometimes found disintegrated, and so he has held that there are only five kinds of non-disintegrating materiality. That will be dealt with later on.

original: 158. Kammanti ekā cetanāeva. Sāyeva hi paṭṭhāne nānākkhaṇika kammapaccayabhāvena🔽vuttā. Yathāha-nānākkhaṇikā kusalākusalā cetanā vipākānaṃ khandhānaṃ kaṭattāca rūpānaṃ
analyzed: kamma nti ekā cetanā eva sāya iva hi paṭṭhāne  vuttā yathā āha nānākkhaṇikā kusala akusalā cetanā vipākānam khandhānam kaṭattā ca rūpānam
translated: . Kamma is a single volition. It is called a condition by way of kamma condition for the materiality that occurs at different times,

original: kammapaccayena paccayoti. Cittanti pana sasampayuttadhammaṃ adhippetaṃ. Paṭṭhāne
analyzed: kamma paccayena paccayo ti cittan ti pana sa sampayutta dhammam adhippetam paṭṭhāne
translated: as it is said: “A volition that is wholesome or unwholesome at a different time is a condition, by way of kamma condition, for the resultant aggregates and for the materiality due to kamma performed” . But consciousness is intended here as associated with its concomitants,

original: cetasikadhammānaṃpi rūpasamuṭṭhāpanabhāvena vuttattā. Yathāha-hetū hetusampayuttakānaṃ
analyzed: cetasika dhammānam pi rūpa samuṭṭhāpana bhāvena vutta ttā yathā aha hetū hetu sampayuttakānam
translated: because in the Paṭṭhāna consciousness and its concomitants are called a condition for materiality by way of producing materiality,🔽as it is said: “Causes are a condition, by way of producing condition, for the associated and for the dissociated” .

original: dhammānaṃ taṃ samuṭṭhānānañca rūpānaṃ hetu paccayena paccayotiādi. Utūti tejoyeva.
analyzed: dhammānam taṃ samuṭṭhānānaṃ ca rūpānaṃ hetu paccayena paccaya utiādi
translated: and of the material instances that originate from them, it is a cause as a condition consisting in object, etc. ‘Temperature’ is just heat.

original: So hi kappasaṇṭhāpanavasena sakalaṃ okāsa lokaṃpi nānāsarīrasaṇṭhāpanavasena saka
analyzed: so hi kappa saṇṭhāpana vasena sakalam nānā sarīra saṇṭhāpana vasena
translated: For that arises, produces, generates, and increases the entire world of space, in the sense of the arrangement of the world of space;

original: laṃ rūpamayaṃ kāyaṃ sattalokaṃpi nānārukkhatiṇādīnaṃ abbhapaṭalameghavuṭṭhijalaaggi
analyzed: rūpa mayam kāyam satta lokam pi nānā rukkha tiṇa ādīnam abbha paṭala megha vuṭṭhi jala aggi
translated: the entire material world of the body, in the sense of the arrangement of the various bodies of beings;

original: vātādīnañca saṇṭhāpanavasena sakalaṃ saṅkhāralokaṃpi udayati pasavati janeti vaḍḍheti.
analyzed: vāta ādīnam ca saṇṭhāpana vasena sakalam saṅkhāra lokam udayati pasavati janeti vaḍḍheti
translated: and the entire world of formations, in the sense of the arrangement of the various trees, creepers, etc., and of the rain-cloud, water, fire, wind, etc., that fall from the sky.

original: Tasmā utūti vuccatīti. Arati gacchati pavattatīti utūtipi vadanti. Āhāroti ojāeva.
analyzed: tasmai utu uti vuccati iti arati gacchati pavattati iti vadanti
translated: That is why it is called ‘temperature.’ Or alternatively, it ‘goes’ arati , it ‘occurs’ pavattati , thus it is ‘temperature’ utu . ‘Nutriment’ is just nutritive essence.

original: Rūpavirāgabhāvanābhūtaṃ arūpakusalaṃ kammajarūpaṃ najanetīti vuttaṃ pañcavīsatividhaṃpīti.
analyzed: rūpa virāga bhāvanā bhūtam arūpa kusalam kamma ja rūpam na janeti iti vuttam pañcavīsatividham pi iti
translated: The profitable kamma that generates materiality in the immaterial becoming generates the twenty-five kinds of materiality, it is said.

original: Atisaṅkhatanti atītakāle yathākā lantare rūpaṃ janeti, tathā visesetvā suṭṭhukataṃ.
analyzed: ati saṅkhatanti atīta kāle rūpam janeti tathā visesetvā suṭṭhu katam
translated: ‘Very formed’: well formed by being formed in the past in the way already stated.

original: Ajjhatti kasantāneti vuttaṃ, ajjhattasantāneti pana vattabbaṃ. Ajjhatta meva ajjhattikantivā
analyzed: ajjhattika santāne ti vuttam ajjhatta santāne iti pana vattabbam ajjhattam eva ajjhattikanti vā
translated: ‘Internally formed’: it should be said ‘internally formed’ ajjhattasantati ; but it is said ‘internally formed’ ajjhattika , as in the case of the expression ‘my internal consciousness’ ajjhattikā viññāṇa .

original: ikasaddassa attho daṭṭhabbo. Paṭisandhimupādāyāti paṭisandhicittassa uppādakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: ika saddassa atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo paṭisandhim upādāya ati paṭisandhi cittassa uppāda kkhaṇam
translated: The word “each” should be understood. “From the rebirth-linking”: from the moment of arising of the rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: upādāya. Khaṇekhaṇeti ekekassa cittassa tīsu tīsu khaṇesu. Ācariyānandatthero pana🔽sabbesaṃpi catusamuṭṭhānikarūpānaṃ ekekassa cittassa uppādakkhaṇeeva uppādaṃ bhaṅgakkhaṇeeva🔽nirodhañca āha. Ahaṃ panassā dhippāyo-sabbānipi catusamuṭṭhānikarūpāni cittassa uppādakkhaṇeeva
analyzed: upādāya khaṇe khaṇe ti ekekassa cittassa tīsu tīsu khaṇesu ācariya ānanda thero pana  sabbesam pi catu samuṭṭhānika rūpānaṃ ekekassa cittassa uppāda khaṇe eva uppādam bhaṅga kkhaṇe eva  nirodham ca āha aham pana assā dhippāyo sabbāni pi catu samuṭṭhānika rūpāni cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe eva
translated: “In each moment”: in the three moments of each consciousness. But the teacher, the Elder Ānanda,🔽says that the arising of all the four kinds of derived matter is only at the moment of arising of the consciousness, and its cessation is only at the moment of cessation of the consciousness.

original: uppajjanti, na bhaṅgakkhaṇe. Yathāha –
analyzed: uppajjanti na bhaṅga kkhaṇe yathā āha
translated: But my opinion is this: all the four kinds of derived matter arise only at the moment of arising of the consciousness, not at the moment of cessation of the consciousness. As it is said:

original: Yassavā pana samudayasaccaṃ nirujjhati, tassa dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjatīti. Noti.
analyzed: yassa vā pana samudaya saccam nirujjhati tassa dukkha saccam uppajjati iti no ti
translated: “But if the truth of origination ceases in anyone, does the truth of suffering arise in him?”— “No.”

original: Tathā tāni cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇeeva nirujjhanti. Na uppādakkhaṇe. Yathāha –
analyzed: tathā tāni cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe eva nirujjhanti na uppāda kkhaṇe yathā āha
translated: So too, those cease only at the moment of cessation of the consciousness, not at the moment of arising of the consciousness. As it is said:

original: Yassa kusalā dhammā akusalā dhammā uppajjanti, tassa abyākatā dhammā nirujjhantīti. Noti.
analyzed: yassa kusalāḥ dhammāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ uppajjanti tassa abyākatāḥ dhammāḥ nirujjhanti iti no ti
translated: “If profitable and unprofitable ideas arise in anyone, do indeterminate ideas cease in him?”— “No.”

original: Arūpabhavaṃ sandhāya etaṃ yamakadvayaṃ vuttaṃ. Rūpāni pana cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇepi uppajjanti. Uppādakkhaṇepi nirujjhantīti ce. Na. Evañhi sati –
analyzed: arūpa bhavam sandhāya etam yamaka dvayam vuttam rūpāni pana cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe api uppajjanti uppāda kkhaṇe api nirujjhanti iti ce na evam hi sati
translated: This pair of dyads is stated with reference to the immaterial becoming. But materiality arises even at the moment of the consciousnesses’ dissolution, and it ceases at the moment of their arising.

original: Yassavā pana samudayasaccaṃ nirujjhati, tassa dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjatīti. Arūpe taṇhāya
analyzed: yassa vā pana samudaya saccam nirujjhati tassa dukkha saccam uppajjati iti arūpe taṇhāya
translated: If it were so, then it would follow that when the truth of origination ceases for anyone, the truth of suffering arises for him.

original: bhaṅgakkhaṇe tesaṃ samudayasaccaṃ nirujjhati. Noca tesaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: bhaṅga kkhaṇe tesam samudaya saccam nirujjhati no ca tesam dukkha saccam uppajjati
translated: But when craving ceases in the immaterial sphere, the truth of origination ceases for him, but the truth of suffering does not arise for him.

original: Pañcavokāre taṇhāya bhaṅgakkhaṇe tesaṃ samudayasaccañca nirujjhati, dukkhasaccañca uppajjatītica.
analyzed: pañcavokāre taṇhāya bhaṅga kkhaṇe tesam samudaya saccam ca nirujjhati dukkha saccam ca uppajjati iti ca
translated: But when craving ceases in the five-constituent becoming, the truth of origination and the truth of suffering cease for him.

original: Itaratthaca
analyzed: itarattha ca
translated: And the other way round:

original: Arūpe kusalānaṃ uppādakkhaṇe tesaṃ kusalā dhammā uppajjanti. Noca tesaṃ abyākatā
analyzed: arūpe kusalānaṃ uppāda kkhaṇe tesam kusalāḥ dhammāḥ uppajjanti no ca tesam abyākatā
translated: At the moment of the arising of the profitable in the immaterial sphere, the profitable states arise for him, but the indeterminate states do not cease for him.

original: dhammā nirujjhanti. Pañcavokāre kusalānaṃ uppādakkhaṇe tesaṃ kusalā dhammāca uppajjanti.🔽Abyākatā dhammāca nirujjhantītica.
analyzed: dhammā nirujjhanti pañcavokāre kusalānaṃ uppāda kkhaṇe tesam kusalāḥ dhammāḥ ca uppajjanti 🔽abyākatāḥ dhammā ca nirujjhanti iti ca
translated: At the moment of the arising of the profitable in the five-constituent becoming, the profitable states arise for him and the indeterminate states cease for him.

original: Evaṃ paripuṇṇapañhāeva uddhaṭā siyuṃ. Noti pana paṭisedhova uddhaṭo. Tasmā nayidaṃ
analyzed: evam paripuṇṇa pañhā eva uddhaṭā siyum no ti pana paṭisedho uva uddhaṭaḥ tasmā
translated: So they would be put as complete questions. But the negative is put only to the second, not to the first. That is why it can be said that this is not stated with reference to immaterial becoming.

original: arūpabhavaṃ sandhāya vuttanti sakkā vattunti. Cittajarūpaṃ sandhāya vuttanti ce.
analyzed: arūpa bhavam sandhāya vuttanti sakkā vattum ti citta ja rūpam sandhāya vuttanti ce
translated: If it be said that it is stated with reference to the materiality originated by consciousness,

original: Tampi na. Kammajarūpassa vigahaṇe virodhassa yamakapāṭhantarassa abhāvato. Anulomassevaca bhāvato. Yathāha –🔽Yassavāpana yattha manindriyaṃ na uppajjati. Tassa tattha jīvitindriyaṃ nauppajjatīti.
analyzed: tat pi na kamma ja rūpassa vigahaṇe virodhassa yamaka pāṭhantarassa abhāvataḥ anulomassa iva ca bhāvataḥ yathā āha  yattha manindriyam na uppajjati tassa tattha jīvitindriyam na uppajjati iti
translated: that is not so either, because there is no contradiction in the omission of kamma-born materiality, and because it is stated in the affirmative in the following way:🔽“When the mind faculty does not arise in anyone, the life faculty does not arise in him too.”

original: Asaññasattānaṃ tesaṃ tattha manindriyaṃ na uppajjati. Noca tesaṃ tattha jīvitindriyaṃ na uppajjati.
analyzed: asaññasattānam tesam tattha manindriyam na uppajjati no ca tesam tattha jīvitindriyam na uppajjati
translated: In the case of non-percipient beings, the mind faculty does not arise in them, but their life faculty does arise.

original: Sabbesaṃ cavantānaṃ pavatte cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe tesaṃ tattha manindriyañca nauppajjati. Jīvitindriyañca nauppajjatīti.
analyzed: sabbesam cavantānam pavatte cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe tesam tattha manindriyam ca na uppajjati jīvitindriyam ca na uppajjati iti
translated: In those who die and at the moment of the mind’s dissolution, the mind faculty does not arise in them, nor does the life faculty” .

original: Ettha hi asaññasattānanti etena rūpajīvitindriya meva vuttaṃ. Yadica taṃ cittassa
analyzed: ettha hi etena rūpa jīvitindriyam eva vuttam yadi ca tam cittassa
translated: Herein, by “non-percipient beings” material life faculty only is meant. And if that is so,

original: bhaṅgakkhaṇepi uppajjeyya, purimakoṭṭhāse pavatte cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe asaññasattānaṃ🔽tesaṃ.La. Jīvitindriyaṃ nauppajjatīti vuttaṃ siyā, pacchimakoṭṭhāseca sabbesaṃ cavantānaṃ
analyzed: bhaṅga kkhaṇe api uppajjeyya purima koṭṭhāse pavatte cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe asaññasattānam  tesam la jīvitindriyam na uppajjati iti vuttam siyā pacchima koṭṭhāse ca sabbesam cavantānam
translated: It would be so at the moment of dissolution too. At the moment of dissolution of the consciousness occurring in the first part of the life-continuum, it would not arise in the case of those in the immaterial world and in the case of those in the fine-material world who are entering the attainment of cessation.🔽It would be so in the case of all who die in the last part of the life-continuum.🔽But it is said only in the case of those in the fine-material world who die in the first part of the life-continuum.

original: icceva vuttaṃ siyāti. Pacchimakoṭṭhāse pana arūpa jīvitindriyaṃ sandhāya vuttanti
analyzed: iccā iva vuttam siyāti pacchima koṭṭhāse pana arūpa jīvitindriyam sandhāya vuttanti
translated: If it be said that it is said in the last part of the life-continuum with reference to the immaterial life faculty,

original: ce. Na. Tathā gahaṇatthaṃ yamaka pāṭhantarābhāvato sabbaññuvisayeca ṭhāne pāḷiyo🔽saṃsanditvā balavatiyā pāḷiyuttiyāeva ṭhātabbatoti. Yasmāca rūpadhammā nāma dandhapavattino
analyzed: ce na tathā gahaṇa attham sabbaññu visaye ca ṭhāne  saṃsanditvā balavatiyā pāḷiyuttiyā eva ṭhātabbato ti yasmā ca rūpa dhammāḥ nāma dandha pavattino
translated: no; because there is no other text to be interpreted in that way, and because the text is to be interpreted in accordance with the more authoritative text that is found in the context of the knowledge of omniscience.🔽And because material phenomena occur slowly,

original: honti. Arūpadhammā lahupavattino ṭhitikkhaṇoca tesaṃ visuṃ gaṇanūpago natthi. Tasmā🔽aññoyeva rūpa dhammānaṃ khaṇapabandho. Añño arūpadhammānaṃ. Tattha sabbepi rūpadhammā
analyzed: honti arūpa dhammāḥ lahu pavattino tesam visum gaṇana upagaḥ natthi tasmā  aññaḥ yeva dhammānam khaṇa pabandhaḥ aññaḥ arūpa dhammānam tattha sabbe pi rūpa dhammā
translated: and immaterial phenomena occur quickly, and because there is no separate counting of the duration of their presence,🔽therefore the continuity of the moment of material phenomena is one, and the continuity of the moment of immaterial phenomena is another.

original: ekacittakkhaṇaparimāṇena attano uppādakkhaṇena yuttā khaṇe khaṇe nirantarameva uppajjanti.
analyzed: eka citta khaṇa parimāṇena attanaḥ uppāda kkhaṇena yuttāḥ khaṇe khaṇe nirantaram eva uppajjanti
translated: Herein, all material phenomena, being associated with the moment of their own arising, which is the measure of a single conscious moment, arise uninterruptedly moment after moment.

original: Paṭisandhito paṭṭhāya sahuppannattāca pana dvinnaṃ tesaṃ uppādādivā nirodhantovā
analyzed: paṭisandhito paṭṭhāya sahuppanna ttā ca pana dvinnam tesam uppāda ādi vā nirodha antovā
translated: And because they arise together with rebirth-linking, their arising, etc., and their cessation,

original: yāvajīvaṃpisaheva hotītipi tassa adhippāyoti. Yamaka pāḷiyo pana nānātthā, nānābyañjanā,
analyzed: yāvajīvam pisahā iva hoti itipi tassa adhippāyo ti yamaka pāḷiyo pana nānā atthā nānā byañjanā
translated: are the same throughout life. This is the meaning intended. But the texts of the Pairs have different meanings and different words,

original: gambhīroca satthu adhippāyo. Tasmā suṭṭhu vicāretvā sallakkhetabbo. Na pana dhammatā
analyzed: satthu adhippāyaḥ tasmā suṭṭhu vicāretvā sallakkhetabbaḥ na pana dhamma tā
translated: and the Master’s intention is profound. So they should be interpreted after being carefully investigated. But this is not the way of the Pairs,

original: esā yamakassa. Yadidaṃ yathālābhayojanāti katvā attano adhippāye ṭhatvā diṭṭhaṃ diṭṭhaṃ🔽yamakapāṭhaṃ yathālābhayo janāyaeva sakkā yojetunti. Rūpavirāgabhāvanāvisesabhūtaṃ
analyzed: esā yamakassa yat idam yathā lābha yojanā ati katvā attanaḥ adhippāye ṭhatvā diṭṭham diṭṭham  yamaka pāṭham yathā lābhayaḥ janāya eva sakkāḥ rūpa virāga bhāvanā visesa bhūtam
translated: namely, that what is seen should be interpreted according to the meaning intended by the Master, taking it as applicable according to how it fits.

original: arūpakusalaṃ tasmiṃ loke rūpasahitaṃ paṭisandhiṃ najaneti. Suddhaarūpameva janeti.🔽Tasmā rūpasantatisīsassa sabbaso abhāvā tatruppannāni sabbāni chacattālīsacittāni
analyzed: arūpa kusalam tasmin loke rūpa sahitam paṭisandhim suddha arūpam eva janeti  tasmā rūpa santati sīsassa sabbasas abhāvā tatra uppannāni sabbāni cha cattālīsa cittāni
translated: The profitable consciousness of the immaterial sphere, which is a special kind of development of the meditation subject consisting in the fading away of lust, does not generate rebirth-linking in that world together with materiality. It generates only pure materiality.

original: rūpaṃ janetuṃ na na sakkonti. Arūpavipākā pana tattheva niyamuppannāti arūpapākasseva
analyzed: rūpam janetum na na sakkonti arūpa vipākā pana tattha eva niyam uppannā ati arūpa pākassa iva
translated: So all the forty-six kinds of consciousness that arise there are unable to generate materiality because there is no head of a materiality continuity at all. But the immaterial resultants arise there by being restricted to that. So they are only the outcome of the immaterial sphere.

original: gahaṇaṃ kataṃ, teneva aṭṭhakathāyaṃ, aññānipi bahūni āruppe uppannāni anokāsatthā🔽rūpaṃ nasamuṭṭhāpentīti vuttaṃ tattha anokāsatānāma ādito paṭṭhāya uppannassa rūpasantatisīsassa
analyzed: gahaṇam katam tena iva aṭṭhakathāyam aññāni pi bahūni āruppe uppannāni  rūpam na samuṭṭhāpenti iti vuttam tattha anokāsa tā nāma āditaḥ paṭṭhāya uppannassa rūpa santati sīsassa
translated: The explanation in the commentary is given because many other immaterial states also arise without causing material instances to arise.

original: abhāvo eva daṭṭhabboti.
analyzed: abhāvo eva daṭṭhabbo ti
translated: The meaning of the words “without causing” should be regarded as the non-existence of a series of material instances that would arise from the beginning.

original: [189] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī

original: “Rūpavirāgabhāvanānibbattattā hetuno tabbidhuratāyā”tipi kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃ akāraṇaṃ.🔽Rūpārūpavirāgabhāvanābhūtamagganibbattassa lokuttaravipākassa rūpokāse sati rūpajanakatādassanatoti.🔽Jhānaṅgavirahena aṅgadubbalānipi rūpaṃ na janentīti dvipañcaviññāṇagahaṇaṃ kataṃ.
analyzed: rūpa virāga bhāvanā nibbatta ttā hetuno tad bidhura tāya ati pi kāraṇam vuttam tam akāraṇam  rūpa arūpa virāga bhāvanā bhūta magga nibbattassa lokuttara vipākassa rūpa ukāse sati rūpa janaka tā dassanato ti  aṅga dubbalāni api rūpam na janenti iti dvi pañca viññāṇa gahaṇam katam
translated: the reason is given thus: “Because of the weakness of the cause, since it is generated by the development of fading away of materiality.” That is not a reason.🔽For it is seen that the supramundane resultant materiality that arises when the path is generated does not cause materiality to arise.🔽The reason is that the five consciousnesses and the five sets of death consciousness do not cause materiality to arise because they are weak in the factors of jhāna.

original: Itarā nipi pana pannarasakāmarūpa paṭisandhicittāni khīṇāsavānaṃ parinibbānacuti
analyzed: pana pannarasa kāmarūpa paṭisandhi cittāni khīṇāsavānam parinibbāna cuti
translated: The other fifteen kinds of sense-sphere rebirth-linking consciousness and the death consciousness of an Arahant do not cause materiality to arise.

original: cittanti imāni cittāni rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpentiyeva. Evaṃsantepi tāni sabbānipi bhavaṅgakāle
analyzed: cittam ti imāni cittāni rūpam na tāni sabbāni pi bhavaṅga kāle
translated: Even though this is so, all these kinds of consciousness do not cause materiality to arise at the time of the life-continuum.

original: akhīṇāsavānañca cutikāle samuṭṭhāpentīti tesaṃ idha agahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: akhīṇāsavānam ca cuti kāle samuṭṭhāpenti iti tesam idha a gahaṇam daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: and it arises at the time of death of those who have not exhausted their taints. That is why it is not mentioned here.

original: [190] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī🔽it is said: “But the rebirth-linking consciousness and the death consciousness are not a different kind of consciousness from the nineteen kinds of normal consciousness, and so they are not mentioned separately.”

original: Paṭisandhicittaṃ pana cuticittañca ekūnavīsati bhavaṅgasseva antogadhattā cittantaraṃ na hotīti na tassa vajjanaṃ kata”nti vuttaṃ. Tattha ekūnavīsati bhavaṅgassevāti na vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisandhi cittam pana cuti cittam ca ekūnavīsati bhavaṅgassa iva citta antaram na hoti iti na tassa vajjanam katam ti vuttam tattha ekūnavīsati bhavaṅgassa iva ati na vattabbam
translated: Here it should not be said that they are “nineteen kinds of normal consciousness.”🔽Because they are mentioned by their own individual names.

original: Arūpavipākassa sarūpato vajjitattāti. Kasmā pana yathā vuttāni pannarasa paṭisandhicittāni🔽paṭisandhikkhaṇe rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpentīti, paridubbalattā. Cittañhināma uppādakkhaṇeeva
analyzed: arūpa vipākassa sarūpataḥ vajjita ttā ati kasmā pana yathā vuttāni pannarasa paṭisandhi cittāni  paṭisandhi khaṇe rūpam na samuṭṭhāpenti iti paridubbala ttā cittam hi nāma uppāda kkhaṇe eva
translated: But why do the fifteen kinds of rebirth-linking consciousness mentioned in this way🔽not produce materiality at the moment of rebirth-linking? Because they are too weak. For consciousness is strong when it gets sufficient conditions at the moment of arising,

original: paripuṇṇaṃ paccayaṃ labhitvā balavaṃ hoti. Rūpañca ṭhitikkhaṇeva.
analyzed: paripuṇṇam paccayam labhitvā balavam hoti rūpam ca ṭhiti kkhaṇā iva
translated: and materiality is so at the moment of presence.

original: Tasmā attano balavantakkhaṇe uppajjamānabhāvena dubbalaṃ vatthuṃ nissāya uppannattā
analyzed: tasmai attanaḥ balavanta kkhaṇe uppajjamāna bhāvena dubbalam vatthum nissāya uppanna ttā
translated: So because they arise with a weak support since they arise at the moment of their own strength,

original: sayaṃpi paridubbalaṃ hotīti sabbānipi tāni tadā rūpaṃ nasamuṭṭhā pentīti. Etthaca
analyzed: sayam pi paridubbalam hoti iti sabbāni pi tāni tadā rūpam na samuṭṭhāpenti iti ettha ca
translated: they themselves are weak too, and that is why they do not produce materiality.🔽Herein,

original: keci anantarāsevanādipaccayā cittassa uppādakkhaṇeeva pharanti. Rūpassa pana upatthambhakabhūtā🔽utuāhārā pacchājātapaccayadhammāca ṭhitikkhaṇeevapharantīti tesaṃ yathākkamaṃ uppādakkhaṇe
analyzed: keci anantara āsevana ādi paccayā cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe eva pharanti rūpassa pana upatthambhaka bhūtā  utu āhārā pacchājāta paccaya dhammā ca tesam yathākkamam uppāda kkhaṇe
translated: some, by the condition of immediate contiguity, by the condition of repetition, etc., only in the moment of arising of consciousness. But the nutriment temperature and consciousness, which are the postnascence condition for materiality, only in the moment of presence.🔽So, in due order, in the moment of arising of consciousness,🔽

original: ṭhitikkhaṇeca paripuṇṇapaccayalābho veditabbo.
analyzed: ṭhiti kkhaṇe ca paripuṇṇa paccaya lābhaḥ veditabbo
translated: Some, by the condition of immediate contiguity, proximity, etc., are effective only at the moment of arising of consciousness. But the nutriment of temperature and the postnascence conditions that are helpful to materiality are effective only at the moment of presence. So the conditionality of these should be understood as complete respectively at the moment of arising and at the moment of presence.

original: [191] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga,

original: “Pacchājāta paccayarahitaṃ pana āhārādīhica anupatthaddhaṃ dubbalavatthuṃ nissāya🔽pavattattā attanoca āgantukatāya kammajarūpehica cittasamuṭṭhānarūpānaṃ ṭhānaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: pacchājāta paccaya rahitam pana āhāra ādīhi ca anupatthaddham dubbala vatthum nissāya  pavatta ttā attano ca āgantuka tāya kamma ja rūpehi ca citta samuṭṭhāna rūpānam ṭhānam gahetvā
translated: “But the materiality originated by kamma, which is devoid of postnascence conditions and is not helped by nutriment, etc., is maintained only by the support of a weak physical basis,

original: ṭhitattā”ti kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha pacchājāta paccaya rahitanti idaṃ vicāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhitattā ti kāraṇam vuttam tattha pacchājāta paccaya rahitanti idam vicāretabbam
translated: and it occurs because of its own coming and because of the appropriation of a place by the materiality originated by consciousness” . Herein, the words “devoid of postnascence conditions” should be examined.

original: Paṭisandhicittassa ṭhitikkhaṇe pacchājāta paccaya rahitassa piutussa rūpajanakabhāvassa
analyzed: paṭisandhi cittassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe pacchājāta paccaya rahitassa rūpa janaka bhāvassa
translated: For the existence of the nutriment of temperature as a producer of materiality is mentioned in the Vibhaṅga at the moment of presence of the rebirth-linking consciousness,

original: vakkhamānattā. Na hi attanā avijjamānaṃ pacchimacittaṃ purimacittakkhaṇe ṭhitassa
analyzed: vakkhamāna ttā na hi attanā a vijjamānam pacchimacittam purima citta kkhaṇe ṭhitassa
translated: though it is devoid of postnascence conditions. For the last consciousness that is not present in itself is not a condition for the preceding consciousness at the moment of its presence.

original: kassaci rūpassa pacchājāta paccayo hoti. Atthi paccayekadesattā tassa paccayassāti.
analyzed: kassaci rūpassa pacchājāta paccayaḥ hoti atthi paccaya eka desa ttā tassa paccayassa ati
translated: But because of the presence of a part of the condition, namely, proximity, it is a condition.

original: Khīṇāsavānaṃ cuticittaṃ pana pakatiyāva vūpasantavaṭṭamūle santāne pavattattā santataraṃ🔽hoti. Puna āyusaṅkhārānaṃ parikkhayena dubbalatare pariyantagate ca vatthumhi nissitattā
analyzed: khīṇāsavānam cuti cittam pana pakatiyā vā vūpasanta vaṭṭa mūle santāne pavatta tā santataram  hoti puna āyu saṅkhārānam parikkhayena dubbalatare pariyanta gate ca vatthumhi nissita ttā
translated: The death consciousness of those whose cankers are destroyed is more tranquil than that of others because it occurs in a life-continuum that is naturally tranquil and that has become still more tranquil at the root of a tree, etc.,🔽and because it is supported by a basis that is weaker and more limited owing to the exhaustion of the life-span.

original: dubbalatarañca hotīti taṃ rūpaṃ nasamuṭṭhāpetīti, ācariyānandatthero pana sabbasattānaṃpi
analyzed: dubbalataram ca hoti iti tam rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti iti ācariya ānanda tthero pana sabba sattānam pi
translated: So it does not generate materiality. But the Elder Ānanda held the view that the death consciousness of all beings does not generate materiality.

original: cuticittaṃ rūpaṃ nasamuṭṭhāpetīti icchati. Yathāha-khīṇāsavānaṃ cuticittanti visesetvā vuttaṃ.🔽Kāmāvacarānaṃ pacchimacittassa uppādakkhaṇe yassa cittassa anantarā kāmāvacarānaṃ
analyzed: cuti cittam rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti iti icchati yathā āha khīṇa āsavānam cuti cittam iti visesetvā vuttam  kāmāvacarānaṃ pacchima cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe yassa cittassa anantarā kāmāvacarānaṃ
translated: As he said: “The death consciousness of those whose cankers are destroyed is mentioned by way of distinction.🔽At the instant of arising of the last consciousness in the sensual-desire existence,🔽after which there is no further arising of consciousness in the sensual-desire existence,🔽at the instant of arising of the last consciousness in the fine-material existence, the non-material existence, and the existence in the next world,

original: pacchimacittaṃ uppajjissati. Rūpāvacare arūpāvacare pacchimabhavikānaṃ yeca rūpāvacaraṃ🔽arūpāvacaraṃ upapajjitvā parinibbāyissanti, tesaṃ, cavantānaṃ tesaṃ vacī saṅkhāro
analyzed: pacchima cittam uppajjissati rūpāvacare arūpāvacare pacchimabhavikānam ye ca rūpāvacaram 🔽arūpāvacaram upapajjitvā parinibbāyissanti tesam cavantānam tesam vacī saṅkhāro
translated: at the instant of arising of the last consciousness in the fine-material existence, the non-material existence, and the existence in the next world, after which there is no further arising of consciousness in the fine-material existence, the non-material existence, and the existence in the next world,🔽at the instant of arising of the last consciousness in the fine-material existence, the non-material existence, and the existence in the next world, after which there is no further arising of consciousness in the fine-material existence, the non-material existence, and the existence in the next world,🔽at the instant of arising of the last consciousness in the fine-material existence, the non-material existence, and the existence in the next world, after which there is no further arising of consciousness in the fine-material existence, the non-material existence, and the existence in the next world,🔽at the instant of arising of the last consciousness in the fine-material existence, the non-material existence, and the existence in the next world, after which there is no further arising of consciousness in the fine-material existence, the non-material existence, and the existence in the next world,🔽at the instant of arising of the last consciousness in the fine-material existence, the non-material existence, and the existence in the next world, after which there is no further arising of consciousness in the fine

original: nirujjhissati, noca tesaṃ kāyasaṅkhāro nirujjhatīti –🔽Pana vacanato aññesaṃpi cuticittaṃ rūpaṃ nasamuṭṭhāpetīti viññāyati. Na hi rūpasamuṭṭhāpaka🔽cittassa gabbhagamanādi vinibaddhābhāve kāyasaṅkhārāsamuṭṭhāpanaṃ atthi, na ca yuttaṃ
analyzed: nirujjhissati no ca tesam kāya saṅkhāraḥ nirujjhati iti  pana vacanataḥ aññesam pi cuti cittam rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti iti viññāyati na hi rūpa samuṭṭhāpaka  cittassa gabbha gamana ādi vinibaddha abhāve kāya saṅkhāra asamuṭṭhāpanaṃ atthi na ca yuttam
translated: and the bodily formation does not cease in them.

original: cutoca cittasamuṭṭhānañcassa pavattatīti. Nāpi cuticittaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpetīti pāḷi atthīti.
analyzed: citta samuṭṭhānam ca assa pavattati iti na api cuti cittam rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti iti atthi iti
translated: It is evident from the words of the text that the death consciousness of others does not cause materiality to arise. For the consciousness that causes materiality to arise does not cause the bodily formation to arise when the rebirth-linking and the other kinds of consciousness are not bound to the womb, etc., and it is not proper to say that materiality arises in one who has died and that it continues to do so. Nor is there a text to the effect that the death consciousness causes materiality to arise.

original: Anuṭīkāyaṃ pana🔽Tasmiṃ pāṭhe tesaṃ cavantānaṃ noca kāyasaṅkhāro nirujjhatīti vacanaṃ na kevalaṃ cuticittasseva🔽rūpasamuṭṭhāpanābhāvaṃ sādheti, athakho tato purimānaṃ sabbesaṃ maraṇāsanna cittānaṃ🔽rūpasamuṭṭhāpanābhāvaṃpi sādhetiyevāti dīpeti. Cuti cittasmiṃhi kāyasaṅkhārassa nirodhe
analyzed: anuṭīkā ayam pana  tasmin pāṭhe tesam cavantānam no ca kāya saṅkhāraḥ nirujjhati iti vacanam na kevalam cuti cittassa iva  rūpa samuṭṭhāpana abhāvam sādheti atha kho tatas purimānam sabbesam maraṇa āsanna cittānam  rūpa samuṭṭhāpana abhāvam dīpeti cittasmin hi kāya saṅkhārassa nirodhe
translated: But in the subcommentary it is said:🔽“In that reading, the words ‘and the bodily formation does not cease in them’ do not prove only that the death consciousness does not cause materiality to arise. They also prove that the bodily formation does not cause materiality to arise in all the consciousnesses that are near to death, beginning with the next one after that.

original: paṭisiddhe tato pubbe yāva sattarasamacittā etthantare tassa uppādopi paṭisiddhoeva
analyzed: paṭisiddhe tatas pubbe yāva satta rasama cittā etthantare tassa uppādaḥ pi paṭisiddhaḥ eva
translated: For when the cessation of the bodily formation in the death consciousness is refuted, then the arising of the bodily formation in the preceding consciousnesses is also refuted, since it is included in the period of time between the death consciousness and the seventeenth consciousness.

original: hotīti. Sabbañcetaṃ vicāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: hoti iti sabbañca itam vicāretabbam
translated: All this should be examined.

original: Kāyasaṅkhāroti hi assāsapassāso vuccati. Soca suṭṭhu oḷāriko rūpadhammoti nacuticitte tannirodhābhāva vacanena itarāni sukhumānipi rūpāni cuticittaṃ najanetīti sakkā vattuṃ.
analyzed: kāya saṅkhāro ti hi assāsa passāsaḥ vuccati saḥ ca suṭṭhu oḷārikaḥ rūpa dhammo ti na cuti citte tad nirodha abhāva vacanena itarāni sukhumāni api rūpāni cuti cittam na janeti iti sakkā vattum
translated: For in-breath and out-breath are called bodily formation. And that is a gross material state. So it cannot be said that the consciousnesses of death cause the cessation of the other subtle material states by the words “because of the non-existence of their reappearance.”

original: [192] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said here:

original: Na hi rūpasamuṭṭhāpakacittassa gabbhagamanādi vinibaddhābhāve kāyasaṅkhārāsamuṭṭhāpanaṃ atthīti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na yujjati.
analyzed: na hi rūpa samuṭṭhāpaka cittassa gabbha gamana ādi vinibaddha abhāve kāya saṅkhāra asamuṭṭhāpanam atthi iti vuttam tat pi na yujjati
translated: For there is no causing of the bodily formation to arise when the consciousness that causes the materiality to arise is not bound to the occurrence of the conception in the womb, and so on. That is not right.

original: Tānieva hi gabbhagamanādīni imassatthassa sādhakāni bhavituṃ arahanti oḷārikassa kāyasaṅkhārassa asamuṭṭhāpakaṃpi cittaṃ itaraṃ sukhumarūpaṃ pana samuṭṭhāpetiyevāti.
analyzed: tāni eva hi gabbha gamana ādīni imassa atthassa sādhakāni bhavitum arahanti oḷārikassa kāya saṅkhārassa a samuṭṭhāpakam pi cittam itaram sukhuma rūpam pana
translated: For those same conception in the womb, and so on, are capable of effecting this meaning. And consciousness that does not cause the gross bodily formation to arise causes the other subtle materiality to arise.

original: [193] Yaṃpi tattha🔽Na ca yuttaṃ cutoca cittasamuṭṭhānañcassa pavattatīti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi akāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: yaṃ pi tattha  na ca yuttam citta samuṭṭhānam ca assa pavattati iti vuttam akāraṇam
translated: And what is said here:🔽And it is not right to say that it is after death that the consciousness that causes the materiality to arise occurs. That is no reason.

original: Na hi cutito paraṃ katipayakhaṇamattaṃ cittajarūpapavattiyā koci virodho atthīti.
analyzed: na hi cutitaḥ param katipaya khaṇa mattam citta ja rūpa pavattiyā koci virodhaḥ atthi iti
translated: For there is no contradiction in the occurrence of consciousness and consciousness-born materiality for a few moments after death.

original: Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is the purpose of that?

original: Nāpi cuticittaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpetīti pāḷi atthīti vuttaṃ. Tatthapi cuticittaṃ rūpaṃ nasamuṭṭhāpetītipi natthi, aññatra kāyasaṅkhārāti na na sakkā vattunti.🔽Evaṃ pana yuttaṃ siyā, yathā rūpadhammā ādito paṭisandhikāle ekacittakkhaṇamatte
analyzed: na api cuti cittam rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti iti atthi iti vuttam tattha api cuti cittam rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti iti pi natthi aññatra kāya saṅkhārā ti na na sakkā vattunti  evam pana yuttam siyā yathā rūpa dhammāḥ āditas paṭisandhi kāle eka citta khaṇa matte
translated: And there is no text to the effect that the death consciousness generates materiality. But there is no text to the effect that it does not generate it either, and it cannot be said that it does not generate it apart from the bodily formation.

original: paccayaparittatāyavā attano dandhavutti tāyavā dubbalā honti, tathā pariyosānepi🔽maraṇakāle parikkhīyamānapaccayatāyavā nirodhāsannatāyavā paridubbalāeva hontīti🔽sakkā vattuṃ. Tasmā vatthussa ādiantanissitāni paṭisandhicuticittāni samadubbalānieva
analyzed: paccaya paritta tāyavā attanaḥ dandha vutti tāyavā dubbalāḥ honti tathā pariyosāne pi  maraṇa kāle parikkhīyamāna paccaya tāyavā nirodha āsanna tāyavā paridubbalā eva honti iti  sakkā vattum tasmā vatthussa ādi anta nissitāni paṭisandhi cuti cittāni sama dubbalāni eva
translated: But it might be argued as follows: Just as material dhammas, beginning with the rebirth-linking consciousness, are weak at the beginning and at the end because their conditions are weak,🔽so too they are weak at the end because their conditions are weak at the time of death, and because of their proximity to cessation.

original: hontīti sakkā viññātunti.🔽Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: honti iti sakkā viññātunti  vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: So it can be said that the rebirth-linking and death consciousnesses at the beginning and end of the materiality continuum are equally weak.

original: Abhidhammatthavikāsaniyañca pāḷivirodhaṃ maññamāno kiñcimattampi avicāretvā ṭīkāsu vuttanayameva suṭṭhu vikāsayitvā gatoti.
analyzed: abhidhamma attha vikāsaniyam ca pāḷi virodham maññamāno a vicāretvā ṭīkāsu vutta nayam eva suṭṭhu vikāsayitvā gataḥ ti
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga and the Abhidhammatthasangaha he seems to have thought that there was a contradiction with the texts, and so he did not consider the matter further but simply followed the method of the commentaries.

original: Pathamabhavaṅgamupādāyāti pathama bhavaṅgacittassa uppādakkhaṇato paṭṭhāya. Jāyantamevāti
analyzed: pathama bhavaṅgam upādāya ati pathama bhavaṅga cittassa uppāda khaṇataḥ paṭṭhāya jāyantam eva ati
translated: Beginning with the first life-continuum: from the moment of arising of the first life-continuum consciousness.🔽Arising:

original: uppādakkhaṇe uppādakkhaṇe uppajja mānameva, na tiṭṭhantaṃ. Naca bhijjamānanti attho.
analyzed: uppāda khaṇe uppāda khaṇe uppajja mānam eva na tiṭṭhantam na ca bhijjamānam ti attho
translated: at the moment of arising, at the moment of arising, it arises and occurs only, not remaining, not breaking up, is the meaning.

original: Kāraṇaṃ vuttameva. Tatthāti tasmiṃ pañcasattatividhe citte. Appanājavananti abhiññādvayavajjitaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇam vuttam eva tattha ati tasmim pañca sattatividhe citte appanā javanam ti abhiññā dvaya vajjitam
translated: The reason has already been stated. Therein: in that consciousness of seventy-five kinds.🔽Absorption- impulsions: the twenty-six kinds of absorption-impulsion consciousness excluding the two kinds of direct-knowledge consciousness.

original: chabbīsatividhaṃ appanājavanacittaṃ. Iriyāpathanti gamanavajjitaṃ tividhaṃpi iriyāpathaṃ.
analyzed: chabbīsatividham appanā javana cittam iriyāpathanti gamana vajjitam tividham pi iriyāpatham
translated: Postures: the three postures excluding walking.

original: [194] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhanga

original: “Gamanādī”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na yujjati.
analyzed: gamana ādi iti vuttam tat na yujjati
translated: “walking, etc.” is said. That is not correct.

original: Na hi aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ calanaphandanamattaṃpi viññattiyā vinā sijjhati. Kuto gamanaṃ.
analyzed: na hi aṅga paccaṅgānam viññattiyā vinā sijjhati kutas gamanam
translated: For the mere shaking and moving of the limbs and secondary limbs is not possible without intimation, how much less so walking?

original: Naca yathāvuttaṃ appanājavanaṃ viññattiṃ samuṭṭhāpetuṃ sakkotīti. Pi saddena taṃ
analyzed: na ca yathāvuttam appanā javanam viññattim samuṭṭhāpetum sakkoti iti pi saddena tam
translated: And the kind of absorption-impulsion stated does not have the ability to generate intimation.

original: nakevalaṃ rūpasamuṭṭhāpakamattaṃti dasseti. Sannāmetīti sandhāreti ayamevavā pāṭho
analyzed: na kevalam rūpa samuṭṭhāpakam attam ti dasseti sat nāma iti iti sandhāra iti ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ
translated: The word “also” shows that it is not only the kind that generates materiality.

original: siyā, vakkhamānehi cittehi abhisaṅkhataṃ yathāpavattaṃ iriyāpathaṃ apatamānaṃ acalamānaṃ🔽dhāreti upatthambhetīti attho. Upatthambhanañcettha yathāpavattassa iriyāpathassa
analyzed: siyā vakkhamānehi cittehi abhisaṅkhatam yathāpavattam iriyāpatham a patamānam a calamānam  dhāreti upatthambheti iti atthaḥ upatthambhanam ca ittha yathā pavattassa iriyāpathassa
translated: It is what is well-ordered by the mind’s being well-ordered. The meaning is that it supports, it sustains, the posture as it occurs without its falling down or wavering.🔽And here the sustaining should be regarded as merely the guarding of the posture as it occurs.

original: rakkhanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Naukkhipitvā viya abhinīharaṇaṃ. Itarathā thambhanaviññattiyā🔽pasaṅgo siyāti. Etthaca yathānisinnassavā ṭhitassavā bhavaṅga citte abbokiṇṇe pavattamāne🔽aṅgāni osīdanti patanti. Na tathā imasmiṃ chabbīsatividhe jāgaraṇacitte vakkhamānesucadvattiṃsa
analyzed: rakkhana mattam daṭṭhabbam na ukkhipitvā viya abhinīharaṇam itarathā thambhana viññattiyā  pasaṅgaḥ siyāti ettha ca yathā nisinna ssavā ṭhita ssavā bhavaṅga citte abbokiṇṇe pavattamāne  aṅgāni osīdanti patanti na tathā imasmin chabbīsatividhe jāgaraṇa citte
translated: The carrying on is like the carrying on of a boat after it has been steered. Otherwise there would be the undesirable conclusion that the sustaining would be the intimation of the posture.🔽And here, when the life-continuum consciousness occurs uninterruptedly in one who is sitting or lying down,

original: vidhesu jāgaraṇacittesupavattamānesu. Tesu pana pavattamānesu aṅgāni upatthaddhāni
analyzed: vidhesu jāgaraṇa cittesu pavattamānesu tesu pana pavattamānesu aṅgāni upatthaddhāni
translated: the limbs sag and go to sleep. But when the twenty-six kinds of consciousness called “waking consciousness” occur, or the thirty-two kinds of consciousness called “waking consciousness,”

original: honti. Na osīdanti na patanti. Pubbe yathā thapitāneva pavattantīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: honti na osīdanti na patanti pubbe yathā thapitāna eva pavattanti iti veditabbam
translated: then the limbs are braced up and do not sag and go to sleep. They occur as though they were set up as before.

original: [195] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Na eva metesu dvattiṃsavidhesu vakkhamānesu ca chabbīsati yā jāgaraṇacittesu pavattamānesū”ti pāṭho.
analyzed: na eva mā etesu dvattiṃsavidhesu vakkhamānesu ca chabbīsati yāḥ jāgaraṇa cittesu pavattamānesu iti pāṭhaḥ
translated: “Nor in the twenty-six kinds of consciousness that occur in the waking state” is the reading in the Paṭisambhidā.

original: Na evametesu chabbīsatiyā jāgaraṇacittesu vakkhamāne suca dvattiṃsa vidhesu pavattamānesūti
analyzed: na evam etesu chabbīsatiyā jāgaraṇa cittesu vakkhamāne su ca dvattiṃsa vidhesu pavattamānesu iti
translated: “Nor in the twenty-six kinds of consciousness that occur in the waking state, nor in the thirty-two kinds of consciousness that occur in the dream state” is the correct reading.

original: pana pāṭho yutto. Voṭṭhabbananti manodvāre āvajjanamāha. Na hi pañcadvārikāni javana🔽cittānipi viññattiṃ samuṭṭhāpenti. Iriyāpathupatthambhana mattaṃ vā pisaddena gahithaṃ
analyzed: pana pāṭhaḥ yuttaḥ voṭṭhabbanam ti manaḥ dvāre āvajjanam āha na hi pañca dvārikāni javana  cittāni pi viññattim samuṭṭhāpenti iriyāpathu patthambhana mattam vā pi saddena gahitham
translated: “Cognition” is said to be the adverting in the mind door. For the five-door adverting consciousnesses
