analyzed: gabbhaseyyakassa pacchimabhavikassa upapajjantassa ekadasa ma sattāhā oratas ṭhitassa rūpa āyatanam nuppajjissati no ca cakkhāyatanam nuppajjissati iti
translated: For one lying in the womb, in the last stage of life, who is about to be reborn, eleven months and so on having elapsed, the visible-data base will arise, but not the eye base.

original: Yaṃ pana yassavā pana yattha rūpāyatanaṃ uppajjittha, tassa tattha ghānāyatanaṃ uppajjatīti.
analyzed: yam pana yassavā pana yattha rūpa āyatanam uppajjittha tassa tattha ghāna āyatanam uppajjati iti
translated: But as regards the question “When the visible-data base arises, does the nose base arise too? ”

original: Kāmāvacarā cavantānaṃ aghānakānaṃ kāmāvacaraṃ upapajjantānaṃ rūpāvacarānaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: kāmāvacarā cavantānam aghānakānam kāmāvacaram upapajjantānam rūpāvacarānam tesam
translated: When those in the sense-desire world who die as non-clansmen and are reborn in the sense-desire world and in the fine-material world,

original: tattha rūpāyatanaṃ uppajjittha. Noca tesaṃ tattha ghānāyatanaṃ uppajjatīti ettha
analyzed: tattha rūpa āyatanam uppajjittha no ca tesam tattha ghāna āyatanam uppajjati iti ettha
translated: then for them the visible-data base arises there, but not the nose base.

original: aghānakānaṃ kāmāvacaraṃ upapajjantānanti vuttaṃ.🔽Taṃ ye ekādasamasattāhā orato kālaṅkarissanti. Tesaṃ ghānāyatanānibbattakakammena🔽gahitapaṭisandhikānaṃ vasena vuttantica vuttaṃ. Etthaca cakkhughānesu vuttesu sotajivhā
analyzed: aghānakānam kāmāvacaram upapajjantānam ti vuttam  tam ye ekādasama sattāhāḥ oratas kālaṅkarissanti tesam ghāna āyatana a nibbattaka kammena  gahita paṭisandhikānam vasena vuttam iti ca vuttam ettha ca cakkhu ghānesu vuttesu sota jivhā
translated: Here “those in the sense-desire world who die as non-clansmen and are reborn in the sense-desire world” is said.🔽That refers to those who will die within eleven months and so on.🔽It is said with reference to those who have taken rebirth-linking by means of the nose-base-producing kamma.

original: avuttāpi atthato siddhāeva hontīti.
analyzed: a vuttā api atthataḥ siddhā eva honti iti
translated: And here, although the ear and the tongue are not mentioned in the way the eye and the nose are, they are nevertheless established in meaning.

original: [199] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yam pana
translated: But as regards the question “When the visible-data base arises, does the nose base arise too? ”

original: “Pavattikāleti sattame sattāheti” vuttaṃ. Taṃ na gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: pavatti kāle iti sattame sattāhe iti vuttam tat na gahetabbam
translated: “The word pavattikā means ‘in the seventh week’ ” is said. That should not be accepted.

original: Aṭṭhakathā virodhato īdisesu ca ṭhānesu aṭṭhakathā pamāṇatoti.
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā virodhataḥ īdisesu ca ṭhānesu aṭṭhakathā pamāṇato ti
translated: Because it contradicts the commentary, and in such places the commentary is the authority.

original: [200] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there

original: “Ṭīkākāramatena ekādasame sattāhe vāti” vuttaṃ. Tampi na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: ṭīkākāra matena ekādasame satta ahe vā iti vuttam tat pi na sundaram
translated: “According to the opinion of the sub-commentator, it is in the eleventh week” is not good.

original: Nahi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ niddiṭṭhato vutto vinicchayo ṭīkākāra matonāma sakkā vattunti.
analyzed: nahi aṭṭhakathā ayam niddiṭṭhataḥ vuttaḥ vinicchayaḥ ṭīkākāra mataḥ nāma sakkā vattun ti
translated: For it cannot be said that the decision given is according to the opinion of the sub-commentator, since it is given in the commentary.

original: [201] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there

original: “Kamenāti cakkhudasakapātubhāvato sattāhātikkamena sotadasakaṃ. Tato sattāhātikkamena
analyzed: kamena ati cakkhu dasaka pātubhāvataḥ sattāha atikkamena sota dasakam tatas sattāha atikkamena
translated: “The word kament means ‘in succession.’ After the lapse of a week from the appearance of the eye-faculty, the ten faculties beginning with the nose-faculty appear. After the lapse of a week from that,

original: ghāna dasakaṃ. Tato sattāhā tikkamena jivhādasakanti evaṃ anukkamenāti vuttaṃ”. Taṃpi na daṭṭhabba.
analyzed: ghāna dasakam tatas sattāhā tikkamena jivhā dasakam ti evam anukkamena ati vuttam tat pi na daṭṭhabba
translated: the ten faculties beginning with the tongue-faculty appear. Thus it is in succession” should not be accepted.

original: Yathāvutta aṭṭhakathāvirodhattā eva.
analyzed: eva
translated: Because it contradicts the commentary as already stated.

original: [202] Yaṃpi tattha
analyzed: yaṃ pi tattha
translated: And what is said there

original: “Aṭṭhakathāyaṃpi hi ayamattho dassito vā”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na yuttaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam pi hi ayam atthaḥ dassitaḥ vā ati vuttam tat pi na yuttam
translated: “In the commentary too this meaning is shown” is not right.

original: Na hi sānāma aṭṭhakathā atthi. Yattha īdiso uppattikkamo dassito siyā. Nanu paṭiccasamuppādaṭṭhakathāsu
analyzed: na hi sā anāma aṭṭhakathā atthi yattha īdisaḥ uppatti kkamaḥ dassitaḥ siyā nanu paṭiccasamuppāda ṭṭhakathāsu
translated: But has it not been said in the commentaries on the dependent origination

original: gabbhaleyyakavasenavā purimaṃbhavacakkaṃ vuttaṃ. Anupubbapavattidīpanatoti vuttanti
analyzed: gabbhaleyyaka vasena vā purimaṃbhava cakkam vuttam anupubba pavatti dīpanato ti vuttam ti
translated: that the wheel of the former state of existence is stated first in the Niddesa in the Gabbhāvasesa Vagga, and that the wheel of the present state of existence is stated first in the commentaries on the rest of the sutta, because the order of arising is stated in the Niddesa in the Gabbhāvasesa Vagga in the order of condition and conditionally-arisen states, and because the order of arising is stated in the rest of the sutta in the order of arising?

original: ce.Na. Tañhi viññāṇādīnaṃ pañcannaṃ aṅgānaṃ paccayapaccayuppannabhāvapavattikkamena🔽pāḷiyaṃ āgataṃ pañcapadaṃ sandhāya vuttanti. Āyatananiddesaṭṭhakathāsu pana so paṭikkhittoyeva.
analyzed: cena tat hi viññāṇa ādīnam pañcannam aṅgānam paccaya paccayuppanna bhāva pavatti kkamena  pāḷiyam āgatam pañca padam sandhāya vuttan ti āyatana niddesa ṭṭhakathāsu pana so paṭikkhittaḥ yeva
translated: No; for that is said with reference to the five terms in the sutta that are stated in the order of condition and conditionally-arisen states, namely, consciousness, etc.,🔽and it is rejected in the Niddesa commentaries.

original: Naca aṭṭhakathāsu paṭikkhitto uppattikkamo therena idha kamenāti iminā pāṭhena dassitoti
analyzed: na ca aṭṭhakathāsu paṭikkhittaḥ uppatti kkamaḥ therena idha kamena ati iminā pāṭhena dassito ti
translated: And it cannot be said that the Elder has shown a sequence of arising rejected in the commentaries by the words “in the order of teaching,”

original: sakkā vattunti. Tasmā kamenāti idhapi desanakkamenāti attho. Desitānīti sambandhoca veditabbo.
analyzed: sakkā vattunti tasmā kamena ati idha api desana kkamena ati atthaḥ desitāni iti sambandhaḥ ca veditabbaḥ
translated: so the meaning here of “in the order of teaching” must be taken as the order in which the teaching is given. And the construction must be understood as follows: “The truths are taught in the order in which they are taught. They are taught.”

original: Saccasaṅkhepa ṭīkāyaṃ pana
analyzed: saccasaṅkhepa ṭīkā ayam pana
translated: But in the Saccasankhepa Tīkā

original: Sākhāvatthaṃ atikkamma pacchā sattame sattāhe cakkhu sotaghānajivhādasakāca uppajjanti. Ṭīkākāropana ekādasame sattāheti āhāti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi nayujjati yevāti.
analyzed: sākhāvattham atikkamma pacchā sattame sattāhe cakkhu sota ghāna jivhā dasa kāca uppajjanti ṭīkāka āropane ekādasame sattāhe iti āha ati vuttam tat pi na yujjati yeva ati
translated: After the stage of the branch, the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body faculties, and the life faculty arise in the seventh week. The formation of the skin occurs in the eleventh week. This is what is said. But that is also quite acceptable.

original: Ettha ca kalalādīnaṃ uppattikkamo saṃyuttake vutto. Yathāha –
analyzed: ettha ca kalala ādīnam uppatti kkamaḥ saṃyuttake vuttaḥ yathā āha
translated: And the order of the arising of the stages of the embryo is given in the Saṃyutta Nikāya:

original: Pathamaṃ kalalaṃ hoti, kalalā hoti abbudaṃ;
analyzed: pathamam kalalam hoti kalalā hoti abbudam
translated: First there is the kalala stage, then the abbuda stage,

original: Abbudā jāyate pesi, pesiyā nibbattate ghano;
analyzed: abbudā jāyate pesī pesiyā nibbattate ghanaḥ
translated: Then the pesi, then the ghana,🔽From the ghana the flesh and bones,

original: Ghanā pasākhā jāyanti, kesā lomā nakhāpicāti.🔽Aṭṭhakathāyañca vuttaṃ. Tattha pathamanti pathamena paṭisandhiviññāṇena tissoti vā
analyzed: ghanāḥ pasākhāḥ jāyanti kesāḥ lomā  aṭṭhakathāyam ca vuttam tattha pathamanti pathamena paṭisandhi viññāṇena tissaḥ ti vā
translated: And then the hair and pores.

original: phussotivā nāmaṃ natthi. Athakho tīhi jātiuṇṇaṃsūhi katasuttagge saṇṭhitatelabindupamāṇaṃ
analyzed: nāmam natthi athakho tīhi jāti uṇṇaṃsūhi kata suttagge saṇṭhita tela bindu pamāṇam
translated: And it is stated in the commentary. Herein, first means by the first rebirth-linking consciousness there is no name such as Tisya or Phussa. Then there is the kalala stage, which is the size of a drop of oil placed on water and held there by the three hot winds.

original: kalalaṃ hoti. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: kalalam hoti yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: With reference to this it is said:🔽Like a drop of oil on water,

original: Tilatelassa yathā bindu, sappimaṇḍo anāvilo;
analyzed: tila telassa yathā bindu sappi maṇḍaḥ anāvilaḥ
translated: Or a drop of oil on a dish,🔽So is the kalala stage,

original: Evaṃ vaṇṇapaṭibhāgaṃ, kalalaṃ saṃpavuccatīti.
analyzed: evam vaṇṇa paṭibhāgam kalalam saṃpavuccati iti
translated: In colour and appearance.

original: Kalalā hoti abbudanti tasmā kalalā sattāhaccayena maṃsadhovanaudakavaṇṇaṃ abbudaṃnāma hoti, kalalanti nāmaṃ anta radhāyati. Vuttaṃpi cetaṃ –
analyzed: kalalā hoti abbudanti tasmā kalalā satta ahaccayena maṃsa dhovana audaka vaṇṇam abbudam nāma hoti kalalanti nāmam anta radhāyati vuttam pi
translated: It becomes a lump of spawn, and after seven days it becomes a bubble, the colour of the water in which laundrymen wash dirty rags. The name “lump of spawn” disappears, and the name “bubble” comes into being. And this is said by the Ancients:🔽For seven days it is a lump of spawn,

original: Sattāhaṃ kalalaṃ hoti, paripakkasamūhakaṃ;
analyzed: satta aham kalalam hoti paripakka samūhakam
translated: A lump of flesh that has begun to grow;🔽And as it grows, there comes to be

original: Vivattamānaṃ tabbhāvaṃ, abbudaṃnāma jāyatīti.🔽Abbudā jāyate pesīti tasmāpi abbudā sattāhaccayena vilīna tipusadisā pesināma sañjāyati.
analyzed: vivattamānam tad bhāvam abbudaṃnāma jāyati iti  abbudā jāyate pesī iti tasmā api abbudā satta ahaccayena vilīna tipu sadisā pesī nāma sañjāyati
translated: A bubble called by that name.🔽It becomes a lump of flesh, and after seven days it becomes a “germ,” like a piece of tender cane.

original: Sā maricaphāṇitena dīpetabbā. Gāmadārakā hi supakkāni maricāni gahetvā sāṭakantare🔽bhaṇḍikaṃ katvā pīḷetvā maṇḍaṃ ādāya kapāle pakkhipitvā ātape thapenti. Taṃ sukkhamānaṃ
analyzed: sā marica phāṇitena dīpetabbā gāma dārakāḥ hi su pakkāni maricāni gahetvā sāṭaka antare  bhaṇḍikam katvā pīḍetvā maṇḍam ādāya kapāle pakkhipitvā ātape thapenti tam sukkha mānam
translated: It should be shown by a lump of sugar-cane juice. For village boys take well-ripened sugar-canes,🔽cut off the tops and the roots,

original: sukkhamānaṃ sabbabhāgehi muccati. Evarūpā pesi hoti. Abbudanti nāmaṃ antaradhāyati. Vuttaṃpi cetaṃ –
analyzed: sukkha mānam sabba bhāgehi muccati evarūpā pesī hoti abbudanti nāmam antaradhāyati vuttam pi ca itam
translated: and put them in a bag. Then they hang the bag from a peg and trample it with their feet. The juice trickles down and is collected in a pot. That is how the “germ” is. The name “bubble” disappears, and the name “lump of flesh” comes into being. And this is said by the Ancients:🔽For seven days it is a bubble,

original: Sattāhaṃ abbudaṃ hoti, paripakkasamūhakaṃ;
analyzed: satta aham abbudam hoti paripakka samūhakam
translated: A lump of flesh that has begun to grow;🔽And as it grows, there comes to be

original: Vivattamānaṃ tabbhāvaṃ, pesināma pajāyatīti.
analyzed: vivattamānam tad bhāvam pesi nāma pajāyati iti
translated: A lump of flesh called by that name.🔽It becomes a “head,” and after seven days it becomes a “foot,” and after seven days it becomes a “head” again. Translation: Kalalantipi vuccati | Tasmā kalalā sattāhaṃ atikkamitvā maṃsadhovanaodakavaṇṇā abbudaṃ nāma hoti | Kalalanti nāmaṃ antaradhāyati | Vuttañhetaṃ – ”sattāhaṃ kalalaṃ hoti paripakkasamūhakaṃ | Vivattamānaṃ tabbhāvaṃ abbudaṃ nāma jāyatī”ti | Abbudaṃ nāmaṃ antaradhāyati | Tasmā abbudā sattāhaṃ atikkamitvā vilīnatīpusadisā pesī nāma sañjāyati | Sā maricaphāṇitena dīpetabbā | Gāmadārakā hi supakkāni maricāni gahetvā sāṭakantarato bhaṇḍikaṃ katvā pīḷetvā maṇḍaṃ ādāya kapāle pakkhipitvā ā

original: Pesiyā nibbattate ghanoti tato pesito sattāhacca yena kukkuṭaṇḍasaṇṭhāno ghanonāma maṃsapesi piṇḍo nibbattati. Pesītināmaṃ antaradhāyati. Vuttaṃpi cetaṃ –
analyzed: pesiyā nibbattate ghano ti tatas pesitaḥ satta ahat ca yena kukkuṭaṇḍa saṇṭhānaḥ ghanaḥ nāma maṃsa pesi piṇḍaḥ nibbattati pesī iti nāmam antaradhāyati vuttam pi ca itam
translated: The lump grows from the film: then, after the lapse of a week, a lump called the “lump” grows from the film, which is a mass of flesh the size of a hen’s egg. The name “film” disappears. And this is said:🔽For a week it is a film,

original: Sattāhaṃ pesi bhavati, paripakkaṃ samūhakaṃ;
analyzed: satta aham pesi bhavati paripakkam samūhakam
translated: And then a bubble it becomes;🔽When it is living in that state,

original: Vivattamānaṃ tabbhāvaṃ, ghanotināma jāyatīti;
analyzed: vivattamānam tad bhāvam ghanoti nāma jāyati iti
translated: The lump is what it then becomes.🔽Just as an egg laid by a hen

original: Yathā kukkuṭiyā aṇḍaṃ, samantaṃ parimaṇḍalaṃ;
analyzed: yathā kukkuṭiyāḥ aṇḍam samantam parimaṇḍalam
translated: Is all around a single shape,🔽So too the lump’s single shape

original: Evaṃ ghanassa saṇṭhānaṃ, nibbattaṃ kammapaccayātica.
analyzed: evam ghanassa saṇṭhānam nibbattam kamma paccayā ati ca
translated: Comes into being through kamma’s power.

original: Ghanā pasākhā jāyantīti pañcame sattāhe dvinnaṃ hatthapādānaṃ sīsassaca atthāya pañcapīḷakā
analyzed: ghanāḥ pasākhāḥ jāyanti iti pañcame sattāhe dvinnam hattha pādānam sīsassa ca atthāya pañca pīḍakā
translated: The limbs grow from the lump: in the fifth week five swellings appear for the sake of the two hands and two feet and the neck. And this is said:🔽“Bhikkhus, in the fifth week five swellings appear in the embryo.

original: jāyanti. Yaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃpañcame kho bhikkhave sattāhe pañcapīḷakā jāyanti.🔽Saṇṭhanti kamma toti. Kesā lomā nakhāpicāti dvācattālīsame sattāhe etāni jāyantīti.
analyzed: jāyanti yam sandhāya itam vuttam pañcame kho bhikkhave sattāhe pañca pīḷakāḥ jāyanti  kesāḥ lomā nakhā picā ati dvācattālīsame sattāhe etāni jāyanti iti
translated: They are the basis for the limbs.”🔽The hair of the head, body hair, and nails: these appear in the thirty-second week.

original: Ettha ca chaṭṭhasattāhādayo chasattāhā pasādanissayānaṃ aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ anukkamena
analyzed: ettha ca chaṭṭha sattāha ādayaḥ cha sattāhā pasāda nissayānam aṅga paccaṅgānam anukkamena
translated: And here the six weeks beginning with the sixth are the period for the gradual appearance of the various parts of the body, the limbs and digits, etc.,

original: vaḍḍhitvā pariṇatakālā honti. Cakkhādīni pana ekādasama sattāhassa pariyo sānadivase🔽ekato jāyantīti niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ. Yaṃ panettha tilatelassa yathābindūtiādinā
analyzed: vaḍḍhitvā pariṇata kālā honti cakkha ādīni pana ekādasama sattāhassa sāna divase  ekatas jāyanti iti niṭṭham ettha gantabbam yam pana ittha tila telassa yathā bindu iti ādinā
translated: but the eleven, the eye, etc., are generated together on the seventh or eighth month after conception.🔽But the colour and shape of the materiality called “germinal,” which is stated here in the way beginning, “As big as a mustard seed or a sesame seed” (Ps.i, 1),

original: kalalassa vaṇṇasaṇṭhānaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃ thokaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Na paṭisandhikkhaṇe
analyzed: kalalassa vaṇṇa saṇṭhānam vuttam tat thokam vaḍḍhitam sandhāya vuttam na paṭisandhi khaṇe
translated: is stated with reference to it when it has grown a little, not as it occurs at the moment of rebirth-linking.

original: pavattamānaṃ. Na hi tadā tādisaṃ pakaticakkhunā diṭṭhaṃ vaṇṇajātaṃvā saṇṭhānaṃvā
analyzed: pavattamānam na hi tadā tādisam pakati cakkhunā diṭṭham vaṇṇa jātam vā saṇṭhānam vā
translated: For no such colour or shape as that can be seen with the ordinary eye.

original: tassa paññāyeyyāti. Anumānato pana evaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ekāya ūkāya sattamo bhāgo likkhānāma.
analyzed: tassa paññāyeyya ti anumānato pana evam veditabbam ekāya ūkāya sattamaḥ bhāgaḥ likkhā nāma
translated: But it can be understood by inference thus. The seventh part of a barley grain is called a “likhā.”

original: Likkhāya chattiṃsatimo bhāgo rathareṇunāma. Rathareṇussa chattiṃsatimo. Tajjārī nāma.
analyzed: likkhāya chattiṃsatimaḥ bhāgaḥ ratha reṇu nāma ratha reṇussa chattiṃsatimaḥ tajjārī nāma
translated: The thirty-sixth part of a līkhā is called a “ratha.” The thirty-sixth part of a ratha is called a “tajja.”

original: Tajjāriyā chattiṃsatimo aṇunāma. Aṇussa chattiṃsatimo bhāgo paramāṇunāma. So pana
analyzed: tajjāriyā chattiṃsatimaḥ aṇu nāma aṇussa chattiṃsatimaḥ bhāgo paramāṇu nāma saḥ pana
translated: The thirty-sixth part of a tajja is called an “aṇu.” The thirty-sixth part of an aṇu is called a “paramāṇu.”

original: ākāsakoṭṭhāsiko maṃsacakkhussa āpātaṃ nāgacchati. Dibbacakkhusseva āgacchatīti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: ākāsakoṭṭhāsikaḥ maṃsa cakkhussa āpātam na āgacchati dibba cakkhussa iva āgacchati iti aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: But that does not come within the range of the fleshly eye. It comes within the range of the divine eye.

original: vuttaṃ. Tesaṃ chattiṃsa parimāno aṇu pana titticchidda tālacchiddehi paviṭṭhasūriyarasmīsu🔽vaṭṭivaṭṭi hutvā paribbhamanto paññāyatīti vuttaṃ. Sakalaṃ pana kalāpattayaparimāṇamattabhūtaṃ🔽paṭisandhikkhaṇe paramāṇutopi parittakameva siyā. So hi santānānubandhavasena pavattattā
analyzed: vuttam tesam chattiṃsa parimāno aṇu pana tālacchiddehi paviṭṭha sūriya rasmīsu  vaṭṭi vaṭṭi hutvā paribbhamanto paññāyati iti vuttam sakalam pana kalā pattaya parimāṇa matta bhūtam  paṭisandhi kkhaṇe paramāṇutaḥ pi parittakam eva siyā saḥ hi santāna anubandha vasena pavatta ttā
translated: This has been said. Their size is thirty-six. But the subtle matter is seen in the holes of the teeth and in the holes of the palms of the hands and soles of the feet,🔽moving round like a ring of light from a firebrand whirled round. But in the moment of rebirth-linking it is only the size of a single kalāpa,

original: khaṇe khaṇe upacitarūpakalāpasamūhoeva hotīti heṭṭhima koṭiyā ekūnapaññāsakalāpaparimāṇoeva
analyzed: khaṇe khaṇe upacita rūpa kalāpa samūhaḥ eva hoti iti heṭṭhima koṭiyā ekūnapaññāsa kalāpa parimāṇaḥ eva
translated: which is the smallest possible amount of matter. For it is only a collection of the many kalāpas of matter that have been accumulated in each moment of the life-continuum.🔽So it is only the size of forty-nine kalāpas at the most at the lower limit. And if it were less than that, the continuity would not be established.

original: siyā. Tato parittake sati santāna ghaṭanasseva asambhavatoti. Yaṃ pana mahāṭīkāyaṃ
analyzed: siyā tatas parittake sati santāna ghaṭanassa iva asambhavato ti yam pana mahā ṭīkāyam
translated: But what is said in the Great Commentary, namely,

original: te pana kalāpā paramāṇuparimāṇā hontīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ dhātūnaṃ cuṇṇamanasikārānurūpamattavasena
analyzed: te pana kalāpā paramāṇu parimāṇāḥ honti iti vuttam tam dhātūnam cuṇṇa manasikāra anurūpa matta vasena
translated: that “these kalāpas are the size of an atom,” should be understood as said in accordance with the “contemplation of the elements in the form of powder” .

original: vuttanti gahetabbaṃ. Dutīyacittanti pathama bhavaṅgacittaṃ. Ṭhitikālanti paṭisandhi
analyzed: vuttanti gahetabbam dutīya cittanti bhavaṅga cittam ṭhiti kālanti paṭisandhi
translated: The second consciousness is the first life-continuum consciousness. The state of presence is the rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: cittassa ṭhitikālaṃ. Ojāpharaṇamupādāyāti gabbhaseyyakānaṃ tāva abbudabhāva pesibhāva
analyzed: cittassa ṭhiti kālam ojā pharaṇam upādāya ati gabbhaseyyakānam tāva abbuda bhāva pesi bhāva
translated: and the time of the mind’s steadiness.

original: ghanabhāvādi pattakāle mātuyā āmāsayagatāya ajjhohaṭāhāra sinehabhūtāya ojāya jalābumūlā
analyzed: ghana bhāva ādi patta kāle mātuyā sineha bhūtāya ojāya
translated: From the time of the spreading of nutriment: from the time of the spreading of the nutriment in the form of serum in the mother’s womb, which is called “food” , in the place of the embryo, which has reached the stage of the “coagulated” , “crablike” ,

original: nusārena vatthusmiṃ pharaṇakālaṃ upādāya, yathāha –
analyzed: anusārena vatthusmim pharaṇa kālam upādāya yathā āha
translated: “elongated” , etc., states, by the force of the root-cause of the water element, as it is said:

original: Yañcassa bhuñjati mātā, annaṃ pānañca bhojanaṃ;
analyzed: yat ca assa bhuñjati mātā annam pānam ca bhojanam
translated: “Whatever food and drink the mother takes,

original: Tena so tattha yāpeti, mātukucchigato tiroti.
analyzed: tena saḥ tattha yāpeti mātukucchi gataḥ tiroti
translated: He there is nourished by that, the one in the mother’s womb.”

original: Aṭṭhakathāyañca tena so tattha yāpetīti tassa hi nātito uṭṭhito nāḷo mātuudara paṭalena🔽ekābaddho hoti. So uppaladaṇḍako viya chiddo. Tena āhāraraso saṃsaritvā āhārasamuṭṭhānarūpaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāyam ca tena so tattha yāpeti iti tassa hi uṭṭhitaḥ nāḷaḥ mātuudara paṭalena  eka ābaddhaḥ hoti saḥ uppala daṇḍakaḥ viya chiddo tena āhāra rasaḥ saṃsaritvā āhāra samuṭṭhāna rūpam
translated: And in the Commentary it is said: “He there is nourished by that”: for the navel string that has grown up in him is attached to the mother’s stomach lining,

original: samuṭṭhāpeti. Evaṃ so dasamāse yāpeti. Mātukucchigato tiroti mātuyā tiro kucchigato.
analyzed: samuṭṭhāpeti evam saḥ dasa māse yāpeti mātu kucchi gataḥ mātuyā tiras kucchi gataḥ
translated: and it is hollow like a reed. The nutriment that has reached the stomach by the force of the wind that churns the food, etc., enters the navel string and goes to the embryo by the force of the root-cause of the water element. So the nutriment that has reached the embryo by the force of the root-cause of the fire element produces materiality originated by nutriment. Thus he is nourished for ten months. The one in the mother’s womb: the one inside the mother’s womb.

original: Mātukucchiyā abbhantaragatoti atthoti vuttaṃ. Tattha pana nābhināḷassa uṭṭhitakālaṃ
analyzed: mātukucchiyāḥ abbhantara gataḥ ti atthaḥ ti vuttam tattha pana nābhināḷassa uṭṭhita kālam
translated: The meaning is: the one inside the mother’s belly. Herein, the time of the navel string’s growth is not stated.

original: sandhāya nātito uṭṭhito nāḷoti vuttanti gahetabbaṃ. Na hi abbudādikāle tassa nātināḷonāma
analyzed: sandhāya nātitas uṭṭhitaḥ nāḷo ti vuttanti gahetabbam na hi abbuda ādi kāle tassa na atināḷo nāma
translated: For it is not called a “umbilical cord” at the time of the “concretion” and so on.

original: uṭṭhito siyāti. Saṃsedajopapātikānaṃ pana yaṃkiñci laddhaṃvā attano kheḷaṃvā ajjhoharaṇakāle
analyzed: uṭṭhitaḥ siyāti saṃseda ja upapātikānam pana yaṃ kiñci laddham vā attano kheḷam vā ajjhoharaṇa kāle
translated: But in the case of those born supernaturally or by eggs, it is the “nutritive essence” that is obtained or their own betel or betel and so on that they swallow at the time of swallowing,🔽taking as the basis the “nutritive essence” that has spread.

original: ojāpharaṇaṃ upādāya. Tena vuttaṃ ojāpharaṇamupādāyaāhārasamuṭṭhānāti. Cuticittopari
analyzed: ojā pharaṇam upādāya tena vuttam ojā pharaṇam upādāya āhāra samuṭṭhānā ati cuti citta upari
translated: That is why it is said, “Derived from nutriment, taking as the basis the ‘nutritive essence’ that has spread.”🔽In the consciousness that is the seventeenth

original: sattarasamacittassāti cuticittato upari pubbakāle sattarasamassa bhavaṅgacittassa.🔽Kammajarūpāni na uppajjanti tesaṃ tato paṭṭhāya anuppannattāyeva tato satta rasamaṃ
analyzed: sattarasama cittassa ati cuti cittato upari pubba kāle sattarasamassa bhavaṅga cittassa  kamma ja rūpāni na uppajjanti tesam tatas paṭṭhāya an uppanna ttāya iva tatas satta
translated: in the series: in the seventeenth consciousness in the series that begins with the death consciousness.🔽The materiality derived from kamma does not arise in them because it has not arisen since then.🔽That is why it is called the death consciousness, not in any other way.

original: cuticittaṃnāma hoti. No aññathāti. Puretaranti tassa sattarasamassa cittassa uppādakkhaṇaṃeva
analyzed: cuti cittaṃ nāma hoti no aññathā ati puretaran ti tassa sattarasamassa cittassa uppāda kkhaṇaṃ eva
translated: Earlier: this is said referring to the moment of arising of that seventeenth consciousness.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tatoparanti cuticittato parasmiṃ soḷasacittakkhaṇaparimāṇe khaṇe.
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam cuti cittataḥ parasmin soḷasa citta khaṇa parimāṇe khaṇe
translated: Later: in the moment that lasts for the sixteen conscious moments after the death consciousness.

original: Cittajāhārajarūpañcāti cittajarūpasantānaṃ āhāraja rūpasantānañca vocchijjati anupādinnakasantāne
analyzed: citta ja āhāra ja rūpam ca ati citta ja rūpa santānam āhāra ja rūpa santānam ca vā ucchijjati an upādinnaka santāne
translated: And the continuity of materiality originated by consciousness and the continuity of materiality originated by nutriment are cut off in the continuity of the unclung-to.

original: tesaṃ uppattiyā asambhavato. Yamettha vattabbaṃ taṃ rūpasamuṭṭhāne vuttameva. Bhāvadasakaṃnāma
analyzed: tesam uppattiyāḥ asambhavataḥ yam ettha vattabbam tam rūpa samuṭṭhāne vuttam eva bhāvadasakam nāma
translated: For it is impossible for them to arise there. What should be said here has already been said in the Description of Materiality .

original: kāmarāganidānakammasamuṭṭhānaṃ hotīti tabbirāga bhāvanākammanibbatte rūpaloke tassa🔽alābho vutto. Āhārajakalāpānica na labbhanti ajjhohaṭā hārā bhāvato, tatoyevaca sarīragatassa
analyzed: kāma rāga nidāna kamma samuṭṭhānam hoti iti tad virāga bhāvanā kamma nibbatte rūpa loke tassa  alābhaḥ vuttaḥ āhāra ja kalāpāni ca na labbhanti ajjhohaṭāḥ hārāḥ bhāvato sarīra gatassa
translated: The ten kinds of being are originated by kamma that has craving for sensual desires as its root cause.🔽So the non-acquisition of that is stated in the case of the world of materiality produced by the kamma of the development of the path that is the opposite of that craving.🔽And the groups of materiality originated by nutriment are not found there, because the nutriment that is swallowed is absent.

original: ajjhattāhārassapi rūpasamuṭṭhānā bhāvato. Ācariyānandatthero pana tattha labbhamāna
analyzed: ajjhatta āhārassa api rūpa samuṭṭhānā bhāvato ācariya ānanda thero pana tattha
translated: And in the case of the materiality that is in the body, the nutriment that is contact is absent there in the ultimate sense.

original: rūpakalāpesupi gandharasānaṃ ojāyaca abhāvaṃ vaṇṇeti. Rūpadhātuyā upapattikkhaṇe
analyzed: rūpa kalāpesu pi gandha rasānaṃ ojāya ca abhāvam rūpadhātuyāḥ upapatti kkhaṇe
translated: But the teacher, the Elder Ānanda, explains that even in the groups of materiality found there the odour and flavour and the nutritive essence are absent.🔽At the moment of reappearing in the fine-material sphere,

original: pañcāyatanāni pātubhavanti cakkhāyatanaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ, sotā yatanaṃ, manā yatanaṃ,
analyzed: pañca āyatanāni pātubhavanti cakkhāyatanam rūpa āyatanam sotā yatanam manā yatanam
translated: five bases become manifest, that is to say, the eye base, the visible-data base, the ear base, the sound base,🔽and the mind base.

original: dhammāyatananti ca, pañcadhātuyo pātubhavanti cakkhudhātu, rūpadhātu, sotadhātu,
analyzed: dhammāyatananti ca pañca dhātuyo pātubhavanti cakkhu dhātu rūpa dhātu sota dhātu
translated: And five elements become manifest, that is to say, the eye element, the visible-data element, the ear element,

original: manoviññāṇa dhātu, dhammadhātūtica, tayo āhārā pātubhavanti phassāhāro, manosañcetanā
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu dhammadhātu uti ca tayo āhārā pātubhavanti phassa āhāraḥ manaḥ sañcetanā
translated: and the mind-consciousness element and the mental-data element, the three nutriments become manifest, namely, contact as nutriment, mental volition as nutriment, and consciousness as nutriment.🔽And because this is said in the Vibhaṅga,

original: hāro, viññāṇā hāroti ca vibhaṅgevuttattā. Etthaca pāḷiyaṃ rūpaloke phoṭṭhabbe paṭikkhittepi🔽kiccantarasabbhāvā mahābhūtānaṃ tattha paṭilābho avārito eva hoti. Gandhādīnaṃ pana
analyzed: hāraḥ viññāṇā hāraḥ ti ca vibhaṅga iva utta ttā ettha ca pāḷiyam rūpa loke phoṭṭhabbe paṭikkhitte api  mahābhūtānam tattha paṭilābhaḥ a vāritaḥ eva hoti gandha ādīnam pana
translated: although visible form, odour, and flavour are rejected in the visible-form element,🔽the obtaining of the primary elements there is not rejected, because they have a function there. But🔽odour, etc., have no function there,

original: kiccantarameva natthi. Yena te dhammamattabhāvepi tiṭṭheyyaṃ tasmā tesaṃ avacanaṃ🔽tattha abhāvameva dīpetīti ācariyassa adhippāyo. Tathā pana bhūtacatukkaṃ tattha
analyzed: kicca antaram eva natthi yena te dhamma matta bhāve pi tiṭṭheyyam tasmā tesam avacanam  tattha abhāvam eva dīpeti iti ācariyassa adhippāyaḥ tathā pana bhūta catukkam tattha
translated: and so their non-mention indicates their absence there. This is the teacher’s intention.

original: atthiyeva, yathāha-asaññasattānaṃ ekaṃ mahābhūtaṃ paṭicca tayo mahābhūtātiādi. Phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ
analyzed: ekam mahābhūtam paṭicca tayaḥ mahābhūta ati ādi phoṭṭhabba āyatanam
translated: But the four primary elements are there, according to the text: “With one primary element of the non-percipient beings as … with three primary elements … ” .🔽The tangible-data base and the tangible-data element are rejected there.

original: pana phoṭṭhabba dhātuca tattha paṭikkhittā. Tasmā sabbesaṃ sabhāvadhammānaṃ dhammabhāve
analyzed: pana phoṭṭhabba dhātu ca tattha paṭikkhittā tasmā sabbesam sabhāva dhammānam dhamma bhāve
translated: So all the individual essences of dhammas are present there,

original: samānepi yena kiccavisesena gandho raso phoṭṭhabbaṃ kabaḷīkārāhārotica vuccati. Tassa
analyzed: samāne pi yena kicca visesena gandhaḥ rasaḥ phoṭṭhabbam kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ ti ca vuccati tassa
translated: but although they are present in the individual essences of dhammas, odour, flavour, and the tangible are called respectively odour as object, flavour as object, and the tangible as nutriment, by virtue of their particular functions.

original: natthitāya tesaṃ tena nāme na tattha anupalabbhamānataṃ sandhāya vibhaṅge kathāvatthumhi
analyzed: tesam tena nāme na tattha anupalabbhamāna tam sandhāya vibhaṅge kathā vatthumhi
translated: The denial of them there is everywhere in the Vibhaṅga in the Khandha-Katikā,

original: yamake sūti sabbattha tesaṃ tattha paṭikkhepo. Mahābhūtānaṃ pana nisanda dhammamattabhāvena
analyzed: yamake su ti sabbattha tesam tattha paṭikkhepaḥ mahābhūtānam pana nisanda dhamma matta bhāvena
translated: and in the Yamaka. But since the great primaries exist there in the mere state of primary qualities,🔽it is proper to say that they are not included in the mental-data base and mental-data element.

original: vijjamānānaṃ tesaṃ dhammāyatanadhammadhātūsu anupavesoti yutto siyāti vadanti. Tīṇidasakāni
analyzed: vijjamānānam tesam dhamma āyatana dhammadhātūsu anupavesaḥ ti yuttaḥ siyā ti vadanti tīṇidasakāni
translated: The three sets of ten

original: jīvitanavakañcāti ettha ācariyānanda matiyā cakkhusattakaṃ sotasattakaṃ vatthusattakanti
analyzed: jīvita navakam ca ati ettha ācariya ānanda matiyā cakkhu sattakam sota sattakam vatthu sattakam ti
translated: and the life-faculty ennead. Herein, according to the opinion of the teacher Ānanda, the eye septad, the ear septad, and the physical-basis septad🔽should be called the three septads and the life-faculty ennead.

original: evaṃ tīṇi sattakāni jīvitachakkañcāti vattabbaṃ. Abhiricchatīti alabbhamāne pathamaṃ
analyzed: evam tīṇi sattakāni jīvita chakkam ca ati vattabbam abhiricchati iti a labbhamāne pathamam
translated: The life-faculty ennead is called “the life-faculty septad” in the text because the first three of the ten are excluded there as not found there,

original: vajjite tattha labbhamānatāvasena avasissati. Atirekaṃvā hotīti attho. Etthaca rūpaloke
analyzed: vajjite tattha labbhamāna tā vasena avasissati atirekam vā hoti iti atthaḥ ettha ca rūpa loke
translated: and the remaining seven are left there as found there. The meaning is that there is a surplus.

original: viya kāmaloke jīvitanavakaṃ kasmā visuṃ na vuttanti. Rūpaloke pana āhārupatthambhakassa
analyzed: viya kāma loke jīvita navakam kasmā visum na vuttan ti rūpa loke pana āhāra upatthambhakassa
translated: And here, why is the life-faculty ennead not stated separately in the sense sphere as it is in the fine-material sphere?🔽In the fine-material sphere, however, it is stated separately because the life-faculty there is the support of the materiality of the physical heart- basis.

original: aññassaca sakalasarīrabyāpino anupālaka jīvitassa abhāvā etadeva tadubhayaṭṭhāne
analyzed: aññassa ca sakala sarīra byāpinaḥ jīvitassa abhāvā etat eva tad ubhaya ṭṭhāne
translated: And in the case of the other, since there is no life that is a guardian pervading the whole body, it is evident that it is this that stands in both places and guards the whole body.

original: ṭhatvā sakalasarīraṃ anupāletīti pākaṭaṃ tattha jīvitanavakanti visuṃ vuttaṃ. Kāmaloke🔽pana aññāni upatthambhakā nupālakāni bahūni pākaṭānica honti. Tasmā jīvitanavakaṃ
analyzed: ṭhatvā sakala sarīram anupāleti iti pākaṭam tattha jīvita navakam ti visum vuttam kāmaloke  pana aññāni upatthambhaka a nupālakāni bahūni pākaṭāni ca honti tasmā jīvita navakam
translated: So the life faculty is stated separately as the ninth.🔽But in the sense-desire world there are many other things that are supporters and guardians, and they are evident too.

original: apākaṭanti katvā visuṃ na vuttaṃ siyā. Kāmalokepi pana etaṃ asitādipācakaggivasena
analyzed: apākaṭanti katvā visum na vuttam siyā kāmaloke pi pana etam asita ādi pācaka aggi vasena
translated: So it may be that the life faculty is not stated separately because it is not evident.

original: tassevaca udayabhūtassa sakalasarī rānupālakassa usmāsaṅkhātassa kāyaggino vasena
analyzed: tassa iva ca udaya bhūtassa sakala sarīra anupālakassa usmā saṅkhātassa kāyagginaḥ vasena
translated: But in the sense-desire world this is evident as the fire of the body called heat, which is the support of the two fires and the guardian of the whole body.

original: pākaṭameva. Yaṃ sandhāya –
analyzed: pākaṭam eva yam sandhāya
translated: And it is with reference to this that it is said:🔽“When life, heat, and consciousness

original: Āyu usmāca viññāṇaṃ, yadā kāyaṃ jahantimaṃ;
analyzed: āyuḥ usmā ca viññāṇam yadā kāyam jahanti imam
translated: Leave the body, then it lies abandoned,

original: Apaviddho tadā seti, niratthaṃva kaliṅgaranti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: apaviddhaḥ tadā sa iti vuttam
translated: Like a useless log.”

original: Tattha āyūti tesu dvīsu aggīsu patiṭṭhitaṃ jīvitameva vuccati. Usmāti te dve aggayo
analyzed: tattha āyu iti tesu dvīsu aggīsu patiṭṭhitam jīvitam eva vuccati te dve aggayo
translated: Herein, “life” is the life faculty itself established in the two fires. “Heat” is the two fires.

original: vuccanti. Yesu tikkhamandavasena visama bhūtesu kāye nānābādhā uppajjanti. Yathāha-bahvābādho
analyzed: vuccanti yesu tikkha manda vasena bhūtesu kāye nānā ābādhāḥ uppajjanti
translated: are called. In these, which are uneven by reason of their sharpness and slowness, various sicknesses arise. As it is said: “He is one who is much afflicted with sickness

original: hoti bahvātaṅko. Visamavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannā gato hoti atiuṇhāyaatisītalāyāti.
analyzed: hoti bahu ātaṅkaḥ visama vepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannā gataḥ hoti ati uṇhāya ati sītalāya ati
translated: They are called “uneven” because they are uneven in the sense of being sharp or dull. And the various sicknesses arise in the body because of them, according as it is said: “He is very sick, very frail. He has an uneven, unworkable digestion, too hot or too cold” .

original: Samabhūtesu pana sattā nirābādhā honti. Yathāha-appābādho hoti. Appātaṅko. Samavepākiniyāgahaṇiyā
analyzed: sama bhūtesu pana sattāḥ nirābādhāḥ honti yathā āha appa ābādhaḥ hoti appa ātaṅkaḥ
translated: But when they are even, beings are free from sickness, according as it is said: “He is little sick, little frail. He has an even, workable digestion, neither too hot nor too cold” .🔽But some say that this is only the fire that digests what is eaten, etc.,

original: samannāgatohoti. Nātisītāya naccuṇhāya majjhimāya padhānakkhamāyāti. Keci pana asitādipācakaggismiṃ🔽eva etaṃmaññanti. Therenacanāmarūpaparicchedejīvitanavakaṃ nāma, rūpaloke visuṃ siyāti vuttaṃ.🔽Visuddhimagge pana sesesu catusamuṭṭhānesu aṭṭhasu jīvitanava kañceva tīṇi ojaṭṭhamakāni
analyzed: na ati sītāya na cuṇhāya majjhimāya padhāna kkhamāya ati keci pana asita ādi pācakaggismin  eva etam maññanti therena ca nāma rūpa paricchede jīvita navakam nāma rūpa loke visum siyā ti vuttam  visuddhi magge pana sesesu catu samuṭṭhānesu aṭṭhasu tīṇi oja ṭṭhamakāni
translated: and that the “nine on the life faculty” are only in the fine-material sphere, not in the immaterial sphere.🔽But in the Path of Purification thirty-three kinds of materiality are said to be evident in each of the remaining eight kinds of origin, that is to say, in the four origins of materiality and in the four of the life faculty and in the four of heat.

original: cāti tettiṃsa tettiṃsa rūpāni pākaṭāni hontīti vuttaṃ. Tattha aṭṭhasūti pācakaggiassāsa
analyzed: ca ati tettiṃsa tettiṃsa rūpāni pākaṭāni honti iti vuttam tattha aṭṭhasūti
translated: Herein, “eight” means the fire of digestion, the fire of heat, the fire of consciousness, the fire of nutriment, the fire of kamma, the fire of climate, the fire of applied thought, and the fire of sustained thought.

original: passāsavajjitesu tīsu tejokoṭṭhāsesu pañcasu vāyo koṭṭhāsesūti aṭṭhasu. Iti kāmalokepi
analyzed: passāsa vajjitesu tīsu tejaḥ koṭṭhāsesu pañcasu vāyo koṭṭhāsesu uti aṭṭhasu iti kāmaloke pi
translated: In the case of the three elements of fire and the five of air, which are free from the in-breath and the out-breath, there are eight. So in the sense sphere,

original: sakalasarīrabyāpīsu tejovāyo koṭṭhāsesu labbhamānattā etaṃ sakala sarīreeva daṭṭhabbanti.
analyzed: sakala sarīra byāpīsu etam daṭṭhabbanti
translated: since the fire and air elements that pervade the whole body are found in the whole body, it should be regarded as the whole body.

original: Ettha siyā, kasmā panettha kāmaloke viya rūpaloke rūpakalāpānaṃ nirodhakkamo na vuttoti.🔽Visesābhāvato, rūpalokepi hi maraṇakāle pana cuticitto pari sattarasamacittassa ṭhitikāla
analyzed: ettha siyā kasmā pana ittha kāma loke viya rūpa loke rūpa kalāpānam nirodha kkamaḥ na vuttaḥ ti  visesa abhāvataḥ rūpa loke pi hi maraṇa kāle pana cuti cittaḥ pari sattarasama cittassa ṭhiti kāla
translated: Here it may be asked: But why is no order of cessation stated for the material groups in the fine-material sphere as it is for those in the sense sphere?

original: mupādāya kammajarūpāni nuppajjantītiādiko nirodhakkamo kāmalokasadisoyeva. Kevalaṃ
analyzed: m upādāya kamma ja rūpāni nu ppajjanti iti ādikaḥ nirodha kkamaḥ kāma loka sadisaḥ yā iva kevalam
translated: Because there is no difference. For in the fine-material sphere too, from the time when the rebirth-linking consciousness has arisen at death up to the time when the life-continuum consciousness arises, the materiality originated by kamma does not arise, and so on. The order of cessation is the same as in the sense sphere.

original: panettha āhārajarūpa nirodhonāma natthi, tathā kaḷevara nikkhepoca. Tasmā tatthapi
analyzed: pana ittha āhāra ja rūpa nirodho nāma natthi tathā kaḷevara nikkhepo ca tasmā tattha pi
translated: Only this difference obtains, that there is no materiality originated by nutriment there, nor any casting off of the corpse. So there too,

original: cuticittato paraṃ soḷasacittakkhaṇa parimāṇe ekasmiṃ khaṇe cittajarūpasantānaṃ vocchijjati.
analyzed: cuti cittataḥ param soḷasa citta kkhaṇa parimāṇe ekasmin khaṇe citta ja rūpa santānam vā ucchijjati
translated: after the death consciousness, the continuity of the materiality originated by consciousness is interrupted in a single instant of sixteen heart-beats.

original: Tato paraṃ utusamuṭṭhānarūpaparaṃparā ekadviti accharākālamattaṃpi pavattitvā vocchijjatīti
analyzed: tatas param utu samuṭṭhāna rūpa paraṃparā pavattitvā vā ucchijjati iti
translated: After that the series of material instances originated by temperature ceases, after continuing for a moment or two only, like the twinkling of an eye.🔽And it is not proper to call a material continuity which continues for so short a time a dead body,

original: yuttaṃ. Naca ettakamattena kālena pavattamānāyapi rūpasantatiyā matakaḷevaraṃnāma🔽sakkā laddhuṃ. Passantānaṃ ekakkhaṇena viya sarīrassa antaradhānassa paññāyanatoti.
analyzed: yuttam na ca ettakam attena kālena rūpa santatiyā  sakkā laddhum passantānam eka khaṇena viya sarīrassa antaradhānassa paññāyanato ti
translated: because it is evident that the disappearance of the body is as instantaneous as the appearance.

original: Yathāca rūpaloke, tathā kāmalokepi upapattidevānaṃ aññesañca opapātikānanti. Tesañhi🔽sarīrāni paṭisandhikkhaṇeyeva sabbaso paripuṇṇena kammajakāyena nibbattattā kammajarūpehi
analyzed: yathā ca rūpa loke tathā kāma loke pi upapatti devānam aññesam ca opapātikānan ti tesam hi  sarīrāni paṭisandhi khaṇeya iva sabbaso paripuṇṇena kamma ja kāyena nibbatta ttā kamma ja rūpehi
translated: And just as in the world of visible form, so too in the world of sense desires, among the gods who are subject to appointed times of death and among the rest who are not so subject.

original: ghanapūritāni sallahukabharāni ca honti. Itararūpāni kammajarūpesu patiṭṭhāya pavattanti.🔽Tasmā tesaṃ cutikāle kammajarūpesu niruddhesu tāni tinna patiṭṭhāni hutvā ciraṃ santānaṃ
analyzed: ghana pūritāni sat lahuka bharāni ca honti itara rūpāni kamma ja rūpesu patiṭṭhāya pavattanti  tasmā tesam cuti kāle kamma ja rūpesu niruddhesu tāni tinna patiṭṭhāni hutvā ciram santānam
translated: For their bodies are produced with materiality generated by kamma, complete in every respect, at the very moment of rebirth-linking, so they are filled with the compact mass of materiality generated by kamma and are light and buoyant. The other kinds of materiality occur dependent on the materiality generated by kamma.

original: ghaṭṭetuṃ nasakkonti. Thokaṃ pavattitvā sabbaso nirujjhanti. Sarīranikkheponāma tesaṃ
analyzed: ghaṭṭetum na sakkonti thokam pavattitvā sabbaso nirujjhanti sarīra nikkhepaḥ nāma tesam
translated: Therefore, when the materiality generated by kamma ceases at the time of death, those other kinds of materiality cannot continue the continuity for long without a support, like the three kinds of earth that have been washed by water. They continue for a little while and then cease altogether. The disappearance of the body is called “the casting off of the body” by those who are subject to appointed times of death.

original: natthīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: na atthi iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: should be seen as non-existent.

original: [203] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī

original: “Maraṇakāle pana brahmānaṃ sarīranikkhepābhāvato sabbesaṃpi tisamuṭṭhānāni dvisamuṭṭhānānica saheva nirujjhantī”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: maraṇa kāle pana brahmānam sarīra nikkhepa abhāvato sabbesam pi ti samuṭṭhānāni dvi samuṭṭhānāni ca saha iva nirujjhanti iti vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: it is said: “But at the time of death, since the Brahmā gods do not abandon the body, all the materiality originated by the three roots and that originated by the two roots ceases together with the life faculty.” That is not good.

original: Evañhi sati sabbesaṃ rūpabrahmānaṃ maraṇāsannacittāni rūpaṃ nasamuṭṭhāpentīti āpajjati.
analyzed: evam hi sati sabbesam rūpa brahmānam maraṇa āsanna cittāni rūpam na samuṭṭhāpenti iti āpajjati
translated: For if it were so, then it would follow that the consciousnesses of all the fine-material Brahmās near to death would not originate materiality.

original: Na hi maraṇāsanna citta samuṭṭhitāni rūpāni kammajarūpehi saheva nirujjhantīti sakkā
analyzed: na hi maraṇa āsanna citta samuṭṭhitāni rūpāni kamma ja rūpehi saha iva nirujjhanti iti sakkā
translated: For it cannot be said that material instances originated by consciousnesses near to death cease together with the materiality originated by kamma.

original: vattunti. Yathācatāni kammajarūpanirodhato thokaṃ pavattitvā nirujjhanti. Tathā utujarūpānipi🔽cittajarūpanirodhato thokaṃ pavattitvā nirujjhantīti na na sakkā viññātuṃ. Naca tāvattakena
analyzed: vattum ti kamma ja rūpa nirodhataḥ thokam nirujjhanti tathā utu ja rūpāni pi  citta ja rūpa nirodhataḥ thokam pavattitvā nirujjhanti iti na na sakkā viññātum na ca tāvattakena
translated: They cease after continuing a little while after the cessation of the materiality originated by kamma, just as the material instances originated by temperature cease after continuing a little while after the cessation of the materiality originated by kamma.🔽So it cannot be known that they cease after continuing a little while after the cessation of the materiality originated by consciousness.🔽And it is not possible for the abandoning of the body to occur in that short time while they are continuing.

original: kālena tesu pavatta mānesupi sarīranikkheponāma sakkā bhavitunti. Brahmānaṃ pana
analyzed: kālena tesu sarīra nikkhepaḥ nāma sakkā bhavitum ti brahmānam pana
translated: But in the case of the Brahmās,

original: thina middhādīnaṃ nīvaraṇajātiyānaṃ atthitāya tadanurūpaṃ cittajarūpānaṃ tadanugatikānañca🔽utujarūpānaṃ lahukagarukatādivikāro na na sambhavatīti lahutādittayaṃpi gahetvā vuttaṃ🔽tevīsarūpesūti. Ghānādittayabhāvadvayavajjāni tevīsarūpāni honti. Tāniyeva cakkhu🔽sotavatthu viññattidvayavajjāni asaññīnaṃ sattaraseva rūpāni hontīti yojanā. Asaññīnaṃ🔽pana garulahutādipakāro cinte tabbo. Na vā cintetabbo rūpadhammānaṃ ruppanavikārassa
analyzed: nīvaraṇa jātiyānam tad anurūpam  lahuka garuka tā ādi vikāraḥ na na sambhavati iti gahetvā vuttam  tevīsarūpesu iti ghāna ādi ttaya bhāva dvaya vajjāni tevīsarūpāni honti cakkhu  sotavatthu viññatti dvaya vajjāni asaññīnam sattarasa iva rūpāni honti iti yojanā asaññīnam  pana garulahuta ādi pakāraḥ cinte tabbaḥ na vā cintetabbaḥ rūpa dhammānam ruppana vikārassa
translated: Because of the presence of the kinds of obstruction called “drowsiness and torpor,” etc., the corresponding kinds of materiality originated by consciousness and the kinds of materiality originated by temperature that accompany them🔽are not incapable of the variations of lightness, heaviness, etc. So the three beginning with lightness are also included and it is said🔽“in the twenty-three kinds of materiality.” The twenty-three kinds of materiality are the twenty-two kinds of materiality excluding the two kinds of materiality called nose and tongue, and the materiality of the physical heart- basis. Those same twenty-three kinds of materiality are the twenty-two kinds of materiality excluding the two kinds of materiality called eye and ear, and the materiality of the physical heart-basis. original: bahukāraṇattāti. Upapattiyanti kāmarūpāsaññīnaṃ paṭisandhiyā uppādakkhaṇe. Uppādakkhaṇoeva🔽hi ekantena upapattikhaṇonāma hotīti. Pavattetūti paṭisandhiyā ṭhitikkhaṇato paṭṭhāya🔽sakale pavattikāle pana nakiñcipi nalabbhati. Labbhatiyevāti adhippāyo. Na hi idaṃnāma
analyzed: bahu kāraṇa ttā ati upapattiyanti kāmarūpa asaññīnam paṭisandhiyā uppāda khaṇe uppāda khaṇaḥ eva 🔽hi ekantena upapatti khaṇaḥ nāma hoti iti pavattetu uti paṭisandhiyā ṭhiti khaṇataḥ paṭṭhāya 🔽sakale pavatti kāle pana na kiñcipi na labbhati labbhatiyā iva ati adhippāyaḥ na hi idaṃnāma
translated: And because the kinds of obstruction such as stiffness and torpor are present, the alteration of the kinds of materiality derived from the primary elements and of the kinds of materiality due to temperature that are in conformity with them is not impossible. So the three beginning with buoyancy are included and it is said that “among the twenty-three kinds of materiality.” The twenty-three kinds of materiality are the twenty-two kinds of materiality excluding the two kinds of materiality consisting of nose and tongue, and the materiality of the physical heart- basis. The twenty-two kinds of materiality excluding the two kinds of materiality consisting of eye and ear are the eighteen kinds of materiality in the case of non-percipient beings. But the alteration of heaviness, lightness, etc., in the case of non-percipient beings should be considered. Or it need not be considered, because the alteration of material dhammas is due to many causes. “At rebirth”: at the moment of arising of the rebirth-linking consciousness in the case of beings in the sense sphere and the fine-material sphere. For the moment of arising is exclusively the moment of rebirth. “In the course of an existence”: from the moment of rebirth-linking onwards. But in the whole course of an existence nothing is not possible. The intention is that it is possible. For there is nothing that is not possible in the course of an existence.

original: rūpaṃ pavatte nalabbhati. Paṭisandhiyaṃeva labbhatīti atthīti. [Rūpapavattikkamo]🔽161. Evaṃ cittacetasika rūpasaṅgahaṃ katvā idāni yathā nuppattaṃ nibbānasaṅgahaṃ
analyzed: rūpam pavatte na labbhati paṭisandhiyam eva labbhati iti atthi iti rūpa pavatti kkamaḥ  evam rūpa saṅgaham katvā idāni yathā nu pattam nibbāna saṅgaham
translated: and it is not found in the process of materiality. It is only found in rebirth-linking.

original: karonto nibbānaṃpanātiādi māha. Nibbānaṃ pana nibbānanti pavuccatīti sambandho. Lokuttarasaṅkhātanti🔽lokuttaranti bhagavatā kathitaṃ, yathāha-katame dhammā lokuttarā. Cattāroca ariyamaggā🔽cattārica sāmaññaphalāni asaṅkhatāca dhātu, ime dhammā lokuttarāti. Etena nibbānassa
analyzed: karontaḥ nibbānam pana ati ādi mā āha nibbānam pana nibbānanti pavuccati iti sambandhaḥ lokuttara saṅkhātanti  lokuttaram iti bhagavatā kathitam yathā āha katame dhammā lokuttarā cattāro ca ariya maggā  cattāri ca sāmañña phalāni asaṅkhatā ca dhātu ime dhammā lokuttarā ti etena nibbānassa
translated: Having thus included the mental factors and materiality, he now includes Nibbāna, which is not included in the fourfold and fivefold reckoning, by saying “Nibbāna, however, is called ‘supramundane’,” etc. The construction is: “Nibbāna, however, is called ‘supramundane’ and ‘to be realized by the noble person’s knowledge.’“

original: paññattimattabhāvaṃ nivatteti. Na hi lokavohārasiddhā paññatti lokuttarānāma sakkā🔽bhavitunti. Catumaggañāṇena sacchikātabbanti cakkhumantena candamaṇḍalaṃviya cakkhunā
analyzed: paññatti matta bhāvam nivatteti na hi lokavohāra siddhā paññatti lokuttarā nāma sakkā  bhavitum ti catu magga ñāṇena sacchikātabbanti cakkhumantena canda maṇḍalam viya cakkhunā
translated: “Supramundane” is said by the Blessed One thus: “What are the supramundane states? They are the four noble paths and the four fruits of recluseship and the unformed element. These are the supramundane states” . By this he rejects the mere designation of Nibbāna. For it is not possible that what is established by mundane usage should be called “supramundane.”

original: paṭiladdhamaggañāṇehi ariyajanehi catūhi ariyamaggañāṇehi paccakkhato daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṭiladdha magga ñāṇehi ariya janehi catūhi ariya magga ñāṇehi paccakkhataḥ daṭṭhabbam
translated: “To be realized by the noble person’s knowledge”: it should be seen by the four kinds of noble person’s knowledge, as one who has eyes sees the orb of the moon.

original: Paṭivijjhitabbanti attho. Tattha catumaggañāṇenāti etena tādi samhā paṭipattimaggato
analyzed: paṭivijjhitabbanti atthaḥ tattha catu magga ñāṇena āti etena tādi samhā paṭipatti maggato
translated: The meaning is that it should be penetrated.

original: vimukhānaṃ andhaputhujjanānaṃ jaccandhānaṃ viya canda maṇḍalassa tassa avisayabhāvaṃ
analyzed: vimukhānam andha puthujjanānam jad candhānam viya canda maṇḍalassa tassa avisaya bhāvam
translated: Herein, by the knowledge of the four paths he shows that it is not the province of blind worldlings who are averse from such practice, like the moon’s disk is not the province of the congenitally blind.

original: dasseti. Na ca jaccandhānaṃ cakkhumhi anupaladdhamattena candamaṇḍalaṃ natthināma🔽hotīti. Sacchikātabbanti etena paramatthato vijjamānabhāvaṃ dasseti. Yañhi kiñci
analyzed: dasseti na ca canda maṇḍalam  hoti iti sacchikātabbanti etena paramatthataḥ vijjamāna bhāvam dasseti yat hi kiñci
translated: And it is not that the moon’s disk does not exist because it is not perceived by the congenitally blind.

original: paramatthato vijjamānaṃ nahoti. Taṃ sarūpato kassa paccakkhaṃnāma bhavissatīti. Tadubhayena🔽panassa paññavantānaṃ kalyāṇakaputhujjanānaṃ anumānato siddhataṃ dīpeti, na hi anumānatopi
analyzed: paramatthataḥ vijjamānam nahoti tam sarūpataḥ kassa paccakkhaṃnāma bhavissati iti tad ubhayena  panassa paññavantānam kalyāṇaka puthujjanānam anumānataḥ siddha tam dīpeti na hi anumānataḥ pi
translated: By “it should be realized” he shows that it exists in the ultimate sense, for whatever exists in the ultimate sense cannot be said to be non-existent, since it will have a specific nature evident to anyone.

original: attano buddhiyaṃ asiddhassa apākaṭassa sacchikiriyāya vāyāmopināma atthi. Yena sacchikiriyā
analyzed: attanaḥ buddhiyam asiddhassa apākaṭassa sacchikiriyāya atthi yena sacchikiriyā
translated: By both of these he shows that it is established by inference for the wise ordinary men of good will, for there is no effort to realize what is not established by inference as well as not evident to one’s own understanding.🔽By what? By the realization of the four paths.

original: siddhiyāti. Evaṃ nibbānassa paramatthato vijjamānataṃ dassetvā idāni kevalaṃ vijjamānamattameva🔽na hoti. Athakho mahātejavantaṃ mahojavantañca taṃ hotīti dassetuṃ maggaphalānamālambaṇabhūtanti
analyzed: siddhiyā ti evam nibbānassa paramatthataḥ vijjamāna tam dassetvā idāni kevalam vijjamāna mattam eva  na hoti athakho mahā tejavantam mahojavantam ca tam hoti iti dassetum magga phalānam ālambaṇa bhūtam ti
translated: ‘Attainment’: after showing in this way the existence of Nibbāna in the ultimate sense, now, in order to show that it is not merely existent, but is also very powerful and very swift, he said, ‘It is the object of the path and fruit.’

original: vuttaṃ. Etena nibbānena vināmagga phalānaṃ akiccasiddhiṃ dasseti. Tato tassa mahātejavanta🔽taṃ mahojavantatañca dīpeti. Yathā hi mahiddhiko eko rājā hoti. Tassa raṭṭhe ekasmiṃ
analyzed: vuttam etena nibbānena phalānam akicca siddhim dasseti tatas tassa  tam dīpeti yathā hi mahiddhikaḥ ekaḥ rājā hoti tassa raṭṭhe ekasmin
translated: By this he shows that without Nibbāna the path and fruit would not be successful. Then he shows its great power and swiftness.

original: mahāgāme eko gāmabhojako ekoca corajeṭṭhako mahāparivāro vasati. Teca aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: mahā gāme ekaḥ gāma bhojakaḥ ekaḥ ca cora jeṭṭhakaḥ mahā parivāraḥ vasati te ca aññam aññam
translated: For example, there is a king who has great power. In his realm there is a great village. In it there is a village headman and a chief robber with a great following. They live there, seeking to kill each other.

original: vadhāya parisakkantā vicaranti. Tattha gāmabhojako nagaraṃ gantvā rājānaṃ upaṭṭhahi.
analyzed: vadhāya parisakkantāḥ vicaranti tattha gāmabhojakaḥ nagaram gantvā rājānam upaṭṭhahi
translated: The village headman goes to the city and attends on the king.

original: So na cirasseva rājavallabho hoti. Rājato mahatiṃ āṇaṃ labhati. Taṃ sutvā corajeṭṭhako
analyzed: saḥ na cirassa iva rāja vallabhaḥ hoti rājataḥ mahatim āṇam labhati tam sutvā cora jeṭṭhakaḥ
translated: Soon he becomes a favourite of the king and receives a great command from him. Hearing this, the chief robber

original: idāni idhavasantassa mamajīvitaṃ natthīti attano parivārena saddhiṃ aṭṭaviṃ paviṭṭho.
analyzed: idāni idha vasantassa mama jīvitam na atthi iti attanaḥ parivārena saddhim aṭṭavim paviṭṭhaḥ
translated: Now, thinking, “There is no life for me here,” he entered the forest together with his retinue.

original: Gāmabhojakoca taṃaṭṭaviṃ paviṭṭhaṃpi muñcituṃ adatvā gahetvā vadhi. Evaṃ sampadamidaṃ🔽daṭṭhabbaṃ. Mahiddhikarājā viya hi nibbānaṃ. Gāma bhojako viya ñāṇaṃ. Corajeṭṭhako🔽viya moho. Parivāra corā viya sesakilesā. Pubbe rañño anupaṭṭhā nakāle gāmabhojako
analyzed: muñcitum a datvā gahetvā evam sampadam idam  daṭṭhabbam mahiddhika rājā viya hi nibbānam gāma bhojakaḥ viya ñāṇam cora jeṭṭhakaḥ  viya mohaḥ parivāra corāḥ viya sesa kilesā pubbe rañño anupaṭṭhā na kāle gāma bhojako
translated: The village headman, too, did not let him go but captured him and killed him. Thus it should be seen🔽that Nibbana is like the king of great power, knowledge is like the village headman, delusion is like the chief thief,

original: viya puthujjanañāṇaṃ. Upaṭṭhānakāle gāma bhojako viya maggañāṇanti. Taṇhā pavattamānā
analyzed: viya puthujjana ñāṇam upaṭṭhāna kāle gāma bhojakaḥ viya magga ñāṇan ti taṇhā pavattamānā
translated: the other defilements are like the thieves in the retinue, and the knowledge of the worldling is like the village headman who did not serve the king in the past, while the knowledge of the path is like the village headman who served the king.

original: ajjhattabahiddhādi bhedesu khandhādidhammesu vinandhamānāva pavattati. Yathāha –
analyzed: ajjhatta bahiddhā ādi bhedesu khandha ādi dhammesu vinandhamānā ava pavattati yathā āha
translated: Craving occurs as it delights in the various kinds of formations such as the aggregates, etc., classified as internal and external, etc.,

original: Antojaṭā bahijaṭā, jaṭāya jaṭitā pajāti.
analyzed: antojaṭā bahijaṭā jaṭāya jaṭitā pajāti
translated: as it is said: “The internal tangle and the external tangle, the tangle of the tangle, the tangle of the people.

original: Tasmā sā veḷugumbe veḷusākhā viya vinanaṭṭhena saṃsibbanaṭṭhena vānasamaññaṃ labhatīti
analyzed: tasmā sā veḷu gumbe veḷu sākhā viya vinana ṭṭhena saṃsibbana ṭṭhena vāna samaññam labhati iti
translated: Therefore it is called craving because it delights in the various kinds of formations such as the aggregates, etc., classified as internal and external, etc., or because it is a tangle like a tangle of bamboo.

original: vuttaṃ vānasaṅkhātāyataṇhāyāti. Nikkhantattāti nissaṭattā. Tassā visayabhāvaṃ atikkamitvā🔽ṭhitattāti attho. Etena vānato nikkhantanti nibbānanti imamatthaṃ dasseti. Sabhāvatoti🔽santilakkhaṇena. Ajjhattasambhūtānaṃ tividhavaṭṭasantāpānaṃ nibbutiatthena. Tesaṃ🔽sabbaso abhāvaṭṭhenāti attho. Ekavidhaṃpīti yathā cittaṃ sabhāvato ekavidhaṃpi jātidhammattā
analyzed: vuttam vāna saṅkhātāya taṇhāya ati nikkhanta ttā ati nissaṭa ttā tassāḥ visaya bhāvam atikkamitvā  ṭhita ttā ti atthaḥ etena vānataḥ nikkhantanti nibbānanti imam attham dasseti sabhāvato ti  santi lakkhaṇena ajjhatta sambhūtānam tividha vaṭṭa santāpānam nibbuti atthena tesam  sabbasas abhāva ṭṭhena ati attho ekavidham pi iti yathā cittam sabhāvataḥ ekavidham api jāti dhamma ttā
translated: “From the wood” is said of craving. “Gone forth” is gone out. The meaning is that it stands having overcome the state of being its object. By this he shows the meaning “Nibbana is that from which the wood has gone forth.” “In its individual essence” is in the sense of the characteristic of stilling. In the sense of the stilling of the three-plane fires that arise internally. The meaning is in the sense of their complete non-existence. “In one way”: although consciousness is in one way in its individual essence, still, because it is subject to birth,

original: jātibhūmisampayogādi bhedena kāla disādesapuggalabhedenaca vatthuto bhinnameva hoti.🔽Na tathā idaṃ nibbānaṃ. Idaṃ pana sabhāvatopi vatthutopi abhinnameva hutvā ekavidhaṃ🔽hoti. Idañhi anamatagge saṃsāre atīte etarahi anāgateca parinibbutānaṃ buddhānaṃvā
analyzed: jāti bhūmi sampayoga ādi bhedena kāla disa ādesa puggala bhedena ca vatthutaḥ bhinnam eva hoti  na tathā idam nibbānam idam pana sabhāvataḥ pi vatthutaḥ pi abhinnam eva hutvā ekavidham  hoti idam hi anamatagge saṃsāre atīte etarahi anāgate ca parinibbutānam buddhānam vā
translated: “Craving called ‘in-breath’ and ‘out-breath’ is stated” . “Gone out” : having been abandoned. The meaning is that it is established by transcending the state of being its object. By this he shows the meaning of “Nibbana is gone out from in-breath and out-breath” . “In its individual essence” : by the characteristic of peace. In the sense of the quenching of the three-plane fires that arise internally. The meaning is: in the sense of their complete non-existence. “It is of one kind” : just as consciousness, although of one kind in its individual essence, is differentiated by time, direction, location, and person, by way of the differentiation of its objective field, through its association with the plane of birth, etc.,

original: paccekabuddhānaṃvā buddhasāvakānaṃvā sabbesaṃpi ekameva hoti. Kasmā, aniddisitabbadhammattā.
analyzed: paccekabuddhānam vā buddhasāvakānam vā sabbesam pi ekam eva hoti kasmai a niddisitabba dhamma ttā
translated: so this Nibbana is not. But this is of one kind only, undifferentiated by way of its individual essence and by way of its objective field. For this is the same for all Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples who have attained final Nibbana in the past, present, or future. Why? Because of the impossibility of distinguishing it.

original: Viññāṇaṃ anidassanaṃ anantaṃ sabbatopabhanti hi bhagavatā vuttaṃ. Tattha viññāṇanti
analyzed: viññāṇam anidassanam anantam sabbata upabhanti hi bhagavatā vuttam tattha viññāṇanti
translated: “Consciousness is signless, infinite, all-luminous” . Herein, consciousness is

original: saṅkhatadhammānaṃ khayanirodhabhāvena siddhattā etaṃ tabbhāvenaeva suṭṭhu abhibyattaṃ🔽katvā ñātabbaṃ. Anidassananti animittadhammattā bālaputhujjanānaṃ dassanavisayabhūtena🔽kenacinimittena nidassituṃvā kālabhedena disādesapuggalasantāna bhedena hīnapaṇītādibhedena
analyzed: saṅkhata dhammānam khaya nirodha bhāvena siddhattā etam tad bhāvena eva suṭṭhu abhibyattam  katvā ñātabbam anidassanam ti animitta dhamma ttā bāla puthujjanānam dassana visaya bhūtena  kenacid nimittena nidassitum vā kāla bhedena disā desa puggala santāna bhedena hīna paṇīta ādi bhedena
translated: to be known as the cessation of the formed dhammas, which is accomplished by the state of exhaustion.🔽Signless: because of the signless nature of the state of exhaustion, it is not possible to point to it, saying: “It is this,” by means of a sign which is the object of the vision of the ignorant worldling,🔽or to point to it, saying: “It is here,” by dividing it into past, future, and present, or into directions, persons, and continuity, or by dividing it into inferior, superior, etc.

original: ca bhinnaṃ katvā nidassituṃvā nārahatīti attho. Anantanti pubbantāparantavirahitaṃ.
analyzed: ca bhinnam katvā nidassitum vā na ārahati iti atthaḥ anantam ti pubba anta apara anta virahitam
translated: Infinite: devoid of a beginning and an end.

original: Sabbatopabhanti vaṭṭadukkhapaṭipakkhasiddhehi anantehi guṇobhāsehi sabbato pabhāvantanti🔽attho. Tathā aniddisitabbadhammattāca pana anamatagge saṃsāre sabbāsuca disāsu asukasmiṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkha paṭipakkha siddhehi anantehi guṇa ubhāsehi sabbatas  attho tathā a niddisitabba dhamma ttā ca pana anamatagge saṃsāre sabbāsu ca disāsu asukasmin
translated: All-luminous: the meaning is that it is all-illuminated by infinite rays of noble qualities, which are the opposites of the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: nāma kāle asukāyanāma disāya natthīti navattabbaṃ. Kasmā, ariyamaggaṃ bhāventena
analyzed: nāma kāle asukāya nāma disāya natthi iti na vattabbam kasmai ariya maggam bhāventena
translated: And because it is a state that cannot be pointed to, it cannot be said that it is not in such and such a place in the beginningless round of rebirths or in any direction.

original: yadā kadāci yattha katthaci avassaṃ adhigantabbatāvasena sabbadā sabbattha ca labbhamānattā.
analyzed: yadā kadāci yattha katthaci avassam adhigantabba tā vasena sabbadā sabbattha ca labbhamāna ttā
translated: Because it is available at all times and in all places, since it is to be attained whenever and wherever the opportunity arises.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ vinaye, aṅguttare, udāneca –🔽Seyyathāpi bhikkhave yākāci loke savantiyo mahāsamuddaṃ appenti. Yāca antalikkhā
analyzed: vuttam ha etam vinaye aṅguttare udāne ca  seyyathā api bhikkhave yākāci loke savantiyaḥ mahā samuddam appenti yāca antalikkhā
translated: For this is said in the Vinaya, in the Aṅguttara Nikāya, and in the Udāna:

original: dhārā papatanti. Na tena mahāsamuddassa ūnattaṃvā pūrattaṃvā paññāyati. Eva meva
analyzed: dhārā papatanti na tena mahā samuddassa ūnattam vā pūrattam vā paññāyati eva mā eva
translated: “Bhikkhus, just as the rivers in the world flow into the great ocean and the rains fall into it, yet the great ocean does not, on that account, have overflow or depletion,

original: kho bhikkhave bahūcepi bhikkhū anupādisesāya nibbāna dhātuyā parinibbāyanti. Na tena
analyzed: kho bhikkhave bahūce pi bhikkhū anupādisesāya nibbāna dhātuyā parinibbāyanti na tena
translated: so too, bhikkhus, although many bhikkhus attain Nibbana, which is the destruction of the taints, yet the Dhamma does not, on that account, have overflow or depletion.”🔽And in the commentaries it is said: “The Dhamma does not, on that account, have overflow or depletion” means that even in the course of an incalculable aeon, if no Buddhas arose, not a single being would fail to attain Nibbana.

original: nibbānadhātuyā ūnattaṃ vā pūrattaṃvā paññāyatīti.🔽Aṭṭhakathāsuca na tena nibbānadhātuyā ūnattaṃvā pūrattaṃvā paññāyatīti asaṅkhyeyyepi
analyzed: nibbāna dhātuyāḥ ūnattam vā pūrattam vā paññāyati iti  aṭṭhakathāsu ca na tena nibbāna dhātuyāḥ ūnattam vā pūrattam vā paññāyati iti asaṅkhyeyye pi
translated: And it cannot be said that the Nibbana element is empty then.

original: mahākappe buddhesu anuppajjantesu ekasattopi parinibbātuṃ nasakkoti. Tadāpi tucchā🔽nibbāna dhātūti nasakkā vattuṃ. Buddhakāle pana ekekasmiṃ samāgame asaṅkhyeyyāpi
analyzed: mahākappe buddhesu an uppajjantesu eka sattaḥ api parinibbātum na sakkoti tadā api tucchā 🔽nibbāna dhātū ti na sakkā vattum buddha kāle pana ekekasmin samāgame asaṅkhyeyyā api
translated: But in the time of the Buddhas, in each of the assemblies, even an incalculable number of beings

original: sattā amataṃ ārādhenti. Tadāpi nasakkā vattuṃ pūrā nibbānadhātūti vuttaṃ. Brahmanimantanasutteca
analyzed: sattāḥ amatam ārādhenti tadā api na sakkā vattum pūrāḥ nibbāna dhātū iti vuttam brahmanimantanasutte ca

original: viññāṇaṃ anidassanaṃ anantaṃ sabbatopabhanti vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāyañca sabbatopabhanti🔽sabbato pabhāsampannaṃ. Nibbānato hi añño koci dhammo pabhassaratarovā jotivantatarovā🔽parisuddhatarovā paṇḍara tarovā natthi. Sabbatovā pabhūtameva hoti. Nakatthaci natthīti
analyzed: viññāṇam anidassanam anantam sabbatas upabhanti vuttam aṭṭhakathāyañca  sabbatas pabhā sampannam nibbānataḥ hi aññaḥ koci dhammo pabhassarataraḥ vā jotivantataraḥ vā  natthi sabbatas vā pabhūtam eva hoti na katthaci natthi iti
translated: “Consciousness is signless, infinite, all-luminous” . And in the commentary:

original: sabbatopataṃ. Puratthimadisādīsu hi asukadisāyaṃnāma nibbānaṃ natthīti navattabbanti vuttaṃ.🔽Evaṃsantepi etaṃ niruddhatekālikadhamma sannissayena viññāya mānattā niruddhadhammabhedena
analyzed: puratthima disā ādīsu hi asuka disā ayaṃnāma nibbānam natthi iti vuttam  evaṃsante pi etam niruddha tekālika dhamma sannissayena viññāya māna ttā niruddha dhamma bhedena
translated: “All-luminous” means that it is endowed with all-round light. For there is no other state whatsoever that is more luminous or more radiant or more purified or more clear than Nibbāna. It is all-luminous, not partly luminous and partly not. It is not the case that Nibbāna is not in such and such a direction as “here” or “there.”🔽Thus it is said that it is all-luminous. But although it is thus, it is nevertheless said to be “all-luminous” because it is known by the sign of a state that has ceased,🔽and it is possible to treat it figuratively by distinguishing it as a state that has ceased.

original: bhinnaṃ katvā upacarituṃ labbhatīti vuttaṃ saupādisesātiādi. Tattha upādīyati taṇhādiṭṭhīhi
analyzed: bhinnam katvā upacaritum labbhati iti vuttam saupādisesa atiādi tattha upādīyati taṇhā diṭṭhīhi

original: bhusaṃ gaṇhīyatīti upādi. Upādinnakhandhapañcakaṃ. Soyeva ekadesenavā anavasesenavā🔽pahīnehi kammakilesehi sesoti upādiseso.
