original: bhavanetti saṅkhayā. Anupādisesā pana samparāyikāti. Aṅguttare pana sattanipāte ubhatobhāgavimutta🔽paññāpi muttānaṃ dvinnaṃ khīṇāsavānaṃ khandhupādisesavasena kāyasakkhidiṭṭhipatta
analyzed: bhavanā itti saṅkhayā anupādisesā pana samparāyikā ati aṅguttare pana satta nipāte  muttānam dvinnam khīṇāsavānam khandhu pādisesa vasena kāya sakkhi diṭṭhi patta
translated: and the extinction element with no residue left is the future one. But in the Book of Elevens in the Collection of Gradual Discourses, in the Section on the Pair,

original: saddhāvimuttadhammānusārīsaṅkhātānaṃ catunnaṃ sekkhānaṃ āraddhavipassa kassaca yogīkalyāṇaputhujjanassa
analyzed: saddhā vimutta dhamma anusārī saṅkhātānam catunnam sekkhānam āraddha vipassa kassa ca yogī kalyāṇa puthujjanassa
translated: the pair of those with cankers destroyed who are both-ways liberated and the four kinds of trainee called “faith-liberated” and “view-attained” who are body-witness and one who attains to peace by insight,🔽and any yogi of fine character who is a worldling and has begun insight, are said to have a residue of clinging in the form of aggregates and a residue of the cankers, respectively.

original: kilesu pādisesavasena saupādisesatā anupādisesatāca vuttā. Tattheva navanipāte antarāparinibbāyī,
analyzed: kilesu pādisesa vasena saupādisesa tā anupādisesa tā ca vuttā tattha iva nava nipāte antarā parinibbāyī
translated: And in the same Collection, in the Section on the Nine, the five kinds of non-returners called “one who attains Nibbāna in the interval,”

original: upahaccaparinibbāyī, asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī, sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī, uddhaṃ sotaakaniṭṭhagāmīti
analyzed: upahacca parinibbāyī asaṅkhāra parinibbāyī sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyī uddham sota akaniṭṭha gāmī iti
translated: “one who attains Nibbāna upon landing,” “one who attains Nibbāna without prompting,” “one who attains Nibbāna with prompting,” and “one who is going upstream to the highest,”

original: pañcannaṃ anāgāmīnaṃ sakadāgāmissa tiṇṇaṃ sotāpannānanti navannaṃ sekkhapuggalānaṃ
analyzed: pañcannam anāgāmīnam sakadāgāmissa tiṇṇam sotāpannānam ti navannam sekkha puggalānam
translated: and the three kinds of stream-enterers and the one kind of once-returner—these nine kinds of trainee

original: kilesupādisesavasena saupādisesatā vuttā.
analyzed: kilesa upādisesa vasena saupādisesa tā vuttā
translated: are said to have a residue of clinging in the form of the cankers.

original: Nettiyaṃ pana arahattaphalaṃpi saupādisesanibbānanti vuttaṃ. Taṃ idha nādhippetaṃ.
analyzed: nettiyam pana arahatta phalam pi sa upādisesa nibbānan ti vuttam tat idha na adhippetam
translated: But in the Netti the fruit of arahantship is called “the extinction element with a residue left” . But that is not intended here.

original: Etthaca maggakkhaṇe kilesānaṃ khayo saupādi sesaṃnāma. Cuti anantare khandhānaṃ anuppādo
analyzed: ettha ca magga kkhaṇe kilesānaṃ khayo cuti anantare khandhānaṃ anuppādo
translated: And here, at the moment of the path, the exhaustion of defilements is called “with a remainder of clinging” . The non-arising of the aggregates next to cessation is called “without remainder of clinging” .

original: anupādisesaṃnāma. Yasmā pana paṭisandhivandhānāma kilesesu satieva jāyanti. Asati🔽najāyanti, tasmā tepi kilesakkhayena saheva khiyyanti. Yāvacutiyā pavattamānaṃ paccuppannakhandhasantānaṃ
analyzed: yasmā pana paṭisandhi vandhā nāma kilesesu sati eva jāyanti asati  na jāyanti tasmā te pi kilesa kkhayena saha iva khiyyanti yāva cutiyā pavattamānam paccuppanna khandha santānam
translated: But since rebirth-linking is only when there are defilements and does not occur when there are not, it is exhausted together with the exhaustion of the defilements.

original: pana khīṇāsavassapi purimabhave pavattakammakilesānaṃ phalanisandabhūtaṃ sabbasattānaṃ🔽dhamma tāsiddhaṃ. Tasmā taṃ khīṇesupi kilesesu yāvacutiyā pavatta tiyeva. Cutikkhaṇe🔽tassa nirodhopi dhammatānirodho eva. Yo pana tadanantare punabhavassa anuppādo. So
analyzed: pana khīṇāsavassa api purima bhave pavatta kamma kilesānam phala nisanda bhūtam sabba sattānam  dhamma tā siddham tasmā tam khīṇesu pi kilesesu yāva cutiyā tiyā iva cuti kkhaṇe  tassa nirodhaḥ api dhamma tā nirodhaḥ eva yaḥ pana tad anantare punabhavassa anuppādaḥ so
translated: But the continuity of the present aggregates that occurs until death is the natural outcome of the kamma and defilements that occurred in a previous existence in the case of one possessed of cankers. It is a natural outcome for all beings.🔽Therefore it occurs until death even in one whose cankers are exhausted. And its cessation at the moment of death is also natural cessation.🔽But the non-arising of renewed existence next to that is established together with the exhaustion of the defilements.

original: kilesakkhayena saheva siddho. Na kevalaṃ tadanantare puna bhavasseva. Tato paraṃpi
analyzed: kilesa kkhayena saha iva siddhaḥ na kevalam tad anantare puna bhavassa iva tatas
translated: Not only that of renewed existence next to that, but also that of any existence beyond that is established together with the exhaustion of the defilements.

original: anamatagga saṃsāre bhavaparaṃparāya anuppādopi tena saheva siddho. Sabbañcetaṃ ekameva
analyzed: saṃsāre bhava paraṃparāya anuppādaḥ api tena saha iva siddhaḥ sabbam ca etat ekam eva
translated: and the non-arising of the world is established together with that, too, in the beginningless and endless round of rebirths and the succession of existences.🔽But all this is only one Nibbana.

original: nibbānaṃ. Evaṃsantepi khandhāvasesassa bhāvā bhāvalesaṃ upādāya ayaṃ bhedo vuttoti
analyzed: nibbānam khandha avasesassa bhāvā bhāva lesam upādāya ayam bhedaḥ vutto ti
translated: And although it is thus, still the distinction is stated by way of the existence and non-existence of the remainder of the aggregates.

original: vuttaṃ duvidhaṃ hoti kāraṇapariyāyenāti duvidha paññāpanassa kāraṇalesenāti attho.
analyzed: vuttam duvidham hoti kāraṇa pariyāyena ati duvidha paññāpanassa kāraṇa lesena ati attho
translated: It is said that it is twofold by way of cause, which means that it is twofold by way of the reason for the distinction.

original: Yasmā pana saṅkhatadhammānāma sapalibodhadhammattā nānāpalibodhehi niccakālaṃ janaṃ
analyzed: yasmā pana saṅkhata dhammā nāma sa palibodha dhamma ttā nānā palibodhehi nicca kālam janam
translated: But because conditioned things are things with impediments, they constantly afflict people with various impediments,

original: pīḷenti. Santasukhaṃnāma laddhuṃ nadenti. Sanimitta dhammattāca kilesānaṃ jarāmaraṇādīnañca
analyzed: pīḍenti laddhum nadenti jarā maraṇa ādīnam ca
translated: and they do not allow them to obtain the happiness of peace. And because the defilements and aging-and-death, etc., have signs,

original: sabbesaṃ anatthānaṃ vatthu bhūtā bhūmibhūtā honti. Sapaṇihitadhammattāca sabbadukkhānaṃ
analyzed: sabbesam anatthānam vatthu bhūtāḥ bhūmi bhūtāḥ honti sa paṇihita dhamma ttā ca sabba dukkhānam
translated: they become the basis for all kinds of misfortune. And because the suffering of hope is the root of all suffering,

original: mūlabhūtaṃ āsādukkhaṃnāma niccakālaṃpi janenti. Tasmā tappaṭipakkhasiddhena guṇabhedena
analyzed: mūla bhūtam āsādukkham nāma nicca kālaṃpi janenti tasmā tad paṭipakkha siddhena guṇa bhedena
translated: it constantly afflicts people. Therefore, in order to show the threefold distinction by way of the distinction of qualities that is the opposite of that,

original: tividhaṃbhedaṃ dassetuṃ suññatantiādi māha. Tattha sabbapalibodha vivittattā suññataṃ.
analyzed: tividham bhedam dassetum suññata nti ādi mā āha tattha sabba palibodha vivitta ttā suññatam
translated: he said “voidness,” etc. Herein, voidness is void because of the absence of all impediments.

original: Sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā hi sati bālānaṃ yattakā pāpakammapalibodhā apāya dukkhapalibodhāca
analyzed: sakkāya diṭṭhiyā hi sati bālānam yattakā pāpa kamma palibodhā dukkha palibodhā ca
translated: For when there is personality view, the hindrances of evil actions and the hindrances of suffering in the states of loss are evident in fools.

original: sandissanti. Paṇḍitānaṃca tato attānaṃ rakkhanatthaṃ yattakā kalyāṇakammapalibodhā
analyzed: sandissanti paṇḍitānam ca tatas attānam rakkhana attham yattakā kalyāṇa kamma palibodhā
translated: And the hindrances of good actions are evident in the wise in order to protect themselves from those .

original: sandissanti. Sakkāyadiṭṭhinirodhoyeva sabbe te sakkāyadiṭṭhimūlake palibodhe nirodhetuṃ
analyzed: sandissanti sakkāya diṭṭhi nirodho yeva sabbe te sakkāya diṭṭhi mūlake palibodhe nirodhetuṃ
translated: Only the cessation of personality view is able to be the cause for the cessation of all the hindrances rooted in personality view.

original: sakkoti. Na vinā tena añño koci. Tasmā sonirodho tehi palibodhehi vivitto hoti, tathā🔽rāgakkhayoyeva rāgamūlake palibodhe nirodhetuṃ sakkoti. Na vinā tena añño koci. Dosakkhayoyeva
analyzed: sakkoti na vinā tena añño koci tasmā tehi palibodhehi vivitto hoti tathā  rāga kkhayaḥ yā iva rāga mūlake palibodhe nirodhetum sakkoti na vinā tena añño koci dosa kkhayaḥ yā iva
translated: No other cause is able to do this apart from that. Therefore cessation is secluded from those hindrances.

original: dosamūlake. Mohakkhayoyeva mohamūlaketiādi vattabbaṃ. Iti nibbānaṃ sabbapali bodhehi
analyzed: dosa mūlake moha kkhayaḥ yeva moha mūlaka iti ādi vattabbam iti nibbānam bodhehi
translated: Likewise, only the destruction of lust is able to be the cause for the cessation of the hindrances rooted in lust. No other cause is able to do this apart from that. Only the destruction of hatred is able to be the cause for the cessation of the hindrances rooted in hatred. Only the destruction of delusion is able to be the cause for the cessation of the hindrances rooted in delusion.

original: vivittattā suññataṃnāma.
analyzed: vivitta ttā suññataṃnāma
translated: Thus Nibbāna is called void because it is secluded from all hindrances.

original: Nimittaṃ vuccati uppādapavattamūlako oḷārikākāro. Yena samannāgatā saṅkhatadhammā
analyzed: nimittam vuccati uppāda pavatta mūlakaḥ oḷārika ākāraḥ yena samannāgatā saṅkhata dhammā
translated: The sign is the gross aspect of the root of arising and occurrence. Conditioned dhammas are endowed with that.

original: sabbesaṃ kilesānaṃ jarāmaraṇānañca vatthubhūtā bhūmibhūtā honti. Tathā sabbesaṃ mārānaṃ
analyzed: sabbesam kilesānam jarā maraṇānam ca vatthu bhūtāḥ bhūmi bhūtāḥ honti tathā sabbesam mārānam
translated: They are the ground, the basis, for all defilements and for aging and death. Likewise they are the ground, the basis, for all the kinds of Mara,

original: sabbesaṃ verānaṃ sabbesaṃ rogādi anatthānaṃ vatthubhūtā bhūmibhūtā honti. Yato te
analyzed: sabbesam verānam sabbesam roga ādi anatthānam vatthu bhūtāḥ bhūmi bhūtāḥ honti yatas te
translated: for all enemies, for all kinds of misfortune beginning with sickness. Therefore

original: māradheyyātipi maccudheyyātipi vuccanti. Kāla disā desa santānādi bhedena hīnapaṇītādi
analyzed: māradheyya atipi maccudheyya atipi vuccanti kāla disā desa santāna ādi bhedena hīna paṇīta ādi
translated: they are called the realm of Mara and the realm of death. They are divided into inferior and superior according to the difference of time, direction, place, continuity, etc.,

original: bhedenaca bhedaṃ gacchanti. Nibbānaṃ pana sabbesaṃ nimittadhammānaṃ khayanirodhabhāvena
analyzed: bhedena ca bhedam gacchanti nibbānam pana sabbesam nimitta dhammānam khaya nirodha bhāvena
translated: and they are divided into the various kinds of formations. But Nibbāna, being the destruction and cessation of all these formations that are objects,

original: siddhattā natthi. Tasmiṃ nimittanti animittaṃ. Tañhi sabbesaṃ kile sādīnaṃ anatthānaṃ🔽vatthubhūte nimittadhamme viddhaṃsetvā tesaṃ anatthānaṃ abhāvaṃ sādhentaṃ niccaṃ🔽tiṭṭhati. Naca taṃ kālabhedena bhinnaṃ hoti. Idaṃ atīte asukakappe asukabuddhassa
analyzed: siddha ttā na atthi tasmin nimittam ti animittam tat hi sabbesam kilesa ādīnam anatthānam  vatthu bhūte nimitta dhamme viddhaṃsetvā tesam anatthānam abhāvam sādhentam niccam  tiṭṭhati na ca tam kāla bhedena bhinnam hoti idam atīte asuka kappe asuka buddhassa
translated: has no such divisions. It is signless because it has no sign of any kind. For it remains permanently🔽destroying the formations that are objects and establishing the non-existence of all misfortune beginning with defilement. And it is not divided into divisions of time,

original: nibbānaṃ, idaṃ anāgate, idaṃ etarahīti. Nāpi disābhedena bhinnaṃ. Idaṃ dasasu disāsu
analyzed: nibbānam idam anāgate idam etarahi iti nā api disā bhedena bhinnam idam dasasu disāsu
translated: as follows: “Nibbāna was in the past in such and such an aeon, in the future, in the present,” nor is it divided into divisions of direction, as follows: “It is in the ten🔽directions.”

original: asukāyanāma disāya nibbānaṃ, idaṃ asukāya nāmāti. Nacāpi desabhedenavā santānabhedenavā
analyzed: asuka āya nāma disāya nibbānaṃ idam asukāya nāma ati na ca api desa bhedena vā santāna bhedena vā
translated: and that nibbana is in such and such a direction. Nor is it divided into sections by differences of place or by differences of continuity.

original: bhinnaṃ. Idaṃ manussaloke idaṃ devaloke idaṃ brahmaloketi vā idaṃ manussānaṃ idaṃ🔽devānaṃ idaṃ brahmānantivāti. Tathā paṇītādi bhedena bhinnaṃ na hoti. Idaṃ sabbaññubuddhānaṃ.
analyzed: bhinnam idam manussa loke idam deva loke idam brahma loke iti vai idam manussānam idam  devānam idam tathā paṇīta ādi bhedena bhinnam na hoti idam sabbaññu buddhānam
translated: It is not as though it were in the human world, in the deva world, in the Brahma-world, or among human beings, devas, or Brahmas.

original: Idaṃ paccekabuddhānaṃ. Idaṃ buddhasāvakānanti.
analyzed: idam paccekabuddhānam idam buddha sāvakānam ti
translated: And similarly it is not divided by such distinctions as ‘inferior’ and ‘superior.’ It is not as though it were of Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and Buddhas’ disciples.

original: Paṇihitaṃ, paṇidhānaṃ, paṇidhi, patthanā, āsā, jīghacchā, pipāsāti atthato ekaṃ.🔽Saṅkhatadhammāca labbhamānāpi bhijjanadhammattā punappunaṃ laddhuṃ āsā dukkhaṃnāma🔽vaḍḍhenti. Āsādukkhassa pariyantonāma natthi. Sabbañca dukkhaṃ āsāmūlakaṃ hoti. Āsāsadisaṃ
analyzed: paṇihitam paṇidhānam paṇidhi patthanā āsā jīghacchā pipāsā ati atthataḥ ekam  saṅkhata dhammā ca labbhamānā api bhijjana dhamma ttā punappunam laddhum āsā dukkham nāma  vaḍḍhenti āsā dukkhassa pariyantaḥ nāma natthi sabbañca dukkham āsā mūlakam hoti āsā sadisam
translated: ‘Aspiration,’ ‘wish,’ ‘desire,’ ‘longing,’ ‘thirst,’ ‘craving,’ are synonyms.🔽And though it is found in formed things, it increases suffering because of the hope of getting it again, since it is subject to destruction.🔽There is no end to the suffering of hope. And all suffering has hope as its root.

original: dukkhanidānaṃnāma natthi, nibbānaṃ pana sayaṃ pipāsavinayadhammattā āsāsaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: dukkha nidānam nāma natthi nibbānam pana sayam pipāsa vinaya dhamma ttā āsā saṅkhātam
translated: There is no source of suffering like hope. But since nibbana is itself the destruction of thirst, it is called ‘the end of hope.’

original: sabbaṃ taṇhāpaṇidhiṃvā chandapaṇidhiṃvā vinentaṃ vidhamentaṃ vattatīti natthi. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: sabbam taṇhā paṇidhim vā chanda paṇidhim vā vinentam vidhamentam vattati iti na atthi tasmin
translated: and it is not the case that it occurs in the absence of the abandoning and the forsaking of all craving and wish.

original: paṇihitanti appaṇīhitaṃ. Etthaca duvidhaṃ sukhaṃ vedayitasukhaṃ santisukhanti. Tattha🔽manussa dibba brahma sampattiyo labhitvā anubhavanavasena pavattaṃ pītisomanassa
analyzed: paṇihitanti appaṇīhitam ettha ca duvidham sukham vedayita sukham santi sukham ti tattha  manussa dibba brahma sampattiyaḥ labhitvā anubhavana vasena pavattam pīti somanassa
translated: It is un-wished-for because it is not wished for. And here there are two kinds of pleasure: the pleasure of feeling and the pleasure of peace.

original: sukhaṃ vedayitasukhaṃnāma. Taṃ pana khaṇekhaṇe vijjuviya bhijjanadhammaṃ. Sampattiyoca🔽aniccadhammā. Sabbe te apariyantaṃ āsādukkhaṃ bhiyyo vaḍḍhentiyeva. Tasmā sabbaṃ
analyzed: sukham vedayitasukhaṃnāma tam pana khaṇekhaṇe bhijjana dhammam  anicca dhammā sabbe te a pariyantam āsā dukkham bhiyyas vaḍḍhenti yeva tasmai sabbam
translated: The pleasure of feeling is the rapture, joy and happiness that occur in one who has obtained and is enjoying the excellence of human beings, of the gods, and of the Brahmās.🔽But that is subject to destruction from moment to moment like a flash of lightning. And the excellences are subject to destruction by their impermanence.

original: vedayitasukhaṃnāma āsā dukkhajanakattā ekantena dukkhameva hoti. Yathāha-yaṃkiñci🔽vedayitaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ dukkhasminti. Dhammasenāpatināca katamaṃ taṃ āvuso sāriputta
analyzed: vedayita sukham nāma āsā dukkha janaka ttā ekantena dukkham eva hoti yathā ha yaṃkiñci  vedayitam sabbam tat dukkhasmin ti dhammasenāpatinā āca katamam tat āvuso sāriputta
translated: All of them increase the suffering of craving, which is infinite. Therefore all the pleasure of feeling is entirely suffering because it generates the suffering of craving. As it is said: “Whatever is felt is suffering” .

original: nibbāne sukhaṃ, yadettha vedayitaṃ natthīti puṭṭhena etadevettha āvuso nibbāne sukhaṃ,
analyzed: nibbāne sukham yat ettha vedayitam na atthi iti puṭṭhena etat eva ittha āvuso nibbāne sukham
translated: And when the General of the Dhamma was asked by Sāriputta: “What, friend, is the pleasure in Nibbāna, where there is no feeling?” he replied: “This, friend, is the pleasure in Nibbāna, that there is no feeling here,

original: yadettha vedayitaṃ natthīti vuttaṃ. Santisukhaṃnāma attani uppannānaṃvā uppajjituṃ
analyzed: yat ettha vedayitam natthi iti vuttam santisukham nāma attani uppannānam vā uppajjitum
translated: “What is meant by ‘there is no feeling’ is that there is no feeling of pleasure.

original: paccupaṭṭhi tānaṃvā kilesādīnaṃ apāyadukkhādīnañca attano sammāpayogaṃ paṭicca vimuccanasukhaṃ.
analyzed: kilesa ādīnam apāya dukkha ādīnam ca attano sammāpayogam paṭicca vimuccana sukham
translated: ‘The pleasure of peace’ is the pleasure of deliverance that arises in one who has rightly applied himself to the destruction of the defilements and to the avoidance of the suffering of the states of woe.

original: Etadevettha ekantasukhaṃ acalasukhaṃ. Etasmiñhi asati puthujjanānaṃ manussa dibbabrahmasampattiyo
analyzed: etat eva itthā ekanta sukham acala sukham etasmin hi asati puthujjanānam manussa dibba brahma sampattiyaḥ
translated: This is the supreme pleasure, the unshakable pleasure. For when this is absent, even the pleasures of human beings, gods, and Brahmas, which are experienced by worldlings,

original: anubhavantānaṃpi avassaṃ pattabbaṭṭhena paccupaṭṭhitāneva honti aviciniraya bhayādīnīti.
analyzed: anubhavantānam pi a vassam pattabba ṭṭhena paccupaṭṭhitāna eva honti a vici niraya bhaya ādīni iti
translated: are present as something to be attained by those who are not yet free from craving. And the fears of the Avici hell, etc., are present as something to be experienced by all.

original: Tasmā sabbassa vedayitasukhamūlakassa āsādukkhassa santisukhadīpakaṃ idaṃ appaṇihitapadaṃ
analyzed: tasmā sabbassa vedayita sukha mūlakassa āsā dukkhassa santi sukha dīpakam idam appaṇihita padam
translated: Therefore this expression ‘the pleasure of peace’ is a term that illuminates the pleasure of the destruction of all the suffering rooted in feeling.

original: nibbānassa ekaṃ mahantaṃ guṇapadaṃ hotīti.🔽Ākāra bhedenāti tividhassa suññatādikassa guṇakoṭṭhāsassa bhedena. Etthaca yadetaṃ
analyzed: nibbānassa ekam mahantam guṇa padam hoti iti  ākāra bhedena ati tividhassa suñña tā ādikassa guṇa koṭṭhāsassa bhedena ettha ca yat etam
translated: It is a great quality of Nibbāna.

original: anamatagge saṃsāre ajjhattaṃ anusayitvā āgatānaṃ kilesānaṃ maggakkhaṇe ajjhattameva
analyzed: anamatagge saṃsāre ajjhattam anusayitvā āgatānam kilesānam magga kkhaṇe ajjhattam eva
translated: ‘By way of its mode’ means by way of the three modes of emptiness, etc. Herein, the ‘defilements that have entered one’s own person’ are the defilements that have arisen in one’s own person. At the moment of the path they are ‘in one’s own person’ only,

original: nirujjhanaṃ khiyyanaṃ. Taṃ khayadhātu nirodhadhātu saṅkhātaṃ ekaṃ dhammāyatanaṃ hoti.
analyzed: nirujjhanam khiyyanam tam khaya dhātu nirodha dhātu saṅkhātam ekam dhamma āyatanam hoti
translated: and its cessation is its fading away. That is the one element of ideas called the “element of ending” and the “element of cessation.”🔽There is one element of mental data,

original: Ekā dhammadhātu hoti. Eko paramatthadhammo hoti. Khayaṭṭhena nirodhaṭṭhena sabhāvato
analyzed: ekā dhammadhātu hoti ekaḥ paramattha dhammo hoti khaya ṭṭhena nirodha ṭṭhena sabhāvato
translated: one ultimate reality, in the sense of ending and in the sense of cessation.

original: vijjamānattā, na hi taṃ paññattirūpaṃ hoti. Kāye ñāṇeca sarūpato upaladdhattā, duvidhañhi
analyzed: vijjamāna ttā na hi tam paññatti rūpam hoti kāye ñāṇe ca sarūpataḥ upaladdha ttā duvidhan hi
translated: Because it exists in actuality, for that is not a conceptually-constructed form. And because it is apprehended in its individual essence by knowledge of the body, for

original: nibbānassa sacchikaraṇaṃ kāyasacchikaraṇaṃ ñāṇasacchikaraṇañca. Yathāha-chandajāto🔽ussahati. Ussahitvā tuleti. Tulayitvā padahati. Pahitatto samāno kāyenaceva paramatthasaccaṃ
analyzed: nibbānassa sacchikaraṇam kāya sacchikaraṇam ñāṇa sacchikaraṇam ca yathā aha chanda jātaḥ  ussahati ussahitvā tuleti tulayitvā padahati pahitattaḥ samāno kāyena ca iva paramattha saccaṃ
translated: Nibbana is realized in two ways: it is realized by the body and it is realized by knowledge. As it is said: “When he has aroused zeal,

original: sacchikaroti. Paññāyaca taṃ paṭivijjha passatīti. Tattha anamatagge saṃsāre ajjhattaṃ🔽niccaṃ santāpetvā paridayhitvā āgatānaṃ kilesānaṃ maggakkhaṇe ajjhattameva nirujjhanaṃ
analyzed: sacchikaroti paññāya ca tam paṭivijjha passati iti tattha anamatagge saṃsāre ajjhattam  niccam santāpetvā paridayhitvā āgatānam kilesānam magga kkhaṇe ajjhattam eva nirujjhanam
translated: he makes an effort. Having made an effort, he exerts his cognizance. Having exerted his cognizance, he controls his mind. When his mind is controlled, he both realizes the ultimate truth by the body and penetrates it by knowledge, seeing it as it is” .🔽Herein, the cessation of defilements that have come down through the beginningless round of rebirths by burning up internally is called realization by the body.🔽The cessation of defilements internally at the moment of the path is called realization by the body.

original: nibbāyanaṃ kāyasacchikaraṇaṃnāma. Evaṃ kāyena sacchikatvā puna paccavekkhanto ajjhattaṃ
analyzed: nibbāyanam kāya sacchikaraṇam nāma evam kāyena sacchikatvā puna paccavekkhantaḥ ajjhattam
translated: Having thus realized it by the body, when he reviews it thus,

original: taṃ nirujjhanaṃ ñāṇena paccakkhato passati. Niruddhā me kilesāti jānāti, idaṃ ñāṇasacchikaraṇaṃnāma.
analyzed: tam nirujjhanam ñāṇena paccakkhataḥ passati niruddhāḥ me kilesāḥ ti jānāti idam ñāṇa sacchikaraṇaṃ nāma
translated: He sees with knowledge the cessation of that, which is the seeing of the cessation of defilements. He knows, “My defilements have ceased,” which is the realization of knowledge.

original: Tesu kāya sacchikaraṇaṃ anantaṃ aparimāṇaṃ vaṭṭadukkhaṃ khepeti. Ñāṇasacchikaraṇaṃ
analyzed: tesu kāya sacchikaraṇam anantam aparimāṇam vaṭṭa dukkham khepeti ñāṇa sacchikaraṇam
translated: Of these, the realization of the body is the abolishing of the endless, immeasurable suffering of the round. The realization of knowledge

original: anappakaṃ pītisomanassaṃ uppādeti. Paññattidhammesu eva rūpaṃ sacchikaraṇaṃnāma natthīti.
analyzed: anappakam pīti somanassam uppādeti paññatti dhammesu eva rūpam sacchikaraṇam nāma natthi iti
translated: arouses a measureless happiness and gladness. But there is no realization of materiality among the ideas that are determinations.

original: Tassa pana nirujjhanassa suññatadhammattā mandabuddhīnaṃ tasmiṃ tucchasaññā niratthakasaññā
analyzed: tassa pana nirujjhanassa suññata dhamma ttā manda buddhīnam tasmim tuccha saññā niratthaka saññā
translated: But because the cessation of that is an idea of voidness, a perception of voidness, a perception of meaninglessness,

original: saṇṭhāti. Animitta dhammattā tasmiṃ abhāvamattasaññā paramatthato avijjamānasaññā
analyzed: tasmin abhāva matta saññā paramatthataḥ avijjamāna saññā
translated: settles down in those of little understanding. Because it is an idea of the signless, a perception of the mere absence of the sign, a perception of what is non-existent in the ultimate sense,

original: saṇṭhāti. Appaṇihitadhammattā taṇhāvasikā janā tasmiṃ sukhaṃ nāma kiñci natthīti maññanti.
analyzed: saṇṭhāti appaṇihita dhamma ttā taṇhāvasikā janā tasmim sukham nāma kiñci natthi iti maññanti
translated: settles down in those of little understanding. Because it is an idea of the desireless, people whose minds are obsessed by craving think that there is no pleasure there at all.

original: Ye pana yathāvuttaṃ khayanirodhamattaṃ nibbānaṃnāma nahoti. Tañhi abhāvamattaṃ paññattirūpaṃ
analyzed: ye pana yathāvuttam khaya nirodha mattam nibbānam nāma tat hi abhāva mattam paññatti rūpam
translated: But those who do not understand that the mere cessation of what is called “extinction” is the mere absence of what is determined as materiality🔽say that it is non-existent.

original: hoti. Nibbānañcanāma gambhīrādīnaṃ anantaguṇānaṃ vatthu hoti, naca abhāvamattaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: hoti gambhīra ādīnam ananta guṇānam vatthu hoti na ca abhāva mattam tesam
translated: And Nibbāna is the ground for the infinite qualities beginning with the deep, and it is not proper for the mere absence of those to be their ground.

original: vatthu bhavituṃ arahati. Nibbānaṃ paramaṃ sukhanti vuttaṃ. Naca abhāvamatte kiñci🔽sukhaṃnāma sakkāladdhuṃ. Tasmā yo tassa khayanirodhassa paccayo atthi. Yassaca ānubhāvena
analyzed: vatthu bhavitum arahati nibbānam paramam sukhanti vuttam na ca abhāva matte kiñci  sukhaṃnāma tasmai yaḥ tassa khaya nirodhassa paccayo atthi yassa ca ānubhāvena
translated: And it is said, “Nibbāna is the supreme bliss,” and in the mere absence of anything there is no bliss at all to be found.🔽So they maintain that Nibbāna is the name for whatever is the condition for that cessation of destruction and by whose power that cessation of destruction comes about.

original: so khayanirodho sijjhati. Eta deva nibbānaṃ nāmāti icchanti. Tesaṃpi vaṭṭadukkha🔽santito atirekapayojanaṃnāma nalabbhati. Nibbānassaca guṇapadāni nāma anantānaṃ vaṭṭadhammānaṃ🔽paṭipakkhavasena sijjhanti, no aññathā. Tasmā yattakāni aguṇapadāni vaṭṭadhammesu
analyzed: saḥ khaya nirodhaḥ sijjhati eta deva nibbānam nāma ati icchanti tesam pi vaṭṭa dukkha  santitaḥ atireka payojanam nāma na labbhati nibbānassa ca guṇa padāni nāma anantānam vaṭṭa dhammānam  paṭipakkha vasena sijjhanti no aññathā tasmā yattakāni aguṇa padāni vaṭṭa dhammesu
translated: And for them there is no further purpose beyond the cessation of the suffering of the round.🔽And the terms of commendation for Nibbāna come about as the opposites of the infinite terms of the round; they do not come about otherwise.

original: labbhanti, tattakāni tesaṃ khaya nirodhe anantāni guṇapadāni hutvā sijjhanti. Yo
analyzed: labbhanti tattakāni tesam khaya nirodhe anantāni guṇa padāni hutvā sijjhanti
translated: So the infinite terms of commendation for the cessation of destruction come about as the opposites of the terms of the round that are found in the states of the round, and they are as many as there are such terms.

original: khayanirodhopi tāva visuṃ dhammabhāvenaviññātuṃ dukkarogambhīro hoti. Yato taṃ abhāvamattaṃ
analyzed: khaya nirodhaḥ api tāva visum dhamma bhāvena viññātum dukkaraḥ gambhīraḥ hoti yatas tam abhāva mattam
translated: And the cessation of destruction is itself hard to see and deep, since it is hard to see individually as a state with its own individual essence.

original: paññattirūpaṃ maññanti. Guṇapadānaṃ panassa gambhīrabhāve vattabbamevanatthi. Santisukhañca
analyzed: paññatti rūpam maññanti guṇa padānam pana assa gambhīra bhāve vattabbam eva natthi santi sukham ca
translated: and they imagine that it is a visible form. But there is nothing to be said about the profundity of its qualities. And the bliss of peace is

original: nāma vaṭṭadukkhānaṃ vūpasantatāeva. Tesaṃ vūpasamo sukhoti hi vuttaṃ. Vūpasantatātica
analyzed: nāma vaṭṭa dukkhānam vūpasanta tā eva tesam vūpasamaḥ sukhaḥ ti hi vuttam vūpasanta tā ati ca
translated: the mere cessation of the suffering of the round. For it is said that “the cessation of that is bliss.” The “cessation” is the complete destruction

original: tesaṃ sabbaso khayanirodhoevāti vaṭṭadukkhapariyāpannānaṃ sabba vedayītasukhānaṃ
analyzed: tesam sabbaso khaya nirodhaḥ eva ati vaṭṭa dukkha pariyāpannānam
translated: and cessation of all that is included in the suffering of the round.

original: ukkaṃsagatā tassa khayanirodhassa paramasukhatā siddhā hotīti. Tassa pana paramatthato
analyzed: ukkaṃsa gatā tassa khaya nirodhassa parama sukha tā siddhā hoti iti tassa pana paramatthato
translated: The supreme bliss of the destruction and cessation of that is established as the highest bliss. But as to its existence in the ultimate sense,

original: vijjamānabhāve tāva idaṃ suttaṃ.🔽Atthi bhikkhave ajātaṃ abhūtaṃ akataṃ asaṅkhataṃ. No ce taṃ bhikkhave abhavissa ajātaṃ🔽abhūtaṃ akataṃ asaṅkhataṃ, na yimassa jātassa bhūtassa katassa saṅkhatassa nissaraṇaṃ
analyzed: vijjamāna bhāve tāva idam suttam  atthi bhikkhave a jātam a bhūtam a katam a saṅkhatam no ce tat bhikkhave abhavissa a jātam  a bhūtam a katam a saṅkhatam na yimassa jātassa bhūtassa katassa saṅkhatassa nissaraṇam
translated: the following sutta should be cited:🔽“Monks, there is an unborn, an unbecome, an unmade, an unformed. If there were not, there would be known an escape from the born, the become, the made, the formed.

original: paññāyetha. Yasmāca kho bhikkhave atthi ajātaṃ abhūtaṃ akataṃ asaṅkhataṃ, tasmā jātassa🔽bhūtassa katassa saṅkhatassa nissaraṇaṃ paññāyatīti.
analyzed: paññāyetha yasmā ca kho bhikkhave atthi a jātam a bhūtam a katam a saṅkhatam tasmā jātassa 🔽bhūtassa katassa saṅkhatassa nissaraṇam paññāyati iti
translated: But since there is an unborn, an unbecome, an unmade, an unformed, an escape from the born, the become, the made, the formed, is known” .

original: Tattha ajānanaṃ ajātaṃ. Jātikkhayoti attho. Abhavanaṃ abhūtaṃ. Abhāvoti attho. Akaraṇaṃ
analyzed: tattha a jānanam a jātam jāti kkhayaḥ ti atthaḥ a bhavanam a bhūtam a bhāvaḥ iti atthaḥ a karaṇam
translated: Herein, non-cognizance is uncognizance, the meaning is that it is the opposite of cognizance. Non-becoming is unbecoming, the meaning is that it is the opposite of becoming. Non-doing is un-doing,

original: akataṃ. Asaṅkharaṇaṃ asaṅkhataṃ. Uppādetuṃvā pavattetuṃvā saṅkhāradukkhassa abhāvoti🔽attho. Jātikkhayotivā visuṃ ekā dhammadhātu hoti. Tasmā visuṃ dhammabhāvaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: akatam a saṅkharaṇam a saṅkhatam uppādetum vā pavattetum vā saṅkhāra dukkhassa abhāvaḥ ti  atthaḥ jāti khayaḥ ti vā visum ekā dhammadhātu hoti tasmā visum dhamma bhāvam sandhāya
translated: Herein, the unborn is the unborn state, the meaning being the destruction of birth. The unmade is the unmade state, the meaning being the non-existence of making. The unformed is the unformed state, the meaning being the non-existence of forming. The unoriginated is the unoriginated state, the meaning being the non-existence of originating. The unconditioned is the unconditioned state, the meaning being the non-existence of the suffering of formations that can be originated or caused to continue.

original: natthi jātaṃ etthāti ajātantīpi yujjatiyeva. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti, saṅkhatadhammānāma🔽paccaye sati jāyanti. Asati na jāyantīti jātaṃ viya ajātaṃpi tesaṃ atthi. Paramatthato
analyzed: natthi jātam ettha ati idam vuttam hoti saṅkhata dhammā nāma  paccaye sati jāyanti asati na jāyanti iti jātam viya ajātam pi tesam atthi paramatthato
translated: Or the destruction of birth is a separate element of mental data, and so it is proper to say that it is unborn since there is no birth in it, construing it as a state of dhammas in the sense of a separate element.

original: vijjamānaṃ hotīti attho. Yadica ajātaṃnāma natthi, jātameva atthi. Evaṃsati attani
analyzed: vijjamānam hoti iti atthaḥ yadi ca ajātam nāma na atthi jātam eva atthi evam sati
translated: This is what is meant: when there are conditions, formed dhammas are born, and when there are not, they are not born. So there is an unborn state of them too, as it were. The meaning is that it exists in the ultimate sense.

original: kilesānaṃ ajātatthāya sammā paṭipajjantānaṃpi sabbe kilesadhammā jātāyeva siyuṃ.
analyzed: kilesānaṃ a jāta tthāya sammā paṭipajjantānam pi sabbe kilesa dhammā jātāya iva siyuṃ
translated: And if there were no unborn state, only the born state, then for those who are rightly practising for the purpose of preventing defilements from arising in themselves, all defilements would be born, not unborn.🔽But they are not born. Why? Because there is no unborn state.

original: No ajātā. Kasmā, ajātassanāma natthitāyāti. Esanayo sabbesu duccaritadhammesu apāyadukkhavaṭṭadukkhesu,
analyzed: no a jātā kasmai na atthitāya ati esa nayo sabbesu duccarita dhammesu apāya dukkha vaṭṭa dukkhesu
translated: This is the method in all cases of bad conduct, and in the suffering of the states of loss, in the suffering of the round of rebirths, and in the suffering of defilements.

original: diṭṭhadhammeca sabbesu rogābādhabhayupaddavesu. Evañca sati loke sabbe purisakārā
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamme ca sabbesu roga ābādha bhaya upaddavesu evam ca sati loke sabbe purisakārā
translated: and in all the dangers of sickness, disease, and affliction in this very life. And if that were so, then all manly effort, manly striving, and manly exertion in the world would be fruitless.🔽With reference to this matter, the Exalted One said: “If, bhikkhus, this were not so,

original: purisathāmā purisaparakkamā niratthakā eva siyunti imamatthaṃ sandhāya no cetaṃ bhikkhave.La.
analyzed: purisa thāmā purisa parakkamā niratthakāḥ eva siyun ti imam attham sandhāya no ca itam bhikkhave
translated: then manly effort would be fruitless.”🔽But since what is unborn exists absolutely,

original: Paññāyethāti vuttaṃ. Yasmā pana ajātaṃnāma ekantena atthiyeva. Tasmā attani ajātatthāya🔽sammāpaṭipajjantānaṃ te ekantena najāyanti. Evaṃ sati sabbe purisakārā purisathāmā
analyzed: paññāyetha iti vuttam yasmā pana ajātaṃ nāma ekantena atthiyā iva tasmā attani ajāta tthāya  sammā paṭipajjantānam te ekantena na jāyanti evam sati sabbe purisakārā purisathāmā
translated: therefore, for those who practice rightly for the sake of what is unborn in themselves, it does not come to be born absolutely.

original: purisaparakkamā satthakā eva hontīti imamatthaṃ sandhāya yasmāca kho bhikkhavetiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Ettāvatā avijjānirodhā saṅkhāra nirodho. Saṅkhāranirodhā viññāṇanirodho.La.
analyzed: purisa parakkamāḥ satthakāḥ eva honti iti imam attham sandhāya yasmā ca kho bhikkhave tiādi  vuttam ettāvatā avijjā nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodho saṅkhāra nirodhā viññāṇa nirodho
translated: And if that were so, then all manly effort, manly striving, and manly exertion would be fruitless. With reference to this matter, the Exalted One said: “But since, bhikkhus, this is so,🔽therefore manly effort is not fruitless.”

original: Dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotīti evaṃ vuttassa nirodhassa paramatthato vijjamānabhāvaṃ
analyzed: dukkhakkhandhassa nirodhaḥ hoti iti evam vuttassa nirodhassa paramatthataḥ vijjamāna bhāvam
translated: Up to this point, the Exalted One has shown the existence in the ultimate sense of the cessation stated thus: “With the cessation of ignorance there is the cessation of volitional formations; with the cessation of volitional formations, the cessation of consciousness; … the cessation of this whole mass of suffering.”

original: dasseti. Atthi saddassa vijjamānatthavacanattā. Tattha nirodho duvidho jātanirodho
analyzed: dassa iti atthi saddassa vijjamāna attha vacana ttā tattha nirodhaḥ duvidhaḥ jāta nirodhaḥ
translated: The word atthi is used to express existence. Herein, cessation is twofold: cessation of the born and cessation of the unborn.

original: ajātanirodhoti. Tattha uppajjitvā nirodho jātanirodhonāma. Maccūtica maraṇantica🔽etassevanāmaṃ. Ajjhattapariyā pannānaṃ kilesādīnaṃ uppādassapi sabbaso abhāvo ajāta🔽nironāma. Yo sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbupadhinissaggo taṇhakkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānanti
analyzed: ajāta nirodho ti tattha uppajjitvā nirodhaḥ jāta nirodhaḥ nāma maccu iti ca maraṇa nti ca  ajjhatta pariyā pannānam kilesa ādīnam uppādassa api sabbasas abhāvaḥ ajāta  niro nāma yaḥ sabba saṅkhāra samatho sabba upadhi nissaggo taṇha kkhayaḥ virāgaḥ nirodhaḥ nibbānanti
translated: and non-occurrence-cessation. Herein, cessation after arising is called “occurrence-cessation.” “Death” is a name for that. The complete absence of the arising of defilements, etc., which are included in the internal is called “non-occurrence-cessation.”

original: vuccati. Ayamidhādhippeto, ayameva hi sabbapalibodhehi suññattā suññatonāma. Kilesānaṃ🔽jārāmaraṇādīnañca vatthubhūtassa nimittassa abhāvā animittonāma. Sabbadukkhānaṃ nidānabhūtassa
analyzed: vuccati ayam idha adhippetaḥ ayam eva hi sabba palibodhehi suññattā suññataḥ nāma kilesānam  jāra amaraṇa ādīnam ca vatthu bhūtassa nimittassa abhāvāḥ sabba dukkhānam nidāna bhūtassa
translated: That which is called the “stilling of all formations, the relinquishing of all acquisitions, the destruction of craving, dispassion, cessation, Nibbāna” is what is intended here. For this is called “void” because it is void of all impediments. It is called “signless” because of the absence of the sign of defilements,🔽and of aging, death, etc. It is called “desireless” because of the absence of the desire for a foundation for aging, death, etc.,

original: āsādukkhassa abhāvā appaṇihitonāma. Tena vuttaṃ suññataṃanimittaṃ appaṇihitañceti
analyzed: āsā dukkhassa abhāvā appaṇihitaḥ nāma tena vuttam suññatam animittam appaṇihitam ca iti
translated: which is the cause of all suffering. Thus it is said: “Void, signless, desireless—🔽These three are its names.”

original: tividhaṃ hotīti. Padantiādi nibbānassa vevacanāni. Tañhi visuṃ asaṃmisso kevalo upalabbhamāno
analyzed: tividham hoti iti nibbānassa vevacanāni tat hi visum asaṃmissaḥ kevalaḥ upalabbhamānaḥ
translated: “State,” etc., are synonyms for Nibbāna. For that which is found apart from all mixture, pure,

original: eko paramattha dhammoti padaṃ nāma. Koṭṭhāsattho hi padasaddo. Yathā padaso dhammaṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ dhammo ti padam nāma koṭṭhāsa tthaḥ hi pada saddaḥ yathā dhammam
translated: is a single ultimate reality, and so it is called a “state.” The word “state” has the meaning of a section. Just as the word “section” is used in the statement: “The Dhamma should be taught by sections” ,

original: vāceyyāti. Cavanābhāvena accutaṃ. Pubbantāparante atikkamma pavattattā accantaṃ.
analyzed: vāceyya ati cavana abhāvena accutam pubbanta aparante atikkamma pavatta ttā accantam
translated: “It is uncreated” because of the absence of creation. “It is absolute” because it occurs transcending the past and future.

original: Saṅkharaṇakiccarahitattā asaṅkhataṃ. Attano uttaritarassa kassaci dhammassa abhāvato
analyzed: saṅkharaṇa kicca rahita ttā asaṅkhatam attanaḥ uttaritarassa kassacid dhammassa abhāvato
translated: “It is unconditioned” because of the absence of the function of conditioning. “It is unsurpassed” because there is no other state higher than it.

original: anuttaranti. Vānamuttā taṇhā vimuttā, mahante sīlakkhandhādike dhamme esiṃsu adhigacchiṃsūti mahesayo, buddhā.🔽Iti paramatthadīpaniyānāma abhidhammatthasaṅgahassa
analyzed: taṇhā vimuttā mahante sīla kkhandha ādike dhamme esiṃsu adhigacchiṃsu iti mahesayaḥ buddhā  iti
translated: “The great seers” are the Buddhas, who are “freed from the forest” of craving, and who have “attained” the great aggregates of dhamma beginning with virtue.🔽Thus in the Abhidhamma-attha-saṅgaha,

original: Catutthavaṇṇanāya rūpanibbāna saṅgahassa
analyzed: catuttha vaṇṇanāya rūpa nibbāna saṅgahassa
translated: the commentary on the fourth chapter, which is called “The Description of Form and Nibbāna,”

original: Paramatthadīpanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: is finished.

original: Samuccaya saṅgaha paramatthadīpanī
translated: The Description of the Aggregates, Bases, and Elements

original: 162. Evaṃ chahi paricchedehi cattāro paramatthe dassetvā idāni tesaṃ taṃtaṃrāsisaṅkhātaṃ🔽samuccayaṃ dassento ādigātha māha. Ye salakkhaṇā dvāsattatividhā vatthudhammā mayā
analyzed: evam chahi paricchedehi cattāraḥ paramatthe dassetvā idāni tesam taṃ taṃ rāsi saṅkhātam  samuccayam dassentaḥ ādi gātha mā āha ye sa lakkhaṇāḥ dvāsattatividhāḥ vatthu dhammāḥ mayā
translated: Having thus shown the four truths in six chapters, the author now begins the description of the “collection” (samuccaya), which is called the “summary” (saṅgaha).🔽The introductory verse states: “The characteristics, the bases, and the dhammas, which are of seventy-two kinds, have been stated by me. Now I shall explain their collection according to the method.”

original: vuttā. Idāni tesaṃ samuccayaṃ yathāyogaṃ pavakkhāmīti yojanā. Tattha salakkhaṇāvatthudhammāti
analyzed: vuttāḥ idāni tesam samuccayam yathāyogam pavakkhāmi iti yojanā tattha sa lakkhaṇā vatthu dhammā ti
translated: Herein, the characteristics, the bases, and the dhammas.

original: padehi dasavidhāni anipphannarūpāni paṭikkhipati. Na hi tāni attano āvenikabhūtena🔽sabhāva lakkhaṇena aniccatādi sāmaññalakkhaṇenaca salakkhaṇāni honti. Ekantaparamatthatāya
analyzed: padehi dasavidhāni anipphanna rūpāni paṭikkhipati na hi tāni attanaḥ āvenika bhūtena  sabhāva lakkhaṇena anicca tā ādi sāmañña lakkhaṇena ca sa lakkhaṇāni honti ekanta paramattha tāya
translated: He rejects the ten kinds of unoriginated materiality by means of the words “not as ultimate.” For these are not characterized by their own individual essences, which are their specific characteristics, and by the general characteristics of impermanence, etc.,

original: abhāvato. Tatoyevaca vatthudhammāca nahonti. Sarūpato anupalabbhamānattā. Dabbavācako
analyzed: abhāvato vatthu dhammā ca na honti sarūpataḥ anupalabbhamāna ttā dabba vācako
translated: because they do not exist as absolute ultimates. And they are not the properties of a basis either, because they are not found in the form of an individual essence.

original: hi idha vatthusaddo. Dabbañcanāma idha sarūpato labbhamāno sabhāvo eva. Etena nibbānassapi
analyzed: hi idha vatthu saddaḥ idha sarūpataḥ labbhamāno sabhāvaḥ eva etena nibbānassa api
translated: For the word “basis” here is a word of common usage, and the individual essence that is found in the form of an individual essence here is just the individual essence.

original: maggaphala paccavekkhanañāṇesu sarūpato labbhamāna sabhāvatā vuttā hoti. Anipphannarūpānaṃ🔽viya ca vatthudhamma sannissayena dissamānadhammamattabhāvaṃ vā paññattidhammānaṃ
analyzed: magga phala paccavekkhana ñāṇesu sarūpataḥ labbhamāna sabhāva tā vuttā hoti anipphanna rūpānam  ca vatthu dhamma sannissayena dissamāna dhamma matta bhāvam vā paññatti dhammānam
translated: And by this it is said that Nibbāna too is found in the form of an individual essence in the reviewing knowledge of the path and fruition.🔽And just as the unoriginated material instances are, so too the formed ideas are mere ideas seen by dependence on the properties of a basis,🔽or mere ideas imagined in the form of an appearance fabricated by the mind, like the horn of a rabbit, the hair of a tortoise, the son of a barren woman, etc.,

original: viya parikappitākāramattabhāvaṃvā sasavisāṇa kacchapalomādīnaṃ viya sabbaso abhūta
analyzed: viya parikappita ākāra matta bhāvam vā kacchapa loma ādīnam viya sabbasas abhūta
translated: which are entirely non-existent.

original: parikappita mattabhāvaṃvā nivāretīti veditabbaṃ. Etthaca dvāsattatividhāsalakkhaṇāvatthudhammāti🔽vacane payojanaṃ nadissati. Tesu hi dvāsattatividhesu ekacce eva dhammā purimesu
analyzed: parikappita matta bhāvam vā nivāreti iti veditabbam ettha ca dvāsattati vidhā salakkhaṇā vatthu dhammā ti  vacane payojanam na dissati tesu hi dvāsattatividhesu ekacce eva dhammā purimesu
translated: And here the words “the states that are the soil, the states that are the sign, the states that are the characteristic”🔽do not show the purpose of the exposition. For some of the seventy-two kinds of states are included in the first three aggregates,

original: tīsu saṅgahesu āgatā. Pacchimeca sabbasaṅgahe anipphannarūpānipi adhippetānievāti.
analyzed: tīsu saṅgahesu āgatā pacchime ca sabba saṅgahe anipphanna rūpāni pi adhippetāni eva ati
translated: and in the last aggregate the unformed element is intended too.🔽And here the words “the states that are the soil, the states that are the sign, the states that are the characteristic”

original: Etthaca vatthudhammāsalakkhaṇāti padehi anipphannarūpānaṃ salakkhaṇatā paṭikkhipane
analyzed: ettha ca vatthu dhammāḥ asalakkhaṇā ti padehi anipphanna rūpānam salakkhaṇa tā paṭikkhipane
translated: exclude the unformed element from being a characteristic.

original: yaṃ vattabbaṃ. Taṃ rūpasamuddesa dīpaniyaṃ vuttamevāti. Ekantākusalajātiyānaṃ āsava
analyzed: yat vattabbam tat rūpa samuddesa dīpaniyam vuttam eva ati ekanta akusala jāti yānam āsava
translated: What should be said about this has already been said in the Description of Matter .

original: catukkādīnaṃ saṅgaho akusalasaṅgaho, na akusala sampayuttattāyeva akusalabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: catukka ādīnam saṅgahaḥ akusala saṅgahaḥ na akusala sampayutta ttāya iva akusala bhūtānam
translated: The aggregate of unprofitable states is the aggregate of the unprofitable kinds of consciousness and its concomitants, which are of one species only, and of the unprofitable kinds of materiality, which are of twenty-two species.🔽The aggregate of indeterminate states is the aggregate of the kinds of materiality associated with profitable and unprofitable consciousness, which are of twenty-two species, and the aggregate of the kinds of materiality associated with resultant consciousness, which are of twenty-two species, and the aggregate of the kinds of materiality originated by temperature, which are of twenty-two species, and the aggregate of the kinds of materiality originated by kamma, which are of twenty-two species, and the aggregate of the unformed element, which is of one species.

original: cittaphassādīnanti. Kusalā kusalābyākatamissakānaṃ saṅgaho missakasaṅgaho.
analyzed: citta phassa ādīnam ti saṅgahaḥ missaka saṅgahaḥ
translated: The aggregate of mixed states is the aggregate of the kinds of materiality associated with the kinds of consciousness of the three roots, which are of seventy-two species.

original: Bodhi vuccati catūsu maggesu ñāṇaṃ, bujjhanti etāyāti katvā. Bodhiyā pakkhā bodhipakkhā.
analyzed: bodhi vuccati catūsu maggesu ñāṇam bujjhanti etāya ati katvā bodhiyā pakkhāḥ bodhi pakkhāḥ
translated: The enlightenment factors are called “enlightenment” because of the words, “He who has developed, made much of, carried through, established, maintained, augmented, and properly instigated this noble eightfold path, he, awakening to that enlightenment, reaches that enlightenment” .

original: Cirapārivāsiyaṭṭhena madaniyaṭṭhenaca āsava sadisattā āsavā. Yadica tadubhayaṭṭhena🔽āsavānāma siyuṃ. Ime lobhādayo eva āsavānāma siyuṃ. Pupphāsavādayo hi loke cha pañca
analyzed: cira pārivāsiya ṭṭhena madaniya ṭṭhena ca āsava āsavāḥ yadi ca tad ubhaya ṭṭhena  āsavā nāma siyum ime lobha ādayaḥ eva āsavā nāma siyum puppha āsava ādayaḥ hi loke cha pañca
translated: They are pollutants because they are like pollutants in the sense of long persistence and intoxicating. And if they were pollutants in the sense of both,

original: rattimattaṃ vā sattaṭṭharattimattaṃ vā sayaṃpi kumbhesu parivāsaṃ gaṇhanti. Kumbheca
analyzed: rattimattam vā kumbhesu parivāsam gaṇhanti

For the pollutants of flowers, etc., in the world, though they themselves persist in the jars for five or six nights or for seven or eight nights,🔽cause the jars to persist in the pollution.

translated: But these persist in the being’s continuity themselves for an endless time and

analyzed: satta santānam ca parivāsam gāhāpenti sakalam satta santānam sadā āsava pūritam eva hoti
translated: cause the being’s continuity to persist in the pollution. The whole of the being’s continuity is always filled with pollutants.

original: Yathāha-cakkhuṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati. Ettha
analyzed: yathā āha cakkhum loke piya rūpam sāta rūpam ettha isā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati ettha

analyzed: nivīsamānā nivīsati itiādi tattha esā taṇhā pariyuṭṭhāna vasena uppajjamānā ettha eva

analyzed: uppajjati uppajjitvā ca punar anusaya bhāvena parivāsam katvā nivīsamānā etthā iva nivīsati iti  atthaḥ yāva ca ariya magga dhovanam tāva santānam gūtha pūrita kūpam viya
translated: and so on. Herein, this craving arises in this way by way of invasion. And having arisen, it invades again by way of lying in wait, and the meaning is that it lies in wait in this way.🔽And as long as it does not get the washing of the noble path, it goes on occurring, making the continuity of being hard to purify like a cesspit full of ordure.

original: dubbisodhaṃ katvā pavattati. Pupphāsavādayoca madaṃ janentā muhuttameva janenti.🔽Ime pana yāva ariyamaggaṃ nalabhati. Tāva niccamadaṃ janenti. Tasmā ekantena imeyeva
analyzed: dubbisodham katvā pavattati madam janentāḥ muhuttam eva janenti  ime pana yāva ariya maggam na labhati tāva nicca madam janenti tasmai ekantena
translated: And just as the flower-juice, etc., make intoxication for only a short time,

original: cirapārivāsiyaṭṭhena madani yaṭṭhenaca āsavānāma bhavituṃ arahantīti.🔽Visandanaṭṭhenavā āsavasadisattā āsavā, yathā hi kudhita kuṭṭhino mahāvaṇamukhehi
analyzed: cira pārivāsi yaṭṭhena madani yaṭṭhena ca āsavāḥ nāma bhavitum arahanti iti  visandana ṭhenavāḥ āsava sadisa ttāḥ āsavāḥ yathā hi kudhita kuṭṭhinaḥ mahā vaṇa mukhehi
translated: but these make it as long as the noble path is not obtained. Therefore these alone are capable of being called “intoxicants” in the sense of lying in wait for a long time and in the sense of intoxicating.🔽And they are “intoxicants” because they resemble intoxicants in the sense of oozing out, just as the oozing matter called “juice” in the body of a leper with the “wine-disease” oozes out from the great sores in his body

original: Athavā, bhavato ābhavaggā dhammato āgotratumhā savanti ārammaṇakaraṇavasena pavattantīti
analyzed: athavā bhavataḥ ā bha vaggāḥ dhammataḥ ā gotra tumhā savanti ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena pavattanti iti
translated: Or alternatively, they flow, they cause to flow, they increase the state of being, the beginning of the round of rebirths, by becoming objects.🔽They are defilements because they are the cause of the state of being.

original: āsavā. Āsaddassa avadhiatthajotakattā. Avadhica duvidho mariyādavisayo abhividhivisayocāti

translated: The state of being is twofold: the state of being as a limit and the state of being as a range.

original: tattha yassa sambandhinīkriyā avadhibhūtaṃ attānaṃ bahikatvā pavattati. So mariyādavisayo🔽nāma. Yathā āpātaliputtā devo vuṭṭhoti. Yassa sambandhinīkriyā avadhibhūtaṃ attānaṃ
analyzed: tattha yassa sambandhinī kriyā avadhi bhūtam attānam bahika tvā pavattati saḥ mariyāda visayaḥ  nāma yathā āpātaliputtā devaḥ vuṭṭho ti yassa sambandhinī kriyā avadhi bhūtam attānam
translated: Herein, that which occurs making its own self external to the action that is related to it is called the state of being as a limit.🔽For example, “The god has rained down on Āp̄. ”

original: byāpetvā anto katvā pavattati, so abhividhivisayonāma. Yathā ābrahmalokā bhagavato🔽kittisaddo abbhuggatoti. Idha pana abhividhivisayo daṭṭhabbo. Tasmā bhavaggañca gotrabhuñca
analyzed: byāpetvā antaḥ katvā pavattati saḥ abhividhivisayaḥ nāma yathā ābrahmalokā bhagavataḥ  kitti saddaḥ abbhuggato ti idha pana abhividhi visayaḥ daṭṭhabbo tasmā bha vaggañca gotrabhun ca
translated: That which occurs making its own self internal to the action that is related to it is called the state of being as a range. For example, “The Blessed One’s fame has spread throughout the world. ”

original: [204] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana

translated: But in the Vibhāvaniyā

analyzed: avadhi ca mariyāda abhividhi vasena duvidhā iti vatvā puna tam tattha āpātali puttā

analyzed: devaḥ vuṭṭhaḥ iti ādīsu viya kriyam bahi katvā pavattaḥ mariyādaḥ abbhuggataḥ iti ādīsu viya

analyzed: byāpetvā pavattati na ca avadhi bhūtaḥ attho kriyam bahivā antovā katvā pavattati iti  kriyā eva pana tam bahivā antarvā katvā pavattati iti evam ca katvā  avadhi abhividhi visayaḥ anabhividhi visayaḥ ca abhividhi visayam pavattati
translated: And it is not correct to say that the meaning that is the domain of the limited occurs making the action external or internal.🔽But it is correct to say that the action itself occurs making the action external or internal.

analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇa mukhena desito sabbo kāmāvacara dhammo idha pana tam nāmena tad ārammaṇā  taṇhā eva adhippetā kāmo eva āsavo ti kāma āsavaḥ kāmāvacara dhammesu assādana abhinandana  vasena pavatto kāmarāgaḥ therena pana icchito vakkhati hi kāma bhava
translated: The whole of the kāmāvacara dhammas taught under the heading of the five strands of sense pleasure are intended here by the word kāma.🔽But here craving itself, which has that as its object, is intended. It is kāma itself that is āsava : it is kāmāsava.

translated: But in the Vibhāvinī,

analyzed: purima atthaḥ uva vuttaḥ saḥ anupapannaḥ thera mata anugatassa idha adhippetassa atthassa a vutta ttā  bhava āsavaḥ ti ettha duvidhaḥ bhavaḥ kamma bhavaḥ upapatti bhavo ca tattha mahaggata kusala dhammā

analyzed: taṇhā eva adhippetā bhavaḥ eva āsavo ti bhava āsavaḥ tasmin duvidhe bhave nikanti vasena
translated: Craving itself is intended. Existence itself is the taint, thus it is the taint of existence. In that twofold existence, by way of attachment,

translated: Craving itself is intended. Existence itself is the cankers, thus it is the canker of existence. In the case of the twofold existence, it is the passion for the fine-material and immaterial kinds of existence that occurs as cleaving to it.

original: [206] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ

translated: But what is to be analysed here is this:

analyzed: diṭṭhi sahagataḥ ca rāgaḥ ettha iva saṅgayhati iti vuttam tat na yuttam  bhavāsavo catūsu diṭṭhigata vippayutta lobha sahagatesu cittuppādesu uppajjati iti hi
translated: “The lust associated with the eternalist view is included here too.” This is not right.🔽For it is said in the Paṭisambhidā in the section on the cankers that “the canker of existence arises in the four unprofitable consciousnesses accompanied by equanimity and associated with the false view of perishing” .

analyzed: sabbā bhava taṇhā ayam saṅgahitā ati yuttā idha pana yathāvuttam bhava āsavam thapetvā

translated: And by this same method it is to be understood that what is said there

original: Yākāci diṭṭhi diṭṭhāsavo. Yokoci moho avijjāsavo. Ettha siyā, kasmā ime eva āsavāti🔽vuttā. Nanu aññepi mānādayo cirapārivāsiyaṭṭhādiyuttā eva hontīti. Saccaṃ. Imesu🔽pana kāmāsave parivuṭṭhe sati sabbekāmavisayā mānādayo parivuṭṭhāeva honti. Tasmiṃ🔽vimutte vimuttāeva, tathā bhavāsave parivuṭṭhe sati bhavavisayā. Diṭṭhāsaveca parivuṭṭhe
analyzed: yākāci diṭṭhi diṭṭha āsavo yokoci mohaḥ avijja āsavo ettha siyā kasmai ime eva  vuttāḥ nanu aññe pi māna ādayaḥ cirapārivāsiya ṭṭhā ādi yuttāḥ eva honti iti saccam imesu  pana kāma āsave parivuṭṭhe sati sabbe kāma visayāḥ māna ādayo parivuṭṭhāḥ eva honti tasmiṃ  vimutte vimuttā eva tathā bhava āsave parivuṭṭhe sati bhava visayāḥ diṭṭha āsave ca parivuṭṭhe
translated: The view is the taint of views. Whatever delusion is the taint of ignorance. Herein, it may be asked: But why are only these called taints? Are not pride, etc., also long-lasting enemies? —True, but when the sense-desire taint is abandoned, all the kinds of pride that have sense desires as their object are abandoned too. When that is freed, they are freed too. Likewise when the being taint is abandoned, all the kinds of pride that have being as their object are abandoned too. When that is freed, they are freed too. And when the view taint is abandoned, all the kinds of conceit that have views as their object are abandoned too. When that is freed, they are freed too.

original: sati diṭṭhivisayāti. Avijjāpana tesaṃ tiṇṇaṃpi mūlabhūtāti. Iti ime eva pārivāsiyaṭṭhādīsu🔽padhānabhūtā honti. Itare pana tadanubandhamattāeva sampajjantīti na te āsavāti visuṃ🔽vattuṃ arahantīti. Attani patitaṃ janaṃ anassāsikaṃ katvā ajjhottha ranto hanati🔽māretīti ogho. Pakatimahogho. Tathā avahananaṭṭhena duttaraṭṭhenaca oghasadisāti
analyzed: tesam tiṇṇam pi mūla bhūtā ti iti ime eva pārivāsiya ṭṭha ādīsu 🔽padhāna bhūtāḥ honti itare pana tad anubandha mattāḥ eva sampajjanti iti na te visum 🔽vattum arahanti iti attani patitam janam anassāsikam katvā ajjhottha rantaḥ hanati 🔽māreti iti ogho pakati mahā ogho tathā avahanana ṭṭhena duttara ṭṭhena ca ogha sadisā ati
translated: The view is the taint of views. Whatever delusion is the taint of ignorance. Here it may be asked: Why are only these called taints? Are not pride, etc., also bound up with long-continued enmity, etc.? —True, but when the sense-desire taint is abandoned, all pride, etc., that have sense-desire as their object are abandoned too. When that is freed, they are freed too. Likewise when the being taint is abandoned, all that have being as their object are abandoned too. And when the view taint is abandoned, all that have views as their object are abandoned too. And ignorance is the root of all three. So these are the principal things among the long-continued enmities, etc., while the others are merely their accompaniments. That is why only these are called taints and are therefore worthy to be mentioned separately. —The flood is what kills by making a person who has fallen into it dissatisfied. It is a flood in the ordinary sense. So too, because of the similarity to a flood in the sense of carrying away and in the sense of being hard to cross,

original: oghā. Yadica avahaññanaṭṭheca duttaraṭṭhenaca oghānāma siyuntiādiko pasaṅgo mānādīnañca
analyzed: oghāḥ yadi ca duttara ṭṭhena ca oghāḥ nāma upasaṅgaḥ māna ādīnam ca
translated: and floods. And the passage beginning, “If the defilements were only of the meaning of carrying away and of being hard to cross, etc., and the meaning of being a stream, etc., would not apply to them” is about pride, etc.

original: oghabhāva parihāro vutta nayena veditabbo.
analyzed: ogha bhāva parihāraḥ vutta nayena veditabbo
translated: And the floods. And the way of escape from the defilements of conceit, etc., should be understood in the way already given .
