original: Kāmanaṭṭhena kāmo, chandanaṭṭhenachandoti kāmacchando. Balavarāgo. Soevanīvaraṇanti🔽kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ. Paṭṭhāneāruppekāmacchandaṃ nīvaraṇaṃ paṭiccauddhaccanīvaraṇanti🔽vuttattā pana thapetvā rūpārūparāge avaseso sabbolobho kāmacchande asaṅgahitonāma
analyzed: kāmana ṭṭhena kāmo chandana ṭṭhena chando ti kāmacchandaḥ  kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam paṭṭhāne āruppe kāmacchandam nīvaraṇam paṭicca auddhacca nīvaraṇam ti  vutta ttā pana thapetvā rūpa arūpa rāge avasesaḥ sabba lobho kāmacchande asaṅgahitaḥ nāma
translated: It is sense desire in the sense of lusting , and it is will in the sense of willing , thus it is will-and-lust . It is strong greed. That is a hindrance,🔽thus it is called the hindrance of will-and-lust . But since it is said in the Paṭṭhāna that “the hindrance of will-and-lust is a condition, as object condition, for the hindrance of stiffness and torpor” ,

original: natthi. Jhānapaṭipakkhabhāvopana pañcakāmaguṇikarāgasseva hotīti veditabbo. Byāpajjanaṃ
analyzed: natthi pañca kāmaguṇika rāgassa iva hoti iti veditabbaḥ byāpajjanam
translated: there is no greed apart from sense desire and greed for existence that is not included in will-and-lust. It should be understood that it is only the defilements that are the opposites of the jhānas that are called “will-and-lust” here.

original: byāpādo. Cittassa pūtibhāvoti attho. Yokocidoso. Kasmā panettha thinamiddha nīvaraṇanti
analyzed: byāpādo cittassa pūti bhāvo ti attho yokocidoso kasmā pana ittha
translated: Ill will is the state of the mind’s corruption. Its characteristic is affliction. It is a mental factor that is the opposite of loving kindness.

original: ca uddhacca kukkucca nīvaraṇanti ca dve dve dhammā ekaṃ nīvaraṇaṃ katvā vuttāti.
analyzed: ca uddhat ca kukkucca nīvaraṇanti ca dve dve dhammā ekam nīvaraṇam katvā vuttā ati
translated: But why are stiffness and torpor stated as one hindrance and also worry and despondency?

original: Kiccato paccayato paṭipakkhatoca sadisattā. Tathā hi kiccato tāva thinamiddhadvayaṃ🔽cittuppādānaṃ līnabhāvā pādanakiccaṃ. Uddhaccakukkuccadvayaṃ avūpasantabhāvāpādanakiccaṃ.
analyzed: kiccataḥ paccayataḥ paṭipakkhato ca sadisa ttā tathā hi kiccataḥ tāva thinam iddha dvayam  citta uppādānam līna bhāvā pādana kiccam uddhacca kukkucca dvayam a vūpasanta bhāva āpādana kiccam
translated: As to function, the two beginning with stiffness-and-torpor🔽have the function of producing slackness in the cognizance and in the postures of the body. The two beginning with agitation-and-worry have the function of producing unquiet in the cognizance and in the postures of the body.

original: Paccayato purimadvayaṃ tandivijambhi tatāpaccayaṃ. Pacchimadvayaṃ ñātibyasanādivitakkapaccayaṃ.
analyzed: paccayataḥ purima dvayam tat tā paccayam pacchima dvayam ñāti byasana ādi vitakka paccayam
translated: As to source, the former pair have sloth and torpor as their source, and the latter pair have thinking about one’s relations, etc., as their source.

original: Paṭipakkhato purimadvayaṃ vīriyapaṭipakkhaṃ. Pacchimadvayaṃ samathapaṭipakkhanti.
analyzed: paṭipakkhato purima dvayam vīriya paṭipakkham pacchima dvayam samatha paṭipakkhanti
translated: As to opposition, the former pair are opposed to energy, and the latter pair to quiet.

original: Anusentīti anusayā. Anurūpaṃ kāraṇaṃ labhitvā uppajjantīti attho. Anuanu sentītivā🔽anusayā. Yāva maggaṃ napaṭilabhati. Tāva antarā aparikkhiyyamānā hutvā kāraṇalābhe🔽sati punappunaṃ uppajjantīti attho. Uppajjanañcettha appahīnaṭṭhena uppajjanā rahabhāvo
analyzed: anusenti iti anusayāḥ anurūpam kāraṇam labhitvā uppajjanti iti atthaḥ anu anu senti itivā  anusayāḥ yāva maggam na paṭilabhati tāva antarā a parikkhiyyamānāḥ hutvā kāraṇa lābhe  sati punappunam uppajjanti iti atthaḥ uppajjanam ca ittha appahīna ṭṭhena uppajjanā raha bhāvaḥ
translated: They lie in wait , thus they are latent . The meaning is that they occur when they get a suitable opportunity. Or alternatively,

original: veditabbo. Na pana sarūpato uppatti, kathaṃ viññā yatīti ce. Yassa kāmarāgānusayo
analyzed: veditabbaḥ na pana sarūpataḥ uppatti katham viññā yati iti ce yassa kāma rāga anusayo
translated: they lie in wait , thus they are latent . As long as he does not obtain the path, they lie in wait in him uninvestigated, and when they get an opportunity they occur again and again. The meaning is that they occur. And here occurrence should be understood as the state of being present in the sense of not being given up, not as actual occurrence. How is this known? Because of the words “The underlying tendency to lust for pleasant” , etc.,

original: uppajjati, tasseva paṭighānusayo uppajjatīti vuttattā. Evañca katvā pāḷiyaṃ puthujjanassa
analyzed: uppajjati tassa iva paṭigha anusayaḥ uppajjati iti vutta ttā evañca katvā pāḷiyam puthujjanassa
translated: because it is said: “If the underlying tendency to resistance arises in him, the underlying tendency to resentment arises in him too.”

original: sattapi anusayā anusayavāre saha anusentīti uppajjanavāre saha uppajjantīti vuttā.
analyzed: satta pi anusayāḥ anusaya vāre saha anusenti iti uppajjana vāre saha uppajjanti iti vuttā
translated: And when it is put like this, it is said in the text that in the case of an ordinary man the seven underlying tendencies occur together in the section on underlying tendencies, and they arise together in the section on arising.

original: Yathāha puthujjanassa avijjānusayoca anuseti. Kāmarāga. Paṭigha. Māna. Diṭṭhi. Vicikicchā.
analyzed: yathā āha puthujjanassa avijjā anusayā ucca anuseti kāma rāga paṭigha māna diṭṭhi vicikicchā
translated: For it is said: “In the case of an ordinary man, the underlying tendency to ignorance, the underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to wrong views, the underlying tendency to uncertainty, and the underlying tendency to the passion for becoming underlie. ”

original: Bhavarāganusayoca anusetīti. Tathā uppajjanavārepīti.
analyzed: bhava rāj anusayaḥ ca anuseti iti tathā uppajjana vāre pi iti
translated: And so too in the section on arising.

original: Apica, sarūpato pariyuṭṭhānaṃ apatvā santāne pavattamānehi kusalākusalā byākatacittuppādehi
analyzed: apica sarūpataḥ pariyuṭṭhānam a patvā santāne pavattamānehi kusala akusalāḥ byākata cittuppādehi
translated: Besides, without actually invading, they lie down in the continuity, accompanying the wholesome and unwholesome kinds of consciousness that occur there,

original: saha anurūpā aviruddhā hutvā senti. Visuṃ sampayuttadhammabhāvena avuṭṭhitā hutvā
analyzed: saha anurūpāḥ a viruddhāḥ hutvā senti visum sampayutta dhamma bhāvena a vuṭṭhitāḥ hutvā
translated: lying down in a way that is in conformity with them and not in opposition to them, not standing out from them by becoming associated factors in their own right,🔽but lying down in a way that is in conformity with them.

original: sayitā hontīti anusayā. Anu anu sentītivā anusayā. Pakatiyā yathānusayitesueva kāmarāgādīsu
analyzed: sayitāḥ honti iti anusayāḥ anu anu senti itivā anusayāḥ yathā anusayitesu eva kāma rāga ādīsu
translated: They lie down in the way already described as underlying tendencies.

original: punappunaṃ uppajjitvā diguṇa tiguṇādi vasena punappunaṃ senti. Sayanākārena uparupari
analyzed: punappunam uppajjitvā diguṇa tiguṇa ādi vasena punappunam senti sayana ākārena upari upari
translated: They lie down again and again by arising again and again in lust for sensual desires, etc., which are the underlying tendencies, and by increasing them two- or three-fold, etc. They lie down by lying down again and again,

original: paliveṭhentīti attho.
analyzed: paliveṭhenti iti attho
translated: by lying down on top of, by lying down over and above, is the meaning.

original: Tīsu rāgādīnaṃ avatthāsu pathamāvatthāya ṭhitānaṃ kāmarāgā dīnametaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: tīsu rāga ādīnam avatthāsu pathama avatthāya adhivacanam
translated: In the three states of greed, etc., this is a term for those established in the first state.

original: Tisso hi avatthā anusayāvatthā pariyuṭṭhānāvatthā vītikkamāvatthāti. Tattha ye kāmarāgādayo
analyzed: tissaḥ hi avatthāḥ anusaya avatthā pariyuṭṭhāna avatthā vītikkama avatthā ti tattha ye kāma rāga ādayo
translated: For there are three states: the state of latent tendency, the state of obsession, and the state of transgression. Herein, those greed, etc.,

original: uppajjitvā kāyaṅgavācaṅgaṃ cālenti, tesaṃ tathāpavattā avatthā vītikkamāvatthānāma.
analyzed: uppajjitvā kāyaṅga vācaṅgam cālenti tesam tathāpavattāḥ avatthāḥ vītikkama avatthā nāma
translated: that arise and impel the bodily formation and the speech formation are called the state of transgression.

original: Ye manasmiṃ eva javanacittasahajātā hutvā pavattanti, tesaṃ tathāpavattā avatthā🔽pariyuṭṭhānāvatthānāma. Ye pana javanasahajātabhāvaṃpi apatvā vāsanādhātuyo viya
analyzed: ye manasmin eva javana citta sahajātāḥ hutvā pavattanti tesam tathāpavattāḥ avatthā  ye pana javana sahajāta bhāvaṃpi a patvā
translated: Those that occur in the mind only, conascent with impulsion consciousness, are called the state of obsession.

original: cikkasantānā nusayitā hutvā pariyuṭṭhānappattiyā bījabhāvena tiṭṭhanti, subhanimittādikeca
analyzed: hutvā pariyuṭṭhāna ppattiyāḥ bīja bhāvena tiṭṭhanti subha nimitta ādike ca
translated: But those that do not even reach the state of being conascent with impulsion but remain as potentialities in the continuity of consciousness like latent tendencies, and on the appearance of a suitable object such as a beautiful visible- data base,

original: ārammaṇe āpātamāgate yesaṃ vasena āvajjanaṃ rāgādipātubhāvatthāya ayoniso bhavaṅgaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇe āpātam āgate vasena āvajjanam rāga ādi pātubhāva tthāya ayonisaḥ bhavaṅgam
translated: by means of which the adverting is unreasoned and so the life-continuum is disturbed for the purpose of the manifestation of greed, etc.,

original: āvaṭṭeti, abhāvitañca cittaṃ yesaṃ vasena damathaṃ naupeti, tesaṃ tathā pavattā avatthā
analyzed: āvaṭṭeti abhāvitam ca cittam yesam vasena damatham na upeti tesam tathā pavattā avatthā
translated: and by means of which the untamed consciousness does not reach calm, their occurrence in this way is called the state of latent tendency.

original: anusayāvatthānāma. Tadavatthikā kāmarāgādayo anusayānāma. Te pana aparamatthabhūtāpi🔽na honti. Ekantaparamatthajātikattā. Naca kusalābyākatabhūtā ekantākusalajātikattā.
analyzed: kāma rāga ādayaḥ anusayā nāma te pana  na honti ekanta paramattha jāti kattā na ca kusala abyākata bhūtāḥ ekanta akusala jāti kattā
translated: and the underlying tendencies are the state. The underlying tendencies to lust for sensual desires, etc., are the state of that state. But they are not a different real entity.🔽Because they are of the nature of being entirely real. And they are not of the nature of being wholesome or indeterminate.

original: Nāpi kusalābyākataviruddhā, visuṃ sampayuttadhammabhāvena anupaladdhattā. Nāpi kālattayavinimuttā,🔽tekālikadhammasannissayena pavattanato. Yadā pana te samuṭṭha hitvā pariyuṭṭhānabhāvaṃ
analyzed: na api kusala abyākata viruddhā visum sampayutta dhamma bhāvena anupaladdha ttā na api kāla ttaya vinimuttā  tekālika dhamma sannissayena pavattanato yadā pana te hitvā pariyuṭṭhāna bhāvam
translated: Because they are of the nature of being entirely unwholesome. Nor are they opposed to the wholesome and indeterminate, because they are not found as associated states separate from them. Nor are they free from the three times,🔽because they occur in dependence on a state that is of the same time as themselves. But when they have arisen and become manifest,

original: gacchanti, tadā visuṃ sampayuttadhamma bhāvañca gacchanti. Sārammaṇādibhāvoca tesaṃ🔽paribyatto hoti. Etadatthaṃ sandhāya kathāvatthumhi tesaṃ sārammaṇadhammabhāvo saṅkhārakkhandhabhāvoca
analyzed: gacchanti tadā visum sampayutta dhamma bhāvam ca gacchanti tesam  paribyattaḥ hoti etad attham sandhāya kathā vatthumhi tesam sa ārammaṇa dhamma bhāvo
translated: then they become associated states separate from that state. And the object, etc., of those underlying tendencies

original: patiṭṭhāpito hotīti.
analyzed: patiṭṭhāpitaḥ hoti iti
translated: are determined. It is with reference to this meaning that the state of being a mental object of those underlying tendencies and the state of being the aggregate of mental formations are established in the Kathāvatthu.

original: Yathā pana phaladhārimhi rukkhamhi visakaṇṭake dinne rukkhānusayito phaluppattiyā
analyzed: yathā pana phala dhārimhi rukkhamhi visakaṇṭake dinne rukkha anusayito phala uppattiyā
translated: But just as when a poisonous thorn is struck into a tree that bears fruit, the fruit that arises is affected by the poison of the thorn,

original: paccayabhūto sineho parikkhayaṃ gacchati. Samaye uppajjissamānāni phalāni nuppajjanti.
analyzed: paccaya bhūto sinehaḥ parikkhayam gacchati samaye uppajjissamānāni phalāni na uppajjanti
translated: and the affection that is the condition for it is exhausted. The fruits that would have arisen in due course do not arise.

original: Evaṃ sānusaye citta santāne yasmiṃ khaṇe maggo pātubhavati, tasmiṃ sahamagguppādā
analyzed: evam sa anusaye citta santāne yasmin khaṇe maggo pātubhavati tasmim saha magga uppādā
translated: So when the path arises in a mental continuity that has latent tendencies, then at that moment

original: so so anusayo parikkhayaṃ gacchati. Parikkhīṇassa pana puna pariyuṭṭhānaṃnāma natthi,
analyzed: saḥ saḥ anusayaḥ parikkhayam gacchati parikkhīṇassa pana puna pariyuṭṭhānam nāma natthi
translated: that latent tendency is exhausted. But when it is exhausted, there is no more ensnaring,

original: kuto vītikkamoti imamatthaṃ sandhāya maggo anāgatasāmaññaṃ kilesajātaṃ pajahatīti
analyzed: kutas vītikkamaḥ ti imam attham sandhāya maggaḥ anāgata sāmaññam kilesa jātam pajahati iti
translated: so how can there be transgression? This is the meaning of the words.

original: tattha tattha vutto. Tattha anāgatasāmaññanti anāgatasammataṃ, na ekanta anāgataṃ.
analyzed: tattha tattha vuttaḥ tattha anāgata sāmaññanti anāgata sammatam na ekanta anāgatam
translated: Herein, “the future state of sameness” is what is accepted as future, not what is absolutely future.

original: Teneva hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ maggo yekilese pajahati, te atītākivā anāgatātivā paccuppannātivā🔽navattabbāti vuttaṃ. Etenaca maggo kilesamukhena yāni kusalākusalakammānica upādinnakakhandhapañcakeca
analyzed: tena iva hi aṭṭhakathā ayam maggo pajahati te anāgata ativā paccuppanna ativā  na vattabbā ti vuttam etena ca maggaḥ kilesa mukhena yāni kusala akusala kammāni ca upādinnaka khandha pañcake ca
translated: That is why it is said in the commentary: “The path abandons defilements whether they are past, future, or present.

original: pajahati, te atītātivāanāgatātivā paccuppannātivā navattabbāti dīpeti. Yadi evaṃ
analyzed: pajahati te atītā ativā anāgatā ativā paccuppannā ativā na vattabbā ati dīpeti yadi evam
translated: They cannot be stated as past, future, or present.” And by this it is also shown that the path abandons the profitable and unprofitable kamma and the five aggregates acquired through kamma whether they are past, future, or present.🔽If that is so,

original: maggena pahīnā sabbe tebhūmakadhammā kālavimuttānāma ataṅkhatā nāma apaccayānāma🔽siyunti.Na. Tekālikajātikattā saṅkhata sapaccayajātikattā ca. Te hi magge anuppanne
analyzed: maggena pahīnā sabbe tebhūmaka dhammā kāla vimuttā nāma ataṅkhatāḥ nāma apaccayā nāma  tekālika jātika ttā sa paccaya jātika ttā ca te hi magge an uppanne
translated: All these states of the three planes that are abandoned by the path are called “unshakable” in one who is liberated by time.🔽They are not, because they are formed and have conditions, being born at a particular time. For these states,

original: ime nāmadhammā uppajjissanti nirujjhissantīti evaṃ saṅkhatalakkhaṇaṃ āhacca ñāṇena
analyzed: ime nāmadhammā uppajjissanti nirujjhissanti iti evam saṅkhata lakkhaṇam āhat ca ñāṇena
translated: before the path arises, are apprehended by knowledge in the way stated thus, “These states will arise, these states will cease,”

original: gahitattā lakkhaṇavasena tebhūmakādibhāvaṃ bhajantīti. Evañca katvā visuṃ sampayuttadhammabhāvaṃ🔽apattānaṃ anusayāvatthāya vā vāsanāvatthāyavā kammasamaṅgītāvatthāyavā āsayajjhāsayā
analyzed: gahita ttā lakkhaṇa vasena tebhūmaka ādi bhāvam bhajanti iti evam ca katvā visum sampayutta dhamma bhāvam  a pattānam anusaya avatthāya vā vāsanā avatthāya vā kamma samaṅgītā avatthāya vā āsaya jhāsayā
translated: and so they come under the three planes, etc., according to their characteristics.

original: dhimutticaritavatthāsuvā ṭhitānaṃ sabhāvānaṃ jātivasena paramattha dhammatā akusalāditāca paccetabbā hotīti.
analyzed: ṭhitānam sabhāvānam jāti vasena paramattha dhamma tā akusala ādi tā ca paccetabbā hoti iti
translated: And thus it is possible to determine the unwholesome, etc., nature of the individual essences that are not included among the associated states, and that are established either as the underlying tendencies, or as the residual impressions, or as the condition by the coincidence of the kamma-resultant aggregates, or as the latent and manifest tendencies, or as the basis for the manifestation of consciousness,🔽by their individual essences.

original: [208] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Appahīnā hi kilesā kāraṇalābhe sati uppajjanā rahā santāne anuanusayitā viya hontīti
analyzed: appahīnāḥ hi kilesā kāraṇa lābhe sati uppajjanāḥ rahā santāne honti iti
translated: “For the defilements that have not been abandoned are like latent tendencies that lie hidden in the continuity when there is an opportunity for their activity.

original: tadavatthā anusayāti vuccanti. Te pana nippariyāyato anāgata kilesā. Atītapaccuppannāpi🔽taṃsabhāvattā tathā vuccantī”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha anusayānāma santāne kadācipi anuppanna
analyzed: tad avatthāḥ anusayā ti vuccanti te pana nippariyāyataḥ anāgata kilesāḥ atīta paccuppannā api  tad sabhāva ttā tathā vuccanti iti vuttam tattha anusaya nāma santāne kadāci pi
translated: and they are called latent tendencies in that state. But in the ultimate sense they are future defilements. Past and present ones are called so because they have that nature.” Herein, latent tendencies are never arisen in the life-continuum,

original: pubbā anāgata kilesā evāti katvā santāne anu anusayitā viya hontīti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na yujjati.
analyzed: pubbā anāgata kilesā eva iti katvā santāne anu viya honti iti vuttam tat na yujjati
translated: They are called latent tendencies in that state. But in the ultimate sense they are future defilements. Past and present defilements are called latent tendencies in the same way because they have that nature. ” Here it is said that the future defilements, which have never arisen before in the life-continuum, are called latent tendencies because they are latent in the life-continuum as if they were latent tendencies. That is incorrect.

original: Na hi te anuanusayitā viya honti. Ekantena anusayitāeva hontīti.🔽[209] Yañca tattha
analyzed: na hi te anuanusayitāḥ viya honti ekantena anusayitāḥ eva honti iti  yañca tattha
translated: For they are not latent in the life-continuum as if they were latent tendencies; they are latent tendencies pure and simple.

original: “Te pana nippariyāyato anāgatakilesā”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na yuttaṃ.
analyzed: te pana nippariyāyataḥ anāgata kilesā ti vuttam tat pi na yuttam
translated: And it is incorrect to say that “they are future defilements in the ultimate sense.”

original: Na hi maggena appahīnā anusayā anāgatānāma honti. Pahīnāpica nippariyāyato anāgatāti🔽nasakkā vattuṃ. Anāgata sāmaññassa adhippetattāti. Etena atītapaccuppannāpi taṃsabhāvattātathā
analyzed: na hi maggena appahīnāḥ anusayāḥ anāgatā nāma honti pahīnā api ca nippariyāyataḥ anāgatā ati  na sakkā vattum anāgata sāmaññassa adhippeta ttā ti etena atīta paccuppannā api
translated: For defilements that have not been abandoned by the path are not future defilements. And it is not possible to say that those that have been abandoned are future defilements in the ultimate sense,🔽because what is intended is a common characteristic of the future.

original: vuccantīti idaṃvipaṭikkhittaṃ hoti. Apica, uppādaṭṭhitibhaṅga pattānaṃeva ekantena
analyzed: vuccanti iti idam vipaṭikkhittam hoti apica uppāda ṭṭhiti bhaṅga pattānam eva ekantena
translated: This refutes the statement that past and present defilements are called latent tendencies in the same way because they have that nature. Moreover, only those defilements that have reached arising, presence, and dissolution are latent tendencies pure and simple.

original: tekālikatā hotīti tadapattānaṃ anusayānaṃ paccuppannatā pariyāyova vattuṃ yutto.
analyzed: tekālika tā hoti iti tad apattānam anusayānam paccuppanna tā pariyāyā uva vattum yuttaḥ
translated: “It is appropriate to say that the condition for the latent tendencies not to have been abandoned is their presence.”

original: Evañca katvā pāḷiyaṃ yassa kāmarāganusayo uppajjati, tassa paṭighānusayo uppajjatītiādinā
analyzed: evañca katvā pāḷiyam yassa kāma rāga anusayaḥ uppajjati tassa paṭigha anusayaḥ uppajjati iti ādinā
translated: And it is in this way that the passage in the text, “In one in whom the underlying tendency to lust is manifest, the underlying tendency to aversion is manifest,”

original: paccuppannakāliko uppādavāro eva vutto, na nirodhavāro, naca atītānāgata vārāti.
analyzed: paccuppanna kālikaḥ uppāda vāraḥ eva vuttaḥ na nirodha vāraḥ na ca atīta anāgata vārā ti
translated: should be understood as referring to the mode of arising, not to the mode of cessation, and not to the past and future.

original: Yaṃ pana paṭisambhidāmagge hañci paccuppanne kilese pajahati. Tena hi ratto rāgaṃ
analyzed: yam pana paṭisambhidā magge hañci paccuppanne kilese pajahati tena hi rattaḥ rāgam
translated: But in the Paṭisambhidā it is said: “If he abandons defilements that are present, then the lustful man abandons lust,

original: pajahati, duṭṭho dosaṃ, muḷho mohanti vuttaṃ. Taṃ pariyuṭṭhānapattānaṃ ekantapaccuppannakkhaṇaṃ🔽sandhāya vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Teneva hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vattamānuppannaṃ bhutvā vigatuppannaṃ🔽okāsakatuppannaṃ samudācāruppannanti catubbidhaṃ uppannaṃ na maggavajjhaṃ. Bhūmiladdhuppannaṃ
analyzed: pajahati duṭṭhaḥ dosam muḷhaḥ mohanti vuttam tam pariyuṭṭhāna pattānam ekanta paccuppanna kkhaṇam  sandhāya vuttanti daṭṭhabbam tena iva hi aṭṭhakathā ayam vattamāna uppannam bhutvā vigata uppannam  okāsa kata uppannam samudācāra uppannam ti catubbidham uppannam na magga vajjham bhūmi laddha uppannam
translated: the hating man hatred, the deluded man delusion.” This should be understood as said with specific reference to the defilements that have already invaded the consciousness element and the corresponding object,🔽which are present in the single moment of arising.🔽That is why in the commentary it is said: “The four kinds of present defilements are not abandoned by the path. They are: present by occurrence, present by proximity, present by object, and present by manifestation.

original: ārammaṇā dhiggahi tuppannaṃ avikkhambhituppannaṃ asamugghāṭituppannanti catubbidhaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇā dhiggahi tuppannam a vikkhambhi tuppannam a samugghāṭi tuppannam ti catubbidham
translated: The four kinds of present defilements that are abandoned by the path are: present by plane, present by appearance in the object, present by non-suppression, and present by non-eradication.”

original: maggavajjhanti vuttaṃ. Tattha vattamānuppannaṃ samudā cāruppannanti idaṃ dvayaṃ khaṇapaccuppannameva.
analyzed: magga vajjhanti vuttam tattha vattamānuppannam samudā cāruppannanti idam dvayam khaṇa paccuppannam eva
translated: Herein, the two kinds called “arisen in the present” and “arisen in the past and present” are only what has occurred in the present.

original: Bhutvāvigatuppannaṃ atītameva. Okāsa katuppannaṃ anāgatameva. Tadubhayaṃ pana paccuppannasamīpattā
analyzed: atītam eva okāsa kata uppannam anāgatam eva tat ubhayam pana paccuppanna samīpa ttā
translated: The kind called “arisen after having been extinguished” is only past. The kind called “arisen by way of opportunity” is only future. But both these kinds are called “arisen” because they are near to the present.

original: uppannanti vuttaṃ. Samīpapaccuppannanti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Bhūmiladdhuppannaṃnāma attano khandhesu anusayitānaṃ maggena appahīnānaṃ anusayānaṃeva🔽nāmaṃ. Ārammaṇādhiggahituppannaṃ nāma subhanimittādike ārammaṇe sakiṃ javitvā yāva
analyzed: uppannanti vuttam samīpa paccuppannanti vuttam hoti  bhūmiladdhuppannam nāma attanaḥ khandhesu anusayitānam maggena appahīnānam anusayānam eva  ārammaṇa adhiggahita uppannam nāma subha nimitta ādike ārammaṇe sakim
translated: What is meant is: “arisen as near to the present.”🔽The kind called “arisen by being acquired in the plane” is the name for the underlying tendencies that have not been abandoned by the path in one’s own aggregates.

original: tammūlako pariyuṭṭhānavego na vūpasammati, tāva adhimattathāmagata bhāvena ṭhitānaṃ🔽tesaññeva nāmaṃ. Anusayā hi nāma anamatagge saṃsāre punappunaṃ pariyuṭṭhānapattānaṃ
analyzed: pariyuṭṭhāna vegaḥ bhāvena  tesam eva nāmam anusayāḥ hi nāma anamatagge saṃsāre punappunam pariyuṭṭhāna pattānam
translated: The kind called “arisen by being acquired as object” is the name for those same underlying tendencies that have occurred in a strong or middling way for as long as the force of the obsession rooted in the object of the kind beginning with the sign of the beautiful does not subside,🔽having once arisen in the object such as the sign of the beautiful.

original: kilesānaṃ vasena uparupari thira tara daḷhatara pattiyā pakatiyāpi thāmagatāevanāma
analyzed: kilesānam vasena uparupari thira tara daḷhatara
translated: For the underlying tendencies are by nature already strong and firm in the beginning in the beginningless round of rebirths, by reason of the defilements that have occurred again and again in the past.

original: honti. Na yenavā tenavā vāyāmena pajahituṃ sakkuṇeyyā. Evaṃ santepi yadā yo yo anusayo
analyzed: honti na yena vā tena vā vāyāmena pajahitum evam sante pi yadā yaḥ yaḥ anusayaḥ
translated: They are not able to abandon them by the mere occurrence of the path. Still, when any given latent tendency becomes strong through the acquisition of its conditions, then it stands out as particularly strong.

original: paccayalābhena pariyuṭṭhāna bahulo hoti, tadā so so visesena adhimattathāma gatabhāvaṃ
analyzed: paccaya lābhena pariyuṭṭhāna bahulaḥ hoti tadā saḥ saḥ visesena gata bhāvam
translated: When it is suppressed by the acquisition of the counter-state, then it stands out as particularly weak.🔽The latent tendency that has arisen but not yet been suppressed is called “unabandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has arisen and been suppressed is called “abandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen but is ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”

original: patvā ṭhito hoti. Yadā yo yo paṭipakkhadhamma samādānena niggahapatto hoti, tadā
analyzed: patvā ṭhitaḥ hoti yadā yaḥ yo paṭipakkha dhamma samādānena niggaha patto hoti tadā
translated: The latent tendency that has not arisen and is suppressed is called “abandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is not ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is suppressed is called “abandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is not ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”

original: so so mandathāma gatabhāvaṃ patvā ṭhito hotīti. Avikkhambhituppannaṃnāma samatha
analyzed: saḥ saḥ manda thāma gata bhāvam patvā ṭhitaḥ hoti iti
translated: The latent tendency that has not arisen and is suppressed is called “abandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is not ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is suppressed is called “abandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is not ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”

original: vipassanāhi suṭṭhuaniggahitānaṃ tesaññeva nāmaṃ. Asamugghāṭi tuppannaṃnāma maggena
analyzed: vipassanāhi suṭṭhu a niggahitānam tesam eva nāmam a samugghāṭi maggena
translated: The latent tendency that has not arisen and is suppressed is called “abandoned.”

original: appahīnānaṃ bhūmiladdhānaṃ tesaṃeva nāmanti. Yasmā pana lokuttaradhammānāma kilesānaṃ
analyzed: appahīnānam bhūmi laddhānam tesam eva nāmanti yasmā pana lokuttara dhammā nāma kilesānam
translated: The latent tendency that has not arisen and is not ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is suppressed is called “abandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is not ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is suppressed is called “abandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is not ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is suppressed is called “abandoned.”

original: accantapaṭipakkhā hontīti heṭṭhimā maggaṭṭhaphalaṭṭhā sekkhā attano maggaphalakkhaṇesu
analyzed: accanta paṭipakkhāḥ honti iti heṭṭhimā magga ṭṭha phala ṭṭhā sekkhā attanaḥ magga phala kkhaṇesu
translated: The latent tendency that has not arisen and is not ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”

original: upari maggājjhehipi anusayehi sānusayātivā nirānusayātivā thāmavatātivā athāmagatātivā
analyzed: upari anusayehi sa anusayā ativā nira anusayā ativā
translated: The latent tendency that has not arisen and is suppressed is called “abandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is not ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is suppressed is called “abandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is not ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is suppressed is called “abandoned.”🔽The latent tendency that has not arisen and is not ready to arise is called “unabandoned.”🔽The latent

original: navattabbā. Tasmā anusayānaṃ tādise paccuppanna bhāve satipi hañci paccuppanne kilese
analyzed: tādise paccuppanna bhāve sati pi hañci paccuppanne kilese
translated: Therefore, even though the latent tendencies are present in the present, the question is asked: “When there are defilements in the present, are there latent tendencies in the present?

original: pajahati. Tenahi thāmagato anusayaṃ pajahatīti vutta doso natthīti veditabboti. Kāmarāgoeva
analyzed: pajahati tena hi thāma gataḥ anusayam pajahati iti vutta doso na atthi iti veditabbaḥ ti kāma rāgaḥ eva
translated: and they are not to be taken as present. So even though there is such a presence of underlying tendencies, still he abandons defilements that are present. Consequently, it should be understood that there is no fault in saying that he abandons the underlying tendency when he reaches the path.

original: anusayo kāmarāgānusayo.🔽Saṃyojenti bandhantīti saṃyojanāni, tāni pana sakkāyadiṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbataparāmāso
analyzed: anusayaḥ kāma rāga anusayaḥ  saṃyojenti bandhanti iti saṃyojanāni tāni pana sakkāya diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāso
translated: Lust is itself the underlying tendency to lust.🔽They bind , thus they are fetters . But these are the five lower fetters, namely, personality view, uncertainty, misapprehension of virtue and duty, sensual desire, and ill will.

original: kāmacchando byāpādoti pañca orambhāgiyāni. Rūparāgo arūparāgo māno uddhaccaṃ avijjāti🔽pañca uddhaṃbhāgiyānīti suttante abhidhammeca dasasaṃyojanāni āgatāni. Itarāni pana🔽abhidhammeeva āgatānīti tato visesakaraṇatthaṃ suttanteti vuttaṃ. Kamo pana dvinnaṃpi
analyzed: kāmacchandaḥ byāpādaḥ uti pañca orambhāgiyāni rūpa rāgaḥ a rūpa rāgaḥ mānaḥ uddhaccam avijjāti  pañca uddhaṃbhāgiyāni iti suttante abhidhamme ca dasa saṃyojanāni āgatāni itarāni pana  abhidhamme eva āgatāni iti tatas visesa karaṇa attham suttante ti vuttam kamaḥ pana dvinnam pi
translated: And these are the five higher fetters, namely, lust for fine-material existence, lust for immaterial existence, conceit , restlessness, and ignorance.🔽So in the texts and in the Abhidhamma these ten fetters are given. But the others are given only in the Abhidhamma.

original: pāḷiyā nasameti. Sabhāga dhammasaṅgahavasena pana idha aññathā kamo vutto siyāti.
analyzed: pāḷiyā dhamma saṅgaha vasena pana idha aññathā kamaḥ vuttaḥ siyāti
translated: So in order to distinguish them it is said in the texts. But the order in which they are given in the texts does not agree with that in which they are given in the two Piṭakas. However, the order in which they are given here may be taken as the order in which they are given in the texts according to the method of the Dhammasanganī.

original: Cittaṃ kilissanti vibādhenti upatāpenticāti kilesā. Kilissantivā malīnabhāvaṃ nihīnabhāvañca
analyzed: cittam kilissanti vibādhenti upatāpenti ca ati kilesā kilissanti vā malīna bhāvam nihīna bhāvam ca
translated: They defile, they afflict, they torment the cognizance, thus they are defilements. Or they defile, they go to a state of corruption, a state of lowliness,

original: gacchanti sattā etehīti kilesā. Kāmabhavanāmenāti vatthukāmadīpakena kāmanāmena rūpārūpabhavadīpakena
analyzed: gacchanti sattāḥ etehi iti kilesā kāma bhava nāmena ati vatthu kāma dīpakena kāma nāmena rūpa arūpa bhava dīpakena
translated: thus they are defilements. By the name of lust for sense desires and by the name of being of sense desires, and by the name of being of the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming,

original: ca bhavanāmena. Tādisaṃ kāma bhavasaṅkhātaṃ ārammaṇabhūtaṃ vatthu etissāti tabbatthukā.
analyzed: ca bhava nāmena tādisam kāma bhava saṅkhātam ārammaṇa bhūtam vatthu etissa ati tabbatthukā
translated: it is the object that is called “sense desires” and “becoming” that is gone to by this, thus it is of that kind of object.

original: Tathā pavattanti sīlabbatāni parato āmasanākārena idaṃ me saccaṃ moghamaññanti abhinivisanākārena
analyzed: tathā pavattanti sīlabbatāni paratas āmasana ākārena idam me saccam mogham aññanti abhinivisana ākārena
translated: It occurs in the way of virtue and duty, in the way of misapprehending what is not the self as the self, and in the way of misapprehending the self as what is not the self.

original: khandhesu attābhinivesākārenaca pavattaṃ. Vatthutoti sabhāvadhammato. Ayaṃ pāpasaṅgaho
analyzed: khandhesu attā abhinivesa ākārena ca pavattam vatthuto ti sa bhāva dhammataḥ ayam pāpa saṅgaho
translated: By its source is meant by its individual essence. This is the exposition of the unprofitable.

original: akusalaṅgaho navadhā vuttoti yojanā. [Akusalasaṅgaho]🔽163. Missaka saṅgahe pāṇātipātādīni pāpakammāni karontānaṃpi cittassa ārammaṇe ujukaraṇaṃnāma
analyzed: akusalaṅgaho navadhā vutto ti yojanā akusala saṅgaho  missaka saṅgahe pāṇātipāta ādīni pāpa kammāni karontānam pi cittassa ārammaṇe ujukaraṇaṃnāma
translated: The unprofitable is said to be ninefold.🔽In the case of those who commit such evil actions as killing breathing things, etc., the straightening of the mind on the object is not possible without jhana,

original: jhānena vinā na sijjhatīti vuttaṃ sattajhānaṅgānīti. Kalyāṇevā pāpakevā ārammaṇe
analyzed: jhānena vinā na sijjhati iti vuttam satta jhāna aṅgāni iti kalyāṇe iva pāpake iva ārammaṇe
translated: and so it is said that the seven jhana factors are good only and the eight unprofitable factors are evil only on the object.

original: ujukaṃ cittapaṭipādanasaṅkhātassa upanijjhāyana kiccassa aṅgānīti attho. Tattha domanassaṃ
analyzed: ujukam citta paṭipādana saṅkhātassa upanijjhāyana kiccassa aṅgāni iti attho tattha domanassam
translated: The meaning is that they are the factors for the act of directing the mind straight, called “looking on at” . Herein, grief

original: akusalajjhānaṅgaṃ. Sesāni kusalākusalābyākatānīti. Kalyāṇakamma pāpakammasaṅkhātāsu🔽sugati duggati vivaṭṭasaṅkhātāsuca nānādisāsu taṃtaṃdisāti mukhappavattisaṅkhātā
analyzed: sesāni kusala akusala abyākatāni iti kalyāṇa kamma pāpa kamma saṅkhātāsu  sugati duggati vivaṭṭa saṅkhātāsu ca nānā disāsu taṃ taṃ disā ti mukha ppavatti saṅkhātā
translated: is a factor of unprofitable jhāna. The rest are either profitable, unprofitable, or indeterminate. In the various directions, called “good destination” and “bad destination” and “escape”🔽respectively, the occurrence of the mind’s going in the various directions, called “the occurrence of the face,”

original: cittassa gatināma sammāvā micchāvā pavattehi dassanādīhi eva sijjhatīti vuttaṃ dvādasamaggaṅgānīti.
analyzed: cittassa gati nāma sammā vā micchā vā pavattehi dassana ādīhi eva sijjhati iti vuttam dvādasa maggaṅgāni iti
translated: is accomplished by means of the right and wrong seeing, etc., respectively. That is why it is said that they are the twelve factors of the path.

original: Cittassa ujugatiyāvā vaṅkagatiyāvā gamanassa pathaṅgāni upāyaṅgānīti attho. Tattha🔽micchādiṭṭhi micchāsaṅkappa micchāvāyāma micchāsamādhayo pāpakamma duggatibhava saṅkhātāsu🔽ahitadisāsu cittassa vaṅkagatiyā gamanassa upāyaṅgāni, itarāni kalyāṇakamma sugatibhava
analyzed: cittassa uju gati yāvā vaṅka gati yāvā gamanassa pathaṅgāni upāyaṅgāni iti tattha  micchā diṭṭhi micchā saṅkappa micchā vāyāma micchā samādhayaḥ pāpa kamma duggati bhava saṅkhātāsu  ahita disāsu cittassa vaṅka gatiyāḥ gamanassa upāyaṅgāni itarāni kalyāṇa kamma sugati bhava
translated: The meaning is that they are the factors for the path of the mind’s going straight or the path of the mind’s going crookedly. Herein,

original: vivaṭṭadhammasaṅkhātāsu hitadisāsu ujugatiyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tattha pāṇātipātakamme
analyzed: vivaṭṭa dhamma saṅkhātāsu hita disāsu uju gatiyā ti daṭṭhabbam tattha pāṇātipāta kamme
translated: wrong view, wrong thinking, wrong effort, and wrong concentration are factors for the path of the mind’s going crookedly in the directions of harm, called “bad destination” and “existence in a bad destination” and “bad kamma” and “bad action.” The others are factors for the path of the mind’s going straight in the directions of benefit, called “good destination” and “existence in a good destination” and “escape” and “good kamma” and “good action.” Herein, in the case of the kamma of killing breathing things,

original: vitakka vicāra domanassekaggatā saṅkhātaṃ caturaṅgikajjhānaṃ micchāsaṅkappa micchāvāyāma
analyzed: vitakka vicāra domanassa ekagga tā saṅkhātam caturaṅgika jhānam micchāsaṅkappa micchāvāyāma
translated: and the four factors of jhāna consisting of applied thought, sustained thought, happiness, and unification of mind are the wrong thought, wrong effort,

original: micchāsamādhi saṅkhāto tiyaṅgīkamaggoca veditabbo. Evaṃ sesesu sucaritaduccaritakammesu
analyzed: micchāsamādhi saṅkhāto evam sesesu su carita duccarita kammesu
translated: and wrong concentration of the three- factored wrong path. The jhāna and path should be understood in this way in the case of the other good and bad kinds of kamma.

original: jhānamaggā uddharitabbā. Vibhaṅge pana suttantesuca micchāvācā micchākammanto micchāājīvo🔽micchāsatīti imepi cattāro āgatā. Ime pana visuṃ cetasikadhammā nahonti. Tathā tathā
analyzed: jhāna maggāḥ uddharitabbāḥ vibhaṅge pana suttantesu ca micchā vācā micchā kammanto micchā ājīvo  micchāsatī iti ime pi cattāraḥ āgatāḥ ime pana visum cetasika dhammā na honti tathā tathā
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga and in the Suttas the wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood,🔽and wrong mindfulness are given as well. But these are not separate mental states. They are not given here,

original: pavattānaṃ catunnaṃ khandhānaṃ adhivacananti katvā idha nagahitā.
analyzed: pavattānam catunnam khandhānam adhivacananti katvā idha
translated: but they are included under the four aggregates that occur in this way and that.

original: [210] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said,

original: “Sugati duggatīnaṃ nibbānassa ca abhimukhaṃ pāpanato maggā; Tesaṃ pathabhūtāni aṅgāni maṅgānī”ti vuttaṃ; Taṃ na sundaraṃ;
analyzed: sugati duggatīnam nibbānassa ca abhimukham pāpanataḥ maggā tesam patha bhūtāni aṅgāni maṅgāni iti vuttam tat na sundaram
translated: “The path is so called because it leads to good destinations, bad destinations, and to Nibbāna. Its factors are its limbs” . That is badly said.

original: Na hi aṅgāni maggānaṃ pathabhūtānināma honti; Maggasaddoyeva pathapariyāyo aṭṭhakathāsu vutto na aṅgasaddoti;
analyzed: na hi aṅgāni maggānam patha bhūtāni nāma honti magga saddaḥ yā iva patha pariyāyaḥ aṭṭhakathāsu vuttaḥ na aṅga saddaḥ ti
translated: For the factors are not called the path’s limbs because they are its feet. The word “path” is used in the commentaries in the sense of “way,” not the word “factor.”

original: [211] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there,

original: “Maggassavā aṭṭhaṅgikassa aṅgāni maggaṅgānī”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi anupapannaṃ.
analyzed: maggassa vā aṭṭhaṅgikassa aṅgāni maggaṅgāni iti vuttam tat pi anupapannam
translated: “The factors of the eightfold path are the path factors” is said. That is not correct.

original: Idha hi katthaci citte tiyaṅgiko katthaci caturaṅgikotiādinā nānāmaggova adhippetoti.🔽Ādhipaccaṭṭhena indriyāni. Kiñca ādhipaccaṃ. Attādhīnavuttike dhamme attano gatiyaṃ
analyzed: idha hi katthaci citte tiyaṅgiko katthaci caturaṅgikaḥ iti ādinā nānā maggaḥ uva adhippeto ti  indriyāni kiñca ādhipaccam atta adhīna vuttike dhamme attanaḥ gatiyam
translated: For here in the first place the path itself is intended, which is of various kinds, consisting of three factors in one instance, four factors in another, and so on.

original: sabbaso vattetuṃ samatthabhāvo. Iti tesu tesu kiccesu attano ādhipaccasaṅkhātaṃ indaṭṭhaṃ🔽karonti sādhentīti indriyāni. Indaṭṭhaṃ kārentītipi indriyāni. Issarā adhipatinoti
analyzed: sabbasas vattetum samattha bhāvaḥ iti tesu tesu kiccesu attanaḥ ādhipacca saṅkhātam indaṭṭham  karonti sādhenti iti indriyāni indaṭṭham kārenti iti pi indriyāni issarāḥ adhipatinoti
translated: The faculties are so called in the sense of predominance. And what is predominance? It is the state of being able to cause occurrence in accordance with one’s own mode of action of those things that are subject to one’s own influence. So they are faculties in the sense that they cause the predominance, the sovereignty, in their several functions, in their several activities.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha pañcacakkhādīni dassanādikiccesu cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ issarāhonti.🔽Balavadubbalamanda tikkhādīsu attākārānuvattāpanato. Bhāvadvayaṃ itthākārādivasena
analyzed: vuttam hoti tattha pañca cakkha ādīni dassana ādi kiccesu cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam issarā honti  tikkha ādīsu atta ākāra anuvattāpanataḥ bhāva dvayam itthā ākāra ādi vasena
translated: They are faculties in the sense that they cause the sovereignty. They are lords, they are masters, is what is meant. Herein, the five beginning with the eye are masters in the sense of sovereignty over the occurrence of eye-consciousness, and so on.🔽They are masters in the sense of sovereignty over the occurrence of the materiality of the four primaries in the mode of the respective sense-base, and so on.

original: pavattiyaṃ catusamuṭṭhānika rūpānaṃ sakalakhandhapañcakasseva vā issaro hoti. Aññathā
analyzed: pavattiyam catu samuṭṭhānika rūpānam sakala khandha pañcakassa iva vā issaraḥ hoti aññathā
translated: They are masters in the sense of sovereignty over the occurrence of the five aggregates in their several modes of being.

original: appavattito. Tathā hi yasmiṃ santāne paṭisandhiyaṃ itthibhāvo pavattati. Tasmiṃ sabbe
analyzed: appavattitaḥ tathā hi yasmin santāne paṭisandhiyam itthi bhāvaḥ pavattati tasmim sabbe

analyzed: kamma ādi paccayā catu samuṭṭhāna rūpa santatim samuṭṭhāpentāḥ itthākāra sahitam eva samuṭṭhāpenti  no aññathā chanda citta adhippāya api tasmin manda ākāra sahitā ava pavattanti tad biparītena  purisa santānam veditabbam jīvita dvayam rūpā rūpa santatīnam ratti diva māsa saṃvacchara anukkamena
translated: for it is thus: in the continuity in which the female sex occurs, all the conditions for it, namely, kamma, etc., generate the continuity of the four-fold-originated material instances together with the female sex,

original: addhānapharaṇe sahajātadhammānaṃ issaro hoti. Tesaṃ tadāyattavutti kattā. Mano vijānanakicce.🔽Vedanāpañcakaṃ tathā tathā ārammaṇarasānubhavane. Saddhā ārammaṇāvīmuccane. Vīriyaṃ
analyzed: addhāna pharaṇe sahajāta dhammānam issaraḥ hoti tesam tad āyatta vutti kattā manaḥ vijānana kicce  vedanā pañcakam tathā tathā ārammaṇa rasa anubhavane saddhā ārammaṇa avīmuccane vīriyam
translated: not otherwise. And the volition, consciousness, and mental factors occur there accompanied by the weak form of the female sex. The opposite should be understood in the case of the male continuity. The two kinds of life faculty are the lords of the occurrence of the material instances in the material continuities in the course of time, by day and by night, by month and by year. They are the makers of those material instances, for they are their support. Mind is the lord of the occurrence of the associated mental phenomena in the course of the cognitive series.

original: kammani alīna vuttibhāve. Sati ārammaṇupaṭṭhāne. Samādhi ārammaṇe niccalaṭṭhi tiyaṃ.
analyzed: kammani alīna vutti bhāve sati ārammaṇupaṭṭhāne samādhi ārammaṇe niccalaṭṭhi tiyaṃ
translated: The five beginning with feeling are the lords of the experiencing of the object in such and such a way. Faith is the lord of the manifestation of the object. Energy is the lord of the non- slackening of the work. Mindfulness is the lord of the object’s remaining before the mind. Concentration is the lord of the object’s remaining steady.

original: Paññā asammohakicce sampayuttadhammānaṃ issaro hoti. Anaññābhibhavanīyabhāvena pavattanato.
analyzed: paññā asammoha kicce sampayutta dhammānam issaraḥ hoti anañña abhibhavanīya bhāvena pavattanato
translated: Understanding is the master of the associated states in the function of non-delusion. Because it occurs in such a way that it is not outshone by anything else.

original: Yathā hi silāyaṃ pathavī sahajātehi anabhibhavanīyā hoti. Attanāvate abhibhavitvā
analyzed: yathā hi silāyam pathavī sahajātehi an abhibhavanīyā hoti attanāvate abhibhavitvā
translated: Just as the earth is not outshone by the things that are born together with it, but it itself outshines them,

original: visuṃ avijjamāneviya katvā pavattati. Yathā ca udake āpo aggimhi tejo vāte vāyo.
analyzed: visum katvā pavattati yathā ca udake āpaḥ aggimhi tejaḥ vāte vāyo
translated: and occurs in such a way that they are as if non-existent in separation from it. And just as the water in the fire, the heat in the air,

original: Evaṃ sampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam sampadam idam daṭṭhabbam
translated: should be regarded in the same way.🔽The four noble truths, the state of deathlessness,

original: Aññāyittha paṭivijjhitthāti aññātaṃ. Na aññātaṃ anaññātaṃ. Catusaccadhammo. Amataṃvā🔽padaṃ. Anaññātaṃ ñassāmi jānissāmīti anaññātaññassāmi. Ākhyātikaṃpi hi padaṃ saññāsaddabhāve
analyzed: aññāyittha paṭivijjhittha ati aññātam na aññātam an aññātam catu sacca dhammaḥ amatam vā  padam an aññātam ñassāmi jānissāmi iti an aññāta ñassāmi ākhyātikaṃpi hi padam saññā sadda bhāve
translated: are not known. What is not known is to be known. The word “known” is a noun formed from the verbal adjective “known” .🔽For a noun formed from a verbal adjective remains in the place of the verbal adjective,

original: ṭhitaṃ nāmikaṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati. Yathā makkhaligosālo ehipassi koti. Evañhi sati tassa
analyzed: ṭhitam nāmika ṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati yathā makkhali gosālo ehipassi evam hi sati tassa
translated: just as the words “cow-pen” and “elephant-stable” remain in the place of the adjectives “having cows” and “having elephants.” If it were otherwise,🔽the compound would not be resolved in the way beginning, “The known is being known” .

original: padantarena saha samāsabhāvo navirujjhatīti. Anaññātaññassāmīti evaṃ paṭipannassa
analyzed: pada antarena saha samāsa bhāvaḥ na virujjhati iti evam paṭipannassa
translated: The meaning of the words of the phrase “I shall make the unknown known” is this:

original: indriyaṃ anaññā taññassāmītindriyaṃ. Ādimanasikārato paṭṭhāya tādisena ussāhena saha
analyzed: indriyam anaññā taññassāmi iti indriyam ādi manasikārato paṭṭhāya tādisena ussāhena saha
translated: From the time of the first adverting, one who begins insight with such a keenness of energy as this,

original: vipassanaṃ ārabhantassa tasmiṃ ussāhe apaṭipassaddheyeva sotāmattimaggaṃ paṭilabhantassa
analyzed: vipassanam ārabhantassa tasmin ussāhe a paṭipassaddheya iva sotāmatti maggam paṭilabhantassa
translated: and who reaches the path of stream-entry while that keenness is unabated,🔽has a faculty that is called “the faculty of final knowledge.”

original: indriyanti vuttaṃ hoti. Ājānātīti aññaṃ. Tameva indriyanti aññindriyaṃ, pathamamaggena
analyzed: indriyam ti vuttam hoti ājānāti iti aññam tam eva indriyan ti aññindriyam pathama maggena
translated: “One who knows” is one who has known. “That” is the same as the “final knowledge.” “The faculty” is the faculty of one who has known.

original: anaññātaṃ ñatvāpi kilesappahānakiccassa apariniṭṭhitattā tassa jānanakiccassa vippakatabhāvena
analyzed: anaññātam ñatvā api kilesa ppahāna kiccassa a pariniṭṭhita ttā tassa jānana kiccassa vippakata bhāvena
translated: Though he has known what was previously unknown by means of the first path, still, because the function of abandoning defilements is not yet completed, the function of knowing is still unfinished.

original: yathā diṭṭhe tasmiṃ catusaccadhamme amatapadeeva vā punappunaṃ jānanakicca yuttānaṃ🔽indriyanti vuttaṃ hoti. Aññātāvindriyanti aññā tāvino pariniṭṭhita ājānana kiccassa
analyzed: yathā diṭṭhe tasmin catu sacca dhamme amata pade eva vā punappunam  indriyanti vuttam hoti aññātāvindriyam ti pariniṭṭhita ājānana kiccassa
translated: And so it is said that he has a faculty that is fit for the repeated performance of the function of knowing the four truths as they have been seen.🔽The faculty of final knowledge is the faculty of one whose final knowledge is complete, whose function of knowing is finished.

original: khīṇāsavassa indriyanti aññātāvindriyaṃ. Tividhaṃ petaṃ tathārūpe jānane sampayutta
analyzed: khīṇāsavassa indriyanti aññātāvindriyam tividham tathārūpe jānane sampayutta
translated: It is the faculty of one whose cankers are destroyed. It is called the faculty of final knowledge.

original: dhammānaṃ issaro hotīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: dhammānam issaraḥ hoti iti veditabbam
translated: It should be understood that it is the master faculty in the knowing of that kind associated with the four truths.

original: Tattha imesaṃ sattānaṃ pākaṭe rūpakāye attagāhadaḷhattaṃ tabbimuttica imesaṃ apariññāya
analyzed: tattha imesam sattānam pākaṭe rūpa kāye atta gāha daḷha ttam imesam a pariññāya
translated: Herein, the gross physical body is evident to these beings, and they are confirmed in the selfhood of that. They do not fully understand🔽

original: pariññāyaca hotīti dīpetuṃ ādito pañca pasādindriyāni vuttāni. Tassa attassa itthipuma🔽tābhedo imesaṃ vasena hoti. Tasmiṃ vā itthipurisa gāho tabbimuttica imesaṃ apariññāya
analyzed: pariññāya ca hoti iti dīpetum āditas pañca pasāda indriyāni vuttāni tassa attassa  imesam vasena hoti tasmin vā itthi purisa gāho imesam a pariññāya
translated: Herein, the five faculties of confidence, etc., are mentioned first in order to show that the self is not fully understood and is fully understood without clinging to the visible-form body of these beings as the self.

original: pariññāyaca hotīti dīpetuṃ kadanantaraṃ bhāvindriyadvayaṃ vuttaṃ. Soca attā imassa🔽vasena jīvasaññaṃ labhati. Tasmiṃvā jīvagāho tabbimuttica imassa apariññāya pariññāyaca
analyzed: pariññāya ca hoti iti dīpetum bhāvindriya dvayam vuttam so ca attā imassa  vasena jīva saññam labhati tasmin vā jīva gāhaḥ tad vimutti ca imassa a pariññāya pariññāya ca
translated: The distinction of the self as female or male is by means of these . Or in order to show that the self is not fully understood and is fully understood without clinging to the apprehension of female or male as the self, the two faculties of femininity and masculinity are mentioned next.

original: hotīti dīpetuṃ tadanantaraṃ jīvitindriyaṃ vuttaṃ. Idaṃ pana bhāvindriyato pure vattabbaṃpi
analyzed: hoti iti dīpetum tad anantaram jīvitindriyam vuttam idam pana bhāvindriyato pure vattabbam api
translated: And the self obtains the concept of “living being” by means of this . Or in order to show that the self is not fully understood and is fully understood without clinging to the apprehension of living being as the self, the faculty of life is mentioned next.

original: rūpārūpa missakattā idha vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Nāmakāye attagāhadaḷhattaṃ tabbimuttica
analyzed: rūpa arūpa missaka ttā idha vutta nti daṭṭhabbam nāmakāye atta gāha daḷha ttam tad vimutti ca
translated: But this should be mentioned before the two faculties of femininity and masculinity. It is mentioned here because of the mixture of the material and immaterial .

original: imassa apariññāya pariññāyaca hotīti dīpetuṃ nāmindriyesu manindriyaṃ ādito vuttaṃ.
analyzed: imassa a pariññāya pariññāya ca hoti iti dīpetum nāma indriyesu manindriyam āditas vuttam
translated: In order to show that the self is not fully understood and is fully understood without clinging to the apprehension of the self as the self in the mental body, the mind faculty is mentioned first among the mental faculties.

analyzed: saḥ ca arūpī attā imesam vasena saṃkiliṭṭhaḥ vipphanditaḥ ca hoti tasmin vā sukhita dukkhita gāhaḥ  tad bimutti ca imesam a pariññāya pariññāya ca hoti iti dīpetum tad anantaram pedan indriya pañcakam  vuttam tassa saṃkiliṭṭhassa vodāna ppattiyā taṃ taṃgāha vimuttiyā vā paṭipatti dassana ttham
translated: and the self is defiled and agitated by these.🔽And the non-penetration and penetration of these is shown by the next two sets of five faculties, the faculties of sorrow and of equanimity, respectively.

original: tadanantaraṃ saddhādipañcindriyaṃ vuttaṃ. Tāya paṭipattiyā vodānappatti yā ādi majjha
analyzed: tad anantaram saddhā ādi pañcindriyam vuttam tāya paṭipattiyā vodāna ppatti yā ādi majjha
translated: The next five faculties, beginning with faith, are stated in order to show the practice for the attainment of purification of the defiled self, and for the liberation of the self from the aforesaid two sets of five faculties.

original: pariyosāna dassanatthaṃ ante tīṇi lokuttarindriyāni vuttānīti.
analyzed: pariyosāna dassana attham ante tīṇi lokuttara indriyāni vuttāni iti
translated: The last three supramundane faculties are stated in order to show the beginning, middle, and end of the practice.

translated: But in the Vibhanga,

analyzed: tesam aññesam bhagavataḥ therassa ca yuttam vattum indriya bhāva arahassa

analyzed: paññābalam nāma sesa duka dvayam pana aññam aññam paṭipakkhena yojetabbam
translated: The power of wisdom is the opposite of the opposite of the power of faith, and so on. The remaining two pairs of powers should be construed as the opposite of the opposite of each other.

original: [213] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana🔽Pāpabaladukaṃ paṭipakkhena yojetuṃ nalabbhatīti katvā “ahirikānottappadvayaṃ pana sampayuttadhammesu thirabhāve nevāti” vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundaraṃ.

translated: But in the Vibhaṅga,🔽“The two powers of non-remorse and of calm are not to be construed as the opposite of the opposite of the two powers of energy and of concentration” . That is not good.

original: Sampayuttadhammesu thirabhāvotica paṭipakkhehi akampiyatā tica atthato nānattābhāvatoti.

translated: For the meaning of “not to be construed as the opposite of the opposite” is “not to be construed as the opposite of the opposite in the sense of being the opposite of the opposite of the opposite of the opposite,” and the meaning of “not to be construed as the opposite of the opposite” is “not to be construed as the opposite of the opposite in the sense of being the opposite of the opposite of the opposite of the opposite.”

original: Vīriyasamādhibalāni kusalākusalābyākatāni. Ahirikānottappāni akusalabalāni. Sesāni🔽kusalābyākatānīti. Adhipatīti ettha patīti sāmi issaro. So pana padesa issaro sakalissaroti🔽duvidho. Tattha indriyāni paresaṃ visaye sayaṃ paravase vattitvā attano visayeeva
analyzed: vīriya samādhi balāni kusala akusala abyākatāni ahirika anottappāni akusala balāni sesāni  kusala abyākatāni iti adhipati iti ettha pati iti sāmi issaro so pana padesa issaro sakalissaro ti  duvidhaḥ tattha indriyāni paresam visaye sayam para vase vattitvā attanaḥ visaye eva
translated: The powers of energy, concentration, and wisdom are profitable, unprofitable, and indeterminate. The powers of non-remorse and of calm are profitable only. The remaining powers are profitable and indeterminate.🔽As to predominance: a lord is a master, a ruler. He is twofold as partial lord and complete lord.🔽Herein, the faculties are called partial lords because, having themselves come under the influence of others in the object of others, they make others come under their own influence in their own object.

original: parehi attano vase vattāpentīti padesissarā nāma. Pubbāti saṅkhāravasena pubbāgamanavasena
analyzed: parehi attanaḥ vase vattāpenti iti padesissarā nāma pubbā ti saṅkhāra vasena pubba āgamana vasena
translated: The roots are called complete lords because they are the cause of the arising of the things they create.

original: vā visesetvā pavattaṃ adhipatiṭṭhānaṃ patvā pana añño dutiyo issaronāma natthi. Tasmā
analyzed: vā visesetvā pavattam adhipati ṭhānam patvā pana aññaḥ dutiyaḥ issaro nāma natthi tasmā
translated: But when it has reached the position of predominance, there is no other second one called ‘lord.’🔽So it is ‘the lord of the lords of what is governed by the self,’

original: adhiko patīti adhipati. Attā dhīnavuttīnaṃ patīti adhipatītica vadanti.

original: Tattha yathā yavabījānaṃvā sālibījānaṃvā ānubhāvo nāma kaḷiraṅkurānaṃ uppādāna padhānaṃ🔽hoti. Tatoparaṃ pana sassabhāvaṃ patvā cha pañca māse vaḍḍhiyāvā ṭhitiyāvā pathavi🔽rasaāporasānaṃ ānubhāvo padhānaṃ hoti. Evamevaṃ kabaḷī kārāhārūpajīvīnaṃ kāmasattānaṃ🔽kammassa ānubhāvonāma paṭisandhirūpuppādane padhānaṃ hoti. Tatoparaṃ pana yāvatāyukaṃ🔽vaḍḍhīyāvāṭhitiyāvā utuāhārānaṃ ānubhāvo padhānaṃ hoti. Kammajarūpāni hi yāva āsannamaraṇā🔽pavattamānānipi utuāhārehi anuggahitānieva pavattanti. Utuca āhāru patthambhitoyeva
analyzed: tattha yathā yava bījānam vā sāli bījānam vā ānubhāvaḥ nāma uppādāna padhānam  hoti tatas uparam pana sassa bhāvam patvā cha pañca māse vaḍḍhiyāvā ṭhitiyāvā pathavi  padhānam hoti evam evam kabaḷī kārā hārūpa jīvīnam kāma sattānam  kammassa ānubhāvaḥ nāma paṭisandhiḥ ūpa uppādane padhānam hoti tatoparam pana yāvatāyukam  padhānam hoti kamma ja rūpāni hi yāvaḥ āsanna maraṇā  pavattamānāni pi utu āhārehi anuggahitāni eva pavattanti
translated: Herein, just as the potency of barley seeds or rice seeds, etc., is the cause of the arising of the barley sprouts, etc., and is the condition for their growth,🔽but after that the potency of the earth, etc., is the cause of their growth and maintenance for four or five months until they reach maturity,🔽so too, in the case of creatures who subsist on physical food, the potency of kamma is the cause of the arising of the rebirth-linking physical heart-basis and is the condition for its growth,🔽but after that the potency of temperature and nutriment is the cause of its growth and maintenance for as long as life lasts. For the kinds of materiality originated by kamma continue to occur even when they are assisted by temperature and nutriment, which are present near to them,🔽but they do not occur when these are absent, even though the kamma is present. And temperature and nutriment assist only the kinds of materiality originated by kamma, not those originated by temperature, etc.,

original: attano kiccaṃ karoti. Tasmā tesaṃ sattānaṃ catusantatirūpaṃ kabaḷīkārāhārena anupatthambhīyamānaṃ🔽ciraṃ napavattati. Upatthambhīyamānaṃeva yāvatāyukaṃ pavattati. Yathāca sakuṇāvā
analyzed: attano kiccam karoti tasmā tesam sattānam catu santati rūpam kabaḷīkāra āhārena an upatthambhīyamānam 🔽ciram na pavattati upatthambhīyamānam eva yāvatā āyukam pavattati yathā ca sakuṇāvā
translated: Herein, just as the potency of barley seeds or rice seeds is the cause of the production of the barley shoots or rice shoots, and after that the potency of the earth-essence and the water-essence is the cause of their growth and maintenance, so too, in the case of creatures who subsist on physical food, the potency of kamma is the cause of the production of the rebirth-linking physical basis, and after that the potency of temperature and nutriment is the cause of its growth and maintenance. For the kamma-born materiality continues to occur as long as death is near without being helped by temperature and nutriment. Temperature and nutriment perform their function only by consolidating it. Consequently, the materiality of the fourfold continuity of these creatures does not occur long without being consolidated by physical food. It occurs as long as life lasts only when consolidated. And just as, when a bird has flown a long distance, its return is dependent on its alighting-place, so too, the return of these creatures’ consciousness is dependent on the physical basis consolidated by physical food.

original: ḍaṃsamakasā dayovā tuṇḍena āhāraṃ gahetvā attabhāvaṃ posenti. Tuṇḍe asante āhāraṃ

translated: The day-owls, when they have no claws, cannot catch their prey with their beaks and so

And when craving is deprived of the opportunity to grow by the absence of the function of feeling,

original: upabhogaparibhogaṃ sampādetvā taṇhāvepullaṃ patvā tividhaṃ vaṭṭaṃ pūretvā yāvajjatanāpi🔽vaṭṭe anukaṇṭhamānā pavattanti.
analyzed: upabhoga paribhogam sampādetvā taṇhā vepullam patvā tividham vaṭṭam pūretvā yāvat jatana api  vaṭṭe anukaṇṭhamānā pavattanti
translated: the round of rebirths, which is filled by the three kinds of craving, is broken, and beings proceed to the destruction of suffering.

analyzed: yadi hi phassaḥ nāma na siyā ārammaṇa rasam a labhitvā vedanā paribhoga rahitena taṇhā uppattiyā  okāsaḥ natthi iti tividha vaṭṭam eva nasiyā ati yathā ca te sakuṇa ādayo pakkhe viyūhitvā
translated: For if there were no contact called “feeling,” craving would not arise because there would be no opportunity for it to do so when there is no experience of the object’s taste.🔽And just as those birds, etc., after stretching out their wings,
