analyzed: antarā a patamānāḥ rukkhataḥ rukkham vanataḥ vanam vicaritvā attānam yāpenti pakkhesu
translated: proceed from tree to tree, from wood to wood, without falling in between, and so maintain themselves, but when their wings are cut off they cannot go and fall down to be killed,

original: asantesu gamanaṃ asampādentā patitvā maranti. Evamevaṃ ime sattā āyūhanalakkhaṇāya
analyzed: asantesu gamanam patitvā maranti evam evam ime sattā āyūhana lakkhaṇāya
translated: so too, these beings, when they have the characteristic of accumulation,

original: cetanāya cetayitvā kammasamaṅgitaṃ sampādetvā bhavato bhavaṃ vicaritvā yāvajjatanā🔽vaṭṭe saṃsaranti. Yadi hi cetanānāma na siyā, kammavaṭṭassa abhāvo. Tadabhāveca vipākavaṭṭassa
analyzed: cetanāya cetayitvā kamma samaṅgitam sampādetvā bhavataḥ bhavam vicaritvā yāvajjatanā  vaṭṭe saṃsaranti yadi hi cetanā nāma na siyā kamma vaṭṭassa abhāvo tad abhāve ca vipāka vaṭṭassa
translated: and after they have completed the act of volition, they pass on from existence to existence,

original: abhāvo. Tadabhāveca tadanusayitassa kilesavaṭṭassa abhāvoti vaṭṭaṃnāma na siyāti.
analyzed: abhāvo tad abhāve ca tad anusayitassa kilesa vaṭṭassa abhāvo ti vaṭṭam nāma na siyāti
translated: and revolve in the round of rebirths as long as the world lasts. If there were no volition, there would be no round of kamma. And if there were no round of kamma, there would be no round of kamma-result. And if there were no round of kamma-result, there would be no round of defilements that underlie the round of kamma-result. Thus the round would not exist.

original: Yathāca te sakuṇādayo cakkhunā gocaraṭṭhānaṃvā taṃtaṃdisābhāgaṃvā vibhāvetvā yāvajīvaṃ🔽attānaṃ yāpenti. Cakkhusmiṃ asante kiñcigahetabbavatthuṃvā gantabbaṭṭhānaṃvā alabhitvā
analyzed: yathā ca te sakuṇa ādayo cakkhunā gocara ṭṭhānam vā taṃ taṃ disā bhāgam vā vibhāvetvā yāvajīvam  attānam yāpenti cakkhusmiṃ a sante kiñci gahetabba vatthum vā gantabba ṭṭhānam vā a labhitvā
translated: And just as those birds, etc., having discerned by means of the eye the place where there is food or the direction in which it lies, maintain themselves there for the rest of their lives,

original: tattheva maranti. Evamevaṃ sampayuttā dhammā ārammaṇavijānalakkhaṇena viññāṇena taṃtaṃārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: tattha iva maranti evam evam sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ ārammaṇa vijāna lakkhaṇena viññāṇena tat tat ārammaṇam
translated: and when the eye is absent they do not get anything to eat or a place to go to, and so they die right there, so too, the associated states, having obtained their object by means of consciousness, which has the characteristic of seeing the object,

original: labhitvā tasmiṃ tasmiṃ phassādayo uppādetvā tividhaṃ vaṭṭaṃ vaṭṭenti. Yadi hi viññāṇaṃnāma
analyzed: labhitvā tasmin tasmin phassa ādayaḥ uppādetvā tividham vaṭṭam vaṭṭenti yadi hi viññāṇaṃ nāma
translated: and having given rise to contact, etc., in that object, set the round going in the three planes. If there were no consciousness,

original: na siyā, phassādīnaṃ ārammaṇalābhoyeva natthīti vaṭṭameva na siyāti. Tenāha cattāro
analyzed: na siyā phassa ādīnam ārammaṇa lābho yeva natthi iti vaṭṭam eva na siyā ti tena āha cattāro
translated: and it would not be so, because there would be no obtaining of object by contact, etc., and so the round would not be so either. Hence he said:🔽“The four nutriments. Consciousness is the fourth.”

original: āhārā.La. Viññāṇaṃ catutthanti. Saṃyuttakeca –
analyzed: viññāṇam catutthan ti saṃyuttake ca
translated: And in the Saṃyutta Nikāya:

original: Cattārome bhikkhave āhārā bhūtānaṃ vā sattānaṃ ṭhitiyā sambhavesīnaṃvā sattānaṃ anuggahāya
analyzed: cattāraḥ me bhikkhave āhārāḥ bhūtānam vā sattānam ṭhitiyā sambhavesīnam vā sattānam anuggahāya
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these four nutriments for the maintenance of beings that have already come to be and for the assistance of those about to come to be.

original: kabaḷīkāro āhāro oḷārikovā sukhumovā, phasso dutīyo, manosañcetanā tatīyā, viññāṇaṃ catutthanti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ oḷārikaḥ vā sukhumaḥ vā phassaḥ dutīyaḥ manaḥ sañcetanā tatīyā viññāṇam catuttham ti vuttam
translated: Physical food as nutriment, gross or subtle; contact as the second; mental volition as the third; and consciousness as the fourth.”

original: Tattha bhūtānanti vuddhippattānaṃ. Sambhavesīnanti kalalādi kāle ṭhitānaṃ. Catunnaṃpana🔽āhārānaṃ yathāsambhavaṃ anamatagge saṃsāravaṭṭevā tasmiṃ tasmiṃ bhavevā ṭhitiyāvā
analyzed: tattha bhūtānam ti vuddhi pattānam kalala ādi kāle ṭhitānam catunnam pana  yathāsambhavam tasmin tasmin
translated: Herein, “beings that have already come to be” are those that have reached growth. “Those about to come to be” are those that are in the state of the kalala, etc.🔽The occurrence, the mode, of the four nutriments should be understood as follows: in the round of rebirths without distinction of beginning or end, in each becoming, for the maintenance of those that have already come to be and for the assistance of those about to come to be.

original: anuggahāyavā pavatti ākāro vuttanayena veditabbo. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana kopanettha āhāro.
analyzed: pavatti ākāraḥ vutta nayena veditabbaḥ aṭṭhakathāyam pana kopanā ittha āhāro
translated: But in the Commentary it is said: “Herein, nutriment is nutriment.

original: Kiṃ āhāretīti. Kabaḷīkārā hāro ojaṭṭhamakarūpāni āhāreti. Phassāhāro tisso vedanā.
analyzed: kim āhāreti iti kabaḷīkārāḥ hāro ojaṭṭha maka rūpāni āhāreti phassa āhāro tissaḥ vedanā
translated: What does it nutrify? It nutrifies the material septad of nutritive essence. Contact nutriment nutrifies the three kinds of feeling.

original: Manosañcetanāhāro tayo bhave. Viññāṇā hāro paṭisandhināmarūpanti vuttaṃ. Taṃ pākaṭaphalavasena🔽vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ojaṭṭhamakarūpuppādanaṃ pana kabaḷīkārāhārassa mahantaṃ kiccaṃ
analyzed: manaḥ sañcetanā āhāro tayaḥ bhave viññāṇā hāro paṭisandhi nāma rūpan ti vuttam tam pākaṭa phala vasena  vuttanti daṭṭhabbam ojaṭṭha maka rūpa uppādanam pana kabaḷīkāra āhārassa mahantam kiccam
translated: The nutriment mental volition is the nutriment of the three kinds of becoming. The nutriment consciousness is the nutriment of rebirth-linking and the first two kinds of mentality-materiality. This is how the nutriments should be understood.

original: nahoti. Catusantatirūpupatthambhanameva mahantaṃ. Teneva hi pāḷiyaṃ ṭhitiyātica anuggahāyātica vuttaṃ.
analyzed: catu santati rūpa upatthambhanam eva mahantam tena iva hi pāḷiyam ṭhitiyā ati ca anuggahāya ati ca vuttam
translated: But the generation of the materiality of the octad consisting of the physical basis and the physical heart-basis is not the great function of the nutriment physical food. The great function is the consolidating of the fourfold continuity of materiality. That is why it is said in the text, “For the maintenance of those that exist and for the support of those seeking a base” .

original: Apica yathā upanissayāsevanapaccayā suttanti kapariyāyā abhidhammapariyāyātica duvidhā
analyzed: apica yathā upanissaya āsevana paccayā suttanti ka pariyāyā abhidhamma pariyāyā ati ca duvidhā
translated: Moreover, just as the conditions of decisive support and repetition are twofold as the suttas’ method and the Abhidhamma method,

original: honti. Tathā āhārapaccayopi duvidho. Tattha yaṃ vuttaṃ manosañcetanāhāro tayobhaveti.🔽Taṃ suttantikapariyāyaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Nahi paṭṭhāne arūpā hārā asahajātānaṃ dhammānaṃ
analyzed: honti tathā āhāra paccayaḥ api duvidhaḥ tattha yam vuttam manaḥ sañcetanā āhāro  tam suttantika pariyāyam sandhāya vuttam nahi paṭṭhāne arūpāḥ hārāḥ asahajātānam dhammānam
translated: so too the condition of nutriment is twofold. Herein, it is said that the nutriment mental volition is the nutriment of the three kinds of becoming.🔽This is said with reference to the method of the suttas. For in the Abhidhamma method the nutriments of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants are not conditions by way of nutriment condition for the states associated with and arising simultaneously with them.

original: āhāraṭṭhena paccayānāma hontīti. Pañcaviññāṇesu jhānaṅgāni nalabbhanti. Tāni hi dubbalakiccaṭṭhānavatthukattā
analyzed: āhāra aṭṭhena paccayā nāma honti iti pañca viññāṇesu jhāna aṅgāni na labbhanti tāni hi dubbala kicca ṭṭhāna vatthuka ttā
translated: The jhāna factors are not found among the five consciousnesses, because they are weak in function, and because their function is to be a basis.

original: rūpādīsu abhinipātamattāni hontīti na tesu vijjamānā vedanā ekaggatā jhānakiccaṃ
analyzed: rūpa ādīsu abhinipāta mattāni honti iti na tesu vijjamānā vedanā ekagga tā jhāna kiccam
translated: They are only the mere falling on to visible data, etc., and so the unification of cognizance and feeling that exist there do not fulfil the function of jhāna.🔽So it is said that it is the last of the applied thoughts that is jhāna.

original: sādhentīti. Vitakkapacchimakaṃ jhānantica vuttaṃ. Jhānaṅgānaṃ nāyakabhūtoca vitakko
analyzed: sādhenti iti vitakka pacchimakam jhānan ti ca vuttam jhāna aṅgānam nāyaka bhūtaḥ ca vitakko
translated: And since applied thought is the leader of the jhāna factors,

original: tesu natthīti tattha tāvedanā ekaggatāyo taṃ na sādhentīti. Vīriyupatthambharahitā🔽dhammā sampayuttadhammesu thirabhāvappattā nahontīti avīriyesu soḷasāhetukacittesu
analyzed: tesu natthi iti tattha tā vedanā ekagga tāyaḥ tam na sādhenti iti vīriya upatthambha rahitā  dhammā sampayutta dhammesu thira bhāva pattāḥ na honti iti a vīriyesu soḷasa ahetuka cittesu
translated: the unification of cognizance and feeling there do not fulfil that.🔽And since dhammas without energy have not reached firmness in the associated dhammas,

original: samādhibalakiccaṃ na sādheti. Vīriyapacchimakaṃ balanti hi vuttanti āha avīriyesu🔽balāni nalabbhantīti. Heturahitā ca dhammā vaṭṭassa vivaṭṭassaca pattiyā pathabhāvaṃ
analyzed: samādhi bala kiccam na sādheti vīriya pacchimakam balanti hi vuttanti āha a vīriyesu  balāni na labbhanti iti hetu rahitā ca dhammā vaṭṭassa vivaṭṭassa ca pattiyā patha bhāvam
translated: concentration does not fulfil its function of strength in the sixteen unprofitable consciousnesses without root-cause.🔽So it is said that it is the last of the energies that is strength.🔽And since dhammas without root-cause do not become the path to the revolution from the round,

original: nagacchanti. Hetupacchimako maggoti hi vuttanti āha ahetukesu maggaṅgāni na labbhantīti.
analyzed: na gacchanti hetu pacchimakaḥ maggaḥ ti hi vuttanti āha ahetukesu maggaṅgāni na labbhanti iti
translated: the path factors do not exist in the root-causeless consciousnesses.

original: Vicikicchāsampayuttecitte ekaggatā adhimokkharahi tattā ekantena saṃsappanasabhāvāya
analyzed: vicikicchā sampayutte citte ekagga tā adhimokkha rahi tattā ekantena saṃsappana sabhāvāya
translated: And since unification of cognizance in consciousness associated with doubt is wholly of the nature of vacillation because it lacks sure confidence,

original: vicikicchāya abhibhūtattā ca maggindriyabalabhāvāya balavatī nahotīti vuttaṃ vicikicchā
analyzed: vicikicchāya abhibhūta ttā ca maggindriya bala bhāvāya balavatī nahoti iti vuttam vicikicchā
translated: And because of being overcome by doubt, it is said that it does not become strong for the state of the path, the faculties, and the powers.🔽One-pointedness of mind does not go to the state of the path, the faculties, and the powers.

original: citte ekaggatā maggindriyabalabhāvaṃ na gacchatīti. Dvihetuka tihetuka javanesvevāti
analyzed: citte ekagga tā maggindriya bala bhāvam na gacchati iti dvi hetuka ti hetuka javanesu eva ati
translated: In the cases of the two-rooted and three-rooted javanas,

original: ettha dvihetuka tihetukasaddena momūhadvayahasanajavanāni nivatteti. Javanasaddena
analyzed: ettha dvi hetuka ti hetuka saddena momūha dvaya hasana javanāni nivattā iti javana saddena
translated: here, by the words “two-rooted” and “three-rooted,” the javanas of delusion, the two kinds of shamelessness, and laughter are excluded. By the word “javana,”

original: tibhūmakāni dvihetukatihetukavipākāni nivatteti.
analyzed: ti bhūmakāni dvi hetuka ti hetuka vipākāni
translated: the two-rooted and three-rooted resultants of the three planes are excluded.

original: [214] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī,

original: “Dvihetukatihetukagahaṇena ekahetukesu adhipatīnaṃ abhāvaṃ dassetī”ti vuttaṃ, javanabhāvasāmaññattā pana hasanacittepi tesaṃ abhāvo dassetabboyeva hotīti.
analyzed: dvi hetuka ti hetuka gahaṇena eka hetukesu adhipatīnam abhāvam dasseti iti vuttam javana bhāva sāmañña ttā pana hasana citte pi tesam abhāvaḥ dassetabbaḥ yeva hoti iti
translated: it is said: “By mentioning the two-rooted and three-rooted, the absence of the dominants in the one-rooted is shown.” But because of the similarity of javana state, the absence of those in the mind of laughter should be shown too.

original: Yathāsambhavanti laddhapubbāti saṅkhārassa laddhapubbāgamassa ca ekekassa adhipatino
analyzed: yathā sambhavanti laddha pubbā ati saṅkhārassa laddha pubba āgamassa ca ekekassa adhipatino
translated: According to what is possible: the dominants of the formations that have gone before and that are to come are one each.

original: sambhavānurūpaṃ ekova labbhati. Na dutiyo. Itarathā adhipatieva nasiyāti. Evañca
analyzed: sambhava anurūpam ekaḥ iva labbhati na dutiyaḥ itarathā evam ca
translated: One is obtained according to what is possible. Not a second. Otherwise, it would not be a dominant.

original: katvā paṭṭhāne yathā indriyapaccayavibhaṅge arūpinoindriyā sampayuttakānaṃdhammānaṃ
analyzed: katvā paṭṭhāne yathā indriya paccaya vibhaṅge arūpino indriyā sampayuttakānam dhammānam
translated: Having done so, in the exposition, as in the analysis of conditions by way of faculties, the immaterial faculties are of the associated states,

original: taṃsamuṭṭhānānañca rūpānaṃ indriyapaccayena paccayoti vuttaṃ. Na tathā adhipatipaccayavibhaṅge.
analyzed: tad samuṭṭhānānaṃ ca rūpānaṃ indriya paccayena paccayaḥ ti vuttam na tathā adhipati paccaya vibhaṅge
translated: In the exposition of the faculties as conditions, however, it is said: “The immaterial faculties are a condition, as faculty condition, for the states associated with the faculties and for the kinds of materiality originated thereby” . But it is not said in the exposition of predominance conditions.

original: Tattha pana chandādhipati chandasampayuttakānantiādinā ekekādhipati vibhāgavaseneva
analyzed: tattha pana chanda adhipati chanda sampayuttaka ananti ādinā ekeka adhipati vibhāga vasena iva
translated: And there it is said by way of the individual predominance of each faculty, thus: “Predominance of zeal is a condition, as predominance condition, for states associated with zeal” , etc.🔽For in this way the difference between the faculties and the predominance conditions becomes evident.

original: vuttanti. Evañhi sati adhipati indriyānaṃ viseso pākaṭo hotīti. Naveritāti nava īritā
analyzed: vuttam ti evam hi sati adhipati indriyānam visesaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti iti navā īritā ati navaḥ īritā
translated: “Ninefold” : ninefold in the sense of being taught,

original: kathitā. Kusalā kusalā byākatehi samākiṇṇo kusalādi samākiṇṇo. [Missakasaṅgaho]🔽164. Cattāri saccāni bujjhatīti bodhi. Bujjhantivā tāni taṃ samaṅgino etāyāti bodhi.🔽Catumaggañāṇaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ mahā niddese bodhi vuccati catūsu maggesu-ñāṇanti. Pakkhoti
analyzed: kathitā kusalā kusalā byākatehi samākiṇṇaḥ kusala ādi samākiṇṇaḥ missaka saṅgaho  cattāri saccāni bujjhati iti bodhi tāni tam samaṅginaḥ etāya ati bodhi  catu magga ñāṇam vuttam ha etam mahā niddese bodhi vuccati catūsu maggesu ñāṇam ti pakkhaḥ ti
translated: “Mixed with the wholesome and the unwholesome” : mixed with the wholesome, etc.🔽“Enlightenment” : enlightenment is the act of knowing the four truths. Or alternatively, it is the act of knowing the four paths.🔽“Factors of enlightenment” : they are factors of enlightenment because they exist for the purpose of enlightenment. They are the seven path factors of the four paths.

original: koṭṭhāso sambhāro. Bodhiyā pakkhe bhavāti bodhipakkhiyā. Adhisīlā dhicittā dhipaññā
analyzed: koṭṭhāsaḥ sambhāraḥ bodhiyā pakkhe bhavāti bodhi pakkhiyā adhi sīlā dhi cittā dhi paññā
translated: “High virtue, high concentration, high wisdom” :

original: saṅkhātāsu tīsu sikkhāsu pariyāpannānaṃ satthusāsanadhammānaṃ etaṃnāmaṃ. Te pana
analyzed: saṅkhātāsu tīsu sikkhāsu pariyāpannānam satthu sāsana dhammānam etaṃnāmam te pana
translated: This is the name for the states of the Master’s Dispensation that are included among the three trainings called “the three kinds of knowledge” .🔽They are of seven kinds according to the method of exposition,

original: koṭṭhāsato satta vidhā hontīti āha cattārosatipaṭṭhānātiādi. Sampayutta dhammesu🔽pamukhā padhānā hutvā kāyādīsu ārammaṇesu tiṭṭhanti nānārammaṇesu cittagamanaṃ nivattetvā
analyzed: koṭṭhāsato satta vidhā honti iti āha sampayutta dhammesu  pamukhā padhānāḥ hutvā kāya ādīsu ārammaṇesu tiṭṭhanti nānā ārammaṇesu citta gamanam nivattetvā
translated: and so he said “The forty foundations of mindfulness” and so on.

original: tesveva kāyādīsu citta nibandhanavasena pavattantīti paṭṭhānāni. Satieva paṭṭhānānīti
analyzed: tesu eva kāya ādīsu citta nibandhana vasena pavattanti iti paṭṭhānāni sati eva paṭṭhānāni iti
translated: They are called “foundations of mindfulness” because they stand as the chief and principal states associated with mindfulness, preventing the mind’s going elsewhere by binding it to the body, etc., as its object.

original: sati paṭṭhānāni. Cattārisatipaṭṭhānānīti vattabbe dhammabhāvaṃ apekkhitvā cattārosatipaṭṭhānā🔽tivuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kāyeanupassanā kāyā nupassanā. Rūpakāye rūpasamūhe assāsapassāsādikassa🔽avayavakāyassa taṃtaṃkāyabhāvenavā aniccādibhāvenavā yāva tasmiṃ tasmiṃ kāye sammoho
analyzed: paṭṭhānāni cattāri sati paṭṭhānāni iti vattabbe dhamma bhāvam apekkhitvā cattāro sati paṭṭhānā  ti vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam kāye anupassanā kāya anupassanā rūpa kāye rūpa samūhe assāsa passāsa ādikassa  avayava kāyassa anicca ādi bhāvena vā yāva tasmin tasmin kāye sammohaḥ
translated: They are “foundations of mindfulness” because they are foundations for mindfulness.

original: pahiyyati. Tāva punappunaṃ nirantaraṃ samanupassanāti attho. Navappabhedāsu vedanāsu
analyzed: pahiyyati tāva punappunam nirantaram samanupassanā ati atthaḥ nava ppabhedāsu vedanāsu
translated: The meaning is that they are looked over again and again, uninterruptedly, in the various aspects of impermanence, etc., in the various bodies, until delusion is abandoned in regard to the material body, the collection of materials, the component body consisting of in-breaths and out-breaths, etc., and until delusion is abandoned in regard to the various kinds of feeling, which are of nine kinds according to the analysis of them as pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant, and according to the threefold analysis of the wholesome, the unwholesome, and the imperturbable.

original: sukhavedanādi kāyaavayavavedanāya taṃtaṃ vedanābhāvena udayabbayavasena ca anupassanā
analyzed: sukha vedanā ādi kāya avayava vedanāya taṃtam vedanā bhāvena udaya bbaya vasena ca anupassanā
translated: Contemplation of the arising and falling away of the various kinds of feeling in the various parts of the body is contemplation of feeling.🔽Contemplation of the various kinds of consciousness in the various states of consciousness is contemplation of consciousness.

original: vedanānupassanā. Soḷasa pabhedesu sarāgā dīsu cittesu sarāgādikassa avayavacittassa🔽taṃtaṃ cittabhāvena udayabbayavasenaca anupassanā cittānupassanā. Pañcapabhedesu🔽nīvaraṇādīsu dhammesu kāmacchandādikassa avayavadhammassa taṃ taṃ dhammabhāvena udayabbayavasenaca
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā soḷasa pabhedesu sa rāga ādīsu cittesu sa rāga ādikassa avayava cittassa  taṃ taṃ citta bhāvena udaya bbaya vasena ca anupassanā citta anupassanā pañca pabhedesu  nīvaraṇa ādīsu dhammesu kāmacchanda ādikassa avayava dhammassa tam tam dhamma bhāvena udaya bbaya vasena ca
translated: In the sixteen kinds of consciousness affected by greed, etc., contemplation of the various kinds of consciousness in the various states of consciousness is contemplation of consciousness.🔽In the five kinds of consciousness affected by greed, etc., contemplation of the various kinds of consciousness in the various states of consciousness is contemplation of consciousness.🔽In the five hindrances, etc., contemplation of the various kinds of consciousness in the various states of consciousness is contemplation of consciousness.

original: anupassanā dhammānupassanā.
analyzed: anupassanā dhamma anupassanā
translated: In the five kinds of consciousness affected by greed, etc., contemplation of the various kinds of states in the various states is contemplation of states.

original: [215] Yaṃ pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: “Kucchitānaṃ kesādīnaṃ āyoti kāyo. Assāsa passāsānaṃvā samūho kāyo”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ na sundara meva.
analyzed: kucchitānam kesa ādīnam āyo ti kāyaḥ assāsa passāsānaṃ vā samūhaḥ kāyo ti vuttam tat na sundara meva
translated: “The body is the collection of the thirty-two parts, such as the head hairs, etc., or the body is the collection of the in-breaths and out-breaths” . That is not good.

original: [216] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there:

original: “Kāyassa anupassanā kāyānupassanā”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na sundaraṃ.
analyzed: kāyassa anupassanā kāya anupassanā ti vuttam tat pi na sundaram
translated: “Contemplation of the body as a body is contemplation of danger” , that is not good either.

original: Kāye kāyānupassī viharatīti hi vuttaṃ. Etena hi kāye anupassanā kāyānupassanāti ayamatthova padhānato dassitoti.
analyzed: kāye kāya anupassī viharati iti hi vuttam etena hi kāye anupassanā kāya anupassanā ti ayam atthaḥ uva padhānataḥ dassitaḥ ti
translated: For it is said: “He dwells contemplating the body in the body” . And by this it is shown that the meaning of “contemplation of the body” is “contemplation as a body.”

original: [217] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there

original: “Vedanānaṃ vasena anupassanā”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na sundaraṃ. Vedanāsu vedanānupassīti hi vuttaṃ. Tathā cittānupassanā padepi.
analyzed: vedanānam vasena anupassanā ti vuttam tat pi na sundaram vedanāsu vedanā anupassī iti hi vuttam tathā citta anupassanā pade pi
translated: “Contemplation by way of feeling” is not good. For it is said, “Contemplating the feelings in the feelings.” And so too in the case of the clause on contemplating the mind.

original: [218] Yaṃpi tattha
analyzed: yaṃ pi tattha
translated: And what is said there

original: “Saññāsaṅkhārānaṃ dhammānaṃ bhinnalakkhaṇānameva anupassanā dhammānupassanā”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi na sundarameva.
analyzed: saññā saṅkhārānam dhammānam bhinna lakkhaṇānam eva anupassanā dhamma anupassanā ti vuttam tat pi na sundaram eva
translated: “Contemplation of ideas is the contemplation of the various individual essences of ideas consisting of perception and formations” is not good either.

original: Na hi katthaci pāḷiyaṃ saññāsaṅkhārāva visesetvā dhammāti vuttā atthīti. Pāḷiyañhi
analyzed: na hi katthaci pāḷiyam saññā saṅkhārau visesetvā dhammā ati vuttāḥ atthi iti pāḷiyam hi
translated: For nowhere in the text is it said that perception and formations are distinguished and called “ideas.” For in the text

original: chanīvaraṇā pathamaṃ dhammāti vuttā. Tato pañcupādānakkhandhā. Tato dvādasāyatanāni.
analyzed: cha nīvaraṇā pathamam vuttā tatas pañca upādānakkhandhā tatas dvādasa āyatanāni
translated: the five hindrances are called “ideas” first, then the five aggregates as objects of clinging, then the twelve bases,🔽then the seven enlightenment factors, then the four noble truths.

original: Tato sattabojjhaṅgā. Tato cattāri saccānīti. Yadievaṃ ekāya dhammānupassanāya vuttāya
analyzed: tatas satta bojjhaṅgā tatas cattāri saccāni iti yadi evam ekāya dhamma anupassanāya vuttāya
translated: So when it is said that one contemplation of ideas

original: itarāpi siddhāti satipaṭṭhānaṃ ekameva vattabbaṃ, na cattāroti.Na. Yo hi dhammānupassanāyaṃ
analyzed: itarā api siddhā iti sati paṭṭhānam ekam eva vattabbam na cattāro ti na yaḥ hi dhamma anupassanā ayam
translated: is enough, the other three are established too, and it should be said that the foundations of mindfulness are one only, not four.🔽—That is not so. For one who is contemplating ideas

original: rūpakkhandho vutto. So ruppanalakkhaṇānupassanavasena vutto. Ruppanalakkhaṇañhi nibbattitapara
analyzed: rūpa kkhandho vuttaḥ saḥ ruppana lakkhaṇa anupassana vasena vuttaḥ ruppana lakkhaṇam hi nibbattita para
translated: The material aggregate is stated. It is stated by the contemplation of the characteristic of distension. For the characteristic of distension is the characteristic of the material aggregate.

original: matthadhammo. Soca tathā anupassantassa visesato sukhumassa attavipallāsassa pahānāya
analyzed: mattha dhammo so ca tathā anupassantassa visesataḥ sukhumassa atta vipallāsassa pahānāya
translated: The material form aggregate is stated. It is stated as the contemplation of the characteristic of being molested. For the characteristic of being molested is a supramundane state that has come into being. And for one who contemplates it thus, the gross form of self-delusion is abandoned.

original: hotīti. Kāyoti pana taṃtaṃ samūhabhūtarūpadhammavasena veditabbo. Naruppanalakkhaṇavasena.🔽Naca taṃtaṃ kāyabhāvena gahito taṃtaṃ rūpadhammasamūho nibbattita paramatthadhammonāma
analyzed: hoti iti kāyaḥ iti pana taṃ taṃ samūha bhūta rūpa dhamma vasena veditabbaḥ na ruppana lakkhaṇa vasena  na ca taṃtaṃ kāya bhāvena gahitaḥ taṃtaṃ rūpa dhamma samūhaḥ paramattha dhammaḥ nāma
translated: As to “material form,” it should be understood as a collection of material states that are the basis for the various kinds of “material form.” As to the characteristic of being molested.🔽And the collection of material states that is apprehended by the various kinds of “material form” is not called a supramundane state that has come into being.

original: hoti. Paññattimissakattā. Soca tathā anupassantassa visesato oḷārikassa subhādi vipallāsassa
analyzed: hoti paññatti missaka ttā so ca tathā anupassantassa visesataḥ oḷārikassa subha ādi vipallāsassa
translated: Because it is mixed with the conventional. And for one who contemplates it thus, the gross form of the delusion of beauty, etc., is abandoned.

original: pahānāya hotīti. Tathā vedanācittesupi oḷārikavipallāso sukhumavipallāsoti dve dve
analyzed: pahānāya hoti iti tathā vedanā cittesu pi oḷārika vipallāso sukhuma vipallāso ti dve dve
translated: So there are two kinds of delusion in the case of feeling and consciousness, the gross and the subtle.

original: vipallāsā honti. Tattha attupanibandhā niccasukha vipallāsā oḷārikā. Attavipallāso
analyzed: vipallāsāḥ honti tattha atta upanibandhāḥ nicca sukha vipallāsāḥ oḷārikāḥ atta vipallāso
translated: Herein, the delusions of permanence and pleasure bound up with self are gross, and the delusion of self is subtle.

original: sukhumo. Tattha vedanā cittā nupassanā oḷārikavipallāsānaṃ pahānāya visuṃ vuttā.
analyzed: tattha vedanā citta anupassanā oḷārika vipallāsānam pahānāya visum vuttā
translated: Herein, the contemplation of feeling and consciousness is stated separately for the abandoning of the gross delusions.

original: Dhammesu vedanākkhandhaviññāṇakkhandhā sukhuma vipallāsa pahānāyāti. Tasmā cattārova
analyzed: dhammesu vedanā kkhandha viññāṇa kkhandhā pahānāya ati tasmā cattāro va
translated: So they should be called the four Arousings of Mindfulness.🔽They are right endeavours because right efforts are made by means of them.

original: satipaṭṭhānā vattabbāti. Sammā padahanti etehīti sammappadhānāni. Kāmaṃ tacoca nhāruca,🔽aṭṭhica avasissatu. Upassussatu me sarīre maṃsalohitaṃ. Yantaṃ purisathāmena purisaparakkamena
analyzed: sati paṭṭhānā vattabbā ti sammā padahanti etehi iti sammappadhānāni kāmam  aṭṭhica avasissatu upassussatu me sarīre maṃsa lohitam yantam purisa thāmena purisa parakkamena
translated: Let skin and sinews and bones remain,🔽let the flesh and blood dry up in my body,🔽but so long as I have not attained what can be attained by manly strength and manly energy,

original: pattabbaṃ. Na taṃ apatvā vīriyassa saṇṭhānaṃ bhavissatīti evaṃ anivattanavutti vasena🔽pavattassa sammāvāyāmassa etaṃ nāmaṃ. So pana tathā pavatto ekopi samāno kiccasiddhivasena
analyzed: pattabbam na tam a patvā vīriyassa saṇṭhānam bhavissati iti evam a nivattana vutti vasena  pavattassa sammāvāyāmassa etam nāmam saḥ pana tathā pavattaḥ ekaḥ api samānaḥ kicca siddhi vasena
translated: I will not relax my energy.” This is the name for right endeavour that occurs in this way with unrelapsing occurrence.🔽And although it occurs in this way as one only, it is fourfold according to the success of its function.

original: catudhā hotīti. Vuttaṃ uppannānantiādi.🔽Tattha uppannānaṃpāpakānanti asukasmiṃ kāle dese ṭhāne vā ahaṃ idañcidañca nāma pāpaṃ
analyzed: catudhā hoti iti vuttam uppannāna ntiādi  tattha uppannānam pāpakānam ti asukasmin kāle dese ṭhāne vā aham nāma pāpam
translated: That is why it is said “arisen” and so on.🔽Herein, arisen bad and unwholesome states is what is meant.

original: akāsiṃ, idañcidañcanāma mayhaṃ uppannanti evaṃ attano santāne uppannabhāvena viditānaṃ
analyzed: akāsim mayham uppannanti evam attanaḥ santāne uppanna bhāvena
translated: “At such and such a time I did this and that evil deed” and “This and that arose in me” are known by him in his own continuity as having arisen.

original: akusalānaṃ. Pahānāyāti tesaṃ attano santāne ajjatagge yāvaparinibbānāpuna anuppādadhammatāpādanakaraṇatthaṃ.
analyzed: akusalānam pahānāya ati tesam attanaḥ santāne ajjatagge anuppāda dhamma tā āpādana karaṇa ttham
translated: For the abandoning of unwholesome roots. For the purpose of making them non-arisen by nature in one’s own continuity from now until the end of time.

original: Vāyāmoti sīla pūraṇa samatha vipassanābhāvanākammesu daḷhaṃ vāyāmo. Anuppannānanti
analyzed: vāyāmaḥ ti sīla pūraṇa samatha vipassanā bhāvanā kammesu daḷham vāyāmaḥ an uppannānam ti
translated: Exertion: strong exertion in the work of fulfilling virtue, developing serenity and insight. Unarisen:🔽unseen in one’s own continuity or in the continuity of others, or unheard in the scriptures.

original: attano santāne uppannapubbanti aviditānaṃ parasantānesuvā suttantesuvā disvāvā sutvāvā
analyzed: attanaḥ santāne uppanna pubbanti aviditānam para santānesu vā suttantesu vā disvā vā sutvā vā
translated: Arisen: seen in one’s own continuity or in the continuity of others, or heard in the scriptures.

original: viditānaṃ. Anuppādāyāti yesaṃ akusala mūlānaṃ atthitāya imesaṃ sattānaṃ īdisāni kilesajātāni
analyzed: viditānam anuppādāya ati yesam akusala mūlānaṃ atthitāya imesam sattānam īdisāni kilesa jātāni
translated: For the non-arising of unwholesome roots: because of the existence of these unwholesome roots, such defilements arise in these beings,

original: vā pāpakammānivā uppajjanti. Tāni mayi vijjantieva. Ahaṃpi tehi kilesehivā kammehivā🔽aparimuttoyeva. Ahaṃpi svevā parasuvevā bhavantaresuvā tāni attano santāne uppādessā
analyzed: vā uppajjanti tāni mayi vijjanti eva aham pi tehi kilesehi vā kammehi vā  aham pi tāni attanaḥ santāne uppādessā
translated: or such evil actions. I am not free from those defilements or those actions.

original: miyevāti evaṃ paccavekkhitvā tesaṃ akusalamūlānaṃ attano santāne uppattiyā paccayasamucchindanatthaṃ.
analyzed: miyā iva ati evam paccavekkhitvā tesam akusala mūlānam attano santāne uppattiyā paccaya samucchindana ttham
translated: I too will give rise to them in my own continuity tomorrow or the day after or in another existence. ’ Having reflected thus, for the purpose of cutting off the conditions for the arising of those unwholesome roots in one’s own continuity.

original: Anuppannānaṃkusalānanti catubhūmakesu kusaladhammesu sattavisuddhipabhedesu imenāma
analyzed: catu bhūmakesu kusala dhammesu satta visuddhi pabhedesu
translated: “Unarisen profitable things”: in the four-constituent kinds of profitable things classed in the seven ways by means of purification.

original: visuddhidhammā mayā appattā anadhigatāeva hontīti evaṃ ñatvā samaye anatikkanteeva🔽appattānaṃ anadhigatānaṃ upari visuddhidhammānaṃ adhigamanatthāya.
analyzed: visuddhi dhammā mayā appattāḥ anadhigatāḥ eva honti iti evam ñatvā samaye an atikkante eva  appattānam anadhigatānam upari visuddhi dhammānam adhigamana tthāya
translated: “Unarisen profitable things”: “These things purified by the seven kinds of purification that are profitable in the four paths are not yet obtained by me, not yet attained” .🔽So understanding, he does not transgress the proper time.

original: Uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ bhiyyo bhāvāyāti yāni sīlādīni kusalāni mayi uppannāni. Tāni🔽yāva niyāmaṃ naokkamanti, tāva mayhaṃ etānīti vattuṃ nārahanti. Svevā parasuvevā
analyzed: uppannānam kusalānam bhiyyas bhāvāya ati yāni sīla ādīni kusalāni mayi uppannāni tāni  yāva niyāmam na okkamanti tāva mayham etāni iti vattum na ārahanti su evā parasuvā iva
translated: “Arisen profitable things”: “These profitable things beginning with virtue that have arisen in me cannot be said to be mine as long as I have not reached the limit of life,🔽but they will break up either with the lapse of time, or with the death of another, or with my own death” .

original: bhavantaraṃ patvāvā bhijjissanti yevāti evaṃ paccavekkhitvā attano santāne uppannānaṃ🔽tesaṃ sabbaso akuppadhammatāpādanavasena suṭṭhutaraṃ vaḍḍhanatthāya. Etesu pana catūsu
analyzed: bhavantaram patvā vā bhijjissanti yeva ati evam paccavekkhitvā attano santāne uppannānam  tesam sabbasas akuppa dhamma tā āpādana vasena suṭṭhutaram vaḍḍhana tthāya etesu pana catūsu
translated: So reflecting, he should make them grow still more by establishing them in the signless through making the sign of impermanence, etc., their object.

original: mukhesu yena kenaci ekena mukhena uppanno vāyāmo catukiccasādhakoeva hotīti veditabbo.
analyzed: mukhesu yena kenaci ekena mukhena uppannaḥ vāyāmaḥ catu kicca sādhakaḥ eva hoti iti veditabbo
translated: And it should be understood that the effort that has arisen by means of any one of these four doors accomplishes the fourfold task.

original: Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana maggakkhaṇe eva ekassa tassa catukiccasādhakatā vuttāti.
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam pana magga kkhaṇe eva ekassa tassa catu kicca sādhaka tā vuttā ti
translated: But in the commentary it is said that it is only one of them that accomplishes the fourfold task at the moment of the path.

original: Ijjhanaṃ iddhi, tassa tassa yogakammassa siddhi samiddhi nibbattīti attho. Sā pana🔽saṅkhepato abhiññeyyānaṃ dhammānaṃ abhiññāsiddhi, pariññeyyānaṃ pariññāsiddhi, pahātabbānaṃ🔽pahānasiddhi, sacchikā tabbānaṃ sacchikaraṇasiddhi, bhāvetabbānaṃ bhāvanāsiddhīti
analyzed: iddhi tassa tassa yogakammassa siddhi samiddhi nibbatti iti attho sā pana  saṅkhepataḥ abhiññeyyānam dhammānam abhiññā siddhi pariññeyyānam pariññā siddhi pahātabbānam  pahāna siddhi sacchikā tabbānam sacchikaraṇa siddhi bhāvetabbānam bhāvanā siddhi iti
translated: Success is success in the various kinds of work, the accomplishment of the various kinds of work, is what is meant.

original: pañcavidhā hoti. Ijjhatītivā iddhi satthusāsane yogakammena ijjhantānaṃ sabbesaṃ
analyzed: pañcavidhā hoti ijjhati itivā id hi satthu sāsane yogakammena ijjhantānam sabbesam
translated: That is of five kinds in brief: success in the direct-knowledge of ideas that can be directly known, success in the full-understanding of ideas that can be fully understood, success in the abandoning of ideas that can be abandoned, success in the realizing of ideas that can be realized, and success in the developing of ideas that can be developed.🔽Or alternatively, success is success in the Dispensation of the Master through the accomplishment of the various kinds of work. It is the name for all the noble ideas of the kinds beginning with the great and the supramundane.🔽It is a foot because it spreads out from here,🔽The foot of success is the footing for success.

original: mahaggata lokuttaradhammānaṃ nāmaṃ. Pajjati etenāti pādo. Iddhiyā pādoti iddhipādo.🔽Iddhipattiyā balavupāyo padhānakāraṇanti vuttaṃ hoti. So pana catunnaṃ adhipatidhammānaṃ
analyzed: mahaggata lokuttara dhammānam nāmam pajjati etena ati pādaḥ iddhiyā pādaḥ iti iddhipādaḥ  iddhipattiyāḥ balavā upāyaḥ padhāna kāraṇan ti vuttam hoti so pana catunnam adhipati dhammānam
translated: What is meant is that it is the principal cause, the powerful means to the attainment of success.🔽And that is fourfold according to the four ideas that are dominant🔽It is said that “There are four things called ‘footing for success’ ” , and so on.

original: vasena catudhā hotīti vuttaṃ cattāro iddhipādātiādi. Adhipatibhūto chandova iddhipādoti
analyzed: vasena catudhā hoti iti vuttam cattāro iddhipādā atiādi adhipati bhūto iddhipādo ti
translated: It is will that is the footing for success.

original: chandiddhipādo. Esanayo sesesupīti. Etthaca sabbe mahaggatānuttarabhūtā uttarimanussa
analyzed: chanda iddhipādaḥ sesesu pi iti ettha ca sabbe mahaggata anuttara bhūtāḥ uttari manussa
translated: is the basis of success consisting in zeal. The same method applies to the remaining three.

original: dhammānāma napākatikena chandenavā vīriyenavā cittenavā paññāya vā adhigantabbā honti.
analyzed: dhammā nāma na pākatikena chandena vā vīriyena vā cittena vā paññāya vā adhigantabbāḥ honti
translated: Herein, all the supramundane and the mundane of the higher- than-human states are not to be attained by zeal, energy, consciousness, and understanding in their ordinary form.

original: Yena kenaci palibodhena paṭibāhituṃ asakkuṇeyyena adhipatibhāvapattena chandādināeva
analyzed: yena kenacid palibodhena paṭibāhitum a sakkuṇeyyena adhipati bhāva pattena chanda ādinā eva
translated: They are to be attained only by zeal, etc., that have become dominant through being assisted by the measureless and supramundane states.

original: adhigantabbā. Tasmā ime cattāro dhammā adhipatibhūtāva idha adhippetāti daṭṭhabbāti.
analyzed: adhigantabbā tasmai ime cattāro dhammā adhipati bhūtā va idha adhippetā ati daṭṭhabbā ati
translated: So these four things, in their dominant form, are what is intended here.

original: [219] Yaṃpana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: yaṃpana vibhāvaniyam
translated: But in the description in the Vibhaṅga,

original: “Ijjhati adhiṭṭhānādikaṃ etāyāti iddhi, iddhividhaññāṇaṃ. Iddhiyā pādo iddhipādo”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Taṃ saṃyuttake katamāca bhikkhave iddhi. Idha bhikkhave bhikkhu anekavihitaṃ
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna ādikam etāya ati iddhi iddhi vidha ññāṇam iddhiyāḥ pādaḥ iddhi pādo ti  vuttam tat saṃyuttake katamā ca bhikkhave iddhi idha bhikkhave bhikkhu aneka vihitam
translated: “It succeeds by means of resolution, etc., thus it is success ; the knowledge of success is the knowledge of the kinds of success. The basis of success is a basis for success” ,🔽it is said that success is the ability to exercise mastery over the kinds of supernormal power, etc., by means of the four roads to power.

original: iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti. Ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti.La. Yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ
analyzed: iddhividham paccanubhoti ekaḥ api hutvā bahudhā kāyena
translated: The kinds of supernormal power are stated in the Saṃyutta: “What is success, bhikkhus? Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu wields the various kinds of success: having been one, he becomes many … he exercises mastery with the body as far as the brahmā world” .

original: vatteti. Ayaṃ vuccati bhikkhave iddhīti imāya pāḷiyā sameti. Evaṃsantepi idha abhidhammapariyāyova
analyzed: vattā iti ayam vuccati bhikkhave iddhi iti imāya pāḷiyā sameti evaṃsante pi idha abhidhamma pariyāyaḥ uva
translated: But since the Abhidhamma method is intended here,

original: adhippetoti taṃ na yujjatiyeva.
analyzed: adhippetā uti tam na
translated: that explanation is not appropriate.

original: Vibhaṅge pana pathamavāre lokiya lokuttaramissakā citta cetasikarāsīeva iddhipādāti
analyzed: vibhaṅge pana pathama vāre iddhipādā
translated: In the Vibhaṅga, however, the first section is called “the basis for psychic power” in the sense of a collection of consciousnesses and consciousness-concomitants that are mixed mundane and supramundane.

original: vuttā. Aṭṭhakathāyañca-pathamajjhāna parikammaṃhi iddhipādonāma. Pathamajjhānaṃ iddhināma.La.
analyzed: vuttā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ ca pathamajjhāna parikammaṃhi iddhipādonāma pathamajjhānaṃ
translated: And in the commentary it is said: “The preliminary-work concentration is called the basis for psychic power. The first jhāna is called psychic power.

original: Nevasaññā nāsaññāyatanajjhānaparikammaṃ iddhipādonāma. Nevasaññānāsaññā yatanajjhānaṃ🔽iddhināma. Sotāpattimaggassa vipassanā iddhipādo nāma. Sotāpattimaggo iddhināma.La.
analyzed: nevasaññā na asaññā āyatana jhāna parikammaṃ iddhipādo nāma nevasaññā nāsaññā yatana jhānaṃ  iddhi nāma sotāpatti maggassa vipassanā iddhipādo nāma sotāpatti maggo
translated: The preliminary-work concentration for the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is called the basis for psychic power. The base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception🔽is called psychic power. The insight leading to the path of stream-entry is called the basis for psychic power. The path of stream-entry

original: Arahattamaggassa vipassanā iddhipādonāma. Arahattamaggo iddhināmātica. Pathamajjhānaṃ
analyzed: arahatta maggassa vipassanā iddhipādo nāma arahatta maggo iddhi nāma ati ca pathama jhānaṃ
translated: is called psychic power. The insight leading to the path of arahatship is called the basis for psychic power. The path of arahatship is called psychic power. The first jhāna

original: iddhipādonāma. Dutiyajjhānaṃ iddhināma. La. Ākiñcaññāyatanajjhānaṃ iddhi pādonāma.
analyzed: iddhi pādonāma dutiya jhānaṃ iddhi nāma ākiñcaññāyatana jhānaṃ iddhi
translated: is called the basis for psychic power. The second jhāna is called psychic power. The base consisting of nothingness is called the basis for psychic power.

original: Nevasaññā nāsaññā yatanajjhānaṃ iddhināma. Sotā pattimaggo iddhipādonāma. Sakadāgāmimaggo
analyzed: nevasaññā na asaññā yatana jhānaṃ iddhi nāma sotā patti maggo iddhipādo nāma sakadāgāmi maggo
translated: The base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is called “success.” The ear-element is called “the basis of success.” The path of stream-entry is called “success.”

original: iddhināma.La. Arahattamaggo iddhināmāti ca vuttaṃ. Taṃtaṃ pādakajjhānaṃ iddhipādonāma.
analyzed: arahatta maggo iddhi nāmā ti ca vuttam taṃ tam pādaka jjhānam iddhipādo nāma
translated: The path of once-return is called “success.” The path of non-return is called “success.” The path of arahatship is called “success.” The basic jhāna is called “the basis of success.”

original: Tato tato vuṭṭhahitvā uppāditamaggo iddhināmātipi vattuṃ vaṭṭatiyeva. Idha pana uttaracūḷabhājaniye
analyzed: tatas tatas vuṭṭhahitvā uppādita maggaḥ vattum pana uttaracūḷa bhājaniye
translated: It is also proper to say that the path produced after emerging from that is called “success.” But here in the Northern Commentary,

original: āgatanayena cattāro adhipatidhammāeva iddhipādāti vuttā.
analyzed: āgata nayena cattāro adhipati dhammā eva iddhipādā ti vuttā
translated: the four dominants are called “the basis of success” in the way stated in the Northern Commentary.

original: Tattha pana lokuttarabhūtāeva adhippetā. Idha lokiya lokuttara missakabhūtāti. Indriyabalāni
analyzed: tattha pana lokuttara bhūtā eva adhippetā idha indriya balāni
translated: But there the supramundane dominants are intended, while here the mundane and supramundane dominants are intended. The faculties and powers

original: atthato heṭṭhā vuttāneva. Pākaṭaṭṭhānato pana catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu saddhāya thāmo
analyzed: atthataḥ heṭṭhā vuttāna eva pākaṭa ṭṭhānato pana catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu saddhāya thāmo
translated: are the same in meaning as those already stated below. But the firmness of faith should be understood in the four factors of stream-entry,

original: veditabbo. Yathāha-kattha bhikkhave saddhindriyaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu
analyzed: veditabbaḥ yathā āhakattha bhikkhave saddhi indriyam daṭṭhabbam catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu
translated: as it is said: “Where, bhikkhus, should the faculty of faith be seen? In the four factors of stream-entry.

original: ettha saddhindriyaṃ daṭṭhabbanti. Catūsu sammappadhānesu vīriyassa. Yathāha-kattha
analyzed: ettha saddhi indriyam daṭṭhabbanti catūsu sammappadhānesu vīriyassa
translated: Herein, the faculty of faith should be seen” . In the four right efforts, the firmness of energy should be understood,🔽as it is said: “Where, bhikkhus, should the faculty of energy be seen?

original: bhikkhave vīriyindriyaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Catūsu sammappadhānesu ettha vīriyindriyaṃ daṭṭhabbanti.
analyzed: bhikkhave vīriya indriyam daṭṭhabbam catūsu sammappadhānesu ettha vīriya indriyam daṭṭhabbanti
translated: The energy faculty should be seen in the four right endeavours.

original: Catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu satiyā. Yathāha-kattha bhikkhavesatindriyaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Catūsu🔽satipaṭṭhānesuettha satindriyaṃ daṭṭhabbanti. Catūsu jhānesu samādhissa. Yathāha-kattha
analyzed: catūsu sati paṭṭhānesu satiyāḥ yathā ahakattha bhikkhave sati indriyam daṭṭhabbam catūsu  sati paṭṭhānesu ettha sati indriyam daṭṭhabbanti catūsu jhānesu samādhissa
translated: In the four foundations of mindfulness, it is mindfulness. As it is said: “Where, bhikkhus, should the mindfulness faculty be seen?🔽In the four foundations of mindfulness. There the mindfulness faculty should be seen” .🔽In the four jhānas, it is concentration. As it is said: “Where, bhikkhus, should the concentration faculty be seen?

original: bhikkhave samādhindriyaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Catūsu jhānesu ettha samādhindriyaṃ daṭṭhabbanti.🔽Catūsu ariyasaccesu paññāya thāmo veditabbo. Yathāha-kattha bhikkhave paññindriyaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhave samādhi indriyam daṭṭhabbam catūsu jhānesu ettha samādhi indriyam daṭṭhabbanti  catūsu ariya saccesu paññāya thāmaḥ veditabbo yathā ahakattha bhikkhave paññindriyam
translated: In the four jhānas. There the concentration faculty should be seen” .🔽The strength of understanding should be understood in the four noble truths. As it is said: “Where, bhikkhus, should the understanding faculty be seen?

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Catūsu ariyasaccesu ettha paññindriyaṃ daṭṭhabbanti. Sambodhi vuccati
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam catūsu ariya saccesu ettha paññindriyam daṭṭhabbanti sambodhi vuccati
translated: In the four noble truths. There the understanding faculty should be seen” .🔽Knowledge in the four paths is called “awakening” .

original: catūsu maggesu ñāṇaṃ, samantato bujjhati paṭivijjhati bujjhanti vā etāyāti katvā.
analyzed: catūsu maggesu ñāṇam samantataḥ bujjhati paṭivijjhati bujjhanti vā etāya ati katvā
translated: It is so called because it awakens, penetrates, or causes to awaken, all round.

original: Sā hi catusaccadhammaṃ bujjhamānā ekakkhaṇe soḷasahi atthehi saddhiṃ samantato bujjhati,
analyzed: sā hi catu sacca dhammam bujjhamānā eka kkhaṇe soḷasahi atthehi saddhim samantataḥ bujjhati
translated: For that, awakening to the four noble truths, awakens all round together with the sixteen categories of meaning in a single moment,

original: na ekadesa toti tassā sambodhiyā samuṭṭhāpanaṭṭhena sambodhiyā aṅgo sahakārībalavapaccayoti
analyzed: na eka desa toti tassā sambodhiyā samuṭṭhāpana ṭṭhena sambodhiyā aṅgo sahakārī balava paccayoti
translated: “Not one part” means that it is a factor of enlightenment in the sense of being a co-operating condition for the generation of enlightenment.

original: sambojjhaṅgo. Satieva sambojjhaṅgo satisambojjhaṅgo. Sā hi kāyādīsu catūsu attano
analyzed: sambojjhaṅaḥ sati eva sambojjhaṅgaḥ sati sambojjhaṅgaḥ sā hi kāya ādīsu catūsu attanaḥ
translated: “Enlightenment factor” means that it is a factor of enlightenment in the sense of generating enlightenment.

original: gocaresu bhāvanāvasena suṭṭhusaṃvaḍḍhamānā anupubbena sabbapamāda pakkhaṃ vidhametvā
analyzed: gocaresu bhāvanā vasena suṭṭhu saṃvaḍḍhamānāḥ anupubbena sabba pamāda pakkham vidhametvā
translated: For this enlightenment factor, when it is being developed by way of meditation, gradually dispels the whole side of negligence and

analyzed: tathā ekasmim vedayita lakkhaṇe sañjānana lakkhaṇe rāsim katvā pariggahitā atīta ādi bheda bhinnā

original: vedanāsaññāyo vedanākkhandho saññākkhandho canāma. Saṅkharontīti saṅkhārā. Phassa
analyzed: vedanā saññāyaḥ vedanā kkhandho saññā kkhandho canāma saṅkharonti iti saṅkhārā phassa
translated: They are called the feeling aggregate and the perception aggregate. Formations are what form , that is, what fashion and mould .

original: cetanā dayo. Tehi chasuvā upapattidvāresu tīsuvā kammadvāresu ekato saṅgamma samāgamma🔽phusanacetayitādīhi attano attano kiccehi dassanasavanādīni sādhāraṇakiccānivā kāyika
analyzed: cetanā dayo tehi chasuvā upapatti dvāresu tīsuvā kamma dvāresu ekatas saṅgamma samāgamma  phusana cetayita ādīhi attanaḥ attanaḥ kiccehi dassana savana ādīni
translated: at the three doors of kamma, at the six sense doors,🔽perform all the functions of seeing, hearing, etc., which are common functions,

original: vācasikamānasikānivā sayana nisajjaṭṭhāna gamana kathana cintanādīni sabbāni kiccāni
analyzed: sayana nisajja ṭṭhāna gamana kathana cintana ādīni sabbāni kiccāni
translated: and the functions of bodily, verbal, and mental action, such as lying down, sitting, standing, walking, speaking, thinking, etc.

original: karonti vidahantīti. Vuttañhetaṃ saṃyuttake –🔽Kiñca bhikkhave saṅkhāre vadetha. Saṅkhataṃ abhisaṅkharontīti kho bhikkhave tasmā
analyzed: karonti vidahanti iti vuttam ha etam saṃyuttake  kiñca bhikkhave saṅkhāre vadetha saṅkhatam abhisaṅkharonti iti kho bhikkhave tasmā
translated: This is said in the Saṃyutta Nikāya:

original: saṅkhārāti vuccanti. Kiñca saṅkhataṃ abhi saṅkharonti, rūpaṃ rūpatthāya saṅkhataṃ🔽abhisaṅkharonti. Vedanaṃ vedanatthāya saṅkhataṃ abhisaṅkharonti. Saññaṃ saññatthāya
analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ ti vuccanti kiñca saṅkhatam abhi saṅkharonti rūpam rūpatthāya saṅkhatam  abhisaṅkharonti vedanam vedana tthāya saṅkhatam abhisaṅkharonti saññam sañña tthāya
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is called a formation? It forms the formed, bhikkhus, thus it is called a formation. And what is the formed that it forms? It forms materiality for the sake of materiality,🔽it forms feeling for the sake of feeling, it forms perception for the sake of perception,

original: saṅkhata abhisaṅkharonti. Saṅkhāre saṅkhāratthāya saṅkhata mabhisaṅkharonti. Viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhata abhisaṅkharonti saṅkhāre saṅkhāra tthāya saṅkhata mabhisaṅkharonti viññāṇaṃ
translated: it forms formations for the sake of formations, it forms consciousness for the sake of consciousness.

analyzed: viññāṇa tthāya saṅkhata mabhi saṅkharonti iti saṅkhata mabhisaṅkharonti iti kho bhikkhave

analyzed: tasmāt saṅkhārāḥ ati vuccanti iti  tattha rūpam rūpatthāya saṅkhatam abhisaṅkharonti iti yasmin yasmin kāle
translated: that is why ‘formations’ is said.🔽Herein, as to the clause They form the formed for the sake of visible form, in whatever instance whatever visible-form category is desired by way of lying down, sitting, etc.,

original: pavattā yā yā rūpavikati icchīyati, tasmiṃtasmiṃ kāle tassā tassā rūpavikatiyā jātatthāya
analyzed: pavattā yā yā rūpa vikati icchīyati tasmin tasmin kāle tassā tassā rūpa vikatiyā jāta tthāya
translated: in that instance for the sake of the arising of that visible-form category

original: iriyāpatha parivattanādi vasena taṃ taṃ rūpavikatiṃ saṅkhataṃ abhisaṅkharontīti attho.🔽Khajjabhojjādikaṃ vatthālaṅkārādikaṃ mañca pīṭha geha rathādikaṃ sabbaṃ upabhoga
analyzed: iriyāpatha parivattana ādi vasena tam tam rūpa vikatim saṅkhatam abhisaṅkharonti iti attho  khajja bhojja ādikam vattha alaṅkāra ādikam mañca pīṭha geha ratha ādikam sabbam upabhoga
translated: they form the formed by way of changing posture, and so on. This is the meaning.

original: paribhogabhūtaṃ bāhira rūpaṃpi gahetvā yojetuṃ vaṭṭatiyeva. Vedananti diṭṭhadhammikaṃ
analyzed: paribhoga bhūtam gahetvā yojetum vaṭṭatiyā iva vedanan ti diṭṭhadhammikam
translated: And all external visible forms that are objects of enjoyment and use, such as food and clothing, etc., and beds and chairs, houses and vehicles, etc., can also be included.

original: samparāyikañca sabbaṃpi vedanaṃ. Tattha diṭṭhadhammikaṃ vedanaṃ saṅkhataṃ abhisaṅkharontā
analyzed: samparāyikam ca sabbam api vedanam tattha diṭṭhadhammikam vedanam saṅkhatam abhisaṅkharontā
translated: Feeling is all feeling, whether of the present existence or of future existence.🔽Herein, as to the clause They form the formed for the sake of feeling, they form the formed for the sake of the arising of the feeling of the present existence.

original: cittakammanaccagītādīni taṃ taṃ vedanupakaraṇāni sampādana vasena samparāyikañca
analyzed: citta kamma nacca gīta ādīni tam tam vedan upakaraṇāni sampādana vasena samparāyikañca

original: abhisaṅkharontā mānusakaṃvā dibbaṃvā taṃtaṃ vedanaṃ patthetvā dāna sīlādi sampādana🔽vasena abhisaṅkharonti. Esanayo sesesupi. Saṅkhāresu pana phassaṃ phassatthāya cetanaṃ🔽cetanatthāyātiādinā dānaṃ dānatthāya sīlaṃ sīlatthāya pāṇātipātaṃ pāṇātipātatthāyātiādinā
analyzed: abhisaṅkharontā mānusakam vā dibbam vā tat tat vedanam patthetvā dāna sīla ādi sampādana  vasena abhisaṅkharonti sesesu pi saṅkhāresu pana phassam phassa atthāya cetanam  cetanā tthāya ati ādinā dānam dāna atthāya sīlam sīla tthāya pāṇa atipātam pāṇa atipāta tthāya ati ādinā
translated: and by producing giving, virtue, etc., in order to obtain the various kinds of feeling, such as heavenly and human. The rest should be understood in the same way.

original: vā sabbaṃ lokapavattiṃ ñatvā vitthāretabbāti. Ettha siyā, kasmā saṅkhāresu pākaṭā🔽cetanādayo vitakkādayo lobhādayo saddhāsatipaññādayoca dhamme visuṃ visuṃ khandhabhāvena
analyzed: vā sabbam loka pavattim ñatvā vitthāretabbā ti ettha siyā kasmā saṅkhāresu pākaṭā  cetanā ādayaḥ vitakka ādayaḥ lobha ādayaḥ saddhā sati paññā ādayaḥ ca dhamme visum visum khandha bhāvena
translated: But in the case of formations, it should be understood that the world is set in motion by the volition of the kind “I will touch” and by the kind “I will be conscious” and so on, and by the kind “I will give” and by the kind “I will be virtuous” and by the kind “I will kill” and by the kind “I will steal” and so on.🔽All this should be understood in detail.🔽Here it may be asked: Why are the obvious volitions, etc., and the thoughts, etc., and the greed, etc., and the faith, mindfulness, understanding, etc., not treated separately as aggregates like feeling and perception?

original: avatvā vedanāsaññāva vuttāti. Vuccate.
analyzed: a vatvā vedanā saññā ava vuttā iti vuccate
translated: The answer is this.

original: Yathā hi cheko mahābhisakko bhesajjamūlāni gahetvā cuṇṇaṃ karonto tesu mūlesu imāni

analyzed: kakkhaḷāni visum uddharitvā suṭṭhu koṭṭetvā cuṇṇam karoti sesāni pana sabbāni mudūni

analyzed: ekatas katvā koṭṭetvā cuṇṇam karoti tatas ubhayāni missetvā silāyam pisetvā bhesajja kamme
translated: so he pounds them together and makes a powder. Then he mixes the two together, grinds them on a stone, and uses them as medicine.

analyzed: upaneti evam karontaḥ na kilamati evam evam bhagavā api nāma rūpa dhammesu tilakkhaṇam  āropetvā nicca sukha atta vipallāsānam pahāna atthāya anuyuñjantā deva manussāḥ vibhāge  a kate tīsu dhammesu kilamissanti iti ñatvā nāma dhammesu vedanā saññā citta saṅkhāte tayo
translated: By doing so, he does not tire himself. In the same way, the Blessed One, after superimposing the three characteristics on the dhammas of mentality-materiality,🔽knew that gods and humans, who are engaged in the destruction of the perversions of permanence, pleasure, and self, would tire themselves if the three dhammas were not

original: dhamme visuṃ uddharitvā ekamekaṃ khandhaṃ nāma katvā desesi. Tathā hi yathā macchānāma
analyzed: dhamme visum uddharitvā ekam ekam khandham nāma katvā desesi tathā hi yathā macchā nāma
translated: differentiated. Therefore, he removed the three dhammas called feeling, perception, and mental formations from the dhammas of mentality, and taught each of the aggregates as a separate🔽aggregate. For just as fish🔽do not tire themselves in water when it is present, but when it is absent they tire themselves completely,

original: udake sati ukkaṇṭhitā nāma natthi. Asati pana ekantena ukkaṇṭhitāyeva honti. Yathāvā
analyzed: udake sati ukkaṇṭhitā nāma natthi asati pana ekantena ukkaṇṭhitāya iva honti yathāvā
translated: and just as

analyzed: madhuka rāvāḥ bhamarāvāḥ yasmin vane puppha rasa phala rase labhanti tattha ukkaṇṭhitā nāma  natthi alabhamānā pana ekantena ukkaṇṭhitāḥ eva honti evam eva imesam sattānam
translated: Just as bees make honey in a forest, in a place where they get the taste of flowers and fruits, and there is no dissatisfaction for them there,🔽but when they do not get it, they are dissatisfied, so too, for these beings there is no refuge like feeling in the objects of attachment considered to be pleasant.

original: saññitesu patisaraṇesu vedanāsadisaṃ patisaraṇaṃnāma natthi. Manussadevabrahmasampattiyo🔽assādentāpi sukhavedanatthāyaeva assādenti. Yadica tāhi vinā yathicchitaṃ sukhavedanaṃ
analyzed: saññitesu patisaraṇesu vedanā sadisam patisaraṇam nāma natthi manussa deva brahma sampattiyo  assādentā api sukha vedana tthāya eva assādenti yadi ca vinā yathā icchitam sukha vedanam
translated: Even though they enjoy the human, divine, and Brahmā states, they enjoy them only for the sake of pleasant feeling.🔽And if they could get the pleasant feeling they desire without those states,🔽who would accept them? analyzed: lobha dosa ādīhi saddhā sati paññā ādīhi ca saṅkhāra kkhandha dhammehi diṭṭhadhammikam samparāyikam ca  yam kiñci saṅkhatam abhisaṅkharonta api sukha vedana tthāya eva abhisaṅkharonti yadi ca
translated: greed, delusion, etc., and faith, mindfulness, understanding, etc.

original: tādisena abhisaṅkharaṇena vināpi yathicchitaṃ sukhaṃ labheyyuṃ, tehi dhammehi attho
analyzed: tādisena abhisaṅkharaṇena vinā api yathicchitam sukham labheyyum tehi dhammehi atthaḥ

analyzed: natthi iti kaḥ nāma te dhamme abhisaṅkharissati iti

analyzed: iti sukha saññitesu dhammesu vedanā nāma imesam sattānam param ukkaṃsa gatam sukha saññita ṭṭhānam
translated: Thus in the case of these states that are called pleasant, feeling is the most outstanding state of pleasantness.

original: hoti. Tasmā bhagavā taṃ visuṃ ekaṃ khandhaṃ katvā khandhadesanaṃ desetīti. Tathā
analyzed: hoti tasmai bhagavā tam visum ekam khandham katvā khandha desanam deseti iti tathā

analyzed: imesam sattānam atta saññitesu patisaraṇesu saññā sadisam patisaraṇam nāma natthi  tathā hi tasmin tasmin satta nikāye uppannā te te sattāḥ attānaḥ attanaḥ visayesu sabbam
translated: Similarly, in the case of these beings’ states that are called self, there is no refuge similar to perception.

original: jānitabbaṃ saññāya sañjānitvā viññuttaṃ āpajjanti. Tathā viññuttaṃ āpajjantā yattakaṃ

analyzed: saññam paramam attānam katvā vicaranti iti atta saññitesu dhammesu saññā nāma imesam
translated: Thus in the case of these states that are called self, perception is the most outstanding state of selfhood.

original: sattānaṃ paramukkaṃ sagataṃ attasaññitaṭṭhānaṃ hoti. Tasmā bhagavātaṃpi visuṃ ekaṃ
analyzed: sattānam paramukkam sagatam atta saññita ṭṭhānam hoti visum ekam

analyzed: khandham katvā khandha desanam deseti iti tathā imesam sattānam nicca saññitesu patisaraṇesu
translated: It is the highest and best of all beings’ ideas of self. That is why the Blessed One, having made it a separate aggregate, teaches it as the aggregate of perception.🔽And there is no other refuge for beings’ ideas of permanence like perception.

analyzed: citta sadisam pati saṃraṇam nāma natthi tathā hi sattā sukham dukkham nāma aniccam

analyzed: sukha pattānam dukkham natthi dukkha pattānam sukham natthi itivā saññā nāma aniccā  kadāci pamussati kadāci na pamussati iti vā vīriyam nāma aniccam kadāci ārabhati kadāci  na ārabhati iti vā lobhaḥ nāma aniccaḥ kadāci uppajjati kadāci na uppajjati iti vā dosaḥ nāma  aniccaḥ kadāci uppajjati kadāci na uppajjati itivā saddhā nāma aniccā kadāci pasanna cittaḥ
translated: there is no pleasure for those who have pain, there is no pain for those who have pleasure.” Or they think thus: “Perception is impermanent,

analyzed: hoti kadāci appasanna cittaḥ hoti iti vā paññā nāma aniccā jānitabbam api kadāci jānāti

analyzed: pākaṭaḥ hoti na pana cittassa na hi sattā cittaṃ nāma aniccam kadāci uppajjati  kadāci na uppajjati iti gaṇhanti tam pana sayam niccam pavattamānam hutvā kadāci sukhena  yuttam hoti kadāci dukkhena ati ādinā tasmin nicca saññam eva uppādenti iti iti cittaṃ nāma
translated: but not of consciousness. For beings do not apprehend consciousness as impermanent, thinking, “Sometimes it arises,🔽sometimes it does not arise.” But it occurs to them that it is permanent, thinking, “It is permanent, but sometimes

analyzed: visum ekam khandham katvā khandha desanam deseti iti
translated: having made it a separate aggregate, teaches the aggregate of consciousness in the teaching of the aggregates.

translated: But in the Vibhānga,

analyzed: tam vibhāvantena rūpam hi vedanā nissaya ttā bhājana ṭṭhāniyam vedanā bhuñjitabba ttā
translated: it analyzes the aggregates as follows: “Material form is the vessel because it is the basis of feeling. Feeling is the food because it is what is eaten.

original: bhojanaṭṭhāniyā. Saññā vedanassāda lābha hetuttā byañjanaṭṭhāniyā. Saṅkhārā abhisaṅkharaṇato
analyzed: bhojana ṭṭhāniyā saññā vedana ssāda lābha hetuttā byañjana ṭṭhāniyā saṅkhārā abhisaṅkharaṇato
translated: and the state of the place where the food is eaten. Perception is the state of the flavour of feeling because it is the cause of the enjoyment of it. Formations are the state of the cook because of their nature of forming.

original: bhattakārakaṭṭhāniyā. Viññāṇaṃ upabhuñjakattā bhuñjakaṭṭhāniyaṃ. Ettāvatāca adhippe
analyzed: bhatta kāraka ṭṭhāniyā viññāṇam upabhuñjaka ttā bhuñjaka ṭṭhāniyam ettāvatā ca adhippe
translated: Consciousness is the state of the eater because of its nature of enjoying. And that is all there is to the establishment of the meaning of the simile.

original: tatthasiddhīti pañceva vuttā”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ sārato nadaṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: tattha siddhi iti pañcā iva vuttā iti vuttam tat sārataḥ na daṭṭhabbam
translated: So only five are mentioned.”

original: Na hi taṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ etapparamavinicchaye āgataṃ. Upamādīpaneeva āgataṃ. Na ca
analyzed: na hi tam etad parama vinicchaye āgatam āgatam na ca
translated: But that is not a decisive conclusion in the commentary. It is only an illustration by simile.

original: bhagavatā bhājanādivikappasiddhimattaṃ uddissa pañceva khandhā vuttāti sakkā vattuṃ.
analyzed: bhagavatā bhājana ādi vikappa siddhi mattam uddissa pañca iva khandhāḥ vuttā iti sakkā vattum
translated: And it cannot be said that the Blessed One mentioned only five aggregates because he was thinking only of the establishment of the bowl, etc., as a simile.

original: Tathāsiddhassa atthassa payojanābhāvatoti.
analyzed: tathā asiddhassa atthassa payojana abhāvato ti
translated: Because there is no purpose in establishing the meaning in that way.

original: [222] Yañca tattha
analyzed: yañca tattha
translated: And what is said there🔽“This is the reason in the teaching order too, namely, that in order to show respectively the place where one eats, what one eats, the means by which one eats, the eater, and the one who eats, he spoke of only five aggregates.”

original: “Desanākkamepi idameva kāraṇaṃ. Yattha bhuñjati, yañca bhuñjati, yenaca bhuñjati, yoca bhojako, yoca bhuñjitā. Tesaṃ anukkamena dassetukāmattā”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃpi asāraṃ.
analyzed: desanā kkame pi idam eva kāraṇam yattha bhuñjati yat ca bhuñjati yena ca bhuñjati yaḥ ca bhojakaḥ yaḥ ca bhuñjitā tesam anukkamena dassetu kāma ttā ti vuttam tat pi asāram
translated: That is worthless.

original: Catunnaṃ upādānānaṃ visayabhūtā khandhā upādānakkhandhā. Sabba sabhāgadhamma pariyādānavasena🔽sāsavā anāsavāca dhammā pañcakkhandhāti vuttā, vipassanā bhūmipariggahavasena sāsavāeva🔽pañcupādānakkhandhāti vuttā. Āyatanti attano phaluppattiyā bhusaṃ ussahantā viya🔽hontīti āyatanāni. Āyatanasaddo pana chasu ajjhattikesu dvāradhammesu pavattamāno
analyzed: catunnam upādānānam visaya bhūtā khandhā upādāna kkhandhā sabba sa bhāga dhamma pariyādāna vasena  sa āsavāḥ anāsavāḥ ca dhammā pañca kkhandhā ti vuttā vipassanā bhūmi pariggaha vasena sa āsavā eva  pañca upādānakkhandhā ti vuttāḥ āyatanti attanaḥ phala uppattiyā bhusam ussahantāḥ viya  honti iti āyatanāni āyatana saddaḥ pana chasu ajjhattikesu dvāra dhammesu pavattamānaḥ
translated: The aggregates that are the objects of the four kinds of clinging are called clinging-aggregates. All states that are subject to cankers, whether themselves subject to cankers or not, are called the five aggregates, according to the method of exposition that takes all states as the five aggregates. But only those that are themselves subject to cankers are called the five aggregates subject to clinging, according to the method of exposition that takes only states belonging to the cognitive series as the five aggregates.🔽They are called sense bases because they are the bases for the arising of the corresponding kinds of consciousness, or because they are the bases for the arising of the aggregates, or because they are the bases for the arising of the world of cognitive objects.🔽The word “sense base” is used for the six internal and six external bases.

original: sañjātidesaṭṭhena nivāsaṭṭhānaṭṭhena ākaraṭṭhena, chasu bāhiresu ārammaṇadhammesu🔽pavattamāno samosaraṇaṭṭhena, ubhayatthapi kāraṇaṭṭhena pavattati. Tattha citta cetasikā🔽dhammā ekasmiṃvā bhave anamataggevā saṃsāre punappunaṃ saha jāyamānā cakkhādīsu chasu🔽dvārapadesesueva jāyanti, na aññattha. Santānānubandhavasena nivasantāpi tesveva
analyzed: sañjāti desa ṭṭhena nivāsa ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena ākara ṭṭhena chasu bāhiresu ārammaṇa dhammesu 🔽pavattamāno samosaraṇa ṭhena ubhayattha api kāraṇa ṭṭhena pavattati tattha 🔽dhammā ekasmin vā bhave anamataggā iva saṃsāre punappunam saha jāyamānā cakkha ādīsu chasu 🔽dvāra padesesu eva jāyanti na aññattha santāna anubandha vasena nivasantā api tesu eva
translated: The aggregates that are the objects of the four kinds of clinging are called clinging-aggregates . All states, whether subject to cankers or not, are called the five aggregates, according to the method of the analytical exposition of the aggregates . But only those subject to cankers are called the five aggregates subject to clinging, according to the method of the direct-knowledge exposition. They are called bases because they are the bases for the arising of their respective kinds of consciousness, and because they are the bases for the maintenance of individual existence. The word “base” is used in the sense of birthplace in the case of the six internal bases, which are states occurring among the aggregates; in the sense of a place of resort, in the case of the six external bases, which are objects; and in the sense of a source, in the case of both, since they are the source of the arising of consciousness. Herein, the states of consciousness and its concomitants are born only in the six bases beginning with the eye, either in one birth in the course of a single existence or in the course of the beginningless round of rebirths, and nowhere else. And though they dwell in continuity, they dwell only in those same bases.

original: nivasanti, na aññattha. Ākiritvā thapitā viya pavattamānāpi tesveva pavattanti, na
analyzed: nivasanti na aññattha ākiritvā thapitāḥ viya pavattamānāḥ api tesu eva pavattanti na
translated: They do not occur elsewhere. Though occurring, they occur only in them, as if they were heaped up there.

original: aññattha. Tasmā cakkhādīni chasañjātidesaṭṭhena nivāsaṭṭhānaṭṭhena ākaraṭṭhenaca
analyzed: aññattha tasmā cakkha ādīni cha sañjāti desa ṭṭhena nivāsa ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena ākara ṭṭhena ca
translated: Therefore the eye, etc., are called bases in the sense of place of abode and in the sense of source.

original: āyatanānināma. Devāyatanaṃ viya adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhenātipi vattuṃ vaṭṭatiyeva.
analyzed: devāyatanam viya vattum
translated: And it is proper to call them bases in the sense of foundation too, as a temple is.

original: Yathāca sampannapupphaphalesu khemesu rukkhesu tato tato pakkhino nilinatthāya āhāratthāyaca🔽niccaṃ samosaranti. Evaṃ rūpādīsu chasuṭhānesu tato tato cittacetasikā dhammā ārammaṇakaraṇatthāya
analyzed: yathā ca sampanna puppha phalesu khemesu rukkhesu tatas tatas pakkhinaḥ nilina tthāya āhāra tthāya ca  niccam samosaranti evam rūpa ādīsu chasu ṭhānesu tatas tatas citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ ārammaṇa karaṇa tthāya
translated: And just as birds flock together from all sides to roost and to nest in well-watered trees in a forest,🔽so too, the states of consciousness and its concomitants flock together to the six objects, form, etc., from all systems of ideas, in order to take them as objects.

original: niccaṃ samosaranti. Tasmā rūpādīni cha samosaraṇaṭṭhena āyatanānināma. Tadubhayāni
analyzed: niccam samosaranti tasmā rūpa ādīni samosaraṇa ṭṭhena tad ubhayāni
translated: Therefore the six objects are called bases in the sense of resort.

original: pana tesaṃ citta cetasikānaṃ kāraṇaṭṭhena āyatanānināma. Cakkhuca taṃ āyatanañcāti
analyzed: pana tesam citta cetasikānam kāraṇa ṭṭhena cakkhu ca tat āyatanam ca ati
translated: And both of them are called bases in the sense of cause of the states of consciousness and its concomitants.🔽The eye is that base, thus it is the eye base. So too with the rest.

original: cakkhāyatanaṃ. Evaṃ sesāni. Tattha cakkhusotāni sattānaṃ hitakriyāsu bahupakārattā
analyzed: cakkha āyatanam evam sesāni tattha cakkhu sotāni sattānam hita kriyāsu bahu pakāra ttā
translated: Herein, the eye and ear are very helpful to beings in the performance of their duties,

original: kāmarūpa byāpitattā ca pākaṭānītiādimhi vuttāni. Tehi āsannattā tadanantaraṃ ghānaṃ.
analyzed: ca pākaṭāni iti ādimhi vuttāni tehi āsanna ttā tad anantaram ghānam
translated: and they are called “visible objects” because they are spread out in the visible-data base and the form base. The nose is next to them, and so it is next to that.

original: Tato jivhāti imāni cattāri padesāyatanānināma. Tato sakalakāyabyāpako kāyo. Tato
analyzed: tatas jivhā ti imāni cattāri tato sakala kāya byāpako kāyo tato
translated: Then the tongue. These are the four “bases of the body’s superficies” . Then the body, which is spread out over the whole body. Then

Sesāni pana tesaṃ visayattā tadanukkameneva vuttānīti.🔽Kassaci pana puggalassavā sattassavā manussassavā devassavā brahmunovā vase avattitvā🔽attanoeva sabhāvaṃ dhārentīti dhātuyo. Visuṃ visuṃ vavatthitasabhāvattāvā yathāsabhāvaṃ🔽dhārīyanti sallakkhīyanti vavatthapīyantīti dhātuyo. Apica, nissatta nijjīvaṭṭhena🔽dhātuyo. Tattha nissattaṭṭhenāti sattākārā bhāvaṭṭhena sattakiccābhāvaṭṭhena. Ko
analyzed: tesam sabbesam gocara visaya ggāhakam manaḥ ti sesāni pana tesam visaya ttā tad anukkamena iva vuttāni iti  kassaci pana  sabhāvam dhārenti iti dhātuyaḥ visum visum yathāsabhāvam  dhārīyanti sallakkhīyanti vavatthapīyanti iti dhātuyaḥ apica  dhātuyaḥ tattha nissatta ṭṭhena ati satta ākārāḥ bhāva ṭṭhena satta kicca abhāva ṭṭhena ko
translated: the mind, which is the apprehender of the objective fields of all those. But the others are stated in that same order because they are the objective fields of those.

original: panettha sattākāro kiṃ sattakiccanti. Jīvayogo sattākāro. Īhāca byāpāro ca sattakiccaṃ.
analyzed: pana ittha satta ākāro kim satta kiccanti jīva yogo satta ākāro īhā ca byāpāro ca satta kiccaṃ
