analyzed: adhipati upanissayā saṅkhatāḥ asaṅkhatāḥ ca honti sesā
translated: It is said that the five kinds of immateriality

original: pavuccati. Kasmā, kadācipi rūpasaṅkhātaṃ saṇṭhānatthaṃ anupagamanato nāmantica pavuccati.
analyzed: pavuccati kasmai kadācipi rūpa saṅkhātam saṇṭhāna attham an upagamanataḥ nāma nti ca pavuccati
translated: are called “materiality” . Why? Because they do not go beyond the meaning of “arrangement” as materiality.

original: Kasmā, adhivacanasaṅkhātanāmābhidhānavaseneva suṇantehi gahetabbabhāvupagamanatoti.
analyzed: kasmai adhivacana saṅkhāta nāma abhidhāna vasena iva suṇantehi gahetabba bhāva upagamanato ti
translated: Why? Because they go to be apprehended by those who hear by means of the meaning of “verbal description,” “designation,” and “expression.”

original: 169. Paññapīyatīti paññatti. Ayaṃpi eko vacanatthoti lokiyamahājanehi thapīyati.
analyzed: paññapīyati iti ayam pi ekaḥ vacana atthaḥ ti lokiya mahājanehi thapīyati
translated: “It is designated” is “designation.” This is one meaning of the word. It is established by ordinary people.

original: Voharīyati ceva sampaṭicchī yaticāti attho. Yokoci sammutisaccabhūto byañjanattho.
analyzed: ca iva sampaṭicchī atthaḥ sammuti sacca bhūtaḥ byañjana ttho
translated: It is spoken of and accepted. This is the meaning. Whatever is the meaning of the word that is conventional truth.

original: Tathā paññāpetabbā atthā paññapīyanti etāyāti paññatti. Byañjanatthajotako paññattisaddoti
analyzed: tathā paññāpetabbāḥ atthā paññapīyanti etāya ati paññatti byañjana attha jotako paññatti saddo ti
translated: Likewise, the meanings that are to be designated are designated by this, thus it is a designation. The word “designation” indicates the meaning of the word.

original: evaṃ duvidhā paññattīti vuttaṃ tatoavasesā.La. Duvidhāhotīti. Tattha paññāpīyattā
analyzed: evam duvidhā paññattī iti vuttam tatoavasesā ala tattha
translated: Thus it is said that there are two kinds of designations. The rest are of two kinds.

original: paññattīti attha paññattimāha. Paññāpanatopaññattīti saddapaññattiṃ. Taṃtaṃbhūtavipariṇāmākāranti
analyzed: paññatti iti attha paññattim āha paññāpanato paññatti iti sadda paññattim taṃ taṃ bhūta vipariṇāma ākāranti
translated: Herein, the meaning “it is designated because it is designated” is the meaning of the designation. The meaning “designation because of the act of designating” is the meaning of the sound-designation. The appearance of the transformation of this or that element.

original: pathaviyādīnaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ adhimattabhāvappakārasaṅkhātaṃ tathā tathā
analyzed: pathaviya ādīnam tesam tesam mahābhūtānam adhimatta bhāva ppakāra saṅkhātam tathā tathā
translated: The mode of the alteration of the primary elements of earth, etc., in the various instances of their predominance is called the mode of alteration.🔽The meaning is the mode of occurrence.

original: pariṇā mākāraṃ. Pavattivisesākāranti attho. Upādāyāti paṭicca. Nissāya. Pathamaṃ
analyzed: pariṇā ma ākāram pavatti visesa ākāram ti attho upādāya ati paṭicca nissāya pathamam
translated: ‘Depending on’: by means of, relying on.🔽The meaning is: having first taken it up with the mind.

original: cittena gahetvāti attho. Tathātathā paññattāti ayaṃ pathavīnāma ayaṃ pabbatonāmāti🔽evamādi nayena mahājanena paññattā, kathitā, voharitāti attho. Pathavipabbatādikātiādisaddena
analyzed: cittena gahetvā ti attho tathā tathā paññattā ati ayam pathavī nāma ayam pabbato nāma ati  evamādi nayena mahājanena paññattā kathitā voharitā ati atthaḥ pathavi pabbata ādikā iti ādi saddena
translated: ‘Is called by such and such a name’ is said by the multitude in such and such a way, ‘This is the name of the earth,’ ‘This is the name of the mountain,’🔽and so on. The meaning is: it is called, spoken of, used in everyday speech.

original: nadi samuddādikāyo saṅgaṇhati. Ayaṃ samūhapaññattināma.
analyzed: nadi samudda ādi kāyaḥ saṅgaṇhati ayam samūha paññatti nāma
translated: The word ‘etc.’ in ‘earth, mountain, etc.’ includes rivers, oceans, and so on. This is the name that is a designation of a collection.

original: [241] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga

original: “Saṇṭhānapaññattīti” vuttā. Sā yuttā viya nadissati.🔽Nahi idha saṇṭhānaṃ padhānaṃ hotīti. Sambhārasannivesākāranti kaṭṭhādīnaṃ sambhārānaṃ
analyzed: saṇṭhāna paññattī iti vuttā sā yuttā viya na dissati  nahi idha saṇṭhānam padhānam hoti iti kaṭṭha ādīnam
translated: it is called ‘a designation of shape.’ That will not be appropriate.🔽For shape is not the principal thing here.🔽The mode of the arrangement of the components is the mode of the arrangement of the components such as timber, etc., in such and such a way.

original: tathā tathā sannivesākāraṃ. Etthāpi ādisaddena nāvādayo saṅgaṇhati. Ayaṃ saṇṭhāna
analyzed: tathā tathā sannivesa ākāram ettha api ādi saddena nāvā ādayo saṅgaṇhati ayam saṇṭhāna
translated: Here too the word ‘etc.’ includes boats, etc. This is the name that is a designation of shape.

original: paññatti. Kaṭṭhādayo eva hi gehākārena saṇṭhitā gehanti rathākārena saṇṭhitā rathoti vuccantīti.
analyzed: paññatti kaṭṭha ādayaḥ eva hi geha ākārena saṇṭhitāḥ ratha ākārena saṇṭhitāḥ ratho ti vuccanti iti
translated: For it is just logs, etc., that are so called when they are arranged in the shape of a house, etc.

original: [242] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana🔽“Samūhapaññattīti” vuttaṃ. Taṃ na yujjati.
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana  samūha paññattī iti vuttam tam na yujjati
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:🔽“The aggregate of material form is a designation for the four great primaries and for material form derived by clinging from the four great primaries.”🔽That is not correct.🔽For here the aggregate is not the primary thing;

original: Nahi idha samūho padhānanti. Purisapuggalādikā sattapaññatti upādāpaññattītipi vuccati.🔽Candāvaṭṭanādikanti candasūriyādīnaṃ sineruṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā āvaṭṭanādikaṃ. Yato
analyzed: nahi idha samūhaḥ padhānan ti purisa puggala ādikā satta paññatti upādā paññatti iti pi vuccati  canda avaṭṭana ādikam ti canda sūriya ādīnam sinerum padakkhiṇam katvā āvaṭṭana ādikam yatas
translated: The designation of a being is called a designation of a person, etc., and also a designation of what is clung to.🔽The designation of the world is the designation of the sun and moon, etc., and of the turning of the sun and moon, etc., to the right of Mount Sineru,

original: candimasūriyā udenti, sā pubbadisānāma. Pubbataraṃ laddhappakāsattā. Yattha pana🔽atthaṃ gacchanti, sā pacchimadisānāma. Pacchāladdhapakāsattā. Tāsaṃ dakkhiṇapassā
analyzed: candima sūriyāḥ udenti sā pubbadisā nāma pubbataram laddha ppakāsa ttā yattha pana  attham gacchanti sā pacchimadisā nāma pacchā laddha pakāsa ttā tāsam dakkhiṇa passā
translated: The direction in which the sun rises is called the east because it comes first in the sequence of directions, and it is called the front because it is in front of those who are facing toward it.🔽The direction in which the sun sets is called the west because it goes last in the sequence of directions, and it is called the rear because it is behind those who are facing toward it.

original: disā vuḍḍhiatthena dakkhiṇadisānāma. Itarā pana uccataraṭṭhena uttarādisāti vuccati.
analyzed: disā vuḍḍhi atthena dakkhiṇadisā nāma itarā pana uccatara aṭṭhena uttarādisā iti vuccati
translated: The direction to the right of those facing toward the east is called the south because it comes after in the sequence of directions, and the direction to the left is called the north because it is ahead in the sequence of directions.

original: Yadā sūriyo udeti, tadā sakalassa ahassa pubbabhāgattā pubbanhoti vuccatīti. Evamādikā
analyzed: yadā sūriyaḥ udeti tadā sakalassa ahassa pubbabhāga ttā pubbanho ti vuccati iti evamādikā
translated: The time when the sun is rising is called the morning because it is the beginning of the day.

original: disā paññatti kālapaññattiyonāma. Ādisaddena thalaninnādikā desapaññatti saṅgahitāti.
analyzed: disā paññatti kāla paññattiyo nāma ādi saddena thala ninna ādikā desa paññatti saṅgahitā ti
translated: Direction-apprehension, time-apprehension, and species-apprehension. And by the word “etc.” place-apprehension such as “on the ground,” “in the air,” and so on, is included.

original: Asamphuṭṭhākāranti mahābhūtānaṃ aññamaññaṃ asamphusanākāraṃ. Ayaṃ ākāsapaññattināma.
analyzed: a samphuṭṭha ākāram ti mahābhūtānam aññam aññam a samphusana ākāram ayam ākāsa paññatti nāma
translated: Unconjoined-shape is the shape of the great primaries’ mutual unconjunction. This is called “space-apprehension.”

original: Taṃ taṃ bhūtanimittanti pathavīkasiṇādikaṃ uddhumātakādikañca bhūtanimittaṃ. Nīlakasiṇādikaṃ
analyzed: tam tam bhūta nimittam ti pathavī kasiṇa ādikam uddhumātaka ādikam ca bhūta nimittam nīla kasiṇa ādikam
translated: The sign of such and such an entity is the sign of an entity such as the earth kasiṇa, the bloated corpse, and so on, and the sign of a colour such as the blue kasiṇa,

original: vaṇṇanimittañca ettheva saṅgayhati. Bhāvanā visesanti parikammādikaṃ bhāvanāvisesaṃca.
analyzed: vaṇṇa nimittam ca ettha iva parikamma ādikam bhāvanā visesam ca
translated: and so on. The “etc.” includes the sign of a visible form. The special development is the special development beginning with the preliminary work.

original: Etena parikammanimitta uggahanimitta paṭibhāganimittānaṃ siddhakāraṇaṃ vadati. Ayaṃ
analyzed: etena siddha kāraṇam vadati ayam
translated: By this he says that the cause of the success of the preliminary-work sign, the learning sign, and the counterpart sign is the special development. This is called

original: nimittapaññattināma.
analyzed: nimitta paññatti nāma
translated: “sign-apprehension.”

original: Evamādibhedāti ettha ādisaddena aṭṭhakathāyaṃ āgatā upādāpaññatti upanidhāpaññattiādayo
analyzed: evamādi bhedā ti ettha ādi saddena aṭṭhakathāyam āgatāḥ upādā paññatti upanidhā paññatti ādayaḥ
translated: By the word “etc.” in the words “apprehension of such kinds as” , the following kinds of apprehension mentioned in the commentaries are included, that is to say,🔽apprehension of what is assumed, apprehension of what is inferred, apprehension of what is accepted, apprehension of what is imagined, apprehension of what is generally agreed, apprehension of what is traditional, apprehension of what is remembered, apprehension of what is learnt, apprehension of what is remembered and learnt, apprehension of what is remembered and taught, apprehension of what is learnt and taught, apprehension of what is remembered, learnt and taught.

original: saṅgahitā. Paramatthato avijjamānāpīti etena sammutito laddhabhāvaṃ dasseti. Teneva
analyzed: saṅgahitā paramatthataḥ a vijjamānā api iti etena sammutitaḥ laddha bhāvam dasseti tena iva
translated: Although they do not exist in the ultimate sense, he shows their existence as conventional usage by the words “although they do not exist in the ultimate sense.”

original: hi tāsaṃ vijjamānabhāvaṃ gahetvā tathā tathā voharantānaṃ musāvādonāma nahotīti.🔽Atthacchāyākārenāti taṃ taṃ bhūtādīnaṃ paramatthānaṃ samūhasaṇṭhānādichāyākārena.
analyzed: hi tāsam vijjamāna bhāvam gahetvā tathā tathā voharantānam musāvādaḥ nāma iti  attha chāyā ākārena ati tam tam bhūta ādīnam param atthānam samūha saṇṭhāna ādi chāyā ākārena
translated: For those who speak thus, taking the state of their existence, do not incur the name of liars.🔽By the appearance of a shadow of meaning: by the appearance of a shadow of the ultimate realities such as the elements, etc., in the form of a collection, shape, etc.🔽Or by the appearance of a shadow of meaning: by the appearance of a shadow of the ultimate realities such as the elements, etc., in the form of a reflection of sound, i.e., a name, together with its meaning.

original: Atthacchā yākārenātivā saddābhidheyyasaṅkhātena dabbapaṭibimbākārena saviggahākārenāti
analyzed: attha chā yākārena ati vā sadda abhidheyya saṅkhātena dabba paṭibimba ākārena sa viggaha ākārena ati
translated: By the appearance of a shadow of meaning: by the appearance of a shadow of the ultimate realities such as the elements, etc., in the form of a reflection of sound, i.e., a name, together with its meaning.

original: attho, taṃtaṃupādāyāti paramatthadhammānaṃ taṃtaṃpavattivisesaṃ upādāya. Upanidhāyāti🔽olumbiya. Parikappiyamānāti parikappabuddhiyā parikappetvā gayhamānā. Ettha pana
analyzed: atthaḥ taṃ taṃ upādāya ati paramattha dhammānam taṃ taṃ pavatti visesam upādāya upanidhāya ati  olumbiya parikappiyamānā ati parikappa buddhiyā parikappetvā gayhamānā ettha pana
translated: By the appearance of a shadow of meaning: by the appearance of a shadow of the ultimate realities such as the elements, etc., in the form of a reflection of sound, i.e., a name, together with its meaning.🔽By the appearance of a shadow of meaning: by the appearance of a shadow of the ultimate realities such as the elements, etc., in the form of a reflection of sound, i.e., a name, together with its meaning.🔽By the appearance of a shadow of meaning: by the appearance of a shadow of the ultimate realities such as the elements, etc., in the form of a reflection of sound, i.e., a name, together with its meaning.

original: evamādipabhedā ālambaṇabhūtā parikappiyamānā sabbā paññatti paññāpīyatīti atthena🔽paññattīti yojanā. Saṅkhāyatīti gaṇīyati. Gaṇanupagaṃ katvā thapīyatīti attho. Samaññāyatīti
analyzed: evamādi pabhedā ālambaṇa bhūtā parikappiyamānā sabbā paññatti paññāpīyati iti atthena  paññatti iti yojanā saṅkhāyati iti gaṇīyati gaṇana upagam katvā thapīyati iti atthaḥ samaññāyati iti
translated: By the appearance of a shadow of meaning: by the appearance of a shadow of the ultimate realities such as the elements, etc., in the form of a reflection of sound, i.e., a name, together with its meaning.🔽By the appearance of a shadow of meaning: by the appearance of a shadow of the ultimate realities such as the elements, etc., in the form of a reflection of sound, i.e., a name, together with its meaning.🔽By the appearance of a shadow of meaning: by the appearance of a shadow of the ultimate realities such as the elements, etc., in the form of a reflection of sound, i.e., a name, together with its meaning.

original: sammannīyati. Nāmaṃ, nāmakammaṃ, nāmadheyyaṃ, nirutti, byañjanaṃ, abhilāpoti ime
analyzed: sammannīyati nāmam nāma kammam nāmadheyyam nirutti byañjanam abhilāpa uti ime
translated: By the appearance of a shadow of meaning: by the appearance of a shadow of the ultimate realities such as the elements, etc., in the form of a reflection of sound, i.e., a name, together with its meaning.🔽By the appearance of a shadow of meaning: by the appearance of a shadow of the ultimate realities

original: cha nāma nāmakammā. Tattha atthe namatīti nāmaṃ. Atthavisayaṃ eva hutvā pavattatīti
analyzed: cha nāma nāma kammā tattha atthe namati iti nāmam attha visayam eva hutvā pavattati iti
translated: “Six kinds” are the six kinds of naming. Herein, it is a name in the sense of bending , since it is what bends the meaning;🔽it is a meaning in the sense of what is bent , since it is what occurs bent on the meaning;

original: attho. Attanica atthaṃ nāmetīti nāmaṃ. Piṭakattayasaṅkhāte hi nāme sati taduggaṇhantānaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ attham nāma iti iti nāmam piṭaka ttaya saṅkhāte hi nāme sati
translated: it is a name in the sense of what names the meaning, since it is what names the meaning. For when there are names in the three Piṭakas, then for those who learn them

original: sabbe tadatthā padepade vākyevākye āgacchanti yevāti.
analyzed: sabbe tad atthā pade pade vākye vākye āgacchanti
translated: all their meanings come to be stated in every verse and in every prose-exposition.

original: Apica suṇantānaṃ ñāṇaṃ taṃtaṃatthābhimukhaṃ nāmetīti nāmaṃ nāmagahaṇavasena kattabbattā
analyzed: apica suṇantānam ñāṇam taṃ taṃ attha abhimukham nāma iti iti nāmam nāma gahaṇa vasena kattabba ttā
translated: Besides, it is a name in the sense of what names the knowledge of those who listen, since it is what names that by making it face the various meanings.

original: nāmameva kammanti nāmakammaṃ. Dhīyati dhārīyatīti dheyyaṃ. Nāmameva dheyyanti nāmadheyyaṃ.
analyzed: nāmam eva kammanti nāma kammam dhīyati dhārīyati iti dheyyam nāmam eva dheyyanti nāmadheyyam
translated: It is a naming in the sense of what is to be done by learning the name. It is a name-spell in the sense of a spell that is a name.

original: Aviditapakkhe ṭhito attho etāya tato nīharitvā vuccati kathīyatīti nirutti. Atthassa
analyzed: avidita pakkhe ṭhitaḥ atthaḥ etāya tatas nīharitvā vuccati kathīyati iti atthassa
translated: It is a reading in the sense of what is said by taking out the meaning that is in the unknown part and saying it.🔽It is a phrasing in the sense of what makes the meaning clear by the phrasing.

original: byañjanato pākaṭakaraṇato byañjanaṃ. Abhibyattaṃ katvā lapīyati kathīyati attho etenāti
analyzed: byañjanataḥ pākaṭa karaṇataḥ byañjanam abhibyattam katvā lapīyati kathīyati etena ati
translated: It is a verbal expression in the sense of what is said by making the meaning manifest.

original: abhilāpo. Etthaca vaṇṇapaññatti, akkharapaññatti, sarapaññatti, dīghapaññatti, rassa
analyzed: abhilāpaḥ ettha ca vaṇṇa paññatti akkhara paññatti sara paññatti dīgha paññatti rassa
translated: Herein, there is the intimation of the letter, the intimation of the syllable, the intimation of the word, the intimation of the long, the intimation of the short,

original: paññatti. Byañjanavaggaghosāghosapaññatti, liṅgapaññatti. Padapaññatti, vākyapaññattiyopi
analyzed: paññatti byañjana vagga ghosa aghosa paññatti liṅga paññatti pada paññatti vākya paññattiyo pi
translated: Description. The Description of Sounds and Non-Sounds, the Description of Gender, the Description of Words, and the Description of Phrases

original: etasseva pabhedāti daṭṭhabbā. Paramatthato vijjamānesu atthesu pavattā paññatti vijjamānapaññatti
analyzed: etassa iva pabhedā ati daṭṭhabbā paramatthataḥ vijjamānesu atthesu pavattā paññatti vijjamāna paññatti
translated: should be regarded as its varieties. Description that occurs in respect of existent meanings is called “description of existents.”

original: nāma. Avijja mānesu bhūmipabbatādīsu pavattā paññatti avijjamānapaññatti nāma. Etā
analyzed: nāma avijja mānesu bhūmi pabbata ādīsu pavattā paññatti avijjamānapaññatti nāma etā
translated: Description that occurs in respect of non-existent things such as the earth, mountains, etc., is called “description of non-existents.”

original: eva samāsaṭṭhānaṃ patvā dvipadasaṃyogavasena itarā catassopi hontīti dassetuṃ tatthātiādi
analyzed: eva samāsa ṭṭhānam patvā dvipada saṃyoga vasena itarā catasso api honti iti dassetum tattha atiādi
translated: When these two come to be combined, they are all four descriptions in the form of a compound of two words. To show this, the following is said: “Herein, etc.”

original: vuttaṃ. Etāya paññāpentīti etena vijjamānaṃ atthaṃ paññapenti etāyāti vijjamānapaññattīti🔽imamatthaṃ vadati. Esanayo paratthapi. Cha abhiññā assāti chaḷabhiññoti katvā visesanabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: vuttam etāya paññāpenti iti etena vijjamānam attham paññapenti etāya ati vijjamāna paññatti iti  imam attham vadati cha abhiññāḥ assa ati chaḍabhiññā iti katvā visesana bhūtānam
translated: By the words “They describe by this” he shows the meaning of this, namely, that they describe existents by this.🔽The same method of explanation applies to the other three descriptions.

original: channaṃ abhiññānaṃ vijjamānattā visesitabbabhūtassa puggalassa avijjamānattā chaḷa
analyzed: channam abhiññānam vijjamāna ttā visesitabba bhūtassa puggalassa a vijjamāna ttā chaḷa
translated: The word “six” is a numeral. The word “direct-knowledge” is a substantive. The compound “chaḷabhiññā” is a bahubbīhi compound. The word “puggala” is a substantive. The compound “chaḷabhiññāssa” is a tatpurisa compound. The word “samāpatti” is a substantive. The compound “catutthajjhānasamāpatti” is a tatpurisa compound. The word “puggalo” is a substantive. The compound “catutthajjhānasamāpattipaṭilābhī” is a tatpurisa compound.

original: bhiññoti vijjamānenaavijjamānapaññatti nāma. Itthī avijjamānā saddo vijjamānoti itthiyāsaddo
analyzed: bhiñño ti vijjamānena avijjamānapaññatti nāma itthī avijjamānā saddaḥ vijjamānaḥ iti itthiyā saddaḥ
translated: ‘Bhiñño’ is a name-concept of the existent by means of the non-existent. The sound ‘itthī’ is non-existent, the sound ‘saddo’ is existent.

original: itthisaddoti avijjamānena vijjamāna paññatti nāma. Cakkhuca cakkhuviññāṇañca ubhayaṃpi
analyzed: itthi saddo ti avijjamānena vijjamāna paññatti nāma cakkhu ca cakkhu viññāṇam ca ubhayam pi
translated: ‘Itthiyāsaddo’ is a name-concept of the existent by means of the non-existent. The eye and eye-consciousness are both existent.

original: vijjāmānanti cakkhusmiṃ viññāṇaṃ cakkhuviññāṇanti vijjamānenavijjamānapaññatti nāma.
analyzed: vijjāmānanti cakkhusmim viññāṇam cakkhu viññāṇam ti vijjamānenavijjamānapaññatti nāma
translated: ‘Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ’ is a name-concept of the existent by means of the existent.

original: Rājāca puttoca dvepi avijjamānāevāti rañño putto rājaputtoti avijjamānenaavijjamānapaññattināmāti
analyzed: rājā ca putto ca dve pi avijjamānā eva ati rañño putto rāja putto ti avijjamānena avijjamāna paññatti nāmā ati
translated: ‘Rājā’ and ‘putto’ are both non-existent. ‘Rājaputto’ is a name-concept of the non-existent by means of the non-existent.

original: imamatthaṃ dassento ubhinnantiādimāha.🔽Ettha pana vacanato ca vacanatthatoca vinimuttā saddasabhāvā nāmapaññattināma visuṃ🔽natthīti vadanti. Taṃ na yujjati. Atthajotaka bhāvena visuṃ siddhattā. Saddo hi nāma
analyzed: imam attham dassentaḥ ubhinnam ti ādim āha  ettha pana vacanato ca vacana atthato ca vinimuttā sadda sabhāvā nāma paññatti nāma visum  natthi iti vadanti tam na yujjati bhāvena visum siddha ttā saddaḥ hi nāma
translated: In order to show this meaning he says ‘ubhinnaṃ’ and so on.

analyzed: akkhara pada byañjana bhāvam attha jotane samatthaḥ hoti

original: paraṃ atthā viññāyantīti sambandho. Yassā nāmapaññattiyā anusārena paramatthapaññattibhūtā
analyzed: param atthāḥ viññāyanti iti sambandhaḥ yassā nāma paññattiyāḥ anusārena paramattha paññatti bhūtā
translated: The construction is: “They make known the ultimate realities by the name-concept.”

original: atthā viññāyanti. Sā ayaṃ paññatti lokasaṅketanimmitāti viññeyyāti yojanā.
analyzed: atthāḥ viññāyanti sā ayam paññatti loka saṅketa nimmitā ati viññeyyā ati yojanā
translated: The name-concept is to be understood as “made by the world’s conventional symbol.”

original: Etthaca sotaviññāṇavīthiyāti ettha atītasaddamattā rammaṇā tadanuvattikānāma manoviññāṇavīthipi
analyzed: ettha ca sota viññāṇa vīthiyā ti ettha atīta sadda mattā rammaṇā tadanuvattikā nāma manaḥ viññāṇa vīthipi
translated: Herein, “in the cognitive series of ear-consciousness” should be understood to include the cognitive series of mind-consciousness that follows upon it.

original: saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbā. Vuttañhi sāratthadīpaniyaṃ-tena vuttavacane yattakāni akkharāni
analyzed: saṅgahitā ti daṭṭhabbā vuttam hi vutta vacane yattakāni akkharāni
translated: For it is said in the Sarattha-Dīpanī: “In the words spoken, there are so many syllables.🔽Taking each one as present and past,

original: honti. Tesu ekamekaṃ paccuppannaṃ atītañca gahetvā sota viññāṇavīthiyā manoviññāṇavīthiyāca
analyzed: honti tesu ekam ekam paccuppannam atītam ca gahetvā sota viññāṇa vīthiyā manas viññāṇa vīthiyā ca
translated: when the cognitive series of ear-consciousness and the cognitive series of mind-consciousness have arisen and ceased,

original: uppajjitvā niruddhāya avasāne tāni akkharāni sampiṇḍetvā akkharasamūhaṃ gahetvā ekā🔽manoviññāṇavīthi uppajjitvā nirujjhati. Tadanantaraṃ ayaṃ akkharasamūho etassa nāmanti
analyzed: uppajjitvā niruddhāya avasāne tāni akkharāni sampiṇḍetvā akkhara samūham gahetvā ekā  manaḥ viññāṇa vīthi uppajjitvā nirujjhati tad anantaram ayam akkhara samūho etassa nāman ti
translated: at the end, they are all combined and taken as a single syllable-group,🔽and a single cognitive series of mind-consciousness arises and ceases, thinking: ‘This syllable-group is the name.’

original: nāmapaññattigahaṇavasena aparāya manoviññāṇa vīthiyā uppajjitvā niruddhāya tadanantaraṃ
analyzed: nāma paññatti gahaṇa vasena aparāya manaḥ viññāṇa vīthiyā uppajjitvā niruddhāya tad anantaram
translated: After that, in the cognitive series of mind-consciousness that has arisen and ceased, thinking: ‘This syllable-group is the name,’

original: uppannāya manoviññāṇa vīthiyā ayametassa atthoti pakatiyā tadatthavijānanaṃ sambhavatīti.
analyzed: uppannāya manaḥ viññāṇa vīthiyā ayam etassa atthaḥ ti pakatiyā tad attha vijānanam sambhavati iti
translated: and so the understanding of the meaning of the sign arises in the normal way.

original: Maṇisāramañjūsāyaṃ pana tadanuvattikavīthito paraṃ ekaṃ vinicchayavīthiṃ viññattigahaṇavīthiñca
analyzed: maṇisāramañjūsāyam pana tad anuvattika vīthitaḥ param ekam vinicchaya vīthim viññatti gahaṇa vīthim ca
translated: But in the Maṇisāra mañjūsā it is said that after the first cognitive series there is a second, a determining series, and a third, a verbalizing series.

original: vadati. Tato paraṃ ekakkhare sadde ekatthajotikāya nāmapaññattiyā gahaṇaṃ hoti. Yā
analyzed: vadati tatas param ekakkhare sadde ekattha jotikāya nāma paññattiyāḥ gahaṇam hoti yā
translated: After that, in the case of a sound consisting of one syllable, there is apprehension of the name-group consisting of the name that signifies the single meaning.

original: vadantassa pubbabhāge manasā vavatthāpito paññattisaddonāma vuccati. Tatoparaṃ tadatthagahaṇanti.
analyzed: vadantassa pubba bhāge manasā vavatthāpito paññatti saddo nāma vuccati tatas uparam tad attha gahaṇam ti
translated: The name of the sound that is defined by the mind in the first stage is called a “name-group consisting of a single name.” After that there is apprehension of the meaning.

original: Īdisesu pana ṭhānesu tattha tattha javanavīthivārānaṃ paṭipāṭikathanaṃnāma padhānapākaṭagahaṇavasenevāti
analyzed: īdisesu pana ṭhānesu tattha tattha javana vīthi vārānam paṭipāṭi kathanaṃ nāma padhāna pākaṭa gahaṇa vasena iva ati
translated: But in such passages as this, the order of succession of the javanas should be regarded as stated according to the order of prominence.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ekaccharakkhaṇe aneka koṭisatasahassāni cittāni uppajjantīti hi vuttaṃ. Tathā –
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam ekaccha rakkhaṇe aneka koṭi sata sahassāni cittāni uppajjanti iti hi vuttam tathā
translated: For it is said that in a single moment of consciousness many hundreds of thousands of millions of consciousnesses arise.

original: Ekamatto bhave rasso, dvimatto dīghamuccate;
analyzed: eka mattaḥ bhave rassaḥ dvi mattaḥ dīgham uccate
translated: And so: “One unit is called a ‘short’ ; two units, a ‘long’ ;

original: Timattotupluto ñeyyo, byañjanaṃ addhamattikanticaṃ.
analyzed: ti matta utu plutaḥ ñeyyaḥ byañjanam addha matti kanticam
translated: Three units, a ‘pluta’ ; the ‘vowel sandhi’ is half a unit.”

original: Na ca paramatthasaddasaṅghāṭānaṃ satasahassaṃpi ekakkharaṃnāma bhavituṃ pahoti. Tasmā idha bahuṃ vicāraṇā amhehi nakatāti.
analyzed: na ca paramattha sadda saṅghāṭānam sata sahassam pi ekakkharam nāma bhavitum pahoti tasmai idha bahum vicāraṇā amhehi
translated: And a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand of the ultimate terms cannot be a single syllable. Therefore we have not written much here about it.

original: Iti paramatthadīpaniyānāma abhidhammatthasaṅgahassa
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus in the Abhidhamma Treatise called The Great Chapter

original: Catutthavaṇṇanāya aṭṭhamassa paccayasaṅgahassa🔽Paramatthadīpanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: catuttha vaṇṇanāya aṭṭhamassa paccaya saṅgahassa
translated: in the fourth chapter called The Conditions Chapter🔽The Great Chapter is finished.

original: Kammaṭṭhāna saṅgaha paramatthadīpanī🔽170. Evaṃ aṭṭhahi paricchedehi sapaccayapabhedaṃ nāmarūpa vibhāgaṃ dassetvā idāni
analyzed: evam aṭṭhahi paricchedehi sa paccaya pabhedam nāma rūpa vibhāgam dassetvā idāni
translated: The Great Chapter🔽Having thus shown the analysis of mentality-materiality with its conditions by means of the eight sections beginning with “Conditioned by ignorance are formations,”

original: viditanāmarūpa vibhāgassa kammaṭṭhānavidhānaṃ dassento samathavipassanānantiādi māha.
analyzed: vidita nāma rūpa vibhāgassa kammaṭṭhāna vidhānam dassento samatha vipassanā na ti ādi mā āha
translated: now, in order to show the method of development of meditation subjects for one who has thus discerned the analysis of mentality-materiality, he said, “Concentration and insight,” etc.🔽The construction is: “I shall explain the twofold meditation subject,

original: Ito paccaya saṅgahato paraṃ samathavipassanānaṃ bhāvanānaṃ duvidhaṃpi kammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽yathākkamaṃ pavakkhāmīti yojanā. Tattha kilese aññepivā vitakkādayo oḷārikadhamme
analyzed: itas saṅgahato param samatha vipassanānam bhāvanānam duvidham pi kammaṭṭhānam  yathākkamam pavakkhāmi iti yojanā tattha kilese vitakka ādayaḥ oḷārika dhamme
translated: which is the means to the development of both concentration and insight,🔽after the Conditions Chapter.” Herein, it is calm because it meets, or because it is met by, the defilements, or other gross states such as applied thought, etc.,

original: sametīti samatho. Tathā pavatto ekaggatāsaṅkhāto samādhi. Visesena passanti etāyāti
analyzed: sameti iti samathaḥ tathā pavattaḥ ekagga tā saṅkhāto samādhi visesena passanti etāya ati
translated: or because it meets, or is met by, the grossness of the earlier states. Concentration is unification of mind, which is called “one-pointedness of mind” . It sees, or penetrates, or inspects, severally, or it is itself severally seen, penetrated, inspected; thus insight .

original: vipassanā. Aniccānupassanādikā bhāvanāpaññā. Tāya hi yogino khandhesu lokiyamahājanena
analyzed: vipassanā anicca anupassanā ādikā bhāvanā paññā tāya hi yoginaḥ khandhesu lokiya mahājanena
translated: Insight. This is the understanding that comes through development, such as the contemplation of impermanence, etc. For by this the meditator sees the aggregates as impermanent, painful, and not-self.

original: passitaṃ itthipurisādikaṃ niccasukhādikañca atikkamitvā visesena aniccādikameva passantīti.
analyzed: passitam itthi purisa ādikam nicca sukha ādikañca atikkamitvā visesena anicca ādikam eva passanti iti
translated: Insight is the understanding that comes from development, that is, from the contemplation of impermanence, etc. For by means of this the meditator, having transcended the perception of woman, man, etc., and of permanent, pleasant, etc., which is held by the worldling, sees the aggregates as impermanent, etc., in a special way.

original: Bhāvetabbāti bhāvanā. Bhāventivā cittasantānaṃ etāhīti bhāvanā. Kiriyā kammaṃ. Tiṭṭhati🔽etthāti ṭhānaṃ. Kammassa ṭhānanti kammaṭṭhānaṃ. Vīriyārabbhasaṅkhātassa yogakammassa🔽pavattiṭṭhānanti attho. Kasiṇamaṇḍalādikaṃ kasiṇabhāvanādikañca. Ādimajjha pariyosānānañhi
analyzed: bhāvetabbā ati bhāvanā bhāventivā citta santānam etāhi iti bhāvanā kiriyā kammam tiṭṭhati  ettha ati ṭhānam kammassa ṭhānan ti kammaṭṭhānam vīriya ārabbha saṅkhātassa yoga kammassa  pavatti ṭṭhānanti attho kasiṇa maṇḍala ādikam kasiṇa bhāvanā ādikam ca ādi majjha hi
translated: Or alternatively, bhāvanā is that by which there is bhāvana, i.e., the development of the continuity of consciousness.

original: samudāyabhūkaṃ ekametaṃ pathavīkasiṇa bhāvanādikaṃ bhāvanākammaṃpi attano avayavabhūtassa
analyzed: samudāya bhūkam ekam etam pathavī kasiṇa bhāvanā ādikam bhāvanā kammam api attanaḥ avayava bhūtassa
translated: The object of the meditation subject is the kasiṇa, etc., and the development of the kasiṇa, etc. For the development of the earth kasiṇa, etc., is a single act of consciousness that is a collection of the beginning, middle, and end.🔽And that is a basis for the occurrence of the act of consciousness consisting in the yoga of energy,

original: yoga kammassa pavattiṭṭhānaṃ sambhavatīti.
analyzed: yoga kammassa pavatti ṭṭhānam sambhavati iti
translated: which is what is meant by the expression “object of the meditation subject.”

original: Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga it is said:

original: Uttaruttara yogakammassa padaṭṭhānatāya kammaṭṭhānabhūtaṃ bhāvanāvidhiñcātipi vuttaṃ. Tampi yujjatiyeva.
analyzed: uttara uttara yoga kammassa padaṭṭhāna tāya kammaṭṭhāna bhūtam vuttam tam pi
translated: “The meditation subject is the method of development consisting in the directions for development. ” This is also appropriate,

original: Yogakammamevavā sukhavisesānaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhenaṭhānanti kammaṭṭhānaṃ. Tatthāti tasmiṃ🔽duvidhepi kammaṭṭhāne. Samathasaṅgaheti samatha kammaṭṭhānasaṅgahe. Dasakasiṇānīti🔽dasakasiṇamaṇḍalāni kasiṇajjhānānica. Tadubhayānipi hi yogānuyogasaṅkhātassa samatha🔽kammassa pavattiṭṭhānattā samathakammaṭṭhānānināma hontīti. Dasaasubhāti dasaasubhavatthūni
analyzed: sukha visesānam kammaṭṭhānam tattha ti tasmin  duvidhe api kammaṭṭhāne samatha saṅgaha iti kammaṭṭhāna saṅgahe dasa kasiṇāni iti  dasa kasiṇa maṇḍalāni kasiṇa jhānāni ca tad ubhayāni pi hi yoga anuyoga saṅkhātassa  kammassa pavatti ṭṭhāna ttā samatha kammaṭṭhānāni nāma honti iti dasa asubhā ati dasa asubha vatthūni
translated: The meditation subject is the means for the attainment of the special kinds of pleasure, in the sense of the basis for the attainment of them.🔽In that: in that twofold meditation subject.🔽In the case of serenity: in the case of the meditation subject for serenity.🔽The ten kasiṇas: the ten kasiṇa discs and the kasiṇa jhānas.🔽For both of these are called meditation subjects for serenity because they are the means for the occurrence of serenity consisting in the practice of development.🔽The ten kinds of foulness: the ten object for the development of foulness meditation.

original: asubhajjhānānica. Dasaanussati yoti buddhaguṇādīni dasaanussatiṭṭhānāni anussaraṇasati🔽yoca. Sesānipi yathānurūpaṃ vattabbānīti. Caraṇaṃ cariyā. Samudācaraṇanti attho.🔽Pavattibahulatāti vuttaṃ hoti. Rāgassa cariyā rāgacariyā. Rāgacaritāti pāṭho, so🔽aṭṭhakathāyaṃ natthi, puggalaṭṭhāneeva so yuttoti. Esanayo sesesupi.🔽[243] Yo pana vibhāvaniyaṃ
analyzed: asubha jjhānāni ca dasa anussati buddha guṇa ādīni dasa anussati ṭhānāni anussaraṇa sati 🔽yathānurūpam vattabbāni iti caraṇam cariyā samudācaraṇam ti atthaḥ 🔽pavatti bahula tā ti vuttam hoti rāgassa cariyā rāga cariyā rāga caritā ati pāṭhaḥ so 🔽aṭṭhakathā yam natthi so yutto ti esa nayo sesesu pi 🔽yaḥ pana
translated: The meditation subject is the means of achieving the special kinds of pleasure. The meaning is: the basis for the achievement of the special kinds of pleasure. Therein: in that twofold meditation subject. In the category of serenity: in the category of serenity meditation subjects. The ten kasiṇas: the ten kasiṇa discs and the kasiṇa jhānas. For both of them are called serenity meditation subjects since they are the basis for the occurrence of serenity consisting in devotion to serenity. The ten kinds of foulness: the ten object for the foulness meditation and the foulness jhānas. The ten recollections: the ten recollections of the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., and the mindfulness that recollects them. The rest should be construed in the same way as is suitable. Practice is practice of. The meaning is: occurrence. The practice of lust is the practice of lust. The reading is “rāgacariyā” . That is not in the commentary, but it is appropriate as a designation of a type of person. The same method applies in the case of the rest. But in the Vibhaṅga it is said: “What is the practice of lust?

original: Cariyānaṃ saṃsaggabhedo vutto. So idha nādhippeto.
analyzed: cariyānam saṃsagga bhedaḥ vuttaḥ saḥ idha na adhippetaḥ
translated: The difference in temperament as to whether one is a person of mixed temperament or a person of single temperament is mentioned in the Paṭisambhidā. But that is not intended here.

original: Nahi kammaṭṭhānānaṃnāma saṃsaggacaritassapi ekassa dve tīṇi dātabbāni hotīti. Teneva🔽hi so bhedo aṭṭhakathāyaṃ nagarukatoti. Sabbāpi appanāya pubbabhāgapavattā kāmāvacara
analyzed: nahi ekassa dve tīṇi dātabbāni hoti iti tena iva  hi so bhedaḥ aṭṭhakathā ayam nagaru kato ti sabbā api appanāya pubba bhāga pavattā kāmāvacara
translated: For it is not necessary to give two or three meditation subjects to a person of mixed temperament who is a beginner.🔽That is why that difference is not mentioned in the Commentaries.🔽All the kinds of development of meditation in the sense sphere that occur in the preliminary stage to absorption are called “preliminary-work development.”

original: bhāvanā parikammabhāvanānāma. Sā pana appanāya āsanne dūreti duvidhā hoti. Tattha
analyzed: bhāvanā parikamma bhāvanā nāma sā pana appanāya āsanne dūrā iti duvidhā hoti tattha
translated: But that is twofold as remote and proximate to absorption.

original: yā āsanne, sā appanaṃ upecca samīpe ṭhatvā pavattattā upacārabhāvanāti vuccati. Itarā🔽pana parikamma bhāvanāevanāma. Iti parikammabhāvanāpi samānā pubbāparavisesa pākaṭabhāvatthaṃ
analyzed: yā āsanne sā appanam upecca samīpe ṭhatvā pavatta ttā upacāra bhāvanā ati vuccati itarā  pana iti parikamma bhāvanā api samānā pubba apara visesa pākaṭa bhāva attham
translated: Herein, that which is remote occurs after absorption has been reached and is called “access development” because it occurs close to absorption.🔽The other is called “preliminary-work development.”🔽So it is said that “preliminary-work development” is mentioned by two names in the Commentaries in order to show the difference between what is earlier and what is later and to make it clear that it is the same as preliminary-work development.

original: aṭṭhakathāsu dvīhi nāmehi gahitāti vuttaṃ parikammabhāvanā.La. Tissobhāvanāti tāsaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāsu dvīhi nāmehi gahitā ti vuttam tāsam
translated: The three kinds of development will be dealt with below .

original: pana viseso parato āgamissati. Parikammanimittanti parikammabhāvanāya ārammaṇabhūtaṃ
analyzed: pana visesaḥ paratas āgamissati parikamma nimittan ti parikamma bhāvanāya ārammaṇa bhūtam
translated: The sign of the preliminary work is the object of the preliminary-work development.

original: kasiṇamaṇḍalādinimittaṃ. Tañca tassā ārammaṇa bhāvena ekaṃpi samānaṃ pubbāparavisesapākaṭabhāvatthaṃ
analyzed: kasiṇa maṇḍala ādi nimittam tat ca tassā ārammaṇa bhāvena ekam pi samānam pubba apara visesa pākaṭa bhāva attham
translated: The sign is the kasiṇa disk, etc., and that is the same as the object in the sense of being the object of the jhāna, but it is called the learning sign because it is the counterpart of the preliminary sign and because it is evident as the result of the prior development.

original: parikammanimittaṃ uggahanimittanti dvidhā bhinditvā vuttaṃ. Tesaṃpi viseso āgamissati.
analyzed: parikamma nimittam uggaha nimittam ti dvidhā bhinditvā vuttam tesam pi visesaḥ āgamissati
translated: The difference between them will be explained later.

original: Vidatthicaturaṅgulasaṅkhātena parittapamāṇenavā khala maṇḍalādisaṅkhātena mahantapamāṇenavā🔽kataṃ akataṃvā pathavī maṇḍalatalameva asesapharitabbaṭṭhena kasiṇanti pathavīkasiṇaṃ.
analyzed: vidatthi catur aṅgula saṅkhātena paritta pamāṇena vā khala maṇḍala ādi saṅkhātena mahanta pamāṇena vā  katam a katam vā pathavī maṇḍala talam eva kasiṇanti pathavī kasiṇam
translated: The kasiṇa is either limited or exalted. It is limited when it is the size of a bushel of white mustard seed, and so on. It is exalted when it is the size of the kasiṇa disk, and so on.🔽It is either made or unmade. It is made when it is made by someone, and it is unmade when it is not made by anyone. It is the surface of the earth, which is to be pervaded in its entirety, in the sense of being pervaded by the consciousness and the mental factors.

original: Sakalasaddapariyāyo hi kasiṇasaddo. Yathā kasiṇena jambudīpassāti. Tasmā yattake
analyzed: sakala sadda pariyāyaḥ hi kasiṇa saddaḥ yathā kasiṇena jambudīpassa ati tasmā yattake
translated: The word kasiṇa is a collective term, like the word “chariots.”

original: pathavītale nimittaṃ gaṇhāti, tattakaṃ cittena asesaṃ pharitvā eva gahetabbaṃ hoti.
analyzed: pathavī tale nimittam gaṇhāti tattakam cittena asesam pharitvā eva gahetabbam hoti
translated: So it is the whole extent of the earth’s surface that is to be apprehended by the mind as a single unit, pervading it entirely.

original: Na pana tassa ekadese ṭhatvāti, tena vuttaṃ pathavīmaṇḍalatalameva asesapharitabbaṭṭhena
analyzed: na pana tassa eka dese ṭhatvā ti tena vuttam pathavī maṇḍala talam eva asesa pharitabba ṭṭhena
translated: It is not to be apprehended by standing in one place.

original: kasiṇanti pathavīkasiṇanti. Esanayo sesakasiṇesupīti. Etthaca, avibhūtavaṇṇāya pathaviyā
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇanti sesa kasiṇesu pi iti ettha ca avibhūta vaṇṇāya pathaviyā
translated: The kasiṇa is the earth kasiṇa. The search is for the rest of the kasiṇas.🔽Herein, the earth kasiṇa is the sign arisen from the water kasiṇa, etc., that has earth as its domain.

original: eka talabhāvenasanniviṭṭhāsaṇṭhānapaññattiidhapathavīkasiṇaṃnāma. Tathā āpokasiṇaṃ
analyzed: eka tala bhāvena sanniviṭṭha asaṇṭhāna paññatti idha pathavīkasiṇam nāma tathā āpokasiṇam
translated: The kasiṇa is the earth kasiṇa. So too with the rest of the kasiṇas. Herein, the earth kasiṇa is a kasiṇa derived by leaving out what is not earth from the earth and water, etc., that are not separated out, and taking the earth only.🔽So too with the water kasiṇa, the fire kasiṇa, and the air kasiṇa.

original: tejokasiṇañca. Phuṭṭhaṭṭhāne cittena saṇṭhānaṃ katvā gahitā vāyuvaṭṭi vāyokasiṇaṃnāma.
analyzed: tejokasiṇam ca phuṭṭha ṭṭhāne cittena saṇṭhānam katvā gahitā vāyuvaṭṭi vāyokasiṇam nāma
translated: The air kasiṇa is a kasiṇa derived by apprehending the shape of the air current as it is directed by the mind in the place touched by the air.

original: Nīlavaṇṇavisiṭṭhāekā saṇṭhānapaññatti nīlakasiṇaṃnāma. Tathā pītalohito dātakasiṇānipi.🔽Candasūriyaaggobhāsavisiṭṭhā katthaci dissamānā saṇṭhānapaññatti ālokakasiṇaṃnāma.

translated: In-breath and out-breath are called “in-breathings and out-breathings.” It “melts” , “dissolves” , thus it is “loving-kindness” . The meaning is that it “melts” , “dissolves” , by making the welfare and happiness of the one it arises towards “unmixed” , “unadulterated.” It is “loving-kindness” because it is “like a friend” , or it is “loving-kindness” because it is “for a friend” . But in fact it is simply non-hate that occurs as the bringing of welfare to other beings. It “looks on” at other beings’ welfare and happiness, which is called “the giving of welfare” and “the giving of happiness,” by abandoning the state of ill will consisting in the depriving of welfare and happiness, and it “looks on” at their ownership of their kamma-result by abandoning the state of sensual-desire-lust consisting in the depriving of their ownership of their kamma-result. Thus it is “equanimity” . In fact it is simply the neutrality that occurs in that way. It “occurs” in “immeasurable” beings, thus it is “immeasurable” . For it should be practiced not only towards these beings but also towards others. It is not that it should not be practiced towards others. So it has no limited field of application. Nevertheless, a beginner should first of all practice it towards himself, or towards a being in the animal kingdom, whichever is most compliant. Then towards a friend, a companion, a blood relation, a neighbor, a fellow-dweller, and an inhabitant of the same country, but of another village. Then in all directions, upwards, downwards, across, and everywhere.

original: nissaraṇañhetaṃ rāgassa. Yadidaṃ upekkhā ceto vimuttīti vacanato upekkhā rāgacaritassāti
analyzed: nissaraṇam hetam rāgassa yat idam upekkhā cetaḥ vimutti iti vacanataḥ upekkhā rāga caritassa ati
translated: it would be necessary to say that equanimity is the counterpart sign for those of lustful temperament, since it is said that equanimity is the escape from lust,

original: vattabbaṃ siyāti. Nīlādīnica cattāri kasiṇānīti idañca manāpiyarūpāni nīlādīni sandhāya🔽vuttaṃ. Amanāpiyāni pana tāni rāgacaritasseva sappāyānīti. Ānāpāṇasati bhāvetabbā
analyzed: vattabbam siyāti nīla ādīni ca cattāri kasiṇāni iti idam ca nīla ādīni sandhāya  vuttam amanāpiyāni pana tāni rāga caritassa iva sappāyāni iti ānāpāna sati bhāvetabbā
translated: “It might be said.” The four kasiṇas beginning with the blue one are mentioned in the sense of the blue, etc., that are pleasing forms.🔽But the unpleasing ones are suitable for one of greedy temperament. Mindfulness of breathing should be developed

original: vitakkupacchedāyāti vacanato ānāpāṇaṃvitakkacaritassāti vuttaṃ. Mohacarito pana pakatiyā
analyzed: vitakka upacchedāya ati vacanataḥ ānāpāṇaṃvitakka caritassa ati vuttam moha caritaḥ pana pakatiyā
translated: for the cutting off of applied thoughts. Therefore it is said that breathing is suitable for one of discursive-thinking temperament. But one of deluded temperament is usually

original: pamādabahulo hoti vikkhittacittoca. Ānāpāṇañcanāma nirantaraṃ pavattamānaṃ tassa
analyzed: pamāda bahulaḥ hoti vikkhitta citta ūcaḥ nirantaram pavattamānam tassa
translated: careless and his cognizance is scattered. And breathing occurs as if arousing mindfulness in him, since it occurs uninterruptedly.

original: satiṃ uppādentaṃ viya pavattatīti taṃ mohacaritassasappāyanti vuttaṃ siyā.
analyzed: satim uppādentam viya pavattati iti tam vuttam siyā
translated: Therefore it might be said that breathing is suitable for one of deluded temperament.

original: [244] Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhaṅga

original: Buddhivisayabhāvena mohapaṭipakkhattāti kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃ yuttaṃ viya na dissati.
analyzed: buddhi visaya bhāvena moha paṭipakkha ttā ti kāraṇam vuttam tat yuttam viya na dissati
translated: the reason given is this: “Because it is the province of understanding it is a counteraction to delusion.” That does not seem appropriate.🔽For if that were so, it would have to be said to be suitable for one of understanding temperament.

original: Evañhi sati so buddhicaritena saha vattabbo siyāti. Kāmañca buddhaguṇādayopi ekantena
analyzed: evam hi sati saḥ buddhi caritena saha vattabbo siyāti kāmam ca buddha guṇa ādayaḥ api ekantena
translated: And it is true that the special qualities of the Enlightened One, etc., are exclusively🔽the province of understanding. But it is said that the recollection of the Buddha,

original: buddhivisayāeva honti. Te pana visesato saddhaṃ upabrūhayantīti vuttaṃ buddhānussati
analyzed: buddhi visayāḥ eva honti te pana visesataḥ saddham upabrūhayanti iti vuttam buddha anussati
translated: which is the special quality of understanding, increases faith.

original: ādayo.La. Saddhācaritassāti. Paramatthato sukhumatarāni maraṇādīni vipulabuddhīnaṃ
analyzed: saddhā caritassa ati paramatthataḥ sukhumatarāni maraṇa ādīni vipula buddhīnam
translated: and so on. “For one of faithful temperament”: the more subtle kinds of object beginning with death are the province only of those of wide-ranging understanding.

original: eva visayānāma hontīti vuttaṃ maraṇa. La. Buddhicaritassāti. Sesānipanasabbānipīti
analyzed: eva visayā nāma honti iti vuttam buddhi caritassa ati
translated: That is why it is said that “death is for one of understanding temperament.”

original: cattāri bhūta kasiṇāni dve ālokākāsakasiṇāni cattāro āruppācāti dasavidhāni kammaṭṭhānāni.
analyzed: cattāri bhūta kasiṇāni dve āloka ākāsa kasiṇāni cattāro āruppā ca ati dasavidhāni kammaṭṭhānāni
translated: “The rest are all suitable”: the four kinds of earth kasiṇa, the two kinds of light kasiṇa, the two kinds of space kasiṇa, and the four immaterial kasiṇas—these ten meditation subjects.

original: Tatthāpīti tesu dasasu sesa kammaṭṭhānesupi. Puthulaṃ khalamaṇḍalādipamāṇaṃ mohacaritassa
analyzed: tattha api iti tesu dasasu sesa kammaṭṭhānesu pi puthulam khala maṇḍala ādi pamāṇam moha caritassa
translated: “There too”: among those ten remaining meditation subjects. A large kasiṇa, the size of a winnowing basket, is suitable for one of deluded temperament.

original: sappāyaṃ. Sambādhasmiñhi okāse cittaṃ bhiyyo saṃmohaṃ āpajjatīti. Khuddakaṃ vidatthicaturaṅgulapamāṇaṃ
analyzed: sappāyam sambādhasmin hi okāse cittam bhiyyas saṃmoham āpajjati iti khuddakam vidatthi catur aṅgula pamāṇam
translated: For the mind falls more quickly into delusion in a confined space. A small one, the size of a saucer or a cake of soap-powder, is suitable for one of speculative-thinking temperament.

original: vitakkacaritasseva sappāyaṃ. Mahantañhi vitakkasandhāvanassa paccayo hotīti. Tatthaca
analyzed: vitakka caritassa iva sappāyam mahantam hi vitakka sandhāvanassa paccayaḥ hoti iti tattha ca
translated: For a large one is a condition for the occurrence of applied thoughts in one given to speculation.

original: vitakkacaritassevāti ettha evasaddo khuddakantipade yujjati. Vitakkacaritassa khuddakameva
analyzed: vitakka caritassa iva ati ettha eva saddaḥ khuddaka nti pade yujjati vitakka caritassa khuddakam eva
translated: And here the word “only” in the clause “and for one of understanding temperament only” should be construed with the word “small” in the clause “a small one is suitable for one of speculative-thinking temperament only.”

original: sappāyaṃ. Na puthulanti. Sabbañcetaṃ ujuvipaccanikavasenaceva atisappāyatāyaca vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sappāyam na puthulanti sabbañca etam uju vipaccanika vasena ca iva ati sappāya tāya ca vuttam
translated: “Not too wide”: all this is said according to what is suitable for the right kind of individual.

original: Rāgādīnaṃ pana avikkhambhikā saddhādīnañca anupakārikā kusalabhāvanānāma natthītipi
analyzed: rāga ādīnam pana avikkhambhikā saddhā ādīnam ca anupakārikā kusala bhāvanā nāma natthi iti pi
translated: But there is nothing that does not help to suppress greed, etc., and to promote faith, etc., in the development of profitable states.🔽This is said in the commentaries.🔽In all: in all the forty meditation subjects.

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Sabbatthāpīti sabbesupi cattālīsa kammaṭṭhānesu. Parikammabhāvanā
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam vuttam sabbattha api iti sabbesu pi cattālīsa kammaṭṭhānesu parikamma bhāvanā
translated: The development of access is possible in all.

original: labbhateva parikammena vinā ekassapi kammaṭṭhānassa asampajjanato. Dasasukammaṭṭhānesuupacārabhāvanāva🔽sampajjati natthi appanā. Kasmā iti ce. Buddha dhamma saṅgha sīla cāga devatā upasama
analyzed: labbha tā iva parikammena vinā ekassa api kammaṭṭhānassa a sampajjanataḥ dasasu kammaṭṭhānesu upacāra bhāvanā va  sampajjati natthi appanā kasmai iti ce buddha dhamma saṅgha sīla cāga devatā upasama
translated: But only in ten meditation subjects is absorption possible.🔽Why is that? Because the qualities of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha, virtue, generosity, and the devas, and the perception of still more refined aspects of the object,

original: guṇānaṃ tāva gambhīratāya nānāppakāraguṇā nussaraṇādhimuttatāyagāti hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: guṇānam tāva gambhīra tāya hi aṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: are profound. This is said in the commentaries.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha gambhīra tāyāti etena ekekassapi guṇapadassa gambhīrattā tabbisayo
analyzed: vuttam tattha gambhīra tāya iti etena ekekassa api guṇa padassa gambhīra ttā tad visayaḥ
translated: Herein, “profound” : because each of the terms is profound, and because the meaning of each is profound.

original: samādhi mahāsamudde sasako viya tattha appanaṃ patvā niccalabhāvena patiṭṭhātuṃ nasakkotīti🔽dasseti. Nānāppakāra guṇānussaraṇādhimuttatāyavāti etena tesaṃ guṇānaṃ atappa niyasabhāvattā
analyzed: mahā samudde sasakaḥ viya tattha appanam patvā niccala bhāvena patiṭṭhātum nasakkoti iti  dasseti etena tesam guṇānaṃ
translated: He shows that it cannot stand still with absorption by entering upon it and attaining to absorption, like a hare in the great ocean.

original: ettakeeva guṇapade ṭhatvā appanaṃ pāpessāmīti attano cittaṃ sandhāretuṃpi nasakkotīti
analyzed: ettake eva guṇa pade ṭhatvā appanam pāpessāmi iti attano cittam sandhāretum pi na sakkoti iti
translated: By the words “because of his being intent on recollecting the special qualities in their various aspects” he shows that he cannot even hold his mind steady by thinking “I will attain to absorption by standing on this much of the special qualities,” because of the unwearying and unbending nature of those special qualities.🔽He shows that it cannot stand still with absorption.

original: dassetīti. Sesesu pana maraṇasaññāvavatthānesu maraṇaṃ tāva sabhāva dhammattā saṃvejanīyadhammattāca
analyzed: dasseti iti sesesu pana maraṇa saññā vavatthānesu maraṇam tāva dhamma ttā saṃvejanīya dhamma ttā ca
translated: But in the remaining three instances of the contemplation of death, death itself is a natural state and a state that inspires one to strive,

original: itarānica dve sabhāvadhammatāya gambhīrattā appanāya patiṭṭhā nahontīti. Yadievaṃ
analyzed: itarāni ca dve gambhīra ttā appanāya patiṭṭhā na honti iti yadi evam
translated: and the other two are natural states and are profound, so absorption does not stand still with them.🔽If that is so,

original: kasmā lokuttarajjhānāni atigambhīre nibbānasaṅkhāte sabhāvadhamme appanaṃ pāpuṇanti.
analyzed: kasmā lokuttara jhānāni ati gambhīre nibbāna saṅkhāte sa bhāva dhamme appanam pāpuṇanti
translated: why does the supramundane jhāna attain to absorption in the natural state called Nibbāna, which is exceedingly profound?🔽And why do the second and fourth immaterial jhānas attain to absorption in the natural states called the base consisting of boundless space and the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception?

original: Dutīyacatutthāruppajjhānānica pathamatatīyāruppa saṅkhāte sabhāvadhammeti. Vuccate,
analyzed: dutīya catuttha āruppa jhānāni ca pathama tatīya āruppa saṅkhāte sa bhāva dhammā iti vuccate
translated: It may be said as follows:

original: lokuttarajjhānāni tāva visuddhito sammasanañāṇatoca paṭṭhāya anukkamena uparuparipavattānaṃ🔽visuddhibhāvanānaṃ balena atigambhīrepi nibbānasaṅkhāte sabhāvadhamme appanābhāvena
analyzed: lokuttara jhānāni tāva visuddhitaḥ sammasana ñāṇato ca paṭṭhāya anukkamena  visuddhi bhāvanānam balena ati gambhīre pi nibbāna saṅkhāte sabhāva dhamme appanā bhāvena
translated: The supramundane jhānas, firstly, are able to stand in the ultimate realities as the object by means of absorption,🔽because of the power of the purification meditations that occur in succession beginning with the knowledge of the way to make an end of suffering, and because of their extreme profundity, which is called Nibbāna.

original: patiṭṭhātuṃ sakkonti. Āruppajjhānānica appanāpattasseva pañcamajjhānasamādhissa udayamattāni
analyzed: patiṭṭhātum sakkonti āruppa jhānāni ca appanā pattassa iva pañcama jhāna samādhissa udaya mattāni
translated: And the immaterial jhānas are able to stand in the ultimate realities as the object by means of absorption, because of the mere arising of the fifth jhāna concentration that has reached absorption,🔽and because of their going beyond the object.

original: hontīti ārammaṇasamatikkamanamattakaraṇena sabhāvadhammepi ārammaṇe appanābhāvena🔽patiṭṭhātuṃ sakkontīti. Tatthāpīti tesu samatiṃsaappanākammaṭṭhānesupi. Pañcakajjhāne
analyzed: honti iti ārammaṇa samatikkamana matta karaṇena sa bhāva dhamme pi ārammaṇe appanā abhāvena  patiṭṭhātum sakkonti iti tattha api iti tesu sama tiṃsa appanā kammaṭṭhānesu pi pañcaka jjhāne
translated: And in that case too, that is to say, in the case of the thirty kinds of absorption,

original: niyuttāni pañcakajjhāni kāni. Jhānapañcakassa ārammaṇabhāvayogyānīti vuttaṃhoti.
analyzed: niyuttāni kāni jhāna pañcakassa ārammaṇa bhāva yogyāni iti
translated: the five jhānas are called “bound to the five” because they are fit to be the object of the jhāna pentad.

original: Paṭikūlārammaṇānināma atianiṭṭhāni lūkhāni cittarabhijanane paridubbalāni hontīti
analyzed: paṭikūla ārammaṇāni nāma ati aniṭṭhāni lūkhāni citta rabhijanane paridubbalāni honti iti
translated: The repulsive objects are very undesirable and rough and are so feeble that they

original: na tāni attani cittaṃ rocetvā thapetuṃ sakkonti. Tasmā vitakkena vinā cittaṃ tattha
analyzed: na tāni attani cittam rocetvā thapetum sakkonti tasmā vitakkena vinā cittam
translated: cannot arouse consciousness. Therefore consciousness cannot be made to stand by them with applied thought.🔽So they are called “bound to applied thought.”

original: ekaggaṃ hutvā na tiṭṭhati. Vitakkabaleneva tiṭṭhatīti vuttaṃ dasaasubhā.La. Pathamajjhānikāti.
analyzed: ekaggam hutvā na tiṭṭhati vitakka balena iva tiṭṭhati iti vuttam pathama jhānikā ti
translated: The ten kinds of foulness are called “of the first jhāna” because they are the counterpart of the first jhāna.

original: Yadievaṃ kathaṃ tesu somanassajjhānaṃ hotīti nīvaraṇasantāpaṃ pahānabalenaceva taṃ
analyzed: yadi evam katham tesu somanassa jhānam hoti iti nīvaraṇa santāpam pahāna balena ca iva tam
translated: And how is it that joy is present in them? It is because of the strength of the abandoning of the torment of the hindrances and🔽because of the strength of the knowledge of the benefits of the jhāna.

original: taṃ ānisaṃsadassana ñāṇabalenaca. Byādhidukkhapīḷitassa rogino vamanavirecanapavattiyaṃ
analyzed: tam ānisaṃsa dassana ñāṇa balena ca byādhi dukkha pīḷitassa rogino vamana virecana pavattiyam
translated: Just as when a patient is oppressed by sickness, his joy is due to the strength of the abandoning of the sickness and to the strength of the knowledge of the benefits of the cure,

original: viya bahuṃ dāni vettanaṃ labhissāmīti ānisaṃsadassāvino pupphacchaṭṭakassa gūtharāsidassane
analyzed: viya bahum dāni vettanam labhissāmi iti ānisaṃsa dassāvino pupphacchaṭṭakassa gūtha rāsi dassane
translated: and just as when a man is exhausted after much hard work, his joy is due to the strength of the abandoning of the exhaustion and to the strength of the knowledge of the benefits of rest,🔽so too, the joy in the ten kinds of foulness is due to the strength of the abandoning of the torment of the hindrances and to the strength of the knowledge of the benefits of the jhāna.

original: viya cāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Mettādayo tayo brahmavihārā domanassasamuṭṭhitānaṃ byāpādavihiṃ
analyzed: viya ca ati daṭṭhabbam metta ādayaḥ tayo brahmavihārāḥ domanassa samuṭṭhitānam byāpāda vihim
translated: The three divine abidings of loving-kindness, compassion and gladness are the escape from ill will, cruelty and irritation, respectively,

original: sāaratīnaṃ nissaraṇabhūtā hontīti na te kadāci somanassena vinā appanaṃ pāpuṇantīti
analyzed: nissaraṇa bhūtāḥ honti iti na te kadāci somanassena vinā appanam pāpuṇanti iti
translated: so they never reach absorption without joy.🔽That is why it was said above, “The three, loving-kindness, and so on, are of the fourth jhāna” .

original: vuttaṃ mettādayo tayo catukkajjhānikāti. Upekkhā pana sattesu sabbaso udāsinapakkhe
analyzed: vuttam mettā ādayo catukka jhānikā ti upekkhā pana sattesu sabbaso
translated: But equanimity is quite neutral as to living beings.

original: ṭhatvā bhāvitabbattā kadācipi upekkhāvedanāya vinā appanaṃ napāpuṇātīti vuttaṃ upekkhāpañcamajjhānikāti.
analyzed: ṭhatvā bhāvitabba ttā kadāci pi upekkhā vedanāya vinā appanam na pāpuṇāti iti vuttam upekkhā pañcama jhānikā ti
translated: and because it must be developed with the feeling of equanimity present, it is said that it “has equanimity as fifth” .

original: Cattāropanaāruppāti kasiṇugghāṭimākāsādīni cattāri āruppārammaṇāni. Sabbatthāpīti
analyzed: cattāropana āruppā ti kasiṇugghāṭima ākāsa ādīni cattāri āruppa ārammaṇāni sabbattha api iti
translated: “The four immaterial states” are the four immaterial object-fields, namely, the base consisting of boundless space, and the rest.🔽“In all instances” :🔽in all the forty meditation subjects.

original: sabbesupi cattālīsakammaṭṭhānesu. Yathārahanti taṃtaṃārammaṇānurūpaṃ. Ārammaṇena🔽vinā parikammaṃnāma na sijjhati. Ārammaṇassa suṭṭhu daḷhavibhūtagahaṇasaṅkhātena
analyzed: sabbesu pi cattālīsa kammaṭṭhānesu yathā arahanti taṃ taṃ ārammaṇa anurūpam ārammaṇena  vinā parikammaṃ nāma na sijjhati ārammaṇassa suṭṭhu daḷha vibhūta gahaṇa saṅkhātena
translated: “As is appropriate” : in accordance with the respective object.🔽Without an object, preliminary work is impossible.

original: uggahena vinā ārammaṇasampatti nāma natthi. Asatica ārammaṇasampattiyā upacārajjhānaṃpi
analyzed: uggahena vinā ārammaṇa sampatti nāma natthi asati ca ārammaṇa sampattiyā upacāra jhānaṃ pi
translated: And without the “learning sign” , which is the proper, very clear and distinct apprehension of the object, the perfection of the object is impossible.🔽Without the perfection of the object, access concentration is impossible, much less absorption.

original: tāva na sampajjati. Pageva appanājhānanti vuttaṃ parikammanimittaṃ.La. Labbhantevāti.
analyzed: tāva na sampajjati pagā iva appanā jhānan ti vuttam labbhante iva ati
translated: “The learning sign is available” :🔽Herein, “in all instances” means in all the forty meditation subjects.

original: Tattha sabbatthāpīti sabbesupi cattālīsakammaṭṭhānesu. Yathārahanti taṃtaṃkammaṭṭhānānurūpaṃ.
analyzed: tattha sabbattha api iti sabbesu pi cattālīsa kammaṭṭhānesu yathā arahanti tat tat kammaṭṭhāna anurūpam
translated: “As is appropriate” means in accordance with the respective meditation subject.

original: Pariyāyenāti idaṃ pana kassaci ārammaṇassa cakkhunā passantasseva avibhūtatarattā
analyzed: pariyāyena ati idam pana kassaci ārammaṇassa cakkhunā passantassa iva avibhūtatara ttā
translated: “By way of” : this is said because for some the learning sign becomes evident through seeing the object with the eye.

original: vuttaṃ. Yattha pana pathamaṃ sabhāvadhammaṃ gaṇhitvā pacchā tādise tadākāre taṃsaṇṭhāne🔽paññattārammaṇe upacārovā appanāvā pavattati. Tattheva paṭibhāganimittaṃnāma labbhatīti
analyzed: vuttam yattha pana pathamam sabhāva dhammam gaṇhitvā pacchā tādise tad ākāre tad saṇṭhāne  paññatta ārammaṇe upacāro vā appanā vā pavattati tattha iva paṭibhāga nimittam nāma labbhati iti
translated: But it is said: “Where firstly the natural sign is apprehended and afterwards access or absorption is entered upon in the aspect and mode of that same sign as described, there the counterpart sign is called the ‘sign of the counterpart’ ” .

original: vuttaṃ paṭibhāga nimittaṃpanātiādi. Vuttamevatthaṃ daḷhaṃ karonto tatthahītiādimāha.🔽Evaṃ samathakamme pathamaṃ uggahakosallaṃ dassetvā idāni ādito paṭṭhāya bhāvanāvidhānaṃ
analyzed: vuttam paṭibhāga nimittam pana atiādi vuttam eva attham daḷham karontaḥ tattha hi itiādim āha  evam samatha kamme pathamam uggaha kosallam dassetvā idāni āditas paṭṭhāya bhāvanā vidhānam
translated: The meaning of this is confirmed by the words “The counterpart sign” , etc., and by the words “There” , etc.🔽Having thus shown the skill in learning in the first place in the case of serenity, he now said “When he has learned” , etc., in order to show the method of development from the beginning.🔽When he has learned the sign: when he has seen the sign of the kind already described as “the natural sign” and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.

original: dassento kathantiādi māha. Nimittaṃ uggaṇhantassāti ārammaṇassa yathā saṇṭhitaṃ ākāraṃ
analyzed: dassentaḥ kathaṃ ti ādi mā āha nimittam uggaṇhantassa ati ārammaṇassa yathā saṇṭhitam ākāram
translated: When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.
