translated: When he has seen it and has learned it by repeatedly looking at it and so has made it his object.🔽When he has seen it and

original: karaṇavasena vaḍḍhanākārasaṇṭhitattā. Samuggahitaṃ hotīti vatvā yathā suṭṭhu uggahitaṃ
analyzed: karaṇa vasena vaḍḍhana ākāra saṇṭhita ttā samuggahitam hoti iti vatvā yathā suṭṭhu uggahitam
translated: After saying “it is called well apprehended,” in order to show how it is well apprehended,

original: samuggahitaṃnāma hoti taṃ dassetuṃ cakkhunāpassantassevamanodvārassa āpātamāgatanti
analyzed: samuggahitaṃ nāma hoti tam dassetum cakkhunā a passantassa iva manaḥ dvārassa āpātam āgatanti
translated: it is said: “when it has come within the range of the mind door by seeing with the eye.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha manodvārassaāpātamāgatanti cakkhūni nimmilitvāvā aññasmiṃ ṭhāne ṭhatvāvā
analyzed: vuttam tattha manaḥ dvārassa āpātam āgatanti cakkhūni nimmilitvā vā aññasmiṃ ṭhāne ṭhatvā vā
translated: Herein, “when it has come within the range of the mind door” means that when one closes the eyes and looks at it from another place,

original: āvajjantassa cakkhunā diṭṭhasadisaṃ manodvāre paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti. Uggahanimittaṃnāma.🔽Suṭṭhu avinassamānaṃ katvā gahitattā. Sāca bhāvanā samādhiyati. Na tāva bhāvanantarabhāvaṃ
analyzed: āvajjantassa cakkhunā diṭṭha sadisam manaḥ dvāre paccupaṭṭhitam hoti uggaha nimittaṃ nāma  suṭṭhu a vinassamānam katvā gahita ttā sā ca bhāvanā samādhiyati na tāva bhāvana antara bhāvam
translated: it appears in the mind door in the same way as it was seen with the eye. This is the learning sign.🔽because it is apprehended without being allowed to disappear. And that development becomes concentrated. The intention is that it has not yet reached the state of being a development of absorption.

original: pāpuṇātīti adhippāyo. Tathā samāhitassāti tena matthakapattena parikammasamādhinā
analyzed: pāpuṇāti iti adhippāyaḥ tathā samāhitassa ati tena matthaka pattena parikamma samādhinā
translated: “When he is thus concentrated”: when this meditator is concentrated by means of the preliminary concentration that has reached its peak.

original: samāhitassa etassa yogino. Tatoparanti uggahanimittuppatti to paraṃ. Bhāvanamanuyuñjantassa
analyzed: samāhitassa etassa yoginaḥ uggaha nimitta uppatti param bhāvanam anuyuñjantassa
translated: “After that”: after the arising of the learning sign. “When he is devoted to the development of”: when he is devoted to the development of the sign of concentration.🔽“In his mind”: the construction is “in his mind.”

original: citte sannisinnanti sambandho. Tattha anuyuñjanthassāti nirantaraṃ padahantassa.
analyzed: citte sannisinnanti sambandhaḥ tattha anuyuñjanthassa ati nirantaram padahantassa
translated: Herein, “when he is devoted to the development of”: when he is devoted to the development of the sign of concentration by means of uninterrupted practice.

original: Tappaṭibhāganti sabhāva dhammabhūtena tena uggahanimittena sadisaṃ. Vatthudhammavimuccitanti🔽meghavalāhakantaratovā rāhumukhatovā nikkhantacandamaṇḍalaṃ viya sabhāvadhammabhūtā🔽uggahanimittato vimuccitvā visuṃ upaṭṭhitaṃ. Tatoyeva paññattisaṅkhātaṃ nimittapaññattiiti
analyzed: tad paṭibhāgam ti sabhāva dhamma bhūtena tena uggaha nimittena sadisam vatthu dhamma vimuccitanti  megha valāha kantarataḥ vā rāhu mukhataḥ vā nikkhanta canda maṇḍalam viya  uggaha nimittataḥ vimuccitvā visum upaṭṭhitam tatas yeva paññatti saṅkhātam nimitta paññatti iti
translated: ‘Corresponds to the sign’: it is similar to the sign arisen by exercise. ‘Apart from the object-sign’:🔽just as the moon’s disk comes out from the mouth of Rāhu or from a cloud or from the darkness, so too, the learning sign comes out from the sign arisen by exercise. That is called ‘the learning sign’ in the sense of learning.

original: kathitaṃ. Bhāvanā mayanti kevalaṃ bhāvanācittabalena pasiddhaṃ. Ālambaṇanti tadeva
analyzed: kathitam bhāvanā kevalam bhāvanā citta balena tat eva
translated: ‘By mere learning’: it is well known by the mere power of the learning consciousness. ‘The object’: that same learning sign.

original: samuggahitaṃ nimittālambaṇaṃ cittesannisannaṃsamappitaṃhotīti manodvārikacittasantāne🔽sannisinnaṃ niccalabhāvena saṇṭhitaṃ hutvā suṭṭhu appitaṃ pavesitaṃ hoti. Tanti nimittālambaṇaṃ
analyzed: samuggahitam nimitta ālambaṇam citte sannisannam samappitam hoti iti manaḥ dvārika citta santāne  sannisinnam niccala bhāvena saṇṭhitam hutvā suṭṭhu appitam pavesitam hoti tanti nimitta ālambaṇam
translated: ‘The mind becomes steadied and well concentrated upon it’: it becomes steadied and well concentrated in the mind door by being placed there.

original: pavuccatīti sambandho. Yasmā candamaṇḍalādikassa viya tassa nimittālambaṇassa parisuddhapariyodātabhāvena
analyzed: pavuccati iti sambandhaḥ yasmā canda maṇḍala ādikassa viya tassa nimitta ālambaṇassa parisuddha pariyodāta bhāvena
translated: ‘That is called the learning sign’: the construction is this. Because of the purity and brightness of the learning sign, like the moon’s disk, etc.,

original: upaṭṭhitatānāma kilesamalavikkhambhanena parisuddhapariyodātabhāvaṃ patvā obhāsajātassa
analyzed: upaṭṭhita tā nāma kilesa mala vikkhambhanena parisuddha pariyodāta bhāvam patvā obhāsa jātassa
translated: having attained a state of purity and brightness by the suppression of the stain of the defilements,🔽

original: cittassa vaseneva hoti. Na tassa ālambaṇassa vasena. Nahi paññatti dhamme tādiso🔽guṇonāma upalabbhatīti. Tasmā paṭibhāga nimitte samuppanne nīvaraṇasaṅkhātānaṃ paṭibandhakadhammānaṃ
analyzed: cittassa vasena iva hoti na tassa ālambaṇassa vasena nahi paññatti dhamme tādiso  upalabbhati iti tasmā paṭibhāga nimitte samuppanne nīvaraṇa saṅkhātānam paṭibandhaka dhammānam
translated: And when the mind, having reached the state of illumination by the suppression of the defilements and impurities, has become purified and cleansed, it is only by the mind’s own wish that it occurs, not by the wish of the object. For such a quality as “sign” is not found in the mental datum.

original: vikkhambhitatā siddhā hotīti vuttaṃ tatopaṭṭhāyātiādi. Paṭibandhanti nīvārenti nissaraṇapakkhikaṃ
analyzed: vikkhambhita tā siddhā hoti iti vuttam tatas upaṭṭhāya atiādi paṭibandhanti nīvārenti nissaraṇa pakkhikam
translated: So when the counterpart sign has arisen, the suppression of the states described as hindrances is accomplished. That is why it is said, “From then on” and so on.

original: cittaṃ pātentīti paṭibandhā. Nīvaraṇa dhammā. Visesena pahīnā paṭibandhā etāyāti🔽paṭibandhavippahīnā. Samāsevantassāti suṭṭhu āsevantassa. Sattavidhaṃ nimitta rakkhaṇavidhānaṃ
analyzed: cittam pātenti iti paṭibandhā nīvaraṇa dhammā visesena pahīnā paṭibandhā etāya ati  paṭibandha vippahīnā samāsevantassa ati suṭṭhu āsevantassa sattavidham nimitta rakkhaṇa vidhānaṃ
translated: The hindrances are states that hinder and obstruct the mind that is tending to seclusion, that prevent it, and that are enemies of the jhāna factors.🔽The hindrances are abandoned in two ways, that is, by suppression and by eradication.🔽By suppression: by temporary suppression. By eradication: by complete cutting off.🔽The hindrances are abandoned by suppression in one who has attained jhāna and by eradication in one who has attained the noble paths.🔽The hindrances are abandoned by suppression in one who has attained jhāna and by eradication in one who has attained the noble paths.

original: sampādetvā cakkavattigabbhaṃ viya suṭṭhu rakkhitvā punappunaṃ bhāvanāvasena sevantassāti attho.
analyzed: sampādetvā cakkavatti gabbham viya suṭṭhu rakkhitvā punappunam bhāvanā vasena sevantassa ati attho
translated: The meaning is that he guards the seven kinds of possession of the sign well, and he cultivates it again and again by development, guarding it like a universal monarch’s harem.

original: Āvāso gocaro bhassaṃ, puggalo bhojanaṃ utu;
analyzed: āvāsaḥ gocaraḥ bhassam puggalaḥ bhojanam utu
translated: Quarters, resort, speech, person, food,

original: Iriyāpathoti satte te, asappāye vivajjaye.
analyzed: iriyāpathā uti satte te asappāye vivajjaye
translated: The posture is the seven, so shun The unsuitable, the seven, too.

original: Sappāye satta sevetha, evañhi paṭipajjato;🔽Nacireneva kālena, hoti kassaci appanāti hi vuttaṃ.🔽Rūpāvacarapathamajjhānaṃappetīti kāmataṇhāya visayabhāvaṃ atikkamitvā sātisayaṃ saṇhasukhumabhāvappattaṃ
analyzed: sappāye satta sevetha evam hi paṭipajjataḥ  nacirena iva kālena hoti kassaci appanā iti hi vuttam  rūpāvacara pathama jhānam appeti iti kāma taṇhāya visaya bhāvam atikkamitvā sa atisayam saṇha sukhuma bhāva ppattam
translated: The suitable, the seven, use: so will The seven be attained, no other way.🔽The first jhāna of the fine-material sphere is called “exalted” because it surmounts the sense sphere by being obtained by surmounting the sense-desire element, etc., and because it is associated with the more refined and more peaceful jhāna factors.

original: upacārajjhānato sataguṇenavā sahassaguṇenavā thiratarajjhānaṅgayuttaṃ rūpāvacara🔽saṅkhātaṃ pathamajjhānaṃ tasmiṃ nimitte anupavisitvā viya vattatīti attho. Tameva
analyzed: upacāra jhānato sataguṇena vā sahassaguṇena vā rūpāvacara  saṅkhātam pathamajjhānam tasmin nimitte an upavisitvā viya vattati iti atthaḥ tam eva
translated: It is “beautiful” because it is associated with the more beautiful and more peaceful jhāna factors.

original: pathamajjhānaṃ vasībhūtaṃ katvāti sambandho. Pañcasu vasītāsu pana pathamajjhānato
analyzed: pathamajjhānam vasībhūtam katvā ati sambandho pañcasu pana pathamajjhānataḥ
translated: It is “singly tunable” because it is associated with the jhāna factors that are singly unified.🔽It is “secluded from sensual desires and secluded from unprofitable things” because it is associated with the jhāna factors that are secluded from the sense desires and from the unprofitable.

original: vuṭṭhāya pathamaṃ vitakkaṃ āvajjati. Tato vicāraṃ. Tato pītiṃ. Tato sukhaṃ. Tato
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya pathamam vitakkam āvajjati tatas vicāram tatas pītim tatas sukham tatas
translated: It is “accompanied by bliss and pleasure” because it is associated with the jhāna factors of bliss and pleasure.🔽It is “arisen from concentration” because it is associated with the jhāna factor of concentration.

original: samādhiṃ. Tato puna vitakkaṃ. Tato vicāranti evaṃ punappunaṃ jhānaṅgāni āvajjantassa
analyzed: samādhim tatas puna vitakkam tatas vicāranti evam punappunam jhān aṅgāni āvajjantassa
translated: It is “accompanied by unification of mind” because it is associated with the jhāna factor of unification.🔽It is “born of seclusion” because it is obtained by seclusion from the hindrances.🔽It is “accompanied by the attainment of the first jhāna” because it is associated with the jhāna factors of applied thought, etc., which are the attainment of the first jhāna.

original: yadā taṃtaṃjhānaṅgālambaṇā cittavārā antarantarā katipayabhavaṅgehi antaritā hutvā
analyzed: yadā taṃ taṃ jhā anaṅga ālambaṇā citta vārā antarantarā katipaya bhavaṅgehi antaritā hutvā
translated: When the mind-door process that has that jhāna factor as its object is interrupted by a few life-continua here and there,🔽

original: nirantarabhūtā viya pavattanti. Tadā āvajjana paccavekkhana vasitāyo vasībhūtānāma🔽honti. Etā pana sabbaññubuddhānaṃ matthakappattā honti. Tesañhi yamakapāṭi hāriyādikālesu
analyzed: nirantara bhūtāḥ viya pavattanti tadā  honti etā pana sabbaññu buddhānam matthaka ppattā honti tesam hi hāriya ādi kālesu
translated: When the mind-door process that has the jhāna factors as its object occurs uninterruptedly, as it were, after being interrupted by a few life-continua, then the directing of attention, reviewing, and the state of mastery are mastered.

original: lahukapavattiṃ icchantānaṃ taṃtaṃjhānaṅgā rammaṇācittavārāpi catupañcajavanikāeva🔽pavattanti. Antarabhavaṅgānipi pacchimavārassa upacāra bhūtāni bhavaṅga calana saṅkhātāni
analyzed: lahuka pavattim icchantānam catu pañca javanikā eva  pavattanti antarabhavaṅgānipi pacchimavārassa upacāra bhūtāni bhavaṅga calana saṅkhātāni
translated: But these are at their highest in omniscient Buddhas. For when they wish to give rise to the light of knowledge rapidly, as in the Twin Miracle, then the mind-door processes that enjoy the jhāna factors occur in four or five impulsions only,🔽and the two life-continua that are like the interval in a recitation occur as if they were the life-continuum’s wavering, which is called “wavering of the life-continuum.”

original: dveeva pavattanti. Yattha aparaṃ jhānaṅgaṃ āpāta māgacchati. Nahi ārammaṇe āpātaṃ
analyzed: dve eva pavattanti yattha aparam jhāna aṅgam āpātam āgacchati nahi ārammaṇe āpātam
translated: For the life-continuum does not waver until the object has been reached,

original: anāgate bhavaṅgaṃ calati. Naca vinā bhavaṅgacalanena āvajjanuppattināma atthīti.
analyzed: anāgate bhavaṅgam calati na ca vinā bhavaṅga calanena āvajjan uppatti nāma atthi iti
translated: and there is no directing of attention that has reached the object without wavering of the life-continuum.

original: Thapetvā sabbaññubuddhe aññesaṃ vasibhāvapattānaṃpi antarantarā bhavaṅgacāre gaṇanānāma
analyzed: thapetvā sabbaññu buddhe aññesam vasi bhāva pattānam pi antarantarā bhavaṅga cāre gaṇanā nāma
translated: Except for omniscient Buddhas, those who have attained mastery count the occurrence of the life-continuum’s wavering in the interval.

original: natthīti paṭisambhidāmaggaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Visuddhimagge pana ayaṃ pana matthakappattāvasī
analyzed: natthi iti paṭisambhidā magga ṭṭhakathā ayam vuttam visuddhi magge pana ayam pana matthaka ppattā vasī
translated: “There is none” is said in the Paṭisambhidā Maggaṭṭhakathā. But in the Visuddhimagga it is said: “This mastery reaches its culmination in the Blessed One.

original: bhagavato yamakapāṭihāriyakāle labbhati. Aññesaṃvā evarūpe kāleti vuttaṃ. Jhānassa
analyzed: bhagavataḥ yamaka pāṭihāriya kāle labbhati aññesam vā evarūpe kāle ti vuttam jhānassa
translated: It is found in others only at the time of the Twin Miracle. Or else it is said that others have it only to that extent.”

original: sīghataraṃ samāpajjanasamatthatā samāpajjanavasīnāma. Teneva hi pāḷiyaṃ samāpajjane
analyzed: sīghataram samāpajjana samattha tā samāpajjana vasī nāma tena iva hi pāḷiyam samāpajjane
translated: The ability to attain jhāna more quickly is mastery in attaining.🔽For this is why it is said in the text, “There is no sluggishness in attaining” .

original: dandhāyitattaṃ natthīti vuttaṃ. Esanayo sesāsupīti. Tathā samāpajjitaṃ jhānaṃ accharāmattādivasena
analyzed: natthi iti vuttam esanayo sesāsu pi iti tathā samāpajjitam jhānam accharāmatta ādi vasena
translated: The rest are as stated.

original: atiparittakaṃpi khaṇaṃ thapetuṃ samatthatā adhiṭṭhānavasīnāma. Samāpajjitajjhānato🔽sīghataraṃ vuṭṭhātuṃ samatthatā vuṭṭhānavasīnāma. Paccavekkhanavasī pana āvajjanavasiyā
analyzed: ati parittakaṃ pi khaṇam thapetum samattha tā adhiṭṭhāna vasī nāma samāpajjita jhānato  sīghataram vuṭṭhātum samattha tā vuṭṭhāna vasī nāma paccavekkhana vasī pana āvajjana vasiyā
translated: The ability to prolong jhāna for as much time as desired, even up to a measureless time, is mastery in resolving.🔽The ability to emerge from jhāna more quickly is mastery in emerging.

original: siddhāya siddhāeva hotīti.
analyzed: siddhāya siddhā eva ha uti iti
translated: But mastery in reviewing is established when mastery in adverting is established.

original: Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvini:

original: Yattakaṃ kālaṃ icchati. Tattakaṃ cirataraṃ jhānaṃ thapetuṃ samatthatā adhiṭṭhānavasitānāmātipi
analyzed: yattakam kālam icchati tattakam cirataram jhānam thapetum samattha tā
translated: “The ability to prolong jhāna for as long as one wishes is mastery in resolving.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tathā paricchinna kālato anto avuṭṭhahitvā yathāparicchinnakālavaseneva vuṭṭhānasamatthatā
analyzed: vuttam tathā paricchinna kālataḥ antar a vuṭṭhahitvā yathā paricchinna kāla vasena iva vuṭṭhāna samattha tā
translated: and so on. And the ability to emerge from the jhāna at the time stated, without remaining longer than the time stated,🔽is mastery in the act of emerging.

original: vuṭṭhānavasitānāmāti. Taṃpi yujjatiyeva.🔽Pāḷiyañhi pathamajjhānaṃ yatthicchakaṃ yadicchakaṃ yāvaticchakaṃ adhiṭṭhāti. Adhiṭṭhānāya🔽dandhāyitattaṃ natthītiādinā sīghataraṃvā hotu. Cirataraṃvā. Yattakaṃ kālaṃ jhānaṃ
analyzed: taṃpi  pāḷiyam hi pathamajjhānam yatthicchakam yadicchakam yāvaticchakam adhiṭṭhāti adhiṭṭhānāya  natthi iti ādinā sīghataram vā hotu cirataram vā yattakam kālam jhānam
translated: That is also appropriate.🔽For in the text it is said: “He determines the first jhāna according to his wish … without difficulty, without trouble” , and so on.🔽So let it be quicker or slower, as he wishes.

original: thapetuṃvā yattake kāle tato uṭṭhātuṃvā icchati. Tattakaṃ kālaṃ anūnaṃvā anadhikaṃvā🔽katvā adhiṭṭhātuṃvā vuṭṭhātuṃvā samatthatāpi dassitāyeva hotīti. Evañcasati vuṭṭhānavasitāpi
analyzed: thapetum vā yattake kāle tatas uṭṭhātum vā icchati tattakam kālam anūnam vā an adhikam vā  katvā adhiṭṭhātum vā vuṭṭhātum vā samattha tā api dassitāya iva hoti iti evam ca sati vuṭṭhāna vasitā api
translated: And the ability to determine the jhāna to last just as long as he wishes, or to emerge from it just when he wishes, without less or more,🔽is shown by the words “He determines it, he emerges from it” .🔽So when mastery in the act of determining is established, mastery in the act of emerging is also established.

original: adhiṭṭhānavasitāya siddhāya siddhāevāti tāsaṃ dvinnaṃ visesakappanāpi nippayojanā
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna avasitāya siddhāya tāsam dvinnam visesa kappanā api nippayojanā
translated: So the postulating of a difference between these two should be regarded as pointless.

original: hotīti daṭṭhabbā. Vasanaṃ vasī. Samatthatāti attho. Issara bhāvoti vuttaṃ hoti. Vasīeva
analyzed: hoti iti daṭṭhabbā vasanam vasī samattha tā ti atthaḥ issara bhāvaḥ ti vuttam hoti vasī eva
translated: Mastery is the state of a master. The meaning is: the state of a controller. The state of a ruler is what is meant.

original: vasitā. Yathā devoeva devatāti. Katvā padahatoti sambandho. Vitakkādikaṃ oḷārikaṅgaṃ🔽pahānāyāti ettha pathamajjhānaṃ tāva vasībhūtaṃ katvā ṭhitassa vitakko oḷārikato🔽upaṭṭhāti. Tadā ahovatame avitakkaṃ jhānaṃ assāti evamassa ajjhāsayo saṇṭhāti. Tadā
analyzed: vasitā yathā katvā sambandhaḥ vitakka ādikam oḷārikaṅgam  pahānāya ti ettha pathamajjhānam tāva vasībhūtam katvā ṭhitassa vitakkaḥ oḷārikato  upaṭṭhāti tadā ahovatame a vitakkam jhānam assa ati evam assa ajjhāsayaḥ saṇṭhāti tadā
translated: ‘Dwelling’—vasitā—is to be construed with ‘as if he were a god among gods’.

translated: and he does the preliminary work thus, “I shall listen to the sound of such and such a person.”🔽But in the commentary it is said:
