analyzed: katvā puna pādaka jjhāna samāpajjanam āgatam eva yathā āha abhiññā pādaka jjhānam samāpajjitvā  vuṭṭhāya sace satam icchati satam homi iti parikammam katvā puna abhiññā pādakam jhānaṃ
translated: and he does the preliminary work thus, “I shall hear the sound of such and such a drum.” But in the commentary the attainment of the basic jhāna is stated again after the preliminary work has been done. For it is said: “Having attained the basic jhāna that is a proximate cause for direct knowledge,🔽he emerges and resolves, ‘Let there be a hundred,’ and he does the preliminary work again. Then he attains the basic jhāna that is a proximate cause for direct knowledge,

original: samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya adhiṭṭhāti. Adhiṭṭhānacittena saheva sataṃ hotīti. Tatthaca🔽ādito pādakajjhānasamāpajjanaṃ parikamma cittassa samādānatthāya hoti. Pacchimaṃ🔽pana abhiññāya anu balappadānatthāyāti. Tathā hi pādakajjhānabalena suṭṭhu samāhitaṃ
analyzed: samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya adhiṭṭhāti adhiṭṭhāna cittena saha iva satam hoti iti tattha ca  āditas pādakajjhāna samāpajjanam parikamma cittassa samādāna atthāya hoti pacchimam  pana abhiññāya anu bala ppadāna tthāya ati tathā hi pādakajjhāna balena suṭṭhu samāhitam
translated: emerges, and resolves. At the same time as the resolving consciousness there are a hundred consciousnesses of the kind called ‘pervading the extent of the object.’🔽And the first attainment of the basic jhāna is for the purpose of directing the preliminary-work consciousness. But the last one is for the purpose of giving strength to the direct knowledge.

original: parikammacittaṃnāma attano visaye abhiññācittagatikaṃ hoti. Pubbenivāsānussaraṇakāle
analyzed: parikamma cittam nāma attanaḥ visaye abhiññā citta gatikam hoti pubbenivāsa anussaraṇa kāle
translated: For the preliminary-work consciousness, which is well concentrated by the strength of the basic jhāna, is called “pervading the extent of the object” in its own objective field, and it is directed towards the direct-knowledge consciousness.

original: teneva cittena tasmiṃ bhave atītaṃ dhammajātaṃ yāva paṭisandhiyā jānāti. Teneva hi
analyzed: tena iva cittena tasmim bhave atītam dhamma jātam yāva paṭisandhiyā jānāti tena iva hi
translated: And at the time of the recollection of past lives, it knows by means of that same consciousness the states of the past in that existence down to the rebirth-linking.🔽For it is said:

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ taṃsampayuttaṃ ñāṇaṃ parikammasamādhiñāṇanti vuttaṃ. Atītaṃsañāṇantipi
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāyam tad sampayuttam ñāṇam parikamma samādhi ñāṇan ti vuttam atīta saṃsa ñāṇam ti pi
translated: and the knowledge associated with it is called “preliminary-work concentration knowledge” in the commentary. It is also called “knowledge of the past.”

original: vuccatīti. Sesābhiññāsupi tassa ñāṇassa visayaviseso yathārahaṃ vattabboti. Therena
analyzed: vuccati iti sesa abhiññāsu pi tassa ñāṇassa visaya visesaḥ yathāraham vattabbaḥ iti therena
translated: The field of this knowledge should be defined in the other kinds of direct knowledge too as appropriate.

original: pana pacchimaṃ pādakajjhānasamāpajjanaṃnāma na sabbesaṃ hoti. Na hi abhiññāsu vasībhāvapattānaṃ
analyzed: pana pacchimam pādakajjhāna samāpajjanam nāma na sabbesam hoti na hi abhiññāsu vasībhāva pattānam
translated: But the attainment of the last basic jhāna does not happen in all cases. For those who have reached mastery in the kinds of direct knowledge have no need for a basic jhāna here.

original: puna pādakajjhānena kiccaṃ atthīti katvā taṃ idha nagahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Rūpādīsuālambaṇesuyathārahamappetīti🔽ettha iddhividhañāṇaṃ tāva tekālikabhūtesu chasu ārammaṇesu pavattati. Tañhi rūpādīsu
analyzed: puna pādaka jjhānena kiccam atthi iti katvā tam idha naga hitanti daṭṭhabbam rūpa ādīsu ālambaṇesu yathāraham appeti iti  ettha iddhividha ñāṇam tāva tekālika bhūtesu chasu ārammaṇesu pavattati tat hi rūpa ādīsu
translated: So it should be regarded as not mentioned here for that reason.🔽As to the objects of direct-knowledge:🔽As regards the kinds of direct knowledge, firstly, the knowledge of the kinds of supernormal power occurs with reference to the six bases consisting of the three kinds of knowledge of the categories of supernormal power and the three kinds of knowledge of the categories of transformation.🔽For this knowledge occurs with reference to whatever states it produces, whether they be the six kinds of direct-knowledge object consisting of visible forms, etc.,

original: chasu ārammaṇadhammesu yaṃ yaṃ nipphādeti. Taṃ taṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattati. Pādakajjhānacittaṃ
analyzed: chasu ārammaṇa dhammesu yam yam nipphādeti tam tam ārammaṇam katvā pavattati pādaka jhāna cittam
translated: or the basic jhāna consciousness, or the supernormal power of the mode of rightness, or the supernormal power of the mode of transformation, or the supernormal power of the mode of resolving.

original: pana kāyagatikaṃ adhiṭṭhahitvā dissamānenakāyena ākāsegamanakāle atītaṃ pādakajjhānacittaṃ
analyzed: pana kāya gatikam adhiṭṭhahitvā dissamānena kāyena ākāse gamana kāle atītam pādaka jhāna cittam
translated: But when the basic jhāna consciousness is resolved upon and the body becomes visible by means of the mode of rightness, then the past basic jhāna consciousness

original: ārabbha pavattati. Kāyaṃ cittagatikaṃ adhiṭṭhahitvā adissamānena kāyena gamanakāle
analyzed: ārabbha pavattati kāyam citta gatikam adhiṭṭhahitvā a dissamānena kāyena gamana kāle
translated: When he resolves upon the body and the mind and goes with the invisible body,🔽it occurs contingent upon the visible-data base of the present.

original: paccuppannaṃ rūpakāyaṃ ārabbha pavattati. Tathāpavattamānassa pana tassa ñāṇassa
analyzed: paccuppannam rūpakāyam ārabbha pavattati tathā a pavattamānassa pana tassa ñāṇassa
translated: But the knowledge occurring thus

original: kiñcirūpaṃ ārammaṇa mattaṃ hoti. Kiñci ārammaṇapurejātaṃ. Kiñci vatthārammaṇa purejātaṃ
analyzed: kiñci rūpam ārammaṇa mattam hoti kiñci ārammaṇa purejātam kiñci vattha ārammaṇa purejātam
translated: should be regarded as having some materiality as its object merely, some as its prenascent condition, and some as its conascent and postnascent condition.

original: hotīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Anāgate idaṃnāma hotūti adhiṭṭhāna kāle anāgataṃ taṃtaṃrūpadhammaṃ🔽ārabbha pavattatīti. Paccuppanno saddo dibbasotassa ārammaṇaṃ hoti. Atīte sattadivasāni
analyzed: hoti iti daṭṭhabbam anāgate idaṃnāma hotu uti adhiṭṭhāna kāle anāgatam taṃ taṃ rūpa dhammam  ārabbha pavattati iti paccuppannaḥ saddo dibba sotassa ārammaṇam hoti atīte satta divasāni
translated: When he resolves, “Let it be thus in the future,” it occurs contingent upon the materiality of the future.🔽The present sound is the divine ear’s object.

original: anāgate sattadivasānīti etthantare kāle atītā nāgatapaccuppannabhūtaṃ parassacittaṃ
analyzed: anāgate satta divasāni iti etthantare kāle atītāḥ nāgata paccuppanna bhūtam parassa cittam
translated: In the passage, “For seven days past and seven days to come” , the other’s cognizance and cognizance-concomitants in the seven-day period are past, future and present.🔽Or the four categories are the knowledge of penetration of minds’s object.

original: cattārovā khandhā cetopariya ñāṇassa. Cittañhi jānanto taṃ sampayuttadhammaṃpi icchanto
analyzed: cattāro vā khandhā cetaḥ upariya ñāṇassa cittam hi jānanto tam sampayutta dhammam pi icchanto
translated: For one who knows the mind will also know the states associated with it if he wishes to do so.

original: jānissatiyeva. Evañca katvā paṭṭhāne kusalā khandhā ceto pariyañāṇassa yathākammupagañāṇassa
analyzed: jānissati yeva evañca katvā paṭṭhāne kusalā khandhā cetaḥ pariya ñāṇassa yathā kammupaga ñāṇassa
translated: And so it is said in the Patthāna: “The profitable aggregates are the object of the knowledge of penetration of minds and of the knowledge of faring according to deeds” .

original: ārammaṇapaccayena paccayoti ñāṇadvayaṃ ekato katvā vuttaṃ. Etthaca aṭṭhakathāyaṃ🔽tāva paracittassa paccuppannālambaṇatānāma santativasenavā addhā vasenavā yojitā.
analyzed: ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ ti ñāṇa dvayam ekatas katvā vuttam ettha ca aṭṭhakathāyam  tāva para cittassa paccuppanna ālambaṇa tā nāma santati vasena vā addhā vasena vā yojitā
translated: The two kinds of knowledge are stated together as “Conditioned by object as condition” because they have a single object.🔽And here, in the first place, the knowledge of the mind of another is applied by the commentator in the way of a continuity or a period, not by moment.

original: Yadi hi khaṇikavasena yojeyya. Āvajjane paccuppannaṃ yaṃkiñci ekaṃ cittaṃ āvajjetvā
analyzed: yadi hi khaṇika vasena yojeyya āvajjane paccuppannam yaṃkiñci ekam cittam āvajjetvā
translated: For if he were to apply it by moment, then, after adverting to any one of the many consciousnesses arisen in the past, present or future,

original: niruddhe javanānipi tadeva āvajjanena saddhiṃ niruddhaṃ atītaṃ gaṇhantīti tāni kālato🔽āvajjanena saha bhinnālambaṇāni nāma honti. Naca aniṭṭhe maggaphalavīthito aññasmiṃ
analyzed: niruddhe tat eva āvajjanena saddhim niruddham atītam gaṇhanti iti tāni kālatas  āvajjanena saha bhinna ālambaṇāni nāma honti na ca aniṭṭhe magga phala vīthitaḥ aññasmin
translated: the impulsion consciousnesses would be apprehending what is past, namely, the adverting, which has already ceased together with the adverting.

original: ṭhāne kālamattenāpi tesaṃ tena saha bhinnālambaṇatā aṭṭhakathācariyehi anu matāti.
analyzed: ṭhāne kāla mattena api tesam tena saha bhinna ālambaṇa tā aṭṭhakathā cariyehi anu matā ati
translated: And the commentator does not admit that they have a different object from the adverting even by the mere lapse of time, except in the case of the path and fruition consciousnesses.

original: Tasmā īdisesu ṭhānesu paccuppannaṃnāma santativasena addhāvasenaca gahetuṃ yuttanti.
analyzed: tasmai īdisesu ṭhānesu paccuppannam nāma santati vasena addhā vasena ca gahetum yuttam ti
translated: So in such cases it is proper to take what is called “present” as a continuity or a period.

original: Mūlaṭīkāyaṃ pana khaṇikapaccuppanna vaseneva yojitaṃ. Nahi abhidhamme atītārammaṇattikaṃ
analyzed: mūla ṭīkāyam pana khaṇika paccuppanna vasena iva yojitam nahi abhidhamme atīta ārammaṇa ttikam
translated: But in the Root Commentary it is applied by moment. For in the Abhidhamma there is no such thing as an object that is past,

original: santati addhānavaseneva vuttanti sakkā vattuṃ. Itarathā paccuppanno dhammo paccuppannassa🔽dhammassa anantarapaccayena paccayo āsevanapaccayena paccayoti vattabbo siyā. Na🔽tu vutto. Atīto dhammo paccuppannassa dhammassa anantarapaccayena paccayo āsevanapaccayena🔽paccayoticceva pana vutto, tasmā āvajjanādīni sabbāni cittāni paccekaṃ attanā khaṇavasena
analyzed: santati addhāna vasena iva vuttan ti sakkā vattum itarathā paccuppannaḥ dhammo paccuppannassa  dhammassa anantara paccayena paccayaḥ āsevana paccayena paccayaḥ iti vattabbaḥ siyā na  tu vuttaḥ atītaḥ dhammaḥ paccuppannassa dhammassa anantara paccayena paccayaḥ āsevana paccayena  paccayaḥ ticca iva pana vuttaḥ tasmai āvajjana ādīni sabbāni cittāni paccekam attanā khaṇa vasena
translated: and the continuity is stated according to the time-division of the life-continuum. Otherwise, it would have to be said that a present state is a condition, by way of proximity condition, for a present state, and by way of repetition condition. But it is not said. Only this is said: “A past state is a condition, by way of proximity condition, for a present state, and by way of repetition condition.” Therefore, all the kinds of consciousness beginning with adverting are stated separately, according to their own moment,

original: sahuppannāni parassa cittānigaṇhantīti yuttaṃ, naca tāni dhammato bhinnā lambaṇānināma🔽honti. Gahaṇā kārassa abhinnattā. Āvajjanaṃpi hi cittanteva āvajjati. Javanānica🔽cittaṃ cittanteva javanti. Tānica sabbāni cittānieva hontīti. Atītānantara cutito🔽pana paṭṭhāya atītā khandhā khandhupani bandhā nāma gottakasiṇa nimittādikā paññattiyo
analyzed: sahuppannāni parassa cittāni gaṇhanti iti yuttam na ca tāni dhammataḥ bhinnā 🔽honti gahaṇā kārassa abhinnattā āvajjanam pi hi āvajjati javanānica 🔽cittam cittanta iva javanti tāni ca sabbāni cittāni eva honti iti atīta anantara cutito 🔽pana paṭṭhāya atītā khandhā bandhā nāma gotta kasiṇa nimitta ādikā paññattiyaḥ
translated: It can be said that the ‘series’ is mentioned in terms of the time-division of the continuity. Otherwise, it would have to be said that a present state is a condition, by way of the condition being immediately prior, for a present state, and by way of the condition being repetition. But that is not said. It is only said that a past state is a condition, by way of the condition being immediately prior, for a present state, and by way of the condition being repetition. Therefore it is proper to say that all the consciousnesses beginning with adverting are each individually associated with their own states arisen at the same time as themselves, and that they apprehend the consciousnesses of another. And they do not become different from the states of consciousness by the name of ‘apprehending’, because the act of apprehending is not different. For adverting adverts only consciousness, and impulsion impels only consciousness. And all these are only consciousness. But beginning with the moment immediately following the past, the past aggregates are called ‘states of aggregates’, and the determinations such as the sign of the kasiṇa derived from the elements are called ‘determinations’.

original: nibbānañca pubbenivāsañāṇassa ārammaṇaṃ hoti. Paccuppannaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ dibbacakkhussāti
analyzed: nibbānam ca pubbenivāsa ñāṇassa ārammaṇam hoti paccuppannam rūpa ārammaṇam dibba cakkhussa ati
translated: and Nibbāna is the object of knowledge of past lives. The present visible-data object is the object of the divine eye.

original: evaṃ rūpādīsu chasu ālambaṇesu yathāraha mappetīti. Idāni abhiññāvasena pavakkhassa
analyzed: evam rūpa ādīsu chasu ālambaṇesu yathāraha mappeti iti idāni abhiññā vasena pavakkhassa
translated: So it occurs in the six objects beginning with visible data, as appropriate. Now, in order to point out the kinds of direct-knowledge,

original: tassa pañcamajjhānassa kiccabhedena pabhedaṃ dassetuṃ iddhividhantiādigātha māha.🔽Tattha yaṃ yaṃ adhiṭṭhāti. Yathā yathāca adhiṭṭhāti. Tassa tassa tathā tathāvā ijjhana
analyzed: tassa pañcama jhānassa kicca bhedena pabhedam dassetum  tattha yam yam adhiṭṭhāti yathā yathā ca adhiṭṭhāti tassa tassa tathā tathāvā
translated: he said the verse beginning with “The kinds of supernormal power” .🔽Herein, the kinds of supernormal power is that in which there is success, called “kind” , in the sense of a section or class or manifestation, of the resolution of whatever and however it is resolved.

original: saṅkhāto vidho koṭṭhāso pakārovā etassāti iddhividhaṃ. Taṃ pana tividhaṃ adhiṭṭhā🔽niddhi vikubbaniddhi manomayiddhi vasena. Tattha attano pakativaṇṇaṃ avijahitvā tasseva🔽sata sahassādi bahubhāva karaṇa vasenavā ākāsagamanādivasena vā bahiddhā nānāvaṇṇa
analyzed: saṅkhātaḥ vidhaḥ koṭṭhāso pakāro vā etassa ati iddhividham tam pana tividham adhiṭṭhā  vasena tattha attanaḥ pakati vaṇṇam a vijahitvā tassa iva  sata sahassa ādi bahu bhāva karaṇa vasena vā ākāsagamana ādi vasena vā bahiddhā nānā vaṇṇa
translated: That is of three kinds as resolution-success, alteration-success, and mind-made-body-success.

original: pāṭihāriya dassana vasenavā pavattitā iddhi adhiṭṭhāniddhināma. Pakativaṇṇaṃ pana
analyzed: pāṭihāriya dassana vasenavā pavatti tā iddhi adhiṭṭhāniddhi nāma pakati vaṇṇam pana
translated: Herein, success that occurs by making the one visible form of one’s own normal physical body appear as many, as a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, etc., or by making it go through the air, or by making it show various kinds of wonders outside, without abandoning the normal visible form, is called resolution-success. But the normal visible form is the visible form of the normal physical body.

original: vijahitvā attānameva kumāravaṇṇanāgavaṇṇādikaṃ katvā dassanavasena pavattitā iddhi
analyzed: vijahitvā attānam eva kumāra vaṇṇa nāga vaṇṇa ādikam katvā dassana vasena pavattitā id hi
translated: It is called the supernormal power of transformation because it occurs by way of showing oneself in the form of a boy, a snake, and so on, after abandoning one’s own form.

original: vikubbaniddhināma. Attano sarīrabbhantare aññaṃ sabbaso attanā sadisaṃ sarīraṃ nimminitvā🔽nīharitvā dassanavasena pavattitā iddhi manomayiddhināma. Dive bhavaṃ dibbaṃ. Devaloke
analyzed: vikubba niddhi nāma attano sarīra abbhantare aññam sabbasas attanā sadisam sarīram nimminitvā  nīharitvā dassana vasena id hi manaḥ maya iddhi nāma dive bhavam dibbam deva loke
translated: It is called the supernormal power of the mind-made body because it occurs by way of creating another body entirely similar to oneself inside one’s own body,🔽and by way of showing it after taking it out.

original: jātanti attho. Dibbañca taṃ sotañcāti dibbasotaṃ. Devānaṃ uḷārakammanibbattā dūrepi🔽paṭicchannepi ārammaṇasampaṭicchanasamatthaṃ pasādasotaṃ. Dibbasotasadisattā pana🔽idaṃ abhiññāñāṇaṃpi dibbasotanti vuccati. Kasiṇajjhāna saṅkhātenavā dibbavihārena
analyzed: jātanti atthaḥ dibbam ca tam sotam ca ati dibba sotam devānam uḷāra kamma nibbattā dūre pi  paṭicchanne pi ārammaṇa sampaṭicchana samattham pasāda sotam dibba sota sadisa ttā pana  idam abhiññā ñāṇam pi dibba sotanti vuccati kasiṇa jhāna saṅkhātena vā dibba vihārena
translated: It is called the divine ear because it is divine and it is hearing. It is divine, heavenly, belonging to the gods, born of good actions, capable of receiving and retaining the sound of the far and the near.🔽But this knowledge of the divine ear is called the divine ear because it is similar to the divine ear.

original: paṭiladdhattā sayañca tasmiṃ dibbavihāre pariyāpannattā dibbañca taṃ sotañcāti dibbasotaṃ.
analyzed: paṭiladdha ttā sayam ca tasmin dibba vihāre pariyāpanna ttā dibbam ca tam sotam ca ati dibba sotam
translated: It is called the divine ear because it is divine and it is hearing. It is divine because it is obtained by means of the divine abiding called the jhāna of the kasiṇa, and because it is included in that divine abiding.

original: Parassa cittaṃ vijānanti etenāti paracittavijānanaṃ. Tadeva cetopariyāyanti paricchijja
analyzed: parassa cittam vijānanti etena ati para citta vijānanam tat eva cetaḥ upariyāyanti paricchijja
translated: It is called the knowledge of penetration of the minds of others because it is by means of this that one knows the minds of others.🔽It is called the knowledge of the categories of the mind because it is by means of this that one knows the categories of the minds of others.

original: jānanti etenāti katvā cetopariyañāṇantipi vuccati. Pubbe nivāso vuccati atītabhavesu
analyzed: jānanti etena ati katvā cetaḥ pariya ñāṇam ti pi vuccati pubbe nivāso vuccati atīta bhavesu
translated: It is called “knowledge of penetration of minds” because it is that by means of which they know . “Recollection of past lives” is said of the states that have occurred in past births.

original: attano chasu dvāresu āpātaṃ āgatā suṭṭhu viditā dhammā. Pubbe atītajātīsu gocara🔽nivāsavasena nivasiṃsu attano chadvārikāni cittāni etthāti katvā. Sabbaññubuddhānaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ chasu dvāresu āpātam āgatā suṭṭhu viditā dhammā pubbe atīta jātīsu gocara  nivāsa vasena nivasiṃsu cha dvārikāni cittāni ettha ati katvā sabbaññu buddhānam
translated: They are “well known” because they have come within the range of one’s own six doors.🔽The six kinds of consciousness that occur in one’s own six doors are called “past lives” because they lived there in the past as the abodes of the cognizance that had them as its objects.

original: pana paresaṃ chadvāragahitāpi dhammā pubbe nivāso hotiyeva, pubbe nivāsassa anussaraṇaṃ
analyzed: pana paresam cha dvāra gahitā api dhammā pubbe nivāsaḥ hotiya iva pubbe nivāsassa anussaraṇam
translated: But in the case of the omniscient Buddhas, states that are not apprehended by others’ six doors are also past lives.

original: pubbenivāsānussati. Idha pana taṃ sampayuttañāṇaṃ adhippetaṃ. Pubbe vuttanayena dibbañca
analyzed: pubbenivāsa anussati idha pana tat sampayutta ñāṇam adhippetam pubbe vutta nayena dibbam ca
translated: The recollection of past lives is the recollection of that. But here the knowledge associated with it is intended.

original: taṃ cakkhucāti dibbacakkhu. Taṃ sadisattā idaṃ abhiññāñāṇaṃpi dibbacakkhūti vuccati.
analyzed: tam dibba cakkhu tam sadisa ttā idam abhiññā ñāṇam pi dibba cakkhu iti vuccati
translated: And because it is like the divine eye, this knowledge of the kinds of supernormal power is called “divine eye” too.

original: Dibbavihāra vasena paṭiladdhattā sayañca dibbavihārasannissitattā dibbañca taṃ cakkhucāti
analyzed: dibba vihāra vasena paṭiladdha ttā sayam ca dibba vihāra sannissita ttā dibbam ca tam
translated: It is divine because it is obtained by means of divine abiding, and it is an eye because it is dependent on the divine abiding.

original: dibbacakkhu. Yathākammupagañāṇaṃ anāgataṃsañāṇanti imāni dve ñāṇāni imasseva paribhaṇḍañāṇānināma.
analyzed: dibba cakkhu yathā kammupaga ñāṇam anāgataṃsa ñāṇam ti imāni dve ñāṇāni imassa eva
translated: The divine eye and the knowledge of faring according to deeds are the two kinds of knowledge called “knowledge of the kinds of states.”

original: Nahi tesaṃ paṭilābhatthāya visuṃ cittaparidamanaparikammaṃnāma atthi. Dibbacakkhuñāṇe🔽paṭiladdhe tesaṃpi paṭiladdhattāti. Tattha dibbacakkhunā nirayesu dukkhaṃ devesuvā
analyzed: nahi tesam paṭilābha tthāya visum atthi dibba cakkhu ñāṇe  paṭiladdhe tesam pi paṭiladdha ttā ti tattha dibba cakkhunā nirayesu dukkham devesu vā
translated: For there is no separate exercise of attention for the purpose of obtaining them.🔽When the knowledge of the divine eye is obtained, they are obtained too.

original: sukhaṃ anubhavante satte disvā tesaṃ atītaṃ kammaṃ jānissāmīti parikammaṃ karontassa🔽taṃ kammārammaṇaṃ yathākammupagañāṇaṃ pavattati. Tato cavitvā kattha bhavissantīti
analyzed: sukham anubhavante satte disvā tesam atītam kammam jānissāmi iti parikammam karontassa  tam kamma ārammaṇam yathā kamma upaga ñāṇam pavattati tatas cavitvā kattha bhavissanti iti
translated: Herein, when one who is exercising the divine eye sees beings experiencing pain in the hells and pleasure in the heavenly worlds, he thinks, “I shall know their past action.”🔽So he does the preliminary work for the knowledge of faring according to deeds.🔽Then the knowledge of faring according to deeds occurs in him with that action as its object.

original: tesaṃ anāgate pavattiṃ passissāmīti parikammaṃ karontassa tesaṃ anāgatakhandhārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: tesam anāgate pavattim passissāmi iti parikammam karontassa tesam anāgata khandha ārammaṇam
translated: After that, he thinks, “Where will they be born when they pass away?”🔽So he does the preliminary work for the knowledge of the future. Then the knowledge of the future occurs in him with their future aggregates as its object.

original: anāgataṃsañāṇaṃ pavattati. Pubbe nivāsānussati ñāṇaṃ viyaca sabbaṃpi anāgatadhammajātaṃ
analyzed: anāgataṃsañāṇam pavattati pubbe nivāsa anussati ñāṇam viya ca sabbam pi anāgata dhamma jātam
translated: Like the knowledge of past lives,

original: etassa ārammaṇaṃ hotiyeva. Etañhi attano visaye sabbaññutañāṇagatikanti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: etassa ārammaṇam hotiyā iva etat hi attanaḥ visaye sabbaññuta ñāṇa gatikan ti aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam
translated: and it has that as its object. For it is said in the commentary: “This has as its object the all-knowing knowledge in its own field.”

original: Vibhāvaniyaṃ pana
analyzed: vibhāvaniyam pana
translated: But in the Vibhāvinī it is said:

original: Anāgate sattadivasato paṭṭhāya cittacetasikadhammā dutīyadivasato paṭṭhāya yaṃkiñci ārammaṇaṃ etassa visayoti adhippetaṃ. Tampi yuttaṃviya dissati.
analyzed: anāgate satta divasataḥ paṭṭhāya citta cetasika dhammā dutīya divasataḥ paṭṭhāya yaṃ kiñci ārammaṇam etassa visayaḥ ti adhippetam tat pi yuttam viya dissati
translated: “The intention is that from the seventh day before the future, and from the second day before the past, any object whatever is the province of this knowledge.” That too seems appropriate.

original: Nahi bhavantarepi anāvatadhamme jānituṃ samatthaṃ etaṃ imasmiṃ bhave anāgatadhamme🔽najānātīti sakkā bhavituṃ. Yathā cetaṃ, tathā pubbenivāsañāṇaṃpi imasmiṃ bhave parasantānagate
analyzed: nahi bhavantare pi anāvata dhamme jānitum samattham etam imasmin bhave anāgata dhamme  na jānāti iti sakkā bhavitum yathā cetam tathā pubbenivāsa ñāṇam pi imasmin bhave para santāna gate
translated: For it is not able to know states that are not present in this birth even in the future,🔽so how can it know future states in this birth? And as this is so, so too the knowledge of past lives is not able to know🔽states that are in another’s continuity in this birth as past states.

original: atītadhammeti. Pāḷiyaṃ pana aṭṭhakathāsuca bhavantaragatadhammehi eva ñāṇadvayaṃ
analyzed: atīta dhamma iti pāḷiyam pana aṭṭhakathāsu ca bhava antara gata dhammehi eva ñāṇa dvayam
translated: But in the texts and in the commentaries the two kinds of knowledge are treated as though they had as their objects states in another birth.

original: yojitaṃ. Taṃ pana asādhāraṇakālavasena ānubhāvavisesapākaṭatthaṃ yojitanti yuttaṃ
analyzed: yojitam tam pana asādhāraṇa kāla vasena yojitam iti yuttam
translated: That is done in order to show the pre-eminence of the knowledge by way of the unusual time.🔽And it is appropriate to do this.

original: siyāti. Gocarabhedoti dasakasiṇādīsu gocaresu samathajjhānānaṃ pavattibhedo.
analyzed: siyā ati gocara bhedaḥ iti dasa kasiṇa ādīsu gocaresu samatha jhānānam pavatti bhedo
translated: Difference of province: the difference in the occurrence of the jhānas of serenity in the provinces beginning with the ten kinds of kasiṇa .

original: Samathakammaṭṭhānanayo.
analyzed: samatha kammaṭṭhānanayaḥ
translated: The method of the meditation subject of insight.

original: 171. Sabbalokiyamahājanehi yathādiṭṭhaṃ puggalasattaitthi purisādikaṃ nicca dhuva🔽sukha atta nimittañca atikkamitvā visesena passanti etāyāti vipassanā. Kiriyā kammaṃ.
analyzed: sabba lokiya mahājanehi yathā diṭṭham puggala satta aitthi purisa ādikam  sukha atta nimittañca atikkamitvā visesena passanti etāyāti vipassanā kiriyā kammaṃ
translated: Insight is the act of seeing, which sees, by surmounting the perception of permanence, etc., the special qualities of impermanence, etc., in the various instances of individual existence among the aggregates, bases, and elements, which are objects of the perception of permanence, etc., and which are seen as permanent, etc., by ordinary people and by some who are not ordinary people.🔽The meditation subject of insight is the meditation subject for insight, or the meditation subject of insight is the meditation subject for that insight.

original: Bhāvanāpayogo. Vipassanāya kammaṃ vipassanākammaṃ. Vipassanā eva vā kammanti vipassanā🔽kammaṃ. Vipassanākammassa ṭhānaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṃ bhumīti vipassanākammaṭṭhānaṃ. Khandhādidhammajātaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvanā apayogaḥ vipassanāya kammam vipassanā kammam vipassanā eva vā kammanti vipassanā  kammam vipassanā kammassa ṭhānam adhiṭṭhānam bhumi iti vipassanā kammaṭṭhānam khandha ādi dhamma jātam
translated: Or the meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.🔽The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.🔽The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.🔽The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.🔽The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.

original: Vipassanā kammameva vā uttaruttarassa bhāvanā visesassa ānisaṃsavisesassavā ṭhānaṃ🔽āsannakāraṇanti vipassanākammaṭṭhānaṃ. Tasmiṃ vipassanākammaṭṭhāne sattavidhena visuddhi
analyzed: vipassanā kammam eva vā uttaruttarassa bhāvanā visesassa ānisaṃsa visesassa vā ṭhānam  āsanna kāraṇam ti vipassanā kammaṭṭhānam tasmin vipassanā kammaṭṭhāne sattavidhena visuddhi
translated: The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.🔽The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.🔽The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.🔽The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.🔽The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.🔽The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.🔽The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of what is special.

original: saṅgaho tīṇi lakkhaṇānītiādinā sambandho. Niccasīlameva sayañca dussilyamalato visuddhattā
analyzed: saṅgaho tīṇi lakkhaṇāni iti ādinā sambandhaḥ nicca sīlam eva sayam ca dussilya malataḥ
translated: The meditation subject of insight is the footing for insight, the proximate cause for insight, which is a special kind of development of

original: kāyaṃ vācañca tato visodhanato visuddhīti sīlavisuddhi. Subhāvita cittasantānameva
analyzed: kāyam vācam ca tatas visodhanataḥ citta santānam eva
translated: and it is purification since it purifies the body and speech.

original: sayañca nīvaraṇamalato visuddhattā taṃsamaṅgipuggalañca tato visodhanato visuddhīti
analyzed: sayam ca nīvaraṇa malataḥ taṃsam aṅgi puggalam ca tatas visodhanataḥ visuddhi iti
translated: and it is purification since it purifies the individual possessing that condition by purifying his own mental continuity from the stain of the hindrances.

original: cittavisuddhi. Cittasīsena cettha samādhi adhippeto. Dhammavavatthānañāṇasaṅkhātā
analyzed: citta visuddhi citta sīsena ca ittha samādhi adhippetaḥ dhamma vavatthāna ñāṇa saṅkhātā
translated: Herein, concentration is intended by the word “mind.”

original: diṭṭhieva taṃ samaṅgipuggalaṃ sakkāyadiṭṭhimalato visodhanato visuddhīti diṭṭhivisuddhi.
analyzed: tam samaṅgi puggalam sakkāya diṭṭhi malataḥ visodhanataḥ visuddhi iti diṭṭhi visuddhi
translated: and it is purification since it purifies the individual possessing that condition by purifying him from the stain of personality view.

original: Soḷasavidhaṃ aṭṭhavidhaṃ kaṅkhaṃ vitaranti atikkamanti etāyāti kaṅkhāvitaraṇā. Paccayapariggahañāṇaṃ.🔽Sā eva taṃsamaṅgipuggalaṃ ahetu diṭṭhi visamahetudiṭṭhīhi saddhiṃ yathāvuttāhi duvidhāhi🔽kaṅkhāhi visodhanato visuddhīti kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhi. Maggoca amaggoca maggāmaggā.
analyzed: soḷasavidham aṭṭhavidham kaṅkham vitaranti atikkamanti etāya ati kaṅkhā vitaraṇā paccaya pariggaha ñāṇam  sā eva tad samaṅgi puggalam ahetu diṭṭhi visama hetu diṭṭhīhi saddhim yathā vuttāhi duvidhāhi  kaṅkhā hi visodhanataḥ maggo ca amaggo ca magga amaggā
translated: They surmount, they go beyond, the sixteen kinds of uncertainty and the eight kinds of doubt by means of this, thus it is the surmounting of uncertainty . It is the knowledge of discerning conditions.🔽and it is purification since it purifies the individual possessing that condition by purifying him from the two kinds of uncertainty mentioned above, together with the false view of no-cause and the false view of wrong-cause.🔽The noble path is the method for attaining purification by knowledge and vision.

original: Tattha ñāṇadassanavisuddhādhigamanassa upāyabhūto manasikāravidhivā ariyamaggovā
analyzed: tattha ñāṇa dassana visuddha adhigamanassa upāya bhūtaḥ manasikāra vidhivā ariya maggaḥ uvā
translated: The method of attention is the path of the noble ones.

original: maggonāma. Tassa anupāyabhūto manasikārovā adhimānavatthūnivā amaggonāma. Maggassa
analyzed: maggo nāma tassa anupāya bhūtaḥ manasikāraḥ vā adhimāna vatthūni vā amaggaḥ nāma maggassa
translated: and the path is called the path. The attention that is not the means to that is called the wrong path, as are the grounds for conceit.

original: maggato amaggassaca amaggato jānanaṃ dassanañca maggāmaggañāṇadassanaṃ. Tameva taṃsamaṅgīpuggalaṃ
analyzed: maggataḥ amaggassa ca amaggataḥ jānanam dassanam ca magga amagga ñāṇa dassanam tam eva tad samaṅgī puggalam
translated: The knowledge and vision of the path and the wrong path is the knowledge and vision of the path and the wrong path as the path and as the wrong path.

original: amagge maggasaññāya visodhanato visuddhīti maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhi nāma. Upari
analyzed: amagge magga saññāya visodhanataḥ visuddhī iti magga amagga ñāṇa dassana visuddhi nāma upari
translated: That purification of the person who possesses that knowledge is called purification by knowledge and vision of the path and the wrong path.

original: visesaṃ paṭipajjanti etāyāti paṭipadā. Vipassanāparaṃparasaṅkhāto pubbabhāgamaggo.🔽Paṭipadābhūtaṃ ñāṇadassananti paṭipadāñāṇadassanaṃ. Tameva niccasaññādito visuddhattā
analyzed: visesam paṭipajjanti etāya ati paṭipadā vipassanā paraṃpara saṅkhātaḥ pubbabhāga maggo  paṭipadā bhūtam ñāṇa dassananti paṭipadā ñāṇa dassanam tam eva nicca saññā āditaḥ visuddhattā
translated: The path is called the way because they enter upon the distinction above by means of it. It is the prior-to-path path consisting in a succession of insight.🔽The knowledge and vision that is the way is called knowledge and vision of the way.🔽That purification of the person who possesses that knowledge is called purification by knowledge and vision of the way.

original: visuddhīti paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhināma, ariyamaggañāṇasaṅkhāta ñāṇadassanameva
analyzed: visuddhi iti paṭipadā ñāṇa dassana visuddhi nāma ariya magga ñāṇa saṅkhāta ñāṇa dassanam eva
translated: Knowledge and vision consisting in the knowledge of the noble paths is called purification by knowledge and vision.

original: sammohamalato visuddhattā visuddhīti ñāṇadassanavisuddhināma. Etthaca sutamayādivasena
analyzed: sammoha malataḥ visuddha ttā visuddhī iti ñāṇa dassana visuddhi nāma ettha ca suta maya ādi vasena
translated: And that is called purification by knowledge and vision because it is purified from the stain of confusion.

original: siddhaṃ anumāna ñāṇaṃpi ñāṇamevāti taṃ paṭikkhipitvā atthapaccakkhañāṇameva gahetuṃ
analyzed: siddham anumāna ñāṇam pi ñāṇam eva ati tam paṭikkhipitvā attha paccakkha ñāṇam eva gahetum
translated: Herein, the inferential knowledge that is established by means of what is learnt, etc., is also knowledge, but in order to exclude that, only knowledge by insight of what can be known is included.

original: sabbattha dassanagahaṇaṃ katanti veditabbaṃ. Lakkhīyanti sallakkhīyanti ime aniccāevāti🔽ekantena vinicchīyanti dhammā etenāti lakkhaṇaṃ aniccatā eva lakkhaṇanti aniccalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: sabbattha dassana gahaṇam katanti veditabbam lakkhīyanti sallakkhīyanti ime aniccā eva ati  ekantena dhammāḥ etena ati lakkhaṇam anicca tā eva lakkhaṇanti anicca lakkhaṇam
translated: It should be understood that the word “characteristic” is used here in the sense of “seeing” and “apprehending.”🔽The dhammas are “characterized” in the sense that they are “seen” and “apprehending” as impermanent.🔽The characteristic is that by which the dhammas are characterized as impermanent.

original: Pubbapade bhāvapaccayalopo. Aññohi anicco, aññā aniccatāti. Tattha yathāgamanakriyāyogena
analyzed: pubba pade bhāva paccaya lopaḥ aññaḥ hi aniccaḥ aññā anicca tā ti tattha yathā gamana kriyā yogena
translated: The locative ending in the compound “aniccalakkhaṇe” is to be resolved as follows: “The characteristic of impermanence is that by which the dhammas are characterized as impermanent.”

original: puriso gatoti vuccati. Na pana gamana kriyā puriso. Naca puriso gamanakriyā. Aññā
analyzed: purisaḥ gataḥ ti vuccati na pana gamana kriyā purisaḥ na ca purisaḥ gamana kriyā aññā
translated: For just as a man is said to have gone by the fact of his connection with the action of going, but the action of going is not the man, nor is the man the action of going, since the action and the man are different from each other;

original: hi kriyā, añño puriso. Tathā aniccatāyogena sabbo saṅkhatadhammo aniccoti vuccati.
analyzed: hi kriyā añño puriso tathā anicca tā yogena sabbo saṅkhata dhammo aniccaḥ iti vuccati
translated: so too, all formed dhammas are said to be impermanent by the fact of their connection with impermanence.

original: Na pana aniccatā so dhammo, naca so dhammo aniccatā. Aññā hi aniccatā, añño so dhammoti.
analyzed: na pana anicca tā so dhammaḥ na ca so dhammo anicca tā aññā hi anicca tā aññaḥ so dhammo ti
translated: But impermanence is not the dhamma, nor is the dhamma impermanence, since impermanence and the dhamma are different from each other.

original: Katamā pana sā aniccatāti. Vipariṇāmā kāro. Jīraṇākāro bhijjanākāroti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: katamā pana sā anicca tā ati vipariṇāmā kāraḥ jīraṇa ākāraḥ bhijjana ākāro ti vuttam hoti
translated: What, then, is this impermanence? It is the mode of change, the mode of ageing, the mode of dissolution.

original: Taṃ pana ākāraṃ disvā tadākāravante dhamme ñāṇaṃ pavattati ayaṃ dhammo aniccoti.
analyzed: tam pana ākāram disvā tad ākāravante dhamme ñāṇam pavattati ayam dhammo aniccaḥ ti
translated: But when one sees this mode, one’s knowledge occurs in regard to the dhammas that possess that mode in the form “This dhamma is impermanent.”

original: Tasmā sā aniccatāyeva idha lakkhaṇantipi vuccatīti. Esanayo sesesupi dvīsu. Tattha
analyzed: tasmā sā anicca tāya iva idha lakkhaṇa nti pi vuccati iti sesesu pi dvīsu tattha
translated: The other two should be sought in the same way.

original: pana abhiṇhasaṃpaṭipīḷanākāro dukkhatānāma. Avasavattanākāro anattatānāmāti. Yathāvuttāya
analyzed: pana abhiṇha saṃpaṭipīḷana ākāraḥ dukkha tā nāma avasavattana ākāraḥ anatta tā nāma ati yathā vuttāya
translated: Herein, the mode of oppressing again and again is the mode of the sign of pain; the mode of non-submission is the mode of the sign of not-self.

original: pana aniccatāya saha aniccassa dhammassa aniccena vā dhammena saha aniccatāya anuanupassanā🔽aniccānupassanā. Esa nayo sesāsupi dvīsu. Yāva sarīre dhammānaṃ tividhalakkhaṇayuttatā
analyzed: pana anicca tāya saha aniccassa dhammassa aniccena vā dhammena saha anicca tāya anuanupassanā  anicca anupassanā esa nayaḥ sesāsu pi dvīsu yāva sarīre dhammānam tividha lakkhaṇa yutta tā
translated: But the contemplation of impermanence as stated is the contemplation of impermanence in the impermanent, either as impermanence in the impermanent or as impermanence in what is associated with the impermanent.🔽The same method applies in the case of the other two.

original: attano ñāṇena paññāyati. Tāva tesu tividhalakkhaṇavibhāvanavasena punappunaṃ masanaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ ñāṇena paññāyati tāva tesu tividha lakkhaṇa vibhāvana vasena punappunam masanam
translated: As long as the fact that the states in the body are endowed with the three characteristics is evident to his knowledge, then his repeated reflection on them by discerning their three characteristics is

original: āmasanaṃ sammasanaṃ. Sammasanākārena pavattaṃ ñāṇaṃ sammasanañāṇaṃ. Udayo vuccati🔽taṃtaṃ khaṇānurūpaṃ taṃtaṃ paccayānurūpañca navanavānaṃ dhammānaṃ pātu bhāvo ceva
analyzed: āmasanam sammasanam sammasana ākārena pavattam ñāṇam sammasana ñāṇam udayaḥ vuccati  taṃtam khaṇa anurūpam taṃtam paccaya anurūpam ca nava navānam dhammānam pātu bhāvaḥ ca iva
translated: “pressing” , “pressing out,” “pressing together.” The knowledge that occurs in the mode of pressing together is “knowledge of pressing together.”🔽Arising is the appearance of fresh states of aggregates, etc., in conformity with the respective moments and in conformity with the respective conditions, and their increase and expansion.

original: uparupari vaḍḍhanañca. Vayo vuccati yattha yattha laddhapaccayā navanavā dhammā pātubhavanti
analyzed: upari upari vaḍḍhanam ca vayaḥ vuccati yattha yattha laddha paccayāḥ nava navāḥ dhammā pātubhavanti
translated: Cessation is the non-appearance of fresh states of aggregates, etc., that have not already appeared, though the conditions are present.

original: ceva vaḍḍhantica. Tattha tattha aladdhapaccayānaṃ purāṇadhammānaṃ antaradhānaṃ. Samūha
analyzed: ca iva vaḍḍhanti ca tattha tattha a laddha paccayānam purāṇa dhammānam antaradhānam samūha
translated: and the old things that have not yet obtained conditions for growth disappear.

original: santativasena pana udayapakkhassavā vayapakkhassavā samanupassanañāṇaṃ udayabbayañāṇaṃ.
analyzed: santati vasena pana udaya pakkha ssavā vaya pakkha ssavā samanupassana ñāṇam udaya bbaya ñāṇam
translated: But the knowledge of the contemplation of rise and subsidence is the knowledge of rise and fall.

original: Tesu pana dvīsu pakkhesu udayakoṭṭhāsonāma uparupari pākaṭo hutvā āgacchati. Vayakoṭṭhāso
analyzed: tesu pana dvīsu pakkhesu udayakoṭṭhāso nāma upara upari pākaṭaḥ hutvā āgacchati vayakoṭṭhāso
translated: Now, in the case of these two aspects, the section on rise is manifest and comes into focus,🔽but the section on fall is not manifest.

original: pana apākaṭo. So eva ca aniccatāya paramā koṭīti tasseva suṭṭhutaraṃ samanupassanañāṇaṃ
analyzed: pana apākaṭaḥ saḥ eva ca anicca tāya paramā koṭī iti tassa iva suṭṭhutaram samanupassana ñāṇam
translated: And that is the ultimate end of impermanence. So the knowledge of the contemplation of that is🔽the knowledge of fall.🔽When fall is seen, the knowledge of the contemplation of the various kinds of fearfulness in formations that have such a breakup as their end is

original: bhaṅgañāṇaṃ. Bhaṅge diṭṭhe evaṃ bhijjanasabhāvānaṃ dhammānaṃ anekasahassasoka dukkhavatthubhāvena🔽tathā tathā bhāyitabbapakārasamanupassanañāṇaṃ bhayañāṇaṃ nāma. Loke pana kiñci bhayavatthuṃ
analyzed: bhaṅga ñāṇam bhaṅge diṭṭhe evam bhijjana sabhāvānam dhammānam aneka sahassa soka dukkha vatthu bhāvena  tathā tathā bhāyitabba pakāra samanupassana ñāṇam bhaya ñāṇam nāma loke pana kiñci bhaya vatthum
translated: the knowledge of fearfulness.🔽But although people see some fearful thing in the world, they are not afraid if they have some other refuge near at hand; they are only afraid if they have no such refuge.

original: passantāpi āsanne aññasmiṃ paṭisaraṇe sati na bhāyanti. Asati eva bhāyanti. Evaṃ
analyzed: passantā api āsanne aññasmim paṭisaraṇe sati na bhāyanti asati eva bhāyanti evam
translated: So too,

original: bhāyitabbānaṃ tesaṃ sabbaso aññapaṭisaraṇābhāvadassanaṃ ādīnavañāṇaṃ nāma. Kutoci
analyzed: bhāyitabbānam tesam sabbasas añña paṭisaraṇa abhāva dassanam ādīnava ñāṇam nāma kutoci
translated: The knowledge of the danger is the insight knowledge that sees that there is no other refuge for them at all.

original: paṭisaraṇābhāvena tehi ukkaṇṭhatākāra sahitaṃ vipassanāñāṇaṃ nibbidāñāṇaṃnāma. Nibbindīyamānehi
analyzed: paṭisaraṇa abhāvena tehi ukkaṇṭha tā ākāra sahitam vipassanā ñāṇam nibbidā ñāṇaṃ nāma nibbindīyamānehi
translated: The knowledge of dispassion is the insight knowledge that is accompanied by the mode of anxiety because there is no refuge for them from anywhere.

original: tehi attānaṃ vimuccituṃ ajjhāsayasahitaṃ vipassanāñāṇaṃ muccitukamyatāñāṇaṃ nāma.🔽Suṭṭhu muccituṃ icchantassa sīghaṃ muccanatthaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ cattālīsāya ākārehi🔽anekādīnavarāsi bhāva paṭisaṅkhānavasena suṭṭhuvipphārataraṃ pavattamānaṃ vipassanā🔽ñāṇaṃ paṭisaṅkhāñāṇaṃ nāma. Tesaṃ pana anekādīnavarāsibhāve suṭṭhu diṭṭhe saṅkhāresu
analyzed: tehi attānam vimuccitum ajjhāsaya sahitam vipassanā ñāṇam muccitu kamya tā ñāṇam nāma  suṭṭhu muccitum icchantassa sīgham muccana attham tesam dhammānam cattālīsāya ākārehi                      ñāṇam paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇam nāma tesam pana aneka ādīnava rāsi bhāve suṭṭhu diṭṭhe saṅkhāresu
translated: The knowledge of desire for deliverance is the insight knowledge that is accompanied by the wish to be delivered from them.🔽The knowledge of reflection is the insight knowledge that occurs in the forty aspects, reflecting on the mass of dangers in those states, in order to bring about a thorough and complete deliverance.

original: nikantiyā pariyādinnāya idāni muccanupāyo laddhoti adhimattabyāpāraṃ akatvā samena🔽vāyāmena saṅkhāre pariggaṇhantassa saṅkhārapariggahe majjhattākārasahitaṃ saṅkhāresuvā
analyzed: nikantiyā pariyādinnāya idāni mucca nupāyaḥ laddhā iti adhimatta byāpāram a katvā samena 🔽vāyāmena saṅkhāre pariggaṇhantassa saṅkhāra pariggahe majjhatta ākāra sahitam saṅkhāresu vā
translated: The knowledge of contemplation is the insight knowledge that occurs in the mode of equanimity, in the contemplation of formations, without excessive exertion, after seeing the mass of dangers in those formations, and after deciding on and relinquishing them, thinking: “Now the means of deliverance has been obtained.”

original: bhayañca nandiñca pahāya udāsinabhāvasahitaṃ vipassanāñāṇaṃ saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇaṃnāma.
analyzed: bhayam ca nandiñca pahāya udāsina bhāva sahitam vipassanā ñāṇam saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇaṃ nāma
translated: The knowledge of equanimity about formations is the insight knowledge accompanied by the equanimity of neutrality, which abandons fear and delight.

original: Upari maggappavattiṃ vahituṃ samatthabhāvena magguppattiyā anulomehi thāmabalehi
analyzed: upari magga ppavattim vahitum samattha bhāvena magga uppattiyāḥ anulomehi thāma balehi
translated: The conformity knowledge is the insight knowledge that is endowed with the conformity strengths, which are able to lead to the arising of the path.

original: sampannaṃ vipassanāñāṇaṃ anulomañāṇaṃ nāma. Heṭṭhimānaṃvā ñāṇānaṃtaṃ anulomaṃ hoti
analyzed: sampannam vipassanā ñāṇam anulomañāṇam nāma heṭṭhimānam vā ñāṇa anaṃtam anulomam hoti
translated: Or it is called conformity knowledge because it conforms to the lower kinds of knowledge,

original: lakkhaṇattayassa suṭṭhutaraṃ vibhāvanato. Uparimaggassavā anulomaṃ hoti tassa parikammabhāvato,🔽padaṭṭhānattācātipi anulomañāṇaṃ nāmāti. Atta jīvasuññatādassana balena khandhesu
analyzed: lakkhaṇa ttayassa suṭṭhutaram vibhāvanataḥ upari maggassa vā anulomam hoti tassa parikamma bhāvato  anulomañāṇam nāma ati atta jīva suñña tā dassana balena khandhesu
translated: since it illuminates the three characteristics more clearly than they are illuminated by the lower kinds of knowledge, and because it conforms to the higher path, since it is the pre-asraite to the higher path.

original: kilesabandhanato vimuccamāno maggo suññatāvimokkho nāma. Saṅkhārānaṃ yāni nimittāni
analyzed: kilesa bandhanataḥ vimuccamānaḥ maggaḥ suñña tā vimokkhaḥ nāma saṅkhārānam yāni nimittāni
translated: The path that is liberated from the defilements by the power of seeing the voidness of self and life in the aggregates is called the void liberation.

original: kilesānaṃ avassayo hoti. Tāni vidhamitvā sabbaso dhammānaṃ anātha bhāva dassana balena
analyzed: kilesānam avassayaḥ hoti tāni vidhamitvā sabbaso dhammānaṃ anātha bhāva dassana balena
translated: The path that is liberated by the power of seeing the helpless state of all dhammas, having completely removed the signs of formations which are the support for the defilements,

original: vimuccamāno maggo animittovimokkho nāma. Saṅkhāresu sabbaso assāsābhāva dassanabalena
analyzed: vimuccamānaḥ maggaḥ animittaḥ vimokkhaḥ nāma saṅkhāresu sabbaso dassana balena
translated: is called the signless liberation. The path that is liberated by the power of seeing the absence of any hope in formations, having completely removed the desire for formations,

original: vimuccamāno maggo appaṇihitovimokkhonāma. Suññatānupassanāti anattānupassanā. Sā🔽hi dhammānaṃ samūhaghana santatighana kiccaghana ārammaṇaghanesu taṃtaṃghana vinibbhujjana
analyzed: vimuccamānaḥ maggaḥ appaṇihitaḥ vimokkhaḥ nāma suññatā anupassanā ti anatta anupassanā sā  hi dhammānam samūha ghana santati ghana kicca ghana ārammaṇa ghanesu taṃtaṃghana vinibbhujjana
translated: Contemplation of voidness: contemplation of non-self.

original: vasena pavattattā attā iti gahetabbassa kassaci sārassa abhāvānupassanato suññatānupassanāti🔽vuccati. Animittā nupassanāti aniccānupassanā. Sāpi hi santati vicchedana vasena
analyzed: vasena pavatta ttā attā iti gahetabbassa kassaci sārassa abhāva anupassanataḥ suññatā anupassanā ti  vuccati animittā anupassanā ati anicca anupassanā sā api hi santati vicchedana vasena
translated: For that is called “contemplation of voidness” because it is the contemplation of the absence of any core that could be apprehended as self, since it occurs by way of the dissolution of the various kinds of compactness, namely, the compactness of mass, the compactness of continuity, the compactness of function, and the compactness of object.🔽Contemplation of the signless: contemplation of impermanence.

original: pavattattā ahanti gahitassa nimittassa vidhamanato animittānupassanāti vuccati. Apaṇihitānupassanāti🔽dukkhā nupassanā. Sāpi hi mahāādīnavarāsi bhāva vibhāvanavasena pavattattā idaṃ mama
analyzed: pavatta ttā ahanti gahitassa nimittassa vidhamanataḥ animittā anupassanā ati vuccati apaṇihita anupassanā ati  dukkhā nupassanā sā api hi mahā ādīnava rāsi bhāva vibhāvana vasena pavatta ttā idam mama
translated: That too is called “contemplation of the signless” because it is the removal of the sign of permanence, since it occurs by way of the severance of continuity.🔽Contemplation of the desireless: contemplation of suffering.

original: etaṃ mamāti gahetabbassa kassaci paṇihita guṇassa abhāvānupassanato appaṇihitānupassanāti
analyzed: etam mama ati gahetabbassa kassaci paṇihita guṇassa abhāva anupassanataḥ appaṇihita anupassanā ti
translated: That too is called “contemplation of the desireless” because it is the contemplation of the absence of any desirable quality that could be apprehended as “This is mine, this I am, this is my self,” since it occurs by way of the manifestation of the mass of great dangers.

original: vuccatīti. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlanti vinayapaññattisīlaṃ. Tañhi sabbalo kiyasīlānaṃ
analyzed: vuccati iti pātimokkha saṃvara sīlam ti vinaya paññatti sīlam tat hi
translated: is said. The virtue of the Pāṭimokkha restraint: the virtue consisting in the rules of the Vinaya. For that is the face of all the virtues that are to be kept in being,🔽because it is the chief of all virtues. And it is the face of the four kinds of profitable volitions,

original: jeṭṭhakattā patica hoti. Catubhūmakakusalānaṃ ādipabhavabhūtattā mukhañca. Iti patimukhaṭṭhena
analyzed: jeṭṭhaka ttā pati ca hoti mukham ca iti pati mukha ṭṭhena
translated: because it is the origin of the beginning of existence. So it is said to be the Pāṭimokkha in the sense of face. And it is said to be restraint

original: pātimokkhanti vuccati. Tamevaca dussilyamaggassa saṃvaraṇato pidahanato saṃvaroti
analyzed: pātimokkham ti vuccati tam eva ca dussilya maggassa saṃvaraṇataḥ pidahanataḥ saṃvaroti
translated: because it restrains, because it suppresses, the path of unvirtue.

original: vuccatīti. Yesaṃ dhammānaṃ uppattiyā cakkhādīni indriyāni viphanditāni honti. Lolāni
analyzed: vuccati iti yesam dhammānam uppattiyā cakkha ādīni indriyāni viphanditāni honti lolāni
translated: The faculties of eye, etc., are called “faculties” because they are the origins of the occurrence of the states beginning with eye-consciousness, and so on.

original: honti. Tadanubandhāca akusaladhammā uppajjanti. Tesaṃ uppatti maggassa saṃvaraṇavasena
analyzed: honti tad anubandhāḥ ca akusala dhammāḥ uppajjanti tesam uppatti maggassa saṃvaraṇa vasena
translated: The states of unprofitable consciousness and its concomitants that arise in one who is occupied with the exercise of those faculties and who is not restrained in his faculties are called “the arising of the hindrances” .

original: pavattamānā sati indriya saṃvaronāma. So eva sīlanti indriyasaṃvarasīlaṃ. Ājīvanti🔽jīvitaṃ kappenti etenāti ājīvo. Paccayapariyesanavāyāmo. Soyeva buddhapaṭikuṭṭhehi
analyzed: sati indriya saṃvaraḥ nāma eva indriya saṃvara sīlam ājīvanti  jīvitam kappenti etena ati ājīvo paccaya pariyesana vāyāmo buddha paṭikuṭṭhehi
translated: The mindfulness that occurs as the restraint of the faculties in the sense of preventing the arising of those states is called “restraint of the faculties.” That is virtue.🔽The effort of seeking requisites is “wrong livelihood.” The three kinds of scheming and the four kinds of wrong conduct in livelihood are called “wrong livelihood” because they are censured by wise men and because they are a wrong way of getting a living.

original: pupphadānādīhi micchāpayogehi tividhakuhanavatthuhica parisuddhattā ājīvapārisuddhināma.
analyzed: puppha dāna ādīhi micchā apayogehi tividha kuhana vatthuhi ca parisuddha ttā ājīvapārisuddhi nāma
translated: The virtue consisting in the restraint of the faculties is called “purity of livelihood” because it is purified by the avoidance of wrong livelihood, which is censured by wise men and is a wrong way of getting a living.

original: Sā eva sīlanti samāso. Tathārūpena parisuddhena bhikkhācārādinā payogena paṭiladdhānaṃ🔽paccayānaṃ paṭiggahaṇa paribhuñjanakālesu sammohassa gedhassa madassa pamādassaca🔽pahānatthaṃ taṃtaṃpayojanamariyādaṃvā paṭikūlalakkhaṇaṃvā dhātumattalakkhaṇaṃvā pariggahaṇa
analyzed: eva sīlanti samāsaḥ tathārūpena parisuddhena bhikkhā ācāra ādinā payogena paṭiladdhānam  paccayānam paṭiggahaṇa paribhuñjana kālesu sammohassa gedhassa madassa pamādassa ca  pahāna attham taṃ taṃ payojanam ariyādam vā paṭikūla lakkhaṇam vā dhātumatta lakkhaṇam vā pariggahaṇa
translated: This is the compound: “purity” is “pārisuddhi,” and that is “sīla.”

original: paccavekkhanavasena pavattaṃ paccayasevane paṭisaṅkhāñāṇaṃ paccaya sannissitasīlaṃnāma.🔽Parisujjhatīti parisuddhi. Parisuddhieva pārisuddhi. Sā eva sīlanti samāso. Cattāri
analyzed: paccavekkhana vasena pavattam paccaya sevane paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇam paccaya sannissita sīlaṃ nāma  parisujjhati iti parisuddhi parisuddhi eva pārisuddhi sā eva sīlanti samāso cattāri
translated: The knowledge of reviewing the requisites in the use of the requisites of alms food, etc., by means of the characteristic of foulness or by means of the characteristic of the elements, in order to abandon confusion, greed, and negligence in the time of receiving and using the requisites, is called “the virtue consisting in the use of requisites.”🔽“Purification” is “parisuddhi.” This is the compound: “purity” is “parisuddhi,” and that is “sīla.”🔽The four kinds of purification are the four kinds of virtue.

original: pārisuddhisīlānīti catupāri suddhisīlaṃ. Cittavisuddhīti ettha cittasaddena samādhi
analyzed: pārisuddhi sīlāni iti catu pāri suddhi sīlam citta visuddhi iti ettha citta saddena samādhi
translated: “Purification of virtue” is the purification of virtue consisting in the four kinds of purification.🔽“Purification of consciousness” : here the word “consciousness” signifies concentration.

original: niddiṭṭhoti vuttaṃ duvidhopisamādhi cittavisuddhināmāti. Lakkhaṇarasapaccupaṭṭhānapadaṭṭhāna
analyzed: niddiṭṭhaḥ ti vuttam duvidhaḥ pi samādhi citta visuddhi nāmā ti lakkhaṇa rasa paccupaṭṭhāna padaṭṭhāna
translated: It is said that both kinds of concentration are called “purification of consciousness.”🔽By means of the characteristic, the function, the manifestation, and the proximate cause: here the individual essence of dhammas is called the characteristic.

original: vasenāti ettha dhammānaṃ paccattasabhāvo lakkhaṇaṃnāma. Aggissa uṇhattaṃ viya. Tena
analyzed: vasena ati ettha dhammānam paccatta sabhāvaḥ lakkhaṇam nāma aggissa uṇha ttam viya tena
translated: Like the heat of fire.

original: sabhāvena sādhetabbaṃ kiccaṃvā sādhanapaccayā paṭiladdhaguṇasaṅkhātā sampattivā rasonāma.
analyzed: sabhāvena sādhetabbam kiccam vā sādhana paccayā paṭiladdha guṇa saṅkhātā sampatti vā rasaḥ nāma
translated: The success called “quality” that is obtained by the condition of accomplishment is called “meaning” .🔽Like the burning and illuminating of a lamp by the condition of surrounding it with fire.

original: Aggissa parivācana jotanāni viya. Sā eva sampattivā kāriyasaṅkhātaṃ phalaṃvā paccupaṭṭhānaṃnāma.
analyzed: aggissa parivācana jotanāni viya sā eva sampatti vā kāriya saṅkhātam phalam vā paccupaṭṭhānam nāma
translated: That same success is called “manifestation” as the fruit called “function” .🔽Like the smoke of a fire.

original: Aggissa dhūmo viya. Attano uppattiyā asādhāraṇapaccayasaṅkhātaṃ āsannakāraṇaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃnāma.
analyzed: aggissa dhūmaḥ viya attanaḥ uppattiyā asādhāraṇa paccaya saṅkhātam āsanna kāraṇam padaṭṭhānam nāma
translated: The proximate cause called “condition” that is not common to its own arising is called “proximate cause” .

original: Tesaṃ vasena nāmassaca rūpassaca pariggaho ñāṇena paricchinditvā gahaṇaṃ nāmarūpavavatthānaṃ
analyzed: tesam vasena nāmassa ca rūpassa ca pariggahaḥ ñāṇena paricchinditvā gahaṇam nāma rūpa vavatthānam
translated: The defining of mentality-materiality by apprehending it with knowledge after discerning it by means of these is the defining of mentality-materiality.🔽It is called “purification by over-coming doubt” .

original: diṭṭhivisuddhināma. Etthaca pariggaho duvidho saṅkhepa pariggaho vitthārapariggahoti.
analyzed: diṭṭhi visuddhi nāma ettha ca pariggahaḥ duvidho saṅkhepa pariggaho vitthāra pariggaho ti
translated: And here apprehending is twofold: apprehending in brief and apprehending in detail.

original: Tattha ajjhattadhamme dvidhā katvā idaṃ nāmameva, na rūpaṃ. Idaṃ rūpameva, na nāmaṃ.🔽Aññaṃ nāmaṃ aññaṃ rūpaṃ. Tadubhayatoca añño attāvā jīvovā sattovā puggalovā manussovā
analyzed: tattha ajjhatta dhamme dvidhā katvā idam nāmam eva na rūpam idam rūpam eva na nāmam 🔽aññam nāmam aññam rūpam tad ubhayatas ca aññaḥ attā vā jīvaḥ vā satto vā puggalo vā manusso vā
translated: Herein, apprehending in brief is the apprehending of mentality-materiality in brief thus: “There are two kinds of becoming, that is to say, sense-desire becoming and becoming without sense-desire” .🔽Apprehending in detail is the apprehending of mentality-materiality in detail after making it twofold as “mentality” and “materiality” thus: “What is mentality? What is materiality?” .🔽Herein, the apprehending of mentality-materiality in brief is the apprehending of mentality-materiality by means of the four immaterial aggregates under the heading of mentality and the apprehending of materiality by means of the materiality aggregate under the heading of materiality.

original: devovā brahmāvā natthīti evaṃ paccakkhato sudiṭṭhaṃ katvā pariggaṇhanaṃ saṅkhepapariggahonāma.
analyzed: devo vā brahmā vā na atthi iti evam paccakkhataḥ su diṭṭham katvā pariggaṇhanam saṅkhepa pariggahaḥ nāma
translated: “There is no god or Brahmā” — thus he comprehends by direct knowledge, having seen well thus. This is called “comprehension by brief characteristic.”

original: Ñāṇuttarikohi puggalo ettakamattenapi sakkāyadiṭṭhiṃ vikkhambhetuṃ sakkoti saddhiṃ
analyzed: ñāṇuttarikaḥ hi puggalaḥ ettaka mattena api sakkāya diṭṭhim vikkhambhetum sakkoti saddhim
translated: For a person who has gone beyond knowledge, it is possible to suppress sakkāyadiṭṭhi by this much alone,

original: saññā cittavipallāsehīti. Tayo hi vipallāsā. Yathāha-anattani attāti saññāvipallāso🔽cittavipallāso diṭṭhivipallāsoti. Tattha satthusāsanadhamme suṭṭhu patiṭṭhitena saddhāmattenapi
analyzed: saññā citta vipallāsehi iti tayaḥ hi vipallāsāḥ yathā āha an attani attā ati saññā vipallāso  citta vipallāso diṭṭhi vipallāso ti tattha satthu sāsana dhamme suṭṭhu patiṭṭhitena saddhā mattena api
translated: together with the perversions of perception and cognizance. For there are three perversions, as stated in the passage: “In the in-itself there is the self-perception perversion,🔽the cognizance perversion, the view perversion” . Herein, when a person is well established in the faith of the Master’s Dispensation, then the view perversion is suppressed by the faith-strength.

original: diṭṭhi vipallāso vikkhambhito hoti. Itare pana nāmarūpapariggahe kateyeva vikkhambhitā
analyzed: diṭṭhi vipallāsaḥ vikkhambhitaḥ hoti itare pana nāma rūpa pariggahe katā iyā iva vikkhambhitā
translated: But the other two are suppressed only when the comprehension of mentality-materiality is made.

original: honti. Yāvaca ete dve avikkhambhitā honti. Tāva nāmarūpapariggahoca aparisuddhoyeva
analyzed: honti yāva ca ete dve a vikkhambhitāḥ honti nāma rūpa pariggahaḥ ca a parisuddhaḥ yeva
translated: And as long as these two are not suppressed, the comprehension of mentality-materiality is not yet purified,🔽and the defilements rooted in that are not suppressed.

original: hoti. Taṃmūlikāca kilesadhammā avikkhambhitā eva hontīti apica. Catunnaṃ āhārānaṃ
analyzed: hoti taṃmūlikāḥ ca kilesa dhammāḥ a vikkhambhitāḥ eva honti iti apica catunnam āhārānaṃ
translated: And again, as to the four nutriments,

original: vasena catudhā, pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ vasena pañcadhā, channaṃ dhātūnaṃ vasena chadhātiādinā🔽nayena nāmarūpaṃ pariggahe tabbameva. Tattha cha dhātuyonāma pathavidhātu āpodhātu🔽tejodhātu vāyodhātu ākāsadhātu viññāṇadhātuyo. Pakkusāti kulaputto hi imā cha dhātuyo
analyzed: vasena catudhā pañcannam khandhānam vasena pañcadhā channam dhātūnam vasena chadhāti ādinā  nayena nāma rūpam pariggahe tabbam eva tattha cha pathavi dhātu āpodhātu  tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu ākāsa dhātu viññāṇa dhātuyaḥ pakkusāti kula puttaḥ hi imā cha dhātuyaḥ
translated: and so on.🔽Herein, the six elements are the earth element, the water element,🔽the fire element, the wind element, the space element, and the consciousness element.🔽The clansman

original: pariggaṇhitvā anāgāmiphalaṃ patvā capitvā suddhāvāsesu nibbattoti. Yattake vā pana🔽dhamme pariggaṇhanto attā meti pavattamāne saññācittadiṭṭhi vipallāse vikkhambhetuṃ🔽sakkoti. translated: But when he discerns mentality-materiality, he sees that there is nothing else apart from mentality-materiality, and so the view that “The self is material in the physical body … or that ‘The self is material and immaterial’ or that ‘The self is neither material nor immaterial’ is abandoned.🔽And when he sees that there is no such thing as a person apart from mere mentality and mere materiality, and that there is no such thing as the activity of a person, he abandons the view that “The self is a person” and the view that “The self is a person who is a being” and the view that “The self is a person who is not a being.”

original: Suddhe nāme evavārūpe evavā puggalasattakriyasaññitānaṃ īhābyāpārānaṃ sabbaso abhāvadassanato🔽tadubhayasaṃyogeeva tesaṃ labbhamānatā dassanatoca tadubhayaṃvā ekamekaṃvā uddissa🔽attāti pavattā diṭṭhi pahīyati. analyzed: suddhe nāme eva vā rūpe eva vā puggala satta kriya saññitānam īhā byāpārānam sabbasas abhāva dassanato  tad ubhaya saṃyoge eva tesam labbhamāna tā dassanato ca tat ubhayam vā ekam ekam vā uddissa  attā iti pavattā diṭṭhi pahīyati attā jīvaḥ satto puggalo manussaḥ devaḥ brahmā ati evamādīsu  vohāresu ca vohāra matte aṭṭhatvā attā nāma ekantataḥ atthi jīvaḥ nāma ekantataḥ atthi itiādinā
