original: tadatthābhinivesavasena atidhāvanañca pahīyatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tadatthābhinivesotica
analyzed: tad attha abhinivesa vasena atidhāvanam ca pahīyati iti daṭṭhabbam tad attha abhinivesa uti ca
translated: And when he sees that the self is only a name, he abandons the view that “The self is a person who is a god” and the view that “The self is a person who is a human being” and the view that “The self is a person who is a being in one of the other four planes” and the view that “The self is a person who is

original: attānāma atthi jīvonāma atthītiādinā daḷhataraṃ abhiniveso. Atidhāvananti nāmarūpaṃ
analyzed: attā nāma atthi jīvaḥ nāma atthi iti ādinā daḷhataram abhinivesaḥ nāma rūpam
translated: and so on, is the more tenacious adherence. “He overshoots” is the apprehending as self of mentality-materiality,

original: attātiādinā gahaṇaṃ. Paccayapariggahoti etthapi duvidho paccayapariggaho saṅkhepato
analyzed: attā ati ādinā gahaṇam paccaya pariggaho ti ettha api duvidhaḥ paccaya pariggaho saṅkhepato
translated: and so on. As regards the investigation of conditions, there are two kinds of investigation of conditions: in brief and in detail.

original: vitthārato cāti. Tattha vatthārammaṇavasena nāmassa cittotukāhāravasena rūpassa avijjātaṇhupādānakammavasena
analyzed: vitthārato ca ati tattha vattha ārammaṇa vasena nāmassa citta utuka āhāra vasena rūpassa avijjā taṇhā upādāna kamma vasena
translated: Herein, one who investigates in brief does so by way of the object-base in the case of mentality, and by way of the mind-faculty, mental volition, and consciousness in the case of materiality.

original: tadubhayassaca paccayaṃ pariggaṇhanto saṅkhepato pariggaṇhātināma. Heṭṭhā paccayasaṅgahe🔽vibhattehi paṭiccasamuppādanaya paṭṭhānanayehi pariggaṇhanto vitthārato pariggaṇhātināma.
analyzed: tad ubhayassa ca paccayam pariggaṇhantaḥ saṅkhepataḥ pariggaṇhāti nāma heṭṭhā paccaya saṅgahe  vibhattehi paṭiccasamuppāda naya paṭṭhāna nayehi pariggaṇhantaḥ vitthārato
translated: By way of ignorance, craving, and kamma in the case of both.🔽One who investigates in detail does so by way of the exposition of the conditions in the section on the conditions in the Paṭṭhāna and in the Paṭṭhāna-naya.

original: Etthapi paṭṭhānanayena pariggaho ādikammikānaṃ avisayoeva. Paccayaṃ pariggaṇhantassapana
analyzed: ettha api paṭṭhāna nayena pariggahaḥ ādikammikānam avisayaḥ eva paccayam pariggaṇhantassa pana
translated: Herein, the investigation by way of the Paṭṭhāna-naya is beyond the scope of beginners.🔽But one who investigates conditions sees that all mentality-materiality, as it is defined, occurs entirely dependent on conditions.

original: yathāvavatthitassa sabbassa nāmarūpassa sabbaso paccayāyattavuttikatādassanato ahetukadiṭṭhi
analyzed: yathā avavatthitassa sabbassa nāma rūpassa sabbaso paccaya āyatta vuttika tā dassanataḥ ahetuka diṭṭhi
translated: Thus he abandons the view that there is no cause.

original: pahīyati. Attano anurūpapaccayasāmaggiyā vinā aññathā pavattiyā adassanato issaranimmāna
analyzed: pahīyati attanaḥ anurūpa paccaya sāmaggiyā vinā aññathā pavattiyāḥ a dassanataḥ
translated: It is abandoned. Because it is not seen to occur in any other way than by the combination of conditions suitable to itself, it is not created by an Overlord,

original: kālanimmānādikā visamahetudiṭṭhica pahīyati. Hetusambhārapaccayehi kammappavattiyā
analyzed: kāla nimmāna ādikā visama hetu diṭṭhi ca pahīyati hetu sambhāra paccayehi kamma ppavattiyā
translated: and the view of a self-creator, such as God, or of a self-determining creator, such as time, etc., is abandoned. And because it is seen that there is no occurrence of kamma and its result except by the concurrence of conditions appropriate to it,

original: vipākappavattiyāca aññassa kammakārakassavā vipāka vedakassavā kattuno abhāvadassanato
analyzed: vipāka ppavattiyāḥ ca aññassa kattuno abhāva dassanato
translated: and because it is seen that there is no other doer of kamma or experiencer of its result apart from the occurrence of kamma and its result,

original: kāraka vedaka diṭṭhi pahīyati. Anamataggeca saṃsāre tīsu addhāsu hetuphala paraṃparāvasena🔽kevalassa nāmarūpamattasseva pavattidassanato ahosiṃ nukho ahamatītamaddhānanti evamādikāya
analyzed: kāraka vedaka diṭṭhi saṃsāre tīsu addhāsu hetu phala paraṃparā vasena  kevalassa nāma rūpa mattassa iva pavatti dassanataḥ ahosim nu kho aham atītam addhā ananti evamādikāya
translated: the view of a doer and a feeler is abandoned. And because it is seen that in the beginningless round of rebirths in the three realms of existence, there occurs only the mere occurrence of mentality-materiality in a succession of cause and effect,

original: puggalasatta visayāya soḷasavidhāya kaṅkhāyaca atikkamo hoti. Sabhāvadhammapavattiyāca
analyzed: puggala satta visayāya soḷasavidhāya kaṅkhāya ca atikkamaḥ hoti sa bhāva dhamma pavattiyā ca
translated: the sixteen kinds of doubt concerning the past, such as “Was I in the past? ” and so on, and the doubt concerning the person and the living being are overcome. And because it is seen that the occurrence of dhammas is in accordance with their individual essences,

original: suṭṭhu diṭṭhāya desanādhammassa sudhammatā dassanato buddhasubuddhatañca disvā satthari
analyzed: suṭṭhu diṭṭhāya desanā dhammassa su dhamma tā dassanataḥ buddha subuddha tañca disvā satthari
translated: and because it is seen that the teaching of the Dhamma is in accordance with the nature of dhammas, the disciple comes to see the excellence of the Buddha and the excellence of the Dhamma.

original: kaṅkhati dhamme kaṅkhatītiādinayapavattā aṭṭhavidhāpi kaṅkhā pahīyatīti. Lokuttaradhammānaṃ
analyzed: kaṅkhati dhamme kaṅkhati iti ādi naya pavattā aṭṭhavidhā api kaṅkhā pahīyati iti lokuttara dhammānam
translated: and the eight kinds of doubt that occur in the way beginning, “He doubts the True Idea” , are abandoned.🔽The words “in the formed ideas of the three planes” are said because the supramundane ideas are not susceptible of being apprehended.🔽And the words “in order to exterminate the underlying tendencies” are said because the ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.

original: saṅkhatānaṃpi sataṃ asammasanupagattā tebhūmakasaṅkhāresūti vuttaṃ. Anusayasamūhanatthañca🔽sammasananti katvā yattha kāmarāgādayo anusayā anusenti. Teyeva dhammā sammasanārahā
analyzed: saṅkhatānam pi tebhūmaka saṅkhāresu iti vuttam anusaya samūhana ttham ca  katvā yattha kāma rāga ādayaḥ anusayāḥ anusenti teyeva dhammā sammasana arahā
translated: The ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.🔽The words “in the formed ideas of the three planes” are said because the ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.🔽And the words “in order to exterminate the underlying tendencies” are said because the ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.

original: hontīti vuttaṃ tebhūmakasaṅkhāresūti. Imassa ca padassa lakkhaṇattayaṃ sammasantassāti🔽iminā sambandho. Atītādibhedabhinnesūti atītānāgatapaccuppannajjhattabahiddhādīhi
analyzed: honti iti vuttam tebhūmaka saṅkhāresu iti imassa ca padassa lakkhaṇa ttayam sammasantassa ati  iminā sambandhaḥ atīta ādi bheda bhinnesu iti atīta anāgata paccuppanna jjhatta bahiddha ādīhi
translated: The words “in the formed ideas of the three planes” are said because the ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.🔽And the words “in order to exterminate the underlying tendencies” are said because the ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.🔽The words “in the formed ideas of the three planes” are said because the ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.

original: ekādasahi bhedehi bhinnesu. Khandhādinayaṃārabbhāti paṭisambhidāmagge vibhattaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ🔽dvārachakkaṃ ārammaṇachakkaṃ viññāṇachakkaṃ phassachakkaṃ vedanāchakkaṃ saññāchakkanti
analyzed: ekādasahi bhedehi bhinnesu khandha ādi nayam ārabbhāti paṭisambhidā magge vibhattam khandha pañcakam 🔽dvāra chakkam ārammaṇa chakkam viññāṇa chakkam phassa chakkam vedanā chakkam saññā chakkanti
translated: And the words “in order to exterminate the underlying tendencies” are said because the ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.🔽The words “in the formed ideas of the three planes” are said because the ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.🔽And the words “in order to exterminate the underlying tendencies” are said because the ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.🔽The words “in the formed ideas of the three planes” are said because the ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.🔽And the words “in order to exterminate the underlying tendencies” are said because the ideas in which the underlying tendencies of lust for sensual desires, etc., lie latent are susceptible of being apprehended.

original: evamādikaṃ sammasanabhūmivibhāganayaṃ ārabbha anugantvā taṃnayānusārenāti attho.
analyzed: evamādikam sammasana bhūmi vibhāga nayam ārabbha anugantvā tad naya anusārena ati attho
translated: The meaning is that he should go on to follow the method of the exposition of the plane of seeing by way of the first of these and so on, and he should pursue it by that method.

original: Tattha pana tevīsatiyā dhammakoṭṭhāsesu yassa yo koṭṭhāso pākaṭo hoti. Tena taṃ gahetvā
analyzed: tattha pana tevīsatiyā dhamma koṭṭhāsesu yassa yaḥ koṭṭhāso pākaṭaḥ hoti tena tam gahetvā
translated: Herein, in the twenty-three sections of ideas, whichever section is evident to him, he should take that🔽and begin insight by using it. But if he is able, he should begin by using all of them.

original: sammasanaṃ ārabhitabbaṃ. Sakkontena pana sabbampi gahetvā ārabhitabbameva. Kalāpavasenasaṃkhipitvāti
analyzed: sammasanam ārabhitabbam sakkontena pana sabbam pi gahetvā ārabhitabbam eva kalāpa vasena saṃkhipitvā ati
translated: By summarizing under the aggregates:

original: khandhapañcakena ye rūpaṃ tāva atītānāgatapaccuppannādibhedabhinnaṃpi samānaṃ sabbaṃ
analyzed: khandha pañcakena ye rūpam samānam sabbam
translated: all materiality, which is classed as past, future, and present, etc., is the same in being materiality,

original: ekarūpapiṇḍabhāvena saṃkhipitvā esa nayo vedanā dīsupīti. Tatrāyaṃ nayo. Yaṃkiñci
analyzed: eka rūpa piṇḍa bhāvena saṃkhipitvā esa nayaḥ vedanā tatra ayam nayaḥ yaṃkiñcid
translated: and he should summarize all that under the single heading of “materiality.” The same method should be applied to feeling, and so on. Here is the method.

original: rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃvā bahiddhāvā oḷāritaṃvā sukhumaṃvā hīnaṃvā
analyzed: rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vā oḷāritam vā sukhumam vā hīnam vā
translated: Any materiality whatever, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—

original: paṇītaṃvā yaṃ dūre santikevā. Sabbaṃ rūpaṃ aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhena dukkhaṃ bhayaṭṭhena
analyzed: paṇītam vā yam dūre santike vā sabbam rūpam aniccam khaya ṭṭhena dukkham bhaya ṭṭhena
translated: all materiality should be seen as it actually is with proper wisdom thus: ‘Materiality is impermanent, suffering, and subject to change’ .

original: anattā asārakaṭṭhena. Yākāci vedanā.La. Yākāci saññā.La. Yekeci saṅkhārā.La. Yaṃkiñci
analyzed: anattā asārakaṭṭhena yākāci vedanā ala yākāci saññā ala yekeci saṅkhārāla yaṃkiñci
translated: Any feeling whatever … Any perception whatever … Any formations whatever … Any consciousness whatever, whether past, future, or present … far or near—🔽all consciousness should be seen as it actually is with proper wisdom thus: ‘Consciousness is impermanent, suffering, and subject to change’ .

original: viññāṇaṃ.La. Sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhena. Dukkhaṃ bhayaṭṭhena anattā asārakaṭṭhenāti.
analyzed: sabbam viññāṇam aniccam khaya ṭṭhena dukkham bhaya ṭṭhena anattā asāraka ṭṭhena ati
translated: All consciousness is impermanent in the sense of destruction, painful in the sense of terror, not-self in the sense of having no core.

original: Etthaca sabbaṃ rūpaṃ.La. Sabbaṃ viññāṇanti gahaṇameva kalāpavasena saṅkhipananti
analyzed: ettha ca sabbam rūpam sabbam viññāṇam ti gahaṇam eva kalāpa vasena saṅkhipana nti
translated: And here the “all” in “all materiality” and “all consciousness” should be regarded as the abbreviation of the “group” .

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Aniccaṃkhayaṭṭhenāti ettha rūpaṃ aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhena. Vedanā aniccā.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam aniccam khaya ṭṭhena ati ettha rūpam aniccam khaya ṭṭhena vedanā aniccā
translated: “Impermanent in the sense of destruction”: materiality is impermanent in the sense of destruction, feeling is impermanent in the sense of destruction,

original: Saññā aniccā. Saṅkhārā aniccā. Viññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhenātiādinā nayena sammasitabbadhammapariggahena
analyzed: saññā aniccā saṅkhārāḥ aniccāḥ viññāṇam aniccam khaya ṭṭhena ati ādinā nayena sammasitabba dhamma pariggahena
translated: perception is impermanent in the sense of destruction, formations are impermanent in the sense of destruction, consciousness is impermanent in the sense of destruction.

original: saheva sammasanaṃ kātabbaṃ. Itarathā sammasanaṃ na ruhati. Tadatthassa pana pākaṭattā🔽idha aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhenātiādinā sammasanapadameva therena gahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: saha iva sammasanam kātabbam itarathā sammasanam na ruhati tad atthassa pana pākaṭa ttā  idha aniccam khaya ṭṭhena ati ādinā sammasana padam eva therena gahitan ti daṭṭhabbam tattha
translated: The contemplation should be done together with the discernment of the states to be contemplated in this way, otherwise the contemplation does not proceed. But since the meaning is evident,🔽it should be regarded as the Elder that the contemplation phrase “impermanent in the sense of destruction” was taken by the Elder.

original: rūpaṃ aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhenāti taṃtaṃrūpaṃ ñāṇena daḷhaṃ gahetvā ayaṃ pathavidhātu aniccā
analyzed: rūpam aniccam khaya ṭṭhena ati tat taṃrūpam ñāṇena daḷham gahetvā ayam aniccā
translated: Herein, “Materiality is impermanent in the sense of destruction”: having firmly grasped the various kinds of materiality with knowledge, he should discern it in this way: “This earth element is impermanent in the sense of destruction,

original: khayaṭṭhena. Ayaṃ āpodhātu aniccā khayaṭṭhenātiādinā sammasanaṃ kātabbaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: khaya ṭṭhena ayam āpodhātu aniccā khaya ṭṭhena ati ādinā sammasanam kātabbam tattha
translated: and by way of destruction. This water element in the eye is impermanent, subject to destruction, disappearance, and change. This is how he comprehends it by way of destruction.

original: imasmiṃ kāye sabbaṃ thaddhakriyāmattaṃ pathavīnāma. Sāca kriyā sītuṇhaparivattiyāvā
analyzed: imasmin kāye sabbam thaddha kriyā mattam pathavī nāma sā ca kriyā sītuṇha parivatti yāvā
translated: In this body all that is merely hard is called the earth element. And that element is subject to cold and heat,

original: parivattati. Nānāhāraparivattiyā vā nānācittaparivattiyāvā nāniriyāpathaparivattiyāvā
analyzed: parivattati nānā āhāra parivattiyā vā nānā citta parivattiyā vā nā niriyāpatha parivattiyā vā
translated: to contraction and expansion, to being bent and straightened. It is subject to change by way of various kinds of nutriment, by way of various kinds of consciousness, by way of various postures,

original: nānā kāyikakriyā parivattiyāvā parivattati. Nānāsantati saṅkanti hotīti attho. Tattha🔽navanavāsu kriyāsantatīsu pātubhontīsu pubbapubbakriyāsantatiyo nassanti. Yasmāca🔽santati nāma dhammato visuṃ natthi, tasmā navanavasantatīnaṃ pātubhāvonāma navanavakriyānaṃ
analyzed: nānā kāyika kriyā parivattiyāvā parivattati nānā santati saṅkanti hoti iti attho tattha  nava navāsu kriyā santatīsu pātubhontīsu pubba pubba kriyā santatiyaḥ nassanti yasmā ca  santati nāma dhammataḥ visum natthi tasmā nava nava santatīnam pātubhāvaḥ nāma nava nava kriyānam
translated: and by way of various bodily actions. It is subject to change by way of various kinds of bodily action. The meaning is that it is subject to various kinds of continuity.🔽In the case of the various kinds of continuity of action that arise anew, the previous kinds of continuity of action cease. And since there is no such thing as continuity apart from the states,

original: uppattieva. Pubbapubbasantatīnaṃ nassanaṃnāma pubbapubba kriyānaṃ bhijjanamevāti.
analyzed: uppatti eva pubba pubba santatīnam nassanam nāma pubba pubba kriyānam bhijjanam eva ati
translated: the arising of the new kinds of continuity is the arising of the new kinds of action, and the cessation of the previous kinds of continuity is the dissolution of the previous kinds of action.

original: Evaṃ attano kāye nānāthaddhakriyānaṃ parivattiṃ passanto pathavidhātuyā khayavayaṃ
analyzed: evam kāye parivattim passanto pathavi dhātuyā khaya vayam
translated: Thus, seeing the change of the various kinds of hardness in his own body, he sees the destruction of the earth element.

original: passati. Tañca passanto taṃsahajātānaṃ rūpānaṃ khayavayaṃ passatiyeva. Āpo nāma ābandhanakriyāmattaṃ.
analyzed: passati tat ca passantaḥ tad sahajātānam rūpānam khaya vayam āpaḥ nāma ābandhana kriyā mattam
translated: and he sees the dissolution of the material instances that are conascent with it. Water is the mere act of binding.

original: Tejonāma sītakriyāmattaṃ uṇha kriyāmattañca. Vāyonāma vitthambhanakriyāmattaṃ. Imāca
analyzed: tejaḥ nāma sīta kriyā mattam uṇha kriyā mattam ca vāyu nāma vitthambhana kriyā mattam imā ca
translated: Fire is the mere act of maturing and the mere act of heating. Air is the mere act of distending.

original: kriyā khaṇe khaṇe parivattantiyeva. Imāsañca, visuṃ visuṃ santatiparivattiṃ passanto
analyzed: kriyā khaṇe khaṇe parivattantiyā iva imāsam ca visum visum santati parivattim passanto
translated: These acts occur in each moment. Seeing the change of continuity of these

original: āpādīnaṃ taṃsahajātarūpānañca khayavayaṃ passati. Santatiparivattiṃ pana bahiddhā🔽cakkhunā disvā jānāti, sarīrabbhantare pana kāyasaṃphassena jānāti. Santatisarīrabhūtānaṃ🔽pana dhātūnaṃ khayavayaṃ ñāṇenaeva passati. Tasmā attano sarīrabbhantare taṃtaṃsantati
analyzed: āpa ādīnam khaya vayam passati santati parivattim pana bahiddhā  cakkhunā disvā jānāti sarīra bbhantare pana kāya saṃphassena jānāti santati sarīra bhūtānaṃ  pana dhātūnam khaya vayam ñāṇena eva passati tasmai attano sarīra abbhantare
translated: he sees the dissolution of the material instances that are conascent with them. But he sees the change of continuity of the external elements

original: parivattiṃ ñatvāvā tathā tathā kappetvā vā rūpadhātūnaṃ aniccattaṃ ñāṇena sudiṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: parivattim ñatvā vā tathā tathā kappetvā vā rūpa dhātūnam anicca ttam ñāṇena su diṭṭham
translated: by means of the eye, and he sees the change of continuity of the internal elements by means of body-contact. But he sees the dissolution of the elements that are the continuity of the body by means of knowledge. Therefore, having known the change of continuity of the elements in his own body, or having made them so by practice, he sees the impermanence of the material elements very clearly by means of knowledge.

original: katvā punappunaṃ sammasitabbaṃ. Sesakhandhesupi taṃtaṃsantatinānāttaṃ ñatvā vedanādīnaṃ
analyzed: katvā punappunam sammasitabbam sesa khandhesu pi taṃ taṃ santati nānā āttam ñatvā vedanā ādīnam
translated: and should be pondered over again and again. Having understood the diversity of the various continua in the other aggregates, he should likewise understand the diversity of the various continua in the case of feeling, etc.

original: khayavayaṃ sudiṭṭhaṃ katvā sammasanaṃ kātabbanti. Bhayaṭṭhenāti bhāyitabbaṭṭhena.
analyzed: khaya vayam su diṭṭham katvā sammasanam kātabbanti bhaya ṭṭhena ati bhāyitabba ṭṭhena
translated: and then it should be pondered again and again. And in the other aggregates their diversity should be discerned in their respective continuities, and their dissolution and appearance should be seen clearly. This is how the discerning of formations should be done. As fear: as what should be feared.

original: Yañhi aniccaṃ hoti. Khaṇamattepi vipariṇāmadhammaṃ. Taṃ ekantena bhāyitabbameva.
analyzed: yat hi aniccam hoti khaṇa matte pi vipariṇāma dhammam tat ekantena bhāyitabbam eva
translated: For what is impermanent is entirely to be feared, since it is subject to change even in the time it takes to chop up some sugar cane.

original: Kasmā, tañhi yo abhāyitvā vissāsaṃ karoti. Etaṃ meti attano aṅgaṃ katvā pariharati.
analyzed: kasmā tat hi yaḥ a bhāyitvā vissāsam karoti etam mā iti attanaḥ aṅgam katvā pariharati
translated: Why? Because whoever does not fear it and trusts it, taking it as his own and making it his mainstay,

original: Taṃ apariyantehi anekasahassehi abhisaṅkharaṇadukkhehivā vipariṇāmadukkhehivā abhiṇhaṃ🔽pīḷeti. Bādhati. Iti nānādukkhadhammehi abhiṇhaṃ sampaṭipīḷanasabhāvattā ekantena
analyzed: tam apariyantehi aneka sahassehi abhisaṅkharaṇa dukkhehi vā vipariṇāma dukkhehi vā abhiṇham  pīḷeti bādhati iti nānā dukkha dhammehi abhiṇham sampaṭipīḷana sabhāva tā ekantena
translated: is often afflicted by the suffering of the many thousands of formations that are without limit, either as suffering due to formations or as suffering due to change.🔽Thus it is called “suffering” in the sense of what should be feared because it is by nature often afflicted by many kinds of suffering.

original: bhāyitabbaṭṭhena dukkhaṃnāmāti. Attapaṭipakkhattā anattā. Yo hi ito uddhaṃ mayhaṃ🔽abbhantarimataronāma natthīti evaṃ paramajjhattabhāvena pariggahito hoti. So attāti
analyzed: bhāyitabba ṭṭhena dukkhaṃnāmā ti atta paṭipakkha ttā anattā yaḥ hi itas uddham mayham 🔽abbhantarimataro nāma natthi iti evam param ajjhatta bhāvena pariggahitaḥ hoti saḥ attā ati
translated: As not-self: because it is the opposite of a self. For what is clung to as “mine” and “I” is not a self,

original: vuccati. Katamo pana tathāpariggahi tabboti. Yo attano vase sabbaso vattati. Yathā🔽vuttehi abhisaṅkharaṇakiccehi vinā kevalaṃ attano chandenavā vasenavā ajjhāsayenavā🔽āṇāvidhānenavā niccaṃ avirajjhamāno pavattati. So tathā pariggahetabboti. Tathārūpo
analyzed: vuccati katamaḥ pana tathā pariggahi tabbaḥ ti yaḥ attanaḥ vase sabbasas vattati yathā  vuttehi abhisaṅkharaṇa kiccehi vinā kevalam chandena vā vasena vā ajjhāsayena vā  niccam a virajjhamāno pavattati saḥ tathā pariggahetabbaḥ ti tathārūpaḥ
translated: But what is it that should be so discerned? It is what is entirely subject to one’s own will. It occurs constantly without the functions of forming, etc., mentioned in the way already given, simply through one’s own wish, or through one’s own will, or through one’s own intention, or through one’s own command. That is what should be so discerned. That is how the meaning should be known here as “the discernment of what is so” .🔽

original: eva hi dhammo niccaṃ sukhakāmānaṃ dukkhapaṭikūlānaṃ sattānaṃ attakiccaṃ karoti nāmāti.🔽Yo pana niccaṃ sukhakāmānaṃ tesaṃ yathāpavattaṃ sukhaṃ viddhaṃseti vikireti. Dukkhapaṭikūlānaṃ🔽tesaṃ abhisaṅkharaṇādi mūlakaṃ nānādukkhaṃ janeti vaḍḍheti. So attapaṭipakkhoeva
analyzed: eva hi dhammaḥ niccam sukha kāmānam dukkha paṭikūlānam sattānam atta kiccam karoti nāma ati  yaḥ pana niccam sukha kāmānam tesam yathāpavattam sukham viddhaṃseti vikireti dukkha paṭikūlānam  tesam abhisaṅkharaṇa ādi mūlakam nānā dukkham janeti vaḍḍheti saḥ atta paṭipakkhaḥ eva
translated: What is it that should be so defined? It is what is wholly subject to one’s own will. It occurs constantly without the functions of determining, etc., as described, only through one’s own desire, inclination, or wish, or through one’s own command. It should be so defined. For such a state is called one’s own affair because it constantly does one’s own work for those who desire pleasure and are averse to pain.

original: hoti. Idañca rūpaṃ edisameva hoti. Iti attakiccassa akaraṇato attapaṭipakkhakiccassa
analyzed: hoti idam ca rūpam edisam eva hoti iti atta kiccassa a karaṇataḥ atta paṭipakkha kiccassa
translated: But that which constantly destroys and scatters the pleasure of those who desire pleasure and which produces and increases the various kinds of pain beginning with determining for those who are averse to pain is an opponent to one’s own self. And this materiality is just such. So materiality is not one’s own because it does not do one’s own work and because it does the work of an opponent to one’s own self.

original: karaṇatoca rūpaṃ anattānāmāti. Kasmā panetaṃ attano vase navattati attakiccaṃ na
analyzed: karaṇa to ca rūpam anatta anāma ati kasmā pana itam attanaḥ vase atta kiccam na
translated: But why is it not subject to one’s own will?

original: karoti attapaṭipakkhakiccaṃ karotīti āha asārakaṭṭhenāti. Tattha sāronāma paccayasāmaggiyā🔽vinā kevalaṃ ajjhāsayamattena uppajjituṃvā uppajjitvāca paccayupatthambhena vinā
analyzed: karoti atta paṭipakkha kiccam karoti iti āha asāraka ṭṭhena ti tattha sāraḥ nāma paccaya sāmaggiyā  vinā kevalam ajjhāsaya mattena uppajjitum vā uppajjitvā ca paccaya upatthambhena vinā
translated: He does the work of an enemy to himself, is what is said. Herein, “strength” is a special kind of firmness and power that is capable of arising by mere intention alone without a concurrence of conditions,

original: yadicchakaṃ patiṭṭhātuṃ vā samatthabhāvasaṅkhāto thāmabalaviseso vuccati. Rūpaṃ pana
analyzed: yadicchakam patiṭṭhātum vā samattha bhāva saṅkhātaḥ thāma bala viseso vuccati rūpam pana
translated: and of remaining as long as it wishes without support by conditions after it has arisen. But materiality

original: sayaṃpi evarūpo sāronāma na hoti. Naca evarūpena sārena yuttanti. Nahi tassa paccayasāmaggiyā
analyzed: sayam pi evarūpaḥ sāraḥ nāma na hoti na ca evarūpena sārena na hi tassa paccaya sāmaggiyā
translated: is not called “strength” in this way, nor is it associated with such strength. For it has no firmness or power

original: vinā uppajjituṃvā uppajjitvāpi paccayupatthambhena vinā khaṇamattaṃpi patiṭṭhātuṃvā
analyzed: vinā uppajjitum vā uppajjitvā api paccaya upatthambhena vinā khaṇa mattam pi patiṭṭhātum vā
translated: to arise without a concurrence of conditions or to remain for even a moment without support by conditions after it has arisen.

original: thāmovā balaṃvā atthi. Yañca attano thāmena balena vinā kevalaṃ paccayasāmaggi baleneva
analyzed: thāmaḥ uvā balaṃvā atthi yat ca thāmena balena vinā kevalam paccaya sāmaggi balena iva
translated: And what arises only by the power of the concurrence of conditions and remains only by the support of conditions without any firmness or power of its own,

original: uppajjati. Paccayupatthambheneva patiṭṭhāti. Taṃ aneka sahassāni paccayābhisaṅkharaṇadukkhāni
analyzed: uppajjati paccaya upatthambhena iva patiṭṭhāti tam aneka sahassāni paccaya abhisaṅkharaṇa dukkhāni
translated: that is born with the suffering of the many thousands of conditions that produce it,

original: janetvā ekantena niccaṃ attapaṭipakkhakiccaṃ karoti, pīḷeti, bādhatiyevāti. Esanayo🔽vedanā aniccā khayaṭṭhenātiādīsu. Iti lakkhaṇattayaṃ samma santassāti sambandho.🔽Addhānavasenāti ekekabhavaparicchinnassa pavattakālassa vasena. Nahi bhavantare uppannaṃ
analyzed: janetvā ekantena niccam atta paṭipakkha kiccam karoti pīḷeti bādhatiyā iva ati  vedanā aniccā khaya ṭṭhena ati ādīsu iti lakkhaṇa ttayam samma santassa ati sambandho  addhāna vasena ati ekeka bhava paricchinnassa pavatta kālassa vasena nahi bhavantare uppannam
translated: and having generated it, it always does the opposite of what is wanted, and it torments and afflicts.🔽In the passages beginning, “Feeling is impermanent … subject to destruction … subject to fading away … subject to cessation … uncompounded … not yours … not self,” the construction is: “The three characteristics, being rightly seen, are the escape.”

original: khandhapañcakaṃ aññaṃ bhavantaraṃ gacchati. Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ bhaveeva asesaṃ nirujjhatīti.
analyzed: khandha pañcakam aññam bhavantaram gacchati tasmin tasmin bhave eva asesam nirujjhati iti
translated: By means of the life-continuum: by means of the time of occurrence delimited by each becoming. For the five aggregates that have arisen in one becoming do not go to another becoming. They cease completely in that very becoming.

original: Apica, ekasmiṃ bhavepi tiṇṇaṃ vayānaṃ mandādīnaṃ dasannaṃ dasakānaṃ saṃvaccharautu🔽māsa pakkhatithi ahoratti yāma pahārādīnañca vasena addhānabhedo yojetabbo. Santativasenāti
analyzed: apica ekasmin bhave pi tiṇṇam manda ādīnam dasannam dasakānam saṃvat śarautu  māsa pakkha tithi ahoratti yāma pahāra ādīnam ca vasena addhāna bhedaḥ yojetabbaḥ santati vasena ati
translated: Moreover, in one becoming too, the division of time should be construed by means of the three ages, the slow and so on, the ten decans, the years, seasons,

original: sabhāgekasantānavasena pavattamānāya rūpasantatiyāvā arūpa santatiyāvā vasena. Khaṇavasenāti
analyzed: sabhāga eka santāna vasena pavattamānāya rūpa santati yāvā arūpa santati yāvā vasena khaṇa vasena ati
translated: months, fortnights, days, nights, watches, periods, etc., and by means of the continuity of the aggregates. By means of continuity: by means of the occurrence of a continuity of materiality or of mentality that is homogeneous. By means of moment: by means of the occurrence of a continuity of materiality or of mentality that is not homogeneous.

original: rūpārūpadhammānaṃ āyu parimāṇasaṅkhātassa khaṇassa vasena. Etthaca khaṇavasena sammasanaṃnāma
analyzed: rūpa arūpa dhammānaṃ āyu parimāṇa saṅkhātassa khaṇassa vasena ettha ca khaṇa vasena sammasanaṃ nāma
translated: and of the material and immaterial dhammas, by way of the measure of their life-span, which is called a moment. And here, the contemplation by way of moment is

original: sabbaññubuddhānaṃ eva visayo siyā, na sāvakānaṃ. Nahi te evaṃ parittake khaṇe uppādaṃvā
analyzed: sabbaññu buddhānam eva visayaḥ siyā na sāvakānam nahi te evam parittake khaṇe uppādam vā
translated: the province of the Omniscient Buddhas alone, not of the disciples. For they are not able to reach the arising or

original: nirodhaṃvā sampāpuṇituṃ sakkontīti. Tasmā addhāsantativasena sammasanameva idhā dhippetanti
analyzed: nirodham vā sampāpuṇitum sakkonti iti tasmai addhā santati vasena sammasanam eva idha
translated: cessation in such a short moment. Therefore, the contemplation by way of the duration of time should be regarded as the meaning here.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Lakkhaṇattayaṃsammasantassāti tesu tebhūmaka saṅkhāresu dhammesu tilakkhaṇāni
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam lakkhaṇa ttayam sammasantassa ti tesu tebhūmaka saṅkhāresu dhammesu ti lakkhaṇāni
translated: Contemplating the three characteristics: having superimposed the three characteristics on the dhammas of the three planes of existence,🔽he touches them again and again, he rubs them over and over again. The meaning is that he makes it very clear to his knowledge that those dhammas are of the nature of

original: āropetvā te dhamme punappunaṃ āmasantassa parimajjantassa. Tesaṃ dhammānaṃ anicca🔽jātikataṃvā dukkhajātikataṃvā anattajātikataṃvā ñāṇe suṭṭhu pākaṭaṃ karontassāti
analyzed: āropetvā te dhamme punappunaṃ āmasantassa parimajjantassa tesam dhammānaṃ anicca  jāti katam vā dukkha jāti katam vā anatta jāti katam vā ñāṇe suṭṭhu pākaṭam karontassa ati
translated: impermanence,🔽suffering, or non-self. But in this knowledge, the seeing of the characteristic of impermanence is especially important. When that is seen,

original: attho. Visesato pana imasmiṃ ñāṇe aniccalakkhaṇadassanameva padhānaṃ. Tasmiṃ diṭṭheyeva
analyzed: atthaḥ visesato pana imasmim ñāṇe anicca lakkhaṇa dassanam eva padhānam tasmim diṭṭheyeva
translated: the other two characteristics are also seen.

original: itarāni kamena diṭṭhāni honti. Adiṭṭheca adiṭṭhānīti. Tasmā ādito aniccalakkhaṇasseva
analyzed: itarāni kamena diṭṭhāni honti adiṭṭhe ca adiṭṭhāni iti tasmai āditas anicca lakkhaṇassa iva
translated: and the other three are seen in due course. And what is not seen is not seen.🔽Therefore it is the clear manifestation of the impermanent characteristic that is intended first.

original: suṭṭhu pākaṭabhāvo adhippetoti. Tesvevāti tebhūmakasaṅkhāresu eva. Paccayavasenāti🔽rūpakkhandhe tāva avijjātaṇhupādānakammāhārasaṅkhātānaṃ paccayānaṃ vasena. Vedanāsaññāsaṅkhāresu
analyzed: suṭṭhu pākaṭa bhāvaḥ adhippeto ti tesu eva āti tebhūmaka saṅkhāresu eva paccaya vasena ati  rūpa kkhandhe tāva avijjā taṇhā upādāna kamma āhāra saṅkhātānam paccayānam vasena vedanā saññā saṅkhāresu
translated: ‘In them’: in the kinds of formations in the three planes.🔽‘By way of conditions’: in the case of the materiality aggregate, by way of the conditions called ignorance, craving, kamma, and nutriment.🔽But in the case of the feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness aggregates, contact should be mentioned in the place of nutriment.

original: pana āhāraṭṭhāne phasso vattabbo. Viññāṇeca nāmarūpaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ nayo. Atītānantarabhave
analyzed: pana āhāra ṭṭhāne phassaḥ vattabbo viññāṇe ca nāma rūpam tatra ayam nayaḥ atīta anantara bhave
translated: And consciousness and mentality-materiality. Here is the method.

original: avijjātaṇhupādāna kammesu appahīnavasena samuditesu imasmiṃ bhave paṭisandhito paṭṭhāya
analyzed: avijjāta ṇhupādāna kammesu appahīna vasena samuditesu imasmin bhave paṭisandhito paṭṭhāya
translated: In the previous existence, ignorance, craving, kamma, and the rest were not abandoned and so they arose together. In this existence, from the moment of rebirth-linking onwards,

original: rūpasantatiyo vedanāsaññāsaṅkhāra viññāṇasantatiyoca samudenti. Yāva maraṇakālā khaṇe🔽khaṇe nānākalāpavasena udenti pasavanti. Tesu pana tasmiṃ bhave eva pahīnavasena
analyzed: rūpa santatiyaḥ vedanā saññā saṅkhāra viññāṇa santatiyaḥ ca samudenti yāva maraṇa kālā khaṇe  khaṇe nānā kalāpa vasena udenti pasavanti tesu pana tasmin bhave eva pahīna vasena
translated: the continuity of materiality, the continuity of feeling, the continuity of perception, the continuity of formations, and the continuity of consciousness arise.🔽From moment to moment they arise, they are produced, in the form of various groups.🔽But when they are abandoned in this existence and cease,🔽those continuities of materiality and immateriality cease.

original: niruddhesu tā rūpārūpasantatiyo nirujjhanti. Bhavantare puna anuppādasaṅkhātaṃ nirodhaṃ
analyzed: niruddhesu tāḥ rūpa arūpa santatiyaḥ nirujjhanti bhavantare puna anuppāda saṅkhātam nirodham
translated: In the next existence they will not arise again, which is called cessation.

original: pāpuṇanti. Ettha pana yathā udake sati macchānāma honti, asati na honti. Evaṃ kammajesu
analyzed: pāpuṇanti ettha pana yathā udake sati macchā nāma honti asati na honti evam kamma jesu
translated: And here, just as fish are found when there is water and are not found when there is none,

original: nāmarūpesu sati itarāni nāmarūpāni honti. Asati na hontīti itarāni sabbāni kammajesu🔽saṅgahetvā kammavasena udayabbayavidhānaṃ gahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evaṃ avijjātaṇhupādānakammapaccayānaṃ
analyzed: nāma rūpesu sati itarāni nāma rūpāni honti asati na honti iti itarāni sabbāni kamma jesu  saṅgahetvā kamma vasena udaya bbaya vidhānam gahitan ti daṭṭhabbam evam avijjā taṇhā upādāna kamma paccayānam
translated: so the other states are found when there is mentality-materiality due to kamma-process and are not found when there is none.🔽So it should be understood that the exposition of the arising and falling away by kamma is given by including all the other states in the kamma-process.

original: vasena pañcakkhandhassa udayabbayapavatti hotīti. Kammavasena pana imasmiṃ bhave🔽samudentānipi paṭisandhito paṭṭhāya khaṇe khaṇe kabaḷīkārāhārūpatthambhanaṃ laddhā
analyzed: vasena pañca kkhandhassa udaya bbaya pavatti hoti iti kamma vasena pana imasmin bhave  paṭisandhitaḥ paṭṭhāya khaṇe khaṇe kabaḷīkāra āhāra upatthambhanam laddhā
translated: This is how there comes to be the arising and falling away of the five aggregates by means of ignorance, craving, kamma, and rebirth-linking.🔽But in this present existence, the aggregates that have been generated by kamma🔽are consolidated by the nutriment consisting of edible food, which is the condition for their occurrence from rebirth-linking onwards moment by moment.

original: eva yathā pavattarūpasantatiyo anubandha mānā navanavā rūpasantatiyo samudenti. Aladdhā
analyzed: eva yathā nava navāḥ rūpa santatiyaḥ samudenti a laddhāḥ
translated: And the new aggregates that are generated by kamma are consolidated by the nutriment consisting of kamma, which is the condition for their occurrence from rebirth-linking onwards moment by moment.

original: pana nirujjhanti. Taṃ santatiyaṃ puna anuppādasaṅkhātaṃ ekabhavanirodhaṃ pāpuṇanti,
analyzed: pana nirujjhanti tam santatiyam puna anuppāda saṅkhātam eka bhava nirodham pāpuṇanti
translated: But those that are not consolidated fall away. They reach the state of non-arising again, called “the cessation of a single becoming,” in the continuity of aggregates that have arisen.

original: yathā pavattasantatiyo vā chijjanti bhijjanti antaradhāyantīti.

original: Vedanāsaññāsaṅkhārā pana bahiddhā ārammaṇesu āpātāgatesu ārammaṇasamphassaṃ laddhāeva🔽chadvārikā kusalākusalavipāka kriyabhūtā samudenti. Navanavā santatiyo pātubhavanti.
analyzed: vedanā saññā saṅkhārā pana bahiddhā ārammaṇesu āpāta āgatesu ārammaṇa samphassam laddhā eva  samudenti nava navā
translated: But the feelings, perceptions, and mental formations, when external objects have come into focus, are set in motion by the contact with the object.

original: Aladdhā pana nirujjhanti. Santatiṃ na ghaṭenti. Viññāṇaṃca sahajāta nāmeca vatthurūpeca
analyzed: a laddhā pana nirujjhanti santatim na ghaṭenti viññāṇam ca sahajāta nāme ca vatthu rūpe ca

analyzed: pavattamāne eva pavattati nivattamāne nivattati iti khaṇa vasena ati vutta ppakāre paccaye  an apekkhitvā kevalam nāma rūpānam pavatti kkhaṇa vasena khaṇa saddena ca ittha sammasana ñāṇe

analyzed: vutta rūpa santati nāma santatiyaḥ api gahetabbāḥ nahi sāvakānam ñāṇam khaṇa vasena nāma rūpānam  udayam vā vayam vā sampāpuṇitum sakkoti iti yathā pana ratta ndhakāre antar leṇe mahantaḥ
translated: for the knowledge of disciples is not able to reach the arising and dissolution of mentality-materiality by moment.🔽But just as in the darkness of the night in a cave a great mass of darkness arises,

analyzed: dīpe nibbāpīyamāne tamaḥ khandhassa udayaḥ hoti ālokassa vayaḥ eva mā evam sarīre  udaya pakkhānaṃ
